dɑkjəmɛn aʊtlaɪn pɹoʊlɑɡ ɡlɪmɝz ə ðə pæɾɝn  wʌn taɪm tə bi ɡɔn  tu tu kæptənz  θɹi eɪ fæn ə kʌlɝz  fɔɹ ðə teɪl ʌv ə dɑl  faɪv ðə fɔɹdʒɪŋ ʌv ə hæmɝ  sɪks ðə sɛn ʌv ə dʒɹim  sɛvən blæksmɪθs pʌzəl  eɪt wɝlpulz ə kʌlɝ  naɪn tʃɹæps  tɛn eɪ bleɪzɪŋ bikən  ɪlɛvən tɔk ə dɛts  twɛlv eɪ bɑɹɡən  θɝtin haɪ sits  fɔɹtin wʌt waɪz wʌnz noʊ  fɪftin ɡæðɝɪŋ dɑɹknəs  sɪkstin ðə sʌbʒɪkt ə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz  sɛvəntin sikɹəts  eɪtin eɪ tʃæt wɪð sɪuən  naɪntin sɝpɹaɪzəz  twɛnti ɪn ðə naɪt  twɛntiwʌn eɪ mɑɹk  twɛntiɾu wʌn ænsɝ  twɛntiθɹi ɔɹnəməns  twɛntifɔɹ eɪ stʃɹɛŋθənɪŋ stɔɹm  twɛntifaɪv wən tə wɛɹ dʒuəlz  twɛntisɪks ɪn soʊ hæbɝ  twɛntisɛvən wʌt mʌs bi dʌn  twɛntieɪɾ eɪ klʌstɝ ə ɹoʊzbʊdz  twɛntinaɪn sʌmθɪŋ flɪkɝz  θɝɾi wʌt ði oʊθ ɹɑd kən də ɛpəlɔɡ ən ænsɝ pɹeɪz fəɹ ðə wil ə taɪm "ðə bæɾəl sinz əv ðə bɹɛθləs ɝdʒənsi ʌv fɝsthæn ɪkspɪɹiəns, ən ði . . . ivəl leɪst ɪndə ðə fɔɹsɪz ʌv ɡʊd, ðə deɪnʒɝz leɪɾənt ɪn ɛni pɹɑməst sælveɪʃən, ðə sɛns ə ði ʌnəvɔɪɾəbəl ɔnslɔɾ ʌv ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl ɪvɛns bɛɹ ðə mɑɹks ʌv əmɛɹəkən næʃənəl ɪkspɪɹiəns dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs θɹi dɛkeɪdz."

Document Outline Prologue Glimmers of the Pattern Ch 1 Time to Be Gone Ch 2 Two Captains Ch 3 A Fan of Colors Ch 4 The Tale of a Doll Ch 5 The Forging of a Hammer Ch 6 The Scent of a Dream Ch 7 Blacksmiths Puzzle Ch 8 Whirlpools of Color Ch 9 Traps Ch 10 A Blazing Beacon Ch 11 Talk of Debts Ch 12 A Bargain Ch 13 High Seats Ch 14 What Wise Ones Know Ch 15 Gathering Darkness Ch 16 The Subject of Negotiations Ch 17 Secrets Ch 18 A Chat with Siuan Ch 19 Surprises Ch 20 In the Night Ch 21 A Mark Ch 22 One Answer Ch 23 Ornaments Ch 24 A Strengthening Storm Ch 25 When to Wear Jewels Ch 26 In So Habor Ch 27 What Must Be Done Ch 28 A Cluster of Rosebuds Ch 29 Something Flickers Ch 30 What the Oath Rod Can Do Epilogue An Answer Praise for THE WHEEL OF TIME "The battle scenes have the breathless urgency of firsthand experience, and the . . . evil laced into the forces of good, the dangers latent in any promised salvation, the sense of the unavoidable onslaught of unpredictable events bear the marks of American national experience during the last three decades."

 - ðə nu jɔɹk taɪmz "hæz ɔl ðə bɹɛdθ ən dɛpθ ðəɾ əv meɪd ðɪs fæntəsi ɔθɝ wʌn ə ði æknɑlɪdʒd ɡɹeɪts ə ðə ʒɑnɹə."

 - The New York Times "Has all the breadth and depth that have made this fantasy author one of the acknowledged greats of the genre."

 - pʌblɪʃɝz wikli "hɪz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪz dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt . . . baɪ ðə ɹɪtʃnəs ʌv ɪts fæbɹɪk, wɪð ɔl ðə tʃɑɹm ən nɑivəteɪ ʌv ðə bɹʌðɝz ɡɹɪm ən ðə soʊʃəlslæʃmɔɹəl kɑməntɛɹi ʌv hʌksliz bɹeɪv nu wɝld. wɪð ɪz wɛl-flɛʃt-aʊt kæɹɪktɝz, dɑɹk ɪmədʒɹi, kɑmɪk ɹɪlif, vɪvəd lændskeɪps, ən ə fæsəneɪɾɪŋ sɛns ə taɪmləsnəs, dʒɔɹɾən əz kɹieɪɾəd ə kɑmplɛks lɪɾɝətʃɝ wɪð ə læŋɡwədʒ ən ɹiæləɾi ɔl ɪts oʊn."

 - Publishers Weekly "His writing is distinguished . . . by the richness of its fabric, with all the charm and naivete of the Brothers Grimm and the social/moral commentary of Huxley's Brave New World. With his well-fleshed-out characters, dark imagery, comic relief, vivid landscapes, and a fascinating sense of timelessness, Jordan has created a complex literature with a language and reality all its own."

 - bʊkpɪdʒ "θɹuaʊt dʒɔɹɾənz pɹiɛmənən haɪ-fæntəsi sɑɡə . . . ðə kæɹɪktɝz (maɪnɝ əz wɛl əz meɪdʒɝ), ðə wɝld, ən ðə sɔɹs ə paʊɝz əv ɹɪmeɪn ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ɹɪtʃ ən kənsɪstənt - noʊ min fit. . . . əmɪɾ ɔl ðə stɝm ʌn dʒɹæŋ, haʊɛvɝ, ɪz ə faɪnli tun kɑmɪk stʃɹeɪn ðət boʊθ lɛvənz ðə stɔɹi ən ædz tə ɪts dɪvɛləpmənt. ə meɪdʒɝ fæntəsi ɛpɪk."

 - BookPage "Throughout Jordan's preeminent high-fantasy saga . . . the characters (minor as well as major), the world, and the source of powers have remained remarkably rich and consistent - no mean feat. . . . Amid all the Sturm und Drang, however, is a finely tuned comic strain that both leavens the story and adds to its development. A major fantasy epic."

 - bʊklɪst "tʃɹuθ ɪz nɑɾ oʊnli stʃɹeɪnʒɝ, ɪts ɹɪtʃɝ ðən fɪkʃən, bʌt dʒɔɹɾənz fɪkʃənəl junəvɝs əpɹoʊtʃɪz ðə vɝaɪəɾi ən kəmplɛksəɾi ʌv ðə ɹil. . . . plɑt laɪnz [ɑɹ] stʃɹʌmd wɪð ɹɛzəneɪɾɪŋ lɔŋ-weɪv ɹɪðəmz sʌmθɪŋ laɪk beɪɾoʊvənz ɝɔɪkə."

 - Booklist "Truth is not only stranger, it's richer than fiction, but Jordan's fictional universe approaches the variety and complexity of the real. . . . Plot lines [are] strummed with resonating long-wave rhythms something like Beethoven's Eroica."

 - ɹɑbɝt nɑks,  nuzpeɪpɝz "ædvɛntʃɝ ən mɪstɝi ən dɑɹk θɪŋz ðət muv ɪn ðə naɪt - ə kɑmbəneɪʃən ə ɹɑbən hʊɾ ən stivən kɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz hɑɹd tə ɹɪzɪst. fɝðɝmɔɹ, dʒɔɹɾən meɪks ðə ɹiɾɝ pʊt daʊn ðə bʊk ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ ðə weɪt fəɹ ðə nɛks taɪɾəl ɪn ðə sɪɹiz."

 - Robert Knox, MPG Newspapers "Adventure and mystery and dark things that move in the night - a combination of Robin Hood and Stephen King that is hard to resist. Furthermore, Jordan makes the reader put down the book regretting the wait for the next title in the series."

 - mɪlwɔki sɛntənəl "ðə wil ə taɪm [ɪz] ɹæpədli bɪkʌmɪŋ ðə dɪfɪnɪɾɪv əmɛɹəkən fæntəsi sɑɡə. ɪts ə fæntəsi teɪl sɛldəm ikwəld ən stɪl lɛs ɔfən sɝpæst ɪn ɪŋɡlɪʃ."

 - Milwaukee Sentinel "The Wheel of Time [is] rapidly becoming the definitive American fantasy saga. It is a fantasy tale seldom equaled and still less often surpassed in English."

 - ʃəkɑɡoʊ sʌn-taɪmz "ɪn ðə dɛkeɪdz sɪns dʒeɪ ɑɹ ɑɹ toʊkinz lɔɹɾ ə ðə ɹɪŋz tʃɹɪlədʒi wɑz pʌblɪʃt, mɛni fæntəsi ɹaɪɾɝz əv tʃɹaɪd tə kæptʃɝ ðə spɪɹəɾ ə ðət sɛmənəl wɝk. waɪl mɛni hæv bɪn eɪbəl tə ɪməteɪt ðə staɪl, dɪvɛləp ə sɪməlɝli swɪft ən kɑmplɛks plɑt, ən kɹieɪt kənvɪnsɪŋ kæɹɪktɝz, nʌn əv kæptʃɝd ðə spɪɹəɾ ə smɔl mɛn ən maɪɾi, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ əɡɛnst ə fɔɹs ʌv oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ ivəl. ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən hæz."

 - Chicago Sun-Times "In the decades since J. R. R. Tolkien's Lord of the Rings trilogy was published, many fantasy writers have tried to capture the spirit of that seminal work. While many have been able to imitate the style, develop a similarly swift and complex plot, and create convincing characters, none have captured the spirit of small men and mighty, struggling against a force of overwhelming evil. Robert Jordan has."

 - ɑɾəwɑ sɪɾəzən "dʒɔɹɾən əz ə paʊɝfəl vɪʒən ʌv ɡʊɾ ən ivəl - bʌt wʌt stʃɹaɪks mi əz moʊs plɛʒɝəbəl . . . ɪz ɔl ðə fæsəneɪɾɪŋ pipəl muvɪŋ θɹu ə ɹɪtʃ ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ wɝld."

 - Ottawa Citizen "Jordan has a powerful vision of good and evil - but what strikes me as most pleasurable . . . is all the fascinating people moving through a rich and interesting world."

 - ɔɹsən skɑt kɑɹd "dʒɔɹɾən kən ɔlweɪz bi kaʊntəɾ ɑn tə ɡɹaʊn ɪz dɪziɪŋ ɪntʃɹiɡz ɪn sɑləd tʃʌŋks ə kʌltʃɝəl dɪteɪl, ən i hɪɹ ɹaɪzəz tə ði əkeɪʒən, wɪð tʃæptɝz əz dɛns əz spɛnsɪɹiən stænzəz wɪð sɪmbəlz ən ɹɪtʃuəlz. . . . hi mənɪpjəleɪts ðə dɪsɔɹɾɝ ə hɪz næɹəɾɪv tə kɹɛɾəbli kənveɪ ə sɛns ʌv ən ɛmbæɾəld wɝld ɑn ðə vɝdʒ ə sɛlf-dɪstʃɹʌkʃən, ən i ɛntɝteɪnɪŋli dʒʌkstəpoʊzɪz ðə kɔɹtli səvɪləɾi ʌv ɪz vɪlənz wɪð ðə pɹikɛɹiəs keɪɑs ðeɪ kɑz."

 - Orson Scott Card "Jordan can always be counted on to ground his dizzying intrigues in solid chunks of cultural detail, and he here rises to the occasion, with chapters as dense as Spenserian stanzas with symbols and rituals. . . . He manipulates the disorder of his narrative to credibly convey a sense of an embattled world on the verge of self-destruction, and he entertainingly juxtaposes the courtly civility of his villains with the precarious chaos they cause."

 - pʌblɪʃɝz wikli "dʒɔɹɾən kəntɪnjuz tə juɾəlaɪz ɪz taʊɝɪŋ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən tə kənstʃɹʌk plɑts ʌv ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl ɪnʒənuəti ən dɪvɛləp θimz hɪɾən, səmtaɪmz kwaɪt dipli, ɪn ɝliɝ ɪnstɔlməns. əz ɛvɝ, dʒɔɹɾən ɹaɪts ɪntɛlɪdʒənli ən lɪɹɪkli - wʌn ə ðə moʊs lɪɾɝɛɹi ɪkspoʊnəns ə ðə ʒɑnɹə."

 - Publishers Weekly "Jordan continues to utilize his towering imagination to construct plots of incredible ingenuity and develop themes hidden, sometimes quite deeply, in earlier installments. As ever, Jordan writes intelligently and lyrically - one of the most literary exponents of the genre."

 -  mæɡəzin "bɪwɛɹ, ðəɹ ɪz mædʒɪk ɪn ðiz bʊks. ðeɪ ɑɹ laɪəbəl tə meɪk jə nəɡlɛk jəɹ wɝk ən kip jə ʌp weɪ pæs jəɹ bɛdtaɪm. . . . ðɪs ɪz ðə dʒɛnjəwən ɑɹɾəkəl."

 - SFX magazine "Beware, there is magic in these books. They are liable to make you neglect your work and keep you up way past your bedtime. . . . This is the genuine article."

 - dʒɑn li, sʌfək kaʊnti nuz "dʒɔɹɾənz bɛstsɛlɪŋ haɪ fæntəsi sɪɹiz kæɹiz ɑn . . . kəlɑsəl, dɔntɪŋli kɑmplɛks stɔɹitɛlɪŋ . . . ðə næɹəɾɪv ɛmplɔɪz ɛləməns ə ɹilɪzəm ɹɛɹ ɪn haɪ fæntəsi."

 - John Lee, Suffolk County News "Jordan's bestselling high fantasy series carries on . . . colossal, dauntingly complex storytelling . . . the narrative employs elements of realism rare in high fantasy."

 - pʌblɪʃɝz wikli (stɑɹd ɹivju)

 - Publishers Weekly (starred review)

"dʒɔɹɾənz kæɹɪktɝz [ɑɹ] flɛʃt aʊt wɪð ðə stʃɹɛŋkθs ən wiknəsəz ə ɹil mɛn ən wɪmən. . . . ɪnvoʊks ði ɛnd-ʌv-ðə-wɝl mɪljʊ ʌv stivən kɪŋz ðə stænd."

"Jordan's characters [are] fleshed out with the strengths and weaknesses of real men and women. . . . Invokes the end-of-the-world milieu of Stephen King's The Stand."

 - ðə poʊst ən kɝiɝ (tʃɑɹlstən, ɛssi.)

 - The Post and Courier (Charleston, S.C.)

"dʒɔɹɾən ɹaɪts wɪð ðə stɑɹk vɪʒən ə laɪɾ ən dɑɹknəs, ən səmtaɪmz tʃaɪldlaɪk sɛns ʌv wʌndɝ, ðət pɝmieɪts dʒeɪ ɑɹ ɑɹ toʊkinz wɝks. hɪz staɪl ɪz ʌndbeɪɾəbli hɪz oʊn."

"Jordan writes with the stark vision of light and darkness, and sometimes childlike sense of wonder, that permeates J. R. R. Tolkien's works. His style is undebatably his own."

 - ðə pɪtsbɝɡ pɹɛs "[ðə wil ə taɪm] wɪl bi ðə dɪfɪnɪɾɪv əmɛɹəkən ɛksplɝeɪʃən ə toʊkinz tɛɹɪtɔɹi fəɹ mɛni jɪɹz tə kʌm. dʒɔɹɾən kən spɪn əz ɹɪtʃ ə wɝld ən əz ɪvɛnt-fɪld ə teɪl əz ðə mæstɝ, ən ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv wɪmən ən ə sɝɾən sɛns ə ðə kɑmɪk pɑsəbɪləɾiz ʌv ə haɪ dɛstəni æd fɝðɝ dɪmɛnʃən tə ðə wɝk."

 - The Pittsburgh Press "[The Wheel of Time] will be the definitive American exploration of Tolkien's territory for many years to come. Jordan can spin as rich a world and as event-filled a tale as the master, and the presence of women and a certain sense of the comic possibilities of a high destiny add further dimension to the work."

 - bʊklɪst "dʒɔɹɾənz mʌltɪvəljum ɛpɪk kəntɪnjuz tə lɪv ʌp tə ɪts haɪ æmbɪʃənz. kɑmplɛks plɑɾɪŋ, ən ɝeɪ ʌv stʃɹɔŋ kæɹɪktɝz, lævɪʃ dɪteɪl, ən ə pænɝæmɪk skoʊp meɪk ðɪs sɪɹiz ə fis fəɹ fæntəsi əfɪʃənɑɾoʊz. . . . ɹɪtʃli dɪteɪld ən vɪvədli ɪmædʒənd."

 - Booklist "Jordan's multivolume epic continues to live up to its high ambitions. Complex plotting, an array of strong characters, lavish detail, and a panoramic scope make this series a feast for fantasy aficionados. . . . Richly detailed and vividly imagined."

 - laɪbɹɛɹi dʒɝnəl "dʒɔɹɾənz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪz klɪɹ ən ɪz vɪʒən ɪz fæsəneɪɾɪŋ, əz ɑɹ ðə fəlɑsəfiz ðət ɹʌn ɪz kæɹɪktɝz. ən spikɪŋ ə kæɹɪktɝz, ə mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ bʌntʃ aɪ wəd bi hɑɹd pʊt tə neɪm."

 - Library Journal "Jordan's writing is clear and his vision is fascinating, as are the philosophies that run his characters. And speaking of characters, a more interesting bunch I would be hard put to name."

 - saɪəns fɪkʃən ɹivju "ðə moʊst æmbɪʃəs əmɛɹəkən fæntəsi sɑɡə, ðə wil ə taɪm, [meɪ] ɔlsoʊ bi ðə faɪnəst. . . . [ɪt] sɝpæsɪz ɔl bʌɾ ə fju ʌv ɪts pɪɹz."

 - Science Fiction Review "The most ambitious American fantasy saga, The Wheel of Time, [may] also be the finest. . . . [It] surpasses all but a few of its peers."

 - bʊklɪst "ðə kɑmplɛks fəlɑsəfi bɪhaɪn ðə wil ə taɪm sɪɹiz ɪz ɪkspaʊndəd soʊ sɪmpli ðə ɹiɾɝ ɔfən ɡɪvz ə stɑɹɾ ə sɝpɹaɪz ət ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə ɹil wɝld. ɹændz ædvɛntʃɝz ɑɹ nɑt fɪnɪʃt ən niðɝ ɪz ðɪs θɪŋkɪŋ pɝsənz fæntəsi sɪɹiz."

 - Booklist "The complex philosophy behind The Wheel of Time series is expounded so simply the reader often gives a start of surprise at returning to the real world. Rand's adventures are not finished and neither is this thinking person's fantasy series."

 - bɹʌnzwɪk sɛntənəl (ɔstʃɹeɪljə)

 - Brunswick Sentinel (Australia)

"ɪntʃɹəkəɾ æləɡɔɹəkəl fæntəsi [ðæt] ɹikɔlz ðə wɝks ə toʊkin kəz ʌv ɪts ɪntɛnsəɾi ən wɔɹmθ."

"Intricate allegorical fantasy [that] recalls the works of Tolkien because of its intensity and warmth."

 - pʌblɪʃɝz wikli "ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən kən ɹaɪt wʌn hɛl ʌv ə stɔɹi. . . . [hi] kips ðə səspɛns əkjuɾ ən ðə sɝpɹaɪzəz ən ɪnvɛnʃən bjuɾəfli peɪst. kəmpɛlɪŋ. ən ɪɡzɪlɝeɪɾɪŋ ɪkspɪɹiəns."

 - Publishers Weekly "Robert Jordan can write one hell of a story. . . . [He] keeps the suspense acute and the surprises and invention beautifully paced. Compelling. An exhilarating experience."

 - aɪzək æsɪmɑvz saɪəns fɪkʃən mæɡəzin "[ðə wil ə taɪm ɪz] ə wɝk ə dʒɛnjəwən ən ɔfən stɝɪŋ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən."

 - Isaac Asimov's Science Fiction magazine "[The Wheel of Time is] a work of genuine and often stirring imagination."

 - kɝkɪs ɹivjuz "fɔɹ ðoʊz u laɪk tə kip ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ə fæntəsi wɝld, ɪts hɑɹd tə bit ðə kɑmplɛks, dɪteɪld wɝl kɹieɪɾəd hɪɹ."

 - Kirkus Reviews "For those who like to keep themselves in a fantasy world, it's hard to beat the complex, detailed world created here."

 - loʊkəs "dʒɔɹɾənz tælən fəɹ səsteɪnɪŋ ðə dɪfəkəl kɑmbəneɪʃən ə səspɛns ən ɹɛzəluʃən, soʊ nɛsəsɛɹi ɪn ə mʌltɪvəljum sɪɹiz . . . ɪz nʌθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl."

 - Locus "Jordan's talent for sustaining the difficult combination of suspense and resolution, so necessary in a multivolume series . . . is nothing short of remarkable."

 - laɪbɹɛɹi dʒɝnəl "dʒɔɹɾən əz nɑt mɪɹli pʊɾ oʊld waɪn ɪndə nu bɑɾəlz: hiz kloʊðd oʊl boʊnz wɪð nu flɛʃ."

 - Library Journal "Jordan has not merely put old wine into new bottles: he has clothed old bones with new flesh."

 - ʃəkɑɡoʊ sʌn-taɪmz naɪf ə dʒɹimz ðə wil ə taɪm baɪ ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝl ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ðə ʃædoʊ ɹaɪzɪŋ ðə faɪɝz ə hɛvən lɔɹɾ ə keɪɑs eɪ kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz ðə pæθ ə dæɡɝz wɪntɝz hɑɹt kɹɔsɹoʊdz ə twaɪlaɪt naɪf ə dʒɹimz baɪ ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən ən bɹændən sændɝsən ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ stɔɹm naɪf ə dʒɹimz ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən eɪ tɑm doʊɝɾi əsoʊsiɪts bʊk nu jɔɹk ðɪs ɪz ə wɝk ə fɪkʃən. ɔl ə ðə kæɹɪktɝz, ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃənz, ən ɪvɛns pɔɹtʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ðɪs nɑvəl ɑɹ iðɝ pɹɑɾəkts ə ði ɔθɝz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən əɹ ɑɹ juz fɪktɪʃəsli.

fɹʌntispis baɪ maɪkəl koʊmɑɹk mæps baɪ ɛlisə mɪtʃəl ɪntɪɹiɝ ɪləstʃɹeɪʃənz baɪ mæθju si nilsən ən ɛlisə mɪtʃəl eɪ tɔɹ bʊk pʌblɪʃt baɪ tɑm doʊɝɾi əsoʊsiɪts,  wʌnhʌnʒɹədsɛvəntifaɪv fɪfθ ævənu nu jɔɹk, nujɔɹk wʌnzɪɹoʊzɪɹoʊwʌnzɪɹoʊ

 naɪnsɛvəneɪt-wʌn-fɔɹθaʊzəntuhʌndʒɹədnaɪntinaɪn-sɪkszɪɹoʊeɪtwʌn-sɪks

fɝst ədɪʃən: ɑktoʊbɝ tuθaʊzənfaɪv

fɝst i-bʊk ədɪʃən: ɑɡəs twɛntiɾɛn

First E-book Edition: August 2010

mænjəfæktʃɝɾ ɪn ðə junaɪɾəd steɪts ʌv əmɛɹəkə zɪɹoʊ naɪn eɪt sɛvən sɪks faɪv fɔɹ θɹi tu wʌn

ɪn mɛmɹi ʌv tʃɑɹlz seɪn dʒɔɹdʒ sɪŋklɝ æɾəmz dʒulaɪ sɪksθ, naɪntinsɛvəntisɪkseɪpɹəl wʌnθɹi, tuzɪɹoʊzɪɹoʊfaɪv

In memory of Charles St. George Sinkler Adams July 6, 1976April 13, 2005

kɑntɛns mæps pɹoʊlɑɡ: ɛmbɝz fɔlɪŋ ɑn dʒɹaɪ ɡɹæs wʌn wən læst saʊnz tu ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ θɹi ət ðə ɡɑɹɾənz fɔɹ eɪ dil faɪv sʌmθɪŋ . . . stʃɹeɪnʒ sɪks eɪ steɪv ən ə ɹeɪzɝ sɛvən eɪ koʊl mədæljən eɪt dʒɹæɡənz' ɛɡz naɪn eɪ ʃɔɹt pæθ tɛn eɪ vɪlədʒ ɪn ʃioʊɾə ɪlɛvən eɪ hɛl ɪn mɑɾɝɪn twɛlv eɪ mænjəfæktɝi θɝtin sidʒ fɔɹtin wɛt θɪŋz fɪftin eɪ dɪfɹən skɪl sɪkstin ðə nu fɑloʊɝ sɛvəntin eɪ bɹɑnz bɛɹ eɪtin nuz fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən naɪntin vaʊz twɛnti ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn twɛntiwʌn wɪðɪn ðə stoʊn twɛntiɾu tə meɪk ən æŋkɝ wip twɛntiθɹi kɔl tə ə sɪɾɪŋ twɛntifɔɹ hʌni ɪn ðə ti twɛntifaɪv ətɛndɪŋ ɪleɪɾə twɛntisɪks əz ɪf ðə wɝld wɝ fɑɡ twɛntisɛvən eɪ pleɪn wʊɾən bɑks twɛntieɪɾ ɪn mɔldən twɛntinaɪn ðə læs nɑt θɝɾi aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡeɪts θɝɾiwʌn ðə haʊs ɑn fʊl mun stʃɹit θɝɾitu tə kip ðə bɑɹɡən θɝɾiθɹi naɪn aʊɾ ə tɛn θɝɾifɔɹ eɪ kʌp ə kæf θɝɾifaɪv ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ə daɪɛlɪn θɝɾisɪks ʌndɝ ən oʊk θɝɾisɛvən pɹɪns ə ðə ɹeɪvənz ɛpəlɔɡ: ɹɪmɛmbɝ ði oʊl seɪɪŋ ɡlɔsɝi ðə switnəs ə vɪktɝi ən ðə bɪɾɝnəs ə dɪfiɾ ɑɹ əlaɪk ə naɪf ə dʒɹimz.

CONTENTS MAPS PROLOGUE: Embers Falling on Dry Grass 1 When Last Sounds 2 The Dark One's Touch 3 At the Gardens 4 A Deal 5 Something . . . Strange 6 A Stave and a Razor 7 A Cold Medallion 8 Dragons' Eggs 9 A Short Path 10 A Village in Shiota 11 A Hell in Maderin 12 A Manufactory 13 Siege 14 Wet Things 15 A Different Skill 16 The New Follower 17 A Bronze Bear 18 News for the Dragon 19 Vows 20 The Golden Crane 21 Within the Stone 22 To Make an Anchor Weep 23 Call to a Sitting 24 Honey in the Tea 25 Attending Elaida 26 As If the World Were Fog 27 A Plain Wooden Box 28 In Malden 29 The Last Knot 30 Outside the Gates 31 The House on Full Moon Street 32 To Keep the Bargain 33 Nine Out of Ten 34 A Cup of Kaf 35 The Importance of Dyelin 36 Under an Oak 37 Prince of the Ravens EPILOGUE: Remember the Old Saying GLOSSARY The sweetness of victory and the bitterness of defeat are alike a knife of dreams.

 - fɹəm fɑɡ ən stil baɪ mæɾək koʊmædʒɹɪn naɪf ə dʒɹimz 
 - From Fog and Steel by Madoc Comadrin KNIFE OF DREAMS 
pɹoʊlɑɡ ɛmbɝz fɔlɪŋ ɑn dʒɹaɪ ɡɹæs



PROLOGUE Embers Falling on Dry Grass

ðə sʌn, klaɪmɪŋ təwɔɹd mɪdmɔɹnɪŋ, stʃɹɛtʃt ɡɑlədz ʃædoʊ ən ðoʊz ə hɪz θɹi ɑɹmɝd kəmpænjənz əhɛɾ ə ðɛm əz ðeɪ tʃɹɑɾəd ðɛɹ maʊns daʊn ðə ɹoʊd ðət ɹæn stʃɹeɪt θɹu ðə fɔɹəst, dɛns wɪð oʊk ən lɛðɝlif, paɪn ən saʊɝɡəm, moʊst ʃoʊɪŋ ðə ɹɛɾ ə spɹɪŋ ɡɹoʊθ. hi tʃɹaɪd tə kip ɪz maɪn ɛmpti, stɪl, bʌt smɔl θɪŋz kɛpt ɪntʃɹuɾɪŋ. ðə deɪ wɑz saɪlən seɪv fəɹ ðə θʌɾ ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz' hʊvz. noʊ bɝd sæŋ ɑn ə bɹæntʃ, noʊ skwɝəl tʃɪɾɝd. tu kwaɪət fəɹ ðə taɪm ə jɪɹ, əz ðoʊ ðə fɔɹəs hɛld ɪts bɹɛθ. ðɪs hæd bɪn ə meɪdʒɝ tʃɹeɪd ɹut wʌns, lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɑmɑdɪʃiə ən tæɹɑbən keɪm ɪndə biɪŋ, ən bɪts ʌv eɪntʃən peɪvɪŋ stoʊn səmtaɪmz stʌɾɪd ðə hɑɹd-pæk sɝfəs ə jɛloʊɪʃ kleɪ. ə sɪŋɡəl fɑɹm kɑɹt fɑɹ əhɛd bɪhaɪn ə plɑɾɪŋ ɑks wɑz ði oʊnli saɪn ə hjumən laɪf naʊ bɪsaɪdz ðɛmsɛlvz. tʃɹeɪd hæd ʃɪftəd fɑɹ nɔɹθ, fɑɹmz ən vɪlədʒəz ɪn ðə ɹidʒən dwɪndəld, ən ðə feɪbəld lɔs maɪnz ʌv æɛlɡɝ ɹɪmeɪn lɔst ɪn ðə tæŋɡəl maʊntən ɹeɪnʒəz ðət bɪɡæn oʊnli ə fju maɪlz tə ðə saʊθ. dɑɹk klaʊdz mæsɪŋ ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən pɹɑməst ɹeɪn baɪ æftɝnun ɪf ðɛɹ sloʊ ədvæns kəntɪnjud. ə ɹɛd-wɪŋ hɔk kɔɹɾɝd bæk ən fɔɹθ əlɔŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝ ə ðə tʃɹiz, hʌntɪŋ ðə fɹɪnʒɪz. əz i hɪmsɛlf wɑz hʌntɪŋ. bʌɾ ət ðə hɑɹt, nɑɾ ɑn ðə fɹɪnʒɪz.

The sun, climbing toward midmorning, stretched Galad's shadow and those of his three armored companions ahead of them as they trotted their mounts down the road that ran straight through the forest, dense with oak and leatherleaf, pine and sourgum, most showing the red of spring growth. He tried to keep his mind empty, still, but small things kept intruding. The day was silent save for the thud of their horses' hooves. No bird sang on a branch, no squirrel chittered. Too quiet for the time of year, as though the forest held its breath. This had been a major trade route once, long before Amadicia and Tarabon came into being, and bits of ancient paving stone sometimes studded the hard-packed surface of yellowish clay. A single farm cart far ahead behind a plodding ox was the only sign of human life now besides themselves. Trade had shifted far north, farms and villages in the region dwindled, and the fabled lost mines of Aelgar remained lost in the tangled mountain ranges that began only a few miles to the south. Dark clouds massing in that direction promised rain by afternoon if their slow advance continued. A red-winged hawk quartered back and forth along the border of the trees, hunting the fringes. As he himself was hunting. But at the heart, not on the fringes.

ðə mænɝ haʊs ðət ðə sintʃæn hæd ɡɪvən imən vɑldə keɪm ɪndə vju, ən i dʒɹu ɹeɪn, wɪʃɪŋ i hæɾ ə hɛlmət stʃɹæp tə taɪɾən fəɹ ɪkskjus. ɪnstɛɾ i hæd tə bi kəntɛnt wɪð ɹeɪ-bʌklɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt, pɹitɛndɪŋ ðəɾ ɪt hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ɹɔŋ. ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ pɔɪn tə wɛɹɪŋ ɑɹmɝ. ɪf ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɛn əz i hoʊpt, hi wʊɾə hæd tə ɹimuv bɹɛstpleɪɾ ən meɪl ɪn ɛni keɪs, ən ɪf ɪt wɛn bædli, ɑɹmɝ wʊɾə pɹəvaɪɾəd lɪɾəl mɔɹ pɹətɛkʃən ðən ɪz waɪt koʊt.

The manor house that the Seanchan had given Eamon Valda came into view, and he drew rein, wishing he had a helmet strap to tighten for excuse. Instead he had to be content with re-buckling his sword belt, pretending that it had been sitting wrong. There had been no point to wearing armor. If the morning went as he hoped, he would have had to remove breastplate and mail in any case, and if it went badly, armor would have provided little more protection than his white coat.

fɔɹmɝli ə dip-kʌntʃɹi lɑdʒ ə ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiə, ðə bɪldɪŋ wɑz ə hjudʒ, blu-ɹuf stʃɹʌktʃɝ stʌɾɪd wɪð ɹɛd-peɪntəd bælkəniz, ə wʊɾən pæləs wɪð wʊɾən spaɪɹz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ətɑp ə stoʊn faʊndeɪʃən laɪk ə loʊ, stip-saɪɾəd hɪl. ði aʊtbɪldɪŋz, steɪbəlz ən bɑɹnz, wɝkmɪnz smɔl haʊsəz ən kɹæftsfoʊks' wɝkʃɑps, ɔl hʌɡd ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn ðə waɪd klɪɹɪŋ ðət sɝaʊndəd ðə meɪn haʊs, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɪɹli əz ɹisplɛndən ɪn ðɛɹ blu-ænd-ɹɛd peɪnt. ə hændfʊl ə mɛn ən wɪmən muvd ɝaʊn ðɛm, taɪni fɪɡjɝz jɛɾ ət ðɪs dɪstəns, ən tʃɪlʒɹən wɝ pleɪɪŋ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ ɛldɝz' aɪz. ən ɪmədʒ ə nɔɹmæləɾi wɛɹ nʌθɪŋ wɑz nɔɹməl. hɪz kəmpænjənz sæt ðɛɹ sæɾəlz ɪn ðɛɹ bɝnɪʃt hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən. ðɛɹ maʊns stæmpt ɪmpeɪʃənli, ði ænəməlz' mɔɹnɪŋ fɹɛʃnəs nɑt jɛt wɔɹn ɔf baɪ ðə ʃɔɹt ɹaɪd fɹəm ðə kæmp.

Formerly a deep-country lodge of the King of Amadicia, the building was a huge, blue-roofed structure studded with red-painted balconies, a wooden palace with wooden spires at the corners atop a stone foundation like a low, steep-sided hill. The outbuildings, stables and barns, workmen's small houses and craftsfolks' workshops, all hugged the ground in the wide clearing that surrounded the main house, but they were nearly as resplendent in their blue-and-red paint. A handful of men and women moved around them, tiny figures yet at this distance, and children were playing under their elders' eyes. An image of normality where nothing was normal. His companions sat their saddles in their burnished helmets and breastplates, watching him without expression. Their mounts stamped impatiently, the animals' morning freshness not yet worn off by the short ride from the camp.

"ɪts ʌndɝstændəbəl ɪf jəɹ hævɪŋ sɛkən θɔts, dəmədʒɹd," tʃɹɑm sɛɾ æftɝ ə taɪm. "ɪts ə hɑɹʃ ækjəzeɪʃən, bɪɾɝ əz ɡɔl, bʌt - "

"It's understandable if you're having second thoughts, Damodred," Trom said after a time. "It's a harsh accusation, bitter as gall, but - "

"noʊ sɛkən θɔts fəɹ mi," ɡɑləd bɹoʊk ɪn. hɪz ɪntɛntʃənz hæd bɪn fɪkst sɪns jɛstɝdeɪ. hi wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl, ðoʊ. tʃɹɑm hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ði oʊpənɪŋ i niɾəd. ðeɪ hæd sɪmpli əpɪɹɾ əz i ɹoʊɾ aʊt, fɔlɪŋ ɪn wɪð ɪm wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd spoʊkən. ðəɹ hæd sim noʊ pleɪs fəɹ wɝdz, ðɛn. "bʌt wʌɾ əbaʊt jə θɹi? jəɹ teɪkɪŋ ə ɹɪsk kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ wɪð mi. ə ɹɪsk juv noʊ nid tə teɪk. haʊɛvɝ ðə deɪ ɹʌnz, ðəɹ wɪl bi mɑɹks əɡɛns ju. ðɪs ɪz maɪ bɪznəs, ən aɪ ɡɪv jə liv tə ɡoʊ əbaʊt jʊɹz." tu stɪfli sɛd, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt faɪnd wɝdz ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, əɹ lusən ɪz θɹoʊt.

"No second thoughts for me," Galad broke in. His intentions had been fixed since yesterday. He was grateful, though. Trom had given him the opening he needed. They had simply appeared as he rode out, falling in with him without a word spoken. There had seemed no place for words, then. "But what about you three? You're taking a risk coming here with me. A risk you have no need to take. However the day runs, there will be marks against you. This is my business, and I give you leave to go about yours." Too stiffly said, but he could not find words this morning, or loosen his throat.

ðə stɑki mæn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðə lɔ ɪz ðə lɔ. ən aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl meɪk jus ə maɪ nu ɹæŋk." ðə θɹi ɡoʊldən stɑɹ-ʃeɪp nɑts ʌv ə kæptən sæt bɪniθ ðə flɛɹɪŋ sʌnbɝst ɑn ðə bɹɛst ə hɪz waɪt kloʊk. ðəɹ hæd bɪn mɔɹ ðən ə fju dɛɾ ət dʒɹəməl, ɪnkluɾɪŋ noʊ fjuɝ ðən θɹi ʌv ðə lɔɹdz kæptən. ðeɪ hæd bɪn faɪɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn ðɛn, nɑɾ əlaɪd wɪð ðɛm.

The stocky man shook his head. "The law is the law. And I might as well make use of my new rank." The three golden star-shaped knots of a captain sat beneath the flaring sunburst on the breast of his white cloak. There had been more than a few dead at Jeramel, including no fewer than three of the Lords Captain. They had been fighting the Seanchan then, not allied with them.

"aɪv dʌn dɑɹk θɪŋz ɪn sɝvəs tə ðə laɪt," ɡɔnt-feɪs baɪɑɝ sɛd ɡɹɪmli, hɪz dip-sɛɾ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ əz ðoʊ əɾ ə pɝsənəl ɪnsəlt, "dɑɹk əz munləs mɪdnaɪt, ən laɪkli əl əɡɛn, bʌt səm θɪŋz ɑɹ tu dɑɹk tə bi əlaʊd." hi lʊkt əz ɪf i maɪt spɪt.

"I've done dark things in service to the Light," gaunt-faced Byar said grimly, his deep-set eyes glittering as though at a personal insult, "dark as moonless midnight, and likely I will again, but some things are too dark to be allowed." He looked as if he might spit.

"ðæts ɹaɪt," jʌŋ bɔɹnhəl mʌɾɝd, skɹʌbɪŋ ə ɡɔntələɾəd hæn əkɹɔs ɪz maʊθ. ɡɑləɾ ɔlweɪz θɔɾ ə hɪm əz jʌŋ, ðoʊ ðə mæn lækt oʊnli ə fju jɪɹz ɑn hɪm. deɪnz aɪz wɝ blʌdʃɑt; hi hæd bɪn ət ðə bɹændi əɡɛn læs naɪt. "ɪf juv dʌn wʌts ɹɔŋ, ivən ɪn sɝvəs tə ðə laɪt, ðən juv tə də wʌts ɹaɪt tə bæləns ɪt." baɪɑɝ ɡɹʌntɪd saʊɝli. laɪkli ðət wɑz nɑt ðə pɔɪn i hæd bɪn meɪkɪŋ.

"That's right," young Bornhald muttered, scrubbing a gauntleted hand across his mouth. Galad always thought of him as young, though the man lacked only a few years on him. Dain's eyes were bloodshot; he had been at the brandy again last night. "If you've done what's wrong, even in service to the Light, then you have to do what's right to balance it." Byar grunted sourly. Likely that was not the point he had been making.

"vɛɹi wɛl," ɡɑləd sɛd, "bʌt ðɛɹz noʊ fɔl tə ɛni mæn u tɝnz bæk. maɪ bɪznəs hɪɹ ɪz maɪn əloʊn."

"Very well," Galad said, "but there's no fault to any man who turns back. My business here is mine alone."

stɪl, wən i hild ɪz beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ tə ə kæntɝ, hi wɑz pliz tə hæv əm ɡæləp tə kætʃ ɪm ən fɔl ɪn əlɔŋsaɪd, waɪt kloʊks bɪloʊɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. hi wʊɾə ɡɔn ɑn əloʊn, ʌv kɔɹs, jɛt ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns maɪt kip ɪm fɹəm biɪŋ ɝɛstəɾ ən hæŋd aʊɾ ə hænd. nɑt ðəɾ i ɪkspɛktəd tə sɝvaɪv ɪn ɛni keɪs. wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn, hæd tə bi dʌn, noʊ mæɾɝ ðə pɹaɪs.

Still, when he heeled his bay gelding to a canter, he was pleased to have them gallop to catch him and fall in alongside, white cloaks billowing behind. He would have gone on alone, of course, yet their presence might keep him from being arrested and hanged out of hand. Not that he expected to survive in any case. What had to be done, had to be done, no matter the price.

ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz klæɾɝd laʊdli ɑn ðə stoʊn ɹæmp ðət klaɪm tə ðə mænɝ haʊs, soʊ ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ðə bɹɔd sɛntʃɹəl kɔɹtʃjɑɹd tɝn tə wɑtʃ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪn: fɪfti ʌv ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɪn ɡlimɪŋ pleɪt-ænd-meɪl ən kɑnɪkəl hɛlməts, moʊs maʊntəd, wɪð kɹɪŋɪŋ, dɑɹk-koʊɾəd ɑmɑdɪʃən ɡɹumz hoʊldɪŋ ænəməlz fəɹ ðə ɹɛst. ði ɪnɝ bælkəniz wɝ ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju sɝvəns u əpɪɹd tə bi wɑtʃɪŋ waɪl pɹitɛndɪŋ tə swip. sɪks kwɛstʃənɝz, bɪɡ mɛn wɪð ðə skɑɹlət ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊk əpɹaɪt bɪhaɪn ðə sʌnflɛɹ ɑn ðɛɹ kloʊks, stʊd kloʊs ɝaʊn ɹɑɾəm əsunɑwə laɪk ə bɑɾiɡɑɹd, əweɪ fɹəm ði ʌðɝz. ðə hæn ə ðə laɪɾ ɔlweɪz stʊɾ əpɑɹt fɹəm ðə ɹɛst ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, ə tʃɔɪs ðə ɹɛst ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən əpɹuvd. ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹɾ əsunɑwə, hɪz sɑɹoʊfəl feɪs meɪkɪŋ baɪɑɝ lʊk fʊli flɛʃt, wɑz ði oʊnli tʃaɪl pɹɛzənt nɑɾ ɪn ɑɹmɝ, ən ɪz snoʊi kloʊk kæɹid dʒʌs ðə bɹɪljən ɹɛd kɹʊk, ənʌðɝ weɪ ʌv stændɪŋ əpɑɹt. bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm mɑɹkɪŋ u wɑz pɹɛzənt, ɡɑləd hæɾ aɪz fəɹ oʊnli wʌn mæn ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. əsunɑwə maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪnvɑlvd ɪn səm weɪ - ðət ɹɪmeɪn ənklɪɹ - jɛɾ oʊnli ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ kəd kɔl ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ tə əkaʊnt.

The horses' hooves clattered loudly on the stone ramp that climbed to the manor house, so every man in the broad central courtyard turned to watch as they rode in: fifty of the Children in gleaming plate-and-mail and conical helmets, most mounted, with cringing, dark-coated Amadician grooms holding animals for the rest. The inner balconies were empty except for a few servants who appeared to be watching while pretending to sweep. Six Questioners, big men with the scarlet shepherd's crook upright behind the sunflare on their cloaks, stood close around Rhadam Asunawa like a bodyguard, away from the others. The Hand of the Light always stood apart from the rest of the Children, a choice the rest of the Children approved. Gray-haired Asunawa, his sorrowful face making Byar look fully fleshed, was the only Child present not in armor, and his snowy cloak carried just the brilliant red crook, another way of standing apart. But aside from marking who was present, Galad had eyes for only one man in the courtyard. Asunawa might have been involved in some way - that remained unclear - yet only the Lord Captain Commander could call the High Inquisitor to account.

imən vɑldə wɑz nɑɾ ə lɑɹdʒ mæn, bʌɾ ɪz dɑɹk, hɑɹd feɪs hæd ðə lʊk ʌv wʌn u ɪkspɛktəɾ oʊbiɾiəns əz ɪz du. əz ðə vɛɹi list i wɑz du. stændɪŋ wɪð ɪz buɾɪd fiɾ əpɑɹɾ ən ɪz hɛd haɪ, kəmæn ɪn ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ə hɪm, hi wɔɹ ðə waɪt-ænd-ɡoʊl tɑbɝɾ ə ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ oʊvɝ ɪz ɡɪldɪd bɹɛst- ən bækpleɪts, ə sɪlk tɑbɝd mɔɹ ɹɪtʃli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ðən ɛni peɪdʒɹən naɪl hæd wɔɹn. hɪz waɪt kloʊk, ðə flɛɹɪŋ sʌn lɑɹdʒ ɑn iðɝ bɹɛst ɪn θɹɛd-ʌv-ɡoʊld, wɑz sɪlk əz wɛl, ən ɪz ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd waɪt koʊt. ðə hɛlmət bɪniθ ɪz ɑɹm wɑz ɡɪldɪɾ ən wɝkt wɪð ðə flɛɹɪŋ sʌn ɑn ðə bɹaʊ, ən ə hɛvi ɡoʊld ɹɪŋ ɑn ɪz lɛf hænd, wɔɹn aʊtsaɪɾ ɪz stil-bækt ɡɔnlət, hɛld ə lɑɹdʒ jɛloʊ sæfaɪɝ kɑɹvd wɪð ðə sʌnbɝst. ənʌðɝ mɑɹk ə feɪvɝ ɹəsiv fɹəm ðə sintʃæn.

Eamon Valda was not a large man, but his dark, hard face had the look of one who expected obedience as his due. As the very least he was due. Standing with his booted feet apart and his head high, command in every inch of him, he wore the white-and-gold tabard of the Lord Captain Commander over his gilded breast- and backplates, a silk tabard more richly embroidered than any Pedron Niall had worn. His white cloak, the flaring sun large on either breast in thread-of-gold, was silk as well, and his gold-embroidered white coat. The helmet beneath his arm was gilded and worked with the flaring sun on the brow, and a heavy gold ring on his left hand, worn outside his steel-backed gauntlet, held a large yellow sapphire carved with the sunburst. Another mark of favor received from the Seanchan.

vɑldə fɹaʊn slaɪtli əz ɡɑləɾ ən ɪz kəmpænjənz dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən ɔfɝd ðɛɹ səluts, ɑɹm əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst. əbsikwiəs ɡɹumz keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ tə teɪk ðɛɹ ɹeɪnz.

Valda frowned slightly as Galad and his companions dismounted and offered their salutes, arm across the chest. Obsequious grooms came running to take their reins.

"waɪ ɑɹən jə ɑn jəɹ weɪ tə næsəd, tʃɹɑm?" dɪsəpɹuvəl kʌlɝd vɑldəz wɝdz. "ði ʌðɝ lɔɹdz kæptən wɪl bi hæfweɪ ðəɹ baɪ naʊ." hi hɪmsɛlf ɔlweɪz ɝaɪv leɪt wən miɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn, pɝhæps tə əsɝt ðət səm ʃɹɛɾ ʌv ɪndɪpɛndəns ɹɪmeɪn tə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən - faɪndɪŋ ɪm ɔlɹɛɾi pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə dɪpɑɹt wɑz ə sɝpɹaɪz; ðɪs miɾɪŋ mʌs bi vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt - bʌɾ i ɔlweɪz meɪd ʃʊɹ ði ʌðɝ haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ ɔfəsɝz ɝaɪvd ɑn taɪm ivən wən ðət ɹikwaɪɝd sɛɾɪŋ aʊt bɪfɔɹ dɔn. əpɛɹənli ɪt wɑz bɛs nɑt tə pɹɛs ðɛɹ nu mæstɝz tu fɑɹ. dɪstʃɹʌst ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən wɑz ɔlweɪz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə sintʃæn.

"Why aren't you on your way to Nassad, Trom?" Disapproval colored Valda's words. "The other Lords Captain will be halfway there by now." He himself always arrived late when meeting the Seanchan, perhaps to assert that some shred of independence remained to the Children - finding him already preparing to depart was a surprise; this meeting must be very important - but he always made sure the other high-ranking officers arrived on time even when that required setting out before dawn. Apparently it was best not to press their new masters too far. Distrust of the Children was always strong in the Seanchan.

tʃɹɑm dɪspleɪd nʌn ə ði ənsɝɾənti ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪkspɛktəd fɹəm ə mæn u hæd hɛld ɪz pɹɛzən ɹæŋk bɛɹli ə mʌnθ. "æn ɝdʒən mæɾɝ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," hi sɛd smuðli, meɪkɪŋ ə vɛɹi pɹɪsaɪs baʊ, niðɝ ə hɛɹ dipɝ nɔɹ haɪɝ ðən pɹoʊɾəkɑl dɪmændəd. "eɪ tʃaɪld ə maɪ kəmæn tʃɑɹdʒəz ənʌðɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən wɪð əbjuzɪŋ ə fimeɪl ɹɛləɾɪv ə hɪz, ən kleɪmz ðə ɹaɪɾ ə tʃɹaɪəl bɪniθ ðə laɪt, wɪtʃ baɪ lɔ jə mʌst ɡɹæn əɹ dɪnaɪ."

Trom displayed none of the uncertainty that might have been expected from a man who had held his present rank barely a month. "An urgent matter, my Lord Captain Commander," he said smoothly, making a very precise bow, neither a hair deeper nor higher than protocol demanded. "A Child of my command charges another of the Children with abusing a female relative of his, and claims the right of Trial Beneath the Light, which by law you must grant or deny."

"ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɹɪkwɛst, maɪ sʌn," əsunɑwə sɛd, tɪltɪŋ ɪz hɛd kwɪtsɪkli əbʌv klæsp hænz, bɪfɔɹ vɑldə kəd spik. ivən ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝz vɔɪs wɑz doʊlfəl; hi saʊndəd peɪn ət tʃɹɑmz ɪɡnɝəns. hɪz aɪz sim dɑɹk hɑt koʊlz ɪn ə bɹeɪziɝ. "ɪt wɑz juʒəwəli ði əkjuzd u æsk tə ɡɪv ðə dʒʌdʒmən tə sɔɹdz, ən aɪ bɪliv juʒəwəli wən i nu ði ɛvəɾəns wəd kənvɪk hɪm. ɪn ɛni keɪs, tʃɹaɪəl bɪniθ ðə laɪɾ əz nɑt bɪn ɪnvoʊk fəɹ nɪɹli fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ɡɪmi ði əkjuzdz neɪm, ən əl dil wɪð ðə mæɾɝ kwaɪətli." hɪz toʊn tɝn tʃɪl əz ə sʌnləs kævɝn ɪn wɪntɝ, ðoʊ hɪz aɪz stɪl bɝnd. "wi ɑɹ əmʌŋ stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, ən wi kænɑɾ əlaʊ ðɛm tə noʊ ðət wʌn ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɪz keɪpəbəl ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ."

"A strange request, my son," Asunawa said, tilting his head quizzically above clasped hands, before Valda could speak. Even the High Inquisitor's voice was doleful; he sounded pained at Trom's ignorance. His eyes seemed dark hot coals in a brazier. "It was usually the accused who asked to give the judgment to swords, and I believe usually when he knew the evidence would convict him. In any case, Trial Beneath the Light has not been invoked for nearly four hundred years. Give me the accused's name, and I will deal with the matter quietly." His tone turned chill as a sunless cavern in winter, though his eyes still burned. "We are among strangers, and we cannot allow them to know that one of the Children is capable of such a thing."

"ðə ɹɪkwɛst wɑz dɝɛktəd tə mi, əsunɑwə," vɑldə snæpt. hɪz ɡlɛɹ maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn oʊpən heɪtʃɹəd. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz dʒʌs dɪslaɪk ə ði ʌðɝ mænz bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪn. flɪpɪŋ wʌn saɪɾ ə hɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ tə bɛɹ ɪz ɹɪŋ-kwɪlən sɔɹd, hi ɹɛstəɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ðə lɔŋ hɪlt ən dʒɹu hɪmsɛlf ʌp. ɔlweɪz wʌn fəɹ ðə ɡɹæn dʒɛstʃɝ, vɑldə ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs soʊ ðəɾ ivən pipəl ɪnsaɪd pɹɑbli hɝd hɪm, ən dɪkleɪmd ɹæðɝ ðən mɪɹli spoʊk.

"The request was directed to me, Asunawa," Valda snapped. His glare might as well have been open hatred. Perhaps it was just dislike of the other man's breaking in. Flipping one side of his cloak over his shoulder to bare his ring-quilloned sword, he rested his hand on the long hilt and drew himself up. Always one for the grand gesture, Valda raised his voice so that even people inside probably heard him, and declaimed rather than merely spoke.

"aɪ bɪliv mɛni ʌv əɹ oʊld weɪz ʃəd bi ɹɪvaɪvd, ən ðət lɔ stɪl stænz. ɪɾəl ɔlweɪz stænd, əz ɹɪɾən ʌv oʊld. ðə laɪt ɡɹæns dʒʌstəs kəz ðə laɪɾ ɪz dʒʌstəs. ɪnfɔɹm jəɹ mæn i meɪ ɪʃu hɪz tʃælənʒ, tʃɹɑm, ən feɪs ðə wʌn i əkjuzɪz sɔɹd-tə-sɔɹd. ɪf ðət wʌn tʃɹaɪz tə ɹəfjuz, aɪ dɪklɛɹ ðət hiz æknɑlɪdʒd ɪz ɡɪlt ən ɔɹɾɝ ɪm hæŋd ɑn ðə spɑt, hɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz ən ɹæŋk fɔɹfɪt tə hɪz əkjuzɝ əz ðə lɔ steɪts. aɪ hæv spoʊkən." ðət wɪð ənʌðɝ skaʊl fəɹ ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ. meɪbi ðəɹ ɹɪli wɑz heɪtʃɹəd ðɛɹ.

"I believe many of our old ways should be revived, and that law still stands. It will always stand, as written of old. The Light grants justice because the Light is justice. Inform your man he may issue his challenge, Trom, and face the one he accuses sword-to-sword. If that one tries to refuse, I declare that he has acknowledged his guilt and order him hanged on the spot, his belongings and rank forfeit to his accuser as the law states. I have spoken." That with another scowl for the High Inquisitor. Maybe there really was hatred there.

tʃɹɑm baʊd fɔɹməli wʌns mɔɹ. "ju hæv ɪnfɔɹmd ɪm jɝsɛlf, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ. dəmədʒɹd?"

Trom bowed formally once more. "You have informed him yourself, my Lord Captain Commander. Damodred?"

ɡɑləd fɛl koʊld. nɑt ðə koʊld ə fɪɹ, bʌɾ ʌv ɛmptinəs. wən deɪn dʒɹʌŋkənli lɛt slɪp ðə kənfjuzd ɹumɝz ðət hæd kʌm tə hɪz ɪɹz, wən baɪɑɝ ɹɪlʌktənli kənfɝm ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ ðən ɹumɝz, ɹeɪdʒ hæd fɪld ɡɑləd, ə boʊn-bɝnɪŋ faɪɝ ðət nɪɹli dʒɹoʊv ɪm ɪnseɪn. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ɪz hɛd wəɾ ɪksploʊɾ ɪf ɪz hɑɹt dɪd nɑt bɝs fɝst. naʊ hi wɑz aɪs, dʒɹeɪn ʌv ɛni ɪmoʊʃən. hi ɔlsoʊ baʊd fɔɹməli. mʌtʃ ʌv wʌɾ i hæd tə seɪ wɑz sɛɾ ɪn ðə lɔ, jɛɾ i tʃoʊz ðə ɹɛst wɪð kɛɹ, tə spɛɹ əz mʌtʃ ʃeɪm əz pɑsəbəl tə ə mɛmɹi hi hɛl dɪɹ.

Galad felt cold. Not the cold of fear, but of emptiness. When Dain drunkenly let slip the confused rumors that had come to his ears, when Byar reluctantly confirmed they were more than rumors, rage had filled Galad, a bone-burning fire that nearly drove him insane. He had been sure his head would explode if his heart did not burst first. Now he was ice, drained of any emotion. He also bowed formally. Much of what he had to say was set in the law, yet he chose the rest with care, to spare as much shame as possible to a memory he held dear.

"imən vɑldə, tʃaɪld ə ðə laɪt, aɪ kɔl jə tə tʃɹaɪəl bɪniθ ðə laɪt fəɹ ənlɔfəl əsɔlt ɑn ðə pɝsən ə mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd, kwin ʌv ændɝ, ən fəɹ əɹ mɝɾɝ." noʊ wʌn hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə kənfɝm ðət ðə wʊmən i ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əz ɪz mʌðɝ wɑz dɛd, jɛɾ ɪt mʌs bi soʊ. ə dʌzən mɛn wɝ sɝɾən ʃi hæd vænɪʃt fɹəm ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ə ðə laɪt bɪfɔɹ ɪt fɛl tə ðə sintʃæn, ən əz mɛni tɛstəfaɪd ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn fɹi tə liv ə hɝ oʊn wɪl.

"Eamon Valda, Child of the Light, I call you to Trial Beneath the Light for unlawful assault on the person of Morgase Trakand, Queen of Andor, and for her murder." No one had been able to confirm that the woman he regarded as his mother was dead, yet it must be so. A dozen men were certain she had vanished from the Fortress of the Light before it fell to the Seanchan, and as many testified she had not been free to leave of her own will.

vɑldə dɪspleɪd noʊ ʃɑk ət ðə tʃɑɹdʒ. hɪz smaɪl maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪntɛndəd tə ʃoʊ ɹəɡɹɛɾ oʊvɝ ɡɑlədz fɑli ɪn meɪkɪŋ sətʃ ə kleɪm, jɛt kəntɛmpt wɑz mɪŋɡəld ɪn ɪt. hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, bʌɾ əsunɑwə kʌɾ ɪn wʌns mɔɹ.

Valda displayed no shock at the charge. His smile might have been intended to show regret over Galad's folly in making such a claim, yet contempt was mingled in it. He opened his mouth, but Asunawa cut in once more.

"ðɪs ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs," hi sɛɾ ɪn toʊnz mɔɹ ə sɑɹoʊ ðən ʌv æŋɡɝ. "teɪk ðə ful, ən wɪl faɪn aʊt wʌt dɑɹkfɹɛn plɑt tə dɪskɹɛɾət ðə tʃɪlʒɹən hiz pɑɹɾ ʌv." hi moʊʃənd, ən tu ʌv ðə hʌlkɪŋ kwɛstʃənɝz tʊk ə stɛp təwɔɹd ɡɑləd, wʌn wɪð ə kɹuəl ɡɹɪn, ði ʌðɝ blæŋk-feɪst, ə wɝkmən əbaʊɾ ɪz wɝk.

"This is ridiculous," he said in tones more of sorrow than of anger. "Take the fool, and we'll find out what Darkfriend plot to discredit the Children he is part of." He motioned, and two of the hulking Questioners took a step toward Galad, one with a cruel grin, the other blank-faced, a workman about his work.

oʊnli wʌn stɛp, ðoʊ. ə sɑft ɹæsp ɹɪpiɾɪd ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ əz tʃɪlʒɹən iz ðɛɹ sɔɹdz ɪn ðɛɹ skæbɝdz. ət list ə dʌzən mɛn dʒɹu ɪntaɪɝli, lɛɾɪŋ ðɛɹ bleɪdz hæŋ baɪ ðɛɹ saɪdz. ði ɑmɑdɪʃən ɡɹumz hʌntʃt ɪn ɑn ðɛmsɛlvz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɪkʌm ɪnvɪzəbəl. laɪkli ðeɪ wəɾ əv ɹʌn, hæd ðeɪ dɛɹd. əsunɑwə stɛɹɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, θɪk aɪbɹaʊz klaɪmɪŋ ʌp ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif, nɑɾɪd fɪsts ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪz kloʊk. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ivən vɑldə əpɪɹd stɑɹɾəld fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. ʃʊɹli hi hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðə tʃɪlʒɹən tə əlaʊ ən ɝɛst æftɝ ɪz oʊn pɹɑkləmeɪʃən. ɪf i hæd, hi ɹəkʌvɝd kwɪkli.

Only one step, though. A soft rasp repeated around the courtyard as Children eased their swords in their scabbards. At least a dozen men drew entirely, letting their blades hang by their sides. The Amadician grooms hunched in on themselves, trying to become invisible. Likely they would have run, had they dared. Asunawa stared around him, thick eyebrows climbing up his forehead in disbelief, knotted fists gripping his cloak. Strangely, even Valda appeared startled for an instant. Surely he had not expected the Children to allow an arrest after his own proclamation. If he had, he recovered quickly.

"ju si, əsunɑwə," hi sɛɾ ɔlmoʊs tʃɪɹfəli, "ðə tʃɪlʒɹən fɑloʊ maɪ ɔɹɾɝz, ən ðə lɔ, nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃənɝz wɪmz." hi hɛld aʊɾ ɪz hɛlmət tə wʌn saɪd fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə teɪk. "aɪ dɪnaɪ jəɹ pɹɪpɑstɝəs tʃɑɹdʒ, jʌŋ ɡɑləd, ən θɹoʊ jəɹ faʊl laɪ ɪn jəɹ tiθ. fəɹ ɪts ə laɪ, əɹ ət bɛst ə mæɾ æksɛptəns ə səm məlɪɡnən ɹumɝ stɑɹɾəd baɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnz əɹ ʌðɝz u wɪʃ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɪl. iðɝ weɪ, juv dɪfeɪmd mi ɪn ðə vaɪləs mænɝ, soʊ aɪ æksɛp jəɹ tʃælənʒ tə tʃɹaɪəl bɪniθ ðə laɪt, wɛɹ əl kɪl ju." ðət bɛɹli skwizd ɪndə ðə ɹɪtʃuəl, bʌɾ i hæd dɪnaɪd ðə tʃɑɹdʒ ən æksɛptɪd ðə tʃælənʒ; ɪt wəd səfaɪs.

"You see, Asunawa," he said almost cheerfully, "the Children follow my orders, and the law, not a Questioner's whims." He held out his helmet to one side for someone to take. "I deny your preposterous charge, young Galad, and throw your foul lie in your teeth. For it is a lie, or at best a mad acceptance of some malignant rumor started by Darkfriends or others who wish the Children ill. Either way, you have defamed me in the vilest manner, so I accept your challenge to Trial Beneath the Light, where I will kill you." That barely squeezed into the ritual, but he had denied the charge and accepted the challenge; it would suffice.

ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ i stɪl hɛl ðə hɛlməɾ ɪn ən aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt hænd, vɑldə fɹaʊn ət wʌn ə ðə dɪsmaʊntɪd tʃɪlʒɹən, ə lin sɑldəiən neɪm kæʃɡɝ, əntɪl ðə mæn stɛp fɔɹwɝd tə ɹɪliv ɪm ʌv ɪt. kæʃɡɝ wɑz oʊnli ən ʌndɝ-lutɛnənt, ɔlmoʊs bɔɪɪʃ dɪspaɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt hʊk noʊz ən θɪk mʌstæʃɪz laɪk ɪnvɝɾɪd hɔɹnz, jɛɾ i muvd wɪð oʊpən ɹɪlʌktəns, ən vɑldəz vɔɪs wɑz dɑɹkɝ ən ækɹɪɾ əz i wɛn ɑn, ənbəklɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt ən hændɪŋ ðəɾ oʊvɝ, tu.

Realizing that he still held the helmet in an outstretched hand, Valda frowned at one of the dismounted Children, a lean Saldaean named Kashgar, until the man stepped forward to relieve him of it. Kashgar was only an under-lieutenant, almost boyish despite a great hooked nose and thick mustaches like inverted horns, yet he moved with open reluctance, and Valda's voice was darker and acrid as he went on, unbuckling his sword belt and handing that over, too.

"teɪk ə kɛɹ wɪð ðæt, kæʃɡɝ. ɪts ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd." ənpɪnɪŋ ɪz sɪlk kloʊk, hi lɛɾ ɪt fɔl tə ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, fɑloʊd baɪ hɪz tɑbɝd, ən ɪz hænz muv tə ðə bʌkəlz ə hɪz ɑɹmɝ. ɪt sim ðəɾ i wɑz ənwɪlɪŋ tə si ɪf ʌðɝz wəd bi ɹɪlʌktən tə hɛlp hɪm. hɪz feɪs wɑz kɑm ɪnʌf, ɪksɛp ðəɾ æŋɡɹi aɪz pɹɑməst ɹɛtʃɹəbjuʃən tə mɔɹ ðən ɡɑləd. "jɔɹ sɪstɝ wɑns tə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪ ʌndɝstænd, dəmədʒɹd. pɝhæps aɪ ʌndɝstæn pɹɪsaɪsli wɛɹ ðɪs ɝɪdʒəneɪɾəd. ðəɹ wɑz ə taɪm aɪ wʊɾə ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd jəɹ dɛθ, bʌt nɑt tədeɪ. aɪ meɪ sɛn jəɹ hɛd tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ soʊ ðə wɪtʃəz kən si ðə fɹuɾ ə ðɛɹ skim."

"Take a care with that, Kashgar. It's a heron-mark blade." Unpinning his silk cloak, he let it fall to the paving stones, followed by his tabard, and his hands moved to the buckles of his armor. It seemed that he was unwilling to see if others would be reluctant to help him. His face was calm enough, except that angry eyes promised retribution to more than Galad. "Your sister wants to become Aes Sedai, I understand, Damodred. Perhaps I understand precisely where this originated. There was a time I would have regretted your death, but not today. I may send your head to the White Tower so the witches can see the fruit of their scheme."

wɝi kɹisɪŋ ɪz feɪs, deɪn tʊk ɡɑlədz kloʊk ən sɔɹd bɛlt, ən stʊd ʃɪftɪŋ ɪz fiɾ əz ðoʊ ənsɝɾən i wɑz duɪŋ ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ. wɛl, hi hæd bɪn ɡɪvən ɪz tʃæns, ən ɪt wɑz tu leɪt tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪz maɪnd, naʊ. baɪɑɝ pʊɾ ə ɡɔntələɾəd hæn ɑn ɡɑlədz ʃoʊldɝ ən lin kloʊs.

Worry creasing his face, Dain took Galad's cloak and sword belt, and stood shifting his feet as though uncertain he was doing the right thing. Well, he had been given his chance, and it was too late to change his mind, now. Byar put a gauntleted hand on Galad's shoulder and leaned close.

"hi laɪks tə stʃɹaɪk ət ði ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs, kæstɪŋ ɡlænsɪz oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət vɑldə. fɹəm ðə weɪ hi ɡlɛɹd, səm mæɾɝ stʊd bɪtwin ðɛm. ʌv kɔɹs, ðət skaʊl dɪfɝd lɪɾəl fɹəm ɪz nɔɹməl ɪkspɹɛʃən. "hi laɪks tə bliɾ ən əpoʊnən əntɪl ðə mæn kæn teɪk ə stɛp əɹ ɹeɪz ɪz sɔɹd bɪfɔɹ i muvz fəɹ ðə kɪl. hiz kwɪkɝ ðən ə vaɪpɝ, tu, bʌt hɪl stʃɹaɪk ət jəɹ lɛf moʊst ɔfən ən ɪkspɛkt ɪt fɹəm ju."

"He likes to strike at the arms and legs," he said in a low voice, casting glances over his shoulder at Valda. From the way he glared, some matter stood between them. Of course, that scowl differed little from his normal expression. "He likes to bleed an opponent until the man can't take a step or raise his sword before he moves for the kill. He's quicker than a viper, too, but he'll strike at your left most often and expect it from you."

ɡɑləd nɑɾəd. mɛni ɹaɪt-hændəd mɛn faʊn ɪɾ iziɝ tə stʃɹaɪk soʊ, bʌɾ ɪt simd ən ɑd wiknəs ɪn ə bleɪdmæstɝ. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn ən hɛnɹ hæslɪn hæd meɪɾ ɪm pɹæktəs ɔltɝneɪɾɪŋ wɪtʃ hænd wɑz ʌpɝmoʊst ɑn ðə hɪl soʊ hi wəd nɑt fɔl ɪndə ðæt. stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət vɑldə wɑntəd tə pɹəlɔŋ ə faɪt, tu. hi hɪmsɛlf hæd bɪn tɔt tə ɛn mæɾɝz əz kwɪkli ən klinli əz pɑsəbəl.

Galad nodded. Many right-handed men found it easier to strike so, but it seemed an odd weakness in a blademaster. Gareth Bryne and Henre Haslin had made him practice alternating which hand was uppermost on the hilt so he would not fall into that. Strange that Valda wanted to prolong a fight, too. He himself had been taught to end matters as quickly and cleanly as possible.

"maɪ θæŋks," hi sɛd, ən ðə hɑloʊ-tʃik mæn meɪɾ ə daʊɝ ɡɹɪmɑs. baɪɑɝ wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm laɪkəbəl, ən i hɪmsɛlf sim tə laɪk noʊ wʌn seɪv jʌŋ bɔɹnhəld. ʌv ðə θɹi, hɪz pɹɛzəns wɑz ðə bɪɡəst sɝpɹaɪz, bʌɾ i wɑz ðɛɹ, ən ðət kaʊntəɾ ɪn ɪz feɪvɝ.

"My thanks," he said, and the hollow-cheeked man made a dour grimace. Byar was far from likable, and he himself seemed to like no one save young Bornhald. Of the three, his presence was the biggest surprise, but he was there, and that counted in his favor.

stændɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ ɪn ɪz ɡoʊld-wɝkt waɪt koʊt wɪð ɪz fɪsts ɑn ɪz hɪps, vɑldə tɝn ɪn ə taɪt sɝkəl. "ɛvɹiwʌn muv bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔlz," hi kəmændəd laʊdli. hɔɹsʃuz ɹæŋ ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz əz ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ən ðə ɡɹumz oʊbeɪd. əsunɑwə ən ɪz kwɛstʃənɝz snætʃt ðɛɹ ænəməlz' ɹeɪnz, ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ wɛɹɪŋ ə feɪs ə koʊl fjʊɹi. "kip ðə mɪɾəl klɪɹ. jʌŋ dəmədʒɹɾ ən əl mit hɪɹ - "

Standing in the middle of the courtyard in his gold-worked white coat with his fists on his hips, Valda turned in a tight circle. "Everyone move back against the walls," he commanded loudly. Horseshoes rang on the paving stones as the Children and the grooms obeyed. Asunawa and his Questioners snatched their animals' reins, the High Inquisitor wearing a face of cold fury. "Keep the middle clear. Young Damodred and I will meet here - "

"fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," tʃɹɑm sɛd wɪð ə slaɪt baʊ, "bʌt sɪns jə ɑɹ ə pɑɹtɪsəpən ɪn ðə tʃɹaɪəl, jə kænɑt bi ɑɹbɪɾɝ. əsaɪd fɹəm ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ, hu baɪ lɔ meɪ nɑt teɪk pɑɹt, aɪ hoʊl ðə haɪəst ɹæŋk hɪɹ æftɝ ju, soʊ wɪð jəɹ pɝmɪʃən . . . ?" vɑldə ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ðən stɔkt oʊvɝ tə stæn bɪsaɪd kæʃɡɝ, ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst. ɑstənteɪʃəsli hi tæpt ɪz fʊt, ɪmpeɪʃən fəɹ mæɾɝz tə pɹəsid.

"Forgive me, my Lord Captain Commander," Trom said with a slight bow, "but since you are a participant in the Trial, you cannot be Arbiter. Aside from the High Inquisitor, who by law may not take part, I hold the highest rank here after you, so with your permission . . . ?" Valda glared at him, then stalked over to stand beside Kashgar, arms folded across his chest. Ostentatiously he tapped his foot, impatient for matters to proceed.

ɡɑləd saɪd. ɪf ðə deɪ wɛn əɡɛns hɪm, əz simd ɔl bʌt sɝɾən, hɪz fɹɛnd wəɾ əv ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl mæn ɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən əz ɪz ɛnəmi. laɪkli tʃɹɑm wʊɾə hæɾ ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, bʌt mɔɹ soʊ naʊ. "kip ən aɪ ɑn ðɛm," hi toʊl bɔɹnhəld, nɑɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə kwɛstʃənɝz klʌstɝɾ ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz nɪɹ ðə ɡeɪt. əsunɑwəz ʌndɝlɪŋz stɪl ɹɪŋd ɪm laɪk bɑɾiɡɑɹdz, ɛvɹi mæn wɪð ə hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt.

Galad sighed. If the day went against him, as seemed all but certain, his friend would have the most powerful man in the Children as his enemy. Likely Trom would have had in any event, but more so now. "Keep an eye on them," he told Bornhald, nodding toward the Questioners clustered on their horses near the gate. Asunawa's underlings still ringed him like bodyguards, every man with a hand on his sword hilt.

"waɪ? ivən əsunɑwə kæn ɪntɝfɪɹ naʊ. ðət wəd bi əɡɛns ðə lɔ."

"Why? Even Asunawa can't interfere now. That would be against the law."

ɪt wɑz vɛɹi hɑɹd nɑt tə saɪ əɡɛn. jʌŋ deɪn hæd bɪn ə tʃaɪl fɑɹ lɔŋɡɝ ðən hi, ən ɪz fɑðɝ hæd sɝvd ɪz ɪntaɪɝ laɪf, bʌt ðə mæn sim tə noʊ lɛs ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ðən i hɪmsɛlf hæd lɝnd. tə kwɛstʃənɝz, ðə lɔ wɑz wʌt ðeɪ sɛɾ ɪt wɑz. "dʒʌst wɑtʃ ðɛm."

It was very hard not to sigh again. Young Dain had been a Child far longer than he, and his father had served his entire life, but the man seemed to know less of the Children than he himself had learned. To Questioners, the law was what they said it was. "Just watch them."

tʃɹɑm stʊɾ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɪð ɪz bɛɹd sɔɹd ɹeɪzd oʊvɝhɛd, bleɪd pɛɹəlɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən ənlaɪk vɑldə, hi spoʊk ðə wɝdz ɪɡzækli əz ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪɾən. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, wəɹ ɡæðɝd tə wɪtnəs tʃɹaɪəl bɪniθ ðə laɪt, ə seɪkɹəd ɹaɪɾ ʌv ɛni tʃaɪld ə ðə laɪt. ðə laɪt ʃaɪnz ɑn tʃɹuθ, ən hɪɹ ðə laɪt ʃæl ɪlumɪnɪt dʒʌstəs. lɛt noʊ mæn spik seɪv i hu hæz liɡəl ɹaɪt, ən lɛɾ ɛni hu sik tə ɪntɝvin bi kʌt daʊn səmɛɹɪli. hɪɹ, dʒʌstəs wɪl bi faʊn ʌndɝ ðə laɪt baɪ ə mæn u plɛdʒɪz ɪz laɪf bɪniθ ðə laɪt, baɪ ðə fɔɹs ə hɪz ɑɹm ən ðə wɪl ə ðə laɪt. ðə kəmbæɾənts wɪl miɾ ənɑɹmd wɛɹ aɪ naʊ stænd," hi kəntɪnjud, loʊɝɪŋ ðə sɔɹd tə hɪz saɪd, "æn spik pɹaɪvətli, fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn ɪɹz əloʊn. meɪ ðə laɪt hɛlp əm faɪnd wɝdz tə ɛn ðɪs ʃɔɹɾ ə blʌdʃɛd, fəɹ ɪf ðeɪ də nɑt, wʌn ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən mʌs daɪ ðɪs deɪ, hɪz neɪm stʃɹɪkən fɹəm əɹ ɹoʊlz ən ənæθəmə dɪklɛɹɾ ɑn ɪz mɛmɹi. ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, ɪɾəl bi soʊ."

Trom stood in the center of the courtyard with his bared sword raised overhead, blade parallel to the ground, and unlike Valda, he spoke the words exactly as they were written. "Under the Light, we are gathered to witness Trial Beneath the Light, a sacred right of any Child of the Light. The Light shines on truth, and here the Light shall illuminate justice. Let no man speak save he who has legal right, and let any who seek to intervene be cut down summarily. Here, justice will be found under the Light by a man who pledges his life beneath the Light, by the force of his arm and the will of the Light. The combatants will meet unarmed where I now stand," he continued, lowering the sword to his side, "and speak privately, for their own ears alone. May the Light help them find words to end this short of bloodshed, for if they do not, one of the Children must die this day, his name stricken from our rolls and anathema declared on his memory. Under the Light, it will be so."

əz tʃɹɑm stʃɹoʊd tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, vɑldə muv təwɔɹd ðə sɛntɝ ɪn ðə wɔkɪŋ stæns kɔl kæt kɹɔsɪz ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, ən ɛɹəɡən sɔntɝ. hi nu ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wɝdz tə stɑp blʌd biɪŋ ʃɛd. tə hɪm, ðə faɪt hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn. ɡɑləd mɪɹli wɔkt aʊt tə mit hɪm. hi wɑz nɪɹli ə hɛd tɔlɝ ðən vɑldə, bʌt ði ʌðɝ mæn hɛl hɪmsɛlf əz ðoʊ hi wɝ ðə lɑɹdʒɝ, ən kɑnfəɾənt ə vɪktɝi.

As Trom strode to the side of the courtyard, Valda moved toward the center in the walking stance called Cat Crosses the Courtyard, an arrogant saunter. He knew there were no words to stop blood being shed. To him, the fight had already begun. Galad merely walked out to meet him. He was nearly a head taller than Valda, but the other man held himself as though he were the larger, and confident of victory.

hɪz smaɪl wɑz ɔl kəntɛmpt, ðɪs taɪm. "nʌθɪŋ tə seɪ, bɔɪ? smɔl wʌndɝ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðəɾ ə bleɪdmæstɝ ɪz gɑnə kʌt jəɹ hɛɾ ɔf ɪn əbaʊt wʌn mɪnət. aɪ wɑnt wʌn θɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn jəɹ maɪn bɪfɔɹ aɪ kɪl ju, ðoʊ. ðə wɛnk wɑz heɪl ðə læst aɪ sɔ hɝ, ən ɪf ʃiz dɛd naʊ, əl ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt." ðət smaɪl dipənd, boʊθ ɪn hjumɝ ən dɪsdeɪn. "ʃi wɑz ðə bɛst ɹaɪɾ aɪ ɛvɝ hæd, ən aɪ hoʊp tə ɹaɪɾ əɹ əɡɛn wʌn deɪ."

His smile was all contempt, this time. "Nothing to say, boy? Small wonder, considering that a blademaster is going to cut your head off in about one minute. I want one thing straight in your mind before I kill you, though. The wench was hale the last I saw her, and if she's dead now, I'll regret it." That smile deepened, both in humor and disdain. "She was the best ride I ever had, and I hope to ride her again one day."

ɹɛd-hɑt sɪɹɪŋ fjʊɹi faʊnteɪn ɪnsaɪd ɡɑləd, bʌt wɪð ən ɛfɝɾ i mænədʒ tə tɝn ɪz bæk ɑn vɑldə ən wɔk əweɪ, ɔlɹɛɾi fiɾɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪdʒ ɪndə ən ɪmædʒən fleɪm əz ɪz tu titʃɝz hæd tɔt hɪm. ə mæn u fɔɾ ɪn ə ɹeɪdʒ, daɪɾ ɪn ə ɹeɪdʒ. baɪ ðə taɪm i ɹitʃt jʌŋ bɔɹnhəld, hi hæɾ ətʃivd wʌt ɡɛɹɪθ ən hɛnɹ hæd kɔl ðə wʌnnəs. floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ɛmptinəs, hi dʒɹu hɪz sɔɹd fɹəm ðə skæbɝd bɔɹnhəl pɹɑfɝd, ən ðə slaɪtli kɝv bleɪd bɪkeɪm ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm.

Red-hot searing fury fountained inside Galad, but with an effort he managed to turn his back on Valda and walk away, already feeding his rage into an imagined flame as his two teachers had taught him. A man who fought in a rage, died in a rage. By the time he reached young Bornhald, he had achieved what Gareth and Henre had called the oneness. Floating in emptiness, he drew his sword from the scabbard Bornhald proffered, and the slightly curved blade became a part of him.

"wʌt dɪɾ i seɪ?" deɪn æskt. "fɔɹ ə moʊmən ðɛɹ, jəɹ feɪs wɑz mɝɾɝəs."

"What did he say?" Dain asked. "For a moment there, your face was murderous."

baɪɑɝ ɡɹɪp deɪnz ɑɹm. "doʊn dɪstʃɹæk hɪm," hi mʌɾɝd.

Byar gripped Dain's arm. "Don't distract him," he muttered.

ɡɑləd wɑz nɑt dɪstʃɹæktəd. ɛvɹi kɹik ə sæɾəl lɛðɝ wɑz klɪɹ ən dɪstɪŋkt, ɛvɹi ɹɪŋɪŋ stæmp ə huf ɑn peɪvɪŋ stoʊn. hi kəd hɪɹ flaɪz bʌzɪŋ tɛn fiɾ əweɪ əz ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ əɾ ɪz ɪɹ. hi ɔlmoʊs θɔɾ i kəd si ðə muvməns ə ðɛɹ wɪŋz. hi wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə flaɪz, wɪð ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, wɪð ðə tu mɛn. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl pɑɹɾ ə hɪm, ən i kəd nɑt bi dɪstʃɹæktəd baɪ hɪmsɛlf.

Galad was not distracted. Every creak of saddle leather was clear and distinct, every ringing stamp of hoof on paving stone. He could hear flies buzzing ten feet away as though they were at his ear. He almost thought he could see the movements of their wings. He was one with the flies, with the courtyard, with the two men. They were all part of him, and he could not be distracted by himself.

vɑldə weɪɾəd əntɪl i tɝn bɪfɔɹ dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz oʊn wɛpən ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, ə flæʃi muv, ðə sɔɹd blɝɪŋ əz ɪt spʌn ɪn ɪz lɛf hænd, lipɪŋ tə hɪz ɹaɪt hæn tə meɪk ənʌðɝ blɝd wil ɪn ði ɛɹ bɪfɔɹ sɛɾəlɪŋ, əpɹaɪɾ ən ɹɑk stɛɾi bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ɪn boʊθ hænz. hi stɑɹɾəd fɔɹwɝd, wʌns mɔɹ ɪn kæt kɹɔsɪz ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd.

Valda waited until he turned before drawing his own weapon on the other side of the courtyard, a flashy move, the sword blurring as it spun in his left hand, leaping to his right hand to make another blurred wheel in the air before settling, upright and rock steady before him, in both hands. He started forward, once more in Cat Crosses the Courtyard.

ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz oʊn sɔɹd, ɡɑləd muv tə mit hɪm, wɪθaʊt θɔɾ əsumɪŋ ə wɔkɪŋ stæns pɝhæps ɪnfluəns baɪ hɪz steɪɾ ə maɪnd. ɛmptinəs, ɪt wɑz kɔld, ən oʊnli ə tʃɹeɪn aɪ wəd noʊ ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt sɪmpli wɔkɪŋ. oʊnli ə tʃɹeɪn aɪ wəd si ðəɾ i wɑz ɪn pɝfək bæləns ɛvɹi hɑɹtbit. vɑldə hæd nɑt ɡeɪn ðət hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd baɪ feɪvɝɪtɪzəm. faɪv bleɪdmæstɝz hæd sæɾ ɪn dʒʌdʒmən ə hɪz skɪlz ən voʊɾəd junænəməsli tə ɡɹæn ɪm ðə taɪɾəl. ðə voʊɾ ɔlweɪz hæd tə bi junænəməs. ði oʊnli ʌðɝ weɪ wɑz tə kɪl ðə bɛɹɝ ʌv ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪɾ ɪn fɛɹ kɑmbæt, wʌn ɑn wʌn. vɑldə hæd bɪn jʌŋɡɝ ðən ðən ɡɑləd wɑz naʊ. ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. hi wɑz nɑt foʊkəst ɑn vɑldəz dɛθ. hi foʊkəst ɑn nʌθɪŋ. bʌɾ i ɪntɛndəd vɑldəz dɛθ ɪf i hæd tə ʃið ðə sɔɹd, wɪlɪŋli wɛlkəmɪŋ ðət hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪɾ ɪn ɪz flɛʃ, tə ətʃiv ɪt. hi æksɛptɪd ðəɾ ɪt maɪt kʌm tə ðæt.

Raising his own sword, Galad moved to meet him, without thought assuming a walking stance perhaps influenced by his state of mind. Emptiness, it was called, and only a trained eye would know that he was not simply walking. Only a trained eye would see that he was in perfect balance every heartbeat. Valda had not gained that heron-mark sword by favoritism. Five blademasters had sat in judgment of his skills and voted unanimously to grant him the title. The vote always had to be unanimous. The only other way was to kill the bearer of a heron-mark blade in fair combat, one on one. Valda had been younger then than Galad was now. It did not matter. He was not focused on Valda's death. He focused on nothing. But he intended Valda's death if he had to Sheathe the Sword, willingly welcoming that heron-mark blade in his flesh, to achieve it. He accepted that it might come to that.

vɑldə weɪstəd noʊ taɪm wɪð mənuvɝɪŋ. ði ɪnstən i wɑz wɪðɪn ɹeɪnʒ, plʌkɪŋ ðə loʊ-hæŋɪŋ æpəl flæʃt təwɔɹd ɡɑlədz nɛk laɪk laɪtnɪŋ, əz ðoʊ ðə mæn tʃɹuli dɪɾ ɪntɛn tə hæv ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ðə fɝs mɪnət. ðəɹ wɝ sɛvɹəl pɑsəbəl ɹɪspɑnsɪz, ɔl meɪɾ ɪnstɪŋk baɪ hɑɹd tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, bʌt baɪɑɝz wɔɹnɪŋz floʊɾəd ɪn ðə dɪm ɹisɛsəz ə hɪz maɪnd, ən ɔlsoʊ ðə fæk ðət vɑldə hæd wɔɹn ɪm ə ðɪs vɛɹi θɪŋ. wɔɹn ɪm twaɪs. wɪθaʊt kɑnʃəs θɔt, hi tʃoʊz ənʌðɝ weɪ, stɛpɪŋ saɪdweɪz ən fɔɹwɝd dʒʌst əz plʌkɪŋ ðə loʊ-hæŋɪŋ æpəl bɪkeɪm ðə lɛpɝdz kɝɛs. vɑldəz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn sɝpɹaɪz əz ɪz stʃɹoʊk mɪst ɡɑlədz lɛf θaɪ baɪ ɪntʃəz, waɪɾənd mɔɹ əz pɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪlk leɪɾ ə ɡæʃ daʊn ɪz ɹaɪt fɔɹɑɹm, bʌɾ i ɪmiɾiətli lɔntʃt ɪndə ðə dʌv teɪks flaɪt, soʊ fæs ðət ɡɑləd hæd tə dæns bæk bɪfɔɹ ɪz bleɪd kəd baɪt dipli, bɛɹli fɛndɪŋ ɔf ði ətæk wɪð kɪŋfɪʃɝ sɝkəlz ðə pɑnd.

Valda wasted no time with maneuvering. The instant he was within range, Plucking the Low-hanging Apple flashed toward Galad's neck like lightning, as though the man truly did intend to have his head in the first minute. There were several possible responses, all made instinct by hard training, but Byar's warnings floated in the dim recesses of his mind, and also the fact that Valda had warned him of this very thing. Warned him twice. Without conscious thought, he chose another way, stepping sideways and forward just as Plucking the Low-hanging Apple became the Leopard's Caress. Valda's eyes widened in surprise as his stroke missed Galad's left thigh by inches, widened more as Parting the Silk laid a gash down his right forearm, but he immediately launched into the Dove Takes Flight, so fast that Galad had to dance back before his blade could bite deeply, barely fending off the attack with Kingfisher Circles the Pond.

bæk ən fɔɹθ ðeɪ dæns ðə fɔɹmz, ɡlaɪɾɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ðən ðəɾ əkɹɔs ðə stoʊn peɪvɪŋ. lɪzɝɾ ɪn ðə θɔɹnbʊʃ mɛt laɪtnɪŋ ə θɹi pɹɔŋz. lif ɑn ðə bɹiz kaʊntɝɾ il əmʌŋ ðə lɪli pædz, ən tu hɛɹz lipɪŋ mɛt ðə hʌmɪŋbɝd kɪsəz ðə hʌniɹoʊz. bæk ən fɔɹθ əz smuðli əz ə dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən ə ðə fɔɹmz. ɡɑləd tʃɹaɪɾ ətæk æftɝ ətæk, bʌt vɑldə wɑz əz fæst əz ə vaɪpɝ. ðə wʊd ɡɹaʊs dænsəz kɑst ɪm ə ʃæloʊ ɡæʃ ɑn ɪz lɛft ʃoʊldɝ, ən ðə ɹɛd hɔk teɪks ə dʌv ənʌðɝ ɑn ðə lɛft ɑɹm, slaɪtli dipɝ. ɹɪvɝ ə laɪt maɪɾ əv teɪkən ði ɑɹm kəmplitli hæɾ i nɑt mɛt ðə dʒɹɔ-kʌt wɪð ə dɛspɝətli kwɪk ɹeɪn ɪn haɪ wɪnd. bæk ən fɔɹθ, bleɪdz flæʃɪŋ kəntɪnjuəsli, fɪlɪŋ ði ɛɹ wɪð ðə klæʃ ə stil ɑn stil.

Back and forth they danced the forms, gliding this way then that across the stone paving. Lizard in the Thornbush met Lightning of Three Prongs. Leaf on the Breeze countered Eel Among the Lily Pads, and Two Hares Leaping met the Hummingbird Kisses the Honeyrose. Back and forth as smoothly as a demonstration of the forms. Galad tried attack after attack, but Valda was as fast as a viper. The Wood Grouse Dances cost him a shallow gash on his left shoulder, and the Red Hawk Takes a Dove another on the left arm, slightly deeper. River of Light might have taken the arm completely had he not met the draw-cut with a desperately quick Rain in High Wind. Back and forth, blades flashing continuously, filling the air with the clash of steel on steel.

haʊ lɔŋ ðeɪ fɔt, hi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm, oʊnli ðə moʊmənt. ɪt sim ðəɾ i ən vɑldə muv laɪk mɛn ʌndɝ wɔɾɝ, ðɛɹ moʊʃənz sloʊd baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡ ʌv ðə si. swɛɾ əpɪɹɾ ɑn vɑldəz feɪs, bʌɾ i smaɪld wɪð sɛlf-əʃʊɹəns, simɪŋli əntʃɹʌbəl baɪ ðə slæʃ ɑn ɪz fɔɹɑɹm, stɪl ði oʊnli ɪnʒɝi hi hæd teɪkən. ɡɑləd kəd fil ðə swɛt ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn ɪz oʊn feɪs, tu, stɪŋɪŋ ɪz aɪz. ən ðə blʌd tʃɹɪklɪŋ daʊn ɪz ɑɹm. ðoʊz wunz wəd sloʊ hɪm ɪvɛntʃəwəli, pɝhæps ɔlɹɛɾi hæd, bʌɾ i hæd teɪkən tu ɑn ɪz lɛf θaɪ, ən boʊθ wɝ mɔɹ sɪɹiəs. hɪz fʊt wɑz wɛɾ ɪn ɪz but fɹəm ðoʊz, ən i kəd nɑɾ əvɔɪɾ ə slaɪt lɪmp ðət wəd ɡɹoʊ wɝs wɪð taɪm. ɪf vɑldə wɑz tə daɪ, ɪt mʌs bi sun.

How long they fought, he could not have said. There was no time, only the moment. It seemed that he and Valda moved like men under water, their motions slowed by the drag of the sea. Sweat appeared on Valda's face, but he smiled with self-assurance, seemingly untroubled by the slash on his forearm, still the only injury he had taken. Galad could feel the sweat rolling down his own face, too, stinging his eyes. And the blood trickling down his arm. Those wounds would slow him eventually, perhaps already had, but he had taken two on his left thigh, and both were more serious. His foot was wet in his boot from those, and he could not avoid a slight limp that would grow worse with time. If Valda was to die, it must be soon.

dɪlɪbɝətli, hi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən ənʌðɝ, θɹu hɪz maʊð, ənʌðɝ. lɛt vɑldə θɪŋk ɪm bɪkʌmɪŋ wɪndɪd. hɪz bleɪd lænst aʊɾ ɪn θɹɛɾɪŋ ðə niɾəl, eɪmd ət vɑldəz lɛft ʃoʊldɝ ən nɑt kwaɪɾ əz fæst əz ɪt kəɾ əv bɪn. ði ʌðɝ mæn kaʊntɝɾ izəli wɪð ðə swɑloʊ teɪks flaɪt, slaɪɾɪŋ ɪmiɾiətli ɪndə ðə laɪən spɹɪŋz. ðət tʊk ə θɝd baɪɾ ɪn ɪz θaɪ; hi dɛɹd nɑt bi fæstɝ ɪn dɪfɛns ðən ɪn ətæk.

Deliberately, he drew a deep breath, then another, through his mouth, another. Let Valda think him becoming winded. His blade lanced out in Threading the Needle, aimed at Valda's left shoulder and not quite as fast as it could have been. The other man countered easily with the Swallow Takes Flight, sliding immediately into the Lion Springs. That took a third bite in his thigh; he dared not be faster in defense than in attack.

əɡɛn i lɔntʃt θɹɛɾɪŋ ðə niɾəl ət vɑldəz ʃoʊldɝ, ən əɡɛn, əɡɛn, ɔl ðə waɪl ɡʌlpɪŋ ɛɹ θɹu hɪz maʊθ. oʊnli lʌk kɛpt ɪm fɹəm teɪkɪŋ mɔɹ wunz ɪn ðoʊz ɪkstʃeɪnʒəz. əɹ pɝhæps ðə laɪt ɹɪli dɪd ʃaɪn ɑn ðɪs faɪt.

Again he launched Threading the Needle at Valda's shoulder, and again, again, all the while gulping air through his mouth. Only luck kept him from taking more wounds in those exchanges. Or perhaps the Light really did shine on this fight.

vɑldəz smaɪl waɪɾənd; ðə mæn bɪlivd ɪm ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ, ɪɡzɔstəɾ ən fɪkseɪɾɪd. əz ɡɑləd bɪɡæn θɹɛɾɪŋ ðə niɾəl, tu sloʊli, fəɹ ðə fɪfθ taɪm, ði ʌðɝ mænz sɔɹd stɑɹɾəd ðə swɑloʊ teɪks flaɪɾ ɪn ən ɔlmoʊs pɝfʌŋktɝi mænɝ. sʌmənɪŋ ɔl ðə kwɪknəs ðət ɹɪmeɪn tə hɪm, ɡɑləɾ ɔltɝɾ ɪz stʃɹoʊk, ən ɹipɪŋ ðə bɑɹli slaɪst əkɹɔs vɑldə dʒʌs bɪniθ ɪz ɹɪb keɪdʒ.

Valda's smile widened; the man believed him on the edge of his strength, exhausted and fixated. As Galad began Threading the Needle, too slowly, for the fifth time, the other man's sword started the Swallow Takes Flight in an almost perfunctory manner. Summoning all the quickness that remained to him, Galad altered his stroke, and Reaping the Barley sliced across Valda just beneath his rib cage.

fəɹ ə moʊmən ɪt sim ðət ðə mæn wɑz ʌnəwɛɹ i hæd bɪn hɪt. hi tʊk ə stɛp, bɪɡæn wʌt maɪɾ əv bɪn stoʊnz fɔlɪŋ fɹəm ðə klɪf. ðən ɪz aɪz waɪɾənd, ən i stæɡɝd, ðə sɔɹd fɔlɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ɡɹɪp tə klæɾɝ ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz əz i sæŋk tə hɪz niz. hɪz hænz wɛn tə ðə hjudʒ ɡæʃ əkɹɔs ɪz bɑɾi əz ðoʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊld ɪz ɪnsaɪdz wɪðɪn hɪm, ən ɪz maʊθ oʊpənd, ɡlæsi aɪz fɪkst ɑn ɡɑlədz feɪs. wʌtɛvɝ i ɪntɛndəd tə seɪ, ɪt wɑz blʌd ðət pɔɹɾ aʊɾ oʊvɝ ɪz tʃɪn. hi tɑpəld ɑntu hɪz feɪs ən leɪ stɪl.

For a moment it seemed that the man was unaware he had been hit. He took a step, began what might have been Stones Falling from the Cliff. Then his eyes widened, and he staggered, the sword falling from his grip to clatter on the paving stones as he sank to his knees. His hands went to the huge gash across his body as though trying to hold his insides within him, and his mouth opened, glassy eyes fixed on Galad's face. Whatever he intended to say, it was blood that poured out over his chin. He toppled onto his face and lay still.

ɔɾəmætɪkli, ɡɑləd ɡeɪv ɪz bleɪɾ ə ɹæpəd twɪs tə ʃeɪk ɔf ðə blʌd steɪnɪŋ ɪts faɪnəl ɪntʃ, ðən bɛn sloʊli tə waɪp ðə læs dʒɹɑps ɑntu vɑldəz waɪt koʊt. ðə peɪn i hæɾ ɪɡnɔɹd naʊ flɛɹd. hɪz lɛft ʃoʊldɝ ən ɑɹm bɝnd; hɪz θaɪ sim tə bi ɑn faɪɝ. stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ tʊk ɛfɝt. pɝhæps i wɑz nɪɹɝ ɪɡzɔstʃən ðən i hæd θɔt. haʊ lɔŋ hæd ðeɪ fɔt? hi hæd θɔɾ i wəd fil sæɾəsfækʃən ðəɾ ɪz mʌðɝ hæd bɪn əvɛnʒd, bʌɾ ɔl i fɛlt wɑz ɛmptinəs. vɑldəz dɛθ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf. nʌθɪŋ ɪksɛp mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkən əlaɪv əɡɛn kəd bi ɪnʌf.

Automatically, Galad gave his blade a rapid twist to shake off the blood staining its final inch, then bent slowly to wipe the last drops onto Valda's white coat. The pain he had ignored now flared. His left shoulder and arm burned; his thigh seemed to be on fire. Straightening took effort. Perhaps he was nearer exhaustion than he had thought. How long had they fought? He had thought he would feel satisfaction that his mother had been avenged, but all he felt was emptiness. Valda's death was not enough. Nothing except Morgase Trakand alive again could be enough.

sʌɾənli hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ʌv ə ɹɪðmɪk klæpɪŋ ən lʊkt ʌp tə si ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, itʃ mæn slæpɪŋ ɪz oʊn ɑɹmɝd ʃoʊldɝ ɪn əpɹuvəl. ɛvɹi mæn. ɪksɛpt əsunɑwə ən ðə kwɛstʃənɝz. ðeɪ wɝ noʊwɛɹ tə bi sin.

Suddenly he became aware of a rhythmic clapping and looked up to see the Children, each man slapping his own armored shoulder in approval. Every man. Except Asunawa and the Questioners. They were nowhere to be seen.

baɪɑɝ hɝiɾ ʌp kæɹiɪŋ ə smɔl lɛðɝ sæk ən kɛɹfəli pɑɹɾəd ðə slæʃɪz ɪn ɡɑlədz koʊtsliv. "ðoʊz wɪl nid soʊɪŋ," hi mʌɾɝd, "bʌt ðeɪ kən weɪt." nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd ɡɑləd, hi tʊk ɹoʊl bændədʒəz fɹəm ðə sæk ən bɪɡæn waɪndɪŋ əm ɝaʊn ðə ɡæʃəz ɪn ɪz θaɪ. "ðiz nid soʊɪŋ, tu, bʌt ðɪs wɪl kip jə fɹəm bliɾɪŋ tə dɛθ bɪfɔɹ jə kən ɡɛɾ ɪt." ʌðɝz bɪɡæn ɡæðɝɪŋ ɝaʊnd, ɔfɝɪŋ kənɡɹætʃəleɪʃənz, mɛn əfʊɾ ɪn fɹʌnt, ðoʊz stɪl maʊntəd bɪhaɪnd. nʌn ɡeɪv ðə kɔɹps ə ɡlæns ɪksɛp fəɹ kæʃɡɝ, hu klin vɑldəz sɔɹɾ ɑn ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi blʌdsteɪn koʊt bɪfɔɹ ʃiðɪŋ ɪt.

Byar hurried up carrying a small leather sack and carefully parted the slashes in Galad's coatsleeve. "Those will need sewing," he muttered, "but they can wait." Kneeling beside Galad, he took rolled bandages from the sack and began winding them around the gashes in his thigh. "These need sewing, too, but this will keep you from bleeding to death before you can get it." Others began gathering around, offering congratulations, men afoot in front, those still mounted behind. None gave the corpse a glance except for Kashgar, who cleaned Valda's sword on that already bloodstained coat before sheathing it.

"wɛɹ dɪɾ əsunɑwə ɡoʊ?" ɡɑləɾ æskt.

"Where did Asunawa go?" Galad asked.

"hi lɛft əz sun əz jə kʌt vɑldə ðə læs taɪm," deɪn ɹɪplaɪɾ ənizəli. "hil bi hɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə kæmp tə bɹɪŋ bæk kwɛstʃənɝz."

"He left as soon as you cut Valda the last time," Dain replied uneasily. "He'll be heading for the camp to bring back Questioners."

"hi ɹoʊd ði ʌðɝ weɪ, təwɔɹd ðə bɔɹɾɝ," sʌmwʌn pʊɾ ɪn. næsəd leɪ dʒʌst oʊvɝ ðə bɔɹɾɝ.

"He rode the other way, toward the border," someone put in. Nassad lay just over the border.

"ðə lɔɹdz kæptən," ɡɑləd sɛd, ən tʃɹɑm nɑɾəd.

"The Lords Captain," Galad said, and Trom nodded.

"noʊ tʃaɪld wəd lɛt ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɝɛs jə fəɹ wʌt hæpən hɪɹ, dəmədʒɹd. ənlɛs ɪz kæptən ɔɹɾɝd ɪt. səm ə ðɛm wəɾ ɔɹɾɝ ɪt, aɪ θɪŋk." æŋɡɹi mʌɾɝɪŋ bɪɡæn, mɛn dɪnaɪɪŋ ðeɪ wəd stæn fəɹ sətʃ ə θɪŋ, bʌt tʃɹɑm kwaɪəɾəd ðɛm, sʌmwʌt, wɪð ɹeɪz hænz. "ju noʊ ɪts tʃɹu," hi sɛd laʊdli. "ɛniθɪŋ ɛls wəd bi mjuɾəni." ðət bɹɔt dɛd saɪləns. ðəɹ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ə mjuɾəni ɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl ðət nʌθɪŋ bɪfɔɹ hæd kʌm əz kloʊs əz ðɛɹ oʊn ɝliɝ dɪspleɪ. "aɪl ɹaɪɾ aʊt jəɹ ɹilis fɹəm ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, ɡɑləd. sʌmwʌn meɪ stɪl ɔɹɾɝ jəɹ ɝɛst, bʌt ðəl əv tə faɪn ju, ən jəl əv ə ɡʊd stɑɹt. ɪɾəl teɪk hæf ðə deɪ fəɹ əsunɑwə tə kætʃ ði ʌðɝ lɔɹdz kæptən, ən huɛvɝ fɔlz ɪn wɪð ɪm kæn bi bæk bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl."

"No Child would let the Questioners arrest you for what happened here, Damodred. Unless his captain ordered it. Some of them would order it, I think." Angry muttering began, men denying they would stand for such a thing, but Trom quieted them, somewhat, with raised hands. "You know it's true," he said loudly. "Anything else would be mutiny." That brought dead silence. There had never been a mutiny in the Children. It was possible that nothing before had come as close as their own earlier display. "I'll write out your release from the Children, Galad. Someone may still order your arrest, but they'll have to find you, and you'll have a good start. It will take half the day for Asunawa to catch the other Lords Captain, and whoever falls in with him can't be back before nightfall."

ɡɑləd ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ æŋɡɹəli. tʃɹɑm wɑz ɹaɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl ɹɔŋ. tu mʌtʃ wɑz ɹɔŋ. "wɪl jə ɹaɪt ɹɪlisɪz fəɹ ðiz ʌðɝ mɛn? jə noʊ əsunɑwə wɪl faɪn ə weɪ tə əkjuz ðɛm, tu. wɪl jə ɹaɪt ɹɪlisɪz fəɹ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən u doʊnt wɑnə hɛlp ðə sintʃæn teɪk əɹ lænz ɪn ðə neɪm ʌv ə mæn dɛd mɔɹ ðən ə θaʊzən jɪɹz?" sɛvɹəl tæɹɑbənɝz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz ən nɑɾəd, ən soʊ dɪɾ ʌðɝ mɛn, nɑɾ ɔl ə ðɛm ɑmɑdɪʃən. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə mɛn u dɪfɛndəd ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ə ðə laɪt? wɪl ɛni ɹilis ɡɛt ðɛɹ tʃeɪnz stʃɹʌk ɔf əɹ meɪk ðə sintʃæn stɑp wɝkɪŋ əm laɪk ænəməlz?" mɔɹ æŋɡɹi ɡɹaʊlz; ðoʊz pɹɪznɝz wɝ ə sɔɹ pɔɪn tə ɔl ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən.

Galad shook his head angrily. Trom was right, but it was all wrong. Too much was wrong. "Will you write releases for these other men? You know Asunawa will find a way to accuse them, too. Will you write releases for the Children who don't want to help the Seanchan take our lands in the name of a man dead more than a thousand years?" Several Taraboners exchanged glances and nodded, and so did other men, not all of them Amadician. "What about the men who defended the Fortress of the Light? Will any release get their chains struck off or make the Seanchan stop working them like animals?" More angry growls; those prisoners were a sore point to all of the Children.

ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst, tʃɹɑm stʌɾid ɪm əz ðoʊ siɪŋ ɪm fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. "wʌt wəd jə du, ðɛn?"

Arms folded across his chest, Trom studied him as though seeing him for the first time. "What would you do, then?"

"hæv ðə tʃɪlʒɹən faɪn sʌmwʌn, ɛniwʌn, hu ɪz faɪɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn ən ælaɪ wɪð ðɛm. meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə læs bæɾəl ɪnstɛɾ ə hɛlpɪŋ ðə sintʃæn hʌn il ən stil əɹ neɪʃənz."

"Have the Children find someone, anyone, who is fighting the Seanchan and ally with them. Make sure that the Children of the Light ride in the Last Battle instead of helping the Seanchan hunt Aiel and steal our nations."

"ɛniwʌn?" ə kɛɹhinɪn neɪm dɔɪɹɛlɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə haɪ-pɪtʃt vɔɪs. noʊ wʌn ɛvɝ meɪd fʌn ə dɔɪɹɛlɪnz vɔɪs. ðoʊ ʃɔɹt, hi wɑz nɪɹli əz waɪɾ əz i wɑz tɔl, ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ən aʊns ə fæɾ ɑn hɪm, ən i kəd pʊt wɔlnʌts bɪtwin ɔl ə hɪz fɪŋɡɝz ən kɹæk əm baɪ klɛntʃɪŋ ɪz fɪsts. "ðæt kəd min ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Anyone?" a Cairhienin named Doirellin said in a high-pitched voice. No one ever made fun of Doirellin's voice. Though short, he was nearly as wide as he was tall, there was barely an ounce of fat on him, and he could put walnuts between all of his fingers and crack them by clenching his fists. "That could mean Aes Sedai."

"ɪf jə ɪntɛn tə bi ət tɑɹmən ɡdən, ðən jəl əv tə faɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɡɑləd sɛd kwaɪətli. jʌŋ bɔɹnhəld ɡɹɪməst ɪn stʃɹɔŋ dɪsteɪst, ən i wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn. baɪɑɝ hæf-stʃɹeɪɾənd bɪfɔɹ bɛndɪŋ bæk tə hɪz tæsk. bʌt noʊ wʌn vɔɪs dɪsɛnt. dɔɪɹɛlɪn nɑɾəd sloʊli, əz ɪf i hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ kənsɪɾɝd ðə mæɾɝ.

"If you intend to be at Tarmon Gai'don, then you will have to fight alongside Aes Sedai," Galad said quietly. Young Bornhald grimaced in strong distaste, and he was not the only one. Byar half-straightened before bending back to his task. But no one voiced dissent. Doirellin nodded slowly, as if he had never before considered the matter.

"aɪ doʊn hoʊld wɪð ðə wɪtʃəz ɛni mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ mæn," baɪɑɝ sɛd faɪnəli, wɪθaʊt ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hɛd fɹəm ɪz wɝk. blʌd wɑz sipɪŋ θɹu ðə bændədʒəz ivən əz i ɹæpt. "bʌt ðə pɹisɛps seɪ, tə faɪt ðə ɹeɪvən, jə meɪ meɪk əlaɪəns wɪð ðə sɝpən əntɪl ðə bæɾəl ɪz dʌn." ə ɹɪpəl ə nɑdz ɹæn θɹu ðə mɛn. ðə ɹeɪvən mɛn ðə ʃædoʊ, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn nu ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ ðə sintʃæn ɪmpɪɹiəl sɪdʒəl.

"I don't hold with the witches any more than any other man," Byar said finally, without raising his head from his work. Blood was seeping through the bandages even as he wrapped. "But the Precepts say, to fight the raven, you may make alliance with the serpent until the battle is done." A ripple of nods ran through the men. The raven meant the Shadow, but everyone knew it was also the Seanchan Imperial sigil.

"aɪl faɪt bɪsaɪd ðə wɪtʃəz," ə læŋki tæɹɑbənɝ sɛd, "ɔɹ ivən ðiz æʃəmən wi kip hɪɹɪŋ əbaʊt, ɪf ðeɪ faɪt ðə sintʃæn. əɹ ət ðə læs bæɾəl. ən əl faɪɾ ɛni mæn u sɛz ɪm ɹɔŋ." hi ɡlɛɹɾ əz ðoʊ ɹɛɾi tə bɪɡɪn ðən ən ðɛɹ.

"I'll fight beside the witches," a lanky Taraboner said, "or even these Asha'man we keep hearing about, if they fight the Seanchan. Or at the Last Battle. And I'll fight any man who says I'm wrong." He glared as though ready to begin then and there.

"ɪt simz mæɾɝz wɪl pleɪ aʊɾ əz jə wɪʃ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ," tʃɹɑm sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ə mʌtʃ dipɝ baʊ ðən i hæd fəɹ vɑldə. "tə ə dɪɡɹi, ət list. hu kən seɪ wʌt ðə nɛkst aʊɝ wɪl bɹɪŋ, mʌtʃ lɛs təmɑɹoʊ?"

"It seems matters will play out as you wish, my Lord Captain Commander," Trom said, making a much deeper bow than he had for Valda. "To a degree, at least. Who can say what the next hour will bring, much less tomorrow?"

ɡɑləd sɝpɹaɪz hɪmsɛlf baɪ læfɪŋ. sɪns jɛstɝdeɪ, hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ i wəd nɛvɝ læf əɡɛn. "ðæts ə pʊɹ dʒoʊk, tʃɹɑm."

Galad surprised himself by laughing. Since yesterday, he had been sure he would never laugh again. "That's a poor joke, Trom."

"ɪɾ ɪz haʊ ðə lɔ ɪz ɹɪɾən. ən vɑldə dɪd meɪk ɪz pɹɑkləmeɪʃən. bɪsaɪdz, jə hæd ðə kɝədʒ tə seɪ wʌt mɛni hæv θɔt waɪl hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ tʌŋz, maɪsɛlf əmʌŋ ðɛm. jʊɹz ɪz ə bɛɾɝ plæn fəɹ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ðən ɛni aɪv hɝd sɪns peɪdʒɹən naɪl daɪd."

"It is how the law is written. And Valda did make his proclamation. Besides, you had the courage to say what many have thought while holding their tongues, myself among them. Yours is a better plan for the Children than any I've heard since Pedron Niall died."

"ɪts stɪl ə pʊɹ dʒoʊk." wʌtɛvɝ ðə lɔ sɛd, ðət pɑɹt hæd bɪn ɪɡnɔɹd sɪns ði ɛn ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz.

"It's still a poor joke." Whatever the law said, that part had been ignored since the end of the War of the Hundred Years.

"wil si wʌt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən əv tə seɪ ɑn ðə mæɾɝ," tʃɹɑm ɹɪplaɪd, ɡɹɪnɪŋ waɪdli, "wɛn jə æsk əm tə fɑloʊ əs tə tɑɹmən ɡdən tə faɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə wɪtʃəz."

"We'll see what the Children have to say on the matter," Trom replied, grinning widely, "when you ask them to follow us to Tarmon Gai'don to fight alongside the witches."

mɛn bɪɡæn slæpɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz əɡɛn, hɑɹɾɝ ðən ðeɪ hæd fəɹ ɪz vɪktɝi. ət fɝst ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə fju, ðən mɔɹ dʒɔɪn ɪn, əntɪl ɛvɹi mæn ɪnkluɾɪŋ tʃɹɑm wɑz sɪɡnəlɪŋ əpɹuvəl. ɛvɹi mæn bʌt kæʃɡɝ, ðət wɑz. meɪkɪŋ ə dip baʊ, ðə sɑldəiən hɛld aʊt ðə skæbɑɹɾɪd hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd wɪð boʊθ hænz.

Men began slapping their shoulders again, harder than they had for his victory. At first it was only a few, then more joined in, until every man including Trom was signaling approval. Every man but Kashgar, that was. Making a deep bow, the Saldaean held out the scabbarded heron-mark blade with both hands.

"ðɪs ɪz jʊɹz, naʊ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ."

"This is yours, now, my Lord Captain Commander."

ɡɑləd saɪd. hi hoʊp ðɪs nɑnsɛns wəd feɪɾ əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə kæmp. ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ðəɹ wɑz fulɪʃ ɪnʌf wɪθaʊɾ æɾɪŋ ɪn ə kleɪm ə ðət sɔɹt. moʊs laɪkli ðeɪ wəd bi pʊl daʊn ən θɹoʊn ɪn tʃeɪnz ɪf nɑt biɾən tə dɛθ ivən wɪθaʊɾ ɪt. bʌɾ i hæd tə ɡoʊ. ɪt wɑz ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə du.

Galad sighed. He hoped this nonsense would fade away before they reached the camp. Returning there was foolish enough without adding in a claim of that sort. Most likely they would be pulled down and thrown in chains if not beaten to death even without it. But he had to go. It was the right thing to do.

deɪlaɪt bɪɡæn tə ɡɹoʊ ɑn ðɪs kul spɹɪŋ mɔɹnɪŋ, ðoʊ ðə sʌn hæd jɛt tə ʃoʊ ivən ə slɪvɝ əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən, ən ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi ɹeɪzd ɪz ɡoʊld-bændɪd lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs tə stʌɾi ðə vɪlədʒ bɪloʊ ðə hɪl wɛɹ i sæɾ ɪz ɹoʊn ɡɛldɪŋ, dip ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə tæɹɑbən. hi dɪd heɪt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪnʌf laɪt tə si. kɛɹfəl ʌv ə ɡlɪn ɔf ðə lɛnz, hi hɛl ði ɛn ə ðə lɔŋ tub ɑn ɪz θʌm ən ʃeɪɾɪd ɪt wɪð ə kʌp hænd. ət ðɪs aʊɝ, sɛntʃɹiz wɝ ət ðɛɹ list wɑtʃfəl, ɹɪliv ðət ðə dɑɹknəs wɛɹ ən ɛnəmi maɪt snik kloʊs wɑz dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ, jɛt sɪns kɹɔsɪŋ fɹəm ɑlməθ pleɪn i hæd hɝd teɪlz ʌv il ɹeɪdz ɪnsaɪd tæɹɑbən. wɝ i ə sɛntʃɹi wɪð il pɝhæps əbaʊt, hi wəd ɡɹoʊ ɛkstʃɹə aɪz. pəkjuljɝ ðət ðə kʌntʃɹi wɑz nɑt mɪlɪŋ laɪk ə kɪkt ænθip oʊvɝ ðoʊz il. pəkjuljɝ, ən pɝhæps ɑmənəs. ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv ɑɹmd mɛn tə bi faʊnd, sintʃæn ən tæɹɑbənɝz swɔɹn tə ðɛm, ən hɔɹdz ə sintʃæn bɪldɪŋ fɑɹmz ən ivən vɪlədʒəz, bʌt ɹitʃɪŋ ðɪs fɑɹ hæd bɪn ɔlmoʊs tu izi. tədeɪ, ði izinəs ɛndəd.

Daylight began to grow on this cool spring morning, though the sun had yet to show even a sliver above the horizon, and Rodel Ituralde raised his gold-banded looking glass to study the village below the hill where he sat his roan gelding, deep in the heart of Tarabon. He did hate waiting for enough light to see. Careful of a glint off the lens, he held the end of the long tube on his thumb and shaded it with a cupped hand. At this hour, sentries were at their least watchful, relieved that the darkness where an enemy might sneak close was departing, yet since crossing from Almoth Plain he had heard tales of Aiel raids inside Tarabon. Were he a sentry with Aiel perhaps about, he would grow extra eyes. Peculiar that the country was not milling like a kicked antheap over those Aiel. Peculiar, and perhaps ominous. There were plenty of armed men to be found, Seanchan and Taraboners sworn to them, and hordes of Seanchan building farms and even villages, but reaching this far had been almost too easy. Today, the easiness ended.

bɪhaɪn ɪm əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, hɔɹsəz stæmpt ɪmpeɪʃənli. ðə hʌnʒɹəd dəmɑni wɪð ɪm wɝ kwaɪət, ɪksɛp fəɹ ən əkeɪʒənəl kɹik ə sæɾəl lɛðɝ əz ə mæn ʃɪftəɾ ɪz sit, bʌɾ i kəd fil ðɛɹ tɛnʃən. hi wɪʃt i hæd twaɪs əz mɛni. faɪv taɪmz. ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, ɪt hæd simd ə dʒɛstʃɝ ʌv ɡʊd feɪθ ðəɾ i hɪmsɛlf wəd ɹaɪd wɪð ə fɔɹs meɪnli kəmpoʊzd ə tæɹɑbənɝz. hi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɝɾən ðət hæd bɪn ðə ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən. ɪt wɑz tu leɪt fəɹ ɹɪkɹɪmɪneɪʃənz, ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt.

Behind him among the trees, horses stamped impatiently. The hundred Domani with him were quiet, except for an occasional creak of saddle leather as a man shifted his seat, but he could feel their tension. He wished he had twice as many. Five times. In the beginning, it had seemed a gesture of good faith that he himself would ride with a force mainly composed of Taraboners. He was no longer certain that had been the right decision. It was too late for recriminations, in any event.

hæfweɪ bɪtwin ɛlmɔɹə ən ði ɑmɑdɪʃən bɔɹɾɝ, sɹænə sæɾ ɪn ə flæt ɡɹæsi væli əmʌŋ fɔɹəstəd hɪlz, wɪð ət list ə maɪl tə ðə tʃɹiz ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən seɪv hɪz, ən ə smɔl, ɹid-fɹɪn leɪk fɛd baɪ tu waɪd stʃɹimz leɪ bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə vɪlədʒ. nɑɾ ə pleɪs ðət kəd bi sɝpɹaɪz baɪ deɪlaɪt. ɪt hæd bɪn saɪzəbəl bɪfɔɹ ðə sintʃæn keɪm, ə stɑpɪŋ pɔɪn fəɹ ðə mɝtʃən tʃɹeɪnz hɛɾɪŋ ist, wɪð oʊvɝ ə dʌzən ɪnz ən nɪɹli əz mɛni stʃɹits. vɪlədʒ foʊk wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɛɾɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ deɪz tæsks, wɪmən bælənsɪŋ bæskəts ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz əz ðeɪ ɡlaɪɾɪd daʊn ðə vɪlədʒ stʃɹits ən ʌðɝz stɑɹɾɪŋ ðə faɪɝz ʌndɝ lɔnʒɹi kɛɾəlz bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ haʊsəz, mɛn stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ təwɔɹd ðɛɹ wɝkpleɪsɪz, səmtaɪmz pɔzɪŋ tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ ə fju wɝdz. ə nɔɹməl mɔɹnɪŋ, wɪð tʃɪlʒɹən ɔlɹɛɾi ɹʌnɪŋ ən pleɪɪŋ, ɹoʊlɪŋ hups ən tɔsɪŋ binbæɡz əmʌŋ ðə θɹɔŋ. ðə klæŋ ʌv ə smɪθi ɹoʊz, dɪm wɪð ðə dɪstəns. ðə smoʊk fɹəm bɹɛkfəs faɪɝz wɑz feɪɾɪŋ ət ðə tʃɪmniz.

Halfway between Elmora and the Amadician border, Serana sat in a flat grassy valley among forested hills, with at least a mile to the trees in any direction save his, and a small, reed-fringed lake fed by two wide streams lay between him and the village. Not a place that could be surprised by daylight. It had been sizable before the Seanchan came, a stopping point for the merchant trains heading east, with over a dozen inns and nearly as many streets.
