Mat cleared his throat. "You're welcome, but there's no need for. . . . Would you stop that? Teslyn?" Reclaiming his hands took some effort.

"aɪ wɑn əm tə stɑp ənɔɪɪŋ mi, tɔɪ," tuɑn sɛɾ əz i tɝn tə dʒoʊlin. fɹəm ɛniwʌn ɛls, ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn pɛtʃələnt. ðə dɑɹk lɪɾəl wʊmən meɪɾ ɪɾ ə dɪmænd.

"I want them to stop annoying me, Toy," Tuon said as he turned to Joline. From anyone else, that might have been petulant. The dark little woman made it a demand.

"aɪ θɪŋk ðəl əɡɹi tə ðəɾ æftɝ ðɪs," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. bʌt dʒoʊlin wɑz lʊkɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm wɪð ə stʌbɝn sɛt tə hɝ dʒɔ. "ju wɪl əɡɹi, woʊn ju?" ðə ɡɹin sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

"I think they'll agree to that after this," he said dryly. But Joline was looking up at him with a stubborn set to her jaw. "You will agree, won't you?" The Green said nothing.

"aɪ də əɡɹi," tɛslɪn sɛd kwɪkli. "wi də ɔl əɡɹi."

"I do agree," Teslyn said quickly. "We do all agree."

"jɛs, wi ɔl əɡɹi," idɛzinə æɾəd.

"Yes, we all agree," Edesina added.

dʒoʊlin stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm saɪlənli, stʌbɝnli, ən mæt saɪd.

Joline stared at him silently, stubbornly, and Mat sighed.

"aɪ kəd lɛt pɹɛʃəs kip jə fəɹ ə fju deɪz, əntɪl jə tʃeɪnʒ jəɹ maɪnd." dʒoʊlinz kɑlɝ klɪkt oʊpən ɪn ɪz hænz. "bʌɾ aɪ woʊnt."

"I could let Precious keep you for a few days, until you change your mind." Joline's collar clicked open in his hands. "But I won't."

stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə hɪz aɪz, ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ θɹoʊɾ əz ðoʊ tə kənfɝm ðə kɑlɝ wɑz ɡɔn. "wʊd jə laɪk tə bi wʌn ə maɪ wɔɹɾɝz?" ʃi æskt, ðən læf sɔfli. "noʊ nid tə lʊk laɪk ðæt. ivən ɪf aɪ wəd bɑn jə əɡɛns jəɹ wɪl, aɪ kʊdn soʊ lɔŋ əz juv ðət tɛɹæŋɡɹil. aɪ əɡɹi, mæstɝ kɔθən. ɪt meɪ kɑst əɹ bɛs tʃæns tə stɑp ðə sintʃæn, bʌɾ əl noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɑðɝ . . . pɹɛʃəs."

Still staring into his eyes, she touched her throat as though to confirm the collar was gone. "Would you like to be one of my Warders?" she asked, then laughed softly. "No need to look like that. Even if I would bond you against your will, I couldn't so long as you have that ter'angreal. I agree, Master Cauthon. It may cost our best chance to stop the Seanchan, but I will no longer bother . . . Precious."

tuɑn hɪs laɪk ə daʊs kæt, ən i saɪɾ əɡɛn. wʌt jə ɡeɪn ɑn ðə swɪŋz, jə lɔst ɑn ðə ɹaʊndəbaʊts.

Tuon hissed like a doused cat, and he sighed again. What you gained on the swings, you lost on the roundabouts.

hi spɛn pɑɹɾ ə ðət naɪt duɪŋ wʌɾ i laɪk list ɪn ðə wɝld. wɝkɪŋ. dɪɡɪŋ ə dip hoʊl tə bɛɹi ðə θɹi æɾəm. hi dɪd ðə dʒɑb hɪmsɛlf bɪkɔz, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, dʒoʊlin wɑntəd ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ tɛɹæŋɡɹil, æftɝ ɔl, ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ niɾəd tə stʌɾi ðɛm. ðət maɪt wɛl əv bɪn soʊ, bʌt ðə taʊɝ wəd dʒʌst əv tə faɪn ðɛɹ æɾəm ɛlswɛɹ. hi wɑz fɛɹli sɝɾən ðət nʌn ə ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz wʊɾə hændəɾ əm oʊvɝ ɪf i toʊld əm tə bɛɹi ðə θɪŋz, jɛɾ i wɑz teɪkɪŋ noʊ tʃænsəz ðət ðeɪ wəd ɹiəpɪɹ tə kɑz mɔɹ tʃɹʌbəl. ɪt stɑɹɾəd ɹeɪnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə hoʊl wɑz ni-dip, ə koʊl dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɹeɪn, ən baɪ ðə taɪm i wɑz dʌn, hi wɑz soʊk tə ðə skɪn ən mʌd tə hɪz weɪst. ə faɪn ɛn tə ə faɪn naɪt, wɪð ðə daɪs baʊnsɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz skʌl.

He spent part of that night doing what he liked least in the world. Working. Digging a deep hole to bury the three a'dam. He did the job himself because, surprisingly, Joline wanted them. They were ter'angreal, after all, and the White Tower needed to study them. That might well have been so, but the Tower would just have to find their a'dam elsewhere. He was fairly certain that none of the Redarms would have handed them over if he told them to bury the things, yet he was taking no chances that they would reappear to cause more trouble. It started raining before the hole was knee-deep, a cold driving rain, and by the time he was done, he was soaked to the skin and mud to his waist. A fine end to a fine night, with the dice bouncing around his skull.

tʃæptɝ tɛn

CHAPTER 10

eɪ vɪlədʒ ɪn ʃioʊɾə ðə fɑloʊɪŋ deɪ bɹɔɾ ə ɹɛspɪt, əɹ soʊ ɪt simd. tuɑn, ɪn ə blu sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ən əɹ waɪd tuld-lɛðɝ bɛlt, nɑɾ oʊnli ɹoʊd bɪsaɪɾ ɪm əz ðə ʃoʊ ɹoʊl sloʊli nɔɹθ, ʃi wæɡəld əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ət sɪlutʃə wən ðə wʊmən tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ əɹ dʌn bɪtwin ðɛm. sɪlutʃə hæɾ əkwaɪɝɾ əɹ oʊn maʊnt, sʌmhaʊ, ə kɑmpækt ɡɛldɪŋ ðət kəd nɑt mætʃ pɪps əɹ əkaɪn bʌt stɪl sɝpæs ðə dæpəl baɪ ə fɛɹ mɑɹdʒən. ðə blu-aɪd wʊmən, wɪð ə ɡɹin hɛd skɑɹf bɪniθ əɹ kaʊl tədeɪ, fɛl ɪn ɑn tuɑnz ʌðɝ saɪd, ən əɹ feɪs wʊɾə dʌn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ pɹaʊd wən ɪt keɪm tə ɡɪvɪŋ nʌθɪŋ əweɪ. mæt kəd nɑt hɛlp ɡɹɪnɪŋ. lɛɾ əɹ haɪd fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ. lækɪŋ hɔɹsəz, ðə ɹil ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ kənfaɪn tə ðɛɹ wæɡən; mɛtwɪn wɑz tu fɑɹ əweɪ, ɑn ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz siɾ ə ðə pɝpəl wæɡən, tə oʊvɝhɪɹ wʌɾ i sɛd tə tuɑn; oʊnli ə fju θɪn klaʊdz ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə skaɪ fɹəm ðə naɪts ɹeɪn; ən ɔl simd ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə wɝld. ivən ðə daɪs baʊnsɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd kəd stil nʌθɪŋ fɹəm ðæt. wɛl, ðəɹ wɝ bæd moʊməns, bʌɾ oʊnli moʊməns.

A Village in Shiota The following day brought a respite, or so it seemed. Tuon, in a blue silk riding dress and her wide tooled-leather belt, not only rode beside him as the show rolled slowly north, she waggled her fingers at Selucia when the woman tried to put her dun between them. Selucia had acquired her own mount, somehow, a compact gelding that could not match Pips or Akein but still surpassed the dapple by a fair margin. The blue-eyed woman, with a green head scarf beneath her cowl today, fell in on Tuon's other side, and her face would have done an Aes Sedai proud when it came to giving nothing away. Mat could not help grinning. Let her hide frustration for a change. Lacking horses, the real Aes Sedai were confined to their wagon; Metwyn was too far away, on the driver's seat of the purple wagon, to overhear what he said to Tuon; only a few thin clouds remained in the sky from the night's rain; and all seemed right in the world. Even the dice bouncing in his head could steal nothing from that. Well, there were bad moments, but only moments.

ɝli ɑn, ə flaɪɾ ə ɹeɪvənz wɪŋd oʊvɝhɛd, ə dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ bɪɡ blæk bɝdz. ðeɪ flu swɪfli, nɛvɝ divieɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ laɪn, bʌɾ i aɪɾ əm ɛniweɪ əntɪl ðeɪ dwɪndəl tə spɛks ən vænɪʃt. nʌθɪŋ tə spɔɪl ðə deɪ ðɛɹ. nɑt fəɹ hɪm, ət list. meɪbi fəɹ sʌmwʌn fɑɹðɝ nɔɹθ.

Early on, a flight of ravens winged overhead, a dozen or more big black birds. They flew swiftly, never deviating from their line, but he eyed them anyway until they dwindled to specks and vanished. Nothing to spoil the day there. Not for him, at least. Maybe for someone farther north.

"dɪd jə si səm oʊmən ɪn ðɛm, tɔɪ?" tuɑn æskt. ʃi wɑz əz ɡɹeɪsfəl ɪn ðə sæɾəl əz ʃi wɑz ɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ʃi dɪd. hi kəd nɑt ɹikɔl siɪŋ əɹ bi ɑkwɝɾ əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ. "moʊst oʊmənz aɪ noʊ kənsɝnɪŋ ɹeɪvənz spəsɪfɪkli hæv tə də wɪð əm pɝtʃɪŋ ɑn sʌmwʌnz ɹuftɑp əɹ kɔɪŋ ət dɔn əɹ dʌsk."

"Did you see some omen in them, Toy?" Tuon asked. She was as graceful in the saddle as she was in everything else she did. He could not recall seeing her be awkward about anything. "Most omens I know concerning ravens specifically have to do with them perching on someone's rooftop or cawing at dawn or dusk."

"ðeɪ kən bi spaɪz fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn," hi toʊl hɝ. "səmtaɪmz. kɹoʊz, tu. ən ɹæts. bʌt ðeɪ dɪdn stɑp tə lʊk əɾ ʌs, soʊ wi doʊnt nid tə wɝi."

"They can be spies for the Dark One," he told her. "Sometimes. Crows, too. And rats. But they didn't stop to look at us, so we don't need to worry."

ɹʌnɪŋ ə ɡɹin-ɡlʌv hæn əkɹɔs ðə tɑp ə hɝ hɛd, ʃi saɪd. "tɔɪ, tɔɪ," ʃi mɝmɝd, ɹisɛɾəlɪŋ ðə kaʊl ə hɝ kloʊk. "haʊ mɛni tʃɪlʒɹənz teɪlz dʒju bɪliv? dʒju bɪliv ðəɾ ɪf jə slip ɑn oʊl hɑbz hɪl ʌndɝ ə fʊl mun, ðə sneɪks wɪl ɡɪv jə tʃɹu ænsɝz tə θɹi kwɛstʃənz, əɹ ðət fɑksəz stil pipəlz skɪnz ən teɪk ðə nɝɪʃmən fɹəm fud soʊ jə kən stɑɹv tə dɛθ waɪl iɾɪŋ jəɹ fɪl?"

Running a green-gloved hand across the top of her head, she sighed. "Toy, Toy," she murmured, resettling the cowl of her cloak. "How many children's tales do you believe? Do you believe that if you sleep on Old Hob's Hill under a full moon, the snakes will give you true answers to three questions, or that foxes steal people's skins and take the nourishment from food so you can starve to death while eating your fill?"

pʊɾɪŋ ɑn ə smaɪl tʊk ɛfɝt. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ ɛvɝ hɝɾ iðɝ wʌn ə ðoʊz." meɪkɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs əmjuzd ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɛfɝt, tu. wʌt wɝ ði ɑdz ə hɝ mɛnʃənɪŋ sneɪks ɡɪvɪŋ tʃɹu ænsɝz, wɪtʃ ði æɛlfɪn dɪɾ æftɝ ə fæʃən, ɪn ðə seɪm bɹɛθ wɪð fɑksəz stilɪŋ skɪnz? hi wɑz pɹɪɾi ʃʊɹ ðət ði ɛlfɪn dɪd, ən meɪd lɛðɝ fɹəm ɪt. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz oʊl hɑb ðət nɪɹli meɪɾ ɪm flɪntʃ. ði ʌðɝ wɑz laɪkli dʒʌs tɑvɝən twɪstɪŋ ət ðə wɝld. ʃi sɝɾənli nu nʌθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪm ən ðə sneɪks əɹ ðə fɑksəz. ɪn ʃændæl, ðə lænd wɛɹ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ hæd bɪn bɔɹn, ðoʊ, oʊl hɑb, ksən hɑb, hæd bɪn ənʌðɝ neɪm fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ði æɛlfɪn ən ði ɛlfɪn boʊθ ʃʊɹli dɪzɝv tə bi kənɛktəd tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, jɛt ðət wɑz hɑɹdli ɛniθɪŋ i wɑntəd tə θɪŋk ɑn wən i hæɾ ɪz oʊn kənɛkʃən tə ðə blʌɾi fɑksəz. ən tə ðə sneɪks, tu? ðət pɑsəbɪləɾi wɑz ɪnʌf tə saʊɝ ɪz stʌmək.

Putting on a smile took effort. "I don't think I ever heard either one of those." Making his voice amused required effort, too. What were the odds of her mentioning snakes giving true answers, which the Aelfinn did after a fashion, in the same breath with foxes stealing skins? He was pretty sure that the Eelfinn did, and made leather from it. But it was Old Hob that nearly made him flinch. The other was likely just ta'veren twisting at the world. She certainly knew nothing about him and the snakes or the foxes. In Shandalle, the land where Artur Hawkwing had been born, though, Old Hob, Caisen Hob, had been another name for the Dark One. The Aelfinn and the Eelfinn both surely deserved to be connected to the Dark One, yet that was hardly anything he wanted to think on when he had his own connection to the bloody foxes. And to the snakes, too? That possibility was enough to sour his stomach.

stɪl, ɪt wɑz ə plɛzən ɹaɪd, wɪð ðə deɪ wɔɹmɪŋ əz ðə sʌn ɹoʊz, ðoʊ ɪt nɛvɝ kəd bi kɔld wɔɹm. hi dʒʌɡəl sɪks kʌlɝd wʊɾən bɔlz, ən tuɑn læft ən klæpt əɹ hænz, əz wɛl ʃi ʃʊd. ðət fit hæɾ ɪmpɹɛs ðə dʒʌɡəlɝ i bɑt ðə bɔlz fɹʌm, ən ɪt wɑz hɑɹɾɝ waɪl ɹaɪɾɪŋ. hi toʊl sɛvɹəl dʒoʊks ðət meɪɾ əɹ læf, ən wʌn ðət meɪɾ əɹ ɹoʊl əɹ aɪz ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒ fɪŋɡɝ-twɪtʃɪŋz wɪð sɪlutʃə. meɪbi ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk dʒoʊks əbaʊt kɑmən ɹum sɝvɪŋ meɪdz. ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn ðə list ɔf-kʌlɝ. hi wɑz noʊ ful. hi dɪd wɪʃ ʃi hæd læft, ðoʊ. ʃi hæɾ ə mɑɹvələs læf, ɹɪtʃ ən wɔɹm ən fɹi. ðeɪ tɔkt ə hɔɹsəz ən ɑɹɡjuɾ oʊvɝ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ mɛθədz wɪð stʌbɝn ænəməlz. ðət pɹɪɾi hɛd hɛld ə fju ɑd noʊʃənz, sətʃ əz ðət jə kəd kɑm ə fɹækʃəs hɔɹs baɪ baɪɾɪŋ ɪts ɪɹ! ðət saʊndəd mɔɹ laɪkli tə sɛn ɪɾ ʌp laɪk ə heɪstæk faɪɝ. ən ʃi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə hʌmɪŋ ʌndɝ jəɹ bɹɛθ tə suð ə hɔɹs, ən wəd nɑt bɪliv ɪz fɑðɝ hæd tɔɾ ɪm sətʃ ə skɪl ʃaɪ ʌv dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən.

Still, it was a pleasant ride, with the day warming as the sun rose, though it never could be called warm. He juggled six colored wooden balls, and Tuon laughed and clapped her hands, as well she should. That feat had impressed the juggler he bought the balls from, and it was harder while riding. He told several jokes that made her laugh, and one that made her roll her eyes and exchange finger-twitchings with Selucia. Maybe she did not like jokes about common room serving maids. It had not been the least off-color. He was no fool. He did wish she had laughed, though. She had a marvelous laugh, rich and warm and free. They talked of horses and argued over training methods with stubborn animals. That pretty head held a few odd notions, such as that you could calm a fractious horse by biting its ear! That sounded more likely to send it up like a haystack fire. And she had never heard of humming under your breath to soothe a horse, and would not believe his father had taught him such a skill shy of demonstration.

"wɛl, aɪ kən hɑɹdli də ðət wɪθaʊɾ ə hɔɹs ðət nidz suðɪŋ, kən aɪ?" hi sɛd. ʃi ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz əɡɛn. sɪlutʃə ɹoʊl hɝz, tu.

"Well, I can hardly do that without a horse that needs soothing, can I?" he said. She rolled her eyes again. Selucia rolled hers, too.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hiɾ ɪn ði ɑɹɡjəmənt, ðoʊ, noʊ æŋɡɝ, dʒʌst spɪɹət. tuɑn hæd soʊ mʌtʃ spɪɹəɾ ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ɪt kəd fɪɾ ɪndə sətʃ ə taɪni wʊmən. ɪt wɑz əɹ saɪlənsɪz ðət pʊɾ ə smɔl dæmpɝ ɑn ðə deɪ, mɔɹ soʊ ðən sneɪks əɹ fɑksəz. ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ əweɪ, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn. ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt ðəɹ bɪsaɪd hɪm, ən i hæɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil tə də kənsɝnɪŋ hɝ. ʃi nɛvɝ əluɾəd tə wʌt hæd hæpənd wɪð ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɹ tə ðə sɪstɝz ðɛmsɛlvz iðɝ. ʃi nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ɪz tɛɹæŋɡɹil, əɹ ðə fæk ðət wʌtɛvɝ ʃi hæd meɪd tɛslɪn əɹ dʒoʊlin wiv əɡɛnst ɪm hæd feɪld. ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ə dʒɹim.

There was no heat in the argument, though, no anger, just spirit. Tuon had so much spirit it seemed impossible it could fit into such a tiny woman. It was her silences that put a small damper on the day, more so than snakes or foxes. They were far away, and there was nothing to be done. She was right there beside him, and he had a great deal to do concerning her. She never alluded to what had happened with the three Aes Sedai, or to the sisters themselves either. She never mentioned his ter'angreal, or the fact that whatever she had made Teslyn or Joline weave against him had failed. The night before might as well have been a dream.

ʃi wɑz laɪk ə dʒɛnɝəl plænɪŋ ə bæɾəl, sɛɾəl hæd sɛd. tʃɹeɪn əɾ ɪntʃɹiɡ ən dɪsəmbəlɪŋ fɹəm ɪnfənsi, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɛdʒiənɪn. ən ɪt wɑz ɔl eɪm stʃɹeɪɾ ət hɪm. bʌt tə wʌɾ ɛnd? ʃʊɹli ɪt kəd nɑt bi səm sintʃæn blʌd fɔɹm ə kɔɹɾɪŋ. ɛdʒiənɪn nu lɪɾəl ə ðæt, bʌt ʃʊɹli nɑt. hi hæd noʊn tuɑn ə mæɾɝ ʌv wiks ən kɪdnæp hɝ, ʃi kɔld ɪm tɔɪ, hæd tʃɹaɪd tə baɪ hɪm, ən oʊnli ə veɪn ful kəd twɪs ðəɾ ɪndə ə wʊmən fɔlɪŋ ɪn lʌv. wɪtʃ lɛft ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm səm ɪlæbɹət skim fəɹ ɹivɛnʒ tə . . . tə ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wʌt. ʃi hæd θɹɛɾənd tə meɪk ɪm ə kʌbɛɹɝ. ðət mɛn dækoʊvæl, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɛdʒiənɪn, ðoʊ ʃi hæd skɔft ət ðə noʊʃən. kʌbɛɹɝz wɝ tʃoʊzən fəɹ ðɛɹ bjuɾi, ən ɪn ɛdʒiənɪnz ɛstəmeɪʃən, hi fɛl fɑɹ ʃɔɹt. wɛl, ɪn ɪz oʊn əz wɛl, tʃɹuθ tə tɛl, nɑt ðəɾ i wɑz laɪkli tə ədmɪɾ ɪt tə ɛnibəɾi. ɛni nʌmbɝ ʌv wɪmən hæɾ ədmaɪɝɾ ɪz feɪs. nʌθɪŋ sɛd tuɑn kəd nɑt kəmplit ðə mɛɹɪdʒ sɛɹəmoʊni dʒʌs tə meɪk ɪm θɪŋk hɪmsɛlf hoʊm fɹi ən seɪf, ðən əv ɪm ɛksəkjuɾəd. wɪmən wɝ nɛvɝ sɪmpəl, bʌt tuɑn meɪd ðə ɹɛs lʊk laɪk tʃɪlʒɹənz ɡeɪmz.

She was like a general planning a battle, Setalle had said. Trained at intrigue and dissembling from infancy, according to Egeanin. And it was all aimed straight at him. But to what end? Surely it could not be some Seanchan Blood form of courting. Egeanin knew little of that, but surely not. He had known Tuon a matter of weeks and kidnapped her, she called him Toy, had tried to buy him, and only a vain fool could twist that into a woman falling in love. Which left anything from some elaborate scheme for revenge to . . . to the Light alone knew what. She had threatened to make him a cupbearer. That meant da'covale, according to Egeanin, though she had scoffed at the notion. Cupbearers were chosen for their beauty, and in Egeanin's estimation, he fell far short. Well, in his own as well, truth to tell, not that he was likely to admit it to anybody. Any number of women had admired his face. Nothing said Tuon could not complete the marriage ceremony just to make him think himself home free and safe, then have him executed. Women were never simple, but Tuon made the rest look like children's games.

fəɹ ə lɔŋ waɪl ðeɪ sɔ nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə fɑɹm, bʌt pɝhæps tu aʊɝz æftɝ ðə sʌn pæst ɪts zinəθ, ðeɪ keɪm ɑn ə saɪzəbəl vɪlədʒ. ðə ɹɪŋ ʌv ə blæksmɪθs hæmɝ ɑn ən ænvəl saʊndəd dɪmli. ðə bɪldɪŋz, səm ə θɹi stɔɹiz, wɝ ɔl hɛvi tɪmbɝ fɹeɪmɪŋ wɪð waɪɾɪʃ plæstɝ bɪtwin ən hæd haɪ-pikt ɹufs ə θætʃ ən tɔl stoʊn tʃɪmniz. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əm tʌɡd ət mæts mɛmɹi, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt seɪ wʌt. ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə fɑɹm tə bi sin ɛniwɛɹ ɪn ði ənbɹoʊkən fɔɹəst. bʌt vɪlədʒəz wɝ ɔlweɪz taɪd tə fɑɹmz, səpɔɹɾɪŋ əm ən lɪvɪŋ ɔf ðɛm. ðeɪ mʌst ɔl bi fɝðɝ ɪn fɹəm ðə ɹoʊd, bæk ɪn ðə tʃɹiz.

For a long while they saw not so much as a farm, but perhaps two hours after the sun passed its zenith, they came on a sizable village. The ring of a blacksmith's hammer on an anvil sounded dimly. The buildings, some of three stories, were all heavy timber framing with whitish plaster between and had high-peaked roofs of thatch and tall stone chimneys. Something about them tugged at Mat's memory, but he could not say what. There was not a farm to be seen anywhere in the unbroken forest. But villages were always tied to farms, supporting them and living off them. They must all be further in from the road, back in the trees.

ɑdli, ðə pipəl i kəd si ɪɡnɔɹd ði əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ tʃɹeɪn ə ʃoʊ wæɡənz. ə fɛloʊ ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz, ɹaɪt bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd, ɡlænst ʌp fɹəm ðə hætʃəɾ i wɑz ʃɑɹpənɪŋ ɑn ə ɡɹaɪndstoʊn wɝk baɪ ə fʊtpəɾəl, ðən bɛn tə hɪz wɝk əɡɛn əz ðoʊ hi hæd sin nʌθɪŋ. ə klʌstɝ ə tʃɪlʒɹən keɪm hɝtlɪŋ ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ ən dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ənʌðɝ stʃɹit wɪθaʊt mɔɹ ðən ə ɡlæns ɪn ðə ʃoʊz dɝɛkʃən. vɛɹi ɑd. moʊs vɪlədʒ tʃɪlʒɹən wəd stɑp tə stɛɹ əɾ ə pæsɪŋ mɝtʃəns tʃɹeɪn, spɛkjəleɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ pleɪsəz ðə mɝtʃən hæd bɪn, ən ðə ʃoʊ hæd mɔɹ wæɡənz ðən ɛni nʌmbɝ ə mɝtʃəns' tʃɹeɪnz. ə pɛdlɝ wɑz kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ bɪhaɪn sɪks hɔɹsəz, hɪz wæɡənz haɪ kænvəs kʌvɝ ɔlmoʊs hɪɾən baɪ klʌstɝz ə pɑts ən pænz ən kɛɾəlz. ðət ʃʊɾə kɑzd ɪntʃɹəst, tu. ivən ə lɑɹdʒ vɪlədʒ ɑn ə wɛl-tʃɹævəld ɹoʊd dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn pɛdlɝz fəɹ moʊs θɪŋz ðə pipəl bɑt. bʌt noʊ wʌn pɔɪntəɾ əɹ ʃaʊɾəd ðəɾ ə pɛdlɝ hæd kʌm. ðeɪ dʒʌst wɛn ɑn əbaʊt ðɛɹ bɪznəs.

Oddly, the people he could see ignored the approaching train of show wagons. A fellow in his shirtsleeves, right beside the road, glanced up from the hatchet he was sharpening on a grindstone worked by a footpedal, then bent to his work again as though he had seen nothing. A cluster of children came hurtling around a corner and darted into another street without more than a glance in the show's direction. Very odd. Most village children would stop to stare at a passing merchant's train, speculating on the strange places the merchant had been, and the show had more wagons than any number of merchants' trains. A peddler was coming from the north behind six horses, his wagon's high canvas cover almost hidden by clusters of pots and pans and kettles. That should have caused interest, too. Even a large village on a well-traveled road depended on peddlers for most things the people bought. But no one pointed or shouted that a peddler had come. They just went on about their business.

pɝhæps θɹi hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ, lukə stʊɾ ʌp ɑn ɪz dʒɹaɪvɝz siɾ ən lʊk bæk oʊvɝ ðə ɹuf ə hɪz wæɡən. "wil tɝn ɪn hɪɹ," hi bɛloʊd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə lɑɹdʒ mɛdoʊ wɛɹ waɪldflaʊɹz, kæt deɪziz ən dʒʌmpʌps ən sʌmθɪŋ ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn lʌvɝsknɑts dɑɾəd spɹɪŋ ɡɹæsəz ɔlɹɛɾi ə fʊt haɪ. sɪɾɪŋ bæk daʊn, hi suɾəd ɪz oʊn wɝdz, ən ði ʌðɝ wæɡənz bɪɡæn fɑloʊɪŋ, ðɛɹ wilz ɹʌɾɪŋ ðə ɹeɪn-sɑɾən ɡɹaʊnd.

Perhaps three hundred paces short of the village, Luca stood up on his driver's seat and looked back over the roof of his wagon. "We'll turn in here," he bellowed, gesturing toward a large meadow where wildflowers, cat daisies and jumpups and something that might have been loversknots dotted spring grasses already a foot high. Sitting back down, he suited his own words, and the other wagons began following, their wheels rutting the rain-sodden ground.

əz mæt tɝn pɪps təwɔɹd ðə mɛdoʊ, hi hɝd ðə ʃuz ə ðə pɛdlɝz hɔɹsəz ɹɪŋɪŋ ɑn peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. ðə saʊn dʒɝkt ɪm əpɹaɪt. ðət ɹoʊd hæd nɑt bɪn peɪv sɪns . . . hi pʊl ðə ɡɛldɪŋ bæk ɝaʊnd. ðə kænvəs-tɑpt wæɡən wɑz ɹoʊlɪŋ oʊvɝ lɛvəl ɡɹeɪ peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ðət stʃɹɛtʃt dʒʌs ðə wɪdθ ə ðə vɪlədʒ. ðə pɛdlɝ hɪmsɛlf, ə ɹoʊtʌn fɛloʊ ɪn ə waɪd hæt, wɑz piɹɪŋ ət ðə peɪvmən ən ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, piɹɪŋ ət ðə vɪlədʒ ən ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. pɛdlɝz fɑloʊd fɪkst ɹuts. hi mʌst əv bɪn ðɪs weɪ ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz. hi hæd tə noʊ. ðə pɛdlɝ hɔltəɾ ɪz tim ən taɪd ðə ɹeɪnz tə ðə bɹeɪk hændəl.

As Mat turned Pips toward the meadow, he heard the shoes of the peddler's horses ringing on paving stones. The sound jerked him upright. That road had not been paved since . . . He pulled the gelding back around. The canvas-topped wagon was rolling over level gray paving stones that stretched just the width of the village. The peddler himself, a rotund fellow in a wide hat, was peering at the pavement and shaking his head, peering at the village and shaking his head. Peddlers followed fixed routes. He must have been this way a hundred times. He had to know. The peddler halted his team and tied the reins to the brake handle.

mæt kʌp boʊθ hænz ɝaʊn ɪz maʊθ. "kip ɡoʊɪŋ, mæn!" hi ʃaʊɾəd ət ðə tɑp ə hɪz lʌŋz. "æz fæst əz jə kæn! kip ɡoʊɪŋ!"

Mat cupped both hands around his mouth. "Keep going, man!" he shouted at the top of his lungs. "As fast as you can! Keep going!"

ðə pɛdlɝ ɡlænst ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən, ðən hɑpt ʌp ɑn ɪz sit kwaɪt spɹɪli fəɹ sətʃ ə staʊt mæn. dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ əz ɡɹænli əz lukə, hi bɪɡæn tə dɪkleɪm. mæt kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt ðə wɝdz, bʌɾ i nu wʌt ðeɪ wəd bi. nuz ə ðə wɝl ðəɾ i hæd pɪkt ʌp əlɔŋ ðə weɪ ɪntɝspɝst wɪð lɪsts ə hɪz ɡʊdz ən kleɪmz fəɹ ðɛɹ væst supɪɹiɔɹɪɾi. noʊbɑdi ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ stɑp tə lɪsən əɹ ivən pɔzd.

The peddler glanced in his direction, then hopped up on his seat quite spryly for such a stout man. Gesturing as grandly as Luca, he began to declaim. Mat could not make out the words, but he knew what they would be. News of the world that he had picked up along the way interspersed with lists of his goods and claims for their vast superiority. Nobody in the village stopped to listen or even paused.

"kip ɡoʊɪŋ!" mæt bɛloʊd. "ðeɪɹ dɛd! kip ɡoʊɪŋ!" bɪhaɪn hɪm, sʌmbɑɾi ɡæspt, tuɑn əɹ sɪlutʃə. meɪbi boʊθ.

"Keep going!" Mat bellowed. "They're dead! Keep going!" Behind him, somebody gasped, Tuon or Selucia. Maybe both.

sʌɾənli ðə pɛdlɝz hɔɹsəz skɹimd, tɔsɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz mædli. ðeɪ skɹim laɪk ænəməlz bɪɑn ðə ɹæɡəɾ ɛdʒ ə tɛɹɝ ən kɛp skɹimɪŋ.

Suddenly the peddler's horses screamed, tossing their heads madly. They screamed like animals beyond the ragged edge of terror and kept screaming.

pɪps dʒɝkt ɪn fɪɹ, ən mæt hæɾ ɪz hænz fʊl; ðə ɡɛldɪŋ dænst ɪn sɝkəlz, wɑntɪŋ tə ɹʌn, ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt wɑz əweɪ fɹəm hɪɹ. ɛvɹi hɔɹs bɪlɔŋɪŋ tə ðə ʃoʊ hɝd ðoʊz skɹimz ən bɪɡæn wɪniɪŋ fɪɹfəli. ðə laɪənz ən bɛɹz bɪɡæn ɹɔɹɪŋ, ən ðə lɛpɝdz dʒɔɪn ɪn. ðət sɛt səm ə ðə ʃoʊz hɔɹsəz tə skɹimɪŋ, tu, ən ɹɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ hɑɹnəsəz. ðə tuməl bɪlt ɑn ɪtsɛlf ɪn moʊməns. əz mæt swʌŋ ɹaʊnd, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl pɪps, ɛvɹiwʌn i kəd si hænlɪŋ ɹeɪnz wɑz faɪɾɪŋ tə kip ə waɪld-aɪd tim fɹəm ɹeɪsɪŋ ɔf əɹ ɪnʒɝɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. tuɑnz mɛɹ wɑz dænsɪŋ, tu, ən sɪlutʃəz dʌn. hi hæɾ ə moʊmən ə fɪɹ fəɹ tuɑn, bʌt ʃi sim tə bi hænlɪŋ əkaɪn əz wɛl əz ʃi hæɾ ɪn əɹ ɹeɪs ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst. ivən sɪlutʃə simd ʃʊɹ ə hɝ sit, ɪf nɑɾ ə hɝ maʊnt. hi kɑt ɡlɪmpsɪz ə ðə pɛdlɝ, əz wɛl, pʊlɪŋ ɔf ɪz hæt, piɹɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ʃoʊ. ət læst, mæt ɡɑt pɪps ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. bloʊɪŋ hɑɹd, əz ɪf i hæd bɪn ɹʌn tu hɑɹd fəɹ tu lɔŋ, bʌt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹeɪs əweɪ. ɪt wɑz tu leɪt. laɪkli, ɪt hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn tu leɪt. hæɾ ɪn hænd, ðə ɹaʊn pɛdlɝ lɛp daʊn tə si wʌt wɑz ðə mæɾɝ wɪð ɪz hɔɹsəz.

Pips jerked in fear, and Mat had his hands full; the gelding danced in circles, wanting to run, in any direction so long as it was away from here. Every horse belonging to the show heard those screams and began whinnying fearfully. The lions and bears began roaring, and the leopards joined in. That set some of the show's horses to screaming, too, and rearing in their harnesses. The tumult built on itself in moments. As Mat swung round, struggling to control Pips, everyone he could see handling reins was fighting to keep a wild-eyed team from racing off or injuring themselves. Tuon's mare was dancing, too, and Selucia's dun. He had a moment of fear for Tuon, but she seemed to be handling Akein as well as she had in her race into the forest. Even Selucia seemed sure of her seat, if not of her mount. He caught glimpses of the peddler, as well, pulling off his hat, peering toward the show. At last, Mat got Pips under control. Blowing hard, as if he had been run too hard for too long, but no longer trying to race away. It was too late. Likely, it had always been too late. Hat in hand, the round peddler leaped down to see what was the matter with his horses.

lændɪŋ, hi lɝtʃt ɔkwɝdli ən lʊk daʊn təwɔɹɾ ɪz fit. hɪz hæt fɛl fɹəm ɪz hænd, lændɪŋ ɑn ðə hɑɹdpækt ɹoʊd. ðət wɑz wən i bɪɡæn skɹimɪŋ. ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz wɝ ɡɔn, ən i wɑz æŋkəl-dip ɪn ðə ɹoʊd, dʒʌs laɪk ɪz ʃɹikɪŋ hɔɹsəz. æŋkəl-dip ən sɪŋkɪŋ ɪndə ɹɑk-hɑɹd kleɪ əz ɪf ɪndə ə bɑɡ, dʒʌs laɪk ɪz hɔɹsəz ən ɪz wæɡən. ən ðə vɪlədʒ, haʊsəz ən pipəl mɛltɪŋ sloʊli ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə pipəl nɛvɝ stɑpt wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ. wɪmən wɔkt əlɔŋ kæɹiɪŋ bæskəts, ə laɪn ə mɛn kæɹiɾ ə lɑɹdʒ tɪmbɝ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, tʃɪlʒɹən dɑɹɾɪd əbaʊt, ðə fɛloʊ ət ðə ɡɹaɪndstoʊn kəntɪnjud ʃɑɹpənɪŋ ɪz hætʃət, ɔl ə ðɛm nɪɹli ni-dip ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn baɪ ðɪs taɪm.

Landing, he lurched awkwardly and looked down toward his feet. His hat fell from his hand, landing on the hardpacked road. That was when he began screaming. The paving stones were gone, and he was ankle-deep in the road, just like his shrieking horses. Ankle-deep and sinking into rock-hard clay as if into a bog, just like his horses and his wagon. And the village, houses and people melting slowly into the ground. The people never stopped what they were doing. Women walked along carrying baskets, a line of men carried a large timber on their shoulders, children darted about, the fellow at the grindstone continued sharpening his hatchet, all of them nearly knee-deep in the ground by this time.

tuɑn kɑt mæts koʊt fɹəm wʌn saɪd, sɪlutʃə fɹəm ði ʌðɝ. ðət wɑz ðə fɝst i ɹilaɪzd i hæd muv pɪps. təwɔɹd ðə pɛdlɝ. laɪt!

Tuon caught Mat's coat from one side, Selucia from the other. That was the first he realized he had moved Pips. Toward the peddler. Light!

"wʌt dʒju θɪŋk jə kən du?" tuɑn dɪmændəd fɪɹsli.

"What do you think you can do?" Tuon demanded fiercely.

"nʌθɪŋ," hi ɹɪplaɪd. hɪz baʊ wɑz dʌn, ðə hɔɹn nɑks fɪɾəd, ðə lɪnən bɑstʃɹɪŋz bɹeɪɾɪd ən wækst, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt fɪɾəd wʌn æɹoʊhɛd tə ɪts æʃ ʃæf jɛt, ən wɪð ɔl ðə ɹeɪn ðeɪ hæd bɪn hævɪŋ, ðə ɡlu hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɡus-fɛðɝ flɛtʃɪŋz wɑz stɪl tæki. ðət wɑz ɔl i kəd θɪŋk ʌv, ðə mɝsi ʌv ən æɹoʊ ɪn ðə pɛdlɝz hɑɹt bɪfɔɹ i wɑz pʊld ʌndɝ kəmplitli. wəd ðə mæn daɪ, əɹ wɑz i biɪŋ kæɹid tə wɛɹɛvɝ ðoʊz dɛd ʃiəɾənz wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ? ðət wɑz wʌt hæd kɑɾ ɪm əbaʊt ðoʊz bɪldɪŋz. ðət wɑz haʊ kʌntʃɹi pipəl hæd bɪlt ɪn ʃioʊɾə fəɹ nɪɹ ɪnʌf θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz.

"Nothing," he replied. His bow was done, the horn nocks fitted, the linen bowstrings braided and waxed, but he had not fitted one arrowhead to its ash shaft yet, and with all the rain they had been having, the glue holding the goose-feather fletchings was still tacky. That was all he could think of, the mercy of an arrow in the peddler's heart before he was pulled under completely. Would the man die, or was he being carried to wherever those dead Shiotans were going? That was what had caught him about those buildings. That was how country people had built in Shiota for near enough three hundred years.

hi kəd nɑt tɛɹ ɪz aɪz əweɪ. ðə sɪŋkɪŋ pɛdlɝ ʃɹik laʊdli ɪnʌf tə bi hɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə skɹimɪŋ ə hɪz tim.

He could not tear his eyes away. The sinking peddler shrieked loudly enough to be heard over the screaming of his team.

"hɛlp miii!" hi kɹaɪd, weɪvɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz. hi sim tə bi lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ət mæt. "hɛlp miii!" oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ.

"Help meeee!" he cried, waving his arms. He seemed to be looking straight at Mat. "Help meeee!" Over and over.

mæt kɛpt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə daɪ, hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə daɪ - ʃʊɹli ðət wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ - bʌt ðə mæn kɛpt ɑn skɹimɪŋ əz i sæŋk tə hɪz weɪst, tə hɪz tʃɛst. dɛspɝətli, hi tɪp bæk ɪz hɛd laɪk ə mæn biɪŋ pʊld ʌndɝ wɔɾɝ, sʌkɪŋ fəɹ wʌn læs bɹɛθ. ðən ɪz hɛd vænɪʃt, ən dʒʌst ɪz ɑɹmz ɹɪmeɪnd, fɹæntəkəli weɪvɪŋ əntɪl ðeɪ, tu, wɝ ɡɔn. oʊnli hɪz hæt laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹoʊd sɛd ðəɹ hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ə mæn ðɛɹ.

Mat kept waiting for him to die, hoping for him to die - surely that was better than the other - but the man kept on screaming as he sank to his waist, to his chest. Desperately, he tipped back his head like a man being pulled under water, sucking for one last breath. Then his head vanished, and just his arms remained, frantically waving until they, too, were gone. Only his hat lying on the road said there had ever been a man there.

wən ðə læst ə ðə θætʃt ɹuftɑps ən tɔl tʃɪmniz mɛltəɾ əweɪ, mæt lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ. wɛɹ ðə vɪlədʒ hæd bɪn wɑz ənʌðɝ mɛdoʊ dɛkt aʊɾ ɪn kæt deɪziz ən dʒʌmpʌps wɛɹ ɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ bʌɾɝflaɪz flʌɾɝd fɹəm blɑsəm tə blɑsəm. soʊ pisfəl. hi wɪʃt i kəd bɪliv ðə pɛdlɝ wɑz dɛd.

When the last of the thatched rooftops and tall chimneys melted away, Mat let out a long breath. Where the village had been was another meadow decked out in cat daisies and jumpups where red and yellow butterflies fluttered from blossom to blossom. So peaceful. He wished he could believe the peddler was dead.

ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə fju ðət hæd fɑloʊd lukə ɪndə ðə mɛdoʊ, ðə ʃoʊz wæɡənz stʊd stʃɹʌŋ aʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd, ən ɛvɹibɑɾi wɑz daʊn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wɪmən kʌmfɝɾɪŋ kɹaɪɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən, mɛn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kwaɪət tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ hɔɹsəz, ɛvɹiwʌn tɔkɪŋ fɪɹfəli, ən laʊdli, tə bi hɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə bɛɹz ən ðə laɪənz ən ðə lɛpɝdz. wɛl, ɛvɹiwʌn ɪksɛp ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ ɡlaɪɾɪd hɝidli ʌp ðə ɹoʊd, dʒoʊlin hil baɪ blɹɪk ən fɛn. baɪ ðɛɹ ɪkspɹɛʃənz, ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz əlaɪk, jə maɪɾ əv θɔt vɪlədʒəz sɪŋkɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɝ əz kɑmən əz haʊs kæts. pɔzɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə pɛdlɝz waɪd hæt, ðə θɹi ʌv əm stɛɹd daʊn əɾ ɪt. tɛslɪn pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp ən tɝn ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪn əɹ hænz, ðən lɛɾ ɪt dʒɹɑp. muvɪŋ ɪndə ðə mɛdoʊ wɛɹ ðə vɪlədʒ hæd stʊd, ðə sɪstɝz wɔkt əbaʊt tɔkɪŋ, piɹɪŋ ət ðɪs ən ðəɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd lɝn sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm waɪldflaʊɹz ən ɡɹæsəz. nʌn hæd teɪkən ðə taɪm tə dɑn ə kloʊk, bʌt fəɹ wʌns mæt kəd nɑt faɪn ɪɾ ɪn ɪm tə ʌpbɹeɪd ðɛm. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv tʃænəld, bʌɾ ɪf soʊ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt juz ɪnʌf ə ðə paʊɝ tə meɪk ðə fɑkshɛd tɝn tʃɪli. hi wəd nɑɾ əv teɪkən əm tə tæsk ɪf ðeɪ hæd. nɑt tədeɪ, nɑɾ æftɝ wʌɾ i hæd dʒʌst sin.

Except for the few that had followed Luca into the meadow, the show's wagons stood strung out along the road, and everybody was down on the ground, women comforting crying children, men trying to quiet trembling horses, everyone talking fearfully, and loudly, to be heard over the bears and the lions and the leopards. Well, everyone except the three Aes Sedai. They glided hurriedly up the road, Joline heeled by Blaeric and Fen. By their expressions, Aes Sedai and Warders alike, you might have thought villages sinking into the ground were as common as house cats. Pausing beside the peddler's wide hat, the three of them stared down at it. Teslyn picked it up and turned it over in her hands, then let it drop. Moving into the meadow where the village had stood, the sisters walked about talking, peering at this and that as if they could learn something from wildflowers and grasses. None had taken the time to don a cloak, but for once Mat could not find it in him to upbraid them. They might have channeled, but if so they did not use enough of the Power to make the foxhead turn chilly. He would not have taken them to task if they had. Not today, not after what he had just seen.

ði ɑɹɡjuɪŋ stɑɹɾəd ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə kɹɔs ðət pætʃ ə hɑɹd-pækt kleɪ ðət simɪŋli hæd bɪn peɪvd wɪð stoʊn. ðeɪ ʃaʊɾəd oʊvɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə hɔɹs hænlɝz ən ðə simstʃɹəsəz, ɔl tɛlɪŋ lukə wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn, ən ɹaɪt naʊ. səm wɑntəd tə tɝn bæk fɑɹ ɪnʌf tə faɪn ə kʌntʃɹi ɹoʊɾ ən juz ðoʊz nɛɹoʊɝ weɪz tə faɪn ðɛɹ weɪ tə luɡɹd. ʌðɝz wɝ fəɹ fɝɡɛɾɪŋ luɡɹɾ ɔltəɡɛðɝ, fəɹ stʃɹaɪkɪŋ aʊt fəɹ ɪljən baɪ ðoʊz kʌntʃɹi ɹoʊdz, əɹ ivən ɡoʊɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ bæk tə ɛbu dɑɹ ən bɪɑnd. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ɑmɑdɪʃiə, ən tæɹɑbən. ɡildən, tu, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. plɛnti ʌv taʊnz ən sɪɾiz ðɛɹ, ən fɑɹ fɹəm ðɪs ʃædoʊ-kɝst spɑt.

The arguing started right away. No one wanted to cross that patch of hard-packed clay that seemingly had been paved with stone. They shouted over one another, including the horse handlers and the seamstresses, all telling Luca what had to be done, and right now. Some wanted to turn back far enough to find a country road and use those narrower ways to find their way to Lugard. Others were for forgetting Lugard altogether, for striking out for Illian by those country roads, or even going all the way back to Ebou Dar and beyond. There was always Amadicia, and Tarabon. Ghealdan, too, for that matter. Plenty of towns and cities there, and far from this Shadow-cursed spot.

mæt sæt pɪps' sæɾəl, aɪdli pleɪɪŋ wɪð ɪz ɹeɪnz, ən hɛld ɪz pis θɹu ɔl ðə ʃaʊɾɪŋ ən ɑɹm-weɪvɪŋ. ðə ɡɛldɪŋ ɡeɪv ə ʃɪvɝ naʊ ən ðɛn, bʌɾ i wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ətɛmptɪŋ tə boʊlt. tɑm keɪm stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾ ən leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn pɪps' nɛk. dʒulɪn ən æməðɛɹə wɝ kloʊs bɪhaɪnd, ʃi klɪŋɪŋ tə hɪm ən aɪɪŋ ðə ʃoʊfoʊk fɪɹfəli, ən ðən noʊl ən oʊlvɝ. ðə bɔɪ lʊkt əz ðoʊ hi wʊɾə laɪk tə klɪŋ tə sʌmwʌn fəɹ kʌmfɝt, tə ɛniwʌn, bʌɾ i wɑz oʊld ɪnʌf nɑt tə wɑn ɪt sin ɪf i dɪd. noʊl əpɪɹd tʃɹʌbəld, tu, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. hi kɛpt piɹɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹoʊd təwɔɹd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. daʊtləs baɪ ðət naɪɾ i wəd bi kleɪmɪŋ tə hæv sin sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi laɪk ðɪs bɪfɔɹ, oʊnli ɑn ə mʌtʃ ɡɹændɝ skeɪl.

Mat sat Pips' saddle, idly playing with his reins, and held his peace through all the shouting and arm-waving. The gelding gave a shiver now and then, but he was no longer attempting to bolt. Thom came striding through the crowd and laid a hand on Pips' neck. Juilin and Amathera were close behind, she clinging to him and eyeing the showfolk fearfully, and then Noal and Olver. The boy looked as though he would have liked to cling to someone for comfort, to anyone, but he was old enough not to want it seen if he did. Noal appeared troubled, too, shaking his head and muttering under his breath. He kept peering up the road toward the Aes Sedai. Doubtless by that night he would be claiming to have seen something very like this before, only on a much grander scale.

"aɪ θɪŋk wɪl bi ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn əloʊn fɹəm hɪɹ," tɑm sɛd kwaɪətli. dʒulɪn nɑɾəd ɡɹɪmli.

"I think we'll be going on alone from here," Thom said quietly. Juilin nodded grimly.

"ɪf wi mʌst," mæt ɹɪplaɪd. smɔl pɑɹɾiz wəd stæn aʊt fəɹ ðoʊz u wɝ hʌntɪŋ fəɹ tuɑn, fəɹ ðə kɪdnæpt ɛɹ tə ðə sintʃæn ɛmpaɪɝ, ɛls i wʊɾə lɛf ðə ʃoʊ lɔŋ sɪns. meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ tə seɪfti wɪθaʊt ðə ʃoʊ tə haɪɾ ɪn wəd bi mʌtʃ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs, bʌɾ ɪt kəd bi dʌn. wʌɾ i kəd nɑt də wɑz tɝn ðiz pipəlz maɪnz. wʌn ɡlæns ɪndə ɛni ʌv ðoʊz fɹaɪɾənd feɪsəz toʊld ɪm i dɪd nɑɾ əv ɪnʌf ɡoʊl fəɹ ðæt. ðəɹ maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪn ɪnʌf ɡoʊld ɪn ðə wɝld.

"If we must," Mat replied. Small parties would stand out for those who were hunting for Tuon, for the kidnapped heir to the Seanchan Empire, else he would have left the show long since. Making their way to safety without the show to hide in would be much more dangerous, but it could be done. What he could not do was turn these people's minds. One glance into any of those frightened faces told him he did not have enough gold for that. There might not have been enough gold in the world.

lukə lɪsən ɪn saɪləns, ə bɹaɪt ɹɛd kloʊk ɹæpt ɝaʊn hɪm, əntɪl moʊst ə ðə ʃoʊfoʊks ɛnɝdʒi wɑz spɛnt. wən ðɛɹ ʃaʊts bɪɡæn tə tʃɹɪkəl əweɪ, hi flʌŋ bæk ðə kloʊk ən wɔkt əmʌŋ ðɛm. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɡɹæn dʒɛstʃɝz, naʊ. hɪɹ i klæpt ə mæn ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ, ðəɹ pɪɹɾ ɝnəsli ɪndə ə wʊmənz aɪz. ðə kʌntʃɹi ɹoʊdz? ðeɪ wəd bi hæf mʌd, mɔɹ stʃɹimz ðən ɹoʊdz, fɹəm ðə spɹɪŋ ɹeɪnz. ɪt wəd teɪk twaɪs əz lɔŋ tə ɹitʃ luɡɹd ðət weɪ, θɹi taɪmz, meɪbi lɔŋɡɝ. mæt ɔlmoʊs tʃoʊk tə hɪɹ lukə ɪnvoʊk spid, bʌt ðə mæn wɑz hɑɹdli wɔɹmɪŋ ʌp. hi tɔkt ə ðə leɪbɝ ə fɹiɪŋ wæɡənz ðət bɑɡd daʊn, meɪɾ ɪz lɪsənɝz ɔl bʌt si ðɛmsɛlvz stʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə hɛlp ðə timz pʊl əm θɹu mʌd nɪɹli hʌb-dip ɑn ðə wæɡən wilz. nɑɾ ivən ə kʌntʃɹi ɹoʊd wəd ɡɛt ðət bæd, bʌɾ i meɪɾ əm si ɪt. ət list, hi meɪd mæt si ɪt. taʊnz ʌv ɛni saɪz wəd bi fju ən fɑɹ bɪtwin əlɔŋ ðoʊz bæk ɹoʊdz, ðə vɪlədʒəz taɪni fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt. fju pleɪsəz tə pɝfɔɹm, ən fud fəɹ soʊ mɛni hɑɹd tə kʌm baɪ. hi sɛd ðət waɪl smaɪlɪŋ sædli əɾ ə lɪɾəl ɡɝl ə sɪks əɹ soʊ hu wɑz piɹɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə ʃɛltɝ ə hɝ mʌðɝz skɝts, ən jə dʒʌs nu hi wɑz ɛnvɪʒənɪŋ əɹ hʌŋɡɹi ən kɹaɪɪŋ fəɹ fud. mɔɹ ðən wʌn wʊmən pʊld əɹ tʃɪlʒɹən kloʊs ɝaʊn hɝ.

Luca listened in silence, a bright red cloak wrapped around him, until most of the showfolk's energy was spent. When their shouts began to trickle away, he flung back the cloak and walked among them. There were no grand gestures, now. Here he clapped a man on the shoulder, there peered earnestly into a woman's eyes. The country roads? They would be half mud, more streams than roads, from the spring rains. It would take twice as long to reach Lugard that way, three times, maybe longer. Mat almost choked to hear Luca invoke speed, but the man was hardly warming up. He talked of the labor of freeing wagons that bogged down, made his listeners all but see themselves straining to help the teams pull them through mud nearly hub-deep on the wagon wheels. Not even a country road would get that bad, but he made them see it. At least, he made Mat see it. Towns of any size would be few and far between along those back roads, the villages tiny for the most part. Few places to perform, and food for so many hard to come by. He said that while smiling sadly at a little girl of six or so who was peering up at him from the shelter of her mother's skirts, and you just knew he was envisioning her hungry and crying for food. More than one woman pulled her children close around her.

əz fəɹ ɑmɑdɪʃiə ən tæɹɑbən, ən jɛs, ɡildən, ðeɪ wəd bi faɪn pleɪsəz tə pɝfɔɹm. vɑlən lukəz ɡɹæn tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ ən mæɡnɪfəsən dɪspleɪ ʌv mɑɹvəlz ən wʌndɝz wəd vɪzət ðoʊz lænz ən dʒɹɔ ɪmɛns kɹaʊdz. wʌn deɪ. tə ɹitʃ ɛni ʌv əm naʊ, ðeɪ mʌs fɝst ɹɪtɝn tə ɛbu dɑɹ, kʌvɝɪŋ ðə seɪm ɡɹaʊn ðeɪ hæd kɹɔs ðiz pæst wiks, pæsɪŋ ðə seɪm taʊnz, wɛɹ pipəl wɝ ənlaɪkli tə leɪ aʊt kɔɪn tə si əɡɛn wʌt ðeɪ hæd sin soʊ ʃɔɹɾ ə taɪm bɪfɔɹ. ə lɔŋ weɪ, wɪð ɛvɹiwʌnz pɝsɪz ɡɹoʊɪŋ laɪɾɝ ən ðɛɹ bɛliz taɪɾɝ baɪ ðə deɪ. ɔɹ, ðeɪ kəd pɹɛs ɑn tə luɡɹd.

As for Amadicia and Tarabon, and yes, Ghealdan, they would be fine places to perform. Valan Luca's Grand Traveling Show and Magnificent Display of Marvels and Wonders would visit those lands and draw immense crowds. One day. To reach any of them now, they must first return to Ebou Dar, covering the same ground they had crossed these past weeks, passing the same towns, where people were unlikely to lay out coin to see again what they had seen so short a time before. A long way, with everyone's purses growing lighter and their bellies tighter by the day. Or, they could press on to Lugard.

hɪɹ ɪz vɔɪs bɪɡæn tə teɪk ɑn ɛnɝdʒi. hi dʒɛstʃɝd, bʌt sɪmpli. hi stɪl muvd əmʌŋ ðɛm, bʌt stɛpɪŋ mɔɹ kwɪkli. luɡɹd wɑz ə ɡɹæn sɪɾi. ɛbu dɑɹ wɑz ə ʃædoʊ bɪsaɪd luɡɹd. luɡɹd tʃɹuli wɑz wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz, soʊ pɑpjələs ðeɪ maɪt pɝfɔɹm ðəɹ ɔl spɹɪŋ ən ɔlweɪz əv nu kɹaʊdz. mæt hæd nɛvɝ bɪn tə luɡɹd, bʌɾ i hæd hɝɾ ɪt wɑz hæf ə ɹuən, wɪð ə kɪŋ u kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə kip ðə stʃɹits klin, jɛt lukə meɪɾ ɪt saʊn əkɪn tə keɪɛmlɪn. ʃʊɹli səm ə ðiz pipəl hæd sin ðə pleɪs, bʌt ðeɪ lɪsənd wɪð ɹæp feɪsəz əz i dɪskɹaɪb pæləsəz ðət meɪd ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ sim ə hʌvəl, tɔkt ə ðə sɪlk-klæd noʊbəlz baɪ ðə skɔɹ u wəd kʌm tə si ðɛm pɝfɔɹm əɹ ivən kəmɪʃən pɹaɪvət pɝfɔɹmənsəz. ʃʊɹli kɪŋ ɹɔdʒɹən wəd wɑn sʌtʃ. hæɾ ɛni ʌv əm ɛvɝ pɝfɔɹm bɪfɔɹ ə kɪŋ bɪfɔɹ? ðeɪ wʊd. ðeɪ wʊd. fɹəm luɡɹd, tə keɪɛmlɪn, ə sɪɾi ðət meɪd luɡɹd lʊk ən ɪməteɪʃən ʌv ə sɪɾi. keɪɛmlɪn, wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒəst ən wɛlθiəst sɪɾiz ɪn ðə wɝld, wɛɹ ðeɪ maɪt pɝfɔɹm ðə hoʊl sʌmɝ tə nɛvɝ-ɛndɪŋ θɹɔŋz.

Here his voice began to take on energy. He gestured, but simply. He still moved among them, but stepping more quickly. Lugard was a grand city. Ebou Dar was a shadow beside Lugard. Lugard truly was one of the great cities, so populous they might perform there all spring and always have new crowds. Mat had never been to Lugard, but he had heard it was half a ruin, with a king who could not afford to keep the streets clean, yet Luca made it sound akin to Caemlyn. Surely some of these people had seen the place, but they listened with rapt faces as he described palaces that made the Tarasin Palace in Ebou Dar seem a hovel, talked of the silk-clad nobles by the score who would come to see them perform or even commission private performances. Surely King Roedran would want such. Had any of them ever performed before a king before? They would. They would. From Lugard, to Caemlyn, a city that made Lugard look an imitation of a city. Caemlyn, one of the largest and wealthiest cities in the world, where they might perform the whole summer to never-ending throngs.

"aɪ ʃəd laɪk tə si ðiz sɪɾiz," tuɑn sɛd, muvɪŋ əkaɪn nɪɹɝ tə pɪps. "wɪl jə ʃoʊ ðɛm tə mi, tɔɪ?" sɪlutʃə kɛp ðə dʌn ət tuɑnz hɪp. ðə wʊmən lʊkt kəmpoʊzd ɪnʌf, bʌt daʊtləs ʃi wɑz ʃeɪkən baɪ wʌt ʃi hæd sin.

"I should like to see these cities," Tuon said, moving Akein nearer to Pips. "Will you show them to me, Toy?" Selucia kept the dun at Tuon's hip. The woman looked composed enough, but doubtless she was shaken by what she had seen.

"luɡɹd, meɪbi. fɹəm ðəɹ aɪ kən faɪn ə weɪ tə sɛn jə bæk tə ɛbu dɑɹ." wɪð ə wɛl-ɡɑɹɾəd mɝtʃəns tʃɹeɪn ən əz mɛni ɹɪlaɪəbəl bɑɾiɡɑɹdz əz i kəd haɪɝ. tuɑn maɪt bi əz keɪpəbəl ən deɪnʒɝəs əz ɛdʒiənɪn meɪɾ aʊt, bʌt tu wɪmən əloʊn wəd bi sin əz izi pɹeɪ baɪ tu mɛni, ən nɑt dʒʌs bɹɪɡænz. "meɪbi keɪɛmlɪn." hi maɪt nid mɔɹ taɪm ðən fɹəm hɪɹ tə luɡɹd, æftɝ ɔl.

"Lugard, maybe. From there I can find a way to send you back to Ebou Dar." With a well-guarded merchant's train and as many reliable bodyguards as he could hire. Tuon might be as capable and dangerous as Egeanin made out, but two women alone would be seen as easy prey by too many, and not just brigands. "Maybe Caemlyn." He might need more time than from here to Lugard, after all.

"wi ʃæl si wʌt wi ʃæl si," tuɑn ɹɪplaɪd kɹɪptɪkli, ðən bɪɡæn ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ fɪŋɡɝ-ɹɪəlz wɪð sɪlutʃə.

"We shall see what we shall see," Tuon replied cryptically, then began exchanging finger-wriggles with Selucia.

tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt mi bɪhaɪn maɪ bæk, oʊnli duɪŋ ɪt ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ maɪ noʊz. hi heɪɾəd ɪt wən ðeɪ dɪd ðæt. "lukəz əz ɡʊɾ əz ə ɡlimən, tɑm, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk hiz gɑnə sweɪ ðɛm."

Talking about me behind my back, only doing it right under my nose. He hated it when they did that. "Luca's as good as a gleeman, Thom, but I don't think he's going to sway them."

tɑm snɔɹɾɪd dɝɪsɪvli ən nʌkəld ɪz lɔŋ waɪt mʌstæʃɪz. "hiz nɑt bæd, əl ɡɹæn ɪm ðæt, bʌt hiz noʊ ɡlimən. stɪl, hiz kɑt ðɛm, aɪd seɪ. ə weɪdʒɝ ɑn ɪt, maɪ bɔɪ? seɪ wʌn ɡoʊl kɹaʊn?"

Thom snorted derisively and knuckled his long white mustaches. "He's not bad, I'll grant him that, but he's no gleeman. Still, he's caught them, I'd say. A wager on it, my boy? Say one gold crown?"

mæt sɝpɹaɪz hɪmsɛlf baɪ læfɪŋ. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ i wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə læf əɡɛn əntɪl i kəd ɹɪɾ ɪz hɛɾ ə ði ɪmədʒ ə ðət pɛdlɝ sɪŋkɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹoʊd. ən ðə hɔɹsəz. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪɹ əm skɹimɪŋ stɪl, laʊdli ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɪt keɪm nɪɹ tə dʒɹaʊnɪŋ aʊt ðə daɪs. "ju wɑnə weɪdʒɝ wɪð mi? vɛɹi wɛl. dʌn."

Mat surprised himself by laughing. He had been sure he would not be able to laugh again until he could rid his head of the image of that peddler sinking into the road. And the horses. He could almost hear them screaming still, loudly enough that it came near to drowning out the dice. "You want to wager with me? Very well. Done."

"aɪ wʊdn pleɪ ət daɪs wɪð ju," tɑm sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "bʌɾ aɪ noʊ ə mæn tɝnɪŋ ə kɹaʊdz hɛd wɪð wɝdz wən aɪ si ɪt. aɪv dʌn əz mʌtʃ maɪsɛlf."

"I wouldn't play at dice with you," Thom said dryly, "but I know a man turning a crowd's head with words when I see it. I've done as much myself."

fɪnɪʃɪŋ wɪð keɪɛmlɪn, lukə ɡæðɝd hɪmsɛlf wɪð ə spɑɹk ə hɪz juʒəwəl ɡɹændiɑsəɾi. ðə mæn stʃɹʌɾɪd. "æn fɹəm ðɛɹ," hi ənaʊnst, "tə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪtsɛlf. əl haɪɝ ʃɪps tə kæɹi əs ɔl." mæt dɪd tʃoʊk ət ðæt. lukə wəd haɪɝ ʃɪps? lukə, hu wɑz taɪɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹɛndɝ maɪs fəɹ tæloʊ? "sʌtʃ kɹaʊdz wɪl kʌm ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn ðət wi kəd spɛn ðə ɹɛst ʌv əɹ laɪvz ɪn ðət væst sɪɾiz splɛndɝ, wɛɹ oʊɡiɝ-bɪlt ʃɑps sim laɪk pæləsəz ən pæləsəz ɑɹ bɪɑn dɪskɹɪpʃən. ɹulɝz siɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm wip ðət ðɛɹ sɪɾiz ɑɹ vɪlədʒəz ən ðɛɹ oʊn pæləsəz noʊ mɔɹ ðən pɛzəns hʌts. ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf ɪz ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst stʃɹʌktʃɝ ɪn ðə wɝld. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hɝsɛlf wɪl æsk əs tə pɝfɔɹm bɪfɔɹ hɝ. wɪv ɡɪvən ʃɛltɝ tə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn nid. hu kən bɪliv ðəl də ʌðɝ ðən spik fəɹ əs wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit?"

Finishing with Caemlyn, Luca gathered himself with a spark of his usual grandiosity. The man strutted. "And from there," he announced, "to Tar Valon itself. I will hire ships to carry us all." Mat did choke at that. Luca would hire ships? Luca, who was tight enough to render mice for tallow? "Such crowds will come in Tar Valon that we could spend the rest of our lives in that vast city's splendor, where Ogier-built shops seem like palaces and palaces are beyond description. Rulers seeing Tar Valon for the first time weep that their cities are villages and their own palaces no more than peasant's huts. The White Tower itself is in Tar Valon, remember, the greatest structure in the world. The Amyrlin Seat herself will ask us to perform before her. We have given shelter to three Aes Sedai in need. Who can believe they will do other than speak for us with the Amyrlin Seat?"

mæt lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən faʊn ðə θɹi sɪstɝz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɑndɝɪŋ əbaʊt ðə mɛdoʊ wɛɹ ðə vɪlədʒ hæd vænɪʃt. ɪnstɛd, ðeɪ stʊd saɪd baɪ saɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹoʊd wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, pɝfəkt ɪmədʒəz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi. noʊ, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, hi ɹilaɪzd. ðeɪ wɝ stʌɾiɪŋ tuɑn. ðə θɹi hæɾ əɡɹid nɑt tə bɑðɝ əɹ ɛnimɔɹ, ən biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɝ baʊn baɪ ðæt, bʌt haʊ fɑɹ dɪɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪz wɝɾ ɛvɝ ɡoʊ? ðeɪ faʊnd weɪz ɝaʊn ði oʊθ əɡɛns laɪɪŋ ɔl ðə taɪm. soʊ tuɑn wəd nɑt ɡɛt tə si keɪɛmlɪn, ən pɝhæps nɑt luɡɹd. tʃænsəz wɝ, ðəɹ wəd bi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn boʊθ sɪɾiz. wʌɾ iziɝ fəɹ dʒoʊlin ən ði ʌðɝz ðən tə ɪnfɔɹm ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ ðət tuɑn wɑz ə sintʃæn haɪ leɪɾi? ɪn ɔl laɪklihʊd, tuɑn wəd bi ɑn əɹ weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn bɪfɔɹ i kəd blɪŋk. əz ə "ɡɛst," ʌv kɔɹs, tə hɛlp stɑp ðə faɪɾɪŋ. noʊ daʊt mɛni wəd seɪ ðət wəd bi fəɹ ðə ɡʊd, ðəɾ i ʃəd hæn əɹ oʊvɝ hɪmsɛlf ən tɛl əm u ʃi ɹɪli wɑz, bʌɾ i hæd ɡɪvən ɪz wɝd. hi bɪɡæn tə kælkjəleɪt haʊ nɪɹ tə luɡɹɾ i dɛɹd weɪt bɪfɔɹ faɪndɪŋ əɹ pæsədʒ bæk tə ɛbu dɑɹ.

Mat looked over his shoulder, and found the three sisters no longer wandering about the meadow where the village had vanished. Instead, they stood side by side in the road watching him, perfect images of Aes Sedai serenity. No, they were not watching him, he realized. They were studying Tuon. The three had agreed not to bother her anymore, and being Aes Sedai, were bound by that, but how far did an Aes Sedai's word ever go? They found ways around the Oath against lying all the time. So Tuon would not get to see Caemlyn, and perhaps not Lugard. Chances were, there would be Aes Sedai in both cities. What easier for Joline and the others than to inform those Aes Sedai that Tuon was a Seanchan High Lady? In all likelihood, Tuon would be on her way to Tar Valon before he could blink. As a "guest," of course, to help stop the fighting. No doubt many would say that would be for the good, that he should hand her over himself and tell them who she really was, but he had given his word. He began to calculate how near to Lugard he dared wait before finding her passage back to Ebou Dar.

lukə hæd hæɾ ə dɪfəkəl taɪm meɪkɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn saʊnd ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən keɪɛmlɪn æftɝ ɪz spil ɑn ðət sɪɾi, ən ɪf ðeɪ ɛvɝ ɹitʃt tɑɹ vəlɑn, səm maɪɾ æktʃəli  bi dɪsəpɔɪntɪd kəmpɛɹɪŋ ɪz mæd dɪskɹɪpʃənz - ðə waɪt taʊɝ ə θaʊzən peɪsɪz haɪ? oʊɡiɝ-bɪl pæləsəz ðə saɪz ə smɔl maʊntənz? hi kleɪm ðəɹ wɑz ən oʊɡiɝ stɛɾɪŋ æktʃəli  ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi! - bʌt faɪnəli hi kɔl fəɹ ə ʃoʊ ʌv hænz ɪn feɪvɝ ə pɹɛsɪŋ ɑn. ɛvɹi hænd ʃɑɾ ʌp, ivən ðə tʃɪlʒɹənz hænz, ən ðeɪ hæd noʊ voʊt.

Luca had had a difficult time making Tar Valon sound greater than Caemlyn after his spiel on that city, and if they ever reached Tar Valon, some might actually be disappointed comparing his mad descriptions - the White Tower a thousand paces high? Ogier-built palaces the size of small mountains? he claimed there was an Ogier stedding actually inside the city! - but finally he called for a show of hands in favor of pressing on. Every hand shot up, even the children's hands, and they had no vote.

mæt pʊld ə pɝs fɹəm ɪz koʊt pɑkəɾ ən hændəɾ oʊvɝ ən ɛbu dɑɹi kɹaʊn. "aɪ nɛvɝ ɛndʒɔɪd luzɪŋ mɔɹ, tɑm." wɛl, hi nɛvɝ ɛndʒɔɪd luzɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪn ðɪs ɪnstəns ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən wɪnɪŋ.

Mat pulled a purse from his coat pocket and handed over an Ebou Dari crown. "I never enjoyed losing more, Thom." Well, he never enjoyed losing, but in this instance it was better than winning.

tɑm æksɛptɪd wɪð ə smɔl baʊ. "aɪ θɪŋk əl kip ðɪs əz ə mɪmɛntoʊ," hi sɛd, ɹoʊlɪŋ ðə fæt ɡoʊl kɔɪn əkɹɔs ðə bæk ə hɪz fɪŋɡɝz. "tə ɹimaɪn mi ðəɾ ivən ðə ləkis mæn ɪn ðə wɝl kən luz."

Thom accepted with a small bow. "I think I'll keep this as a memento," he said, rolling the fat gold coin across the back of his fingers. "To remind me that even the luckiest man in the world can lose."

fəɹ ɔl ə ðə ʃoʊ ʌv hænz, ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃædoʊ ʌv ɹɪlʌktəns tə kɹɔs ðət pætʃ ə ɹoʊɾ əhɛd. æftɝ lukə ɡɑɾ ɪz wæɡən bæk ɑntu ðə ɹoʊd, hi sæt stɛɹɪŋ, wɪð lətɛl klɪŋɪŋ tə hɪz ɑɹm əz hɑɹɾ əz æməðɛɹə ɛvɝ klʌŋ tə dʒulɪn. faɪnəli, hi mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ən oʊθ ən wɪpt ɪz tim ʌp wɪð ðə ɹeɪnz. baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə feɪɾəl stʃɹɛtʃ, ðeɪ wɝ əɾ ə ɡæləp, ən lukə kɛpt əm ðəɹ əntɪl wɛl bɪɑnd wɛɹ ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz hæd bɪn. ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm wɪð ɛvɹi wæɡən. ə pɔz, weɪɾɪŋ əntɪl ðə wæɡən əhɛd wɑz klɪɹ, ðən ə fleɪlɪŋ ə ɹeɪnz ən ə hɑɹd ɡæləp. mæt hɪmsɛlf dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ bɪfɔɹ hilɪŋ pɪps fɔɹwɝd. əɾ ə wɔk, nɑɾ ə ɡæləp, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd nɑt tə dɪɡ hɪz hilz ɪn, ɪspɛʃli wən pæsɪŋ ðə pɛdlɝz hæt. tuɑnz dɑɹk feɪs ən sɪlutʃəz peɪl dɪspleɪd noʊ mɔɹ ɪmoʊʃən ðən ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪsəz dɪd.

For all of the show of hands, there was a shadow of reluctance to cross that patch of road ahead. After Luca got his wagon back onto the road, he sat staring, with Latelle clinging to his arm as hard as Amathera ever clung to Juilin. Finally, he muttered something that might have been an oath and whipped his team up with the reins. By the time they reached the fatal stretch, they were at a gallop, and Luca kept them there until well beyond where the paving stones had been. It was the same with every wagon. A pause, waiting until the wagon ahead was clear, then a flailing of reins and a hard gallop. Mat himself drew a deep breath before heeling Pips forward. At a walk, not a gallop, but it was hard not to dig his heels in, especially when passing the peddler's hat. Tuon's dark face and Selucia's pale displayed no more emotion than Aes Sedai's faces did.

"aɪ wɪl si tɑɹ vəlɑn wʌn deɪ," tuɑn sɛd kɑmli ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðæt. "aɪ ʃæl pɹɑbli meɪk ɪt maɪ kæpəɾəl. aɪ ʃæl əv jə ʃoʊ mi ðə sɪɾi, tɔɪ. juv bɪn ðɛɹ?"

"I will see Tar Valon one day," Tuon said calmly in the middle of that. "I shall probably make it my capital. I shall have you show me the city, Toy. You have been there?"

laɪt! ʃi wɑz ə tʌf lɪɾəl wʊmən. ɡɔɹdʒəs, bʌt dɛfənətli tʌf əz neɪlz.

Light! She was a tough little woman. Gorgeous, but definitely tough as nails.

æftɝ sloʊɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ɡæləp, lukə sɛt ðə peɪs əɾ ə fæst wɔk ɹæðɝ ðən ðə ʃoʊz juʒəwəl æmbəl. ðə sʌn slɪd loʊɝ, ən ðeɪ pæst sɛvɹəl ɹoʊdsaɪd mɛdoʊz səfɪʃənli lɑɹdʒ tə hoʊl ðə ʃoʊ, bʌt lukə pɹɛst ɑn əntɪl ðɛɹ ʃædoʊz stʃɹɛtʃt lɔŋ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm ən ðə sʌn wɑz ə fæt ɹɛd bɔl ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən. ivən ðən i sæt hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz ən piɹɪŋ əɾ ə ɡɹæsi ɪkspæns bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd.

After slowing from his gallop, Luca set the pace at a fast walk rather than the show's usual amble. The sun slid lower, and they passed several roadside meadows sufficiently large to hold the show, but Luca pressed on until their shadows stretched long ahead of them and the sun was a fat red ball on the horizon. Even then he sat holding the reins and peering at a grassy expanse beside the road.

"ɪts dʒʌst ə fild," hi sɛɾ ət læst, tu laʊdli, ən tɝn ɪz tim təwɔɹɾ ɪt.

"It's just a field," he said at last, too loudly, and turned his team toward it.

mæt əkʌmpənid tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə tə ðə pɝpəl wæɡən wʌns ðə hɔɹsəz hæd bɪn hændəɾ oʊvɝ tə mɛtwɪn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz tə bi noʊ mil əɹ ɡeɪmz ə stoʊnz wɪð əɹ ðət naɪt.

Mat accompanied Tuon and Selucia to the purple wagon once the horses had been handed over to Metwyn, but there was to be no meal or games of stones with her that night.

"ðɪs ɪz ə naɪt fəɹ pɹɛɹ," ʃi toʊld ɪm bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn wɪð əɹ meɪd. "du jə noʊ nʌθɪŋ, tɔɪ? ðə dɛd wɔkɪŋ ɪz ə saɪn ðət tɑɹmən ɡdən ɪz nɪɹ." hi dɪd nɑt teɪk ðɪs fəɹ wʌn ə hɝ supɝstɪʃənz; æftɝ ɔl, hi hæd θɔt sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi laɪk ðət hɪmsɛlf. hi wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ fəɹ pɹeɪɪŋ, jɛɾ i ɔfɝɾ ə smɔl wʌn ðən ən ðɛɹ. səmtaɪmz ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls tə du.

"This is a night for prayer," she told him before going in with her maid. "Do you know nothing, Toy? The dead walking is a sign that Tarmon Gai'don is near." He did not take this for one of her superstitions; after all, he had thought something very like that himself. He was not much for praying, yet he offered a small one then and there. Sometimes there was nothing else to do.

noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə slip, soʊ læmps bɝn leɪt θɹuaʊt ðə kæmp. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə bi əloʊn, iðɝ. mæt eɪt baɪ hɪmsɛlf ɪn ɪz tɛnt, wɪð lɪɾəl æpətaɪɾ ən ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd saʊndɪŋ laʊɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ, bʌt tɑm keɪm tə pleɪ stoʊnz dʒʌst əz i fɪnɪʃt, ən noʊl sun æftɝ. ləpɪn ən nɹɪm pɑpt ɪn ɛvɹi fju mɪnəts, boʊɪŋ ən ɪnkwaɪɝɪŋ wɛðɝ mæt əɹ ði ʌðɝz wɑntəɾ ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt wʌns ðeɪ fɛtʃt waɪn ən kʌps - ləpɪn kæɹid ðə tɔl pɑɾɝi dʒɑɹ ən bɹoʊk ðə wæks sil; nɹɪm kæɹid ðə kʌps ɑn ə wʊɾən tʃɹeɪ - mæt toʊld əm tə faɪn hɑɹnən ən ði ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝz.

No one wanted to sleep, so lamps burned late throughout the camp. No one wanted to be alone, either. Mat ate by himself in his tent, with little appetite and the dice in his head sounding louder than ever, but Thom came to play stones just as he finished, and Noal soon after. Lopin and Nerim popped in every few minutes, bowing and inquiring whether Mat or the others wanted anything, but once they fetched wine and cups - Lopin carried the tall pottery jar and broke the wax seal; Nerim carried the cups on a wooden tray - Mat told them to find Harnan and the other soldiers.

"aɪ doʊn daʊt ðəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ dʒɹʌŋk, wɪtʃ simz ə ɡʊd noʊʃən tə mi," hi sɛd. "ðæts ən ɔɹɾɝ. jə tɛl əm aɪ sɛd tə ʃɛɹ."

"I don't doubt they're getting drunk, which seems a good notion to me," he said. "That's an order. You tell them I said to share."

ləpɪn baʊd ɡɹeɪvli oʊvɝ ɪz ɹaʊn bɛli. "aɪ hæv əsɪstəd ðə faɪl liɾɝ naʊ ən əɡɛn baɪ pɹoʊkjʊɹɪŋ ə fju aɪɾəmz fəɹ hɪm, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ ɪkspɛk hɪl bi dʒɛnɝəs wɪð ðə bɹændi. kʌm əlɔŋ, nɹɪm. lɔɹd mæt wɑns əs tə ɡɛt dʒɹʌŋk, ən jə ɑɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ dʒɹʌŋk wɪð mi ɪf aɪ hæv tə sɪɾ ɑn jə ən pɔɹ bɹændi daʊn jəɹ θɹoʊt." ði əbstimiəs kɛɹhinɪnz nɛɹoʊ feɪs ɡɹu pɪntʃt wɪð dɪsəpɹuvəl, bʌɾ i baʊɾ ən fɑloʊd ðə tɛɹən aʊt wɪð əlækɹəɾi. mæt dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ləpɪn wəd nid tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə mæn, nɑt tənaɪt.

Lopin bowed gravely over his round belly. "I have assisted the file leader now and again by procuring a few items for him, my Lord. I expect he will be generous with the brandy. Come along, Nerim. Lord Mat wants us to get drunk, and you are getting drunk with me if I have to sit on you and pour brandy down your throat." The abstemious Cairhienin's narrow face grew pinched with disapproval, but he bowed and followed the Tairen out with alacrity. Mat did not think Lopin would need to sit on the man, not tonight.

dʒulɪn keɪm wɪð æməðɛɹə ən oʊlvɝ, soʊ ɡeɪmz ə sneɪks ən fɑksəz, pleɪd spɹɔld ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd-klɔθ, wɝ æɾəd tə stoʊnz pleɪɾ ət ðə smɔl teɪbəl. æməðɛɹə pɹuvd ən æɾəkwət pleɪɝ ət stoʊnz, ənsɝpɹaɪzɪŋ ɡɪvən ðət ʃi hæd bɪn ə ɹulɝ wʌns, bʌɾ əɹ maʊθ bɪkeɪm ivən mɔɹ paʊɾi wən ʃi ən oʊlvɝ lɔst ət sneɪks ən fɑksəz, ɔlðoʊ noʊbɑdi ɛvɝ wʌn ðət ɡeɪm. ðən əɡɛn, mæt səspɛktəd ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ə vɛɹi ɡʊd ɹulɝ. huɛvɝ wɑz nɑt pleɪɪŋ sæɾ ɑn ðə kɑt. mæt wɑtʃt ðə ɡeɪmz wən ɪt wɑz ɪz tɝn ðɛɹ, əz dɪd dʒulɪn ɪf æməðɛɹə wɑz pleɪɪŋ. hi sɛldəm tʊk ɪz aɪz fɹəm əɹ ɪksɛpt wən ɪt wɑz ɪz tɝn əɾ ə ɡeɪm. noʊl næɾɝd ɑn wɪð ɪz stɔɹiz - bʌt ðɛn, hi spʌn ðoʊz teɪlz ivən waɪl pleɪɪŋ, ən tɔkɪŋ sim tə hæv noʊ ɪfɛkt ɑn ɪz skɪl ət stoʊnz - ən tɑm sæt ɹiɾɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ mæt hæd bɹɔɾ ɪm wʌt simd ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ. ðə peɪdʒ wɑz hɛvəli kɹis fɹəm biɪŋ kæɹiɾ ɪn tɑmz koʊt pɑkəɾ ən mʌtʃ smʌdʒ fɹəm biɪŋ ɹɛɾ ən ɹeɪ-ɹɛd. hi hæd sɛɾ ɪt wɑz fɹəm ə dɛd wʊmən.

Juilin came with Amathera and Olver, so games of Snakes and Foxes, played sprawled on the ground-cloth, were added to stones played at the small table. Amathera proved an adequate player at stones, unsurprising given that she had been a ruler once, but her mouth became even more pouty when she and Olver lost at Snakes and Foxes, although nobody ever won that game. Then again, Mat suspected she had not been a very good ruler. Whoever was not playing sat on the cot. Mat watched the games when it was his turn there, as did Juilin if Amathera was playing. He seldom took his eyes from her except when it was his turn at a game. Noal nattered on with his stories - but then, he spun those tales even while playing, and talking seemed to have no effect on his skill at stones - and Thom sat reading the letter Mat had brought him what seemed a very long time ago. The page was heavily creased from being carried in Thom's coat pocket and much smudged from being read and re-read. He had said it was from a dead woman.

ɪt wɑz ə sɝpɹaɪz wən doʊmən ən ɛdʒiənɪn dʌk θɹu ði ɛntʃɹi flæps. ðeɪ hæd nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli bɪn əvɔɪɾɪŋ mæt sɪns i muvd aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹin wæɡən, bʌt niðɝ hæd ðeɪ ɡɔn aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ weɪ tə sik ɪm aʊt. laɪk ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, ðeɪ wɝ ɪn bɛɾɝ kloʊðz ðən ðeɪ hæd wɔɹn fəɹ dɪsɡaɪzɪz ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ɛdʒiənɪnz dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ən haɪ-kɑlɝd koʊt, boʊθ ə blu wʊl ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ə jɛloʊ nɪɹ tə ɡoʊld ɑn ðə hɛm ən kʌfs, hæd sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə junəfɔɹm əbaʊt ðɛm, waɪl doʊmən, ɪn ə wɛl-kʌt bɹaʊn koʊɾ ən bæɡi tʃɹaʊzɝz stʌft ɪndə tɝnd-daʊn buts dʒʌs bɪloʊ hɪz niz, lʊkt ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ðə pɹɑspɝəs, ɪf nɑɾ ɪɡzækli wɛlθi, ɪliɑnɝ mɝtʃənt.

It was a surprise when Domon and Egeanin ducked through the entry flaps. They had not precisely been avoiding Mat since he moved out of the green wagon, but neither had they gone out of their way to seek him out. Like everyone else, they were in better clothes than they had worn for disguises in the beginning. Egeanin's divided skirts and high-collared coat, both of blue wool and embroidered in a yellow near to gold on the hem and cuffs, had something of a uniform about them, while Domon, in a well-cut brown coat and baggy trousers stuffed into turned-down boots just below his knees, looked every inch the prosperous, if not exactly wealthy, Illianer merchant.

əz sun əz ɛdʒiənɪn ɛntɝd, æməðɛɹə, hu wɑz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd-klɔθ wɪð oʊlvɝ, kɝl hɝsɛlf ɪndə ə bɔl ɑn əɹ niz. dʒulɪn saɪɾ ən ɡɑɾ ʌp fɹəm ðə stul əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl fɹəm mæt, bʌɾ ɛdʒiənɪn ɹitʃt ði ʌðɝ wʊmən fɝst.

As soon as Egeanin entered, Amathera, who was on the ground-cloth with Olver, curled herself into a ball on her knees. Juilin sighed and got up from the stool across the table from Mat, but Egeanin reached the other woman first.

"ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ ðæt, wɪð mi əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls," ʃi dʒɹɔld, bɛndɪŋ tə teɪk æməðɛɹə baɪ ðə ʃoʊldɝz ən dʒɹɔ hɝ tə hɝ fit. æməðɛɹə ɹoʊz sloʊli, hɛzɪɾəntli, ən kɛpt əɹ aɪz daʊn əntɪl ɛdʒiənɪn pʊɾ ə hæn bɪniθ əɹ tʃɪn ən ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd dʒɛnli. "ju lʊk mi ɪn ði aɪz. jə lʊk ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ði aɪz." ðə tæɹɑbənɝ wʊmən tʌtʃt əɹ tʌŋ tə hɝ lɪps nɝvəsli, bʌt ʃi dɪd kip lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əɾ ɛdʒiənɪnz feɪs wən ðə hænd wɑz ɹimuv fɹəm əɹ tʃɪn. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, hɝ aɪz wɝ vɛɹi waɪd.

"There's no need for that, with me or anyone else," she drawled, bending to take Amathera by the shoulders and draw her to her feet. Amathera rose slowly, hesitantly, and kept her eyes down until Egeanin put a hand beneath her chin and raised her head gently. "You look me in the eyes. You look everyone in the eyes." The Taraboner woman touched her tongue to her lips nervously, but she did keep looking straight at Egeanin's face when the hand was removed from her chin. On the other hand, her eyes were very wide.

"ðɪs ɪz ə tʃeɪnʒ," dʒulɪn sɛd səspɪʃəsli. ən wɪð ə tʌtʃ ʌv æŋɡɝ. hi stʊd stɪf əz ə stætʃu kɑɹv fɹəm dɑɹk wʊd. hi dɪslaɪkt ɛni sintʃæn, fəɹ wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn tə æməðɛɹə. "juv kɔl mi ə θif fəɹ fɹiɪŋ hɝ." ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə tʌtʃ ʌv æŋɡɝ ɪn ðæt. hi heɪɾəd θivz. ən smʌɡəlɝz, wɪtʃ doʊmən wɑz.

"This is a change," Juilin said suspiciously. And with a touch of anger. He stood stiff as a statue carved from dark wood. He disliked any Seanchan, for what they had done to Amathera. "You've called me a thief for freeing her." There was more than a touch of anger in that. He hated thieves. And smugglers, which Domon was.

"ɔl θɪŋz tʃeɪnʒ ɡɪvən taɪm," doʊmən sɛd dʒoʊviəli, smaɪlɪŋ tə hɛɾ ɔf mɔɹ hiɾəd wɝdz. "waɪ, jə də bi lʊkɪŋ əɾ ən ɑnəs mæn, mæstɝ θif-kætʃɝ. laɪlwɪn dɪd meɪk mi pɹɑməs tə ɡɪv ʌp smʌɡəlɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi wəɾ əɡɹi tə mɛɹi mi. fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, hu dɪɾ ɛvɝ hɪɹ ʌv ə wʊmən ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə mɛɹi ə mæn ənlɛs i dɪd ɡɪv ʌp ə lukɹəɾɪv tʃɹeɪd?" hi læft əz ðoʊ ðət wɝ ðə fʌniəs dʒoʊk ɪn ðə wɝld.

"All things change given time," Domon said jovially, smiling to head off more heated words. "Why, you do be looking at an honest man, Master Thief-catcher. Leilwin did make me promise to give up smuggling before she would agree to marry me. Fortune prick me, who did ever hear of a woman refusing to marry a man unless he did give up a lucrative trade?" He laughed as though that were the funniest joke in the world.

ɛdʒiənɪn fɪstɪɾ ɪm ɪn ðə ɹɪbz hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪz læftɝ tə ə ɡɹʌnt. mɛɹid tə hɝ, hɪz ɹɪbz mʌs bi ə mæs ə bɹuzəz. "aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə kip ðət pɹɑməs, beɪl. aɪm tʃeɪnʒɪŋ, ən soʊ mʌs ju." aɪɪŋ æməðɛɹə bɹifli - pɝhæps tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz stɪl oʊbeɪɪŋ; ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz bɪɡ ɑn ʌðɝz duɪŋ əz ʃi toʊld əm - ʃi stʌk aʊɾ ə hæn təwɔɹd dʒulɪn. "aɪ æm tʃeɪnʒɪŋ, mæstɝ sændɑɹ. wɪl ju?"

Egeanin fisted him in the ribs hard enough to change his laughter to a grunt. Married to her, his ribs must be a mass of bruises. "I expect you to keep that promise, Bayle. I am changing, and so must you." Eyeing Amathera briefly - perhaps to make sure she was still obeying; Egeanin was big on others doing as she told them - she stuck out a hand toward Juilin. "I am changing, Master Sandar. Will you?"

dʒulɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən klæspt əɹ hænd. "aɪl meɪk ə tʃɹaɪ əɾ ɪt." hi saʊndəd daʊtfəl.

Juilin hesitated, then clasped her hand. "I'll make a try at it." He sounded doubtful.

"æn ɑnəs tʃɹaɪ ɪz ɔl aɪ æsk." fɹaʊnɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə tɛnt, ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪv sin ɔɹləp dɛks lɛs kɹaʊɾəd ðən ðɪs. wɪv səm disənt waɪn ɪn əɹ wæɡən, mæstɝ sændɑɹ. wɪl jə ən jəɹ leɪɾi dʒɔɪn əs ɪn ə kʌp əɹ tu?"

"An honest try is all I ask." Frowning around the tent, she shook her head. "I've seen orlop decks less crowded than this. We have some decent wine in our wagon, Master Sandar. Will you and your lady join us in a cup or two?"

əɡɛn dʒulɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "hi hæz ðɪs ɡeɪm ɔl bʌt wʌn," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "noʊ pɔɪn ɪn pleɪɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt." klæpɪŋ ɪz kɑnɪkəl ɹɛd hæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd, hi ədʒʌstəɾ ɪz dɑɹk, flɛɹɪŋ tɛɹən koʊɾ ənnɛsəsɛɹəli, ən ɔfɝɾ ɪz ɑɹm tə æməðɛɹə fɔɹməli. ʃi klæspt ɪt taɪtli, ən ðoʊ hɝ aɪz wɝ stɪl ɑn ɛdʒiənɪnz feɪs, ʃi tʃɹɛmbəl vɪzəbli. "aɪ ɪkspɛkt oʊlvɝ wɪl wɑnə steɪ hɪɹ ən pleɪ hɪz ɡeɪm, bʌt maɪ leɪɾi ən əl bi pliz tə ʃɛɹ waɪn wɪð jə ən jəɹ hʌzbənd, mɪstʃɹəs ʃɪpləs." ðəɹ wɑz ə hɪn ə tʃælənʒ ɪn ɪz ɡeɪz. ɪt wɑz klɪɹ ðət tə hɪm, ɛdʒiənɪn hæd fɝðɝ tə ɡoʊ tə pɹuv ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɔ æməðɛɹə əz stoʊlən pɹɑpɝɾi.

Again Juilin hesitated. "He has this game all but won," he said finally. "No point in playing it out." Clapping his conical red hat on his head, he adjusted his dark, flaring Tairen coat unnecessarily, and offered his arm to Amathera formally. She clasped it tightly, and though her eyes were still on Egeanin's face, she trembled visibly. "I expect Olver will want to stay here and play his game, but my lady and I will be pleased to share wine with you and your husband, Mistress Shipless." There was a hint of challenge in his gaze. It was clear that to him, Egeanin had further to go to prove she no longer saw Amathera as stolen property.

ɛdʒiənɪn nɑɾəd əz ɪf ʃi ʌndɝstʊd pɝfəkli. "ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn jə tənaɪt, ən fəɹ əz mɛni deɪz ən naɪts əz wɪv ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ," ʃi sɛd baɪ weɪ ʌv fɛɹwɛl tə ðoʊz steɪɪŋ. tʃɪɹfəl ə hɝ.

Egeanin nodded as if she understood perfectly. "The Light shine on you tonight, and for as many days and nights as we have remaining," she said by way of farewell to those staying. Cheerful of her.

noʊ sunɝ hæd ðə fɔɹ dɪpɑɹɾəd ðən θʌndɝ bumd oʊvɝhɛd. ənʌðɝ laʊd pil, ən ɹeɪn bɪɡæn pæɾɝɪŋ ɑn ðə tɛn ɹuf, kwɪkli ɡɹoʊɪŋ tə ə daʊnpɔɹ ðət dʒɹʌm ðə ɡɹin-stʃɹaɪp kænvəs. ənlɛs dʒulɪn ən ði ʌðɝz hæd ɹʌn, ðeɪ wəd də ðɛɹ dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ wɛt.

No sooner had the four departed than thunder boomed overhead. Another loud peal, and rain began pattering on the tent roof, quickly growing to a downpour that drummed the green-striped canvas. Unless Juilin and the others had run, they would do their drinking wet.

noʊl sɛɾəld ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɛd klɔθ fɹəm oʊlvɝ ən tʊk ʌp æməðɛɹəz pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɡeɪm, ɹoʊlɪŋ ðə daɪs fəɹ ðə sneɪks ən ðə fɑksəz. ðə blæk dɪsks ðət naʊ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾ oʊlvɝ ən ɪm wɝ nɪɹli tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə wɛb-mɑɹkt klɔθ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɛvəɾənt tə ɛni aɪ ðət ðeɪ wəd nɑt meɪk ɪt. tə ɛni aɪ bʌɾ oʊlvɝz, ət list. hi ɡɹoʊn laʊdli wən ə peɪl dɪsk ɪŋkt wɪð ə weɪvi laɪn, ə sneɪk, tʌtʃt ɪz pis, ən əɡɛn wən ə dɪsk mɑɹkt wɪð ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl tʌtʃt noʊlz.

Noal settled on the other side of the red cloth from Olver and took up Amathera's part of the game, rolling the dice for the snakes and the foxes. The black discs that now represented Olver and him were nearly to the edge of the web-marked cloth, but it was evident to any eye that they would not make it. To any eye but Olver's, at least. He groaned loudly when a pale disc inked with a wavy line, a snake, touched his piece, and again when a disc marked with a triangle touched Noal's.

noʊl tʊk ʌp ðə teɪl i hæd lɛft ɔf wən ɛdʒiənɪn ən doʊmən əpɪɹd, əz wɛl, ə stɔɹi ʌv səm səpoʊz vɔɪədʒ ɑn ə si foʊk ɹeɪkɝ. "æθɑn maɪɹ wɪmən ɑɹ ðə moʊst ɡɹeɪsfəl ɪn ðə wɝld," hi sɛd, muvɪŋ ðə blæk dɪsks bæk tə ðə sɝkəl ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə bɔɹd, "ivən mɔɹ soʊ ðən dəmɑni, ən jə noʊ ðæts seɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. ən wən ðəɹ aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə lænd - " hi kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli ən klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt, aɪɪŋ oʊlvɝ, hu wɑz stækɪŋ ðə sneɪks ən fɑksəz ɑn ðə bɔɹdz kɔɹnɝz.

Noal took up the tale he had left off when Egeanin and Domon appeared, as well, a story of some supposed voyage on a Sea Folk raker. "Atha'an Miere women are the most graceful in the world," he said, moving the black discs back to the circle in the center of the board, "even more so than Domani, and you know that's saying something. And when they're out of sight of land - " He cut off abruptly and cleared his throat, eyeing Olver, who was stacking the snakes and foxes on the board's corners.

"wʌt də ðeɪ də ðɛn?" oʊlvɝ æskt.

"What do they do then?" Olver asked.

"waɪ. . . ." noʊl ɹʌbd ɪz noʊz wɪð ə nɑɹl fɪŋɡɝ. "waɪ, ðeɪ skɹæmbəl əbaʊt ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ soʊ nɪmbli jud θɪŋk ðeɪ hæd hænz wɛɹ ðɛɹ fit ʃəd bi. ðæts wʌt ðeɪ du." oʊlvɝ ut, ən noʊl ɡeɪv ə sɑf saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif.

"Why. . . ." Noal rubbed his nose with a gnarled finger. "Why, they scramble about the rigging so nimbly you'd think they had hands where their feet should be. That's what they do." Olver oohed, and Noal gave a soft sigh of relief.

mæt bɪɡæn ɹimuvɪŋ ðə blæk ən waɪt stoʊnz fɹəm ðə bɔɹɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, pleɪsɪŋ əm ɪn tu kɑɹvd wʊɾən bɑksəz. ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd baʊnst ən ɹæɾəld ivən wən ðə θʌndɝ wɑz laʊɾəst. "ənʌðɝ ɡeɪm, tɑm?"

Mat began removing the black and white stones from the board on the table, placing them in two carved wooden boxes. The dice in his head bounced and rattled even when the thunder was loudest. "Another game, Thom?"

ðə waɪt-hɛɹd mæn lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ɪz lɛɾɝ. "aɪ θɪŋk nɑt, mæt. maɪ maɪnz ɪn ə meɪz, tənaɪt."

The white-haired man looked up from his letter. "I think not, Mat. My mind's in a maze, tonight."

"ɪf jə doʊn maɪn maɪ æskɪŋ, tɑm, waɪ dʒju ɹɛd ðət lɛɾɝ ðə weɪ jə du? aɪ min, səmtaɪmz jəɹ feɪs lʊks laɪk jəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʌzəl aʊt wʌɾ ɪt minz." oʊlvɝ jɛlpt wɪð ɡli əɾ ə ɡʊd tɔs ə ðə daɪs.

"If you don't mind my asking, Thom, why do you read that letter the way you do? I mean, sometimes your face looks like you're trying to puzzle out what it means." Olver yelped with glee at a good toss of the dice.

"ðæts kəz aɪ æm. ɪn ə weɪ. hɪɹ." hi hɛld aʊt ðə lɛɾɝ, bʌt mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"That's because I am. In a way. Here." He held out the letter, but Mat shook his head.

"ɪts noʊ bɪznəs ə maɪn, tɑm. ɪts jəɹ lɛɾɝ, ən ɪm noʊ ɡʊd wɪð pʌzəlz."

"It's no business of mine, Thom. It's your letter, and I'm no good with puzzles."

"oʊ, ɪts jəɹ bɪznəs, tu. mɔɪɹeɪn ɹoʊɾ ɪt dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ. . . . wɛl, ɛniweɪ, ʃi ɹoʊɾ ɪt."

"Oh, it's your business, too. Moiraine wrote it just before. . . . Well, anyway, she wrote it."

mæt stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ðə kɹis peɪdʒ, ən wən ɪz aɪz fɛl ɑn ðə smʌdʒd ɪŋk, hi blɪŋkt. smɔl, pɹɪsaɪs ɹaɪɾɪŋ kʌvɝd ðə ʃit, bʌɾ ɪt bɪɡæn, "maɪ dɪɹəs tɑm." hu wʊɾə θɔt mɔɪɹeɪn, ʌv ɔl pipəl, wəɾ ædʒɹɛs oʊl tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn soʊ? "tɑm, ðɪs ɪz pɝsənəl. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ ʃəd - "

Mat stared at him for a long moment before taking the creased page, and when his eyes fell on the smudged ink, he blinked. Small, precise writing covered the sheet, but it began, "My dearest Thom." Who would have thought Moiraine, of all people, would address old Thom Merrilin so? "Thom, this is personal. I don't think I should - "

"ɹɛd," tɑm kʌɾ ɪn. "jul si."

"Read," Thom cut in. "You'll see."

mæt dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ə dɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ðət wɑz ə pʌzəl ən kənsɝn ɪm ɪn səm weɪ? sʌɾənli, hi wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ lɛs ðən tə ɹid ðə θɪŋ. bʌɾ i bɪɡæn ɛniweɪ. ɪt wɑz nɪɹ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪz hɛɹ stæn ɑn ɛnd.

Mat drew a deep breath. A letter from a dead Aes Sedai that was a puzzle and concerned him in some way? Suddenly, he wanted nothing less than to read the thing. But he began anyway. It was near enough to make his hair stand on end.

maɪ dɪɹəs tɑm, ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni wɝdz aɪ wəd laɪk tə ɹaɪt tə ju, wɝdz fɹəm maɪ hɑɹt, bʌɾ aɪ hæv pʊt ðɪs ɔf kəz aɪ nu ðəɾ aɪ mʌst, ən naʊ ðəɹ ɪz lɪɾəl taɪm. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni θɪŋz aɪ kænɑt tɛl jə lɛst aɪ bɹɪŋ dɪzæstɝ, bʌt wʌɾ aɪ kæn, aɪ wɪl. hid kɛɹfəli wʌɾ aɪ seɪ. ɪn ə ʃɔɹt waɪl əl ɡoʊ daʊn tə ðə dɑks, ən ðəɹ əl kənfɹʌn lænfɝ. haʊ kən aɪ noʊ ðæt? ðət sikɹət bɪlɔŋz tə ʌðɝz. səfaɪs ɪt ðəɾ aɪ noʊ, ən lɛt ðət fɹknoʊlɪdʒ stæn əz pɹuf fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ʌv wʌɾ aɪ seɪ.

My dearest Thom, There are many words I would like to write to you, words from my heart, but I have put this off because I knew that I must, and now there is little time. There are many things I cannot tell you lest I bring disaster, but what I can, I will. Heed carefully what I say. In a short while I will go down to the docks, and there I will confront Lanfear. How can I know that? That secret belongs to others. Suffice it that I know, and let that foreknowledge stand as proof for the rest of what I say.

wən jə ɹəsiv ðɪs, jəl bi toʊl ðəɾ aɪm dɛd. ɔl wɪl bɪliv ðæt. aɪm nɑt dɛd, ən ɪt meɪ bi ðəɾ aɪ ʃæl lɪv tə maɪ əpɔɪntəd jɪɹz. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ meɪ bi ðət jə ən mæt kɔθən ən ənʌðɝ, ə mæn aɪ də nɑt noʊ, wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə ɹɛskju mi. meɪ, aɪ seɪ kəz ɪt meɪ bi ðət jəl nɑɾ əɹ kænɑt, əɹ kəz mæt meɪ ɹəfjuz. hi dʌz nɑt hoʊl mi ɪn ði əfɛkʃən jə sim tə, ən hiz ɪz ɹizənz wɪtʃ i noʊ daʊt θɪŋks ɑɹ ɡʊd. ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ, ɪt mʌs bi oʊnli jə ən mæt ən wʌn ʌðɝ. mɔɹ wɪl min dɛθ fəɹ ɔl. fjuɝ wɪl min dɛθ fəɹ ɔl. ivən ɪf jə kʌm oʊnli wɪð mæt ən wʌn ʌðɝ, dɛθ ɔlsoʊ meɪ kʌm. aɪ hæv sin jə tʃɹaɪ ən daɪ, wʌn əɹ tu əɹ ɔl θɹi. aɪ hæv sin maɪsɛlf daɪ ɪn ði ətɛmpt. aɪ hæv sin ɔl ʌv əs lɪv ən daɪ əz kæptɪvz.

When you receive this, you will be told that I am dead. All will believe that. I am not dead, and it may be that I shall live to my appointed years. It also may be that you and Mat Cauthon and another, a man I do not know, will try to rescue me. May, I say because it may be that you will not or cannot, or because Mat may refuse. He does not hold me in the affection you seem to, and he has his reasons which he no doubt thinks are good. If you try, it must be only you and Mat and one other. More will mean death for all. Fewer will mean death for all. Even if you come only with Mat and one other, death also may come. I have seen you try and die, one or two or all three. I have seen myself die in the attempt. I have seen all of us live and die as captives.

ʃəd jə dɪsaɪd tə meɪk ði ətɛmpt ɛniweɪ, jʌŋ mæt noʊz ðə weɪ tə faɪn mi, jɛt jə mʌs nɑt ʃoʊ hɪm ðɪs lɛɾɝ əntɪl i æsks əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðəɾ ɪz ə ði ʌtmoʊst ɪmpɔɹɾəns. hi mʌs noʊ nʌθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz ɪn ðɪs lɛɾɝ əntɪl i æsks. ɪvɛns mʌs pleɪ aʊɾ ɪn sɝɾən weɪz, wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɑsts.

Should you decide to make the attempt anyway, young Mat knows the way to find me, yet you must not show him this letter until he asks about it. That is of the utmost importance. He must know nothing that is in this letter until he asks. Events must play out in certain ways, whatever the costs.

ɪf jə si læn əɡɛn, tɛl ɪm ðəɾ ɔl ə ðɪs ɪz fəɹ ðə bɛst. hɪz dɛstəni fɑloʊz ə dɪfɹən pæθ fɹəm maɪn. aɪ wɪʃ ɪm ɔl hæpinəs wɪð nɪneɪiv.

If you see Lan again, tell him that all of this is for the best. His destiny follows a different path from mine. I wish him all happiness with Nynaeve.

ə faɪnəl pɔɪnt. ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt jə noʊ əbaʊt ðə ɡeɪm ə sneɪks ən fɑksəz. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ən hid.

A final point. Remember what you know about the game of Snakes and Foxes. Remember, and heed.

ɪts taɪm, ən aɪ mʌs də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn.

It is time, and I must do what must be done.

meɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin jə ən ɡɪv jə dʒɔɪ, maɪ dɪɹəs tɑm, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt wi ɛvɝ si wʌn ənʌðɝ əɡɛn.

May the Light illumine you and give you joy, my dearest Thom, whether or not we ever see one another again.

mɔɪɹeɪn θʌndɝ bumd əz i fɪnɪʃt. fɪɾɪŋ, ðæt. ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, hi hændəd ðə lɛɾɝ bæk. "tɑm," hi sɛd dʒɛnli, "lænz bɑn tə hɝ wɑz bɹoʊkən. ɪt teɪks dɛθ tə də ðæt. hi sɛd ʃi wɑz dɛd."

Moiraine Thunder boomed as he finished. Fitting, that. Shaking his head, he handed the letter back. "Thom," he said gently, "Lan's bond to her was broken. It takes death to do that. He said she was dead."

"æn əɹ lɛɾɝ sɛz ɛvɹiwʌn wəd bɪliv ðæt. ʃi nu, mæt. ʃi nu ɪɾ ɔl ɪn ədvæns."

"And her letter says everyone would believe that. She knew, Mat. She knew it all in advance."

"ðæts əz meɪ bi, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn ən lænfɝ wɛn ɪndə ðət dɔɹfɹeɪm tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ən ɪt mɛltəd. ðə θɪŋ wɑz ɹɛdstoʊn, əɹ lʊk tə bi, stoʊn, tɑm, jɛɾ ɪt mɛltəd laɪk wæks. aɪ sɔ ɪt. ʃi wɛn tə wɛɹɛvɝ ði ɛlfɪn ɑɹ, ən ivən ɪf ʃiz əlaɪv, ðɛɹz noʊ weɪ fəɹ əs tə ɡɛt ðəɹ ɛnimɔɹ."

"That's as may be, but Moiraine and Lanfear went into that doorframe ter'angreal, and it melted. The thing was redstone, or looked to be, stone, Thom, yet it melted like wax. I saw it. She went to wherever the Eelfinn are, and even if she is alive, there's no way for us to get there anymore."

"ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ," oʊlvɝ paɪpt ʌp, ən ɔl θɹi ədʌls tɝn ðɛɹ hɛdz tə stɛɹ ət hɪm. "bɝdʒɪt toʊl mi," hi sɛd dɪfɛnsɪvli. "ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ ɪz ðə weɪ tə ðə lænz ə ði æɛlfɪn ən ði ɛlfɪn." hi meɪd ðə dʒɛstʃɝ ðət bɪɡæn ə ɡeɪm ə sneɪks ən fɑksəz, ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl dʒɹɔn ɪn ði ɛɹ ən ðən ə weɪvi laɪn θɹu ɪt. "ʃi noʊz ivən mɔɹ stɔɹiz ðən ju, mæstɝ tʃɛɝɪn."

"The Tower of Ghenjei," Olver piped up, and all three adults turned their heads to stare at him. "Birgitte told me," he said defensively. "The Tower of Ghenjei is the way to the lands of the Aelfinn and the Eelfinn." He made the gesture that began a game of Snakes and Foxes, a triangle drawn in the air and then a wavy line through it. "She knows even more stories than you, Master Charin."

"ðæt wʊdn bi bɝdʒɪt sɪlvɝboʊ, wəɾ ɪt?" noʊl sɛd ɹaɪli.

"That wouldn't be Birgitte Silverbow, would it?" Noal said wryly.

ðə bɔɪ ɡeɪv ɪm ə lɛvəl lʊk. "aɪm nɑɾ ən ɪnfənt, mæstɝ tʃɛɝɪn. bʌt ʃiz vɛɹi ɡʊd wɪð ə baʊ, soʊ meɪbi ʃi ɪz. bɝdʒɪt bɔɹn əɡɛn, aɪ min."

The boy gave him a level look. "I'm not an infant, Master Charin. But she is very good with a bow, so maybe she is. Birgitte born again, I mean."

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðɛɹz ɛni tʃæns ə ðæt," mæt sɛd. "aɪv tɔkt wɪð hɝ, tu, jə noʊ, ən ðə læs θɪŋ ʃi wɑns ɪz tə bi ɛni kaɪndə hɪɹoʊ." hi kɛpt ɪz pɹɑməsəz, ən bɝdʒɪts sikɹəts wɝ seɪf wɪð hɪm. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, noʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs taʊɝ dʌzn hɛlp mʌtʃ ənlɛs ʃi toʊl jə wɛɹ ɪɾ ɪz." oʊlvɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sædli, ən mæt bɛn tə ɹʌfəl ɪz hɛɹ. "nɑt jəɹ fɔlt, bɔɪ. wɪθaʊt ju, wi wʊdn ivən noʊ ɪɾ ɪɡzɪsts." ðət dɪd nɑt sim tə hɛlp mʌtʃ. oʊlvɝ stɛɹɾ ət ðə ɹɛd klɔθ ɡeɪm bɔɹd dɪdʒɛktɪdli.

"I don't think there's any chance of that," Mat said. "I've talked with her, too, you know, and the last thing she wants is to be any kind of hero." He kept his promises, and Birgitte's secrets were safe with him. "In any case, knowing about this tower doesn't help much unless she told you where it is." Olver shook his head sadly, and Mat bent to ruffle his hair. "Not your fault, boy. Without you, we wouldn't even know it exists." That did not seem to help much. Olver stared at the red cloth game board dejectedly.

"ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ," noʊl sɛd, sɪɾɪŋ ʌp kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ən tʌɡɪŋ ɪz koʊt stʃɹeɪt. "nɑt mɛni noʊ ðət teɪl ɛnimɔɹ. dʒaɪn ɔlweɪz sɛd hid ɡoʊ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɪt wʌn deɪ. sʌmwɛɹ əlɔŋ ðə ʃædoʊ koʊst, hi sɛd."

"The Tower of Ghenjei," Noal said, sitting up cross-legged and tugging his coat straight. "Not many know that tale anymore. Jain always said he'd go looking for it one day. Somewhere along the Shadow Coast, he said."

"ðæts stɪl ə lɑɾ ʌv ɡɹaʊn tə sɝtʃ." mæt fɪɾəd ðə lɪɾ ɑn wʌn ə ðə bɑksəz. "ɪt kəd teɪk jɪɹz." jɪɹz ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ əv ɪf tuɑn wɑz ɹaɪt, ən i wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət ʃi wɑz.

"That's still a lot of ground to search." Mat fitted the lid on one of the boxes. "It could take years." Years they did not have if Tuon was right, and he was sure that she was.

tɑm ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ʃi sɛz jə noʊ, mæt. 'mæt noʊz ðə weɪ tə faɪn mi.' aɪ daʊt vɛɹi mʌtʃ ʃiɾ əv ɹɪɾən ðəɾ ɑn ə wɪm."

Thom shook his head. "She says you know, Mat. 'Mat knows the way to find me.' I doubt very much she'd have written that on a whim."

"wɛl, aɪ kæn hɛlp wʌt ʃi sɛz, naʊ kən aɪ? aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛni taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ əntɪl tənaɪt."

"Well, I can't help what she says, now can I? I never heard of any Tower of Ghenjei until tonight."

"ə pɪɾi," noʊl saɪd. "aɪd laɪk tə hæv sin ɪt, sʌmθɪŋ dʒaɪn blʌɾi fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ nɛvɝ dɪd. jə maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡɪv oʊvɝ," hi æɾəd wən tɑm oʊpən ɪz maʊθ. "hi wʊdn fɝɡɛt siɪŋ ɪt, ən ivən ɪf i nɛvɝ hɝd ðə neɪm, hiɾ əv tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt wən i hɝɾ ʌv ə stʃɹeɪnʒ taʊɝ ðət lɛts pipəl ɪndə ʌðɝ lænz. ðə θɪŋ ɡlimz laɪk bɝnɪʃt stil, aɪm toʊld, tu hʌnʒɹəd fit haɪ ən fɔɹɾi θɪk, ən ðɛɹz nɑɾ ən oʊpənɪŋ tə bi faʊn ɪn ɪt. hu kəd fɝɡɛt siɪŋ ðæt?"

"A pity," Noal sighed. "I'd like to have seen it, something Jain bloody Farstrider never did. You might as well give over," he added when Thom opened his mouth. "He wouldn't forget seeing it, and even if he never heard the name, he'd have to think of it when he heard of a strange tower that lets people into other lands. The thing gleams like burnished steel, I'm told, two hundred feet high and forty thick, and there's not an opening to be found in it. Who could forget seeing that?"

mæt wɛn vɛɹi stɪl. hɪz blæk skɑɹf fɛl tu taɪɾ əɡɛnst ɪz hæŋɪŋ skɑɹ. ðə skɑɹ ɪtsɛlf sʌɾənli fɛl fɹɛʃ ən hɑt. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd fəɹ ɪm tə dʒɹɔ bɹɛθ.

Mat went very still. His black scarf felt too tight against his hanging scar. The scar itself suddenly felt fresh and hot. It was hard for him to draw breath.

"ɪf ðɛɹz noʊ oʊpənɪŋ, haʊ də wi ɡɛɾ ɪn?" tɑm wɑntəd tə noʊ.

"If there's no opening, how do we get in?" Thom wanted to know.

noʊl ʃɹʌɡd, bʌɾ oʊlvɝ spoʊk ʌp wʌns mɔɹ. "bɝdʒɪt sɛz jə meɪk ðə saɪn ɑn ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɪɾ ɛniwɛɹ wɪð ə bɹɑnz naɪf." hi meɪd ðə saɪn ðət stɑɹɾəd ðə ɡeɪm. "ʃi sɛz ɪts tə bi ə bɹɑnz naɪf. meɪk ðə saɪn, ən ə dɔɹ oʊpənz."

Noal shrugged, but Olver spoke up once more. "Birgitte says you make the sign on the side of it anywhere with a bronze knife." He made the sign that started the game. "She says it has to be a bronze knife. Make the sign, and a door opens."

"wʌɾ ɛls dɪd ʃi tɛl jə əbaʊt - " tɑm bɪɡæn, ðən kʌɾ ɔf wɪð ə fɹaʊn. "wʌɾ eɪlz ju, mæt? jə lʊk əbaʊt tə sɪk ʌp."

"What else did she tell you about - " Thom began, then cut off with a frown. "What ails you, Mat? You look about to sick up."
