Most people had had sense enough to leave as soon they caught a glimmering that hundreds of men were about to start swinging swords in their vicinity. One curtain twitched; a woman's face showed for a moment, then vanished. Some others took ghoulish delight in watching.

tɔkɪŋ kwaɪətli əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ðə fɔɹ kɪnswɪmən tʊk ðɛɹ pleɪsəz wɛɹ ðeɪ hæɾ oʊpən ðɛɹ ɡeɪtweɪ səm aʊɝz ɝliɝ. ðeɪ aɪd ðə kɔɹpsəz ɪn ðə stʃɹiɾ ən ʃʊk ðɛɹ hɛdz, bʌt ðiz wɝ nɑt ðə fɝs dɛd mɛn ðeɪ hæd sin. nɑt wʌn wʊɾə bɪn əlaʊd tə tɛs fəɹ æksɛptɪd, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ kɑm, ʃʊɹ ə ðɛmsɛlvz, əz dɪɡnəfaɪɾ əz sɪstɝz dɪspaɪt ðə ɹeɪn soʊkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛɹ ən dʒɹɛsəz. lɝnɪŋ ɛɡwinz plænz fəɹ ðə kɪn, tə bi əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð ðə taʊɝ ən ə pleɪs fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ɹɪtaɪɹ, hæd lɛsən ðɛɹ fɪɹz oʊvɝ ðɛɹ fjutʃɝ, ɪspɛʃli wʌns ðeɪ faʊn aʊt ðət ðɛɹ ɹul wəd ɹɪmeɪn ɪn pleɪs ən ðə fɔɹmɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ əv tə fɑloʊ ɪt, tu. nɑɾ ɔl bɪlivd - oʊvɝ ðə læs mʌnθ, sɛvən ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ hæd ɹʌn əweɪ wɪθaʊt livɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə noʊt - jɛt moʊs dɪd, ən tʊk stʃɹɛŋkθ fɹəm bɪlif. hævɪŋ wɝk tə də hæd ɹɪstɔɹd ðɛɹ pɹaɪd. ɪleɪn hæd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðət hæd bɪn dɛntɪɾ əntɪl ðeɪ stɑp siɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz əz ɹɛfjudʒiz hoʊli dɪpɛndən ɑn hɝ. ðeɪ hɛl ðɛmsɛlvz stʃɹeɪɾɝ, naʊ. wɝi hæd vænɪʃt fɹəm ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ən ðeɪ wɝ nɑt soʊ kwɪk tə bɛn ðɛɹ nɛks fəɹ ə sɪstɝ, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. ðoʊ ðət pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt ɹɪli hæd bɪɡʌn ɝliɝ. ðeɪ wʌns hæd kənsɪɾɝd ɛɛs sədaɪ supɪɹiɝ tə mɔɹɾəl flɛʃ, bʌt hæd lɝn tə ðɛɹ dɪsmeɪ ðət ðə ʃɔl dɪd nɑt meɪk ə wʊmən mɔɹ ðən ʃi wɑz wɪθaʊɾ ɪt.

Talking quietly among themselves, the four Kinswomen took their places where they had opened their gateway some hours earlier. They eyed the corpses in the street and shook their heads, but these were not the first dead men they had seen. Not one would have been allowed to test for Accepted, yet they were calm, sure of themselves, as dignified as sisters despite the rain soaking their hair and dresses. Learning Egwene's plans for the Kin, to be associated with the Tower and a place for Aes Sedai to retire, had lessened their fears over their future, especially once they found out that their Rule would remain in place and the former Aes Sedai would have to follow it, too. Not all believed - over the last month, seven of their number had run away without leaving so much as a note - yet most did, and took strength from belief. Having work to do had restored their pride. Elayne had not realized that had been dented until they stopped seeing themselves as refugees wholly dependent on her. They held themselves straighter, now. Worry had vanished from their faces. And they were not so quick to bend their necks for a sister, unfortunately. Though that part of it really had begun earlier. They once had considered Aes Sedai superior to mortal flesh, but had learned to their dismay that the shawl did not make a woman more than she was without it.

æləz aɪɾ ɪleɪn, kəmpɹɛsɪŋ əɹ lɪps fəɹ ə moʊmən ən ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ bɹaʊn skɝts ənnɛsəsɛɹəli. ʃi hæɾ ɑɹɡjuɾ əɡɛnst ɪleɪn biɪŋ əlaʊd - əlaʊd! - tə kʌm hɪɹ. ən bɝdʒɪt hæɾ ɔlmoʊst ɡɪvən weɪ! æləz wɑz ə fɔɹsfəl wʊmən. "ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi fəɹ ʌs, kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl?" ʃi sɛd.

Alise eyed Elayne, compressing her lips for a moment and adjusting her brown skirts unnecessarily. She had argued against Elayne being allowed - allowed! - to come here. And Birgitte had almost given way! Alise was a forceful woman. "Are you ready for us, Captain-General?" she said.

"wi ɑɹ," ɪleɪn sɛd, bʌɾ æləz weɪɾəd əntɪl bɝdʒɪt nɑɾəd bɪfɔɹ lɪŋkɪŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝ θɹi kɪnswɪmən. ʃi ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪleɪn æftɝ ðət wʌn ɡlæns. ɹɪli, nɪneɪiv ʃəd nɛvɝ əv bɪɡʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə "pʊt səm bækboʊn ɪndə ðɛm," əz ʃi hæd pʊɾ ɪt. wən ʃi kəd leɪ hænz ɑn nɪneɪiv əɡɛn, ʃi wɑz gɑnə hæv wɝdz wɪð ðə wʊmən.

"We are," Elayne said, but Alise waited until Birgitte nodded before linking with the other three Kinswomen. She ignored Elayne after that one glance. Really, Nynaeve should never have begun trying to "put some backbone into them," as she had put it. When she could lay hands on Nynaeve again, she was going to have words with the woman.

ðə fəmɪljɝ vɝɾɪkəl slæʃ əpɪɹɾ ən sim tə ɹoʊteɪɾ ɪndə ə vju ʌv ðə meɪn steɪbliɑɹɾ ɪn ðə pæləs, ə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ nɪɹli fɔɹ peɪsɪz baɪ fɔɹ, bʌt ðə vju θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ, ʌv ðə tɔl ɑɹtʃt dɔɹz ʌv wʌn ə ðə waɪt mɑɹbəl steɪbəlz, wɑz ə lɪɾəl ɔf-sɛntɝ fɹəm wʌt ʃi ɪkspɛktəd. wən ʃi ɹoʊɾ ɑntu ðə ɹeɪn-dʒɹɛntʃt flæɡstoʊnz ə ðə steɪbliɑɹd, ʃi sɔ waɪ. ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ ɡeɪtweɪ, slaɪtli smɔlɝ, oʊpən. ɪf jə tʃɹaɪd tə oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ wɛɹ wʌn ɔlɹɛɾi ɪɡzɪstəd, jʊɹz wɑz dɪspleɪs dʒʌst ɪnʌf ðət ðə tu dɪd nɑt tʌtʃ, ðoʊ ðə ɡæp bɪtwin wɑz θɪnɝ ðən ə ɹeɪzɝz ɛdʒ. fɹəm ðəɾ ʌðɝ ɡeɪtweɪ ə twɪn kɑləm ə mɛn sim tə bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə steɪbliɑɹdz aʊɾɝ wɔl, kɝvɪŋ əweɪ tə ɛɡzɪt ðə steɪbliɑɹd θɹu ði oʊpən aɪɝn-stʃɹæpt ɡeɪts. səm wɔɹ bɝnɪʃt hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts əɹ pleɪt-ænd-meɪl, bʌɾ ɛvɹi mæn hæɾ ɑn ðə waɪt-kɑlɝd ɹɛd koʊɾ ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd. ə tɔl, bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd mæn wɪð tu ɡoʊldən nɑts ɑn ðə lɛft ʃoʊldɝ ə hɪz ɹɛd koʊt stʊɾ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛm, hɛlmət bælənst ɑn ɪz hɪp.

The familiar vertical slash appeared and seemed to rotate into a view of the main stableyard in the palace, a hole in the air nearly four paces by four, but the view through the opening, of the tall arched doors of one of the white marble stables, was a little off-center from what she expected. When she rode onto the rain-drenched flagstones of the stableyard, she saw why. There was another gateway, slightly smaller, open. If you tried to open a gateway where one already existed, yours was displaced just enough that the two did not touch, though the gap between was thinner than a razor's edge. From that other gateway a twinned column of men seemed to be riding out of the stableyard's outer wall, curving away to exit the stableyard through the open iron-strapped gates. Some wore burnished helmets and breastplates or plate-and-mail, but every man had on the white-collared red coat of the Queen's Guard. A tall, broad-shouldered man with two golden knots on the left shoulder of his red coat stood in the rain watching them, helmet balanced on his hip.

"ðæts ə saɪt tə suð sɔɹ aɪz," bɝdʒɪt mɝmɝd. smɔl ɡɹups ə kɪnswɪmən wɝ skaʊɝɪŋ ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd fəɹ ɛniwʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kʌm tə ɪleɪnz səpɔɹt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə tʃænsi bɪznəs. ðʌs fɑɹ, ðə kɪnswɪmən hæd bɹɔt wɝɾ ə dʌzənz ən dʌzənz ʌv ɡɹups tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ə weɪ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, jɛt ðeɪ hæɾ oʊnli mænədʒ tə loʊkeɪt faɪv bænz toʊɾəlɪŋ fjuɝ ðən ə θaʊzənd. wɝd hæd spɹɛɾ ə haʊ mɛni mɛn ɛɹəmɪlə hæɾ ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi, ən mɛn səpɔɹɾɪŋ tʃɹəkənd wɝ skɪɾɪʃ əbaʊt biɪŋ faʊnd. əbaʊɾ u maɪt də ðə faɪndɪŋ.

"That's a sight to soothe sore eyes," Birgitte murmured. Small groups of Kinswomen were scouring the countryside for anyone trying to come to Elayne's support, but it was a chancy business. Thus far, the Kinswomen had brought word of dozens and dozens of groups trying to find a way into the city, yet they had only managed to locate five bands totaling fewer than a thousand. Word had spread of how many men Arymilla had around the city, and men supporting Trakand were skittish about being found. About who might do the finding.

əz sun əz ɪleɪn ən ði ʌðɝz əpɪɹd, ɹɛd-klæd ɡɹumz wɪð ðə waɪt laɪən ɑn ðɛɹ lɛft ʃoʊldɝz keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ. ə skɹɔni, ɡæp-tuθ fɛloʊ wɪð ə fɹɪnʒ ʌv waɪt hɛɹ tʊk faɪɹhɑɹts bɹaɪɾəl waɪl ə lin, ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən hɛld ɪleɪnz stɝəp fəɹ əɹ tə dɪsmaʊnt. ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə daʊnpɔɹ, ʃi stʃɹoʊd təwɔɹd ðə tɔl mæn, splæʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ wɪð ɛvɹi stɛp. hɪz hɛɹ hʌŋ ɛvɹi wɪtʃ weɪ oʊvɝ ɪz feɪs, klɪŋɪŋ wɛtli, bʌt ʃi kəd si hi wɑz jʌŋ, wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə hɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz.

As soon as Elayne and the others appeared, red-clad grooms with the White Lion on their left shoulders came running. A scrawny, gap-toothed fellow with a fringe of white hair took Fireheart's bridle while a lean, graying woman held Elayne's stirrup for her to dismount. Ignoring the downpour, she strode toward the tall man, splashing water with every step. His hair hung every which way over his face, clinging wetly, but she could see he was young, well short of his middle years.

"ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ju, lutɛnənt," ʃi sɛd. "jɔɹ neɪm? haʊ mɛni dɪd jə bɹɪŋ? ən fɹəm wɛɹ?" θɹu ðət smɔlɝ oʊpənɪŋ ʃi kəd si ə laɪn ə hɔɹsmən ɪkstɛndɪŋ aʊɾ ə saɪɾ əmʌŋ tɔl tʃɹiz. wɛnɛvɝ ə pɛɹ ɹoʊd θɹu, ənʌðɝ əpɪɹɾ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə kɑləm. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv bɪliv ðət mɛni ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdz ɹɪmeɪn ɛniwɛɹ.

"The Light shine on you, Lieutenant," she said. "Your name? How many did you bring? And from where?" Through that smaller opening she could see a line of horsemen extending out of sight among tall trees. Whenever a pair rode through, another appeared at the far end of the column. She would not have believed that many of the Guards remained anywhere.

"ɑɹlz ɡaɪbɑn, maɪ kwin," hi ɹɪplaɪd, sɪŋkɪŋ tə wʌn ni ən pɹɛsɪŋ ə ɡɔntələɾəd fɪs tə ðə flæɡstoʊnz. "kæptən kɪnlɪn ɪn ɑɹɪŋɡəl ɡeɪv mi pɝmɪʃən tə tʃɹaɪ ɹitʃɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn. ðət wɑz æftɝ wi lɝn leɪɾi nɑiən ən ði ʌðɝz hæɾ ɪskeɪpt."

"Charlz Guybon, my Queen," he replied, sinking to one knee and pressing a gauntleted fist to the flagstones. "Captain Kindlin in Aringill gave me permission to try reaching Caemlyn. That was after we learned Lady Naean and the others had escaped."

ɪleɪn læft. "stænd, mæn. stænd. aɪm nɑt kwin jɛt." ɑɹɪŋɡəl? ðəɹ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn soʊ mɛni ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdz ðɛɹ.

Elayne laughed. "Stand, man. Stand. I'm not Queen yet." Aringill? There had never been so many of the Guards there.

"æz jə seɪ, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛɾ əz i ɹiɡeɪn ɪz fiɾ ən meɪɾ ə baʊ ðət wɑz mɔɹ pɹɑpɝ fəɹ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ.

"As you say, my Lady," he said as he regained his feet and made a bow that was more proper for the Daughter-Heir.

"kæn wi kəntɪnju ðɪs ɪnsaɪd?" bɝdʒɪt pʊɾ ɪn ɪɹɪɾəbli. ɡaɪbɑn tʊk ɪn əɹ koʊt wɪð ɪts ɡoʊl stʃɹaɪps ɑn ðə kʌfs ən nɑts ə ɹæŋk, ən ɔfɝɾ ə səlut ðət ʃi ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ə kwɪk ɑɹm əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst. ɪf i wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si ə wʊmən əz kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl, hi wɑz waɪz ɪnʌf nɑt tə ʃoʊ ɪt. "aɪm soʊk tə ðə skɪn, ən soʊ ɑɹ ju, ɪleɪn." eɪvinhə wɑz ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɝ, ʃɔl ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ hɛɾ ən nɑt lʊkɪŋ soʊ plizd wɪð ɹeɪn naʊ ðəɾ əɹ waɪt blaʊs klʌŋ wɛtli ən əɹ dɑɹk skɝts hʌŋ wɪð wɔɾɝ. ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɝ liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz təwɔɹd wʌn ə ðə steɪbəlz, ɪksɛp fəɹ ði eɪɾ u wəd ɹɪmeɪn wɪð ɪleɪn əntɪl ðɛɹ ɹipleɪsməns ɝaɪvd. ɡaɪbɑn meɪd noʊ kɑmɛn ɑn ðɛm, iðɝ. ə vɛɹi waɪz mæn.

"Can we continue this inside?" Birgitte put in irritably. Guybon took in her coat with its gold stripes on the cuffs and knots of rank, and offered a salute that she returned with a quick arm across her chest. If he was surprised to see a woman as Captain-General, he was wise enough not to show it. "I'm soaked to the skin, and so are you, Elayne." Aviendha was right behind her, shawl wrapped around her head and not looking so pleased with rain now that her white blouse clung wetly and her dark skirts hung with water. The Guardswomen were leading their horses toward one of the stables, except for the eight who would remain with Elayne until their replacements arrived. Guybon made no comment on them, either. A very wise man.

ɪleɪn əlaʊd hɝsɛlf tə bi hʌsəld əz fɑɹ əz ðə sɪmpəl kɑləneɪd ðəɾ ɔfɝɾ ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə pæləs ɪtsɛlf. ivən hɪɹ ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən sɝaʊndəd hɝ, fɔɹ əhɛɾ ən fɔɹ bɪhaɪnd, soʊ ʃi fɛlt ə pɹɪznɝ. wʌns aʊɾ ə ðə ɹeɪn, ðoʊ, ʃi bɔkt. ʃi wɑntəd tə noʊ. ʃi tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn tə ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ - ɹimuvɪŋ ðə mɔɪstʃɝ fɹəm əɹ kloʊðz wəd bi ə sɪmpəl mæɾɝ wɪð ðə paʊɝ - bʌt ðə sɔɹs skɪɾɝd əweɪ wʌns mɔɹ. eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt noʊ ðə wiv, soʊ ðeɪ hæd tə stæn ðəɹ dʒɹɪpɪŋ. ðə pleɪn aɪɝn stænd-læmps əlɔŋ ðə wɔl wɝ stɪl ənlɪt, ən wɪð ðə ɹeɪn, ðə speɪs wɑz dɪm. ɡaɪbɑn ɹeɪkt ɪz hɛɹ ɪndə ə sɛmbləns ʌv ɔɹɾɝ wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. laɪt, hi wɑz lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ə bjuɾəfəl! hɪz ɡɹinɪʃ heɪzəl aɪz wɝ taɪɝd, bʌɾ ɪz feɪs sim suɾəd tə smaɪlɪŋ. hi lʊkt əz ɪf i hæd nɑt smaɪld ɪn tu lɔŋ.

Elayne allowed herself to be hustled as far as the simple colonnade that offered entrance to the palace itself. Even here the Guardswomen surrounded her, four ahead and four behind, so she felt a prisoner. Once out of the rain, though, she balked. She wanted to know. She tried again to embrace saidar - removing the moisture from her clothes would be a simple matter with the Power - but the Source skittered away once more. Aviendha did not know the weave, so they had to stand there dripping. The plain iron stand-lamps along the wall were still unlit, and with the rain, the space was dim. Guybon raked his hair into a semblance of order with his fingers. Light, he was little short of beautiful! His greenish hazel eyes were tired, but his face seemed suited to smiling. He looked as if he had not smiled in too long.

"kæptən kɪnlɪn sɛɾ aɪ kəd tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn mɛn hud bɪn dɪstʃɑɹdʒ baɪ ɡeɪbɹəl, maɪ leɪɾi, ən ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd flɑkɪŋ ɪn əz sun əz aɪ pʊɾ aʊt ðə kɔl. jud bi sɝpɹaɪz haʊ mɛni tʌk ðɛɹ junəfɔɹmz ɪndə ə tʃɛst əɡɛns ðə deɪ ðeɪ maɪt bi wɑntəɾ əɡɛn. ə ɡʊd mɛni kæɹiɾ ɔf ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ, tu, wɪtʃ ðeɪ ʃʊdn əv dʌn, stʃɹɪkli spikɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪm ɡlæd ðeɪ dɪd. aɪ fɪɹɾ aɪd weɪɾəd tu lɔŋ wən aɪ hɝɾ ə ðə sidʒ. aɪ wɑz kənsɪɾɝɪŋ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪt maɪ weɪ tə wʌn ə ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts wən mɪstʃɹəs zɪɡɑn ən ði ʌðɝz faʊn mi." ə pʌzəld lʊk keɪm oʊvɝ ɪz feɪs. "ʃi bɪkeɪm vɛɹi əpsɛt wən aɪ kɔld əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ðəɾ əz tə bi ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðət bɹɔɾ əs hɪɹ."

"Captain Kindlin said I could try to find men who'd been discharged by Gaebril, my Lady, and they started flocking in as soon as I put out the call. You'd be surprised how many tucked their uniforms into a chest against the day they might be wanted again. A good many carried off their armor, too, which they shouldn't have done, strictly speaking, but I'm glad they did. I feared I'd waited too long when I heard of the siege. I was considering trying to fight my way to one of the city gates when Mistress Zigane and the others found me." A puzzled look came over his face. "She became very upset when I called her Aes Sedai, but that has to be the One Power that brought us here."

"ɪt wɑz, ən ʃi ɪzənt," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. "haʊ mɛni, mæn?"

"It was, and she isn't," Elayne said impatiently. "How many, man?"

"fɔɹ θaʊzən sɛvən hʌnʒɹəd ən sɪksti-tu ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdz, maɪ leɪɾi. ən aɪ ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz u wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn wɪð ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn. bi kɑntɛnt. aɪ meɪd ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ lɔɪəl tə jə bɪfɔɹ aɪ lɛɾ əm dʒɔɪn mi. ðəɹ ɑɹ nʌn fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt haʊsəz, bʌt ðeɪ bɹɪŋ ðə toʊɾəl nɪɹ tə tɛn θaʊzənd, maɪ leɪɾi." hi sɛd ðəɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə noʊ moʊmən əɾ ɔl. ðəɹ ɑɹ fɔɹɾi hɔɹsəz fɪt fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə steɪbəl. aɪ hæv bɹɔt jə tɛn θaʊzən soʊlʒɝz.

"Four thousand seven hundred and sixty-two of the Guards, my Lady. And I encountered a number of lords and ladies who were trying to reach Caemlyn with their armsmen. Be content. I made sure they were loyal to you before I let them join me. There are none from the great Houses, but they bring the total near to ten thousand, my Lady." He said that as if it were of no moment at all. There are forty horses fit for riding in the stable. I have brought you ten thousand soldiers.

ɪleɪn læft ən klæpt əɹ hænz ɪn dɪlaɪt. "wʌndɝfəl, kæptən ɡaɪbɑn! wʌndɝfəl!" ɛɹəmɪlə stɪl hæɾ əɹ aʊtnʌmbɝd, bʌt nɑt soʊ bædli əz bɪfɔɹ.

Elayne laughed and clapped her hands in delight. "Wonderful, Captain Guybon! Wonderful!" Arymilla still had her outnumbered, but not so badly as before.

"ɡɑɹdzmæn lutɛnənt, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪm ə lutɛnənt."

"Guardsman Lieutenant, my Lady. I am a Lieutenant."

"fɹʌm ðɪs moʊmənt, jə ɑɹ kæptən ɡaɪbɑn."

"From this moment, you are Captain Guybon."

"æn maɪ sɛkənd," bɝdʒɪɾ æɾəd, "æt lis fəɹ ðə pɹɛzənt. juv ʃoʊn ɹisɔɹsfəlnəs, jəɹ oʊld ɪnʌf tə hæv ɪkspɪɹiəns, ən aɪ nid boʊθ."

"And my second," Birgitte added, "at least for the present. You've shown resourcefulness, you're old enough to have experience, and I need both."

ɡaɪbɑn simd oʊvɝwɛlmd, boʊɪŋ ən mɝmɝɪŋ stæmɝd θæŋks. wɛl, ə mæn ə hɪz eɪdʒ wəd nɔɹməli ɪkspɛk tə sɝv ət lis tɛn əɹ fɪftin mɔɹ jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ kənsɪɾɝd fəɹ kæptən, mʌtʃ lɛs sɛkən tə ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl, haʊɛvɝ tɛmpɝɛɹi.

Guybon seemed overwhelmed, bowing and murmuring stammered thanks. Well, a man of his age would normally expect to serve at least ten or fifteen more years before being considered for captain, much less second to the Captain-General, however temporary.

"ænd naʊ ɪts pæs taɪm fəɹ əs tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪndə dʒɹaɪ kloʊðz," bɝdʒɪt kəntɪnjud. "ɪspɛʃli ju, ɪleɪn." ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn kæɹiɾ ən ɪmplækəbəl fɝmnəs ðət sədʒɛstəd ʃi maɪt tʃɹaɪ dʒɹæɡɪŋ ɪleɪn ɪf ʃi dælid.

"And now it's past time for us to be getting into dry clothes," Birgitte continued. "Especially you, Elayne." The Warder bond carried an implacable firmness that suggested she might try dragging Elayne if she dallied.

tɛmpɝ flɛɹd, hɑɾ ən ʃɑɹp, bʌɾ ɪleɪn fɔɾ ɪt daʊn. ʃi hæd nɪɹli dʌbəl ðə nʌmbɝ ə hɝ soʊlʒɝz, ən ʃi wəd nɑt lɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ spɔɪl ðɪs deɪ. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi wɑntəd dʒɹaɪ kloʊðz, tu.

Temper flared, hot and sharp, but Elayne fought it down. She had nearly doubled the number of her soldiers, and she would not let anything spoil this day. Besides, she wanted dry clothes, too.

tʃæptɝ fɔɹtin

CHAPTER 14

wɛt θɪŋz ɪnsaɪd, ðə ɡɪldɪd stænd-læmps wɝ lɪt, sɪns deɪlaɪt nɛvɝ pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd fɑɹ ɪndə ðə pæləs, fleɪmz flɪkɝɪŋ ɑn ðə læmps ðət lækt ɡlæs mæntəlz. ðə læmps' mɪɹɝz pɹəvaɪɾəd ə ɡʊd laɪɾ ɪn ðə bʌsəlɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ, ðoʊ, ən bʌsəlɪŋ ɪt wɑz, wɪð lɪvɹid sɝvəns skɝiɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, əɹ swipɪŋ əɹ mɑpɪŋ. sɝvɪŋ mɛn wɪð ðə waɪt laɪən ɑn ðə lɛf bɹɛst ə ðɛɹ ɹɛd koʊts wɝ ʌp ɑn tɔl læɾɝz teɪkɪŋ daʊn ðə wɪntɝ tæpəstʃɹiz, meɪnli flaʊɝz ən sinz ə sʌmɝ, ən pʊɾɪŋ ʌp ðə spɹɪŋ tæpəstʃɹiz, mɛni dɪspleɪɪŋ ðə kʌlɝfəl foʊlɪdʒ ə fɔl. ɔlweɪz tu sizənz əhɛd fəɹ ðə mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv ðə hæŋʒɪŋz wɑz ðə kʌstəm, tə pɹəvaɪɾ ə tʌtʃ ə ɹɪlif fɹəm wɪntɝz koʊld əɹ sʌmɝz hit, tə ɹimaɪnd waɪl spɹɪŋz nu ɡɹoʊθ wɑz ɑn ɔl ðə tʃɹiz ðət ðə bɹæntʃəz wəd ɡɹoʊ bɛɹ ən ðə snoʊz kʌm əɡɛn, tə ɹimaɪnd wən dɛd livz wɝ fɔlɪŋ ən ðə fɝst snoʊz, tu, ən deɪz ɡɹu ɛvɝ koʊldɝ, ðət ðəɹ wəd bi ə spɹɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ ə fju bæɾəlz əmʌŋ ðɛm, ʃoʊɪŋ deɪz ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɡlɔɹi fəɹ ændɝ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn dɪd nɑɾ ɛndʒɔɪ lʊkɪŋ ət ðoʊz əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi hæɾ əz ə ɡɝl. stɪl, ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ pleɪs naʊ, əz wɛl, toʊkənz ʌv wʌt bæɾəl æktʃəli  wɑz. ðə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin haʊ ə tʃaɪld lʊkt ət θɪŋz ən ə wʊmən dɪd. ɡlɔɹi wɑz ɔlweɪz bɑt wɪð blʌd. ɡlɔɹi əsaɪd, nɛsəsɛɹi θɪŋz wɝ ɔfən peɪd fəɹ wɪð bæɾəl ən blʌd.

Wet Things Inside, the gilded stand-lamps were lit, since daylight never penetrated far into the palace, flames flickering on the lamps that lacked glass mantles. The lamps' mirrors provided a good light in the bustling corridor, though, and bustling it was, with liveried servants scurrying in every direction, or sweeping or mopping. Serving men with the White Lion on the left breast of their red coats were up on tall ladders taking down the winter tapestries, mainly flowers and scenes of summer, and putting up the spring tapestries, many displaying the colorful foliage of fall. Always two seasons ahead for the majority of the hangings was the custom, to provide a touch of relief from winter's cold or summer's heat, to remind while spring's new growth was on all the trees that the branches would grow bare and the snows come again, to remind when dead leaves were falling and the first snows, too, and days grew ever colder, that there would be a spring. There were a few battles among them, showing days of particular glory for Andor, but Elayne did not enjoy looking at those as much as she had as a girl. Still, they had their place now, as well, tokens of what battle actually was. The difference between how a child looked at things and a woman did. Glory was always bought with blood. Glory aside, necessary things were often paid for with battle and blood.

ðəɹ wɝ tu fju sɝvəns tə kæɹi aʊt sətʃ tæsks ɪn ə taɪmli mænɝ, ən ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ wɝ waɪt-hɛɹd pɛnʃənɝz wɪð bɛn bæks u sɛldəm muv kwɪkli ɪn ɛni keɪs. haʊɛvɝ sloʊ ðeɪ wɝ, ʃi wɑz ɡlæd ðeɪ hæd wɪlɪŋli kʌm aʊɾ ə ɹitaɪɝmənt, tə tʃɹeɪn ðoʊz nuli haɪɝɾ ən teɪk ʌp ðə slæk lɛf baɪ ðoʊz u hæd flɛd waɪl ɡeɪbɹəl ɹeɪn əɹ æftɝ ɹænd tʊk keɪɛmlɪn, ɛls ðə pæləs wʊɾə teɪkən ɑn ði æspɛkt ʌv ə bɑɹn baɪ ðɪs taɪm. ə dɝɾi bɑɹn. ət list ɔl ə ðə wɪntɝ ɹʌnɝz wɝ ʌp ɔf ðə flɔɹz. ʃi lɛft ə dæmp tʃɹeɪl bɪhaɪn əɹ ɑn ðə ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt flɔɹ taɪlz, ən wɪð ɔl ðə spɹɪŋ ɹeɪnz, wɛt ɹʌnɝz wʊɾə bɪn spɹaʊɾɪŋ mɪldu bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl.

There were too few servants to carry out such tasks in a timely manner, and a fair number were white-haired pensioners with bent backs who seldom moved quickly in any case. However slow they were, she was glad they had willingly come out of retirement, to train those newly hired and take up the slack left by those who had fled while Gaebril reigned or after Rand took Caemlyn, else the palace would have taken on the aspect of a barn by this time. A dirty barn. At least all of the winter runners were up off the floors. She left a damp trail behind her on the red-and-white floor tiles, and with all the spring rains, wet runners would have been sprouting mildew before nightfall.

sɝvəns ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt hɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ duɾiz lʊkt əɡæst əz ðeɪ baʊɾ əɹ kɝtsid, wɪtʃ dɪd nʌθɪŋ fəɹ əɹ tɛmpɝ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ ʌpsɛt tə si eɪvinhə əɹ bɝdʒɪt dʒɹɛntʃt ən dʒɹɪpɪŋ, əɹ ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən iðɝ. bɝn hɝ, ɪf ɛvɹiwʌn dɪd nɑt stɑp ɪkspɛktɪŋ əɹ tə bi mɑlɪkɑɾəld ɔl ðə deɪ lɔŋ . . . ! hɝ skaʊl wɑz sətʃ ðət ðə sɝvəns bɪɡæn meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ kɝɾəsiz kwɪkli ən skɝiɪŋ ɑn. hɝ tɛmpɝ wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ ðə stʌf ʌv ivnɪŋ stɔɹiz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, ðoʊ ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə ənliʃ ɪɾ ɑn sɝvəns. ɑn ɛniwʌn, ɹɪli, bʌt mɔɹ soʊ wɪð sɝvəns. ðeɪ læk ðə lʌɡʒɝi ʌv ʃaʊɾɪŋ bæk.

Servants in red-and-white hurrying about their duties looked aghast as they bowed or curtsied, which did nothing for her temper. They did not appear upset to see Aviendha or Birgitte drenched and dripping, or the Guardswomen either. Burn her, if everyone did not stop expecting her to be mollycoddled all the day long . . . ! Her scowl was such that the servants began making their courtesies quickly and scurrying on. Her temper was becoming the stuff of evening stories in front of the fireplace, though she tried not to unleash it on servants. On anyone, really, but more so with servants. They lacked the luxury of shouting back.

ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə ɡoʊ stʃɹeɪt tə hɝ əpɑɹtməns ən tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ ɪntɛntʃənz əɹ noʊ, ʃi tɝn əsaɪd wən ʃi sɔ ɹin kɔɹli wɔkɪŋ ɪn ə kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ wɛɹ ðə flɔɹ taɪlz wɝ ɔl ɹɛd. ðə sɝvəns' ɹiækʃənz hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪt. ʃi wɑz nɑt biɪŋ stʌbɝn. ʃi wɑz wɛt, ən ʃi wɑntəd dʒɹaɪ kloʊðɪŋ ən ə wɔɹm taʊəl ɪn ðə wɝst weɪ, bʌt siɪŋ ðə kɪnswʊmən wɑz ə sɝpɹaɪz, ən ðə tu wɪmən wɪð ɹin ɔlsoʊ kɑɾ əɹ aɪ. bɝdʒɪt mʌɾɝd ə kɝs bɪfɔɹ fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ, swɪʃɪŋ əɹ bɑstɑv saɪdweɪz θɹu ði ɛɹ əz ðoʊ θɪŋkɪŋ ə stʃɹaɪkɪŋ sʌmwʌn. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ ə blɛn ə lɔŋ sʌfɝɪŋ ən ɪɹɪɾəbɪlɪti, sun staɪfəld. eɪvinhə nɛvɝ lɛft ɪleɪnz saɪd, ðoʊ bɪzəli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪŋ wɔɾɝ aʊɾ ə hɝ ʃɔl. dɪspaɪɾ ɔl ðə ɹeɪn ʃi hæd sin, ɔl ðə ɹɪvɝz sɪns kɹɔsɪŋ ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld ən ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪstɝnz bɪniθ ðə sɪɾi, eɪvinhə wɪnst ət ðə weɪst, ðə wɔɾɝ splæʃɪŋ jusləsli ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ði eɪt ɡɑɹdzwɪmən, lɛf bɪhaɪn baɪ hɝ sʌɾən swɝv, hɝid tə kætʃ ʌp, stɑləɾ ən saɪlən ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə stæmp ə ðɛɹ buts ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz. ɡɪv ɛniwʌn ə sɔɹɾ ən buts, ən ðeɪ bɪɡæn stæmpɪŋ.

She intended to go straight to her apartments and change, but intentions or no, she turned aside when she saw Reanne Corly walking in a crossing corridor where the floor tiles were all red. The servants' reactions had nothing to do with it. She was not being stubborn. She was wet, and she wanted dry clothing and a warm towel in the worst way, but seeing the Kinswoman was a surprise, and the two women with Reanne also caught her eye. Birgitte muttered a curse before following her, swishing her bowstave sideways through the air as though thinking of striking someone. The bond carried a blend of long suffering and irritability, soon stifled. Aviendha never left Elayne's side, though busily trying to wring water out of her shawl. Despite all the rain she had seen, all the rivers since crossing the Spine of the World and the great cisterns beneath the city, Aviendha winced at the waste, the water splashing uselessly on the floor. The eight Guardswomen, left behind by her sudden swerve, hurried to catch up, stolid and silent except for the stamp of their boots on the floor tiles. Give anyone a sword and boots, and they began stamping.

wʌn ə ðə wɪmən wɪð ɹin wɑz kɛɹə dɪfən, hu hæd bɪn ðə waɪz wʊmən, əɹ hilɝ, ʌv ə fɪʃɪŋ vɪlədʒ ɑn toʊmən hɛd bɪfɔɹ ðə sintʃæn kɑlɝd hɝ. plʌmp ən mɛɹi-aɪɾ ɪn bɹaʊn wʊl wɪð ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd blu ən waɪt flaʊɝz əɾ əɹ kʌfs, kɛɹə əpɪɹd lɪɾəl oʊldɝ ðən ɪleɪn, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz nɪɹli fɪfti. ði ʌðɝ wɑz neɪm dʒɪlɑɹi, ə fɔɹmɝ deɪmeɪn fɹəm sintʃæn. dɪspaɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ meɪɾ ɪleɪnz flɛʃ fil koʊld. wʌtɛvɝ ɛls kəd bi sɛɾ ə hɝ, ðə wʊmən wɑz sintʃæn, æftɝ ɔl.

One of the women with Reanne was Kara Defane, who had been the wise woman, or Healer, of a fishing village on Toman Head before the Seanchan collared her. Plump and merry-eyed in brown wool with embroidered blue and white flowers at her cuffs, Kara appeared little older than Elayne, though she was nearly fifty. The other was named Jillari, a former damane from Seanchan. Despite everything, the sight of her made Elayne's flesh feel cold. Whatever else could be said of her, the woman was Seanchan, after all.

nɑɾ ivən dʒɪlɑɹi hɝsɛlf nu haʊ oʊld ʃi wɑz, ðoʊ ʃi əpɪɹd dʒʌst ɪndə hɝ mɪɾəl jɪɹz. slaɪɾ ə bɪld, wɪð lɔŋ, faɪɝi ɹɛd hɛɹ ən aɪz əz ɡɹin əz eɪvinhəz, ʃi ən mɑɹɪl, ði ʌðɝ sintʃæn-bɔɹn deɪmeɪn u ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə pæləs, pɝsɪstəɾ ɪn meɪnteɪnɪŋ ðət ðeɪ stɪl wɝ deɪmeɪn, ðət ðeɪ niɾəd tə bi kɑlɝd kəz ʌv wʌt ðeɪ kəd du. deɪli wɔks wɝ wʌn weɪ ðə kɪn wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əkʌstəm əm tə fɹiɾəm. kɛɹfəli supɝvaɪzd wɔks, ʌv kɔɹs. ðeɪ wɝ ɔlweɪz kloʊsli wɑtʃt, deɪ ən naɪt. iðɝ maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə fɹi ðə sʌldəm, ʌðɝwaɪz. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, kɛɹə hɝsɛlf wɑz nɑt tʃɹʌstɪɾ əloʊn wɪð ɛni ʌv ðə sʌldəm, nɔɹ wɑz lɛmɔɹ, ə jʌŋ tæɹɑbənɝ noʊbəl kɑlɝd wən tæntʃəkoʊ fɛl. ðə noʊʃən wəd nɑt kʌm tə ðɛm ɑn ɪts oʊn, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ seɪɪŋ wʌɾ iðɝ wəd də ɪf ə sʌldəm ɔɹɾɝd əɹ tə hɛlp ðə wʊmən ɪskeɪp. ðə hæbəɾ ʌv oʊbiɾiəns ɹɪmeɪn stʃɹɔŋ ɪn kɛɹə ən lɛmɔɹ boʊθ.

Not even Jillari herself knew how old she was, though she appeared just into her middle years. Slight of build, with long, fiery red hair and eyes as green as Aviendha's, she and Marille, the other Seanchan-born damane who remained in the palace, persisted in maintaining that they still were damane, that they needed to be collared because of what they could do. Daily walks were one way the Kin were trying to accustom them to freedom. Carefully supervised walks, of course. They were always closely watched, day and night. Either might try to free the sul'dam, otherwise. For that matter, Kara herself was not trusted alone with any of the sul'dam, nor was Lemore, a young Taraboner noble collared when Tanchico fell. The notion would not come to them on its own, yet there was no saying what either would do if a sul'dam ordered her to help the woman escape. The habit of obedience remained strong in Kara and Lemore both.

dʒɪlɑɹiz aɪz waɪɾənd ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɪleɪn, ən ʃi ɪmiɾiətli fɛl tə hɝ niz wɪð ə θʌd. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə foʊl hɝsɛlf ɪndə ə bʌndəl ɑn ðə flɔɹ, bʌt kɛɹə kɑɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən dʒɛnli ɝdʒd əɹ bæk tə hɝ fit. ɪleɪn tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lɛɾ əɹ dɪsteɪst ʃoʊ. ən hoʊp ðəɾ ɪf ɪt dɪd, ɛvɹiwʌn wəd teɪk ɪt fəɹ ðə nilɪŋ ən kɹaʊtʃɪŋ. səm ʌv ɪt wɑz. haʊ kəɾ ɛniwʌn wɑnə bi kɑlɝd? ʃi hɝd liniz vɔɪs əɡɛn, ən ʃɪvɝd. jə kænt noʊ ənʌðɝ wʊmənz ɹizənz əntɪl juv wɔɹn əɹ dʒɹɛs fəɹ ə jɪɹ. bɝn əɹ ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɛni dɪzaɪɝ tə də ðæt!

Jillari's eyes widened at the sight of Elayne, and she immediately fell to her knees with a thud. She tried to fold herself into a bundle on the floor, but Kara caught her shoulders and gently urged her back to her feet. Elayne tried not to let her distaste show. And hoped that if it did, everyone would take it for the kneeling and crouching. Some of it was. How could anyone want to be collared? She heard Lini's voice again, and shivered. You can't know another woman's reasons until you've worn her dress for a year. Burn her if she had any desire to do that!

"noʊ nid fəɹ ɔl ðæt," kɛɹə sɛd. "ðɪs ɪz wʌt wi du." ʃi kɝtsid, nɑt vɛɹi ɡɹeɪsfəli. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin ə taʊn lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə fju hʌnʒɹəd pipəl bɪfɔɹ ðə sintʃæn tʊk hɝ. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ðə ɹɛd-hɛɹd wʊmən spɹɛɾ əɹ oʊn dɑɹk blu skɝts mɔɹ ɔkwɝdli stɪl. ʃi ɔlmoʊs fɛl oʊvɝ, ɪn fækt, ən blʌʃt ə bɹaɪt kɹɪmzən.

"No need for all that," Kara said. "This is what we do." She curtsied, not very gracefully. She had never seen a town larger than a few hundred people before the Seanchan took her. After a moment, the red-haired woman spread her own dark blue skirts more awkwardly still. She almost fell over, in fact, and blushed a bright crimson.

"dʒɪlɑɹi ɪz sɑɹi," ʃi ɔlmoʊst wɪspɝd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ hænz əɾ əɹ weɪst. hɝ aɪz, ʃi kɛp mikli dɝɛktəɾ ət ðə flɔɹ. "dʒɪlɑɹi wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ."

"Jillari is sorry," she almost whispered, folding her hands at her waist. Her eyes, she kept meekly directed at the floor. "Jillari will try to remember."

" 'aɪ,' " kɛɹə sɛd. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ aɪ toʊl ju? aɪ kɔl jə dʒɪlɑɹi, bʌt jə kɔl jɝsɛlf 'aɪ' əɹ 'mi.' tʃɹaɪ ɪt. ən lʊk ət mi. jə kən də ɪt." ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ ə tʃaɪld.

" 'I,' " Kara said. "Remember what I told you? I call you Jillari, but you call yourself 'I' or 'me.' Try it. And look at me. You can do it." She sounded as though she were encouraging a child.

ðə sintʃæn wʊmən wɛɾ əɹ lɪps, ɡɪvɪŋ kɛɹə ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk. "aɪ," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. ən pɹɑmpli bɪɡæn wipɪŋ, tɪɹz ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃiks fæstɝ ðən ʃi kəd waɪp əm əweɪ wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. kɛɹə ɛnvɛləpt əɹ ɪn ə hʌɡ ən meɪd suðɪŋ nɔɪzɪz. ʃi simd əbaʊt tə kɹaɪ, tu. eɪvinhə ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə tɪɹz - mɛn əɹ wɪmən, il wɛpt ʌnəʃeɪmd wən ðeɪ fɛl ðə nid - bʌt fəɹ ðɛm, tʌtʃɪŋ hænz wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt dɪspleɪ ɪn pʌblɪk.

The Seanchan woman wet her lips, giving Kara a sidelong look. "I," she said softly. And promptly began weeping, tears rolling down her cheeks faster than she could wipe them away with her fingers. Kara enveloped her in a hug and made soothing noises. She seemed about to cry, too. Aviendha shifted uncomfortably. It was not the tears - men or women, Aiel wept unashamed when they felt the need - but for them, touching hands was a great display in public.

"waɪ doʊn jə tu wɔk ɑn əloʊn fəɹ ə waɪl," ɹin toʊl ðə pɛɹ wɪð ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ smaɪl ðət dipən ðə faɪn laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ blu aɪz. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz haɪ ən lʌvli, suɾəbəl fəɹ sɪŋɪŋ. "aɪl kætʃ jə ʌp, ən wi kən it təɡɛðɝ." ðeɪ ɔfɝɾ əɹ kɝtsiz, tu, dʒɪlɑɹi stɪl wipɪŋ, ən tɝn əweɪ wɪð kɛɹəz ɑɹm ɝaʊn ðə smɔlɝ wʊmənz ʃoʊldɝz. "ɪf jə kɛɹ tə, maɪ leɪɾi," ɹin sɛd bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn tu stɛps, "wi kəd tɔk ɑn ðə weɪ tə jəɹ əpɑɹtməns."

"Why don't you two walk on alone for a while," Reanne told the pair with a comforting smile that deepened the fine lines at the corners of her blue eyes. Her voice was high and lovely, suitable for singing. "I'll catch you up, and we can eat together." They offered her curtsies, too, Jillari still weeping, and turned away with Kara's arm around the smaller woman's shoulders. "If you care to, my Lady," Reanne said before they had gone two steps, "we could talk on the way to your apartments."

ðə wʊmənz feɪs wɑz kɑm, ən əɹ toʊn pʊt noʊ spɛʃəl fɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə wɝdz, jɛɾ ɪleɪnz dʒɔ taɪɾənd. ʃi fɔɹst ɪt tə ɹɪlæks. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn biɪŋ stʌbɝn stupəd. ʃi wɑz wɛt. ən bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃɪvɝ, ðoʊ ðə deɪ kəd hɑɹdli bi kɔl koʊld. "æn ɛksələn sədʒɛstʃən," ʃi sɛd, ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ sɑɾən ɡɹeɪ skɝts. "kʌm."

The woman's face was calm, and her tone put no special freight on the words, yet Elayne's jaw tightened. She forced it to relax. There was no point in being stubborn stupid. She was wet. And beginning to shiver, though the day could hardly be called cold. "An excellent suggestion," she said, gathering her sodden gray skirts. "Come."

"wi kəd wɔk ə lɪɾəl fæstɝ," bɝdʒɪt mʌɾɝd, nɑt kwaɪt fɑɹ ɪnʌf ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ.

"We could walk a little faster," Birgitte muttered, not quite far enough under her breath.

"wi kəd ɹʌn," eɪvinhə sɛd, wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip əɹ vɔɪs loʊ əɾ ɔl. "wi maɪt ɡɛt dʒɹaɪ fɹəm ði ɪɡzɝʃən."

"We could run," Aviendha said, without trying to keep her voice low at all. "We might get dry from the exertion."

ɪleɪn ɪɡnɔɹɾ əm ən ɡlaɪɾɪd əɾ ə suɾəbəl peɪs. ɪn əɹ mʌðɝ, ɪt wʊɾə bɪn kɔld ɹiɡəl. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi mænədʒ ðæt, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ɹʌn θɹu ðə pæləs. əɹ ivən hɝi. ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ ɹʌʃɪŋ wəd stɑɹɾ ə dʌzən ɹumɝz ɪf nɑɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd, itʃ wʌn ə səm daɪɹ ɪvɛnt wɝs ðən ðə wʌn bɪfɔɹ. tu mɛni ɹumɝz floʊɾəd ɑn ɛvɹi bɹɛθ ʌv ɛɹ əz ɪt wɑz. ðə wɝst wɑz ðət ðə sɪɾi wɑz əbaʊt tə fɔl, ðət ʃi plæn tə fli bɪfɔɹ ɪt dɪd. noʊ, ʃi wəd bi sin tə bi ʌɾɝli ənɹʌfəld. ɛvɹiwʌn hæd tə bɪliv əɹ kəmplitli kɑnfəɾənt. ivən ɪf ðət wɑz ə fɔls fəsɑd. ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ən ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl jil tə ɛɹəmɪlə. fɪɹ ə dɪfit hæd lɔst əz mɛni bæɾəlz əz wiknəs hæd, ən ʃi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə luz ə sɪŋɡəl wʌn. "aɪ θɔt ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl hæd jə aʊt skaʊɾɪŋ, ɹin."

Elayne ignored them and glided at a suitable pace. In her mother, it would have been called regal. She was not sure she managed that, but she was not about to run through the palace. Or even hurry. The sight of her rushing would start a dozen rumors if not a hundred, each one of some dire event worse than the one before. Too many rumors floated on every breath of air as it was. The worst was that the city was about to fall, that she planned to flee before it did. No, she would be seen to be utterly unruffled. Everyone had to believe her completely confident. Even if that was a false facade. Anything else, and she might as well yield to Arymilla. Fear of defeat had lost as many battles as weakness had, and she could not afford to lose a single one. "I thought the Captain-General had you out scouting, Reanne."

bɝdʒɪt hæd bɪn juzɪŋ tu ʌv ðə kɪn fəɹ skaʊts, wɪmən u kəd nɑt meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə ədmɪɾ ə hɔɹs kɑɹt, bʌt wɪð sɝkəlz ə kɪnswɪmən əveɪləbəl tə meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz, fəɹ tʃɹeɪɾ əz wɛl əz muvɪŋ soʊlʒɝz, ʃi hæd koʊ-ɑptɪd ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ sɪks u kəd tʃɹævəl ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn. ən ɛnsɝkəlɪŋ ɑɹmi wɑz noʊ ɪmpɛɾəmənt tə ðɛm. jɛt ɹinz wɛl-kʌt, faɪn blu wʊl, ðoʊ ʌnədɔɹn seɪv fəɹ ə ɹɛd-ɪnæməl sɝkəl pɪn ɑn ðə haɪ nɛk, wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli ənsuɾɪd fəɹ skʌlkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd.

Birgitte had been using two of the Kin for scouts, women who could not make a gateway large enough to admit a horse cart, but with circles of Kinswomen available to make gateways, for trade as well as moving soldiers, she had co-opted the remaining six who could Travel on their own. An encircling army was no impediment to them. Yet Reanne's well-cut, fine blue wool, though unadorned save for a red-enameled circle pin on the high neck, was decidedly unsuited for skulking about the countryside.

"ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl bɪlivz əɹ skaʊts nid ɹɛst. ənlaɪk hɝsɛlf," ɹin æɾəd blænli, ɹeɪzɪŋ ən aɪbɹaʊ ət bɝdʒɪt. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ ə bɹif flæʃ ʌv ənɔɪəns. eɪvinhə læft fəɹ səm ɹizən; ɪleɪn stɪl dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn il hjumɝ. "təmɑɹoʊ, aɪ ɡoʊ aʊɾ əɡɛn. ɪt teɪks mi bæk tə ðə deɪz lɔŋ əɡoʊ wən aɪ wɑz ə pæk-pɛdlɝ wɪð wʌn mjul." ðə kɪn ɔl fɑloʊd mɛni kɹæfs dʊɹɪŋ ðɛɹ lɔŋ laɪvz, ɔlweɪz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ loʊkeɪʃən ən kɹæf bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn tʊk noʊɾ ə haʊ sloʊli ðeɪ eɪdʒd. ði oʊldəst əmʌŋ əm hæd mæstɝd hæf ə dʌzən kɹæfs əɹ mɔɹ, ʃɪftɪŋ fɹəm wʌn tə ənʌðɝ izəli. "aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə juz maɪ fɹideɪ hɛlpɪŋ dʒɪlɑɹi sɛɾəl ɑn ə sɝneɪm." ɹin ɡɹɪməst. "ɪts kʌstəm ɪn sintʃæn tə stʃɹaɪk ə ɡɝlz neɪm fɹəm əɹ fæmliz ɹoʊlz wən ʃiz kɑlɝd, ən ðə pʊɹ wʊmən filz ʃiz noʊ ɹaɪt tə ðə neɪm ʃi wɑz bɔɹn wɪð. dʒɪlɑɹi wɑz ɡɪvən wɪð ðə kɑlɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑns tə kip ðæt."

"The Captain-General believes her scouts need rest. Unlike herself," Reanne added blandly, raising an eyebrow at Birgitte. The bond carried a brief flash of annoyance. Aviendha laughed for some reason; Elayne still did not understand Aiel humor. "Tomorrow, I go out again. It takes me back to the days long ago when I was a pack-peddler with one mule." The Kin all followed many crafts during their long lives, always changing location and craft before anyone took note of how slowly they aged. The oldest among them had mastered half a dozen crafts or more, shifting from one to another easily. "I decided to use my freeday helping Jillari settle on a surname." Reanne grimaced. "It's custom in Seanchan to strike a girl's name from her family's rolls when she's collared, and the poor woman feels she has no right to the name she was born with. Jillari was given with the collar, but she wants to keep that."

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ ɹizənz tə heɪt ðə sintʃæn ðən aɪ kən kaʊnt," ɪleɪn sɛd hiɾɪdli. ðɛn, bɪleɪɾədli, ʃi kɑɾ ʌp tə ði ɪmpɔɹɾ ʌv ɪɾ ɔl. lɝnɪŋ tə kɝtsi. tʃuzɪŋ ə nu sɝneɪm. bɝn hɝ, ɪf pɹɛɡnənsi wɑz meɪkɪŋ əɹ sloʊ-wɪɾɪd ɑn tɑp ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls . . . ! "wɛn dɪd dʒɪlɑɹi tʃeɪnʒ əɹ maɪn əbaʊt ðə kɑlɝ?" ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə lɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn noʊ ʃi wɑz biɪŋ dɛns tədeɪ.

"There are more reasons to hate the Seanchan than I can count," Elayne said heatedly. Then, belatedly, she caught up to the import of it all. Learning to curtsy. Choosing a new surname. Burn her, if pregnancy was making her slow-witted on top of everything else . . . ! "When did Jillari change her mind about the collar?" There was no reason to let everyone know she was being dense today.

ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz ɪkspɹɛʃən dɪd nɑɾ ɔltɝ ə wɪt, bʌt ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd dʒʌs lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə lɛɾ ɪleɪn noʊ hɝ dɪsɛpʃən hæd feɪld. "dʒʌs ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, æftɝ jə ən ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl lɛft, əɹ juɾ əv bɪn ɪnfɔɹmd." ɹin hɝiɾ ɑn soʊ ðə pɔɪn hæd noʊ taɪm tə fɛstɝ. "æn ðɛɹz ʌðɝ nuz əz ɡʊd. ət list, ɪts sʌmwʌt ɡʊd. wʌn ə ðə sʌldəm, mɑɹli noʊkɪn - jə ɹikɔl hɝ? - hæz ədmɪɾəd siɪŋ ðə wivz."

The other woman's expression did not alter a whit, but she hesitated just long enough to let Elayne know her deception had failed. "Just this morning, after you and the Captain-General left, or you'd have been informed." Reanne hurried on so the point had no time to fester. "And there's other news as good. At least, it's somewhat good. One of the sul'dam, Marli Noichin - you recall her? - has admitted seeing the weaves."

"oʊ, ðəɾ ɪz ɡʊd nuz," ɪleɪn mɝmɝd. "vɛɹi ɡʊd. twɛnti-eɪt mɔɹ tə ɡoʊ, bʌt ðeɪ maɪt bi iziɝ naʊ ðət wʌn ə ðɛm əz bɹoʊkən." ʃi hæd wɑtʃt ən ətɛmp tə kənvɪns mɑɹli ðət ʃi kəd lɝn tə tʃænəl, ðət ʃi kəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi si wivz ə ðə paʊɝ. ðə plʌmp sintʃæn wʊmən hæd bɪn stʌbɝnli dɪfaɪən ivən æftɝ ʃi bɪɡæn kɹaɪɪŋ.

"Oh, that is good news," Elayne murmured. "Very good. Twenty-eight more to go, but they might be easier now that one of them has broken." She had watched an attempt to convince Marli that she could learn to channel, that she could already see weaves of the Power. The plump Seanchan woman had been stubbornly defiant even after she began crying.

"sʌmwʌt ɡʊd, aɪ sɛd." ɹin saɪd. "ɪn mɑɹliz əpɪnjən, ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv ədmɪɾəd ʃi kɪlz tʃɪlʒɹən. naʊ ʃi ɪnsɪsts ðət ʃi mʌs bi kɑlɝd. ʃi bɛɡz fəɹ ði æɾəm. ɪt meɪks maɪ skɪn kɹip. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt tə də wɪð hɝ."

"Somewhat good, I said." Reanne sighed. "In Marli's opinion, she might as well have admitted she kills children. Now she insists that she must be collared. She begs for the a'dam. It makes my skin creep. I don't know what to do with her."

"sɛn əɹ bæk tə ðə sintʃæn əz sun əz wi kæn," ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd.

"Send her back to the Seanchan as soon as we can," Elayne replied.

ɹin stɑp dɛɾ ɪn ʃɑk, hɝ aɪbɹaʊz klaɪmɪŋ. bɝdʒɪt klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt laʊdli - ɪmpeɪʃəns fɪl ðə bɑn bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ staɪfəld - ən ðə kɪnswʊmən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ðən bɪɡæn wɔkɪŋ əɡɛn, əɾ ə fæstɝ peɪs ðən bɪfɔɹ. "bʌt ðəl meɪk əɹ ə deɪmeɪn. aɪ kæn kəndɛm ɛni wʊmən tə ðæt."

Reanne stopped dead in shock, her eyebrows climbing. Birgitte cleared her throat loudly - impatience filled the bond before being stifled - and the Kinswoman gave a start, then began walking again, at a faster pace than before. "But they'll make her a damane. I can't condemn any woman to that."

ɪleɪn ɡeɪv əɹ wɔɹɾɝ ə lʊk ðət slɪɾ ɔf laɪk ə dæɡɝ slaɪɾɪŋ ɔf ɡʊɾ ɑɹmɝ. bɝdʒɪts ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz . . . blænd. tə ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən, biɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ kənteɪn stʃɹɔŋ ɛləməns ʌv oʊldɝ sɪstɝ. ən wɝs, səmtaɪmz mʌðɝ.

Elayne gave her Warder a look that slid off like a dagger sliding off good armor. Birgitte's expression was . . . bland. To the golden-haired woman, being a Warder contained strong elements of older sister. And worse, sometimes mother.

"aɪ kæn," ʃi sɛɾ ɛmfæɾɪkli, lɛŋθənɪŋ əɹ oʊn stʃɹaɪd. wɛl, ɪt wəd nɑt hɝt tə ɡɛt dʒɹaɪ ə lɪɾəl sunɝ ɹæðɝ ðən leɪɾɝ. "ʃi hɛlp hoʊld ɪnʌf ʌðɝz pɹɪznɝ ðət ʃi dɪzɝvz ə teɪst ʌv ɪt hɝsɛlf, ɹin. bʌt ðæts nɑt waɪ aɪ min tə sɛn əɹ bæk. ɪf ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz wɑns tə steɪ ən lɝn, ən meɪk ʌp fəɹ wʌt ʃiz dʌn, aɪ sɝɾənli woʊn hæn əɹ tə ðə sintʃæn, bʌt laɪts tʃɹuθ, aɪ hoʊp ðeɪ ɔl fil laɪk mɑɹli. ðəl pʊɾ ən æɾəm ɑn hɝ, ɹin, bʌt ðeɪ woʊn bi eɪbəl tə kip sikɹəɾ u ʃi wɑz. ɛvɹi wʌn-taɪm sʌldəm aɪ kən sɛn ðə sintʃæn tə kɑlɝ wɪl bi ə mætɑk dɪɡɪŋ ət ðɛɹ ɹuts."

"I can," she said emphatically, lengthening her own stride. Well, it would not hurt to get dry a little sooner rather than later. "She helped hold enough others prisoner that she deserves a taste of it herself, Reanne. But that's not why I mean to send her back. If any of the others wants to stay and learn, and make up for what she's done, I certainly won't hand her to the Seanchan, but Light's truth, I hope they all feel like Marli. They'll put an a'dam on her, Reanne, but they won't be able to keep secret who she was. Every one-time sul'dam I can send the Seanchan to collar will be a mattock digging at their roots."

"ə hɑɹʃ dɪsɪʒən," ɹin sɛd sædli. ʃi plʌkt əɾ əɹ skɝts ɪn ən ædʒəteɪɾəd mænɝ, smuðd ðɛm, ðən plʌkt əɾ əm əɡɛn. "pɝhæps jə maɪt kənsɪɾɝ θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn ɪt fəɹ ə fju deɪz? ʃʊɹli ɪɾ ɪzən ɛniθɪŋ ðəɾ əz tə bi dʌn ɪmiɾiətli."

"A harsh decision," Reanne said sadly. She plucked at her skirts in an agitated manner, smoothed them, then plucked at them again. "Perhaps you might consider thinking on it for a few days? Surely it isn't anything that has to be done immediately."

ɪleɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. ðə wʊmən hæɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ɪmplaɪd ðət ʃi hæd ɹitʃt ðɪs dɪsɪʒən ɪn wʌn ə hɝ swɪŋɪŋ mudz! bʌt hæd ʃi? ɪt simd ɹizənəbəl ən lɑdʒɪkəl. ðeɪ kəd nɑt kip ðə sʌldəm ɪmpɹɪzən fɝɛvɝ. sɛndɪŋ ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi fɹi bæk tə ðə sintʃæn wɑz ə weɪ tə bi ɹɪɾ ə ðɛm ən stʃɹaɪk ə bloʊ ət ðə sintʃæn ət ðə seɪm taɪm. ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən heɪtʃɹəɾ ʌv ɛni sintʃæn. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪt wɑz. bɝn hɝ, bʌt ʃi blʌɾi wɛl heɪɾəd biɪŋ ənʃʊɹ wɛðɝ əɹ oʊn dɪsɪʒənz wɝ saʊnd! ʃi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə meɪk ənsaʊn dɪsɪʒənz. stɪl, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɝi. bɛɾɝ tə sɛn bæk ə ɡɹup, ɪf pɑsəbəl, ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt. ðəɹ wɑz lɛs tʃæns ə sʌmwʌn ɝeɪnʒɪŋ ən "æksəɾənt," ðət weɪ. ʃi dɪd nɑt pʊt ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ pæs ðə sintʃæn. "aɪ wɪl θɪŋk ɑn ɪt, ɹin, bʌɾ aɪ daʊɾ əl tʃeɪnʒ maɪ maɪnd."

Elayne gritted her teeth. The woman had as much as implied that she had reached this decision in one of her swinging moods! But had she? It seemed reasonable and logical. They could not keep the sul'dam imprisoned forever. Sending those who did not want to be free back to the Seanchan was a way to be rid of them and strike a blow at the Seanchan at the same time. It was more than hatred of any Seanchan. Of course, it was. Burn her, but she bloody well hated being unsure whether her own decisions were sound! She could not afford to make unsound decisions. Still, there was no hurry. Better to send back a group, if possible, in any event. There was less chance of someone arranging an "accident," that way. She did not put that sort of thing past the Seanchan. "I will think on it, Reanne, but I doubt I'll change my mind."

ɹin saɪɾ əɡɛn, dipli. iɡɝ fəɹ əɹ pɹɑməst ɹɪtɝn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən nɑvəs waɪt - ʃi hæd bɪn hɝd tə seɪ ʃi ɛnvid kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə - ʃi wɑntəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ tə ɛntɝ ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn hæɾ əɹ daʊts. ɹin wɑz kaɪndhɑɹɾɪd, sɔfθɑɹɾɪd ɪn fækt, ən ɪleɪn hæd nɛvɝ mɛɾ ɛni ɡɹin u kəd bi kɔl sɑft. ivən ðoʊz u sim fɹɪli əɹ fɹeɪl ɑn ðə sɝfəs wɝ koʊl stil ɪnsaɪd.

Reanne sighed again, deeply. Eager for her promised return to the White Tower and novice white - she had been heard to say she envied Kirstian and Zarya - she wanted very much to enter the Green Ajah, but Elayne had her doubts. Reanne was kindhearted, softhearted in fact, and Elayne had never met any Green who could be called soft. Even those who seemed frilly or frail on the surface were cold steel inside.

əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, vændin ɡlaɪɾɪd fɹəm ə kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ, slɛndɝ, waɪt-hɛɹɾ ən ɡɹeɪsfəl ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ wʊl wɪð dip bɹaʊn tʃɹɪm, ən tɝn ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ, əpɛɹənli wɪθaʊt noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðɛm. ʃi wɑz ɡɹin, ən əz hɑɹɾ əz ə hæmɝhɛd. jeɪɛm, hɝ wɔɹɾɝ, wɔk bɪsaɪd hɝ, hɛd bɛn ɪn kloʊs kɑnvɝseɪʃən, naʊ ən ðən ɹeɪkɪŋ ə hæn θɹu hɪz θɪnɪŋ ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ. nɑɹld ən lin, hɪz dɑɹk ɡɹin koʊt hæŋɪŋ lus ɑn hɪm, hi wɑz oʊld, bʌɾ ɛvɹi skɹæp əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi, ən oʊld ɹut ðət kəd dʌl æksiz. kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə, boʊθ ɪn pleɪn nɑvəs waɪt, fɑloʊd mikli wɪð ðɛɹ hænz foʊldəɾ ət ðɛɹ weɪsts, ðə wʌn peɪl əz ə kɛɹhinɪn, ði ʌðɝ ʃɔɹɾ ən slɪm-hɪpt. fəɹ ɹʌnəweɪz u hæd səksiɾəd ɪn wʌt soʊ fju dɪd, ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ fɹi ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝ fəɹ jɪɹz, oʊvɝ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ɪn kɝstʃənz keɪs, ðeɪ hæd ɹisɛɾəld ɪndə ðɛɹ pleɪsəz əz nɑvəsɪz wɪð ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl iz. bʌt ðɛn, ðə kɪnz ɹul wɑz ə blɛndɪŋ ə ðə ɹulz ðət ɡʌvɝnd nɑvəsɪz ən ðoʊz ðəɾ æksɛptɪd lɪv baɪ. pɝhæps, tə ðɛm, ðə waɪt wʊlən dʒɹɛsəz ən ðə lɔs ə fɹiɾəm tə kʌm ən ɡoʊ əz ðeɪ tʃoʊz wɝ ði oʊnli ɹil tʃeɪnʒ, ðoʊ ðə kɪn ɹɛɡjəleɪɾəd ðət læs tə səm ɪkstɛnt.

Ahead of them, Vandene glided from a crossing corridor, slender, white-haired and graceful in dark gray wool with deep brown trim, and turned in the same direction they were going, apparently without noticing them. She was Green, and as hard as a hammerhead. Jaem, her Warder, walked beside her, head bent in close conversation, now and then raking a hand through his thinning gray hair. Gnarled and lean, his dark green coat hanging loose on him, he was old, but every scrap as hard as she, an old root that could dull axes. Kirstian and Zarya, both in plain novice white, followed meekly with their hands folded at their waists, the one pale as a Cairhienin, the other short and slim-hipped. For runaways who had succeeded in what so few did, remaining free of the White Tower for years, over three hundred years in Kirstian's case, they had resettled into their places as novices with remarkable ease. But then, the Kin's Rule was a blending of the rules that governed novices and those that Accepted lived by. Perhaps, to them, the white woolen dresses and the loss of freedom to come and go as they chose were the only real change, though the Kin regulated that last to some extent.

"aɪm vɛɹi ɡlæd ʃiz ðoʊz tu tə ɑkjəpaɪ hɝ," ɹin mɝmɝɾ ɪn toʊnz ə sɪmpəθi. peɪn kɛɹɪŋ ʃoʊn ɪn əɹ aɪz. "ɪts ɡʊd ðət ʃi mɔɹnz əɹ sɪstɝ, bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ ʃid bi əbsɛst wɪð æɾɪliz' dɛθ wɪθaʊt kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə. ʃi meɪ bi ɛniweɪ. aɪ bɪliv ðət dʒɹɛs ʃiz wɛɹɪŋ bɪlɔŋ tə æɾɪliz. aɪv tʃɹaɪɾ ɔfɝɪŋ sɑləs - aɪ hæv ɪkspɪɹiəns hɛlpɪŋ pipəl oʊvɝkʌm ɡɹif; aɪv bɪn ə vɪlədʒ waɪz wʊmən əz wɛl əz wɛɹɪŋ ðə ɹɛd bɛlt ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ mɛni jɪɹz əɡoʊ - bʌt ʃi woʊnt ɡɪmi tu wɝdz."

"I'm very glad she has those two to occupy her," Reanne murmured in tones of sympathy. Pained caring shone in her eyes. "It's good that she mourns her sister, but I fear she'd be obsessed with Adeleas' death without Kirstian and Zarya. She may be anyway. I believe that dress she's wearing belonged to Adeleas. I've tried offering solace - I have experience helping people overcome grief; I've been a village Wise Woman as well as wearing the red belt in Ebou Dar many years ago - but she won't give me two words."

ɪn fækt, vændin wɔɹ oʊnli hɝ dɛd sɪstɝz kloʊðɪŋ, naʊ, ən æɾɪliz' flaʊɝi pɝfjum, əz wɛl. ət taɪmz, ɪleɪn θɔt vændin wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɪkʌm æɾɪliz, tə ɔfɝ ʌp hɝsɛlf ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə bɹɪŋ əɹ sɪstɝ bæk tə laɪf. bʌt kəd jə fɔl sʌmwʌn fəɹ biɪŋ əbsɛst wɪð faɪndɪŋ u hæd mɝɾɝd əɹ sɪstɝ? nɑt ðət mɔɹ ðən ə hændfʊl ə pipəl nu ðət wɑz wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls bɪlivd əz ɹin dɪd, ðət ʃi wɑz əbzɔɹbd wɪð titʃɪŋ kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə, ðəɾ ən bɪɡɪnɪŋ ðɛɹ pʌnɪʃmən fəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ. vændin wɑz duɪŋ boʊθ, ʌv kɔɹs, ən wɪð ə wɪl, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz ɹɪli dʒʌst ə kʌvɝ fəɹ əɹ tʃɹu pɝpəs.

In fact, Vandene wore only her dead sister's clothing, now, and Adeleas' flowery perfume, as well. At times, Elayne thought Vandene was trying to become Adeleas, to offer up herself in order to bring her sister back to life. But could you fault someone for being obsessed with finding who had murdered her sister? Not that more than a handful of people knew that was what she was doing. Everyone else believed as Reanne did, that she was absorbed with teaching Kirstian and Zarya, that and beginning their punishment for running away. Vandene was doing both, of course, and with a will, yet it was really just a cover for her true purpose.

ɪleɪn ɹitʃt aʊt wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ, ən faʊn eɪvinhəz hænd weɪɾɪŋ tə teɪk hɝz, ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ ɡɹɪp. ʃi skwiz bæk, əneɪbəl tə ɪmædʒən ðə ɡɹif ə luzɪŋ eɪvinhə. ðeɪ ʃɛɹɾ ə kwɪk ɡlæns, ən eɪvinhəz aɪz mɪɹɝɾ əɹ oʊn filɪŋz. hæd ʃi ɹɪli wʌns θɔɾ il feɪsəz ɪmpæsɪv ən ənɹiɾəbəl?

Elayne reached out without looking, and found Aviendha's hand waiting to take hers, a comforting grip. She squeezed back, unable to imagine the grief of losing Aviendha. They shared a quick glance, and Aviendha's eyes mirrored her own feelings. Had she really once thought Aiel faces impassive and unreadable?

"æz jə seɪ, ɹin, ʃiz kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə tə ɑkjəpaɪ hɝ." ɹin wɑz nɑɾ əmʌŋ ðə hændfʊl u nu ðə tʃɹuθ. "wi ɔl mɔɹn ɪn əɹ oʊn weɪ. vændin wɪl faɪn sɑləs əlɔŋ əɹ oʊn pæθ."

"As you say, Reanne, she has Kirstian and Zarya to occupy her." Reanne was not among the handful who knew the truth. "We all mourn in our own way. Vandene will find solace along her own path."

wən ʃi faʊn æɾɪliz' mɝɾɝɝ, ɪt wɑz tə bi hoʊpt. ɪf ðət feɪl tə ət lis bɪɡɪn əswɑdʒɪŋ ðə peɪn. . . . wɛl, ðət wɑz tə bi feɪst wən ɪt mʌs bi. fəɹ naʊ, ʃi mʌst əlaʊ vændin əɹ hɛd. ɪspɛʃli sɪns ʃi hæd noʊ daʊt ðə ɡɹin wəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ɛni ətɛmp tə ɹeɪn əɹ ɪn. ðət wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪɹəteɪɾɪŋ; ɪt wɑz ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ. ʃi hæd tə wɑtʃ vændin pɝhæps dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ən wɝs, meɪk jus ʌv ɪt. hævɪŋ noʊ ɔltɝnəɾɪv meɪd ðət noʊ lɛs ənpæləɾəbəl.

When she found Adeleas' murderer, it was to be hoped. If that failed to at least begin assuaging the pain. . . . Well, that was to be faced when it must be. For now, she must allow Vandene her head. Especially since she had no doubt the Green would ignore any attempt to rein her in. That was more than irritating; it was infuriating. She had to watch Vandene perhaps destroying herself, and worse, make use of it. Having no alternative made that no less unpalatable.

əz vændin ən əɹ kəmpænjənz tɝn əsaɪd daʊn ənʌðɝ hɔlweɪ, ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ʌv ə saɪd kɔɹəɾɝ ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪleɪn, ə staʊt, kwaɪət wʊmən wɪð ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ bʌn ətɑp əɹ hɛɾ ən ən ɛɹ ə ɹiɡəl dɪɡnəɾi, hɝ fɔɹməl skɑɹlət tɑbɝd wɪð ðə waɪt laɪən ʌv ændɝ əz ɔlweɪz lʊkɪŋ fɹɛʃli aɪɝnd. ɪleɪn hæd nɛvɝ sin əɹ wɪð ə hɛɹ aʊɾ ə pleɪs əɹ lʊkɪŋ ivən slaɪtli ðə wɝs fəɹ ə lɔŋ deɪ spɛn oʊvɝsiɪŋ ðə wɝkɪŋz ə ðə pæləs. ən mɔɹ bɪsaɪdz. hɝ ɹaʊn feɪs əpɪɹd pʌzəl fəɹ səm ɹizən, bʌɾ ɪt tʊk ɑn ə lʊk ə kənsɝn ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɪleɪn. "waɪ, maɪ leɪɾi, jəɹ dʒɹɛntʃt," ʃi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ʃɑkt, əz ʃi meɪɾ əɹ kɝtsi. "ju nid tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðoʊz wɛt θɪŋz ɹaɪɾ əweɪ."

As Vandene and her companions turned aside down another hallway, Reene Harfor appeared out of a side corridor right in front of Elayne, a stout, quiet woman with a graying bun atop her head and an air of regal dignity, her formal scarlet tabard with the White Lion of Andor as always looking freshly ironed. Elayne had never seen her with a hair out of place or looking even slightly the worse for a long day spent overseeing the workings of the palace. And more besides. Her round face appeared puzzled for some reason, but it took on a look of concern at the sight of Elayne. "Why, my Lady, you're drenched," she said, sounding shocked, as she made her curtsy. "You need to get out of those wet things right away."

"θæŋk ju, mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd θɹu hɝ tiθ. "aɪ hædnt noʊɾəst."

"Thank you, Mistress Harfor," Elayne said through her teeth. "I hadn't noticed."

ʃi ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ði aʊtbɝst ɪnstənli - ðə fɝs meɪd hæd bɪn əz feɪθfəl tə hɝ əz tə hɝ mʌðɝ - bʌt wʌt meɪd mæɾɝz wɝs wɑz ðət mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ tʊk əɹ flɛɹ-ʌp ɪn stʃɹaɪd, nɛvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz blɪŋkɪŋ. ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənz mudz wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɛniθɪŋ tə bi sɝpɹaɪzd æt.

She regretted the outburst instantly - the First Maid had been as faithful to her as to her mother - but what made matters worse was that Mistress Harfor took her flare-up in stride, never so much as blinking. Elayne Trakand's moods were no longer anything to be surprised at.

"aɪ wɪl wɔk wɪð jə ɪf aɪ meɪ, maɪ leɪɾi," ʃi sɛd kɑmli, fɔlɪŋ ɪn əɾ ɪleɪnz saɪd. ə fɹɛkəl jʌŋ sɝvɪŋ wʊmən kæɹiɪŋ ə bæskəɾ ə foʊldəd bɛd lɪnənz bɪɡæn tə ɔfɝ əɹ kɝɾəsiz, oʊnli ə hɛɹ mɔɹ dɝɛktəɾ əɾ ɪleɪn ðən ðə fɝs meɪd, bʌt ɹɪn meɪɾ ə kwɪk dʒɛstʃɝ ðət sɛn ðə ɡɝl skɝiɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəmpliɾəd bɛndɪŋ əɹ niz. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz dʒʌs tə kip əɹ fɹəm oʊvɝhɪɹɪŋ. ɹɪn dɪd nɑt stɑp tɔkɪŋ. "θɹi ʌv ðə mɝsənɛɹi kæptənz ɑɹ dɪmændɪŋ tə mit wɪð ju. aɪ pʊɾ əm ɪn ðə blu ɹɪsɛpʃən ɹum, ən toʊl ðə sɝvəns tə kip wɑtʃ soʊ noʊ smɔl væljəbəlz æksədɛntəli fɔl ɪndə ðɛɹ pɑkəts. nɑt ðəɾ aɪ hæd tə, əz ɪt tɝn aʊt. kɛɝin sədaɪ ən sɝaɪðə sədaɪ əpɪɹd sun æftɝ ən sɛɾəld ɪn tə kip ðə kæptənz kʌmpəni. kæptən mɛlɝ ɪz wɪð ðɛm, tu."

"I will walk with you if I may, my Lady," she said calmly, falling in at Elayne's side. A freckled young serving woman carrying a basket of folded bed linens began to offer her courtesies, only a hair more directed at Elayne than the First Maid, but Reene made a quick gesture that sent the girl scurrying before she completed bending her knees. Perhaps it was just to keep her from overhearing. Reene did not stop talking. "Three of the mercenary captains are demanding to meet with you. I put them in the Blue Reception Room, and told the servants to keep watch so no small valuables accidentally fall into their pockets. Not that I had to, as it turned out. Careane Sedai and Sareitha Sedai appeared soon after and settled in to keep the captains company. Captain Mellar is with them, too."

ɪleɪn fɹaʊnd. mɛlɝ. ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ɪm tu bɪzi fəɹ mɪstʃəf, jɛɾ i hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv tɝnɪŋ ʌp wɛɹ ən wən ʃi list wɑntəd hɪm. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, soʊ dɪd kɛɝin ən sɝaɪðə. wʌn ə ðɛm hæd tə bi ðə blæk ədʒɑ kɪlɝ. ənlɛs ɪt wɑz mɛɝɪlɪl, ən ʃi wɑz bɪɑn ɹitʃ, ɪt simd. ɹɪn nu əbaʊt ðæt. kipɪŋ əɹ ɪn ðə dɑɹk wʊɾə bɪn kɹɪmənəl. ʃi hæɾ aɪz ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən ðeɪ maɪt noʊɾəs ə vaɪɾəl klu. "wʌt də ðə mɝsənɛɹiz wɑnt, mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ?"

Elayne frowned. Mellar. She was trying to keep him too busy for mischief, yet he had a way of turning up where and when she least wanted him. For that matter, so did Careane and Sareitha. One of them had to be the Black Ajah killer. Unless it was Merilille, and she was beyond reach, it seemed. Reene knew about that. Keeping her in the dark would have been criminal. She had eyes everywhere, and they might notice a vital clue. "What do the mercenaries want, Mistress Harfor?"

"mɔɹ mʌni, ɪz maɪ ɡɛs," bɝdʒɪt ɡɹaʊld, ən swʌŋ əɹ ənstʃɹʌŋ baʊ laɪk ə klʌb.

"More money, is my guess," Birgitte growled, and swung her unstrung bow like a club.

"moʊs laɪkli," ɹɪn əɡɹid, "bʌt ðeɪ ɹəfjuz tə tɛl mi." hɝ maʊθ taɪɾənd slaɪtli. noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt, jɛɾ ɪt sim ðiz mɝsənɛɹiz hæd mænədʒ tə əfɛn hɝ. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ stupəɾ ɪnʌf nɑt tə si ðət ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə supɪɹiɝ sɝvɪŋ wʊmən, ðən ðeɪ wɝ vɛɹi dɛns ɪndid.

"Most likely," Reene agreed, "but they refused to tell me." Her mouth tightened slightly. No more than that, yet it seemed these mercenaries had managed to offend her. If they were stupid enough not to see that she was more than a superior serving woman, then they were very dense indeed.

"hæz daɪɛlɪn ɹɪtɝnd?" ɪleɪn æskt, ən wən ðə fɝs meɪd sɛd nɑt, æɾəd, "ðɛn əl si ðiz mɝsənɛɹiz əz sun əz aɪv tʃeɪnʒd kloʊðz." ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡɛɾ əm aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ.

"Has Dyelin returned?" Elayne asked, and when the First Maid said not, added, "Then I will see these mercenaries as soon as I've changed clothes." She might as well get them out of the way.

ɹaʊndɪŋ ə kɔɹnɝ, ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð tu ʌv ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ən bɛɹli səpɹɛst ə saɪ. ðə si foʊk wɝ ðə læs pipəl ɑn ɝθ ʃi wɑntəd tə kənfɹʌn ɹaɪt ðɛn. lin ən dɑɹk ən bɛɹfʊɾ ɪn ɹɛd bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd sɪlk tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ə blu bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd sɪlk blaʊs wɪð ə ɡɹin sæʃ taɪɾ ɪn ən ɪlæbɹət nɑt, tʃənɛl dɪn sɹən waɪt ʃɑɹk wɑz æpli neɪmd. ɪleɪn hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌɾ ə waɪt ʃɑɹk lʊk laɪk - ɪt maɪt wɛl əv bɪn ə lɪɾəl θɪŋ - bʌt tʃənɛlz bɪɡ aɪz wɝ hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə bɪlɔŋ ɑn ə fɪɹs pɹɛɾətɝ, ɪspɛʃli wən ʃi tʊk ɪn eɪvinhə. ðəɹ wɑz bæd blʌd, ðɛɹ. ə tætud hæn ɹeɪz ðə ɡoʊl pɪɹswɝk sɛn bɑks hæŋɪŋ ɑn ə tʃeɪn əbaʊt tʃənɛlz nɛk, ən ʃi ɪnheɪl ðə ʃɑɹp, spaɪsi sɛn dipli, əz ðoʊ kʌvɝɪŋ səm faʊl oʊɾɝ. eɪvinhə læft aʊt laʊd, wɪtʃ meɪd tʃənɛlz fʊl lɪps ɡɹoʊ θɪn. θɪnɝ, ət list. θɪn wɑz bɪɑn ðɛm.

Rounding a corner, she found herself face-to-face with two of the Windfinders and barely suppressed a sigh. The Sea Folk were the last people on earth she wanted to confront right then. Lean and dark and barefoot in red brocaded silk trousers and a blue brocaded silk blouse with a green sash tied in an elaborate knot, Chanelle din Seran White Shark was aptly named. Elayne had no idea what a white shark looked like - it might well have been a little thing - but Chanelle's big eyes were hard enough to belong on a fierce predator, especially when she took in Aviendha. There was bad blood, there. A tattooed hand raised the gold piercework scent box hanging on a chain about Chanelle's neck, and she inhaled the sharp, spicy scent deeply, as though covering some foul odor. Aviendha laughed out loud, which made Chanelle's full lips grow thin. Thinner, at least. Thin was beyond them.

ði ʌðɝ wɑz ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn, wʌns wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps, ɪn blu lɪnən tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ə ɹɛd blaʊs sæʃt wɪð blu, taɪɾ ɪn ə mʌtʃ lɛs ɪntʃɹəkət nɑt. boʊθ wɪmən wɔɹ ðə lɔŋ waɪt mɔɹnɪŋ stoʊlz fəɹ nɛstə dɪn ɹiz, jɛt ɹɪneɪl mʌst əv fɛl nɛstəz dɛθ moʊs kinli. ʃi wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ə kɑɹvd wʊɾən ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɑks wɪð ə kæpt ɪŋk dʒɑɹ sɛɾ ɪn wʌn kɔɹnɝ ən ə ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ wɪð ə fju skɹɔld laɪnz klɪp tə ɪts tɑp. wɪŋz ʌv waɪɾ ɪn əɹ blæk hɛɹ hɪd ðə sɪks ɡoʊld ɪɹɪŋz ɪn əɹ ɪɹz, mʌtʃ θɪnɝ ɹɪŋz ðən ðə tɛn ʃi hæd wɔɹn bɪfɔɹ lɝnɪŋ ə nɛstəz feɪt, ən ðə ɡoʊld ɑnɝ tʃeɪn kɹɔsɪŋ əɹ dɑɹk lɛf tʃik lʊk stɑɹk səpɔɹɾɪŋ oʊnli ðə mədæljən ðət neɪmd əɹ klæn. æftɝ si foʊk kʌstəm, nɛstəz dɛθ hæd mɛn stɑɹɾɪŋ oʊvɝ fəɹ ɹɪneɪl, wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ɹæŋk ðən ə wʊmən ɹeɪz fɹəm əpɹɛntəs ɑn ðə deɪ ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd pʊɾ ɔf əɹ ɑnɝz. hɝ feɪs stɪl hɛl dɪɡnəɾi, ðoʊ mʌtʃ səbdud naʊ ðət ʃi wɑz æktɪŋ əz tʃənɛlz sɛkɹətɛɹi.

The other was Renaile din Calon, once Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships, in blue linen trousers and a red blouse sashed with blue, tied in a much less intricate knot. Both women wore the long white mourning stoles for Nesta din Reas, yet Renaile must have felt Nesta's death most keenly. She was carrying a carved wooden writing box with a capped ink jar set in one corner and a sheet of paper with a few scrawled lines clipped to its top. Wings of white in her black hair hid the six gold earrings in her ears, much thinner rings than the ten she had worn before learning of Nesta's fate, and the gold honor chain crossing her dark left cheek looked stark supporting only the medallion that named her clan. After Sea Folk custom, Nesta's death had meant starting over for Renaile, with no more rank than a woman raised from apprentice on the day she herself had put off her honors. Her face still held dignity, though much subdued now that she was acting as Chanelle's secretary.

"aɪ æm ɑn maɪ weɪ - " ɪleɪn bɪɡæn, bʌt tʃənɛl kʌɾ əɹ ɔf ɪmpɪɹiəsli.

"I am on my way - " Elayne began, but Chanelle cut her off imperiously.

"wʌt nuz juv ə tɑlɑn? ən ə mɛɝɪlɪl. ɑɹ jə ivən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ðɛm?"

"What news do you have of Talaan? And of Merilille. Are you even trying to find them?"

ɪleɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət tʃənɛl nɛvɝ dɪɾ ɛni ɡʊd. ðə wʊmən wɑz mɔɹ ðən wɪlɪŋ tə ʃaʊt bæk ən sɛldəm wɪlɪŋ tə lɪsən tə ɹizən. ʃi wəd nɑɾ ɛnɡeɪdʒ ɪn ənʌðɝ skɹimɪŋ mætʃ. sɝvəns slɪpɪŋ baɪ tə iðɝ saɪd dɪd nɑt pɔz tə ɔfɝ baʊz əɹ kɝtsiz - ðeɪ kəd sɛns ðə mud hɪɹ - bʌt ðeɪ ʃɑt ɡɹɪm lʊks ət ðə si foʊk wɪmən. ðət wɑz plizɪŋ, ðoʊ ɪt ʃəd nɑɾ əv bɪn. haʊɛvɝ əpsɛɾɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ, ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ ɡɛsts. ɪn ə weɪ, ðeɪ wɝ, bɑɹɡən əɹ noʊ bɑɹɡən. tʃənɛl hæd kəmpleɪn mɔɹ ðən wʌns ə sloʊ-fʊɾɪd sɝvəns ən tɛpɪd bæθwɔɾɝ. ən ðət wɑz plizɪŋ, tu. stɪl, ʃi wəd meɪnteɪn əɹ dɪɡnəɾi, ən səvɪləɾi.

Elayne took a deep breath. Shouting at Chanelle never did any good. The woman was more than willing to shout back and seldom willing to listen to reason. She would not engage in another screaming match. Servants slipping by to either side did not pause to offer bows or curtsies - they could sense the mood here - but they shot grim looks at the Sea Folk women. That was pleasing, though it should not have been. However upsetting they were, the Windfinders were guests. In a way, they were, bargain or no bargain. Chanelle had complained more than once of slow-footed servants and tepid bathwater. And that was pleasing, too. Still, she would maintain her dignity, and civility.

"ðə nuz ɪz ðə seɪm əz jɛstɝdeɪ," ʃi ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn toʊnz ə mɑɾɝeɪʃən. wɛl, ʃi ətɛmptəd toʊnz ə mɑɾɝeɪʃən. ɪf tʃɹeɪsəz ə ʃɑɹpnəs ɹɪmeɪnd, ðə wɪndfɪndɝ wəɾ əv tə lɪv wɪð ðɛm. "ðə seɪm əz læst wik, ən ðə wik bɪfɔɹ ðæt. ɪnkwaɪɝiz əv bɪn meɪɾ əɾ ɛvɹi ɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. jəɹ əpɹɛntəs ɪz nɑt tə bi faʊnd. mɛɝɪlɪl ɪz nɑt tə bi faʊnd. ɪt simz ðeɪ mʌst əv mænədʒ tə liv ðə sɪɾi." ðə ɡeɪt ɡɑɹdz hæd bɪn wɔɹn tə wɑtʃ fəɹ ə si foʊk wʊmən wɪð tætud hænz, bʌt ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp ən ɛɛs sədaɪ livɪŋ, əɹ teɪkɪŋ ɛniwʌn wɪð əɹ ðət ʃi wɑntəd. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ðə mɝsənɛɹiz wəd lɛɾ ɛniwʌn əɾ ɔl pæs u ɔfɝɾ ə fju kɔɪnz. "ænd naʊ, ɪf jəl ɪkskjuz mi, aɪm ɑn maɪ weɪ - "

"The news is the same as yesterday," she replied in tones of moderation. Well, she attempted tones of moderation. If traces of sharpness remained, the Windfinder would have to live with them. "The same as last week, and the week before that. Inquiries have been made at every inn in Caemlyn. Your apprentice is not to be found. Merilille is not to be found. It seems they must have managed to leave the city." The gate guards had been warned to watch for a Sea Folk woman with tattooed hands, but they would not have tried to stop an Aes Sedai leaving, or taking anyone with her that she wanted. For that matter, the mercenaries would let anyone at all pass who offered a few coins. "And now, if you will excuse me, I am on my way - "

"ðæɾ ɪz nɑt ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf." tʃənɛlz vɔɪs wɑz hɑɾ ɪnʌf tə sɪnʒ lɛðɝ. "ju ɛɛs sədaɪ stɪk təɡɛðɝ əz taɪtli əz ɔɪstɝz. mɛɝɪlɪl kɪdnæp tɑlɑn, ən aɪ θɪŋk jə ɑɹ haɪɾɪŋ hɝ. wɪl sɝtʃ fəɹ ðɛm, ən aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, wən wi faɪn ðɛm, mɛɝɪlɪl wɪl bi pʌnɪʃt ʃɑɹpli bɪfɔɹ ʃiz sɛn tə ðə ʃɪps tə fʊlfɪl əɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən."

"That is not good enough." Chanelle's voice was hot enough to singe leather. "You Aes Sedai stick together as tightly as oysters. Merilille kidnapped Talaan, and I think you are hiding her. We will search for them, and I assure you, when we find them, Merilille will be punished sharply before she is sent to the ships to fulfill her part of the bargain."

"ju sim tə bi fɝɡɛɾɪŋ jɝsɛlf," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz maɪld, hɝ feɪs kɑm, bʌt ðə bɑn kwɪvɝd wɪð æŋɡɝ. ʃi hɛld əɹ bɑstɑv pɹɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ wɪð boʊθ hænz əz ɪf tə kip əm fɹəm meɪkɪŋ fɪsts. "jul wɪðdʒɹɔ jəɹ ækjəzeɪʃənz, əɹ jəl sʌfɝ fəɹ ɪt." pɝhæps ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əz sɛlf-kəntʃɹoʊld əz ʃi simd. ðɪs wɑz noʊ weɪ tə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð wɪndfɪndɝz. ðeɪ wɝ wɪmən ə paʊɝ əmʌŋ ðɛɹ oʊn pipəl, ən əkʌstəm tə wildɪŋ ɪt. bʌt bɝdʒɪt dɪd nɑt hɛzəteɪt. "baɪ ðə bɑɹɡən zeɪɾə meɪd, jəɹ ʌndɝ ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪnz əθɔɹəɾi. jəɹ ʌndɝ maɪ əθɔɹəɾi. ɛni sɝtʃɪŋ jə də wɪl bi wən jə ɑɹənt niɾəd. ən ənlɛs aɪ mɪsɹɪmɛmbɝ bædli, jəɹ səpoʊz tə bi ɪn tɛɹ ɹaɪt naʊ tə bɹɪŋ bæk wæɡoʊnloʊdz ʌv ɡɹeɪn ən sɔl bif. aɪ stʃɹɔŋli sədʒɛs jə tʃɹævəl ðəɹ ɪmiɾiətli, əɹ jə maɪt lɝn ə lɪɾəl əbaʊt pʌnɪʃmən jɝsɛlf." oʊ, ðət wɑz ɪntaɪɝli ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ wɪð wɪndfɪndɝz.

"You seem to be forgetting yourself," Birgitte said. Her voice was mild, her face calm, but the bond quivered with anger. She held her bowstave propped in front of her with both hands as if to keep them from making fists. "You'll withdraw your accusations, or you'll suffer for it." Perhaps she was not as self-controlled as she seemed. This was no way to go on with Windfinders. They were women of power among their own people, and accustomed to wielding it. But Birgitte did not hesitate. "By the bargain Zaida made, you're under the Lady Elayne's authority. You're under my authority. Any searching you do will be when you aren't needed. And unless I misremember badly, you're supposed to be in Tear right now to bring back wagonloads of grain and salt beef. I strongly suggest you Travel there immediately, or you might learn a little about punishment yourself." Oh, that was entirely the wrong way with Windfinders.

"noʊ," ɪleɪn sɛɾ əz hɑtli əz tʃənɛl, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ hɝsɛlf. "sɝtʃ ɪf jə wɪʃ, tʃənɛl, jə ən ɔl ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz. sɝtʃ keɪɛmlɪn fɹəm ɛn tə ɛnd. ən wən jə kæn faɪn tɑlɑn əɹ mɛɝɪlɪl, jəl əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ kɔlɪŋ mi ə laɪɝ." wɛl, ðə wʊmən hæd. əz ɡʊɾ æz, ɛniweɪ. ʃi fɛlt ə stʃɹɔŋ dɪzaɪɝ tə slæp tʃənɛl. ʃi wɑntəd tə. . . . laɪt, hɝ æŋɡɝ ən bɝdʒɪts wɝ fiɾɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ! fɹæntəkəli ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə suð əɹ fjʊɹi bɪfɔɹ ɪt bɝst ɪndə oʊpən ɹeɪdʒ, bʌt ði oʊnli ɹɪzʌlt wɑz ə sʌɾən lɔŋɪŋ tə wip ðət ʃi hæd tə faɪt dʒʌst əz waɪldli.

"No," Elayne said as hotly as Chanelle, surprising herself. "Search if you wish, Chanelle, you and all of the Windfinders. Search Caemlyn from end to end. And when you can't find Talaan or Merilille, you will apologize for calling me a liar." Well, the woman had. As good as, anyway. She felt a strong desire to slap Chanelle. She wanted to. . . . Light, her anger and Birgitte's were feeding each other! Frantically she tried to soothe her fury before it burst into open rage, but the only result was a sudden longing to weep that she had to fight just as wildly.

tʃənɛl dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, skaʊlɪŋ. "ju wəd kleɪm wi hæd ɹɪnɪɡd ɑn ðə bɑɹɡən. wɪv leɪbɝd laɪk bɪlʒ ɡɝlz ðɪs pæs mʌnθ ən mɔɹ. jəl nɑt kæst əs ɔf wɪθaʊt miɾɪŋ jəɹ saɪɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən. ɹɪneɪl, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ət ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn ɑɹ tə bi toʊld - toʊld, maɪnd! - ðət ðeɪ mʌs pɹədus mɛɝɪlɪl ən tɑlɑn əɹ ɛls peɪ wʌt ðə waɪt taʊɝ oʊz ðɛmsɛlvz. ðeɪ kænɑt peɪ ɔl, bʌt ðeɪ kən meɪk ə stɑɹt."

Chanelle drew herself up, scowling. "You would claim we had reneged on the bargain. We have labored like bilge girls this past month and more. You will not cast us off without meeting your side of the bargain. Renaile, the Aes Sedai at The Silver Swan are to be told - told, mind! - that they must produce Merilille and Talaan or else pay what the White Tower owes themselves. They cannot pay all, but they can make a start."

ɹɪneɪl bɪɡæn ənskɹuɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝ kæp ə ði ɪŋk dʒɑɹ.

Renaile began unscrewing the silver cap of the ink jar.

"nɑɾ ə noʊt," tʃənɛl snæpt. "ɡoʊ jɝsɛlf ən tɛl ðɛm. naʊ."

"Not a note," Chanelle snapped. "Go yourself and tell them. Now."

taɪɾənɪŋ ðə kæp, ɹɪneɪl baʊɾ ɔlmoʊs pɛɹəlɛl tə ðə flɔɹ, kwɪkli tʌtʃɪŋ fɪŋɡɝtɪps tə hɝ hɑɹt. "æz jə kəmænd," ʃi mɝmɝd, hɝ feɪs ə dɑɹk mæsk. ʃi dɪd nɑt dɪleɪ ɪn oʊbeɪɪŋ, sɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ əɾ ə tʃɹɑt ðə weɪ ʃi hæd kʌm wɪð ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɑks tʌkt ʌndɝ əɹ ɑɹm.

Tightening the cap, Renaile bowed almost parallel to the floor, quickly touching fingertips to her heart. "As you command," she murmured, her face a dark mask. She did not delay in obeying, setting out at a trot the way she had come with the writing box tucked under her arm.

stɪl faɪɾɪŋ ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə stʃɹaɪk tʃənɛl ən wip ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ɪleɪn wɪnst. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm ðə si foʊk hæd ɡɔn tə ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn, nɔɹ ivən ðə sɛkən əɹ θɝd, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn æskɪŋ, nɑt dɪmændɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ naɪn sɪstɝz ɹɛzəɾənt ət ði ɪn ət pɹizɛnt - ðə nʌmbɝ kɛp tʃeɪnʒɪŋ əz sɪstɝz ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi əɹ lɛft, ən ɹumɝ sɛd ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə sɪɾi, tu - ən ɪt wɝiɾ əɹ ðət nʌn hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ət ðə pæləs. ʃi hæd steɪd klɪɹ ə ðə swɑn - ʃi nu haʊ mʌtʃ ɪleɪɾə wɑntəd tə leɪ hænz ɑn hɝ, bʌt nɑɾ u ðə sɪstɝz ət ðə swɑn səpɔɹɾəd, əɹ wɛðɝ ðeɪ səpɔɹɾəd ɛniwʌn; ðeɪ hæd bɪn kloʊsəməðd əz mʌsəlz wɪð sɝaɪðə ən kɛɝin - jɛt ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd səm ə ðɛm tə kʌm tə ðə pæləs ɪf oʊnli tə lɝn wʌt wɑz bɪhaɪn ðə si foʊks kleɪm. waɪ wɝ soʊ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn wən tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪtsɛlf wɑz ʌndɝ sidʒ? ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz ðə fɝst ænsɝ ðət keɪm tə maɪnd, ən ðət meɪɾ əɹ mɔɹ dɪtɝmən tə əvɔɪɾ ɛni sɪstɝ ʃi dɪd nɑt pɝsənəli noʊ tə bi ə səpɔɹɾɝ ʌv ɛɡwin. bʌt ðət wəd nɑt stɑp wɝɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən meɪd fəɹ eɪɾ ɪn juzɪŋ ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz fɹəm spɹɛɾɪŋ, ən ə ðə pɹaɪs ðə taʊɝ hæd bɪn kəmɪɾəd tə peɪ fəɹ ðət hɛlp. bɝn hɝ, bʌt ðət nuz wəd bi ə blʌɾi wæɡoʊnloʊɾ ə faɪɹwɝks ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf ət wʌns wən ɪt bɪkeɪm dʒɛnɝəl nɑlədʒ əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. wɝs. tɛn wæɡoʊnloʊdz.

Still fighting the desire to strike Chanelle and weep at the same time, Elayne winced. This was not the first time the Sea Folk had gone to The Silver Swan, nor even the second or third, but always before they had gone asking, not demanding. There were nine sisters resident at the inn at present - the number kept changing as sisters entered the city or left, and rumor said there were other Aes Sedai in the city, too - and it worried her that none had appeared at the palace. She had stayed clear of the Swan - she knew how much Elaida wanted to lay hands on her, but not who the sisters at the Swan supported, or whether they supported anyone; they had been closemouthed as mussels with Sareitha and Careane - yet she had expected some of them to come to the palace if only to learn what was behind the Sea Folk's claim. Why were so many Aes Sedai in Caemlyn when Tar Valon itself was under siege? She herself was the first answer that came to mind, and that made her more determined to avoid any sister she did not personally know to be a supporter of Egwene. But that would not stop word of the bargain made for aid in using the Bowl of the Winds from spreading, and of the price the Tower had been committed to pay for that help. Burn her, but that news would be a bloody wagonload of fireworks going off at once when it became general knowledge among Aes Sedai. Worse. Ten wagonloads.

wɑtʃɪŋ ɹɪneɪl tʃɹɑɾ əweɪ, ʃi fɔt tə stɛɾi hɝ ɪmoʊʃənz. ən tʃɹaɪd tə bɹɪŋ ðə toʊn bæk tə sʌmθɪŋ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ səvɪləɾi. "ʃi hændəlz əɹ tʃeɪnʒ ɪn sɝkəmstænsəz vɛɹi wɛl, aɪ θɪŋk."

Watching Renaile trot away, she fought to steady her emotions. And tried to bring the tone back to something approaching civility. "She handles her change in circumstances very well, I think."

tʃənɛl ɡeɪv ə dɪsmɪsɪv pʌf. "ænd wɛl ʃi ʃʊd. ɛvɹi wɪnd-faɪndɝ noʊz ʃɪl ɹaɪz ən fɔl mɛni taɪmz bɪfɔɹ əɹ bɑɾi ɪz ɡɪvən bæk tə ðə sɔlt." ʃi twɪstəd tə ɡeɪz æftɝ ði ʌðɝ si foʊk wʊmən, ən ə tʌtʃ ə mæləs ɛntɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs. ʃi sim tə bi spikɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. "ʃi fɛl fɹəm ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ haɪt ðən moʊst, ən ʃi ʃəd nɑɾ əv bɪn sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn əɹ lændɪŋ hɑɹɾ æftɝ soʊ mɛni fɪŋɡɝz ʃi tʃɹɑɾ ɑn waɪl ʃi wɑz - " hɝ maʊθ snæpt ʃʌt, ən ʃi dʒɝkt əɹ hɛɾ ɝaʊn tə ɡlɛɹ əɾ ɪleɪn, ət bɝdʒɪt, əɾ eɪvinhə ən ɹɪn, ivən ət ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən, dɛɹɪŋ əm tə kɑmɛnt.

Chanelle gave a dismissive puff. "And well she should. Every Wind-finder knows she will rise and fall many times before her body is given back to the salt." She twisted to gaze after the other Sea Folk woman, and a touch of malice entered her voice. She seemed to be speaking to herself. "She fell from a greater height than most, and she should not have been surprised to find her landing hard after so many fingers she trod on while she was - " Her mouth snapped shut, and she jerked her head around to glare at Elayne, at Birgitte, at Aviendha and Reene, even at the Guardswomen, daring them to comment.

ɪleɪn pɹuɾəntli kɛpt əɹ maʊθ kloʊzd, ænd, ðə laɪt bi θæŋkt, soʊ dɪɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. fəɹ əɹ pɑɹt, ʃi θɔt ʃi ɔlmoʊs hæɾ əɹ tɛmpɝ smuðd, ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə kɹaɪ səpɹɛst, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə seɪ ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪt stɑɹt tʃənɛl ʃaʊɾɪŋ ən əndu ɔl əɹ wɝk. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ tə seɪ æftɝ hɪɹɪŋ ðæt. ʃi daʊɾɪd ɪt wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv æθɑn maɪɹ kʌstəm tə teɪk ɹivɛnʒ ɑn sʌmwʌn jə bɪliv hæd mɪsjuz ðɛɹ pəzɪʃən əbʌv ju. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi hjumən, ðoʊ.

Elayne prudently kept her mouth closed, and, the Light be thanked, so did everyone else. For her part, she thought she almost had her temper smoothed, the desire to cry suppressed, and she did not want to say anything that might start Chanelle shouting and undo all her work. For that matter, she could not think of anything to say after hearing that. She doubted it was part of Atha'an Miere custom to take revenge on someone you believed had misused their position above you. It was very human, though.

ðə wɪndfɪndɝ stɛɹɾ əɹ ʌp ən daʊn, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "jɔɹ wɛt," ʃi sɛɾ əz ðoʊ dʒʌs noʊɾɪsɪŋ. "ɪɾ ɪz vɛɹi bæd tə bi wɛt fəɹ lɔŋ ɪn jəɹ kəndɪʃən. jə ʃəd tʃeɪnʒ jəɹ kloʊðz ɹaɪɾ əweɪ."

The Windfinder stared her up and down, frowning. "You're wet," she said as though just noticing. "It is very bad to be wet for long in your condition. You should change your clothes right away."

ɪleɪn θɹu bæk əɹ hɛɾ ən skɹimd əz laʊdli əz ʃi kʊd, ə haʊl ə pjʊɹ aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ ən fjʊɹi. ʃi skɹimd əntɪl əɹ lʌŋz wɝ ɛmpti, livɪŋ əɹ pæntɪŋ.

Elayne threw back her head and screamed as loudly as she could, a howl of pure outrage and fury. She screamed until her lungs were empty, leaving her panting.

ɪn ðə saɪləns ðət fɑloʊd, ɛvɹiwʌn stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ ɪn əmeɪzmənt. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn. eɪvinhə bɪɡæn læfɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd ʃi hæd tə lin əɡɛnst ə tæpəstʃɹi ʌv maʊntəd hʌntɝz kənfɹʌntɪŋ ə lɛpɝd ðət hæd tɝnd. ʃi hæd wʌn ɑɹm pɹɛst əkɹɔs ðə mɪɾəl əz ɪf əɹ ɹɪbz hɝt. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ əmjuzmənt, tu - əmjuzmənt! - ðoʊ bɝdʒɪts feɪs ɹɪmeɪn əz smuð əz ə sɪstɝz.

In the silence that followed, everyone stared at her in amazement. Almost everyone. Aviendha began laughing so hard she had to lean against a tapestry of mounted hunters confronting a leopard that had turned. She had one arm pressed across the middle as if her ribs hurt. The bond carried amusement, too - amusement! - though Birgitte's face remained as smooth as a sister's.

"aɪ mʌs tʃɹævəl tə tɛɹ," tʃənɛl sɛd bɹɛθəli æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ən ʃi tɝn əweɪ wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝɾ əɹ ɛni dʒɛstʃɝ təwɔɹɾ ə kɝɾəsi. ɹɪn ən ɹin ɔfɝd kɝtsiz, niðɝ kwaɪt miɾɪŋ ɪleɪnz aɪ, ən plɛd duɾiz bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ ɔf.

"I must Travel to Tear," Chanelle said breathily after a moment, and she turned away without another word or any gesture toward a courtesy. Reene and Reanne offered curtsies, neither quite meeting Elayne's eye, and pled duties before hurrying off.

ɪleɪn stɛɹɾ ət bɝdʒɪɾ ən eɪvinhə ɪn tɝn. "ɪf wʌn ə jə sɛz ə sɪŋɡəl wɝd," ʃi sɛd wɔɹnɪŋli.

Elayne stared at Birgitte and Aviendha in turn. "If one of you says a single word," she said warningly.

bɝdʒɪt pʊɾ ɑn sətʃ ən ɪkspɹɛʃən ʌv ɪnəsəns ðəɾ ɪt wɑz pælpəbli fɔls, ən ðə bɑn kæɹid sətʃ mɝθ ðəɾ ɪleɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf faɪɾɪŋ ði ɝdʒ tə læf. eɪvinhə oʊnli læf ðə hɑɹɾɝ.

Birgitte put on such an expression of innocence that it was palpably false, and the bond carried such mirth that Elayne found herself fighting the urge to laugh. Aviendha only laughed the harder.

ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts ən sətʃ dɪɡnəɾi əz ʃi kəd sʌmən, ɪleɪn sɛɾ aʊt fəɹ əɹ əpɑɹtməns. ɪf ʃi wɔk fæstɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ, wɛl, ʃi dɪd wɑnə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðiz dæmp kloʊðz. ðət wɑz ði oʊnli ɹizən. ði oʊnli ɹizən.

Gathering her skirts and such dignity as she could summon, Elayne set out for her apartments. If she walked faster than before, well, she did want to get out of these damp clothes. That was the only reason. The only reason.

tʃæptɝ fɪftin

CHAPTER 15

eɪ dɪfɹən skɪl tə ɪleɪnz fjʊɹi, ə kwaɪət, sɪmɝɪŋ fjʊɹi ðət klɛntʃt əɹ dʒɔ, ʃi ɡɑt lɔst ɑn ðə weɪ tə hɝ əpɑɹtməns. ðoʊz ɹumz hæd bɪn hɝz sɪns ʃi lɛf ðə nɝsɝi, jɛt twaɪs ʃi tʊk ə tɝn oʊnli tə faɪn ðəɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt lɛd wɛɹ ʃi ɪkspɛktəd. ən ə swipɪŋ flaɪɾ ə mɑɹbəl-ɹeɪl stɛɹz tʊk əɹ ɪn ɪntaɪɝli ðə ɹɔŋ dɝɛkʃən. bɝn hɝ, naʊ biɪŋ wɪð tʃaɪld wɑz fʌzɪŋ əɹ wɪts kəmplitli! ʃi kəd fil pʌzəlmənt, ən ɪnkɹisɪŋ kənsɝn, θɹu ðə bɑn əz ʃi ɹitʃɹeɪst əɹ weɪ, klaɪmd ə dɪfɹən sɛɾ ə stɛɹz. səm ə ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən mɝmɝɾ ənizəli, nɑt kwaɪt laʊdli ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə meɪk aʊt ðə wɝdz, əntɪl ðə bænɝwʊmən ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, ə slɪm, kul-aɪd sɑldəiən neɪm dɛvɝ zɑɹbaɪən, saɪlənst əm wɪð ə ʃɑɹp wɝd. ivən eɪvinhə bɪɡæn lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ daʊtfəli. wɛl, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə hæv ɡɛɾɪŋ lɔst - ɪn ðə pæləs! - flʌŋ ɪn əɹ feɪs.

A Different Skill To Elayne's fury, a quiet, simmering fury that clenched her jaw, she got lost on the way to her apartments. Those rooms had been hers since she left the nursery, yet twice she took a turn only to find that it did not lead where she expected. And a sweeping flight of marble-railed stairs took her in entirely the wrong direction. Burn her, now being with child was fuzzing her wits completely! She could feel puzzlement, and increasing concern, through the bond as she retraced her way, climbed a different set of stairs. Some of the Guardswomen murmured uneasily, not quite loudly enough for her to make out the words, until the Bannerwoman in charge, a slim, cool-eyed Saldaean named Devore Zarbayan, silenced them with a sharp word. Even Aviendha began looking at her doubtfully. Well, she was not about to have getting lost - in the palace! - flung in her face.

"nɑɾ ə wɝd fɹəm ɛnibəɾi," ʃi sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "nɑt wʌn!" ʃi æɾəd wən bɝdʒɪɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ ɛniweɪ.

"Not a word from anybody," she said grimly. "Not one!" she added when Birgitte opened her mouth anyway.

ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən snæpt əɹ dʒɔz ʃʌɾ ən ɡeɪv ə tʌɡ əɾ əɹ θɪk bɹeɪd, ɔlmoʊs ðə weɪ nɪneɪiv dɪd. ʃi dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə kip dɪsəpɹuvəl fɹəm əɹ feɪs, ən ðə bɑn stɪl kæɹid pʌzəlmənt, ən wɝi. ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɪleɪn bɪɡæn tə fil wɝid hɝsɛlf. ʃi stʃɹʌɡəl tə faɪt ðəɾ ɔf bɪfɔɹ ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf ɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ hænz ən əpɑlədʒaɪzɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ðət stʃɹɔŋ.

The golden-haired woman snapped her jaws shut and gave a tug at her thick braid, almost the way Nynaeve did. She did not bother to keep disapproval from her face, and the bond still carried puzzlement, and worry. Enough that Elayne began to feel worried herself. She struggled to fight that off before she found herself wringing her hands and apologizing. It was that strong.

"aɪ θɪŋk əl tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn maɪ ɹumz, ɪf aɪ kən əv dʒʌst ə fju wɝdz," bɝdʒɪt sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. "aɪ wɑnə ɡɛt dʒɹaɪ bɪfɔɹ aɪ wɛɹ aʊt maɪ buts. wi nid tə tɔk ə ðɪs leɪɾɝ. aɪ fɪɹ ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn, bʌt. . . ." wɪð ə stɪf nɑd, bɛɹli bɛndɪŋ əɹ nɛk, ʃi stɔkt ɔf slæʃɪŋ əɹ ənstʃɹʌŋ baʊ fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd.

"I think I'll try to find my rooms, if I can have just a few words," Birgitte said in a tight voice. "I want to get dry before I wear out my boots. We need to talk of this later. I fear there's nothing to be done, but. . . ." With a stiff nod, barely bending her neck, she stalked off slashing her unstrung bow from side to side.

ɪleɪn ɔlmoʊs kɔld əɹ bæk. ʃi wɑntəd tə. bʌt bɝdʒɪt hæɾ əz mʌtʃ niɾ ə dʒɹaɪ kloʊðɪŋ əz ʃi. bɪsaɪdz, hɝ mud hæd swʌŋ tə ɡɹʌmpi ən stʌbɝn. ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə tɔk əbaʊt luzɪŋ əɹ weɪ ɪn ðə vɛɹi hɔlz wɛɹ ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp, nɑt naʊ əɹ leɪɾɝ. nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn? wʌd ðət min? ɪf bɝdʒɪt wɑz sədʒɛstɪŋ ðəɾ əɹ wɪts wɝ tu bɪfʌɾəld tə bi sɛt stʃɹeɪt . . . ! hɝ dʒɔ taɪɾənd ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn.

Elayne almost called her back. She wanted to. But Birgitte had as much need of dry clothing as she. Besides, her mood had swung to grumpy and stubborn. She was not going to talk about losing her way in the very halls where she had grown up, not now or later. Nothing to be done? What did that mean? If Birgitte was suggesting that her wits were too befuddled to be set straight . . . ! Her jaw tightened all over again.

ət læst, æftɝ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd tɝn, ʃi faʊn ðə tɔl, laɪən-kɑɹv dɔɹz ə hɝ əpɑɹtməns ən hivd ə smɔl saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk əɹ mɛmɹiz ə ðə pæləs ɹɪli wɝ kəmplitli dʒʌmbəld. ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɑɹdzwɪmən, ɹisplɛndən ɪn bɹɔd-bɹɪm hæts wɪð waɪt plumz ən leɪs-ɛdʒ sæʃɪz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ðə waɪt laɪən slæntɪŋ əkɹɔs ðɛɹ bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪts ən mɔɹ peɪl leɪs ət ðɛɹ kʌfs ən nɛks, stɪfən ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹz əɾ əɹ əpɹoʊtʃ. ʃi ɪntɛndəɾ əm tə hæv ɹɛd-lækɝd bɹɛstpleɪts tə mætʃ ðɛɹ sɪlk koʊts ən bɹitʃɪz wən ʃi hæd taɪm tə spɛn ɑn ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tə bi soʊ pɹɪɾi ðəɾ ɛni əseɪlənt wəd dɪskaʊn əm əntɪl ɪt wɑz tu leɪt, ʃi wəd meɪk əm pɑzəɾɪvli ɡɔɾi. nʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən sim tə maɪnd. ɪn fækt, ðeɪ wɝ iɡɝli lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə ðə lækɝd bɹɛstpleɪts.

At last, after yet another unexpected turn, she found the tall, lion-carved doors of her apartments and heaved a small sigh of relief. She had begun to think her memories of the palace really were completely jumbled. A pair of Guardswomen, resplendent in broad-brimmed hats with white plumes and lace-edged sashes embroidered with the White Lion slanting across their burnished breastplates and more pale lace at their cuffs and necks, stiffened on either side of the doors at her approach. She intended them to have red-lacquered breastplates to match their silk coats and breeches when she had time to spend on that sort of thing.
