If they were to be so pretty that any assailant would discount them until it was too late, she would make them positively gaudy. None of the Guardswomen seemed to mind. In fact, they were eagerly looking forward to the lacquered breastplates.

ʃi hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd səm u wɝ ʌnəwɛɹ ʃi wɑz nɪɹ dɪspɛɹɪdʒ ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən - moʊsli wɪmən, bʌɾ ɪnkluɾɪŋ dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝ, ðɛɹ oʊn kəmændɝ - jɛt ʃi hæd fʊl kɑnfəɾəns ɪn ðɛɹ əbɪləɾi tə pɹətɛk hɝ. ðeɪ wɝ bɹeɪv ən dɪtɝmənd, əɹ ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ðɛɹ. jʊɹɪθ əzɛɹi ən ʌðɝz u hæd bɪn mɝtʃəns' ɡɑɹdz, ə ɹɛɹ tʃɹeɪd fəɹ wɪmən, ɡeɪv deɪli lɛsənz ɪn ðə sɔɹd, ən wʌn əɹ ənʌðɝ ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɡeɪv ə sɛkən lɛsən ɛvɹi deɪ, tu. sɝaɪðəz nɛd jɑɹmən ən vændinz jeɪɛm wɝ kwaɪt lɔɾətɔɹi əbaʊt haʊ kwɪkli ðeɪ lɝnd. jeɪɛm sɛɾ ɪt wɑz kəz ðeɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi nu sʌmθɪŋ ə haʊ tə juz ə bleɪd, wɪtʃ sim sɪli. haʊ kəd jə bɪliv jə ɔlɹɛɾi nu sʌmθɪŋ ɪf jə niɾəd lɛsənz ɪn ɪt?

She had overheard some who were unaware she was near disparage the Guardswomen - mostly women, but including Doilin Mellar, their own commander - yet she had full confidence in their ability to protect her. They were brave and determined, or they would not have been there. Yurith Azeri and others who had been merchants' guards, a rare trade for women, gave daily lessons in the sword, and one or another of the Warders gave a second lesson every day, too. Sareitha's Ned Yarman and Vandene's Jaem were quite laudatory about how quickly they learned. Jaem said it was because they did not think they already knew something of how to use a blade, which seemed silly. How could you believe you already knew something if you needed lessons in it?

dɪspaɪt ðə ɡɑɹdz ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ, dɛvɝ toʊld ɔf tu ʌv ðoʊz u əkʌmpənid hɝ, ən ðeɪ dʒɹu ðɛɹ sɔɹdz ən wɛn ɪnsaɪd waɪl ɪleɪn weɪɾəd ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ wɪð eɪvinhə ən ðə ɹɛst, tæpɪŋ əɹ fʊɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. ɛvɹiwʌn əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. ðə sɝtʃ wɑz nɑɾ ə slɝ ɑn ðə wɪmən ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə dɔɹz - ʃi səpoʊzd ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə skeɪl ðə saɪɾ ə ðə pæləs; ðəɹ sɝɾənli wɑz kɑɹvɪŋ ɪnʌf tə pɹəvaɪd hændhoʊlz - jɛt ʃi fɛlt ɪɹɪteɪʃən ət biɪŋ meɪd tə weɪɾ ɑn ɪt. oʊnli wən ðeɪ keɪm aʊɾ ən ɹipɔɹɾəd tə dɛvɝ ðət ðəɹ wɝ noʊ əsæsənz weɪɾɪŋ wɪðɪn, noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ weɪɾɪŋ tə wɪsk ɪleɪn bæk tə ɪleɪɾə ən ðə taʊɝ, wɝ ʃi ən eɪvinhə əlaʊd tə ɛntɝ, wɪð ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən fɔɹmɪŋ ʌp ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹz wɪð ði ʌðɝz. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wəɾ əv fɪzɪkəli pɹɪvɛntɪɾ əɹ fɹəm ɛntɝɪŋ sunɝ, bʌt soʊ fɑɹ ʃi hæd bɪn ənwɪlɪŋ tə pʊɾ ɪt tə ðə tɛst. biɪŋ ɹistʃɹeɪn baɪ hɝ oʊn bɑɾiɡɑɹdz wʊɾə bɪn bɪɑn ɪnsʌfɝəbəl, noʊ mæɾɝ ðət ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌs duɪŋ ðɛɹ dʒɑbz. bɛɾɝ tə əvɔɪd ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ɔltəɡɛðɝ.

Despite the guards already there, Devore told off two of those who accompanied her, and they drew their swords and went inside while Elayne waited in the corridor with Aviendha and the rest, tapping her foot impatiently. Everyone avoided looking at her. The search was not a slur on the women guarding the doors - she supposed it was possible for someone to scale the side of the palace; there certainly was carving enough to provide handholds - yet she felt irritation at being made to wait on it. Only when they came out and reported to Devore that there were no assassins waiting within, no Aes Sedai waiting to whisk Elayne back to Elaida and the Tower, were she and Aviendha allowed to enter, with the Guardswomen forming up on either side of the doors with the others. She was not sure they would have physically prevented her from entering sooner, but so far she had been unwilling to put it to the test. Being restrained by her own bodyguards would have been beyond insufferable, no matter that they were just doing their jobs. Better to avoid the possibility altogether.

ə smɔl faɪɝ bɝn ɑn ðə waɪt mɑɹbəl hɑɹθ ə ði æntəɹum, bʌɾ ɪt sim tə ɡɪv lɪɾəl wɔɹmθ. ðə kɑɹpəts hæd bɪn teɪkən ʌp fəɹ spɹɪŋ, ən ðə flɔɹ taɪlz fɛl koʊl bɪniθ ðə soʊlz ə hɝ ʃuz, staʊɾ əz ðeɪ wɝ. ɛsænd, hɝ meɪd, spɹɛd ɹɛd-tʃɹɪmd ɡɹeɪ skɝts wɪð stɪl sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ ɡɹeɪs, ðoʊ ðə slɪm, waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən sʌfɝd fɹəm peɪnfəl dʒɔɪns, wɪtʃ ʃi dɪnaɪɾ ən ɹəfjuz hilɪŋ fɔɹ. ʃi wʊɾə ɹəfjuzd ɛni sədʒɛstʃən ðət ʃi ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ ɹitaɪɝmən əz viəmənli. ɪleɪnz ɡoʊldən lɪli wɑz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd lɑɹdʒ ɑn əɹ bɹɛst, ən pɹaʊdli wɔɹn. tu jʌŋɡɝ wɪmən flæŋkt əɹ ə peɪs bæk ɪn sɪməlɝ lɪvɝi bʌt wɪð smɔlɝ lɪliz, stɑki skwɛɹ-feɪst sɪstɝz neɪm sɛfæni ən nɛɹɪs. ʃaɪ-aɪd jɛt kwaɪt wɛl tʃɹeɪn baɪ ɛsænd, ðeɪ meɪd dip kɝtsiz, sɛɾəlɪŋ nɪɹli tə ðə flɔɹ.

A small fire burned on the white marble hearth of the anteroom, but it seemed to give little warmth. The carpets had been taken up for spring, and the floor tiles felt cold beneath the soles of her shoes, stout as they were. Essande, her maid, spread red-trimmed gray skirts with still surprising grace, though the slim, white-haired woman suffered from painful joints, which she denied and refused Healing for. She would have refused any suggestion that she return to her retirement as vehemently. Elayne's Golden Lily was embroidered large on her breast, and proudly worn. Two younger women flanked her a pace back in similar livery but with smaller lilies, stocky square-faced sisters named Sephanie and Naris. Shy-eyed yet quite well trained by Essande, they made deep curtsies, settling nearly to the floor.

sloʊ-muvɪŋ ən fɹeɪl ɛsæn maɪt bi, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ weɪstəd taɪm ɪn aɪɾəl tʃɪttʃæɾ əɹ steɪɾɪŋ ði ɑbviəs. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɛkskləmeɪʃənz oʊvɝ haʊ wɛɾ ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə wɝ, ðoʊ daʊtləs ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən hæɾ əlɝɾɪd hɝ. "wil ɡɛt jə boʊθ wɔɹm ən dʒɹaɪ, maɪ leɪɾi, ən ɹaɪɾ ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ suɾəbəl fəɹ miɾɪŋ mɝsənɛɹiz. ðə ɹɛd sɪlk wɪð faɪɝdʒɹɑps ɑn ðə nɛk ʃəɾ ɪmpɹɛs əm suɾəbli. ɪts pæs taɪm jə eɪt, tu. doʊn bɑðɝ tɛlɪŋ mi jə hæv, maɪ leɪɾi. nɛɹɪs, ɡoʊ fɛtʃ milz fɹəm ðə kɪtʃənz fəɹ ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn ən ðə leɪɾi eɪvinhə." eɪvinhə ɡeɪv ə snɔɹɾ ə læftɝ, jɛt ʃi hæd lɔŋ sɪns sist əbdʒɛktɪŋ tə biɪŋ kɔld leɪɾi. ən ə ɡʊd θɪŋ, sɪns ʃi wəd nɛvɝ stɑp ɛsænd. wɪð sɝvəns, ðəɹ wɝ θɪŋz jə kəmændəɾ ən θɪŋz jə sɪmpli hæd tə tɑlɝeɪt.

Slow-moving and frail Essande might be, but she never wasted time in idle chitchat or stating the obvious. There were no exclamations over how wet Elayne and Aviendha were, though doubtless the Guardswomen had alerted her. "We'll get you both warm and dry, my Lady, and right into something suitable for meeting mercenaries. The red silk with firedrops on the neck should impress them suitably. It's past time you ate, too. Don't bother telling me you have, my Lady. Naris, go fetch meals from the kitchens for the Lady Elayne and the Lady Aviendha." Aviendha gave a snort of laughter, yet she had long since ceased objecting to being called Lady. And a good thing, since she would never stop Essande. With servants, there were things you commanded and things you simply had to tolerate.

nɛɹɪs ɡɹɪməst ən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ fəɹ səm ɹizən, bʌt dʒɹɑpt ənʌðɝ dip kɝtsi, ðɪs tə ɛsænd, ən wʌn oʊnli slaɪtli dipɝ tə ɪleɪn - ʃi ən əɹ sɪstɝ wɝ ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz mʌtʃ ɪn ɑ ʌv ði ɛldɝli wʊmən əz ðeɪ wɝ ə ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ - bɪfɔɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts ən dɑɹɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ.

Naris grimaced and took a deep breath for some reason, but dropped another deep curtsy, this to Essande, and one only slightly deeper to Elayne - she and her sister were every bit as much in awe of the elderly woman as they were of the Daughter-Heir of Andor - before gathering her skirts and darting into the corridor.

ɪleɪn ɡɹɪməst, tu. ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ɔlsoʊ hæd toʊld ɛsæn əbaʊt ðə mɝsənɛɹiz, əpɛɹənli. ən ðət ʃi hæd nɑɾ iɾən. ʃi heɪɾəd pipəl tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk. bʌt haʊ mʌtʃ ə ðət wɑz əɹ ʃɪftɪŋ mudz? ʃi kəd nɑt ɹikɔl biɪŋ əpsɛt bɪfɔɹ kəz ə meɪd nu wʌt dʒɹɛs tə leɪ aʊɾ ɪn ədvæns, əɹ kəz sʌmwʌn nu ʃi wɑz hʌŋɡɹi ən sɛn fəɹ ə mil wɪθaʊt biɪŋ æskt. sɝvəns tɔkt əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz - ɡɑsaɪp kɑnstənli, ɪn tʃɹuθ; ðət wɑz ə ɡɪvən - ən pæst əlɔŋ ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪt hɛlp ðɛɹ mɪstʃɹəs bi sɝv bɛɾɝ, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɡʊɾ ət ðɛɹ dʒɑbz. ɛsænd wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət hɝz. stɪl, ɪt ɹæŋkəld, ən ɹæŋkəl ðə wɝs fəɹ əɹ noʊɪŋ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɪɹæʃənəl.

Elayne grimaced, too. The Guardswomen also had told Essande about the mercenaries, apparently. And that she had not eaten. She hated people talking about her behind her back. But how much of that was her shifting moods? She could not recall being upset before because a maid knew what dress to lay out in advance, or because someone knew she was hungry and sent for a meal without being asked. Servants talked among themselves - gossiped constantly, in truth; that was a given - and passed along anything that might help their mistress be served better, if they were good at their jobs. Essande was very good at hers. Still, it rankled, and rankled the worse for her knowing that it was irrational.

ʃi lɛɾ ɛsæn lɛɾ əɹ ən eɪvinhə ɪndə ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum, wɪð sɛfæni bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ. ʃi wɑz filɪŋ vɛɹi mɪzɝəbəl baɪ ðɪs taɪm, dæmp ən ʃɪvɝɪŋ, nɑt tə mɛnʃən æŋɡɹi wɪð bɝdʒɪt fəɹ stɔkɪŋ ɔf, fɹaɪɾənd baɪ luzɪŋ əɹ weɪ ɪn ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp, ən sʌlən oʊvɝ əɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹdz ɡɑsəpɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi fɛlt æbsəlutli ɹɛtʃɪd.

She let Essande lead her and Aviendha into the dressing room, with Sephanie bringing up the rear. She was feeling very miserable by this time, damp and shivering, not to mention angry with Birgitte for stalking off, frightened by losing her way in the place where she had grown up, and sullen over her bodyguards gossiping about her. In truth, she felt absolutely wretched.

sun ɪnʌf, ðoʊ, ɛsæn hæɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə hɝ wɛt θɪŋz ən ɹæpt ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ waɪt taʊəl ðət hæd bɪn hæŋɪŋ ɑn ə wɔɹmɪŋ ɹæk ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə waɪd mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs ət ði ɛn ə ðə ɹum. ðət hæɾ ə suðɪŋ ɪfɛkt. ðɪs faɪɝ wɑz nɑɾ əɾ ɔl smɔl, ən ðə ɹum sim nɑt fɑɹ ʃɔɹɾ ə hɑt, ə wɛlkəm hit ðət soʊkt ɪndə ðə flɛʃ ən bænɪʃt ʃɪvɝz. ɛsæn taʊəld ɪleɪnz hɛɹ dʒɹaɪ waɪl sɛfæni pɝfɔɹm ðə seɪm ɔfəs fəɹ eɪvinhə, wɪtʃ ʃəɡɹɪn eɪvinhə stɪl, ðoʊ ðɪs wɑz hɑɹdli ðə fɝs taɪm. ʃi ən ɪleɪn fɹikwənli bɹʌʃt itʃ ʌðɝz hɛɹ ət naɪt, jɛɾ æksɛptɪŋ ðɪs sɪmpəl sɝvəs fɹəm ə leɪɾiz meɪd pʊt spɑts ə kʌlɝ ɪn eɪvinhəz sʌn-dɑɹk tʃiks.

Soon enough, though, Essande had her out of her wet things and wrapped in a large white towel that had been hanging on a warming rack in front of the wide marble fireplace at the end of the room. That had a soothing effect. This fire was not at all small, and the room seemed not far short of hot, a welcome heat that soaked into the flesh and banished shivers. Essande toweled Elayne's hair dry while Sephanie performed the same office for Aviendha, which chagrined Aviendha still, though this was hardly the first time. She and Elayne frequently brushed each other's hair at night, yet accepting this simple service from a lady's maid put spots of color in Aviendha's sun-dark cheeks.

wən sɛfæni oʊpənd wʌn ə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊbz laɪnɪŋ wʌn wɔl, eɪvinhə saɪd dipli. ʃi hɛld wʌn taʊəl lusli dʒɹeɪpt ɝaʊn əɹ - ənʌðɝ wʊmən dʒɹaɪɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ maɪt bi ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ, bʌt nɪɹ nuɾɪti pɹizɛntəd noʊ dɪfəkəltiz - ən ə sɛkənd, smɔlɝ, wɑz ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ hɛɹ. "du jə θɪŋk aɪ ʃəd wɛɹ wɛtləndɝ kloʊðz, ɪleɪn, sɪns wəɹ gɑnə mit ðiz mɝsənɛɹiz?" ʃi æskt ɪn toʊnz ʌv ɡɹeɪt ɹɪlʌktəns. ɛsæn smaɪld. ʃi ɛndʒɔɪd dʒɹɛsɪŋ eɪvinhə ɪn sɪlks.

When Sephanie opened one of the wardrobes lining one wall, Aviendha sighed deeply. She held one towel loosely draped around her - another woman drying her hair might be embarrassing, but near nudity presented no difficulties - and a second, smaller, was wrapped around her hair. "Do you think I should wear wetlander clothes, Elayne, since we are going to meet these mercenaries?" she asked in tones of great reluctance. Essande smiled. She enjoyed dressing Aviendha in silks.

ɪleɪn hɪɾ ə smaɪl ə hɝ oʊn, noʊ izi tæsk sɪns ʃi wɑntəd tə læf. hɝ sɪstɝ pɹitɛndəd tə dɪsdeɪn sɪlks, bʌt ʃi sɛldəm mɪst ən ɑpɝtunəɾi tə wɛɹ ðɛm. "ɪf jə kən bɛɹ ɪt, eɪvinhə," ʃi sɛd ɡɹeɪvli, ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ oʊn ɹɑbɪŋ taʊəl kɛɹfəli. ɛsæn sɔ hɝ ɪn əɹ skɪn ɛvɹi deɪ, ən sɛfæni, tu, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə lɛt hæpən wɪθaʊt ɹizən. "fɔɹ bɛst ɪfɛkt, wi ʃəd boʊθ oʊvɝ-ɑ ðɛm. jə woʊn maɪn tu mʌtʃ, wɪl ju?"

Elayne hid a smile of her own, no easy task since she wanted to laugh. Her sister pretended to disdain silks, but she seldom missed an opportunity to wear them. "If you can bear it, Aviendha," she said gravely, adjusting her own robing towel carefully. Essande saw her in her skin every day, and Sephanie, too, but it was nothing to let happen without reason. "For best effect, we should both over-awe them. You won't mind too much, will you?"

bʌɾ eɪvinhə wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ət ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb, hɝ taʊəl ɡeɪpɪŋ kɛɹləsli əz ʃi fɪŋɡɝd dʒɹɛsəz. sɛvɹəl sɛts ʌv il ɡɑɹb hʌŋ ɪn ənʌðɝ ə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊbz, bʌt taɪlɪn hæd ɡɪvən əɹ tʃɛsts ə faɪnli kʌt sɪlks ən wʊlənz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ lɛft ɛbu dɑɹ, ɪnʌf tə fɪl nɪɹli ə kɔɹɾɝ ə ðə kɑɹv kæbənəts.

But Aviendha was already at the wardrobe, her towel gaping carelessly as she fingered dresses. Several sets of Aiel garb hung in another of the wardrobes, but Tylin had given her chests of finely cut silks and woolens before they left Ebou Dar, enough to fill nearly a quarter of the carved cabinets.

ðət bɹif bɝst ʌv əmjuzmən lɛft ɪleɪn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ filɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi hæd tə ɑɹɡju oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, soʊ wɪθaʊt dɪmɹəl ʃi lɛɾ ɛsænd ɡɛɾ əɹ ɪndə ðə ɹɛd sɪlk wɪð faɪɝdʒɹɑps ðə saɪz ʌv ə fɪŋɡɝ dʒɔɪn soʊn ɪn ə bæn ɝaʊn ðə haɪ nɛk. ðə ɡɑɹmənt wəɾ ɪmpɹɛs, fəɹ ʃʊɹ, wɪð noʊ nid fəɹ ʌðɝ dʒuəlz, ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hænd wɑz dʒuəl ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛniwʌn. ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən hæɾ ə dɛləkət tʌtʃ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn stɪl wɪnst əz ʃi bɪɡæn duɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹoʊz ə taɪni bʌɾənz daʊn əɹ bæk, taɪɾənɪŋ ðə bɑɾəs əkɹɔs əɹ tɛndɝ bʊzəm. əpɪnjənz vɛɹiɾ ɑn haʊ lɔŋ ðət wəd læst, jɛɾ ɔl əɡɹid ðət ʃi kəɾ ɪkspɛk mɔɹ swɛlɪŋ.

That brief burst of amusement left Elayne no longer feeling as if she had to argue over everything, so without demurral she let Essande get her into the red silk with firedrops the size of a finger joint sewn in a band around the high neck. The garment would impress, for sure, with no need for other jewels, though in truth the Great Serpent ring on her right hand was jewel enough for anyone. The white-haired woman had a delicate touch, but Elayne still winced as she began doing up the rows of tiny buttons down her back, tightening the bodice across her tender bosom. Opinions varied on how long that would last, yet all agreed that she could expect more swelling.

oʊ, haʊ ʃi wɪʃt ɹænd wɝ nɪɹ ɪnʌf tə ʃɛɹ ðə fʊl ɪfɛkt ə hɝ bɑnd wɪð hɪm. ðət wəd titʃ ɪm tə ɡɛɾ əɹ wɪð tʃaɪl soʊ kɛɹləsli. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi cʊɾə dʒɹʌŋk ðə hɑɹtlif ti bɪfɔɹ laɪɪŋ wɪð ɪm - ʃi pʊʃt ðət θɔɾ əweɪ fɝmli. ðɪs wɑz ɔl ɹændz fɔlt, ən ðət wɑz ðæt.

Oh, how she wished Rand were near enough to share the full effect of her bond with him. That would teach him to get her with child so carelessly. Of course, she could have drunk the heartleaf tea before lying with him - she pushed that thought away firmly. This was all Rand's fault, and that was that.

eɪvinhə tʃoʊz blu, wɪtʃ ʃi ɔfən dɪd, wɪð ɹoʊz ə taɪni pɝlz ɛdʒɪŋ ðə bɑɾəs. ðə sɪlk wɑz nɑt soʊ dipli kʌɾ əz ɛbu dɑɹi fæʃənz, jɛt stɪl wəd dɪspleɪ ə lɪɾəl klivədʒ; fju dʒɹɛsəz soʊn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ feɪl tə də ðæt. əz sɛfæni bɪɡæn fæsənɪŋ əɹ bʌɾənz, eɪvinhə fɑndəl sʌmθɪŋ ʃi hæd ɹitʃɹiv fɹəm əɹ bɛl paʊtʃ, ə smɔl dæɡɝ wɪð ə ɹʌf hɪlt ə dɪɹhɝn ɹæpt ɪn ɡoʊld waɪɝ. ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ðoʊ ɪleɪn hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə pʌzəl aʊt wʌɾ ɪt dɪd bɪfɔɹ pɹɛɡnənsi fɔɹst ə hɔl tə sətʃ stʌɾiz. ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn əɹ sɪstɝ wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ðə θɪŋ. eɪvinhəz aɪz wɝ ɔlmoʊs dʒɹimi əz ʃi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt.

Aviendha chose blue, which she often did, with rows of tiny pearls edging the bodice. The silk was not so deeply cut as Ebou Dari fashions, yet still would display a little cleavage; few dresses sewn in Ebou Dar failed to do that. As Sephanie began fastening her buttons, Aviendha fondled something she had retrieved from her belt pouch, a small dagger with a rough hilt of deerhorn wrapped in gold wire. It was also a ter'angreal, though Elayne had not been able to puzzle out what it did before pregnancy forced a halt to such studies. She had not known her sister was carrying the thing. Aviendha's eyes were almost dreamy as she stared at it.

"waɪ dʌz ðət fæsəneɪt jə soʊ?" ɪleɪn æskt. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi hæd sin ði ʌðɝ wʊmən əbzɔɹbd ɪn ðət naɪf.

"Why does that fascinate you so?" Elayne asked. This was not the first time she had seen the other woman absorbed in that knife.

eɪvinhə ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən blɪŋkt ət ðə dæɡɝ ɪn əɹ hænz. ði aɪɝn bleɪd - ɪt lʊk laɪk aɪɝn, ət list, ən fɛlt ɔlmoʊs laɪk aɪɝn - hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ʃɑɹpən soʊ fɑɹ əz ɪleɪn kəd tɛl ən wɑz lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ ðən əɹ pɑm, ðoʊ waɪɾ ɪn pɹəpɔɹʃən. ivən ðə pɔɪnt wɑz tu blʌn fəɹ stæbɪŋ. "aɪ θɔt tə ɡɪv ɪt tə ju, bʌt jə nɛvɝ sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, soʊ aɪ θɔɾ aɪ maɪt bi ɹɔŋ, ən ðən wi wəd bɪliv jə wɝ seɪf, fɹəm səm deɪnʒɝz ət list, wən jə wɝ nɑt. soʊ aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə kip ɪt. ðət weɪ, ɪf aɪm ɹaɪt, ət list aɪ kəd pɹətɛk ju, ən ɪf aɪm ɹɔŋ, ɪt dʌz noʊ hɑɹm."

Aviendha gave a start and blinked at the dagger in her hands. The iron blade - it looked like iron, at least, and felt almost like iron - had never been sharpened so far as Elayne could tell and was little longer than her palm, though wide in proportion. Even the point was too blunt for stabbing. "I thought to give it to you, but you never said anything about it, so I thought I might be wrong, and then we would believe you were safe, from some dangers at least, when you were not. So I decided to keep it. That way, if I am right, at least I could protect you, and if I am wrong, it does no harm."

ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ taʊəl-ɹæp hɛɾ ɪn kənfjuʒən. "ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt wʌt? wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?"

Elayne shook her towel-wrapped head in confusion. "Right about what? What are you talking about?"

"ðɪs," eɪvinhə sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ðə dæɡɝ. "aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪf juv ðɪs ɪn jəɹ pəzɛʃən, ðə ʃædoʊ kænɑt si ju. nɑt ði aɪləs əɹ ðə ʃæɾoʊtwɪstɪd, meɪbi nɑɾ ivən lifblaɪɾɝ. ɪksɛp ðəɾ aɪ mʌs bi ɹɔŋ ɪf jə dɪd nɑt si ɪt."

"This," Aviendha said, holding up the dagger. "I think that if you have this in your possession, the Shadow cannot see you. Not the Eyeless or the Shadowtwisted, maybe not even Leafblighter. Except that I must be wrong if you did not see it."

sɛfæni ɡæspt, hɝ hænz ɡoʊɪŋ stɪl əntɪl ɛsæn mɝmɝɾ ə sɑft ædmənɪʃən. ɛsæn hæd lɪv tu lɔŋ tə bi ʃeɪkən baɪ mɪɹ mɛnʃən ə ðə ʃædoʊ. əɹ mʌtʃ ɛls, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ.

Sephanie gasped, her hands going still until Essande murmured a soft admonition. Essande had lived too long to be shaken by mere mention of the Shadow. Or much else, for that matter.

ɪleɪn stɛɹd. ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd titʃɪŋ eɪvinhə tə meɪk tɛɹæŋɡɹil, bʌɾ əɹ sɪstɝ pəzɛs nɑɾ ə skɹæp ə fəsɪlɪɾi ðɛɹ. jɛt pɝhæps ʃi hæɾ ə dɪfɹən skɪl, meɪbi ivən wʌn ðət kəd bi kɔld ə tælənt. "kʌm wɪð mi," ʃi sɛd, ən teɪkɪŋ eɪvinhəz ɑɹm, ʃi ɔlmoʊs pʊld əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum. ɛsæn fɑloʊd wɪð ə tɔɹən ə pɹoʊɾɛst, ən sɛfæni, ətɛmptɪŋ tə kəntɪnju bʌtoʊnɪŋ ʌp eɪvinhəz dʒɹɛs ɑn ðə flaɪ.

Elayne stared. She had tried teaching Aviendha to make ter'angreal, but her sister possessed not a scrap of facility there. Yet perhaps she had a different skill, maybe even one that could be called a Talent. "Come with me," she said, and taking Aviendha's arm, she almost pulled her out of the dressing room. Essande followed with a torrent of protest, and Sephanie, attempting to continue buttoning up Aviendha's dress on the fly.

ɪn ðə lɑɹdʒɝ ə ði əpɑɹtməns tu sɪɾɪŋ ɹumz, ɡʊdli faɪɝz bleɪzd ɪn boʊθ ə ðə faɪɝpleɪsəz, ən ɪf ði ɛɹ wɑz nɑt soʊ wɔɹm əz ɪn ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum, ɪt wɑz stɪl kʌmftəɹbəl. ðə skɹoʊl-ɛdʒ teɪbəl bɔɹɾɝd wɪð loʊ-bæk tʃɛɹz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə waɪt-taɪl flɔɹ wɑz wɛɹ ʃi ən eɪvinhə tʊk moʊst ə ðɛɹ milz. sɛvɹəl lɛðɝ-baʊn bʊks fɹəm ðə pæləs laɪbɹɛɹi sæɾ ɪn ə stæk ɑn wʌn ɛn ə ðə teɪbəl, hɪstɝiz ʌv ændɝ ən bʊks ə teɪlz. ðə mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps ɡeɪv ə ɡʊd laɪt, ən ðeɪ ɔfən ɹɛd hɪɹ ʌv ən ivnɪŋ.

In the larger of the apartment's two sitting rooms, goodly fires blazed in both of the fireplaces, and if the air was not so warm as in the dressing room, it was still comfortable. The scroll-edged table bordered with low-backed chairs in the middle of the white-tiled floor was where she and Aviendha took most of their meals. Several leather-bound books from the palace library sat in a stack on one end of the table, histories of Andor and books of tales. The mirrored stand-lamps gave a good light, and they often read here of an evening.

mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ə lɔŋ saɪd teɪbəl əɡɛnst wʌn dɑɹk-pænəld wɔl wɑz kʌvɝd wɪð tɛɹæŋɡɹil fɹəm ðə kæʃ ðə kɪn hæd kɛp hɪɾən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, kʌps ən boʊlz, stætʃuɛts ən fɪɡjɝinz, dʒuəlɹi, ɔl mænɝ ə θɪŋz. moʊs lʊkt kɑmənpleɪs, əsaɪd fɹəm pɝhæps ə stʃɹeɪnʒnəs ə dɪzaɪn, jɛɾ ivən ðə moʊs fɹædʒəl-simɪŋ kəd nɑt bi bɹoʊkən, ən səm wɝ mʌtʃ laɪɾɝ əɹ hɛviɝ ðən ðeɪ əpɪɹd. ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ seɪfli stʌɾi ðɛm ɪn ɛni minɪŋfəl weɪ - ʃi hæd mɪnz əʃʊɹəns əɹ beɪbz kəd nɑt bi hɑɹmd, bʌt wɪð əɹ kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə paʊɝ soʊ slɪpɝi, dæmɪdʒɪŋ hɝsɛlf wɑz mɔɹ ə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðən ɛvɝ - jɛt ʃi tʃeɪnʒd wʌt wɑz ɑn ðə teɪbəl ɛvɹi deɪ, pɪkɪŋ aʊt pisəz ət ɹændəm fɹəm ðə pænɪɝz kɛpt ɪn ði əpɑɹtməns bəksɹum, dʒʌst soʊ ʃi kəd lʊk əɾ əm ən spɛkjəleɪɾ ɑn wʌt ʃi hæd lɝn bɪfɔɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ wɪð tʃaɪld. nɑt ðət ʃi hæd lɝn vɛɹi mʌtʃ - wɛl, nʌθɪŋ, ɹɪli - bʌt ʃi kəd θɪŋk ɑn ðɛm. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɝi ʌv ɛniθɪŋ biɪŋ stoʊlən. ɹɪn hæd ɹuɾəd aʊt moʊst, ɪf nɑɾ ɔl, ʌv ðə dɪsɑnəst əmʌŋ ðə sɝvəns, ən ðə kɑnstənt ɡɑɹɾ ət ði ɛntʃɹəns sɔ tə ðə ɹɛst.

More important, a long side table against one dark-paneled wall was covered with ter'angreal from the cache the Kin had kept hidden in Ebou Dar, cups and bowls, statuettes and figurines, jewelry, all manner of things. Most looked commonplace, aside from perhaps a strangeness of design, yet even the most fragile-seeming could not be broken, and some were much lighter or heavier than they appeared. She could no longer safely study them in any meaningful way - she had Min's assurance her babes could not be harmed, but with her control of the Power so slippery, damaging herself was more a possibility than ever - yet she changed what was on the table every day, picking out pieces at random from the panniers kept in the apartment's boxroom, just so she could look at them and speculate on what she had learned before getting with child. Not that she had learned very much - well, nothing, really - but she could think on them. There was no worry of anything being stolen. Reene had rooted out most, if not all, of the dishonest among the servants, and the constant guard at the entrance saw to the rest.

maʊθ taɪt wɪð dɪsəpɹuvəl - dʒɹɛsɪŋ wɑz dʌn ɪn ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum, disənli, nɑɾ aʊt wɛɹ ɛniwʌn əɾ ɔl maɪt wɔk ɪn - ɛsæn ɹɪzumd əɹ tæsk wɪð ɪleɪnz bʌɾənz. sɛfæni, laɪkli əz ædʒəteɪɾəd baɪ ði oʊldɝ wʊmənz dɪsplɛʒɝ əz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, bɹið hɑɹɾ əz ʃi wɝkt ɑn eɪvinhəz.

Mouth tight with disapproval - dressing was done in the dressing room, decently, not out where anyone at all might walk in - Essande resumed her task with Elayne's buttons. Sephanie, likely as agitated by the older woman's displeasure as anything else, breathed hard as she worked on Aviendha's.

"pɪk aʊt sʌmθɪŋ ən tɛl mi wʌt jə θɪŋk ɪt dʌz," ɪleɪn sɛd. lʊkɪŋ ən spɛkjəleɪɾɪŋ hæd dʌn noʊ ɡʊd, ən ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪt tə. jɛɾ ɪf eɪvinhə kəd sʌmhaʊ tɛl wʌɾ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil dɪd dʒʌs baɪ hoʊldɪŋ ɪt. . . . dʒɛləsi sɝdʒd ʌp ɪn hɝ, hɑɾ ən bɪɾɝ, bʌt ʃi nɑkt ɪt daʊn, ðən fəɹ ɡʊd mɛʒɝ dʒʌmpt ʌp ən daʊn ɑn ɪɾ əntɪl ɪt vænɪʃt. ʃi wəd nɑt bi dʒɛləs ʌv eɪvinhə!

"Pick out something and tell me what you think it does," Elayne said. Looking and speculating had done no good, and she had not expected it to. Yet if Aviendha could somehow tell what a ter'angreal did just by holding it. . . . Jealousy surged up in her, hot and bitter, but she knocked it down, then for good measure jumped up and down on it until it vanished. She would not be jealous of Aviendha!

"aɪ æm nɑt ʃʊɹ ðəɾ aɪ kæn, ɪleɪn. aɪ oʊnli θɪŋk ðɪs naɪf meɪks ə kaɪndə wɔɹɾɪŋ. ən aɪ mʌs bi ɹɔŋ əɹ jə wəd noʊ ɪt. jə noʊ mɔɹ ə ðiz θɪŋz ðən ɛniwʌn."

"I am not sure that I can, Elayne. I only think this knife makes a kind of warding. And I must be wrong or you would know it. You know more of these things than anyone."

ɪleɪnz tʃiks hiɾəd wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz jə sim tə θɪŋk. tʃɹaɪ, eɪvinhə. aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn biɪŋ eɪbəl tə . . . tə 'ɹid' tɛɹæŋɡɹil, bʌɾ ɪf jə kæn, ivən ə lɪɾəl, doʊn jə si haʊ wʌndɝfəl ðət wəd bi?"

Elayne's cheeks heated with embarrassment. "I don't know nearly as much as you seem to think. Try, Aviendha. I've never heard of anyone being able to . . . to 'read' ter'angreal, but if you can, even a little, don't you see how wonderful that would be?"

eɪvinhə nɑɾəd, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs hɛl daʊt. hɛzɪɾəntli, ʃi tʌtʃt ə slɪm blæk ɹɑd, ə peɪs lɔŋ ən soʊ flɛksəbəl ɪt kəd bi bɛn ɪndə ə sɝkəl ən spɹɪŋ bæk, laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə teɪbəl. tʌtʃt ɪɾ ən dʒɝkt əɹ hæn bæk swɪfli, waɪpɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ʌnkɑnʃəsli ɑn əɹ skɝt. "ðɪs kɑzəz peɪn."

Aviendha nodded, but her face held doubt. Hesitantly, she touched a slim black rod, a pace long and so flexible it could be bent into a circle and spring back, lying in the middle of the table. Touched it and jerked her hand back swiftly, wiping her fingers unconsciously on her skirt. "This causes pain."

"nɪneɪiv toʊld əs ðæt," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli, ən eɪvinhə ɡeɪv əɹ ə lɛvəl lʊk.

"Nynaeve told us that," Elayne said impatiently, and Aviendha gave her a level look.

"nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə dɪd nɑt seɪ jə kən tʃeɪnʒ haʊ mʌtʃ peɪn itʃ bloʊ ɡɪvz." ənsɝɾənti oʊvɝkeɪm əɹ əɡɛn ət wʌns, ðoʊ, ən əɹ vɔɪs bɪkeɪm tɛntəɾɪv. "æt list, aɪ θɪŋk ðət kən bi dʌn. aɪ θɪŋk wʌn bloʊ kən fil laɪk wʌn, əɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd. bʌɾ aɪm oʊnli ɡɛsɪŋ, ɪleɪn. ɪts oʊnli wʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk."

"Nynaeve al'Meara did not say you can change how much pain each blow gives." Uncertainty overcame her again at once, though, and her voice became tentative. "At least, I think that can be done. I think one blow can feel like one, or a hundred. But I am only guessing, Elayne. It is only what I think."

"kip ɡoʊɪŋ," ɪleɪn toʊld əɹ ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋli. "meɪbi wɪl faɪn sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪks ɪt sɝɾən. wʌɾ əbaʊt ðɪs?" ʃi pɪkt ʌp ən ɑdli ʃeɪp mɛɾəl kæp. kʌvɝd wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒ, æŋɡjəlɝ pæɾɝnz ʌv wʌt sim tə bi ðə moʊs mɪnəɾ ɪnɡɹeɪvɪŋ, ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ tu θɪn tə bi ʌv jus əz ə hɛlmət, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz twaɪs əz hɛvi əz ɪɾ əpɪɹd. ðə mɛɾəl fɛl slɪk, tu, nɑt sɪmpli smuð, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɔɪld.

"Keep going," Elayne told her encouragingly. "Maybe we'll find something that makes it certain. What about this?" She picked up an oddly shaped metal cap. Covered with strange, angular patterns of what seemed to be the most minute engraving, it was much too thin to be of use as a helmet, though it was twice as heavy as it appeared. The metal felt slick, too, not simply smooth, as if it were oiled.

eɪvinhə pʊt daʊn ðə dæɡɝ ɹɪlʌktənli ən tɝn ðə kæp oʊvɝ wʌns ɪn əɹ hænz bɪfɔɹ sɛɾɪŋ ɪt bæk ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən teɪkɪŋ ʌp ðə dæɡɝ əɡɛn. "aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ əlaʊz jə tə dɝɛkt ə . . . ə dɪvaɪs ə səm sɔɹt. ə məʃin." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ taʊəl-ɹæp hɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt noʊ haʊ, əɹ wʌt kaɪndə məʃin. jə si? aɪm oʊnli ɡɛsɪŋ əɡɛn."

Aviendha put down the dagger reluctantly and turned the cap over once in her hands before setting it back on the table and taking up the dagger again. "I think that allows you to direct a . . . a device of some sort. A machine." She shook her towel-wrapped head. "But I do not know how, or what kind of machine. You see? I am only guessing again."

ɪleɪn wəd nɑt lɛɾ əɹ stɑp, ðoʊ. tɛɹæŋɡɹil æftɝ tɛɹæŋɡɹil eɪvinhə tʌtʃt əɹ səmtaɪmz hɛl fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi hæɾ ən ænsɝ. dɪlɪvɝd hɛzɪɾəntli ən wɪð kɔʃənz ðəɾ ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə sɝmaɪz, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ən ænsɝ. ʃi θɔɾ ə smɔl hɪnʒd bɑks, əpɛɹənli aɪvɝi ən kʌvɝd wɪð ɹɪpəlɪŋ ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin stʃɹaɪps, hɛl mjuzɪk, hʌnʒɹədz ə tunz, pɝhæps θaʊzənz. wɪð ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ðət maɪt bi pɑsəbəl. æftɝ ɔl, ə faɪn mjuzɪk bɑks maɪɾ əv sɪləndɝz fəɹ əz mɛni əz ə hʌnʒɹəd tunz ən səm kəd pleɪ kwaɪt lɔŋ pisəz ɑn wʌn sɪləndɝ æftɝ ənʌðɝ wɪθaʊt tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ðɛm. ə flæɾɪʃ waɪt boʊl ɔlmoʊst ə peɪs əkɹɔs wɑz fəɹ lʊkɪŋ ət θɪŋz ðət wɝ fɑɹ əweɪ, ʃi θɔt, ən ə tɔl veɪs wɝkt wɪð vaɪnz ɪn ɡɹin ən blu - blu vaɪnz! - wəd ɡæðɝ wɔɾɝ aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ. ðət saʊndəd jusləs, bʌɾ eɪvinhə ɔlmoʊs kɝɛst ɪt, ən æftɝ kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən, ɪleɪn ɹilaɪzd ɪt wəd bi vɛɹi jusfəl ɪndiɾ ɪn ðə weɪst. ɪf ɪt wɝkt əz eɪvinhə bɪlivd. ən sʌmwʌn fɪɡjɝɾ aʊt haʊ tə meɪk ɪt wɝk. ə blæk-ænd-waɪt fɪɡjɝin ʌv ə bɝd wɪð lɔŋ wɪŋz spɹɛɾ ɪn flaɪt wɑz fəɹ tɔkɪŋ tə pipəl ə lɔŋ weɪ ɔf, ʃi sɛd. soʊ wɑz ə blu fɪɡjɝ ʌv ə wʊmən, smɔl ɪnʌf tə fɪɾ ɪn ðə pɑm ə hɝ hænd, ɪn ən ɑdli kʌt skɝɾ ən koʊt. ən faɪv ɪɹɪŋz, sɪks fɪŋɡɝ-ɹɪŋz ən θɹi bɹeɪslɪts.

Elayne would not let her stop, though. Ter'angreal after ter'angreal Aviendha touched or sometimes held for a moment, and every time she had an answer. Delivered hesitantly and with cautions that it was only a surmise, but always an answer. She thought a small hinged box, apparently ivory and covered with rippling red and green stripes, held music, hundreds of tunes, perhaps thousands. With a ter'angreal, that might be possible. After all, a fine music box might have cylinders for as many as a hundred tunes and some could play quite long pieces on one cylinder after another without changing them. A flattish white bowl almost a pace across was for looking at things that were far away, she thought, and a tall vase worked with vines in green and blue - blue vines! - would gather water out of the air. That sounded useless, but Aviendha almost caressed it, and after consideration, Elayne realized it would be very useful indeed in the Waste. If it worked as Aviendha believed. And someone figured out how to make it work. A black-and-white figurine of a bird with long wings spread in flight was for talking to people a long way off, she said. So was a blue figure of a woman, small enough to fit in the palm of her hand, in an oddly cut skirt and coat. And five earrings, six finger-rings and three bracelets.

ɪleɪn bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ðəɾ eɪvinhə wɑz ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp, ɔfɝɪŋ ðə seɪm ænsɝ ɛvɹi taɪm ɪn hoʊps ðət ʃi wəd stɑp æskɪŋ, bʌt ðən ʃi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ əɹ sɪstɝz vɔɪs wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ mɔɹ kɑnfəɾənt ɹæðɝ ðən lɛs, ðət ðə pɹoʊɾɛsts ðət ʃi wɑz oʊnli ɡɛsɪŋ hæd dwɪndəld. ən əɹ "ɡɛsəz" wɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪn dɪteɪl. ə bɛnt, fitʃɝləs ɹɑɾ ə dʌl blæk, əz waɪɾ əz əɹ ɹɪst - ɪt simd mɛɾəl, jɛt wʌn ɛn əkɑmədeɪɾəd ɪtsɛlf tə ɛni hæn ðət ɡɹɪpt ɪt - meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ə kʌɾɪŋ, iðɝ mɛɾəl əɹ stoʊn ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt tu θɪk. nʌθɪŋ ðət kəd kætʃ faɪɝ, ðoʊ. ði əpɛɹənli ɡlæs fɪɡjɝ ʌv ə mæn, ə fʊt tɔl, wɪð ɪz hæn ɹeɪzd əz ɪf tə sɪɡnəl stɑp, wəd tʃeɪs əweɪ vɝmɪn, wɪtʃ wəd sɝɾənli hæv bɪn jusfəl, ɡɪvən keɪɛmlɪnz pleɪɡ ʌv ɹæts ən flaɪz. ə stoʊn kɑɹvɪŋ ðə saɪz ə hɝ hænd, ɔl dip blu kɝvz - ɪt fɛlt laɪk stoʊn, ət list, ðoʊ sʌmhaʊ ɪt dɪd nɑt ɹɪli lʊk kɑɹvd - wɑz fəɹ ɡɹoʊɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. nɑt plæns. ɪt meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ə hoʊlz, oʊnli ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɪɡzækli hoʊlz. ən ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɛniwʌn hæd tə tʃænəl tə meɪk ɪt wɝk. oʊnli sɪŋ ðə ɹaɪt sɔŋ! səm tɛɹæŋɡɹil dɪd nɑt ɹikwaɪɝ tʃænəlɪŋ, bʌt ɹɪli! sɪŋɪŋ?

Elayne began to think that Aviendha was giving up, offering the same answer every time in hopes that she would stop asking, but then she realized that her sister's voice was becoming more confident rather than less, that the protests that she was only guessing had dwindled. And her "guesses" were growing in detail. A bent, featureless rod of dull black, as wide as her wrist - it seemed metal, yet one end accommodated itself to any hand that gripped it - made her think of cutting, either metal or stone if they were not too thick. Nothing that could catch fire, though. The apparently glass figure of a man, a foot tall, with his hand raised as if to signal stop, would chase away vermin, which would certainly have been useful, given Caemlyn's plague of rats and flies. A stone carving the size of her hand, all deep blue curves - it felt like stone, at least, though somehow it did not really look carved - was for growing something. Not plants. It made her think of holes, only they were not exactly holes. And she did not believe anyone had to channel to make it work. Only sing the right song! Some ter'angreal did not require channeling, but really! Singing?

dʌn wɪð eɪvinhəz dʒɹɛs, sɛfæni hæd ɡɹoʊn ɛnθɹɔld wɪð ðə ɹɛsəteɪʃən, hɝ aɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ waɪɾɝ ən waɪɾɝ. ɛsæn lɪsənd wɪð ɪntʃɹəs tu, hɝ hɛd tɪltəd tə wʌn saɪd, mɝmɝɪŋ smɔl ɛkskləmeɪʃənz əɾ itʃ nu ɹɛvəleɪʃən, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt baʊnsɪŋ ɑn əɹ toʊz ðə weɪ sɛfæni wɑz. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ðət wʌn, maɪ leɪɾi?" ðə jʌŋɡɝ wʊmən blɝɾɪd wən eɪvinhə pɔzd. ʃi pɔɪntəd tə ðə stætʃuɛɾ ʌv ə staʊt, bɪɹɾəd mæn wɪð ə mɛɹi smaɪl, hoʊldɪŋ ə bʊk. tu fit tɔl, ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə bi eɪdʒ-dɑɹkən bɹɑnz ən wɑz sɝɾənli hɛvi ɪnʌf tə bi. "lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɔlweɪz meɪks mi wɑnə smaɪl, tu, maɪ leɪɾi."

Done with Aviendha's dress, Sephanie had grown enthralled with the recitation, her eyes getting wider and wider. Essande listened with interest too, her head tilted to one side, murmuring small exclamations at each new revelation, but she was not bouncing on her toes the way Sephanie was. "What about that one, my Lady?" the younger woman blurted when Aviendha paused. She pointed to the statuette of a stout, bearded man with a merry smile, holding a book. Two feet tall, it appeared to be age-darkened bronze and was certainly heavy enough to be. "Looking at him always makes me want to smile, too, my Lady."

"mi əz wɛl, sɛfæni pɛldən," eɪvinhə sɛd, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ðə bɹɑnz mænz hɛd. "hi hoʊlz mɔɹ ðən ðə bʊk jə si. hi hoʊlz θaʊzənz ən θaʊzənz ə bʊks." əbɹʌpli ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɛnvɛləp hɝ, ən ʃi tʌtʃt θɪn floʊz ə faɪɝ ən ɝθ tə ðə bɹɑnz fɪɡjɝ.

"Me as well, Sephanie Pelden," Aviendha said, stroking the bronze man's head. "He holds more than the book you see. He holds thousands and thousands of books." Abruptly the light of saidar enveloped her, and she touched thin flows of Fire and Earth to the bronze figure.

sɛfæni skwikt əz tu wɝdz ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ əbʌv ðə stætʃuɛt, əz blæk əz ɪf pɹɪntəd wɪð ɡʊɾ ɪŋk. səm ə ðə lɛɾɝz wɝ ʃeɪpt ə lɪɾəl ɑdli, bʌt ðə wɝdz wɝ kwaɪt klɪɹ. ɑnsoʊn ən ɪmzoʊn, floʊɾɪŋ ɑn nʌθɪŋ. eɪvinhə lʊk nɪɹli əz stɑɹɾəld əz ðə meɪd.

Sephanie squeaked as two words in the Old Tongue appeared in the air above the statuette, as black as if printed with good ink. Some of the letters were shaped a little oddly, but the words were quite clear. Ansoen and Imsoen, floating on nothing. Aviendha looked nearly as startled as the maid.

"aɪ θɪŋk wɪv pɹuf ət læst," ɪleɪn sɛd mɔɹ kɑmli ðən ʃi fɛlt. hɝ hɑɹt wɑz ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, ən paʊndɪŋ. laɪz ən tʃɹuθ, ðə tu wɝdz maɪt bi tʃɹænzleɪɾəd. əɹ ɪn kɑntɛkst, pɝhæps fɪkʃən ən nɑt fɪkʃən wəd bi bɛɾɝ. ɪt wɑz pɹuf ɪnʌf fəɹ hɝ. ʃi mɑɹkt wɛɹ ðə floʊz tʌtʃt ðə fɪɡjɝ, fəɹ wən ʃi kəd ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ stʌɾiz. "bʌt jə ʃʊdn əv dʌn ðæt. ɪɾ ɪzən seɪf."

"I think we have proof at last," Elayne said more calmly than she felt. Her heart was in her throat, and pounding. Lies and Truth, the two words might be translated. Or in context, perhaps Fiction and Not Fiction would be better. It was proof enough for her. She marked where the flows touched the figure, for when she could return to her studies. "But you shouldn't have done that. It isn't safe."

ðə ɡloʊ ɝaʊn eɪvinhə vænɪʃt. "oʊ, laɪt," ʃi ɪkskleɪmd, flɪŋɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ɪleɪn, "aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt! aɪ hæv ɡɹeɪt toʊ tə ju! aɪ nɛvɝ mɛn tə ɛndeɪnʒɝ jə əɹ jəɹ beɪbz! nɛvɝ!"

The glow around Aviendha vanished. "Oh, Light," she exclaimed, flinging her arms around Elayne, "I never thought! I have great toh to you! I never meant to endanger you or your babes! Never!"

"maɪ beɪbz ən aɪ ɑɹ seɪf." ɪleɪn læft, hʌɡɪŋ bæk. "mɪnz vjuɪŋ?" hɝ beɪbz wɝ seɪf, ət list. əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ bɔɹn. soʊ mɛni beɪbiz daɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ fɝs jɪɹ. mɪn hæd sɛd nʌθɪŋ bɪɑn əm biɪŋ bɔɹn hɛlθi. mɪn hæd sɛd nʌθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ nɑt biɪŋ bɝn aʊt, iðɝ, bʌt ʃi hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə bɹɪŋɪŋ ðəɾ ʌp wɪð əɹ sɪstɝ ɔlɹɛɾi filɪŋ ɡɪlti. "ju hæv noʊ toʊ tə mi. ɪt wɑz jə aɪ wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv. jə kəɾ əv daɪd, əɹ bɝn jɝsɛlf aʊt."

"My babes and I are safe." Elayne laughed, hugging back. "Min's viewing?" Her babes were safe, at least. Until they were born. So many babies died in their first year. Min had said nothing beyond them being born healthy. Min had said nothing about her not being burned out, either, but she had no intention of bringing that up with her sister already feeling guilty. "You have no toh to me. It was you I was thinking of. You could have died, or burned yourself out."

eɪvinhə pʊl bæk ɪnʌf tə lʊk ɪndə ɪleɪnz aɪz. wʌt ʃi sɔ ðəɹ ɹiəʃʊɹd hɝ, fəɹ ə smɔl smaɪl kɝvd əɹ lɪps. "aɪ dɪd meɪk ɪt wɝk, ðoʊ. pɝhæps aɪ kən teɪk oʊvɝ ðə stʌɾi ʌv ðɛm. wɪð jə tə ɡaɪd mi, ɪt ʃəd bi pɝfəkli seɪf. wɪv mʌnθs bɪfɔɹ jə kən də ɪt jɝsɛlf."

Aviendha pulled back enough to look into Elayne's eyes. What she saw there reassured her, for a small smile curved her lips. "I did make it work, though. Perhaps I can take over the study of them. With you to guide me, it should be perfectly safe. We have months before you can do it yourself."

"ju hæv noʊ taɪm əɾ ɔl, eɪvinhə," ə wʊmənz vɔɪs sɛd fɹəm ðə dɔɹweɪ. "wi ɑɹ livɪŋ. aɪ hoʊp juv nɑt ɡɹoʊn tu juz tə wɛɹɪŋ sɪlk. aɪ si ju, ɪleɪn."

"You have no time at all, Aviendha," a woman's voice said from the doorway. "We are leaving. I hope you have not grown too used to wearing silk. I see you, Elayne."

eɪvinhə lɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ði ɛmbɹeɪs, flʌʃɪŋ fjʊɹiəsli, əz tu il wɪmən ɛntɝd ðə ɹum, ən nɑt dʒʌst ɛni tu il. peɪl-hɛɹd neɪdɪɹ, əz tɔl əz moʊs mɛn ən waɪd wɪð ɪt, wɑz ə waɪz wʌn ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl əθɔɹəɾi əmʌŋ ðə ɡoʊʃin, ən dɔɹinhə, hɝ lɔŋ ɹɛd hɛɹ tʌtʃt wɪð waɪt, wɑz ðə waɪf ə beɪl, klæn tʃif ə ðə ɡoʊʃin, ðoʊ hɝ tʃɹu pɹɑmənəns keɪm fɹəm biɪŋ ɹufməstʃɹəs ə smoʊk spɹɪŋz hoʊld, ðə klænz lɑɹdʒəs hoʊld. ɪt wɑz ʃi hu hæd spoʊkən.

Aviendha leaped away from the embrace, flushing furiously, as two Aiel women entered the room, and not just any two Aiel. Pale-haired Nadere, as tall as most men and wide with it, was a Wise One of considerable authority among the Goshien, and Dorindha, her long red hair touched with white, was the wife of Bael, clan chief of the Goshien, though her true prominence came from being Roofmistress of Smoke Springs Hold, the clan's largest hold. It was she who had spoken.

"aɪ si ju, dɔɹinhə," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ si ju, neɪdɪɹ. waɪ ɑɹ jə teɪkɪŋ eɪvinhə əweɪ?"

"I see you, Dorindha," Elayne said. "I see you, Nadere. Why are you taking Aviendha away?"

"ju sɛɾ aɪ kəd steɪ wɪð ɪleɪn, tə hɛlp ɡɑɹɾ əɹ bæk," eɪvinhə pɹətɛstəd.

"You said I could stay with Elayne, to help guard her back," Aviendha protested.

"ju dɪd, dɔɹinhə." ɪleɪn tʊk əɹ sɪstɝz hæn ɪn ə fɝm ɡɹɪp, ən eɪvinhə skwiz bæk. "ju ən ðə waɪz wʌnz, tu."

"You did, Dorindha." Elayne took her sister's hand in a firm grip, and Aviendha squeezed back. "You and the Wise Ones, too."

ɡoʊld ən aɪvɝi bɹeɪslɪts klæɾɝd əz dɔɹinhə ʃɪftəɾ əɹ dɑɹk ʃɔl. "haʊ mɛni dʒju nid tə ɡɑɹd jəɹ bæk, ɪleɪn?" ʃi æsk dʒɹaɪli. "ju hæv pɝhæps ə hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə nʌθɪŋ ɛls, ən əz hɑɹɾ əz fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ." ə smaɪl dipən ðə kɹisɪz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz. "aɪ θɪŋk ðoʊz wɪmən aʊtsaɪd wɑntəɾ əs tə ɡɪv ʌp əɹ bɛl naɪvz bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ əs ɪn."

Gold and ivory bracelets clattered as Dorindha shifted her dark shawl. "How many do you need to guard your back, Elayne?" she asked dryly. "You have perhaps a hundred or more dedicated to nothing else, and as hard as Far Dareis Mai." A smile deepened the creases at the corners of her eyes. "I think those women outside wanted us to give up our belt knives before letting us in."

neɪdɪɹ tʌtʃt ðə hɔɹn hɪlt ə hɝ naɪf, hɝ ɡɹin aɪz hoʊldɪŋ ə fɪɹs laɪt, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðə ɡɑɹdz hæd ʃoʊn ɛni sətʃ dɪzaɪɝ. ivən bɝdʒɪt, səspɪʃəs ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn wən ɪt keɪm tə ɪleɪnz seɪfti, kəd si noʊ deɪnʒɝ fɹəm ði il, ən ɪleɪn hæɾ æksɛptɪd sɝɾən ɑbləɡeɪʃənz wən ʃi ən eɪvinhə ədɑptəɾ itʃ ʌðɝ. waɪz wʌnz u hæd teɪkən pɑɹɾ ɪn ðət sɛɹəmoʊni, əz neɪdɪɹ hæd, kəd ɡoʊ wɛɹɛvɝ ðeɪ wɪʃt ɪn ðə pæləs wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ wɪʃt; ðət wɑz wʌn ə ði ɑbləɡeɪʃənz. əz fəɹ dɔɹinhə, hɝ pɹɛzəns wɑz soʊ kəmændɪŋ, ɪf ɪn ə kwaɪət weɪ, ðəɾ ɪt simd ɪnkənsivəbəl ɛniwʌn wəɾ ətɛmp tə bɑɹ əɹ weɪ.

Nadere touched the horn hilt of her knife, her green eyes holding a fierce light, though it was unlikely the guards had shown any such desire. Even Birgitte, suspicious of everyone when it came to Elayne's safety, could see no danger from the Aiel, and Elayne had accepted certain obligations when she and Aviendha adopted each other. Wise Ones who had taken part in that ceremony, as Nadere had, could go wherever they wished in the palace whenever they wished; that was one of the obligations. As for Dorindha, her presence was so commanding, if in a quiet way, that it seemed inconceivable anyone would attempt to bar her way.

"jɔɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ əz bɪn ɪn əbeɪəns tu lɔŋ, eɪvinhə," neɪdɪɹ sɛd fɝmli. "ɡoʊ ən tʃeɪnʒ ɪndə pɹɑpɝ kloʊðɪŋ."

"Your training has been in abeyance too long, Aviendha," Nadere said firmly. "Go and change into proper clothing."

"bʌɾ aɪm lɝnɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ fɹəm ɪleɪn, neɪdɪɹ. wivz ivən jə də nɑt noʊ. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən meɪk ɪt ɹeɪn ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd! ən dʒʌs naʊ wi lɝn ðəɾ aɪ kən - "

"But I am learning so much from Elayne, Nadere. Weaves even you do not know. I think I can make it rain in the Three-fold Land! And just now we learned that I can - "

"wʌtɛvɝ jə meɪ hæv lɝnd," neɪdɪɹ kʌɾ ɪn ʃɑɹpli, "ɪt simz juv fɝɡɑɾən əz mʌtʃ. sətʃ əz ðə fæk ðət jə ɑɹ ən əpɹɛntəs stɪl. ðə paʊɝ ɪz ðə list ʌv wʌɾ ə waɪz wʌn mʌs noʊ, ɛls oʊnli ðoʊz u kən tʃænəl wəd bi waɪz wʌnz. naʊ ɡoʊ ən tʃeɪnʒ, ən kaʊn jəɹ lʌk ðəɾ aɪ də nɑt meɪk jə ɹɪtɝn ɪn jəɹ skɪn tə feɪs ə stʃɹæpɪŋ. ðə tɛns ɑɹ biɪŋ stʃɹʌk əz wi spik, ən ɪf ðə klænz dɪpɑɹtʃɝ ɪz dɪleɪd, jəl feɪs ðə stʃɹæp."

"Whatever you may have learned," Nadere cut in sharply, "it seems you have forgotten as much. Such as the fact that you are an apprentice still. The Power is the least of what a Wise One must know, else only those who can channel would be Wise Ones. Now go and change, and count your luck that I do not make you return in your skin to face a strapping. The tents are being struck as we speak, and if the clan's departure is delayed, you will face the strap."

wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝd, eɪvinhə dʒɹɑpt ɪleɪnz hæn ən ɹæn fɹəm ðə ɹum, bʌmpɪŋ ɪndə nɛɹɪs, hu stæɡɝɾ ən ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑp ðə lɑɹdʒ, klɔθ-kʌvɝd tʃɹeɪ ʃi wɑz kæɹiɪŋ. əɾ ə kwɪk dʒɛstʃɝ fɹəm ɛsænd, sɛfæni hɝiɾ æftɝ eɪvinhə. nɛɹɪs' aɪz wɛnt waɪɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə ði il wɪmən, bʌɾ ɛsæn ədmɑnɪʃt əɹ fəɹ teɪkɪŋ soʊ lɔŋ ən dɝɛktəɾ əɹ tə leɪ aʊt ðə mil ɑn ðə teɪbəl, sɛɾɪŋ ðə jʌŋ meɪɾ ɪndə hɝid moʊʃən waɪl mʌɾɝɪŋ əpɑlədʒiz ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ.

Without another word, Aviendha dropped Elayne's hand and ran from the room, bumping into Naris, who staggered and almost dropped the large, cloth-covered tray she was carrying. At a quick gesture from Essande, Sephanie hurried after Aviendha. Naris' eyes went wide at the sight of the Aiel women, but Essande admonished her for taking so long and directed her to lay out the meal on the table, setting the young maid into hurried motion while muttering apologies under her breath.

ɪleɪn wɑntəd tə ɹʌn æftɝ eɪvinhə, tu, tə ɡɹæsp ɛvɹi moʊmənt wɪð hɝ, bʌt neɪdɪɹz wɝdz hɛl hɝ. "jɔɹ livɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn, dɔɹinhə? wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ?" əz mʌtʃ əz ɪleɪn laɪk ði il, ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn əm wɑndɝɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. wɪð ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən əz ənsteɪbəl əz ɪt wɑz, ðeɪ wɝ pɹɑbləm ɪnʌf sɪmpli vɛntʃɝɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ kæmp tə hʌn əɹ tʃɹeɪd.

Elayne wanted to run after Aviendha, too, to grasp every moment with her, but Nadere's words held her. "You're leaving Caemlyn, Dorindha? Where are you going?" As much as Elayne liked the Aiel, she did not want them wandering about the countryside. With the situation as unstable as it was, they were problem enough simply venturing out of their camp to hunt or trade.

"wi ɑɹ livɪŋ ændɝ, ɪleɪn. ɪn ə fju aʊɝz, wɪl bi fɑɹ bɪɑn jəɹ bɔɹɾɝz. əz tə wɛɹ, jə mʌst æsk ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn."

"We are leaving Andor, Elayne. In a few hours, we will be far beyond your borders. As to where, you must ask the Car'a'carn."

neɪdɪɹ hæd wɔkt oʊvɝ tə stʌɾi wʌt nɛɹɪs wɑz leɪɪŋ aʊt, ən nɛɹɪs bɪɡæn tə tʃɹɛmbəl soʊ ðət ʃi nɪɹli dʒɹɑp mɔɹ ðən wʌn dɪʃ. "ðɪs lʊks ɡʊd, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz səm ə ðiz ɝbz," ðə waɪz wʌn sɛd. "jɔɹ mɪdwaɪf əz əpɹuvd ɔl ə ðɪs, ɪleɪn?"

Nadere had walked over to study what Naris was laying out, and Naris began to tremble so that she nearly dropped more than one dish. "This looks good, but I do not recognize some of these herbs," the Wise One said. "Your midwife has approved all of this, Elayne?"

"aɪl sʌmən ə mɪdwaɪf wən maɪ taɪm ɪz nɪɹ, neɪdɪɹ. dɔɹinhə, jə kæn θɪŋk ɹænd wəd wɑn jəɹ dɛstəneɪʃən kɛp fɹəm mi. wʌɾ i seɪ?"

"I'll summon a midwife when my time is near, Nadere. Dorindha, you can't think Rand would want your destination kept from me. What did he say?"

dɔɹinhə ɡeɪv ə smɔl ʃɹʌɡ. "hi sɛn ə mɛsənʒɝ, wʌn ə ðə blæk koʊts, wɪð ə lɛɾɝ fəɹ beɪl. beɪl lemi ɹɛɾ ɪt, ʌv kɔɹs" - hɝ toʊn sɛd ðəɹ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɛni kwɛstʃən ə hɝ nɑt ɹɛɾɪŋ ɪt - "bʌt ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn æsk beɪl nɑt tə tɛl ɛniwʌn, soʊ aɪ kænɑt tɛl ju."

Dorindha gave a small shrug. "He sent a messenger, one of the black coats, with a letter for Bael. Bael let me read it, of course" - her tone said there had never been any question of her not reading it - "but the Car'a'carn asked Bael not to tell anyone, so I cannot tell you."

"noʊ mɪdwaɪf?" neɪdɪɹ sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "hu tɛlz jə wʌt tə iɾ ən dʒɹɪŋk? hu ɡɪvz jə ðə pɹɑpɝ ɝbz? stɑp lʊkɪŋ dæɡɝz ət mi, wʊmən. məleɪnz tɛmpɝ ɪz wɝs ðən jʊɹz kəɾ ɛvɝ bi, bʌt ʃiz sɛns ɪnʌf tə lɛt mɑneɪəl ɡʌvɝn əɹ ɪn ðiz θɪŋz."

"No midwife?" Nadere said incredulously. "Who tells you what to eat and drink? Who gives you the proper herbs? Stop looking daggers at me, woman. Melaine's temper is worse than yours could ever be, but she has sense enough to let Monaelle govern her in these things."

"ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn ðə pæləs ɡʌvɝnz wʌɾ aɪ it," ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd bɪɾɝli. "səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn keɪɛmlɪn dʌz. dɔɹinhə, kæn jə ət list - "

"Every woman in the palace governs what I eat," Elayne replied bitterly. "Sometimes I think every woman in Caemlyn does. Dorindha, can't you at least - "

"maɪ leɪɾi, jəɹ fuɾ ɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ koʊld," ɛsæn sɛd maɪldli, bʌt wɪð dʒʌs ðə tʌtʃ ə fɝmnəs ðəɾ ən ɛldɝli ɹɪteɪnɝ wɑz əlaʊd.

"My Lady, your food is getting cold," Essande said mildly, but with just the touch of firmness that an elderly retainer was allowed.

ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ, ɪleɪn ɡlaɪɾɪd tə ðə tʃɛɹ ɛsæn stʊd bɪhaɪnd. ʃi dɪd nɑt flaʊns, mʌtʃ əz ʃi wɑntəd tə. ʃi ɡlaɪɾɪd. ɛsæn pɹədust ən aɪvɝi-bæk hɛɹbɹʌʃ ænd, ɹimuvɪŋ ðə taʊəl fɹəm ɪleɪnz hɛd, bɪɡæn bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ waɪl ʃi eɪt. ʃi eɪt lɑɹdʒli kəz nɑɾ iɾɪŋ oʊnli mɛn sʌmwʌn wəd bi toʊl tə fɛtʃ mɔɹ hɑt fud, kəz ɛsæn ən əɹ oʊn bɑɾiɡɑɹdz bɪtwin əm maɪt wɛl kip əɹ ðəɹ əntɪl ʃi dɪd, bʌɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ səm dʒɹaɪɾ æpəl ðət hæd nɑt ɡɔn bæd, ðə mil wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli ʌnæpətaɪzɪŋ. ðə bɹɛd wɑz kɹʌsti bʌt flɛkt wɪð wivəlz, ən ðə soʊk dʒɹaɪd binz, sɪns ɔl ə ðə pɹəzɝv binz hæd spɔɪld, wɝ tʌf ən teɪsləs. ði æpəl wɑz mɪkst ɪn ə boʊl ə ɝbz - slaɪs bɝɾək ɹut, blæk hɔ, kɹæmp bɑɹk, dændəlaɪən, nɛɾəl lif - wɪð ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɔɪl, ən fəɹ mit ʃi hæɾ ə pis ə kɪd sɪmɝɾ ɪn blæn bɹɔθ. wɪð nɛks tə noʊ sɔlt, əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəd tɛl. ʃi wʊɾə kɪl fəɹ sɔlti bif dʒɹɪpɪŋ wɪð fæt! eɪvinhəz pleɪt hæd slaɪs bif, ðoʊ ɪt lʊk tʌf. ʃi kəɾ əz wɛl æsk fəɹ waɪn. tə dʒɹɪŋk, ʃi hæɾ əɹ tʃɔɪs ʌv wɔɾɝ əɹ ɡoʊts mɪlk. ʃi wɑntəd ti ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi dɪd fæɾi mit, bʌɾ ivən ðə wikəs ti sɛn əɹ ɹʌnɪŋ tə meɪk wɔɾɝ, ən ʃi hæd kwaɪɾ ɪnʌf dɪfəkəltiz wɪð ðəɾ əz ɪt wɑz. soʊ ʃi eɪt məθɑɾɪkəli, məkænɪkli, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ bʌt ðə teɪsts ɪn əɹ maʊθ. ɪksɛp fəɹ ði æpəl, ət list.

Gritting her teeth, Elayne glided to the chair Essande stood behind. She did not flounce, much as she wanted to. She glided. Essande produced an ivory-backed hairbrush and, removing the towel from Elayne's head, began brushing her hair while she ate. She ate largely because not eating only meant someone would be told to fetch more hot food, because Essande and her own bodyguards between them might well keep her there until she did, but except for some dried apple that had not gone bad, the meal was decidedly unappetizing. The bread was crusty but flecked with weevils, and the soaked dried beans, since all of the preserved beans had spoiled, were tough and tasteless. The apple was mixed in a bowl of herbs - sliced burdock root, black haw, cramp bark, dandelion, nettle leaf - with a touch of oil, and for meat she had a piece of kid simmered in bland broth. With next to no salt, as far as she could tell. She would have killed for salty beef dripping with fat! Aviendha's plate had sliced beef, though it looked tough. She could as well ask for wine. To drink, she had her choice of water or goat's milk. She wanted tea almost as much as she did fatty meat, but even the weakest tea sent her running to make water, and she had quite enough difficulties with that as it was. So she ate methodically, mechanically, trying to think of anything but the tastes in her mouth. Except for the apple, at least.

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə pɹaɪ səm nuz ə ɹænd aʊɾ ə ðə tu il wɪmən, bʌɾ ɪt sim ðeɪ nu lɛs ðən ʃi. əz fɑɹ əz ðeɪ wəɾ ədmɪt, ɛniweɪ. ðeɪ kəd bi kloʊsəməðd wən ðeɪ wɑntəd tə bi. ʃi ət lis nu ðəɾ i wɑz sʌmwɛɹ fɑɹ tə ðə saʊθist. sʌmwɛɹ ɪn tɛɹ, ʃi səspɛktəd, ðoʊ hi kəɾ əz izəli hæv bɪn ɑn ðə pleɪnz ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ əɹ ɪn ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. bɪɑn ðæt, ʃi nu hi wɑz əlaɪv ən nɑɾ ə wɪt mɔɹ. ʃi tʃɹaɪd kipɪŋ ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən ɑn ɹænd ɪn ðə hoʊp ðeɪ maɪt lɛt sʌmθɪŋ slɪp, jɛt ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv tʃɹaɪd dʒɹɛsɪŋ bɹɪks wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. dɔɹinhə ən neɪdɪɹ hæd ðɛɹ oʊn ɡoʊl, kənvɪnsɪŋ əɹ tə əkwaɪɝ ə mɪdwaɪf ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. ðeɪ wɛn ɑn ən ɑn əbaʊt haʊ ʃi maɪt bi ɛndeɪnʒɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf ən əɹ beɪbz, ən nɑɾ ivən mɪnz vjuɪŋ wəd dɪsweɪd ðɛm.

She tried to pry some news of Rand out of the two Aiel women, but it seemed they knew less than she. As far as they would admit, anyway. They could be closemouthed when they wanted to be. She at least knew that he was somewhere far to the southeast. Somewhere in Tear, she suspected, though he could as easily have been on the Plains of Maredo or in the Spine of the World. Beyond that, she knew he was alive and not a whit more. She tried keeping the conversation on Rand in the hope they might let something slip, yet she might as well have tried dressing bricks with her fingers. Dorindha and Nadere had their own goal, convincing her to acquire a midwife right away. They went on and on about how she might be endangering herself and her babes, and not even Min's viewing would dissuade them.

"vɛɹi wɛl," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst, slæpɪŋ daʊn əɹ naɪf ən fɔɹk. "aɪ wɪl stɑɹt lʊkɪŋ fəɹ wʌn tədeɪ." ən ɪf ʃi feɪl tə faɪnd wʌn, wɛl, ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ noʊ.

"Very well," she said at last, slapping down her knife and fork. "I will start looking for one today." And if she failed to find one, well, they would never know.

"aɪ hæv ə nis huz ə mɪdwaɪf, maɪ leɪɾi," ɛsæn sɛd. "mɛlfən dɪspɛnsɪz ɝbz ən ɔɪnmənts fɹəm ə ʃɑp ɑn kændəl stʃɹiɾ ɪn ðə nu sɪɾi, ən aɪ bɪliv ʃiz kwaɪt nɑlədʒəbəl." ʃi pæɾəd ə fju læs kɝlz ɪndə pleɪs ən stɛp bæk wɪð ə pliz smaɪl. "ju də soʊ ɹimaɪn mi ʌv jəɹ mʌðɝ, maɪ leɪɾi."

"I have a niece who's a midwife, my Lady," Essande said. "Melfane dispenses herbs and ointments from a shop on Candle Street in the New City, and I believe she is quite knowledgeable." She patted a few last curls into place and stepped back with a pleased smile. "You do so remind me of your mother, my Lady."

ɪleɪn saɪd. ɪt simd ʃi wɑz tə hæv ə mɪdwaɪf wɛðɝ ʃi wɑntəd wʌn əɹ nɑt. sʌmwʌn ɛls tə si ðəɾ əɹ milz wɝ ɹɛtʃɪd. wɛl, pɝhæps ðə mɪdwaɪf kəd sədʒɛst ə ɹɛməɾi fəɹ ðoʊz bækeɪks ət naɪt, ən ðə tɛndɝ bʊzəm. θæŋk ðə laɪt ʃi hæd bɪn spɛɹd ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə sɪk ʌp. wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl nɛvɝ sʌfɝd ðət pɑɹɾ ə pɹɛɡnənsi.

Elayne sighed. It seemed she was to have a midwife whether she wanted one or not. Someone else to see that her meals were wretched. Well, perhaps the midwife could suggest a remedy for those backaches at night, and the tender bosom. Thank the Light she had been spared the desire to sick up. Women who could channel never suffered that part of pregnancy.

wən eɪvinhə ɹɪtɝnd, ʃi wɑz ɪn il ɡɑɹb əɡɛn, wɪð əɹ stɪl-dæmp ʃɔl dʒɹeɪpt oʊvɝ əɹ ɑɹmz, ə dɑɹk skɑɹf taɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ tɛmpəlz tə hoʊl bæk əɹ hɛɹ, ən ə bʌndəl ɑn əɹ bæk. ənlaɪk ðə mʌltətʃjudz ə bɹeɪslɪts ən nɛkləsɪz dɔɹinhə ən neɪdɪɹ wɔɹ, ʃi hæɾ ə sɪŋɡəl sɪlvɝ nɛkləs, ɪntʃɹəkətli wɝk dɪsks ɪn ə kɑmplɛks pæɾɝn, ən wʌn aɪvɝi bɹeɪslət dɛnsli kɑɹvd wɪð ɹoʊzɪz ən θɔɹnz. ʃi hændəɾ ɪleɪn ðə blʌn dæɡɝ. "ju mʌs kip ðɪs, soʊ jəl bi seɪf. əl tʃɹaɪ tə vɪzət jə əz ɔfən əz aɪ kæn."

When Aviendha returned, she was in Aiel garb again, with her still-damp shawl draped over her arms, a dark scarf tied around her temples to hold back her hair, and a bundle on her back. Unlike the multitudes of bracelets and necklaces Dorindha and Nadere wore, she had a single silver necklace, intricately worked discs in a complex pattern, and one ivory bracelet densely carved with roses and thorns. She handed Elayne the blunt dagger. "You must keep this, so you will be safe. I will try to visit you as often as I can."

"ðɛɹ meɪ bi taɪm fəɹ ən əkeɪʒənəl vɪzət," neɪdɪɹ sɛd səvɪɹli, "bʌt juv fɔlən bɪhaɪn ən mʌst wɝk hɑɹd tə kætʃ ʌp. stʃɹeɪnʒ," ʃi mjuzd, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, "tə spik kæʒəwəli ʌv vɪzəɾɪŋ fɹəm soʊ fɑɹ. tə kʌvɝ liɡz, hʌnʒɹədz ə liɡz, ɪn ə stɛp. stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz wɪv lɝn ɪn ðə wɛtlænz."

"There may be time for an occasional visit," Nadere said severely, "but you have fallen behind and must work hard to catch up. Strange," she mused, shaking her head, "to speak casually of visiting from so far. To cover leagues, hundreds of leagues, in a step. Strange things we have learned in the wetlands."

"kʌm, eɪvinhə, wi mʌst ɡoʊ," dɔɹinhə sɛd.

"Come, Aviendha, we must go," Dorindha said.

"weɪt," ɪleɪn toʊl ðɛm. "pliz weɪt, dʒʌst ə moʊmənt." klʌtʃɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ, ʃi ɹeɪs tə hɝ dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum. sɛfæni pɔzd ɪn hæŋɪŋ ʌp eɪvinhəz blu dʒɹɛs tə kɝtsi, bʌɾ ɪleɪn ɪɡnɔɹɾ əɹ ən oʊpən ðə kɑɹv lɪɾ ə hɝ aɪvɝi dʒuəlɹi tʃɛst. sɪɾɪŋ ətɑp ðə nɛkləsɪz ən bɹeɪslɪts ən pɪnz ɪn ðɛɹ kəmpɑɹtməns wɝ ə bɹutʃ ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə tɝɾəl ðəɾ əpɪɹd tə bi æmbɝ ən ə siɾəd wʊmən, ɹæpt ɪn əɹ oʊn hɛɹ, əpɛɹənli kɑɹv fɹəm eɪdʒ-dɑɹkən aɪvɝi. boʊθ wɝ æŋɡɹil. pleɪsɪŋ ði ænlɝ-hɪltɪd dæɡɝ ɪn ðə tʃɛst, ʃi pɪkt ʌp ðə tɝɾəl, ən ðɛn, ɪmpʌlsɪvli, snætʃt ʌp ðə twɪstəd stoʊn dʒɹim ɹɪŋ, ɔl ɹɛɾ ən blu ən bɹaʊn. ɪt sim tə bi jusləs tə hɝ sɪns ʃi bɪkeɪm pɹɛɡnənt, ən ɪf ʃi kəd mænədʒ tə wiv spɪɹət, ʃi stɪl hæd ðə sɪlvɝ ɹɪŋ, wɝkt ɪn bɹeɪɾɪd spaɪɹəlz, ðət hæd bɪn ɹəkʌvɝd fɹəm ɪspæn.

"Wait," Elayne told them. "Please wait, just a moment." Clutching the dagger, she raced to her dressing room. Sephanie paused in hanging up Aviendha's blue dress to curtsy, but Elayne ignored her and opened the carved lid of her ivory jewelry chest. Sitting atop the necklaces and bracelets and pins in their compartments were a brooch in the shape of a turtle that appeared to be amber and a seated woman, wrapped in her own hair, apparently carved from age-darkened ivory. Both were angreal. Placing the antler-hilted dagger in the chest, she picked up the turtle, and then, impulsively, snatched up the twisted stone dream ring, all red and blue and brown. It seemed to be useless to her since she became pregnant, and if she could manage to weave Spirit, she still had the silver ring, worked in braided spirals, that had been recovered from Ispan.

hɝiɪŋ bæk tə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ʃi faʊn dɔɹinhə ən neɪdɪɹ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ, əɹ ət lis hævɪŋ ən ænəmeɪɾəd dɪskʌʃən, waɪl ɛsæn pɹitɛndəd tə bi tʃɛkɪŋ fəɹ dʌst, ɹʌnɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə teɪbəl. fɹəm ði æŋɡəl ə hɝ hɛd, ʃi wɑz lɪsnɪŋ ævədli, ðoʊ. nɛɹɪs, pʊɾɪŋ ɪleɪnz dɪʃəz bæk ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ, wɑz ɡeɪpɪŋ ət ði il wɪmən oʊpənli.

Hurrying back to the sitting room, she found Dorindha and Nadere arguing, or at least having an animated discussion, while Essande pretended to be checking for dust, running her fingers under the edge of the table. From the angle of her head, she was listening avidly, though. Naris, putting Elayne's dishes back on the tray, was gaping at the Aiel women openly.

"aɪ toʊld əɹ ʃi wəd fil ðə stʃɹæp ɪf wi dɪleɪd ðə dɪpɑɹtʃɝ," neɪdɪɹ wɑz seɪɪŋ wɪð səm hiɾ əz ɪleɪn ɛntɝd ðə ɹum. "ɪɾ ɪz hɑɹdli fɛɹ ɪf ʃiz nɑt ðə kɑz, bʌɾ aɪ sɛd wʌɾ aɪ sɛd."

"I told her she would feel the strap if we delayed the departure," Nadere was saying with some heat as Elayne entered the room. "It is hardly fair if she is not the cause, but I said what I said."

"ju wɪl də əz jə mʌst," dɔɹinhə ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli, bʌt wɪð ə taɪtnəs tə hɝ aɪz ðət sədʒɛstəd ðiz wɝ nɑt ðə fɝst wɝdz ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd. "pɝhæps wɪl nɑt dɪleɪ ɛniθɪŋ. ən pɝhæps eɪvinhə wɪl peɪ ðə pɹaɪs ɡlædli tə seɪ fɛɹwɛl tə hɝ sɪstɝ."

"You will do as you must," Dorindha replied calmly, but with a tightness to her eyes that suggested these were not the first words they had exchanged. "Perhaps we will not delay anything. And perhaps Aviendha will pay the price gladly to say farewell to her sister."

ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ wɪð tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɑɹɡju fəɹ eɪvinhə. ɪt wʊɾə dʌn noʊ ɡʊd. eɪvinhə hɝsɛlf dɪspleɪɾ ən ikwənɪmɪɾi ðət wʊɾə kɹɛɾətəd ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, əz ɪf wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz tə bi biɾən fəɹ ənʌðɝz fɔlt wɝ ə noʊ mæɾɝ əɾ ɔl.

Elayne did not bother with trying to argue for Aviendha. It would have done no good. Aviendha herself displayed an equanimity that would have credited an Aes Sedai, as if whether she was to be beaten for another's fault were of no matter at all.

"ðiz ɑɹ fəɹ ju," ɪleɪn sɛd, pɹɛsɪŋ ðə ɹɪŋ ən ðə bɹutʃ ɪndə hɝ sɪstɝz hænd. "nɑɾ əz ɡɪfs, aɪm əfɹeɪd. ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɪl wɑn əm bæk. bʌt tə juz əz jə nid."

"These are for you," Elayne said, pressing the ring and the brooch into her sister's hand. "Not as gifts, I'm afraid. The White Tower will want them back. But to use as you need."

eɪvinhə lʊkt ət ðə θɪŋz ən ɡæspt. "ivən ðə loʊn ə ðiz ɪz ə ɡɹeɪt ɡɪft. jə ʃeɪm mi, sɪstɝ. aɪ hæv noʊ fɛɹwɛl ɡɪf tə ɡɪv ɪn ɹɪtɝn."

Aviendha looked at the things and gasped. "Even the loan of these is a great gift. You shame me, sister. I have no farewell gift to give in return."

"ju ɡɪmi jəɹ fɹɛndʃɪp. jə ɡeɪv mi ə sɪstɝ." ɪleɪn fɛlt ə tiɹ slaɪd daʊn əɹ tʃik. ʃi ɛseɪɾ ə læf, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə wik, tʃɹɛmjələs θɪŋ. "haʊ kən jə seɪ juv nʌθɪŋ tə ɡɪv? juv ɡɪvən mi ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

"You give me your friendship. You gave me a sister." Elayne felt a tear slide down her cheek. She essayed a laugh, but it was a weak, tremulous thing. "How can you say you have nothing to give? You've given me everything."

tɪɹz ɡlɪsən ɪn eɪvinhəz aɪz, tu. dɪspaɪt ði ʌðɝz wɑtʃɪŋ, ʃi pʊɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ɪleɪn ən hʌɡd əɹ hɑɹd. "aɪ wɪl mɪs ju, sɪstɝ," ʃi wɪspɝd. "maɪ hɑɹɾ ɪz əz koʊld əz naɪt."

Tears glistened in Aviendha's eyes, too. Despite the others watching, she put her arms around Elayne and hugged her hard. "I will miss you, sister," she whispered. "My heart is as cold as night."

"æn maɪn, sɪstɝ," ɪleɪn wɪspɝd, hʌɡɪŋ bæk ikwəli hɑɹd. "aɪ wɪl mɪs ju, tu. bʌt jəl bi əlaʊd tə vɪzət mi səmtaɪmz. ðɪs ɪzən fɝɛvɝ."

"And mine, sister," Elayne whispered, hugging back equally hard. "I will miss you, too. But you will be allowed to visit me sometimes. This isn't forever."

"noʊ, nɑt fɝɛvɝ. bʌɾ əl stɪl mɪs ju."

"No, not forever. But I will still miss you."

ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪɡʌn wipɪŋ nɛkst, oʊnli dɔɹinhə leɪɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. "ɪɾ ɪz taɪm, eɪvinhə. wi mʌst ɡoʊ ɪf jə ɑɹ tə hæv ɛni hoʊp ʌv əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə stʃɹæp."

They might have begun weeping next, only Dorindha laid her hands on their shoulders. "It is time, Aviendha. We must go if you are to have any hope of avoiding the strap."

eɪvinhə stʃɹeɪɾənd wɪð ə saɪ, skɹʌbɪŋ əɾ əɹ aɪz. "meɪ jə ɔlweɪz faɪnd wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd, sɪstɝ."

Aviendha straightened with a sigh, scrubbing at her eyes. "May you always find water and shade, sister."

"meɪ jə ɔlweɪz faɪnd wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd, sɪstɝ," ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd. ði il weɪ hæɾ ə faɪnæləɾi əbaʊɾ ɪt, soʊ ʃi æɾəd, "əntɪl aɪ si jəɹ feɪs əɡɛn."

"May you always find water and shade, sister," Elayne replied. The Aiel way had a finality about it, so she added, "Until I see your face again."

ən əz kwɪkli əz ðæt, ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn. əz kwɪkli əz ðæt, ʃi fɛl vɛɹi əloʊn. eɪvinhəz pɹɛzəns hæd bɪkʌm ə sɝɾənti, ə sɪstɝ tə tɔk tə, læf wɪð, ʃɛɹ əɹ hoʊps ən fɪɹz wɪð, bʌt ðət kʌmfɝt wɑz ɡɔn.

And as quickly as that, they were gone. As quickly as that, she felt very alone. Aviendha's presence had become a certainty, a sister to talk to, laugh with, share her hopes and fears with, but that comfort was gone.

ɛsæn hæd slɪp fɹəm ðə ɹum waɪl ʃi ən eɪvinhə wɝ hʌɡɪŋ, ən naʊ ʃi ɹɪtɝn tə sɛt ðə kɔɹənɛɾ ə ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ɑn ɪleɪnz hɛd, ə sɪmpəl sɝkləɾ ʌv ɡoʊl səpɔɹɾɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl ɡoʊldən ɹoʊz ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛd. "soʊ ðiz mɝsənɛɹiz woʊn fɝɡɛɾ u ðəɹ tɔkɪŋ tə, maɪ leɪɾi."

Essande had slipped from the room while she and Aviendha were hugging, and now she returned to set the coronet of the Daughter-Heir on Elayne's head, a simple circlet of gold supporting a single golden rose on her forehead. "So these mercenaries won't forget who they're talking to, my Lady."

ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz əɹ ʃoʊldɝz hæd slʌmpt əntɪl ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd ðɛm. hɝ sɪstɝ wɑz ɡɔn, jɛt ʃi hæɾ ə sɪɾi tə dɪfɛn ən ə θɹoʊn tə ɡeɪn. duɾi wəɾ əv tə səsteɪn hɝ, naʊ.

Elayne did not realize her shoulders had slumped until she straightened them. Her sister was gone, yet she had a city to defend and a throne to gain. Duty would have to sustain her, now.

tʃæptɝ sɪkstin

CHAPTER 16

ðə nu fɑloʊɝ ðə blu ɹɪsɛpʃən ɹum, neɪm fəɹ ɪts ɑɹtʃt silɪŋ, peɪntəd tə dɪspleɪ ðə skaɪ ən waɪt klaʊdz, ən ɪts blu flɔɹ taɪlz, wɑz ðə smɔləst ɹɪsɛpʃən ɹum ɪn ðə pæləs, lɛs ðən tɛn peɪsɪz skwɛɹ. ði ɑɹtʃt wɪndoʊz ðət meɪɾ ʌp ðə fɑɹ wɔl, oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ ən stɪl fɪld wɪð ɡlæs keɪsməns əɡɛns ðə spɹɪŋ wɛðɝ, ɡeɪv ə fɛɹ laɪɾ ivən wɪð ðə ɹeɪn fɔlɪŋ aʊtsaɪd, bʌt dɪspaɪt tu lɑɹdʒ faɪɝpleɪsəz wɪð kɑɹv mɑɹbəl mæntəlz, ə kɔɹnəs ə plæstɝ laɪənz ən ə pɛɹ ə tæpəstʃɹiz bɛɹɪŋ ðə waɪt laɪən ðət flæŋk ðə dɔɹz, ə dɛləɡeɪʃən ə keɪɛmlɪnz mɝtʃəns wʊɾə bɪn ɪnsʌltɪd tə bi ɹəsivd ɪn ðə blu ɹum, ə dɛləɡeɪʃən ə bæŋkɝz lɪvɪd. laɪkli ðət wɑz waɪ mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ hæd pʊt ðə mɝsənɛɹiz ðɛɹ, ɔlðoʊ ðeɪ wəd nɑt noʊ ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ ɪnsʌltɪd. ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz pɹɛzənt, "oʊvɝsiɪŋ" ðə pɛɹ ə lɪvɹid jʌŋ meɪdz u wɝ kipɪŋ ðə waɪnkʌps fʊl fɹəm tɔl sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝz stændɪŋ ɑn ə tʃɹeɪ ətɑp ə pleɪnli kɑɹv saɪdbɔɹd, bʌt ʃi hæd ði ɪmbɔs lɛðɝ foʊldɝ juz tə kæɹi hɝ ɹɪpɔɹts pɹɛs tə hɝ bʊzəm, əz ɪf ɪn æntɪsəpeɪʃən ə ðə mɝsənɛɹiz biɪŋ dɛlt wɪð kwɪkli. hælwɪn nɔɹi, ðə wɪsps ʌv waɪt hɛɹ bɪhaɪn ɪz ɪɹz əz ɔlweɪz lʊkɪŋ laɪk fɛðɝz, wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ, ɔlsoʊ wɪð ɪz lɛðɝ foʊldɝ klʌtʃt tə hɪz nɛɹoʊ tʃɛst. ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts wɝ ə deɪli fɪkstʃɝ, ən sɛldəm mʌtʃ ɪn əm tə tʃɪɹ ðə hɑɹɾ ə leɪt. kwaɪt ði ɑpəzət.

The New Follower The Blue Reception Room, named for its arched ceiling, painted to display the sky and white clouds, and its blue floor tiles, was the smallest reception room in the palace, less than ten paces square. The arched windows that made up the far wall, overlooking a courtyard and still filled with glassed casements against the spring weather, gave a fair light even with the rain falling outside, but despite two large fireplaces with carved marble mantels, a cornice of plaster lions and a pair of tapestries bearing the White Lion that flanked the doors, a delegation of Caemlyn's merchants would have been insulted to be received in the Blue Room, a delegation of bankers livid. Likely that was why Mistress Harfor had put the mercenaries there, although they would not know they were being insulted. She herself was present, "overseeing" the pair of liveried young maids who were keeping the winecups full from tall silver pitchers standing on a tray atop a plainly carved sideboard, but she had the embossed leather folder used to carry her reports pressed to her bosom, as if in anticipation of the mercenaries being dealt with quickly. Halwin Norry, the wisps of white hair behind his ears as always looking like feathers, was standing in a corner, also with his leather folder clutched to his narrow chest. Their reports were a daily fixture, and seldom much in them to cheer the heart of late. Quite the opposite.

wɔɹn baɪ ðə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɑɹdzwɪmən u hæd tʃɛk ðə ɹum əhɛɾ ə hɝ, ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz ɑn ðɛɹ fit wən ɪleɪn ɛntɝd wɪð ənʌðɝ pɛɹ əɾ əɹ bæk. dɪni koʊlfɝd, ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən u hæd ɹipleɪs dɛvɝ ən ði ʌðɝz, hæd sɪmpli ɪɡnɔɹɾ əɹ ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ əm ɔl tə ɹɪmeɪn aʊtsaɪd. ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ! ʃi səpoʊz ðeɪ meɪɾ ə ɡʊd ʃoʊ, swæɡɝɪŋ pɹaʊdli əz ðeɪ dɪd, jɛt ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp ɡɹaɪndɪŋ əɹ tiθ.

Warned by the pair of Guardswomen who had checked the room ahead of her, everyone was on their feet when Elayne entered with another pair at her back. Deni Colford, in charge of the Guardswomen who had replaced Devore and the others, had simply ignored her order for them all to remain outside. Ignored her! She supposed they made a good show, swaggering proudly as they did, yet she could not stop grinding her teeth.

kɛɝin ən sɝaɪðə, fɔɹməl ɪn ðɛɹ fɹɪnd ʃɔlz, baʊd ðɛɹ hɛdz slaɪtli ɪn ɹɪspɛkt, bʌt mɛlɝ swɛpt ɔf ɪz plum hæɾ ɪn ə flɝɪʃɪŋ baʊ, wʌn hæn leɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə leɪs-ɛdʒ sæʃ slæntɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪt. ðə sɪks ɡoʊldən nɑts bɹeɪz tə ðət bɹɛstpleɪt, θɹi ɑn itʃ ʃoʊldɝ, ɹæŋkəl hɝ, jɛt ʃi hæd lɛɾ əm pæs soʊ fɑɹ. hɪz hætʃət feɪs ɔfɝɾ əɹ ə smaɪl ðət wɑz mʌtʃ tu wɔɹm, tu, bʌt ðɛn, haʊɛvɝ koʊld ʃi wɑz tə hɪm, hi θɔɾ i hæd səm tʃæns wɪð əɹ kəz ʃi hæd nɑt dɪnaɪd ðə ɹumɝ əɹ beɪbz wɝ hɪz. hɝ ɹizənz fəɹ nɑt kaʊntɝɪŋ ðət fɪlθi teɪl hæd tʃeɪnʒd - ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hæd nid tə pɹətɛkt əɹ beɪbz, ɹændz beɪbz - jɛt ʃi lɛɾ ɪt stænd. ɡɪv ðə mæn taɪm, ən i wəd bɹeɪɾ ə ɹoʊp fəɹ ɪz oʊn nɛk. ən ɪf i feɪl tə, ʃi wəd bɹeɪd wʌn fəɹ hɪm.

Careane and Sareitha, formal in their fringed shawls, bowed their heads slightly in respect, but Mellar swept off his plumed hat in a flourishing bow, one hand laid over the lace-edged sash slanting across his burnished breastplate. The six golden knots brazed to that breastplate, three on each shoulder, rankled her, yet she had let them pass so far. His hatchet face offered her a smile that was much too warm, too, but then, however cold she was to him, he thought he had some chance with her because she had not denied the rumor her babes were his. Her reasons for not countering that filthy tale had changed - she no longer had need to protect her babes, Rand's babes - yet she let it stand. Give the man time, and he would braid a rope for his own neck. And if he failed to, she would braid one for him.

ðə mɝsənɛɹiz, ɔl wɛl ɪndə ðɛɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, wɝ oʊnli ə hɑɹtbit bɪhaɪn mɛlɝ, ðoʊ nɑt soʊ ɪlæbɹəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ kɝɾəsiz. ɪvɹd kɔɹdwɪn, ə tɔl, skwɛɹ-dʒɔɾ ændɔɝən, wɔɹ ə lɑɹdʒ ɹubi ɪn ɪz lɛft ɪɹ, ən ældɝd ɡoʊmsən, ʃɔɹɾ ən slɛndɝ, ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd ʃeɪvd, hæd hɔɹəzɑntəl stʃɹaɪps ə ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin ən blu kʌvɝɪŋ hæf ɪz tʃɛst, fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ɪt simd əɾ ɔl laɪkli hi wɑz ɛntaɪɾəld tə ɪn ɪz neɪɾɪv kɛɹhin. hɑfin bɑkəvʌn, ɡɹeɪɪŋ, wɑz ɔɹnəmɛntɪd wɪð ə θɪk ɡoʊl hup ɪn ɪz lɛft ɪɹ ən ə dʒuəld ɹɪŋ ɑn ɛvɹi fɪŋɡɝ. ðə dəmɑni wɑz vɛɹi staʊt, bʌt ðə weɪ hi muv spoʊk ə sɑləd mʌsəl bɪniθ ðə fæt.

The mercenaries, all well into their middle years, were only a heartbeat behind Mellar, though not so elaborate in their courtesies. Evard Cordwyn, a tall, square-jawed Andoran, wore a large ruby in his left ear, and Aldred Gomaisen, short and slender, the front of his head shaved, had horizontal stripes of red and green and blue covering half his chest, far more than it seemed at all likely he was entitled to in his native Cairhien. Hafeen Bakuvun, graying, was ornamented with a thick gold hoop in his left ear and a jeweled ring on every finger. The Domani was very stout, but the way he moved spoke of solid muscle beneath the fat.

"doʊn juv duɾiz, kæptən mɛlɝ?" ɪleɪn sɛd kuli, teɪkɪŋ wʌn ə ðə ɹumz fju tʃɛɹz. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli faɪv, ɑɹmz ən haɪ bæks sɪmpli kɑɹvd wɪð vaɪnz ən livz ən lækɪŋ ivən ə hɪn ʌv ɡɪlt. stændɪŋ ɪn ə waɪdli speɪst ɹoʊ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə wɪndoʊz, ðə tʃɛɹz pʊt ðə laɪt bɪhaɪn huɛvɝ sæɾ ɪn ðɛm. ɑn ə bɹaɪt deɪ, ðoʊz ɡɪvən ɑɾiəns hɪɹ skwɪntɪɾ ɪn ðə ɡlɛɹ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðəɾ ædvæntɪdʒ wɑz lɔs tədeɪ. ðə tu ɡɑɹdzwɪmən tʊk ʌp pəzɪʃənz bɪhaɪn əɹ ən tə iðɝ saɪd, itʃ wɪð ə hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn əɹ sɔɹd hɪlt, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə mɝsənɛɹiz wɪð fɪɹs ɪkspɹɛʃənz ðət meɪd bɑkəvʌn smaɪl ən ɡoʊmsən ɹʌb ɪz tʃɪn tə hæf-haɪɾ ə slaɪ ɡɹɪn. ðə wɪmən ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ə biɪŋ əfɛndəd; ðeɪ nu ðə pɔɪn ə ðɛɹ junəfɔɹmz. ɪleɪn nu ðeɪ wəd waɪp əweɪ ɛni smaɪlz vɛɹi kwɪkli ɪf ðeɪ niɾəd tə dʒɹɔ ðɛɹ bleɪdz.

"Don't you have duties, Captain Mellar?" Elayne said coolly, taking one of the room's few chairs. There were only five, arms and high backs simply carved with vines and leaves and lacking even a hint of gilt. Standing in a widely spaced row in front of the windows, the chairs put the light behind whoever sat in them. On a bright day, those given audience here squinted in the glare. Unfortunately, that advantage was lost today. The two Guardswomen took up positions behind her and to either side, each with a hand resting on her sword hilt, watching the mercenaries with fierce expressions that made Bakuvun smile and Gomaisen rub his chin to half-hide a sly grin. The women gave no sign of being offended; they knew the point of their uniforms. Elayne knew they would wipe away any smiles very quickly if they needed to draw their blades.

"maɪ fɝs duɾi əbʌv ɔl ɪz tə pɹətɛk ju, maɪ leɪɾi." izɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd, mɛlɝ aɪd ðə mɝsənɛɹiz əz ðoʊ hi ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə ətæk hɝ, əɹ pɝhæps hɪm. ɡoʊmsən lʊk bɪɾɝli əmjuzd, ən bɑkəvʌn læft əlaʊd. ɔl θɹi mɛn hæɾ ɛmpti skæbɝdz, kɔɹdwɪn ə pɛɹ ɑn ɪz bæk; noʊ mɝsənɛɹi wɑz əlaʊd tə ɛntɝ ðə pæləs kæɹiɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə dæɡɝ.

"My first duty above all is to protect you, my Lady." Easing his sword, Mellar eyed the mercenaries as though he expected them to attack her, or perhaps him. Gomaisen looked bitterly amused, and Bakuvun laughed aloud. All three men had empty scabbards, Cordwyn a pair on his back; no mercenary was allowed to enter the palace carrying so much as a dagger.

"aɪ noʊ juv ʌðɝ duɾiz," ʃi sɛd lɛvəli, "bɪkɔz aɪ əsaɪn əm tə ju, kæptən. tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ðə mɛn aɪ bɹɔɾ ɪn fɹəm ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. jə ɑɹ nɑt spɛndɪŋ əz mʌtʃ taɪm wɪð əm əz aɪ ɪkspɛkt. juv ə kʌmpəni ʌv mɛn tə tʃɹeɪn, kæptən." ə kʌmpəni ʌv oʊl mɛn ən bɔɪz, ən ʃʊɹli ɪnʌf tə ɑkjəpaɪ hɪz aʊɝz. hi spɛn fju ɪnʌf wɪð əɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹdz ɪn spaɪɾ ə kəmændɪŋ ðɛm. ðət wɑz dʒʌst əz wɛl, ɹɪli. hi laɪk tə pɪntʃ bɑɾəmz. "aɪ sədʒɛs jə si tə ðɛm. naʊ."

"I know you have other duties," she said levelly, "because I assigned them to you, Captain. Training the men I brought in from the countryside. You are not spending as much time with them as I expect. You have a company of men to train, Captain." A company of old men and boys, and surely enough to occupy his hours. He spent few enough with her bodyguards in spite of commanding them. That was just as well, really. He liked to pinch bottoms. "I suggest you see to them. Now."

ɹeɪdʒ flæʃt əkɹɔs mɛlɝz nɛɹoʊ feɪs - hi æktʃəli  kwɪvɝd! - bʌɾ i mæstɝd hɪmsɛlf ɪnstənli. ɪt wɑz ɔl ɡɔn soʊ fæs ðət ʃi maɪɾ əv ɪmædʒən ɪt. bʌt ʃi nu ʃi hæd nɑt. "æz jə kəmænd, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd smuðli. hɪz smaɪl hæɾ ən ɔɪli smuðnəs, tu. "maɪ ɑnɝ ɪz tə sɝv jə wɛl." wɪð ənʌðɝ flæmbɔɪən baʊ, hi stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ, əz nɪɹ tə stʃɹʌɾɪŋ əz meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns. lɪɾəl kəd dɛn dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝz dɪminɝ fəɹ lɔŋ.

Rage flashed across Mellar's narrow face - he actually quivered! - but he mastered himself instantly. It was all gone so fast that she might have imagined it. But she knew she had not. "As you command, my Lady," he said smoothly. His smile had an oily smoothness, too. "My honor is to serve you well." With another flamboyant bow, he started for the door, as near to strutting as made no difference. Little could dent Doilin Mellar's demeanor for long.

bɑkəvʌn læft əɡɛn, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪz hɛd bæk. "mæn wɛɹz soʊ mʌtʃ leɪs naʊ, aɪ vaʊ, aɪ kip ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɪm tə ɔfɝ tə titʃ əs tə dæns, ən naʊ hi dʌz dæns." ðə kɛɹhinɪn læft, tu, ə næsti, ɡʌɾɝəl saʊnd.

Bakuvun laughed again, throwing his head back. "Man wears so much lace now, I vow, I keep expecting him to offer to teach us to dance, and now he does dance." The Cairhienin laughed, too, a nasty, guttural sound.

mɛlɝz bæk stɪfən ən ɪz stɛp hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən kwɪkənd, soʊ mʌtʃ soʊ ðəɾ i bʌmpt ɪndə bɝdʒɪɾ ət ðə dɔɹweɪ. hi hɝiɾ ɑn wɪθaʊt stɑpɪŋ tə æsk pɑɹɾən, ən ʃi fɹaʊn æftɝ ɪm - ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ æŋɡɝ, kwɪkli səpɹɛst, ən ɪmpeɪʃəns, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt - bɪfɔɹ ʃʌɾɪŋ ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn əɹ ən muvɪŋ tə stæn bɪsaɪɾ ɪleɪnz tʃɛɹ wɪð wʌn hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ðə tʃɛɹbæk. hɝ θɪk bɹeɪd wɑz nɑt soʊ nitli dʌn əz juʒəwəl æftɝ hævɪŋ bɪn əndʌn fəɹ dʒɹaɪɪŋ, bʌt ðə junəfɔɹm ə ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl suɾəd hɝ. tɔlɝ ðən ɡoʊmsən ɪn əɹ hil buts, bɝdʒɪt hæɾ ə kəmændɪŋ pɹɛzəns wən ʃi wɑntəd tə. ðə mɝsənɛɹiz ɔfɝɾ əɹ smɔl baʊz, ɹɪspɛkfəl ðoʊ nɑt dɛfɝɛntʃəl. wʌtɛvɝ mɪsɡɪvɪŋz ə hɝ ðeɪ maɪɾ əv ɛntɝteɪn ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, fju hu hæd sin əɹ juz əɹ baʊ, əɹ ɪkspoʊz hɝsɛlf tə ði ɛnəmi, hæɾ ɛni ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ.

Mellar's back stiffened and his step hesitated, then quickened, so much so that he bumped into Birgitte at the doorway. He hurried on without stopping to ask pardon, and she frowned after him - the bond carried anger, quickly suppressed, and impatience, which was not - before shutting the door behind her and moving to stand beside Elayne's chair with one hand resting on the chairback. Her thick braid was not so neatly done as usual after having been undone for drying, but the uniform of the Captain-General suited her. Taller than Gomaisen in her heeled boots, Birgitte had a commanding presence when she wanted to. The mercenaries offered her small bows, respectful though not deferential. Whatever misgivings of her they might have entertained in the beginning, few who had seen her use her bow, or expose herself to the enemy, had any remaining.

"ju spik əz ɪf jə noʊ kæptən mɛlɝ, kæptən bɑkəvʌn." ɪleɪn pʊt dʒʌst ə hɪn ə kwɛstʃən ɪn ðæt, bʌt kɛpt əɹ toʊn kæʒəwəl. bɝdʒɪt wɑz ətɛmptɪŋ tə pɹədʒɛkt kɑnfəɾəns əlɔŋ ðə bɑn tə ikwəl əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən, jɛt wɛɹinɪs ən wɝi kɛpt ɪntʃɹuɾɪŋ. ən ði ɛvɝ-pɹɛzənt wɪɹinəs. ɪleɪn taɪɾənd əɹ dʒɔ tə faɪɾ ə jɔn. bɝdʒɪt hæd tə ɡɛt səm ɹɛst.

"You speak as if you know Captain Mellar, Captain Bakuvun." Elayne put just a hint of question in that, but kept her tone casual. Birgitte was attempting to project confidence along the bond to equal her expression, yet wariness and worry kept intruding. And the ever-present weariness. Elayne tightened her jaw to fight a yawn. Birgitte had to get some rest.

"aɪv sin ɪm wʌns əɹ twaɪs bɪfɔɹ, maɪ leɪɾi," ðə dəmɑni ɹɪplaɪd kɔʃəsli. "nɑɾ əbʌv θɹaɪs ət moʊst, aɪd seɪ. jɛs, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt." hi tɪltəɾ ɪz hɛd, aɪɪŋ əɹ ɔlmoʊst saɪdweɪz. "ju noʊ hiz fɑloʊd maɪ tʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ðə pæst?"

"I've seen him once or twice before, my Lady," the Domani replied cautiously. "Not above thrice at most, I'd say. Yes, no more than that." He tilted his head, eyeing her almost sideways. "You know he's followed my trade in the past?"

"hi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə haɪd ðə fækt, kæptən," ʃi sɛd, əz ɪf taɪɝɾ ə ðə sʌbʒɪkt. hæɾ i lɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ slɪp, ʃi maɪɾ əv ɝeɪnʒd tə kwɛstʃən ɪm əloʊn, bʌt pɹɛsɪŋ wɑz nɑt wɝθ ðə ɹɪsk ə mɛlɝ dɪskʌvɝɪŋ ðət kwɛstʃənz wɝ biɪŋ æskt. hi maɪt ɹʌn ðɛn, bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd lɝn wʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə noʊ.

"He did not try to hide the fact, Captain," she said, as if tired of the subject. Had he let anything interesting slip, she might have arranged to question him alone, but pressing was not worth the risk of Mellar discovering that questions were being asked. He might run then, before she could learn what she wanted to know.

"du wi ɹɪli hæv niɾ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, maɪ leɪɾi?" bɑkəvʌn æskt. "ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ," hi æɾəd, ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ. hi hɛld aʊɾ ɪz sɪlvɝ kʌp, ən wʌn ə ðə meɪdz dɑɹɾɪd tə fɪl ɪt. ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ pɹɪɾi wɪmən, pɝhæps nɑt ðə bɛs tʃɔɪsəz, bʌt ɹɪn hæd nɑt mʌtʃ tə tʃuz fɹʌm; moʊst ə ðə meɪdz wɝ iðɝ jʌŋ əɹ ɛls eɪdʒɪɾ ən nɑt soʊ spɹaɪ əz ðeɪ wʌns hæd bɪn. "ɔl ðeɪv dʌn ðə hoʊl taɪm wiv bɪn hɪɹ ɪz tʃɹaɪ tə pʊɾ əs ɪn ɑ ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝz maɪɾ ən ɹitʃ. aɪ ɹɪspɛkt ɛɛs sədaɪ əz mʌtʃ əz ɛni mæn, jɛs, aɪ də ɪndid, bʌɾ ɪf jəl fɝɡɪv mi, ɪt ɡɛts taɪɝsəm wən ðeɪ tɝn tə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɹaʊbiɾ ə mæn. aɪ vaʊ ɪt dʌz, maɪ leɪɾi."

"Do we really have need of the Aes Sedai, my Lady?" Bakuvun asked. "The other Aes Sedai," he added, glancing at her Great Serpent ring. He held out his silver cup, and one of the maids darted to fill it. They were both pretty women, perhaps not the best choices, but Reene had not much to choose from; most of the maids were either young or else aged and not so spry as they once had been. "All they've done the whole time we've been here is try to put us in awe of the White Tower's might and reach. I respect Aes Sedai as much as any man, yes, I do indeed, but if you'll forgive me, it gets tiresome when they turn to trying to browbeat a man. I vow it does, my Lady."

"ə waɪz mæn ɔlweɪz stænz ɪn ɑ ʌv ðə taʊɝ," sɝaɪðə sɛd kɑmli, ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ bɹaʊn-fɹɪnd ʃɔl, pɝhæps tə dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən tə ɪt. hɝ dɑɹk, skwɛɹ feɪs læk ði eɪdʒləs lʊk əz jɛt, ən ʃi ədmɪɾəd jɝnɪŋ fəɹ ɪt.

"A wise man always stands in awe of the Tower," Sareitha said calmly, shifting her brown-fringed shawl, perhaps to draw attention to it. Her dark, square face lacked the ageless look as yet, and she admitted yearning for it.

"oʊnli fulz feɪl tə stæn ɪn ɑ ʌv ðə taʊɝ," kɛɝin sɛɾ ɑn sɝaɪðəz hilz. ə bʌlki wʊmən, əz waɪɾ ɪn ðə ʃoʊldɝz əz moʊs mɛn, ðə ɡɹin hæd noʊ nid fəɹ dʒɛstʃɝz. hɝ kɑpɝi feɪs pɹoʊkleɪmd wʌt ʃi wɑz tə ɛniwʌn u nu wʌt tə lʊk fəɹ əz laʊdli əz dɪd ðə ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ.

"Only fools fail to stand in awe of the Tower," Careane said on Sareitha's heels. A bulky woman, as wide in the shoulders as most men, the Green had no need for gestures. Her coppery face proclaimed what she was to anyone who knew what to look for as loudly as did the ring on her right forefinger.

"ðə wɝɾ aɪ hɪɹ," ɡoʊmsən sɛd dɑɹkli, "ɪz ðət tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪz bɪsidʒd. aɪ hɪɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz splɪt, wɪð tu æmɪɝlənz. aɪ ivən hɪɹ ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf ɪz hɛl baɪ ðə blæk ədʒɑ." ə bɹeɪv mæn, tə mɛnʃən ðət ɹumɝ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ i stɪl flɪntʃt seɪɪŋ ɪt. flɪntʃt ən wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn. "hu ɪz ɪt jə wɑn əs tə bi ɪn ɑ ʌv?"

"The word I hear," Gomaisen said darkly, "is that Tar Valon is besieged. I hear the White Tower is split, with two Amyrlins. I even hear the Tower itself is held by the Black Ajah." A brave man, to mention that rumor to Aes Sedai, but he still flinched saying it. Flinched and went right on. "Who is it you want us to be in awe of?"

"du nɑt bɪliv ɛvɹiθɪŋ jə hɪɹ, kæptən ɡoʊmsən." sɝaɪðəz vɔɪs wɑz sɝin, ə wʊmən steɪɾɪŋ ɪndɪspjuɾəbəl fækt. "tʃɹuθ əz mɔɹ ʃeɪɾɪŋz ðən jə maɪt θɪŋk, ən dɪstəns ɔfən dɪstɔɹts tʃɹuθ ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə fæks. laɪz əbaʊt dɑɹkfɹɛn sɪstɝz ɑɹ deɪnʒɝəs tə ɹɪpit, haʊɛvɝ."

"Do not believe everything you hear, Captain Gomaisen." Sareitha's voice was serene, a woman stating indisputable fact. "Truth has more shadings than you might think, and distance often distorts truth into something very different from the facts. Lies about Darkfriend sisters are dangerous to repeat, however."

"wʌt jə hæd bɛs bɪliv," kɛɝin æɾəd, dʒʌst əz kɑmli, "ɪz ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz ðə waɪt taʊɝ, naʊ ən ɔlweɪz. ən jə stæn bɪfɔɹ θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə ʃəɾ əv ə kɛɹ wɪð jəɹ wɝdz, kæptən."

"What you had best believe," Careane added, just as calmly, "is that the White Tower is the White Tower, now and always. And you stand before three Aes Sedai. You should have a care with your words, Captain."

ɡoʊmsən skɹʌb ðə bæk ʌv ə hæn əkɹɔs ɪz maʊθ, bʌɾ ɪz dɑɹk aɪz hɛl dɪfaɪəns. ə hʌntəd dɪfaɪəns. "aɪ æm dʒʌst seɪɪŋ wʌt kən bi hɝɾ ɑn ɛni stʃɹit," hi mʌɾɝd.

Gomaisen scrubbed the back of a hand across his mouth, but his dark eyes held defiance. A hunted defiance. "I am just saying what can be heard on any street," he muttered.

"ɑɹ wi hɪɹ tə tɔk əbaʊt ðə waɪt taʊɝ?" kɔɹdwɪn sɛd, skaʊlɪŋ. hi ɛmptiɾ ɪz waɪnkʌp bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn, əz ɪf ðɪs tɔk meɪɾ ɪm ənizi. haʊ mʌtʃ hæɾ i ɔlɹɛɾi kənsumd? hi simd ə tʃɹaɪfəl ənstɛɾi ɑn ɪz fit, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə tʌtʃ ə slɝ ɪn ɪz wɝdz. "ðə taʊɝ ɪz hʌnʒɹədz ə liɡz fɹəm hɪɹ, ən wʌt hæpənz ðəɹ ɪz noʊ bɪznəs ʌv aʊɝz."

"Are we here to talk about the White Tower?" Cordwyn said, scowling. He emptied his winecup before going on, as if this talk made him uneasy. How much had he already consumed? He seemed a trifle unsteady on his feet, and there was a touch of slur in his words. "The Tower is hundreds of leagues from here, and what happens there is no business of ours."

"tʃɹu, fɹɛnd," bɑkəvʌn sɛd. "tʃɹu. əɹ bɪznəs ɪz sɔɹdz, sɔɹdz ən blʌd. wɪtʃ, maɪ leɪɾi, bɹɪŋz əs tə ðə sɔɹɾəd mæɾɝ ʌv . . ." - hi wæɡəl θɪk, bi-ɡɛm fɪŋɡɝz - "ɡoʊld. ɛvɹi deɪ, wi luz mɛn, deɪ æftɝ deɪ wɪð noʊ ɛn ɪn saɪt, ən ðəɹ ɑɹ vɛɹi fju suɾəbəl ɹipleɪsməns tə bi faʊn ɪn ðə sɪɾi."

"True, friend," Bakuvun said. "True. Our business is swords, swords and blood. Which, my Lady, brings us to the sordid matter of . . ." - he waggled thick, be-gemmed fingers - "gold. Every day, we lose men, day after day with no end in sight, and there are very few suitable replacements to be found in the city."
