"nʌn əɾ ɔl ðəɾ aɪv faʊnd," kɔɹdwɪn mʌɾɝd, aɪɪŋ ðə jʌŋ meɪd fɪlɪŋ ɪz kʌp. ʃi blʌʃt əɾ ɪz skɹuɾəni ən fɪnɪʃt əɹ tæsk kwɪkli, spɪlɪŋ waɪn ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz ən meɪkɪŋ mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ fɹaʊn. "ðoʊz ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ɑɹ ɔl saɪnɪŋ ʌp fəɹ ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz." ðət wɑz tʃɹu ɪnʌf; ɛnlɪsmənts sim tə ɪnkɹis baɪ ðə deɪ. ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz wəd bi ə fɔɹməɾəbəl fɔɹs. ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðə væs mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv ðoʊz mɛn wɝ mʌnθs fɹəm biɪŋ eɪbəl tə hændəl ə sɔɹd wɪθaʊt stæbɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ðə fʊt, ən fɝðɝ fɹəm biɪŋ ʌv ɛni jus ɪn bæɾəl.

"None at all that I've found," Cordwyn muttered, eyeing the young maid filling his cup. She blushed at his scrutiny and finished her task quickly, spilling wine on the floor tiles and making Mistress Harfor frown. "Those that might have been are all signing up for the Queen's Guards." That was true enough; enlistments seemed to increase by the day. The Queen's Guards would be a formidable force. Eventually. Unfortunately, the vast majority of those men were months from being able to handle a sword without stabbing themselves in the foot, and further from being of any use in battle.

"æz jə seɪ, fɹɛnd," bɑkəvʌn mɝmɝd. "æz jə seɪ." hi dɝɛktəɾ ə waɪd smaɪl əɾ ɪleɪn. pɝhæps i mɛn tə sim fɹɛnli, əɹ meɪbi ɹizənəbəl, bʌɾ ɪt maɪndəɾ əɹ ʌv ə mæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sɛl əɹ ə pɪɡ ɪn ə sæk. "ivən æftɝ wɝ dʌn hɪɹ, faɪndɪŋ nu mɛn woʊn bi izi, maɪ leɪɾi. suɾəbəl mɛn ɑɹən faʊn ʌndɝ kæbədʒ livz, noʊ ðəɹ nɑt. fjuɝ mɛn minz fjuɝ kɔɪnz fəɹ əɹ nɛks haɪɝz. ən ɪnɪskeɪpəbəl fækt ə ðə wɝld. wi θɪŋk ɪts oʊnli dʒʌs ðət wi ɹəsiv kɑmpənseɪʃən."

"As you say, friend," Bakuvun murmured. "As you say." He directed a wide smile at Elayne. Perhaps he meant to seem friendly, or maybe reasonable, but it minded her of a man trying to sell her a pig in a sack. "Even after we're done here, finding new men won't be easy, my Lady. Suitable men aren't found under cabbage leaves, no they're not. Fewer men means fewer coins for our next hires. An inescapable fact of the world. We think it's only just that we receive compensation."

æŋɡɝ sɝdʒd ɪn ɪleɪn. ðeɪ θɔt ʃi wɑz dɛspɹɪt tə hoʊld ɑn tə ðɛm wɑz wʌt ðeɪ θɔt! wɝs, ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪt. ðiz θɹi mɛn ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd bɛɾɝ ðən ə θaʊzən mɔɹ bɪtwin ðɛm. ivən wɪð wʌt ɡaɪbɑn hæd bɹɔt hɝ, ðət wəd bi ə ɡɹivəs lɔs. ɪspɛʃli ɪf ɪt stɑɹɾəd ʌðɝ mɝsənɛɹiz θɪŋkɪŋ əɹ kɑz wɑz lɔst. mɝsənɛɹiz dɪslaɪk biɪŋ ɑn ðə luzɪŋ saɪd. ðeɪ wəd ɹʌn laɪk ɹæts fliɪŋ faɪɝ tə əvɔɪd ðæt. hɝ æŋɡɝ sɝdʒd, bʌt ʃi hɛld ɪɾ ɪn ɹeɪn. baɪ ə hɛɹz bɹɛdθ. ʃi kəd nɑt kip ðə skɔɹn fɹəm əɹ vɔɪs, ðoʊ. "dɪd jə θɪŋk jə wəd teɪk noʊ kæʒəwəltiz? dɪd jə ɪkspɛk tə maʊnt ɡɑɹɾ ən teɪk ɡoʊl fəɹ ɪt wɪθaʊt bɛɹɪŋ jəɹ sɔɹdz?"

Anger surged in Elayne. They thought she was desperate to hold on to them was what they thought! Worse, they were right. These three men represented better than a thousand more between them. Even with what Guybon had brought her, that would be a grievous loss. Especially if it started other mercenaries thinking her cause was lost. Mercenaries disliked being on the losing side. They would run like rats fleeing fire to avoid that. Her anger surged, but she held it in rein. By a hair's breadth. She could not keep the scorn from her voice, though. "Did you think you would take no casualties? Did you expect to mount guard and take gold for it without baring your swords?"

"ju saɪn fəɹ soʊ mʌtʃ ɡoʊld itʃ deɪ," bɝdʒɪt pʊɾ ɪn. ʃi dɪd nɑt seɪ haʊ mʌtʃ kəz ɛvɹi kʌmpəni hæd bɑɹɡən fəɹ ɪts oʊn əɡɹimənt. ðə læs θɪŋ ðeɪ niɾəd wɑz fəɹ ðə mɝsənɛɹi kʌmpəniz tə ɡɹoʊ dʒɛləs ʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ. əz ɪt wɑz, ɪt sim ðət hæf ðə kɑmən ɹum faɪts ðə ɡɑɹdz bɹoʊk ʌp wɝ bɪtwin mɛn ə dɪfɹən kʌmpəniz. "ə fɪkst əmaʊnt. tə pʊɾ ɪt kɹuli, ðə mɔɹ mɛn jə luz, ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ jəɹ pɹɑfət."

"You signed for so much gold each day," Birgitte put in. She did not say how much because every company had bargained for its own agreement. The last thing they needed was for the mercenary companies to grow jealous of one another. As it was, it seemed that half the common room fights the Guards broke up were between men of different companies. "A fixed amount. To put it cruelly, the more men you lose, the greater your profit."

"ɑ, kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl," ðə staʊt mæn sɛd blænli, "bʌt jə fɝɡɛt ðə dɛθ-mʌni ðəɾ əz tə bi peɪd tə ðə wɪɾoʊz ən ɔɹfənz." ɡoʊmsən meɪɾ ə tʃoʊkɪŋ nɔɪz, ən kɔɹdwɪn stɛɹɾ ət bɑkəvʌn ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli ðən tʃɹaɪd tə kʌvɝ ɪt baɪ dʒɹeɪnɪŋ ɪz waɪnkʌp əɡɛn.

"Ah, Captain-General," the stout man said blandly, "but you forget the death-money that has to be paid to the widows and orphans." Gomaisen made a choking noise, and Cordwyn stared at Bakuvun incredulously then tried to cover it by draining his winecup again.

ɪleɪn tʃɹɛmbəld, hɝ hænz taɪɾənɪŋ tə fɪsts ɑn ði ɑɹmz ə hɝ tʃɛɹ. ʃi wəd nɑt ɡɪv weɪ tə æŋɡɝ. ʃi wəd nɑt! "aɪ ɪntɛn tə hoʊl jə tə jəɹ əɡɹiməns," ʃi sɛd koʊldli. wɛl, ət list ʃi wɑz nɑt ɹeɪdʒɪŋ. "jul bi peɪd wʌt jə saɪn fɔɹ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə juʒəwəl vɪktɝi ɡoʊld æftɝ aɪ ɡeɪn ðə θɹoʊn, bʌt nɑɾ ə pɛni mɔɹ. ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ tə bæk aʊt, əl əsum jə ɑɹ tɝnɪŋ koʊɾ ən ɡoʊɪŋ oʊvɝ tə ɛɹəmɪlə, ɪn wɪtʃ keɪs, əl əv jə ən jəɹ kʌmpəniz ɝɛstəɾ ən pʊɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡeɪts wɪθaʊt sɔɹdz əɹ hɔɹsəz." ðə meɪd ɹifɪlɪŋ kɔɹdwɪnz waɪnkʌp jɛɾ əɡɛn sʌɾənli skwild ən dænst əweɪ fɹəm ɪm ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ hɪp. ði æŋɡɝ ɪleɪn hæd bɪn hoʊldɪŋ daʊn faʊnteɪnd waɪt hɑt. "æn ɪf wʌn ə jə ɛvɝ əɡɛn dɛɹz fɑndəl wʌn ə maɪ wɪmən, hi ən ɪz kʌmpəni wɪl bi pʊɾ aʊt wɪθaʊt sɔɹdz, hɔɹsəz, əɹ buts! də aɪ meɪk maɪsɛlf klɪɹ?"

Elayne trembled, her hands tightening to fists on the arms of her chair. She would not give way to anger. She would not! "I intend to hold you to your agreements," she said coldly. Well, at least she was not raging. "You'll be paid what you signed for, including the usual victory gold after I gain the throne, but not a penny more. If you try to back out, I'll assume you are turning coat and going over to Arymilla, in which case, I'll have you and your companies arrested and put outside the gates without swords or horses." The maid refilling Cordwyn's winecup yet again suddenly squealed and danced away from him rubbing her hip. The anger Elayne had been holding down fountained white hot. "And if one of you ever again dares fondle one of my women, he and his company will be put out without swords, horses, or boots! Do I make myself clear?"

"vɛɹi klɪɹ, maɪ leɪɾi." bɑkəvʌnz vɔɪs hɛld ə dɪstɪŋk tʃɪl, ən ɪz waɪd maʊθ wɑz taɪt. "vɛɹi klɪɹ ɪndid. ən naʊ, sɪns əɹ . . . dɪskʌʃən . . . simz kənkluɾəd, meɪ wi wɪðdʒɹɔ?"

"Very clear, my Lady." Bakuvun's voice held a distinct chill, and his wide mouth was tight. "Very clear indeed. And now, since our . . . discussion . . . seems concluded, may we withdraw?"

"θɪŋk kɛɹfəli," sɝaɪðə sɛd sʌɾənli. "wɪl ðə waɪt taʊɝ tʃuz tə si ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn, əɹ ə ful laɪk ɛɹəmɪlə mɑɹn?"

"Think carefully," Sareitha said suddenly. "Will the White Tower choose to see an Aes Sedai on the Lion Throne, or a fool like Arymilla Marne?"

"kaʊn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðɪs pæləs," kɛɝin æɾəd. "kaʊn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪnsaɪd keɪɛmlɪn. ðəɹ ɑɹ nʌn ɪn ɛɹəmɪləz kæmps. kaʊn ən dɪsaɪd wɛɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝz feɪvɝ laɪz."

"Count the Aes Sedai in this palace," Careane added. "Count the Aes Sedai inside Caemlyn. There are none in Arymilla's camps. Count and decide where the White Tower's favor lies."

"kaʊnt," sɝaɪðə sɛd, "æn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝz dɪsplɛʒɝ kən bi feɪɾəl."

"Count," Sareitha said, "and remember that the White Tower's displeasure can be fatal."

ɪt wɑz vɛɹi hɑɹd tə bɪliv ðət wʌn ə ðɛm mʌs bi blæk ədʒɑ, jɛɾ ɪt mʌs bi soʊ. ənlɛs ɪt wɑz mɛɝɪlɪl, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪleɪn hoʊp ðət wɑz nɑt soʊ. ʃi laɪk mɛɝɪlɪl. bʌt ðɛn, ʃi laɪkt kɛɝin ən sɝaɪðə, tu. nɑɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi dɪd mɛɝɪlɪl, jɛt stɪl ə laɪkɪŋ. ɛni weɪ ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪt, ə wʊmən ʃi laɪkt wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ən ɔlɹɛɾi ʌndɝ pɛnəlti ʌv dɛθ.

It was very hard to believe that one of them must be Black Ajah, yet it must be so. Unless it was Merilille, of course. Elayne hoped that was not so. She liked Merilille. But then, she liked Careane and Sareitha, too. Not as much as she did Merilille, yet still a liking. Any way she looked at it, a woman she liked was a Darkfriend, and already under penalty of death.

wən ðə mɝsənɛɹiz hæd dɪpɑɹɾəd, meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ kɝɾəsiz hɝidli, ən mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ hæd sɛn ðə meɪdz əweɪ wɪð ðə ɹɛmnəns ə ðə waɪn, ɪleɪn lin bæk ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ ən saɪd. "aɪ hændəl ðət vɛɹi bædli, dɪdn aɪ?"

When the mercenaries had departed, making their courtesies hurriedly, and Mistress Harfor had sent the maids away with the remnants of the wine, Elayne leaned back in her chair and sighed. "I handled that very badly, didn't I?"

"mɝsənɛɹiz ɹikwaɪɝ ə stʃɹɔŋ hæn ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz," bɝdʒɪt ɹɪplaɪd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz daʊɾ ɪn ðə bɑnd. daʊɾ ən wɝi.

"Mercenaries require a strong hand on the reins," Birgitte replied, but there was doubt in the bond. Doubt and worry.

"ɪf aɪ meɪ seɪ, maɪ leɪɾi," nɔɹi sɛɾ ɪn ɪz dʒɹaɪ vɔɪs, "aɪ kænɑt si ɛniθɪŋ ɛls jə kəɾ əv dʌn. maɪlnəs wəɾ oʊnli hæv ɛmboʊldən əm tə meɪk fɝðɝ dɪmænz." hi hæd bɪn soʊ stɪl ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæɾ ɔlmoʊs fɝɡɑɾən i wɑz ðɛɹ. blɪŋkɪŋ ət ðə wɝld, hi simd ə weɪɾɪŋ bɝd wʌndɝɪŋ wɛɹ ðə wɔɾɝ hæd ɡɔn. ɪn kɑntʃɹæs tə mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝz nitnəs, ɪŋk steɪnz mɑɹkt ɪz tɑbɝd, ən ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. ʃi aɪd ðə lɛðɝ foʊldɝ ɪn ɪz hænz wɪð dɪstɪŋk dɪsteɪst.

"If I may say, my Lady," Norry said in his dry voice, "I cannot see anything else you could have done. Mildness would only have emboldened them to make further demands." He had been so still that Elayne had almost forgotten he was there. Blinking at the world, he seemed a wading bird wondering where the water had gone. In contrast to Mistress Harfor's neatness, ink stains marked his tabard, and his fingers. She eyed the leather folder in his hands with distinct distaste.

"wɪl jə liv ʌs, pliz, sɝaɪðə, kɛɝin?" ʃi sɛd. ðeɪ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd slaɪtli, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ðeɪ kəd də seɪv baʊ ðɛɹ hɛdz ən ɡlaɪd fɹəm ðə ɹum laɪk swɑnz. "æn jə tu əz wɛl," ʃi æɾəd oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ tə ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz twɪtʃ!

"Will you leave us, please, Sareitha, Careane?" she said. They hesitated slightly, but there was nothing they could do save bow their heads and glide from the room like swans. "And you two as well," she added over her shoulder to the Guardswomen. They did not so much as twitch!

"aʊtsaɪd!" bɝdʒɪt snæpt wɪð ə dʒɝk ə hɝ hɛd ðət sɛɾ əɹ bɹeɪd sweɪɪŋ. "naʊ!" oʊ, ðə pɛɹ dʒʌmp fəɹ hɝ, ðeɪ dɪd! ðeɪ hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹz soʊ fæs ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl əv tʃɹɑɾəd!

"Outside!" Birgitte snapped with a jerk of her head that set her braid swaying. "Now!" Oh, the pair jumped for her, they did! They headed for the doors so fast they might as well have trotted!

ɪleɪn skaʊld əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðɛm. "bɝn mi, aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hɪɹ ɛni blʌɾi bæd nuz, nɑt tədeɪ. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hɪɹ haʊ mʌtʃ ə ðə fud bɹɔɾ ɪn fɹəm ɪljən ən tiɹ ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi spɔɪld wən ɪɾ ɝaɪvz. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hɪɹ əbaʊɾ ɑɹsən, əɹ flaʊɝ blæk wɪð wivəlz, əɹ suɝz bɹiɾɪŋ ɹæts fæstɝ ðən ðeɪ kən bi kɪld, əɹ flaɪz soʊ θɪk jud θɪŋk keɪɛmlɪn wɑz ə fɪlθi steɪbəl. aɪ wɑnə hɪɹ səm blʌɾi ɡʊd nuz fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ." bɝn hɝ, ʃi saʊndəd pɛtʃələnt! tʃɹuθ bi toʊld, ʃi fɛl pɛtʃələnt. oʊ, haʊ ðət ɡɹeɪɾɪd! ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡeɪn ə θɹoʊn, ən bɪheɪvɪŋ laɪk ə tʃaɪld ɪn ðə nɝsɝi!

Elayne scowled as the door closed behind them. "Burn me, I don't want to hear any bloody bad news, not today. I don't want to hear how much of the food brought in from Illian and Tear is already spoiled when it arrives. I don't want to hear about arson, or flour black with weevils, or sewers breeding rats faster than they can be killed, or flies so thick you'd think Caemlyn was a filthy stable. I want to hear some bloody good news for a change." Burn her, she sounded petulant! Truth be told, she felt petulant. Oh, how that grated! She was trying to gain a throne, and behaving like a child in the nursery!

mæstɝ nɔɹi ən mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz, wɪtʃ oʊnli meɪd mæɾɝz wɝs. hi fɑndəld ɪz foʊldɝ wɪð ə saɪ ʌv ɹəɡɹɛt. ðə mæn ɛndʒɔɪd dʒɹoʊnɪŋ ɪz nʌmbɝz, ivən wən ðeɪ wɝ daɪɹ. ət lis ðeɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɔkt ət ɡɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts ɪn kʌmpəni. wɛl, nɑt vɛɹi fɑɹ. dʒɛləs ə ðɛɹ oʊn ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾiz, itʃ wɑz wɛɹi ʌv ði ʌðɝ stʃɹeɪɪŋ ən kwɪk tə pɔɪn aʊt wɛɹ səm ɪmædʒən baʊndɝi hæd bɪn kɹɔst. stɪl, ðeɪ mænədʒ tə ɹʌn ðə pæləs ən ðə sɪɾi ɪfɪʃənli, wɪð fju bɑɹk nʌkəlz.

Master Norry and Mistress Harfor exchanged glances, which only made matters worse. He fondled his folder with a sigh of regret. The man enjoyed droning his numbers, even when they were dire. At least they no longer balked at giving their reports in company. Well, not very far. Jealous of their own responsibilities, each was wary of the other straying and quick to point out where some imagined boundary had been crossed. Still, they managed to run the palace and the city efficiently, with few barked knuckles.

"ɑɹ wi pɹaɪvət, maɪ leɪɾi?" ɹɪn æskt.

"Are we private, my Lady?" Reene asked.

ɪleɪn dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən pɝfɔɹm nɑvəs ɛksɝsaɪzəz ðət sim tə hæv noʊ kɑmɪŋ ɪfɛkt wʌtsoʊɛvɝ, ðən ətɛmptəd tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, seɪaɪdɑɹ keɪm tə hɝ izəli, fɪlɪŋ əɹ wɪð ðə switnəs ə laɪf ən dʒɔɪ. ən suðɪŋ əɹ mudz, tu. ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz ðət weɪ. æŋɡɝ əɹ sɑɹoʊ əɹ dʒʌs biɪŋ wɪð tʃaɪl maɪɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, jɛt wʌns ɪt fɪl hɝ, hɝ ɪmoʊʃənz stɑp dʒʌmpɪŋ əbaʊt. dɛfli ʃi woʊv faɪɝ ən ɛɹ, dʒʌst soʊ, wɪð tʃɹeɪsəz ʌv wɔɾɝ, bʌt wən ʃi wɑz dʌn, ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹilis ðə sɔɹs. ðə fil ə biɪŋ fɪld wɪð ðə paʊɝ wɑz wʌnʒɹəs, jɛt nɑt ðət mʌtʃ mɔɹ soʊ ðən noʊɪŋ ʃi wəd nɑt bi wɑntɪŋ tə wip fəɹ noʊ ɹizən əɹ ʃaʊt fəɹ əz lɪɾəl ɪn ðə nɛks moʊmənt. æftɝ ɔl, ʃi wɑz nɑt fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə dʒɹɔ tu dipli.

Elayne drew a deep breath and performed novice exercises that seemed to have no calming effect whatsoever, then attempted to embrace the Source. To her surprise, saidar came to her easily, filling her with the sweetness of life and joy. And soothing her moods, too. It was always that way. Anger or sorrow or just being with child might interfere with embracing the Power in the first place, yet once it filled her, her emotions stopped jumping about. Deftly she wove Fire and Air, just so, with traces of Water, but when she was done, she did not release the Source. The feel of being filled with the Power was wondrous, yet not that much more so than knowing she would not be wanting to weep for no reason or shout for as little in the next moment. After all, she was not foolish enough to draw too deeply.

"wi ɑɹ pɹaɪvət," ʃi sɛd. seɪaɪdɑɹ tʌtʃt əɹ wɔɹɾ ən wɑz ɡɔn. sʌmwʌn hæd tʃɹaɪd tə lɪsən ɪn, nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm ðət hæd hæpənd. wɪð soʊ mɛni wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ðə pæləs, ɪt wʊɾə bɪn sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ ɪf noʊ wʌn ətɛmptəd tə snup, bʌt ʃi wɪʃt ʃi nu haʊ tə tʃɹeɪs huɛvɝ wɑz meɪkɪŋ ðoʊz ətɛmps. əz ɪt wɑz, ʃi hɑɹdli dɛɹd seɪ ɛniθɪŋ ə sʌbstəns wɪθaʊɾ ə wɔɹɾ ɪn pleɪs.

"We are private," she said. Saidar touched her ward and was gone. Someone had tried to listen in, not the first time that had happened. With so many women who could channel gathered in the palace, it would have been surprising if no one attempted to snoop, but she wished she knew how to trace whoever was making those attempts. As it was, she hardly dared say anything of substance without a ward in place.

"ðɛn aɪ hæv ə lɪɾəl ɡʊd nuz," mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ sɛd, ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ foʊldɝ bʌt nɑɾ oʊpənɪŋ ɪt, "fɹʌm dʒɑn skɛlɪt." ðə bɑɹbɝ hæd bɪn moʊst əsɪdwəs əbaʊt kæɹiɪŋ ɪz ɹɪpɔɹts, əpɹuv bɪfɔɹhæn baɪ ɹɪn, aʊt tə ɛɹəmɪlə ən bɹɪŋɪŋ bæk wʌɾ i kəd lɝn ɪn ðə kæmps aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. hi wɑz ɪn ði ɛmplɔɪ ʌv nɑiən ɑɝɔn, bʌt nɑiən, səpɔɹɾɪŋ ɛɹəmɪləz kleɪm, wəd ʃʊɹli ʃɛɹ skɛlɪts ɹɪpɔɹts wɪð ɛɹəmɪlə. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, wʌɾ i hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə lɝn soʊ fɑɹ hæd nɑt bɪn mʌtʃ ə jus. "hi sɛz ðəɾ ɛɹəmɪlə ən ðə haɪ sits səpɔɹɾɪŋ əɹ ɪntɛn tə bi ɪn ðə fɝs pɑɹɾi tə ɹaɪɾ ɪndə keɪɛmlɪn. ʃi boʊsts ʌv ɪt kɑnstənli, ɪt simz."

"Then I have a little good news," Mistress Harfor said, shifting her folder but not opening it, "from Jon Skellit." The barber had been most assiduous about carrying his reports, approved beforehand by Reene, out to Arymilla and bringing back what he could learn in the camps outside the city. He was in the employ of Naean Arawn, but Naean, supporting Arymilla's claim, would surely share Skellit's reports with Arymilla. Unfortunately, what he had been able to learn so far had not been much of use. "He says that Arymilla and the High Seats supporting her intend to be in the first party to ride into Caemlyn. She boasts of it constantly, it seems."

ɪleɪn saɪd. ɛɹəmɪlə ən ði ʌðɝz steɪd təɡɛðɝ, muvɪŋ fɹəm kæmp tə kæmp əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə noʊ pæɾɝn ʃi kəd si, ən fəɹ səm taɪm ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝt hæd ɡɔn ɪndə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɝn wɛɹ ðeɪ wəd bi əhɛɾ ə taɪm. ə sɪmpəl mæɾɝ ðən tə sɛn soʊlʒɝz θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə siz ɔl ə ðɛm ət wʌns ən dɪkæpəteɪɾ əɹ ɑpəzɪʃən. əz sɪmpəl əz sətʃ θɪŋz kəd bi, ɛniweɪ. mɛn wəd daɪ ʌndɝ ðə bɛst ə sɝkəmstænsəz, səm ə ðə haɪ sits maɪt wɛl ɪskeɪp, jɛɾ ɪf oʊnli ɛɹəmɪlə hɝsɛlf kəd bi teɪkən, ðəɹ wəd bi ən ɛn tə ɪt. ɛləniə ən nɑiən hæd meɪd pʌblɪk ɹɪnʌnsieɪʃən ə ðɛɹ oʊn kleɪmz, wɪtʃ wɑz ɪɹɪvɝsəbəl. ðət pɛɹ maɪt ɡoʊ ɑn səpɔɹɾɪŋ ɛɹəmɪlə ɪf ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn fɹi - ðeɪ hæd taɪd ðɛmsɛlvz tə hɝ taɪtli - bʌt wɪð ɛɹəmɪlə ɪn hænd, ɔl ɪleɪn ɹɪli wəɾ əv tə kəntɛnd wɪð wɑz ɡeɪnɪŋ ðə səpɔɹɾ ʌv ət lis fɔɹ mɔɹ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt haʊsəz. əz ɪf ɪt wɝ izi. soʊ fɑɹ, ɛfɝts ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən hæd pɹuvən fjuɾəl. pɝhæps tədeɪ wəd bɹɪŋ ɡʊd nuz ɑn ðət fɹʌnt, ðoʊ. bʌt ðɪs nuz wɑz jusləs. ɪf ɛɹəmɪlə ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪndə keɪɛmlɪn ɪt wəd min ðə sɪɾi wɑz bɪɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə fɔlɪŋ. wɝs, ɪf ɛɹəmɪlə wɑz boʊstɪŋ, ʃi mʌs bɪliv ɪt wəd hæpən sun. ðə wʊmən wɑz ə ful ɪn mɛni weɪz, bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi ə mɪsteɪk tə ʌndɝɛstəmeɪɾ əɹ kəmplitli. ʃi hæd nɑt kæɹiɾ əɹ kleɪm ðɪs fɑɹ baɪ biɪŋ ən æbsəlut ful.

Elayne sighed. Arymilla and the others stayed together, moving from camp to camp according to no pattern she could see, and for some time great effort had gone into trying to learn where they would be ahead of time. A simple matter then to send soldiers through a gateway to seize all of them at once and decapitate her opposition. As simple as such things could be, anyway. Men would die under the best of circumstances, some of the High Seats might well escape, yet if only Arymilla herself could be taken, there would be an end to it. Elenia and Naean had made public renunciation of their own claims, which was irreversible. That pair might go on supporting Arymilla if they remained free - they had tied themselves to her tightly - but with Arymilla in hand, all Elayne really would have to contend with was gaining the support of at least four more of the great Houses. As if it were easy. So far, efforts in that direction had proven futile. Perhaps today would bring good news on that front, though. But this news was useless. If Arymilla and the others were riding into Caemlyn it would mean the city was beyond the brink of falling. Worse, if Arymilla was boasting, she must believe it would happen soon. The woman was a fool in many ways, but it would be a mistake to underestimate her completely. She had not carried her claim this far by being an absolute fool.

"ðɪs ɪz jəɹ ɡʊd nuz?" bɝdʒɪt sɛd. ʃi sɔ ði ɪmpləkeɪʃənz, tu. "ə hɪn ʌv wən maɪt hɛlp."

"This is your good news?" Birgitte said. She saw the implications, too. "A hint of when might help."

ɹɪn spɹɛɾ əɹ hænz. "ɛɹəmɪlə ɡeɪv skɛlɪɾ ə ɡoʊl kɹaʊn wɪð əɹ oʊn hænz wʌns, maɪ leɪɾi. hi tɝn ɪɾ oʊvɝ tə mi əz pɹuf ðət hiz ɹɪfɔɹmd." hɝ lɪps kəmpɹɛs fəɹ ə moʊmənt; skɛlɪt hæd seɪv hɪmsɛlf fɹəm hæŋɪŋ, jɛɾ i wəd nɛvɝ ɹɪɡeɪn tʃɹʌst. "ðæts ði oʊnli taɪm ðə mænz bɪn wɪðɪn tɛn peɪsɪz ə hɝ. hiz tə ɡoʊ baɪ wʌɾ i kən pɪk ʌp ɡɑsəpɪŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝ mɛn." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "hiz vɛɹi əfɹeɪd, maɪ leɪɾi. ðə mɛn ɪn ðoʊz kæmps ɑɹ sɝɾən ðəl teɪk ðə sɪɾi ɪn ə mæɾɝ ə deɪz."

Reene spread her hands. "Arymilla gave Skellit a gold crown with her own hands once, my Lady. He turned it over to me as proof that he's reformed." Her lips compressed for a moment; Skellit had saved himself from hanging, yet he would never regain trust. "That's the only time the man's been within ten paces of her. He has to go by what he can pick up gossiping with the other men." She hesitated. "He's very afraid, my Lady. The men in those camps are certain they'll take the city in a matter of days."

"əfɹeɪɾ ɪnʌf tə tɝn ɪz koʊɾ ə θɝd taɪm?" ɪleɪn æskt kwaɪətli. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə seɪ tə ði ʌðɝ mæɾɝ.

"Afraid enough to turn his coat a third time?" Elayne asked quietly. There was nothing to say to the other matter.

"noʊ, maɪ leɪɾi. ɪf nɑiən, əɹ ɛɹəmɪlə, lɝnz wʌt hiz dʌn, hiz ə dɛd mæn, ən i noʊz ɪt. bʌt hiz əfɹeɪɾ ɪf ðə sɪɾi fɔlz, ðəl lɝn. aɪ θɪŋk i meɪ boʊl sun."

"No, my Lady. If Naean, or Arymilla, learns what he's done, he's a dead man, and he knows it. But he's afraid if the city falls, they will learn. I think he may bolt soon."

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd ɡɹɪmli. mɝsənɛɹiz wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli ɹæts tə fli faɪɝ. "du juv ɛni ɡʊd nuz, mæstɝ nɔɹi?"

Elayne nodded grimly. Mercenaries were not the only rats to flee fire. "Do you have any good news, Master Norry?"

ðə fɝs klɝk hæd bɪn stændɪŋ kwaɪətli, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ɪz ɪmbɔs lɛðɝ foʊldɝ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əpɪɹ əz ɪf i wɝ nɑt lɪsnɪŋ tə ɹɪn. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən bɛɾɝ mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ, maɪ leɪɾi." ðəɹ maɪɾ əv bɪn ə tʌtʃ ə tʃɹaɪəmf ɪn ɪz smaɪl. ʌv leɪt, ɪt wɑz ɹɛɹ fəɹ ɪm tə hæv bɛɾɝ nuz ðən ʃi. "aɪ hæv ə mæn aɪ bɪliv kən fɑloʊ mɛlɝ səksɛsfəli. meɪ aɪ hæv ɪm bɹɔɾ ɪn?"

The First Clerk had been standing quietly, fingering his embossed leather folder and trying to appear as if he were not listening to Reene. "I think I can better Mistress Harfor, my Lady." There might have been a touch of triumph in his smile. Of late, it was rare for him to have better news than she. "I have a man I believe can follow Mellar successfully. May I have him brought in?"

naʊ, ðət wɑz ɛksələnt nuz. faɪv mɛn hæd daɪd tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɑloʊ dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝ wən i wɛn aʊɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi ət naɪt, ən ðə "koʊɪnsɪɾəns" sim stʃɹeɪnd. ðə fɝs taɪm, ɪt hæɾ əpɪɹd ðə fɛloʊ fɛl əfaʊl ʌv ə fʊtpæd, ən ʃi θɔt nʌθɪŋ ʌv ɪt bɪɑn sɛɾəlɪŋ ə pɛnʃən ɑn ðə mænz wɪɾoʊ. ðə ɡɑɹdz mænədʒ tə kip kɹaɪm ʌndɝ səm kəntʃɹoʊl - ɪksɛp fəɹ ɑɹsən, ət list - jɛt ɹɑbɝz juz dɑɹknəs əz ə kloʊk tə haɪɾ ɪn. ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ hæd sim ðə seɪm, kɪld wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl naɪf θɹʌst, ðɛɹ pɝsɪz ɛmptid, bʌt haʊɛvɝ deɪnʒɝəs ðə stʃɹits ət naɪt, koʊɪnsɪɾəns hɑɹdli sim kɹɛɾəbəl.

Now, that was excellent news. Five men had died trying to follow Doilin Mellar when he went out into the city at night, and the "coincidence" seemed strained. The first time, it had appeared the fellow fell afoul of a footpad, and she thought nothing of it beyond settling a pension on the man's widow. The Guards managed to keep crime under some control - except for arson, at least - yet robbers used darkness as a cloak to hide in. The other four had seemed the same, killed with a single knife thrust, their purses emptied, but however dangerous the streets at night, coincidence hardly seemed credible.

wən ʃi nɑɾəd, ðə spɪnli oʊl mæn hɝid tə ðə dɔɹz ən oʊpənd wʌn tə pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ aʊt. ʃi kəd nɑt hɪɹ wʌɾ i sɛd - ðə wɔɹd wɝk boʊθ weɪz - bʌɾ ɪn ə fju mɪnəts ə bɝli ɡɑɹdzmæn ɛntɝd pʊʃɪŋ əhɛɾ ə hɪm ə ʃʌflɪŋ mæn wɪð fɛɾɝz ɑn ɪz ɹɪsts ən æŋkəlz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə pɹɪznɝ simd . . . ævɝɪdʒ. hi wɑz niðɝ fæt nɔɹ θɪn, tɔl nɔɹ ʃɔɹt. hɪz hɛɹ wɑz bɹaʊn, ʌv noʊ pɝtɪkjəlɝ ʃeɪd ʃi kəd neɪm, ən ɪz aɪz əz wɛl. hɪz feɪs wɑz soʊ ɔɹɾənɛɹi ʃi daʊɾɪd ʃi kəd dɪskɹaɪb hɪm. noʊ fitʃɝ stʊɾ aʊɾ əɾ ɔl. hɪz kloʊðɪŋ wɑz dʒʌst əz ənɹɪmɑɹkəbəl, ə pleɪn bɹaʊn koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz ə niðɝ ðə bɛst wʊl nɔɹ ðə wɝst, sʌmwʌt ɹʌmpəld ən bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃoʊ dɝt, ə laɪtli ɪmbɔs bɛlt wɪð ə sɪmpəl mɛɾəl bʌkəl ðət maɪɾ əv tɛn θaʊzən twɪnz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ɪn ʃɔɹt, hi wɑz ɛmənənli fɔɹɡɛɾəbəl. bɝdʒɪt moʊʃən ðə ɡɑɹdzmæn tə stɑp ðə fɛloʊ wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə tʃɛɹz ən toʊld ɪm tə weɪɾ aʊtsaɪd.

When she nodded, the spindly old man hurried to the doors and opened one to put his head out. She could not hear what he said - the ward worked both ways - but in a few minutes a burly Guardsman entered pushing ahead of him a shuffling man with fetters on his wrists and ankles. Everything about the prisoner seemed . . . average. He was neither fat nor thin, tall nor short. His hair was brown, of no particular shade she could name, and his eyes as well. His face was so ordinary she doubted she could describe him. No feature stood out at all. His clothing was just as unremarkable, a plain brown coat and breeches of neither the best wool nor the worst, somewhat rumpled and beginning to show dirt, a lightly embossed belt with a simple metal buckle that might have ten thousand twins in Caemlyn. In short, he was eminently forgettable. Birgitte motioned the Guardsman to stop the fellow well short of the chairs and told him to wait outside.

"ə ɹɪlaɪəbəl mæn," nɔɹi sɛd, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə ɡɑɹdzmæn liv. "æfɹim hænsɝd. hi sɝv jəɹ mʌðɝ feɪθfəli, ən noʊz haʊ tə kip ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt."

"A reliable man," Norry said, watching the Guardsman leave. "Afrim Hansard. He served your mother faithfully, and knows how to keep his mouth shut."

"tʃeɪnz?" ɪleɪn sɛd.

"Chains?" Elayne said.

"ðɪs ɪz sæmwɪl hɑɹk, maɪ leɪɾi," nɔɹi sɛd, aɪɪŋ ðə mæn wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ə kjʊɹiɑsəɾi hi maɪɾ əv ʃoʊn təwɔɹɾ ən ʌnfəmɪljɝ ən ɑdli ʃeɪpt ænəməl, "ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbli səksɛsfəl kʌtpɝs. ðə ɡɑɹdz oʊnli kɑɾ ɪm kəz ənʌðɝ ɹʌfaɪən . . . ʌm . . . 'tɝn ðə kæɾ ɑn hɪm,' əz ðeɪ seɪ ɪn ðə stʃɹits, hoʊpɪŋ tə lɛsən ɪz oʊn sɛntəns fəɹ ə θɝɾ əfɛns ə stʃɹɔŋɡɑɹm ɹɑbɝi." ə θif wəd bi iɡɝ fəɹ ðæt. nɑɾ oʊnli wɑz ðə flɑɡɪŋ lɔŋɡɝ, ðə θif-mɑɹk bɹændɪɾ ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd wəd bi mʌtʃ hɑɹɾɝ tə dɪsɡaɪz əɹ haɪd ðən ðə mɑɹk ɑn ɪz θʌm fəɹ ɪz sɛkən əfɛns. "ɛniwʌn u hæz mænədʒ tə kip fɹəm biɪŋ kɑt fəɹ əz lɔŋ əz mæstɝ hɑɹk ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə kæɹi aʊt ðə tæsk aɪ hæv ɪn maɪn fəɹ hɪm."

"This is Samwil Hark, my Lady," Norry said, eyeing the man with the sort of curiosity he might have shown toward an unfamiliar and oddly shaped animal, "a remarkably successful cutpurse. The Guards only caught him because another ruffian . . . um . . . 'turned the cat on him,' as they say in the streets, hoping to lessen his own sentence for a third offense of strongarm robbery." A thief would be eager for that. Not only was the flogging longer, the thief-mark branded on his forehead would be much harder to disguise or hide than the mark on his thumb for his second offense. "Anyone who has managed to keep from being caught for as long as Master Hark should be able to carry out the task I have in mind for him."

"aɪm ɪnəsənt, aɪ æm, maɪ leɪɾi." hɑɹk nʌkəld ɪz fɔɹhɛd, ði aɪɝn tʃeɪnz ə hɪz fɛɾɝz klɪŋkɪŋ, ən pʊɾ ɑn ən ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪɾɪŋ smaɪl. hi tɔk vɛɹi kwɪkli. "ɪts ɔl laɪz ən hæpənstənsɪz, ɪɾ ɪz. ɪm ə ɡʊd kwinz mæn, aɪ æm. aɪ wɔɹ jəɹ mʌðɝz kʌlɝz ɪn ðə ɹaɪəts, maɪ leɪɾi. nɑt ðəɾ aɪ tʊk pɑɹɾ ɪn ðə ɹaɪəɾɪŋ, jə ʌndɝstænd. ɪm ə klɝk wən aɪ hæv wɝk, wɪtʃ aɪm aʊɾ ʌv ət ðə moʊmənt. bʌɾ aɪ wɔɹ əɹ kʌlɝz ɑn maɪ kæp fəɹ ɔl tə si, aɪ dɪd." ðə bɑnd wɑz fʊl ə bɝdʒɪts skɛptɪsɪzəm.

"I'm innocent, I am, my Lady." Hark knuckled his forehead, the iron chains of his fetters clinking, and put on an ingratiating smile. He talked very quickly. "It's all lies and happenstances, it is. I'm a good Queen's man, I am. I wore your mother's colors in the riots, my Lady. Not that I took part in the rioting, you understand. I'm a clerk when I have work, which I'm out of at the moment. But I wore her colors on my cap for all to see, I did." The bond was full of Birgitte's skepticism.

"mæstɝ hɑɹks ɹumz kənteɪn tʃɛsts fʊl ə nitli kʌt pɝsɪz," ðə fɝs klɝk wɛn ɑn. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ θaʊzənz ə ðɛm, maɪ leɪɾi. kwaɪt lɪɾɝəli θaʊzənz. aɪ səpoʊz i meɪ ɹəɡɹɛt kipɪŋ . . . ʌm . . . tʃɹoʊfiz. moʊs kʌtpɝsɪz əv sɛns ɪnʌf tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðə pɝs əz sun əz pɑsəbəl."

"Master Hark's rooms contained chests full of neatly cut purses," the First Clerk went on. "There are thousands of them, my Lady. Quite literally thousands. I suppose he may regret keeping . . . um . . . trophies. Most cutpurses have sense enough to get rid of the purse as soon as possible."

"aɪ pɪks əm ʌp wən aɪ siz wʌn, aɪ dʌz, maɪ leɪɾi." hɑɹk spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz əz fɑɹ əz ɪz tʃeɪnz əlaʊɾ ən ʃɹʌɡd, ðə vɛɹi ɪmədʒ ʌv ɪnʒɝd ɪnəsəns. "meɪbi ɪt wɝ fulɪʃ, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ sɔ noʊ hɑɹm. dʒʌst ə hɑɹmləs sɔɹɾ ʌv əmjuzmənt, maɪ leɪɾi."

"I picks them up when I sees one, I does, my Lady." Hark spread his hands as far as his chains allowed and shrugged, the very image of injured innocence. "Maybe it were foolish, but I never saw no harm. Just a harmless sort of amusement, my Lady."

mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ snɪf laʊdli, dɪsəpɹuvəl klɪɹ ɑn əɹ feɪs. hɑɹk mænədʒ tə lʊk ivən mɔɹ hɝt.

Mistress Harfor sniffed loudly, disapproval clear on her face. Hark managed to look even more hurt.

"hɪz ɹumz ɔlsoʊ kənteɪn kɔɪnz tə ðə vælju ʌv oʊvɝ wʌn hʌnʒɹəd twɛnti ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz, səkɹiɾəd ʌndɝ ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz, ɪn kʌbihoʊlz ɪn ðə wɔlz, ɪn ðə ɹæftɝz, ɛvɹiwɛɹ. hɪz ɪkskjus fəɹ ðæt," nɔɹi ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs əz hɑɹk oʊpən ɪz maʊθ əɡɛn, "ɪz ðəɾ i dɪstʃɹʌsts bæŋkɝz. hi kleɪmz ðə mʌni ɪz ən ɪnhɛɹəɾəns fɹəm ən eɪdʒɪɾ æn ɪn fɔɹ kɪŋz. aɪ maɪsɛlf vɛɹi mʌtʃ daʊt ðə mædʒɪstʃɹeɪts ɪn fɔɹ kɪŋz wɪl əv ɹɛdʒəstɝd sətʃ ən ɪnhɛɹəɾəns, ðoʊ. ðə mædʒəstʃɹeɪt dʒʌdʒɪŋ ɪz keɪs sɛz i sim sɝpɹaɪz tə lɝn ðəɾ ɪnhɛɹɪɾənsɪz ɑɹ ɹɛdʒəstɝd." ɪndid, hɑɹks smaɪl feɪɾəd sʌmwʌɾ ət biɪŋ ɹimaɪndəd. "hi sɛz ðəɾ i wɝk fəɹ wɪlbɪn seɪɛmz, ə mɝtʃənt, əntɪl seɪɛmz' dɛθ fɔɹ mʌnθs əɡoʊ, bʌt mæstɝ seɪɛmz' dɔɾɝ meɪnteɪnz ðə bɪznəs, ən niðɝ ʃi nɔɹ ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝ klɝks ɹikɔl ɛni sæmwɪl hɑɹk."

"His rooms also contained coins to the value of over one hundred twenty gold crowns, secreted under the floorboards, in cubbyholes in the walls, in the rafters, everywhere. His excuse for that," Norry raised his voice as Hark opened his mouth again, "is that he distrusts bankers. He claims the money is an inheritance from an aged aunt in Four Kings. I myself very much doubt the magistrates in Four Kings will have registered such an inheritance, though. The magistrate judging his case says he seemed surprised to learn that inheritances are registered." Indeed, Hark's smile faded somewhat at being reminded. "He says that he worked for Wilbin Saems, a merchant, until Saems' death four months ago, but Master Saems' daughter maintains the business, and neither she nor any of the other clerks recall any Samwil Hark."

"ðeɪ heɪts mi, ðeɪ dʌz, maɪ leɪɾi," hɑɹk sɛɾ ɪn ə sʌlən vɔɪs. hɪz hænz ɡɹɪp ðə tʃeɪn bɪtwin əm ɪn fɪsts. "aɪ wɑz ɡæðɝɪŋ ɛvəɾəns ə haʊ ðeɪ wɑz stilɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɡʊd mæstɝ - hɪz oʊn dɔɾɝ, maɪnd! - oʊnli hi daɪɾ əfɔɹ aɪ kəd ɡɪv ɪt tə hɪm, ən aɪ wɑz tɝn aʊɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹits wɪθaʊɾ ə ɹɛfɝəns əɹ ə pɛni, aɪ wɑz. ðeɪ bɝnd wʌɾ aɪd ɡæðɝd, ɡeɪv mi ə dʒɹʌbɪŋ ən θɹu mi aʊt."

"They hates me, they does, my Lady," Hark said in a sullen voice. His hands gripped the chain between them in fists. "I was gathering evidence of how they was stealing from the good master - his own daughter, mind! - only he died afore I could give it to him, and I was turned out in the streets without a reference or a penny, I was. They burned what I'd gathered, gave me a drubbing and threw me out."

ɪleɪn tæpt əɹ tʃɪn θɔtfəli. "ə klɝk, jə seɪ. moʊs klɝks ɑɹ bɛɾɝ spoʊkən ðən ju, mæstɝ hɑɹk, bʌɾ əl ɔfɝ jə ə tʃæns tə ɡɪv ɛvəɾəns fəɹ jəɹ kleɪm. wəd jə sɛn fəɹ ə læpdɛsk, mæstɝ nɔɹi?"

Elayne tapped her chin thoughtfully. "A clerk, you say. Most clerks are better spoken than you, Master Hark, but I'll offer you a chance to give evidence for your claim. Would you send for a lapdesk, Master Norry?"

nɔɹi ɡeɪv ə θɪn smaɪl. haʊ kəd ðə mæn meɪk ə smaɪl sim dʒɹaɪ? "noʊ nid, maɪ leɪɾi. ðə mædʒəstʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ðə keɪs hæd ðə seɪm aɪdiə." fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, hi tʊk ə ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ fɹəm ðə foʊldɝ klʌtʃt tə hɪz tʃɛst. ʃi θɔt tʃɹʌmpəts ʃəd saʊnd! hɑɹks smaɪl feɪɾəd əweɪ kəmplitli əz ɪz aɪz fɑloʊd ðət peɪdʒ fɹəm nɔɹiz hæn tə hɝz.

Norry gave a thin smile. How could the man make a smile seem dry? "No need, my Lady. The magistrate in the case had the same idea." For the first time that she had ever seen, he took a sheet of paper from the folder clutched to his chest. She thought trumpets should sound! Hark's smile faded away completely as his eyes followed that page from Norry's hand to hers.

wʌn ɡlæns wɑz ɔl ðət wɑz niɾəd. ə fju ənivən laɪnz kʌvɝd lɛs ðən hæf ðə ʃit, ðə lɛɾɝz kɹæmpt ən ɑkwɝd. noʊ mɔɹ ðən hæf ə dʌzən wɝdz wɝ æktʃəli  lɛɡəbəl, ən ðoʊz bɛɹli.

One glance was all that was needed. A few uneven lines covered less than half the sheet, the letters cramped and awkward. No more than half a dozen words were actually legible, and those barely.

"hɑɹdli ðə hæn ʌv ə klɝk," ʃi mɝmɝd. ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ðə peɪdʒ tə nɔɹi, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk əɹ feɪs stɝn. ʃi hæd sin əɹ mʌðɝ pæsɪŋ dʒʌdʒmənt. mɔɹɡeɪs hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk hɝsɛlf əpɪɹ ɪmplækəbəl. "aɪ fɪɹ, mæstɝ hɑɹk, ðət jəl sɪɾ ɪn ə sɛl əntɪl ðə mædʒɪstʃɹeɪts ɪn fɔɹ kɪŋz kən bi kwɪɹid, ən sun æftɝ ðət jəl hæŋ." hɑɹks lɪps ɹɪθd, ən i pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɪz θɹoʊɾ əz ɪf i kəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi fil ðə nus. "ənlɛs, ʌv kɔɹs, jə əɡɹi tə fɑloʊ ə mæn fəɹ mi. ə deɪnʒɝəs mæn u dʌzn laɪk tə bi fɑloʊd. ɪf jə kən tɛl mi wɛɹ i ɡoʊz ət naɪt, ɪnstɛɾ ə hæŋɪŋ, jəl bi ɛɡzaɪl tə bɛɹlən. wɛɹ jə wəd bi wɛl ædvaɪz tə faɪn ə nu laɪn ʌv wɝk. ðə ɡʌvɝnɝ wɪl bi ɪnfɔɹmd ə ju."

"Hardly the hand of a clerk," she murmured. Returning the page to Norry, she tried to make her face stern. She had seen her mother passing judgment. Morgase had been able to make herself appear implacable. "I fear, Master Hark, that you will sit in a cell until the magistrates in Four Kings can be queried, and soon after that you will hang." Hark's lips writhed, and he put a hand to his throat as if he could already feel the noose. "Unless, of course, you agree to follow a man for me. A dangerous man who doesn't like to be followed. If you can tell me where he goes at night, instead of hanging, you will be exiled to Baerlon. Where you would be well advised to find a new line of work. The governor will be informed of you."

sʌɾənli hɑɹks smaɪl wɑz bæk. "ʌv kɔɹs, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪm ɪnəsənt, bʌɾ aɪ kən si haʊ θɪŋz lʊk dɑɹk əɡɛns mi, aɪ kæn. əl fɑloʊ ɛni mæn jə wɑn mi tə. aɪ wɑz jəɹ mʌðɝz mæn, aɪ wɑz, ən aɪm jəɹ mæn, tu. lɔɪəl ɪz wʌɾ aɪ æm, maɪ leɪɾi, lɔɪəl ɪf aɪ sʌfɝz fəɹ ɪt."

Suddenly Hark's smile was back. "Of course, my Lady. I'm innocent, but I can see how things look dark against me, I can. I'll follow any man you want me to. I was your mother's man, I was, and I'm your man, too. Loyal is what I am, my Lady, loyal if I suffers for it."

bɝdʒɪt snɔɹɾɪd dɝɪsɪvli.

Birgitte snorted derisively.

"ɝeɪnʒ fəɹ mæstɝ hɑɹk tə si mɛlɝz feɪs wɪθaʊt biɪŋ sin, bɝdʒɪt." ðə mæn wɑz ənmɪmɝəbəl, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn teɪkɪŋ tʃænsəz. "ðɛn tɝn ɪm lus." hɑɹk lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə dæns, aɪɝn tʃeɪnz əɹ noʊ aɪɝn tʃeɪnz. "bʌt fɝst. . . . jə si ðɪs, mæstɝ hɑɹk?" ʃi hɛld ʌp əɹ ɹaɪt hæn soʊ hi kəd nɑt mɪs ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ. "ju meɪ hæv hɝd ðəɾ aɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ." wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn hɝ, ɪt wɑz ə sɪmpəl mæɾɝ tə wiv spɪɹət. "ɪɾ ɪz tʃɹu." ðə wiv ʃi leɪɾ ɑn hɑɹks bɛl bʌkəl, hɪz buts, hɪz koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz, wɑz sʌmwʌɾ əkɪn tə ðət fəɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑnd, ðoʊ mʌtʃ lɛs kɑmplɛks. ɪt wəd feɪd fɹəm ðə kloʊðɪŋ ən buts ɪn ə fju wiks, əɹ mʌnθs ət bɛst, bʌt mɛɾəl wəd hoʊld ə faɪndɝ fɝɛvɝ. "aɪv leɪɾ ə wiv ɑn ju, mæstɝ hɑɹk. naʊ jə kən bi faʊnd wɛɹɛvɝ jə ɑɹ." ɪn tʃɹuθ, oʊnli ʃi wəd bi eɪbəl tə faɪn ɪm - ə faɪndɝ wɑz ətun tə ðə wʌn u woʊv ɪt - bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə tɛl ɪm ðæt. "dʒʌs tə bi ʃʊɹ ðət jə ɑɹ ɪndid lɔɪəl."

"Arrange for Master Hark to see Mellar's face without being seen, Birgitte." The man was unmemorable, but there was no point in taking chances. "Then turn him loose." Hark looked ready to dance, iron chains or no iron chains. "But first. . . . You see this, Master Hark?" She held up her right hand so he could not miss the Great Serpent ring. "You may have heard that I am Aes Sedai." With the Power already in her, it was a simple matter to weave Spirit. "It is true." The weave she laid on Hark's belt buckle, his boots, his coat and breeches, was somewhat akin to that for the Warder bond, though much less complex. It would fade from the clothing and boots in a few weeks, or months at best, but metal would hold a Finder forever. "I've laid a weave on you, Master Hark. Now you can be found wherever you are." In truth, only she would be able to find him - a Finder was attuned to the one who wove it - but there was no reason to tell him that. "Just to be sure that you are indeed loyal."

hɑɹks smaɪl sim fɹoʊzən ɪn pleɪs. swɛt biɾɪd ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd. wən bɝdʒɪt wɛn tə ðə dɔɹ ən kɔld ɪn hænsɝd, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz tə teɪk hɑɹk əweɪ ən kip ɪm seɪf fɹəm pɹaɪɪŋ aɪz, hɑɹk stæɡɝɾ ən wʊɾə fɔlən ɪf ðə hʌski ɡɑɹdzmæn hæd nɑt hɛld ɪm ʌp ɑn ðə weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum.

Hark's smile seemed frozen in place. Sweat beaded on his forehead. When Birgitte went to the door and called in Hansard, giving him instructions to take Hark away and keep him safe from prying eyes, Hark staggered and would have fallen if the husky Guardsman had not held him up on the way out of the room.

"aɪ fɪɹ aɪ meɪ dʒʌst əv ɡɪvən mɛlɝ ə sɪksθ vɪktəm," ɪleɪn mʌɾɝd. "hi hɑɹdli simz keɪpəbəl ə fɑloʊɪŋ ɪz oʊn ʃædoʊ wɪθaʊt tʃɹɪpɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz buts." ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ hɑɹks dɛθ ʃi ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd. ðə mæn wʊɾə hæŋ fəɹ ʃʊɹ. "aɪ wɑn huɛvɝ pʊt ðət blʌɾi mæn ɪn maɪ pæləs. aɪ wɑn əm soʊ bædli maɪ tiθ eɪk!" ðə pæləs wɑz ɹɪɾəld wɪð spaɪz - ɹɪn hæɾ ənkʌvɝɾ əbʌv ə dʌzən bɪɑn skɛlɪt, ðoʊ ʃi bɪliv ðət wɑz ɔl ə ðɛm - bʌt wɛðɝ mɛlɝ hæd bɪn sɛt tə spaɪ əɹ tə fəsɪləteɪt kɪdnæpɪŋ hɝ, hi wɑz wɝs ðən ði ʌðɝz. hi hæɾ ɝeɪnʒd fəɹ mɛn tə daɪ, əɹ i hæd kɪl ðɛm, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɡeɪn ɪz pleɪs. ðət ðoʊz mɛn hæd θɔt ðeɪ wɝ tə kɪl əɹ meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns. mɝɾɝ wɑz mɝɾɝ.

"I fear I may just have given Mellar a sixth victim," Elayne muttered. "He hardly seems capable of following his own shadow without tripping over his boots." It was not so much Hark's death she regretted. The man would have hanged for sure. "I want whoever put that bloody man in my palace. I want them so badly my teeth ache!" The palace was riddled with spies - Reene had uncovered above a dozen beyond Skellit, though she believed that was all of them - but whether Mellar had been set to spy or to facilitate kidnapping her, he was worse than the others. He had arranged for men to die, or he had killed them, in order to gain his place. That those men had thought they were to kill her made no difference. Murder was murder.

"tʃɹʌs mi, maɪ leɪɾi," nɔɹi sɛd, leɪɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪz lɔŋ noʊz. "kʌtpɝsɪz ɑɹ . . . ʌm . . . stɛlθi baɪ neɪtʃɝ, jɛt ðeɪ sɛldəm læs lɔŋ. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðeɪ kʌt ðə pɝs ə sʌmwʌn fæstɝ əfʊt ðən ðeɪ, sʌmwʌn u dʌznt weɪt fəɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz." hi meɪɾ ə kwɪk dʒɛstʃɝ əz ɪf stæbɪŋ sʌmwʌn. "hɑɹk əz læstəɾ ət lis twɛnti jɪɹz. ə nʌmbɝ ə ðə pɝsɪz ɪn ɪz . . . ʌm . . . kəlɛkʃən wɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð pɹɛɹz ə θæŋks fəɹ ði ɛn ə ði il wɔɹ. ðoʊz wɛn aʊɾ ə fæʃən vɛɹi kwɪkli, əz aɪ ɹikɔl."

"Trust me, my Lady," Norry said, laying a finger alongside his long nose. "Cutpurses are . . . um . . . stealthy by nature, yet they seldom last long. Sooner or later they cut the purse of someone faster afoot than they, someone who doesn't wait for the Guards." He made a quick gesture as if stabbing someone. "Hark has lasted at least twenty years. A number of the purses in his . . . um . . . collection were embroidered with prayers of thanks for the end of the Aiel War. Those went out of fashion very quickly, as I recall."

bɝdʒɪt sæt daʊn ɑn ði ɑɹm ə ðə nɛks tʃɛɹ ən foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts. "aɪ kəɾ ɝɛs mɛlɝ," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli, "æn əv ɪm pʊt tə ðə kwɛstʃən. juɾ əv noʊ niɾ ə hɑɹk ðɛn."

Birgitte sat down on the arm of the next chair and folded her arms beneath her breasts. "I could arrest Mellar," she said quietly, "and have him put to the question. You'd have no need of Hark then."

"ə pʊɹ dʒoʊk, maɪ leɪɾi, ɪf aɪ meɪ seɪ soʊ," mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ sɛd stɪfli, ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðət mæstɝ nɔɹi sɛd, "ðæt wəd bi . . . ʌm . . . əɡɛns ðə lɔ, maɪ leɪɾi."

"A poor joke, my Lady, if I may say so," Mistress Harfor said stiffly, at the same time that Master Norry said, "That would be . . . um . . . against the law, my Lady."

bɝdʒɪt baʊndəd tə hɝ fit, aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ flʌɾɪŋ ðə bɑnd. "blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz! wi noʊ ðə mænz əz ɹɑɾən əz læs mʌnθs fɪʃ."

Birgitte bounded to her feet, outrage flooding the bond. "Blood and bloody ashes! We know the man's as rotten as last month's fish."

"noʊ." ɪleɪn saɪd, faɪɾɪŋ nɑt tə fil aʊtʃɹeɪdʒd əz wɛl. "wi hæv səspɪʃənz, nɑt pɹuf. ðoʊz faɪv mɛn maɪɾ əv fɔlən əfaʊl ə fʊtpædz. ðə lɔ ɪz kwaɪt klɪɹ ɑn wən sʌmwʌn meɪ bi pʊt tə ðə kwɛstʃən, ən səspɪʃənz ɑɹ nɑt ɹizən ɪnʌf. sɑləɾ ɛvəɾəns ɪz niɾəd. maɪ mʌðɝ ɔfən sɛd, 'ðə kwin mʌst oʊbeɪ ðə lɔ ʃi meɪks, əɹ ðəɹ ɪz noʊ lɔ.' əl nɑt bɪɡɪn baɪ bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə lɔ." ðə bɑn kæɹid sʌmθɪŋ . . . stʌbɝn. ʃi fɪks bɝdʒɪt wɪð ə stɛɾi lʊk. "niðɝ wɪl ju. dʒju ʌndɝstæn mi, bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑilaɪən? niðɝ wɪl ju."

"No." Elayne sighed, fighting not to feel outraged as well. "We have suspicions, not proof. Those five men might have fallen afoul of footpads. The law is quite clear on when someone may be put to the question, and suspicions are not reason enough. Solid evidence is needed. My mother often said, 'The Queen must obey the law she makes, or there is no law.' I will not begin by breaking the law." The bond carried something . . . stubborn. She fixed Birgitte with a steady look. "Neither will you. Do you understand me, Birgitte Trahelion? Neither will you."

tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, ðə stʌbɝnnəs læstəɾ oʊnli moʊməns lɔŋɡɝ bɪfɔɹ dwɪndəlɪŋ əweɪ tə bi ɹipleɪs baɪ ʃəɡɹɪn. "ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə sədʒɛstʃən," bɝdʒɪt mʌɾɝd wikli.

To her surprise, the stubbornness lasted only moments longer before dwindling away to be replaced by chagrin. "It was only a suggestion," Birgitte muttered weakly.

ɪleɪn wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ haʊ ʃi hæd dʌn ðəɾ ən haʊ tə də ɪɾ əɡɛn - səmtaɪmz ðəɹ sim daʊɾ ɪn bɝdʒɪts maɪn oʊvɝ wɪtʃ ə ðɛm wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ - wən dɪni koʊlfɝd slɪpt ɪndə ðə ɹum ən klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt tə dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən tə hɝsɛlf. ə lɔŋ, bɹæs-stʌɾɪd kʌdʒəl bæləns ðə sɔɹd hæŋɪŋ ət ðə hɛvisɛt wʊmənz weɪst, lʊkɪŋ aʊɾ ə pleɪs. dɪni wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ bɛɾɝ wɪð ðə sɔɹd bʌt stɪl pɹəfɝd ðə kʌdʒəl ʃi hæd juz kipɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ ɪn ə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz' tævɝn. "ə sɝvən keɪm tə seɪ ðət ðə leɪɾi daɪɛlɪn əz ɝaɪvd, maɪ leɪɾi, ən wɪl bi ət jəɹ sɝvəs əz sun əz ʃiz fɹɛʃən hɝsɛlf."

Elayne was wondering how she had done that and how to do it again - sometimes there seemed doubt in Birgitte's mind over which of them was in charge - when Deni Colford slipped into the room and cleared her throat to draw attention to herself. A long, brass-studded cudgel balanced the sword hanging at the heavyset woman's waist, looking out of place. Deni was getting better with the sword but still preferred the cudgel she had used keeping order in a wagon drivers' tavern. "A servant came to say that the Lady Dyelin has arrived, my Lady, and will be at your service as soon as she's freshened herself."

"sɛn ðə leɪɾi daɪɛlɪn wɝd ðət ʃiz tə mit mi ɪn ðə mæp ɹum." ɪleɪn fɛlt ə sɝdʒ ə hoʊp. ət læst, pɝhæps, ʃi maɪt hɪɹ səm ɡʊd nuz.

"Send the Lady Dyelin word that she's to meet me in the Map Room." Elayne felt a surge of hope. At last, perhaps, she might hear some good news.

tʃæptɝ sɛvəntin

CHAPTER 17

eɪ bɹɑnz bɛɹ livɪŋ mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ ən mæstɝ nɔɹi, ɪleɪn stɑɹɾəd iɡɝli təwɔɹd ðə mæp ɹum stɪl hoʊldɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ. iɡɝli, bʌt nɑt hɝidli. dɪni ən θɹi ɡɑɹdzwɪmən stʃɹoʊɾ əhɛɾ ə hɝ, hɛdz swɪvəlɪŋ ɪn kɑnstən sɝtʃ ə θɹɛts, ən ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ stæmpt əlɔŋ bɪhaɪnd. ʃi daʊɾɪd ðət daɪɛlɪn wəd teɪk lɔŋ oʊvɝ əɹ æbluʃənz, ɡʊd nuz əɹ bæd. ðə laɪt sɛn ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɡʊd. bɝdʒɪt, hænz klæsp bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk ən wɛɹɪŋ ə fɹaʊn, sim sʌŋk ɪn saɪləns əz ðeɪ wɔkt, ðoʊ ʃi stʌɾid ɛvɹi kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ən ətæk fɹəm ɪt. ðə bɑn stɪl kæɹid wɝi. ən taɪɹədnəs. ə jɔn kɹækt ɪleɪnz dʒɔz bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd stɑp hɝsɛlf.

A Bronze Bear Leaving Mistress Harfor and Master Norry, Elayne started eagerly toward the Map Room still holding saidar. Eagerly, but not hurriedly. Deni and three Guardswomen strode ahead of her, heads swiveling in constant search of threats, and the other four stamped along behind. She doubted that Dyelin would take long over her ablutions, good news or bad. The Light send that it was good. Birgitte, hands clasped behind her back and wearing a frown, seemed sunk in silence as they walked, though she studied every crossing corridor as if expecting an attack from it. The bond still carried worry. And tiredness. A yawn cracked Elayne's jaws before she could stop herself.

ən ənwɪlɪŋnɪs tə stɑɹt ɹumɝz wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli ɹizən ʃi meɪnteɪn ə steɪtli peɪs. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ðən sɝvəns ɪn ðə hɔlweɪz, naʊ. kɝɾəsi hæd ɹikwaɪɝɾ əɹ tə ɔfɝ ɹumz ɪn ðə pæləs tə ðə noʊbəlz u mænədʒ tə ɹitʃ ðə sɪɾi wɪð ɑɹmmɪn - kaʊntɪŋ ɑɹmmɪn lusli; səm wɝ wɛl-tʃɹeɪn ən kæɹiɾ ə sɔɹɾ ɛvɹi deɪ, ʌðɝz hæd bɪn ɡaɪɾɪŋ ə plaʊ bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ kɔl tə fɑloʊ ðɛɹ lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi - ən ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ hæɾ æksɛptɪd. meɪnli ðoʊz u hæd noʊ dwɛlɪŋ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ɔɹ, ʃi səspɛktəd, fɛl pɪntʃt fəɹ kɔɪn. fɑɹmɝz əɹ leɪbɝɝz maɪt θɪŋk ɔl noʊbəlz wɛlθi, ən sɝɾənli moʊst wɝ, ɪf oʊnli ɪn kəmpɛɹəsən, bʌt ði ɪkspɛnsəz ɹikwaɪɝd baɪ ðɛɹ pəzɪʃənz ən duɾiz lɛf mɛni kaʊntɪŋ kɔɪnz əz kɛɹfəli əz ɛni fɑɹmwaɪf. wʌt ʃi wɑz tə də fəɹ ðə nuəst ɝaɪvəlz ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ. noʊbəlz ɔlɹɛɾi wɝ slipɪŋ θɹi ən fɔɹ tə ə bɛd wɛɹɛvɝ ðə bɛdz wɝ lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf; ɔl bʌt ðə nɛɹoʊəs kəd teɪk ət lis tu, ən dɪd. mɛni kɪnswɪmən hæd bɪn ɹədus tə pæləts ɑn ðə flɔɹ ɪn ðə sɝvəns' kɔɹɾɝz, ən θæŋk ðə laɪt spɹɪŋ hæd meɪd ðət pɑsəbəl.

An unwillingness to start rumors was not the only reason she maintained a stately pace. There were more than servants in the hallways, now. Courtesy had required her to offer rooms in the palace to the nobles who managed to reach the city with armsmen - counting armsmen loosely; some were well-trained and carried a sword every day, others had been guiding a plow before being called to follow their lord or lady - and a fair number had accepted. Mainly those who had no dwelling in Caemlyn or, she suspected, felt pinched for coin. Farmers or laborers might think all nobles wealthy, and certainly most were, if only in comparison, but the expenses required by their positions and duties left many counting coins as carefully as any farmwife. What she was to do for the newest arrivals she did not know. Nobles already were sleeping three and four to a bed wherever the beds were large enough; all but the narrowest could take at least two, and did. Many Kinswomen had been reduced to pallets on the floor in the servants' quarters, and thank the Light spring had made that possible.

ɪt sim ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə hɝ noʊbəl ɡɛsts wɝ aʊt stʃɹoʊlɪŋ, ən wən ðeɪ ɔfɝɾ əɹ kɝɾəsiz, ʃi hæd tə stɑp ən pæs ət list ə fju wɝdz. sɝɡeɪs ɡɪlbɛɝn, smɔl ən slɪm ɪn ə ɡɹin ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs, hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ laɪtli tʌtʃt wɪð waɪt, hu hæd bɹɔɾ ɔl twɛnti ʌv ði ɑɹmmɪn ɪn əɹ sɝvəs, ən vɪnɪɡɛɹi oʊl kɛlwɪn dʒænəvɝ, wɪɹi ɪn ɪz dɪskɹitli dɑɹn blu wʊl koʊt, hu hæd bɹɔt tɛn, ɹəsivd əz ɡɹeɪʃəs ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒ əz dɪd læŋki bɑɹəl leɪɾən ən staʊɾ ænθɛl ʃɑɹplɪn, ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ haɪ sits, ɪf ə maɪnɝ haʊzɪz. ɔl hæd ɹɪɾən tə hɝ səpɔɹt wɪð wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ kəd ɡæðɝ, ən nʌn hæd tɝn bæk ɑn lɝnɪŋ ði ɑdz. mɛni lʊkt ənizi tədeɪ, ðoʊ. noʊ wʌn sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ ʌv ɪt - ðeɪ wɝ ɔl fʊl ʌv ɡʊd wɪʃɪz ən hoʊps fəɹ ə spiɾi kɔɹəneɪʃən ən haʊ ɑnɝd ðeɪ wɝ tə fɑloʊ hɝ - bʌt wɝi wɑz ɹɪɾən ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ɑɹəlɪn bɹænstʃɹəm, nɔɹməli soʊ ɪbʌljən jə maɪt θɪŋk ʃi bɪlivd əɹ fɪfti ɑɹmmɪn kəd tɝn ðə taɪd fəɹ ɪleɪn baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz, wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʊmən tʃuɪŋ əɹ lɪp, ən lɝəd tʃɹæhænd, stɑki ən tæsɪtɝn ən juʒəwəli əz stɑləɾ əz stoʊn, wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli mæn wɪð ə fɝoʊd bɹaʊ. ivən nuz ʌv ɡaɪbɑn ən ði eɪɾ i hæd bɹɔt kɑzd oʊnli bɹif smaɪlz, kwɪkli swɑloʊɾ ɪn ɪl iz.

It seemed the whole lot of her noble guests were out strolling, and when they offered her courtesies, she had to stop and pass at least a few words. Sergase Gilbearn, small and slim in a green riding dress, her dark hair lightly touched with white, who had brought all twenty of the armsmen in her service, and vinegary old Kelwin Janevor, wiry in his discreetly darned blue wool coat, who had brought ten, received as gracious an exchange as did lanky Barel Layden and stout Anthelle Sharplyn, though they were High Seats, if of minor Houses. All had ridden to her support with whatever they could gather, and none had turned back on learning the odds. Many looked uneasy today, though. No one said anything of it - they were all full of good wishes and hopes for a speedy coronation and how honored they were to follow her - but worry was written on their faces. Arilinde Branstrom, normally so ebullient you might think she believed her fifty armsmen could turn the tide for Elayne by themselves, was not the only woman chewing her lip, and Laerid Traehand, stocky and taciturn and usually as stolid as stone, was not the only man with a furrowed brow. Even news of Guybon and the aid he had brought caused only brief smiles, quickly swallowed in ill ease.

"du jə θɪŋk ðeɪv hɝɾ ʌv ɛɹəmɪləz kɑnfəɾəns?" ʃi æskt ɪn wʌn ə ðə bɹif ɪntɝvəlz wən ʃi wɑz nɑt ɹɪspɑndɪŋ tə baʊz ən kɝtsiz. "noʊ, ðət wʊdn bi ɪnʌf tə əpsɛɾ ɑɹəlɪn əɹ lɝəd." ɛɹəmɪlə ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz wɪð θɝɾi θaʊzən mɛn laɪkli wəd feɪl tə əpsɛt ðət pɛɹ.

"Do you think they've heard of Arymilla's confidence?" she asked in one of the brief intervals when she was not responding to bows and curtsies. "No, that wouldn't be enough to upset Arilinde or Laerid." Arymilla inside the walls with thirty thousand men likely would fail to upset that pair.

"ɪt wʊdnt," bɝdʒɪɾ əɡɹid. ʃi ɡlænst ɝaʊn əz ɪf tə si hu bɪsaɪdz ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən maɪt hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "meɪbi ðəɹ wɝiɾ oʊvɝ wʌts bɪn wɝiɪŋ mi. jə dɪdnt ɡɛt lɔst wən wi ɡɑt bæk. əɹ ɹæðɝ, jə hæd hɛlp."

"It wouldn't," Birgitte agreed. She glanced around as if to see who besides the Guardswomen might hear before going on. "Maybe they're worried over what's been worrying me. You didn't get lost when we got back. Or rather, you had help."

ɪleɪn pɔz tə ɔfɝ ə fju hɝid wɝdz tə ə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd kʌpəl ɪn wʊlənz ðət wʊɾə suɾəd pɹɑspɝəs fɑɹmɝz. bɹænɪn ən ɛlveɪn mɑɹɾənz mænɝ haʊs wɑz mʌtʃ laɪk ə lɑɹdʒ fɑɹmhaʊs, spɹɔlɪŋ ən haʊzɪŋ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz. ə θɝɾ ə ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn wɝ ðɛɹ sʌnz ən ɡɹændsʌnz, nɛfjuz ən ɡɹeɪt-nɛfjuz. oʊnli ðoʊz tu jʌŋ əɹ tu oʊl tə ɹaɪd hæd bɪn lɛf bɪhaɪn tə si tə plæntɪŋ. ʃi hoʊp ðə smaɪlɪŋ pɛɹ dɪd nɑt fil ðeɪ wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ ʃɔɹt ʃɹɪft, bʌt ʃi wɑz wɔkɪŋ ɑn ɔlmoʊst əz sun əz ʃi stɑpt. "wʌt dʒju min, aɪ hæd hɛlp?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

Elayne paused to offer a few hurried words to a gray-haired couple in woolens that would have suited prosperous farmers. Brannin and Elvaine Martan's manor house was much like a large farmhouse, sprawling and housing generations. A third of their armsmen were their sons and grandsons, nephews and great-nephews. Only those too young or too old to ride had been left behind to see to planting. She hoped the smiling pair did not feel they were getting short shrift, but she was walking on almost as soon as she stopped. "What do you mean, I had help?" she demanded.

"ðə pæləs ɪz . . . tʃeɪnʒd." fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðəɹ wɑz kənfjuʒən ɪn ðə bɑnd. bɝdʒɪt ɡɹɪməst. "ɪt saʊnz mæd, aɪ noʊ, bʌɾ ɪts əz ɪf ðə hoʊl θɪŋ hæd bɪn bɪl tə ə slaɪtli dɪfɹən plæn." wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən əhɛd mɪst ə stɛp, kɑt hɝsɛlf. "aɪ hæv ə ɡʊd mɛmɹi. . . ." bɝdʒɪt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðə bɑn fɪld wɪð ə dʒʌmbəl ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz heɪstəli pʊʃt daʊn. moʊst ə hɝ mɛmɹiz ə pæs laɪvz hæd vænɪʃt əz ʃʊɹli əz ðə wɪntɝz snoʊ. nʌθɪŋ ɹɪmeɪn bɪfɔɹ ðə faʊndɪŋ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ðə fɔɹ laɪvz ʃi hæd lɪv bɪtwin ðən ən ði ɛn ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fɹæɡmɛnt. lɪɾəl sim tə fɹaɪɾən hɝ, jɛt ʃi fɪɹd luzɪŋ ðə ɹɛst, ɪspɛʃli hɝ mɛmɹiz ʌv ɡeɪɾəl keɪn. "aɪ doʊn fɝɡɛɾ ə pæθ wʌns aɪv fɑloʊɾ ɪt," ʃi wɛn ɑn, "æn səm ə ðiz hɔlweɪz ɑɹən ðə seɪm əz ðeɪ wɝ. səm ə ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz əv bɪn . . . ʃɪftəd. ʌðɝz ɑɹən ðəɹ ɛnimɔɹ, ən ðəɹ ɑɹ səm nu. noʊbɑdi ɪz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt ðəɾ aɪ kəd faɪn aʊt, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ði oʊl pipəl ɑɹ kipɪŋ kwaɪət kəz ðəɹ əfɹeɪd ðɛɹ wɪts ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ, ən ðə jʌŋɡɝ ɑɹ əfɹeɪd ðəl luz ðɛɹ pəzɪʃənz."

"The palace is . . . changed." For a moment, there was confusion in the bond. Birgitte grimaced. "It sounds mad, I know, but it's as if the whole thing had been built to a slightly different plan." One of the Guardswomen ahead missed a step, caught herself. "I have a good memory. . . ." Birgitte hesitated, the bond filled with a jumble of emotions hastily pushed down. Most of her memories of past lives had vanished as surely as the winter's snow. Nothing remained before the founding of the White Tower, and the four lives she had lived between then and the end of the Trolloc Wars were beginning to fragment. Little seemed to frighten her, yet she feared losing the rest, especially her memories of Gaidal Cain. "I don't forget a path once I've followed it," she went on, "and some of these hallways aren't the same as they were. Some of the corridors have been . . . shifted. Others aren't there anymore, and there are some new. Nobody is talking about it that I could find out, but I think the old people are keeping quiet because they're afraid their wits are going, and the younger are afraid they'll lose their positions."

"ðæts - " ɪleɪn ʃʌɾ əɹ maʊθ. klɪɹli ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl. bɝdʒɪt dɪd nɑt sʌfɝ fɹəm sʌɾən fænsiz. nɛɹɪs' ɹɪlʌktəns tə liv əɹ əpɑɹtməns sʌɾənli meɪd sɛns, ən pɝhæps ɹɪnz ɝliɝ pʌzəlmənt, tu. ʃi ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt biɪŋ wɪð tʃaɪld ɹɪli hæd bɪfʌɾəld hɝ. bʌt haʊ? "nɑt ðə fɔɹseɪkən," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "ɪf ðeɪ kəd də sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs, ðeɪɾ əv dʌn ɪt lɔŋ sɪns, ən wɝs ðæn. . . . ə ɡʊd deɪ tə ju, tu, lɔɹɾ ɔbɹəm."

"That's - " Elayne shut her mouth. Clearly it was not impossible. Birgitte did not suffer from sudden fancies. Naris' reluctance to leave her apartments suddenly made sense, and perhaps Reene's earlier puzzlement, too. She almost wished being with child really had befuddled her. But how? "Not the Forsaken," she said firmly. "If they could do something like this, they'd have done it long since, and worse than. . . . A good day to you, too, Lord Aubrem."

lin ən kɹæɡi ən bɔl seɪv fəɹ ə θɪn waɪt fɹɪnʒ, ɔbɹəm pɛnsənɔɝ ʃʊɾə bɪn dænlɪŋ ɪz ɡɹæntʃɪlʒɹənz tʃɪlʒɹən ɑn ɪz ni, bʌɾ ɪz bæk wɑz stʃɹeɪt, hɪz aɪz klɪɹ. hi hæd bɪn əmʌŋ ðə fɝs tə ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn, wɪð nɪɹ tə ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ən ðə fɝs nuz ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɛɹəmɪlə mɑɹn mɑɹtʃɪŋ əɡɛns ðə sɪɾi, wɪð nɑiən ən ɛləniə səpɔɹɾɪŋ hɝ. hi bɪɡæn ɹɛmənɪsɪŋ əbaʊt ɹaɪɾɪŋ fəɹ əɹ mʌðɝ ɪn ðə səksɛʃən, əntɪl bɝdʒɪt mɝmɝd ðət leɪɾi daɪɛlɪn wəd bi weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ hɝ.

Lean and craggy and bald save for a thin white fringe, Aubrem Pensenor should have been dandling his grandchildren's children on his knee, but his back was straight, his eyes clear. He had been among the first to reach Caemlyn, with near to a hundred men and the first news that it was Arymilla Marne marching against the city, with Naean and Elenia supporting her. He began reminiscing about riding for her mother in the Succession, until Birgitte murmured that Lady Dyelin would be waiting for her.

"oʊ, ɪn ðət keɪs, doʊn lemi dɪleɪ ju, maɪ leɪɾi," ði oʊl mæn sɛd hɑɹɾəli. "pliz ɡɪv maɪ ɹɪɡɑɹdz tə leɪɾi daɪɛlɪn. ʃiz bɪn soʊ bɪzi, aɪv nɑɾ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd tu wɝdz wɪð əɹ sɪns ɹitʃɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn. maɪ vɛɹi bɛst ɹɪɡɑɹdz, ɪf jə wɪl." haʊs pɛnsənɔɝ hæd bɪn əlaɪd tə daɪɛlɪnz tæɹɑvɪn sɪns taɪm aʊɾ ə maɪnd.

"Oh, in that case, don't let me delay you, my Lady," the old man said heartily. "Please give my regards to Lady Dyelin. She's been so busy, I've not exchanged two words with her since reaching Caemlyn. My very best regards, if you will." House Pensenor had been allied to Dyelin's Taravin since time out of mind.

"nɑt ðə fɔɹseɪkən," bɝdʒɪt sɛd wʌns ɔbɹəm wɑz aʊɾ ʌv ɪɹʃɑt. "bʌt wʌt kɑzd ɪts oʊnli ðə fɝs kwɛstʃən. wɪl ɪt hæpən əɡɛn? ɪf ɪt dʌz, wɪl ðə tʃeɪnʒəz ɔlweɪz bi bɪnaɪn? əɹ maɪt jə weɪk ʌp ən faɪn jɝsɛlf ɪn ə ɹum wɪθaʊt dɔɹz əɹ wɪndoʊz? wʌt hæpənz ɪf jəɹ slipɪŋ ɪn ə ɹum ðət dɪsəpɪɹz? ɪf ə kɔɹəɾɝ kən ɡoʊ, soʊ kən ə ɹum. ən wʌɾ ɪf ɪts mɔɹ ðən ðə pæləs? wi nid tə faɪn aʊɾ ɪf ɔl ðə stʃɹits stɪl lɛd wɛɹ ðeɪ dɪd. wʌɾ ɪf ðə nɛks taɪm, pɑɹɾ ə ðə sɪɾi wɔl ɪzən ðəɹ ɛnimɔɹ?"

"Not the Forsaken," Birgitte said once Aubrem was out of earshot. "But what caused it is only the first question. Will it happen again? If it does, will the changes always be benign? Or might you wake up and find yourself in a room without doors or windows? What happens if you're sleeping in a room that disappears? If a corridor can go, so can a room. And what if it's more than the palace? We need to find out if all the streets still lead where they did. What if the next time, part of the city wall isn't there anymore?"

"ju də θɪŋk dɑɹk θɔts," ɪleɪn sɛd blikli. ivən wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn hɝ, ðə pɑsəbɪləɾiz wɝ ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv əɹ ə saʊɝ stʌmək.

"You do think dark thoughts," Elayne said bleakly. Even with the Power in her, the possibilities were enough to give her a sour stomach.

bɝdʒɪt fɪŋɡɝd ðə fɔɹ ɡoʊldən nɑts ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ ə hɝ waɪt-kɑlɝd ɹɛd koʊt. "ðeɪ keɪm wɪð ðiz." stʃɹeɪnʒli, ðə wɝi kæɹid baɪ ðə bɑnd wɑz lɛs naʊ ðət ʃi hæd ʃɛɹɾ əɹ kənsɝnz. ɪleɪn hoʊp ðə wʊmən dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi hæɾ ænsɝz. noʊ, ðət ɹɪli wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl. bɝdʒɪt nu hɝ tu wɛl fəɹ ðæt.

Birgitte fingered the four golden knots on the shoulder of her white-collared red coat. "They came with these." Strangely, the worry carried by the bond was less now that she had shared her concerns. Elayne hoped the woman did not think she had answers. No, that really was impossible. Birgitte knew her too well for that.

"dʌz ðɪs fɹaɪɾən ju, dɪni?" ʃi æskt. "aɪl ədmɪɾ ɪt dʌz mi."

"Does this frighten you, Deni?" she asked. "I'll admit it does me."

"noʊ mɔɹ ðən nidfəl, maɪ leɪɾi," ðə blɑki wʊmən ænsɝd wɪθaʊt stɑpɪŋ əɹ kɛɹfəl skæn ʌv wʌt leɪ əhɛd. wɛɹ ði ʌðɝz wɔkt wɪð ə hæn ɑn ðɛɹ sɔɹd hɪls, hɝ hæn ɹɛstəɾ ɑn əɹ lɔŋ kʌdʒəl. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz əz plæsəd, ən əz mæɾɝ-ʌv-fækt, əz əɹ feɪs. "wʌn taɪm ə bɪɡ wæɡən mæn neɪmd ɛlʒɹɪn hækli keɪm nɪɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ maɪ nɛk. nɑt juʒəwəli ə ɹʌf mæn, bʌɾ i wɑz dʒɹʌŋk bɪɑn dʒɹʌŋk ðət naɪt. aɪ kʊdnt ɡɛt ði æŋɡəl ɹaɪt, ən maɪ kʌdʒəl sim tə baʊns ɔf ɪz skʌl wɪθaʊt meɪkɪŋ ə dɛnt. ðət fɹaɪɾənd mi mɔɹ, kəz aɪ nu sɝɾən ʃʊɹ aɪ wɑz əbaʊt tə daɪ. ðɪs ɪz dʒʌs meɪbi, ən ɛni deɪ jə weɪk ʌp, meɪbi jə daɪ."

"No more than needful, my Lady," the blocky woman answered without stopping her careful scan of what lay ahead. Where the others walked with a hand on their sword hilts, her hand rested on her long cudgel. Her voice was as placid, and as matter-of-fact, as her face. "One time a big wagon man named Eldrin Hackly came near breaking my neck. Not usually a rough man, but he was drunk beyond drunk that night. I couldn't get the angle right, and my cudgel seemed to bounce off his skull without making a dent. That frightened me more, because I knew certain sure I was about to die. This is just maybe, and any day you wake up, maybe you die."

ɛni deɪ jə weɪk ʌp, meɪbi jə daɪ. ðəɹ wɝ wɝs weɪz tə lʊk ət laɪf, ɪleɪn səpoʊzd. stɪl, ʃi ʃɪvɝd. ʃi wɑz seɪf, ət lis tɪl əɹ beɪbz wɝ bɔɹn, bʌt noʊ wʌn ɛls wɑz.

Any day you wake up, maybe you die. There were worse ways to look at life, Elayne supposed. Still, she shivered. She was safe, at least till her babes were born, but no one else was.

ðə tu ɡɑɹdz ət ðə waɪd, laɪən-kɑɹv dɔɹz tə ðə mæp ɹum wɝ ɪkspɪɹiənst ɡɑɹdzmɪn, wʌn ʃɔɹɾ ən ðə nɛks θɪŋ tə skɹɔni, ði ʌðɝ waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə əpɪɹ skwɑt ðoʊ hi wɑz ʌv ævɝɪdʒ haɪt. nʌθɪŋ vɪzəbəl pɪkt əm aʊt fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ mɛn ɪn ðə ɡɑɹdz, bʌɾ oʊnli ɡʊd sɔɝdzmɪn, tʃɹʌstɪd mɛn, ɡɑt ðɪs duɾi. ðə ʃɔɹt mæn nɑɾəd tə dɪni, ðən stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪz bæk stɪfli əɾ ə dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ fɹaʊn fɹəm bɝdʒɪt. dɪni smaɪld əɾ ɪm ʃaɪli - dɪni! ʃaɪli! - waɪl ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɛn θɹu ði ɪnɛvəɾəbəl ɹutin. bɝdʒɪɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm, ən ði ʌðɝ wʊmən lʊkt ət hɝ, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, θɪk ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd sweɪɪŋ sloʊli.

The two guards at the wide, lion-carved doors to the Map Room were experienced Guardsmen, one short and the next thing to scrawny, the other wide enough to appear squat though he was of average height. Nothing visible picked them out from any other men in the Guards, but only good swordsmen, trusted men, got this duty. The short man nodded to Deni, then straightened his back stiffly at a disapproving frown from Birgitte. Deni smiled at him shyly - Deni! shyly! - while a pair of Guardswomen went through the inevitable routine. Birgitte opened her mouth, but Elayne laid a hand on her arm, and the other woman looked at her, then shook her head, thick golden braid swaying slowly.

"ɪts nɑt ɡʊd wən ðəɹ ɑn duɾi, ɪleɪn. ðeɪ ʃəd bi siɪŋ tə ðɛɹ duɾiz, nɑt munɪŋ oʊvɝ itʃ ʌðɝ." ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹeɪz əɹ vɔɪs, jɛt kʌlɝ əpɪɹɾ ɪn dɪniz ɹaʊn tʃiks, ən ʃi stɑp smaɪlɪŋ ən stɑɹɾəd wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kɔɹəɾɝ əɡɛn. ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðət weɪ, pɝhæps, jɛt stɪl ə pɪɾi. sʌmbɑɾi ɔt tə hæv ə lɪɾəl plɛʒɝ ɪn ðɛɹ laɪvz.

"It's not good when they're on duty, Elayne. They should be seeing to their duties, not mooning over each other." She did not raise her voice, yet color appeared in Deni's round cheeks, and she stopped smiling and started watching the corridor again. It was better that way, perhaps, yet still a pity. Somebody ought to have a little pleasure in their lives.

ðə mæp ɹum wɑz ðə sɛkənd-lɑɹdʒəs bɔlɹum ɪn ðə pæləs, ən speɪʃəs, wɪð fɔɹ ɹɛd-stʃɹik mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪsəz wɛɹ smɔl faɪɝz bɝn bɪniθ ðə kɑɹv mæntəlz, ə doʊm silɪŋ wɝkt wɪð ɡɪlt ən səpɔɹɾəd baɪ waɪdli speɪs kɑləmz tu spænz fɹəm waɪt mɑɹbəl wɔlz ðət hæd bɪn stʃɹɪpt ə tæpəstʃɹiz, ən səfɪʃən mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps tə laɪt ðə ɹum əz wɛl əz ɪf ɪt hæd wɪndoʊz. ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪts taɪl flɔɹ wɑz ə dɪteɪl moʊzeɪɪk mæp ə keɪɛmlɪn, ɝɪdʒənəli leɪd daʊn mɔɹ ðən ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ, æftɝ ðə nu sɪɾi hæd bɪn kəmpliɾəd ðoʊ bɪfɔɹ loʊ keɪɛmlɪn bɪɡæn ɡɹoʊɪŋ. lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ wɑz ən ændɝ, bɪfɔɹ ivən ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. ɪt hæd bɪn ɹidʌn sɛvɹəl taɪmz sɪns, əz taɪlz feɪɾəd əɹ bɪkeɪm wɔɹn, soʊ ɛvɹi stʃɹit wɑz ɪɡzækt - ət list, ðeɪ hæd bɪn əntɪl tədeɪ; ðə laɪt sɛn ðeɪ stɪl wɝ - ən dɪspaɪt mɛni bɪldɪŋz ɹipleɪst oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz, ivən səm ə ði æliz wɝ əntʃeɪnʒd fɹəm wʌt ðə hjudʒ mæp ʃoʊd.

The Map Room was the second-largest ballroom in the palace, and spacious, with four red-streaked marble fireplaces where small fires burned beneath the carved mantels, a domed ceiling worked with gilt and supported by widely spaced columns two spans from white marble walls that had been stripped of tapestries, and sufficient mirrored stand-lamps to light the room as well as if it had windows. The greatest part of its tile floor was a detailed mosaic map of Caemlyn, originally laid down more than a thousand years ago, after the New City had been completed though before Low Caemlyn began growing. Long before there was an Andor, before even Artur Hawkwing. It had been redone several times since, as tiles faded or became worn, so every street was exact - at least, they had been until today; the Light send they still were - and despite many buildings replaced over the years, even some of the alleys were unchanged from what the huge map showed.

ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ dænsɪŋ ɪn ðə mæp ɹum fəɹ ðə fɔɹsiəbəl fjutʃɝ, haʊɛvɝ. lɔŋ teɪbəlz bɪtwin ðə kɑləmz hɛl mɔɹ mæps, səm lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə spɪl oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒəz, ən ʃɛlvz əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz hɛl stæks ə ɹɪpɔɹts, ðoʊz nɑt soʊ sɛnsəɾɪv ðeɪ niɾəd tə bi lɑkt əweɪ əɹ ɛls kəmɪɾəd tə mɛmɹi ən bɝnd. bɝdʒɪts waɪd ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl, nɪɹli kʌvɝd wɪð bæskəts, moʊs fʊl ə peɪpɝz, stʊɾ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə ɹum. əz kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl, ʃi hæɾ əɹ oʊn stʌɾi, bʌɾ əz sun əz ʃi dɪskʌvɝd ðə mæp ɹum, ʃi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ðə mæp ɪn ðə flɔɹ meɪɾ ɪt tu ɡʊd nɑt tə juz.

There would be no dancing in the Map Room for the foreseeable future, however. Long tables between the columns held more maps, some large enough to spill over the edges, and shelves along the walls held stacks of reports, those not so sensitive they needed to be locked away or else committed to memory and burned. Birgitte's wide writing table, nearly covered with baskets, most full of papers, stood at the far end of the room. As Captain-General, she had her own study, but as soon as she discovered the Map Room, she had decided the map in the floor made it too good not to use.

ə smɔl wʊɾən dɪsk, peɪntəd ɹɛd, mɑɹk ðə spɑɾ ɑn ði aʊɾɝ wɔl wɛɹ ði əsɔl hæd dʒʌs bɪn biɾən bæk. bɝdʒɪt skupt ɪɾ ʌp ɪn pæsɪŋ ən tɔst ɪɾ ɪndə ə ɹaʊn bæskət fʊl ə ðə θɪŋz ɑn əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl. ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ɪt wɑz ə smɔl bæskət, bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ɪnʌf ətæks ət wʌns tə nid ðət mɛni mɑɹkɝz. . . .

A small wooden disc, painted red, marked the spot on the outer wall where the assault had just been beaten back. Birgitte scooped it up in passing and tossed it into a round basket full of the things on her writing table. Elayne shook her head. It was a small basket, but if there were enough attacks at once to need that many markers. . . .

"maɪ leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt, aɪ hæv ðət ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn əveɪləbəl fɑɾɝ jə æsk fɔɹ," ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ ə peɪdʒ kʌvɝd wɪð nit laɪnz. ðə waɪt laɪən wɑz wɝk smɔl ɑn ðə bɹɛst ə hɝ nit bɹaʊn dʒɹɛs. faɪv ʌðɝ klɝks wɛn ɑn wɪð ðɛɹ wɝk, pɛnz skɹɪtʃɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ əmʌŋ mæstɝ nɔɹiz moʊs tʃɹʌstɪd, ən mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ hæd pɝsənəli skɹin ðə hæf dʌzən mɛsənʒɝz ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt lɪvɝi, swɪf jʌŋ mɛn - bɔɪz ɹɪli - hu stʊɾ əɡɛns ðə wɔl bɪhaɪn ðə klɝks' smɔl ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəlz. wʌn, ə pɹɪɾi juθ, bɪɡæn ə baʊ bɪfɔɹ kʌɾɪŋ ɪt ʃɔɹt wɪð ə blʌʃ. bɝdʒɪt hæd sɛɾəld ðə kwɛstʃən ə kɝɾəsiz, tə hɝ əɹ ʌðɝ noʊbəlz, wɪð vɛɹi fju wɝdz. wɝk keɪm fɝst, ən ɛni noʊbəl u dɪslaɪk ðət kəd dʒʌst əvɔɪd ðə mæp ɹum.

"My Lady Birgitte, I have that report on available fodder you asked for," a graying woman said, holding out a page covered with neat lines. The White Lion was worked small on the breast of her neat brown dress. Five other clerks went on with their work, pens scritching. They were among Master Norry's most trusted, and Mistress Harfor had personally screened the half dozen messengers in red-and-white livery, swift young men - boys really - who stood against the wall behind the clerks' small writing tables. One, a pretty youth, began a bow before cutting it short with a blush. Birgitte had settled the question of courtesies, to her or other nobles, with very few words. Work came first, and any noble who disliked that could just avoid the Map Room.

"θæŋk ju, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnfɝd. əl lʊk əɾ ɪt leɪɾɝ. ɪf jə ən ði ʌðɝz wɪl weɪɾ aʊtsaɪd, pliz?"

"Thank you, Mistress Anford. I'll look at it later. If you and the others will wait outside, please?"

mɪstʃɹəs ɑnfɝd kwɪkli ɡæðɝɾ ʌp ðə mɛsənʒɝz ən ði ʌðɝ klɝks, ɡɪvɪŋ əm oʊnli taɪm tə stɑpɝ ðɛɹ ɪŋk dʒɑɹz ən blɑt ðɛɹ wɝk. noʊ wʌn ʃoʊɾ ə ɡlɪmɝ ə sɝpɹaɪz. ðeɪ wɝ əkʌstəm tə ðə nid fəɹ pɹaɪvəsi ət taɪmz. ɪleɪn hæd hɝd pipəl kɔl ðə mæp ɹum ðə sikɹəts ɹum, ðoʊ nʌθɪŋ vɛɹi sikɹət wɑz kɛp ðɛɹ. ɔl ə ðət wɑz lɑkt əweɪ ɪn əɹ əpɑɹtməns.

Mistress Anford quickly gathered up the messengers and the other clerks, giving them only time to stopper their ink jars and blot their work. No one showed a glimmer of surprise. They were accustomed to the need for privacy at times. Elayne had heard people call the Map Room the Secrets Room, though nothing very secret was kept there. All of that was locked away in her apartments.

waɪl ðə klɝks ən mɛsənʒɝz wɝ faɪlɪŋ aʊt, ɪleɪn stʃɹoʊd tə wʌn ə ðə lɔŋ teɪbəlz wɛɹ ə mæp ʃoʊd keɪɛmlɪn ən ɪts sɝaʊndɪŋz fəɹ ət lis fɪfti maɪlz ɪn itʃ dɝɛkʃən. ivən ðə blæk taʊɝ hæd bɪn ɪŋkt ɪn, ə skwɛɹ sɪɾɪŋ lɛs ðən tu liɡz saʊθ ə ðə sɪɾi. ə ɡɹoʊθ ɑn ændɝ, ən noʊ weɪ tə bi ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt. ʃi stɪl sɛn pɑɹɾiz ʌv ɡɑɹdzmæn tə ɪnspɛk səm deɪz, vaɪə ɡeɪtweɪz, bʌt ðə pleɪs wɑz lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf ðət ði æʃəmən cʊɾə bɪn ʌp tə ɛniθɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ əɹ lɝnɪŋ ʌv ɪt. pɪnz wɪð ɪnæməl hɛdz mɑɹkt ɛɹəmɪləz eɪt kæmps ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi, ən smɔl mɛɾəl fɪɡjɝz vɛɹiəs ʌðɝ kæmps. ə fælkən, faɪnli ɹɔɾ ɪn ɡoʊld ən noʊ tɔlɝ ðən əɹ lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝ, ʃoʊd wɛɹ ðə ɡoʊʃin wɝ. əɹ hæd bɪn. wɝ ðeɪ ɡɔn jɛt? ʃi slɪp ðə fælkən ɪndə hɝ bɛl paʊtʃ. eɪvinhə wɑz vɛɹi mʌtʃ ə fælkən. ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə teɪbəl, bɝdʒɪt ɹeɪzd ə kwɛstʃənɪŋ aɪbɹaʊ.

While the clerks and messengers were filing out, Elayne strode to one of the long tables where a map showed Caemlyn and its surroundings for at least fifty miles in each direction. Even the Black Tower had been inked in, a square sitting less than two leagues south of the city. A growth on Andor, and no way to be rid of it. She still sent parties of Guardsman to inspect some days, via gateways, but the place was large enough that the Asha'man could have been up to anything without her learning of it. Pins with enameled heads marked Arymilla's eight camps around the city, and small metal figures various other camps. A falcon, finely wrought in gold and no taller than her little finger, showed where the Goshien were. Or had been. Were they gone yet? She slipped the falcon into her belt pouch. Aviendha was very much a falcon. On the other side of the table, Birgitte raised a questioning eyebrow.

"ðeɪɹ ɡɔn, əɹ ɡoʊɪŋ," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ. ðəɹ wəd bi vɪzəts. eɪvinhə wɑz nɑt ɡɔn fɝɛvɝ. "sɛn sʌmwɛɹ baɪ ɹænd. wɛɹ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ, bɝn hɪm."

"They're gone, or going," Elayne told her. There would be visits. Aviendha was not gone forever. "Sent somewhere by Rand. Where, I don't know, burn him."

"aɪ wʌndɝd waɪ eɪvinhə wɑznt wɪð ju."

"I wondered why Aviendha wasn't with you."

ɪleɪn leɪd wʌn fɪŋɡɝ ətɑp ə bɹɑnz hɔɹsmən lɛs ðən ə hæn tɔl, stændɪŋ ə fju liɡz wɛst ə ðə sɪɾi. "sʌmwʌn nidz tə teɪk ə lʊk ət dævɹæm bæʃɪɹz kæmp. faɪn aʊt wɛðɝ ðə sɑldəiənz ɑɹ livɪŋ, tu. ən ðə lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən." ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ, ɹɪli. ðeɪ hæd nɑɾ ɪntɝfɪɹɾ ɪn mæɾɝz, θæŋk ðə laɪt, ən ðə taɪm wən fɪɹ ðət ðeɪ maɪt ɹistʃɹeɪn ɛɹəmɪlə wɑz lɔŋ pæst. bʌt ʃi dɪslaɪk θɪŋz hæpənɪŋ ɪn ændɝ wɪθaʊɾ əɹ nɑlədʒ. "sɛnd ɡɑɹdzmɪn tə ðə blæk taʊɝ təmɑɹoʊ, əz wɛl. tɛl əm tə kaʊn haʊ mɛni æʃəmən ðeɪ si."

Elayne laid one finger atop a bronze horseman less than a hand tall, standing a few leagues west of the city. "Someone needs to take a look at Davram Bashere's camp. Find out whether the Saldaeans are leaving, too. And the Legion of the Dragon." It did not matter if they were, really. They had not interfered in matters, thank the Light, and the time when fear that they might restrained Arymilla was long past. But she disliked things happening in Andor without her knowledge. "Send Guardsmen to the Black Tower tomorrow, as well. Tell them to count how many Asha'man they see."

"soʊ hiz plænɪŋ ə bɪɡ bæɾəl. ənʌðɝ bɪɡ bæɾəl. əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn, aɪ səpoʊz." foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, bɝdʒɪt fɹaʊn ət ðə mæp. "aɪd wʌndɝ wɛɹ ən wɛn, ɪksɛpt wɪv ɪnʌf ɪn fɹʌn ʌv əs tə bi ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn wɪð."

"So he's planning a big battle. Another big battle. Against the Seanchan, I suppose." Folding her arms beneath her breasts, Birgitte frowned at the map. "I'd wonder where and when, except we have enough in front of us to be going on with."

ðə mæp dɪspleɪd ðə ɹizənz ɛɹəmɪlə wɑz pɹɛsɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd. fəɹ wʌn, tə ðə nɔɹθist ə keɪɛmlɪn, ɔlmoʊst ɔf ðə mæp, leɪ ðə bɹɑnz ɪmədʒ ʌv ə slipɪŋ bɛɹ, kɝld ʌp wɪð ɪts pɔz oʊvɝ ɪts noʊz. tu hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən mɛn, nɪɹ ɪnʌf, ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni tʃɹeɪn mɛn əz ɔl ʌv ændɝ kəd fild. fɔɹ bɔɹɾɝlənd ɹulɝz, əkʌmpənid baɪ pɝhæps ə dʌzən ɛɛs sədaɪ ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə kip hɪɾən, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ɹænd, ðɛɹ ɹizənz ənsteɪɾɪd. bɔɹɾɝləndɝz hæd noʊ kɑz tə tɝn əɡɛnst ɹænd ðət ʃi kəd si - ðoʊ ðə sɪmpəl fækt wɑz, hi hæd nɑt baʊn əm tə hɪm əz i hæɾ ʌðɝ lænz - bʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ, ɪspɛʃli wɪð ðɛɹ əlidʒəns ənsɝɾən, ən twɛlv əpɹoʊtʃt ə deɪnʒɝəs nʌmbɝ ivən fəɹ hɪm. wɛl, ðə fɔɹ ɹulɝz hæɾ ɪn pɑɹt dɪsaɪfɝɾ əɹ moʊɾɪvz fəɹ æskɪŋ əm ɪndə ændɝ, jɛt ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə mɪsliɾ əm kənsɝnɪŋ ɹændz wɛɹəbaʊts. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz hæd bɪlaɪɾ ɛvɹi teɪl ə haʊ swɪfli ðeɪ kəd muv əz ðeɪ kɹɛp saʊθ, ən naʊ ðeɪ sæɾ ɪn pleɪs, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ə weɪ tə əvɔɪd kʌmɪŋ nɪɹ ə sɪɾi ʌndɝ sidʒ. ðət wɑz ʌndɝstændəbəl, ivən lɔɾəbəl. aʊtlæn ɑɹmiz ɪn kloʊs pɹɑksɪməɾi tə ændɔɝən ɑɹmmɪn, ɑn ændɔɝən sɔɪl, wəd meɪk fəɹ ə tʌtʃi sɪtʃueɪʃən. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz ət list ə fju hɑthɛdz. blʌdʃɛd, ən meɪbi wɔɹ, kəd stɑɹɾ ɔl tu izəli ʌndɝ ðoʊz sɝkəmstænsəz. ivən soʊ, baɪpæsɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn wɑz gɑnə bi dɪfəkəlt; ðə nɛɹoʊ kʌntʃɹi ɹoʊdz hæd bɪn tɝn tə bɑɡz baɪ ðə ɹeɪnz, ɡɪvɪŋ hɑɹd pæsədʒ tə ən ɑɹmi ðət lɑɹdʒ. ɪleɪn cʊɾə wɪʃt ðeɪ hæd mɑɹtʃt ənʌðɝ twɛnti əɹ θɝɾi maɪlz təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn, ðoʊ. ʃi hæd hoʊp ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns wʊɾə hæɾ ə dɪfɹən ɪfɛk baɪ naʊ. ɪt maɪt stɪl.

The map displayed the reasons Arymilla was pressing so hard. For one, to the northeast of Caemlyn, almost off the map, lay the bronze image of a sleeping bear, curled up with its paws over its nose. Two hundred thousand men, near enough, almost as many trained men as all of Andor could field. Four Borderland rulers, accompanied by perhaps a dozen Aes Sedai they tried to keep hidden, searching for Rand, their reasons unstated. Borderlanders had no cause to turn against Rand that she could see - though the simple fact was, he had not bound them to him as he had other lands - but Aes Sedai were another matter, especially with their allegiance uncertain, and twelve approached a dangerous number even for him. Well, the four rulers had in part deciphered her motives for asking them into Andor, yet she had managed to mislead them concerning Rand's whereabouts. Unfortunately, the Borderlanders had belied every tale of how swiftly they could move as they crept south, and now they sat in place, trying to find a way to avoid coming near a city under siege. That was understandable, even laudable. Outland armies in close proximity to Andoran armsmen, on Andoran soil, would make for a touchy situation. There were always at least a few hotheads. Bloodshed, and maybe war, could start all too easily under those circumstances. Even so, bypassing Caemlyn was going to be difficult; the narrow country roads had been turned to bogs by the rains, giving hard passage to an army that large. Elayne could have wished they had marched another twenty or thirty miles toward Caemlyn, though. She had hoped their presence would have had a different effect by now. It might still.

mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, sɝɾənli tə ɛɹəmɪlə ən pɑsəbli tə hɝsɛlf, ə fju liɡz bɪloʊ ðə blæk taʊɝ stʊɾ ə taɪni sɪlvɝ sɔɝdzmən wɪð ɪz bleɪɾ əpɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ən ə sɪlvɝ hælbɝɾiɝ, pleɪnli baɪ ðə seɪm sɪlvɝsmɪθs hænd, wʌn tə ðə wɛst ə ðə blæk skwɛɹ, ði ʌðɝ tə ði ist. lwɑn, ɛlɹin ən æbəl, æɛmlɪn, ɑɝəθɛl ən pɛlɪvɑɹ hæd kloʊs tə sɪksti θaʊzən mɛn bɪtwin əm ɪn ðoʊz tu kæmps. ðɛɹ ɪsteɪts ən ðoʊz ə ðə noʊbəlz taɪd tə ðɛm mʌst əv bɪn stʃɹɪp nɪɹ ðə boʊn. ðoʊz tu kæmps wɝ wɛɹ daɪɛlɪn hæd bɪn ðiz pæs θɹi deɪz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɝn ðɛɹ ɪntɛntʃənz.

More important, certainly to Arymilla and possibly to herself, a few leagues below the Black Tower stood a tiny silver swordsman with his blade upright in front of him and a silver halberdier, plainly by the same silversmith's hand, one to the west of the black square, the other to the east. Luan, Ellorien and Abelle, Aemlyn, Arathelle and Pelivar had close to sixty thousand men between them in those two camps. Their estates and those of the nobles tied to them must have been stripped near the bone. Those two camps were where Dyelin had been these past three days, trying to learn their intentions.

ðə spɪnli ɡɑɹdzmæn oʊpənd wʌn ə ðə dɔɹz ən hɛld ɪt fəɹ ən ɛldɝli sɝvɪŋ wʊmən kæɹiɪŋ ə ɹoʊp-wɝk sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ wɪð tu tɔl ɡoʊldən waɪn pɪtʃɝz ən ə sɝkəl ʌv ɡoʊbləts meɪɾ ə blu si foʊk pɔɹsələn. ɹɪn mʌst əv bɪn ənsɝɾən haʊ mɛni wəd bi pɹizɛnt. ðə fɹeɪl wʊmən muv sloʊli, kɛɹfəl nɑt tə tɪl ðə hɛvi tʃɹeɪ ən dʒɹɑp ɛniθɪŋ. ɪleɪn tʃænəl floʊz ʌv ɛɹ tə teɪk ðə tʃɹeɪ, ðən lɛɾ əm dɪsəpeɪɾ ənjuzd. ɪmplaɪɪŋ ðət ðə wʊmən kəd nɑt də hɝ dʒɑb wəɾ oʊnli bi hɝtfəl. ʃi wɑz ɛfjusɪv ɪn əɹ θæŋks, ðoʊ. ði oʊld wʊmən smaɪl bɹɔdli, klɪɹli dɪlaɪɾəd, ən ɔfɝɾ əɹ ə dip kɝtsi wʌns ənbɝɾənd ə ðə tʃɹeɪ.

The spindly Guardsman opened one of the doors and held it for an elderly serving woman carrying a rope-work silver tray with two tall golden wine pitchers and a circle of goblets made of blue Sea Folk porcelain. Reene must have been uncertain how many would be present. The frail woman moved slowly, careful not to tilt the heavy tray and drop anything. Elayne channeled flows of Air to take the tray, then let them dissipate unused. Implying that the woman could not do her job would only be hurtful. She was effusive in her thanks, though. The old woman smiled broadly, clearly delighted, and offered her a deep curtsy once unburdened of the tray.

daɪɛlɪn ɝaɪvd ɔlmoʊst ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn ðə meɪd, ən ɪmədʒ ə vɪɡɝ, ən ʃuɾ əɹ aʊt bɪfɔɹ ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə kɑntɛns ʌv wʌn pɪtʃɝ - ɪleɪn saɪd; daʊtləs ɪt hɛld ɡoʊts mɪlk - ən fɪlɪŋ ə ɡɑblət fɹəm ði ʌðɝ. pleɪnli daɪɛlɪn hæd kənfaɪn əɹ fɹɛʃənɪŋ tə wɑʃɪŋ əɹ feɪs ən bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ, ɡoʊldən flɛkt wɪð ɡɹeɪ, kəz əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs, wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ ɹaʊn sɪlvɝ pɪn wɝkt wɪð tæɹɑvɪnz aʊl ən oʊk ɑn ðə haɪ nɛk, hæd spɑts ə hæf-dʒɹaɪd mʌɾ ɑn ðə skɝts.

Dyelin arrived almost right behind the maid, an image of vigor, and shooed her out before grimacing over the contents of one pitcher - Elayne sighed; doubtless it held goat's milk - and filling a goblet from the other. Plainly Dyelin had confined her freshening to washing her face and brushing her hair, golden flecked with gray, because her dark gray riding dress, with a large round silver pin worked with Taravin's Owl and Oak on the high neck, had spots of half-dried mud on the skirts.

"ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ sɪɹiəsli əmɪs," ʃi sɛd, swɝlɪŋ ðə waɪn ɪn əɹ ɡɑblət wɪθaʊt dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ. ə fɹaʊn dipən ðə faɪn laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz. "aɪv bɪn ɪn ðɪs pæləs mɔɹ taɪmz ðən aɪ kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ən tədeɪ aɪ ɡɑt lɔs twaɪs."

"There's something seriously amiss," she said, swirling the wine in her goblet without drinking. A frown deepened the fine lines at the corners of her eyes. "I've been in this palace more times than I can remember, and today I got lost twice."

"wi noʊ əbaʊt ðæt," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ, ən kwɪkli ɪkspleɪnd wʌt lɪɾəl ðeɪ hæd pʌzəld aʊt, wʌt ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə du. bɪleɪɾədli, ʃi woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ən wɑz ənsɝpɹaɪz tə fil ɪt slaɪs θɹu seɪaɪdɑɹ. ət lis huɛvɝ hæd bɪn lɪsnɪŋ ɪn wəd ɡɛɾ ə dʒoʊl fɹəm ðæt. ə smɔl dʒoʊlt, sɪns soʊ lɪɾəl ə ðə paʊɝ wɑz ɪnvɑlv ðət ʃi hæd nɑt sɛnst ɪt. meɪbi ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ tə meɪk ɪɾ ə hɑɹd dʒoʊl nɛks taɪm, ðoʊ. meɪbi ðət wəd bɪɡɪn tə dɪskɝɪdʒ ivzdʒɹɑpɝz.

"We know about that," Elayne told her, and quickly explained what little they had puzzled out, what she intended to do. Belatedly, she wove a ward against eavesdropping and was unsurprised to feel it slice through saidar. At least whoever had been listening in would get a jolt from that. A small jolt, since so little of the power was involved that she had not sensed it. Maybe there was a way to make it a hard jolt next time, though. Maybe that would begin to discourage eavesdroppers.

"soʊ ɪt maɪt hæpən əɡɛn," daɪɛlɪn sɛd wən ɪleɪn wɑz dʌn. hɝ toʊn wɑz kɑm, bʌt ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps ən tʊk ə swɑloʊ ʌv waɪn, əz ɪf əɹ maʊθ wɑz sʌɾənli dʒɹaɪ. "wɛl. wɛl, ðɛn. ɪf jə doʊnt noʊ wʌt kɑzd ɪt, ən jə doʊnt noʊ wɛðɝ ɪɾəl hæpən əɡɛn, wʌɾ ɑɹ wi tə du?"

"So it might happen again," Dyelin said when Elayne was done. Her tone was calm, but she licked her lips and took a swallow of wine, as if her mouth was suddenly dry. "Well. Well, then. If you don't know what caused it, and you don't know whether it will happen again, what are we to do?"

ɪleɪn stɛɹd. əɡɛn sʌmwʌn sim tə θɪŋk ʃi hæɾ ænsɝz ʃi dɪd nɑt. bʌt ðɛn, ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɪt mɛn tə bi kwin. jə wɝ ɔlweɪz ɪkspɛktəd tə hæv ən ænsɝ, tə faɪnd wʌn. ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɪt mɛn tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. "wi kæn stɑp ɪt, soʊ wɪl lɪv wɪð ɪt, daɪɛlɪn, ən tʃɹaɪ tə kip pipəl fɹəm ɡɹoʊɪŋ tu əfɹeɪd. əl ənaʊns wʌt hæpənd, əz mʌtʃ əz wi noʊ, ən əv ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz də ðə seɪm. ðət weɪ, pipəl wɪl noʊ ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ əwɛɹ, ən ðət ʃəd pɹəvaɪd səm kʌmfɝt. ə lɪɾəl. ðəl stɪl bi fɹaɪɾənd, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt nɑɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ðəl bi ɪf wi seɪ nʌθɪŋ ən ɪt dʌz hæpən əɡɛn."

Elayne stared. Again someone seemed to think she had answers she did not. But then, that was what it meant to be queen. You were always expected to have an answer, to find one. That was what it meant to be Aes Sedai. "We can't stop it, so we'll live with it, Dyelin, and try to keep people from growing too afraid. I'll announce what happened, as much as we know, and have the other sisters do the same. That way, people will know that Aes Sedai are aware, and that should provide some comfort. A little. They'll still be frightened, of course, but not as much as they'll be if we say nothing and it does happen again."

ðət simd ə fibəl ɛfɝt tə hɝ, bʌt sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli daɪɛlɪn əɡɹid wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən. "aɪ maɪsɛlf kən sədʒɛs nʌθɪŋ ɛls tə bi dʌn. moʊs pipəl θɪŋk jə ɛɛs sədaɪ kən hændəl ɛniθɪŋ. ɪt ʃəd səfaɪs, ɪn ðə sɝkəmstænsəz."

That seemed a feeble effort to her, but surprisingly Dyelin agreed without hesitation. "I myself can suggest nothing else to be done. Most people think you Aes Sedai can handle anything. It should suffice, in the circumstances."

ən wən ðeɪ ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt hændəl ɛniθɪŋ, ðət ʃi kəd nɑt? wɛl, ðət wɑz ə ɹɪvɝ ðət ʃi wəd kɹɔs wən ʃi ɹitʃt ɪt. "ɪz ðə nuz ɡʊd, əɹ bæd?"

And when they realized that Aes Sedai could not handle anything, that she could not? Well, that was a river that she would cross when she reached it. "Is the news good, or bad?"

bɪfɔɹ daɪɛlɪn kəɾ ænsɝ, ðə dɔɹ oʊpən əɡɛn.
