Before Dyelin could answer, the door opened again.

"aɪ hɝd ðət leɪɾi daɪɛlɪn hæd ɹɪtɝnd. jə ʃʊɾə sɛn fəɹ ʌs, ɪleɪn. jə ɑɹən kwin jɛt, ən aɪ dɪslaɪk jə kipɪŋ sikɹəts fɹəm mi. wɛɹ ɪz eɪvinhə?" kæɾəlɪn hɛvɪn, ə kul-aɪd, ənɡʌvɝnəbəl jʌŋ wʊmən - ə ɡɝl ɪn tʃɹuθ, stɪl lɔŋ mʌnθs ʃɔɹɾ ə hɝ mədʒɔɹəɾi, ðoʊ hɝ ɡɑɹɾiən hæɾ əbændən əɹ tə ɡoʊ hɝ oʊn weɪ - wɑz pɹaɪd tə hɝ toʊneɪlz, hɝ plʌmp tʃɪn hɛl haɪ. ʌv kɔɹs, ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn kəz ə ðə lɑɹdʒ ɪnæməl pɪn ə hɛvɪnz blu bɛɹ ðət dɛkɝeɪɾəd ðə haɪ nɛk ə hɝ blu ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs. ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn ʃoʊɪŋ daɪɛlɪn ɹɪspɛkt, ən ə sɝɾən wɛɹinɪs, ʃɔɹtli æftɝ ʃi stɑɹɾəd ʃɛɹɪŋ ə bɛd wɪð əɹ ən sɝɡeɪs, bʌt wɪð ɪleɪn ʃi ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ɛvɹi pɝkwəzəɾ ʌv ə haɪ sit.

"I heard that Lady Dyelin had returned. You should have sent for us, Elayne. You aren't queen yet, and I dislike you keeping secrets from me. Where is Aviendha?" Catalyn Haevin, a cool-eyed, ungovernable young woman - a girl in truth, still long months short of her majority, though her guardian had abandoned her to go her own way - was pride to her toenails, her plump chin held high. Of course, that might have been because of the large enameled pin of Haevin's Blue Bear that decorated the high neck of her blue riding dress. She had begun showing Dyelin respect, and a certain wariness, shortly after she started sharing a bed with her and Sergase, but with Elayne she insisted on every perquisite of a High Seat.

"wi ɔl hɝd," kɑneɪl nɔɹθən sɛd. lin ən tɔl ɪn ə ɹɛd sɪlk koʊt, wɪð læfɪŋ aɪz ən ən iɡəlz bik ʌv ə noʊz, hi wɑz ʌv eɪdʒ, dʒʌst, ə fju mʌnθs pæst ɪz sɪkstinθ neɪm deɪ. hi swæɡɝɾ ən kɝɛs ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd mʌtʃ tu fɑnli, bʌt ðəɹ sim noʊ hɑɹm ɪn hɪm. oʊnli bɔɪɪʃnəs, ən ənfɔɹtʃənət tʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ə haɪ sit. "ænd nʌn ʌv əs kəd weɪt tə hɪɹ wən lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz wɪl dʒɔɪn ʌs. ðɪs pɛɹ wʊɾə ɹʌn ðə hoʊl weɪ." hi ɹʌfəl ðə hɛɹ ə ðə tu jʌŋɡɝ bɔɪz wɪð hɪm, pɛɝaɪvəl mæntʃɹ ən bɹænlət ʒəljɑɹd, hu ɡeɪv ɪm ə dɑɹk lʊk ən ɹeɪk fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ tə stʃɹeɪɾən ɪt. pɛɝaɪvəl blʌʃt. kwaɪt ʃɔɹt bʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi pɹɪɾi, hi wɑz ðə jʌŋɡəst ət twɛlv, jɛt bɹænlət hæɾ oʊnli ə jɪɹ ɑn hɪm.

"We all heard," Conail Northan said. Lean and tall in a red silk coat, with laughing eyes and an eagle's beak of a nose, he was of age, just, a few months past his sixteenth name day. He swaggered and caressed the hilt of his sword much too fondly, but there seemed no harm in him. Only boyishness, an unfortunate trait in a High Seat. "And none of us could wait to hear when Luan and the others will join us. This pair would have run the whole way." He ruffled the hair of the two younger boys with him, Perival Mantear and Branlet Gilyard, who gave him a dark look and raked fingers through his hair to straighten it. Perival blushed. Quite short but already pretty, he was the youngest at twelve, yet Branlet had only a year on him.

ɪleɪn saɪd, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑɾ æsk əm tə liv. tʃɪlʒɹən moʊst ə ðɛm maɪt bi - pɝhæps ɔl, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ kɑneɪlz bɪheɪvjɝ - jɛt ðeɪ wɝ ðə haɪ sits ə ðɛɹ haʊsəz, ən əlɔŋ wɪð daɪɛlɪn, hɝ moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt ælaɪz. ʃi dɪd wɪʃ ʃi nu haʊ ðeɪ hæd lɝn ðə pɝpəs ə daɪɛlɪnz dʒɝni. ðət hæd bɪn ɪntɛndəd tə bi ə sikɹəɾ əntɪl ʃi nu wʌt nuz daɪɛlɪn bɹɔt. ənʌðɝ tæsk fəɹ ɹɪn. ɡɑsəp əntʃɛkt, ðə ɹɔŋ ɡɑsəp, kəd bi əz deɪnʒɝəs əz spaɪz.

Elayne sighed, but she could not ask them to leave. Children most of them might be - perhaps all, considering Conail's behavior - yet they were the High Seats of their Houses, and along with Dyelin, her most important allies. She did wish she knew how they had learned the purpose of Dyelin's journey. That had been intended to be a secret until she knew what news Dyelin brought. Another task for Reene. Gossip unchecked, the wrong gossip, could be as dangerous as spies.

"wɛɹ ɪz eɪvinhə?" kæɾəlɪn dɪmændəd. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ʃi hæd bɪkʌm kwaɪt teɪkən wɪð eɪvinhə. fæsəneɪɾəd maɪɾ əv bɪn ə bɛɾɝ wɝd. ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ʃi hæd pɝsɪstəɾ ɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk eɪvinhə titʃ əɹ tə juz ə spɪɹ!

"Where is Aviendha?" Catalyn demanded. Strangely, she had become quite taken with Aviendha. Fascinated might have been a better word. Of all things, she had persisted in trying to make Aviendha teach her to use a spear!

"soʊ, maɪ leɪɾi," kɑneɪl sɛd, stʃɹoʊlɪŋ oʊvɝ tə fɪl ə blu ɡɑblət wɪð waɪn, "wɛn ɑɹ ðeɪ dʒɔɪnɪŋ ʌs?"

"So, my Lady," Conail said, strolling over to fill a blue goblet with wine, "when are they joining us?"

"ðə bæd nuz ɪz ðət ðeɪ ɑɹənt," daɪɛlɪn sɛd kɑmli. "ðə ɡʊd nuz ɪz ðət ðeɪv itʃ ɹɪdʒɛktɪɾ ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən tə dʒɔɪn ɛɹəmɪlə." ʃi klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt laʊdli əz bɹænlət ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə waɪn pɪtʃɝ. hɪz tʃiks ɹɛɾənd, ən i pɪkt ʌp ði ʌðɝ pɪtʃɝ əz ɪf i hæd ɹɪli mɛn tə ɔl əlɔŋ. ðə haɪ siɾ ə haʊs ʒəljɑɹd, jɛt stɪl ə bɔɪ fəɹ ɔl ə ðə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp. pɛɝaɪvəl ɔlsoʊ wɔɹ ə sɔɹd, wʌn ðət dʒɹæɡd ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz ən lʊk tu bɪɡ fəɹ hɪm, bʌɾ i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi teɪkən ɡoʊts mɪlk. pɔɹɪŋ əɹ oʊn waɪn, kæɾəlɪn smɝkt ət ðə jʌŋɡɝ bɔɪz, ə supɪɹiɝ smaɪl ðət vænɪʃt wən ʃi noʊɾəst daɪɛlɪn lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ.

"The bad news is that they aren't," Dyelin said calmly. "The good news is that they've each rejected an invitation to join Arymilla." She cleared her throat loudly as Branlet reached for the wine pitcher. His cheeks reddened, and he picked up the other pitcher as if he had really meant to all along. The High Seat of House Gilyard, yet still a boy for all of the sword on his hip. Perival also wore a sword, one that dragged on the floor tiles and looked too big for him, but he had already taken goat's milk. Pouring her own wine, Catalyn smirked at the younger boys, a superior smile that vanished when she noticed Dyelin looking at her.

"ðæts smɔl tɝnəps tə kɔl ɡʊd nuz," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "bɝn mi, ɪf ɪɾ ɪzənt. jə bɹɪŋ bæk ə blʌɾi hæf-stɑɹv skwɝəl ən kɔl ɪɾ ə saɪɾ ə bif."

"That's small turnips to call good news," Birgitte said. "Burn me, if it isn't. You bring back a bloody half-starved squirrel and call it a side of beef."

"pʌnʒənt əz ɔlweɪz," daɪɛlɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. ðə tu wɪmən ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ, bɝdʒɪts hænz bɔlɪŋ ɪndə fɪsts, daɪɛlɪn fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ əɾ əɹ bɛlt.

"Pungent as always," Dyelin said dryly. The two women glared at each other, Birgitte's hands balling into fists, Dyelin fingering the dagger at her belt.

"noʊ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ," ɪleɪn sɛd, meɪkɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs ʃɑɹp. ði æŋɡɝ ɪn ðə bɑn hɛlpt. ət taɪmz ʃi fɪɹd ðə pɛɹ maɪt kʌm tə bloʊz. "aɪ woʊn pʊɾ ʌp wɪð jəɹ bɪkɝɪŋ tədeɪ."

"No arguing," Elayne said, making her voice sharp. The anger in the bond helped. At times she feared the pair might come to blows. "I won't put up with your bickering today."

"wɛɹ ɪz eɪvinhə?"

"Where is Aviendha?"

"ɡɔn, kæɾəlɪn. wʌɾ ɛls dɪd jə lɝn, daɪɛlɪn?"

"Gone, Catalyn. What else did you learn, Dyelin?"

"ɡɔn wɛɹ?"

"Gone where?"

"ɡɔn əweɪ," ɪleɪn sɛd kɑmli. seɪaɪdɑɹ əɹ noʊ seɪaɪdɑɹ, ʃi wɑntəd tə slæp ðə ɡɝlz feɪs. "daɪɛlɪn?"

"Gone away," Elayne said calmly. Saidar or no saidar, she wanted to slap the girl's face. "Dyelin?"

ði oʊldɝ wʊmən tʊk ə sɪp ʌv waɪn tə kʌvɝ bɹeɪkɪŋ ɔf əɹ stɛɹɪŋ mætʃ wɪð bɝdʒɪt. kʌmɪŋ tə stæn bɪsaɪɾ ɪleɪn, ʃi pɪkt ʌp ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɝdzmən, tɝn ɪm oʊvɝ, sɛɾ ɪm daʊn əɡɛn. "æɛmlɪn, ɑɝəθɛl ən pɛlɪvɑɹ tʃɹaɪd tə kənvɪns mi tə ənaʊns ə kleɪm tə ðə θɹoʊn, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ lɛs æɾəmənt ðən wən aɪ spoʊk wɪð əm læst. aɪ bɪliv aɪv ɔlmoʊs kənvɪnst əm aɪ woʊn də ɪt."

The older woman took a sip of wine to cover breaking off her staring match with Birgitte. Coming to stand beside Elayne, she picked up the silver swordsman, turned him over, set him down again. "Aemlyn, Arathelle and Pelivar tried to convince me to announce a claim to the throne, but they were less adamant than when I spoke with them last. I believe I've almost convinced them I won't do it."

"ɔlmoʊst?" bɝdʒɪt pʊɾ ə hʌnʒɹədweɪt ə dɝɪʒən ɪn ðə wɝd. daɪɛlɪn ɪɡnɔɹɾ əɹ pɔɪntɪdli. ɪleɪn fɹaʊn ət bɝdʒɪt, hu ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli ən stɔkt ɔf lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɡɛt hɝsɛlf ə ɡɑbləɾ ʌv waɪn. vɛɹi sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ. wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑz duɪŋ ɹaɪt, ʃi hoʊpt ɪt kəntɪnjud tə wɝk.

"Almost?" Birgitte put a hundredweight of derision in the word. Dyelin ignored her pointedly. Elayne frowned at Birgitte, who shifted uncomfortably and stalked off long enough to get herself a goblet of wine. Very satisfying. Whatever she was doing right, she hoped it continued to work.

"maɪ leɪɾi," pɛɝaɪvəl sɛd wɪð ə baʊ, ɪkstɛndɪŋ wʌn ə tu ɡoʊbləts i hɛl tə ɪleɪn. ʃi mænədʒd ə smaɪl ən ə kɝtsi bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ði ɔfɝɪŋ. ɡoʊts mɪlk. laɪt, bʌt ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹɛvaɪl ðə stʌf!

"My Lady," Perival said with a bow, extending one of two goblets he held to Elayne. She managed a smile and a curtsy before taking the offering. Goat's milk. Light, but she was beginning to revile the stuff!

"lwɑn ən æbəl wɝ . . . nɑnkəmɪɾəl," daɪɛlɪn kəntɪnjud, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə hælbɝɾiɝ. "ðeɪ meɪ bi sweɪɪŋ təwɔɹd ju." ʃi hɑɹdli saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi bɪlivd ɪt, haʊɛvɝ. "aɪ ɹimaɪndəd lwɑn ðəɾ i hɛlp mi ɝɛs nɑiən ən ɛləniə, bæk ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, bʌt ðət meɪ hæv dʌn noʊ mɔɹ ɡʊd ðən ɪt dɪd wɪð pɛlɪvɑɹ."

"Luan and Abelle were . . . noncommittal," Dyelin continued, frowning at the halberdier. "They may be swaying toward you." She hardly sounded as though she believed it, however. "I reminded Luan that he helped me arrest Naean and Elenia, back in the beginning, but that may have done no more good than it did with Pelivar."

"soʊ ðeɪ meɪ ɔl bi weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɛɹəmɪlə tə wɪn," bɝdʒɪt sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "ɪf jə sɝvaɪv, ðəl dɪklɛɹ fəɹ jə əɡɛns hɝ. ɪf jə doʊnt, wʌn ə ðɛm wɪl meɪk əɹ oʊn kleɪm. ɛlɹin əz ðə nɛks bɛst ɹaɪɾ æftɝ ju, dʌznt ʃi?" daɪɛlɪn skaʊld, bʌt ʃi ɔfɝd noʊ dɪnaɪəlz.

"So they may all be waiting for Arymilla to win," Birgitte said grimly. "If you survive, they'll declare for you against her. If you don't, one of them will make her own claim. Ellorien has the next best right after you, doesn't she?" Dyelin scowled, but she offered no denials.

"æn ɛlɹin?" ɪleɪn æskt kwaɪətli. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi nu ði ænsɝ ðəɹ ɔlɹɛɾi. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd hæɾ ɛlɹin flɑɡd. ðət hæd bɪn ʌndɝ ɹɑvɪnz ɪnfluəns, bʌt fju sim tə bɪliv ðæt. fju sim tə bɪliv ɡeɪbɹəl hæɾ ivən bɪn ɹɑvɪn.

"And Ellorien?" Elayne asked quietly. She was sure she knew the answer there already. Her mother had had Ellorien flogged. That had been under Rahvin's influence, but few seemed to believe that. Few seemed to believe Gaebril had even been Rahvin.

daɪɛlɪn ɡɹɪməst. "ðə wʊmənz hɛɾ ɪz stoʊn! ʃiɾ ənaʊns ə kleɪm ɪn maɪ neɪm ɪf ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wəd də ɛni ɡʊd. ət list ʃiz ɪnʌf sɛns tə si ɪt woʊnt." ɪleɪn noʊɾəd ðət ʃi meɪd noʊ mɛnʃən ʌv ɛni kleɪmz ɪn ɛlɹinz oʊn neɪm. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, aɪ lɛf kɛɹeɪl sɝtɑvni ən dʒulənjə foʊt tə wɑtʃ ðɛm. aɪ daʊt ðəl muv, bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ du, wɪl noʊ stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ." θɹi kɪnswɪmən u niɾəd tə fɔɹm ə sɝkəl tə tʃɹævəl wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən.

Dyelin grimaced. "The woman's head is stone! She'd announce a claim in my name if she thought it would do any good. At least she has enough sense to see it won't." Elayne noted that she made no mention of any claims in Ellorien's own name. "In any case, I left Keraille Surtovni and Julanya Fote to watch them. I doubt they'll move, but if they do, we'll know straightaway." Three Kinswomen who needed to form a circle to Travel were watching the Borderlanders for the same reason.

noʊ ɡʊd nuz əɾ ɔl, ðɛn, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt feɪs daɪɛlɪn tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ ɑn ɪt. ɪleɪn hæd hoʊp ðə θɹɛɾ ə ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz wəd dʒɹaɪv səm ə ðə haʊsəz tə səpɔɹt hɝ. ət list wʌn ɹizən aɪ lɛɾ əm kɹɔs ændɝ stɪl hoʊlz, ʃi θɔt ɡɹɪmli. ivən ɪf ʃi feɪl tə ɡeɪn ðə θɹoʊn, ʃi hæd dʌn ðət sɝvəs fəɹ ændɝ. ənlɛs huɛvɝ dɪd teɪk ðə θɹoʊn bʌŋɡəl mæɾɝz kəmplitli. ʃi kəd si ɛɹəmɪlə duɪŋ dʒʌs ðæt. wɛl, ɛɹəmɪlə wɑz nɑt gɑnə wɛɹ ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn, ən ðət wɑz ðæt. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, ʃi hæd tə bi stɑpt.

No good news at all, then, no matter what face Dyelin tried to put on it. Elayne had hoped the threat of the Borderlanders would drive some of the Houses to support her. At least one reason I let them cross Andor still holds, she thought grimly. Even if she failed to gain the throne, she had done that service for Andor. Unless whoever did take the throne bungled matters completely. She could see Arymilla doing just that. Well, Arymilla was not going to wear the Rose Crown, and that was that. One way or another, she had to be stopped.

"soʊ ɪts sɪks, sɪks ən sɪks," kæɾəlɪn sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ ən θʌmɪŋ ðə lɔŋ sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ lɛf hænd. ʃi lʊk θɔtfəl, ənjuʒəwəl fəɹ hɝ. hɝ juʒəwəl staɪl wɑz tə spik əɹ maɪnd wɪð noʊ kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən wʌtsoʊɛvɝ. "ivən ɪf kændʒɹeɪd dʒɔɪnz ʌs, wəɹ ʃɔɹɾ ə tɛn." wɑz ʃi wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ʃi hæd taɪd hɛvɪn tə ə hoʊpləs kɑz? ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ʃi hæd nɑt taɪɾ əɹ haʊs soʊ taɪtli ðə nɑts kəd nɑt bi əndʌn.

"So it's six, six and six," Catalyn said, frowning and thumbing the long signet ring on her left hand. She looked thoughtful, unusual for her. Her usual style was to speak her mind with no consideration whatsoever. "Even if Candraed joins us, we are short of ten." Was she wondering whether she had tied Haevin to a hopeless cause? Unfortunately, she had not tied her House so tightly the knots could not be undone.

"aɪ wɑz sɝɾən lwɑn wəd dʒɔɪn ʌs," kɑneɪl mʌɾɝd. "æn æbəl ən pɛlɪvɑɹ." hi tʊk ə dip swɑloʊ ʌv waɪn. "wʌns wi biɾ ɛɹəmɪlə, ðəl kʌm. jə mɑɹk mi ɑn ɪt."

"I was certain Luan would join us," Conail muttered. "And Abelle and Pelivar." He took a deep swallow of wine. "Once we beat Arymilla, they'll come. You mark me on it."

"bʌt wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ θɪŋkɪŋ?" bɹænlət dɪmændəd. "ɑɹ ðeɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɑɹɾ ə wɔɹ wɪð θɹi saɪdz?" hɪz vɔɪs wɛn fɹəm tʃɹɛbəl tə bæs hæfweɪ θɹu ðæt, ən ɪz feɪs flʌɾəd wɪð ɹɛd. hi bɛɹiɾ ɪz feɪs ɪn ɪz ɡɑblət, bʌt ɡɹɪməst. əpɛɹənli hi laɪkt ɡoʊts mɪlk əz lɪɾəl əz ʃi dɪd.

"But what are they thinking?" Branlet demanded. "Are they trying to start a war with three sides?" His voice went from treble to bass halfway through that, and his face flooded with red. He buried his face in his goblet, but grimaced. Apparently he liked goat's milk as little as she did.

"ɪts ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz." pɛɝaɪvəlz vɔɪs wɑz ə bɔɪz paɪpɪŋ, bʌɾ i saʊndəd ʃʊɹ ə hɪmsɛlf. "ðeɪɹ hoʊldɪŋ bæk kəz huɛvɝ wɪnz hɪɹ, ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz stɪl əv tə bi dɛlt wɪð." hi pɪkt ʌp ðə bɛɹ, hɛftɪŋ ɪɾ əz ɪf ɪts weɪt wəd ɡɪv ɪm ænsɝz. "wʌɾ aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ɪz waɪ ðəɹ ɪnveɪɾɪŋ əs ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. wɝ soʊ fɑɹ fɹəm ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ən waɪ hævən ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt ɑn ən ətækt keɪɛmlɪn? ðeɪ kəd swip ɛɹəmɪlə əsaɪd, ən aɪ daʊt wi kəd kip əm aʊɾ əz izəli əz wi də hɝ. soʊ waɪ ɑɹ ðeɪ hɪɹ?"

"It's the Borderlanders." Perival's voice was a boy's piping, but he sounded sure of himself. "They're holding back because whoever wins here, the Borderlanders still have to be dealt with." He picked up the bear, hefting it as if its weight would give him answers. "What I don't understand is why they're invading us in the first place. We're so far from the Borderlands. And why haven't they marched on and attacked Caemlyn? They could sweep Arymilla aside, and I doubt we could keep them out as easily as we do her. So why are they here?"

smaɪlɪŋ, kɑneɪl klæpt ɪm ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ. "naʊ ðət wɪl bi ə bæɾəl tə si, wən wi feɪs ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz. nɔɹθənz iɡəlz ən mæntʃɹz ænvəl wɪl də ændɝ pɹaʊd ðət deɪ, ɛ?" pɛɝaɪvəl nɑɾəd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt lʊk hæpi ət ðə pɹɑspɛkt. kɑneɪl sɝɾənli dɪd.

Smiling, Conail clapped him on the shoulder. "Now that will be a battle to see, when we face the Borderlanders. Northan's Eagles and Mantear's Anvil will do Andor proud that day, eh?" Perival nodded, but he did not look happy at the prospect. Conail certainly did.

ɪleɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð daɪɛlɪn ən bɝdʒɪt, boʊθ ə hum lʊkt əmeɪzd. ɪleɪn fɛlt əstɑnɪʃt hɝsɛlf. ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən nu, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt lɪɾəl pɛɝaɪvəl hæd kʌm nɪɹ tʌtʃɪŋ ə sikɹət ðət hæd tə bi kɛpt. ʌðɝz maɪt pʌzəl aʊɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðət ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz hæd bɪn mɛn tə pʊʃ haʊsəz ɪndə dʒɔɪnɪŋ hɝ, bʌɾ ɪt mʌs nɑt bi kənfɝmd.

Elayne exchanged glances with Dyelin and Birgitte, both of whom looked amazed. Elayne felt astonished herself. The other two women knew, of course, but little Perival had come near touching a secret that had to be kept. Others might puzzle out eventually that the Borderlanders had been meant to push Houses into joining her, but it must not be confirmed.

"lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz sɛn tə ɛɹəmɪlə æskɪŋ fəɹ ə tʃɹus əntɪl ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz wɝ tɝn bæk," daɪɛlɪn sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "ʃi æsk taɪm tə kənsɪɾɝ. əz nɪɹ əz aɪ kən kælkjəleɪt, ɪt wɑz ðən ðət ʃi bɪɡæn ɪnkɹisɪŋ əɹ ɛfɝts ət ðə wɔlz. ʃi tɛlz əm ʃiz stɪl kənsɪɾɝɪŋ."

"Luan and the others sent to Arymilla asking for a truce until the Borderlanders were turned back," Dyelin said after a moment. "She asked time to consider. As near as I can calculate, it was then that she began increasing her efforts at the walls. She tells them she's still considering."

"əsaɪd fɹəm ɛniθɪŋ ɛls," kæɾəlɪn sɛd hiɾɪdli, "ðæt ʃoʊz waɪ ɛɹəmɪlə dʌzn dɪzɝv ðə θɹoʊn. ʃi pʊts əɹ oʊn æmbɪʃən əbʌv ændɝz seɪfti. lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz mʌs bi fulz nɑt tə si ɪt."

"Aside from anything else," Catalyn said heatedly, "that shows why Arymilla doesn't deserve the throne. She puts her own ambition above Andor's safety. Luan and the others must be fools not to see it."

"nɑt fulz," daɪɛlɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "dʒʌs mɛn ən wɪmən u θɪŋk ðeɪ si ðə fjutʃɝ bɛɾɝ ðən ðeɪ du."

"Not fools," Dyelin replied. "Just men and women who think they see the future better than they do."

wʌɾ ɪf ʃi ən daɪɛlɪn wɝ ðə wʌnz u wɝ nɑt siɪŋ ðə fjutʃɝ klɪɹli, ɪleɪn wʌndɝd. tə seɪv ændɝ, ʃi wʊɾə θɹoʊn əɹ səpɔɹt tə daɪɛlɪn. nɑt ɡlædli, bʌt tə seɪv ændɝz blʌd, ʃi wəd hæv. daɪɛlɪn wəɾ əv ðə səpɔɹɾ ə tɛn haʊsəz, mɔɹ ðən tɛn. ivən deɪnin kændʒɹeɪd maɪt faɪnəli dɪsaɪd tə stɝ hɝsɛlf ɪn səpɔɹɾ ə daɪɛlɪn. ɪksɛp ðət daɪɛlɪn dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi kwin. ʃi bɪliv ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑz ðə wʌn tə wɛɹ ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn. soʊ dɪɾ ɪleɪn. bʌt wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɹɔŋ? nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm ðət kwɛstʃən hæd kʌm tə hɝ, bʌt naʊ, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə mæp wɪð ɔl ʌv ɪts ɪl taɪɾɪŋz, ʃi kəd nɑt ʃeɪk fɹi ʌv ɪt.

What if she and Dyelin were the ones who were not seeing the future clearly, Elayne wondered. To save Andor, she would have thrown her support to Dyelin. Not gladly, but to save Andor's blood, she would have. Dyelin would have the support of ten Houses, more than ten. Even Danine Candraed might finally decide to stir herself in support of Dyelin. Except that Dyelin did not want to be queen. She believed that Elayne was the one to wear the Rose Crown. So did Elayne. But what if they were wrong? Not the first time that question had come to her, but now, staring at the map with all of its ill tidings, she could not shake free of it.

ðəɾ ivnɪŋ, æftɝ ə dɪnɝ mɛmɝəbəl oʊnli fəɹ ðə sɝpɹaɪz ə taɪni stʃɹɔbɛɹiz, ʃi sæɾ ɪn ðə lɑɹdʒ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ə hɝ əpɑɹtməns, ɹɛɾɪŋ. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹid. ðə lɛðɝ-baʊn bʊk wɑz ə hɪstɝi ʌv ændɝ, əz wɑz moʊst ə hɝ ɹɛɾɪŋ ə leɪt. ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə ɹiɾ əz mɛni əz pɑsəbəl tə ɡeɪn ɛni ɹil vɝʒən ə tʃɹuθ, kɹɔs-tʃɛkɪŋ wʌn əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ə bʊk fɝs pʌblɪʃt dʊɹɪŋ ɛni mɑnɑɹks ɹeɪn nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ɛni ʌv əɹ mɪsstɛps, əɹ ðoʊz ə hɝ ɪmiɾiət pɹɛɾəsɛsɝz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ə hɝ oʊn haʊs. jə hæd tə ɹid bʊks ɹɪɾən waɪl tʃɹəkən hɛl ðə θɹoʊn tə lɝn ə mæntʃɹz mɪsteɪks, ən bʊks ɹɪɾən ʌndɝ mæntʃɹ tə lɝn ə nɔɹwlɪnz ɛɹɝz. ʌðɝz' mɪsteɪks kəd titʃ əɹ haʊ nɑt tə meɪk ðə seɪm hɝsɛlf. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd meɪd ðəɾ ɔlmoʊst əɹ fɝs lɛsən.

That evening, after a dinner memorable only for the surprise of tiny strawberries, she sat in the large sitting room of her apartments, reading. Trying to read. The leather-bound book was a history of Andor, as was most of her reading of late. It was necessary to read as many as possible to gain any real version of truth, cross-checking one against another. For one thing, a book first published during any monarch's reign never mentioned any of her missteps, or those of her immediate predecessors if they were of her own House. You had to read books written while Trakand held the throne to learn of Mantear's mistakes, and books written under Mantear to learn of Norwelyn's errors. Others' mistakes could teach her how not to make the same herself. Her mother had made that almost her first lesson.

ʃi kəd nɑt kɑnsəntʃɹeɪt, haʊɛvɝ. ʃi ɔfən faʊn hɝsɛlf stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə peɪdʒ wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ə wɝd, θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɝ sɪstɝ, əɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ tə eɪvinhə bɪfɔɹ ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ. ʃi fɛl vɛɹi loʊnli, wɪtʃ wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs. sɛfæni stʊɾ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ əɡɛns ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʃi wɑntəɾ ɛniθɪŋ. eɪt ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɝ stændɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə dɔɹ tə ði əpɑɹtməns, ən wʌn ə ðɛm, jʊɹɪθ əzɛɹi, wɑz ən ɛksələn kɑnvɝseɪʃənələst, ən ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd wʊmən ðoʊ saɪlən ɑn əɹ pæst. bʌt nʌn ə ðɛm wɑz eɪvinhə.

She could not concentrate, however. She often found herself staring at a page without seeing a word, thinking of her sister, or starting to say something to Aviendha before remembering that she was not there. She felt very lonely, which was ridiculous. Sephanie stood in a corner against the possibility she wanted anything. Eight Guardswomen were standing outside the door to the apartments, and one of them, Yurith Azeri, was an excellent conversationalist, an educated woman though silent on her past. But none of them was Aviendha.

wən vændin ɡlaɪɾɪd ɪndə ðə ɹum fɑloʊd baɪ kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə, ɪt simd ə ɹɪlif. ðə tu waɪt-klæd wɪmən stɑp baɪ ðə dɔɹweɪ, ɪkspɹɛʃənz mik. əntʌtʃt baɪ ði oʊθ ɹɑd, peɪl kɝstʃən, hænz foʊldəɾ əɾ əɹ weɪst, əpɪɹd dʒʌst ɪndə hɝ mɪɾəl jɪɹz; zɛɹjə, wɪð əɹ tɪltəɾ aɪz ən hʊk noʊz, wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðɛm. ʃi hɛl sʌmθɪŋ ɹæpt ɪn waɪt taʊəlɪŋ.

When Vandene glided into the room followed by Kirstian and Zarya, it seemed a relief. The two white-clad women stopped by the doorway, expressions meek. Untouched by the Oath Rod, pale Kirstian, hands folded at her waist, appeared just into her middle years; Zarya, with her tilted eyes and hooked nose, well short of them. She held something wrapped in white toweling.

"fɝɡɪv mi ɪf aɪm ɪntɝʌptɪŋ," vændin bɪɡæn, ðən fɹaʊnd. ðə waɪt-hɛɹd ɡɹinz feɪs sʌmhaʊ ɡeɪv ən ɪmpɹɛʃən ʌv eɪdʒ dɪspaɪɾ əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ fitʃɝz. ðoʊz cʊɾə bɪn twɛnti, əɹ fɔɹɾi, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɪn bɪtwin; ðət sim tə tʃeɪnʒ əɾ ɛvɹi blɪŋk. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz əɹ dɑɹk aɪz, lumənəs ən dip ən peɪnd, wɪtʃ hæd sin soʊ mʌtʃ. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛɹ ə taɪɹədnəs əbaʊt hɝ, tu. hɝ bæk wɑz stʃɹeɪt, bʌt ʃi stɪl lʊkt wɪɹi. "ɪɾ ɪz nʌn ə maɪ bɪznəs, ʌv kɔɹs," ʃi sɛd dɛləkətli, "bʌɾ ɪz ðəɹ ə ɹizən jə ɑɹ hoʊldɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ ə ðə paʊɝ? aɪ θɔt jə mʌs bi wivɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi kɑmplɛks wən aɪ fɛl jə ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ."

"Forgive me if I'm interrupting," Vandene began, then frowned. The white-haired Green's face somehow gave an impression of age despite her Aes Sedai features. Those could have been twenty, or forty, or anything in between; that seemed to change at every blink. Perhaps it was her dark eyes, luminous and deep and pained, which had seen so much. There was an air of tiredness about her, too. Her back was straight, but she still looked weary. "It is none of my business, of course," she said delicately, "but is there a reason you are holding so much of the Power? I thought you must be weaving something very complex when I felt you in the corridor."

wɪð ə stɑɹt, ɪleɪn ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi hɛl nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ əz ʃi kəd kənteɪn seɪfli. haʊ hæd ðət hæpənd? ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹikɔl dʒɹɔɪŋ ɛni dipɝ. heɪstəli, ʃi ɹilis ðə sɔɹs, ɹəɡɹɛt fɪlɪŋ əɹ əz ðə paʊɝ dʒɹeɪn əweɪ ən ðə wɝl bɪkeɪm . . . ɔɹɾənɛɹi əɡɛn. ɑn ði ɪnstənt, hɝ mud baʊnst saɪdweɪz.

With a start, Elayne realized that she held nearly as much of saidar as she could contain safely. How had that happened? She did not recall drawing any deeper. Hastily, she released the Source, regret filling her as the Power drained away and the world became . . . ordinary again. On the instant, her mood bounced sideways.

"ju ɑɹən ɪntɝʌptɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ," ʃi sɛd pivɪʃli, sɛɾɪŋ əɹ bʊk daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. ʃi hæd nɑt fɪnɪʃt θɹi peɪdʒəz ə ðə θɪŋ ɛniweɪ.

"You aren't interrupting anything," she said peevishly, setting her book down on the table in front of her. She had not finished three pages of the thing anyway.

"meɪ aɪ meɪk əs pɹaɪvət, ðɛn?"

"May I make us private, then?"

ɪleɪn ɡeɪv ə kɝt nɑd - ɪt wɑz nʌn ə ðə wʊmənz blʌɾi bɪznəs haʊ mʌtʃ ə ðə paʊɝ ʃi hɛld; ʃi nu ðə pɹoʊɾəkɔlz əz wɛl əz ɪleɪn, əɹ bɛɾɝ - ən toʊl sɛfæni tə weɪɾ ɪn ði æntəɹum waɪl vændin woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ.

Elayne gave a curt nod - it was none of the woman's bloody business how much of the Power she held; she knew the protocols as well as Elayne, or better - and told Sephanie to wait in the anteroom while Vandene wove a ward against eavesdropping.

wɔɹɾ əɹ noʊ wɔɹd, vændin weɪɾəd əntɪl ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðə meɪd bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. "ɹin kɔɹli ɪz dɛd, ɪleɪn."

Ward or no ward, Vandene waited until the door closed behind the maid before speaking. "Reanne Corly is dead, Elayne."

"oʊ, laɪt, noʊ." tɛmpɝ vænɪʃt ɪndə sɑbz, ən ʃi heɪstəli snætʃt ə leɪs-ɛdʒ hæŋkɝtʃɪf fɹəm əɹ sliv tə blɑt ðə tɪɹz sʌɾənli stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃiks. hɝ kɝst ʃɪftɪŋ mudz ət wɝk, jɛt ɹin ʃʊɹli dɪzɝv tɪɹz. ʃi hæd soʊ wɑntəd tə bɪkʌm ə ɡɹin. "haʊ?" bɝn hɝ, ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd stɑp blʌbɝɪŋ!

"Oh, Light, no." Temper vanished into sobs, and she hastily snatched a lace-edged handkerchief from her sleeve to blot the tears suddenly streaming down her cheeks. Her cursed shifting moods at work, yet Reanne surely deserved tears. She had so wanted to become a Green. "How?" Burn her, she wished she could stop blubbering!

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tɪɹz fɹəm vændin. pɝhæps ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɔɹ tɪɹz ɪn hɝ. "ʃi wɑz smʌðɝd wɪð ðə paʊɝ. huɛvɝ dɪɾ ɪt juz mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən wɑz niɾəd. ðə ɹɛzəduz ə seɪaɪdɑɹ wɝ θɪk ɑn əɹ ən ɪn ðə ɹum wɛɹ ʃi wɑz faʊnd. ðə mɝɾɝɝ wɑntəd tə bi ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn wəd mɪs siɪŋ haʊ ʃi daɪd."

There were no tears from Vandene. Perhaps there were no more tears in her. "She was smothered with the Power. Whoever did it used much more than was needed. The residues of saidar were thick on her and in the room where she was found. The murderer wanted to be sure no one would miss seeing how she died."

"ðæt meɪks noʊ sɛns, vændin."

"That makes no sense, Vandene."

"pɝhæps ɪt dʌz. zɛɹjə?"

"Perhaps it does. Zarya?"

ðə sɑldəiən wʊmən leɪɾ əɹ smɔl bʌndəl ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən ənɹæpt ɪt tə ɹɪvil ən ɑɹtɪkjəleɪɾəd wʊɾən dɑl. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi oʊld, ðə sɪmpəl dʒɹɛs θɹɛdbɛɹ, ðə peɪntəd feɪs fleɪkɪŋ ən mɪsɪŋ ən aɪ, hæf ʌv ɪts lɔŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ ɡɔn.

The Saldaean woman laid her small bundle on the table and unwrapped it to reveal an articulated wooden doll. It was very old, the simple dress threadbare, the painted face flaking and missing an eye, half of its long dark hair gone.

"ðɪs bɪlɔŋ tə mɪɹɑn lɑɹənən," zɛɹjə sɛd. "dɛɹiz nɝmɑlə faʊn ɪt bɪhaɪn ə kʌbɝd."

"This belonged to Mirane Larinen," Zarya said. "Derys Nermala found it behind a cupboard."

"aɪ doʊn si wʌt mɪɹɑn livɪŋ ə dɑl bɪhaɪn əz tə də wɪð ɹinz dɛθ," ɪleɪn sɛd, waɪpɪŋ əɹ aɪz. mɪɹɑn wɑz wʌn ə ðə kɪnswɪmən u hæd ɹʌn əweɪ.

"I don't see what Mirane leaving a doll behind has to do with Reanne's death," Elayne said, wiping her eyes. Mirane was one of the Kinswomen who had run away.

"oʊnli ðɪs," vændin ænsɝd. "wɛn mɪɹɑn wɛn tə ðə taʊɝ, ʃi hɪd ðɪs dɑl aʊtsaɪd kəz ʃi hæd hɝd ðəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi oʊnd wəd bi bɝnd. æftɝ ʃi wɑz pʊɾ aʊt, ʃi ɹitʃɹivd ɪɾ ən ɔlweɪz kæɹiɾ ɪt wɪð hɝ. ɔlweɪz. ʃi hæɾ ə kwɝk, ðoʊ. wɛɹɛvɝ ʃi stɑp fəɹ ə taɪm, ʃi hɪd ðə dɑl əɡɛn. də nɑɾ æsk mi waɪ. bʌt ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ɹʌn əweɪ ən əbændən ɪt."

"Only this," Vandene answered. "When Mirane went to the Tower, she hid this doll outside because she had heard that everything she owned would be burned. After she was put out, she retrieved it and always carried it with her. Always. She had a quirk, though. Wherever she stopped for a time, she hid the doll again. Do not ask me why. But she would not have run away and abandoned it."

stɪl dæbɪŋ əɾ əɹ aɪz, ɪleɪn lin bæk ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. hɝ wipɪŋ hæd dwɪndəl tə snɪfəlz, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz stɪl lik tɪɹz. "soʊ mɪɹɑn dɪdn ɹʌn əweɪ. ʃi wɑz mɝɾɝd ən . . . dɪspoʊzd ʌv." ə ɡɹɪzli weɪ tə pʊɾ ɪt. "ði ʌðɝz, tu, jə θɪŋk? ɔl ə ðɛm?"

Still dabbing at her eyes, Elayne leaned back in her chair. Her weeping had dwindled to sniffles, but her eyes still leaked tears. "So Mirane didn't run away. She was murdered and . . . disposed of." A grisly way to put it. "The others, too, you think? All of them?"

vændin nɑɾəd, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən əɹ slɛndɝ ʃoʊldɝz slʌmpt. "aɪ vɛɹi mʌtʃ fɪɹ soʊ," ʃi sɛd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ. "aɪ ɪkspɛkt kluz wɝ lɛft əmʌŋ ðə θɪŋz ðeɪ lɛf bɪhaɪnd, tʃɹɛʒɝd kipseɪks laɪk ðɪs dɑl, ə feɪvɹɪt pis ə dʒuəlɹi. ðə mɝɾɝɝ wɑntəɾ əs tə θɪŋk ʃi wɑz biɪŋ klɛvɝ ət haɪɾɪŋ əɹ kɹaɪmz bʌt nɑt klɛvɝ ɪnʌf, oʊnli wi wɝn klɛvɝ ɪnʌf tə faɪn ðoʊz kluz, soʊ ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bɪkʌm mɔɹ bleɪɾənt."

Vandene nodded, and for a moment her slender shoulders slumped. "I very much fear so," she said, straightening. "I expect clues were left among the things they left behind, treasured keepsakes like this doll, a favorite piece of jewelry. The murderer wanted us to think she was being clever at hiding her crimes but not clever enough, only we weren't clever enough to find those clues, so she decided to become more blatant."

"tə fɹaɪɾən ðə kɪnswɪmən ɪndə fliɪŋ," ɪleɪn mʌɾɝd. ðət wəd nɑt kɹɪpəl hɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wəd θɹoʊ hɝ bæk ɑn ðə mɝsiz ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, ən ðoʊz sim tə bi ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɪnʒi. "haʊ mɛni ʌv əm noʊ ʌv ðɪs?"

"To frighten the Kinswomen into fleeing," Elayne muttered. That would not cripple her, but it would throw her back on the mercies of the Windfinders, and those seemed to be growing mingy. "How many of them know of this?"

"ɔl, baɪ naʊ, aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk," vændin sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "zɛɹjə toʊl dɛɹiz tə kip kwaɪət, bʌt ðət wʊmən laɪks ðə saʊn ə hɝ oʊn vɔɪs."

"All, by now, I should think," Vandene said dryly. "Zarya told Derys to keep quiet, but that woman likes the sound of her own voice."

"ðɪs simz eɪmd ət mi, ət hɛlpɪŋ ɛɹəmɪlə ɡeɪn ðə θɹoʊn, bʌt waɪ wəɾ ə blæk sɪstɝ əv ɛni ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ðæt? aɪ kæn θɪŋk wɪv tu mɝɾɝɝz əmʌŋ ʌs. ət lis ðɪs sɛɾəlz ðə kwɛstʃən ə mɛɝɪlɪl. spik wɪð sumeɪkoʊ ən æləz, vændin. ðeɪ kən meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə ɹɛs doʊn pænɪk." sumeɪkoʊ ɹæŋk nɛkst æftɝ ɹin, əz ðə kɪn ɔɹɾɝd ðɛɹ haɪɝɑɹki, ən waɪl æləz stʊd mʌtʃ loʊɝ, ʃi wɑz ə wʊmən ʌv ɡɹeɪɾ ɪnfluəns. "fɹʌm naʊ ɑn, nʌn ə ðɛm ɪz tə bi əloʊn, nɑɾ ɛvɝ. ɔlweɪz ət lis tu təɡɛðɝ, ən θɹi əɹ fɔɹ wəd bi bɛɾɝ. ən wɔɹn əm tə bi kɛɹfəl ə kɛɝin ən sɝaɪðə."

"This seems aimed at me, at helping Arymilla gain the throne, but why would a Black sister have any interest in that? I can't think we have two murderers among us. At least this settles the question of Merilille. Speak with Sumeko and Alise, Vandene. They can make sure the rest don't panic." Sumeko ranked next after Reanne, as the Kin ordered their hierarchy, and while Alise stood much lower, she was a woman of great influence. "From now on, none of them is to be alone, not ever. Always at least two together, and three or four would be better. And warn them to be careful of Careane and Sareitha."

"aɪɾ ædvaɪz əɡɛns ðæt," vændin sɛd kwɪkli. "ðeɪ ʃəd bi seɪf ɪn ɡɹups, ən wɝd wəd ɹitʃ kɛɝin ən sɝaɪðə. wɔɹn əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ? ðə kɪn wəd ɡɪv ðɛmsɛlvz əweɪ ɪn ə mɪnət." kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə nɑɾəd sɔləmli.

"I'd advise against that," Vandene said quickly. "They should be safe in groups, and word would reach Careane and Sareitha. Warned against Aes Sedai? The Kin would give themselves away in a minute." Kirstian and Zarya nodded solemnly.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ɪleɪn ɹɪlʌktənli əɡɹid tə ðə kəntɪnjud sikɹəsi. ðə kɪn ʃəd bi seɪf ɪn ɡɹups. "lɛt tʃənɛl noʊ əbaʊt ɹin ən ði ʌðɝz. aɪ kæn ɪmædʒən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ɑɹ ɪn ɛni deɪnʒɝ - luzɪŋ əm wʊdn hɝt mi ðə weɪ luzɪŋ ðə kɪn wəd - bʌt wʊdn ɪt bi wʌndɝfəl ɪf ðeɪ dɪd dɪsaɪd tə liv?"

After a moment, Elayne reluctantly agreed to the continued secrecy. The Kin should be safe in groups. "Let Chanelle know about Reanne and the others. I can't imagine the Windfinders are in any danger - losing them wouldn't hurt me the way losing the Kin would - but wouldn't it be wonderful if they did decide to leave?"

ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk ðət ðeɪ wəd - tʃənɛl fɪɹd ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə si foʊk wɪð ðə bɑɹɡən ʌnfʊlfɪld - jɛɾ ɪt wəd bi ə bɹaɪt spɑɾ ɪn ən ʌðɝwaɪz mɪzɝəbəl deɪ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd. ət list ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ɛniθɪŋ kəd dɑɹkən ðə deɪ fɝðɝ. ðə θɔt sɛn ə tʃɪl θɹu hɝ. ðə laɪt sɛnd nʌθɪŋ wəd dɑɹkən ɪt mɔɹ.

She did not expect that they would - Chanelle feared returning to the Sea Folk with the bargain unfulfilled - yet it would be a bright spot in an otherwise miserable day if they did. At least it seemed unlikely anything could darken the day further. The thought sent a chill through her. The Light send nothing would darken it more.

ɛɹəmɪlə pʊʃt əɹ pleɪɾ ə stu əweɪ wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs. ʃi hæd bɪn ɔfɝɾ əɹ tʃɔɪs ə bɛdz fəɹ ðə naɪt - ɑɹlin, hɝ meɪd, wɑz meɪkɪŋ ðə tʃɔɪs naʊ; ðə wʊmən nu wʌt ʃi laɪkt - ən ðə list ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd wɑz ə disən mil, bʌt ðə mʌɾən wɑz fæɾi, ən dɛfənətli bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɡoʊ ɹænsɪd bɪsaɪdz. ðəɹ hæd bɪn tu mʌtʃ ə ðət leɪtli. ðɪs taɪm ðə kʊk wɑz gɑnə bi flɑɡd! ʃi wɑz ənʃʊɹ wɪtʃ ə ðə noʊbəlz ɪn ðɪs kæmp ɛmplɔɪd hɪm, dʒʌs ðəɾ i wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ðə bɛst ət hænd - ðə bɛst! - bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. hi wəd bi flɑɡd tə meɪk ən ɪɡzæmpəl. ən ðən sɛn əweɪ, ʌv kɔɹs. jə kəd nɛvɝ tʃɹʌst ə kʊk æftɝ i hæd bɪn pʌnɪʃt.

Arymilla pushed her plate of stew away with a grimace. She had been offered her choice of beds for the night - Arlene, her maid, was making the choice now; the woman knew what she liked - and the least she had expected was a decent meal, but the mutton was fatty, and definitely beginning to go rancid besides. There had been too much of that lately. This time the cook was going to be flogged! She was unsure which of the nobles in this camp employed him, just that he was supposed to be the best at hand - the best! - but that did not matter. He would be flogged to make an example. And then sent away, of course. You could never trust a cook after he had been punished.

ðə muɾ ɪn ðə tɛnt wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm laɪvli. sɛvɹəl ə ðə noʊbəlz ɪn ðə kæmp hæd hoʊp fəɹ ɪnvɪteɪʃənz tə daɪn wɪð hɝ, bʌt nʌn stʊd haɪ ɪnʌf. ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹəɡɹɛt nɑɾ æskɪŋ wʌn əɹ tu, ivən səm ə nɑiənz əɹ ɛləniəz pipəl. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn ɛntɝteɪnɪŋ. hɝ kloʊsəst ælaɪz ət teɪbəl təɡɛðɝ, ən jə maɪɾ əv θɔt ðeɪ sæɾ oʊvɝ fjunɝəl mits. oʊ, skɹɔni oʊl næsən, hɪz θɪnɪŋ waɪt hɛɹ ʌnkoʊmd, wɑz iɾɪŋ əweɪ hɑɹɾəli, əpɛɹənli nɑt noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðət ðə mit wɑz nɪɹli ɹɑɾən, ən ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ fɑðɝli pæts ɑn ðə hænd. ʃi mɛɾ ɪz smaɪlz laɪk ə duɾifəl dɔɾɝ. ðə ful wɑz wɛɹɪŋ wʌn ə hɪz flaʊɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd koʊts tənaɪt. ðə θɪŋ cʊɾə pæs fəɹ ə wʊmənz dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹoʊb! hæpəli, hɪz lɪɹz wɝ ɔl dɝɛktəd daʊn ðə teɪbəl əɾ ɛləniə; ðə hʌni-hɛɹd wʊmən flɪntʃt, hɝ fɑkslaɪk feɪs pælɪŋ wɛnɛvɝ ʃi ɡlænst ət hɪm. ʃi kəntʃɹoʊl haʊs sɑɝən əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ðə haɪ siɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə hɝ hʌzbənd, jɛt ʃi fɪɹd ðəɾ ɛɹəmɪlə wəd stɪl lɛt næsən əv ɪz weɪ wɪð hɝ. ðət θɹɛt wɑz ənniɾɪd, naʊ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz wɛl tə hæv ɪt tə hæn dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. jɛs, næsən wɑz hæpi ɪnʌf ɪn ɪz fjuɾəl pɝsuɾ ʌv ɛləniə, bʌt ði ʌðɝz wɝ sʌŋk ɪn ɡlum. ðɛɹ pleɪts wɝ əbændən bɛɹli tʌtʃt, ən ðeɪ kɛpt əɹ tu sɝvɪŋ mɛn tʃɹɑɾɪŋ tə ɹifɪl waɪn kʌps. ʃi nɛvɝ laɪk tʃɹʌstɪŋ ʌðɝz' sɝvəns. ət lis ðə waɪn hæd nɑt tɝnd.

The mood in the tent was far from lively. Several of the nobles in the camp had hoped for invitations to dine with her, but none stood high enough. She was beginning to regret not asking one or two, even some of Naean's or Elenia's people. They might have been entertaining. Her closest allies at table together, and you might have thought they sat over funeral meats. Oh, scrawny old Nasin, his thinning white hair uncombed, was eating away heartily, apparently not noticing that the meat was nearly rotten, and giving her fatherly pats on the hand. She met his smiles like a dutiful daughter. The fool was wearing one of his flower-embroidered coats tonight. The thing could have passed for a woman's dressing robe! Happily, his leers were all directed down the table at Elenia; the honey-haired woman flinched, her foxlike face paling whenever she glanced at him. She controlled House Sarand as if she were the High Seat instead of her husband, yet she feared that Arymilla would still let Nasin have his way with her. That threat was unneeded, now, but it was well to have it to hand just in case. Yes, Nasin was happy enough in his futile pursuit of Elenia, but the others were sunk in gloom. Their plates were abandoned barely touched, and they kept her two serving men trotting to refill wine cups. She never liked trusting others' servants. At least the wine had not turned.

"aɪ stɪl seɪ wi ʃəd meɪk ə hɛviɝ pʊʃ," lɝ ɡɹʌmbəl dʒɹʌŋkənli ɪndə hɪz kʌp. ə wɪp ʌv ə mæn, hɪz ɹɛd koʊt ʃoʊɪŋ ðə wɛɹ ʌv ɑɹmɝ stʃɹæps, ðə haɪ siɾ ə bɛɹɪn wɑz ɛvɝ iɡɝ tə stʃɹaɪk. sʌɾəlti wɑz sɪmpli bɪɑn hɪm. "maɪ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɹipɔɹt mɔɹ ɑɹmmɪn ɛntɝɪŋ ðə sɪɾi ɛvɹi deɪ θɹu ðiz 'ɡeɪtweɪz.' " hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. ðə mæn æktʃəli  bɪliv ðoʊz ɹumɝz ə dʌzənz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs. "ɔl ðiz pɪnpɹɪk ətæks də ɪz luz mɛn."

"I still say we should make a heavier push," Lir grumbled drunkenly into his cup. A whip of a man, his red coat showing the wear of armor straps, the High Seat of Baryn was ever eager to strike. Subtlety was simply beyond him. "My eyes-and-ears report more armsmen entering the city every day through these 'gateways.' " He shook his head and muttered something under his breath. The man actually believed those rumors of dozens of Aes Sedai in the Royal Palace. "All these pinprick attacks do is lose men."

"aɪ əɡɹi," kɑɝɪn sɛd, fɪdlɪŋ wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ ɡoʊldən pɪn, ɪnæməld wɪð ðə ɹʌnɪŋ ɹɛd fɑks ʌv ænʃɝ, ðət wɑz fæsən tə hɝ bʊzəm. ʃi wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ lɛs ɪntɑksəkeɪɾəd ðən lɝ. hɝ skwɛɹ feɪs hæɾ ə slæknəs əbaʊɾ ɪt. "wi nid tə pɹɛs hoʊm ɪnstɛɾ ə θɹoʊɪŋ mɛn əweɪ. wʌns wɝ oʊvɝ ðə wɔlz, əɹ ædvæntɪdʒ ɪn nʌmbɝz wɪl peɪ ɔf."

"I agree," Karind said, fiddling with a large golden pin, enameled with the running Red Fox of Anshar, that was fastened to her bosom. She was not much less intoxicated than Lir. Her square face had a slackness about it. "We need to press home instead of throwing men away. Once we're over the walls, our advantage in numbers will pay off."

ɛɹəmɪləz maʊθ taɪɾənd. ðeɪ maɪɾ ət list ʃoʊ hɝ ðə ɹɪspɛk du ə wʊmən u wɑz sun tə bi kwin ʌv ændɝ, ɹæðɝ ðən dɪsəɡɹiɪŋ wɪð əɹ ɔl ðə taɪm. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, bɛɹɪn ən ænʃɝ wɝ nɑt baʊn tə hɝ soʊ taɪtli əz sɑɝən ən ɑɝɔn. ənlaɪk dʒɑɝɪɾ ən nɑiən, lɝ ən kɑɝɪn hæɾ ənaʊns ðɛɹ səpɔɹɾ ə hɝ wɪθaʊt pʌblɪʃɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ. niðɝ hæd næsən, bʌt ʃi hæd noʊ fɪɹ ə luzɪŋ hɪm. hɪm, ʃi hæd waʊn ɝaʊn əɹ ɹɪs fəɹ ə bɹeɪslət.

Arymilla's mouth tightened. They might at least show her the respect due a woman who was soon to be Queen of Andor, rather than disagreeing with her all the time. Unfortunately, Baryn and Anshar were not bound to her so tightly as Sarand and Arawn. Unlike Jarid and Naean, Lir and Karind had announced their support of her without publishing it in writing. Neither had Nasin, but she had no fear of losing him. Him, she had wound around her wrist for a bracelet.

fɔɹsɪŋ ə smaɪl, ʃi meɪɾ əɹ vɔɪs dʒoʊviəl. "wi luz mɝsənɛɹiz. wʌɾ ɛls ɑɹ mɝsənɛɹiz ɡʊd fəɹ ɪf nɑt daɪɪŋ ɪn pleɪs ʌv əɹ ɑɹmmɪn?" ʃi hɛld ʌp əɹ waɪnkʌp ən ə lin mæn ɪn əɹ sɪlvɝ-tʃɹɪm blu heɪsən tə fɪl ɪt. ɪn fækt, hi wɑz soʊ heɪsti ðəɾ i spɪld ə dʒɹɑp ɑn əɹ hænd. hɝ skaʊl meɪɾ ɪm snætʃ ə hæŋkɝtʃɪf fɹəm ɪz pɑkət tə blɑɾ ʌp ðə dʒɹɑp bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd pʊl əɹ hæn əweɪ. hɪz hæŋkɝtʃɪf! ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu wɛɹ ðət fɪlθi θɪŋ hæd bɪn, ən i hæd tʌtʃt əɹ wɪð ɪt! hɪz maʊθ ɹɪθd wɪð fɪɹ əz i ɹitʃɹiɾəd, boʊɪŋ ən mʌmbəlɪŋ əpɑlədʒiz. lɛɾ ɪm sɝv aʊt ðə mil. hi kəd bi dɪsmɪst æftɝ. "wi wɪl niɾ ɔl ʌv əɹ ɑɹmmɪn wən aɪ ɹaɪɾ əɡɛns ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz. doʊn jə əɡɹi, nɑiən?"

Forcing a smile, she made her voice jovial. "We lose mercenaries. What else are mercenaries good for if not dying in place of our armsmen?" She held up her winecup and a lean man in her silver-trimmed blue hastened to fill it. In fact, he was so hasty that he spilled a drop on her hand. Her scowl made him snatch a handkerchief from his pocket to blot up the drop before she could pull her hand away. His handkerchief! The Light only knew where that filthy thing had been, and he had touched her with it! His mouth writhed with fear as he retreated, bowing and mumbling apologies. Let him serve out the meal. He could be dismissed after. "We will need all of our armsmen when I ride against the Borderlanders. Don't you agree, Naean?"

nɑiən twɪtʃt əz ðoʊ stʌk wɪð ə pɪn. slɪm ən peɪl ɪn jɛloʊ sɪlk wɝkt wɪð sɪlvɝ pæɾɝnz ʌv ɑɝɔnz tʃɹɪpəl kiz ɑn ðə bɹɛst, ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn lʊkɪŋ hæɡɝɾ ɪn ɹisənt wiks, hɝ blu aɪz dʒɹɔn ən taɪɝd. ɔl ə hɝ supɝsɪliəs ɛɹz wɝ kwaɪt ɡɔn. "ʌv kɔɹs, ɛɹəmɪlə," ʃi sɛd mikli ən dʒɹeɪn əɹ kʌp. ɡʊd. ʃi ən ɛləniə wɝ dɛfənətli teɪmd, bʌɾ ɛɹəmɪlə laɪk tə tʃɛk naʊ ən ðən tə meɪk ʃʊɹ niðɝ wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ə nu bækboʊn.

Naean twitched as though stuck with a pin. Slim and pale in yellow silk worked with silver patterns of Arawn's Triple Keys on the breast, she had begun looking haggard in recent weeks, her blue eyes drawn and tired. All of her supercilious airs were quite gone. "Of course, Arymilla," she said meekly and drained her cup. Good. She and Elenia were definitely tamed, but Arymilla liked to check now and then to make sure neither was growing a new backbone.

"ɪf lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz wɪl nɑt səpɔɹt ju, wʌt ɡʊd wɪl teɪkɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn du?" sɪlveɪs, næsənz ɡɹændɔɾɝ ən ɛɹ, spoʊk soʊ sɛldəm ðət ðə kwɛstʃən keɪm əz ə ʃɑk. stɝɾi ən nɑt kwaɪt pɹɪɾi, ʃi juʒəwəli hæɾ ə væpɪd ɡeɪz, bʌɾ əɹ blu aɪz əpɪɹd kwaɪt ʃɑɹp ət ðə moʊmənt. ɛvɹiwʌn stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. ðət sim nɑt tə feɪz əɹ ə bɪt. ʃi tɔɪd wɪð ə waɪnkʌp, bʌɾ ɛɹəmɪlə θɔɾ ɪt noʊ mɔɹ ðən əɹ sɛkənd. "ɪf wi mʌs faɪt ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz, waɪ nɑɾ æksɛp lwɑnz tʃɹus soʊ ændɝ kən fild ɪts fʊl stʃɹɛŋkθ ənhɪndɝd baɪ dɪvɪʒənz?"

"If Luan and the others will not support you, what good will taking Caemlyn do?" Sylvase, Nasin's granddaughter and heir, spoke so seldom that the question came as a shock. Sturdy and not quite pretty, she usually had a vapid gaze, but her blue eyes appeared quite sharp at the moment. Everyone stared at her. That seemed not to faze her a bit. She toyed with a winecup, but Arymilla thought it no more than her second. "If we must fight the Borderlanders, why not accept Luan's truce so Andor can field its full strength unhindered by divisions?"

ɛɹəmɪlə smaɪld. ʃi wɑntəd tə slæp ðə sɪli wʊmən. næsən wəd bi æŋɡɝd baɪ ðæt, haʊɛvɝ. hi wɑntəɾ əɹ kɛpt əz ɛɹəmɪləz "ɡɛst" tə pɹɪvɛn ɪz ɹɪmuvəl əz haɪ sit - pɑɹɾ ə hɪm simd əwɛɹ ðəɾ ɪz wɪts wɝ ɡɔn; ɔl ə hɪm ɪntɛndəd hoʊldɪŋ ɑn əz haɪ siɾ əntɪl i daɪd - bʌɾ i dɪd lʌv hɝ. "ɛlɹin ən səm ə ði ʌðɝz wɪl kʌm tə mi jɛt, tʃaɪld," ʃi sɛd smuðli. smuðnəs ɹikwaɪɝd səm ɛfɝt. hu dɪd ðə tʃɪt θɪŋk ʃi wɑz? "æɛmlɪn, ɑɝəθɛl, pɛlɪvɑɹ. ðeɪv ɡɹivənsəz əɡɛns tʃɹəkənd." ʃʊɹli ðeɪ wəd kʌm wʌns ɪleɪn ən daɪɛlɪn wɝ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. ðoʊz tu wəd nɑt sɝvaɪv keɪɛmlɪnz fɔl. "wʌns aɪ hæv ðə sɪɾi, ðəl bi maɪn ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt. θɹi ʌv ɪleɪnz səpɔɹɾɝz ɑɹ tʃɪlʒɹən, ən kɑneɪl nɔɹθən ɪz lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə tʃaɪld. aɪ tʃɹʌst aɪ kən kənvɪns əm tə pʌblɪʃ ðɛɹ səpɔɹɾ ə mi izəli ɪnʌf." ən ɪf ʃi kəd nɑt, mæstɝ laʊnɔlt ʃʊɹli kʊd. ə pɪɾi ɪf tʃɪlʒɹən hæd tə bi hændəɾ oʊvɝ tə hɪm ən ɪz kɔɹdz. "aɪ wɪl bi kwin baɪ sʌnsɛɾ ə ðə deɪ keɪɛmlɪn fɔlz tə mi. ɪzən ðət ɹaɪt, fɑðɝ?"

Arymilla smiled. She wanted to slap the silly woman. Nasin would be angered by that, however. He wanted her kept as Arymilla's "guest" to prevent his removal as High Seat - part of him seemed aware that his wits were gone; all of him intended holding on as High Seat until he died - but he did love her. "Ellorien and some of the others will come to me yet, child," she said smoothly. Smoothness required some effort. Who did the chit think she was? "Aemlyn, Arathelle, Pelivar. They have grievances against Trakand." Surely they would come once Elayne and Dyelin were out of the way. Those two would not survive Caemlyn's fall. "Once I have the city, they will be mine in any event. Three of Elayne's supporters are children, and Conail Northan is little more than a child. I trust I can convince them to publish their support of me easily enough." And if she could not, Master Lounalt surely could. A pity if children had to be handed over to him and his cords. "I will be queen by sunset of the day Caemlyn falls to me. Isn't that right, father?"

næsən læft, spɹeɪɪŋ ɡɑbɛts ə hæf-tʃud stu əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl. "jɛs, jɛs," hi sɛd, pæɾɪŋ ɛɹəmɪləz hænd. "ju lɪsən tə jəɹ ænt, sɪlveɪs. də əz ʃi tɛlz ju. ʃɪl bi kwin ʌv ændɝ sun." hɪz smaɪl feɪɾəd, ən ən ɑd noʊɾ ɛntɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. ɪt maɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əv bɪn . . . pliɾɪŋ. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ, jəl bi haɪ siɾ ə kɝən æftɝ aɪm ɡɔn. æftɝ aɪm ɡɔn. jəl bi haɪ sit."

Nasin laughed, spraying gobbets of half-chewed stew across the table. "Yes, yes," he said, patting Arymilla's hand. "You listen to your aunt, Sylvase. Do as she tells you. She'll be Queen of Andor soon." His smile faded, and an odd note entered his voice. It might almost have been . . . pleading. "Remember, you will be High Seat of Caeren after I'm gone. After I'm gone. You will be High Seat."

"æz jə seɪ, ɡɹændfɑðɝ," sɪlveɪs mɝmɝd, ɪnklaɪnɪŋ əɹ hɛd bɹifli. wən ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd, hɝ ɡeɪz wɑz əz ɪnsɪpəɾ əz ɛvɝ. ðə ʃɑɹpnəs mʌst əv bɪn ə tʃɹɪk ə ðə laɪt. ʌv kɔɹs.

"As you say, Grandfather," Sylvase murmured, inclining her head briefly. When she straightened, her gaze was as insipid as ever. The sharpness must have been a trick of the light. Of course.

næsən ɡɹʌntɪɾ ən wɛn hæpəli bæk tə wʊlfɪŋ daʊn ðə stu. "bɛst aɪv hæɾ ɪn deɪz. aɪ θɪŋk əl əv ənʌðɝ pleɪt. mɔɹ waɪn hɪɹ, mæn. kæn jə si maɪ kʌps dʒɹaɪ?"

Nasin grunted and went happily back to wolfing down the stew. "Best I've had in days. I think I'll have another plate. More wine here, man. Can't you see my cup's dry?"

ðə saɪləns ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl stʃɹɛtʃt ɪn dɪskʌmfɝt. næsənz mɔɹ oʊpən dɪspleɪz ə sənɪləɾi hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv kɑzɪŋ ðæt.

The silence around the table stretched in discomfort. Nasin's more open displays of senility had a way of causing that.

"aɪ stɪl seɪ," lɝ bɪɡæn faɪnəli, oʊnli tə kʌɾ ɔf əz ə stɑki ɑɹmsmən wɪð mɑɹnz fɔɹ sɪlvɝ munz ɑn ɪz tʃɛst ɛntɝd ðə tɛnt.

"I still say," Lir began finally, only to cut off as a stocky armsman with Marne's four Silver Moons on his chest entered the tent.

boʊɪŋ ɹɪspɛkfəli, ðə fɛloʊ meɪɾ ɪz weɪ ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl ən bɛn tə wɪspɝ ɪn ɛɹəmɪləz ɪɹ. "mæstɝ hɝnvəl æsks ə wɝɾ ɪn pɹaɪvət, maɪ leɪɾi."

Bowing respectfully, the fellow made his way around the table and bent to whisper in Arymilla's ear. "Master Hernvil asks a word in private, my Lady."

ɛvɹiwʌn bʌt næsən ən ɪz ɡɹændɔɾɝ pɹitɛndəd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ðɛɹ waɪn, sɝɾənli nɑɾ ətɛmptɪŋ tə ivzdʒɹɑp. hi wɛn ɑn iɾɪŋ. ʃi wɑtʃt ɛɹəmɪlə, blænd-feɪst. ðət ʃɑɹpnəs mʌst əv bɪn ə tʃɹɪk ə ðə laɪt.

Everyone but Nasin and his granddaughter pretended to concentrate on their wine, certainly not attempting to eavesdrop. He went on eating. She watched Arymilla, bland-faced. That sharpness must have been a trick of the light.

"aɪl bi bʌɾ ə fju moʊməns," ɛɹəmɪlə sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. ʃi weɪvd ə hænd, ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ ðə fuɾ ən waɪn. "ɛndʒɔɪ jʊɹsɛlvz əntɪl aɪ ɹɪtɝn. ɛndʒɔɪ." lɝ kɔl fəɹ mɔɹ waɪn.

"I'll be but a few moments," Arymilla said, rising. She waved a hand, indicating the food and wine. "Enjoy yourselves until I return. Enjoy." Lir called for more wine.

aʊtsaɪd, ʃi dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ skɝts tə kip əm klɪɹ ə ðə mʌd. ɑɹlin wəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæv tə klin ðɛm, soʊ wʌɾ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ mʌd mæɾɝ? laɪt ʃoʊɾ ɪn səm tɛns, bʌt baɪ ən lɑɹdʒ ðə kæmp wɑz dɑɹk bɪniθ ə hæf mun. dʒækəb hɝnvəl, hɝ sɛkɹətɛɹi, weɪɾəd ə lɪɾəl əweɪ fɹəm ðə tɛn ɪn ə pleɪn koʊt, hoʊldɪŋ ə læntɝn ðət meɪɾ ə jɛloʊ pul ɝaʊn hɪm. hi wɑz ə lɪɾəl mæn, ən lin, əz ɪf ɔl ðə fæt hæd bɪn bɔɪl fɹəm hɪm. dɪskɹɛʃən wɑz bɹɛɾ ɪn ɪz boʊnz, ən ʃi ɛnʃʊɹɾ ɪz lɔɪəlti baɪ peɪɪŋ ɪm ɪnʌf ðəɾ oʊnli ðə lɑɹdʒəs bɹaɪbz kəd bi ʌv ɪntʃɹəst, fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ɛniwʌn wəɾ ɔfɝ ə skɹɪvnɝ.

Outside, she did not bother raising her skirts to keep them clear of the mud. Arlene would already have to clean them, so what did a little more mud matter? Light showed in some tents, but by and large the camp was dark beneath a half moon. Jakob Hernvil, her secretary, waited a little away from the tent in a plain coat, holding a lantern that made a yellow pool around him. He was a little man, and lean, as if all the fat had been boiled from him. Discretion was bred in his bones, and she ensured his loyalty by paying him enough that only the largest bribes could be of interest, far more than anyone would offer a scrivener.

"fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ ɪntɝʌptɪŋ jəɹ mil, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd wɪð ə baʊ, "bʌɾ aɪ wɑz ʃʊɹ jə wəd wɑnə hɪɹ ɹaɪɾ əweɪ." ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz ə sɝpɹaɪz, hɪɹɪŋ sətʃ ə dip vɔɪs fɹəm sətʃ ə taɪni mæn. "ðeɪ hæv əɡɹid. bʌt ðeɪ wɑn ðə hoʊl əmaʊn ʌv ɡoʊl fɝst."

"Forgive me for interrupting your meal, my Lady," he said with a bow, "but I was sure you would want to hear right away." It was always a surprise, hearing such a deep voice from such a tiny man. "They have agreed. But they want the whole amount of gold first."

hɝ lɪps kəmpɹɛst ə ðɛɹ oʊn əkɔɹd. ðə hoʊl əmaʊnt. ʃi hæd hoʊp tə ɡɛɾ ɔf wɪð peɪɪŋ oʊnli ðə fɝs hæf. æftɝ ɔl, hu wəd dɛɹ dʌn əɹ wʌns ʃi wɑz kwin? "dʒɹɔ ʌp ə lɛɾɝ tə mɪstʃɹəs ændskeɪl. əl saɪn ən sil ɪt fɝs θɪŋ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ." tʃɹænsfɝɪŋ ðət mʌtʃ ɡoʊld wəd ɹikwaɪɝ deɪz. ən haʊ lɔŋ tə hæv ði ɑɹmmɪn ɹɛɾi? ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɹɪli peɪɾ ətɛnʃən tə ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ. lɝ kəd tɛl hɝ, bʌt ʃi heɪɾəd ʃoʊɪŋ wiknəs. "tɛl əm ə wik fɹəm təmɑɹoʊ, tə ðə deɪ." ðət ʃəd bi ɪnʌf. ɪn ə wik, keɪɛmlɪn wəd bi hɝz. ðə θɹoʊn wəd bi hɝz. ɛɹəmɪlə, baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt, kwin ʌv ændɝ, dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə ɹɛlm, pɹətɛktɝ ə ðə pipəl, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs mɑɹn. smaɪlɪŋ, ʃi wɛn bæk ɪnsaɪd tə tɛl ði ʌðɝz ðə wʌndɝfəl nuz.

Her lips compressed of their own accord. The whole amount. She had hoped to get off with paying only the first half. After all, who would dare dun her once she was queen? "Draw up a letter to Mistress Andscale. I'll sign and seal it first thing in the morning." Transferring that much gold would require days. And how long to have the armsmen ready? She had never really paid attention to that sort of thing. Lir could tell her, but she hated showing weakness. "Tell them a week from tomorrow, to the day." That should be enough. In a week, Caemlyn would be hers. The throne would be hers. Arymilla, by the Grace of the Light, Queen of Andor, Defender of the Realm, Protector of the People, High Seat of House Marne. Smiling, she went back inside to tell the others the wonderful news.

tʃæptɝ eɪtin

CHAPTER 18

nuz fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪnʌf, lɔɪəl," ɹænd sɛd fɝmli, θʌmɪŋ təbæk ɪndə hɪz ʃɔɹt-stɛm paɪp fɹəm ə ɡoʊtskɪn paʊtʃ. ɪt wɑz tɛɹən lif, wɪð ə slaɪtli ɔɪli teɪs fɹəm ðə kjʊɹɪŋ, bʌt ðət wɑz ɔl ðət wɑz tə bi hæd. θʌndɝ ɹoʊld oʊvɝhɛd, sloʊ ən pɑndɝəs. "jul tɔk mi hɔɹs wɪð ɔl ðiz kwɛstʃənz."

News for the Dragon Enough, Loial," Rand said firmly, thumbing tabac into his short-stemmed pipe from a goatskin pouch. It was Tairen leaf, with a slightly oily taste from the curing, but that was all that was to be had. Thunder rolled overhead, slow and ponderous. "You'll talk me hoarse with all these questions."

ðeɪ wɝ siɾəd əɾ ə lɔŋ teɪbəl ɪn wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒɝ ɹumz ɪn lɔɹɾ ælɡɝɪnz mænɝ haʊs, ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə ðə mɪddeɪ mil pʊʃt daʊn tə wʌn ɛnd. ðə sɝvəns wɝ oʊld, fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ən sloʊɝ muvɪŋ ðən ɛvɝ sɪns ælɡɝɪn lɛft fəɹ ðə blæk taʊɝ. ðə ɹeɪn pɔɹɪŋ daʊn aʊtsaɪd sim tə bi slækənɪŋ, ðoʊ stʃɹɔŋ ɡʌsts ʌv wɪn stɪl pɛltɪd ðə wɪndoʊz wɪð ɹeɪndʒɹɑps hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹæɾəl ðə ɡlæs ɪn ðə sɪks jɛloʊ-peɪntəd keɪsməns. mɛni ʌv ðoʊz peɪnz hɛl bʌbəlz; səm dɪstɔɹɾəd wʌt leɪ aʊtsaɪɾ ɔlmoʊs bɪɑn ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən. ðə teɪbəl ən tʃɛɹz wɝ sɪmpli kɑɹvd, noʊ mɔɹ ɪlæbɹət ðən maɪt bi faʊn ɪn mɛni fɑɹmhaʊsəz, ən ðə jɛloʊ kɔɹnɪsəz bɪniθ ðə haɪ, bim silɪŋ lɪɾəl mɔɹ soʊ. ðə tu faɪɝpleɪsəz, əɾ iðɝ ɛn ə ðə ɹum, wɝ bɹɔɾ ən tɔl bʌɾ ə pleɪn stoʊn, ði ændaɪɝənz ən faɪɝtulz stɝɾi ɹɔɾ aɪɝn ən sɪmpəl. lɔɹɾ əɹ noʊ, ælɡɝɪn wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm wɛlθi.

They were seated at a long table in one of the larger rooms in Lord Algarin's manor house, the remains of the midday meal pushed down to one end. The servants were old, for the most part, and slower moving than ever since Algarin left for the Black Tower. The rain pouring down outside seemed to be slackening, though strong gusts of wind still pelted the windows with raindrops hard enough to rattle the glass in the six yellow-painted casements. Many of those panes held bubbles; some distorted what lay outside almost beyond recognition. The table and chairs were simply carved, no more elaborate than might be found in many farmhouses, and the yellow cornices beneath the high, beamed ceiling little more so. The two fireplaces, at either end of the room, were broad and tall but of plain stone, the andirons and firetools sturdy wrought iron and simple. Lord or no, Algarin was far from wealthy.

tʌkɪŋ ðə təbæk paʊtʃ ɪndə hɪz pɑkət, ɹænd stʃɹoʊl tə wʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪsəz ən juz smɔl bɹæs tɑŋz fɹəm ðə mæntəl tə lɪft ə bɝnɪŋ slɪvɝ ʌv oʊk fəɹ laɪɾɪŋ ɪz paɪp. hi hoʊp noʊ wʌn θɔt ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ. hi əvɔɪɾəd tʃænəlɪŋ ɛni mɔɹ ðən æbsəlutli nɛsəsɛɹi, ɪspɛʃli ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛls wɑz pɹizɛnt - ðə dɪzinəs ðət hɪɾ ɪm wən i dɪd wɑz dɪfəkəl tə kənsil - bʌt noʊ wʌn hæd mɛnʃən ɪt soʊ fɑɹ. ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪn bɹɔɾ ə skwikɪŋ əz ðoʊ tʃɹi bɹæntʃəz hæd skɹeɪpt əkɹɔs ðə wɪndoʊpeɪnz. ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. ðə nɪɹəs tʃɹiz wɝ bɪɑn ðə filz, mɔɹ ðən hæf ə maɪl əweɪ.

Tucking the tabac pouch into his pocket, Rand strolled to one of the fireplaces and used small brass tongs from the mantel to lift a burning sliver of oak for lighting his pipe. He hoped no one thought that strange. He avoided channeling any more than absolutely necessary, especially if anyone else was present - the dizziness that hit him when he did was difficult to conceal - but no one had mentioned it so far. A gust of wind brought a squeaking as though tree branches had scraped across the windowpanes. Imagination. The nearest trees were beyond the fields, more than half a mile away.

lɔɪəl hæd bɹɔt daʊn ə vaɪn-kɑɹv tʃɛɹ fɹəm ði oʊɡiɝ ɹumz ðət pʊɾ ɪz niz lɛvəl wɪð ðə teɪbəltɑp, soʊ hi hæd tə lin fɔɹwɝd ʃɑɹpli tə ɹaɪɾ ɪn ɪz lɛðɝ-baʊnd noʊtbʊk. ðə vɑljum wɑz smɔl fəɹ hɪm, lɪɾəl ɪnʌf tə fɪt nitli ɪndə wʌn ə hɪz kəpeɪʃəs koʊt pɑkəts, bʌt stɪl əz lɑɹdʒ əz moʊs hjumən bʊks ɹænd hæd sin. faɪn hɛɹ dɛkɝeɪɾəd lɔɪəlz ʌpɝ lɪp ən ə pætʃ bɪniθ ɪz tʃɪn; hi wɑz ətɛmptɪŋ ə bɪɹɾ ən mʌstæʃɪz, ðoʊ wɪð oʊnli ə fju wiks' ɡɹoʊθ, ɪt dɪd nɑt sim ə vɛɹi səksɛsfəl ətɛmp soʊ fɑɹ.

Loial had brought down a vine-carved chair from the Ogier rooms that put his knees level with the tabletop, so he had to lean forward sharply to write in his leather-bound notebook. The volume was small for him, little enough to fit neatly into one of his capacious coat pockets, but still as large as most human books Rand had seen. Fine hair decorated Loial's upper lip and a patch beneath his chin; he was attempting a beard and mustaches, though with only a few weeks' growth, it did not seem a very successful attempt so far.

"bʌt juv toʊl mi ɔlmoʊs nʌθɪŋ ɹɪli jusfəl," ði oʊɡiɝ ɹʌmbəld, ə dʒɹʌm bumɪŋ ɪts dɪsəpɔɪnmənt. hɪz tʌftəɾ ɪɹz dʒɹupt. ivən soʊ, hi bɪɡæn waɪpɪŋ ðə stil nɪb ə hɪz pɑlɪʃt wʊɾən pɛn. fæɾɝ ðən ɹændz θʌm ən lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə sim slɛndɝ, ɪt fɪɾəd lɔɪəlz θɪk fɪŋɡɝz pɝfəkli. "ju nɛvɝ mɛnʃən hɪɹoʊɪks, ɪksɛp baɪ sʌmbɑɾi ɛls. jə meɪk ɪɾ ɔl saʊn soʊ ɛvɹideɪ. tə hɪɹ jə tɛl ɪt, ðə fɔl ʌv ɪljən wɑz əz ɪksaɪɾɪŋ əz wɑtʃɪŋ ə wivɝ ɹɪpɛɹ əɹ lum. ən klɛnzɪŋ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs? jə ən nɪneɪiv lɪŋkt, ðən jə sæɾ ən tʃænəld waɪl ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls wɑz ɔf faɪɾɪŋ fɔɹseɪkən. ivən nɪneɪiv toʊl mi mɔɹ ðən ðæt, ən ʃi kleɪmz tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɔlmoʊs nʌθɪŋ."

"But you've told me almost nothing really useful," the Ogier rumbled, a drum booming its disappointment. His tufted ears drooped. Even so, he began wiping the steel nib of his polished wooden pen. Fatter than Rand's thumb and long enough to seem slender, it fitted Loial's thick fingers perfectly. "You never mention heroics, except by somebody else. You make it all sound so everyday. To hear you tell it, the fall of Illian was as exciting as watching a weaver repair her loom. And cleansing the True Source? You and Nynaeve linked, then you sat and channeled while everybody else was off fighting Forsaken. Even Nynaeve told me more than that, and she claims to remember almost nothing."

nɪneɪiv, wɛɹɪŋ ɔl ə hɝ dʒuəl tɛɹæŋɡɹil ən əɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ bɹeɪslət-ænd-ɹɪŋz æŋɡɹil, ʃɪftəɾ ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ʌðɝ faɪɝpleɪs, ðən wɛn bæk tə wɑtʃɪŋ əliviə. ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən ʃi ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə wɪndoʊz ən tʌɡd əɾ əɹ θɪk bɹeɪd, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt ʃi foʊkəst ɑn ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd sintʃæn wʊmən. stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹweɪ laɪk ə ɡɑɹd, əliviə ɡeɪv ə smɔl, bɹif smaɪl ʌv əmjuzmənt. ðə fɔɹmɝ deɪmeɪn nu nɪneɪivz dɪspleɪ wɑz mɛn fəɹ hɝ. ði ɪntɛnsəɾi nɛvɝ lɛft əɹ hɔkɪʃ blu aɪz, ðoʊ. ɪt sɛldəm hæd, ɛvɝ sɪns əɹ kɑlɝ hæd bɪn ɹimuvd ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ðə tu meɪɾənz skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ hilz nɪɹ əɹ pleɪɪŋ kæts kɹeɪɾəl, hɑɹɪlɪn ə ði aɪɝn maʊntən tɑɹdæɾ ən ɪneɪlə ʌv ðə dʒɹə tʃɑɝin, wɝ meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn dɪspleɪ. ʃoʊufə ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz ən blæk veɪlz hæŋɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts, itʃ hæd θɹi əɹ fɔɹ spɪɹz stʌk θɹu ðə hɑɹnəs hoʊldɪŋ əɹ baʊ keɪs ɑn əɹ bæk ən ə bʊl-haɪd bʌkəlɝ laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðəɹ wɝ fɪfti meɪɾənz ɪn ðə mænɝ haʊs, sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm ʃeɪɾoʊ, ən ðeɪ ɔl wɛn əbaʊt ɹɛɾi tə dæns ðə spɪɹz ɪn ə hɑɹtbit. pɝhæps wɪð hɪm. ðeɪ sim tɔɹn bɪtwin dɪlaɪɾ ət pɹəvaɪɾɪŋ ə ɡɑɹd fəɹ ɪm əɡɛn ən dɪsplɛʒɝ oʊvɝ haʊ lɔŋ i hæɾ əvɔɪɾəd ðɛm.

Nynaeve, wearing all of her jeweled ter'angreal and her strange bracelet-and-rings angreal, shifted in her chair in front of the other fireplace, then went back to watching Alivia. Every so often she glanced toward the windows and tugged at her thick braid, but for the most part she focused on the yellow-haired Seanchan woman. Standing beside the doorway like a guard, Alivia gave a small, brief smile of amusement. The former damane knew Nynaeve's display was meant for her. The intensity never left her hawkish blue eyes, though. It seldom had, ever since her collar had been removed in Caemlyn. The two Maidens squatting on their heels near her playing cat's cradle, Harilin of the Iron Mountain Taardad and Enaila of the Jarra Chareen, were making their own display. Shoufa wrapped around their heads and black veils hanging down their chests, each had three or four spears stuck through the harness holding her bow case on her back and a bull-hide buckler lying on the floor. There were fifty Maidens in the manor house, several of them Shaido, and they all went about ready to dance the spears in a heartbeat. Perhaps with him. They seemed torn between delight at providing a guard for him again and displeasure over how long he had avoided them.

əz fəɹ hɪmsɛlf, hi kəd nɑt lʊk əɾ ɛni ʌv əm wɪθaʊt ðə lɪɾəni ʌv wɪmən u hæd daɪd fəɹ hɪm, wɪmən i hæd kɪld, stɑɹɾɪŋ ʌp ɪn ɪz hɛd. mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd. hɝ əbʌv ɔl. hɝ neɪm wɑz ɹɪɾən ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz skʌl ɪn faɪɝ. laɪæ ʌv ðə koʊseɪɾə tʃɑɝin, sɛndɑɹə ʌv ði aɪɝn maʊntən tɑɹdæd, ləmɛl ə ðə smoʊk wɔɾɝ maɪæɡoʊmə, ænhaɪlɪn ə ðə ɹɛd sɔlt ɡoʊʃin, dɪsɔɹə ʌv ðə musɑɹə ɹn. . . . soʊ mɛni neɪmz. səmtaɪmz i woʊk ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt mʌɾɝɪŋ ðət lɪst, wɪð mɪn hoʊldɪŋ ɪm ən mɝmɝɪŋ tə hɪm əz ɪf suðɪŋ ə tʃaɪld. hi ɔlweɪz toʊld əɹ i wɑz ɔl ɹaɪɾ ən wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ bæk tə slip, jɛɾ æftɝ i kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, hi dɪd nɑt slip əntɪl ðə lɪs hæd bɪn kəmpliɾəd. səmtaɪmz luz θɝɪn tʃæntɪɾ ɪt wɪð hɪm.

As for himself, he could not look at any of them without the litany of women who had died for him, women he had killed, starting up in his head. Moiraine Damodred. Her above all. Her name was written inside his skull in fire. Liah of the Cosaida Chareen, Sendara of the Iron Mountain Taardad, Lamelle of the Smoke Water Miagoma, Andhilin of the Red Salt Goshien, Desora of the Musara Reyn. . . . So many names. Sometimes he woke in the middle of the night muttering that list, with Min holding him and murmuring to him as if soothing a child. He always told her he was all right and wanted to go back to sleep, yet after he closed his eyes, he did not sleep until the list had been completed. Sometimes Lews Therin chanted it with him.

mɪn lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðə vɑljum ʃi hæɾ oʊpən ɑn ðə teɪbəl, wʌn ə hɹɪd fɛlz bʊks. ʃi dɪvaʊɝd ðoʊz, ən juz ðə noʊɾ i hæd sɛn ɹænd bɪfɔɹ ɪz mɝɾɝ, ðə wʌn wɛɹ i sɛd ʃi wɑz ə dɪstʃɹækʃən kəz ʃi wɑz soʊ pɹɪɾi, əz ə bʊkmɑɹk. hɝ ʃɔɹt blu koʊt, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð waɪt flaʊɝz ɑn ðə slivz ən ləpɛlz, wɑz kʌt tə fɪt snʌɡli oʊvɝ əɹ bʊzəm, wɛɹ əɹ kɹimi sɪlk blaʊs ʃoʊɾ ə tʌtʃ ə klivədʒ, ən əɹ bɪɡ dɑɹk aɪz, fɹeɪm baɪ dɑɹk ɹɪŋləts tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz, hɛld ə pliz laɪt. hi kəd fil əɹ plɛʒɝ θɹu ðə bɑnd. ʃi laɪkt ɪm lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. wɪθaʊɾ ə daʊt ðə bɑn toʊld əɹ haʊ mʌtʃ i laɪk lʊkɪŋ. ɑdli ɪnʌf, ɪt sɛd ʃi laɪk lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, tu. pɹɪɾi? hi hʌmd, θʌmɪŋ ɪz ɝloʊb. ʃi wɑz bjuɾəfəl. ən taɪd tə hɪm taɪɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ. ʃi ən ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə. haʊ wɑz i tə kip əm seɪf naʊ? hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə smaɪl bæk əɾ əɹ ɝaʊn ɪz paɪpɛstəm, ənʃʊɹ haʊ wɛl ðə dɪsɛpʃən wɑz wɝkɪŋ. ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən hæɾ ɛntɝd ðə bɑn fɹəm əɹ ɛnd, ðoʊ waɪ ʃi ʃəd bɪkʌm ɪɹəɾəbəl wɛnɛvɝ ʃi θɔɾ i wɑz wɝiɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ wɑz bɪɑn hɪm. laɪt, ʃi wɑntəd tə pɹətɛk hɪm!

Min looked up from the volume she had open on the table, one of Herid Fel's books. She devoured those, and used the note he had sent Rand before his murder, the one where he said she was a distraction because she was so pretty, as a bookmark. Her short blue coat, embroidered with white flowers on the sleeves and lapels, was cut to fit snugly over her bosom, where her creamy silk blouse showed a touch of cleavage, and her big dark eyes, framed by dark ringlets to her shoulders, held a pleased light. He could feel her pleasure through the bond. She liked him looking at her. Without a doubt the bond told her how much he liked looking. Oddly enough, it said she liked looking at him, too. Pretty? He hummed, thumbing his earlobe. She was beautiful. And tied to him tighter than ever. She and Elayne and Aviendha. How was he to keep them safe now? He forced himself to smile back at her around his pipestem, unsure how well the deception was working. A touch of irritation had entered the bond from her end, though why she should become irritable whenever she thought he was worrying about her was beyond him. Light, she wanted to protect him!

"ɹæn ɪzən vɛɹi tɔkəɾɪv, lɔɪəl," ʃi sɛd, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ smaɪlɪŋ. hɝ loʊ, ɔlmoʊs mjuzɪkəl vɔɪs hɛl noʊ æŋɡɝ, bʌt ðə bɑn toʊld ənʌðɝ stɔɹi. "ɪn fækt, səmtaɪmz hiz əbaʊɾ əz tɔkəɾɪv əz ə mʌsəl." ðə lʊk ʃi dɝɛktəɾ ət ɹænd meɪɾ ɪm saɪ. ɪt sim ðəɹ wəd bi ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə tɔkɪŋ wʌns ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn təɡɛðɝ. "aɪ kæn tɛl jə mʌtʃ, maɪsɛlf, bʌɾ aɪm ʃʊɹ kædzueɪn ən vɛɹɪn wɪl tɛl jə ɛniθɪŋ jə wɑnə noʊ. ʌðɝz wɪl, tu. æsk əm ɪf jə wɑn mɔɹ ðən jɛs ən noʊ ən tu wɝdz bɪsaɪdz."

"Rand isn't very talkative, Loial," she said, no longer smiling. Her low, almost musical voice held no anger, but the bond told another story. "In fact, sometimes he's about as talkative as a mussel." The look she directed at Rand made him sigh. It seemed there would be a great deal of talking once they were alone together. "I can't tell you much, myself, but I'm sure Cadsuane and Verin will tell you anything you want to know. Others will, too. Ask them if you want more than yes and no and two words besides."

staʊt lɪɾəl vɛɹɪn, nɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə tʃɛɹ bɪsaɪd nɪneɪiv, əpɪɹd stɑɹɾəld tə hɪɹ əɹ neɪm mɛnʃənd. ʃi blɪŋk veɪɡli, əz ðoʊ wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ ɪt hæd bɪn. kædzueɪn, ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə teɪbəl wɪð əɹ soʊɪŋ bæskəɾ oʊpən bɪsaɪd hɝ, oʊnli tʊk əɹ ətɛnʃən əweɪ fɹəm əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɡlæns ət lɔɪəl. ɡoʊldən ɔɹnəməns sweɪd, dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ði aɪɝn-ɡɹeɪ bʌn ətɑp əɹ hɛd. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ðæt, ə ɡlæns, nɑɾ ə fɹaʊn, jɛt lɔɪəlz ɪɹz twɪtʃt. ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlweɪz ɪmpɹɛs hɪm, ən kædzueɪn mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ.

Stout little Verin, knitting in a chair beside Nynaeve, appeared startled to hear her name mentioned. She blinked vaguely, as though wondering why it had been. Cadsuane, at the far end of the table with her sewing basket open beside her, only took her attention away from her embroidery hoop long enough to glance at Loial. Golden ornaments swayed, dangling from the iron-gray bun atop her head. It was only that, a glance, not a frown, yet Loial's ears twitched. Aes Sedai always impressed him, and Cadsuane more than any other.

"oʊ, aɪ wɪl, mɪn, aɪ wɪl," hi sɛd. "bʌt ɹænd ɪz sɛntʃɹəl tə maɪ bʊk." wɪð noʊ sæn dʒɑɹ ət hænd, hi bɪɡæn bloʊɪŋ dʒɛnli ɑn ðə peɪdʒ ə hɪz noʊtbʊk tə dʒɹaɪ ði ɪŋk, bʌt lɔɪəl biɪŋ lɔɪəl, hi stɪl tɔk bɪtwin pʌfs. "ju nɛvɝ ɡɪv ɪnʌf dɪteɪl, ɹænd. jə meɪk mi dʒɹæɡ ɛvɹiθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ju. waɪ, jə nɛvɝ ivən mɛnʃən biɪŋ ɪmpɹɪzən ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ əntɪl mɪn dɪd. nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ɪt! wʌd ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn seɪ wən ðeɪ ɔfɝd jə ðə lɔɹəl kɹaʊn? ən wən jə ɹineɪmd ɪt? aɪ kæn θɪŋk ðeɪ laɪk ðæt. wʌt wɑz ðə kɔɹəneɪʃən laɪk? wɑz ðəɹ fistɪŋ, ə fɛstəvəl, pɝeɪdz? haʊ mɛni fɔɹseɪkən keɪm əɡɛns jə ət ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ? wɪtʃ wʌnz? wʌɾ ɪt lʊk laɪk ət ði ɛnd? wʌɾ ɪt fil laɪk? maɪ bʊk woʊn bi vɛɹi ɡʊd wɪθaʊt ðə dɪteɪlz. aɪ hoʊp mæt ən pɛɹɪn ɡɪmi bɛɾɝ ænsɝz." hi fɹaʊnd, lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz ɡɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz tʃiks. "aɪ hoʊp ðəɹ ɔl ɹaɪt."

"Oh, I will, Min, I will," he said. "But Rand is central to my book." With no sand jar at hand, he began blowing gently on the page of his notebook to dry the ink, but Loial being Loial, he still talked between puffs. "You never give enough detail, Rand. You make me drag everything out of you. Why, you never even mentioned being imprisoned in Far Madding until Min did. Never mentioned it! What did the Council of Nine say when they offered you the Laurel Crown? And when you renamed it? I can't think they liked that. What was the coronation like? Was there feasting, a festival, parades? How many Forsaken came against you at Shadar Logoth? Which ones? What did it look like at the end? What did it feel like? My book won't be very good without the details. I hope Mat and Perrin give me better answers." He frowned, long eyebrows grazing his cheeks. "I hope they're all right."

kʌlɝz spʌn ɪn ɹændz hɛd, twɪn ɹeɪnboʊz swɝld ɪn wɔɾɝ. hi nu haʊ tə səpɹɛs ðɛm, naʊ, bʌt ðɪs taɪm i dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ. wʌn ɹizɑlvd ɪndə ə bɹif ɪmədʒ ə mæt ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu fɔɹəst ət ðə hɛɾ ʌv ə laɪn ə maʊntəd foʊk. hi sim tə bi ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð ə smɔl, dɑɹk wʊmən u ɹoʊd bɪsaɪd hɪm, teɪkɪŋ ɪz hæɾ ɔf ən piɹɪŋ ɪndə ɪt, ðən kɹæmɪŋ ɪt bæk ɑntu hɪz hɛd. ðət læstəɾ oʊnli moʊməns, ðən wɑz ɹipleɪs baɪ pɛɹɪn sɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ waɪnkʌps ɪn ə kɑmən ɹum əɹ tævɝn wɪð ə mæn ən ə wʊmən u wɔɹ aɪdɛntɪkəl ɹɛd koʊts ɔɹnətli tʃɹɪmd wɪð blu ən jɛloʊ. ɑd ɡɑɹməns. pɛɹɪn lʊkt ɡɹɪm əz dɛθ, hɪz kəmpænjənz wɛɹi. ʌv hɪm?

Colors spun in Rand's head, twin rainbows swirled in water. He knew how to suppress them, now, but this time he did not try. One resolved into a brief image of Mat riding through forest at the head of a line of mounted folk. He seemed to be arguing with a small, dark woman who rode beside him, taking his hat off and peering into it, then cramming it back onto his head. That lasted only moments, then was replaced by Perrin sitting over winecups in a common room or tavern with a man and a woman who wore identical red coats ornately trimmed with blue and yellow. Odd garments. Perrin looked grim as death, his companions wary. Of him?

"ðeɪɹ wɛl," hi sɛd, kɑmli ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ə pɪɹsɪŋ lʊk fɹəm kædzueɪn. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ən i ɪntɛndəd tə kip ɪt ðət weɪ. kɑm ɑn ðə sɝfəs, kɑntɛnt, bloʊɪŋ smoʊk ɹɪŋz. ɪnsaɪd wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. wɛɹ ɑɹ ðeɪ? hi θɔɾ æŋɡɹəli, pʊʃɪŋ daʊn ənʌðɝ əpɪɹəns ə ðə kʌlɝz. ðət wɑz əz izi əz bɹiðɪŋ, naʊ. aɪ nid ðɛm, ən ðəɹ ɔf fəɹ ə deɪ ət ði ænsəlin ɡɑɹɾənz!

"They're well," he said, calmly ignoring a piercing look from Cadsuane. She did not know everything, and he intended to keep it that way. Calm on the surface, content, blowing smoke rings. Inside was another matter. Where are they? he thought angrily, pushing down another appearance of the colors. That was as easy as breathing, now. I need them, and they're off for a day at the Ansaline Gardens!

əbɹʌpli ənʌðɝ ɪmədʒ wɑz floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd, ə mænz feɪs, ən ɪz bɹɛθ kɑt. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ɪt keɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɛni dɪzinəs. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, hi kəd si ɪt klɪɹli ɪn ðə moʊməns bɪfɔɹ ɪt vænɪʃt. ə blu-aɪd mæn wɪð ə skwɛɹ tʃɪn, pɝhæps ə fju jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən hɪmsɛlf. əɹ ɹæðɝ, hi sɔ ɪt klɪɹli fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn ə lɔŋ waɪl. ɪt wɑz ðə feɪs ə ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ u hæd seɪvd ɪz laɪf ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ wən i fɔt sɑmaɪl. wɝs. . . .

Abruptly another image was floating in his head, a man's face, and his breath caught. For the first time, it came without any dizziness. For the first time, he could see it clearly in the moments before it vanished. A blue-eyed man with a square chin, perhaps a few years older than himself. Or rather, he saw it clearly for the first time in a long while. It was the face of the stranger who had saved his life in Shadar Logoth when he fought Sammael. Worse. . . .

hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə mi, luz θɝɪn sɛd. hi saʊndəd seɪn fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ. səmtaɪmz i dɪd, bʌt ðə mædnəs ɔlweɪz ɹɪtɝn ɪvɛntʃəwəli. haʊ kən ə feɪs əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn maɪ maɪn bi əwɛɹ ə mi?

He was aware of me, Lews Therin said. He sounded sane for a change. Sometimes he did, but the madness always returned eventually. How can a face appearing in my mind be aware of me?

ɪf jə doʊnt noʊ, haʊ dʒju ɪkspɛk mi tə? ɹænd θɔt. bʌɾ aɪ wɑz əwɛɹ ə hɪm, əz wɛl. ɪt hæd bɪn ə stʃɹeɪnʒ sɛnseɪʃən, əz ɪf i wɝ . . . tʌtʃɪŋ . . . ði ʌðɝ mæn sʌmhaʊ. oʊnli nɑt fɪzɪkəli. ə ɹɛzədu hʌŋ ɑn. ɪt simd i oʊnli hæd tə muv ə hɛɹz bɹɛdθ, ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən, tə tʌtʃ ɪm əɡɛn. aɪ θɪŋk i sɔ maɪ feɪs, tu.

If you don't know, how do you expect me to? Rand thought. But I was aware of him, as well. It had been a strange sensation, as if he were . . . touching . . . the other man somehow. Only not physically. A residue hung on. It seemed he only had to move a hair's breadth, in any direction, to touch him again. I think he saw my face, too.

tɔkɪŋ tə ə vɔɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sim pəkjuljɝ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɪt hæd nɑt fəɹ kwaɪɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm. ən naʊ . . . ? naʊ, hi kəd si mæt ən pɛɹɪn baɪ θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðɛm əɹ hɪɹɪŋ ðɛɹ neɪmz, ən i hæd ðɪs ʌðɝ feɪs kʌmɪŋ tə hɪm ənbɪddən. mɔɹ ðən ə feɪs, əpɛɹənli. wʌt wɑz hoʊldɪŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃənz ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz oʊn skʌl əlɔŋsaɪd ðæt? bʌt ðə mæn hæd bɪn əwɛɹ, ən ɹænd ə hɪm.

Talking to a voice in his head no longer seemed peculiar. In truth, it had not for quite a long time. And now . . . ? Now, he could see Mat and Perrin by thinking of them or hearing their names, and he had this other face coming to him unbidden. More than a face, apparently. What was holding conversations inside his own skull alongside that? But the man had been aware, and Rand of him.

wən əɹ stʃɹimz ə bɑlfaɪɝ tʌtʃt ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ɪt mʌst əv kɹieɪɾəd səm sɔɹɾ ə lɪŋk bɪtwin ʌs. aɪ kæn θɪŋk ʌv ɛni ʌðɝ ɛkspləneɪʃən. ðət wɑz ði oʊnli taɪm wi ɛvɝ mɛt. hi wɑz juzɪŋ ðɛɹ soʊ-kɔl tʃɹu paʊɝ. ɪt hæd tə bi ðæt. aɪ fɛl nʌθɪŋ, sɔ nʌθɪŋ ɪksɛpt ɪz stʃɹim ə bɑlfaɪɝ. hævɪŋ bɪts ə nɑlədʒ sim ɪz wən i nu ðeɪ keɪm fɹəm luz θɝɪn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ simd ɑd, iðɝ. hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ði ænsəlin ɡɑɹɾənz, dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, əz wɛl əz i dɪɾ ɪz fɑðɝz fɑɹm. nɑlədʒ dʒɹɪftəd ði ʌðɝ weɪ, tu. luz θɝɪn səmtaɪmz spoʊk ʌv ɛmənz fild əz ɪf i hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp ðɛɹ. dʌz ðət meɪk ɛni sɛns tə ju?

When our streams of balefire touched in Shadar Logoth, it must have created some sort of link between us. I can't think of any other explanation. That was the only time we ever met. He was using their so-called True Power. It had to be that. I felt nothing, saw nothing except his stream of balefire. Having bits of knowledge seem his when he knew they came from Lews Therin no longer seemed odd, either. He could remember the Ansaline Gardens, destroyed in the War of the Shadow, as well as he did his father's farm. Knowledge drifted the other way, too. Lews Therin sometimes spoke of Emond's Field as if he had grown up there. Does that make any sense to you?

oʊ, laɪt, waɪ də aɪ hæv ðɪs vɔɪs ɪn maɪ hɛd? luz θɝɪn moʊnd. waɪ kən aɪ nɑt daɪ? oʊ, aɪlaɪɛnə, maɪ pɹɛʃəs aɪlaɪɛnə, aɪ wɑnə dʒɔɪn ju. hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf ɪndə wipɪŋ. hi ɔfən dɪd wən i spoʊk ə ðə waɪf i hæd mɝɾɝd ɪn ɪz mædnəs.

Oh, Light, why do I have this voice in my head? Lews Therin moaned. Why can I not die? Oh, Ilyena, my precious Ilyena, I want to join you. He trailed off into weeping. He often did when he spoke of the wife he had murdered in his madness.

ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. ɹænd səpɹɛs ðə saʊn ə ðə mæn kɹaɪɪŋ, pʊʃt ɪt daʊn tə ə feɪnt nɔɪz ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɪɹɪŋ. hi wɑz sɝɾən ðəɾ i wɑz ɹaɪt. bʌɾ u wɑz ðə fɛloʊ? eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnd, fəɹ ʃʊɹ, bʌt nɑt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. luz θɝɪn nu ðɛɹ feɪsəz əz wɛl əz i nu hɪz oʊn, ən naʊ ɹænd dɪd, tu. ə sʌɾən θɔt meɪɾ ɪm ɡɹɪmɑs. haʊ əwɛɹ ə hɪm wɑz ði ʌðɝ mæn? tɑvɝən kəd bi faʊn baɪ ðɛɹ ɪfɛkt ɑn ðə pæɾɝn, ðoʊ oʊnli ðə fɔɹseɪkən nu haʊ. luz θɝɪn sɝɾənli hæd nɛvɝ mɛnʃənd noʊɪŋ - ðɛɹ "kɑnvɝseɪʃənz" wɝ ɔlweɪz bɹif, ən ðə mæn sɛldəm ɡeɪv ɪnfɝmeɪʃən wɪlɪŋli - ən nʌθɪŋ hæd dʒɹɪftəɾ əkɹɔs fɹəm ɪm ɑn ðə sʌbʒɪkt. ət list, lænfɝ ən ɪʃəml hæd noʊn haʊ, bʌt noʊ wʌn hæd faʊn ɪm ðət weɪ sɪns ðeɪ hæd daɪd. kəd ðɪs lɪŋk bi juzd ɪn ðə seɪm fæʃən? ðeɪ kəɾ ɔl bi ɪn deɪnʒɝ. mɔɹ deɪnʒɝ ðən juʒəwəl, əz ɪf ðə juʒəwəl wɝ nɑɾ ɪnʌf.

It did not matter. Rand suppressed the sound of the man crying, pushed it down to a faint noise on the edge of hearing. He was certain that he was right. But who was the fellow? A Darkfriend, for sure, but not one of the Forsaken. Lews Therin knew their faces as well as he knew his own, and now Rand did, too. A sudden thought made him grimace. How aware of him was the other man? Ta'veren could be found by their effect on the Pattern, though only the Forsaken knew how. Lews Therin certainly had never mentioned knowing - their "conversations" were always brief, and the man seldom gave information willingly - and nothing had drifted across from him on the subject. At least, Lanfear and Ishamael had known how, but no one had found him that way since they had died. Could this link be used in the same fashion? They could all be in danger. More danger than usual, as if the usual were not enough.

"ɑɹ jə wɛl, ɹænd?" lɔɪəl æskt wɝidli, skɹuɪŋ ðə lif-ɪnɡɹeɪv sɪlvɝ kæp ɑntu hɪz ɪŋk dʒɑɹ. ðə ɡlæs ə ðət wɑz soʊ θɪk ɪt cʊɾə sɝvaɪvd ɛniθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə biɪŋ hɝld əɡɛnst stoʊn, bʌt lɔɪəl hændəld ɪɾ əz ðoʊ ɪt wɝ fɹædʒəl. ɪn ɪz hjudʒ hænz, ɪt lʊk fɹædʒəl. "aɪ θɔt ðə tʃiz teɪstəɾ ɔf, bʌt jə eɪɾ ə ɡʊd bɪɾ ʌv ɪt."

"Are you well, Rand?" Loial asked worriedly, screwing the leaf-engraved silver cap onto his ink jar. The glass of that was so thick it could have survived anything short of being hurled against stone, but Loial handled it as though it were fragile. In his huge hands, it looked fragile. "I thought the cheese tasted off, but you ate a good bit of it."

"aɪm faɪn," ɹænd sɛd, bʌɾ ə kɔɹs, nɪneɪiv peɪɾ ɪm noʊ hid. ʃi wɑz aʊɾ ə hɝ tʃɛɹ ən ɡlaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə ɹum ɪn ə flæʃ, blu skɝts swɝlɪŋ. ɡus bʌmps pɑpt aʊɾ ɑn ɪz skɪn əz ʃi ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ ən stʃɹɛtʃt tə leɪ hɝ hænz ɑn ɪz hɛd. ən ɪnstən leɪɾɝ, ə tʃɪl ɹɪpəl θɹu hɪm. ðə wʊmən nɛvɝ æskt! səmtaɪmz ʃi bɪheɪvd əz ɪf ʃi wɝ stɪl ðə wɪzdəm ɪn ɛmənz fild ən i wəd bi hɛɾɪŋ bæk tə ðə fɑɹm kʌm mɔɹnɪŋ.

"I'm fine," Rand said, but of course, Nynaeve paid him no heed. She was out of her chair and gliding down the room in a flash, blue skirts swirling. Goose bumps popped out on his skin as she embraced saidar and stretched to lay her hands on his head. An instant later, a chill rippled through him. The woman never asked! Sometimes she behaved as if she were still the Wisdom in Emond's Field and he would be heading back to the farm come morning.

"jɔɹ nɑɾ ɪl," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn toʊnz ə ɹɪlif. spɔɪl fud wɑz kɑzɪŋ ɔl sɔɹts ə sɪknəs əmʌŋ ðə sɝvəns, səm ʌv ɪt sɪɹiəs. pipəl wʊɾə daɪɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv æʃəmən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ɡɪv hilɪŋ. ɹɪlʌktən tə kɑs ðɛɹ lɔɹd skɛɹs mʌni baɪ θɹoʊɪŋ fuɾ aʊt, dɪspaɪɾ ɔl ði ædmənɪʃənz kædzueɪn ən nɪneɪiv ən ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪv ðɛm, ðeɪ fɛd ðɛmsɛlvz θɪŋz ðət ʃʊɾə bɪn tɔst ɑn ðə mɪɾən hip. ə dɪfɹən tɪŋɡəlɪŋ sɛntɝd bɹifli ɝaʊn ðə dʌbəl waʊn ɪn ɪz lɛf saɪd.

"You're not ill," she said in tones of relief. Spoiled food was causing all sorts of sickness among the servants, some of it serious. People would have died except for the presence of Asha'man and Aes Sedai to give Healing. Reluctant to cost their lord scarce money by throwing food out, despite all the admonitions Cadsuane and Nynaeve and the other Aes Sedai gave them, they fed themselves things that should have been tossed on the midden heap. A different tingling centered briefly around the double wound in his left side.

"ðæt waʊn ɪz noʊ bɛɾɝ," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə fɹaʊn. ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd hilɪŋ ɪt, səksiɾɪŋ noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən flɪn hæd. ðət dɪd nɑt sɪt wɛl wɪð hɝ. nɪneɪiv tʊk feɪljɝ əz ə pɝsənəl ɪnsəlt. "haʊ kən jə ivən stæn ʌp? jə mʌs bi ɪn æɡəni."

"That wound is no better," she said with a frown. She had tried Healing it, succeeding no better than Flinn had. That did not sit well with her. Nynaeve took failure as a personal insult. "How can you even stand up? You must be in agony."

"hi ɪɡnɔɹz ɪt," mɪn sɛd flætli. oʊ, jɛs, ðəɹ wəd bi wɝdz.

"He ignores it," Min said flatly. Oh, yes, there would be words.

"ɪt hɝts noʊ wɝs stændɪŋ ðən sɪɾɪŋ," hi toʊl nɪneɪiv, dʒɛnli teɪkɪŋ əɹ hænz fɹəm ɪz hɛd. sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ. soʊ wɑz wʌt mɪn hæd sɛd. hi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə lɛt peɪn meɪk ɪm ə pɹɪznɝ.

"It hurts no worse standing than sitting," he told Nynaeve, gently taking her hands from his head. Simple truth. So was what Min had said. He could not afford to let pain make him a prisoner.

wʌn ə ðə twɪn dɔɹz kɹikt oʊpən tə ədmɪɾ ə waɪt-hɛɹd mæn ɪn ə wɔɹn jɛloʊ koʊt tʃɹɪmd wɪð ɹɛɾ ən blu ðət hʌŋ lusli ɑn ɪz boʊni fɹeɪm. hɪz baʊ wɑz hɔltɪŋ, ə fɔlt ə hɪz dʒɔɪns ɹæðɝ ðən dɪsɹɪspɛkt. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs nɪɹli əz kɹiki əz ðə hɪnʒɪz, "lɔɹd lɑɡən əz ɹɪtɝnd."

One of the twinned doors creaked open to admit a white-haired man in a worn yellow coat trimmed with red and blue that hung loosely on his bony frame. His bow was halting, a fault of his joints rather than disrespect. "My Lord Dragon," he said in a voice nearly as creaky as the hinges, "Lord Logain has returned."

lɑɡən dɪd nɑt weɪɾ ɑn ɪnvɪteɪʃənz, ɛntɝɪŋ pɹæktəkli ɑn ðə sɝvɪŋ mænz hilz. ə tɔl mæn wɪð dɑɹk hɛɹ kɝlɪŋ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ən dɑɹk fəɹ ə ɡildænɪn, wɪmən laɪkli θɔɾ ɪm hænsəm, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz ə stʃɹik ə dɑɹknəs ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm əz wɛl. hi wɔɹ ɪz blæk koʊt wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɑn ðə haɪ kɑlɝ, ən ə lɔŋ-hɪltɪd sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp, bʌɾ i hæd meɪɾ ən ədɪʃən, ə ɹaʊn ɪnæməl pɪn ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ʃoʊɪŋ θɹi ɡoʊldən kɹaʊnz ɪn ə fild ə blu. hæd ðə mæn ədɑptəɾ ə sɪdʒəl? ði oʊl mænz hɛɹi aɪbɹaʊz ʃɑɾ ʌp ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ən i lʊk tə ɹænd əz ɪf ɪnkwaɪɝɪŋ wɛðɝ i wɑntəd lɑɡən ɹimuvd.

Logain did not wait on invitations, entering practically on the serving man's heels. A tall man with dark hair curling to his shoulders, and dark for a Ghealdanin, women likely thought him handsome, yet there was a streak of darkness inside him as well. He wore his black coat with the Sword and the Dragon on the high collar, and a long-hilted sword on his hip, but he had made an addition, a round enameled pin on his shoulder showing three golden crowns in a field of blue. Had the man adopted a sigil? The old man's hairy eyebrows shot up in surprise, and he looked to Rand as if inquiring whether he wanted Logain removed.

"ðə nuz fɹəm ændɝ ɪz fɛɹ ɪnʌf, aɪ səpoʊz," lɑɡən sɛd, tʌkɪŋ blæk ɡɔnləts bɪhaɪn ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt. hi ɔfɝd ɹænd ə mɪnəməl baʊ, ðə slaɪɾəst bɛndɪŋ ə hɪz bæk. "ɪleɪn stɪl hoʊlz keɪɛmlɪn, ən ɛɹəmɪlə stɪl hoʊlz əɹ sidʒ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn əz ði ædvæntɪdʒ sɪns ɛɹəmɪlə kæn ivən stɑp fud ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪn, mʌtʃ lɛs ɹiɪnfɔɹsməns. noʊ nid tə skaʊl. aɪ kɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi. blæk koʊts ɑɹən ɪɡzækli wɛlkəm ðɛɹ, ɪn ɛni keɪs. ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz ɑɹ stɪl ɪn ðə seɪm pleɪs. jə wɝ waɪz tə steɪ klɪɹ ə ðɛm, ɪt simz. ɹumɝ sɛz ðəɹ ɑɹ θɝtin ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ðɛm. ɹumɝ sɛz ðəɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju. hæz bæʃɪɹ ɡɑɾən bæk jɛt?" nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ɪm ə skaʊl ən muvd əweɪ fɹəm ɹænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪd taɪtli. ɛɛs sədaɪ bɑndɪŋ æʃəmən wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl ɪn əɹ bʊk, bʌt nɑt ðə ɹɪvɝs.

"The news from Andor is fair enough, I suppose," Logain said, tucking black gauntlets behind his sword belt. He offered Rand a minimal bow, the slightest bending of his back. "Elayne still holds Caemlyn, and Arymilla still holds her siege, but Elayne has the advantage since Arymilla can't even stop food getting in, much less reinforcements. No need to scowl. I kept out of the city. Black coats aren't exactly welcome there, in any case. The Borderlanders are still in the same place. You were wise to stay clear of them, it seems. Rumor says there are thirteen Aes Sedai with them. Rumor says they're looking for you. Has Bashere gotten back yet?" Nynaeve gave him a scowl and moved away from Rand gripping her braid tightly. Aes Sedai bonding Asha'man was all very well in her book, but not the reverse.

θɝtin ən lʊkɪŋ fəɹ hɪm? hi hæd steɪd klɪɹ ə ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz kəz ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt wɛlkəm ɪz hɛlp - ɪntɝfɪɹəns, ʃi kɔld ɪt, ən i hæd bɪɡʌn tə si ðət ʃi hæd ðə ɹaɪɾ ʌv ɪt; ðə laɪən θɹoʊn wɑz hɝz tə ɡeɪn, nɑɾ ɪz tə ɡɪv - bʌt pɝhæps ɪt wɑz əz wɛl ðəɾ i hæd. ðə bɔɹɾɝlənd ɹulɝz ɔl hæd taɪz tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən noʊ daʊɾ ɪleɪɾə wɑz stɪl iɡɝ tə ɡɛɾ əɹ hænz ɑn hɪm. hɝ ən ðət mæd pɹɑkləmeɪʃən əbaʊt noʊ wʌn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɪm ɪksɛp θɹu hɝ. ɪf ʃi bɪliv ðət wəd fɔɹs ɪm tə kʌm tə hɝ, ʃi wɑz ə ful.

Thirteen and looking for him?
