He had stayed clear of the Borderlanders because Elayne did not welcome his help - interference, she called it, and he had begun to see that she had the right of it; the Lion Throne was hers to gain, not his to give - but perhaps it was as well that he had. The Borderland rulers all had ties to the White Tower, and no doubt Elaida was still eager to get her hands on him. Her and that mad proclamation about no one approaching him except through her. If she believed that would force him to come to her, she was a fool.

"θæŋk ju, ðət wɪl bi ɔl, ɛθən. lɔɹd lɑɡən?" hi æskt əz ðə sɝvɪŋ mæn baʊd hɪmsɛlf aʊt wɪð ə læs dɪsɡɹʌntəld ɡlæns ət lɑɡən. ɹænd θɔt ðə mæn wʊɾə tʃɹaɪd hæɾ i toʊld ɪm tə hɔl lɑɡən aʊt.

"Thank you, that will be all, Ethin. Lord Logain?" he asked as the serving man bowed himself out with a last disgruntled glance at Logain. Rand thought the man would have tried had he told him to haul Logain out.

"ðə taɪɾəl ɪz ɪz baɪ bɝθ," kædzueɪn sɛd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. ʃi wəd noʊ; ʃi hæd hɛlp kæptʃɝ ɪm bæk wən i wɑz kɔlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, hɪm ən teɪm boʊθ. hɝ hɛɹ ɔɹnəməns bɑbd əz ʃi nɑɾəd tə hɝsɛlf. "fɔ! ə maɪnɝ lɔɹɾəlɪŋ wɪð ə skɹæp ə læn ɪn ðə maʊntənz, moʊst ʌv ɪɾ ɔl bʌt stʃɹeɪɾ ʌp ən daʊn. bʌt kɪŋ dʒoʊhənɪn ən ðə kɹaʊn haɪ kaʊnsəl stʃɹɪpt ɪm ə hɪz lænz ən taɪɾəl æftɝ i bɪkeɪm ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən."

"The title is his by birth," Cadsuane said without looking up from her embroidery. She would know; she had helped capture him back when he was calling himself the Dragon Reborn, him and Taim both. Her hair ornaments bobbed as she nodded to herself. "Phaw! A minor lordling with a scrap of land in the mountains, most of it all but straight up and down. But King Johanin and the Crown High Council stripped him of his lands and title after he became a false Dragon."

smɔl spɑts ə kʌlɝ əpɪɹɾ ɪn lɑɡənz tʃiks, jɛɾ ɪz vɔɪs wɑz kul ən kəmpoʊzd. "ðeɪ kəd teɪk maɪ ɪsteɪt, bʌt ðeɪ kəd nɑt teɪk əweɪ hu aɪ æm."

Small spots of color appeared in Logain's cheeks, yet his voice was cool and composed. "They could take my estate, but they could not take away who I am."

stɪl simɪŋli ɪntɛn ɑn əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi niɾəl, kædzueɪn læf sɔfli. vɛɹɪnz nɪɾɪŋ niɾəlz hæd stɑpt. ʃi wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ lɑɡən, ə plʌmp spɛɹoʊ stʌɾiɪŋ ən ɪnsɛkt. əliviə hæd ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ɪntɛns ɡeɪz tə ðə mæn, tu, ən hɑɹɪlɪn ən ɪneɪlə sim tə bi dʒʌst ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu ðə moʊʃənz ə ðɛɹ ɡeɪm. mɪn əpɪɹd tə bi ɹiɾɪŋ stɪl, bʌɾ itʃ hæn ɹɛstəd nɪɹ ði ɑpəzət kʌf ə hɝ koʊtslivz. ʃi kɛp səm ə hɝ naɪvz hɪɾən ðɛɹ. nʌn ə ðɛm tʃɹʌstɪd hɪm.

Still seemingly intent on her embroidery needle, Cadsuane laughed softly. Verin's knitting needles had stopped. She was studying Logain, a plump sparrow studying an insect. Alivia had shifted her intense gaze to the man, too, and Harilin and Enaila seemed to be just going through the motions of their game. Min appeared to be reading still, but each hand rested near the opposite cuff of her coatsleeves. She kept some of her knives hidden there. None of them trusted him.

ɹænd fɹaʊnd. ðə mæn kəd kɔl hɪmsɛlf wʌtɛvɝ i wɑntəd soʊ lɔŋ əz i dɪd wʌɾ i wɑz səpoʊz tə, bʌt kædzueɪn pɹɑɾɪd ɪm ən ɛniwʌn ɛls ɪn ə blæk koʊt nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi dɪd ɹænd hɪmsɛlf. hi wɑz ənʃʊɹ haʊ fɑɹ tə tʃɹʌs lɑɡən iðɝ, jɛɾ i hæd tə wɝk wɪð ðə tulz i hæd tə hænd. "ɪz ɪt dʌn?" wɪð lɑɡən hɪɹ, lɔɪəl wɑz ənkæpɪŋ ɪz ɪŋk dʒɑɹ əɡɛn.

Rand frowned. The man could call himself whatever he wanted so long as he did what he was supposed to, but Cadsuane prodded him and anyone else in a black coat nearly as much as she did Rand himself. He was unsure how far to trust Logain either, yet he had to work with the tools he had to hand. "Is it done?" With Logain here, Loial was uncapping his ink jar again.

"mɔɹ ðən hæf ðə blæk taʊɝ ɪz ɪn ɑɹæd dumən ən ɪljən. aɪ sɛn ɔl ðə mɛn wɪð bɑndəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪksɛp ðoʊz hɪɹ, əz jə ɔɹɾɝd." lɑɡən wɔk tə ðə teɪbəl waɪl i tɔkt, faʊn ə blu-ɡleɪz pɪtʃɝ ðət stɪl hɛld waɪn əmʌŋ ðə pleɪts ən skɹæps, ən fɪld ə ɡɹin-ɡleɪz kʌp. ðəɹ wɑz vɛɹi lɪɾəl sɪlvɝ ɪn ðə haʊs. "ju ʃʊɾə lemi bɹɪŋ mɔɹ mɛn hɪɹ. ðə nʌmbɝz tɪl tu mʌtʃ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ maɪ laɪkɪŋ."

"More than half the Black Tower is in Arad Doman and Illian. I sent all the men with bonded Aes Sedai except those here, as you ordered." Logain walked to the table while he talked, found a blue-glazed pitcher that still held wine among the plates and scraps, and filled a green-glazed cup. There was very little silver in the house. "You should have let me bring more men here. The numbers tilt too much to Aes Sedai for my liking."

ɹænd ɡɹʌntɪd. "sɪns pɑɹɾ ə ðəɾ ɪz jəɹ duɪŋ, jə kən lɪv wɪð ɪt. ʌðɝz wɪl əv tə, əz wɛl. ɡoʊ ɑn."

Rand grunted. "Since part of that is your doing, you can live with it. Others will have to, as well. Go on."

"dɑbɹeɪn ən ɹəɑɹk wɪl sɛn ə soʊlʒɝ wɪð ə mɛsədʒ əz sun əz ðeɪ faɪn ɛniwʌn ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə mɔɹ ðən ə vɪlədʒ. ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns kleɪm kɪŋ ælsələm stɪl ɹeɪnz, bʌt ðeɪ wʊdn əɹ kʊdn pɹədus ɪm əɹ seɪ wɛɹ i ɪz, ðeɪ sim tə bi ət wʌn ənʌðɝz θɹoʊts ðɛmsɛlvz, ən bændɑɹ ɛbən ɪz mɔɹ ðən hæf dɪzɝɾɪd ən ɡɪvən oʊvɝ tə ðə mɑb." lɑɡən ɡɹɪməst ɪndə hɪz waɪnkʌp. "ɡæŋz ə stʃɹɔŋɡɑɝmz pɹəvaɪd wʌt lɪɾəl ɔɹɾɝ ðəɹ ɪz, ən ðeɪ ɪkstɔɹt fuɾ ən kɔɪn fɹəm ðə pipəl ðeɪ kleɪm tə pɹətɛkt ən teɪk wʌtɛvɝ ɛls ðeɪ wɑnt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ wɪmən." ðə bɑn sʌɾənli hɛld waɪt-hɑt ɹeɪdʒ, ən nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊld ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. "ɹəɑɹk əz sɛɾ əbaʊt pʊɾɪŋ ən ɛn tə ðæt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi tɝnɪŋ ɪndə ə bæɾəl wən aɪ lɛft," lɑɡən fɪnɪʃt.

"Dobraine and Rhuarc will send a Soldier with a message as soon as they find anyone in charge of more than a village. The Council of Merchants claim King Alsalam still reigns, but they wouldn't or couldn't produce him or say where he is, they seem to be at one another's throats themselves, and Bandar Eban is more than half deserted and given over to the mob." Logain grimaced into his winecup. "Gangs of strongarms provide what little order there is, and they extort food and coin from the people they claim to protect and take whatever else they want, including women." The bond suddenly held white-hot rage, and Nynaeve growled in her throat. "Rhuarc has set about putting an end to that, but it was already turning into a battle when I left," Logain finished.

"stʃɹɔŋɡɑɝmz woʊn hoʊld aʊt lɔŋ əɡɛnst il. ɪf dɑbɹeɪn kæn faɪn ɛniwʌn ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, ðən hɪl əv tə bi, fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ." ɪf ælsələm wɑz dɛd, əz sim laɪkli, hi wəɾ əv tə əpɔɪn ə stuɝd fəɹ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɪn ɑɹæd dumən. bʌt hu? ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi sʌmwʌn ðə dəmɑni wəɾ æksɛpt.

"Strongarms won't hold out long against Aiel. If Dobraine can't find anyone in charge, then he will have to be, for the time being." If Alsalam was dead, as seemed likely, he would have to appoint a Steward for the Lord Dragon in Arad Doman. But who? It would have to be someone the Domani would accept.

ði ʌðɝ mæn tʊk ə lɔŋ swɑloʊ ʌv waɪn. "teɪm wɑzn plizd ət mi teɪkɪŋ soʊ mɛni mɛn aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ən nɑt tɛlɪŋ ɪm wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ. aɪ θɔɾ i wɑz gɑnə ɹɪp ʌp jəɹ ɔɹɾɝ. hi tʃɹaɪɾ ɛvɹi tʃɹɪk tə lɝn wɛɹ jə ɑɹ. oʊ, hi bɝnz tə noʊ ðæt. hɪz aɪz wɝ pɹæktəkli ɑn faɪɝ. aɪ wʊdn pʊɾ ɪt pæst ɪm tə hæv hæd mi pʊt tə ðə kwɛstʃən ɪf aɪd bɪn ful ɪnʌf tə miɾ ɪm wɪθaʊt kʌmpəni. wʌn θɪŋ pliz hɪm, ðoʊ: ðəɾ aɪ dɪdn teɪk ɛni ʌv ɪz kɹoʊniz. ðət wɑz pleɪn ɑn ɪz feɪs." hi smaɪld, ə dɑɹk smaɪl, nɑɾ əmjuzd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ fɔɹɾi-wʌn ə ðoʊz naʊ, baɪ ðə weɪ. hiz ɡɪvən oʊvɝ ə dʌzən mɛn ðə dʒɹæɡən pɪn ɪn ðə pæs fju deɪz, ən hiz əbʌv fɪfti mɔɹ ɪn ɪz 'spɛʃəl' klæsəz, moʊst ə ðɛm mɛn ɹɪkɹuɾɪd dʒʌs leɪtli. hiz plænɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, ən aɪ daʊt jəl laɪk ɪt."

The other man took a long swallow of wine. "Taim wasn't pleased at me taking so many men out of the Tower and not telling him where they were going. I thought he was going to rip up your order. He tried every trick to learn where you are. Oh, he burns to know that. His eyes were practically on fire. I wouldn't put it past him to have had me put to the question if I'd been fool enough to meet him without company. One thing pleased him, though: that I didn't take any of his cronies. That was plain on his face." He smiled, a dark smile, not amused. "There are forty-one of those now, by the way. He's given over a dozen men the Dragon pin in the past few days, and he has above fifty more in his 'special' classes, most of them men recruited just lately. He's planning something, and I doubt you'll like it."

aɪ toʊl jə tə kɪl ɪm wən jə hæd ðə tʃæns, luz θɝɪn kækəld ɪn mæd mɝθ. aɪ toʊl ju. ən naʊ ɪts tu leɪt. tu leɪt.

I told you to kill him when you had the chance, Lews Therin cackled in mad mirth. I told you. And now it's too late. Too late.

ɹænd æŋɡɹəli ɪkspɛld ə stʃɹim ə blu-ɡɹeɪ smoʊk. "ɡɪv oʊvɝ," hi sɛd, minɪŋ ɪt fəɹ boʊθ lɑɡən ən luz θɝɪn. "teɪm bɪl ðə blæk taʊɝ tɪl ɪt nɪɹli mætʃəz ðə waɪt taʊɝ fəɹ nʌmbɝz, ən ɪt ɡɹoʊz ɛvɹi deɪ. ɪf hiz ə dɑɹkfɹɛn ðə weɪ jə kleɪm, waɪ wəɾ i də ðæt?"

Rand angrily expelled a stream of blue-gray smoke. "Give over," he said, meaning it for both Logain and Lews Therin. "Taim built the Black Tower till it nearly matches the White Tower for numbers, and it grows every day. If he's a Darkfriend the way you claim, why would he do that?"

lɑɡən mɛɾ ɪz stɛɹ lɛvəli. "bɪkɔz i kʊdn stɑp ɪt. fɹəm wʌɾ aɪv hɝd, ivən ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ðəɹ wɝ mɛn u kəd tʃɹævəl u wɝn ɪz toʊd-iɾɝz, ən i hæd noʊ ɪkskjus tə də ɔl ðə ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. bʌt hiz meɪɾ ə taʊɝ ə hɪz oʊn hɪɾən ɪnsaɪd ðə blæk taʊɝ, ən ðə mɛn ɪn ɪɾ ɑɹ lɔɪəl tə hɪm, nɑt ju. hi əmɛndəd ðə dɛzɝɾɝz' lɪst ən sɛnz ɪz əpɑlədʒiz fəɹ ən 'ɑnəs mɪsteɪk,' bʌt jə kən weɪdʒɝ ɔl jə oʊn ɪt wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪk."

Logain met his stare levelly. "Because he couldn't stop it. From what I've heard, even in the beginning there were men who could Travel who weren't his toad-eaters, and he had no excuse to do all the recruiting himself. But he's made a Tower of his own hidden inside the Black Tower, and the men in it are loyal to him, not you. He amended the deserters' list and sends his apologies for an 'honest mistake,' but you can wager all you own it was no mistake."

ən haʊ lɔɪəl wɑz lɑɡən? ɪf wʌn fɔls dʒɹæɡən tʃeɪft ət fɑloʊɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, waɪ nɑɾ ənʌðɝ? hi maɪt θɪŋk i hæd kɑz. hi hæd bɪn fɑɹ mɔɹ feɪməs əz ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən ðən teɪm, mɔɹ səksɛsfəl, ɡæðɝɪŋ ən ɑɹmi ðət swɛpt aʊɾ ʌv ɡildən ən nɪɹli ɹitʃt luɡɹɾ ɑn ɪts weɪ tə tɛɹ. hæf ðə noʊn wɝl hæd tʃɹɛmbəld ət ðə neɪm lɑɡən. jɛt mæzɹim teɪm kəmændəd ðə blæk taʊɝ waɪl lɑɡən əblɝ wɑz oʊnli ənʌðɝ æʃəmən. mɪn stɪl sɔ ən ɔɹə ʌv ɡlɔɹi ɝaʊn hɪm. dʒʌs haʊ ðət ɡlɔɹi wɑz tə bi ətʃivd wɑz bɪɑn əɹ vjuɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ.

And how loyal was Logain? If one false Dragon chafed at following the Dragon Reborn, why not another? He might think he had cause. He had been far more famous as a false Dragon than Taim, more successful, gathering an army that swept out of Ghealdan and nearly reached Lugard on its way to Tear. Half the known world had trembled at the name Logain. Yet Mazrim Taim commanded the Black Tower while Logain Ablar was only another Asha'man. Min still saw an aura of glory around him. Just how that glory was to be achieved was beyond her viewing, however.

hi tʊk ðə paɪp fɹəm ɪz maʊθ, ən ðə boʊl wɑz hɑɾ əɡɛns ðə hɛɹən bɹændɪɾ ɪndə hɪz pɑm. hi mʌst əv bɪn pʌfɪŋ əweɪ fjʊɹiəsli wɪθaʊt biɪŋ əwɛɹ ʌv ɪt. ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɑz, teɪm ən lɑɡən wɝ lɛsɝ pɹɑbləmz. ðeɪ hæd tə weɪt. ðə tulz ət hænd. hi meɪɾ ən ɛfɝt tə kip ɪz vɔɪs ivən. "teɪm tʊk ðɛɹ neɪmz ɔf ðə lɪst. ðæts ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ. ɪf hiz ʃoʊɪŋ feɪvɝɪtɪzəm, əl pʊɾ ən ɛn tə ɪt wən aɪ hæv taɪm. bʌt ðə sintʃæn əv tə kʌm fɝst. ən meɪbi tɑɹmən ɡdən, tu."

He took the pipe from his mouth, and the bowl was hot against the heron branded into his palm. He must have been puffing away furiously without being aware of it. The trouble was, Taim and Logain were lesser problems. They had to wait. The tools at hand. He made an effort to keep his voice even. "Taim took their names off the list. That's the important thing. If he's showing favoritism, I'll put an end to it when I have time. But the Seanchan have to come first. And maybe Tarmon Gai'don, too."

"ɪf?" lɑɡən ɡɹaʊld, slæmɪŋ ɪz kʌp daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪt bɹoʊk. waɪn spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəltɑp ən dʒɹɪpt oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ. skaʊlɪŋ, hi waɪpt ɪz dæmp hæn ɑn ɪz koʊt. "du jə θɪŋk aɪm ɪmædʒənɪŋ θɪŋz?" hɪz toʊn ɡɹu mɔɹ hiɾəd baɪ ðə wɝd. "ɔɹ meɪkɪŋ əm ʌp? dʒju θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz dʒɛləsi, ælθɹ? ɪz ðət wʌt jə θɪŋk?"

"If?" Logain growled, slamming his cup down on the table so hard that it broke. Wine spread across the tabletop and dripped over the edge. Scowling, he wiped his damp hand on his coat. "Do you think I'm imagining things?" His tone grew more heated by the word. "Or making them up? Do you think this is jealousy, al'Thor? Is that what you think?"

"ju lɪsən tə mi," ɹænd bɪɡæn, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs əɡɛnst ə pil ə θʌndɝ.

"You listen to me," Rand began, raising his voice against a peal of thunder.

"aɪ toʊl jə aɪ ɪkspɛktəd jə ən jəɹ fɹɛnz ɪn blæk koʊts tə bi sɪvəl tə mi, maɪ fɹɛnz ən maɪ ɡɛsts," kædzueɪn sɛd stɝnli, "bʌɾ aɪv dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət mʌs bi ɪkspændəd tə ɪnkluɾ itʃ ʌðɝ." hɝ hɛd wɑz stɪl bɛn oʊvɝ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup, bʌt ʃi spoʊk əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ʃeɪkɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz. "æt list wən aɪm pɹɛzənt. ðət minz ɪf jə kəntɪnju skwɑbəlɪŋ, aɪ meɪ hæv tə spæŋk boʊθ ə ju." hɑɹɪlɪn ən ɪneɪlə bɪɡæn læfɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd ðeɪ ɡɑt ðə stʃɹɪŋ ə ðɛɹ ɡeɪm ɪn ə snɑɹl. nɪneɪiv læft, tu, ðoʊ ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə haɪɾ ɪt bɪhaɪn əɹ hænd. laɪt, ivən mɪn smaɪld!

"I told you I expected you and your friends in black coats to be civil to me, my friends and my guests," Cadsuane said sternly, "but I've decided that must be expanded to include each other." Her head was still bent over her embroidery hoop, but she spoke as if she were shaking a finger under their noses. "At least when I am present. That means if you continue squabbling, I may have to spank both of you." Harilin and Enaila began laughing so hard they got the string of their game in a snarl. Nynaeve laughed, too, though she tried to hide it behind her hand. Light, even Min smiled!

lɑɡən bɹɪsəld, dʒɔ taɪɾənɪŋ əntɪl ɹænd θɔɾ i ʃəd hɪɹ ðə mænz tiθ ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ. hi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ hɑɹd nɑt tə bɹɪsəl hɪmsɛlf. kædzueɪn ən əɹ blʌɾi ɹulz. hɝ kəndɪʃənz fəɹ bɪkʌmɪŋ ɪz ædvaɪzɝ. ʃi pɹitɛndəd ðəɾ i hæɾ æsk fəɹ ðɛm, ən ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən ʃi æɾəd ənʌðɝ tə hɝ lɪst. ðə ɹulz wɝ nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli oʊnɝəs, ðoʊ ðɛɹ ɛɡzɪstəns wɑz, bʌɾ əɹ weɪ ʌv pɹɪzɛntɪŋ əm wɑz ɔlweɪz laɪk ə poʊk wɪð ə ʃɑɹp stɪk. hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə tɛl əɹ i wɑz fɪnɪʃt wɪð əɹ ɹulz, ən wɪð hɝ, tu, ɪf nid bi.

Logain bristled, jaw tightening until Rand thought he should hear the man's teeth grating. He was trying hard not to bristle himself. Cadsuane and her bloody rules. Her conditions for becoming his advisor. She pretended that he had asked for them, and every so often she added another to her list. The rules were not precisely onerous, though their existence was, but her way of presenting them was always like a poke with a sharp stick. He opened his mouth to tell her he was finished with her rules, and with her, too, if need be.

"teɪm vɛɹi laɪkli wɪl əv tə weɪɾ ɑn ðə læs bæɾəl, wʌtɛvɝ hiz əbaʊt," vɛɹɪn sɛd sʌɾənli. hɝ nɪɾɪŋ, ə ʃeɪpləs lʌmp ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ɛniθɪŋ, sæɾ ɪn əɹ læp. "ɪt wɪl kʌm sun. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪv ɹɛɾ ɑn ðə sʌbʒɪkt, ðə saɪnz ɑɹ kwaɪt klɪɹ. hæf ðə sɝvəns əv ɹɛkəɡnaɪz dɛd pipəl ɪn ðə hɔlz, pipəl ðeɪ nu əlaɪv. ɪts hæpən ɔfən ɪnʌf ðət ðeɪ ɑɹən fɹaɪɾənd baɪ ɪɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ən ə dʌzən mɛn muvɪŋ ðə kæɾəl tə spɹɪŋ pæstʃɝ wɑtʃt ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl taʊn mɛlt ɪndə mɪs dʒʌst ə fju maɪlz tə ðə nɔɹθ."

"Taim very likely will have to wait on the Last Battle, whatever he's about," Verin said suddenly. Her knitting, a shapeless lump that might have been anything, sat in her lap. "It will come soon. According to everything I've read on the subject, the signs are quite clear. Half the servants have recognized dead people in the halls, people they knew alive. It's happened often enough that they aren't frightened by it any longer. And a dozen men moving the cattle to spring pasture watched a considerable town melt into mist just a few miles to the north."

kædzueɪn hæd ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛɾ ən wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə staʊt bɹaʊn sɪstɝ. "θæŋk jə fəɹ ɹɪpiɾɪŋ wʌt jə toʊld əs jɛstɝdeɪ, vɛɹɪn," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. vɛɹɪn blɪŋkt, ðən tʊk ʌp əɹ nɪɾɪŋ əɡɛn, fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ ɪɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi, tu, wɝ ənʃʊɹ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə bi.

Cadsuane had raised her head and was staring at the stout Brown sister. "Thank you for repeating what you told us yesterday, Verin," she said dryly. Verin blinked, then took up her knitting again, frowning at it as though she, too, were unsure what it was going to be.

mɪn kɑt ɹændz aɪz, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd sloʊli, ən i saɪd. ðə bɑn hɛld ɪɹɪteɪʃən ən wɛɹinɪs, ðə læst ə dɪlɪbɝɪt wɔɹnɪŋ tə hɪm, hi səspɛktəd. ət taɪmz, ʃi simd eɪbəl tə ɹiɾ ɪz maɪnd. wɛl, ɪf i niɾəd kædzueɪn, ən mɪn sɛɾ i dɪd, ðən i niɾəd hɝ. hi dʒʌst wɪʃt i nu wʌt ʃi wɑz səpoʊz tə titʃ ɪm əsaɪd fɹəm haʊ tə ɡɹaɪn ɪz tiθ.

Min caught Rand's eyes, shaking her head slowly, and he sighed. The bond held irritation and wariness, the last a deliberate warning to him, he suspected. At times, she seemed able to read his mind. Well, if he needed Cadsuane, and Min said he did, then he needed her. He just wished he knew what she was supposed to teach him aside from how to grind his teeth.

"ædvaɪz mi, kædzueɪn. wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ə maɪ plæn?"

"Advise me, Cadsuane. What do you think of my plan?"

"æt læs ðə bɔɪ æsks," ʃi mɝmɝd, sɛɾɪŋ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi daʊn bɪsaɪɾ əɹ soʊɪŋ bæskət. "ɔl ɪz skimz ɪn moʊʃən, səm aɪv nɑt bɪn meɪd pɹɪvi tə, ən naʊ hi æsks. vɛɹi wɛl. jəɹ pis wɪð ðə sintʃæn wɪl bi ʌnpɑpjəlɝ."

"At last the boy asks," she murmured, setting her embroidery down beside her sewing basket. "All his schemes in motion, some I've not been made privy to, and now he asks. Very well. Your peace with the Seanchan will be unpopular."

"ə tʃɹus," hi bɹoʊk ɪn. "æn ə tʃɹus wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl læst oʊnli əz lɔŋ əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. wən aɪ daɪ, ɛvɹiwʌn wɪl bi fɹi tə ɡoʊ tə wɔɹ wɪð ðə sintʃæn əɡɛn ɪf ðeɪ wɪʃ."

"A truce," he broke in. "And a truce with the Dragon Reborn will last only as long as the Dragon Reborn. When I die, everyone will be free to go to war with the Seanchan again if they wish."

mɪn slæmd əɹ bʊk ʃʌɾ ən foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts. "doʊn jə tɔk ðət weɪ!" ʃi sɛd, ɹɛd-feɪst wɪð æŋɡɝ. ðə bɑn ɔlsoʊ kæɹid fɪɹ.

Min slammed her book shut and folded her arms beneath her breasts. "Don't you talk that way!" she said, red-faced with anger. The bond also carried fear.

"ðə pɹɑfəsiz, mɪn," hi sɛd sædli. nɑt sæd fəɹ hɪmsɛlf, bʌt fəɹ hɝ. hi wɑntəd tə pɹətɛk hɝ, hɝ ən ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə, bʌɾ i wəd hɝɾ əm ɪn ði ɛnd.

"The Prophecies, Min," he said sadly. Not sad for himself, but for her. He wanted to protect her, her and Elayne and Aviendha, but he would hurt them in the end.

"aɪ sɛd doʊn jə tɔk ðət weɪ! ðə pɹɑfəsiz doʊn seɪ juv tə daɪ! aɪm nɑt gɑnə lɛt jə daɪ, ɹænd ælθɹ! ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə ən aɪ woʊn lɛt ju!" ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ əliviə, hu hɝ vjuɪŋ hæd sɛd wəd hɛlp ɹænd daɪ, ən əɹ hænz slɪd daʊn əɹ ɑɹmz təwɔɹɾ əɹ kʌfs.

"I said don't you talk that way! The Prophecies don't say you have to die! I'm not going to let you die, Rand al'Thor! Elayne and Aviendha and I won't let you!" She glared at Alivia, who her viewing had said would help Rand die, and her hands slid down her arms toward her cuffs.

"bɪheɪv, mɪn," hi sɛd. hɝ hænz ʃɑɾ əweɪ fɹəm əɹ kʌfs, bʌt ʃi sɛɾ əɹ dʒɔ, ən ðə bɑn sʌɾənli wɑz flʌɾəd wɪð stʌbɝnnəs. laɪt, wɑz i gɑnə hæv tə wɝi əbaʊt mɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl əliviə? nɑt ðət ʃi wɑz laɪkli tə səksid - əz wɛl tʃɹaɪ θɹoʊɪŋ ə naɪf əɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ət ðə sintʃæn wʊmən - bʌt ʃi maɪt ɡɛt hɝsɛlf ɪnʒɝd. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ əliviə nu ɛni wivz bʌt ðoʊz fəɹ wɛpənz.

"Behave, Min," he said. Her hands shot away from her cuffs, but she set her jaw, and the bond suddenly was flooded with stubbornness. Light, was he going to have to worry about Min trying to kill Alivia? Not that she was likely to succeed - as well try throwing a knife at an Aes Sedai as at the Seanchan woman - but she might get herself injured. He was not sure Alivia knew any weaves but those for weapons.

"ʌnpɑpjəlɝ, əz aɪ seɪ," kædzueɪn sɛd fɝmli, ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs. ʃi feɪvɝd mɪn wɪð ə bɹif fɹaʊn bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ əɹ ətɛnʃən bæk tə ɹænd. hɝ feɪs wɑz smuð, kəmpoʊzd, ən ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs. hɝ dɑɹk aɪz wɝ hɑɹd, laɪk pɑlɪʃt blæk stoʊnz. "ɪspɛʃli ɪn tæɹɑbən, ɑmɑdɪʃiə ən ɔltɑɹə, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ ɛlswɛɹ. ɪf jə əɡɹi tə əlaʊ ðə sintʃæn tə kip wʌt ðeɪv ɔlɹɛɾi teɪkən, wʌt lænz wɪl jə ɡɪv əweɪ nɛkst? ðəɾ ɪz haʊ moʊst ɹulɝz wɪl si mæɾɝz."

"Unpopular, as I say," Cadsuane said firmly, raising her voice. She favored Min with a brief frown before turning her attention back to Rand. Her face was smooth, composed, an Aes Sedai's face. Her dark eyes were hard, like polished black stones. "Especially in Tarabon, Amadicia and Altara, but also elsewhere. If you agree to allow the Seanchan to keep what they've already taken, what lands will you give away next? That is how most rulers will see matters."

ɹænd dʒɹɑp bæk ɪndə hɪz tʃɛɹ, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ɪz lɛɡz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ən kɹɔsɪŋ ɪz æŋkəlz. "ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ haʊ ʌnpɑpjəlɝ ɪɾ ɪz. aɪ wɛn θɹu ðət dɔɹfɹeɪm tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪn tɛɹ, kædzueɪn. jə noʊ əbaʊt ðæt?" ɡoʊldən ɔɹnəməns bɑbəld əz ʃi nɑɾəd ɪmpeɪʃənli. "wʌn ə maɪ kwɛstʃənz fəɹ ði æɛlfɪn wɑz 'haʊ kən aɪ wɪn ðə læs bæɾəl?' "

Rand dropped back into his chair, stretching his legs in front of him and crossing his ankles. "It doesn't matter how unpopular it is. I went through that doorframe ter'angreal in Tear, Cadsuane. You know about that?" Golden ornaments bobbled as she nodded impatiently. "One of my questions for the Aelfinn was 'How can I win the Last Battle?' "

"ə deɪnʒɝəs kwɛstʃən tə poʊz," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli, "tʌtʃɪŋ ɑn ðə ʃædoʊ əz ɪt dʌz. səpoʊzədli, ðə ɹɪzʌls kən bi kwaɪɾ ənplɛzənt. wʌt wɑz ði ænsɝ?"

"A dangerous question to pose," she said quietly, "touching on the Shadow as it does. Supposedly, the results can be quite unpleasant. What was the answer?"

" 'ðə nɔɹθ ən ði is mʌs bi əz wʌn. ðə wɛst ən ðə saʊθ mʌs bi əz wʌn. ðə tu mʌs bi əz wʌn.' " hi blu ə smoʊk ɹɪŋ, pʊɾ ənʌðɝ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪɾ əz ɪɾ ɪkspændəd. ðət wɑz nɑt ðə hoʊl ʌv ɪt. hi hæɾ æsk haʊ tə wɪn ən sɝvaɪv. ðə læs pɑɹɾ ə hɪz ænsɝ hæd bɪn 'tə lɪv, jə mʌs daɪ.' nɑt sʌmθɪŋ i wɑz gɑnə bɹɪŋ ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə mɪn ɛnitaɪm sun. ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛniwʌn ɪksɛpt əliviə, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. naʊ hi dʒʌs hæd tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə lɪv baɪ daɪɪŋ. "æt fɝst, aɪ θɔɾ ɪt mɛn aɪ hæd tə kɑŋkɝ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, bʌt ðət wɑznt wʌt ðeɪ sɛd. wʌɾ ɪf ɪt minz ðə sintʃæn hoʊl ðə wɛst ən saʊθ, əz jə kəd seɪ ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi du, ən ðɛɹz ən əlaɪəns tə faɪt ðə læs bæɾəl, ðə sintʃæn wɪð ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls?"

" 'The north and the east must be as one. The west and the south must be as one. The two must be as one.' " He blew a smoke ring, put another in the middle of it as it expanded. That was not the whole of it. He had asked how to win and survive. The last part of his answer had been 'To live, you must die.' Not something he was going to bring up in front of Min anytime soon. In front of anyone except Alivia, for that matter. Now he just had to figure out how to live by dying. "At first, I thought it meant I had to conquer everywhere, but that wasn't what they said. What if it means the Seanchan hold the west and south, as you could say they already do, and there's an alliance to fight the Last Battle, the Seanchan with everybody else?"

"ɪts pɑsəbəl," ʃi əlaʊd. "bʌɾ ɪf jəɹ gɑnə meɪk ðɪs . . . tʃɹus . . . waɪ ɑɹ jə muvɪŋ wʌt simz tə bi ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɑɹmi tə ɑɹæd dumən ən ɹiɪnfɔɹsɪŋ wʌɾ ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ɪljən?"

"It's possible," she allowed. "But if you're going to make this . . . truce . . . why are you moving what seems to be a considerable army to Arad Doman and reinforcing what is already in Illian?"

"bɪkɔz tɑɹmən ɡdən ɪz kʌmɪŋ, kædzueɪn, ən aɪ kæn faɪt ðə ʃædoʊ ən ðə sintʃæn ət ðə seɪm taɪm. əl əv ə tʃɹus, əɹ əl kɹʌʃ əm wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɑst. ðə pɹɑfəsiz seɪ aɪ hæv tə baɪn ðə naɪn munz tə mi. aɪ oʊnli ʌndɝstʊd wʌt ðət mɛn ə fju deɪz əɡoʊ. əz sun əz bæʃɪɹ ɹɪtɝnz, əl noʊ wən ən wɛɹ aɪm tə mit ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. ði oʊnli kwɛstʃən naʊ ɪz haʊ də aɪ baɪn hɝ, ən ʃɪl əv tə ænsɝ ðæt."

"Because Tarmon Gai'don is coming, Cadsuane, and I can't fight the Shadow and the Seanchan at the same time. I'll have a truce, or I'll crush them whatever the cost. The Prophecies say I have to bind the nine moons to me. I only understood what that meant a few days ago. As soon as Bashere returns, I'll know when and where I'm to meet the Daughter of the Nine Moons. The only question now is how do I bind her, and she'll have to answer that."

hi spoʊk mæɾɝ-ʌv-fæktli, naʊ ən ðən bloʊɪŋ ə smoʊk ɹɪŋ fəɹ pʌŋktʃueɪʃən. ɹiækʃənz vɛɹid. lɔɪəl dʒʌst ɹoʊt vɛɹi fæst, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kæptʃɝ ɛvɹi wɝd, waɪl hɑɹɪlɪn ən ɪneɪlə wɛn ɑn wɪð ðɛɹ ɡeɪm. ɪf ðə spɪɹz hæd tə bi dænst, ðeɪ wɝ ɹɛɾi. əliviə nɑɾəd fɪɹsli, daʊtləs hoʊpɪŋ ɪt wəd kʌm tə kɹʌʃɪŋ ðoʊz u hæd kɛpt əɹ wɛɹɪŋ ən æɾəm fəɹ faɪv hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. lɑɡən hæd faʊn ənʌðɝ waɪnkʌp ən fɪld ɪt wɪð ðə læst ʌv wʌt wɑz ɪn ðə pɪtʃɝ, bʌɾ i mɪɹli hɛl ðə kʌp ɹæðɝ ðən dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən ənɹiɾəbəl. naʊ ɪt wɑz ɹænd hum vɛɹɪn stʌɾid ɪntɛnli. bʌt ðɛn, ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn kjʊɹiəs əbaʊt hɪm. bʌt waɪ ɪn ðə laɪt wəd mɪn fil boʊn-dip sædnəs? ən kædzueɪn. . . .

He spoke matter-of-factly, now and then blowing a smoke ring for punctuation. Reactions varied. Loial just wrote very fast, trying to capture every word, while Harilin and Enaila went on with their game. If the spears had to be danced, they were ready. Alivia nodded fiercely, doubtless hoping it would come to crushing those who had kept her wearing an a'dam for five hundred years. Logain had found another winecup and filled it with the last of what was in the pitcher, but he merely held the cup rather than drinking, his expression unreadable. Now it was Rand whom Verin studied intently. But then, she had always been curious about him. But why in the Light would Min feel bone-deep sadness? And Cadsuane. . . .

"stoʊn kɹæks fɹəm ə hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf bloʊ," ʃi sɛd, hɝ feɪs ən ɛɛs sədaɪ mæsk ə kɑm. "stil ʃæɾɝz. ði oʊk faɪts ðə wɪn ən bɹeɪks. ðə wɪloʊ bɛnz wɛɹ ɪt mʌst ən sɝvaɪvz."

"Stone cracks from a hard enough blow," she said, her face an Aes Sedai mask of calm. "Steel shatters. The oak fights the wind and breaks. The willow bends where it must and survives."

"ə wɪloʊ woʊnt wɪn tɑɹmən ɡdən," hi toʊl hɝ.

"A willow won't win Tarmon Gai'don," he told her.

ðə dɔɹ kɹikt oʊpən əɡɛn, ən ɛθən tɑɾɝd ɪn. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, θɹi oʊɡiɝ əv ɝaɪvd. ðeɪ wɝ moʊs pliz tə lɝn ðət mæstɝ lɔɪəl ɪz hɪɹ. wʌn ə ðɛm ɪz ɪz mʌðɝ."

The door creaked open again, and Ethin tottered in. "My Lord Dragon, three Ogier have arrived. They were most pleased to learn that Master Loial is here. One of them is his mother."

"maɪ mʌðɝ?" lɔɪəl skwikt, ən ivən ðət saʊndəd laɪk ə hɑloʊ wɪnd ɡʌstɪŋ ɪn kævɝnz. hi lɛpt ʌp soʊ fæs ðəɾ ɪz tʃɛɹ fɛl oʊvɝ bækwɝd, ɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz hænz, ɪɹz wɪltɪŋ. hɪz hɛd swʌŋ fɹəm saɪd tə saɪɾ əz ɪf i wɝ hʌntɪŋ fəɹ ə weɪ aʊt bɪsaɪdz ðə dɔɹ. "wʌɾ æm aɪ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du, ɹænd? ði ʌðɝ tu mʌs bi ɛldɝ heɪmən ən ɛɹɪθ. wʌɾ æm aɪ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?"

"My mother?" Loial squeaked, and even that sounded like a hollow wind gusting in caverns. He leaped up so fast that his chair fell over backward, wringing his hands, ears wilting. His head swung from side to side as if he were hunting for a way out besides the door. "What am I going to do, Rand? The other two must be Elder Haman and Erith. What am I going to do?"

"mɪstʃɹəs koʊvɹəl sɛd ʃi wɑz moʊst æŋkʃəs tə spik wɪð ju, mæstɝ lɔɪəl," ɛθən sɛɾ ɪn ðət kɹiki vɔɪs. "moʊst æŋkʃəs. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔl dæmp fɹəm ðə ɹeɪn, bʌt ʃi sɛd ðəl weɪt fəɹ jə ɪn ði oʊɡiɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum əpstɛɹz."

"Mistress Covril said she was most anxious to speak with you, Master Loial," Ethin said in that creaky voice. "Most anxious. They are all damp from the rain, but she said they will wait for you in the Ogier sitting room upstairs."

"wʌɾ æm aɪ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du, ɹænd?"

"What am I going to do, Rand?"

"ju sɛd jə wɑnə mɛɹi ɛɹɪθ," ɹænd sɛɾ əz dʒɛnli əz i kʊd. dʒɛntəlnəs wɑz dɪfəkəlt ɪksɛpt wɪð mɪn.

"You said you want to marry Erith," Rand said as gently as he could. Gentleness was difficult except with Min.

"bʌt maɪ bʊk! maɪ noʊts ɑɹən kəmplit, ən əl nɛvɝ faɪn aʊt wʌt hæpənz nɛkst. ɛɹɪθ wɪl teɪk mi bæk tə stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu wɪð hɝ."

"But my book! My notes aren't complete, and I'll never find out what happens next. Erith will take me back to Stedding Tsofu with her."

"fɔ!" kædzueɪn pɪkt ʌp əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi əɡɛn ən bɪɡæn wɝkɪŋ ðə niɾəl dɛləkətli. ʃi wɑz meɪkɪŋ ði eɪntʃən sɪmbəl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ ən ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn mɛldəɾ ɪndə ə dɪsk, blæk ən waɪt sɛpɝeɪɾəd baɪ ə sɪnwəs laɪn. "ɡoʊ tə jəɹ mʌðɝ, lɔɪəl. ɪf ʃiz koʊvɹəl, dɔɾɝ ʌv ɛlə dɔɾɝ ə suŋ, jə doʊnt wɑnə kip əɹ weɪɾɪŋ. əz aɪ ɪkspɛk jə noʊ."

"Phaw!" Cadsuane picked up her embroidery again and began working the needle delicately. She was making the ancient symbol of Aes Sedai, the Dragon's Fang and the Flame of Tar Valon melded into a disc, black and white separated by a sinuous line. "Go to your mother, Loial. If she's Covril, daughter of Ella daughter of Soong, you don't want to keep her waiting. As I expect you know."

lɔɪəl sim tə teɪk kædzueɪnz wɝdz əz ə kəmænd. hi bɪɡæn waɪpɪŋ ɪz pɛn nɪb əɡɛn, kæpɪŋ ɪz ɪŋk dʒɑɹ. bʌɾ i dɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ vɛɹi sloʊli, wɪð ɪz ɪɹz dʒɹupɪŋ. ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən i moʊn sædli, hæf ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, "maɪ bʊk!"

Loial seemed to take Cadsuane's words as a command. He began wiping his pen nib again, capping his ink jar. But he did everything very slowly, with his ears drooping. Every so often he moaned sadly, half under his breath, "My book!"

"wɛl," vɛɹɪn sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp əɹ nɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪnspɛkʃən, "aɪ bɪliv aɪ hæv dʌn ɔl ðəɾ aɪ kən hɪɹ. aɪ θɪŋk əl ɡoʊ faɪn toʊmɑs. ðə ɹeɪn meɪks ɪz ni eɪk, ðoʊ hi dɪnaɪz ɪɾ ivən tə mi." ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə wɪndoʊ. "ɪt dʌz sim tə bi sloʊɪŋ."

"Well," Verin said, holding up her knitting for inspection, "I believe I have done all that I can here. I think I'll go find Tomas. The rain makes his knee ache, though he denies it even to me." She glanced at the window. "It does seem to be slowing."

"æn aɪ θɪŋk əl ɡoʊ faɪn læn," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts. "ðə kʌmpəni ɪz bɛɾɝ wɛɹ i ɪz." ðət wɪð ə ʃɑɹp tʌɡ ɑn əɹ bɹeɪɾ ən ə ɡlɛɹ dɪvaɪɾəd bɪtwin əliviə ən lɑɡən. "ðə wɪn tɛlz mi ə stɔɹm ɪz kʌmɪŋ, ɹænd. ən jə noʊ aɪ doʊn min ɹeɪn."

"And I think I'll go find Lan," Nynaeve said, gathering her skirts. "The company is better where he is." That with a sharp tug on her braid and a glare divided between Alivia and Logain. "The wind tells me a storm is coming, Rand. And you know I don't mean rain."

"ðə læs bæɾəl?" ɹænd æskt. "haʊ sun?" wən ɪt keɪm tə wɛðɝ, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə wɪn kəd səmtaɪmz tɛl əɹ wən ðə ɹeɪnz wəd kʌm tə ði aʊɝ.

"The Last Battle?" Rand asked. "How soon?" When it came to weather, listening to the wind could sometimes tell her when the rains would come to the hour.

"ɪt meɪ bi, ən aɪ doʊnt noʊ. dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ. ə stɔɹm ɪz kʌmɪŋ. ə tɛɹəbəl stɔɹm." oʊvɝhɛd, θʌndɝ ɹoʊld.

"It may be, and I don't know. Just remember. A storm is coming. A terrible storm." Overhead, thunder rolled.

tʃæptɝ naɪntin

CHAPTER 19

vaʊz ənizi, lɔɪəl wɑtʃt nɪneɪiv ɡlaɪɾ ɔf daʊn ðə læmp-lɪt kɔɹəɾɝ ɪn wʌn dɝɛkʃən ən vɛɹɪn ɪn ði ʌðɝ. niðɝ wɑz mʌtʃ tɔlɝ ðən ɪz weɪst, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə fæk nɑɾɪd ɪz tʌŋ səfɪʃənli ðət baɪ ðə taɪm i hæd wɝkt ʌp ɪz nɝv tə æsk wʌn ə ðɛm tə əkʌmpəni hɪm, boʊθ wɝ aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ɝaʊnd ʃɑɹp kɔɹnɝz. ðə mænɝ haʊs wɑz ə ɹæmblɪŋ pleɪs, æɾəd tə oʊvɝ mɛni jɪɹz wɪð noʊ ɹil oʊvɝɔl plæn ðəɾ i kəd dɪsɝn, ən hɔlweɪz fɹikwənli mɛɾ əɾ ɑɾ æŋɡəlz. hi ɹɪli wɪʃt i hæɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ kʌmpəni wən i feɪst ɪz mʌðɝ. ivən kædzueɪn, ɔlðoʊ ʃi meɪɾ ɪm vɛɹi nɝvəs wɪð haʊ ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz pɪntʃɪŋ ət ɹænd. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ɹænd wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɪksploʊd. hi wɑz nɑt ðə seɪm mæn lɔɪəl fɝs mɛɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, əɹ ivən ðə mæn i hæd lɛft ɪn kɛɹhin. ðə muɾ ɝaʊn ɹænd wɑz dɑɹk ən stoʊni naʊ, ə dɛns pætʃ ə laɪənz klɔ ən tʃɹɛtʃɝəs ɡɹaʊn ʌndɝfʊt. ðə hoʊl haʊs fɛl ðət weɪ wɪð ɹænd ɪn ɪt.

Vows Uneasy, Loial watched Nynaeve glide off down the lamp-lit corridor in one direction and Verin in the other. Neither was much taller than his waist, but they were Aes Sedai. The fact knotted his tongue sufficiently that by the time he had worked up his nerve to ask one of them to accompany him, both were out of sight around sharp corners. The manor house was a rambling place, added to over many years with no real overall plan that he could discern, and hallways frequently met at odd angles. He really wished he had an Aes Sedai for company when he faced his mother. Even Cadsuane, although she made him very nervous with how she was always pinching at Rand. Sooner or later, Rand was going to explode. He was not the same man Loial first met in Caemlyn, or even the man he had left in Cairhien. The mood around Rand was dark and stony now, a dense patch of lion's claw and treacherous ground underfoot. The whole house felt that way with Rand in it.

ə lin, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd sɝvɪŋ wʊmən kæɹiɪŋ ə bæskəɾ ə foʊldəd taʊəlz ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ bɪfɔɹ ɔfɝɪŋ ɪm ə bɹif kɝtsi ən wɔkɪŋ ɑn. ʃi meɪɾ ə smɔl saɪdstɛp əz ðoʊ ʃi wɑz muvɪŋ ɝaʊn sʌmθɪŋ. əɹ sʌmwʌn. hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə spɑɾ ən skɹætʃt bɪhaɪn ɪz ɪɹ. meɪbi hi kəɾ oʊnli si oʊɡiɝ dɛd. nɑt ðəɾ i æktʃəli  wɑntəd tə. ɪt wɑz sæɾ ɪnʌf dʒʌs noʊɪŋ ðət hjumən dɛd kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹɛst. hævɪŋ ðə seɪm kənfɝm fəɹ oʊɡiɝ wəd bi ɪnʌf tə bɹeɪk ɪz hɑɹt. moʊs laɪkli ðeɪ wəɾ əpɪɹ oʊnli ɪnsaɪd stɛɾɪŋ, ɪn ɛni keɪs. hi wəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk tə si ə taʊn vænɪʃ, ðoʊ. nɑɾ ə ɹil taʊn, bʌɾ ə taʊn ðət wɑz əz dɛɾ əz ðoʊz spɪɹəts ðə hjumənz kleɪm tə si. jə maɪt bi eɪbəl tə wɔk ɪts stʃɹits bɪfɔɹ ɪt mɛltəɾ ən si wʌt pipəl wɝ laɪk bɪfɔɹ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, əɹ ivən ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. soʊ vɛɹɪn sɛd, ən ʃi sim tə noʊ ə vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt dil əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðət wəd sɝɾənli bi wɝθ ə mɛnʃən ɪn ɪz bʊk. ɪt gɑnə tə bi ə faɪn bʊk. skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz bɪɹd wɪð tu fɪŋɡɝz - ðə θɪŋ ɪtʃt! - hi saɪd. wʊɾə əv bɪn ə faɪn bʊk.

A lean, gray-haired serving woman carrying a basket of folded towels gave a start, then shook her head and muttered something under her breath before offering him a brief curtsy and walking on. She made a small sidestep as though she was moving around something. Or someone. He stared at the spot and scratched behind his ear. Maybe he could only see Ogier dead. Not that he actually wanted to. It was sad enough just knowing that human dead could no longer rest. Having the same confirmed for Ogier would be enough to break his heart. Most likely they would appear only inside stedding, in any case. He would very much like to see a town vanish, though. Not a real town, but a town that was as dead as those spirits the humans claimed to see. You might be able to walk its streets before it melted and see what people were like before the War of the Hundred Years, or even the Trolloc Wars. So Verin said, and she seemed to know a very great deal about it. That would certainly be worth a mention in his book. It was going to be a fine book. Scratching his beard with two fingers - the thing itched! - he sighed. It would have been a fine book.

stændɪŋ ðəɹ ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ wɑz oʊnli pʊɾɪŋ ɔf ði ɪnɛvəɾəbəl. pʊɾ ɔf klɪɹɪŋ ðə bɹʌʃ ən jə ɔlweɪz faɪn tʃoʊkɪvaɪn ɪn ɪt, soʊ ði oʊl seɪɪŋ wɛnt. oʊnli hi fɛlt əz ðoʊ ðə tʃoʊkɪvaɪn wɑz taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪm ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə tʃɹi. bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd, hi fɑloʊd ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə waɪd stɛɹz ðət lɛɾ ʌp tə ði oʊɡiɝ ɹumz. ðə stɛɹkeɪs hæd tu stɝɾi bænɪstɝz, ʃoʊldɝ-haɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən ən staʊɾ ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ə disən hændhoʊld. hi wɑz ɔfən əfɹeɪd dʒʌs tə bɹʌʃ əɡɛnst stɛɹ ɹeɪlz meɪd fəɹ hjumənz fəɹ fɪɹ i maɪt bɹeɪk ðɛm. wʌn ɹæn daʊn ðə mɪɾəl, wɪð ðə stɛps əlɔŋ ðə wʊd-pænəld wɔl pɪtʃt fəɹ hjumən fit, ðoʊz ɑn ði aʊtsaɪd fəɹ oʊɡiɝ.

Standing there in the corridor was only putting off the inevitable. Put off clearing the brush and you always find chokevine in it, so the old saying went. Only he felt as though the chokevine was tight around him instead of a tree. Breathing hard, he followed the serving woman all the way to the wide stairs that led up to the Ogier rooms. The staircase had two sturdy bannisters, shoulder-high on the gray-haired woman and stout enough to give a decent handhold. He was often afraid just to brush against stair rails made for humans for fear he might break them. One ran down the middle, with the steps along the wood-paneled wall pitched for human feet, those on the outside for Ogier.

ðə wʊmən wɑz oʊld əz hjumənz kaʊntəd jɪɹz, jɛt ʃi klaɪmd mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən i ən wɑz skɝiɪŋ daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ baɪ ðə taɪm i ɹitʃt ðə tɑp. daʊtləs ʃi wɑz teɪkɪŋ ðə taʊəlz tə hɪz mʌðɝz ɹum, ən tə ɛldɝ heɪmənz ən ɛɹɪθs. ʃʊɹli ðeɪ wəd pɹəfɝ tə ɡɛt dʒɹaɪ bɪfɔɹ tɔkɪŋ. hi wəd sədʒɛs ðæt. ɪt wəd ɡeɪn ɪm taɪm tə θɪŋk. hɪz θɔts simd əz slʌɡɪʃ əz ɪz fit, ən ɪz fit fɛlt laɪk mɪlstoʊnz.

The woman was old as humans counted years, yet she climbed more quickly than he and was scurrying down the corridor by the time he reached the top. Doubtless she was taking the towels to his mother's room, and to Elder Haman's and Erith's. Surely they would prefer to get dry before talking. He would suggest that. It would gain him time to think. His thoughts seemed as sluggish as his feet, and his feet felt like millstones.

ðəɹ wɝ sɪks bɛdʒɹumz bɪl fəɹ oʊɡiɝ əlɔŋ ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, wɪtʃ ɪtsɛlf wɑz pɹɑpɝli skeɪl fəɹ əm - hɪz ʌpstʃɹɛtʃt hænz wʊɾə kʌm ə peɪs ʃɔɹɾ ə tʌtʃɪŋ ðə silɪŋ bimz - əlɔŋ wɪð ə stɔɹɹum, ə beɪðɪŋ ɹum wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ kɑpɝ tʌb, ən ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. ðɪs wɑz ði oʊldəs pɑɹɾ ə ðə haʊs, deɪɾɪŋ bæk nɪɹli faɪv hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ə laɪftaɪm fəɹ ə vɛɹi oʊld oʊɡiɝ, bʌt mɛni laɪftaɪmz fəɹ hjumənz. ðeɪ lɪv sətʃ bɹif laɪvz, ɪksɛp fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ; ðət hæd tə bi waɪ ðeɪ flɪɾɪd əbaʊt laɪk hʌmɪŋbɝdz. bʌɾ ivən ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd bi nɪɹli əz pɹɪsɪpɪɾəs əz ðə ɹɛst. ðət wɑz ə pʌzəlmənt.

There were six bedrooms built for Ogier along the corridor, which itself was properly scaled for them - his upstretched hands would have come a pace short of touching the ceiling beams - along with a storeroom, a bathing room with a large copper tub, and the sitting room. This was the oldest part of the house, dating back nearly five hundred years. A lifetime for a very old Ogier, but many lifetimes for humans. They lived such brief lives, except for Aes Sedai; that had to be why they flitted about like hummingbirds. But even Aes Sedai could be nearly as precipitous as the rest. That was a puzzlement.

ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum dɔɹ wɑz kɑɹvd wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹi, nɑɾ oʊɡiɝ wɝk, jɛt faɪnli dɪteɪld ən ɪnstənli ɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbəl. hi stɑpt, tʌɡɪŋ ɪz koʊt stʃɹeɪt, koʊmɪŋ ɪz hɛɹ wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, wɪʃɪŋ i hæd taɪm tə blæk ɪz buts. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪŋk steɪn ɑn ɪz kʌf. noʊ taɪm tə də ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ðæt, iðɝ. kædzueɪn wɑz ɹaɪt. hɪz mʌðɝ wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊmən tə bi kɛpt weɪɾɪŋ. stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət kædzueɪn nu ʌv hɝ. pɝhæps nu hɝ, baɪ ðə weɪ ʃi hæd spoʊkən. koʊvɹəl, dɔɾɝ ʌv ɛlə dɔɾɝ ə suŋ, wɑz ə feɪməs spikɝ, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɑz noʊn aʊtsaɪd. laɪt, hi wɑz ɔl bʌt pæntɪŋ wɪð æŋzaɪəɾi.

The sitting room door was carved with a Great Tree, not Ogier work, yet finely detailed and instantly recognizable. He stopped, tugging his coat straight, combing his hair with his fingers, wishing he had time to black his boots. There was an ink stain on his cuff. No time to do anything about that, either. Cadsuane was right. His mother was not a woman to be kept waiting. Strange that Cadsuane knew of her. Perhaps knew her, by the way she had spoken. Covril, daughter of Ella daughter of Soong, was a famous Speaker, but he had not realized she was known Outside. Light, he was all but panting with anxiety.

tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪz bɹiðɪŋ, hi wɛn ɪn. ivən hɪɹ ðə hɪnʒɪz kɹikt. ðə sɝvəns hæd bɪn əɡæst wən i æskt æftɝ səm ɔɪl tə pʊɾ ɑn əm - ðət wɑz ðɛɹ tæsk; hi wɑz ə ɡɛst - bʌt ðeɪ stɪl hæd nɑt ɡɑɾən ɝaʊn tə ɪt ðɛmsɛlvz.

Trying to control his breathing, he went in. Even here the hinges creaked. The servants had been aghast when he asked after some oil to put on them - that was their task; he was a guest - but they still had not gotten around to it themselves.

ðə haɪ-silɪŋɡd ɹum wɑz kwaɪt speɪʃəs, wɪð dɑɹk pɑlɪʃt wɔlpeɪpɝz ən vaɪn-kɑɹv tʃɛɹz ən smɔl vaɪn-kɑɹv teɪbəlz ən ɹɔt-aɪɝn stænd-læmps ʌv ə pɹɑpɝ saɪz, ðɛɹ mɪɹɝd fleɪmz dænsɪŋ əbʌv ɪz hɛd. ɪksɛp fəɹ ə ʃɛlf ə bʊks, ɔl oʊld ɪnʌf ðət ðə lɛðɝ baɪndɪŋz wɝ fleɪkɪŋ ən ɔl ʌv wɪtʃ i hæd ɹɛd bɪfɔɹ, oʊnli ə smɔl boʊl ə sʌŋ wʊd wɑz oʊɡiɝ meɪd. ə naɪs pis; hi wɪʃt i nu hu hæd sʌŋ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz eɪdʒd ɪnʌf ðət sɪŋɪŋ tə ɪt hæd feɪl tə ɹeɪz soʊ mʌtʃ əz ən ɛkoʊ. jɛɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd bɪn meɪd baɪ sʌmwʌn u ət lis hæd bɪn tə ə stɛɾɪŋ. ðə pisəz wʊɾə lʊkt ət hoʊm ɪn ɛni dwɛlɪŋ. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə ɹum lʊk nʌθɪŋ laɪk ə ɹum ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ, bʌt lɔɹɾ ælɡɝɪnz ænsɛstɝ hæd meɪɾ ən ɛfɝt tə hæv ɪz vɪzəɾɝz fil kʌmftəɹbəl.

The high-ceilinged room was quite spacious, with dark polished wallpapers and vine-carved chairs and small vine-carved tables and wrought-iron stand-lamps of a proper size, their mirrored flames dancing above his head. Except for a shelf of books, all old enough that the leather bindings were flaking and all of which he had read before, only a small bowl of sung wood was Ogier made. A nice piece; he wished he knew who had sung it, but it was aged enough that singing to it had failed to raise so much as an echo. Yet everything had been made by someone who at least had been to a stedding. The pieces would have looked at home in any dwelling. Of course, the room looked nothing like a room in a stedding, but Lord Algarin's ancestor had made an effort to have his visitors feel comfortable.

hɪz mʌðɝ wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʌn ə ðə bɹɪk faɪɝpleɪsəz, ə stʃɹɔŋ-feɪst wʊmən wɪð əɹ vaɪn-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd skɝts spɹɛd tə lɛt ðə fleɪmz dʒɹaɪ ðɛm. hi hivd ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif ət siɪŋ ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əz wɛɾ əz i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd, ɔlðoʊ ɪt pʊt peɪd tə sədʒɛstɪŋ ðeɪ teɪk ðə taɪm tə ɡɛt dʒɹaɪ. ðɛɹ ɹeɪnkloʊks mʌst əv dɪvɛləp liks. ðeɪ dɪd ðəɾ æftɝ ə taɪm, əz ði ænsiɾ ɔɪl wɔɹ ɔf. meɪbi hɝ tɛmpɝ wəd nɑt bi əz bæɾ əz i fɪɹd, iðɝ. waɪt-hɛɹɾ ɛldɝ heɪmən, hɪz flɛɹɪŋ koʊt dɑɹk wɪð dæmp ɪn sɛvɹəl lɑɹdʒ pætʃəz, wɑz ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ wʌn ə ði æksiz fɹəm ðə wɔl, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ oʊvɝ ɪt. ɪts hæft wɑz əz lɔŋ əz i wɑz tɔl. meɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz əɹ ivən bɪfɔɹ, ðəɹ wɝ ə pɛɹ ə ðoʊz, ðə lɔŋ æks hɛdz ɪnleɪd wɪð ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ, ən ə pɛɹ ʌv ɔɹneɪt pɔɪntəd pɹunɪŋ naɪvz wɪð lɔŋ ʃæfs, əz wɛl. ʌv kɔɹs, pɹunɪŋ naɪvz, ʃɑɹp ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ən sɔtuðd ɑn ði ʌðɝ, ɔlweɪz hæd lɔŋ hændəlz, bʌt ði ɪnleɪz ən lɔŋ ɹɛd tæsəlz ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðət ðiz hæd bɪn meɪd fəɹ wɛpənz, tu. nɑt ðə moʊs fɪlɪsəɾəs tʃɔɪsəz fəɹ hæŋɪŋ ɪn ə ɹum mɛn fəɹ ɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən əɹ ðə kwaɪət kɑntəmpleɪʃən ə stɪlnəs.

His mother was standing in front of one of the brick fireplaces, a strong-faced woman with her vine-embroidered skirts spread to let the flames dry them. He heaved a sigh of relief at seeing she was not as wet as he had expected, although it put paid to suggesting they take the time to get dry. Their raincloaks must have developed leaks. They did that after a time, as the anseed oil wore off. Maybe her temper would not be as bad as he feared, either. White-haired Elder Haman, his flaring coat dark with damp in several large patches, was examining one of the axes from the wall, shaking his head over it. Its haft was as long as he was tall. Made during the Trolloc Wars or even before, there were a pair of those, the long axe heads inlaid with gold and silver, and a pair of ornate pointed pruning knives with long shafts, as well. Of course, pruning knives, sharp on one side and sawtoothed on the other, always had long handles, but the inlays and long red tassels indicated that these had been made for weapons, too. Not the most felicitous choices for hanging in a room meant for reading or conversation or the quiet contemplation of stillness.

bʌt lɔɪəlz aɪz swɛpt pæst ɪz mʌðɝ ən ɛldɝ heɪmən tə ði ʌðɝ faɪɝpleɪs, wɛɹ ɛɹɪθ, smɔl ən ɔlmoʊs fɹædʒəl əpɪɹɪŋ, wɑz dʒɹaɪɪŋ əɹ oʊn skɝts. hɝ maʊθ wɑz stʃɹeɪt, hɝ noʊz ʃɔɹɾ ən wɛl-ɹaʊndəd, hɝ aɪz ði ɪɡzækt kʌlɝ ʌv ə sɪlvɝbɛlz ɹaɪp sidpɑd. ɪn ʃɔɹt, ʃi wɑz bjuɾəfəl! ən əɹ ɪɹz, stɪkɪŋ ʌp θɹu ðə ɡlɔsi blæk hɛɹ ðət hʌŋ daʊn əɹ bæk. . . . kɝvɪŋ ən plʌmp, tɪpt wɪð faɪn tʌfs ðət lʊkt əz sɑft əz dændəlaɪən daʊn, ðeɪ wɝ ðə moʊst ɡɔɹdʒəs ɪɹz i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. nɑt ðəɾ i wəd bi kɹuɾ ɪnʌf tə seɪ soʊ. ʃi smaɪld ət hɪm, ə vɛɹi mɪstɪɹiəs smaɪl, ən ɪz oʊn ɪɹz kwɪvɝd wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. ʃʊɹli ʃi kəd nɑt noʊ wʌɾ i hæd bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ. kəd ʃi? ɹænd sɛd wɪmən kəd səmtaɪmz, bʌt ðət wɑz hjumən wɪmən.

But Loial's eyes swept past his mother and Elder Haman to the other fireplace, where Erith, small and almost fragile appearing, was drying her own skirts. Her mouth was straight, her nose short and well-rounded, her eyes the exact color of a silverbell's ripe seedpod. In short, she was beautiful! And her ears, sticking up through the glossy black hair that hung down her back. . . . Curving and plump, tipped with fine tufts that looked as soft as dandelion down, they were the most gorgeous ears he had ever seen. Not that he would be crude enough to say so. She smiled at him, a very mysterious smile, and his own ears quivered with embarrassment. Surely she could not know what he had been thinking. Could she? Rand said women could sometimes, but that was human women.

"soʊ, hɪɹ jə ɑɹ," hɪz mʌðɝ sɛd, plæntɪŋ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ smaɪlz fɹəm hɝ. hɝ bɹaʊz wɝ dʒɹɔn daʊn, hɝ dʒɔ sɛt. ɪf ðɪs wɑz əɹ bɛɾɝ tɛmpɝ, ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn dʒɹɛntʃt. "aɪ mʌst seɪ, juv lɛd mi ə mɛɹi tʃeɪs, bʌɾ aɪ hæv jə ɪn hænd naʊ, ən aɪ də nɑt min tə lɛt jə ɹʌn - wʌɾ ɪz ðəɾ ɑn jəɹ lɪp? ən jəɹ tʃɪn! wɛl, jə kən ʃeɪv ðoʊz ɹaɪɾ ɔf əɡɛn. doʊn jə ɡɹɪmɑs ət mi, sʌn lɔɪəl."

"So, here you are," his mother said, planting her fists on her hips. There were no smiles from her. Her brows were drawn down, her jaw set. If this was her better temper, she might as well have been drenched. "I must say, you've led me a merry chase, but I have you in hand now, and I do not mean to let you run - What is that on your lip? And your chin! Well, you can shave those right off again. Don't you grimace at me, Son Loial."

fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə ɡɹoʊθ ɑn ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp ənizəli, hi tʃɹaɪd tə smuð ɪz feɪs - wən jəɹ mʌðɝ neɪm jə sʌn, ʃi wɑz ɪn noʊ mud tə tʃɹaɪfəl wɪð - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd. hi wɑntəɾ ɪz bɪɹɾ ən mʌstæʃɪz. səm maɪt θɪŋk ɪt pɹitɛnʃəs, əz jʌŋ əz i wɑz, bʌt dʒʌs ðə seɪm. . . .

Fingering the growth on his upper lip uneasily, he tried to smooth his face - when your mother named you Son, she was in no mood to trifle with - but it was hard. He wanted his beard and mustaches. Some might think it pretentious, as young as he was, but just the same. . . .

"ə mɛɹi tʃeɪs ɪndid," ɛldɝ heɪmən sɛd dʒɹaɪli, hæŋɪŋ ði æks bæk ɑn ɪts hʊks. hi hæd lɔŋ waɪt mʌstæʃɪz ðət fɛl pæst ɪz tʃɪn ən ə lɔŋ nɛɹoʊ bɪɹd ðət hʌŋ tə hɪz tʃɛst. tʃɹu, hi wɑz wɛl əbʌv θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz oʊld, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl simd ənfɛɹ. "ə vɛɹi mɛɹi tʃeɪs. fɝst wi wɔk tə kɛɹhin, hævɪŋ hɝd jə wɝ ðɛɹ, oʊnli jə hæd ɡɔn. æftɝ ə stɑp ət stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu, wi wɔk tə keɪɛmlɪn, wɛɹ jʌŋ ælθɹ ɪnfɔɹmd əs jə wɝ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ən tʊk əs ðɛɹ. bʌt jə wɝ ɡɔn əɡɛn. tə keɪɛmlɪn, ɪt simd!" hɪz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz ɔlmoʊs tə hɪz hɛɹlaɪn. "aɪ bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk wi wɝ pleɪɪŋ ɹɪŋ-ɪn-ðə-dɛl."

"A merry chase indeed," Elder Haman said dryly, hanging the axe back on its hooks. He had long white mustaches that fell past his chin and a long narrow beard that hung to his chest. True, he was well above three hundred years old, but it still seemed unfair. "A very merry chase. First we walked to Cairhien, having heard you were there, only you had gone. After a stop at Stedding Tsofu, we walked to Caemlyn, where young al'Thor informed us you were in the Two Rivers and took us there. But you were gone again. To Caemlyn, it seemed!" His eyebrows rose almost to his hairline. "I began to think we were playing ring-in-the-dell."

"ðə pipəl ɪn ɛmənz fil toʊld əs haʊ hɪɹoʊɪk jə wɝ," ɛɹɪθ sɛd, hɝ haɪ vɔɪs laɪk mjuzɪk. klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ skɝts wɪð boʊθ hænz, ɪɹz flʌɾɝɪŋ wɪð ɪksaɪtmənt, ʃi simd əbaʊt tə baʊns ʌp ən daʊn. "ðeɪ toʊld əs ɔl əbaʊt jə faɪɾɪŋ tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl, ən ɡoʊɪŋ aʊɾ əmʌŋ əm baɪ jɝsɛlf tə sil ðə meɪnɛðɝən weɪɡeɪt soʊ noʊ mɔɹ kəd kʌm."

"The people in Emond's Field told us how heroic you were," Erith said, her high voice like music. Clutching her skirts with both hands, ears fluttering with excitement, she seemed about to bounce up and down. "They told us all about you fighting Trollocs and Myrddraal, and going out among them by yourself to seal the Manetheren Waygate so no more could come."

"aɪ wɑzn baɪ maɪsɛlf," lɔɪəl pɹətɛstəd, weɪvɪŋ ɪz hænz. hi θɔɾ ɪz ɪɹz maɪt flaɪ fɹəm ɪz hɛd, ðeɪ wɝ twɪtʃɪŋ soʊ wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. "ɡɔl wɑz wɪð mi. wi dɪɾ ɪt təɡɛðɝ. aɪd nɛvɝ əv ɹitʃt ðə weɪɡeɪt wɪθaʊt ɡɔl." ʃi ɹɪŋkəld əɹ dɛləkət noʊz ət hɪm, dɪsmɪsɪŋ ɡɔlz pɑɹtɪsəpeɪʃən.

"I wasn't by myself," Loial protested, waving his hands. He thought his ears might fly from his head, they were twitching so with embarrassment. "Gaul was with me. We did it together. I'd never have reached the Waygate without Gaul." She wrinkled her delicate nose at him, dismissing Gaul's participation.

hɪz mʌðɝ snɪft. hɝ ɪɹz wɝ ɹɪdʒəd wɪð dɪsteɪst. "fulɪʃnəs. faɪɾɪŋ ɪn bæɾəlz. pʊɾɪŋ jɝsɛlf ɪn deɪnʒɝ. ɡæmbəlɪŋ. ɔl ʌv ɪt. pjʊɹ fulɪʃnəs, ən ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ mɔɹ ʌv ɪt."

His mother sniffed. Her ears were rigid with distaste. "Foolishness. Fighting in battles. Putting yourself in danger. Gambling. All of it. Pure foolishness, and there will be no more of it."

ɛldɝ heɪmən hæɹəmft, ɪɹz twɪtʃɪŋ ɪɹɪɾəbli, ən foʊldəɾ ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. hi dɪslaɪk biɪŋ ɪntɝʌptɪd. "soʊ wi ɹɪtɝn tə keɪɛmlɪn, tə faɪn jə ɡɔn, ən ðən tə kɛɹhin wʌns mɔɹ, tə faɪn jə ɡɔn jɛɾ əɡɛn."

Elder Haman harrumphed, ears twitching irritably, and folded his hands behind his back. He disliked being interrupted. "So we returned to Caemlyn, to find you gone, and then to Cairhien once more, to find you gone yet again."

"æn jə pʊt jɝsɛlf ɪn deɪnʒɝ əɡɛn ɪn kɛɹhin," lɔɪəlz mʌðɝ bɹoʊk ɪn, ʃeɪkɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ ət hɪm. "hæv jə noʊ sɛns əɾ ɔl?"

"And you put yourself in danger again in Cairhien," Loial's mother broke in, shaking a finger at him. "Have you no sense at all?"

"ði il sɛd jə wɝ vɛɹi bɹeɪv ət dəməaɪz wɛlz," ɛɹɪθ mɝmɝd, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm θɹu hɝ lɔŋ aɪlæʃɪz. hi swɑloʊd hɑɹd. hɝ ɡeɪz meɪɾ ɪz θɹoʊt fil taɪt. hi nu hi ʃəd lʊk əweɪ, bʌt haʊ kəɾ i bi dɪmjʊɹ wən ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm?

"The Aiel said you were very brave at Dumai's Wells," Erith murmured, looking at him through her long eyelashes. He swallowed hard. Her gaze made his throat feel tight. He knew he should look away, but how could he be demure when she was looking at him?

"ɪn kɛɹhin jəɹ mʌðɝ dɪsaɪɾɪd ʃi kʊdn steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, ðoʊ waɪ aɪ kænɑt seɪ, sɪns ðeɪ ɑɹən laɪkli tə ɹitʃ ɛni sɔɹɾ ə dɪsɪʒən fəɹ ənʌðɝ jɪɹ əɹ tu, soʊ wi sɛɾ aʊt tə ɹɪtɝn tə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ ɪn ðə hoʊp wi kəd faɪn jə leɪɾɝ." ɛldɝ heɪmən sɛɾ ɔl ə ðət vɛɹi fæst, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə tu wɪmən əz ɪf i θɔt ðeɪ maɪt bɹeɪk ɪn ɑn ɪm əɡɛn. hɪz bɪɹɾ ən mʌstæʃɪz sim tə bɹɪsəl.

"In Cairhien your mother decided she couldn't stay away from the Great Stump any longer, though why I cannot say, since they aren't likely to reach any sort of decision for another year or two, so we set out to return to Stedding Shangtai in the hope we could find you later." Elder Haman said all of that very fast, glaring at the two women as if he thought they might break in on him again. His beard and mustaches seemed to bristle.

lɔɪəlz mʌðɝ ɡeɪv ənʌðɝ snɪf, ʃɑɹpɝ. "aɪ ɪkspɛk tə bɹɪŋ ə dɪsɪʒən vɛɹi kwɪkli, ɪn ə mʌnθ əɹ tu, əɹ aɪd nɛvɝ əv ɡɪvən oʊvɝ ðə sɝtʃ fəɹ lɔɪəl ivən tɛmpɝɛɹəli. naʊ ðəɾ aɪv faʊn hɪm, wi kən fɪnɪʃ mæɾɝz ən bi ɑn əɹ weɪ wɪθaʊɾ ɛni mɔɹ dɪleɪ." ʃi tʊk ɪn ɛldɝ heɪmən, hu wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ, hɪz ɪɹz slæntəd bæk, ən əmɛndəɾ əɹ toʊn. hi wɑz ən ɛldɝ, æftɝ ɔl. "fɝɡɪv mi, ɛldɝ heɪmən. aɪ mɛn tə seɪ, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ju, wɪl jə pɝfɔɹm ðə sɛɹəmoʊni?"

Loial's mother gave another sniff, sharper. "I expect to bring a decision very quickly, in a month or two, or I'd never have given over the search for Loial even temporarily. Now that I've found him, we can finish matters and be on our way without any more delay." She took in Elder Haman, who was frowning, his ears slanted back, and amended her tone. He was an Elder, after all. "Forgive me, Elder Haman. I meant to say, if it pleases you, will you perform the ceremony?"

"aɪ bɪliv ðəɾ ɪt dʌz pliz mi, koʊvɹəl," hi sɛd maɪldli. mʌtʃ tu maɪldli. wən lɔɪəl hɝd ðət toʊn fɹəm ɪz titʃɝ, wɪð ɪɹz bæk, hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz noʊn ðəɾ i hæd pʊɾ ə fʊt vɛɹi bædli ɹɔŋ. ɛldɝ heɪmən hæd bɪn noʊn tə θɹoʊ ə pis ə tʃɑk əɾ ə pjupəl wən i juz ðət toʊn. "sɪns aɪ əbændən maɪ stuɾənts, nɑt tə mɛnʃən spikɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp, tə fɑloʊ jə ɑn ðɪs waɪl tʃeɪs fəɹ ðət vɛɹi ɹizən, aɪ bɪliv ɪt dʌz pliz mi ɪndid. ɛɹɪθ, jə ɑɹ vɛɹi jʌŋ."

"I believe that it does please me, Covril," he said mildly. Much too mildly. When Loial heard that tone from his teacher, with ears back, he had always known that he had put a foot very badly wrong. Elder Haman had been known to throw a piece of chalk at a pupil when he used that tone. "Since I abandoned my students, not to mention speaking to the Great Stump, to follow you on this wild chase for that very reason, I believe it does please me indeed. Erith, you are very young."

"ʃiz pæst eɪɾi, oʊld ɪnʌf tə mɛɹi," lɔɪəlz mʌðɝ sɛd ʃɑɹpli, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst. hɝ ɪɹz twɪtʃt wɪð ɪmpeɪʃəns. "hɝ mʌðɝ ən aɪ ɹitʃt əɡɹimənt. jə jɝsɛlf wɪtnəst əs saɪnɪŋ ðə bɪtʃɹɑθɔl ən lɔɪəlz daʊɹi."

"She's past eighty, old enough to marry," Loial's mother said sharply, folding her arms across her chest. Her ears twitched with impatience. "Her mother and I reached agreement. You yourself witnessed us signing the betrothal and Loial's dowry."

ɛldɝ heɪmənz ɪɹz tɪltəd bæk ə lɪɾəl fɝðɝ, ən ɪz ʃoʊldɝz hʌntʃt əz ɪf i wɑz ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ vɛɹi hɑɹd bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. hɪz aɪz nɛvɝ lɛft ɛɹɪθ. "aɪ noʊ jə wɑnə mɛɹi lɔɪəl, bʌɾ ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jə ɑɹ ɹɛɾi? teɪkɪŋ ə hʌzbən ɪz ə ɡɹeɪv ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi."

Elder Haman's ears tilted back a little further, and his shoulders hunched as if he was gripping his hands together very hard behind his back. His eyes never left Erith. "I know you want to marry Loial, but are you sure you are ready? Taking a husband is a grave responsibility."

lɔɪəl wɪʃt sʌmwʌn wəɾ æsk ɪm ðət kwɛstʃən, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt ðə weɪ. hɪz mʌðɝ ən ɛɹɪθs hæd ɹitʃt ðɛɹ əɡɹimənt, ən oʊnli ɛɹɪθ kəd stɑp ɪt naʊ. ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə. dɪɾ i wɑn əɹ tə? hi kəd nɑt stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɪz bʊk. hi kəd nɑt stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɛɹɪθ.

Loial wished someone would ask him that question, but that was not the way. His mother and Erith's had reached their agreement, and only Erith could stop it now. If she wanted to. Did he want her to? He could not stop thinking of his book. He could not stop thinking of Erith.

ʃi sɝɾənli lʊkt ɡɹeɪv. "maɪ wivɪŋ sɛlz wɛl, ən aɪm ɹɛɾi tə baɪ ənʌðɝ lum ən teɪk ən əpɹɛntəs. bʌt ðət meɪ nɑt bi wʌt jə min. aɪm ɹɛɾi tə tɛn ə hʌzbənd." sʌɾənli, ʃi ɡɹɪnd, ə lʌvli ɡɹɪn ðət dɪvaɪɾəd əɹ feɪs ɪn tu. "ɪspɛʃli wʌn wɪð sətʃ bjuɾəfəl lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz."

She certainly looked grave. "My weaving sells well, and I am ready to buy another loom and take an apprentice. But that may not be what you mean. I am ready to tend a husband." Suddenly, she grinned, a lovely grin that divided her face in two. "Especially one with such beautiful long eyebrows."

lɔɪəlz ɪɹz kwɪvɝd, ən soʊ dɪɾ ɛldɝ heɪmənz, ɪf nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ. wɪmən wɝ vɛɹi fɹi ɪn ðɛɹ tɔk əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, soʊ hi hæd hɝd, bʌt juʒəwəli ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə ɪmbɛɹəs mɛn wɪð ɪt. juʒəwəli. hɪz mʌðɝz ɪɹz æktʃəli  tʃɹɛmbəld wɪð əmjuzmənt!

Loial's ears quivered, and so did Elder Haman's, if not so much. Women were very free in their talk among themselves, so he had heard, but usually they tried not to embarrass men with it. Usually. His mother's ears actually trembled with amusement!

ði oʊldɝ mæn klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "ðɪs ɪz sɪɹiəs, ɛɹɪθ. kʌm naʊ. ɪf jə ɑɹ ʃʊɹ, teɪk ɪz hænz."

The older man cleared his throat. "This is serious, Erith. Come now. If you are sure, take his hands."

wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən, ʃi keɪm tə stæn ɪn fɹʌn ə lɔɪəl, smaɪlɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm əz ʃi tʊk ɪz hænz ɪn hɝz. hɝ smɔl hænz fɛl vɛɹi wɔɹm. hɪz fɛl nʌm ən koʊld. hi swɑloʊd. ɪt ɹɪli wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən.

Without hesitation, she came to stand in front of Loial, smiling up at him as she took his hands in hers. Her small hands felt very warm. His felt numb and cold. He swallowed. It really was going to happen.

"ɛɹɪθ, dɔɾɝ ʌv ivə dɔɾɝ ʌv eɪlɑɹ," ɛldɝ heɪmən sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ wʌn hæn pɑm daʊn oʊvɝ itʃ ə ðɛɹ hɛdz, "wɪl jə teɪk lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən, əz hʌzbən ən vaʊ ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ ðə tʃɹi tə tʃɹɛʒɝ, ɪstim ən lʌv ɪm soʊ lɔŋ əz i laɪvz, tə kɛɹ fəɹ ɪm ən tɛn hɪm, ən tə ɡaɪɾ ɪz fiɾ ɑn ðə pæθ ðeɪ ʃəd fɑloʊ?"

"Erith, daughter of Iva daughter of Alar," Elder Haman said, holding one hand palm down over each of their heads, "will you take Loial, son of Arent son of Halan, as husband and vow under the Light and by the Tree to treasure, esteem and love him so long as he lives, to care for him and tend him, and to guide his feet on the path they should follow?"

"ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ ðə tʃɹi, aɪ soʊ vaʊ." ɛɹɪθs vɔɪs wɑz fɝm ən klɪɹ, ən əɹ smaɪl sim tə hæv ɡɹoʊn waɪɾɝ ðən əɹ feɪs.

"Under the Light and by the Tree, I so vow." Erith's voice was firm and clear, and her smile seemed to have grown wider than her face.

"lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən, wɪl jə æksɛpt ɛɹɪθ, dɔɾɝ ʌv ivə dɔɾɝ ʌv eɪlɑɹ, əz waɪf ən vaʊ ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ ðə tʃɹi tə tʃɹɛʒɝ, ɪstim ən lʌv əɹ soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi laɪvz, tə kɛɹ fəɹ əɹ ən tə hiɾ əɹ ɡaɪɾəns?"

"Loial, son of Arent son of Halan, will you accept Erith, daughter of Iva daughter of Alar, as wife and vow under the Light and by the Tree to treasure, esteem and love her so long as she lives, to care for her and to heed her guidance?"

lɔɪəl tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. hɪz ɪɹz tʃɹɛmbəld. hi wɑntəd tə mɛɹi hɝ. hi dɪd. dʒʌs nɑt jɛt. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ ðə tʃɹi, aɪ soʊ vaʊ," hi sɛd hɔɹsli.

Loial took a deep breath. His ears trembled. He wanted to marry her. He did. Just not yet. "Under the Light and by the Tree, I so vow," he said hoarsely.

"ðɛn ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ ðə tʃɹi, aɪ dɪklɛɹ jə wɛd. meɪ ðə blɛsɪŋz ə ðə laɪɾ ən ðə tʃɹi bi əpɑn jə ɔlweɪz."

"Then under the Light and by the Tree, I declare you wed. May the blessings of the Light and the Tree be upon you always."

lɔɪəl lʊk daʊn əɾ ɪz waɪf. hɪz waɪf. ʃi ɹeɪzd ə hæn ən stʃɹoʊk slɛndɝ fɪŋɡɝz əlɔŋ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz. ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋz ə mʌstæʃɪz, ɛniweɪ.

Loial looked down at his wife. His wife. She raised a hand and stroked slender fingers along his mustaches. The beginnings of mustaches, anyway.

"ju ɑɹ vɛɹi hænsəm, ən aɪ θɪŋk mʌstæʃɪz wɪl bi bjuɾəfəl ɑn ju. ə bɪɹd, tu."

"You are very handsome, and I think mustaches will be beautiful on you. A beard, too."

"nɑnsɛns," hɪz mʌðɝ sɛd. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ʃi wɑz dæbɪŋ əɾ əɹ aɪz wɪð ə smɔl leɪs hæŋkɝtʃɪf. ʃi wɑz nɛvɝ ɪmoʊʃənəl. "hiz mʌtʃ tu jʌŋ fəɹ ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ."

"Nonsense," his mother said. Surprisingly, she was dabbing at her eyes with a small lace handkerchief. She was never emotional. "He's much too young for that sort of thing."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi θɔɾ ɛɹɪθs ɪɹz bɪɡæn tə slæn bæk. ðət hæd tə bi hɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. hi hæd hæɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə lɔŋ tɔks wɪð əɹ - ʃi wɑz ə wʌndɝfəl kɑnvɝseɪʃənələst; ðoʊ kʌm tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt ʃi lɪsənd, bʌt wʌt lɪɾəl ʃi dɪd seɪ wɑz ɔlweɪz vɛɹi koʊdʒənt - ən i wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi pəzɛs noʊ sɔɹɾ ə tɛmpɝ əɾ ɔl. hi hæd noʊ taɪm tə θɪŋk ɑn ɪt, ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt. ɹɛstɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn ɪz ɑɹmz, ʃi ɹoʊz ɑn tɪptoʊz, ən i bɛn tə ɹʌb ɪz noʊz əɡɛns hɝz. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðeɪ noʊz fəɹ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv wɪð ɛldɝ heɪmən ən ɪz mʌðɝ pɹɛzənt, bʌɾ ʌðɝz feɪɾəd fɹəm ɪz θɔts əz i ɪnheɪld ɪz waɪfs sɛn ən ʃi hɪz. ən ðə fil ə hɝ noʊz ɑn hɪz! pjʊɹ blɪs! hi kʌp ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛɾ ən bɛɹli hæd ðə pɹɛzəns ə maɪnd nɑt tə fɪŋɡɝ əɹ ɪɹ. ʃi tʌɡd ðə tʌft ɑn wʌn ə hɪz! æftɝ ə waɪl, ə vɛɹi lɔŋ waɪl ɪt simd, vɔɪsəz ɪntʃɹuɾəd.

For a moment, he thought Erith's ears began to slant back. That had to be his imagination. He had had a number of long talks with her - she was a wonderful conversationalist; though come to think of it, for the most part she listened, but what little she did say was always very cogent - and he was sure she possessed no sort of temper at all. He had no time to think on it, in any event. Resting her hands on his arms, she rose on tiptoes, and he bent to rub his nose against hers. In truth, they nosed for longer than they should have with Elder Haman and his mother present, but others faded from his thoughts as he inhaled his wife's scent and she his. And the feel of her nose on his! Pure bliss! He cupped the back of her head and barely had the presence of mind not to finger her ear. She tugged the tuft on one of his! After a while, a very long while it seemed, voices intruded.

"ɪɾ ɪz stɪl ɹeɪnɪŋ, koʊvɹəl. jə kænɑt sɪɹiəsli bi sədʒɛstɪŋ wi sɛɾ aʊɾ əɡɛn wən wɪv ə saʊn ɹuf oʊvɝ əɹ hɛdz ən pɹɑpɝ bɛdz tə slip ɪn fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ. noʊ, aɪ seɪ. noʊ! əl nɑt slip ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn tənaɪt, əɹ ɪn ə bɑɹn, əɹ wɝst ʌv ɔl, ɪn ə haʊs wɛɹ maɪ fiɾ ən niz hæŋ oʊvɝ ði ɛn ə ðə lɑɹdʒəs bɛɾ əveɪləbəl. ðəɹ əv bɪn taɪmz aɪv sɪɹiəsli θɔɾ ə ɹəfjuzɪŋ hɑspətæləɾi, ən tə ðə pɪt wɪð ɹudnəs."

"It is still raining, Covril. You cannot seriously be suggesting we set out again when we have a sound roof over our heads and proper beds to sleep in for a change. No, I say. No! I will not sleep on the ground tonight, or in a barn, or worst of all, in a house where my feet and knees hang over the end of the largest bed available. There have been times I've seriously thought of refusing hospitality, and to the Pit with rudeness."

"ɪf jə ɪnsɪst," hɪz mʌðɝ sɛd ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli, "bʌɾ aɪ wɑn ən ɝli stɑɹt kʌm mɔɹnɪŋ. aɪ ɹəfjuz tə weɪst ən aʊɝ mɔɹ ðən aɪ mʌst. ðə bʊk ə tʃɹænzleɪʃən mʌs bi oʊpən əz sun əz pɑsəbəl."

"If you insist," his mother said grudgingly, "but I want an early start come morning. I refuse to waste an hour more than I must. The Book of Translation must be opened as soon as possible."

lɔɪəl dʒɝkt ɪɹɛkt, əɡæst. "ðæts wʌt ðə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp ɪz dɪskʌsɪŋ? ðeɪ kæn də ðæt, nɑt naʊ!"

Loial jerked erect, aghast. "That's what the Great Stump is discussing? They can't do that, not now!"

"wi mʌs liv ðɪs wɝld ɪvɛntʃəwəli, soʊ wi kən kʌm tə ɪt wən ðə wil tɝnz," hɪz mʌðɝ sɛd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ tə ðə nɪɹəs faɪɝpleɪs tə spɹɛɾ əɹ skɝts əɡɛn. "ðæɾ ɪz ɹɪɾən. naʊ ɪz ɪɡzækli ðə ɹaɪt taɪm, ən ðə sunɝ ðə bɛɾɝ."

"We must leave this world eventually, so we can come to it when the Wheel turns," his mother said, striding to the nearest fireplace to spread her skirts again. "That is written. Now is exactly the right time, and the sooner the better."

"ɪz ðət wʌt jə θɪŋk, ɛldɝ heɪmən?" lɔɪəl æskt wɝidli.

"Is that what you think, Elder Haman?" Loial asked worriedly.

"noʊ, maɪ bɔɪ, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl. bɪfɔɹ wi lɛft, aɪ ɡeɪv ə spitʃ ə θɹi aʊɝz ðəɾ aɪ θɪŋk sweɪɾ ə fju maɪnz ɪn ðə ɹaɪt dɝɛkʃən." ɛldɝ heɪmən pɪkt ʌp ə tɔl jɛloʊ pɪtʃɝ ən fɪld ə blu kʌp, bʌt ɹæðɝ ðən dʒɹɪŋk, hi fɹaʊn ɪndə ðə ti. "jɔɹ mʌðɝ əz sweɪd mɔɹ, aɪ fɪɹ. ʃi meɪ ivən ɡɛɾ əɹ dɪsɪʒən ɪn mʌnθs, əz ʃi sɛz."

"No, my boy, not at all. Before we left, I gave a speech of three hours that I think swayed a few minds in the right direction." Elder Haman picked up a tall yellow pitcher and filled a blue cup, but rather than drink, he frowned into the tea. "Your mother has swayed more, I fear. She may even get her decision in months, as she says."

ɛɹɪθ fɪld ə kʌp fəɹ ɪz mʌðɝ, ðən tu mɔɹ, bɹɪŋɪŋ wʌn tə hɪm. hɪz ɪɹz kwɪvɝd wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmən jɛɾ əɡɛn. hi ʃʊɾə dʌn ðæt. hi hæɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil tə lɝn əbaʊt biɪŋ ə hʌzbənd, bʌɾ i nu ðət mʌtʃ.

Erith filled a cup for his mother, then two more, bringing one to him. His ears quivered with embarrassment yet again. He should have done that. He had a great deal to learn about being a husband, but he knew that much.

"aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəɾ ædʒɹɛs ðə stʌmp," hi sɛd bɪɾɝli.

"I wish I could address the Stump," he said bitterly.

"ju saʊn iɡɝ, hʌzbənd." hʌzbənd. ðət mɛn ɛɹɪθ wɑz vɛɹi sɪɹiəs. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾ əz biɪŋ kɔl sʌn lɔɪəl. "wʌt wəd jə seɪ tə ðə stʌmp?"

"You sound eager, Husband." Husband. That meant Erith was very serious. It was almost as bad as being called Son Loial. "What would you say to the Stump?"

"aɪ woʊn əv ɪm ɪmbɛɹəst, ɛɹɪθ," hɪz mʌðɝ sɛd bɪfɔɹ i kəɾ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ. "lɔɪəl ɹaɪts wɛl, ən ɛldɝ heɪmən sɛz i meɪ hæv ðə meɪkɪŋz ʌv ə skɑlɝ əbaʊt hɪm, bʌɾ i ɡɛts tʌŋ-taɪd bɪfɔɹ ivən ə hʌnʒɹəd. bɪsaɪdz, hiz oʊnli ə bɔɪ."

"I won't have him embarrassed, Erith," his mother said before he could open his mouth. "Loial writes well, and Elder Haman says he may have the makings of a scholar about him, but he gets tongue-tied before even a hundred. Besides, he is only a boy."

ɛldɝ heɪmən hæd sɛd ðæt? lɔɪəl wʌndɝd wən ɪz ɪɹz wəd stɑp kwɪvɝɪŋ.

Elder Haman had said that? Loial wondered when his ears would stop quivering.

"ɛni mɛɹid mæn meɪ ædʒɹɛs ðə stʌmp," ɛɹɪθ sɛd fɝmli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊt ðɪs taɪm. hɝ ɪɹz dɛfənətli slæntəd bæk. "wɪl jə əlaʊ mi tə tɛn maɪ oʊn hʌzbənd, mʌðɝ koʊvɹəl?" hɪz mʌðɝz maʊθ muvd, bʌt noʊ saʊn keɪm aʊt, ən əɹ aɪbɹaʊz wɝ hæfweɪ ʌp əɹ fɔɹhɛd. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin əɹ soʊ teɪkən əbæk, ðoʊ ʃi mʌst əv ɪkspɛktəd ðɪs. ə waɪf ɔlweɪz tʊk pɹɛsəɾəns wɪð əɹ hʌzbən oʊvɝ ɪz mʌðɝ. "wɛl, hʌzbənd, wʌt wəd jə seɪ?"

"Any married man may address the Stump," Erith said firmly. There was no doubt this time. Her ears definitely slanted back. "Will you allow me to tend my own husband, Mother Covril?" His mother's mouth moved, but no sound came out, and her eyebrows were halfway up her forehead. He did not think he had ever seen her so taken aback, though she must have expected this. A wife always took precedence with her husband over his mother. "Well, Husband, what would you say?"

hi wɑz nɑɾ iɡɝ, hi wɑz dɛspɹɪt. hi tʊk ə lɔŋ swɑloʊ ʌv ðə spaɪs-sɛntɪd ti, bʌɾ ɪz maʊθ fɛl dʒʌst əz dʒɹaɪ æftɝwɝd. hɪz mʌðɝ wɑz ɹaɪt; ðə mɔɹ pipəl wɝ lɪsnɪŋ, ðə mɔɹ i tɛndəd tə fɝɡɛt wʌɾ i ɪntɛndəd tə seɪ ən ɡoʊ ɔf ɑn tænʒənts. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi hæd tə ədmɪt ðət səmtaɪmz i ɹæmbəld ə bɪt wɪð oʊnli ə fju lɪsənɝz. dʒʌst ə bɪt. naʊ ən ðɛn. hi nu ðə fɔɹmz - ə tʃaɪld ə fɪfti nu ðə fɔɹmz - jɛɾ i kəd nɑt meɪk ðə wɝdz kʌm. ðə fju lɪsnɪŋ tə hɪm naʊ wɝ nɑt dʒʌst ɛni fju. hɪz mʌðɝ wɑz ə feɪməs spikɝ, ɛldɝ heɪmən ə noʊɾəd wʌn, nɑt tə mɛnʃən biɪŋ ən ɛldɝ. ən ðəɹ wɑz ɛɹɪθ. ə mæn wɑntəd tə stænd wɛl ɪn ɪz waɪfs aɪz.

He was not eager, he was desperate. He took a long swallow of the spice-scented tea, but his mouth felt just as dry afterward. His mother was right; the more people were listening, the more he tended to forget what he intended to say and go off on tangents. In truth, he had to admit that sometimes he rambled a bit with only a few listeners. Just a bit. Now and then. He knew the forms - a child of fifty knew the forms - yet he could not make the words come. The few listening to him now were not just any few. His mother was a famous Speaker, Elder Haman a noted one, not to mention being an Elder. And there was Erith. A man wanted to stand well in his wife's eyes.

tɝnɪŋ ɪz bæk ɑn ðɛm, hi stʃɹoʊd tə ðə nɪɹəst wɪndoʊ ən stʊd ɹoʊlɪŋ ðə tikʌp bɪtwin ɪz pɑmz. ðə wɪndoʊ wɑz saɪz disənli, ðoʊ ðə peɪnz sɛɾ ɪn ðə kɑɹv keɪsmənt wɝ noʊ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðoʊz ɪn ðə ɹumz bɪloʊ. ðə ɹeɪn hæd dwɪndəl tə ə dʒɹɪzəl fɔlɪŋ fɹəm ə ɡɹeɪ skaɪ, ən dɪspaɪt bʌbəlz ɪn ðə ɡlæs i kəd meɪk aʊt ðə tʃɹiz bɪɑn ðə filz, paɪn ən saʊɝɡəm ən ði əkeɪʒənəl oʊk, ɔl fʊl ə nu ɡɹoʊθ. ælɡɝɪnz pipəl tɛndəd ðɛɹ fɔɹəst wɛl, klɪɹɪŋ aʊt ðə dɛdfɔl tə ɹɑb waɪldfaɪɝ ʌv ɪts tɪndɝ. faɪɝ hæd tə bi juz kɛɹfəli.

Turning his back on them, he strode to the nearest window and stood rolling the teacup between his palms. The window was sized decently, though the panes set in the carved casement were no larger than those in the rooms below. The rain had dwindled to a drizzle falling from a gray sky, and despite bubbles in the glass he could make out the trees beyond the fields, pine and sourgum and the occasional oak, all full of new growth. Algarin's people tended their forest well, clearing out the deadfall to rob wildfire of its tinder. Fire had to be used carefully.

ðə wɝdz keɪm mɔɹ izəli naʊ ðəɾ i kəd nɑt si ði ʌðɝz wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. ʃəɾ i bɪɡɪn wɪð ðə lɔŋɪŋ? kəd ðeɪ dɛɹ liv ɪf ðeɪ wəd bɪɡɪn daɪɪŋ ɪn ə hændfʊl ə jɪɹz? noʊ, ðət kwɛstʃən wʊɾə bɪn ədʒɹɛs fɝs θɪŋ ən suɾəbəl ænsɝz faʊnd, ɛls ðə stʌmp wʊɾə fɪnɪʃt ɪnsaɪɾ ə jɪɹ. laɪt, ɪf i dɪɾ ædʒɹɛs ðə stʌmp. . . . fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi sɔ ðə kɹaʊdz stændɪŋ ɔl ɝaʊn hɪm, hʌnʒɹədz ən hʌnʒɹədz ə mɛn ən wɪmən weɪɾɪŋ tə hɪɹ ɪz wɝdz, pɝhæps sɛvɹəl θaʊzənd. hɪz tʌŋ tʃɹaɪd tə klɪŋ tə ðə ɹuf ə hɪz maʊθ. hi blɪŋkt, ən ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə bʌbəld ɡlæs bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ən ðə tʃɹiz. hi hæd tə də ɪt. hi wɑz nɑt pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli bɹeɪv, wʌtɛvɝ ɛɹɪθ θɔt, bʌɾ i hæd lɝn əbaʊt bɹeɪvɝi wɑtʃɪŋ hjumənz, wɑtʃɪŋ əm hæŋ ɑn noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðə wɪnz ɡɹu, faɪt wən ðeɪ hæd noʊ hoʊp, faɪɾ ən wɪn kəz ðeɪ fɔt wɪð dɛspɹɪt kɝədʒ. sʌɾənli, hi nu wʌt tə seɪ.

The words came more easily now that he could not see the others watching him. Should he begin with the Longing? Could they dare leave if they would begin dying in a handful of years? No, that question would have been addressed first thing and suitable answers found, else the Stump would have finished inside a year. Light, if he did address the Stump. . . . For a moment, he saw the crowds standing all around him, hundreds and hundreds of men and women waiting to hear his words, perhaps several thousand. His tongue tried to cling to the roof of his mouth. He blinked, and there was only the bubbled glass before him, and the trees. He had to do it. He was not particularly brave, whatever Erith thought, but he had learned about bravery watching humans, watching them hang on no matter how strong the winds grew, fight when they had no hope, fight and win because they fought with desperate courage. Suddenly, he knew what to say.

"ɪn ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, wi dɪd nɑt hʌɾəl ɪn əɹ stɛɾɪŋ, hoʊpɪŋ noʊ tʃɹɑləks əɹ mɹdʒɹɑl wəd bi dʒɹɪvən tə ɛntɝ. wi dɪd nɑɾ oʊpən ðə bʊk ə tʃɹænzleɪʃən ən fli. wi mɑɹtʃt əlɔŋsaɪd ðə hjumənz ən fɔt ðə ʃædoʊ. ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, wi niðɝ hɪɾ ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ nɔɹ oʊpən ðə bʊk ə tʃɹænzleɪʃən. wi mɑɹtʃt wɪð ðə hjumənz ən fɔt ðə ʃædoʊ. ɪn ðə dɑɹkəs jɪɹz, wən hoʊp simd ɡɔn, wi fɔt ðə ʃædoʊ."

"In the War of the Shadow, we did not huddle in our stedding, hoping no Trollocs or Myrddraal would be driven to enter. We did not open the Book of Translation and flee. We marched alongside the humans and fought the Shadow. In the Trolloc Wars, we neither hid in the stedding nor opened the Book of Translation. We marched with the humans and fought the Shadow. In the darkest years, when hope seemed gone, we fought the Shadow."

"æn baɪ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz wi hæd lɝnd nɑt tə ɡɛɾ aʊɝsɛlvz tæŋɡəld ɪn hjumən əfɛɹz," hɪz mʌðɝ pʊɾ ɪn. ðət wɑz əlaʊd. spikɪŋ kəd tɝn ɪndə ə dəbeɪɾ ənlɛs ðə pjʊɹ bjuɾi ʌv jəɹ wɝdz hɛl ðə lɪsənɝz. ʃi hæd wʌns spoʊkən fɹəm sʌnɹaɪz tə sʌnsɛɾ ɪn feɪvɝ ʌv ə vɛɹi ʌnpɑpjəlɝ pəzɪʃən wɪθaʊɾ ə sɪŋɡəl ɪntɝʌpʃən, ən ðə nɛks deɪ, noʊ wʌn hæd ɹɪzən tə spik əɡɛns hɝ. hi kəd nɑt fɔɹm bjuɾəfəl sɛntənsəz. hi kəɾ oʊnli seɪ wʌɾ i bɪlivd. hi dɪd nɑt tɝn fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ.

"And by the War of the Hundred Years we had learned not to get ourselves tangled in human affairs," his mother put in. That was allowed. Speaking could turn into a debate unless the pure beauty of your words held the listeners. She had once spoken from sunrise to sunset in favor of a very unpopular position without a single interruption, and the next day, no one had risen to Speak against her. He could not form beautiful sentences. He could only say what he believed. He did not turn from the window.

"ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz wɑz ə hjumən əfɛɹ, ən nʌn ʌv aʊɝz. ðə ʃædoʊ ɪz əɹ əfɛɹ. wən ɪts ðə ʃædoʊ ðət mʌs bi fɔt, əɹ æksiz əv ɔlweɪz ɡɹoʊn lɔŋ hændəlz. pɝhæps ɪn ə jɪɹ, əɹ faɪv, əɹ tɛn, wɪl oʊpən ðə bʊk ə tʃɹænzleɪʃən, bʌɾ ɪf wi də ɪt naʊ, wi kænɑt ɹʌn əweɪ wɪð ɛni ɹil hoʊp ə seɪfti. tɑɹmən ɡdən ɪz kʌmɪŋ, ən ɑn ðət hæŋz ðə feɪt nɑɾ oʊnli ʌv ðɪs wɝld, bʌɾ ʌv ɛni wɝld wi maɪt fli tə. wən faɪɝ θɹɛɾənz ðə tʃɹiz, wi də nɑt ɹʌn əweɪ ən hoʊp ðət ðə fleɪmz wɪl nɑt fɑloʊ ʌs. wi faɪt. naʊ ðə ʃædoʊ ɪz kʌmɪŋ laɪk waɪldfaɪɝ, ən wi dɛɹ nɑt ɹʌn fɹəm ɪt." sʌmθɪŋ wɑz muvɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, ɔl əlɔŋ ðə laɪn i kəd si. ə hɝɾ ə kæɾəl? ə vɛɹi bɪɡ hɝd, ɪf soʊ.

"The War of the Hundred Years was a human affair, and none of ours. The Shadow is our affair. When it is the Shadow that must be fought, our axes have always grown long handles. Perhaps in a year, or five, or ten, we will open the Book of Translation, but if we do it now, we cannot run away with any real hope of safety. Tarmon Gai'don is coming, and on that hangs the fate not only of this world, but of any world we might flee to. When fire threatens the trees, we do not run away and hope that the flames will not follow us. We fight. Now the Shadow is coming like wildfire, and we dare not run from it." Something was moving among the trees, all along the line he could see. A herd of cattle? A very big herd, if so.

"ðæɾ ɪzən bæd," hɪz mʌðɝ sɛd. "mʌtʃ tu pleɪnspoʊkən tə kæɹi ɛni weɪɾ əɾ ə stɛɾɪŋ stʌmp mʌtʃ lɛs ðə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt nɑt bæd. ɡoʊ ɑn."

"That isn't bad," his mother said. "Much too plainspoken to carry any weight at a stedding Stump much less the Great Stump, of course, but not bad. Go on."

"tʃɹɑləks," hi bɹiðd. ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɪt wɑz, θaʊzənz ə tʃɹɑləks ɪn blæk, spaɪk meɪl spɪlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz əɾ ə ɹʌn wɪð saɪð-kɝv sɔɹdz ɹeɪzd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ spaɪk spɪɹz, səm kæɹiɪŋ tɔɹtʃɪz. tʃɹɑləks əz fɑɹ əz i kəd si tə lɛft ən ɹaɪt. nɑt θaʊzənz. tɛnz ə θaʊzənz.

"Trollocs," he breathed. That was what it was, thousands of Trollocs in black, spiked mail spilling out of the trees at a run with scythe-curved swords raised, shaking their spiked spears, some carrying torches. Trollocs as far as he could see to left and right. Not thousands. Tens of thousands.

ɛɹɪθ pʊʃt ɪn bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ət ðə wɪndoʊ ən ɡæspt. "soʊ mɛni! ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ, lɔɪəl?" ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn əfɹeɪd. ʃi saʊndəd . . . ɪksaɪɾəd!

Erith pushed in beside him at the window and gasped. "So many! Are we going to die, Loial?" She did not sound afraid. She sounded . . . excited!

"nɑɾ ɪf aɪ kən wɔɹn ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz." hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi stɑɹɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə dɔɹ. oʊnli ɛɛs sədaɪ ən æʃəmən kəd seɪv əm naʊ.

"Not if I can warn Rand and the others." He was already starting for the door. Only Aes Sedai and Asha'man could save them now.

"hɪɹ, maɪ bɔɪ, aɪ θɪŋk wi meɪ nid ðiz."

"Here, my boy, I think we may need these."

hi tɝn dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə kætʃ ðə lɔŋ-hændəld æks ðəɾ ɛldɝ heɪmən tɔs hɪm. ði ʌðɝ mænz ɪɹz wɝ bæk ɔl ðə weɪ, leɪd flæɾ əɡɛnst ɪz skʌl. lɔɪəl ɹilaɪzd ɪz oʊn wɝ, tu.

He turned just in time to catch the long-handled axe that Elder Haman tossed him. The other man's ears were back all the way, laid flat against his skull. Loial realized his own were, too.

"hɪɹ, ɛɹɪθ," hɪz mʌðɝ sɛd kɑmli, lɪftɪŋ daʊn wʌn ə ðə pɹunɪŋ naɪvz. "ɪf ðeɪ ɡɛɾ ɪnsaɪd, wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə hoʊld əm ət ðə stɛɹz."

"Here, Erith," his mother said calmly, lifting down one of the pruning knives. "If they get inside, we will try to hold them at the stairs."

"ju ɑɹ maɪ hɪɹoʊ, hʌzbənd," ɛɹɪθ sɛɾ əz ʃi tʊk ðə naɪfs ʃæft ɪn hænd, "bʌɾ ɪf jə ɡɛt jɝsɛlf kɪld, əl bi vɛɹi æŋɡɹi wɪð ju." ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi mɛn ɪt.

"You are my hero, Husband," Erith said as she took the knife's shaft in hand, "but if you get yourself killed, I will be very angry with you." She sounded as if she meant it.

ən ðən i ən ɛldɝ heɪmən wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ təɡɛðɝ, paʊndɪŋ daʊn ðə stɛɹz, bɛloʊɪŋ ət ðə tɑps ə ðɛɹ lʌŋz ə wɔɹnɪŋ, ən ə bæɾəl kɹaɪ ðət hæd nɑt bɪn hɝɾ ɪn oʊvɝ tu θaʊzən jɪɹz. "tʃɹɑləks kʌmɪŋ! ʌp æksiz ən klɪɹ ðə fild! tʃɹɑləks kʌmɪŋ!"

And then he and Elder Haman were running down the corridor together, pounding down the stairs, bellowing at the tops of their lungs a warning, and a battle cry that had not been heard in over two thousand years. "Trollocs coming! Up axes and clear the field! Trollocs coming!"

". . . soʊ əl teɪk kɛɹ ə tɛɹ, lɑɡən, waɪl jə - " əbɹʌpli ɹænd ɹɪŋkəld ɪz noʊz. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðəɾ i æktʃəli  smɛld ə ɹɑɾɪŋ mɪɾən hip sʌɾənli, bʌɾ i fɛlt əz ɪf i dɪd, ən ðə filɪŋ wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ stʃɹɔŋɝ.

". . . so I will take care of Tear, Logain, while you - " Abruptly Rand wrinkled his nose. It was not that he actually smelled a rotting midden heap suddenly, but he felt as if he did, and the feeling was getting stronger.

"ʃæɾoʊzpɔn," kædzueɪn sɛd kwaɪətli, pʊɾɪŋ daʊn əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ən ɹaɪzɪŋ. hɪz skɪn tɪŋɡəld əz ʃi ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz əliviə, wɔkɪŋ bɹɪskli təwɔɹd ðə wɪndoʊz æftɝ ðə ɡɹin sɪstɝ. mɪn stʊd, dʒɹɔɪŋ ə pɛɹ ə θɹoʊɪŋ naɪvz fɹəm əɹ koʊtslivz.

"Shadowspawn," Cadsuane said quietly, putting down her embroidery and rising. His skin tingled as she embraced the Source. Or maybe it was Alivia, walking briskly toward the windows after the Green sister. Min stood, drawing a pair of throwing knives from her coatsleeves.

ət ðə seɪm ɪnstənt, θɹu ðə θɪk wɔlz, hi feɪnli hɝɾ oʊɡiɝ ʃaʊɾɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðoʊz dip, dʒɹʌmlaɪk vɔɪsəz. "tʃɹɑləks kʌmɪŋ! ʌp æksiz ən klɪɹ ðə fild!"

At the same instant, through the thick walls, he faintly heard Ogier shouting. There was no mistaking those deep, drumlike voices. "Trollocs coming! Up axes and clear the field!"

wɪð ən oʊθ, hi lɛp tə hɪz fiɾ ən ɹæn tə ə wɪndoʊ. tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə θaʊzənz keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ðə laɪt ɹeɪn əkɹɔs ðə nuli plæntəd filz, tʃɹɑləks əz tɔl əz oʊɡiɝ ən tɔlɝ, tʃɹɑləks wɪð ɹæmz' hɔɹnz ən ɡoʊts' hɔɹnz, wʊlvz' snaʊts, bɔɹz' snaʊts, tʃɹɑləks wɪð iɡəlz' biks ən kɹɛsts ə fɛðɝz, mʌɾi ɝθ splæʃɪŋ bɪniθ buts ən hʊvz ən pɔz. saɪlən əz dɛθ ðeɪ ɹæn. blæk-klæd mɹdʒɹɑl ɡæləp bɪhaɪn ðɛm, kloʊks hæŋɪŋ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ stændɪŋ stɪl. hi kəd si θɝɾi əɹ fɔɹɾi. haʊ mɛni mɔɹ ɑn ʌðɝ saɪdz ə ðə haʊs?

With an oath, he leaped to his feet and ran to a window. Trollocs in the thousands came running through the light rain across the newly planted fields, Trollocs as tall as Ogier and taller, Trollocs with rams' horns and goats' horns, wolves' snouts, boars' snouts, Trollocs with eagles' beaks and crests of feathers, muddy earth splashing beneath boots and hooves and paws. Silent as death they ran. Black-clad Myrddraal galloped behind them, cloaks hanging as if they were standing still. He could see thirty or forty. How many more on other sides of the house?

ʌðɝz hæd hɝd ði oʊɡiɝz kɹaɪz, əɹ meɪbi dʒʌs lʊkt aʊɾ ə wɪndoʊ. laɪtnɪŋ bɪɡæn tə fɔl əmʌŋ ðə tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ tʃɹɑləks, sɪlvɝi boʊls ðət stʃɹʌk wɪð ə ɹɔɹ ən hɝl hjudʒ bɑɾiz ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. ɪn ʌðɝ pleɪsəz, ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪɹʌptəɾ ɪn fleɪmz, faʊnteɪnɪŋ dɝɾ ən pɑɹts ə tʃɹɑləks, hɛdz, ɑɹmz, lɛɡz wilɪŋ θɹu ði ɛɹ. bɔlz ə faɪɝ stʃɹʌk əm ən ɪksploʊɾəd, itʃ kɪlɪŋ dʌzənz. bʌɾ ɑn ðeɪ ɹæn, əz fæst əz hɔɹsəz ɪf nɑt fæstɝ. ɹænd kəd nɑt si ðə wivz ðət dʒɹu səm ə ðoʊz laɪtnɪŋ boʊls. naʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝ dɪskʌvɝd, ðə tʃɹɑləks bɪɡæn tə ʃaʊt, ə wɝdləs ɹɔɹ ə ɹeɪdʒ. ɪn ðə θætʃ-ɹuft aʊtbɪldɪŋz, lɑɹdʒ stɝɾi bɑɹnz ən steɪbəlz, səm ə bæʃɪɹz sɑldəiənz stʌk ðɛɹ hɛdz aʊɾ ən kwɪkli pʊld əm bæk əɡɛn, dʒɹɔɪŋ ðə dɔɹz ʃʌt bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

Others had heard the Ogier's cries, or maybe just looked out a window. Lightning began to fall among the charging Trollocs, silvery bolts that struck with a roar and hurled huge bodies in every direction. In other places, the ground erupted in flames, fountaining dirt and parts of Trollocs, heads, arms, legs wheeling through the air. Balls of fire struck them and exploded, each killing dozens. But on they ran, as fast as horses if not faster. Rand could not see the weaves that drew some of those lightning bolts. Now that they were discovered, the Trollocs began to shout, a wordless roar of rage. In the thatch-roofed outbuildings, large sturdy barns and stables, some of Bashere's Saldaeans stuck their heads out and quickly pulled them back again, drawing the doors shut behind them.

"ju toʊl jəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ðeɪ kəd tʃænəl tə dɪfɛn ðɛmsɛlvz?" hi sɛd kɑmli.

"You told your Aes Sedai they could channel to defend themselves?" he said calmly.

"du aɪ lʊk ful ɪnʌf nɑt tə?" lɑɡən snɑɹəld. əɾ ənʌðɝ wɪndoʊ, hi ɔlɹɛɾi hɛl seɪɾɪn, nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ɹænd kəd dʒɹɔ. hi wɑz wivɪŋ əz fæst əz i kʊd. "du jə ɪntɛn tə hɛlp əɹ dʒʌst wɑtʃ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən?" ðəɹ wɑz ɪntaɪɝli tu mʌtʃ sɑɹkæzəm ɪn ðæt, bʌt naʊ wɑz nɑt ðə taɪm tə bɹɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp.

"Do I look fool enough not to?" Logain snarled. At another window, he already held saidin, nearly as much as Rand could draw. He was weaving as fast as he could. "Do you intend to help or just watch, my Lord Dragon?" There was entirely too much sarcasm in that, but now was not the time to bring it up.
