dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ɹænd ɡɹɪp ðə keɪsmən ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɪndoʊ əɡɛns ðə dɪzinəs ðət wəd kʌm - ðə dʒɹæɡənz' ɡoʊldən-meɪn hɛdz ɑn ðə bæks ə hɪz hænz sim tə ɹɪð - ən ɹitʃt aʊt tə siz ðə paʊɝ. hɪz hɛd spʌn əz seɪɾɪn flʌɾəd ɪndə hɪm, aɪsi fleɪmz ən kɹʌmbəlɪŋ maʊntənz, ə keɪɑs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl ɪm ʌndɝ. bʌt blɛsədli klin. hi stɪl fɛl ðə wʌndɝ ə ðæt. hɪz hɛd spʌn ən ɪz stʌmək wɑntəd tə ɛmpti ɪtsɛlf, ði ɑɾ ɪlnəs ðət ʃʊɾə ɡɔn wɪð ðə teɪnt, jɛt ðət wɑz nɑt waɪ hi klʌŋ tə ðə keɪsmən ivən hɑɹɾɝ. ðə wʌn paʊɝ fɪld ɪm - bʌɾ ɪn ðət moʊmən ə dɪzinəs, luz θɝɪn hæd sizd ɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. nʌm wɪð hɔɹɝ, hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl ɹeɪsɪŋ təwɔɹd ði aʊtbɪldɪŋz. wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn hɪm, hi kəd meɪk aʊt ðə pɪnz fæsən tə mæsɪv meɪld ʃoʊldɝz. ðə sɪlvɝ wɝlwɪn ə ði ɑfɹeɪt bæn ən ðə blʌd-ɹɛd tʃɹaɪɾənt ə ðə koʊbəl. ðə fɔɹk laɪtnɪŋ ə ðə ɹmlən ən ðə hʊkt æks ə ði ɑlɡhəl. ði aɪɝn fɪst ə ðə deɪmən ən ðə ɹɛd, blʌdsteɪn fɪst ə ðə nɑmən. ən ðəɹ wɝ skʌlz. ðə hɔɹn skʌl ə ðə dɑvɑl ən ðə paɪl hjumən skʌlz ə ðə ɡɑɹɡl ən ðə skʌl kloʊvən baɪ ə saɪð-kɝv sɔɹɾ ə ðə dʒɪnən ən ðə dæɡɝ-pɪɹst skʌl ə ðə bænʃin. tʃɹɑləks laɪk skʌlz, ɪf ðeɪ kəd bi sɛd tə laɪk ɛniθɪŋ. ɪt sim ðə twɛlv pɹɪnsəpəl bænz maɪɾ ɔl bi ɪnvɑlvd, ən səm ə ðə lɛsɝ. hi sɔ pɪnz i dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz. wʌt simd ə stɛɹɪŋ aɪ, ə dæɡɝ-pɪɹs hænd, ə mæn-ʃeɪp ɹæpt ɪn fleɪmz. ðeɪ nɪɹd ði aʊtbɪldɪŋz, wɛɹ sɔɹdz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɹʌs θɹu ðə θætʃ əz ðə sɑldəiənz tʃɹaɪd tə kʌt weɪz ɑntu ðə ɹufs. θætʃ wɑz tʌf. ðeɪ wəd nid tə wɝk dɛspɝətli hɑɹd. ɑd, ðə θɔts ðət keɪm wən ə mædmæn u wɑntəd tə daɪ maɪt wɛl kɪl jə ɪn ðə nɛks hɑɹtbit.

Drawing a deep breath, Rand gripped the casement on either side of the window against the dizziness that would come - the Dragons' golden-maned heads on the backs of his hands seemed to writhe - and reached out to seize the Power. His head spun as saidin flooded into him, icy flames and crumbling mountains, a chaos trying to pull him under. But blessedly clean. He still felt the wonder of that. His head spun and his stomach wanted to empty itself, the odd illness that should have gone with the taint, yet that was not why he clung to the casement even harder. The One Power filled him - but in that moment of dizziness, Lews Therin had seized it away from him. Numb with horror, he stared at the Trollocs and Myrddraal racing toward the outbuildings. With the Power in him, he could make out the pins fastened to massive mailed shoulders. The silver whirlwind of the Ahf'frait band and the blood-red trident of the Ko'bal. The forked lightning of the Ghraem'lan and the hooked axe of the Al'ghol. The iron fist of the Dhai'mon and the red, bloodstained fist of the Kno'mon. And there were skulls. The horned skull of the Dha'vol and the piled human skulls of the Ghar'ghael and the skull cloven by a scythe-curved sword of the Dhjin'nen and the dagger-pierced skull of the Bhan'sheen. Trollocs liked skulls, if they could be said to like anything. It seemed the twelve principal bands might all be involved, and some of the lesser. He saw pins he did not recognize. What seemed a staring eye, a dagger-pierced hand, a man-shape wrapped in flames. They neared the outbuildings, where swords were beginning to thrust through the thatch as the Saldaeans tried to cut ways onto the roofs. Thatch was tough. They would need to work desperately hard. Odd, the thoughts that came when a madman who wanted to die might well kill you in the next heartbeat.

floʊz ʌv ɛɹ pʊʃt ðə keɪsmən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm aʊɾ ɪn ə ʃaʊɝ ə ʃæɾɝd ɡlæs ən fɹæɡməntɪd wʊd. maɪ hænz, luz θɝɪn pæntɪd. waɪ kæn aɪ muv maɪ hænz? aɪ nid tə ɹeɪz maɪ hænz! ɝθ, ɛɹ ən faɪɝ wɛn ɪndə ə wiv ɹænd dɪd nɑt noʊ, sɪks ə ðɛm ət wʌns. ɪksɛp ðəɾ əz sun əz i sɔ ðə spɪnɪŋ, hi dɪd noʊ. blɑsəm ə faɪɝ. sɪks vɝɾɪkəl ɹɛd ʃæfs əpɪɹɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks, tɛn fit tɔl ən θɪnɝ ðən ɹændz fɔɹɑɹm. ðə nɪɹəs tʃɹɑləks wəd bi hɪɹɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃɹɪl waɪn, bʌɾ ənlɛs mɛmɹiz hæd bɪn pæs daʊn fɹəm ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ðeɪ wəd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ hɪɹɪŋ dɛθ. luz θɝɪn spʌn ðə læs θɹɛɾ ʌv ɛɹ, ən faɪɝ blɑsəmd. wɪð ə ɹɔɹ ðət ʃʊk ðə mænɝ haʊs, itʃ ɹɛd ʃæft ɪkspændəɾ ɪn ə hɑɹtbit tə ə dɪsk ə fleɪm θɝɾi fiɾ əkɹɔs. hɔɹn hɛdz ən snaʊɾəd hɛdz flu ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ən pɪnwilɪŋ ɑɹmz, buɾɪd lɛɡz ən lɛɡz ðəɾ ɛndəɾ ɪn pɔz əɹ hʊvz. tʃɹɑləks ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ən mɔɹ əweɪ fɹəm ði ɪksploʊʒənz wɛn daʊn, ən oʊnli səm ɡɑɾ ʌp əɡɛn. ivən əz i wɑz spɪnɪŋ ðoʊz wɛbz, luz θɝɪn spʌn sɪks ʌðɝz, spɪɹət tʌtʃt wɪð faɪɝ, ðə wiv fəɹ ə ɡeɪtweɪ, bʌt ðən i æɾəd tʌtʃəz ə ɝθ, soʊ, ən soʊ. ðə fəmɪljɝ sɪlvɝi-blu vɝɾɪkəl stʃɹiks əpɪɹd, speɪst aʊt nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə mænɝ haʊs, ɡɹaʊn ɹænd nu wɛl, ɹoʊteɪɾɪŋ ɪndə - nɑɾ oʊpənɪŋz, bʌt ðə mɪsti bæk ʌv ə ɡeɪtweɪ, fɔɹ peɪsɪz baɪ fɔɹ. ɹæðɝ ðən ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ oʊpən, ðeɪ ɹoʊteɪɾɪd ʃʌɾ əɡɛn, oʊpənɪŋ ən ʃʌɾɪŋ kəntɪnjuəsli. ən ɹæðɝ ðən ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ fɪkst, ðeɪ spɛd təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹɑləks. ɡeɪtweɪz ən jɛt nɑt. dɛθɡeɪts. əz sun əz ðə dɛθɡeɪts bɪɡæn tə muv, luz θɝɪn nɑɾɪd ðə wɛbz, ə lus nɑɾɪŋ ðət wəd hoʊld oʊnli fəɹ mɪnəts bɪfɔɹ əlaʊɪŋ ðə hoʊl wiv tə dɪsəpeɪt, ən bɪɡæn spɪnɪŋ əɡɛn. mɔɹ dɛθɡeɪts, mɔɹ blɑsəmz ə faɪɝ, ɹætlɪŋ ðə wɔlz ə ðə haʊs, bloʊɪŋ tʃɹɑləks əpɑɹt, flɪŋɪŋ əm daʊn. ðə fɝst ə ðə spiɾɪŋ dɛθɡeɪts stʃɹʌk ðə tʃɹɑləks ən kɑɹv θɹu ðɛm. ɪt wɑz nɑt dʒʌs ðə slaɪsɪŋ ɛdʒ ə ðə kɑnstənli oʊpənɪŋ ən kloʊzɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪz. wɛɹ ə dɛθɡeɪt pæst, ðəɹ sɪmpli wɝ noʊ tʃɹɑləks ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ. maɪ hænz! ðə mædmæn haʊld. maɪ hænz!

Flows of Air pushed the casement in front of him out in a shower of shattered glass and fragmented wood. My hands, Lews Therin panted. Why can't I move my hands? I need to raise my hands! Earth, Air and Fire went into a weave Rand did not know, six of them at once. Except that as soon as he saw the spinning, he did know. Blossom of Fire. Six vertical red shafts appeared among the Trollocs, ten feet tall and thinner than Rand's forearm. The nearest Trollocs would be hearing their shrill whine, but unless memories had been passed down from the War of the Shadow, they would not realize they were hearing death. Lews Therin spun the last thread of Air, and fire blossomed. With a roar that shook the manor house, each red shaft expanded in a heartbeat to a disc of flame thirty feet across. Horned heads and snouted heads flew into the air, and pinwheeling arms, booted legs and legs that ended in paws or hooves. Trollocs a hundred paces and more away from the explosions went down, and only some got up again. Even as he was spinning those webs, Lews Therin spun six others, Spirit touched with Fire, the weave for a gateway, but then he added touches of Earth, so, and so. The familiar silvery-blue vertical streaks appeared, spaced out not far from the manor house, ground Rand knew well, rotating into - not openings, but the misty back of a gateway, four paces by four. Rather than remaining open, they rotated shut again, opening and shutting continuously. And rather than remaining fixed, they sped toward the Trollocs. Gateways and yet not. Deathgates. As soon as the Deathgates began to move, Lews Therin knotted the webs, a loose knotting that would hold only for minutes before allowing the whole weave to dissipate, and began spinning again. More Deathgates, more Blossoms of Fire, rattling the walls of the house, blowing Trollocs apart, flinging them down. The first of the speeding Deathgates struck the Trollocs and carved through them. It was not just the slicing edge of the constantly opening and closing gateways. Where a Deathgate passed, there simply were no Trollocs remaining. My hands! the madman howled. My hands!

sloʊli ɹænd ɹeɪzd ɪz hænz, stʌk əm θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ. ɪmiɾiətli luz θɝɪn woʊv faɪɝ ən ɝθ ɪn ɪntʃɹəkət kɑmbəneɪʃən, ən ɹɛd fɪləməns flæʃt fɹəm ɹændz fɪŋɡɝtɪps, tɛn fɹəm itʃ, fænɪŋ aʊt. æɹoʊz ə faɪɝ, ðɪs. hi nu. əz sun əz ðoʊz vænɪʃt, mɔɹ əpɪɹd, soʊ fæs ðət ðeɪ sim tə flɪkɝ ɹæðɝ ðən æktʃəli  ɡoʊ əweɪ. tʃɹɑləks stʃɹʌk baɪ ðə fɪləməns dʒɝkt əz flɛʃ ən blʌd, hiɾəd ɪn ə flæʃ bɪɑn bɔɪlɪŋ, ɪɹʌptəd, dʒɝkt ən fɛl, hoʊlz bloʊn ɪntaɪɝli θɹu ðɛɹ θɪk bɑɾiz. ɔfən, tu əɹ θɹi bɪhaɪn fɛl vɪktəm əz wɛl bɪfɔɹ ə fɪləmən daɪd. hi spɹɛɾ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ən muvd ɪz hænz sloʊli fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd, spɹɛɾɪŋ dɛθ əkɹɔs ðə hoʊl laɪn. blɑsəmz ə faɪɝ əpɪɹd ðət wɝ nɑɾ ɪz wivɪŋ, ən dɛθɡeɪts, slaɪtli smɔlɝ ðən luz θɝɪnz, ən æɹoʊz ə faɪɝ ðət mʌst əv bɪn lɑɡənz. ði ʌðɝ æʃəmən wɝ peɪɪŋ ətɛnʃən, bʌt fju wəd bi wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd si ðoʊz læs tu wɛbz spʌn.

Slowly Rand raised his hands, stuck them through the opening. Immediately Lews Therin wove Fire and Earth in intricate combination, and red filaments flashed from Rand's fingertips, ten from each, fanning out. Arrows of Fire, this. He knew. As soon as those vanished, more appeared, so fast that they seemed to flicker rather than actually go away. Trollocs struck by the filaments jerked as flesh and blood, heated in a flash beyond boiling, erupted, jerked and fell, holes blown entirely through their thick bodies. Often, two or three behind fell victim as well before a filament died. He spread his fingers and moved his hands slowly from side to side, spreading death across the whole line. Blossoms of Fire appeared that were not his weaving, and Deathgates, slightly smaller than Lews Therin's, and Arrows of Fire that must have been Logain's. The other Asha'man were paying attention, but few would be where they could see those last two webs spun.

tʃɹɑləks fɛl baɪ ðə hʌnʒɹədz, ðə θaʊzənz, ɹɪvən baɪ laɪtnɪŋ boʊls ən bɔlz ə faɪɝ, blɑsəmz ə faɪɝ ən dɛθɡeɪts ən æɹoʊz ə faɪɝ, ði ɝθ ɪtsɛlf ɪksploʊɾɪŋ bɪniθ ðɛɹ fit, jɛɾ ɑn ðeɪ ɹeɪst, ɹɔɹɪŋ ən weɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ wɛpənz, mɹdʒɹɑl ɹaɪɾɪŋ kloʊs bɪhaɪnd, blæk-bleɪɾɪd sɔɹdz ɪn hænd. əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ði aʊtbɪldɪŋz, səm ə ðə tʃɹɑləks sɝaʊndəd ðɛm, paʊndɪŋ ɑn ðə dɔɹz wɪð ðɛɹ fɪsts, pɹaɪɪŋ ət ðə bɔɹdz ə ðə wɔlz wɪð ðɛɹ sɔɹdz ən spɪɹz, tɔsɪŋ fleɪmɪŋ tɔɹtʃɪz ɑntu ðə θætʃt ɹufs. sɑldəiənz ʌp ðɛɹ, wɝkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsboʊz əz fæst əz ðeɪ kʊd, kɪk ðə tɔɹtʃɪz bæk daʊn, bʌt səm hʌŋ ʌp ɑn ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə ɹuf, ən fleɪmz bɪɡæn kætʃɪŋ ivən ɑn dæmp θætʃ.

Trollocs fell by the hundreds, the thousands, riven by lightning bolts and balls of fire, Blossoms of Fire and Deathgates and Arrows of Fire, the earth itself exploding beneath their feet, yet on they raced, roaring and waving their weapons, Myrddraal riding close behind, black-bladed swords in hand. As they reached the outbuildings, some of the Trollocs surrounded them, pounding on the doors with their fists, prying at the boards of the walls with their swords and spears, tossing flaming torches onto the thatched roofs. Saldaeans up there, working their horsebows as fast as they could, kicked the torches back down, but some hung up on the edges of the roof, and flames began catching even on damp thatch.

ðə faɪɝz, ɹænd θɔɾ ət luz θɝɪn. ðə sɑldəiənz wɪl bɝn! də sʌmθɪŋ!

The fires, Rand thought at Lews Therin. The Saldaeans will burn! Do something!

luz θɝɪn meɪd noʊ ɹɪplaɪ, oʊnli woʊv dɛθ əz fæst əz i kəɾ ən hɝld ɪɾ ət ðə tʃɹɑləks, dɛθɡeɪts ən æɹoʊz ə faɪɝ. eɪ mɹdʒɹɑl, ɹɪɾəld baɪ hæf ə dʌzən ɹɛd fɪləməns, wɑz flʌŋ fɹəm ɪts sæɾəl, ðən ənʌðɝ. ə θɝd lɔst ɪts hɛd tə ən æɹoʊ ʌv faɪɝ ɪn ən ɪksploʊʒən ə bɔɪl blʌɾ ən flɛʃ, bʌt ðət wʌn ɹoʊɾ ɑn, weɪvɪŋ ɪts sɔɹd, əz ɪf ɪt dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪt wɑz dɛd. ɹænd wɑz sikɪŋ əm aʊt. ɪf ðə mɹdʒɹɑl wɝ ɔl kɪld, ðə tʃɹɑləks maɪt wɛl tɝn ən ɹʌn.

Lews Therin made no reply, only wove death as fast as he could and hurled it at the Trollocs, Deathgates and Arrows of Fire. A Myrddraal, riddled by half a dozen red filaments, was flung from its saddle, then another. A third lost its head to an Arrow of Fire in an explosion of boiled blood and flesh, but that one rode on, waving its sword, as if it did not know it was dead. Rand was seeking them out. If the Myrddraal were all killed, the Trollocs might well turn and run.

dɛθɡeɪts ən æɹoʊz ə faɪɝ oʊnli, luz θɝɪn spʌn naʊ. ðə mæs ə tʃɹɑləks wɑz tu kloʊz tə ðə mænɝ haʊs fəɹ blɑsəmz ə faɪɝ. səm ə ði æʃəmən əpɛɹənli dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðət ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. ðə ɹum ʃʊk tə ɡɹeɪt bumz, ðə hoʊl mænɝ haʊs ʃʊk, əz ɪf stʃɹʌk baɪ hjudʒ slɛdʒhæmɝz, ʃʊk əz ðoʊ əbaʊt tə ʃeɪk əpɑɹt, ən ðən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɔɹ ɪksploʊʒənz, ɪksɛpt wɛɹ ə faɪɝbɔl ɪɹʌptəɾ əɹ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪtsɛlf ɪksploʊɾəd tə θɹoʊ tʃɹɑləks laɪk bɹoʊkən tɔɪz. ðə skaɪ sim tə ɹeɪn laɪtnɪŋ. sɪlvɝ-blu boʊls stʃɹʌk kəntɪnjuəsli soʊ kloʊs tə ðə haʊs ðət ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɹændz ɑɹmz ən tʃɛs tʃɹaɪd tə lɪft, ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz hɛd.

Deathgates and Arrows of Fire only, Lews Therin spun now. The mass of Trollocs was too close to the manor house for Blossoms of Fire. Some of the Asha'man apparently did not realize that right away. The room shook to great booms, the whole manor house shook, as if struck by huge sledgehammers, shook as though about to shake apart, and then there were no more explosions, except where a fireball erupted or the ground itself exploded to throw Trollocs like broken toys. The sky seemed to rain lightning. Silver-blue bolts struck continuously so close to the house that the hair on Rand's arms and chest tried to lift, the hair on his head.

səm ə ðə tʃɹɑləks səksiɾəd ɪn fɔɹsɪŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹz tə wʌn ə ðə bɑɹnz ən bɪɡæn flʌɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. hi ʃɪftəɾ ɪz hænz, kʌɾɪŋ daʊn ðoʊz stɪl aʊtsaɪd wɪð flɪkɝɪŋ ɹɛd fɪləməns ðət blu hoʊlz ɪn ðɛm. səm hæd mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ɪnsaɪd, bʌt ðoʊz ðə sɑldəiənz wəɾ əv tə dil wɪð ðɛmsɛlvz. ɑn ənʌðɝ bɑɹn ən ə steɪbəl, fleɪmz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹɪpəl ʌp ðə θætʃ, mɛn kɑfɪŋ fɹəm ði ækɹɪd smoʊk əz ðeɪ ʃɑt ðɛɹ baʊz.

Some of the Trollocs succeeded in forcing open the doors to one of the barns and began flooding inside. He shifted his hands, cutting down those still outside with flickering red filaments that blew holes in them. Some had managed to get inside, but those the Saldaeans would have to deal with themselves. On another barn and a stable, flames were beginning to ripple up the thatch, men coughing from the acrid smoke as they shot their bows.

lɪsən tə mi, luz θɝɪn. ðə faɪɝ. jə mʌs də sʌmθɪŋ!

Listen to me, Lews Therin. The fire. You must do something!

luz θɝɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ, dʒʌst spʌn ɪz wɛbz tə kɪl tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl.

Lews Therin said nothing, just spun his webs to kill Trollocs and Myrddraal.

"lɑɡən," ɹænd ʃaʊɾəd. "ðə faɪɝz! pʊɾ əm aʊt!"

"Logain," Rand shouted. "The fires! Put them out!"

ði ʌðɝ mæn dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ iðɝ, bʌt ɹænd sɔ ðə wivz ðət pʊl ðə hit fɹəm ðə fleɪmz, kɪlɪŋ ðɛm. ðeɪ dʒʌs vænɪʃt, livɪŋ bɪhaɪn koʊl blækən θætʃ wɛɹ nɑɾ ivən tɛnʒɹəlz ə smoʊk ɹoʊz. dɛθ wɔkt əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ soʊ kloʊz ðəɾ ivən ði ɪksploʊʒənz ə faɪɝbɔlz ɹæɾəld ðə haʊs, naʊ.

The other man did not answer either, but Rand saw the weaves that pulled the heat from the flames, killing them. They just vanished, leaving behind cold blackened thatch where not even tendrils of smoke rose. Death walked among the Trollocs, but they were so close that even the explosions of fireballs rattled the house, now.

sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɑz ə mɹdʒɹɑl əfʊt bɪsaɪd ðə wɪndoʊ, peɪl aɪləs feɪs əz kɑm əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪz, blæk sɔɹɾ ɔlɹɛɾi stæbɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm. tu θɹoʊn il spɪɹz tʊk ɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛst, ən ə θɹoʊɪŋ naɪf blɑsəmd ɪn ɪts θɹoʊt, bʌɾ ɪɾ oʊnli stæɡɝd bɪfɔɹ ɹɪzumɪŋ ðə θɹʌst. ɹænd bʌntʃt ɪz fɪŋɡɝz təɡɛðɝ, ən dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðə bleɪd ɹitʃt hɪm, ə hʌnʒɹəd æɹoʊz ə faɪɝ ɹɪp θɹu ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, flɪŋɪŋ ɪt bæk twɛnti peɪsɪz tə laɪ ɹɪɾəld ən likɪŋ blæk blʌɾ ɑntu ðə ɡɹaʊnd. mɹdʒɹɑl sɛldəm daɪd ɹaɪɾ əweɪ, bʌt ðɪs wʌn nɛvɝ twɪtʃt.

Suddenly there was a Myrddraal afoot beside the window, pale eyeless face as calm as an Aes Sedai's, black sword already stabbing toward him. Two thrown Aiel spears took it in the chest, and a throwing knife blossomed in its throat, but it only staggered before resuming the thrust. Rand bunched his fingers together, and just before the blade reached him, a hundred Arrows of Fire ripped through the Myrddraal, flinging it back twenty paces to lie riddled and leaking black blood onto the ground. Myrddraal seldom died right away, but this one never twitched.

hɝidli, ɹænd sɝtʃt fəɹ mɔɹ tɑɹɡəts, bʌɾ i ɹilaɪz ðət luz θɝɪn hæd stɑp tʃænəlɪŋ. hi kəd stɪl fil ðə ɡus bʌmps ðət toʊld ɪm kædzueɪn ən əliviə hɛl ðə paʊɝ, stɪl fil seɪɾɪn ɪn lɑɡən, bʌt ði ʌðɝ mæn wɑz wivɪŋ noʊ mɔɹ wɛbz iðɝ. aʊtsaɪd, ðə ɡɹaʊn leɪ kɑɹpəɾɪd wɪð bɑɾiz ən pɑɹts ə bɑɾiz fɹəm ðə filz ɔlmoʊs tə ðə mænɝ haʊs wɔlz. wɪðɪn peɪsɪz ə ðɛm. ə fju hɔɹsəz bɪlɔŋɪŋ tə mɹdʒɹɑl stɪl stʊd, wʌn hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ə fɔɹɛlɪɡ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ bɹoʊkən. ə hɛdləs mɹdʒɹɑl stæɡɝɾ əbaʊt, fleɪlɪŋ waɪldli wɪð ɪts sɔɹd, ən hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ə tʃɹɑlɑk dʒɝkt əɹ tʃɹaɪd tə lɪft ɪtsɛlf ən feɪld, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ɛls muvd.

Hurriedly, Rand searched for more targets, but he realized that Lews Therin had stopped channeling. He could still feel the goose bumps that told him Cadsuane and Alivia held the Power, still feel saidin in Logain, but the other man was weaving no more webs either. Outside, the ground lay carpeted with bodies and parts of bodies from the fields almost to the manor house walls. Within paces of them. A few horses belonging to Myrddraal still stood, one holding up a foreleg as if it were broken. A headless Myrddraal staggered about, flailing wildly with its sword, and here and there a Trolloc jerked or tried to lift itself and failed, but nothing else moved.

ɪts dʌn, hi θɔt. ɪts dʌn, luz θɝɪn. jə kən ɹilis seɪɾɪn naʊ. hɑɹɪlɪn ən ɪneɪlə wɝ stændɪŋ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, veɪld ən spɪɹz ɪn hænd. mɪn stʊd bɪsaɪd ðɛm, hɝ feɪs ɡɹɪm, ə θɹoʊɪŋ naɪf ɪn iðɝ hænd. ðə bɑnd wɑz fʊl ə fɪɹ, ən nɑt fəɹ hɝsɛlf, hi səspɛktəd. ðeɪ hæd seɪvd ɪz laɪf, bʌɾ i hæd tə seɪv ɪt hɪmsɛlf, naʊ.

It's done, he thought. It's done, Lews Therin. You can release saidin now. Harilin and Enaila were standing on the table, veiled and spears in hand. Min stood beside them, her face grim, a throwing knife in either hand. The bond was full of fear, and not for herself, he suspected. They had saved his life, but he had to save it himself, now.

"ə kloʊs ɹʌn θɪŋ," lɑɡən mʌɾɝd. "ɪf ðɪs hæd hæpən bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɝaɪvd. . . . ə kloʊs-ɹʌn θɪŋ." hi ɡeɪv hɪmsɛlf ə ʃeɪk ən ɹilis ðə sɔɹs, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɪz ɡlæsləs wɪndoʊ. "dɪd jə ɪntɛn kipɪŋ ðiz nu wivz fəɹ jəɹ feɪvɹɪts, laɪk teɪm? ðoʊz ɡeɪtweɪz. wɛɹ dɪd wi sɛn ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks? aɪ dʒʌs kɑpid jəɹ wiv ɪɡzækli."

"A close run thing," Logain muttered. "If this had happened before I arrived. . . . A close-run thing." He gave himself a shake and released the Source, turning away from his glassless window. "Did you intend keeping these new weaves for your favorites, like Taim? Those gateways. Where did we send those Trollocs? I just copied your weave exactly."

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ wɛɹ ðeɪ wɛnt," ɹænd sɛɾ æbsənli. hɪz ətɛnʃən wɑz foʊkəst ɑn luz θɝɪn. ðə mædmæn, ðə blʌɾi vɔɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd, dʒɹu ə lɪɾəl dipɝ ɑn ðə paʊɝ. lɛt ɡoʊ, mæn. "ʃæɾoʊzpɔn kæn sɝvaɪv pæsɪŋ θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ."

"It doesn't matter where they went," Rand said absently. His attention was focused on Lews Therin. The madman, the bloody voice in his head, drew a little deeper on the Power. Let go, man. "Shadowspawn can't survive passing through a gateway."

aɪ wɑnə daɪ, luz θɝɪn sɛd. aɪ wɑnə dʒɔɪn aɪlaɪɛnə.

I want to die, Lews Therin said. I want to join Ilyena.

ɪf jə ɹɪli wɑntəd tə daɪ, waɪ dɪd jə kɪl tʃɹɑləks? ɹænd θɔt. waɪ kɪl ðət mɹdʒɹɑl? "pipəl wɪl faɪnd ɡɹups ə dɛd tʃɹɑləks ən meɪbi mɹdʒɹɑl wɪθaʊɾ ə mɑɹk ɑn ðɛm," hi sɛɾ əlaʊd.

If you really wanted to die, why did you kill Trollocs? Rand thought. Why kill that Myrddraal? "People will find groups of dead Trollocs and maybe Myrddraal without a mark on them," he said aloud.

aɪ sim tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ daɪɪŋ, luz θɝɪn mɝmɝd. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ aɪ dɪɾ ɪt. hi dʒɹu dipɝ stɪl, ən smɔl peɪnz ɡɹu ɪn ɹændz tɛmpəlz.

I seem to remember dying, Lews Therin murmured. I remember how I did it. He drew deeper still, and small pains grew in Rand's temples.

"nɑt tu mɛni ɪn ɛni wʌn pleɪs, ðoʊ. ðə dɛstəneɪʃən ʃɪfs ɛvɹi taɪm ə dɛθɡeɪɾ oʊpənz." ɹænd ɹʌbd əɾ ɪz tɛmpəlz. ðət peɪn wɑz ə wɔɹnɪŋ. hi wɑz kloʊs tə ði əmaʊn ə seɪɾɪn i kəd hoʊld wɪθaʊt daɪɪŋ əɹ biɪŋ bɝn aʊt. jə kæn daɪ jɛt, hi toʊld luz θɝɪn. wɪv tə ɹitʃ tɑɹmən ɡdən əɹ ðə wɝl daɪz.

"Not too many in any one place, though. The destination shifts every time a Deathgate opens." Rand rubbed at his temples. That pain was a warning. He was close to the amount of saidin he could hold without dying or being burnt out. You can't die yet, he told Lews Therin. We have to reach Tarmon Gai'don or the world dies.

"eɪ dɛθɡeɪt," lɑɡən sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs tɪŋd wɪð dɪsteɪst. "waɪ ɑɹ jə stɪl hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ?" hi æsk sʌɾənli. "æn soʊ mʌtʃ. ɪf jəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃoʊ mi ðət jəɹ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən aɪ æm, aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ ɪt. aɪ sɔ haʊ lɑɹdʒ jəɹ . . . jəɹ dɛθɡeɪts wɝ kəmpɛɹd tə maɪn. ən aɪd seɪ jəɹ hoʊldɪŋ ɛvɹi dʒɹɑp ə seɪɾɪn ðət jə kən seɪfli."

"A Deathgate," Logain said, his voice tinged with distaste. "Why are you still holding the Power?" he asked suddenly. "And so much. If you're trying to show me that you're stronger than I am, I already know it. I saw how large your . . . your Deathgates were compared to mine. And I'd say you're holding every drop of saidin that you can safely."

ðət sɝɾənli kɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌnz ətɛnʃən. mɪn tʌkt əɹ naɪvz əweɪ ən lɛp daʊn fɹəm ðə teɪbəl, ðə bɑn sʌɾənli soʊ fʊl ə fɪɹ ɪt sim tə θɹəb wɪð ɪt. hɑɹɪlɪn ən ɪneɪlə ɪkstʃeɪnʒd wɝid ɡlænsɪz, ðən wɛn bæk tə stɛɹɪŋ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊz. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs tʃɹɑləks tə bi dɛɾ əntɪl ðə kɔɹpsəz wɝ θɹi deɪz bɛɹid. əliviə tʊk ə stɛp təwɔɹd hɪm, fɹaʊnɪŋ, bʌɾ i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd slaɪtli, ən ʃi tɝn bæk tə hɝ wɪndoʊ, ðoʊ hɝ fɹaʊn ɹɪmeɪnd.

That certainly caught everyone's attention. Min tucked her knives away and leapt down from the table, the bond suddenly so full of fear it seemed to throb with it. Harilin and Enaila exchanged worried glances, then went back to staring out the windows. They did not trust Trollocs to be dead until the corpses were three days buried. Alivia took a step toward him, frowning, but he shook his head slightly, and she turned back to her window, though her frown remained.

kædzueɪn ɡlaɪɾɪd daʊn ðə ɹum, hɝ smuð feɪs stɝnli kəmpoʊzd. "wʌt dʌz i fil?" ʃi dɪmændəɾ ə mɪn. "doʊn tɔɪ wɪð mi, ɡɝl. jə noʊ ðə kɑst ə ðæt. aɪ noʊ ðəɾ i bɑndəd ju, ən jə noʊ aɪ noʊ. ɪz i əfɹeɪd?"

Cadsuane glided down the room, her smooth face sternly composed. "What does he feel?" she demanded of Min. "Don't toy with me, girl. You know the cost of that. I know that he bonded you, and you know I know. Is he afraid?"

"hiz nɛvɝ əfɹeɪd," mɪn sɛd. "ɪksɛp fəɹ mi ɔɹ. . . ." ʃi sɛɾ əɹ dʒɔ stʌbɝnli ən foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, fɪksɪŋ kædzueɪn wɪð ə ɡlɛɹ ðət dɛɹd ðə ɡɹin sɪstɝ tə də hɝ wɝst. baɪ ðə tæŋɡəl mɪks ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ɹeɪnʒɪŋ fɹəm fɪɹ tə ʃeɪm ðət ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kip aʊɾ ə ðə bɑn ən feɪld, ʃi hæd səm aɪdiə ʌv wʌt kædzueɪnz wɝs kəd bi.

"He's never afraid," Min said. "Except for me or. . . ." She set her jaw stubbornly and folded her arms beneath her breasts, fixing Cadsuane with a glare that dared the Green sister to do her worst. By the tangled mix of emotions ranging from fear to shame that she tried to keep out of the bond and failed, she had some idea of what Cadsuane's worst could be.

"aɪm stændɪŋ ʌndɝ jəɹ noʊz," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪf jə wɑnə noʊ haʊ aɪ fil, æsk mi." luz θɝɪn? hi θɔt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ænsɝ, ən ðə seɪɾɪn fɪlɪŋ ɪm dɪd nɑt slækən. hɪz tɛmpəlz bɪɡæn tə θɹəb.

"I'm standing under your nose," Rand said. "If you want to know how I feel, ask me." Lews Therin? he thought. There was no answer, and the saidin filling him did not slacken. His temples began to throb.

"wɛl?" kædzueɪn sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli.

"Well?" Cadsuane said impatiently.

"aɪ fil ɹaɪɾ əz wɛl wɔɾɝ." luz θɝɪn? "bʌɾ aɪ hæv ə ɹul fəɹ ju, kædzueɪn. doʊn θɹɛɾən mɪn əɡɛn. ɪn fækt, liv əɹ əloʊn ɔltəɡɛðɝ."

"I feel right as well water." Lews Therin? "But I have a rule for you, Cadsuane. Don't threaten Min again. In fact, leave her alone altogether."

"wɛl, wɛl. ðə bɔɪ ʃoʊz səm tiθ." ɡoʊldən bɝdz ən fɪʃ, stɑɹz ən munz, sweɪɾ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "dʒʌs doʊnt ʃoʊ tu mɛni. ən jə maɪɾ æsk ðə jʌŋ wʊmən wɛðɝ ʃi wɑns jəɹ pɹətɛkʃən." stʃɹeɪnʒli, mɪn hæd ʃɪftəɾ əɹ fɹaʊn tə hɪm, ən ðə bɑnd wɑz θɹɛɾəd wɪð ɪɹɪteɪʃən. laɪt, ɪt wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪm wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ. naʊ ʃi sim tə wɑnə teɪk ɑn kædzueɪn sɪŋɡəl-hændəd, sʌmθɪŋ i wəd nɑt bi iɡɝ tə də hɪmsɛlf.

"Well, well. The boy shows some teeth." Golden birds and fish, stars and moons, swayed as she shook her head. "Just don't show too many. And you might ask the young woman whether she wants your protection." Strangely, Min had shifted her frown to him, and the bond was threaded with irritation. Light, it was bad enough that she did not like him worrying about her. Now she seemed to want to take on Cadsuane single-handed, something he would not be eager to do himself.

wi kən daɪ ət tɑɹmən ɡdən, luz θɝɪn sɛd, ən sʌɾənli, ðə paʊɝ dʒɹeɪn aʊɾ ə hɪm.

We can die at Tarmon Gai'don, Lews Therin said, and suddenly, the Power drained out of him.

"hi ɹilist," lɑɡən sɛd, əz ɪf i wɝ sʌɾənli ɑn kædzueɪnz saɪd.

"He released," Logain said, as if he were suddenly on Cadsuane's side.

"aɪ noʊ," ʃi toʊl hɪm. hi wɪpt ɪz hɛɾ ɝaʊn ɪn sɝpɹaɪz.

"I know," she told him. He whipped his head around in surprise.

"mɪn kən dil wɪð jə ɪn jəɹ oʊn weɪ ɪf ʃi wɪʃɪz," ɹænd sɛd stɑɹɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə dɔɹ. "bʌt doʊn θɹɛɾən hɝ." jɛs, hi θɔt. wi kən daɪ ət tɑɹmən ɡdən.

"Min can deal with you in your own way if she wishes," Rand said starting for the door. "But don't threaten her." Yes, he thought. We can die at Tarmon Gai'don.

tʃæptɝ twɛnti

CHAPTER 20

ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn ðə wɪn hæd daɪɾ əweɪ əz ðə ɹeɪn dɪmɪnɪʃt, bʌt ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz stɪl hɪd ðə sʌn. ðə faɪn dʒɹɪzəl wɑz ɪnʌf tə dæmpən ɹændz hɛɹ, haʊɛvɝ, ən bɪɡɪn soʊkɪŋ ɪndə hɪz ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd blæk koʊɾ əz i wɔk θɹu ðə dɛd tʃɹɑləks. lɑɡən hæd spʌn ə ʃild ʌv ɛɹ soʊ ðət ɹeɪndʒɹɑps baʊns fɹəm ɪɾ əɹ əpɛɹənli slɪd daʊn nʌθɪŋ tə kæskeɪɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, bʌt ɹænd ɹəfjuz tə ɹɪsk luz θɝɪn sizɪŋ seɪɾɪn əɡɛn. ðə mæn hæd sɛɾ i kəd weɪɾ əntɪl ðə læs bæɾəl tə daɪ, bʌt haʊ fɑɹ kəd jə tʃɹʌst ə mædmæn ɑn ɛniθɪŋ?

The Golden Crane The wind had died away as the rain diminished, but gray clouds still hid the sun. The fine drizzle was enough to dampen Rand's hair, however, and begin soaking into his gold-embroidered black coat as he walked through the dead Trollocs. Logain had spun a shield of Air so that raindrops bounced from it or apparently slid down nothing to cascade around him, but Rand refused to risk Lews Therin seizing saidin again. The man had said he could wait until the Last Battle to die, but how far could you trust a madman on anything?

mædmæn? luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. æm aɪ ɛni mæɾɝ ðən ju? hi kækəld wɪð waɪld læftɝ.

Madman? Lews Therin whispered. Am I any madder than you? He cackled with wild laughter.

naʊ ən ðən nændɛɹə lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət ɹænd. ə tɔl, sɪnjui wʊmən, hɝ ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ hɪɾən bɪniθ əɹ bɹaʊn ʃoʊufə, ʃi lɛd ðə meɪɾənz, ðoʊz ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, ət list, bʌt ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən tə liɾ ɪz bɑɾiɡɑɹd ə meɪɾənz pɝsənəli. hɝ ɡɹin aɪz, ɔl i kəd si ʌv əɹ sʌn-dɑɹk feɪs əbʌv əɹ blæk veɪl, kæɹid lɪɾəl ɪkspɹɛʃən, jɛɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz wɝiɾ oʊvɝ ɪm nɑt pɹətɛktɪŋ hɪmsɛlf fɹəm ðə ɹeɪn. meɪɾənz noʊɾəst wʌt simd aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi. hi hoʊpt ʃi wəd kip kwaɪət.

Now and then Nandera looked over her shoulder at Rand. A tall, sinewy woman, her graying hair hidden beneath her brown shoufa, she led the Maidens, those on this side of the Dragonwall, at least, but she had chosen to lead his bodyguard of Maidens personally. Her green eyes, all he could see of her sun-dark face above her black veil, carried little expression, yet he was sure she was worried over him not protecting himself from the rain. Maidens noticed what seemed out of the ordinary. He hoped she would keep quiet.

juv tə tʃɹʌs mi, luz θɝɪn sɛd. tʃɹʌs mi. oʊ, laɪt, aɪm pliɾɪŋ wɪð ə vɔɪs ɪn maɪ hɛd! aɪ mʌs bi mæd.

You have to trust me, Lews Therin said. Trust me. Oh, Light, I'm pleading with a voice in my head! I must be mad.

nændɛɹə ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə fɪfti veɪl meɪɾənz meɪɾ ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ɹænd, ɔlmoʊst ʃoʊldɝ-tə-ʃoʊldɝ, pɹɑɾɪŋ ðɛɹ spɪɹz ɪndə ɛvɹi tʃɹɑlɑk ən mɹdʒɹɑl ðeɪ pæst, kæʒəwəli stɛpɪŋ oʊvɝ hjudʒ sɛvɝɾ ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz, sɛvɝd hɛdz bɛɹɪŋ hɔɹnz əɹ tʌsks əɹ ʃɑɹp tiθ. əkeɪʒənəli ə tʃɹɑlɑk ɡɹoʊn əɹ fibli tʃɹaɪd tə kɹɔl əweɪ - əɹ tə lʌnʒ ət ðɛm, snɑɹlɪŋ - bʌt nɑt fəɹ lɔŋ. wɔɹ wɪð tʃɹɑləks wɑz laɪk wɔɹ wɪð ɹæbɪd dɑɡz. jə kɪl ðɛm, əɹ ðeɪ kɪl ju. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɑɹli, noʊ sɝɛndɝ, noʊ mɪɾəl ɡɹaʊnd.

Nandera and the rest of the fifty veiled Maidens made a large ring around Rand, almost shoulder-to-shoulder, prodding their spears into every Trolloc and Myrddraal they passed, casually stepping over huge severed arms and legs, severed heads bearing horns or tusks or sharp teeth. Occasionally a Trolloc groaned or feebly tried to crawl away - or to lunge at them, snarling - but not for long. War with Trollocs was like war with rabid dogs. You killed them, or they killed you. There was no parley, no surrender, no middle ground.

ɹeɪn hæd kɛp ðə vʌltʃɝz əweɪ soʊ fɑɹ, jɛt kɹoʊz ən ɹeɪvənz flæpt ɛvɹiwɛɹ, blæk fɛðɝz ɡlɪsnɪŋ wɛtli, ən ɪf ɛni wɝ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz, ɪt dɪd nɑt stɑp əm əlaɪɾɪŋ tə plʌk aʊt tʃɹɑləks' aɪz əɹ si wɛðɝ ðeɪ kəd ɹɛntʃ lus səm ʌðɝ ɡɑbɛt. ɪnʌf ə ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd bɪn tɔɹn əpɑɹt ðət ðə bɝdz hæd ɹɪtʃ fistɪŋ. nʌn wɛnt nɪɹ ɛni dɛd mɹdʒɹɑl, ðoʊ, ən ðeɪ ʃʌn tʃɹɑləks tu nɪɹ ə mɹdʒɹɑl. ðəɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd nʌθɪŋ bɪɑn kɑʃən. vɛɹi laɪkli ðə mɹdʒɹɑl smɛld ɹɔŋ tə ðə bɝdz. eɪ mɹdʒɹɑlz blʌd wəɾ ɛtʃ stil ɪf lɛft ɑn ɪt vɛɹi lɔŋ. tə ɹeɪvənz ən kɹoʊz, ɪt mʌst əv smɛld laɪk pɔɪzən.

Rain had kept the vultures away so far, yet crows and ravens flapped everywhere, black feathers glistening wetly, and if any were the Dark One's eyes, it did not stop them alighting to pluck out Trollocs' eyes or see whether they could wrench loose some other gobbet. Enough of the Trollocs had been torn apart that the birds had rich feasting. None went near any dead Myrddraal, though, and they shunned Trollocs too near a Myrddraal. That indicated nothing beyond caution. Very likely the Myrddraal smelled wrong to the birds. A Myrddraal's blood would etch steel if left on it very long. To ravens and crows, it must have smelled like poison.

ðə sɝvaɪvɪŋ sɑldəiənz ʃɑt ðə bɝdz wɪð æɹoʊz əɹ skjuɝɾ əm ɑn ðɛɹ sɪnjuəsli kɝv sɔɹdz əɹ sɪmpli blʌdʒən əm wɪð ʃʌvəlz əɹ hoʊz əɹ ɹeɪks, ɛniθɪŋ ðət kəd meɪk ə hændi klʌb - ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, livɪŋ ə kɹoʊ əɹ ɹeɪvən əlaɪv wɑz ənθɪŋkəbəl; ðɛɹ, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl tu ɔfən ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz - jɛt ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni. hʌnʒɹədz ə blæk-fɛðɝd ʃeɪps leɪ kɹʌmpəld əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks, ən fəɹ ɛvɹi kɔɹps ðəɹ sim tə bi hʌnʒɹədz mɔɹ skwɑbəlɪŋ laʊdli oʊvɝ ðə sɑftɝ bɪts, ɪnkluɾɪŋ pisəz ə ðɛɹ dɛd fɛloʊz. ði æʃəmən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd lɔŋ sɪns ɡɪvən ʌp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl əm ɔl.

The surviving Saldaeans shot the birds with arrows or skewered them on their sinuously curved swords or simply bludgeoned them with shovels or hoes or rakes, anything that could make a handy club - in the Borderlands, leaving a crow or raven alive was unthinkable; there, they were all too often the Dark One's eyes - yet there were too many. Hundreds of black-feathered shapes lay crumpled among the Trollocs, and for every corpse there seemed to be hundreds more squabbling loudly over the softer bits, including pieces of their dead fellows. The Asha'man and Aes Sedai had long since given up trying to kill them all.

"aɪ doʊn laɪk maɪ mɛn taɪɹɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ðɪs weɪ," lɑɡən sɛd. hɪz mɛn. "ɔɹ ðə sɪstɝz, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ɡɑbɹɛl ən tʌvaɪn wɪl bi nɪɹ ɪɡzɔstʃən baɪ naɪtfɔl." hi hæd bɑndəd ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ, soʊ hi ʃəd noʊ. "wʌɾ ɪf ðɛɹz ənʌðɝ ətæk?"

"I don't like my men tiring themselves this way," Logain said. His men. "Or the sisters, for that matter. Gabrelle and Toveine will be near exhaustion by nightfall." He had bonded the two Aes Sedai, so he should know. "What if there's another attack?"

ɔl ɝaʊn ðə mænɝ haʊs ən aʊtbɪldɪŋz bɹif faɪɝz flɛɹd, soʊ hɑt ðət pipəl ʃildɪd ðɛɹ aɪz əɡɛns ðɛm, əz ɛɛs sədaɪ ən æʃəmən ɪnsɪnɝeɪɾɪd tʃɹɑlɑk ən mɹdʒɹɑl dɛd wɛɹ ðeɪ leɪ. ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni tə əfɔɹd ðə leɪbɝ ʌv ɡæðɝɪŋ əm ɪndə hips. wɪð fjuɝ ðən twɛnti ɛɛs sədaɪ, fjuɝ ðən ə dʌzən æʃəmən, ən meɪbi ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən tʃɹɑləks, ɪt wɑz gɑnə bi ə lɔŋ dʒɑb. vɛɹi laɪkli, bɪfɔɹ ɪt wɑz dʌn ðə stɛntʃ ə dəkeɪ wəd bi æɾəd tə ði ɔlɹɛɾi faʊl oʊɾɝz ɪn ði ɛɹ, ðə fɛɾəd, kɑpɝi smɛl ə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn blʌd, ðə stɪŋk ʌv wʌtɛvɝ hæd bɪn ɪn ðə tʃɹɑləks' ɪntɛstənz wən ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪpt oʊpən. bɛs nɑt tə θɪŋk tu kloʊsli ɑn ðæt. ðəɹ maɪt nɑt bi ə fɑɹmɝ əɹ vɪlɪdʒɝ lɛft əlaɪv bɪtwin ðə mænɝ haʊs ən ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. ðət hæd tə bi wɛɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd kʌm fɹʌm, ðə weɪɡeɪɾ aʊtsaɪd stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ. ət lis lɔɪəlz hoʊm ɪtsɛlf wɑz seɪf. niðɝ tʃɹɑləks nɔɹ mɹdʒɹɑl wəɾ ɛntɝ ə stɛɾɪŋ ənlɛs dʒɹɪvən, ən ɪt ɹikwaɪɝd kənsɪɾɝəbəl dʒɹaɪvɪŋ.

All around the manor house and outbuildings brief fires flared, so hot that people shielded their eyes against them, as Aes Sedai and Asha'man incinerated Trolloc and Myrddraal dead where they lay. There were too many to afford the labor of gathering them into heaps. With fewer than twenty Aes Sedai, fewer than a dozen Asha'man, and maybe a hundred thousand Trollocs, it was going to be a long job. Very likely, before it was done the stench of decay would be added to the already foul odors in the air, the fetid, coppery smell of Shadowspawn blood, the stink of whatever had been in the Trollocs' intestines when they were ripped open. Best not to think too closely on that. There might not be a farmer or villager left alive between the manor house and the Spine of the World. That had to be where the Trollocs had come from, the Waygate outside Stedding Shangtai. At least Loial's home itself was safe. Neither Trollocs nor Myrddraal would enter a stedding unless driven, and it required considerable driving.

"wʊd jə ɹæðɝ lɛɾ əm ɹɑt wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ?" kædzueɪn ɪnkwaɪɝd, saʊndɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd noʊ pɹɛfɝəns ɪn ðə mæɾɝ. ʃi hɛld əɹ ɡɹin skɝts ʌp soʊ ðə sɪlk dɪd nɑt tʃɹeɪl ɪn ðə blʌd-soʊk mʌɾ əɹ ði ɑfəl ðət lɪɾɝd ðə ɡɹaʊnd, jɛt ʃi stɛpt oʊvɝ lɛɡz ən ɝaʊn hɛdz əz kæʒəwəli əz dɪd ðə meɪɾənz. ʃi ɔlsoʊ hæd woʊvən ə pɛɹɑsɑl əɡɛns ðə ɹeɪn, əz hæɾ əliviə, ɔlðoʊ nɑɾ əntɪl ʃi sɔ ðə ɡɹin də soʊ. ɹænd hæd tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ðə sɪstɝz swɔɹn tə hɪm titʃ ðə sintʃæn wʊmən mɔɹ əbaʊt ðə paʊɝ, bʌt tə ðɛɹ maɪnz, ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðɛɹ oʊðz ə fiəlti. ʃi wɑz seɪf tə hɝsɛlf ən sim seɪf tə ʌðɝz, ən ðeɪ wɝ kɑntɛn tə liv mæɾɝz əz ðeɪ wɝ. nɪneɪiv hæd ɹəfjuzd, tu, kəz ə mɪnz vjuɪŋ. kædzueɪn hæd kuli ɪnfɔɹmd ɪm ðət ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɪn ðə bɪznəs ʌv ɪnstʃɹʌktɪŋ waɪldɝz.

"Would you rather let them rot where they are?" Cadsuane inquired, sounding as if she herself had no preference in the matter. She held her green skirts up so the silk did not trail in the blood-soaked mud or the offal that littered the ground, yet she stepped over legs and around heads as casually as did the Maidens. She also had woven a parasol against the rain, as had Alivia, although not until she saw the Green do so. Rand had tried to make the sisters sworn to him teach the Seanchan woman more about the Power, but to their minds, that had nothing to do with their oaths of fealty. She was safe to herself and seemed safe to others, and they were content to leave matters as they were. Nynaeve had refused, too, because of Min's viewing. Cadsuane had coolly informed him that she was not in the business of instructing wilders.

"ðɪs tʃɹuli wəd bi ə tʃɑɹnəl haʊs ðɛn," mɪn sɛd. hɝ wɔk hæɾ ə fɛtʃɪŋ sweɪ tə ɪt, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz pleɪnli tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə θɪŋk ʌv wʌt leɪ ʌndɝfʊt waɪl əvɔɪɾɪŋ plæntɪŋ ə hil blu buɾ ɑn ɛni ʌv ɪɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ən ðət meɪɾ əɹ stʌmbəl naʊ ən əɡɛn. ʃi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ wɛt, tu, hɝ ɹɪŋləts bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə klɪŋ tə hɝ hɛd, ðoʊ ðə bɑn kæɹid noʊ hɪn ə vɛkseɪʃən. oʊnli æŋɡɝ, ən ðət sim dɝɛktəɾ ət lɑɡən fɹəm ðə ʃɑɹp stɛɹ ʃi wɑz ɡɪvɪŋ hɪm. "wɛɹ wəd ðə sɝvəns ɡoʊ, ən ðə pipəl u wɝk ðə filz ən steɪbəlz ən bɑɹnz? haʊ wəd ðeɪ lɪv?"

"This truly would be a charnel house then," Min said. Her walk had a fetching sway to it, though she was plainly trying not to think of what lay underfoot while avoiding planting a heeled blue boot on any of it at the same time, and that made her stumble now and again. She was getting wet, too, her ringlets beginning to cling to her head, though the bond carried no hint of vexation. Only anger, and that seemed directed at Logain from the sharp stare she was giving him. "Where would the servants go, and the people who work the fields and stables and barns? How would they live?"

"ðɛɹ woʊn bi ənʌðɝ ətæk," ɹænd sɛd. "nɑɾ əntɪl huɛvɝ sɛn ðɪs wʌn lɝnz ɪt feɪld, ən meɪbi nɑt ðɛn. ðɪs ɪz ɔl ðeɪ sɛnt. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl wʊdn əv ətæk pismil." lɑɡən ɡɹʌntɪd, bʌɾ i kəd nɑɾ ɑɹɡju wɪð ðæt.

"There won't be another attack," Rand said. "Not until whoever sent this one learns it failed, and maybe not then. This is all they sent. The Myrddraal wouldn't have attacked piecemeal." Logain grunted, but he could not argue with that.

ɹænd lʊk bæk təwɔɹd ðə mænɝ haʊs. ɪn səm pleɪsəz, dɛd tʃɹɑləks leɪ ɹaɪɾ ət ðə faʊndeɪʃənz. nʌn hæd meɪɾ ɪɾ ɪnsaɪd, bʌt. . . . lɑɡən wɑz ɹaɪt, hi θɔt, sɝveɪɪŋ ðə kɑɹnɪdʒ. ɪt hæd bɪn ə kloʊs-ɹʌn θɪŋ. maɪnəs ði æʃəmən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ lɑɡən hæd bɹɔt, ði ɛn maɪt wɛl əv bɪn dɪfɹənt. ə vɛɹi kloʊs-ɹʌn θɪŋ. ən ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ ətæk, leɪɾɝ . . . ? pleɪnli sʌmwʌn nu ɪʃəmlz tʃɹɪk. əɹ ðət blu-aɪd mæn ɪn ɪz hɛd ɹɪli kəd loʊkeɪt hɪm. ənʌðɝ ətæk wəd bi lɑɹdʒɝ. ðæt, əɹ kʌm fɹəm səm ʌnɪkspɛktɪd dɝɛkʃən. pɝhæps i ʃəd lɛt lɑɡən bɹɪŋ ə fju mɔɹ æʃəmən.

Rand looked back toward the manor house. In some places, dead Trollocs lay right at the foundations. None had made it inside, but. . . . Logain was right, he thought, surveying the carnage. It had been a close-run thing. Minus the Asha'man and Aes Sedai Logain had brought, the end might well have been different. A very close-run thing. And if there was another attack, later . . . ? Plainly someone knew Ishamael's trick. Or that blue-eyed man in his head really could locate him. Another attack would be larger. That, or come from some unexpected direction. Perhaps he should let Logain bring a few more Asha'man.

jə ʃʊɾə kɪl ðɛm, luz θɝɪn wɛpt. tu leɪt, naʊ. tu leɪt.

You should have killed them, Lews Therin wept. Too late, now. Too late.

ðə sɔɹs ɪz klin naʊ, ful, ɹænd θɔt.

The Source is clean now, fool, Rand thought.

jɛs, luz θɝɪn ɹɪplaɪd. bʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ? æm aɪ?

Yes, Lews Therin replied. But are they? Am I?

ɹænd hæd wʌndɝd ðəɾ əbaʊt hɪmsɛlf. hæf ə ðə dʌbəl waʊn ɪn ɪz saɪd hæd kʌm fɹəm ɪʃəml, ði ʌðɝ hæf fɹəm pdən feɪnz dæɡɝ ðət kæɹid ðə teɪn ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. ðeɪ ɔfən θɹɑbd, ən wən ðeɪ dɪd, ðeɪ simd əlaɪv.

Rand had wondered that about himself. Half of the double wound in his side had come from Ishamael, the other half from Padan Fain's dagger that carried the taint of Shadar Logoth. They often throbbed, and when they did, they seemed alive.

ðə sɝkəl ə meɪɾənz pɑɹɾəd slaɪtli tə lɛt θɹu ə waɪt-hɛɹd sɝvɪŋ mæn wɪð ə lɔŋ ʃɑɹp noʊz u lʊkt ivən fɹeɪlɝ ðən ɛθən. hi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃɛltɝ bɪniθ ə tu-tiɹd si foʊk pɛɹɑsɑl mɪsɪŋ hæf ɪts fɹɪnʒ, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, bʌt ði eɪdʒɪd blu sɪlk hæd sɛvɹəl ɹæɡəd hoʊlz wɔɹn ɪn ɪt, soʊ smɔl ɹɪvələts fɛl ɑn ɪz jɛloʊ koʊɾ ən wʌn ɑn ɪz hɛd. hɪz θɪnɪŋ hɛɹ klʌŋ tə hɪz skʌl ən dʒɹɪpt. hi simd wɛɾɝ ðən ɪf i hæd ɡɔn wɪθaʊt. daʊtləs wʌn ʌv ælɡɝɪnz fɔɹbɛɹz hæɾ əbteɪn ðə θɪŋ sʌmhaʊ əz ə mɪmɛntoʊ, bʌt ði əbteɪnɪŋ mʌst əv bɪn ə stɔɹi ɪn ɪtsɛlf. ɹænd daʊɾɪd ðə si foʊk ɡeɪv ʌp ə klæn weɪvməstʃɹəsəz pɛɹɑsɑl laɪtli.

The circle of Maidens parted slightly to let through a white-haired serving man with a long sharp nose who looked even frailer than Ethin. He was trying to shelter beneath a two-tiered Sea Folk parasol missing half its fringe, of all things, but the aged blue silk had several ragged holes worn in it, so small rivulets fell on his yellow coat and one on his head. His thinning hair clung to his skull and dripped. He seemed wetter than if he had gone without. Doubtless one of Algarin's forebears had obtained the thing somehow as a memento, but the obtaining must have been a story in itself. Rand doubted the Sea Folk gave up a clan Wavemistress's parasol lightly.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ði oʊl mæn sɛd wɪð ə baʊ ðət spɪl mɔɹ wɔɾɝ daʊn ɪz bæk, "vɛɹɪn sədaɪ ɪnstʃɹʌktəd mi tə ɡɪv ðɪs tə jə stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ." fɹəm bɪniθ ɪz koʊt, hi pɹədust ə peɪpɝ, foʊldəɾ ən sild.

"My Lord Dragon," the old man said with a bow that spilled more water down his back, "Verin Sedai instructed me to give this to you straightaway." From beneath his coat, he produced a paper, folded and sealed.

ɹænd heɪstəli stʌft ɪɾ ɪndə ə pɑkəɾ ə hɪz oʊn koʊɾ əɡɛns ðə ɹeɪn. ɪŋk ɹæn izəli. "θæŋk ju, bʌɾ ɪt cʊɾə weɪɾəd tɪl aɪ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə haʊs. bɛs jə ɡɛt bæk ɪnsaɪd bɪfɔɹ jəɹ soʊk θɹu kəmplitli."

Rand hastily stuffed it into a pocket of his own coat against the rain. Ink ran easily. "Thank you, but it could have waited till I returned to the house. Best you get back inside before you're soaked through completely."

"ʃi dɪd seɪ stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." ðə fɛloʊ saʊndəɾ əfɛndəd. "ʃi ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"She did say straightaway, my Lord Dragon." The fellow sounded offended. "She is Aes Sedai."

ət ɹændz nɑd, hi baʊɾ əɡɛn ən stɑɹɾəd sloʊli bæk təwɔɹd ðə mænɝ haʊs, hɪz bæk stɪf wɪð pɹaɪd, ðə pɛɹɑsɑl ʃaʊɝɪŋ ɪm wɪð stʃɹimz ʌv wɔɾɝ. ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɛvɹiwʌn hɑp fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ivən ɪn tiɹ, wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt mʌtʃ laɪkt. wʌd vɛɹɪn əv tə seɪ ðət ʃi niɾəd tə pʊɾ ɪn ə lɛɾɝ? θʌmɪŋ ðə sil, ɹænd wɔkt ɑn.

At Rand's nod, he bowed again and started slowly back toward the manor house, his back stiff with pride, the parasol showering him with streams of water. She was Aes Sedai. Everyone hopped for Aes Sedai, even in Tear, where they were not much liked. What did Verin have to say that she needed to put in a letter? Thumbing the seal, Rand walked on.

hɪz dɛstəneɪʃən wɑz wʌn ə ðə bɑɹnz, ɪts θætʃt ɹuf pɑɹʃəli blækənd. ðɪs wɑz ðə bɑɹn ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd ɡɑɾən ɪntu. ə bɝli fɛloʊ ɪn ə ɹʌf bɹaʊn koʊɾ ən mʌɾi buts, linɪŋ əɡɛnst ə dʒæm ɪn ði oʊpən dɔɹz, stʃɹeɪɾənd ən fəɹ səm ɹizən heɪstəli lʊkt ɪnsaɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əz ɹænd əpɹoʊtʃt, ðə meɪɾənz spɹɛɾɪŋ aʊt tə sɝaʊn ðə bɑɹn.

His destination was one of the barns, its thatched roof partially blackened. This was the barn the Trollocs had gotten into. A burly fellow in a rough brown coat and muddy boots, leaning against a jamb in the open doors, straightened and for some reason hastily looked inside over his shoulder as Rand approached, the Maidens spreading out to surround the barn.

hi stɑp dɛɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, mɪn ən ði ʌðɝz hɔltɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm. lɑɡən ɡɹaʊld ən oʊθ. ə pɛɹ ə læntɝnz hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ʌpɹaɪts ðət səpɔɹɾəd ðə lɔft ɡeɪv ə dɪm laɪt, ɪnʌf tə si ðəɾ ɛvɹi sɪŋɡəl sɝfəs wɑz θɪk wɪð kɹɔlɪŋ flaɪz, ivən ðə stʃɹɔ-kʌvɝd dɝt flɔɹ. əz mɛni mɔɹ bʌzd ɝaʊn ɪn ði ɛɹ, ɪt simd.

He stopped dead in the doorway, Min and the others halting beside him. Logain growled an oath. A pair of lanterns hanging from uprights that supported the loft gave a dim light, enough to see that every single surface was thick with crawling flies, even the straw-covered dirt floor. As many more buzzed around in the air, it seemed.

"wɛɹ dɪd ðeɪ kʌm fɹʌm?" ɹænd æskt. ælɡɝɪn maɪt nɑt bi wɛlθi, jɛɾ ɪz bɑɹnz ən steɪbəlz wɝ kɛpt əz klin əz sətʃ pleɪsəz kəd bi. ðə bɝli mæn ɡeɪv ə ɡɪlti stɑɹt. hi wɑz jʌŋɡɝ ðən moʊst ə ðə sɝvəns ɪn ðə haʊs, bʌɾ ɪz hɛd wɑz bɔl hæfweɪ bæk, ən kɹisɪz bɹækəɾɪd ɪz waɪd maʊθ, fæn aʊt fɹəm ɪz aɪz.

"Where did they come from?" Rand asked. Algarin might not be wealthy, yet his barns and stables were kept as clean as such places could be. The burly man gave a guilty start. He was younger than most of the servants in the house, but his head was bald halfway back, and creases bracketed his wide mouth, fanned out from his eyes.

"doʊnt noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd," hi mʌɾɝd, nʌklɪŋ ɪz fɔɹhɛd wɪð ə ɡɹaɪmi hænd. hi foʊkəst ɑn ɹænd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz pleɪn i dɪd nɑt wɑnə lʊk ɪndə ðə bɑɹn. "aɪ stɛp tə ðə dɔɹ fəɹ ə bɹɛθ ə fɹɛʃ, ən wən aɪ tɝn ɝaʊnd, ðeɪ wɑz ɔl oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. aɪ θɔt. . . . aɪ θɔt meɪbi ðeɪz dɛd flaɪz."

"Don't know, my Lord," he muttered, knuckling his forehead with a grimy hand. He focused on Rand so hard that it was plain he did not want to look into the barn. "I stepped to the door for a breath of fresh, and when I turned around, they was all over everything. I thought. . . . I thought maybe they's dead flies."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn dɪsɡʌst. ðiz flaɪz wɝ ɔl tu əlaɪv. nɑɾ ɛvɹi sɑldəiən dɪfɛndɪŋ ðɪs bɑɹn hæd daɪd, bʌɾ ɔl ə ðə sɑldəiən dɛd hæd bɪn ɡæðɝd hɪɹ. sɑldəiənz dɪslaɪk bɛɹiəlz ɪn ɹeɪn. nʌn ə ðɛm kəd seɪ waɪ, bʌt jə dʒʌs dɪd nɑt bɛɹi pipəl waɪl ɪt wɑz ɹeɪnɪŋ. naɪntin mɛn leɪ ɪn ə nit ɹoʊ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, əz niɾ əz ɪt kəd bi wən səm wɝ mɪsɪŋ lɪmz əɹ hæd ðɛɹ hɛdz splɪɾ oʊpən. bʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn leɪɾ aʊt kɛɹfəli baɪ ðɛɹ fɹɛnz ən kəmpænjənz, ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɑʃt, ðɛɹ aɪz kloʊzd. ðeɪ wɝ waɪ hi hæd kʌm ðɛɹ. nɑt tə seɪ ɡʊd-baɪ əɹ ɛniθɪŋ sɛntəmɛntəl; hi hæd nɑt noʊn ɛni ʌv ðiz mɛn mɔɹ ðən tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ə feɪs hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ. hi hæd kʌm tə ɹimaɪn hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ ivən wʌt simd ə kəmplit vɪktɝi hæɾ ɪts kɑst ɪn blʌd. stɪl, ðeɪ dɪzɝv bɛɾɝ ðən tə bi kɹɔlɪŋ wɪð flaɪz.

Rand shook his head in disgust. These flies were all too alive. Not every Saldaean defending this barn had died, but all of the Saldaean dead had been gathered here. Saldaeans disliked burials in rain. None of them could say why, but you just did not bury people while it was raining. Nineteen men lay in a neat row on the floor, as neat as it could be when some were missing limbs or had their heads split open. But they had been laid out carefully by their friends and companions, their faces washed, their eyes closed. They were why he had come there. Not to say good-bye or anything sentimental; he had not known any of these men more than to recognize a face here and there. He had come to remind himself that even what seemed a complete victory had its cost in blood. Still, they deserved better than to be crawling with flies.

aɪ nid noʊ ɹimaɪndɝz, luz θɝɪn ɡɹaʊld.

I need no reminders, Lews Therin growled.

aɪm nɑt ju, ɹænd θɔt. aɪ hæv tə hɑɹɾən maɪsɛlf. "lɑɡən, ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðiz blʌɾi θɪŋz!" hi sɛɾ əlaʊd.

I'm not you, Rand thought. I have to harden myself. "Logain, get rid of these bloody things!" he said aloud.

jəɹ hɑɹɾɝ ðən aɪ ɛvɝ wɑz, luz θɝɪn sɛd. sʌɾənli hi ɡɪɡəld. ɪf jəɹ nɑt mi, ðən u ɑɹ ju?

You're harder than I ever was, Lews Therin said. Suddenly he giggled. If you're not me, then who are you?

"naʊ ɪm ə fleɪmɪŋ flaɪ-wɪsk?" lɑɡən mʌɾɝd.

"Now I'm a flaming fly-whisk?" Logain muttered.

ɹænd ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ɪm æŋɡɹəli, bʌɾ əliviə spoʊk ɪn ðət slɝd dʒɹɔl bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɡɛɾ ə wɝɾ aʊt.

Rand rounded on him angrily, but Alivia spoke in that slurred drawl before he could get a word out.

"lɛt mi tʃɹaɪ, maɪ lɔɹd." ʃi æskt, ɪn ə mænɝ ə spikɪŋ, bʌt laɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əweɪt pɝmɪʃən. hɪz skɪn tɪŋɡəld wɪð ɡus bʌmps əz ʃi ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ ən tʃænəld.

"Let me try, my Lord." She asked, in a manner of speaking, but like an Aes Sedai, she did not await permission. His skin tingled with goose bumps as she embraced saidar and channeled.

flaɪz ɔlweɪz tʊk ʃɛltɝ fɹəm ivən ðə laɪɾəst ɹeɪn kəz wʌn ɹeɪndʒɹɑp wɑz ɪnʌf tə pʊɾ ə flaɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, izi pɹeɪ əntɪl ɪts wɪŋz dʒɹaɪɾ ɔf, jɛt sʌɾənli ðə dɔɹweɪ wɑz bɪloʊɪŋ wɪð bʌzɪŋ flaɪz əz ɪf ðə ɹeɪn wɝ fɑɹ pɹɛfɝəbəl tə ðə bɑɹn. ði ɛɹ sim sɑləd wɪð ðɛm. ɹænd bæɾɪd flaɪz əweɪ fɹəm ɪz feɪs, ən mɪn kʌvɝɾ əɹ feɪs wɪð əɹ hænz, ðə bɑn hɛvi wɪð dɪsteɪst, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ oʊnli ɪn flaɪt. ɪn moʊməns, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɡɔn. ðə bɔldɪŋ mæn, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əliviə wɪð ɪz maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən, sʌɾənli kɔft ən spæɾ aʊt tu flaɪz ɑntu hɪz hænd. kædzueɪn ɡeɪv ɪm ə lʊk ðət snæpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌɾ ən sɛn ɪz ɹʌf nʌkəl flaɪɪŋ tə hɪz fɔɹhɛd. dʒʌst ə lʊk, jɛt ʃi wɑz u ʃi wɑz.

Flies always took shelter from even the lightest rain because one raindrop was enough to put a fly on the ground, easy prey until its wings dried off, yet suddenly the doorway was billowing with buzzing flies as if the rain were far preferable to the barn. The air seemed solid with them. Rand batted flies away from his face, and Min covered her face with her hands, the bond heavy with distaste, but they were interested only in flight. In moments, they were all gone. The balding man, staring at Alivia with his mouth hanging open, suddenly coughed and spat out two flies onto his hand. Cadsuane gave him a look that snapped his mouth shut and sent his rough knuckle flying to his forehead. Just a look, yet she was who she was.

"soʊ jə wɑtʃ," ʃi sɛd tə əliviə. hɝ dɑɹk aɪz wɝ fɪkst ɑn ðə sintʃæn wʊmənz feɪs, bʌɾ əliviə dɪd nɑt stɑɹɾ əɹ stæmɝ. ʃi wɑz mʌtʃ lɛs ɪmpɹɛs baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ ðən moʊs pipəl.

"So you watch," she said to Alivia. Her dark eyes were fixed on the Seanchan woman's face, but Alivia did not start or stammer. She was much less impressed by Aes Sedai than most people.

"æn ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ aɪ si. aɪ mʌs lɝn sʌmhaʊ ɪf aɪm tə hɛlp ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. aɪ hæv lɝn mɔɹ ðən jə ɑɹ əwɛɹ ʌv." mɪn meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, vɛɹi nɪɹli ə ɡɹaʊl, ən ðə bɑn swɛld wɪð æŋɡɝ, bʌt ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd wʊmən ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ. "ju ɑɹ nɑɾ æŋɡɹi wɪð mi?" ʃi æskt ɹænd, hɝ vɔɪs æŋkʃəs.

"And remember what I see. I must learn somehow if I am to help the Lord Dragon. I have learned more than you are aware of." Min made a sound in her throat, very nearly a growl, and the bond swelled with anger, but the yellow-haired woman ignored her. "You are not angry with me?" she asked Rand, her voice anxious.

"aɪm nɑɾ æŋɡɹi. lɝn əz mʌtʃ əz jə kæn. jəɹ duɪŋ vɛɹi wɛl."

"I'm not angry. Learn as much as you can. You're doing very well."

ʃi blʌʃt ən dʒɹɑpt əɹ aɪz laɪk ə ɡɝl stɑɹɾəld baɪ ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd kɑmpləmənt. faɪn laɪnz dɛkɝeɪɾəd ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz, bʌt səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət ʃi wɑz ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən ɛni lɪvɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹæðɝ ðən hæf ə dʌzən jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ ðən hɪmsɛlf. hi hæd tə faɪn sʌmwʌn tə titʃ əɹ mɔɹ.

She blushed and dropped her eyes like a girl startled by an unexpected compliment. Fine lines decorated the corners of her eyes, but sometimes it was hard to remember that she was a hundred years older than any living Aes Sedai, rather than half a dozen years younger than himself. He had to find someone to teach her more.

"ɹæn ælθɹ," mɪn sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, "ju ɑɹ nɑt gɑnə lɛt ðət wʊmən - "

"Rand al'Thor," Min said angrily, folding her arms beneath her breasts, "you are not going to let that woman - "

"jɔɹ vjuɪŋz ɑɹ nɛvɝ ɹɔŋ," hi bɹoʊk ɪn. "wʌt jə si ɔlweɪz hæpənz. juv tʃɹaɪd tə tʃeɪnʒ θɪŋz, ən ɪt nɛvɝ wɝkt. jə toʊl mi soʊ jɝsɛlf, mɪn. wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk ðɪs taɪm kən bi dɪfɹənt?"

"Your viewings are never wrong," he broke in. "What you see always happens. You've tried to change things, and it never worked. You told me so yourself, Min. What makes you think this time can be different?"

"bɪkɔz ɪts tə bi dɪfɹənt," ʃi toʊld ɪm fɪɹsli. ʃi lin təwɔɹɾ ɪm əz ðoʊ ɹɛɾi tə lɔntʃ hɝsɛlf ət hɪm. "bɪkɔz aɪ wɑn ɪt tə bi dɪfɹənt. kəz ɪɾəl bi dɪfɹənt. ɛniweɪ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪv sin. pipəl muv ɑn. aɪ wɑz ɹɔŋ əbaʊt mɔɪɹeɪn. aɪ sɔ ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz ɪn əɹ fjutʃɝ, ən ʃiz dɛd. meɪbi səm ə ði ʌðɝ θɪŋz aɪ sɔ nɛvɝ keɪm tʃɹu iðɝ."

"Because it has to be different," she told him fiercely. She leaned toward him as though ready to launch herself at him. "Because I want it to be different. Because it will be different. Anyway, I don't know about everything I've seen. People move on. I was wrong about Moiraine. I saw all sorts of things in her future, and she's dead. Maybe some of the other things I saw never came true either."

ɪt mʌs nɑt bi dɪfɹən ðɪs taɪm, luz θɝɪn pæntɪd. jə pɹɑməst!

It must not be different this time, Lews Therin panted. You promised!

ə feɪn skaʊl əpɪɹɾ ɑn lɑɡənz feɪs, ən i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd slaɪtli. hi kəd nɑt laɪk hɪɹɪŋ mɪn kwɛstʃən əɹ əbɪləɾi. ɹænd ɔlmoʊst ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd tɛlɪŋ ɪm əbaʊɾ əɹ vjuɪŋ ə hɪm, ðoʊ ɪt hæd sim hɑɹmləs ɛnkɝɪdʒmən ət ðə taɪm. ðə mæn hæɾ æktʃəli  æskt ɛɛs sədaɪ tə kənfɝm mɪnz əbɪləɾi, ðoʊ hi hæd bɪn waɪz ɪnʌf tə tʃɹaɪ tə kip ɪz daʊɾɪŋ fɹəm ɹænd.

A faint scowl appeared on Logain's face, and he shook his head slightly. He could not like hearing Min question her ability. Rand almost regretted telling him about her viewing of him, though it had seemed harmless encouragement at the time. The man had actually asked Aes Sedai to confirm Min's ability, though he had been wise enough to try to keep his doubting from Rand.

"aɪ kænɑt si wʌt meɪks ðɪs jʌŋ wʊmən soʊ viəmən fəɹ ju, bɔɪ," kædzueɪn mjuzd. ʃi pɝst əɹ lɪps ɪn θɔt, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ɔɹnəməns sweɪɪŋ. "oʊ, jəɹ pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf, aɪ səpoʊz, bʌɾ aɪ dʒʌs kænɑt si ɪt."

"I cannot see what makes this young woman so vehement for you, boy," Cadsuane mused. She pursed her lips in thought, then shook her head, ornaments swaying. "Oh, you're pretty enough, I suppose, but I just cannot see it."

tə əvɔɪɾ ənʌðɝ ɑɹɡjəmənt wɪð mɪn - ʃi dɪd nɑt kɔl əm ðæt; ʃi kɔld əm "tɔkɪŋ," bʌɾ i nu ðə dɪfɝəns - ɹænd tʊk aʊt vɛɹɪnz lɛɾɝ ən bɹoʊk ðə blɑb ə jɛloʊ silɪŋ wæks ɪmpɹɛst wɪð ðə hɛɾ ʌv ə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ. ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝz spaɪɾɝi hæn kʌvɝd moʊst ə ðə peɪdʒ, ə fju lɛɾɝz blɑɾɪd wɛɹ ɹeɪndʒɹɑps hæd soʊk ðə peɪpɝ. hi wɔkt kloʊsɝ tə ðə nɪɹəs læntɝn. ɪt ɡeɪv ɔf ə feɪn stɪŋk ə spɔɪld ɔɪl.

To avoid another argument with Min - she did not call them that; she called them "talking," but he knew the difference - Rand took out Verin's letter and broke the blob of yellow sealing wax impressed with the head of a Great Serpent ring. The Brown sister's spidery hand covered most of the page, a few letters blotted where raindrops had soaked the paper. He walked closer to the nearest lantern. It gave off a faint stink of spoiled oil.

əz aɪ sɛd, aɪ hæv dʌn wʌɾ aɪ kən də hɪɹ. aɪ bɪliv ðəɾ aɪ kən fʊlfɪl maɪ oʊθ tə jə bɛɾɝ ɛlswɛɹ, soʊ aɪ hæv teɪkən toʊmɑs ən ɡɔn tə bi əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni weɪz tə sɝv ju, æftɝ ɔl, ən mɛni nidz. aɪm kənvɪns ðət jə kən tʃɹʌs kædzueɪn, ən jə sɝɾənli ʃəd hiɾ əɹ ædvaɪs, bʌt bi wɛɹi ʌv ʌðɝ sɪstɝz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðoʊz u hæv swɔɹn fiəlti tə ju. sətʃ ən oʊθ minz nʌθɪŋ tə ə blæk sɪstɝ, ən ivən ðoʊz u wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt meɪ ɪntɝpɹəɾ ɪɾ ɪn weɪz jə wəd dɪsəpɹuv ʌv. jə ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ ðət fju si ðəɾ oʊθ əz ɪnvoʊkɪŋ æbsəluɾ oʊbiɾiəns ɪn ɔl θɪŋz. səm meɪ faɪn ʌðɝ hoʊlz. soʊ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt jə fɑloʊ kædzueɪnz ædvaɪs, ən aɪ ɹɪpit ðət jə ʃʊd, fɑloʊ maɪn. bi vɛɹi wɛɹi.

As I said, I have done what I can do here. I believe that I can fulfill my oath to you better elsewhere, so I have taken Tomas and gone to be about it. There are many ways to serve you, after all, and many needs. I am convinced that you can trust Cadsuane, and you certainly should heed her advice, but be wary of other sisters, including those who have sworn fealty to you. Such an oath means nothing to a Black sister, and even those who walk in the Light may interpret it in ways you would disapprove of. You already know that few see that oath as invoking absolute obedience in all things. Some may find other holes. So whether or not you follow Cadsuane's advice, and I repeat that you should, follow mine. Be very wary.

ɪt wɑz saɪn sɪmpli, "vɛɹɪn."

It was signed simply, "Verin."

hi ɡɹʌntɪd saʊɝli. fju θɔt ði oʊθ mɛn æbsəluɾ oʊbiɾiəns? ɪt wɑz mɔɹ laɪk nʌn. ðeɪ oʊbeɪd, juʒəwəli, jɛt ðə lɛɾɝ wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ðə spɪɹət. teɪk vɛɹɪn hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɔɹn ɪm əɡɛns ði ʌðɝz duɪŋ θɪŋz i maɪt dɪsəpɹuv ʌv, bʌt ʃi hæd nɑt sɛd wɛɹ ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ əɹ wʌt ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə də ðɛɹ. wɑz ʃi əfɹeɪɾ i maɪt nɑɾ əpɹuv? meɪbi ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ɛɛs sədaɪ kənsilmənt. sɪstɝz kɛp sikɹəts əz nætʃɹəli əz ðeɪ bɹiðd.

He grunted sourly. Few thought the oath meant absolute obedience? It was more like none. They obeyed, usually, yet the letter was not always the spirit. Take Verin herself. She warned him against the others doing things he might disapprove of, but she had not said where she was going or what she intended to do there. Was she afraid he might not approve? Maybe it was just Aes Sedai concealment. Sisters kept secrets as naturally as they breathed.

wən i hɛld aʊt ðə lɛɾɝ tə kædzueɪn, hɝ lɛft aɪbɹaʊ twɪtʃt slaɪtli. ʃi mʌst əv bɪn tʃɹuli stɑɹɾəld tə ʃoʊ soʊ mʌtʃ, bʌt ʃi tʊk ðə lɛɾɝ ən hɛld ɪt wɛɹ ðə læntɝnz laɪɾ ɪluməneɪɾəd ɪt.

When he held out the letter to Cadsuane, her left eyebrow twitched slightly. She must have been truly startled to show so much, but she took the letter and held it where the lantern's light illuminated it.

"ə wʊmən ə mɛni mæsks," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli, hændɪŋ ðə peɪdʒ bæk. "bʌt ʃi ɡɪvz ɡʊɾ ædvaɪs hɪɹ."

"A woman of many masks," she said finally, handing the page back. "But she gives good advice here."

wʌd ʃi min əbaʊt mæsks? hi wɑz əbaʊt tə æsk əɹ wən lɔɪəl ən ɛldɝ heɪmən sʌɾənli əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, itʃ kæɹiɪŋ ə lɔŋ-hændəld æks, wɪð ən ɔɹnətli dɛkɝeɪɾəd hɛd, ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðə waɪt-hɛɹɾ oʊɡiɝz tʌftəɾ ɪɹz wɝ leɪd bæk, hɪz feɪs ɡɹɪm, ən lɔɪəlz ɪɹz wɝ flɪkɝɪŋ. wɪð ɪksaɪtmənt, ɹænd ɡɛst. ɪt kəd bi dɪfəkəl tə tɛl.

What did she mean about masks? He was about to ask her when Loial and Elder Haman suddenly appeared in the doorway, each carrying a long-handled axe, with an ornately decorated head, on his shoulder. The white-haired Ogier's tufted ears were laid back, his face grim, and Loial's ears were flickering. With excitement, Rand guessed. It could be difficult to tell.

"aɪ tʃɹʌst wəɹ nɑɾ ɪntɝʌptɪŋ?" ɛldɝ heɪmən sɛd, hɪz ɪɹz ɹaɪzɪŋ əz i lʊk sædli ət ðə laɪn ə bɑɾiz.

"I trust we are not interrupting?" Elder Haman said, his ears rising as he looked sadly at the line of bodies.

"ju ɑɹ nɑt," ɹænd toʊl hɪm, stɪkɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ bæk ɪn ɪz pɑkət. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəd kʌm tə jəɹ wɛɾɪŋ, lɔɪəl, bʌt - "

"You are not," Rand told him, sticking the letter back in his pocket. "I wish I could come to your wedding, Loial, but - "

"oʊ, ðæts dʌn, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd. hi mʌs bi ɪksaɪɾəd; ɪt wɑz ənlaɪk ɪm tə ɪntɝʌpt. "maɪ mʌðɝ ɪnsɪstəd. ðəɹ woʊn ivən bi taɪm fəɹ mʌtʃ ʌv ə wɛɾɪŋ fist, meɪbi nʌn, wʌt wɪð ðə stʌmp ən mi hævɪŋ tə - " ði oʊldɝ oʊɡiɝ leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. "wʌt?" lɔɪəl sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. "oʊ. jɛs. ʌv kɔɹs. wɛl." hi skɹʌbd ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɔd noʊz wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ ðə saɪz ʌv ə fæt sɔsədʒ.

"Oh, that's done, Rand," Loial said. He must be excited; it was unlike him to interrupt. "My mother insisted. There won't even be time for much of a wedding feast, maybe none, what with the Stump and me having to - " The older Ogier laid a hand on his arm. "What?" Loial said, looking at him. "Oh. Yes. Of course. Well." He scrubbed under his broad nose with a finger the size of a fat sausage.

sʌmθɪŋ i wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə bi toʊld? ivən oʊɡiɝ hæd sikɹəts, ɪt simd. ɹænd fɪŋɡɝd ðə lɛɾɝ ɪn ɪz pɑkət. bʌt ðɛn, soʊ dɪɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls.

Something he was not supposed to be told? Even Ogier had secrets, it seemed. Rand fingered the letter in his pocket. But then, so did everyone else.

"aɪ pɹɑməs jə ðɪs, ɹænd," lɔɪəl sɛd. "wʌtɛvɝ hæpənz, əl bi ðəɹ wɪð jə ət tɑɹmən ɡdən. wʌtɛvɝ hæpənz."

"I promise you this, Rand," Loial said. "Whatever happens, I will be there with you at Tarmon Gai'don. Whatever happens."

"maɪ bɔɪ," ɛldɝ heɪmən mɝmɝd, "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jə ʃʊd. . . ." hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən ɹʌmbəlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, laɪk ə dɪstən ɝθkweɪk.

"My boy," Elder Haman murmured, "I don't think you should. . . ." He trailed off, shaking his head and rumbling under his breath, like a distant earthquake.

ɹænd kɹɔs ðə stʃɹɔ ɪn θɹi stʃɹaɪdz ən ɔfɝɾ ɪz ɹaɪt hænd. smaɪlɪŋ waɪdli, ən wɪð ən oʊɡiɝ ðət mɛn vɛɹi waɪd, lɔɪəl tʊk ɪɾ ɪn ə hæn ðəɾ ɛnvɛləp hɪz. ðɪs kloʊs, ɹænd hæd tə kɹeɪn ɪz nɛk tə lʊk ʌp əɾ ɪz fɹɛnz feɪs. "θæŋk ju, lɔɪəl. aɪ kæn tɛl jə haʊ mʌtʃ hɪɹɪŋ ðət minz tə mi. bʌɾ əl nid jə bɪfɔɹ ðɛn."

Rand crossed the straw in three strides and offered his right hand. Smiling widely, and with an Ogier that meant very wide, Loial took it in a hand that enveloped his. This close, Rand had to crane his neck to look up at his friend's face. "Thank you, Loial. I can't tell you how much hearing that means to me. But I'll need you before then."

"ju . . . nid mi?"

"You . . . need me?"

"lɔɪəl, aɪv sil ðə weɪɡeɪts aɪ noʊ, ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ən kɛɹhin, ɪljən ən tiɹ, ən aɪ pʊɾ ə vɛɹi næsti tʃɹæp ɑn ðə wʌn ðət wɑz kʌɾ oʊpən nɪɹ fæl dæɹə, bʌɾ aɪ kʊdn faɪn ðə wʌn nɪɹ fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. ivən wən aɪ noʊ ðɛɹz ə weɪɡeɪɾ æktʃəli  ɪn ə sɪɾi, aɪ kæn faɪn ɪt baɪ maɪsɛlf, ən ðən ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔl ðoʊz sɪɾiz ðət doʊn ɪɡzɪst ɛnimɔɹ. aɪ nid jə tə faɪn ðə ɹɛs fəɹ mi, lɔɪəl, əɹ tʃɹɑləks wɪl bi eɪbəl tə flʌɾ ɪndə ɛvɹi kʌntʃɹi ət wʌns, ən noʊ wʌn wɪl noʊ ðəɹ kʌmɪŋ əntɪl ðəɹ ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv ændɝ əɹ kɛɹhin."

"Loial, I've sealed the Waygates I know, in Caemlyn and Cairhien, Illian and Tear, and I put a very nasty trap on the one that was cut open near Fal Dara, but I couldn't find the one near Far Madding. Even when I know there's a Waygate actually in a city, I can't find it by myself, and then there are all those cities that don't exist anymore. I need you to find the rest for me, Loial, or Trollocs will be able to flood into every country at once, and no one will know they're coming until they're in the heart of Andor or Cairhien."

lɔɪəlz smaɪl vænɪʃt. hɪz ɪɹz tʃɹɛmbəld ən ɪz aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹu daʊn tɪl ði ɛnz leɪ ɑn ɪz tʃiks. "aɪ kænt, ɹænd," hi sɛd mɔɹnfəli. "aɪ mʌs liv fɝs θɪŋ təmɑɹoʊ mɔɹnɪŋ, ən aɪ doʊnt noʊ wən əl bi eɪbəl tə kʌm aʊtsaɪɾ əɡɛn."

Loial's smile vanished. His ears trembled and his eyebrows drew down till the ends lay on his cheeks. "I can't, Rand," he said mournfully. "I must leave first thing tomorrow morning, and I don't know when I'll be able to come Outside again."

"aɪ noʊ juv bɪn aʊɾ ə ðə stɛɾɪŋ ə lɔŋ taɪm, lɔɪəl." ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs dʒɛntəl, bʌɾ ɪt keɪm aʊt hɑɹd. dʒɛntəlnəs simd ə feɪɾɪŋ mɛmɹi. "aɪl spik tə jəɹ mʌðɝ. əl kənvɪns əɹ tə lɛt jə liv æftɝ juv hæɾ ə lɪɾəl ɹɛst."

"I know you've been out of the stedding a long time, Loial." Rand tried to make his voice gentle, but it came out hard. Gentleness seemed a fading memory. "I'll speak to your mother. I'll convince her to let you leave after you've had a little rest."

"hi nidz mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl ɹɛst." ɛldɝ heɪmən plæntəd ðə bʌɾ ə hɪz æks hæft ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ði æks wɪð boʊθ hænz, ən dɝɛktəɾ ə stɝn lʊk ət ɹænd. oʊɡiɝ wɝ pisfəl foʊk, jɛɾ i lʊkt ɛniθɪŋ bʌt. "hi hæz bɪn aʊtsaɪd mɔɹ ðən faɪv jɪɹz, fɑɹ tu lɔŋ. hi nidz wiks ə ɹɛst ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ ət ðə list. mʌnθs wəd bi bɛɾɝ."

"He needs more than a little rest." Elder Haman planted the butt of his axe haft on the floor, gripping the axe with both hands, and directed a stern look at Rand. Ogier were peaceful folk, yet he looked anything but. "He has been Outside more than five years, far too long. He needs weeks of rest in a stedding at the least. Months would be better."

"maɪ mʌðɝ dʌzn meɪk ðoʊz dɪsɪʒənz ɛnimɔɹ, ɹænd. ðoʊ tʃɹuθ tə tɛl, aɪ θɪŋk ʃiz stɪl sɝpɹaɪz tə ɹilaɪz ɪt. ɛɹɪθ dʌz. maɪ waɪf." hɪz bumɪŋ vɔɪs pʊt soʊ mʌtʃ pɹaɪɾ ɪndə ðət wɝd ðəɾ i simd ɹɛɾi tə bɝst wɪð ɪt. hɪz tʃɛst sɝɾənli swɛld, ən ɪz smaɪl splɪɾ ɪz feɪs ɪn tu.

"My mother doesn't make those decisions anymore, Rand. Though truth to tell, I think she's still surprised to realize it. Erith does. My wife." His booming voice put so much pride into that word that he seemed ready to burst with it. His chest certainly swelled, and his smile split his face in two.

"æn aɪ hævən ivən kənɡɹætʃəleɪɾɪd ju," ɹænd sɛd, klæpɪŋ ɪm ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ. hɪz ətɛmpt ət hɑɹtinəs saʊndəd fɔls ɪn ɪz oʊn ɪɹz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə bɛst i kəd mænədʒ. "ɪf jə nid mʌnθs, ðən mʌnθs jə ʃæl hæv. bʌɾ aɪ stɪl niɾ ən oʊɡiɝ tə faɪn ðoʊz weɪɡeɪts. ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, əl teɪk jə ɔl tə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ maɪsɛlf. meɪbi aɪ kən kənvɪns sʌmwʌn ðəɹ tə də ðə dʒɑb." ɛldɝ heɪmən ʃɪftəɾ ɪz fɹaʊn tə hɪz hænz ɑn ði æks hæft ən bɪɡæn mʌɾɝɪŋ əɡɛn, tu sɔfli tə meɪk aʊt wɝdz, laɪk ə bʌmbəlɪbi ðə saɪz ʌv ə hjudʒ mæstəf bʌzɪŋ ɪn ən ɪmɛns dʒɑɹ ɪn ðə nɛkst ɹum. hi sim tə bi ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð hɪmsɛlf.

"And I haven't even congratulated you," Rand said, clapping him on the shoulder. His attempt at heartiness sounded false in his own ears, but it was the best he could manage. "If you need months, then months you shall have. But I still need an Ogier to find those Waygates. In the morning, I'll take you all to Stedding Shangtai myself. Maybe I can convince someone there to do the job." Elder Haman shifted his frown to his hands on the axe haft and began muttering again, too softly to make out words, like a bumblebee the size of a huge mastiff buzzing in an immense jar in the next room. He seemed to be arguing with himself.

"ðæt maɪt teɪk taɪm," lɔɪəl sɛd daʊtfəli. "ju noʊ wi doʊn laɪk tə meɪk heɪsti dɪsɪʒənz. aɪm nɑt sɝɾən ðəl ivən lɛɾ ə hjumən ɪndə ðə stɛɾɪŋ, kəz ə ðə stʌmp. ɹænd? ɪf aɪ kæn kʌm bæk bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl. . . . jəl ænsɝ maɪ kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt wʌt hæpənd waɪl aɪ wɑz ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ, woʊn ju? aɪ min, wɪθaʊt meɪkɪŋ mi dʒɹæɡ ɛvɹiθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ju?"

"That might take time," Loial said doubtfully. "You know we don't like to make hasty decisions. I'm not certain they will even let a human into the stedding, because of the Stump. Rand? If I can't come back before the Last Battle. . . . You will answer my questions about what happened while I was in the stedding, won't you? I mean, without making me drag everything out of you?"

"ɪf aɪ kæn, aɪ wɪl," ɹænd toʊl hɪm.

"If I can, I will," Rand told him.

ɪf jə kæn, luz θɝɪn snɑɹəld. jə əɡɹid wi kəd faɪnəli daɪ ət tɑɹmən ɡdən. jə əɡɹid, mædmæn!

If you can, Lews Therin snarled. You agreed we could finally die at Tarmon Gai'don. You agreed, madman!

"hil ænsɝ kwɛstʃənz tə jəɹ hɑɹts dɪlaɪt, lɔɪəl," mɪn sɛd fɝmli, "ɪf aɪ hæv tə stæn oʊvɝ ɪm ðə hoʊl waɪl." æŋɡɝ səfjuz ðə bɑnd. ʃi ɹɪli dɪd sim tə noʊ wʌɾ i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ.

"He'll answer questions to your heart's delight, Loial," Min said firmly, "if I have to stand over him the whole while." Anger suffused the bond. She really did seem to know what he was thinking.

ɛldɝ heɪmən klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "ɪt simz tə mi ðəɾ aɪ maɪsɛlf æm mɔɹ əkʌstəm tə aʊtsaɪd ðən ɔlmoʊst ɛniwʌn ɪksɛp ðə stoʊnmeɪsɑnz. ʌm. jɛs. ɪn fækt, aɪ θɪŋk aɪm laɪkli tə bi ðə bɛs kændəɾeɪt fəɹ jəɹ tæsk."

Elder Haman cleared his throat. "It seems to me that I myself am more accustomed to Outside than almost anyone except the stonemasons. Um. Yes. In fact, I think I am likely to be the best candidate for your task."

"fɔ!" kædzueɪn sɛd. "ɪt simz jə ɪnfɛkt ivən oʊɡiɝ, bɔɪ." hɝ toʊn wɑz stɝn, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ kəmpoʊʒɝ, ənɹiɾəbəl, haɪɾɪŋ wʌtɛvɝ wɑz pæsɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðoʊz dɑɹk aɪz.

"Phaw!" Cadsuane said. "It seems you infect even Ogier, boy." Her tone was stern, but her face was all Aes Sedai composure, unreadable, hiding whatever was passing behind those dark eyes.

lɔɪəlz ɪɹz wɛn ɹɪdʒəd wɪð ʃɑk, ən i ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑpt ɪz æks, fʌmbəlɪŋ tə kætʃ ɪt. "ju? bʌt ðə stʌmp, ɛldɝ heɪmən! ðə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp!"

Loial's ears went rigid with shock, and he almost dropped his axe, fumbling to catch it. "You? But the Stump, Elder Haman! The Great Stump!"

"aɪ bɪliv aɪ kən seɪfli liv ðəɾ ɪn jəɹ hænz, maɪ bɔɪ. jəɹ wɝdz wɝ sɪmpəl jɛɾ ɛləkwənt. ʌm. ʌm. maɪ ædvaɪs ɪz, doʊn tʃɹaɪ fəɹ bjuɾi. kip ðə sɪmpəl ɛləkwəns, ən jə meɪ sɝpɹaɪz kwaɪɾ ə fju. ɪnkluɾɪŋ jəɹ mʌðɝ."

"I believe I can safely leave that in your hands, my boy. Your words were simple yet eloquent. Um. Um. My advice is, don't try for beauty. Keep the simple eloquence, and you may surprise quite a few. Including your mother."

ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ðət lɔɪəlz ɪɹz kəd ɡɹoʊ ɛni stɪfɝ, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd. hɪz maʊθ muvd, bʌt noʊ wɝdz keɪm aʊt. soʊ hi wɑz tə spik tə ðə stʌmp. wʌt wɑz soʊ sikɹəɾ əbaʊt ðæt?

It seemed impossible that Loial's ears could grow any stiffer, but they did. His mouth moved, but no words came out. So he was to speak to the Stump. What was so secret about that?

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, lɔɹd dævɹæm əz ɹɪtɝnd." ɪt wɑz ɛlzə pɛnfəl u ɛskɔɹɾɪd bæʃɪɹ ɪndə ðə bɑɹn. ʃi wɑz ə hænsəm wʊmən ɪn ə dɑɹk ɡɹin ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs; hɝ bɹaʊn aɪz sim tə ɡɹoʊ fivɝɪʃ wən ðeɪ faʊn ɹænd. ʃi, ət list, wɑz wʌn i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə wɝi əbaʊt. ɛlzə wɑz fənæɾɪkəl ɪn əɹ dɪvoʊʃən.

"My Lord Dragon, Lord Davram has returned." It was Elza Penfell who escorted Bashere into the barn. She was a handsome woman in a dark green riding dress; her brown eyes seemed to grow feverish when they found Rand. She, at least, was one he did not have to worry about. Elza was fanatical in her devotion.

"θæŋk ju, ɛlzə," hi sɛd. "bɛs jə ɹɪtɝn tə hɛlp wɪð ðə klinʌp. ðɛɹz ə lɔŋ weɪ tə ɡoʊ, jɛt."

"Thank you, Elza," he said. "Best you return to help with the cleanup. There's a long way to go, yet."

hɝ maʊθ taɪɾənd slaɪtli, ən əɹ ɡeɪz tʊk ɪn ɛvɹiwʌn fɹəm kædzueɪn tə ði oʊɡiɝ wɪð ən ɛɹ ə dʒɛləsi bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɔfɝɾ ə kɝtsi ən lɛft. jɛs, fənæɾɪkəl wɑz ðə wɝd.

Her mouth tightened slightly, and her gaze took in everyone from Cadsuane to the Ogier with an air of jealousy before she offered a curtsy and left. Yes, fanatical was the word.

bæʃɪɹ wɑz ə ʃɔɹt, slɛndɝ mæn ɪn ə ɡoʊld-wɝkt ɡɹeɪ koʊt wɪð ði aɪvɝi bətɑn ə ðə mɑɹʃəl-dʒɛnɝəl ə sɑldɑiə, tɪpt wɪð ə ɡoʊldən wʊlfs hɛd, tʌk bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt ɑpəzəɾ ɪz sɔɹd. hɪz bæɡi tʃɹaʊzɝz wɝ tʌkt ɪndə tɝnd-daʊn buts ðət hæd bɪn wæks tɪl ðeɪ ʃoʊn dɪspaɪɾ ə laɪt splɑɾɝɪŋ ə mʌd. hɪz ɹisənt wɝk hæd ɹikwaɪɝɾ əz mʌtʃ fɔɹmæləɾi ən dɪɡnəɾi əz i kəd səplaɪ, ən i kəd səplaɪ ə ɡɹeɪt dil. ivən ðə sintʃæn mʌst əv hɝɾ ɪz ɹɛpjəteɪʃən baɪ naʊ. ɡɹeɪ stʃɹikt ɪz blæk hɛɹ ən ðə θɪk mʌstæʃɪz ðət kɝld ɝaʊn ɪz maʊθ laɪk daʊn-tɝn hɔɹnz. dɑɹk tɪltəɾ aɪz sæd, hi wɔkt ɹaɪt pæst ɹænd wɪð ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ ɡeɪɾ ʌv ə mæn mɔɹ əkʌstəm tə ə sæɾəl ðən ɪz oʊn fit, wɔk sloʊli əlɔŋ ðə laɪn ə dɛd mɛn, stɛɹɪŋ ɪntɛnli əɾ itʃ feɪs. ɪmpeɪʃən əz ɹænd wɑz, hi ɡeɪv ɪm ɪz taɪm tə mɔɹn.

Bashere was a short, slender man in a gold-worked gray coat with the ivory baton of the Marshal-General of Saldaea, tipped with a golden wolf's head, tucked behind his belt opposite his sword. His baggy trousers were tucked into turned-down boots that had been waxed till they shone despite a light splattering of mud. His recent work had required as much formality and dignity as he could supply, and he could supply a great deal. Even the Seanchan must have heard his reputation by now. Gray streaked his black hair and the thick mustaches that curled around his mouth like down-turned horns. Dark tilted eyes sad, he walked right past Rand with the rolling gait of a man more accustomed to a saddle than his own feet, walked slowly along the line of dead men, staring intently at each face. Impatient as Rand was, he gave him his time to mourn.

"aɪv nɛvɝ sin ɛniθɪŋ laɪk wʌts aʊtsaɪd," bæʃɪɹ sɛd kwaɪətli əz i wɔkt. "ə bɪɡ ɹeɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə blaɪɾ ɪz ə θaʊzən tʃɹɑləks. moʊst ɑɹ oʊnli ə fju hʌnʒɹəd. ɑ, kɝkən, jə nɛvɝ dɪd ɡɑɹd jəɹ lɛf ðə weɪ jə ʃʊd. ivən ðɛn, jə nid tə aʊtnʌmbɝ əm θɹi əɹ fɔɹ taɪmz tə bi əʃʊɹd jə woʊnt ɡoʊ ɪndə ðɛɹ kʊkpɑts. aʊt ðɛɹ. . . . aɪ θɪŋk aɪ sɔ ə fɔɹʃæɾoʊɪŋ ə tɑɹmən ɡdən. ə smɔl pɑɹɾ ə tɑɹmən ɡdən. lɛts hoʊp ɪt ɹɪli ɪz ðə læs bæɾəl. ɪf wi lɪv θɹu ðæt, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wɪl ɛvɝ wɑnə si ənʌðɝ. wi wɪl, ðoʊ. ðɛɹz ɔlweɪz ənʌðɝ bæɾəl. aɪ səpoʊz ðət wɪl bi ðə keɪs əntɪl ðə hoʊl wɝl tɝnz tɪŋkɝ." ət ði ɛn ə ðə ɹoʊ, hi stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə mæn huz feɪs wɑz splɪɾ ɔlmoʊs daʊn tə hɪz ləɡʒɝiən blæk bɪɹd. "ɑzkən hɪɹ hæɾ ə bɹaɪt fjutʃɝ əhɛɾ ə hɪm. bʌt jə kəd seɪ ðə seɪm ʌv ə lɑɾ ə dɛd mɛn."

"I've never seen anything like what's outside," Bashere said quietly as he walked. "A big raid out of the Blight is a thousand Trollocs. Most are only a few hundred. Ah, Kirkun, you never did guard your left the way you should. Even then, you need to outnumber them three or four times to be assured you won't go into their cookpots. Out there. . . . I think I saw a foreshadowing of Tarmon Gai'don. A small part of Tarmon Gai'don. Let's hope it really is the Last Battle. If we live through that, I don't think we'll ever want to see another. We will, though. There's always another battle. I suppose that will be the case until the whole world turns Tinker." At the end of the row, he stopped in front of a man whose face was split almost down to his luxuriant black beard. "Ahzkan here had a bright future ahead of him. But you could say the same of a lot of dead men."

saɪɪŋ hɛvəli, hi tɝn tə feɪs ɹænd. "ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz wɪl mit jə ɪn θɹi deɪz əɾ ə mænɝ haʊs ɪn nɔɹðɝn ɔltɑɹə, nɪɹ ðə bɔɹɾɝ ʌv ændɝ." hi tʌtʃt ðə bɹɛst ə hɪz koʊt. "aɪ hæv ə mæp. ʃiz ɔlɹɛɾi nɪɹ ðəɹ sʌmwɛɹ, bʌt ðeɪ seɪ ɪɾ ɪzən ɪn lænz ðeɪ kəntʃɹoʊl. wən ɪt kʌmz tə sikɹəsi, ðiz sintʃæn meɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ lʊk əz oʊpən əz vɪlədʒ ɡɝlz." kædzueɪn snɔɹɾɪd.

Sighing heavily, he turned to face Rand. "The Daughter of the Nine Moons will meet you in three days at a manor house in northern Altara, near the border of Andor." He touched the breast of his coat. "I have a map. She's already near there somewhere, but they say it isn't in lands they control. When it comes to secrecy, these Seanchan make Aes Sedai look as open as village girls." Cadsuane snorted.

"ju səspɛkt ə tʃɹæp?" lɑɡən izd ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪts skæbɝd, pɝhæps ʌnkɑnʃəsli.

"You suspect a trap?" Logain eased his sword in its scabbard, perhaps unconsciously.

bæʃɪɹ meɪɾ ə dɪsmɪsɪv dʒɛstʃɝ, bʌɾ i izd ɪz sɔɹd, tu. "aɪ ɔlweɪz səspɛkt ə tʃɹæp. ɪɾ ɪzən ðæt. ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ stɪl dɪdnt wɑn mi əɹ mænfɝ tə tɔk tə ɛniwʌn bʌt hɝ. nɑɾ ɛniwʌn. əɹ sɝvəns wɝ mjuts, dʒʌst əz wən wi wɛn tə ɛbu dɑɹ wɪð lɔɪəl."

Bashere made a dismissive gesture, but he eased his sword, too. "I always suspect a trap. It isn't that. The High Lady Suroth still didn't want me or Manfor to talk to anyone but her. Not anyone. Our servants were mutes, just as when we went to Ebou Dar with Loial."

"maɪn hæd hæɾ əɹ tʌŋ kʌɾ aʊt," lɔɪəl sɛɾ ɪn toʊnz ə dɪsɡʌst, hɪz ɪɹz tɪltɪŋ bæk. hɪz nʌkəlz peɪld ɑn ðə hæft ə hɪz æks. heɪmən meɪɾ ə ʃɑk saʊnd, hɪz ɪɹz ɡoʊɪŋ stɪf əz fɛns poʊsts.

"Mine had had her tongue cut out," Loial said in tones of disgust, his ears tilting back. His knuckles paled on the haft of his axe. Haman made a shocked sound, his ears going stiff as fence posts.

"ɔltɑɹə dʒʌs kɹaʊn ə nu kɪŋ," bæʃɪɹ wɛn ɑn, "bʌɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs sim tə bi wɔkɪŋ ɑn ɛɡʃəlz ən lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, sintʃæn ən ɔltɑɹən əlaɪk. ivən sjuɹɔθ lʊkt əz ðoʊ ʃi fɛlt ə sɔɹd hʌvɝɪŋ əbʌv əɹ nɛk."

"Altara just crowned a new King," Bashere went on, "but everybody in the Tarasin Palace seemed to be walking on eggshells and looking over their shoulders, Seanchan and Altaran alike. Even Suroth looked as though she felt a sword hovering above her neck."

"meɪbi ðəɹ fɹaɪɾənd ə tɑɹmən ɡdən," ɹænd sɛd. "ɔɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. əl əv tə bi kɛɹfəl. fɹaɪɾənd pipəl də stupəd θɪŋz. wʌɾ ɑɹ ði ɝeɪnʒmənts, bæʃɪɹ?"

"Maybe they're frightened of Tarmon Gai'don," Rand said. "Or the Dragon Reborn. I'll have to be careful. Frightened people do stupid things. What are the arrangements, Bashere?"

ðə sɑldəiən pʊl ðə mæp fɹəm ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz koʊɾ ən wɔk bæk tə ɹænd ənfoʊldɪŋ ɪt. "ðeɪɹ vɛɹi pɹɪsaɪs. ʃɪl bɹɪŋ sɪks sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn, bʌt noʊ ʌðɝ ətɛndəns." əliviə meɪɾ ə nɔɪz laɪk ən æŋɡɹi kæt, ən i blɪŋk bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn, noʊ daʊɾ ənsɝɾən ʌv ə fɹid deɪmeɪn, tə seɪ ðə list. "ju kən bɹɪŋ faɪv pipəl u kən tʃænəl. ʃɪl əsum ɛni mæn wɪð jə kæn, bʌt jə kən bɹɪŋ ə wʊmən u kæn tə meɪk ði ɑnɝz ivən."

The Saldaean pulled the map from inside his coat and walked back to Rand unfolding it. "They're very precise. She will bring six sul'dam and damane, but no other attendants." Alivia made a noise like an angry cat, and he blinked before going on, no doubt uncertain of a freed damane, to say the least. "You can bring five people who can channel. She'll assume any man with you can, but you can bring a woman who can't to make the honors even."

mɪn wɑz sʌɾənli ət ɹændz saɪd, ɹæpɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm ɝaʊn hɪz.

Min was suddenly at Rand's side, wrapping her arm around his.

"noʊ," hi sɛd fɝmli. hi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə teɪk əɹ ɪndə ə pɑsəbəl tʃɹæp.

"No," he said firmly. He was not about to take her into a possible trap.

"wil tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt," ʃi mɝmɝd, ðə bɑn fɪlɪŋ wɪð stʌbɝn ɹizɑlv.

"We'll talk about it," she murmured, the bond filling with stubborn resolve.

ðə moʊs daɪɹ wɝdz ə wʊmən kən seɪ ʃɔɹɾ ʌv "aɪm gɑnə kɪl ju," ɹænd θɔt. sʌɾənli hi fɛlt ə tʃɪl. hæɾ ɪt bɪn hɪm? əɹ luz θɝɪn? ðə mædmæn tʃʌkəl sɔfli ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd. noʊ mæɾɝ. ɪn θɹi deɪz, wʌn dɪfəkəlti wəd bi ɹizɑlvd. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ. "wʌɾ ɛls, bæʃɪɹ?"

The most dire words a woman can say short of "I'm going to kill you," Rand thought. Suddenly he felt a chill. Had it been him? Or Lews Therin? The madman chuckled softly in the back of his head. No matter. In three days, one difficulty would be resolved. One way or another. "What else, Bashere?"

lɪftɪŋ ðə dæmp klɔθ ðət leɪ əkɹɔs əɹ aɪz, kɛɹfəli soʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt kætʃ ðə bɹeɪslət-ænd-ɹɪŋz æŋɡɹil ɪn əɹ hɛɹ - ʃi wɔɹ ðəɾ ən əɹ dʒuəl tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɛvɹi weɪkɪŋ moʊmənt naʊ - nɪneɪiv sæɾ ʌp ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ bɛd. wɪð mɛn niɾɪŋ hilɪŋ fɹəm dʒɹɛdfəl wunz, səm mɪsɪŋ ə hæn əɹ ən ɑɹm, ɪt hæd sim pɛɾi tə æsk hilɪŋ fəɹ ə hɛdeɪk, bʌt ðə wɪloʊ bɑɹk sim tə hæv wɝkt əz wɛl. oʊnli mɔɹ sloʊli. wʌn ə hɝ ɹɪŋz, sɛt wɪð ə peɪl ɡɹin stoʊn ðət naʊ əpɪɹd tə ɡloʊ wɪð ə feɪn ɪntɝnəl laɪt, sim tə vaɪbɹeɪt kəntɪnjuəli ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝ ðoʊ ɪt dɪd nɑt ɹɪli muv. ðə pæɾɝn ə vaɪbɹeɪʃənz wɑz mɪkst, ə ɹiækʃən tə seɪaɪdɑɹ ən seɪɾɪn biɪŋ tʃænəld aʊtsaɪd. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, sʌmwʌn cʊɾə bɪn tʃænəlɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. kædzueɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə ɪndəkeɪt dɝɛkʃən, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ haʊ. hɑ! fəɹ kædzueɪn ən əɹ səpoʊz supɪɹiɝ nɑlədʒ! ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd seɪ ðət tə ðə wʊmənz feɪs. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðət kædzueɪn ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd əɹ - sɝɾənli nɑt; ʃi stʊɾ əbʌv kædzueɪn - dʒʌs ðət ʃi wɑntəd tə meɪnteɪn səm dɪɡɹi ʌv hɑɹməni. ðət wɑz ðə ɹizən ʃi hɛld əɹ tʌŋ ɝaʊn ðə wʊmən.

Lifting the damp cloth that lay across her eyes, carefully so she did not catch the bracelet-and-rings angreal in her hair - she wore that and her jeweled ter'angreal every waking moment now - Nynaeve sat up on the edge of her bed. With men needing Healing from dreadful wounds, some missing a hand or an arm, it had seemed petty to ask Healing for a headache, but the willow bark seemed to have worked as well. Only more slowly. One of her rings, set with a pale green stone that now appeared to glow with a faint internal light, seemed to vibrate continually on her finger though it did not really move. The pattern of vibrations was mixed, a reaction to saidar and saidin being channeled outside. For that matter, someone could have been channeling inside. Cadsuane was sure it should be able to indicate direction, but she could not say how. Ha! for Cadsuane and her supposed superior knowledge! She wished she could say that to the woman's face. It was not that Cadsuane intimidated her - certainly not; she stood above Cadsuane - just that she wanted to maintain some degree of harmony. That was the reason she held her tongue around the woman.

ðə ɹumz ʃi ʃɛɹd wɪð læn wɝ speɪʃəs, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæfti, wɪð noʊ keɪsmən fɪɾɪŋ ɪts wɪndoʊ pɹɑpɝli, ən oʊvɝ ðə dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz ðə haʊs hæd sɛɾəld ɪnʌf ðət ðə dɔɹz hæd bɪn tʃɹɪm soʊ ðeɪ kəd kloʊz ɔl ðə weɪ, meɪkɪŋ mɔɹ ɡæps tə lɛɾ ɛvɹi bɹiz wɪsəl θɹu. ðə faɪɝ ɑn ðə stoʊn hɑɹθ dænst əz ðoʊ ɪt wɝ aʊtdɔɹz, kɹæklɪŋ ən spɪɾɪŋ spɑɹks. ðə kɑɹpət, soʊ feɪɾəd ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹɪli meɪk aʊt ðə pæɾɝn, hæd mɔɹ hoʊlz bɝn ɪn ɪt ðən ʃi kəd kaʊnt. ðə bɛd wɪð ɪts hɛvi bɪdpoʊsts ən wɔɹn kænəpi wɑz lɑɹdʒ ən stɝɾi, bʌt ðə mætʃɹəs wɑz lʌmpi, ðə pɪloʊz hɛl mɔɹ fɛðɝz ðət poʊk θɹu ðən ðeɪ dɪd daʊn, ən ðə blæŋkəts simd ɔlmoʊs mɔɹ dɑɹnz ðən ɝɪdʒənəl mətɪɹiəl. bʌt læn ʃɛɹd ðə ɹumz, ən ðət meɪɾ ɔl ðə dɪfɝəns. ðət meɪɾ əm ə pæləs.

The rooms she shared with Lan were spacious, but also drafty, with no casement fitting its window properly, and over the generations the house had settled enough that the doors had been trimmed so they could close all the way, making more gaps to let every breeze whistle through. The fire on the stone hearth danced as though it were outdoors, crackling and spitting sparks. The carpet, so faded she could no longer really make out the pattern, had more holes burned in it than she could count. The bed with its heavy bedposts and worn canopy was large and sturdy, but the mattress was lumpy, the pillows held more feathers that poked through than they did down, and the blankets seemed almost more darns than original material. But Lan shared the rooms, and that made all the difference. That made them a palace.

hi stʊɾ ət wʌn ə ðə wɪndoʊz wɛɹ i hæd bɪn sɪns ði ətæk bɪɡæn, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn naʊ ət ðə wɝk ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn aʊtsaɪd. əɹ pɝhæps stʌɾiɪŋ ðə slɔɾɝ jɑɹd ðə mænɝ haʊs ɡɹaʊnz hæd bɪkʌm. hi wɑz soʊ stɪl, hi maɪɾ əv bɪn ə stætʃu, ə tɔl mæn ɪn ə wɛl-fɪɾɪŋ dɑɹk ɡɹin koʊt, hɪz ʃoʊldɝz bɹɔɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪz weɪst əpɪɹ slɛndɝ, wɪð ðə lɛðɝ kɔɹɾ ə hɪz hædɔɹi hoʊldɪŋ bæk ɪz ʃoʊldɝ-lɛŋθ hɛɹ, blæk tɪŋd wɪð waɪɾ ət ðə tɛmpəlz. ə hɑɹd-feɪs mæn, jɛt bjuɾəfəl. ɪn əɹ aɪz i wɑz, lɛɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls seɪ wʌt ðeɪ wʊd. oʊnli ðeɪ hæd bɛs nɑt seɪ ɪɾ ɪn əɹ hɪɹɪŋ. ivən kædzueɪn. ə ɹɪŋ bɛɹɪŋ ə flɔləs sæfaɪɝ wɑz koʊld ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hænd. ɪt simd mɔɹ laɪkli hi wɑz filɪŋ æŋɡɝ ðən hɑstɪləɾi. ðət ɹɪŋ dɪɾ əv ə flɔ, ɪn əɹ ɛstəmeɪʃən. ɪt wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl tə noʊ sʌmwʌn nɪɹbaɪ wɑz filɪŋ æŋɡɹi əɹ hɑstəl, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt min ði ɪmoʊʃən wɑz dɝɛktəɾ ət ju.

He stood at one of the windows where he had been since the attack began, staring down now at the work going on outside. Or perhaps studying the slaughter yard the manor house grounds had become.
