He was so still, he might have been a statue, a tall man in a well-fitting dark green coat, his shoulders broad enough to make his waist appear slender, with the leather cord of his hadori holding back his shoulder-length hair, black tinged with white at the temples. A hard-faced man, yet beautiful. In her eyes he was, let anyone else say what they would. Only they had best not say it in her hearing. Even Cadsuane. A ring bearing a flawless sapphire was cold on her right hand. It seemed more likely he was feeling anger than hostility. That ring did have a flaw, in her estimation. It was all very well to know someone nearby was feeling angry or hostile, but that did not mean the emotion was directed at you.

"ɪts taɪm fəɹ mi tə ɡoʊ bæk aʊtsaɪɾ ən lɛn ə hæn əɡɛn," ʃi sɛɾ əz ʃi stʊd.

"It's time for me to go back outside and lend a hand again," she said as she stood.

"nɑt jɛt," hi toʊld əɹ wɪθaʊt tɝnɪŋ fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ. ɹɪŋ əɹ noʊ ɹɪŋ, hɪz dip vɔɪs wɑz kɑm. ən kwaɪt fɝm. "mɔɪɹeɪn juz tə seɪ ə hɛdeɪk wɑz saɪn ʃi hæd bɪn tʃænəlɪŋ tu mʌtʃ. ðæts deɪnʒɝəs."

"Not yet," he told her without turning from the window. Ring or no ring, his deep voice was calm. And quite firm. "Moiraine used to say a headache was sign she had been channeling too much. That's dangerous."

hɝ hæn stʃɹeɪd təwɔɹɾ əɹ bɹeɪd bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd snætʃ ɪt daʊn əɡɛn. əz ɪf i nu mɔɹ əbaʊt tʃænəlɪŋ ðən ʃi! wɛl, ɪn səm weɪz i dɪd. twɛnti jɪɹz əz mɔɪɹeɪnz wɔɹɾɝ hæd tɔɾ ɪm əz mʌtʃ əz ə mæn kəd noʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ. "maɪ hɛdeɪk ɪz kəmplitli ɡɔn. aɪm pɝfəkli ɔl ɹaɪt naʊ."

Her hand strayed toward her braid before she could snatch it down again. As if he knew more about channeling than she! Well, in some ways he did. Twenty years as Moiraine's Warder had taught him as much as a man could know of saidar. "My headache is completely gone. I'm perfectly all right now."

"doʊn bi pɛtʃələnt, maɪ lʌv. ðəɹ ɑɹ oʊnli ə fju aʊɝz tɪl twaɪlaɪt. plɛnti ʌv wɝk wɪl bi lɛf təmɑɹoʊ." hɪz lɛf hæn taɪɾənd ɑn ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd, ɹɪlækst, taɪɾənd. oʊnli ðət hæn muvd.

"Don't be petulant, my love. There are only a few hours till twilight. Plenty of work will be left tomorrow." His left hand tightened on the hilt of his sword, relaxed, tightened. Only that hand moved.

hɝ lɪps kəmpɹɛst. pɛtʃələnt? ʃi smuðd əɹ skɝt fjʊɹiəsli. ʃi wɑz nɑt pɛtʃələnt! hi sɛldəm ɪnvoʊkt ɪz ɹaɪt tə kəmæn ɪn pɹaɪvət - kɝs ðoʊz si foʊk fəɹ ɛvɝ θɪŋkɪŋ ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ! - bʌt wən i dɪd, ðə mæn wɑz ʌnbɛndɪŋ. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi kəd ɡoʊ ɛniweɪ. hi wəd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp əɹ fɪzɪkəli. ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ə ðæt. fɛɹli sɝɾən. oʊnli ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə vaɪəleɪɾ əɹ mɛɹɪdʒ vaʊz ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst weɪ. ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd wɑnə kɪk əɹ bɪlʌv hʌzbənz ʃɪnz.

Her lips compressed. Petulant? She smoothed her skirt furiously. She was not petulant! He seldom invoked his right to command in private - curse those Sea Folk for ever thinking of such a thing! - but when he did, the man was unbending. Of course, she could go anyway. He would not try to stop her physically. She was certain of that. Fairly certain. Only she did not intend to violate her marriage vows in the slightest way. Even if she did want to kick her beloved husband's shins.

kɪkɪŋ əɹ skɝts ɪnstɛd, ʃi wɛn tə stæn bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ət ðə wɪndoʊ ən slɪp əɹ ɑɹm θɹu hɪz. hɪz ɑɹm wɑz ɹɑk hɑɹd, ðoʊ. hɪz mʌsəlz wɝ hɑɹd, wʌndɝfəli soʊ, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ðə hɑɹdnəs ə tɛnʃən, əz ðoʊ hi wɝ stʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə lɪft ə ɡɹeɪt weɪt. haʊ ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæɾ ɪz bɑnd, tə ɡɪv əɹ hɪns ʌv wʌt wɑz tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ hɪm. wən ʃi leɪd hænz ɑn maɪɹɛl. . . . noʊ, bɛs nɑt tə θɪŋk ə ðət hʌsi! ɡɹinz! ðeɪ sɪmpli kəd nɑt bi tʃɹʌstɪd wɪð mɛn!

Kicking her skirts instead, she went to stand beside him at the window and slip her arm through his. His arm was rock hard, though. His muscles were hard, wonderfully so, but this was the hardness of tension, as though he were straining to lift a great weight. How she wished she had his bond, to give her hints of what was troubling him. When she laid hands on Myrelle. . . . No, best not to think of that hussy! Greens! They simply could not be trusted with men!

aʊtsaɪd, nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə haʊs, ʃi kəd si ə pɛɹ ə ðoʊz blæk-koʊɾəd æʃəmən, ən ðə sɪstɝz bɑndəd tə ðɛm. ʃi hæɾ əvɔɪɾəd ðət hoʊl lɑɾ əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl - ði æʃəmən fəɹ ɑbviəs ɹizənz, ðə sɪstɝz kəz ðeɪ səpɔɹɾəd ɪleɪɾə - jɛt jə kəd nɑt spɛn taɪm ɪn ðə seɪm haʊs wɪð pipəl, ivən ə haʊs əz lɑɹdʒ ən ɹæmblɪŋ əz ælɡɝɪnz, ən əvɔɪd kʌmɪŋ tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɛm. ɑɹɛl mælvɪn wɑz ə kɛɹhinɪn u simd ivən waɪɾɝ ðən i æktʃəli  wɑz kəz i stʊd bɛɹli tʃɛst-haɪ tə læn, dɑnɑloʊ sændʌmɪɹ ə tɛɹən wɪð ə ɡɑɹnəɾ ɪn ɪz lɛft ɪɹ ən ɪz ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik bɪɹd tʃɹɪm tə ə pɔɪn ən ɔɪld, ɔlðoʊ ʃi daʊɾɪd vɛɹi mʌtʃ ðəɾ ɪz kɹist, lɛðɝi feɪs bɪlɔŋ tə ə noʊbəl. mælvɪn hæd bɑndəd səlɪŋ nun, ə fɪɹs-aɪd ɡɹin u pɛpɝɾ əɹ spitʃ wɪð bɔɹɾɝlənd oʊðz ðət səmtaɪmz meɪd læn wɪns. nɪneɪiv wɪʃt ʃi ʌndɝstʊd ðɛm, bʌɾ i ɹəfjuz tə ɪkspleɪn. sændʌmɪɹz kæptɪv wɑz aɪɑkoʊ nɔɹsoʊni, ə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv waɪt wɪð weɪvi weɪst-lɛŋθ blæk hɛɹ u wɑz nɪɹli əz bɹaʊn-skɪn əz ə dəmɑni. ʃi simd ʃaɪ, ə ɹɛɹəɾi əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. boʊθ wɪmən wɔɹ ðɛɹ fɹɪnd ʃɔlz. ðə kæptɪvz ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz dɪd, pɝhæps əz dʒɛstʃɝz ə dɪfaɪəns. bʌt ðɛn, ðeɪ sim tə ɡɛɾ ɑn stʃɹeɪnʒli wɛl wɪð ðə mɛn. ɔfən nɪneɪiv hæd sin əm tʃæɾɪŋ kəmpænjənəbli, hɑɹdli ðə bɪheɪvjɝ ə dɪfaɪən pɹɪznɝz. ən ʃi səspɛktəd ðət lɑɡən ən ɡɑbɹɛl wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli pɛɹ ʃɛɹɪŋ ə bɛɾ aʊtsaɪd wɛdlɑk. ɪt wɑz dɪsɡɹeɪsfəl!

Outside, not far from the house, she could see a pair of those black-coated Asha'man, and the sisters bonded to them. She had avoided that whole lot as much as possible - the Asha'man for obvious reasons, the sisters because they supported Elaida - yet you could not spend time in the same house with people, even a house as large and rambling as Algarin's, and avoid coming to recognize them. Arel Malevin was a Cairhienin who seemed even wider than he actually was because he stood barely chest-high to Lan, Donalo Sandomere a Tairen with a garnet in his left ear and his gray-streaked beard trimmed to a point and oiled, although she doubted very much that his creased, leathery face belonged to a noble. Malevin had bonded Aisling Noon, a fierce-eyed Green who peppered her speech with Borderland oaths that sometimes made Lan wince. Nynaeve wished she understood them, but he refused to explain. Sandomere's captive was Ayako Norsoni, a diminutive White with wavy waist-length black hair who was nearly as brown-skinned as a Domani. She seemed shy, a rarity among Aes Sedai. Both women wore their fringed shawls. The captives almost always did, perhaps as gestures of defiance. But then, they seemed to get on strangely well with the men. Often Nynaeve had seen them chatting companionably, hardly the behavior of defiant prisoners. And she suspected that Logain and Gabrelle were not the only pair sharing a bed outside wedlock. It was disgraceful!

sʌɾənli faɪɝz blum bɪloʊ, sɪks ɪnvɛləpɪŋ dɛd tʃɹɑləks ɪn fɹʌn ə mælvɪn ən səlɪŋ, sɛvən ɪn fɹʌn ə sændʌmɪɹ ən aɪɑkoʊ, ən ʃi skwɪntɪɾ əɡɛns ðə blaɪndɪŋ ɡlɛɹ. ɪt wɑz laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ət θɝtin nundeɪ sʌnz bleɪzɪŋ ɪn ə klaʊdləs skaɪ. ðeɪ wɝ lɪŋkt. ʃi kəd tɛl fɹəm ðə weɪ ðə floʊz ə seɪaɪdɑɹ muvd, stɪfli, əz ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ fɔɹst ɪndə pleɪs ɹæðɝ ðən ɡaɪɾəd. əɹ ɹæðɝ, ðə mɛn wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs ðɛm. ðət nɛvɝ wɝkt wɪð ðə fimeɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ. ɪt wɑz pjʊɹ faɪɝ, ən ðə bleɪzɪz wɝ fɝoʊʃəs, fɪɹsɝ ðən ʃi wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd fɹəm faɪɝ əloʊn. bʌɾ ə kɔɹs ðeɪ wəd bi juzɪŋ seɪɾɪn əz wɛl, ən u kəd seɪ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ æɾɪŋ fɹəm ðət mɝɾɝəs keɪɑs? ðə lɪɾəl ʃi kəd ɹikɔl ə biɪŋ lɪŋkt wɪð ɹænd lɛft əɹ wɪð noʊ dɪzaɪɝ ɛvɝ əɡɛn tə ɡoʊ nɪɹ ðæt. ɪn dʒʌst ə fju mɪnəts ðə faɪɝz vænɪʃt, livɪŋ oʊnli loʊ hips ʌv ɡɹeɪɪʃ æʃ laɪɪŋ ɑn sɪɹɾ ɝθ ðət lʊk hɑɹɾ ən kɹækt. ðət kəd nɑt də ðə sɔɪl mʌtʃ ɡʊd.

Suddenly fires bloomed below, six enveloping dead Trollocs in front of Malevin and Aisling, seven in front of Sandomere and Ayako, and she squinted against the blinding glare. It was like trying to look at thirteen noonday suns blazing in a cloudless sky. They were linked. She could tell from the way the flows of saidar moved, stiffly, as though they were being forced into place rather than guided. Or rather, the men were trying to force them. That never worked with the female half of the Power. It was pure Fire, and the blazes were ferocious, fiercer than she would have expected from Fire alone. But of course they would be using saidin as well, and who could say what they were adding from that murderous chaos? The little she could recall of being linked with Rand left her with no desire ever again to go near that. In just a few minutes the fires vanished, leaving only low heaps of grayish ash lying on seared earth that looked hard and cracked. That could not do the soil much good.

"ju kæn faɪn ðɪs vɛɹi ɛntɝteɪnɪŋ, læn. wʌɾ ɑɹ jə θɪŋkɪŋ?"

"You can't find this very entertaining, Lan. What are you thinking?"

"aɪɾəl θɔts," hi sɛd, hɪz ɑɹm hɑɹɾ əz stoʊn bɪniθ əɹ hænd. nu faɪɝz flɛɹɾ aʊtsaɪd.

"Idle thoughts," he said, his arm hard as stone beneath her hand. New fires flared outside.

"ʃɛɹ əm wɪð mi." ʃi mænədʒ tə pʊɾ ə hɪn ə kwɛstʃən ɪn ðæt. hi simd əmjuz baɪ ðə neɪtʃɝ ə ðɛɹ vaʊz, jɛɾ i æbsəlutli ɹəfjuz tə fɑloʊ ðə smɔləst ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən wən ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn. ɹɪkwɛsts, hi ɡɹæntəɾ ɪnstənli - wɛl, moʊst ə ðə taɪm - bʌt ðə mæn wəd kwaɪətli liv ɪz buts mʌɾi tɪl ðə mʌd fleɪkt ɔf ɪf ʃi toʊld ɪm nɑt tə tʃɹæk ɪn mʌd.

"Share them with me." She managed to put a hint of question in that. He seemed amused by the nature of their vows, yet he absolutely refused to follow the smallest instruction when they were alone. Requests, he granted instantly - well, most of the time - but the man would quietly leave his boots muddy till the mud flaked off if she told him not to track in mud.

"ənplɛzən θɔts, bʌɾ ɪf jə wɪʃ. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl ən tʃɹɑləks meɪk mi θɪŋk ə tɑɹmən ɡdən."

"Unpleasant thoughts, but if you wish. The Myrddraal and Trollocs make me think of Tarmon Gai'don."

"ənplɛzən θɔts, ɪndid."

"Unpleasant thoughts, indeed."

stɪl stɛɹɪŋ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ, hi nɑɾəd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs - læn kəd titʃ ɛɛs sədaɪ əbaʊt haɪɾɪŋ ɪmoʊʃənz! - bʌɾ ə tʌtʃ ə hiɾ ɛntɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "ɪts kʌmɪŋ sun, nɪneɪiv, jɛɾ ælθɹ simz tə θɪŋk hiz fɝɛvɝ tə dæns wɪð ðə sintʃæn. ʃæɾoʊzpɔn kəd bi muvɪŋ daʊn θɹu ðə blaɪt waɪl wi stæn hɪɹ, daʊn θɹu - " hɪz maʊθ snæpt ʃʌt. daʊn θɹu mɔlkiɝ, hi hæɾ ɔlmoʊst sɛd, dɛd mɔlkiɝ, ðə mɝɾɝd læn ə hɪz bɝθ. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. hi wɛn ɑn əz ɪf i hæd nɑt pɔzd. "ðeɪ kəd stʃɹaɪk ət ʃaɪnɝ, ət ðə hoʊl bɔɹɾɝlændz, nɛkst wik, əɹ təmɑɹoʊ. ən ælθɹ sɪts wivɪŋ ɪz sintʃæn skimz. hi ʃəd sɛn sʌmwʌn tə kənvɪns kɪŋ isɑɹ ən ði ʌðɝz tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ duɾi əlɔŋ ðə blaɪt. hi ʃəd bi mɑɹʃəlɪŋ ɔl ðə fɔɹs i kən ɡæðɝ ən teɪkɪŋ ɪt tə ðə blaɪt. ðə læs bæɾəl wɪl bi ðɛɹ, ən ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ðə wɔɹ ɪz ðɛɹ."

Still staring out the window, he nodded. There was no expression on his face - Lan could teach Aes Sedai about hiding emotions! - but a touch of heat entered his voice. "It's coming soon, Nynaeve, yet al'Thor seems to think he has forever to dance with the Seanchan. Shadowspawn could be moving down through the Blight while we stand here, down through - " His mouth snapped shut. Down through Malkier, he had almost said, dead Malkier, the murdered land of his birth. She was sure of it. He went on as if he had not paused. "They could strike at Shienar, at the whole Borderlands, next week, or tomorrow. And al'Thor sits weaving his Seanchan schemes. He should send someone to convince King Easar and the others to return to their duty along the Blight. He should be marshaling all the force he can gather and taking it to the Blight. The Last Battle will be there, and at Shayol Ghul. The war is there."

sædnəs wɛld ʌp ɪn hɝ, jɛt ʃi mænədʒ tə kip ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ vɔɪs. "ju hæv tə ɡoʊ bæk," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli.

Sadness welled up in her, yet she managed to keep it out of her voice. "You have to go back," she said quietly.

ət læst i tɝn ɪz hɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ daʊn ət hɝ. hɪz klɪɹ blu aɪz wɝ soʊ koʊld. ðeɪ hɛld lɛs ə dɛθ ðən ðeɪ hæd, ʌv ðət ʃi wɑz sɝɾən, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɪl soʊ koʊld. "maɪ pleɪs ɪz wɪð ju, hɑɹɾ ə maɪ hɑɹt. ɛvɝ ən ɔlweɪz."

At last he turned his head, frowning down at her. His clear blue eyes were so cold. They held less of death than they had, of that she was certain, but they were still so cold. "My place is with you, heart of my heart. Ever and always."

ʃi ɡæðɝɾ ɔl ə hɝ kɝədʒ ən hɛld ɑn tə ɪt hɑɹd, soʊ hɑɹd ðət ʃi ætʃt. ʃi wɑntəd tə spik fæst, tə ɡɛt ðə wɝdz aʊt bɪfɔɹ kɝədʒ feɪld, bʌt ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə ə stɛɾi toʊn ən ən ivən peɪs. "eɪ bɔɹɾɝlənd seɪɪŋ aɪ hɝd fɹəm jə wʌns. 'dɛθ ɪz laɪɾɝ ðən ə fɛðɝ, duɾi hɛviɝ ðən ə maʊntən.' maɪ duɾi laɪz hɪɹ, meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ əliviə dʌzn kɪl ɹænd. bʌɾ əl teɪk jə tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. jəɹ duɾi laɪz ðɛɹ. jə wɑnə ɡoʊ tə ʃaɪnɝ? jə mɛnʃən kɪŋ isɑɹ ən ʃaɪnɝ. ən ɪts kloʊs tə mɔlkiɝ."

She gathered all of her courage and held on to it hard, so hard that she ached. She wanted to speak fast, to get the words out before courage failed, but she forced herself to a steady tone and an even pace. "A Borderland saying I heard from you once. 'Death is lighter than a feather, duty heavier than a mountain.' My duty lies here, making sure Alivia doesn't kill Rand. But I will take you to the Borderlands. Your duty lies there. You want to go to Shienar? You mentioned King Easar and Shienar. And it is close to Malkier."

hi lʊk daʊn əɾ əɹ fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, bʌɾ ət læst i ɛksheɪl sɔfli, ən ðə tɛnʃən lɛft ɪz ɑɹm. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ, nɪneɪiv? ɪf jə ɑɹ, ðɛn, jɛs, ʃaɪnɝ. ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, ðə ʃædoʊ juz tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp tə muv lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə tʃɹɑləks, dʒʌst əz ɪt dɪɾ ə fju jɪɹz bæk, wən wi sɔt ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld. bʌɾ oʊnli ɪf jə ɑɹ kəmplitli ʃʊɹ."

He looked down at her for a long time, but at last he exhaled softly, and the tension left his arm. "Are you sure, Nynaeve? If you are, then, yes, Shienar. In the Trolloc Wars, the Shadow used Tarwin's Gap to move large numbers of Trollocs, just as it did a few years back, when we sought the Eye of the World. But only if you are completely sure."

noʊ, ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ. ʃi wɑntəd tə kɹaɪ, tə skɹim əɾ ɪm ðəɾ i wɑz ə ful, ðəɾ ɪz pleɪs wɑz wɪð hɝ, nɑt daɪɪŋ əloʊn ɪn ə fjuɾəl pɹaɪvət wɔɹ wɪð ðə ʃædoʊ. oʊnli, ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ ɛni ʌv ðæt. bɑn əɹ noʊ bɑnd, ʃi nu hi wɑz tɔɹn ɪnsaɪd, tɔɹn bɪtwin ɪz lʌv ə hɝ ən ɪz duɾi, tɔɹn ən bliɾɪŋ əz ʃʊɹli əz ɪf i hæd bɪn stæbd wɪð ə sɔɹd. ʃi kəd nɑɾ æd tə hɪz wunz. ʃi kəd tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ i sɝvaɪvd, ðoʊ. "wʊɾ aɪ meɪk ði ɔfɝ ɪf aɪ wɑznt ʃʊɹ?" ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ kɑm ʃi saʊndəd. "aɪ woʊn laɪk sɛndɪŋ jə əweɪ, bʌt juv jəɹ duɾi, ən aɪ hæv maɪn."

No, she was not sure. She wanted to cry, to scream at him that he was a fool, that his place was with her, not dying alone in a futile private war with the Shadow. Only, she could not say any of that. Bond or no bond, she knew he was torn inside, torn between his love of her and his duty, torn and bleeding as surely as if he had been stabbed with a sword. She could not add to his wounds. She could try to make sure he survived, though. "Would I make the offer if I wasn't sure?" she said dryly, surprised at how calm she sounded. "I won't like sending you away, but you have your duty, and I have mine."

ɹæpɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝ, hi hʌɡd əɹ tə hɪz tʃɛst, dʒɛnli ət fɝst, ðən hɑɹɾɝ, əntɪl ʃi θɔɾ i maɪt skwiz ɔl ði ɛɹ fɹəm əɹ lʌŋz. ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. ʃi hʌɡd ɪm dʒʌst əz fɪɹsli, ən hæd tə pɹaɪ hɝ hænz fɹəm ɪz bɹɔd bæk wən ʃi wɑz dʌn ət læst. laɪt, ʃi wɑntəd tə wip. ən nu ʃi mʌs nɑt.

Wrapping his arms around her, he hugged her to his chest, gently at first, then harder, until she thought he might squeeze all the air from her lungs. She did not care. She hugged him just as fiercely, and had to pry her hands from his broad back when she was done at last. Light, she wanted to weep. And knew she must not.

əz i bɪɡæn pækɪŋ ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz, ʃi hɝidli tʃeɪnʒd ɪndə ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ə jɛloʊ-slæʃt ɡɹin sɪlk ən staʊt lɛðɝ ʃuz, ðən slɪp fɹəm ðə ɹum bɪfɔɹ i wɑz dʌn. ælɡɝɪnz laɪbɹɛɹi wɑz lɑɹdʒ, ə skwɛɹ, haɪ-silɪŋɡd ɹum laɪnd wɪð ʃɛlvz. hæf ə dʌzən kʊʃən tʃɛɹz stʊd skæɾɝd ɝaʊn ðə flɔɹ, ən ə lɔŋ teɪbəl ən ə tɔl mæp-ɹæk kəmpliɾəd ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz. ðə stoʊn hɑɹθ wɑz koʊld ən ði aɪɝn stænd-læmps ənlɪt, bʌt ʃi tʃænəl bɹifli tə laɪt θɹi ʌv ðɛm. ə heɪsti sɝtʃ faʊn ðə mæps ʃi niɾəd ɪn ðə ɹæks daɪmənd-ʃeɪp kəmpɑɹtməns. ðeɪ wɝ əz oʊld əz moʊst ə ðə bʊks, jɛt ðə læn dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ɡɹeɪtli ɪn tu əɹ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz.

As he began packing his saddlebags, she hurriedly changed into a riding dress of yellow-slashed green silk and stout leather shoes, then slipped from the room before he was done. Algarin's library was large, a square, high-ceilinged room lined with shelves. Half a dozen cushioned chairs stood scattered around the floor, and a long table and a tall map-rack completed the furnishings. The stone hearth was cold and the iron stand-lamps unlit, but she channeled briefly to light three of them. A hasty search found the maps she needed in the rack's diamond-shaped compartments. They were as old as most of the books, yet the land did not change greatly in two or three hundred years.

wən ʃi ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ ɹumz, læn wɑz ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, sæɾəlbæɡz ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, wɔɹɾɝz kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk hæŋɪŋ daʊn ɪz bæk. hɪz feɪs wɑz stɪl, ə stoʊn mæsk. ʃi tʊk oʊnli taɪm tə ɡɛɾ əɹ oʊn kloʊk, blu sɪlk laɪnd wɪð vɛlvət, ən ðeɪ wɔkt ɪn saɪləns, hɝ ɹaɪt hæn ɹɛstɪŋ laɪtli ɑn ɪz lɛft ɹɪst, aʊt tə ðə dɪmli lɪt steɪbəl wɛɹ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɝ kɛpt. ði ɛɹ ðəɹ smɛld ə heɪ ən hɔɹsəz ən hɔɹs dʌŋ, əz ɪɾ ɔlweɪz dɪɾ ɪn steɪbəlz.

When she returned to their rooms, Lan was in the sitting room, saddlebags on his shoulder, Warder's color-shifting cloak hanging down his back. His face was still, a stone mask. She took only time to get her own cloak, blue silk lined with velvet, and they walked in silence, her right hand resting lightly on his left wrist, out to the dimly lit stable where their horses were kept. The air there smelled of hay and horses and horse dung, as it always did in stables.

ə lin, bɔldɪŋ ɡɹum wɪð ə noʊz ðət hæd bɪn bɹoʊkən mɔɹ ðən wʌns saɪd wən læn toʊld ɪm ðeɪ wɑntəd mændɑɹb ən lʌvɝsknət sæɾəld. ə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən bɪɡæn wɝk ɑn nɪneɪivz staʊt bɹaʊn mɛɹ, waɪl θɹi ʌv ði eɪdʒɪŋ mɛn meɪɾ ə dʒɑb ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ lænz tɔl blæk stæljən bɹaɪɾəld ən aʊɾ ə hɪz stɔl.

A lean, balding groom with a nose that had been broken more than once sighed when Lan told him they wanted Mandarb and Loversknot saddled. A gray-haired woman began work on Nynaeve's stout brown mare, while three of the aging men made a job of getting Lan's tall black stallion bridled and out of his stall.

"aɪ wɑn ə pɹɑməs fɹəm ju," nɪneɪiv sɛd kwaɪətli əz ðeɪ weɪɾəd. mændɑɹb dænst ɪn sɝkəlz soʊ ðət ðə plʌmp fɛloʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɪf ðə sæɾəl ɑntu ðə stæljənz bæk hæd tə ɹʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ ʌp. "æn oʊθ. aɪ min ɪt, læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən. wi ɑɹən əloʊn ɛni lɔŋɡɝ."

"I want a promise from you," Nynaeve said quietly as they waited. Mandarb danced in circles so that the plump fellow trying to lift the saddle onto the stallion's back had to run trying to catch up. "An oath. I mean it, Lan Mandragoran. We aren't alone any longer."

"wʌt dʒju wɑn maɪ oʊθ ɑn?" hi æskt wɛɹəli. ðə bɔldɪŋ ɡɹum kɔl fəɹ tu mɔɹ mɛn tə hɛlp.

"What do you want my oath on?" he asked warily. The balding groom called for two more men to help.

"ðæt jəl ɹaɪd tə fæl mɝæn bɪfɔɹ jə ɛntɝ ðə blaɪt, ən ðəɾ ɪf ɛniwʌn wɑns tə ɹaɪd wɪð ju, jəl lɛt hɪm."

"That you'll ride to Fal Moran before you enter the Blight, and that if anyone wants to ride with you, you'll let him."

hɪz smaɪl wɑz smɔl, ən sæd. "aɪv ɔlweɪz ɹəfjuz tə lid mɛn ɪndə ðə blaɪt, nɪneɪiv. ðəɹ wɝ taɪmz mɛn ɹoʊd wɪð mi, bʌɾ aɪ wəd nɑt - "

His smile was small, and sad. "I've always refused to lead men into the Blight, Nynaeve. There were times men rode with me, but I would not - "

"ɪf mɛn əv ɹɪɾən wɪð jə bɪfɔɹ," ʃi kʌɾ ɪn, "mɛn kən ɹaɪd wɪð jə əɡɛn. jəɹ oʊθ ɑn ɪt, əɹ aɪ vaʊ əl lɛt jə ɹaɪd ðə hoʊl lɔŋ weɪ tə ʃaɪnɝ." ðə wʊmən wɑz fæsənɪŋ ðə sɪntʃɪz ɑn lʌvɝsknəts sæɾəl, bʌt ðə θɹi mɛn wɝ stɪl stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə ɡɛt mændɑɹbz sæɾəl ɑn ɪz bæk, tə kip ɪm fɹəm ʃeɪkɪŋ ɔf ðə sæɾəl blæŋkət.

"If men have ridden with you before," she cut in, "men can ride with you again. Your oath on it, or I vow I'll let you ride the whole long way to Shienar." The woman was fastening the cinches on Loversknot's saddle, but the three men were still struggling to get Mandarb's saddle on his back, to keep him from shaking off the saddle blanket.

"haʊ fɑɹ saʊθ ɪn ʃaɪnɝ dʒju min tə liv mi?" hi æskt. wən ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, hi nɑɾəd. "vɛɹi wɛl, nɪneɪiv. ɪf ðæts wʌt jə wɑnt. aɪ swɛɹ ɪɾ ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ maɪ hoʊp ə ɹibɝθ ən sælveɪʃən."

"How far south in Shienar do you mean to leave me?" he asked. When she said nothing, he nodded. "Very well, Nynaeve. If that's what you want. I swear it under the Light and by my hope of rebirth and salvation."

ɪt wɑz vɛɹi hɑɹd nɑt tə saɪ wɪð ɹɪlif. ʃi hæd mænədʒd ɪt, ən wɪθaʊt laɪɪŋ. ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə də əz ɛɡwin wɑntəɾ ən bɪheɪv əz ðoʊ ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi teɪkən ðə θɹi oʊðz ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz vɛɹi hɑɹd dilɪŋ wɪð ə hʌzbən ɪf jə kəd nɑt laɪ ivən wən ɪt wɑz æbsəlutli nɛsəsɛɹi.

It was very hard not to sigh with relief. She had managed it, and without lying. She was trying to do as Egwene wanted and behave as though she had already taken the Three Oaths on the Oath Rod, but it was very hard dealing with a husband if you could not lie even when it was absolutely necessary.

"kɪs mi," ʃi toʊl hɪm, æɾɪŋ heɪstəli, "ðæt wɑzn ən ɔɹɾɝ. aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə kɪs maɪ hʌzbənd." ə ɡʊd-baɪ kɪs. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ taɪm fəɹ wʌn leɪɾɝ.

"Kiss me," she told him, adding hastily, "that wasn't an order. I just want to kiss my husband." A good-bye kiss. There would be no time for one later.

"ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn?" hi sɛd, læfɪŋ. "juv ɔlweɪz bɪn soʊ ʃaɪ əbaʊt ðæt."

"In front of everyone?" he said, laughing. "You've always been so shy about that."

ðə wʊmən wɑz nɪɹli dʌn wɪð lʌvɝsknət, ən wʌn ə ðə ɡɹumz wɑz hoʊldɪŋ mændɑɹb əz stɛɾi əz i kəd waɪl ði ʌðɝ tu hɝidli bʌkəl ðə sɪntʃɪz.

The woman was nearly done with Loversknot, and one of the grooms was holding Mandarb as steady as he could while the other two hurriedly buckled the cinches.

"ðeɪɹ tu bɪzi tə si ɛniθɪŋ. kɪs mi, əɹ əl θɪŋk jəɹ ðə wʌn huz - " hɪz lɪps ɑn hɝz ʃʌɾ ɔf wɝdz. hɝ toʊz kɝld.

"They're too busy to see anything. Kiss me, or I'll think you're the one who's - " His lips on hers shut off words. Her toes curled.

səm taɪm leɪɾɝ, ʃi wɑz linɪŋ ɑn ɪz bɹɔd tʃɛs tə kætʃ əɹ bɹɛθ waɪl i stʃɹoʊkt əɹ hɛɹ. "pɝhæps wi kən əv wʌn læs naɪt təɡɛðɝ ɪn ʃaɪnɝ," hi mɝmɝd sɔfli. "ɪt meɪ bi səm taɪm bɪfɔɹ wɝ təɡɛðɝ əɡɛn, ən əl mɪs hævɪŋ maɪ bæk klɔd."

Some time later, she was leaning on his broad chest to catch her breath while he stroked her hair. "Perhaps we can have one last night together in Shienar," he murmured softly. "It may be some time before we're together again, and I'll miss having my back clawed."

hɝ feɪs ɡɹu hɑt, ən ʃi pʊʃt əweɪ fɹəm ɪm ənstɛɾəli. ðə ɡɹumz wɝ dʌn, ən stɛɹɪŋ vɛɹi pɔɪntɪdli ət ðə stʃɹɔ-kʌvɝd flɔɹ, bʌt ðeɪ maɪt wɛl bi kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ! "aɪ θɪŋk nɑt." ʃi wɑz pɹaʊd ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn bɹɛθləs. "aɪ doʊnt wɑnə liv ɹænd əloʊn wɪð əliviə ðət lɔŋ."

Her face grew hot, and she pushed away from him unsteadily. The grooms were done, and staring very pointedly at the straw-covered floor, but they might well be close enough to overhear! "I think not." She was proud that she did not sound breathless. "I don't want to leave Rand alone with Alivia that long."

"hi tʃɹʌsts hɝ, nɪneɪiv. aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ɪt, bʌt ðəɹ ɪɾ ɪz, ən ðæts ɔl ðət mæɾɝz."

"He trusts her, Nynaeve. I don't understand it, but there it is, and that's all that matters."

ʃi snɪft. əz ɪf ɛni mæn nu wʌt wɑz ɡʊd fəɹ hɪm.

She sniffed. As if any man knew what was good for him.

hɝ staʊt mɛɹ wɪkɝɾ ənizəli əz ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ əmʌŋ dɛd tʃɹɑləks tə ə pætʃ ʌv ɡɹaʊnd nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə steɪbəl ðət ʃi nu wɛl ɪnʌf tə wiv ə ɡeɪtweɪ. mændɑɹb, ə tʃɹeɪnd wɔɹhɔɹs, ɹiæktəd nɑɾ əɾ ɔl tə ðə blʌɾ ən ðə stɛntʃ ən ðə hjudʒ kɔɹpsəz. ðə blæk stæljən simd əz kɑm əz ɪz ɹaɪɾɝ, naʊ ðət læn wɑz ɑn ɪz bæk. ʃi kəɾ ʌndɝstæn ðæt. læn hæɾ ə vɛɹi kɑmɪŋ ɪfɛkt ɑn hɝ, tu. juʒəwəli. səmtaɪmz, hi hæɾ ɪɡzækli ði ɑpəzəɾ ɪfɛkt. ʃi wɪʃt ðeɪ kəɾ əv wʌn mɔɹ naɪt təɡɛðɝ. hɝ feɪs ɡɹu hɑɾ əɡɛn.

Her stout mare whickered uneasily as they rode among dead Trollocs to a patch of ground not far from the stable that she knew well enough to weave a gateway. Mandarb, a trained warhorse, reacted not at all to the blood and the stench and the huge corpses. The black stallion seemed as calm as his rider, now that Lan was on his back. She could understand that. Lan had a very calming effect on her, too. Usually. Sometimes, he had exactly the opposite effect. She wished they could have one more night together. Her face grew hot again.

dɪsmaʊntɪŋ, ʃi dʒɹu ɑn seɪaɪdɑɹ wɪθaʊt juzɪŋ ði æŋɡɹil ən woʊv ə ɡeɪtweɪ dʒʌs tɔl ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə lid lʌvɝsknət θɹu ɑntu ɡɹæslæn dɑɾəd wɪð θɪkəts ə blæk-spɑɾəd bitʃ ən tʃɹiz ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz. ðə sʌn wɑz ə ɡoʊldən bɔl oʊnli ə lɪɾəl daʊn fɹəm ɪts pik, jɛt ði ɛɹ wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli kulɝ ðən ɪn tɛɹ. koʊld ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ ɡæðɝ əɹ kloʊk, ɪn fækt. maʊntənz tɑpt wɪð snoʊ ən klaʊdz ɹoʊz tə ði ist ən nɔɹθ ən saʊθ. əz sun əz læn wɑz θɹu, ʃi lɛt ðə wiv dɪsəpeɪɾ ən ɪmiɾiətli woʊv ənʌðɝ ɡeɪtweɪ, lɑɹdʒɝ, waɪl ʃi klaɪmd ɪndə hɝ sæɾəl ən sɛɾəld ðə kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ əɡɛn.

Dismounting, she drew on saidar without using the angreal and wove a gateway just tall enough for her to lead Loversknot through onto grassland dotted with thickets of black-spotted beech and trees she did not recognize. The sun was a golden ball only a little down from its peak, yet the air was decidedly cooler than in Tear. Cold enough to make her gather her cloak, in fact. Mountains topped with snow and clouds rose to the east and north and south. As soon as Lan was through, she let the weave dissipate and immediately wove another gateway, larger, while she climbed into her saddle and settled the cloak around her again.

læn lɛd mændɑɹb ə fju stɛps wɛstwɝd, stɛɹɪŋ. læn ɛndəɾ əbɹʌpli ɪn wʌt wɑz ɑbviəsli ə klɪf noʊ mɔɹ ðən twɛnti peɪsɪz fɹəm hɪm, ən fɹəm ðəɹ oʊʃən stʃɹɛtʃt tə ðə hɝaɪzən. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə minɪŋ ə ðɪs?" hi dɪmændəd, tɝnɪŋ bæk. "ðɪs ɪzənt ʃaɪnɝ. ɪts wɝlz ɛnd, ɪn sɑldɑiə, əz fɑɹ fɹəm ʃaɪnɝ əz jə kən ɡɛɾ ən stɪl bi ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz."

Lan led Mandarb a few steps westward, staring. Land ended abruptly in what was obviously a cliff no more than twenty paces from him, and from there ocean stretched to the horizon. "What is the meaning of this?" he demanded, turning back. "This isn't Shienar. It's World's End, in Saldaea, as far from Shienar as you can get and still be in the Borderlands."

"aɪ toʊl jə aɪ wəd teɪk jə tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, læn, ən aɪ hæv. ɹɪmɛmbɝ jəɹ oʊθ, maɪ hɑɹt, kəz aɪ ʃʊɹli wɪl." ən wɪð ðət ʃi dʌɡ hɝ hilz ɪn ðə mɛɹz flæŋks ən lɛt ði ænəməl boʊl θɹu ði oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪ. ʃi hɝɾ ɪm kɔl əɹ neɪm, bʌt ʃi lɛt ðə ɡeɪtweɪ kloʊs bɪhaɪn hɝ. ʃi wəd ɡɪv ɪm ə tʃæns tə sɝvaɪv.

"I told you I would take you to the Borderlands, Lan, and I have. Remember your oath, my heart, because I surely will." And with that she dug her heels in the mare's flanks and let the animal bolt through the open gateway. She heard him call her name, but she let the gateway close behind her. She would give him a chance to survive.

oʊnli ə fju aʊɝz pæs mɪddeɪ, lɛs ðən hæf ə dʌzən teɪbəlz wɝ ɑkjəpaɪɾ ɪn ðə lɑɹdʒ kɑmən ɹum ə ðə kwinz læns. moʊst ə ðə wɛl-dʒɹɛs mɛn ən wɪmən, wɪð klɝks ən bɑɾiɡɑɹdz stændɪŋ ətɛntɪvli bɪhaɪn ðɛm, wɝ ðəɹ tə baɪ əɹ sɛl aɪs pɛpɝz, wɪtʃ ɡɹu wɛl ɪn ðə fʊthɪlz ɑn ðə lændwɝd saɪɾ ə ðə bænɪkən maʊntənz, kɔl ðə si wɔl baɪ mɛni ɪn sɑldɑiə. wlɪn ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən hæd noʊ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn pɛpɝz. ðə si wɔl hæɾ ʌðɝ kɹɑps, ən ɹɪtʃɝ.

Only a few hours past midday, less than half a dozen tables were occupied in the large common room of The Queen's Lance. Most of the well-dressed men and women, with clerks and bodyguards standing attentively behind them, were there to buy or sell ice peppers, which grew well in the foothills on the landward side of the Banikhan Mountains, called the Sea Wall by many in Saldaea. Weilin Aldragoran had no interest in peppers. The Sea Wall had other crops, and richer.

"maɪ faɪnəl pɹaɪs," hi sɛd, weɪvɪŋ ə hæn oʊvɝ ðə teɪbəl. ɛvɹi fɪŋɡɝ bɔɹ ə dʒuəld ɹɪŋ. nɑt lɑɹdʒ stoʊnz, bʌt faɪn. ə mæn u soʊl dʒɛmz ʃəɾ ædvɝtaɪz. hi tʃɹeɪɾɪd ɪn ʌðɝ θɪŋz əz wɛl - fɝz, ɹɛɹ wʊdz fəɹ kæbəntmeɪkɝz, faɪnli meɪd sɔɹdz ən ɑɹmɝ, əkeɪʒənəli ʌðɝ θɪŋz ðəɾ ɔfɝɾ ə ɡʊd ɹɪtɝn - bʌt dʒɛmz bɹɔɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹɾ ə hɪz pɹɑfəɾ ɪn ɛni jɪɹ. "aɪl kʌm noʊ loʊɝ." ðə teɪbəl wɑz kʌvɝd wɪð ə pis ə blæk vɛlvət, ðə bɛɾɝ tə ʃoʊ ɔf ə ɡʊd pɔɹʃən ə hɪz stɑk. ɛmɹəlz, faɪɝdʒɹɑps, sæfaɪɝz, ən bɛst ʌv ɔl, daɪmənz. sɛvɹəl ə ðoʊz wɝ lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə ɪntʃɹəst ə ɹulɝ, ən nʌn wɑz smɔl. nʌn hɛld ə flɔ, iðɝ. hi wɑz noʊn θɹuaʊt ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz fəɹ ɪz flɔləs stoʊnz. "æksɛpt ɪt, əɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls wɪl."

"My final price," he said, waving a hand over the table. Every finger bore a jeweled ring. Not large stones, but fine. A man who sold gems should advertise. He traded in other things as well - furs, rare woods for cabinetmakers, finely made swords and armor, occasionally other things that offered a good return - but gems brought in the greater part of his profit in any year. "I'll come no lower." The table was covered with a piece of black velvet, the better to show off a good portion of his stock. Emeralds, firedrops, sapphires, and best of all, diamonds. Several of those were large enough to interest a ruler, and none was small. None held a flaw, either. He was known throughout the Borderlands for his flawless stones. "Accept it, or someone else will."

ðə jʌŋɡɝ ə ðə tu dɑɹk-aɪɾ ɪliɑnɝz əkɹɔs fɹəm hɪm, ə klin-ʃeɪvən fɛloʊ neɪm pəvəl dʒɹeɪnəoʊz, oʊpən ɪz maʊθ æŋɡɹəli, bʌt ði oʊldɝ, dʒɛɔɹɡ dɑmɛntənɪs, hɪz ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik bɪɹd pɹæktəkli kwɪvɝɪŋ, leɪɾ ə fæt hæn ɑn dʒɹeɪnəoʊz' ɑɹm ən ɡeɪv ɪm ə hɔɹəfaɪd lʊk. ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə kənsil ɪz smaɪl, ʃoʊɪŋ ə lɪɾəl tuθ.

The younger of the two dark-eyed Illianers across from him, a clean-shaven fellow named Pavil Geraneos, opened his mouth angrily, but the older, Jeorg Damentanis, his gray-streaked beard practically quivering, laid a fat hand on Geraneos' arm and gave him a horrified look. Aldragoran made no effort to conceal his smile, showing a little tooth.

hi hæd bɪn oʊnli ə tɑdlɝ wən ðə tʃɹɑləks swɛp daʊn ɪndə mɔlkiɝ, ən i hæd noʊ mɛmɹiz ə ðət læn əɾ ɔl - hi sɛldəm ivən θɔɾ ə mɔlkiɝ; ðə lænd wɑz dɛɾ ən ɡɔn - jɛɾ i wɑz ɡlæɾ i hæd lɛɾ ɪz ʌŋkəlz ɡɪv ɪm ðə hædɔɹi. əɾ ənʌðɝ teɪbəl, mænəɡæn wɑz ɪn ə ʃaʊɾɪŋ mætʃ wɪð ə dɑɹk tɛɹən wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ə leɪs ɹʌf ən ɹæðɝ ɪnfɪɹiɝ ɡɑɹnəts ɪn əɹ ɪɹz, ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm nɪɹli dʒɹaʊnɪŋ aʊt ðə jʌŋ wʊmən pleɪɪŋ ðə hæmɝd dʌlsɪmɝ ɑn ðə loʊ plætfɔɹm bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə tɔl stoʊn faɪɝpleɪsəz. ðət lin jʌŋ mæn hæd ɹəfjuz ðə hædɔɹi, əz hæd ɡɔɹnɛlɪn, hu wɑz nɪɹ ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹənz eɪdʒ. ɡɔɹnɛlɪn wɑz bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ hɑɹd wɪð ə pɛɹ ʌv ɑləv-skɪn ɔltɑɹənz, wʌn ə hum hæɾ ə naɪs ɹubi ɪn ɪz lɛft ɪɹ, ən ðəɹ wɑz swɛɾ ɑn ɡɔɹnɛlɪnz fɔɹhɛd. noʊ wʌn ʃaʊɾəd əɾ ə mæn u wɔɹ ðə hædɔɹi ən ə sɔɹd, əz ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən dɪd, ən ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə əvɔɪd meɪkɪŋ ɪm swɛt. sətʃ mɛn kæɹiɾ ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ sʌɾən, ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl vaɪələns. ɪf i hæd sɛldəm bɪn fɔɹs tə juz ðə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz hɪp, ɪt wɑz waɪdli noʊn ðəɾ i kəɾ ən wʊd.

He had been only a toddler when the Trollocs swept down into Malkier, and he had no memories of that land at all - he seldom even thought of Malkier; the land was dead and gone - yet he was glad he had let his uncles give him the hadori. At another table, Managan was in a shouting match with a dark Tairen woman wearing a lace ruff and rather inferior garnets in her ears, the pair of them nearly drowning out the young woman playing the hammered dulcimer on the low platform beside one of the tall stone fireplaces. That lean young man had refused the hadori, as had Gorenellin, who was near Aldragoran's age. Gorenellin was bargaining hard with a pair of olive-skinned Altarans, one of whom had a nice ruby in his left ear, and there was sweat on Gorenellin's forehead. No one shouted at a man who wore the hadori and a sword, as Aldragoran did, and they tried to avoid making him sweat. Such men carried a reputation for sudden, unpredictable violence. If he had seldom been forced to use the sword at his hip, it was widely known that he could and would.

"aɪ də æksɛpt, mæstɝ ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən," dɑmɛntənɪs sɛd, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪz kəmpænjən ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlɛɹ. nɑt noʊɾɪsɪŋ, dʒɹeɪnəoʊz bɛɹɾ ɪz tiθ ɪn wʌɾ i pɹɑbli hoʊpt ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən wəd teɪk fəɹ ə smaɪl. ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən lɛɾ ɪt pæs. hi wɑz ə mɝtʃənt, æftɝ ɔl. ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən wɑz ə faɪn θɪŋ wən ɪɾ ɛnhæns jəɹ bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ paʊɝ, bʌɾ oʊnli ə ful wɛn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ faɪts.

"I do accept, Master Aldragoran," Damentanis said, giving his companion a sidelong glare. Not noticing, Geraneos bared his teeth in what he probably hoped Aldragoran would take for a smile. Aldragoran let it pass. He was a merchant, after all. A reputation was a fine thing when it enhanced your bargaining power, but only a fool went looking for fights.

ði ɪliɑnɝz' klɝk, ə wiɾi, ɡɹeɪɪŋ fɛloʊ ən ɔlsoʊ ɪliɑnɝ, ənlɑk ðɛɹ aɪɝn-stʃɹæp kɔɪn bɑks ʌndɝ ðə wɑtʃfəl aɪz ə ðɛɹ tu bɑɾiɡɑɹdz, bʌlki mɛn wɪð ðoʊz ɑd bɪɹdz ðət lɛf ði ʌpɝ lɪp bɛɹ, ɪn lɛðɝ koʊts soʊn wɪð stil dɪsks. itʃ kæɹiɾ ə sɔɹɾ ən staʊt kʌdʒəl əɾ ɪz bɛlt. ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən hæɾ ə klɝk əɾ ɪz oʊn bæk, ə hɑɹd-aɪd sɑldəiən u dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌn ɛn ʌv ə sɔɹd fɹəm ði ʌðɝ, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ juz bɑɾiɡɑɹdz. ɡɑɹdz ɑn ɪz pɹɛməsəz, tə bi ʃʊɹ, bʌt nɑt bɑɾiɡɑɹdz. ðəɾ oʊnli æɾəd ɪts bɪt tə hɪz ɹɛpjəteɪʃən. ən ə kɔɹs, hi hæd noʊ niɾ ə ðɛm.

The Illianers' clerk, a weedy, graying fellow and also Illianer, unlocked their iron-strapped coin box under the watchful eyes of their two bodyguards, bulky men with those odd beards that left the upper lip bare, in leather coats sewn with steel discs. Each carried a sword and stout cudgel at his belt. Aldragoran had a clerk at his own back, a hard-eyed Saldaean who did not know one end of a sword from the other, but he never used bodyguards. Guards on his premises, to be sure, but not bodyguards. That only added its bit to his reputation. And of course, he had no need of them.

wʌns dɑmɛntənɪs hæɾ ɛndɔɹs tu lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts ən pæst oʊvɝ θɹi lɛðɝ pɝsɪz fæt wɪð ɡoʊld - ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən kaʊntəd ðə kɔɪnz bʌt dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ weɪɪŋ ðɛm; səm ə ðoʊz θɪk kɹaʊnz fɹəm tɛn dɪfɹən lænz wəd bi laɪɾɝ ðən ʌðɝz, jɛɾ i wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə æksɛp ði ɪnɛvəɾəbəl lɔs - ði ɪliɑnɝz kɛɹfəli ɡæðɝɾ ʌp ðə stoʊnz, sɔɹɾɪŋ əm ɪndə wɑʃlðɝ pɝsɪz ðət wɛn ɪndə ðə kɔɪn bɑks. hi ɔfɝɾ əm mɔɹ waɪn, bʌt ðə staʊt mæn dɪklaɪn pəlaɪtli, ən ðeɪ dɪpɑɹɾəd wɪð ðə bɑɾiɡɑɹdz kæɹiɪŋ ði aɪɝn-stʃɹæp bɑks bɪtwin ðɛm. haʊ ðeɪ wɝ tə pɹətɛkt ɛniθɪŋ bɝɾənd soʊ wɑz bɪɑn hɪm. kaɪəkən wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm ə lɔləs taʊn, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ fʊtpædz əbɹɔd ðən juʒəwəl ə leɪt, mɔɹ fʊtpædz, mɔɹ mɝɾɝɝz, mɔɹ ɑɹsənəsts, mɔɹ ʌv ɛvɹi sɔɹɾ ə kɹaɪm, nɑt tə mɛnʃən mædnəs ə ðə sɔɹɾ ə mæn dʒʌs dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk ɑn. stɪl, ðə dʒɛmz wɝ ði ɪliɑnɝz' kənsɝn naʊ.

Once Damentanis had endorsed two letters-of-rights and passed over three leather purses fat with gold - Aldragoran counted the coins but did not bother weighing them; some of those thick crowns from ten different lands would be lighter than others, yet he was willing to accept the inevitable loss - the Illianers carefully gathered up the stones, sorting them into washleather purses that went into the coin box. He offered them more wine, but the stout man declined politely, and they departed with the bodyguards carrying the iron-strapped box between them. How they were to protect anything burdened so was beyond him. Kayacun was far from a lawless town, but there were more footpads abroad than usual of late, more footpads, more murderers, more arsonists, more of every sort of crime, not to mention madness of the sort a man just did not want to think on. Still, the gems were the Illianers' concern now.

ɹʌθən hæɾ ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹənz kɔɪn bɑks oʊpən - ə pɛɹ ə bɛɹɝz wɝ weɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd tə kæɹi ɪt - bʌɾ i sæt stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts ən ðə pɝsɪz. hæf əɡɛn wʌɾ i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə ɡɛt. laɪt kɔɪnz fɹəm ɔltɑɹə ən mʊɹændi əɹ noʊ laɪt kɔɪnz, ət lis hæf əɡɛn. ðɪs wəd bi hɪz moʊs pɹɑfəɾəbəl jɪɹ ɛvɝ. ən ɔl du tə dʒɹeɪnəoʊz lɛɾɪŋ ɪz æŋɡɝ ʃoʊ. dɑmɛntənɪs hæd bɪn əfɹeɪd tə bɑɹɡən fɝðɝ æftɝ ðæt. ə wʌndɝfəl θɪŋ, ɹɛpjəteɪʃən.

Ruthan had Aldragoran's coin box open - a pair of bearers were waiting outside to carry it - but he sat staring at the letters-of-rights and the purses. Half again what he had expected to get. Light coins from Altara and Murandy or no light coins, at least half again. This would be his most profitable year ever. And all due to Geraneos letting his anger show. Damentanis had been afraid to bargain further after that. A wonderful thing, reputation.

"mæstɝ ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən?" ə wʊmən sɛd, linɪŋ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "ju wɝ pɔɪntəɾ aʊt tə mi əz ə mɝtʃənt wɪð ə waɪd kɔɹəspɑndəns baɪ pɪdʒən."

"Master Aldragoran?" a woman said, leaning on the table. "You were pointed out to me as a merchant with a wide correspondence by pigeon."

hi noʊɾəst əɹ dʒuəlɹi fɝst, ʌv kɔɹs, ə mæɾɝ ə hæbət. ðə slɪm ɡoʊldən bɛlt ən lɔŋ nɛkləs wɝ sɛt wɪð vɛɹi ɡʊd ɹubiz, əz wɑz wʌn ə hɝ bɹeɪslɪts, əlɔŋ wɪð səm peɪl ɡɹin ən blu stoʊnz i dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ən soʊ dɪsmɪst əz wɝθləs. ðə ɡoʊldən bɹeɪsləɾ ɑn əɹ lɛft ɹɪst, ən ɑɾ əfɛɹ lɪŋk tə fɔɹ fɪŋɡɝ ɹɪŋz baɪ flæt tʃeɪnz ən ðə hoʊl ɪntʃɹəkətli ɪnɡɹeɪvd, hɛl noʊ stoʊnz, bʌɾ əɹ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ tu bɹeɪslɪts wɝ sɛt wɪð faɪn sæfaɪɝz ən mɔɹ ə ðə ɡɹin stoʊnz. tu ʌv ðə ɹɪŋz ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hæn hɛl ðoʊz ɡɹin stoʊnz, bʌt ði ʌðɝ tu hɛl pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli faɪn sæfaɪɝz. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli faɪn. ðən i ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɔɹ ə fɪfθ ɹɪŋ ɑn ðət hænd, stʌk əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðə ɹɪŋz wɪð ə wɝθləs stoʊn. ə ɡoʊldən sɝpən baɪɾɪŋ ɪts oʊn teɪl.

He noticed her jewelry first, of course, a matter of habit. The slim golden belt and long necklace were set with very good rubies, as was one of her bracelets, along with some pale green and blue stones he did not recognize and so dismissed as worthless. The golden bracelet on her left wrist, an odd affair linked to four finger rings by flat chains and the whole intricately engraved, held no stones, but her remaining two bracelets were set with fine sapphires and more of the green stones. Two of the rings on her right hand held those green stones, but the other two held particularly fine sapphires. Particularly fine. Then he realized she wore a fifth ring on that hand, stuck against one of the rings with a worthless stone. A golden serpent biting its own tail.

hɪz aɪz dʒɝk tə hɝ feɪs, ən i sʌfɝɾ ɪz sɛkənd ʃɑk. hɝ feɪs, fɹeɪm baɪ ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ kloʊk, wɑz vɛɹi jʌŋ, bʌt ʃi wɔɹ ðə ɹɪŋ, ən fju wɝ fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə də ðət wɪθaʊt ðə ɹaɪt. hi hæd sin jʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪfɔɹ, tu əɹ θɹi taɪmz. noʊ, hɝ eɪdʒ dɪd nɑt ʃɑk hɪm. bʌɾ ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛd, ʃi wɔɹ ðə kɪsən, ðə ɹɛd dɑɾ ʌv ə mɛɹid wʊmən. ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk mɔlkɪɹi. ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn mɔlkɪɹi. mɛni jʌŋɡɝ foʊk hæd ði æksɛns ə sɑldɑiə əɹ kændɝ, ɝæfəl əɹ ʃaɪnɝ - hi hɪmsɛlf saʊndəɾ ə sɑldɑiə - bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn ə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ əɾ ɔl. bɪsaɪdz, hi kəd nɑt ɹikɔl ðə læs taɪm i hæd hɝɾ ʌv ə mɔlkɪɹi ɡɝl ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðə taʊɝ hæd feɪl mɔlkiɝ ɪn nid, ən ðə mɔlkɪɹi hæd tɝn ðɛɹ bæks ɑn ðə taʊɝ. stɪl, hi stʊd hɝidli. wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, kɝɾəsi wɑz ɔlweɪz waɪz. hɝ dɑɹk aɪz hɛl hit. jɛs, kɝɾəsi wɑz waɪz.

His eyes jerked to her face, and he suffered his second shock. Her face, framed by the hood of her cloak, was very young, but she wore the ring, and few were foolish enough to do that without the right. He had seen young Aes Sedai before, two or three times. No, her age did not shock him. But on her forehead, she wore the ki'sain, the red dot of a married woman. She did not look Malkieri. She did not sound Malkieri. Many younger folk had the accents of Saldaea or Kandor, Arafel or Shienar - he himself sounded of Saldaea - but she did not sound a Borderlander at all. Besides, he could not recall the last time he had heard of a Malkieri girl going to the White Tower. The Tower had failed Malkier in need, and the Malkieri had turned their backs on the Tower. Still, he stood hurriedly. With Aes Sedai, courtesy was always wise. Her dark eyes held heat. Yes, courtesy was wise.

"haʊ meɪ aɪ hɛlp ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ? jə wɪʃ mi tə sɛn ə mɛsədʒ fəɹ jə vaɪə maɪ pɪdʒənz? ɪɾəl bi maɪ plɛʒɝ." ɪt wɑz ɔlsoʊ waɪz tə ɡɹæn ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛni feɪvɝz ðeɪ æskt, ən ə pɪdʒən wɑz ə smɔl feɪvɝ.

"How may I help you, Aes Sedai? You wish me to send a message for you via my pigeons? It will be my pleasure." It was also wise to grant Aes Sedai any favors they asked, and a pigeon was a small favor.

"ə mɛsədʒ tə itʃ mɝtʃən jə kɔɹəspɑnd wɪð. tɑɹmən ɡdən ɪz kʌmɪŋ sun."

"A message to each merchant you correspond with. Tarmon Gai'don is coming soon."

hi ʃɹʌɡd ənizəli. "ðæɾ ɪz nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪm ə mɝtʃənt." ʃi wɑz æskɪŋ fəɹ ə ɡʊd mɛni pɪdʒənz. hi kɔɹəspɑndɪd wɪð mɝtʃəns əz fɑɹ əweɪ əz ʃaɪnɝ. "bʌɾ əl sɛn jəɹ mɛsədʒ." hi wʊd, tu, haʊɛvɝ mɛni bɝdz ɪt ɹikwaɪɝd. oʊnli stoʊn-blaɪn ɪɾiəts feɪl tə kip pɹɑməsəz tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. bɪsaɪdz wɪtʃ, hi wɑntəd ɹɪɾ ə hɝ ən əɹ tɔk ə ðə læs bæɾəl.

He shrugged uneasily. "That is nothing to do with me, Aes Sedai. I'm a merchant." She was asking for a good many pigeons. He corresponded with merchants as far away as Shienar. "But I will send your message." He would, too, however many birds it required. Only stone-blind idiots failed to keep promises to Aes Sedai. Besides which, he wanted rid of her and her talk of the Last Battle.

"du jə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɪs?" ʃi sɛd, fɪʃɪŋ ə lɛðɝ kɔɹd fɹəm ðə nɛk ə hɝ dʒɹɛs.

"Do you recognize this?" she said, fishing a leather cord from the neck of her dress.

hɪz bɹɛθ kɑt, ən i stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ə hænd, bɹʌʃt ə fɪŋɡɝ əkɹɔs ðə hɛvi ɡoʊl sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ ɑn ðə kɔɹd. əkɹɔs ðə kɹeɪn ɪn flaɪt. haʊ hæd ʃi kʌm baɪ ðɪs? ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, haʊ? "aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪt," hi toʊl hɝ, hɪz vɔɪs sʌɾənli hɔɹs.

His breath caught, and he stretched out a hand, brushed a finger across the heavy gold signet ring on the cord. Across the crane in flight. How had she come by this? Under the Light, how? "I recognize it," he told her, his voice suddenly hoarse.

"maɪ neɪm ɪz nɪneɪiv ti ɑlmɹə mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən. ðə mɛsədʒ aɪ wɑn sɛn ɪz ðɪs. maɪ hʌzbən ɹaɪdz fɹəm wɝlz ɛn təwɔɹd tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp, təwɔɹd tɑɹmən ɡdən. wɪl i ɹaɪɾ əloʊn?"

"My name is Nynaeve ti al'Meara Mandragoran. The message I want sent is this. My husband rides from World's End toward Tarwin's Gap, toward Tarmon Gai'don. Will he ride alone?"

hi tʃɹɛmbəld. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ i wɑz læfɪŋ əɹ kɹaɪɪŋ. pɝhæps boʊθ. ʃi wɑz ɪz waɪf? "aɪ wɪl sɛn jəɹ mɛsədʒ, maɪ leɪɾi, bʌɾ ɪts nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð mi. aɪm ə mɝtʃənt. mɔlkiɝ ɪz dɛd. dɛd, aɪ tɛl ju."

He trembled. He did not know whether he was laughing or crying. Perhaps both. She was his wife? "I will send your message, my Lady, but it has nothing to do with me. I am a merchant. Malkier is dead. Dead, I tell you."

ðə hiɾ ɪn əɹ aɪz sim tə ɪntɛnsəfaɪ, ən ʃi ɡɹɪpt əɹ lɔŋ, θɪk bɹeɪd wɪð wʌn hænd. "læn toʊl mi wʌns ðət mɔlkiɝ laɪvz soʊ lɔŋ əz wʌn mæn wɛɹz ðə hædɔɹi ɪn plɛdʒ ðət hɪl faɪt ðə ʃædoʊ, soʊ lɔŋ əz wʌn wʊmən wɛɹz ðə kɪsən ɪn plɛdʒ ðət ʃɪl sɛn əɹ sʌnz tə faɪt ðə ʃædoʊ. aɪ wɛɹ ðə kɪsən, mæstɝ ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən. maɪ hʌzbənd wɛɹz ðə hædɔɹi. soʊ də ju. wɪl læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən ɹaɪd tə ðə læs bæɾəl əloʊn?"

The heat in her eyes seemed to intensify, and she gripped her long, thick braid with one hand. "Lan told me once that Malkier lives so long as one man wears the hadori in pledge that he will fight the Shadow, so long as one woman wears the ki'sain in pledge that she will send her sons to fight the Shadow. I wear the ki'sain, Master Aldragoran. My husband wears the hadori. So do you. Will Lan Mandragoran ride to the Last Battle alone?"

hi wɑz læfɪŋ, ʃeɪkɪŋ wɪð ɪt. ən jɛt, hi kəd fil tɪɹz ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn ɪz tʃiks. ɪt wɑz mædnəs! kəmplit mædnəs! bʌɾ i kəd nɑt hɛlp hɪmsɛlf. "hi wɪl nɑt, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪ kænɑt stænd ʃʊɹəɾi fəɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls, bʌɾ aɪ swɛɹ tə jə ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ maɪ hoʊp ə ɹibɝθ ən sælveɪʃən, hɪl nɑt ɹaɪɾ əloʊn." fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi stʌɾid ɪz feɪs, ðən nɑɾəd wʌns fɝmli ən tɝn əweɪ. hi flʌŋ aʊɾ ə hæn æftɝ hɝ. "meɪ aɪ ɔfɝ jə waɪn, maɪ leɪɾi? maɪ waɪf wɪl wɑnə mit ju." ɑliɾə wɑz sɑldəiən, bʌt ʃi dɛfənətli wəd wɑnə mit ðə waɪf ə ði ʌnkɹoʊn kɪŋ.

He was laughing, shaking with it. And yet, he could feel tears rolling down his cheeks. It was madness! Complete madness! But he could not help himself. "He will not, my Lady. I cannot stand surety for anyone else, but I swear to you under the Light and by my hope of rebirth and salvation, he will not ride alone." For a moment, she studied his face, then nodded once firmly and turned away. He flung out a hand after her. "May I offer you wine, my Lady? My wife will want to meet you." Alida was Saldaean, but she definitely would want to meet the wife of the Uncrowned King.

"θæŋk ju, mæstɝ ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən, bʌɾ aɪ hæv sɛvɹəl mɔɹ taʊnz tə vɪzət tədeɪ, ən aɪ mʌs bi bæk ɪn tɛɹ tənaɪt."

"Thank you, Master Aldragoran, but I have several more towns to visit today, and I must be back in Tear tonight."

hi blɪŋkt əɾ əɹ bæk əz ʃi ɡlaɪɾɪd təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ kloʊk. ʃi hæd sɛvɹəl mɔɹ taʊnz tə vɪzət tədeɪ, ən ʃi hæd tə bi bæk ɪn tɛɹ tənaɪt? tʃɹuli, ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ keɪpəbəl ə mɑɹvəlz!

He blinked at her back as she glided toward the door gathering her cloak. She had several more towns to visit today, and she had to be back in Tear tonight? Truly, Aes Sedai were capable of marvels!

saɪləns hʌŋ ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum. ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn kipɪŋ ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz loʊ, ən ivən ðə ɡɝl wɪð ðə dʌlsɪmɝ hæd sis plaɪɪŋ əɹ hæmɝz. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm. moʊst ə ði aʊtləndɝz hæd ðɛɹ maʊðz hæŋɪŋ oʊpən.

Silence hung in the common room. They had not been keeping their voices low, and even the girl with the dulcimer had ceased plying her hammers. Everyone was staring at him. Most of the outlanders had their mouths hanging open.

"wɛl, mænəɡæn, ɡɔɹnɛlɪn," hi dɪmændəd, "du jə stɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ u jə ɑɹ? dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ jəɹ blʌd? hu ɹaɪdz wɪð mi fəɹ tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp?"

"Well, Managan, Gorenellin," he demanded, "do you still remember who you are? Do you remember your blood? Who rides with me for Tarwin's Gap?"

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi θɔt niðɝ mæn wəd spik, bʌt ðən ɡɔɹnɛlɪn wɑz ɑn ɪz fit, tɪɹz ɡlɪsnɪŋ ɪz aɪz. "ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn flaɪz fəɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən," hi sɛd sɔfli.

For a moment, he thought neither man would speak, but then Gorenellin was on his feet, tears glistening his eyes. "The Golden Crane flies for Tarmon Gai'don," he said softly.

"ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn flaɪz fəɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən!" mænəɡæn ʃaʊɾəd, lipɪŋ ʌp soʊ fæst i oʊvɝtɝn ɪz tʃɛɹ.

"The Golden Crane flies for Tarmon Gai'don!" Managan shouted, leaping up so fast he overturned his chair.

læfɪŋ, ɔlʒɹɑɡɔɹən dʒɔɪn ðɛm, ɔl θɹi ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət ðə tɑp ə ðɛɹ lʌŋz. "ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn flaɪz fəɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən!"

Laughing, Aldragoran joined them, all three shouting at the top of their lungs. "The Golden Crane flies for Tarmon Gai'don!"

tʃæptɝ twɛntiwʌn

CHAPTER 21

wɪðɪn ðə stoʊn ðə mʌɾ ə ði aʊɾɝ sɪɾi ɡeɪv weɪ tə peɪv stʃɹits ət ðə wɔlz ə tiɹ, wɛɹ ðə fɝs θɪŋ ɹænd noʊɾəst wɑz ði æbsəns ʌv ɡɑɹdz. dɪspaɪt ðə lɔfti stoʊn ɹæmpɑɹts wɪð ðɛɹ taʊɝz, ðə sɪɾi wɑz lɛs dɪfɛndəd ðən stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ, wɛɹ i ən ɛvɹi ʌðɝ hjumən hæd bɪn dʒɛnli bʌt fɝmli ɹəfjuzd ɛntʃɹəns ət fɝs laɪt. hɪɹ, ði ɑɹtʃɝz' bælkəniz ɑn ðə taʊɝz wɝ ɛmpti. ði aɪɝn-stʃɹæp dɔɹ ə ðə skwɑt ɡɹeɪ ɡɑɹdhaʊs dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə bɹɔd ɡeɪts stʊd waɪɾ oʊpən, ən ə hɑɹd-feɪst wʊmən ɪn ɹʌf wʊlənz, hɝ slivz ʃʌvd ʌp əɹ θɪn ɑɹmz, sæt ðəɹ əɾ ə wʊɾən tʌb skɹʌbɪŋ kloʊðz wɪð ə wɑʃbɔɹd. ʃi əpɪɹd tə hæv teɪkən ʌp ɹɛzəɾəns; tu smɔl, ɡɹʌbi tʃɪlʒɹən sʌkɪŋ ðɛɹ θʌmz stɛɹd waɪd-aɪd pæst əɹ əɾ ɪm ən ɪz kəmpænjənz. ət ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ət list.

Within the Stone The mud of the outer city gave way to paved streets at the walls of Tear, where the first thing Rand noticed was the absence of guards. Despite the lofty stone ramparts with their towers, the city was less defended than Stedding Shangtai, where he and every other human had been gently but firmly refused entrance at first light. Here, the archers' balconies on the towers were empty. The iron-strapped door of the squat gray guardhouse just inside the broad gates stood wide open, and a hard-faced woman in rough woolens, her sleeves shoved up her thin arms, sat there at a wooden tub scrubbing clothes with a washboard. She appeared to have taken up residence; two small, grubby children sucking their thumbs stared wide-eyed past her at him and his companions. At their horses, at least.

teɪdeɪʃɝ wɑz ə saɪt tə stɛɹ æt, ə slik blæk stæljən wɪð ə mæsɪv tʃɛst, ə hɔɹs ðət dʒɹu ətɛnʃən, jɛɾ i hæd tʃoʊzən tə ɹaɪd ði ænəməl ɛniweɪ. ɪf ðə fɔɹseɪkən kəd faɪn ɪm əz izəli əz ðeɪ hæɾ əɾ ælɡɝɪnz mænɝ haʊs, ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl pɔɪn tə haɪɾɪŋ. əɹ ət lis tə pʊɾɪŋ tu mʌtʃ ɛfɝɾ ɪndə ɪt. hi wɔɹ blæk ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz tə kənsil ðə dʒɹæɡənz' hɛdz ɑn ɪz hænz ən ðə hɛɹənz bɹændɪɾ ɪndə hɪz pɑmz. hɪz koʊt wɑz dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ wʊl wɪθaʊɾ ə stɪtʃ ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, ðə stæljənz sæɾəl klɔθ sɪmpəl, ən ɪz sɔɹdz hɪlt ən skæbɝd hæd bɪn kʌvɝɾ ɪn ənwɝk bɔɹhaɪɾ ɛvɝ sɪns ɪt keɪm ɪndə hɪz pəzɛʃən, nʌθɪŋ tə pʊl ə sɛkənd ɡlæns. kædzueɪn, ɪn ʌnədɔɹnd ɡɹeɪ wʊl, wɔɹ ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ dɑɹk ɡɹin kloʊk wɛl ʌp tə ʃild əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs, bʌt mɪn, nɪneɪiv ən əliviə hæd noʊ nid fəɹ haɪɾɪŋ. ðoʊ mɪnz flaʊɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɹɛd koʊɾ ən snʌɡ bɹitʃɪz maɪɾ ətʃɹækt ə lɪɾəl noʊɾəs, nɑt tə mɛnʃən əɹ hild ɹɛd buts. hi hæd sin wɪmən ɪn kɛɹhin wɛɹɪŋ kloʊðz laɪk ðæt, kɑpiɪŋ hɝ, jɛɾ ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ðəɾ əɹ fæʃən hæd spɹɛd tə tɛɹ, wɛɹ mɑɾəsti hɛl sweɪ. ɪn pʌblɪk, ət list. nɪneɪiv wɑz wɛɹɪŋ jɛloʊ-slæʃt blu sɪlk ən ɔl ə hɝ dʒuəlɹi, dʒʌs pɑɹtli kənsil baɪ hɝ blu kloʊk, bʌt tiɹ wəd bi fʊl ə sɪlks. ʃi hæd wɑntəd tə wɛɹ əɹ ʃɔl! ðət wɑz ɪn əɹ sæɾəlbæɡz, ðoʊ. ə lɪɾəl ɛfɝɾ oʊnli.

Tai'daishar was a sight to stare at, a sleek black stallion with a massive chest, a horse that drew attention, yet he had chosen to ride the animal anyway. If the Forsaken could find him as easily as they had at Algarin's manor house, there was little point to hiding. Or at least to putting too much effort into it. He wore black riding gloves to conceal the dragons' heads on his hands and the herons branded into his palms. His coat was dark gray wool without a stitch of embroidery, the stallion's saddle cloth simple, and his sword's hilt and scabbard had been covered in unworked boarhide ever since it came into his possession, nothing to pull a second glance. Cadsuane, in unadorned gray wool, wore the hood of her dark green cloak well up to shield her Aes Sedai face, but Min, Nynaeve and Alivia had no need for hiding. Though Min's flower-embroidered red coat and snug breeches might attract a little notice, not to mention her heeled red boots. He had seen women in Cairhien wearing clothes like that, copying her, yet it seemed unlikely that her fashion had spread to Tear, where modesty held sway. In public, at least. Nynaeve was wearing yellow-slashed blue silk and all of her jewelry, just partly concealed by her blue cloak, but Tear would be full of silks. She had wanted to wear her shawl! That was in her saddlebags, though. A little effort only.

ðə sɛkən θɪŋ i noʊɾəst wɑz ðə saʊnd, ə ɹɪðmɪk ɹækəɾɪŋ klæɾɝ əkʌmpənid piɹiɑɾɪkəli baɪ ə pɪɹsɪŋ wɪsəl. feɪn ət fɝst, ɪt sim tə bi kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ ɹæpədli. dɪspaɪt ði ɝli aʊɝ, ðə stʃɹits i kəd si fɹəm ðə ɡeɪts wɝ kɹaʊɾəd. hæf ðə pipəl ɪn saɪɾ əpɪɹd tə bi si foʊk, ðə mɛn bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd, ðə wɪmən ɪn bɹaɪt lɪnən blaʊsəz, ɔl wɛɹɪŋ lɔŋ sæʃɪz mɔɹ kʌlɝfəl ðən ðoʊz wɔɹn baɪ tɛɹən kɑmənɝz. ɛvɹi hɛɾ əpɪɹd tə bi tɝn təwɔɹd ðət saʊnd. tʃɪlʒɹən dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ðə θɹɔŋ, dɑdʒɪŋ kɑɹts moʊst ɔfən pʊl baɪ ɑksən wɪð waɪd hɔɹnz, ɹeɪsɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə nɔɪz. sɛvɹəl wɛl-dʒɹɛs mɛn ən wɪmən hæd dɪsmaʊntɪd fɹəm ðɛɹ sɪdæn tʃɛɹz ən stʊd wɪð ðə bɛɹɝz tə wɑtʃ. ə fɔɹk-bɪɹɾəd mɝtʃənt wɪð sɪlvɝ tʃeɪnz əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst ə hɪz koʊt wɑz hæf aʊɾ ə ðə wɪndoʊ ʌv ə ɹɛd-lækɝd koʊtʃ, ʃaʊɾɪŋ əɾ ɪz dʒɹaɪvɝ tə mænədʒ ðə nɝvəsli dænsɪŋ tim waɪl i stʃɹeɪn fəɹ ə bɛɾɝ vju.

The second thing he noticed was the sound, a rhythmic racketing clatter accompanied periodically by a piercing whistle. Faint at first, it seemed to be coming closer rapidly. Despite the early hour, the streets he could see from the gates were crowded. Half the people in sight appeared to be Sea Folk, the men bare-chested, the women in bright linen blouses, all wearing long sashes more colorful than those worn by Tairen commoners. Every head appeared to be turned toward that sound. Children darted through the throng, dodging carts most often pulled by oxen with wide horns, racing toward the noise. Several well-dressed men and women had dismounted from their sedan chairs and stood with the bearers to watch. A fork-bearded merchant with silver chains across the chest of his coat was half out of the window of a red-lacquered coach, shouting at his driver to manage the nervously dancing team while he strained for a better view.

waɪt-wɪŋ pɪdʒənz, stɑɹɾəld fɹəm pɔɪntəd sleɪt ɹuftɑps baɪ ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ʃɑɹp wɪsəl, sʌɾənli wild ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ən tu lɑɹdʒ flɑks kɹæʃt ɪndə itʃ ʌðɝ, pɛltɪŋ ðə foʊk bɪloʊ wɪð stʌn bɝdz. ɛvɹi sɪŋɡəl bɝd fɛl. ə fju pipəl æktʃəli  stɑp stɛɹɪŋ təwɔɹd ði əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ nɔɪz ən ɡeɪpt ət ðə skaɪ. ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ nʌmbɝ snætʃt ʌp fɔlən bɝdz ən ɹʌŋ ðɛɹ nɛks, ðoʊ, ən nɑt dʒʌs bɛɹfʊt pipəl ɪn wɔɹn wʊlənz. ə wʊmən ɪn sɪlk ən leɪs, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə sɪdæn tʃɛɹz, kwɪkli ɡæðɝd hæf ə dʌzən bɪfɔɹ ɡeɪzɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə nɔɪz wɪð ðə bɝdz dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm əɹ hænz baɪ ðɛɹ fit.

White-winged pigeons, startled from pointed slate rooftops by a particularly sharp whistle, suddenly wheeled into the air. And two large flocks crashed into each other, pelting the folk below with stunned birds. Every single bird fell. A few people actually stopped staring toward the approaching noise and gaped at the sky. A surprising number snatched up fallen birds and wrung their necks, though, and not just barefoot people in worn woolens. A woman in silk and lace, standing beside one of the sedan chairs, quickly gathered half a dozen before gazing toward the noise with the birds dangling from her hands by their feet.

əliviə meɪɾ ə stɑɹɾəld saʊnd. "ɪz ðəɾ ɪl lʌk əɹ ɡʊd?" ʃi dʒɹɔld. "ɪt mʌs bi ɪl. ənlɛs pɪdʒənz hɪɹ ɑɹ dɪfɹənt?" nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv əɹ ə saʊɝ lʊk, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ʃi hæd bɪn vɛɹi kwaɪət sɪns læn vænɪʃt ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ, ə sʌbʒɪkt ɑn wɪtʃ ʃi wɑz dʌbli saɪlənt.

Alivia made a startled sound. "Is that ill luck or good?" she drawled. "It must be ill. Unless pigeons here are different?" Nynaeve gave her a sour look, but said nothing. She had been very quiet since Lan vanished the day before, a subject on which she was doubly silent.

"sʌm ə ðoʊz pipəl ɑɹ gɑnə daɪ ʌv hʌŋɡɝ," mɪn sɛd sædli. ðə bɑn kwɪvɝd wɪð sɑɹoʊ. "ɛvɹi læst wʌn aɪ kən si sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt."

"Some of those people are going to die of hunger," Min said sadly. The bond quivered with sorrow. "Every last one I can see something about."

haʊ kən aɪ haɪd? luz θɝɪn læft. aɪm tɑvɝən!

How can I hide? Lews Therin laughed. I am ta'veren!

jəɹ dɛd, ɹænd θɔɾ əɾ ɪm ʃɑɹpli. pipəl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə stɑɹv, ən i læft? ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn, ʌv kɔɹs, nɑt wən mɪn spoʊk, bʌt læfɪŋ wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. aɪm tɑvɝən. mi!

You're dead, Rand thought at him sharply. People in front of him were going to starve, and he laughed? There was nothing to be done, of course, not when Min spoke, but laughing was another matter. I am ta'veren. Me!

wʌɾ ɛls wɑz hæpənɪŋ ɪn tiɹ kəz ə hɪz pɹɛzəns? hɪz biɪŋ tɑvɝən dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz əv ɛni ɪfɛkt əɾ ɔl, bʌt wən ɪt dɪd, ðə ɹɪzʌl kəd blæŋkəɾ ən ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi. bɛs tə ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð wʌɾ i hæd kʌm fəɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹɔŋ pipəl fɪɡjɝɾ aʊt wʌt θɪŋz laɪk pɪdʒənz flaɪɪŋ ɪndə wʌn ənʌðɝ mɛnt. ɪf ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɝ sɛndɪŋ ɑɹmiz ə tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl æftɝ hɪm, ɪt wɑz laɪkli ðət dɑɹkfɹɛnz wəd teɪk ɛni ɑpɝtunəɾi tə pʊɾ ən æɹoʊ θɹu hɪz ɹɪbz. meɪkɪŋ lɪɾəl ɛfɝt tə haɪd wɑz nɑt ðə seɪm əz meɪkɪŋ noʊ ɛfɝt.

What else was happening in Tear because of his presence? His being ta'veren did not always have any effect at all, but when it did, the result could blanket an entire city. Best to get on with what he had come for before the wrong people figured out what things like pigeons flying into one another meant. If the Forsaken were sending armies of Trollocs and Myrddraal after him, it was likely that Darkfriends would take any opportunity to put an arrow through his ribs. Making little effort to hide was not the same as making no effort.

"ju maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɹɔt ðə bænɝ ə laɪɾ ən ən ɑnɝ ɡɑɹɾ ə θaʊzənz ɪnstɛɾ ə sɪks," kædzueɪn mɝmɝd dʒɹaɪli, aɪɪŋ ðə meɪɾənz u wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹitɛn ðeɪ hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɹændz pɑɹɾi waɪl stændɪŋ ɪn ə waɪd sɝkəl ɝaʊn ɪt, ʃoʊufə kʌvɝɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz ən veɪlz hæŋɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts. tu wɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ, fɪɹs-aɪd wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ lʊkt ət hɪm. ðə meɪɾənz' spɪɹz wɝ ɔl ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, stʌk θɹu ðə hɑɹnəs ə ðɛɹ boʊkeɪsɪz, bʌɾ oʊnli kəz ɹænd hæɾ ɔfɝd tə liv əm bɪhaɪn ən teɪk sʌmwʌn ɛls ʌðɝwaɪz. nændɛɹə hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ət list ə fju meɪɾənz, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɪð aɪz əz hɑɹɾ əz ɛmɹəlz. hi hæd nɛvɝ kənsɪɾɝd ɹəfjuzɪŋ. ði oʊnli tʃaɪld ʌv ə meɪɾən ɛni meɪɾən hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn, hi hæɾ ɑbləɡeɪʃənz tə mit.

"You might as well have brought the Banner of Light and an honor guard of thousands instead of six," Cadsuane murmured dryly, eyeing the Maidens who were trying to pretend they had nothing to do with Rand's party while standing in a wide circle around it, shoufa covering their heads and veils hanging down their chests. Two were Shaido, fierce-eyed whenever they looked at him. The Maidens' spears were all on their backs, stuck through the harness of their bowcases, but only because Rand had offered to leave them behind and take someone else otherwise. Nandera had insisted on at least a few Maidens, staring at him with eyes as hard as emeralds. He had never considered refusing. The only child of a Maiden any Maiden had ever known, he had obligations to meet.

hi ɡæðɝd teɪdeɪʃɝz ɹeɪnz, ən əbɹʌpli ə lɑɹdʒ wæɡən fʊl ə məʃinɝi keɪm ɪndə saɪt, klæŋkɪŋ ən hɪsɪŋ, waɪɾ aɪɝn-stʌɾɪd wilz stʃɹaɪkɪŋ spɑɹks fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪ peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz əz ɪt muvd əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹiɾ əz fæst əz ə mæn kəd tʃɹɑt. ðə məʃinɝi sim tə swɛt stim; ə hɛvi wʊɾən ʃæf swʌŋ ʌp ən daʊn pʊʃɪŋ ənʌðɝ, vɝɾɪkəl ʃæft, ən ɡɹeɪ wʊdzmoʊk dʒɹɪftəd fɹəm ə mɛɾəl tʃɪmni; bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ʌv ə hɔɹs, dʒʌst ən ɑd sɔɹɾ ə tɪlɝ ɪn ðə fɹʌn tə tɝn ðə wilz. wʌn ə ðə θɹi mɛn stændɪŋ ɪn ðə wæɡən pʊld ə lɔŋ kɔɹd, ən stim ɹʌʃt ɪn ə ʃɹɪl wɪsəl aʊɾ ʌv ə tub ətɑp ə hjudʒ aɪɝn sɪləndɝ. ɪf ði ɔnlʊkɝz stɛɹɾ ɪn ɑ ən meɪbi kʌvɝd ðɛɹ ɪɹz, ðə fɔɹk-bɪɹɾəd mɝtʃəns tim wɑz ɪn noʊ sətʃ mud. wɪniɪŋ waɪldli, ðeɪ boʊltəd, skæɾɝɪŋ pipəl əz ðeɪ ɹæn ən nɪɹli pɪtʃɪŋ ðə mæn aʊɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd. kɝsɪz pɝsud ðɛm, ən sɛvɹəl bɹeɪɪŋ mjulz ðət ɡæləpt ɔf wɪð ðɛɹ dʒɹaɪvɝz ɪn baʊnsɪŋ kɑɹts sɔɪŋ ət ðə ɹeɪnz. ivən ə fju ɑksən bɪɡæn tə lʌmbɝ əlɔŋ mɔɹ kwɪkli. mɪnz əstɑnɪʃmən fɪl ðə bɑnd.

He gathered Tai'daishar's reins, and abruptly a large wagon full of machinery came into sight, clanking and hissing, wide iron-studded wheels striking sparks from the gray paving stones as it moved along the street as fast as a man could trot. The machinery seemed to sweat steam; a heavy wooden shaft swung up and down pushing another, vertical shaft, and gray woodsmoke drifted from a metal chimney; but there was no sign of a horse, just an odd sort of tiller in the front to turn the wheels. One of the three men standing in the wagon pulled a long cord, and steam rushed in a shrill whistle out of a tube atop a huge iron cylinder. If the onlookers stared in awe and maybe covered their ears, the fork-bearded merchant's team was in no such mood. Whinnying wildly, they bolted, scattering people as they ran and nearly pitching the man out on his head. Curses pursued them, and several braying mules that galloped off with their drivers in bouncing carts sawing at the reins. Even a few oxen began to lumber along more quickly. Min's astonishment filled the bond.

kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ðə blæk wɪð ɪz niz - tʃɹeɪn əz ə wɔɹhɔɹs, teɪdeɪʃɝ ɹɪspɑndɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli, ðoʊ hi stɪl snɔɹɾɪd - ɹænd stɛɹɾ ɪn əmeɪzmənt, tu. ɪt simd mæstɝ poʊəl æktʃəli  hæd meɪɾ ɪz stimwæɡən wɝk. "bʌt haʊ dɪd ðə θɪŋ ɡɛt tə tɛɹ?" hi æsk ði ɛɹ. ðə læst i hæd sin, ɪt hæd bɪn ət ði əkæɾəmi ʌv kɛɹhin, ən sizɪŋ ʌp ɛvɹi fju peɪsɪz.

Controlling the black with his knees - trained as a warhorse, Tai'daishar responded immediately, though he still snorted - Rand stared in amazement, too. It seemed Master Poel actually had made his steamwagon work. "But how did the thing get to Tear?" he asked the air. The last he had seen, it had been at the Academy of Cairhien, and seizing up every few paces.

"ɪts kɔld ə stieɪmhɔɹs, maɪ lɔɹd," ə bɛɹfʊt, dɝɾi-feɪst ɝtʃən ɪn ə ɹæɡəd ʃɝt sɛd, baʊnsɪŋ ɑn ðə peɪvmənt. ivən ðə sæʃ hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ɪz bæɡi bɹitʃɪz simd əz mʌtʃ hoʊlz əz klɔθ. "aɪv sin ɪt naɪn taɪmz! kɑm hɪɹz oʊnli sin ɪt sɛvən."

"It's called a steamhorse, my Lord," a barefoot, dirty-faced urchin in a ragged shirt said, bouncing on the pavement. Even the sash holding up his baggy breeches seemed as much holes as cloth. "I've seen it nine times! Com here's only seen it seven."

"ə stimwæɡən, doʊni," hɪz ikwəli ɹæɡəd kəmpænjən pʊɾ ɪn. "ə stim-wæɡən." niðɝ ə ðɛm cʊɾə bɪn mɔɹ ðən tɛn, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn ɹæðɝ ðən skɪni. ðɛɹ mʌɾi fit, tɔɹn ʃɝts ən hoʊl bɹitʃɪz mɛn ðeɪ keɪm fɹəm aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz, wɛɹ ðə pʊɹɪs foʊk lɪvd. ɹænd hæd tʃeɪnʒd ə nʌmbɝ ə lɔz ɪn tɛɹ, ɪspɛʃli ðoʊz ðət weɪd hɛvəli ɑn ðə pʊɹ, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn əneɪbəl tə tʃeɪnʒ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. hi hæd nɑɾ ivən noʊn haʊ tə bɪɡɪn. luz θɝɪn bɪɡæn tə mɔndɝ ɑn əbaʊt tæksəz ən mʌni kɹieɪɾɪŋ dʒɑbz, bʌɾ i maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn spɪlɪŋ aʊt wɝdz ət ɹændəm fəɹ ɔl ðə sɛns i meɪd. ɹænd mjuɾɪd ðə vɔɪs tə ə bʌz, ə flaɪ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ʌv ə ɹum.

"A steamwagon, Doni," his equally ragged companion put in. "A steam-wagon." Neither of them could have been more than ten, and they were gaunt rather than skinny. Their muddy feet, torn shirts and holed breeches meant they came from outside the walls, where the poorest folk lived. Rand had changed a number of laws in Tear, especially those that weighed heavily on the poor, but he had been unable to change everything. He had not even known how to begin. Lews Therin began to maunder on about taxes and money creating jobs, but he might as well have been spilling out words at random for all the sense he made. Rand muted the voice to a buzz, a fly on the other side of a room.

"fɔɹ ə ðɛm hɪtʃt təɡɛðɝ, wʌn bɪhaɪn ði ʌðɝ, pʊld ə hʌnʒɹəd wæɡənz ɔl ðə weɪ fɹəm kɛɹhin," doʊni wɛn ɑn, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ði ʌðɝ bɔɪ. "ðeɪ kʌvɝd nɪɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz ɛvɹi deɪ, maɪ lɔɹd. ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz!"

"Four of them hitched together, one behind the other, pulled a hundred wagons all the way from Cairhien," Doni went on, ignoring the other boy. "They covered near a hundred miles every day, my Lord. A hundred miles!"

kɑm saɪd hɛvəli. "ðɛɹ wɝ sɪks ə ðɛm, doʊni, ən ðeɪ oʊnli pʊl fɪfti wæɡənz, bʌt ðeɪ kʌvɝd mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz ɛvɹi deɪ. ə hʌnʒɹəd ən twɛnti səm deɪz, aɪ hɝd, ən ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə stim-mɛn sɛɾ ɪt." doʊni tɝn tə skaʊl ət hɪm, ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm bɔlɪŋ ʌp fɪsts.

Com sighed heavily. "There were six of them, Doni, and they only pulled fifty wagons, but they covered more than a hundred miles every day. A hundred and twenty some days, I heard, and it was one of the steam-men said it." Doni turned to scowl at him, the pair of them balling up fists.

"iðɝ weɪ, ɪts ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl ətʃivmənt," ɹænd toʊld əm kwɪkli, bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd bɪɡɪn tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ bloʊz. "hɪɹ."

"Either way, it's a remarkable achievement," Rand told them quickly, before they could begin trading blows. "Here."

dɪpɪŋ ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkət, hi pʊld aʊt tu kɔɪnz ən tɔst wʌn təwɔɹɾ itʃ bɔɪ wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ tə si wʌt ðeɪ wɝ. ɡoʊld ɡlɪɾɝd ɪn ði ɛɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə bɔɪz iɡɝli snætʃt ðə kɔɪnz. ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ stɑɹɾəld ɡlænsɪz, ðeɪ wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ aʊt θɹu ðə ɡeɪts əz fæst əz ðeɪ kəd ɡoʊ, noʊ daʊt fɪɹfəl i wəd dɪmæn ðə kɔɪnz bæk. ðɛɹ fæmliz kəd lɪv fəɹ mʌnθs ɑn ðət mʌtʃ ɡoʊld.

Dipping into his coat pocket, he pulled out two coins and tossed one toward each boy without looking to see what they were. Gold glittered in the air before the boys eagerly snatched the coins. Exchanging startled glances, they went running out through the gates as fast as they could go, no doubt fearful he would demand the coins back. Their families could live for months on that much gold.

mɪn ɡeɪzd æftɝ əm wɪð ən ɪkspɹɛʃən ə mɪzɝi ðət ðə bɑn ɛkoʊɾ ivən æftɝ ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən smuðd əɹ feɪs. wʌt hæd ʃi sin? dɛθ, pɹɑbli. ɹænd fɛlt æŋɡɝ, bʌt noʊ sɑɹoʊ. haʊ mɛni tɛnz ə θaʊzənz wəd daɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz dʌn? haʊ mɛni wəd bi tʃɪlʒɹən? hi hæd noʊ ɹum lɛft ɪn ɪm fəɹ sɑɹoʊ.

Min gazed after them with an expression of misery that the bond echoed even after she shook her head and smoothed her face. What had she seen? Death, probably. Rand felt anger, but no sorrow. How many tens of thousands would die before the Last Battle was done? How many would be children? He had no room left in him for sorrow.

"vɛɹi dʒɛnɝəs," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs, "bʌɾ ɑɹ wi gɑnə stæn hɪɹ ɔl mɔɹnɪŋ?" ðə stimwæɡən wɑz muvɪŋ ɑn aʊɾ ə saɪt kwɪkli, jɛɾ əɹ plʌmp bɹaʊn mɛɹ wɑz stɪl bloʊɪŋ æŋkʃəsli ən tɔsɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ən ʃi wɑz hævɪŋ dɪfəkəlti wɪð ði ænəməl, plæsəɾ əz ɪt wɑz baɪ neɪtʃɝ. ʃi wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm əz ɡʊɾ ə ɹaɪɾɝ əz ʃi θɔt hɝsɛlf. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, mɪnz maʊnt, ən ɑɹtʃ-nɛkt ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ fɹəm ælɡɝɪnz steɪbəlz, dænst soʊ ðəɾ oʊnli mɪnz fɝm, ɹɛd-ɡlʌvd ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz kɛpt əɹ fɹəm ɹʌnɪŋ, ən əliviəz ɹoʊn wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dæns, ðoʊ ðə fɔɹmɝ deɪmeɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ði ænəməl əz izəli əz kædzueɪn dɪɾ əɹ beɪ. əliviə səmtaɪmz dɪspleɪd sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ tæləns. deɪmeɪn wɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə ɹaɪd wɛl.

"Very generous," Nynaeve said in a tight voice, "but are we going to stand here all morning?" The steamwagon was moving on out of sight quickly, yet her plump brown mare was still blowing anxiously and tossing her head, and she was having difficulty with the animal, placid as it was by nature. She was far from as good a rider as she thought herself. For that matter, Min's mount, an arch-necked gray mare from Algarin's stables, danced so that only Min's firm, red-gloved grip on the reins kept her from running, and Alivia's roan was trying to dance, though the former damane controlled the animal as easily as Cadsuane did her bay. Alivia sometimes displayed surprising talents. Damane were expected to ride well.

əz ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, ɹænd tʊk ə læst ɡlæns ət ðə dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ stimwæɡən. ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl wɑz hɑɹdli ðə wɝd. ə hʌnʒɹəd wæɡənz əɹ oʊnli fɪfti - oʊnli! - ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl wɑz mɔɹ laɪk ɪt. wəd mɝtʃəns stɑɹt juzɪŋ ðoʊz θɪŋz ɪnstɛɾ ə hɔɹsəz? ɪt hɑɹdli sim laɪkli. mɝtʃəns wɝ kənsɝvəɾɪv foʊk, nɑt noʊn fəɹ lipɪŋ ət nu weɪz ə duɪŋ θɪŋz. fəɹ səm ɹizən, luz θɝɪn bɪɡæn læfɪŋ əɡɛn.

As they rode into the city, Rand took a last glance at the disappearing steamwagon. Remarkable was hardly the word. A hundred wagons or only fifty - only! - incredible was more like it. Would merchants start using those things instead of horses? It hardly seemed likely. Merchants were conservative folk, not known for leaping at new ways of doing things. For some reason, Lews Therin began laughing again.

tiɹ wɑz nɑt bjuɾəfəl, laɪk keɪɛmlɪn əɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən fju ʌv ɪts stʃɹits kəd bi kɔl pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli bɹɔd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz lɑɹdʒ ən spɹɔlɪŋ, wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz ə ðə wɝld, ænd, laɪk moʊst ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz, ə dʒʌmbəl ðət hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪli-nɪli. ɪn ðoʊz tæŋɡəl stʃɹits, taɪl-ɹuft ɪnz ən sleɪt-ɹuf steɪbəlz, ðə ɹuf kɔɹnɝz slæntəd ʃɑɹpli, stʊɾ əlɔŋsaɪd pæləsəz wɪð skwɛɹd waɪt doʊmz ən tɔl, bælkəni-ɹɪŋ taʊɝz ðəɾ ɔfən keɪm tə pɔɪns, ðə haɪts ə doʊmz ən taʊɝz ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ði ɝli-mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn. smɪθiz ən kʌtlɝz, simstʃɹəsəz ən bʊtʃɝz, fɪʃmɑŋɡɝz ən ɹʌɡ-wivɝz' ʃɑps ɹʌbd əɡɛns mɑɹbəl stʃɹʌktʃɝz wɪð tɔl bɹɑnz dɔɹz bɪhaɪn mæsɪv waɪt kɑləmz, ɡɪl hɔlz ən bæŋkɝz ən mɝtʃəns' ɪkstʃeɪnʒəz.

Tear was not beautiful, like Caemlyn or Tar Valon, and few of its streets could be called particularly broad, but it was large and sprawling, one of the great cities of the world, and, like most great cities, a jumble that had grown up willy-nilly. In those tangled streets, tile-roofed inns and slate-roofed stables, the roof corners slanted sharply, stood alongside palaces with squared white domes and tall, balcony-ringed towers that often came to points, the heights of domes and towers gleaming in the early-morning sun. Smithies and cutlers, seamstresses and butchers, fishmongers and rug-weavers' shops rubbed against marble structures with tall bronze doors behind massive white columns, guild halls and bankers and merchants' exchanges.

ət ðɪs aʊɝ, ðə stʃɹits ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ stɪl kæst ɪn dip ʃædoʊz, jɛt ðeɪ bʌsəld wɪð ðət stɔɹid sʌðɝn ɪndəstʃɹi. sɪdæn tʃɛɹz bɔɹn baɪ pɛɹz ə lin mɛn woʊv θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz ɔlmoʊst əz kwɪkli əz ðə tʃɪlʒɹən u ɹeɪst əbaʊɾ ɪn pleɪ waɪl koʊtʃɪz ən kæɹɪdʒɪz bɪhaɪn timz ə fɔɹ əɹ sɪks muvd əz sloʊli əz ðə kɑɹts ən wæɡənz, moʊs dʒɹɔn baɪ lɑɹdʒ ɑksən. pɔɹɾɝz tʃɹʌdʒd əlɔŋ, ðɛɹ bʌndəlz slʌŋ bɪniθ poʊlz kæɹiɾ ɑn tu mɛnz ʃoʊldɝz, ən əpɹɛntəsɪz kæɹid ɹoʊl kɑɹpəts ən bɑksəz ə ðə mæstɝz' hændiwɝk ɑn ðɛɹ bæks. hɔkɝz kɹaɪd ðɛɹ wɛɹz fɹəm tʃɹeɪz əɹ hændbæɹoʊz, pɪnz ən ɹɪbənz, ə fju wɪð ɹoʊstəd nʌts ən mit paɪz, ən tʌmblɝz əɹ dʒʌɡəlɝz əɹ mjuzɪʃənz pɝfɔɹmd ət nɪɹli ɛvɹi ɪntɝsɛkʃən. jə wəd nɛvɝ əv θɔt ðɪs sɪɾi wɑz ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə sidʒ.

At this hour, the streets themselves were still cast in deep shadows, yet they bustled with that storied southern industry. Sedan chairs borne by pairs of lean men wove through the crowds almost as quickly as the children who raced about in play while coaches and carriages behind teams of four or six moved as slowly as the carts and wagons, most drawn by large oxen. Porters trudged along, their bundles slung beneath poles carried on two men's shoulders, and apprentices carried rolled carpets and boxes of the masters' handiwork on their backs. Hawkers cried their wares from trays or handbarrows, pins and ribbons, a few with roasted nuts and meat pies, and tumblers or jugglers or musicians performed at nearly every intersection. You would never have thought this city was the site of a siege.

nɑɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz pisfəl, ðoʊ. ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ əɹ nɑt, ɹænd sɔ ɑbstʃɹipɝəs dʒɹʌŋks biɪŋ θɹoʊn aʊɾ ʌv ɪnz ən tævɝnz ən soʊ mɛni fɪstfaɪts ən mɛn ɹɛslɪŋ ɑn ðə peɪvmən ðəɾ ɪt simd wʌn pɛɹ wɑz nɑt wɛl aʊɾ ə saɪt bɪfɔɹ ðə nɛks keɪm ɪndə vju. ə ɡʊd mɛni ɑbviəs ɑɹmmɪn mɪŋɡəld ɪn ðə kɹaʊd, sɔɹdz ət ðɛɹ hɪps ən ðə fæt slivz ə ðɛɹ wʊlən koʊts stʃɹaɪpt ɪn vɛɹiəs haʊs kʌlɝz, bʌɾ ivən ðoʊz wɛɹɪŋ bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts meɪd noʊ muv tə bɹeɪk ʌp ðə ɹoʊz. ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə ðə faɪts ɪnvɑlvd ɑɹmmɪn, wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ, wɪð si foʊk, wɪð ɹʌfli klæd fɛloʊz u maɪɾ əv bɪn leɪbɝɝz əɹ əpɹɛntəsɪz əɹ ʃoʊldɝ-θʌmpɝz. soʊlʒɝz wɪð nʌθɪŋ tə də ɡɹu bɔɹd, ən bɔɹd soʊlʒɝz ɡɑt dʒɹʌŋk ən fɔt. hi wɑz ɡlæd tə si ðə ɹɛbəlz' ɑɹmmɪn bɔɹd.

Not everything was peaceful, though. Early morning or not, Rand saw obstreperous drunks being thrown out of inns and taverns and so many fistfights and men wrestling on the pavement that it seemed one pair was not well out of sight before the next came into view. A good many obvious armsmen mingled in the crowd, swords at their hips and the fat sleeves of their woolen coats striped in various House colors, but even those wearing breastplates and helmets made no move to break up the rows. A fair number of the fights involved armsmen, with one another, with Sea Folk, with roughly clad fellows who might have been laborers or apprentices or shoulder-thumpers. Soldiers with nothing to do grew bored, and bored soldiers got drunk and fought. He was glad to see the rebels' armsmen bored.

ðə meɪɾənz, dʒɹɪftɪŋ θɹu ðə θɹɔŋ ən stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹitɛn ðeɪ hæd noʊ əsoʊsieɪʃən wɪð ɹænd, dʒɹu pʌzəld lʊks ən hɛd-skɹætʃɪŋ, meɪnli fɹəm dɑɹk-feɪst si foʊk, ðoʊ ə ɡæɡəl ə tʃɪlʒɹən tʃɹeɪld æftɝ əm ɡeɪpɪŋ. ðə tɛɹənz, mɛni ʌv hum wɝ nɑɾ ɔl ðət mʌtʃ fɛɹɝ ðən ðə si foʊk, hæd sin il bɪfɔɹ, ən ɪf ðeɪ wʌndɝd waɪ ðeɪ hæd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə sɪɾi, ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðeɪ hæd dɪfɹən bɪznəs ət hæn ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ən mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. noʊ wʌn sim tə ɡɪv ɹænd əɹ ɪz ʌðɝ kəmpænjənz ə sɛkənd ɡlæns. ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ maʊntəd mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn ðə stʃɹits, moʊst ə ðɛm aʊtləndɝz, hɪɹ ə peɪl kɛɹhinɪn mɝtʃən ɪn ə sɑmbɝ koʊt, ðəɹ ən ɝæfɛlɪn wɪð sɪlvɝ bɛlz fæsən tə hɪz dɑɹk bɹeɪdz, hɪɹ ə kɑpɝ-skɪn dəmɑni ɪn ə bɛɹli oʊpeɪk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs bɛɹli hɪɾən baɪ hɝ kloʊk fɑloʊd baɪ ə pɛɹ ə hʌlkɪŋ bɑɾiɡɑɹdz ɪn lɛðɝ koʊts soʊn wɪð stil dɪsks, ðəɹ ə ʃaɪnɝən wɪð ɪz hɛd ʃeɪvd ɪksɛp fəɹ ə ɡɹeɪ tɑpnɑɾ ən ɪz bɛli stʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪz bʌɾənz. jə kəd nɑt muv tɛn peɪsɪz ɪn tiɹ wɪθaʊt siɪŋ aʊtləndɝz. tɛɹən kɑmɝs hæd lɔŋ ɑɹmz.

The Maidens, drifting through the throng and still trying to pretend they had no association with Rand, drew puzzled looks and head-scratching, mainly from dark-faced Sea Folk, though a gaggle of children trailed after them gaping. The Tairens, many of whom were not all that much fairer than the Sea Folk, had seen Aiel before, and if they wondered why they had returned to the city, it appeared they had different business at hand this morning, and more important. No one seemed to give Rand or his other companions a second glance. There were other mounted men and women in the streets, most of them outlanders, here a pale Cairhienin merchant in a somber coat, there an Arafellin with silver bells fastened to his dark braids, here a copper-skinned Domani in a barely opaque riding dress barely hidden by her cloak followed by a pair of hulking bodyguards in leather coats sewn with steel discs, there a Shienaran with his head shaved except for a gray topknot and his belly straining his buttons. You could not move ten paces in Tear without seeing outlanders. Tairen commerce had long arms.

wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt tə seɪ ðəɾ i pæs θɹu ðə sɪɾi wɪθaʊɾ ɪnsəɾənt. əhɛɾ ə hɪm, ə ɹʌnɪŋ beɪkɝz bɔɪ tʃɹɪpt ən fɛl, flɪŋɪŋ ɪz bæskəɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ən wən ðə bɔɪ lɛvɝd hɪmsɛlf ɔf ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz əz ɹænd ɹoʊd baɪ, hi stɑp hæfweɪ ʌp wɪð ɪz maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə lɔŋ loʊvz stændɪŋ ɑn ɛnd nɪɹ ðə bæskət, pɹɑp təɡɛðɝ ɪn ə ɹʌf koʊn. ə fɛloʊ ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ɪn ə sɛkənd-stɔɹi wɪndoʊ ʌv ən ɪn, oʊvɝbælənst ən tɑpəl təwɔɹd ðə stʃɹit wɪð ə ʃɹik ðət kʌɾ ɔf wən i lændəɾ ɑn ɪz fit nɑt tɛn peɪsɪz fɹəm teɪdeɪʃɝ, mʌɡ stɪl ɪn hænd. ɹænd lɛft ɪm bɪhaɪnd waɪd-aɪɾ ən filɪŋ ət hɪmsɛlf ɪn wʌndɝmənt. ɹɪpəlz ʌv ɔltɝd tʃæns wɝ fɑloʊɪŋ ɹænd, spɹɛɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə sɪɾi.

Which was not to say that he passed through the city without incident. Ahead of him, a running baker's boy tripped and fell, flinging his basket into the air, and when the boy levered himself off the paving stones as Rand rode by, he stopped halfway up with his mouth hanging open, staring at the long loaves standing on end near the basket, propped together in a rough cone. A fellow in his shirtsleeves, drinking in a second-story window of an inn, overbalanced and toppled toward the street with a shriek that cut off when he landed on his feet not ten paces from Tai'daishar, mug still in hand. Rand left him behind wide-eyed and feeling at himself in wonderment. Ripples of altered chance were following Rand, spreading across the city.

nɑɾ ɛvɹi ɪvɛnt wəd bi əz hɑɹmləs əz ðə loʊvz, əɹ əz bɛnəfɪʃəl əz ðə mæn lændɪŋ ɑn ɪz fit ɹæðɝ ðən ɪz hɛd. ðoʊz ɹɪpəlz kəd tɝn wʌt ʃəd bi ə bɹuɪzləs tʌmbəl ɪndə bɹoʊkən boʊnz əɹ ə bɹoʊkən nɛk. laɪflɔŋ fjudz kəd bi stɑɹɾəd baɪ mɛn spikɪŋ wɝdz ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ θɔt tə hɪɹ kʌm fɹəm ðɛɹ oʊn lɪps. wɪmən kəd dɪsaɪd tə pɔɪzən ðɛɹ hʌzbənz oʊvɝ tʃɹɪviəl əfɛnsɪz ðeɪ hæd tɑlɝeɪɾəd kəmpleɪsənli fəɹ jɪɹz. oʊ, səm fɛloʊ maɪt faɪn ə ɹɑɾɪŋ sæk fʊl ʌv ɡoʊl bɛɹiɾ ɪn ɪz oʊn beɪsmənt wɪθaʊt ɹɪli noʊɪŋ waɪ hi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə dɪɡ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, əɹ ə mæn maɪɾ æsk ən ɡeɪn ðə hæn ʌv ə wʊmən i hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ hæd ðə kɝədʒ tə əpɹoʊtʃ, bʌɾ əz mɛni wəd faɪn ɹuəneɪʃən əz faʊnd ɡʊd fɔɹtʃən. bæləns, mɪn hæd kɔld ɪt. ə ɡʊd tə bæləns ɛvɹi ɪl. hi sɔ ən ɪl tə bæləns ɛvɹi ɡʊd. hi niɾəd tə bi dʌn ɪn tiɹ ən ɡɔn əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. ɡæləpɪŋ ɪn ðoʊz kɹaʊɾəd stʃɹits wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃən, bʌɾ i pɪkt ʌp ɪz peɪs ɪnʌf ðət ðə meɪɾənz hæd tə tʃɹɑt.

Not every event would be as harmless as the loaves, or as beneficial as the man landing on his feet rather than his head. Those ripples could turn what should be a bruiseless tumble into broken bones or a broken neck. Lifelong feuds could be started by men speaking words they had never thought to hear come from their own lips. Women could decide to poison their husbands over trivial offenses they had tolerated complacently for years. Oh, some fellow might find a rotting sack full of gold buried in his own basement without really knowing why he had decided to dig in the first place, or a man might ask and gain the hand of a woman he had never before had the courage to approach, but as many would find ruination as found good fortune. Balance, Min had called it. A good to balance every ill. He saw an ill to balance every good. He needed to be done in Tear and gone as soon as possible. Galloping in those crowded streets was out of the question, but he picked up his pace enough that the Maidens had to trot.

hɪz dɛstəneɪʃən hæd bɪn ɪn saɪt sɪns lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ i ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi, ə mæs ə stoʊn laɪk ə bæɹən, ʃɪɹ-saɪɾəd hɪl ðət stʃɹɛtʃt fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn ɪndə ðə sɪɾiz hɑɹt, kʌvɝɪŋ ət list eɪɾ əɹ naɪn mɑɹtʃɪz, ə ɡʊd skwɛɹ maɪl əɹ mɔɹ, ən dɑməneɪɾɪŋ ðə sɪɾiz skaɪ. ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ wɑz mænkaɪnz oʊldəst stʃɹɔŋhoʊld, ði oʊldəst stʃɹʌktʃɝ ɪn ðə wɝld, meɪd wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪn ðə læs deɪz ə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪtsɛlf. wʌn sɑləd pis ə stoʊn ɪt wɑz, wɪθaʊɾ ə sɪŋɡəl dʒɔɪn, ðoʊ bɛɾɝ ðən θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz ə ɹeɪn ən wɪn hæd wɛðɝd ðə sɝfəs tə ɹʌnəs. ðə fɝs bæɾəlmənts stʊɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɝ æɹoʊslɪts əplɛnti loʊɝ, ən stoʊn spaʊts fəɹ ʃaʊɝɪŋ ətækɝz wɪð bɔɪlɪŋ ɔɪl əɹ moʊltən lɛd. noʊ bɪsiɡɝ kəd stɑp ðə stoʊn fɹəm biɪŋ səplaɪd θɹu ɪts oʊn wɔl-ʃildɪd dɑks, ən ɪt kənteɪn fɔɹdʒɪz ən mænjəfæktɝiz tə ɹipleɪs əɹ mɛn ɛvɹi sɔɹɾ ʌv wɛpən ʃəɾ ɪts ɑɹmɔɹiz fɔl ʃɔɹt. ɪts haɪəs taʊɝ, ɹɪɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə vɛɹi sɛntɝ ə ðə stoʊn, hɛl ðə bænɝ ə tɛɹ, hæf ɹɛd, hæf ɡoʊld, wɪð ə slæntɪŋ laɪn ə θɹi sɪlvɝ kɹɛsəns, ən soʊ lɑɹdʒ ðəɾ ɪt kəd bi meɪɾ aʊt pleɪnli əz ɪt kɝld ɪn ə stʃɹɔŋ bɹiz. ɪt hæd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ tə muv ðət flæɡ. loʊɝ taʊɝz səpɔɹɾəd smɔlɝ vɝʒənz, bʌt hɪɹ ðeɪ ɔltɝneɪɾəd wɪð ənʌðɝ ɹɪpəlɪŋ bænɝ, ði eɪntʃən sɪmbəl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ blæk-ænd-waɪɾ ɑn ə fild ə ɹɛd. ðə bænɝ ə laɪt. ðə dʒɹæɡən bænɝ, səm kɔld ɪt, əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ nɑɾ ənʌðɝ ðət bɔɹ ðət neɪm. ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn wɑz flɔntɪŋ ɪz əlidʒəns, ɪt simd. ðət wɑz wɛl.

His destination had been in sight since long before he entered the city, a mass of stone like a barren, sheer-sided hill that stretched from the River Erinin into the city's heart, covering at least eight or nine marches, a good square mile or more, and dominating the city's sky. The Stone of Tear was mankind's oldest stronghold, the oldest structure in the world, made with the One Power in the last days of the Breaking itself. One solid piece of stone it was, without a single join, though better than three thousand years of rain and wind had weathered the surface to roughness. The first battlements stood a hundred paces above the ground, though there were arrowslits aplenty lower, and stone spouts for showering attackers with boiling oil or molten lead. No besieger could stop the Stone from being supplied through its own wall-shielded docks, and it contained forges and manufactories to replace or mend every sort of weapon should its armories fall short. Its highest tower, rearing over the very center of the Stone, held the banner of Tear, half red, half gold, with a slanting line of three silver crescents, and so large that it could be made out plainly as it curled in a strong breeze. It had to be strong to move that flag. Lower towers supported smaller versions, but here they alternated with another rippling banner, the ancient symbol of Aes Sedai black-and-white on a field of red. The Banner of Light. The Dragon Banner, some called it, as if there were not another that bore that name. The High Lord Darlin was flaunting his allegiance, it seemed. That was well.

ɑlɑnə wɑz ɪn ðɛɹ, ən wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðət wɑz wɛl i wəɾ əv tə lɝn. hi wɑz nɑɾ əz ʃɑɹpli əwɛɹ ə hɝ əz bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə ən mɪn dʒɔɪnli bɑndəɾ ɪm - hi θɔɾ i wɑz nɑt; ðeɪ hæd pʊʃt əɹ əsaɪd tə teɪk pɹaɪməsi sʌmhaʊ, ən ʃi hæd toʊld ɪm ʃi kəd sɛns lɪɾəl mɔɹ ə hɪm ðən ɪz pɹɛzəns - jɛt ʃi stɪl leɪ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd, ə bʌndəl ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ən fɪzɪkəl sɛnseɪʃənz. ɪt simd ə lɔŋ taɪm sɪns i hæd bɪn nɪɹ ɪnʌf tə hɝ tə sɛns ðoʊz. wʌns əɡɛn, ðə bɑnd wɪð əɹ fɛlt ən ɪntʃɹuʒən, ə wʊd-bi jusɝpɝ ə hɪz bɑn tə mɪn ən ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə. ɑlɑnə wɑz wɪɹi, əz ɪf pɝhæps ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪnʌf slip leɪtli, ən fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd, wɪð stʃɹɔŋ stʃɹiks ʌv æŋɡɝ ən sʌlkənəs. wɝ ðə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz ɡoʊɪŋ bædli? hi wəd faɪn aʊt sun ɪnʌf. ʃi wəd bi əwɛɹ i wɑz ɪn ðə sɪɾi, əwɛɹ i wɑz kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ ɪf lɪɾəl mɔɹ. mɪn hæd tʃɹaɪd tə titʃ ɪm ə tʃɹɪk kɔl mæskɪŋ ðət səpoʊzədli kəd haɪɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə bɑnd, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk ɪt wɝk. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi ədmɪɾəd ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk ɪt wɝk iðɝ.
