Most were small and low-rigged, their triangular sails nearly all high-boomed. Some seemed quick enough, but since the shorebound seldom sailed beyond sight of land and usually anchored at night for fear of shoals, their quickness availed them little. Cargo that required true speed went to Atha'an Miere ships. At a premium price, to be sure. It was a small portion of what Atha'an Miere carried, in part because of the price, in part because few things actually required their speed. Besides, cargo hire guaranteed some profit, but when the Cargomaster traded on his own for the ship, all of the profit went to vessel and clan.

əz fɑɹ əz ði aɪ kəd si tə ist ən wɛst əlɔŋ ðə koʊstlaɪn, æθɑn maɪɹ ʃɪps leɪ əɾ æŋkɝ, ɹeɪkɝz ən skɪmɝz, sɔɹɝz ən dɑɹɾɝz, moʊst sɝaʊndəd baɪ bʌmboʊts soʊ klʌɾɝd ðeɪ lʊk laɪk dʒɹʌŋkən ʃɔɹ fɛstəvəlz. ɹoʊɾ aʊt fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, ðə bʌmboʊts ɔfɝd fəɹ seɪl ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɹəm dʒɹaɪd fɹut tə kɔɹɾɝd bivz ən ʃip, fɹəm aɪɝn neɪlz ən aɪɝn stɑk tə sɔɹdz ən dæɡɝz, fɹəm ɡɔɾi tʃɹɪŋkəts ʌv ɪljən ðət maɪt kætʃ ə dɛkhænz aɪ tə ɡoʊld ən dʒɛmz. ðoʊ ðə ɡoʊld wɑz juʒəwəli ə θɪn pleɪt ðət wɔɹ ɔf ɪn ə fju mʌnθs tə ʃoʊ ðə bɹæs bɪniθ ən ðə dʒɛmz kʌlɝd ɡlæs. ðeɪ bɹɔt ɹæts, tu, ɪf nɑt fəɹ seɪl. æŋkɝd soʊ lɔŋ, ɛvɹi ʃɪp wɑz pleɪɡd baɪ ɹæts, naʊ. ɹæts ən spɔɪlədʒ meɪd ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə mɑɹkət fəɹ ðə pɛdlɝz.

As far as the eye could see to east and west along the coastline, Atha'an Miere ships lay at anchor, rakers and skimmers, soarers and darters, most surrounded by bumboats so cluttered they looked like drunken shore festivals. Rowed out from the city, the bumboats offered for sale everything from dried fruit to quartered beeves and sheep, from iron nails and iron stock to swords and daggers, from gaudy trinkets of Illian that might catch a deckhand's eye to gold and gems. Though the gold was usually a thin plate that wore off in a few months to show the brass beneath and the gems colored glass. They brought rats, too, if not for sale. Anchored so long, every ship was plagued by rats, now. Rats and spoilage made sure there was always a market for the peddlers.

bʌmboʊts ɔlsoʊ sɝaʊndəd ðə mæsɪv sintʃæn-bɪl vɛsəlz, dʌzənz əpɑn dʌzənz ə ðɛm, ðət hæd bɪn juzd ɪn ði ɪskeɪp. ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɪt wɑz biɪŋ kɔld, naʊ, ðə ɡɹeɪɾ ɪskeɪp fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ. seɪ ði ɪskeɪp, ən noʊ wʌn æskt wʌɾ ɪskeɪp jə mɛnt. ɡɹeɪt blʌf-baʊd θɪŋz ðeɪ wɝ, twaɪs ðə bim ʌv ə ɹeɪkɝ ən mɔɹ, sʌm, suɾəbəl fəɹ bæɾɝɪŋ θɹu hɛvi siz pɝhæps, bʌt stʃɹeɪnʒli ɹɪɡd ən wɪð ɑd ɹɪb seɪlz tu stɪf fəɹ pɹɑpɝ sɛɾɪŋ. mɛn ən wɪmən wɝ swɔɹmɪŋ oʊvɝ ðoʊz mæsts ən jɑɹdz naʊ, ɔltɝɪŋ ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ tə sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ juzəbəl. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd ðə kɹæft, bʌt ðə ʃɪpjɑɹdz wəd ɹikwaɪɝ jɪɹz tə ɹipleɪs ɔl ə ðə vɛsəlz lɔst əɾ ɛbu dɑɹ. ən ði ɪkspɛns! oʊvɝli bimi əɹ nɑt, ðoʊz ʃɪps wəd si mɛni jɪɹz ə juz. noʊ seɪlməstʃɹəs hæɾ ɛni dɪzaɪɝ tə sɪŋk ɪndə dɛt, bɑɹoʊɪŋ fɹəm ðə klæn kɑfɝz, wən moʊst ɪf nɑɾ ɔl ə hɝ oʊn ɡoʊld wɑz biɪŋ sælvɪdʒ baɪ ðə sintʃæn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, nɑɾ ənlɛs ʃi hæd noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs. sʌm, ənlʌki ɪnʌf tə hæv niðɝ ðɛɹ oʊn ʃɪps nɔɹ wʌn ə ðə sintʃænz, dɪɾ əv noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs.

Bumboats also surrounded the massive Seanchan-built vessels, dozens upon dozens of them, that had been used in the Escape. That was what it was being called, now, the great Escape from Ebou Dar. Say the Escape, and no one asked what escape you meant. Great bluff-bowed things they were, twice the beam of a raker and more, some, suitable for battering through heavy seas perhaps, but strangely rigged and with odd ribbed sails too stiff for proper setting. Men and women were swarming over those masts and yards now, altering the rigging to something more usable. No one wanted the craft, but the shipyards would require years to replace all of the vessels lost at Ebou Dar. And the expense! Overly beamy or not, those ships would see many years of use. No Sailmistress had any desire to sink into debt, borrowing from the clan coffers, when most if not all of her own gold was being salvaged by the Seanchan in Ebou Dar, not unless she had no other choice. Some, unlucky enough to have neither their own ships nor one of the Seanchan's, did have no other choice.

hɑɹɪnz twɛlv pæs ðə hɛvi wɔl ə ðə bɹeɪkwɔɾɝ, θɪk wɪð dɑɹk slaɪm ən lɔŋ hɛɹi wid ðət ðə bɹeɪkɝz kɹæʃɪŋ əɡɛns ðə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn feɪl tə dɪslɑdʒ, ən ðə bɹɔd, ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin hɑɹbɝ ʌv ɪljən oʊpən ʌp bɪfɔɹ hɝ, ɹɪŋd wɪð dip ɪkspænsɪz ə mɑɹʃ, dʒʌs tɝnɪŋ fɹəm wɪntɝ bɹaʊn tə ɡɹin ɪn pætʃəz, wɛɹ lɔŋ-lɛɡəd bɝdz weɪɾɪd. ə laɪn ə mɪs dʒɹɪftəɾ əkɹɔs ðə boʊɾ ɑn ə dʒɛntəl bɹiz, dæmpənɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ bɪfɔɹ ɪt pæst ɑn ʌp ðə hɑɹbɝ. smɔl fɪʃɪŋ boʊts wɝ pʊlɪŋ ðɛɹ nɛts əlɔŋ ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə mɑɹʃ, ə dʌzən sɔɹts ʌv ɡʌl ən tɝn wilɪŋ oʊvɝhɛd tə stil wʌt ðeɪ kʊd. ðə sɪɾi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəst əɹ bɪɑn ðə lɔŋ stoʊn dɑks, laɪnd wɪð tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ kɹæft, bʌt ðə hɑɹbɝ. . . . ðət bɹɔd, nɪɹli sɝkjəlɝ ɪkspæns ʌv wɔɾɝ wɑz ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst æŋkɝədʒ noʊn, ən fɪld wɪð ʃɪpɪŋ ən ɹɪvɝ kɹæft, moʊst weɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tɝn ət ðə dɑks. ɪt tʃɹuli wɑz fɪld, baɪ hʌnʒɹədz ə vɛsəlz ɪn ɛvɹi ʃeɪp ən saɪz, ən nɑɾ ɔl ə ðoʊz ʃɪps bɪlɔŋ tə ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ɹeɪkɝz hɪɹ, ðoʊz slɛndɝ θɹi-mæstɝz ðət kəd ɹeɪs pɔɹpəsəz. ɹeɪkɝz ən θɹi ʌv ði ənɡeɪnli sintʃæn mɑnstʃɹɑsəɾiz. ðeɪ wɝ ðə vɛsəlz ʌv weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz ən ə seɪlməstʃɹɛsəz u fɔɹm ðə fɝs twɛlv ʌv itʃ klæn, ðoʊz ðət kəd bi fɪɾəd ɪndə ðə hɑɹbɝ bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ɹum. ivən ɪljənz æŋkɝədʒ hæɾ ɪts lɪməts, ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðɪs stuɝɾ ɪn ɪljən fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, wʊɾə meɪd tʃɹʌbəl hæd ði æθɑn maɪɹ bɪɡʌn kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪd.

Harine's twelve passed the heavy wall of the breakwater, thick with dark slime and long hairy weed that the breakers crashing against the gray stone failed to dislodge, and the broad, gray-green harbor of Illian opened up before her, ringed with deep expanses of marsh, just turning from winter brown to green in patches, where long-legged birds waded. A line of mist drifted across the boat on a gentle breeze, dampening her hair before it passed on up the harbor. Small fishing boats were pulling their nets along the edges of the marsh, a dozen sorts of gull and tern wheeling overhead to steal what they could. The city did not interest her beyond the long stone docks, lined with trading craft, but the harbor. . . . That broad, nearly circular expanse of water was the greatest anchorage known, and filled with shipping and river craft, most waiting their turn at the docks. It truly was filled, by hundreds of vessels in every shape and size, and not all of those ships belonged to the shorebound. There were only rakers here, those slender three-masters that could race porpoises. Rakers and three of the ungainly Seanchan monstrosities. They were the vessels of Wavemistresses and of Sailmistresses who formed the First Twelve of each clan, those that could be fitted into the harbor before there was no more room. Even Illian's anchorage had its limits, and the Council of Nine, not to mention this Steward in Illian for the Dragon Reborn, would have made trouble had the Atha'an Miere begun crowding their trade.

əbɹʌpli ə stʃɹɔŋ, aɪsi wɪn keɪm ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə nɔɹθ. noʊ, ɪt dɪd nɑt kʌm ʌp; ɪt dʒʌst sʌɾənli wɑz ðəɹ fʊl stʃɹɛŋkθ, wɪpɪŋ ðə hɑɹbɝ tə tʃɑpi waɪtkæps ən kæɹiɪŋ ə smɛl ə paɪnz ən sʌmθɪŋ . . . ɝθi. ʃi nu lɪɾəl ə tʃɹiz, bʌt mʌtʃ ə tɪmbɝz juzd ɪn bɪldɪŋ ʃɪps. ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðəɹ wɝ mɛni paɪnz ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ tə ɪljən. ðən ʃi noʊɾəst ðə mɪs laɪn. waɪl ʃɪps ɹɑkt ən pɪtʃt ʌndɝ ðət saʊʌðɝli blæst, ðə mɪs kəntɪnjuɾ ɪts sloʊ dʒɹɪf nɔɹθwɝd. kipɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ niz ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɛfɝt. ʃi wɑntəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ tə waɪp ðə dæmpnəs aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛɹ. ʃi hæd θɔɾ æftɝ ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ðət nʌθɪŋ ɛvɝ wəd ʃeɪk əɹ əɡɛn, bʌt ʃi hæd sin tu mɛni . . . ɑɾətiz . . . ʌv leɪt, ɑɾətiz ðət spoʊk ə ðə wɝl twɪstɪŋ.

Abruptly a strong, icy wind came up out of the north. No, it did not come up; it just suddenly was there full strength, whipping the harbor to choppy whitecaps and carrying a smell of pines and something . . . earthy. She knew little of trees, but much of timbers used in building ships. Though she did not think there were many pines anywhere near to Illian. Then she noticed the mist line. While ships rocked and pitched under that southerly blast, the mist continued its slow drift northward. Keeping her hands on her knees required effort. She wanted very much to wipe the dampness out of her hair. She had thought after Shadar Logoth that nothing ever would shake her again, but she had seen too many . . . oddities . . . of late, oddities that spoke of the world twisting.

əz əbɹʌpli əz ɪt hæd kʌm, ðə wɪnd wɑz ɡɔn. mɝmɝz ɹoʊz, ðə stʃɹoʊk fɔltɝd, ən ðə nʌmbɝ fɔɹ pɔɹɾ ɔɹ kɑɾ ə kɹæb, splæʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ ɪndə ðə boʊt. ðə kɹu nu wɪnz dɪd nɑt bɪheɪv ðət weɪ.

As abruptly as it had come, the wind was gone. Murmurs rose, the stroke faltered, and the number four port oar caught a crab, splashing water into the boat. The crew knew winds did not behave that way.

"stɛɾi ðɛɹ," hɑɹɪn sɛd fɝmli. "stɛɾi!"

"Steady there," Harine said firmly. "Steady!"

"ɡɪv weɪ təɡɛðɝ, jə ʃɔɹbaʊn ɹæɡpɪkɝz," hɝ dɛkməstʃɹəs ʃaʊɾəd fɹəm ðə baʊ. lin ən lɛðɝi, dʒədaɪn hæd lɛðɝ lʌŋz əz wɛl. "du aɪ nid tə kɔl ðə stʃɹoʊk fəɹ ju?" ðə twɪn ɪnsʌls taɪɾənd səm feɪsəz ɪn æŋɡɝ, ʌðɝz ɪn ʃəɡɹɪn, bʌt ði ɔɹz bɪɡæn muvɪŋ smuðli əɡɛn.

"Give way together, you shorebound ragpickers," her deckmistress shouted from the bow. Lean and leathery, Jadein had leather lungs as well. "Do I need to call the stroke for you?" The twin insults tightened some faces in anger, others in chagrin, but the oars began moving smoothly again.

ʃələn wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ðə mɪst, naʊ. æskɪŋ wʌt ʃi sɔ, wʌt ʃi θɔt, wəɾ əv tə weɪt. hɑɹɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑntəd ði ænsɝ hɝd baɪ ɛni ʌv əɹ kɹu. ðeɪ hæd sin ɪnʌf tə hæv əm fɹaɪɾənd ɔlɹɛɾi.

Shalon was studying the mist, now. Asking what she saw, what she thought, would have to wait. Harine was not sure she wanted the answer heard by any of her crew. They had seen enough to have them frightened already.

ðə stɪɹsmən tɝn ðə twɛlv təwɔɹd wʌn ə ðə bʌlki sintʃæn ʃɪps, wɛɹ ɛni bʌmboʊt ðət vɛntʃɝd nɪɹ wɑz biɪŋ tʃeɪst əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə pɛdlɝ kəd ɡɛɾ aʊt tu wɝdz. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒəst ə ðɛm, wɪð ə taʊɝɪŋ stɝnkæsəl ðət hæd θɹi lɛvəlz. θɹi! ən ðə θɪŋ æktʃəli  hæɾ ə pɛɹ ə bælkəniz əkɹɔs ðə stɝn! ʃi wəd nɑt kɛɹ tə si wʌɾ ə fɑloʊɪŋ si dʒɹɪvən baɪ ə sɛmɑɹoʊz əɹ wʌn ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃənz sɑinz wəd də tə ðoʊz. ʌðɝ twɛlvz ən ə fju eɪts weɪɾəd ðɛɹ tɝn tə saɪɾəl ʌp tə ðə vɛsəl ɪn ði ɔɹɾɝ ə pɹɛsəɾəns ə ðɛɹ pæsənʒɝz.

The steersman turned the twelve toward one of the bulky Seanchan ships, where any bumboat that ventured near was being chased away before the peddler could get out two words. It was one of the largest of them, with a towering sterncastle that had three levels. Three! And the thing actually had a pair of balconies across the stern! She would not care to see what a following sea driven by a cemaros or one of the Aryth Ocean's soheens would do to those. Other twelves and a few eights waited their turn to sidle up to the vessel in the order of precedence of their passengers.

dʒədaɪn stʊɾ ʌp ɪn ðə baʊ ən bɛloʊd, "ʃoʊdaɪn!" hɝ vɔɪs kæɹid wɛl, ən ə twɛlv ðət wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə ʃɪp sɝkəld əweɪ. ði ʌðɝz kəntɪnjud ðɛɹ weɪɾɪŋ.

Jadein stood up in the bow and bellowed, "Shodein!" Her voice carried well, and a twelve that was approaching the ship circled away. The others continued their waiting.

hɑɹɪn dɪd nɑt stæn əntɪl ðə kɹu hæd bækt ɔɹz, ən dʒɹɔn əm ɪn ɑn ðə stɑɹbɝd, bɹɪŋɪŋ ðə twɛlv tə ə smuð hɔlt ɹaɪt wɛɹ dʒədaɪn kəd kætʃ ə dæŋɡəlɪŋ laɪn ən hoʊl ðə smɔl kɹæft əlɔŋsaɪd ðə lɑɹdʒɝ. ʃələn saɪd.

Harine did not stand until the crew had backed oars, and drawn them in on the starboard, bringing the twelve to a smooth halt right where Jadein could catch a dangling line and hold the small craft alongside the larger. Shalon sighed.

"kɝədʒ, sɪstɝ," hɑɹɪn toʊl hɝ. "wi hæv sɝvaɪvd ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ðoʊ ðə laɪt hɛlp mi, aɪm ənʃʊɹ wʌt wi sɝvaɪvd." ʃi bɑɹkt ə læf. "mɔɹ ðən ðæt, wi sɝvaɪv kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn, ən aɪ daʊɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls hɪɹ kəd də ðæt."

"Courage, sister," Harine told her. "We have survived Shadar Logoth, though the Light help me, I am unsure what we survived." She barked a laugh. "More than that, we survived Cadsuane Melaidhrin, and I doubt anyone else here could do that."

ʃələn smaɪld wikli, bʌɾ ət list ʃi smaɪld.

Shalon smiled weakly, but at least she smiled.

hɑɹɪn skɹæmbəld ʌp ðə ɹoʊp læɾɝ əz izəli əz ʃi kəɾ əv twɛnti jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ ən wɑz paɪpt əbɔɹd baɪ ðə dɛkmæstɝ, ə skwɑt fɛloʊ wɪð ə fɹɛʃ skɑɹ ɹʌnɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə lɛðɝ pætʃ ðət kʌvɝd wɛɹ ɪz ɹaɪɾ aɪ hæd bɪn. mɛni hæd teɪkən wunz ɪn ði ɪskeɪp. mɛni hæd daɪd. ivən ðə dɛk ə ðɪs ʃɪp fɛl stʃɹeɪnʒ bɪniθ əɹ bɛɹ fit, ðə plæŋkɪŋ leɪɾ ɪn ən ɑd pæɾɝn. ðə saɪd wɑz mæn pɹɑpɝli, haʊɛvɝ, twɛlv bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd mɛn tə hɝ lɛft, twɛlv wɪmən ɪn bɹaɪt lɪnən blaʊsəz tə hɝ ɹaɪt, ɔl boʊɪŋ tɪl ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪt daʊn ət ðə dɛk. ʃi weɪɾəd fəɹ ʃələn ən ðə pɛɹɑsɑl bɛɹɝz tə dʒɔɪn əɹ bɪfɔɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. ðə vɛsəlz seɪlməstʃɹəs ən wɪndfɪndɝ, ət ði ɛn ə ðə ɹoʊz, baʊd lɛs dipli waɪl tʌtʃɪŋ hɑɹts, lɪps ən fɔɹhɛdz. boʊθ wɔɹ weɪst-lɔŋ waɪt mɔɹnɪŋ stoʊlz ðəɾ ɔl bʌt hɪd ðɛɹ mɛni nɛkləsɪz, əz dɪd ʃi ən ʃələn.

Harine scrambled up the rope ladder as easily as she could have twenty years before and was piped aboard by the deckmaster, a squat fellow with a fresh scar running under the leather patch that covered where his right eye had been. Many had taken wounds in the Escape. Many had died. Even the deck of this ship felt strange beneath her bare feet, the planking laid in an odd pattern. The side was manned properly, however, twelve bare-chested men to her left, twelve women in bright linen blouses to her right, all bowing till they were looking straight down at the deck. She waited for Shalon and the parasol bearers to join her before starting forward. The vessel's Sailmistress and Windfinder, at the end of the rows, bowed less deeply while touching hearts, lips and foreheads. Both wore waist-long white mourning stoles that all but hid their many necklaces, as did she and Shalon.

"ðə wɛlkəm ə maɪ ʃɪp tə ju, weɪvməstʃɹəs," ðə seɪlməstʃɹəs sɛd, snɪfɪŋ əɹ sɛn bɑks, "æn ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt bi əpɑn jə əntɪl jə liv ɪz dɛks. ði ʌðɝz əweɪt jə ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt kæbən."

"The welcome of my ship to you, Wavemistress," the Sailmistress said, sniffing her scent box, "and the grace of the Light be upon you until you leave his decks. The others await you in the great cabin."

"ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt bi əpɑn jə ɔlsoʊ," hɑɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd. tʃɹeɪn, ɪn blu sɪlk tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ə ɹɛd sɪlk blaʊs, wɑz stɑki ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ wɪndfɪndɝ, sɛɝəl, lʊk slɛndɝ ɹæðɝ ðən ævɝɪdʒ, ən ʃi hæɾ ə ɡɪmləɾ aɪ ən ə saʊɝ twɪs tə hɝ maʊθ, bʌt niðɝ ðoʊz nɔɹ ðə snɪfɪŋ wɑz mɛn fəɹ dɪskɔɝɾɪsi. tʃɹeɪn wɑz nɑt ðət boʊld. ðə ɡeɪz wɑz ðə seɪm ʃi ɡeɪv ɛvɹiwʌn, hɝ oʊn vɛsəl leɪ ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə hɑɹbɝ əɾ ɛbu dɑɹ, ən ðə hɑɹbɝ dɪd stɪŋk æftɝ ðə klin ɛɹ ə ði oʊpən sɔlt.

"The grace of the Light be upon you also," Harine replied. Turane, in blue silk trousers and a red silk blouse, was stocky enough to make her Windfinder, Serile, look slender rather than average, and she had a gimlet eye and a sour twist to her mouth, but neither those nor the sniffing was meant for discourtesy. Turane was not that bold. The gaze was the same she gave everyone, her own vessel lay at the bottom of the harbor at Ebou Dar, and the harbor did stink after the clean air of the open salt.

ðə ɡɹeɪt kæbən ɹæn nɪɹli ðə hoʊl lɛŋθ ə ðə tɔl stɝnkæsəl, ə speɪs klɪɹ ʌv ɛni fɝnɪtʃɝ seɪv fəɹ θɝtin tʃɛɹz ən ə teɪbəl əɡɛns ðə bʌlkhɛd ðət hɛl tɔl-nɛkt waɪn pɪtʃɝz ən ɡoʊbləts ə jɛloʊ pɔɹsələn, ən tu dʌzən wɪmən ɪn bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd sɪlks kəd nɑt kʌm nɪɹ fɪlɪŋ ɪt. ʃi wɑz ðə læst ə ðə fɝs twɛlv ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ tə ɝaɪv, ən ðə ɹiækʃən tə hɝ əmʌŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz wɑz wʌt ʃi hæd kʌm tə ɪkspɛkt. lɪnkɔɹə ən wɔlaɪn tɝn ðɛɹ bæks vɛɹi dɪlɪbɝətli. ɹaʊnd-feɪs niɑl ɡeɪv əɹ ə skaʊl, ðən stɔkt oʊvɝ tə ɹifɪl əɹ ɡɑblət. lɑsin, soʊ slɛndɝ ðəɾ əɹ bʊzəm simd ɪmɛns, ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ ət hɑɹɪnz pɹɛzəns. ʌðɝz wɛn ɑn tʃæɾɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ nɑt ðɛɹ. ɔl wɔɹ ðə mɔɹnɪŋ stoʊlz, ʌv kɔɹs.

The great cabin ran nearly the whole length of the tall sterncastle, a space clear of any furniture save for thirteen chairs and a table against the bulkhead that held tall-necked wine pitchers and goblets of yellow porcelain, and two dozen women in brocaded silks could not come near filling it. She was the last of the First Twelve of the Atha'an Miere to arrive, and the reaction to her among the other Wavemistresses was what she had come to expect. Lincora and Wallein turned their backs very deliberately. Round-faced Niolle gave her a scowl, then stalked over to refill her goblet. Lacine, so slender that her bosom seemed immense, shook her head as if wondering at Harine's presence. Others went on chatting as if she were not there. All wore the mourning stoles, of course.

pɛlænə stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə dɛk tə hɝ, ðə lɔŋ pɪŋk skɑɹ daʊn ðə ɹaɪt saɪɾ ə hɝ skwɛɹ feɪs ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ə deɪnʒɝəs lʊk. hɝ taɪtli kɝl hɛɹ wɑz nɪɹli ɔl ɡɹeɪ, ði ɑnɝ tʃeɪn əkɹɔs əɹ lɛf tʃik hɛvi wɪð ɡoʊl mədæljənz ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ əɹ tʃɹaɪəmfs, ɪnkluɾɪŋ wʌn fəɹ əɹ pɑɹɾ ɪn ði ɪskeɪp. hɝ ɹɪsts ən æŋkəlz stɪl bɔɹ ðə mɑɹks ə sintʃæn tʃeɪnz, ðoʊ hɪɾən baɪ hɝ sɪlks naʊ. "aɪ hoʊp jə ɑɹ kwaɪt ɹəkʌvɝd, hɑɹɪn, ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ," ʃi sɛd, tɪltɪŋ əɹ hɛd tə wʌn saɪɾ ən klæspɪŋ əɹ plʌmp, tætud hænz ɪn mɑk sɪmpəθi. "nɑt stɪl sɪɾɪŋ tɛndɝ, ɑɹ ju? aɪ pʊɾ ə kʊʃən ɑn jəɹ tʃɛɹ dʒʌst ɪn keɪs."

Pelanna strode across the deck to her, the long pink scar down the right side of her square face giving her a dangerous look. Her tightly curled hair was nearly all gray, the honor chain across her left cheek heavy with gold medallions recording her triumphs, including one for her part in the Escape. Her wrists and ankles still bore the marks of Seanchan chains, though hidden by her silks now. "I hope you are quite recovered, Harine, the Light willing," she said, tilting her head to one side and clasping her plump, tattooed hands in mock sympathy. "Not still sitting tender, are you? I put a cushion on your chair just in case."

ʃi læft əpɹɔɑɹiəsli, lʊkɪŋ tə hɝ wɪndfɪndɝ, bʌt kɛɹ ɡeɪv əɹ ə blæŋk lʊk, əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt hɝd, ðən æɾəd ə feɪn læf. pɛlænə fɹaʊnd. wən ʃi læft əɾ ɛniθɪŋ, ʃi ɪkspɛktəd ðoʊz ʌndɝ əɹ tə læf əz wɛl. ðə steɪtli wɪndfɪndɝ hæɾ əɹ oʊn wɝiz, haʊɛvɝ, ə dɔɾɝ mɪsɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd, æbdʌktɪd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðəɹ wəd bi ɹipeɪmən fəɹ ðæt. wʌn dɪd nɑt nid tə laɪk kɛɹ əɹ pɛlænə tə noʊ ðət wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi.

She laughed uproariously, looking to her Windfinder, but Caire gave her a blank look, as if she had not heard, then added a faint laugh. Pelanna frowned. When she laughed at anything, she expected those under her to laugh as well. The stately Windfinder had her own worries, however, a daughter missing among the shorebound, abducted by Aes Sedai. There would be repayment for that. One did not need to like Caire or Pelanna to know that was necessary.

hɑɹɪn feɪvɝd ðə pɛɹ wɪð ə taɪt smaɪl ən bɹʌʃt baɪ pɛlænə kloʊsli ɪnʌf ðət ðə wʊmən hæd tə stɛp bæk əɹ əv əɹ fit tʃɹɑɾən ɑn, skaʊlɪŋ əz ʃi dɪd. dɔɾɝ ə ðə sænz, hɑɹɪn θɔt saʊɝli.

Harine favored the pair with a tight smile and brushed by Pelanna closely enough that the woman had to step back or have her feet trodden on, scowling as she did. Daughter of the sands, Harine thought sourly.

mɑɹaɪlz əpɹoʊtʃ bɹɔɾ ə dʒɛnjəwən smaɪl, haʊɛvɝ. ðə tɔl, slɛndɝ wʊmən, hɝ ʃoʊldɝ-lɛŋθ hɛɹ əz mʌtʃ waɪɾ əz blæk, hæd bɪn əɹ fɹɛn sɪns ðeɪ bɪɡæn əz dɛkhənz təɡɛðɝ ɑn ən eɪdʒɪŋ ɹeɪkɝ wɪð ən aɪɝn-hændəd seɪlməstʃɹəs ɛmbɪɾɝd baɪ hɝ læk ə pɹɑspɛks. lɝnɪŋ ðət mɑɹaɪl hæɾ ɪskeɪpt ɛbu dɑɹ, ən ənhɑɹmd, hæd bɪn ə dʒɔɪ. ʃi feɪvɝd pɛlænə ən kɛɹ wɪð ə fɹaʊn. tɛbɹl, hɝ wɪndfɪndɝ, ɔlsoʊ ɡɹɪməst ət ðə pɛɹ, bʌɾ ənlaɪk ðɛm, ɪt wɑz nɑt kəz mɑɹaɪl dɪmændəd ɹɪst-lɪkɪŋ. sɪstɝz, tɛbɹl ən kɛɹ ʃɛɹɾ ə dip kənsɝn fəɹ tɑlɑn, kɛɹz dɔɾɝ, jɛt bɪɑn ðæt, iðɝ wʊɾə slɪt ði ʌðɝz θɹoʊt fəɹ ə kɑpɝ. əɹ bɛɾɝ, ɪn ðɛɹ vju, sin əɹ sɪstɝ ɹədus tə klinɪŋ ðə bɪlʒz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ heɪtʃɹəd dipɝ ðən heɪtʃɹəd bɪtwin sɪblɪŋz.

Mareil's approach brought a genuine smile, however. The tall, slender woman, her shoulder-length hair as much white as black, had been her friend since they began as deckhands together on an aging raker with an iron-handed Sailmistress embittered by her lack of prospects. Learning that Mareil had escaped Ebou Dar, and unharmed, had been a joy. She favored Pelanna and Caire with a frown. Tebreille, her Windfinder, also grimaced at the pair, but unlike them, it was not because Mareil demanded wrist-licking. Sisters, Tebreille and Caire shared a deep concern for Talaan, Caire's daughter, yet beyond that, either would have slit the other's throat for a copper. Or better, in their view, seen her sister reduced to cleaning the bilges. There was no hatred deeper than hatred between siblings.

"doʊn lɛt ðoʊz mʌd-dʌks pɛk ət ju, hɑɹɪn." mɑɹaɪlz vɔɪs wɑz dip fəɹ ə wʊmən, bʌt məloʊɾiəs. ʃi hændəd hɑɹɪn wʌn ə ðə tu ɡoʊbləts ʃi kæɹid. "ju dɪd wʌt jə fɛl jə hæd tə du, ən ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ, ɔl wɪl kʌm ɹaɪt."

"Don't let those mud-ducks peck at you, Harine." Mareil's voice was deep for a woman, but melodious. She handed Harine one of the two goblets she carried. "You did what you felt you had to do, and the Light willing, all will come right."

əɡɛnst əɹ wɪl, hɑɹɪnz aɪz wɛn tə ðə ɹɪŋboʊl sɛɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə bimz ə ði oʊvɝhɛd. ɪt cʊɾə bɪn ɹimuv baɪ naʊ. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt ɹɪmeɪn fəɹ ðə pɝpəs ə pɹəvoʊkɪŋ hɝ. ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ jʌŋ wʊmən mɪn hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. hɝ bɑɹɡən wɪð ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ hæd bɪn dʒʌdʒ dɪfɪʃənt, ɡɪvɪŋ əweɪ tu mʌtʃ ən dɪmændɪŋ tu lɪɾəl ɪn ɹɪtɝn. ɪn ðɪs seɪm kæbən, wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə fɝs twɛlv ən ðə nu mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps wɑtʃɪŋ, ʃi hæd bɪn stʃɹɪpt ən hʌŋ baɪ hɝ æŋkəlz fɹəm ðət ɹɪŋboʊlt, stʃɹɛtʃt taɪt tə ənʌðɝ sɛɾ ɪn ðə dɛk, ðən stʃɹæpt əntɪl ʃi haʊld əɹ lʌŋz aʊt. ðə wɛls ən bɹuzəz hæd feɪɾəd, bʌt ðə mɛmɹi lɪŋɡɝd haʊɛvɝ hɑɹd ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə səpɹɛs ɪt. nɑt haʊlz fəɹ mɝsi əɹ ɹɛspɪt, ðoʊ. nɛvɝ ðæt, ɛls ʃi wʊɾə hæd noʊ ɔltɝnəɾɪv tə stɛpɪŋ əsaɪd, bɪkʌmɪŋ dʒʌst ə seɪlməstʃɹəs əɡɛn waɪl sʌmwʌn ɛls wɑz tʃoʊzən weɪvməstʃɹəs ə klæn ʃoʊdaɪn. moʊst ə ðə wɪmən ɪn ðɪs ɹum bɪlivd ʃi ʃʊɾə dʌn soʊ ɛniweɪ æftɝ sətʃ ə pʌnɪʃmənt, pɝhæps ivən mɑɹaɪl. bʌt ʃi hæd ði ʌðɝ pɑɹɾ ə mɪnz fɔɹtɛlɪŋ tə boʊlstɝ əɹ kɝədʒ. ʃi wəd bi mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps wʌn deɪ. ɪn lɔ, ðə fɝs twɛlv ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ kəd tʃuz ɛni seɪlməstʃɹəs əz mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps, jɛɾ oʊnli faɪv taɪmz ɪn mɔɹ ðən θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz hæd ðeɪ ɹitʃt aʊtsaɪd ðɛɹ oʊn nʌmbɝ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd mɪnz pəkjuljɝ vɪʒənz ɔlweɪz keɪm tʃɹu, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə ɡæmbəl.

Against her will, Harine's eyes went to the ringbolt set in one of the beams of the overhead. It could have been removed by now. She was sure it remained for the purpose of provoking her. That strange young woman Min had been right. Her Bargain with the Coramoor had been judged deficient, giving away too much and demanding too little in return. In this same cabin, with the rest of the First Twelve and the new Mistress of the Ships watching, she had been stripped and hung by her ankles from that ringbolt, stretched tight to another set in the deck, then strapped until she howled her lungs out. The welts and bruises had faded, but the memory lingered however hard she tried to suppress it. Not howls for mercy or respite, though. Never that, else she would have had no alternative to stepping aside, becoming just a Sailmistress again while someone else was chosen Wavemistress of Clan Shodein. Most of the women in this room believed she should have done so anyway after such a punishment, perhaps even Mareil. But she had the other part of Min's foretelling to bolster her courage. She would be Mistress of the Ships one day. In law, the First Twelve of the Atha'an Miere could choose any Sailmistress as Mistress of the Ships, yet only five times in more than three thousand years had they reached outside their own number. The Aes Sedai said Min's peculiar visions always came true, but she did not intend to gamble.

"ɔl wɪl kʌm ɹaɪt, mɑɹaɪl, ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ," ʃi sɛd. ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ʃi dʒʌs hæd tə hæv ðə kɝədʒ tə ɹaɪɾ aʊt wʌtɛvɝ keɪm bɪfɔɹ.

"All will come right, Mareil, the Light willing," she said. Eventually. She just had to have the courage to ride out whatever came before.

əz juʒəwəl, zeɪɾə ɝaɪvd wɪθaʊt sɛɹəmoʊni, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn fɑloʊd baɪ ʃilɪn, hɝ wɪndfɪndɝ, tɔl ən slɪm ən ɹɪzɝvd, ən æmɪliə, ðə boʊsəmi, peɪl-hɛɹɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ zeɪɾə hæd bɹɔt bæk wɪð əɹ fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn. eɪdʒləs feɪs simɪŋ pɝmənənli sɝpɹaɪzd, hɝ stɑɹtlɪŋ blu aɪz vɛɹi waɪd, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz bɹiðɪŋ hɛvəli fəɹ səm ɹizən. ɛvɹiwʌn baʊd, bʌt zeɪɾə peɪd ðə kɝɾəsiz noʊ hid. ɪn ɡɹin bɹoʊkeɪdz ən waɪt mɔɹnɪŋ stoʊl, ʃi wɑz ʃɔɹt, wɪð ə kloʊs kæp ʌv ɡɹeɪɪŋ kɝlz, jɛt ʃi mænədʒ tə meɪk hɝsɛlf sim ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz tɔl əz ʃilɪn. ə mæɾɝ ə pɹɛzəns, hɑɹɪn hæd tə ədmɪt. zeɪɾə hæd ðæt, ən ə kulnəs ə θɔt ðət biɪŋ kɑt baɪ ə sɛmɑɹoʊz ɑn ə li ʃɔɹ kəd nɑt ʃeɪk. ɪn ədɪʃən tə ɹɪtɝnɪŋ wɪð ðə fɝst ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɹid tə ɪn ðə bɑɹɡən fəɹ jus ə ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, ʃi ɔlsoʊ hæd ɹɪtɝnd wɪð əɹ oʊn bɑɹɡən, fəɹ læn ɪn ændɝ ʌndɝ æθɑn maɪɹ lɔ, ən wɛɹ hɑɹɪnz bɑɹɡən hæd bɪn dʒʌdʒd wɑntɪŋ, zeɪɾəz hæd faʊnd ɡɹeɪt feɪvɝ. ðəɾ ən ðə fæk ðət ʃi hæd kʌm stʃɹeɪt tə ɪljən vaɪə wʌn ə ðoʊz pəkjuljɝ ɡeɪtweɪz, woʊvən baɪ hɝ oʊn wɪndfɪndɝ, wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli ɹizənz ðət ʃi wɑz naʊ mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps, bʌt niðɝ hæd hɝɾ əɹ kɑz. hɑɹɪn hɝsɛlf θɔt ðɪs tʃɹævlɪŋ oʊvɝɹeɪɾɪd. ʃələn kəd meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ, naʊ, bʌt meɪkɪŋ wʌn tə ðə dɛk ʌv ə ʃɪp wɪθaʊt kɑzɪŋ dæmədʒ, ivən ɑn stɪl wɔɾɝz laɪk ðiz, ɪspɛʃli fɹəm ðə dɛk ʌv ənʌðɝ ʃɪp, wɑz tʃænsi ət bɛst, ən noʊ wʌn kəd meɪk wʌn lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə seɪl ə ʃɪp θɹu. vɛɹi oʊvɝɹeɪɾɪd.

As usual, Zaida arrived without ceremony, striding in followed by Shielyn, her Windfinder, tall and slim and reserved, and Amylia, the bosomy, pale-haired Aes Sedai Zaida had brought back with her from Caemlyn. Ageless face seeming permanently surprised, her startling blue eyes very wide, the Aes Sedai was breathing heavily for some reason. Everyone bowed, but Zaida paid the courtesies no heed. In green brocades and white mourning stole, she was short, with a close cap of graying curls, yet she managed to make herself seem every bit as tall as Shielyn. A matter of presence, Harine had to admit. Zaida had that, and a coolness of thought that being caught by a cemaros on a lee shore could not shake. In addition to returning with the first of the Aes Sedai agreed to in the bargain for use of the Bowl of the Winds, she also had returned with her own bargain, for land in Andor under Atha'an Miere law, and where Harine's Bargain had been judged wanting, Zaida's had found great favor. That and the fact that she had come straight to Illian via one of those peculiar gateways, woven by her own Windfinder, were not the only reasons that she was now Mistress of the Ships, but neither had hurt her cause. Harine herself thought this Traveling overrated. Shalon could make a gateway, now, but making one to the deck of a ship without causing damage, even on still waters like these, especially from the deck of another ship, was chancy at best, and no one could make one large enough to sail a ship through. Very overrated.

"ðə mæn əz nɑɾ ɝaɪv jɛt," zeɪɾə ənaʊnst, teɪkɪŋ ðə tʃɛɹ wɪð ɪts bæk tə ðə lɑɹdʒ stɝn wɪndoʊz ən ɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ lɔŋ, fɹɪn ɹɛd sæʃ dʒʌst soʊ, ədʒʌstɪŋ ði æŋɡəl ə ði ɛmɹəld-stʌɾɪd dæɡɝ θɹʌs θɹu ðə sæʃ. ʃi wɑz ə vɛɹi pɝtɪkjəlɝ wʊmən. ɪt wɑz nætʃɹəl ɪnʌf tə wɑn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ɪts pleɪs ɑn bɔɹɾ ə ʃɪp - taɪdinəs bɪkeɪm ə hæbəɾ əz wɛl əz ə nəsɛsəɾi - jɛt ʃi wɑz ɪɡzæktɪŋ ivən baɪ ðə juʒəwəl stændɝdz. ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ tʃɛɹz, nʌn fæsən tə ðə dɛk ɪn pɹɑpɝ fæʃən, meɪd tu ɹoʊz feɪsɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ, ən ðə weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz bɪɡæn teɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ sits, itʃ wʊmənz wɪndfɪndɝ stændɪŋ bɪhaɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. "ɪɾ əpɪɹz i ɪntɛnz əs tə weɪɾ ɑn hɪm. æmɪliə, si ðət ðə ɡoʊbləts ɑɹ ɔl fɪld." ɑ. ɪt sim ðə wʊmən hæd pʊɾ əɹ fʊt ɹɔŋ jɛɾ əɡɛn.

"The man has not arrived yet," Zaida announced, taking the chair with its back to the large stern windows and arranging her long, fringed red sash just so, adjusting the angle of the emerald-studded dagger thrust through the sash. She was a very particular woman. It was natural enough to want everything in its place on board a ship - tidiness became a habit as well as a necessity - yet she was exacting even by the usual standards. The remaining chairs, none fastened to the deck in proper fashion, made two rows facing each other, and the Wavemistresses began taking their seats, each woman's Windfinder standing behind her chair. "It appears he intends us to wait on him. Amylia, see that the goblets are all filled." Ah. It seemed the woman had put her foot wrong yet again.

æmɪliə dʒʌmpt, ðən ɡæðɝɾ əɹ bɹɑnz-kʌlɝd skɝts tə hɝ niz ən wɛn ɹeɪsɪŋ fəɹ ðə teɪbəl wɛɹ ðə waɪn pɪtʃɝz sæt. bædli ɹɔŋ, ɪɾ əpɪɹd. hɑɹɪn wʌndɝd haʊ lɔŋ zeɪɾə wəd kəntɪnju tə əlaʊ hɝ tə wɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz ɹæðɝ ðən tʃɹaʊzɝz, wɪtʃ wɝ mʌtʃ mɔɹ pɹæktəkəl ʃɪpbɔɹd. ɪt wəd ʃʊɹli bi ə ʃɑk tə hɝ wən ðeɪ pæs bɪɑn saɪɾ ə læn ən blaʊsəz wɝ əbændənd. ʌv ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, æmɪliə hæd wɑntəd tə stʌɾi ði æθɑn maɪɹ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɡɪvən lɪɾəl taɪm fəɹ stʌɾi. hɝ pɝpəs wɑz tə wɝk, ən zeɪɾə sɔ ðət ʃi dɪd. ʃi wɑz ðəɹ tə titʃ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ɔl ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ nu. ʃi stɪl dɪðɝɾ oʊvɝ ðæt, bʌt ʃɔɹbaʊn ɪnstʃɹʌktɝz, ɹɛɹ əz ðeɪ wɝ, ɹæŋk bɛɹli ə wɪskɝ əbʌv ðə dɛkhənz - ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, ðə wʊmən əpɛɹənli hæd bɪlivd əɹ dɪɡnəɾi fʊli ikwəl tə zeɪɾəz ɪf nɑt mɔɹ! - ən ðə dɛkmæstɝz fleɪl leɪd wɪð səm fɹikwən ɹɛɡjəlɛɹəɾi əkɹɔs əɹ ɹʌmp səpoʊzədli wɑz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ maɪnd, ɪf sloʊli. æmɪliə hæɾ æktʃəli  tʃɹaɪd tə dɪzɝt θɹi taɪmz! stʃɹeɪnʒli, ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ, nɑlədʒ ðət kɛɹfəli wɑz biɪŋ kɛp fɹəm hɝ, ən ʃʊɾə əv noʊn ʃi wɑz biɪŋ wɑtʃt tu kloʊsli tə bɹaɪb əɹ weɪ ɑntu ə bʌmboʊt. wɛl, ʃi wɑz ənlaɪkli tə tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn. ɹɪpɔɹɾədli ʃi hæd bɪn toʊl ðəɾ ə fɔɹθ ətɛmpt wəɾ ɝn ə pʌblɪk stʃɹæpɪŋ ðɪs taɪm fɑloʊd baɪ biɪŋ hʌŋ baɪ hɝ æŋkəlz ɪn ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ. noʊ wʌn wəd ɹɪsk ðət ʃeɪm, ʃʊɹli. seɪlməstʃɹɛsəz ən ivən weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz hæd bɪn ɹədus tə dɛkhənz ən ɡɔn wɪlɪŋli æftɝ ðæt, iɡɝ tə luz ðɛmsɛlvz ən ðɛɹ dɪsɡɹeɪs ɪn ðə mæs ə mɛn ən wɪmən hɔlɪŋ laɪnz ən hænlɪŋ seɪl.

Amylia jumped, then gathered her bronze-colored skirts to her knees and went racing for the table where the wine pitchers sat. Badly wrong, it appeared. Harine wondered how long Zaida would continue to allow her to wear dresses rather than trousers, which were much more practical shipboard. It would surely be a shock to her when they passed beyond sight of land and blouses were abandoned. Of the Brown Ajah, Amylia had wanted to study the Atha'an Miere, but she was given little time for study. Her purpose was to work, and Zaida saw that she did. She was there to teach the Windfinders all that the Aes Sedai knew. She still dithered over that, but shorebound instructors, rare as they were, ranked barely a whisker above the deckhands - in the beginning, the woman apparently had believed her dignity fully equal to Zaida's if not more! - and the deckmaster's flail laid with some frequent regularity across her rump supposedly was changing her mind, if slowly. Amylia had actually tried to desert three times! Strangely, she did not know how to make a gateway, knowledge that carefully was being kept from her, and she should have known she was being watched too closely to bribe her way onto a bumboat. Well, she was unlikely to try again. Reportedly she had been told that a fourth attempt would earn a public strapping this time followed by being hung by her ankles in the rigging. No one would risk that shame, surely. Sailmistresses and even Wavemistresses had been reduced to deckhands and gone willingly after that, eager to lose themselves and their disgrace in the mass of men and women hauling lines and handling sail.

ɹimuvɪŋ ðə kʊʃən fɹəm ðə siɾ ə hɝ tʃɛɹ ən dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪt dɪsdeɪnfəli ɑn ðə dɛk, hɑɹɪn tʊk əɹ pleɪs ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə lɛft-hæn ɹoʊ, ʃələn əɾ əɹ bæk. ʃi wɑz ðə list sinjɝ ɪksɛp fəɹ mɑɹaɪl, siɾəd əkɹɔs fɹəm hɝ. bʌt ðɛn, zeɪɾə wʊɾə sæɾ oʊnli wʌn tʃɛɹ fɑɹðɝ ʌp hæd ʃi nɑt ɡeɪn ðə sɪksθ fæt ɡoʊldən ɪɹɪŋ fəɹ itʃ ɪɹ ən ðə tʃeɪnz ðət kənɛktəd ðɛm. hɝ loʊbz maɪt stɪl bi sɔɹ fɹəm ðə pɪɹsɪŋz. ə plɛzən θɔt. "æz i meɪks əs weɪt, pɝhæps wi ʃəd meɪk ɪm weɪt wən i faɪnəli dʌz əpɪɹ." wɪð ən əntʌtʃt ɡɑbləɾ ɪn hænd, ʃi weɪvd əweɪ ði æŋkʃəs ɛɛs sədaɪ, hu skɝiɾ oʊvɝ tə mɑɹaɪl. fulɪʃ wʊmən. dɪd ʃi nɑt noʊ ʃi ʃʊɾə sɝv ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps fɝst ən ðən fɑloʊd wɪð ðə weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz baɪ sinjɔɹɪɾi?

Removing the cushion from the seat of her chair and dropping it disdainfully on the deck, Harine took her place at the bottom of the left-hand row, Shalon at her back. She was the least senior except for Mareil, seated across from her. But then, Zaida would have sat only one chair farther up had she not gained the sixth fat golden earring for each ear and the chains that connected them. Her lobes might still be sore from the piercings. A pleasant thought. "As he makes us wait, perhaps we should make him wait when he finally does appear." With an untouched goblet in hand, she waved away the anxious Aes Sedai, who scurried over to Mareil. Foolish woman. Did she not know she should have served the Mistress of the Ships first and then followed with the Wavemistresses by seniority?

zeɪɾə tɔɪd wɪð əɹ pɪɹswɝk sɛn bɑks, hæŋɪŋ ɑn ə vɛɹi hɛvi ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. ʃi wɔɹ ə waɪd, kloʊs-fɪɾɪŋ kɑlɝ ə hɛvi ɡoʊld lɪŋks, tu, ə ɡɪft fɹəm ɪleɪn ʌv ændɝ. "hi kʌmz fɹəm ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "hum jə wɝ səpoʊz tə stɪk tə laɪk ə bɑɹnəkəl." hɝ vɔɪs nɛvɝ hɑɹɾənd, bʌɾ ɛvɹi wɝd kʌɾ ət hɑɹɪn. "ðɪs mæn wɪl bi əz kloʊz əz aɪ kən kʌm tə spikɪŋ tə ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ wɪθaʊt daɪɹ nid, sɪns jə əɡɹiɾ i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə ətɛn mi mɔɹ ðən θɹi taɪmz ɪn ɛni pɪɹiəɾ ə tu jɪɹz. kəz ə ju, aɪ mʌst æksɛp ðɪs mænz dɪskɔɝɾɪsi ɪf i tɝnz aʊt tə bi ə skəbɹəs dʒɹʌŋkɝɾ u mʌst ɹʌn tə ðə ɹeɪl ən ɛmpti hɪz stʌmək ɛvɹi sɛkən sɛntəns. ði æmbæsəɾɝ aɪ sɛn tə ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ wɪl bi sʌmwʌn u noʊz haʊ tə oʊbeɪ hɝ ɔɹɾɝz." pɛlænə tɪɾɝd ən smɝkt. ʃi θɔɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz laɪk hɝsɛlf.

Zaida toyed with her piercework scent box, hanging on a very heavy golden chain around her neck. She wore a wide, close-fitting collar of heavy gold links, too, a gift from Elayne of Andor. "He comes from the Coramoor," she said dryly, "whom you were supposed to stick to like a barnacle." Her voice never hardened, but every word cut at Harine. "This man will be as close as I can come to speaking to the Coramoor without dire need, since you agreed he did not have to attend me more than three times in any period of two years. Because of you, I must accept this man's discourtesy if he turns out to be a scabrous drunkard who must run to the rail and empty his stomach every second sentence. The ambassador I send to the Coramoor will be someone who knows how to obey her orders." Pelanna tittered and smirked. She thought everyone was like herself.

ʃələn skwiz hɑɹɪnz ʃoʊldɝ ɹiəʃɝɪŋli, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt niɾ ɪt. steɪ wɪð ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ? ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ ʃi kəɾ ɪkspleɪn tə ɛniwʌn, ivən ʃələn, kædzueɪnz ɹud mɛθədz ʌv ɛnfɔɹsɪŋ əɹ wɪl əɹ əɹ toʊɾəl læk ə ɹɪspɛk fəɹ hɑɹɪnz dɪɡnəɾi. ʃi hæd bɪn ən æmbæsəɾɝ fɹəm ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɪn neɪm, ən fɔɹs tə dæns tə ɛni tun ði ɛɛs sədaɪ paɪpt. ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə ədmɪt, ɪf oʊnli tə hɝsɛlf, ðət ʃi hæɾ ɔlmoʊst wɛpt wɪð ɹɪlif wən ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət kɝst wʊmən wɑz gɑnə lɛɾ əɹ liv. bɪsaɪdz, ðət ɡɝlz vɪʒənz ɔlweɪz keɪm tʃɹu. soʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd, ən ðeɪ kəd nɑt laɪ. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf.

Shalon squeezed Harine's shoulder reassuringly, but she did not need it. Stay with the Coramoor? There was no way she could explain to anyone, even Shalon, Cadsuane's rude methods of enforcing her will or her total lack of respect for Harine's dignity. She had been an ambassador from the Atha'an Miere in name, and forced to dance to any tune the Aes Sedai piped. She was willing to admit, if only to herself, that she had almost wept with relief when she realized that cursed woman was going to let her leave. Besides, that girl's visions always came true. So the Aes Sedai said, and they could not lie. It was enough.

tʃɹeɪn slɪpt ɪndə ðə kæbən ən baʊd tə zeɪɾə. "ðə kɔɹəmʊɹz ɛməsɛɹi hæz ɝaɪvd, ʃɪpməstʃɹəs. hi . . . hi stɛpt aʊɾ ʌv ə ɡeɪtweɪ ɑn ðə kɔɹɾɝdɛk." ðət kɹieɪɾəd mɝmɝz əmʌŋ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, ən æmɪliə dʒɝkt əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd fɛl ðə dɛkmæstɝz fleɪl əɡɛn.

Turane slipped into the cabin and bowed to Zaida. "The Coramoor's emissary has arrived, Shipmistress. He . . . he stepped out of a gateway on the quarterdeck." That created murmurs among the Windfinders, and Amylia jerked as though she had felt the deckmaster's flail again.

"aɪ hoʊp i dɪd nɑt dæmədʒ jəɹ dɛk tu bædli, tʃɹeɪn," zeɪɾə sɛd. hɑɹɪn sɪpt waɪn tə haɪɾ əɹ smɔl smaɪl. əpɛɹənli ðə mæn wɑz tə bi meɪd tə weɪɾ ə lɪɾəl, ət list.

"I hope he did not damage your deck too badly, Turane," Zaida said. Harine sipped wine to hide her small smile. Apparently the man was to be made to wait a little, at least.

"nɑɾ əɾ ɔl, ʃɪpməstʃɹəs." tʃɹeɪn saʊndəd sɝpɹaɪzd. "ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən ə ɡʊd fʊɾ əbʌv ðə dɛk, ən i stɛp θɹu fɹəm wʌn ə ðə sɪɾiz dɑks."

"Not at all, Shipmistress." Turane sounded surprised. "The gateway opened a good foot above the deck, and he stepped through from one of the city's docks."

"jɛs," ʃələn wɪspɝd. "aɪ kən si haʊ tə də ðæt." ʃi θɔɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə paʊɝ wɑz wʌndɝfəl.

"Yes," Shalon whispered. "I can see how to do that." She thought anything to do with the Power was wonderful.

"ðæt mʌst əv ə ʃɑk, siɪŋ ə stoʊn dɑk əbʌv jəɹ kɔɹɾɝdɛk," zeɪɾə sɛd. "vɛɹi wɛl. əl si wɛðɝ ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ əz sɛn mi ə skəbɹəs dʒɹʌŋkɝd. sɛn ɪm ɪn, tʃɹeɪn. bʌt də nɑt ɹʌʃ. æmɪliə, æm aɪ tə ɡɛɾ ɛni waɪn bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl?"

"That must have a shock, seeing a stone dock above your quarterdeck," Zaida said. "Very well. I will see whether the Coramoor has sent me a scabrous drunkard. Send him in, Turane. But do not rush. Amylia, am I to get any wine before nightfall?"

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡæspt ænd, meɪkɪŋ lɪɾəl wɪmpɝz əz ɪf ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə tɪɹz, ɹʌʃt tə fɛtʃ ə ɡɑbləɾ əz tʃɹeɪn baʊɾ ən lɛft. laɪt, wʌt hæɾ æmɪliə dʌn? lɔŋ moʊməns pæst, ən zeɪɾə hæɾ əɹ waɪn wɛl bɪfɔɹ ə lɑɹdʒ mæn wɪð dɑɹk hɛɹ kɝlɪŋ tə hɪz bɹɔd ʃoʊldɝz ɛntɝd ðə kæbən. hi sɝɾənli wɑz nɑt skəbɹəs, nɔɹ dɪɾ i əpɪɹ dʒɹʌŋk. ðə haɪ kɑlɝ ə hɪz blæk koʊt hɛld ə sɪlvɝ pɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə sɔɹɾ ɑn wʌn saɪd, ən ɑn ði ʌðɝ ə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl pɪn ʃeɪp laɪk wʌn ə ðə kɹitʃɝz ðəɾ ɛntwaɪn ðə kɔɹəmʊɹz fɹɑɹmz. ə dʒɹæɡən. jɛs, ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɪt wɑz kɔld. ə ɹaʊn pɪn fæsən tə hɪz lɛft ʃoʊldɝ ʃoʊd θɹi ɡoʊldən kɹaʊnz əɡɛns blu ɪnæməl. ə sɪdʒəl, pɝhæps? wɑz i ə ʃɔɹbaʊnd noʊbəl? kəd ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ æktʃəli  hæv dʌn zeɪɾə ɑnɝ ɪn sɛndɪŋ ðɪs mæn? noʊɪŋ ɹænd ælθɹ əz ʃi dɪd, ʃi daʊɾɪd ɪt hæd bɪn ɪntɛnʃənəl. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðəɾ i tʃɹaɪd tə dɪsɑnɝ ɛniwʌn, jɛɾ i kɛɹd lɪɾəl fəɹ ði ɑnɝz ʌv ʌðɝz.

The Aes Sedai gasped and, making little whimpers as if on the point of tears, rushed to fetch a goblet as Turane bowed and left. Light, what had Amylia done? Long moments passed, and Zaida had her wine well before a large man with dark hair curling to his broad shoulders entered the cabin. He certainly was not scabrous, nor did he appear drunk. The high collar of his black coat held a silver pin in the shape of a sword on one side, and on the other a red-and-gold pin shaped like one of the creatures that entwined the Coramoor's forearms. A dragon. Yes, that was what it was called. A round pin fastened to his left shoulder showed three golden crowns against blue enamel. A sigil, perhaps? Was he a shorebound noble? Could the Coramoor actually have done Zaida honor in sending this man? Knowing Rand al'Thor as she did, she doubted it had been intentional. It was not that he tried to dishonor anyone, yet he cared little for the honors of others.

hi baʊd tə zeɪɾə, hænlɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd smuðli, bʌɾ i feɪl tə tʌtʃ hɑɹɾ ən lɪps ən fɔɹhɛd. stɪl, səm ʃɔɹtkʌmɪŋz hæd tə bi oʊvɝlʊkt wɪð ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd. "aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz ɪf aɪ ɝaɪv leɪt, ʃɪpməstʃɹəs," hi sɛd, "bʌɾ ɪt simd ənnɛsəsɛɹi tə kʌm bɪfɔɹ ɔl ə jəɹ nʌmbɝ wɝ hɪɹ." hi mʌst əv ə vɛɹi ɡʊd lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs tə hæv əbzɝv ðət fɹəm ðə dɑks.

He bowed to Zaida, handling the sword at his side smoothly, but he failed to touch heart and lips and forehead. Still, some shortcomings had to be overlooked with the shorebound. "I apologize if I arrive late, Shipmistress," he said, "but it seemed unnecessary to come before all of your number were here." He must have a very good looking glass to have observed that from the docks.

stʌɾiɪŋ ɪm ʌp ən daʊn wɪð ə fɹaʊn, zeɪɾə sɪpt əɹ waɪn. "ju hæv ə neɪm?"

Studying him up and down with a frown, Zaida sipped her wine. "You have a name?"

"aɪ æm lɑɡən," hi sɛd sɪmpli.

"I am Logain," he said simply.

hæf ðə wɪmən ɪn ðə ɹum ɛksheɪld ʃɑɹpli, ən moʊst ə ðə ɹɛs lɛt ðɛɹ dʒɔz dʒɹɑp. mɔɹ ðən wʌn slɑpt waɪn fɹəm əɹ ɡɑblət. nɑt zeɪɾə, ən nɑt hɑɹɪn, bʌt ði ʌðɝz. lɑɡən. ðət wɑz ə neɪm noʊn ivən tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ.

Half the women in the room exhaled sharply, and most of the rest let their jaws drop. More than one slopped wine from her goblet. Not Zaida, and not Harine, but the others. Logain. That was a name known even to the Atha'an Miere.

"meɪ aɪ spik, ʃɪpməstʃɹəs?" æmɪliə æsk bɹɛθəli. ʃi wɑz klʌtʃɪŋ ðə pɔɹsələn pɪtʃɝ soʊ hɑɹd ðət hɑɹɪn fɪɹɾ ɪt maɪt ʃæɾɝ ɪn əɹ hænz, bʌt ðə wʊmən hæd lɝn ɪnʌf sɛns tə seɪ noʊ mɔɹ əntɪl zeɪɾə nɑɾəd. ðən wɝdz spɪl fɹəm əɹ ɪn ə bɹɛθləs ɹʌʃ. "ðɪs mæn wɑz ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. hi wɑz dʒɛntəl fəɹ ɪt. haʊ ɪts i kən tʃænəl əɡɛn, aɪ kænɑt noʊ, bʌɾ i tʃænəlz seɪɾɪn. seɪɾɪn! hiz teɪntɪd, ʃɪpməstʃɹəs. ɪf jə dil wɪð hɪm, jəl ɪnkɝ ðə ɹæθ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. aɪ noʊ - "

"May I speak, Shipmistress?" Amylia asked breathily. She was clutching the porcelain pitcher so hard that Harine feared it might shatter in her hands, but the woman had learned enough sense to say no more until Zaida nodded. Then words spilled from her in a breathless rush. "This man was a false Dragon. He was gentled for it. How it is he can channel again, I cannot know, but he channels saidin. Saidin! He is tainted, Shipmistress. If you deal with him, you will incur the wrath of the White Tower. I know - "

"ɪnʌf," zeɪɾə kʌɾ ɪn. "ju ʃəd bi wɛl əwɛɹ baɪ naʊ haʊ mʌtʃ aɪ fɪɹ ðə ɹæθ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"Enough," Zaida cut in. "You should be well aware by now how much I fear the wrath of the White Tower."

"bʌt - !" zeɪɾə hɛld ʌp ə sɪŋɡəl fɪŋɡɝ, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪz maʊθ snæpt ʃʌt, hɝ lɪps twɪstɪŋ ɪn ə sɪkli fæʃən. ðət wʌn wɝd maɪt lɛd tə hɝ kɪsɪŋ ðə dɛkmæstɝz sɪstɝ əɡɛn, ən ʃi nu ɪt.

"But - !" Zaida held up a single finger, and the Aes Sedai's mouth snapped shut, her lips twisting in a sickly fashion. That one word might lead to her kissing the deckmaster's sister again, and she knew it.

"wʌt ʃi sɛz ɪz tʃɹu ɪn pɑɹt," lɑɡən sɛd kɑmli. "aɪ æm ən æʃəmən, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz noʊ teɪn ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. seɪɾɪn ɪz klin. ðə kɹieɪɾɝ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ʃoʊ əs mɝsi, ɪt simz. aɪ hæv ə kwɛstʃən fəɹ hɝ. hum dʒju sɝv, ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ əɹ ɪleɪɾə ɹɔɪhən?" waɪzli, æmɪliə kɛpt əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt.

"What she says is true in part," Logain said calmly. "I am an Asha'man, but there is no taint any longer. Saidin is clean. The Creator decided to show us mercy, it seems. I have a question for her. Whom do you serve, Aes Sedai, Egwene al'Vere or Elaida a'Roihan?" Wisely, Amylia kept her mouth shut.

"fɔɹ ðə nɛks jɪɹ, ʃi sɝvz mi, lɑɡən," zeɪɾə sɛd fɝmli. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ skwizd əɹ peɪl aɪz ʃʌt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən wən ðeɪ oʊpən əɡɛn, ðeɪ wɝ ivən waɪɾɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ, ɪmpɑsəbəl əz ðət simd, ən ðeɪ hɛld ə lʊk ə hɔɹɝ. wɑz ɪt pɑsəbəl ʃi hæd bɪliv zeɪɾə maɪt ɹɪlɛn ən lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ ɝli? "ju kən kənfaɪn jəɹ kwɛstʃənz tə mi," ðə ʃɪpməstʃɹəs wɛn ɑn, "bʌt fɝst, aɪ hæv tu fəɹ ju. wɛɹ ɪz ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ? aɪ mʌst sɛn ən æmbæsəɾɝ tə hɪm, ən i mʌs kip əɹ kloʊs, ɪn əkɔɹɾəns wɪð ðə bɑɹɡən. ɹimaɪn ɪm ə ðæt. ən wʌt mɛsədʒ dʒju bɹɪŋ fɹəm hɪm? ə ɹɪkwɛs fəɹ səm sɝvəs, aɪ səpoʊz."

"For the next year, she serves me, Logain," Zaida said firmly. The Aes Sedai squeezed her pale eyes shut for a moment, and when they opened again, they were even wider than before, impossible as that seemed, and they held a look of horror. Was it possible she had believed Zaida might relent and let her go early? "You can confine your questions to me," the Shipmistress went on, "but first, I have two for you. Where is the Coramoor? I must send an ambassador to him, and he must keep her close, in accordance with the Bargain. Remind him of that. And what message do you bring from him? A request for some service, I suppose."

"æz tə wɛɹ i ɪz, aɪ kænɑt seɪ." ðə mæn smaɪl slaɪtli, əz ɪf i hæd meɪɾ ə dʒoʊk. hi smaɪld!

"As to where he is, I cannot say." The man smiled slightly, as if he had made a joke. He smiled!

"aɪ dɪmænd," zeɪɾə bɪɡæn, bʌɾ i kʌɾ əɹ ɔf, pɹəvoʊkɪŋ æŋɡɹi mʌɾɝz ən hɑt ɡlɛɹz fɹəm ði ʌðɝ wɪmən. ðə ful sim tə θɪŋk i wɑz ən ikwəl tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps!

"I demand," Zaida began, but he cut her off, provoking angry mutters and hot glares from the other women. The fool seemed to think he was an equal to the Mistress of the Ships!

"hi wɑns ɪz wɛɹəbaʊts kɛp sikɹət fəɹ naʊ, ʃɪpməstʃɹəs. ðə fɔɹseɪkən əv meɪɾ ɛfɝts tə kɪl hɪm. aɪm wɪlɪŋ tə teɪk hɑɹɪn dɪn toʊɡɑɹə wɪð mi, haʊɛvɝ. fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ hɝd, aɪ θɪŋk i faʊn əɹ æksɛptəbəl."

"He wants his whereabouts kept secret for now, Shipmistress. The Forsaken have made efforts to kill him. I am willing to take Harine din Togara with me, however. From what I heard, I think he found her acceptable."

hɑɹɪn dʒɝk soʊ hɑɹd ʃi spɪld waɪn oʊvɝ ðə bæk ə hɝ hænd, ðən tʊk ənʌðɝ lɔŋ swɑloʊ. bʌt, noʊ, zeɪɾə wəd dɪvɔɹs əməl ən mɛɹi ə bæləst stoʊn bɪfɔɹ ʃi sɛn hɑɹɪn dɪn toʊɡɑɹə əz əɹ æmbæsəɾɝ. stɪl, ivən ðə θɔɾ ʌv ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ tʌŋ stɪk tə ðə ɹuf ə hɝ maʊθ. ivən bɪkʌmɪŋ mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps maɪt bi ɪnsəfɪʃən ɹɛkəmpɛns fəɹ biɪŋ fɔɹs tə ɛndʒjʊɹ kædzueɪn ɛni lɔŋɡɝ.

Harine jerked so hard she spilled wine over the back of her hand, then took another long swallow. But, no, Zaida would divorce Amel and marry a ballast stone before she sent Harine din Togara as her ambassador. Still, even the thought of it was enough to make her tongue stick to the roof of her mouth. Even becoming Mistress of the Ships might be insufficient recompense for being forced to endure Cadsuane any longer.

stʌɾiɪŋ lɑɡən wɪð ə stoʊni feɪs, zeɪɾə toʊld æmɪliə tə pɔɹ waɪn fəɹ hɪm. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ flɪntʃt, ən baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi ɹitʃt ðə teɪbəl, ʃi wɑz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd ðət ðə pɪtʃɝz spaʊt klæɾɝd ɑn ðə ɹɪm ə ðə ɡɑblət. ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ waɪn wɛn ɑntu ðə dɛk əz ɪnsaɪd ðə ɡɑblət. stʃɹeɪnʒli, lɑɡən wɔkt oʊvɝ tə hɝ ən pʊɾ ɪz hænz ɑn hɝz tə stɛɾi hɝ. wɑz i wʌn ə ðoʊz u kəd nɑt liv ʌðɝz tə də ðɛɹ oʊn wɝk?

Studying Logain with a stony face, Zaida told Amylia to pour wine for him. The Aes Sedai flinched, and by the time she reached the table, she was trembling so hard that the pitcher's spout clattered on the rim of the goblet. Almost as much wine went onto the deck as inside the goblet. Strangely, Logain walked over to her and put his hands on hers to steady her. Was he one of those who could not leave others to do their own work?

"juv nʌθɪŋ tə fɪɹ fɹəm mi, æmɪliə sədaɪ," hi toʊl hɝ. "ɪts bɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm sɪns aɪ eɪɾ ɛniwʌn fəɹ bɹɛkfəst." ʃi stɛɹɾ ʌp əɾ ɪm wɪð əɹ maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən əz ðoʊ ənsɝɾən wɛðɝ i wɑz meɪkɪŋ ə dʒoʊk.

"You've nothing to fear from me, Amylia Sedai," he told her. "It's been a long time since I ate anyone for breakfast." She stared up at him with her mouth hanging open as though uncertain whether he was making a joke.

"æn ðə sɝvəs i ɹɪkwɛsts?" zeɪɾə sɛd.

"And the service he requests?" Zaida said.

"nɑɾ ə ɹɪkwɛst, ʃɪpməstʃɹəs." hi hæd tə stʃɹeɪɾən ðə pɪtʃɝ tə kip ðə ɡɑblət fɹəm oʊvɝfloʊɪŋ. teɪkɪŋ ðə ɡɑblət, hi stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm æmɪliə, bʌt ʃi stʊd ɡeɪpɪŋ əɾ ɪz bæk. laɪt, bʌt ðə wʊmən faʊnd noʊ ɛn ʌv weɪz tə ɡɛɾ ɪndə tʃɹʌbəl. "ə kɔl ɑn jəɹ saɪɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən wɪð ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ. əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz, jə pɹɑməst ɪm ʃɪps, ən i nidz ʃɪps tə kæɹi fuɾ ən ʌðɝ səplaɪz tə bændɑɹ ɛbən fɹəm ɪljən ən tiɹ."

"Not a request, Shipmistress." He had to straighten the pitcher to keep the goblet from overflowing. Taking the goblet, he stepped away from Amylia, but she stood gaping at his back. Light, but the woman found no end of ways to get into trouble. "A call on your side of the Bargain with the Coramoor. Among other things, you promised him ships, and he needs ships to carry food and other supplies to Bandar Eban from Illian and Tear."

"ðæt kən bi dʌn," zeɪɾə sɛd, nɑt kwaɪt mæskɪŋ əɹ ɹɪlif, ðoʊ ʃi ʃɑɾ ə fɹaʊn ət hɑɹɪn. pɛlænə ɡlɛɹɾ əz wɛl, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt soʊ dɪd lɑsin ən niɑl ən sɛvɹəl ʌðɝz. hɑɹɪn səpɹɛst ə saɪ.

"That can be done," Zaida said, not quite masking her relief, though she shot a frown at Harine. Pelanna glared as well, of course, but so did Lacine and Niolle and several others. Harine suppressed a sigh.

səm ə ðə dɪteɪlz ə ðə bɑɹɡən wɝ kwaɪɾ oʊnɝəs, ʃi hæd tə ədmɪt, sətʃ əz ðə ɹɪkwaɪɹmən ðət ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps bi pɹipɛɹd tə ətɛn ɪm ʌp tə θɹi taɪmz ɪn ɛni tu jɪɹz. ðə dʒɛndaɪ pɹɑfəsi sɛd ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɝ tə sɝv ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, jɛt fju əpɪnjənz ə haʊ ðeɪ wɝ tə sɝv ɪnkluɾəd ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps ɡoʊɪŋ ɹʌnɪŋ wən i kɔld. bʌt ði ʌðɝz hæd nɑt bɪn ðɛɹ, bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ kənvɪns ðət ʃi hæd noʊ ɔltɝnəɾɪv tə meɪkɪŋ wʌtɛvɝ bɑɹɡən ʃi kʊd. tʃɹuθ ə ðə laɪt, ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ ʃi hæd ɡɑɾən əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi hæd!

Some of the details of the Bargain were quite onerous, she had to admit, such as the requirement that the Mistress of the Ships be prepared to attend him up to three times in any two years. The Jendai Prophecy said the Atha'an Miere were to serve the Coramoor, yet few opinions of how they were to serve included the Mistress of the Ships going running when he called. But the others had not been there, bargaining with Aes Sedai convinced that she had no alternative to making whatever Bargain she could. Truth of the Light, it was a wonder she had gotten as much as she had!

"səplaɪz fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə mɪljən pipəl, ʃɪpməstʃɹəs," lɑɡən æɾəd əz kæʒəwəli əz ɪf i wɝ æskɪŋ fəɹ ənʌðɝ ɡɑbləɾ ʌv waɪn. "haʊ mɛni mɔɹ, aɪ kænɑt seɪ, bʌt bændɑɹ ɛbən ɪtsɛlf ɪz stɑɹvɪŋ. ðə ʃɪps mʌst ɝaɪv əz sun əz pɑsəbəl."

"Supplies for more than a million people, Shipmistress," Logain added as casually as if he were asking for another goblet of wine. "How many more, I cannot say, but Bandar Eban itself is starving. The ships must arrive as soon as possible."

ʃɑk ɹɪpəl θɹu ðə kæbən. hɑɹɪn wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn ɪn teɪkɪŋ ə lɔŋ dʒɹɪŋk ʌv waɪn. ivən zeɪɾəz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn əmeɪzmənt. "ðæt maɪt ɹikwaɪɝ mɔɹ ɹeɪkɝz ðən wi pəzɛs," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst, əneɪbəl tə kip ði ɪnkɹədulɪɾi fɹəm əɹ vɔɪs.

Shock rippled through the cabin. Harine was not alone in taking a long drink of wine. Even Zaida's eyes widened in amazement. "That might require more rakers than we possess," she said at last, unable to keep the incredulity from her voice.

lɑɡən ʃɹʌɡd əz ðoʊ ðət wɝ ə noʊ əkaʊnt. "ivən soʊ, ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ i ɹikwaɪɝz ə ju. jus ʌðɝ ʃɪps ɪf jə mʌst."

Logain shrugged as though that were of no account. "Even so, that is what he requires of you. Use other ships if you must."

zeɪɾə stɪfən ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. ɹikwaɪɝd. bɑɹɡən əɹ noʊ bɑɹɡən, ðət wɑz ɪmpɹuɾənt læŋɡwədʒ tə juz wɪð hɝ.

Zaida stiffened in her chair. Required. Bargain or no Bargain, that was imprudent language to use with her.

tʃɹeɪn slɪpt ɪndə ðə kæbən əɡɛn, ən ɪn bɹitʃ ʌv ɔl pɹoʊɾəkɑl, ɹæn tə zeɪɾə, hɝ bɛɹ fit slæpɪŋ ðə dɛk. bɛndɪŋ kloʊs, ʃi wɪspɝɾ ɪndə ðə ʃɪpməstʃɹəsəz ɪɹ. zeɪɾəz feɪs sloʊli tʊk ɑn ə lʊk ə hɔɹɝ. ʃi hæf-ɹeɪzd əɹ sɛn bɑks, ðən ʃʌɾɝəd ən lɛɾ ɪt fɔl tə hɝ bʊzəm.

Turane slipped into the cabin again, and in breach of all protocol, ran to Zaida, her bare feet slapping the deck. Bending close, she whispered into the Shipmistress's ear. Zaida's face slowly took on a look of horror. She half-raised her scent box, then shuddered and let it fall to her bosom.

"sɛn əɹ ɪn," ʃi sɛd. "sɛn əɹ ɪn ɪmiɾiətli. ðəɹ ɪz nuz tə meɪk ən æŋkɝ wip," ʃi wɛn ɑn əz tʃɹeɪn ɹeɪs fɹəm ðə kæbən. "aɪ wɪl lɛt jə hɪɹ ɪt fɹəm ʃi hu bɹɔɾ ɪt. jə mʌst weɪt," ʃi æɾəd wən lɑɡən oʊpən ɪz maʊθ. "ju mʌst weɪt." hi hæd səfɪʃən sɛns tə hoʊld ɪz pis, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə haɪɾ ɪz ɪmpeɪʃəns, stɔkɪŋ tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə kæbən tə stænd wɪð ɪz maʊθ taɪɾ ən ɪz bɹaʊz dʒɹɔn daʊn.

"Send her in," she said. "Send her in immediately. There is news to make an anchor weep," she went on as Turane raced from the cabin. "I will let you hear it from she who brought it. You must wait," she added when Logain opened his mouth. "You must wait." He had sufficient sense to hold his peace, but not enough to hide his impatience, stalking to the side of the cabin to stand with his mouth tight and his brows drawn down.

ðə jʌŋ wʊmən u ɛntɝɾ ən baʊd dipli tə zeɪɾə wɑz tɔl ən lin, ən ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn lʌvli ɪksɛp ðəɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz hæɡɝd. hɝ blu lɪnən blaʊs ən ɡɹin tʃɹaʊzɝz lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn wɔɹn fəɹ deɪz, ən ʃi sweɪɾ ɑn əɹ fit wɪð wɪɹinəs. hɝ ɑnɝ tʃeɪn hɛld oʊnli ə hændfʊl ə mədæljənz, əz bɪfɪɾɪd əɹ juθ, jɛt hɑɹɪn kəd si ðət noʊ fjuɝ ðən θɹi kəmɛndɪɾ æks ʌv ɡɹeɪt kɝədʒ.

The young woman who entered and bowed deeply to Zaida was tall and lean, and she might have been lovely except that her face was haggard. Her blue linen blouse and green trousers looked as if they had been worn for days, and she swayed on her feet with weariness. Her honor chain held only a handful of medallions, as befitted her youth, yet Harine could see that no fewer than three commended acts of great courage.

"aɪ æm seɪmil dɪn sɛlɑn lɔŋ aɪz, ʃɪpməstʃɹəs," ʃi sɛd hɔɹsli, "seɪlməstʃɹəs ə ðə dɑɹɾɝ wɪn ɹeɪsɝ. aɪ seɪld əz fæst əz aɪ kʊd, bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ ɪts tu leɪt fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ tə bi dʌn. aɪ stɑpt əɾ ɛvɹi aɪlən bɪtwin tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ ən hɪɹ, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz ɔlweɪz tu leɪt." tɪɹz bɪɡæn tə tʃɹɪkəl daʊn əɹ tʃiks, jɛt ʃi simd ʌnəwɛɹ ə ðɛm.

"I am Cemeille din Selaan Long Eyes, Shipmistress," she said hoarsely, "Sailmistress of the darter Wind Racer. I sailed as fast as I could, but I fear it is too late for anything to be done. I stopped at every island between Tremalking and here, but I was always too late." Tears began to trickle down her cheeks, yet she seemed unaware of them.

"tɛl ðə fɝs twɛlv jəɹ sæd nuz ɪn jəɹ oʊn weɪ, ət jəɹ oʊn peɪs," zeɪɾə sɛd dʒɛnli. "æmɪliə, ɡɪv əɹ waɪn!" nɑt dʒɛnli sɛɾ əɾ ɔl. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lɛp tə oʊbeɪ.

"Tell the First Twelve your sad news in your own way, at your own pace," Zaida said gently. "Amylia, give her wine!" Not gently said at all. The Aes Sedai leaped to obey.

"ɔlmoʊs θɹi wiks əɡoʊ," seɪmil sɛd, "æmɑjɹ ɑn tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ bɪɡæn æskɪŋ ðə ɡɪft ə pæsədʒ tə ɛvɹi aɪlənd. ɔlweɪz ə mæn ən ə wʊmən tə itʃ aɪlənd. ðoʊz u æsk fəɹ eɪl sʌmɛɹə ɹɪkwɛstɪd ðeɪ bi pʊɾ ɔf ɪn boʊts aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə lænd wən ðeɪ wɝ toʊl ðət ðə sintʃæn hoʊld ɔl ə sʌmɛɹə." ʃi tʊk ə fʊl ɡɑblət fɹəm æmɪliə, nɑɾɪŋ əɹ θæŋks, ðən dʒɹæŋk dipli.

"Almost three weeks ago," Cemeille said, "Amayar on Tremalking began asking the gift of passage to every island. Always a man and a woman to each island. Those who asked for Aile Somera requested they be put off in boats out of sight of land when they were told that the Seanchan hold all of Somera." She took a full goblet from Amylia, nodding her thanks, then drank deeply.

hɑɹɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd kwɛstʃənɪŋ ɡlænsɪz wɪð mɑɹaɪl, hu ʃʊk əɹ hɛd slaɪtli. noʊ æmɑjɹ hæɾ ɛvɝ ɹɪkwɛstɪd ðə ɡɪft ə pæsədʒ ɪn hɑɹɪnz mɛmɹi, ðoʊ fəɹ ðɛm, ɪt tʃɹuli wɑz ə ɡɪft, wɪð noʊ ɡɪft ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪn ɹɪtɝn. ən ðeɪ əvɔɪɾəd ðə sɔlt, kipɪŋ ðɛɹ smɔl fɪʃɪŋ boʊts kloʊs tə ʃɔɹ, soʊ æskɪŋ tə bi pʊɾ ɔf aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə lænd wɑz əz stʃɹeɪnʒ əz æskɪŋ pæsədʒ. bʌt wʌt kəd bi soʊ daɪɹ ɪn ðɪs?

Harine exchanged questioning glances with Mareil, who shook her head slightly. No Amayar had ever requested the gift of passage in Harine's memory, though for them, it truly was a gift, with no gift expected in return. And they avoided the salt, keeping their small fishing boats close to shore, so asking to be put off out of sight of land was as strange as asking passage. But what could be so dire in this?

"ɔl ə ði æmɑjɹ ɪn ðə pɔɹts lɛft, ivən ðoʊz oʊd mʌni fɹəm ðə ʃɪpjɑɹdz əɹ ðə ɹoʊpɔks, bʌt noʊ wʌn θɔɾ ɛniθɪŋ ʌv ɪt fəɹ tu əɹ θɹi deɪz." ðə waɪn hæd nɑt wɛt seɪmilz θɹoʊɾ ɪnʌf tə mɪɾəɡeɪt əɹ hɔɹsnəs. ʃi skɹʌbd ət ðə tɪɹz ɑn əɹ tʃiks wɪð ðə bæk ə hɝ hænd. "nɑɾ əntɪl wi ɹilaɪz nʌn hæd kʌm bæk. ðə ɡʌvɝnɝ sɛn pipəl tə ði æmɑjɹ vɪlədʒəz, ən ðeɪ faʊnd. . . ." ʃi skwizd əɹ aɪz ʃʌt. "ði æmɑjɹ wɝ ɔl dɛɾ əɹ daɪɪŋ. mɛn, wɪmən" - hɝ vɔɪs bɹoʊk - "tʃɪlʒɹən."

"All of the Amayar in the ports left, even those owed money from the shipyards or the ropewalks, but no one thought anything of it for two or three days." The wine had not wet Cemeille's throat enough to mitigate her hoarseness. She scrubbed at the tears on her cheeks with the back of her hand. "Not until we realized none had come back. The governor sent people to the Amayar villages, and they found. . . ." She squeezed her eyes shut. "The Amayar were all dead or dying. Men, women" - her voice broke - "children."

fjunɝəl kinɪŋ ɹoʊz ɪn ðə kæbən, ən hɑɹɪn wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə ɹilaɪz ðət ʃɹɪl saʊnd wɑz kʌmɪŋ fɹəm əɹ maʊθ, tu. sæɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ən æŋkɝ wip? ðɪs ʃəd meɪk ðə hɛvənz sɑb. noʊ wʌndɝ ðə seɪlməstʃɹəs wɑz hɔɹs. haʊ mɛni aʊɝz, haʊ mɛni deɪz, hæd ʃi kɹaɪd sɪns lɝnɪŋ ə ðɪs kətæstʃɹəfi?

Funeral keening rose in the cabin, and Harine was surprised to realize that shrill sound was coming from her mouth, too. Sad enough to make an anchor weep? This should make the heavens sob. No wonder the Sailmistress was hoarse. How many hours, how many days, had she cried since learning of this catastrophe?

"haʊ?" pɛlænə dɪmændəd wən ðə kinɪŋ daɪd. feɪs dɪstʃɹɔt, ʃi lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. ʃi wɑz hoʊldɪŋ əɹ sɛn bɑks tə hɝ noʊz əz ɪf ðə sɛn kəd sʌmhaʊ wɔɹɾ ɔf ðə stɛntʃ ə ðɪs nuz. "sʌm sɪknəs? spik, wʊmən!"

"How?" Pelanna demanded when the keening died. Face distraught, she leaned forward in her chair. She was holding her scent box to her nose as if the scent could somehow ward off the stench of this news. "Some sickness? Speak, woman!"

"pɔɪzən, weɪvməstʃɹəs," seɪmil ɹɪplaɪd. ʃi stʃɹʌɡəl tə kəmpoʊz hɝsɛlf, bʌt tɪɹz stɪl lik daʊn əɹ feɪs. "ɛvɹiwɛɹ aɪ hæv bɪn, ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm. ðeɪ ɡeɪv ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən ə pɔɪzən ðət pʊɾ əm ɪndə ə dip slip fɹəm wɪtʃ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt weɪkən. ɪt simz ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf ə ðət tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊnd, soʊ mɛni ʌv ði ədʌls tʊk sloʊɝ pɔɪzənz. səm lɪv lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bi faʊn ən tɛl ðə teɪl. ðə ɡɹeɪt hæn ɑn tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ mɛltəd. ðə hɪl wɛɹ ɪt stʊd ɹɪpɔɹɾədli ɪz naʊ ə dip hɑloʊ. ɪt simz ði æmɑjɹ hæd pɹɑfəsiz ðət spoʊk ə ðə hænd, ən wən ɪt wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd, ðeɪ bɪliv ðɪs sɪɡnəl ði ɛn ə taɪm, wʌt ðeɪ kɔl ði ɛn ʌv ɪluʒən. ðeɪ bɪlivd ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ əm tə liv ðɪs . . . ðɪs ɪluʒən" - ʃi læf ðə wɝd bɪɾɝli - "wi kɔl ðə wɝld."

"Poison, Wavemistress," Cemeille replied. She struggled to compose herself, but tears still leaked down her face. "Everywhere I have been, it was the same. They gave their children a poison that put them into a deep sleep from which they did not waken. It seems there was not enough of that to go around, so many of the adults took slower poisons. Some lived long enough to be found and tell the tale. The Great Hand on Tremalking melted. The hill where it stood reportedly is now a deep hollow. It seems the Amayar had prophecies that spoke of the Hand, and when it was destroyed, they believed this signaled the end of time, what they called the end of Illusion. They believed it was time for them to leave this . . . this illusion" - she laughed the word bitterly - "we call the world."

"hæv nʌn bɪn seɪvd?" zeɪɾə æskt. "nʌn əɾ ɔl?" tɪɹz ɡlɪsən ɑn əɹ tʃiks, tu, bʌt hɑɹɪn kəd nɑt fɔlt əɹ ɑn ðæt. hɝ oʊn tʃiks wɝ wɛt.

"Have none been saved?" Zaida asked. "None at all?" Tears glistened on her cheeks, too, but Harine could not fault her on that. Her own cheeks were wet.

"nʌn, ʃɪpməstʃɹəs."

"None, Shipmistress."

zeɪɾə stʊd, ən tɪɹz əɹ noʊ tɪɹz, ʃi hɛl ði ɔɹə ʌv kəmænd, ən əɹ vɔɪs wɑz stɛɾi. "ðə fæstəst ʃɪps mʌs bi sɛn tə ɛvɹi aɪlənd. ivən tə ðoʊz ʌv eɪl sʌmɛɹə. ə weɪ mʌs bi faʊnd. wən ðə sɔl fɝst stɪld æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, ði æmɑjɹ æskt əɹ pɹətɛkʃən fɹəm bɹɪɡænz ən ɹeɪɾɝz, ən wi oʊ ðɛm pɹətɛkʃən stɪl. ɪf wi kən faɪn oʊnli ə hændfʊl u stɪl laɪv, wi stɪl oʊ ɪt."

Zaida stood, and tears or no tears, she held the aura of command, and her voice was steady. "The fastest ships must be sent to every island. Even to those of Aile Somera. A way must be found. When the salt first stilled after the Breaking, the Amayar asked our protection from brigands and raiders, and we owe them protection still. If we can find only a handful who still live, we still owe it."

"ðɪs ɪz əz sæɾ ə stɔɹi əz aɪ hæv ɛvɝ hɝd." lɑɡənz vɔɪs saʊndəd tu laʊɾ əz i wɔk bæk aʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə zeɪɾə. "bʌt jəɹ ʃɪps ɑɹ kəmɪɾəd tə bændɑɹ ɛbən. ɪf jə doʊn əv ɪnʌf ɹeɪkɝz, ðən jə mʌs juz jəɹ ʌðɝ fæst ʃɪps, tu. ɔl ə ðɛm ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi."

"This is as sad a story as I have ever heard." Logain's voice sounded too loud as he walked back out in front of Zaida. "But your ships are committed to Bandar Eban. If you don't have enough rakers, then you must use your other fast ships, too. All of them if necessary."

"ɑɹ jə mæɾ əz wɛl əz hɑɹtləs?" zeɪɾə dɪmændəd. fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps ən fiɾ əpɑɹt, ʃi sim tə bi stændɪŋ ɑn ə kɔɹɾɝdɛk. hɝ ɡlɛɹ stæbd ət lɑɡən. "wi mʌs mɔɹn. wi mʌst seɪv u wi kæn, ən mɔɹn fəɹ ðə kaʊnləs θaʊzənz wi kænɑt seɪv."

"Are you mad as well as heartless?" Zaida demanded. Fists on her hips and feet apart, she seemed to be standing on a quarterdeck. Her glare stabbed at Logain. "We must mourn. We must save who we can, and mourn for the countless thousands we cannot save."

ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv smaɪl fəɹ ɔl ði ɪfɛkt əɹ ɡlɛɹz hæɾ ɑn lɑɡən. əz i spoʊk, ɪt sim tə hɑɹɪn ðət ðə speɪs tɝn tʃɪl ən ðə laɪt dɪmd. ʃi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʊmən tə hʌɡ hɝsɛlf əɡɛns ðət koʊld. "mɔɹn ɪf jə mʌst," hi sɛd, "bʌt mɔɹn ɑn ðə mɑɹtʃ fəɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən."

She might as well have smiled for all the effect her glares had on Logain. As he spoke, it seemed to Harine that the space turned chill and the light dimmed. She was not the only woman to hug herself against that cold. "Mourn if you must," he said, "but mourn on the march for Tarmon Gai'don."

tʃæptɝ twɛntiθɹi

CHAPTER 23

kɔl tə ə sɪɾɪŋ wɪð mæɡlə ən sæliɾə aʊt fəɹ ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, ɹoʊmændə hæd ðə pætʃt bɹaʊn tɛn tə hɝsɛlf, ə blɛsɪɾ ɑpɝtunəɾi tə ɹid, ðoʊ ðə tu mɪsmætʃt bɹæs læmps ɑn ðə smɔl teɪbəl ɡeɪv ɔf ə feɪn jɛt noʊz-ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ sɛn ə ɹænsɪɾ ɔɪl. wʌn hæd tə lɪv wɪð sətʃ θɪŋz ðiz deɪz. səm maɪt kənsɪɾɝ ðə fleɪm, ðə bleɪɾ ən ðə hɑɹɾ ənsimli fəɹ wʌn ə hɝ əteɪnməns ən pəzɪʃən - əz ə ɡɝl ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹbɪɾən sətʃ bʊks - bʌɾ ɪt meɪɾ ən əɡɹiəbəl tʃeɪnʒ fɹəm dʒɹaɪ hɪstɝiz ən tɛɹəfaɪɪŋ ɹɪpɔɹts ə fud spɔɪlədʒ. ʃi hæd sin ə saɪɾ ə bif kɛp fəɹ mʌnθs əz fɹɛʃ əz ðə deɪ ðə kaʊ wɑz slɔɾɝd, bʌt naʊ ðə kipɪŋz wɝ feɪlɪŋ wʌn baɪ wʌn. səm hæd teɪkən tə mʌɾɝɪŋ ðət ðəɹ mʌs bi ə flɔ ɪn ɛɡwinz kɹieɪʃən, jɛt ðət wɑz æɹən blæðɝ. ɪf ə wiv wɝkt wʌns, ðən pɹɑpɝli dʌn, ɪɾ ɔlweɪz wɝkt, bɑɹɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ tə dɪsɹʌp ðə wiv, ən ɛɡwinz nu wivz ɔlweɪz wɝkt əz kleɪmd. ʃi hæd tə ɡɪv ðə wʊmən ðæt. ən tʃɹaɪ əz ðeɪ maɪt, ən ðeɪ hæd tʃɹaɪd vɛɹi hɑɹd, noʊ wʌn kəd dɪtɛkt ɛni ɪntɝfɪɹəns. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf seɪaɪdɑɹ ɪtsɛlf wɝ feɪlɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ənθɪŋkəbəl. ən ɪnɪskeɪpəbəl. wɝst ʌv ɔl, noʊ wʌn kəd θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ tə du! ʃi sɝɾənli kəd nɑt. ə bɹif ɪntɝlud wɪð teɪlz ə ɹoʊmæns ən ædvɛntʃɝ wɑz mʌtʃ pɹɛfɝəbəl tə kɑntəmpleɪɾɪŋ ʌɾɝ fjutɪləɾi ən ðə feɪljɝ ʌv wʌt wɑz baɪ ɪts vɛɹi neɪtʃɝ ənfeɪlɪŋ.

Call to a Sitting With Magla and Salita out for the morning, Romanda had the patched brown tent to herself, a blessed opportunity to read, though the two mismatched brass lamps on the small table gave off a faint yet nose-wrinkling scent of rancid oil. One had to live with such things these days. Some might consider The Flame, the Blade and the Heart unseemly for one of her attainments and position - as a girl in Far Madding, she had been forbidden such books - but it made an agreeable change from dry histories and terrifying reports of food spoilage. She had seen a side of beef kept for months as fresh as the day the cow was slaughtered, but now the Keepings were failing one by one. Some had taken to muttering that there must be a flaw in Egwene's creation, yet that was arrant blather. If a weave worked once, then properly done, it always worked, barring something to disrupt the weave, and Egwene's new weaves always worked as claimed. She had to give the woman that. And try as they might, and they had tried very hard, no one could detect any interference. It was as if saidar itself were failing. It was unthinkable. And inescapable. Worst of all, no one could think of anything to do! She certainly could not. A brief interlude with tales of romance and adventure was much preferable to contemplating utter futility and the failure of what was by its very nature unfailing.

ðə nɑvəs stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ðə tɛn hæd sɛns ɪnʌf nɑt tə kɑmɛn ɑn əɹ ɹɛɾɪŋ, əɹ tə ɡlæns ət ðə wʊd-baʊn bʊk twaɪs. boʊɾuwɪn kɔθən wɑz kwaɪt pɹɪɾi, bʌt ʃi wɑz ən ɪntɛlədʒənt ɡɝl ivən soʊ, ðoʊ ʃi hæd sʌmθɪŋ ə hɝ bɹʌðɝ ɝaʊn ði aɪz ən ɹæðɝ mɔɹ ə hɪm ɪn əɹ hɛd ðən ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə ədmɪt. əndaʊɾɪdli ʃi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə pæθ tə ðə ɡɹin, əɹ pɝhæps ðə blu. ðə ɡɝl wɑntəd tə lɪv ædvɛntʃɝ, nɑt dʒʌst ɹɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, əz ɪf ən ɛɛs sədaɪz laɪf wəd nɑt bɹɪŋ əɹ mɔɹ ædvɛntʃɝ ðən ʃi wɪʃt wɪθaʊt sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪt. ɹoʊmændə fɛl noʊ ɹəɡɹɛɾ oʊvɝ ðə ɡɝlz pæθ. ðə jɛloʊ wəɾ əv plɛnti tə tʃuz fɹəm əmʌŋ mɔɹ suɾəbəl nɑvəsɪz. ðəɹ kəd bi noʊ kwɛstʃən ʌv æksɛptɪŋ ɛni ʌv ði oʊldɝ wɪmən, ʌv kɔɹs, jɛt ðət lɛft ə wɛlθ ə tʃɔɪs. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə foʊkəs ɑn ðə peɪdʒ. ʃi dɪɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ðə stɔɹi ʌv bɝdʒɪɾ ən ɡeɪɾəl keɪn.

The novice straightening the tent had sense enough not to comment on her reading, or to glance at the wood-bound book twice. Bodewhin Cauthon was quite pretty, but she was an intelligent girl even so, though she had something of her brother around the eyes and rather more of him in her head than she was willing to admit. Undoubtedly she was already hard on the path to the Green, or perhaps the Blue. The girl wanted to live adventure, not just read about it, as if an Aes Sedai's life would not bring her more adventure than she wished without searching for it. Romanda felt no regret over the girl's path. The Yellow would have plenty to choose from among more suitable novices. There could be no question of accepting any of the older women, of course, yet that left a wealth of choice. She tried to focus on the page. She did enjoy the story of Birgitte and Gaidal Cain.

ðə tɛnt wɑz nɑt pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli lɑɹdʒ ən wɑz kwaɪt kɹaʊɾəd. ɪt hɛld ə tʃɹioʊ ʌv hɑɹd kænvəs kɑts bɛɹli sɔfən baɪ θɪn mætʃɹəsəz stʌft wɪð lʌmpi wʊl, θɹi læɾɝbæk tʃɛɹz meɪd baɪ dɪstɪŋkli dɪfɹən hænz, ə ɹɪkəɾi wɑʃstænd wɪð ə kɹæk mɪɹɝ ən ə tʃɪp blu pɪtʃɝ stændɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt beɪsən, ænd, əlɔŋ wɪð ðə teɪbəl, meɪd stɛɾi baɪ ə smɔl blɑk ʌv wʊɾ ʌndɝ wʌn lɛɡ, bɹæsbaʊn tʃɛsts fəɹ kloʊðɪŋ, bɛd lɪnənz ən pɝsənəl pəzɛʃənz. əz ə sɪɾɝ, ʃi cʊɾə hæd ðə speɪs tə hɝsɛlf, bʌt ʃi laɪk biɪŋ eɪbəl tə kip ə kloʊs aɪ ɑn mæɡlə ən sæliɾə. dʒʌs kəz ðeɪ ɔl sæt fəɹ ðə jɛloʊ wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə tʃɹʌs tu fɑɹ. mæɡlə səpoʊzədli wɑz əɹ ælaɪ ɪn ðə hɔl jɛt wɛn əɹ oʊn weɪ mʌtʃ tu ɔfən, ən sæliɾə sɛldəm dɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. stɪl, ɪt meɪd fəɹ ɪnkənvinjəns əsaɪd fɹəm kɹaʊɾɪŋ. boʊɾuwɪn hæɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv wɝk, meɪnli pʊɾɪŋ əweɪ ðə dʒɹɛsəz ən slɪpɝz sæliɾə skæɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə tæɾɝd kɑɹpəts æftɝ dəsaɪɾɪŋ ðeɪ wəd nɑt du. ðət wʊmən wɑz fɹɪvələs ɪnʌf fəɹ ə ɡɹin. ʃi wɛn θɹu hɝ ɪntaɪɝ wɔɹdʒɹoʊb ɛvɹi sɪŋɡəl mɔɹnɪŋ! laɪkli ʃi θɔt ɹoʊmændə wəɾ əv əɹ sɝvɪŋ wʊmən stʃɹeɪɾən - ʃi ɔlweɪz sim tə θɪŋk æɛlmɑɹə wɑz əz mʌtʃ ɪn əɹ sɝvəs əz ɹoʊmændəz - bʌɾ æɛlmɑɹə hæd sɝvd ɹoʊmændə fəɹ jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɛn ɪndə ɹitaɪɝmənt, nɑt tə mɛnʃən hɛlpɪŋ əɹ ɪskeɪp fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ æftɝ ə slaɪt mɪsəndɝstændɪŋ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm leɪɾɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɑsəbɪləɾi ʃi wəd ɹikwaɪɝ æɛlmɑɹə tə lʊk æftɝ ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ əz wɛl əz hɝsɛlf.

The tent was not particularly large and was quite crowded. It held a trio of hard canvas cots barely softened by thin mattresses stuffed with lumpy wool, three ladderback chairs made by distinctly different hands, a rickety washstand with a cracked mirror and a chipped blue pitcher standing in the white basin, and, along with the table, made steady by a small block of wood under one leg, brassbound chests for clothing, bed linens and personal possessions. As a Sitter, she could have had the space to herself, but she liked being able to keep a close eye on Magla and Salita. Just because they all sat for the Yellow was no reason to trust too far. Magla supposedly was her ally in the Hall yet went her own way much too often, and Salita seldom did anything else. Still, it made for inconvenience aside from crowding. Bodewhin had a great deal of work, mainly putting away the dresses and slippers Salita scattered across the tattered carpets after deciding they would not do. That woman was frivolous enough for a Green. She went through her entire wardrobe every single morning! Likely she thought Romanda would have her serving woman straighten - she always seemed to think Aelmara was as much in her service as Romanda's - but Aelmara had served Romanda for years before she went into retirement, not to mention helping her escape Far Madding after a slight misunderstanding a short time later. There was no possibility she would require Aelmara to look after another sister as well as herself.

ʃi fɹaʊn ət ðə bʊk, nɑt siɪŋ ə wɝd. waɪ ɪn ðə laɪt hæd mæɡlə ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn sæliɾə bæk ɪn sɑlədɑɹ? ɪn tʃɹuθ, mæɡlə hæd bændid sɛvɹəl neɪmz əbaʊt, itʃ mɔɹ ɹɪdɪkjələs ðən ðə læst, bʌt hæd sɛɾəld ɑn sæliɾə wʌns ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd ðə plʌmp tɛɹən hæd ðə bɛs tʃæns ə biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə ə tʃɛɹ. ɹoʊmændə hæd θɹoʊn əɹ oʊn səpɔɹt bɪhaɪn dæɡdɑɹə, ə fɑɹ mɔɹ suɾəbəl kændəɾeɪt, nɑt tə mɛnʃən wʌn ʃi θɔt ʃi kəd sweɪ wɪθaʊt tu mʌtʃ dɪfəkəlti, jɛt ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ fəɹ ə tʃɛɹ waɪl mæɡlə ɔlɹɛɾi hɛld wʌn. ðət kæɹid weɪt, ən noʊ mæɾɝ ðət ɹoʊmændə hæd pɹiviəsli hɛld ə tʃɛɹ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ɛniwʌn ɪn lɪvɪŋ mɛmɹi. wɛl, ɪt wɑz dʌn, ən ðət wɑz ðæt. wʌt kəd nɑt bi kjʊɹd mʌs bi ɛndʒjʊɹd.

She frowned at the book, not seeing a word. Why in the Light had Magla insisted on Salita back in Salidar? In truth, Magla had bandied several names about, each more ridiculous than the last, but had settled on Salita once she decided the plump Tairen had the best chance of being raised to a chair. Romanda had thrown her own support behind Dagdara, a far more suitable candidate, not to mention one she thought she could sway without too much difficulty, yet she herself had been trying for a chair while Magla already held one. That carried weight, and no matter that Romanda had previously held a chair longer than anyone in living memory. Well, it was done, and that was that. What could not be cured must be endured.

naɪsaʊ dʌkt ɪndə ðə tɛnt, ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɝaʊn əɹ wɪŋkɪŋ aʊɾ əz ʃi dɪd soʊ. ɪn ðə bɹif ɪnstən bɪfɔɹ ðə tɛntflæp fɛl ʃʌt, sɑɹɪn, hɝ bɔld-hɛɾəd stʌmp ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ, wɑz vɪzəbəl aʊtsaɪd, ə hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt ən ɪz hɛd swɪvəlɪŋ, pleɪnli stændɪŋ ɡɑɹd.

Nisao ducked into the tent, the light of saidar around her winking out as she did so. In the brief instant before the tentflap fell shut, Sarin, her bald-headed stump of a Warder, was visible outside, a hand resting on his sword hilt and his head swiveling, plainly standing guard.

"meɪ aɪ spik wɪð jə əloʊn?" ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv sɪstɝ sɛd. ʃɔɹɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk sɑɹɪn sim tɔl, ʃi ɔlweɪz maɪndəd ɹoʊmændə ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ-aɪd spɛɹoʊ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ taɪni əbaʊɾ əɹ paʊɝz ʌv ɑbzɝveɪʃən əɹ əɹ ɪntəlɛkt, haʊɛvɝ. ʃi hæd bɪn ə nætʃɹəl tʃɔɪs fəɹ ðə kaʊnsəl ði ədʒəz kɹieɪɾəd tə tʃɹaɪ kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn ɛɡwin, ən ɪt wɑz sɝɾənli noʊ fɔlt ə hɝz ðət sɛd kaʊnsəl hæd hæd lɪɾəl əɹ noʊ ɹistʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪfɛkt ɑn ðə wʊmən.

"May I speak with you alone?" the diminutive sister said. Short enough to make Sarin seem tall, she always minded Romanda of a large-eyed sparrow. There was nothing tiny about her powers of observation or her intellect, however. She had been a natural choice for the council the Ajahs created to try keeping an eye on Egwene, and it was certainly no fault of hers that said council had had little or no restraining effect on the woman.

"ʌv kɔɹs, naɪsaʊ." ɹoʊmændə kæʒəwəli kloʊz ðə bʊk ən izd ʌp tə tʌk ɪt bɪniθ ðə jɛloʊ-tæsɛl kʊʃən ɑn əɹ tʃɛɹ. ɪt wəd nɛvɝ də tə hæv wɝd ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn ðət ʃi wɑz ɹiɾɪŋ ðæt. "ɪt mʌs bi ɔlmoʊs taɪm fəɹ jəɹ nɛks klæs, boʊɾuwɪn. jə doʊnt wɑnə bi leɪt."

"Of course, Nisao." Romanda casually closed the book and eased up to tuck it beneath the yellow-tasseled cushion on her chair. It would never do to have word get around that she was reading that. "It must be almost time for your next class, Bodewhin. You don't want to be late."

"oʊ, noʊ, ɛɛs sədaɪ! ʃɛɝinə wəd bi vɛɹi ʌpsɛt." spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ waɪt skɝts ɪn ə dip kɝtsi, ðə nɑvəs dɑɹɾɪd fɹəm ðə tɛnt.

"Oh, no, Aes Sedai! Sharina would be very upset." Spreading her white skirts in a deep curtsy, the novice darted from the tent.

ɹoʊmændə kəmpɹɛst əɹ lɪps. ʃɛɝinə wəd bi əpsɛt. ðət wʊmən wɑz ɛmbləmæɾɪk ʌv ɔl ðət wɑz ɹɔŋ wɪð əlaʊɪŋ ðoʊz əbʌv eɪtin ɪndə ðə nɑvəs ɹæŋks. hɝ pətɛnʃəl wɑz bɪɑn ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl, bʌt ðət wɑz bɪsaɪd ðə pɔɪnt. ʃɛɝinə mɛlɔɪ wɑz ə dɪsɹʌpʃən. bʌt haʊ tə bi ɹɪɾ ə hɝ? hɝ ən ɔl ði ʌðɝ wɪmən tu oʊl tə hæv hæd ðɛɹ neɪmz ɹɪɾən ɪn ðə nɑvəs bʊk ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. pɹəvɪʒənz wɝ stʃɹɪkli lɪməɾəd fəɹ pʊɾɪŋ ə wʊmən aʊt wʌns əɹ neɪm wɑz ɪn ðə bʊk. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz ə nʌmbɝ ʌv wɪmən hæd bɪn faʊn tə hæv laɪɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ eɪdʒ tə ɡeɪn ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə taʊɝ. baɪ ə fju jɪɹz oʊnli ɪn moʊs keɪsəz, bʌɾ əlaʊɪŋ əm tə ɹɪmeɪn hæd sɛt pɹɛsəɾənts. ən ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ hæd sɛɾ ənʌðɝ, ən wɝs. ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm weɪ tə oʊvɝkʌm ɪt.

Romanda compressed her lips. Sharina would be upset. That woman was emblematic of all that was wrong with allowing those above eighteen into the novice ranks. Her potential was beyond incredible, but that was beside the point. Sharina Melloy was a disruption. But how to be rid of her? Her and all the other women too old to have had their names written in the novice book in the first place. Provisions were strictly limited for putting a woman out once her name was in the book. Unfortunately, over the years a number of women had been found to have lied about their age to gain entrance to the Tower. By a few years only in most cases, but allowing them to remain had set precedents. And Egwene al'Vere had set another, and worse. There had to be some way to overcome it.

"meɪ aɪ meɪk əs pɹaɪvət?" naɪsaʊ æskt.

"May I make us private?" Nisao asked.

"ɪf jə wɪʃ. hæv jə lɝn sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz?" dɪspaɪɾ ɛɡwinz kæptʃɝ, tɔks kəntɪnjuɾ ʌndɝ ðə pəvɪljən ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə bɹɪdʒ ɪn dɛɹn. əɹ ɹæðɝ, ðə sɛmbləns ə tɔks. ðeɪ wɝ ə fɑɹs, ə dʌm-ʃoʊ ʌv ɑbstənəsi, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə kip ə kloʊs aɪ ɑn ðə nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɝz. vɛɹɪlɪn hæd snætʃt moʊst ə ðət wɝk tə hɝsɛlf, kleɪmɪŋ ɡɹeɪ ədʒɑ pɹɪɹɑɡəɾɪv, bʌt mæɡlə faʊnd weɪz tə ɹɪɡəl ɪndə ðə mæɾɝ wɛnɛvɝ ʃi kʊd, ən soʊ dɪd sɛɝɔɪjə ən tɑkimə ən feɪsɛl. wɝs ðən ðə fæk ðət nʌn ə ðɛm sim tə tʃɹʌs ði ʌðɝz tə kæɹi aʊt ðə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz - əɹ mʌtʃ əɾ ɔl, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ - ət taɪmz, ɔl ə ðɛm ɔlmoʊst sim tə bi nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪleɪɾə. wɛl, pɝhæps ɪt wɑz nɑt ðət bæd. ðeɪ hɛl fæst əɡɛns ðə wʊmənz ɹɪdɪkjələs dɪmæn ðət ðə blu ədʒɑ bi dɪzɑlvd ən ɑɹɡjud, ɪf nɑt nɪɹli wɪð səfɪʃən fɔɹs, fəɹ ɪleɪɾə stɛpɪŋ daʊn, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi - ən ləleɪn, ʃi wɑz fɔɹs tə ədmɪt - dɪd nɑt stɪfən ðɛɹ bækboʊnz naʊ ən ðɛn, ðeɪ maɪt wɛl æksid tə səm ʌv ɪleɪɾəz ʌðɝ oʊɾiəs kəndɪʃənz. laɪt, ət taɪmz ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd fɝɡɑɾən ði ɪntaɪɝ pɝpəs ə mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɑn tɑɹ vəlɑn! "pɔɹ əs ti," ʃi wɛn ɑn, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ə peɪntəd wʊɾən tʃɹeɪ sɪɾɪŋ ətɑp tu stæk tʃɛsts ðət hɛld ə sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ ən sɛvɹəl bæɾɝd pjuɾɝ kʌps, "æn tɛl mi wʌt juv hɝd."

"If you wish. Have you learned something about the negotiations?" Despite Egwene's capture, talks continued under the pavilion at the foot of the bridge in Darein. Or rather, the semblance of talks. They were a farce, a dumb-show of obstinacy, yet it was necessary to keep a close eye on the negotiators. Varilin had snatched most of that work to herself, claiming Gray Ajah prerogative, but Magla found ways to wriggle into the matter whenever she could, and so did Saroiya and Takima and Faiselle. Worse than the fact that none of them seemed to trust the others to carry out the negotiations - or much at all, for that matter - at times, all of them almost seemed to be negotiating for Elaida. Well, perhaps it was not that bad. They held fast against the woman's ridiculous demand that the Blue Ajah be dissolved and argued, if not nearly with sufficient force, for Elaida stepping down, but if she - and Lelaine, she was forced to admit - did not stiffen their backbones now and then, they might well accede to some of Elaida's other odious conditions. Light, at times it was as if they had forgotten the entire purpose of marching on Tar Valon! "Pour us tea," she went on, gesturing to a painted wooden tray sitting atop two stacked chests that held a silver pitcher and several battered pewter cups, "and tell me what you've heard."

ðə ɡloʊ sɝaʊndəd naɪsaʊ bɹifli waɪl ʃi wɔɹɾɪd ðə tɛn ən taɪɾ ɔf ðə wiv. "aɪ noʊ nʌθɪŋ ə ðə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz," ʃi sɛd, fɪlɪŋ tu ʌv ðə kʌps. "aɪ wɑnə æsk jə tə spik tə ləleɪn."

The glow surrounded Nisao briefly while she warded the tent and tied off the weave. "I know nothing of the negotiations," she said, filling two of the cups. "I want to ask you to speak to Lelaine."

ɹoʊmændə tʊk ðə pɹɑfɝd kʌp ən juz teɪkɪŋ ə sloʊ swɑloʊ tə ɡɪv hɝsɛlf taɪm fəɹ θɔt. ət lis ðɪs ti hæd nɑt jɛt tɝnd. ləleɪn? wʌt kəd ðəɹ bi əbaʊt ləleɪn ðət ɹikwaɪɝd wɔɹɾɪŋ? stɪl, ɛniθɪŋ ðət ɡeɪv əɹ lɛvɝɪdʒ əɡɛns ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wəd bi jusfəl. ləleɪn simd ɪntaɪɝli tu smʌɡ ʌv leɪt fəɹ əɹ tə bi ɪntaɪɝli kʌmftəɹbəl əbaʊɾ ɪt. ʃi ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ðə sit kʊʃən. "ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ wʌt? waɪ doʊn jə spik tə hɝ jɝsɛlf? wi hævən fɔlən əz loʊ əz ɪt simz ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz ʌndɝ ɪleɪɾə."

Romanda took the proffered cup and used taking a slow swallow to give herself time for thought. At least this tea had not yet turned. Lelaine? What could there be about Lelaine that required warding? Still, anything that gave her leverage against the other woman would be useful. Lelaine seemed entirely too smug of late for her to be entirely comfortable about it. She shifted on the seat cushion. "Regarding what? Why don't you speak to her yourself? We haven't fallen as low as it seems the White Tower has under Elaida."

"aɪ hæv spoʊkən tə hɝ. əɹ ɹæðɝ, ʃiz spoʊkən tə mi, ən ɹæðɝ fɔɹsfəli." naɪsaʊ sæt daʊn, ən sɛɾ əɹ kʌp ɑn ðə teɪbəl waɪl ʃi ɝeɪnʒd əɹ jɛloʊ-slæʃt skɝts wɪð oʊvɝli ɪlæbɹət kɛɹ. ʃi wɔɹ ə smɔl fɹaʊn. ɪt simd ʃi wɑz fɪdlɪŋ fəɹ taɪm, tu. "ləleɪn dɪmændəd ðəɾ aɪ stɑp æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz əbaʊɾ æneɪjə ən kɛɹən," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə hɝ, ðɛɹ mɝɾɝz ɑɹ blu ədʒɑ bɪznəs."

"I have spoken to her. Or rather, she has spoken to me, and rather forcefully." Nisao sat down, and set her cup on the table while she arranged her yellow-slashed skirts with overly elaborate care. She wore a small frown. It seemed she was fiddling for time, too. "Lelaine demanded that I stop asking questions about Anaiya and Kairen," she said finally. "According to her, their murders are Blue Ajah business."

ɹoʊmændə snɔɹɾɪd, ʃɪftɪŋ əɡɛn. ðə bʊks wʊɾən kʌvɝ wɑz ə hɑɹd lʌmp bɪniθ hɝ, ɪts kɔɹnɝz dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə hɝ hɪp. "ðæɾ ɪz ʌɾɝ nɑnsɛns. bʌt waɪ wɝ jə æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz? aɪ doʊn ɹikɔl jə biɪŋ ɪnkwɪzɪɾɪv əbaʊt sətʃ mæɾɝz."

Romanda snorted, shifting again. The book's wooden cover was a hard lump beneath her, its corners digging into her hip. "That is utter nonsense. But why were you asking questions? I don't recall you being inquisitive about such matters."

ði ʌðɝ wʊmən tʌtʃt əɹ kʌp tə hɝ lɪps, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi dʒɹæŋk, ɪt wɑz ðə taɪniəst sɪp. loʊɝɪŋ ðə kʌp, ʃi ɔlmoʊst sim tə ɡɹoʊ tɔlɝ, ʃi sæɾ ʌp soʊ stʃɹeɪt. ə spɛɹoʊ bɪkʌmɪŋ ə hɔk. "bɪkɔz ðə mʌðɝ ɔɹɾɝd mi tə."

The other woman touched her cup to her lips, but if she drank, it was the tiniest sip. Lowering the cup, she almost seemed to grow taller, she sat up so straight. A sparrow becoming a hawk. "Because the Mother ordered me to."
