ətɛndɪŋ ɪleɪɾə ɡoʊld-ɪmbɔs lɛðɝ foʊldɝ ʌndɝ əɹ ɑɹm, tɑɹnə kɛp tə ðə sɛntʃɹəl kɔɹ ə ðə taʊɝ əz ʃi klaɪm təwɔɹɾ ɪleɪɾəz əpɑɹtməns, ɔlðoʊ ɪt mɛn juzɪŋ ə simɪŋli ɛnləs sɪɹiz ə stɛɹkeɪsɪz - twaɪs ðoʊz stɛɹz wɝ nɑt loʊkeɪɾəd wɛɹ ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðɛm, bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi kəntɪnjuɾ ʌpwɝd, ʃi wəd ɹitʃ əɹ dɛstəneɪʃən - ɹæðɝ ðən ðə dʒɛnli spaɪɹəlɪŋ kɔɹɪɾɝz. ɑn ðə stɛɹz, ʃi mɛt noʊ wʌn bʌɾ əkeɪʒənəl lɪvɹid sɝvəns u baʊɾ əɹ kɝtsid bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ ɑn əbaʊt ðɛɹ tæsks. ɪn iðɝ ə ðə spaɪɹəlɪŋ hɔlweɪz ʃi wəɾ əv tə pæs ði ɛntʃɹənsəz tə ði ədʒɑ kɔɹɾɝz ən pɝhæps ɪnkaʊntɝ ʌðɝ sɪstɝz. hɝ kipɝz stoʊl əlaʊɾ əɹ tə ɛntɝ ɛni ədʒɑz kɔɹɾɝz, jɛt ʃi əvɔɪɾəd ɔl ɪksɛp ðə ɹɛd seɪv wən duɾi kɔld. əmʌŋ sɪstɝz ə ði ʌðɝ ədʒəz ʃi wɑz ɔl tu əwɛɹ ðəɾ əɹ nɛɹoʊ stoʊl wɑz ɹɛd, ɔl tu əwɛɹ ə hɑɾ aɪz wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ fɹəm koʊl feɪsəz. ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ənɝv əɹ - lɪɾəl dɪd; ʃi tʊk ðə ʃɪftɪŋ ɪntɪɹiɝ ə ðə taʊɝ ɪn stʃɹaɪd - bʌt stɪl. . . . ʃi θɔt mæɾɝz hæd nɑt ɡɔn soʊ fɑɹ ðəɾ ɛniwʌn wəɾ æktʃəli  ətæk ðə kipɝ, jɛt ʃi tʊk noʊ tʃænsəz. ɹitʃɹivɪŋ ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən gɑnə tə bi ə lɔŋ, hɑɹd stʃɹʌɡəl, wʌtɛvɝ ɪleɪɾə θɔt, ən ən əsɔlt ɑn ðə kipɝ maɪt meɪk ɪɾ ɪɹətʃɹivəbəl.

Attending Elaida Gold-embossed leather folder under her arm, Tarna kept to the central core of the Tower as she climbed toward Elaida's apartments, although it meant using a seemingly endless series of staircases - twice those stairs were not located where she remembered them, but so long as she continued upward, she would reach her destination - rather than the gently spiraling corridors. On the stairs, she met no one but occasional liveried servants who bowed or curtsied before hurrying on about their tasks. In either of the spiraling hallways she would have to pass the entrances to the Ajah quarters and perhaps encounter other sisters. Her Keeper's stole allowed her to enter any Ajah's quarters, yet she avoided all except the Red save when duty called. Among sisters of the other Ajahs she was all too aware that her narrow stole was red, all too aware of hot eyes watching her from cold faces. They did not unnerve her - little did; she took the shifting interior of the Tower in stride - but still. . . . She thought matters had not gone so far that anyone would actually attack the Keeper, yet she took no chances. Retrieving the situation was going to be a long, hard struggle, whatever Elaida thought, and an assault on the Keeper might make it irretrievable.

bɪsaɪdz, nɑt hævɪŋ tə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ əlaʊɾ əɹ tə θɪŋk ɑn pɛvɑɹəz tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ kwɛstʃən, wʌn ʃi hæd nɑt kənsɪɾɝd bɪfɔɹ sədʒɛstɪŋ ðə bɑndɪŋ ʌv æʃəmən. hu ɪn ðə ɹɛɾ æktʃəli  kəd bi tʃɹʌstɪd wɪð ðə tæsk? hʌntɪŋ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl lɛd ɹɛd sɪstɝz tə lʊk əskæns əɾ ɔl mɛn, ən ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ heɪɾəd ðɛm. ə sɝvaɪvɪŋ bɹʌðɝ əɹ fɑðɝ maɪt wɛl ɪskeɪp heɪtʃɹəd, ə feɪvɹɪt kʌzən əɹ ʌŋkəl, bʌt wʌns ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɡɔn, soʊ wɑz əfɛkʃən. ən tʃɹʌst. ən ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ ə tʃɹʌst. bɑndɪŋ ɛni mæn vaɪəleɪɾɪd kʌstəm stʃɹɔŋ əz lɔ. ivən wɪð tsutɑməz blɛsɪŋz, hu maɪt ɹʌn tə ɪleɪɾə wən bɑndɪŋ æʃəmən wɑz bɹoʊtʃt? ʃi hæd ɹimuv θɹi mɔɹ neɪmz fɹəm əɹ mɛntəl lɪst ə pɑsəbɪləɾiz baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi ɹitʃt ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ɪleɪɾəz əpɑɹtməns, oʊnli tu flɔɹz bɪloʊ ðə tɑp ə ðə taʊɝ. æftɝ ɔlmoʊs tu wiks, hɝ lɪst ə ðoʊz ʃi kəd bi sɝɾən ə stɪl kənteɪn oʊnli ə sɪŋɡəl neɪm, ən ðət wʌn wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl fəɹ ðə tæsk.

Besides, not having to watch over her shoulder allowed her to think on Pevara's troubling question, one she had not considered before suggesting the bonding of Asha'man. Who in the Red actually could be trusted with the task? Hunting men who could channel led Red sisters to look askance at all men, and a fair number hated them. A surviving brother or father might well escape hatred, a favorite cousin or uncle, but once they were all gone, so was affection. And trust. And there was another matter of trust. Bonding any man violated custom strong as law. Even with Tsutama's blessings, who might run to Elaida when bonding Asha'man was broached? She had removed three more names from her mental list of possibilities by the time she reached the entrance to Elaida's apartments, only two floors below the top of the Tower. After almost two weeks, her list of those she could be certain of still contained only a single name, and that one was impossible for the task.

ɪleɪɾə wɑz ɪn əɹ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, wɛɹ ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz wɝ ɔl ɡɪlt ən aɪvɝi ɪnleɪz ən ðə lɑɹdʒ pæɾɝnd kɑɹpət wɑz wʌn ə tɛɹz faɪnəs kɹieɪʃənz. ʃi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə loʊ-bæk tʃɛɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs sɪpɪŋ waɪn wɪð maɪdɑni. siɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪ wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz dɪspaɪt ði ɝli aʊɝ. maɪdɑni daɪnd wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn moʊs naɪts, ən vɪzəɾəd ɔfən dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪ baɪ ɪnvɪteɪʃən. ɪleɪɾə, hɝ sɪks-stʃɹaɪp stoʊl waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə kʌvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, wɑz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə tɔlɝ wʊmən oʊvɝ əɹ kɹɪstəl ɡɑblət, ə dɑɹk-aɪɾ iɡəl ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ə maʊs wɪð bɪɡ blu aɪz. maɪdɑni, ɛmɹəlz əɾ əɹ ɪɹz ən ɑn ə waɪd kɑlɝ ɝaʊn əɹ slɪm θɹoʊt, sim vɛɹi kɑnʃəs ə ðət ɡeɪz. hɝ fʊl lɪps smaɪld, bʌt ðeɪ sim tʃɹɛmjələs. ðə hænd nɑt hoʊldɪŋ əɹ ɡɑblət muv kɑnstənli, tʌtʃɪŋ ði ɛmɹəl koʊm oʊvɝ əɹ lɛft ɪɹ, pæɾɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ, kʌvɝɪŋ əɹ bʊzəm, wɪtʃ wɑz lɑɹdʒli ɪkspoʊz baɪ hɝ snʌɡ bɑɾəs ə bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd sɪlvɝi-ɡɹeɪ sɪlk. hɝ bʊzəm wɑz hɑɹdli ɪksɛsɪv, jɛɾ əɹ slɛndɝnəs meɪɾ ɪt sim soʊ, ən ʃi əpɪɹɾ əbaʊt tə pɑp fɹi ʌv ðə ɡɑɹmənt. ðə wʊmən wɑz ɡɑɹb fəɹ ə bɔl. əɹ ə sɪdʌkʃən.

Elaida was in her sitting room, where the furnishings were all gilt and ivory inlays and the large patterned carpet was one of Tear's finest creations. She was sitting in a low-backed chair before the marble fireplace sipping wine with Meidani. Seeing the Gray was no surprise despite the early hour. Meidani dined with the Amyrlin most nights, and visited often during the day by invitation. Elaida, her six-striped stole wide enough to cover her shoulders, was regarding the taller woman over her crystal goblet, a dark-eyed eagle regarding a mouse with big blue eyes. Meidani, emeralds at her ears and on a wide collar around her slim throat, seemed very conscious of that gaze. Her full lips smiled, but they seemed tremulous. The hand not holding her goblet moved constantly, touching the emerald comb over her left ear, patting her hair, covering her bosom, which was largely exposed by her snug bodice of brocaded silvery-gray silk. Her bosom was hardly excessive, yet her slenderness made it seem so, and she appeared about to pop free of the garment. The woman was garbed for a ball. Or a seduction.

"ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ɹɪpɔɹts ɑɹ ɹɛɾi, mʌðɝ," tɑɹnə sɛd, boʊɪŋ slaɪtli. laɪt! ʃi fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɪntʃɹuɾəd ɑn lʌvɝz!

"The morning reports are ready, Mother," Tarna said, bowing slightly. Light! She felt as if she had intruded on lovers!

"ju woʊn maɪn livɪŋ ʌs, maɪdɑni?" ivən ðə smaɪl ɪleɪɾə dɝɛktəɾ ət ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd wʊmən wɑz pɹɛɾətɔɹi.

"You won't mind leaving us, Meidani?" Even the smile Elaida directed at the yellow-haired woman was predatory.

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt, mʌðɝ." maɪdɑni sɛɾ əɹ ɡɑbləɾ ɑn ðə smɔl teɪbəl bɪsaɪɾ əɹ tʃɛɹ ən lɛp tə hɝ fit, ɔfɝɪŋ ə kɝtsi ðət nɪɹli hæɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə hɝ dʒɹɛs. "ʌv kɔɹs nɑt." ʃi skɝid fɹəm ðə ɹum bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd, hɝ aɪz waɪd.

"Of course not, Mother." Meidani set her goblet on the small table beside her chair and leaped to her feet, offering a curtsy that nearly had her out of her dress. "Of course not." She scurried from the room breathing hard, her eyes wide.

wən ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɝ, ɪleɪɾə læft. "wi wɝ pɪloʊ-fɹɛnz əz nɑvəsɪz," ʃi sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ, "æn aɪ bɪliv ʃi wɑns tə ɹɪnu ðə ɹileɪʃənʃɪp. aɪ meɪ lɛt hɝ. ʃi maɪt ɹɪvil mɔɹ ɑn ðə pɪloʊz ðən ʃiz lɛt slɪp soʊ fɑɹ. wɪtʃ ɪz nʌθɪŋ, tʃɹuθ tə tɛl." ʃi stʃɹoʊd tə ðə nɪɹəst wɪndoʊ ən stʊd stɛɹɪŋ daʊn təwɔɹd wɛɹ əɹ fæntæstɪkəl pæləs wəd ɹaɪz tə oʊvɝtɑp ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ɪf sɪstɝz kəd bi kənvɪns tə wɝk ɑn ɪɾ əɡɛn. ðə hɛvi ɹeɪn ðət hæd bɪɡʌn dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt wɑz stɪl fɔlɪŋ, ən ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ʃi kəd si ɛniθɪŋ ə ðət pæləsəz faʊndeɪʃənz, ɔl ðət hæd bɪn kəmpliɾəd soʊ fɑɹ. "hɛlp jɝsɛlf tə waɪn ɪf jə wɪʃ."

When the door closed behind her, Elaida laughed. "We were pillow-friends as novices," she said, rising, "and I believe she wants to renew the relationship. I may let her. She might reveal more on the pillows than she's let slip so far. Which is nothing, truth to tell." She strode to the nearest window and stood staring down toward where her fantastical palace would rise to overtop the Tower itself. Eventually. If sisters could be convinced to work on it again. The heavy rain that had begun during the night was still falling, and it seemed unlikely she could see anything of that palace's foundations, all that had been completed so far. "Help yourself to wine if you wish."

tɑɹnə kɛpt əɹ feɪs smuð wɪð ən ɛfɝt. pɪloʊ-fɹɛnz wɝ kɑmən əmʌŋ nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd, bʌt ɡɝlhʊd θɪŋz ʃəd bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd wɪð ɡɝlhʊd. nɑɾ ɔl sɪstɝz sɔ ɪt soʊ, sɝɾənli. ɡəlinə hæd bɪn kwaɪt sɝpɹaɪzd wən tɑɹnə ɹəfjuzd əɹ ədvænsəz æftɝ ɡeɪnɪŋ ðə ʃɔl. ʃi hɝsɛlf faʊn mɛn fɑɹ mɔɹ ətʃɹæktɪv ðən wɪmən. moʊst sim hɛvəli ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, tə bi ʃʊɹ, ɪspɛʃli ɪf ðeɪ lɝn jə wɝ ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, bʌɾ oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz ʃi hæd kʌm əkɹɔs ə fju hu wɝ nɑt.

Tarna kept her face smooth with an effort. Pillow-friends were common among novices and Accepted, but girlhood things should be left behind with girlhood. Not all sisters saw it so, certainly. Galina had been quite surprised when Tarna refused her advances after gaining the shawl. She herself found men far more attractive than women. Most seemed heavily intimidated by Aes Sedai, to be sure, especially if they learned you were Red Ajah, but over the years she had come across a few who were not.

"ðæt simz ɑd, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd, pʊɾɪŋ ðə lɛðɝ foʊldɝ daʊn ɑn ðə saɪd teɪbəl ðət hɛld ən ɔɹnətli ɹɔt ɡoʊldən tʃɹeɪ bɛɹɪŋ ə kɹɪstəl waɪn pɪtʃɝ ən ɡoʊbləts. "ʃi əpɪɹz fɹaɪɾənd ə ju." fɪlɪŋ ə ɡɑblət, ʃi snɪf ðə waɪn bɪfɔɹ sɪpɪŋ. ðə kipɪŋz sim tə bi wɝkɪŋ. fəɹ naʊ. ɪleɪɾə hæd faɪnəli əɡɹid ðət ðət wiv, ət list, mʌs bi ʃɛɹd. "ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ʃi nu ðət jə noʊ əbaʊɾ əɹ biɪŋ ə spaɪ."

"That seems odd, Mother," she said, putting the leather folder down on the side table that held an ornately wrought golden tray bearing a crystal wine pitcher and goblets. "She appears frightened of you." Filling a goblet, she sniffed the wine before sipping. The Keepings seemed to be working. For now. Elaida had finally agreed that that weave, at least, must be shared. "Almost as if she knew that you know about her being a spy."

"ʌv kɔɹs ʃiz əfɹeɪɾ ə mi." sɑɹkæzəm dʒɹɪp hɛvəli fɹəm ɪleɪɾəz vɔɪs, bʌt ðən hɑɹɾənd tə stoʊn. "aɪ wɑn əɹ əfɹeɪd. aɪ ɪntɛn tə pʊɾ əɹ θɹu ðə mæŋɡəl. baɪ ðə taɪm aɪ hæv əɹ bɝtʃt, ʃɪl taɪ hɝsɛlf tə ðə bɝtʃɪŋ fɹeɪm ɪf aɪ ɔɹɾɝ ɪt. ɪf ʃi nu aɪ nu, tɑɹnə, ʃid bi fliɪŋ ɪnstɛɾ ə dɪlɪvɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪndə maɪ hænz." stɪl stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹeɪnstɔɹm, ɪleɪɾə sɪpt əɾ əɹ waɪn. "hæv jə ɛni nuz ə ði ʌðɝz?"

"Of course she's afraid of me." Sarcasm dripped heavily from Elaida's voice, but then hardened to stone. "I want her afraid. I intend to put her through the mangle. By the time I have her birched, she'll tie herself to the birching frame if I order it. If she knew I knew, Tarna, she'd be fleeing instead of delivering herself into my hands." Still staring out into the rainstorm, Elaida sipped at her wine. "Have you any news of the others?"

"noʊ, mʌðɝ. ɪf aɪ kəɾ ɪnfɔɹm ðə sɪɾɝz ʌv waɪ ðəɹ tə bi wɑtʃt - "

"No, Mother. If I could inform the Sitters of why they're to be watched - "

"noʊ!" ɪleɪɾə snæpt, spɪnɪŋ tə feɪs hɝ. hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz sətʃ ə mæs ʌv ɪntʃɹəkət ɹɛd skɹɑlwɝk ðət ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɔl bʌt hɪd ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪlk bɪniθ. tɑɹnə hæd sədʒɛstəd ðət lɛs flɔntɪŋ ə hɝ fɔɹmɝ ədʒɑ - ʃi hæd fɹeɪzd ɪt mɔɹ dɪpləmæɾɪkli, bʌt ðət wɑz wʌt ʃi mɛnt - maɪt hɛlp bɹɪŋ ði ədʒəz təɡɛðɝ əɡɛn, jɛɾ ɪleɪɾəz ɪɹʌpʃən ə fjʊɹi hæd bɪn səfɪʃən tə kip əɹ kwaɪəɾ ɑn ðə tɑpɪk sɪns. "wʌɾ ɪf səm ə ðə sɪɾɝz ɑɹ wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðɛm? aɪ wʊdn pʊɾ ɪt pæs ðɛm. ðoʊz ɹɪdɪkjələs tɔks kəntɪnju ət ðə bɹɪdʒ dɪspaɪt maɪ ɔɹɾɝz. noʊ, aɪ wʊdn pʊɾ ɪt pæst əm əɾ ɔl!"

"No!" Elaida snapped, spinning to face her. Her dress was such a mass of intricate red scrollwork that the embroidery all but hid the gray silk beneath. Tarna had suggested that less flaunting of her former Ajah - she had phrased it more diplomatically, but that was what she meant - might help bring the Ajahs together again, yet Elaida's eruption of fury had been sufficient to keep her quiet on the topic since. "What if some of the Sitters are working with them? I wouldn't put it past them. Those ridiculous talks continue at the bridge despite my orders. No, I wouldn't put it past them at all!"

tɑɹnə ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛɾ oʊvɝ əɹ ɡɑblət, æksɛptɪŋ wʌt ʃi kəd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ. ɪleɪɾə ɹəfjuz tə si ðəɾ ɪf ði ədʒəz dɪsoʊbeɪɾ əɹ ɔɹɾɝ tə bɹeɪk ɔf ðə tɔks, ðeɪ wɝ ənlaɪkli tə spaɪ ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn sɪstɝz əɾ əɹ kəmænd wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ waɪ. seɪɪŋ soʊ wəɾ oʊnli ɹɪzʌlt ɪn ənʌðɝ taɪɹeɪd, ðoʊ.

Tarna inclined her head over her goblet, accepting what she could not change. Elaida refused to see that if the Ajahs disobeyed her order to break off the talks, they were unlikely to spy on their own sisters at her command without knowing why. Saying so would only result in another tirade, though.

ɪleɪɾə stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ əz ɪf tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɑɹɡju. ðə wʊmən sim hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ. ən mɔɹ bɹɪɾəl. "ə pɪɾi ðə ɹɪbɛljən ɪn tæɹɑbən feɪld," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst. "ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn əbaʊɾ ɪt, aɪ səpoʊz." bʌt ʃi mɛnʃən ɪt fɹikwənli, əɾ ɑd moʊməns, sɪns wɝd keɪm ðət ðə sintʃæn wɝ ɹiəsɝɾɪŋ ðɛɹ ɡɹɪp ɑn ðət kʌntʃɹi. ʃi wɑz nɑt soʊ ɹɪzaɪn əz ʃi pɹitɛndəd. "aɪ wɑnə hɪɹ səm ɡʊd nuz, tɑɹnə. ɪz ðəɹ ɛni wɝɾ ə ðə silz ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən? wi mʌs meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ mɔɹ ɡɛt bɹoʊkən." əz ɪf tɑɹnə dɪd nɑt noʊ ðæt!

Elaida stared at her as if to make sure she was not going to argue. The woman seemed harder than ever. And more brittle. "A pity the rebellion in Tarabon failed," she said at last. "There's nothing to be done about it, I suppose." But she mentioned it frequently, at odd moments, since word came that the Seanchan were reasserting their grip on that country. She was not so resigned as she pretended. "I want to hear some good news, Tarna. Is there any word of the seals on the Dark One's prison? We must make sure no more get broken." As if Tarna did not know that!

"nɑt ðət ði ədʒəz əv ɹipɔɹɾəd, mʌðɝ, ən aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ wəd hoʊl ðət bæk." ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd ðoʊz læst wɝdz bæk əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ spoʊkən.

"Not that the Ajahs have reported, Mother, and I don't think they would hold that back." She wished she had those last words back as soon as they were spoken.

ɪleɪɾə ɡɹʌntɪd. ði ədʒəz ɹilist oʊnli tʃɹɪkəlz ʌv wʌt ðɛɹ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz toʊl ðɛm, ən ʃi ɹizɛntəd ðət bɪɾɝli. hɝ oʊn aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz wɝ kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɪn ændɝ. "haʊ ɪz ðə wɝk kʌmɪŋ ət ðə hɑɹbɝz?"

Elaida grunted. The Ajahs released only trickles of what their eyes-and-ears told them, and she resented that bitterly. Her own eyes-and-ears were concentrated in Andor. "How is the work coming at the harbors?"

"sloʊli, mʌðɝ." wɪð ðə floʊ ʌv tʃɹeɪd staɪfəld, ðə sɪɾi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi filɪŋ hʌŋɡɝ. ɪt wəd bɪɡɪn stɑɹvɪŋ sun, ənlɛs ðə hɑɹbɝ maʊðz wɝ klɪɹd. ivən kʌɾɪŋ əweɪ ðə pɔɹʃən ə ðə saʊθhɑɹbɝ tʃeɪn ðət wɑz stɪl aɪɝn hæd pɹuv nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə əlaʊ səfɪʃənt ʃɪps ɪn tə fid tɑɹ vəlɑn. wʌns tɑɹnə wɑz eɪbəl tə kənvɪns əɹ ə ðə nəsɛsəɾi, ɪleɪɾə hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðə tʃeɪn taʊɝz dɪsmæntəl soʊ ðoʊz hjudʒ pisəz ə kwəndɪlɝ kəd bi ɹimuvd. laɪk ðə sɪɾi wɔlz, haʊɛvɝ, ðə taʊɝz hæd bɪn bɪlt ən stʃɹɛŋθənd wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ən oʊnli ðə paʊɝ kəd dɪsəsɛmbəl ðɛm. ɪt wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm izi. ði ɝɪdʒənəl bɪldɝz hæd dʌn ɡʊd wɝk, ən ðoʊz wɔɹdz sim nɑt tə hæv wikən ə hɛɹ. "ɹɛdz ɑɹ duɪŋ moʊst ə ðə wɝk fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ. sɪstɝz fɹəm ʌðɝ ədʒəz kʌm naʊ ən ðɛn, bʌɾ oʊnli ə fju. aɪ ɪkspɛk ðət wɪl tʃeɪnʒ sun, ðoʊ." ðeɪ nu ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv ðə wɝk, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ðeɪ maɪt ɹɪzɛn ɪt - noʊ sɪstɝ kəd laɪk hævɪŋ tə leɪbɝ ɪn ðət fæʃən; ðə ɹɛdz duɪŋ moʊst ʌv ɪt sɝɾənli ɡɹʌmbəld ɪnʌf - bʌt ði ɔɹɾɝ hæd kʌm fɹəm ɪleɪɾə, ən ðiz deɪz, ðət ɹɪzʌltɪɾ ɪn fʊt-dʒɹæɡɪŋ.

"Slowly, Mother." With the flow of trade stifled, the city was already feeling hunger. It would begin starving soon, unless the harbor mouths were cleared. Even cutting away the portion of the Southharbor chain that was still iron had proved not enough to allow sufficient ships in to feed Tar Valon. Once Tarna was able to convince her of the necessity, Elaida had ordered the chain towers dismantled so those huge pieces of cuendillar could be removed. Like the city walls, however, the towers had been built and strengthened with the Power, and only the Power could disassemble them. It was far from easy. The original builders had done good work, and those wards seemed not to have weakened a hair. "Reds are doing most of the work for the time being. Sisters from other Ajahs come now and then, but only a few. I expect that will change soon, though." They knew the necessity of the work, however much they might resent it - no sister could like having to labor in that fashion; the Reds doing most of it certainly grumbled enough - but the order had come from Elaida, and these days, that resulted in foot-dragging.

ɪleɪɾə bɹið hɛvəli, ðən tʊk ə lɔŋ dʒɹɪŋk. ʃi sim tə niɾ ɪt. hɝ hænd ɡɹɪp ðə ɡɑblət soʊ hɑɹd ðət tɛndənz stʊɾ aʊɾ ɑn ɪts bæk. ʃi ədvænst əkɹɔs ðə pæɾɝnd sɪlk kɑɹpəɾ əz ɪf ʃi mɛn tə stʃɹaɪk ət tɑɹnə. "ðeɪ dɪfaɪ mi əɡɛn. əɡɛn! əl əv oʊbiɾiəns, tɑɹnə. əl əv ɪt! ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ən ɔɹɾɝ, ən wʌns aɪ saɪn ən sil ɪt, poʊst ɪɾ ɪn ɛvɹi ədʒɑz kɔɹɾɝz." ʃi stɑpt ɔlmoʊs noʊz-tə-noʊz wɪð tɑɹnə, hɝ dɑɹk aɪz ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ laɪk ə ɹeɪvənz. "ðə sɪɾɝz ʌv ɛni ədʒɑ ðət feɪlz tə sɛn ɪts fɛɹ ʃɛɹ ə sɪstɝz tə wɝk ɑn ðə tʃeɪn taʊɝz wɪl teɪk ə deɪli pɛnəns fɹəm sɪlviænə əntɪl ðə mæɾɝ ɪz ɹɛktəfaɪd. deɪli! ən ðə sɪɾɝz ʌv ɛni ədʒɑ ðət sɛnz sɪstɝz tə ðoʊz . . . ðoʊz tɔks wɪl də ðə seɪm. ɹaɪɾ ɪɾ aʊt fəɹ mi tə saɪn!"

Elaida breathed heavily, then took a long drink. She seemed to need it. Her hand gripped the goblet so hard that tendons stood out on its back. She advanced across the patterned silk carpet as if she meant to strike at Tarna. "They defy me again. Again! I will have obedience, Tarna. I will have it! Write out an order, and once I sign and seal it, post it in every Ajah's quarters." She stopped almost nose-to-nose with Tarna, her dark eyes glittering like a raven's. "The Sitters of any Ajah that fails to send its fair share of sisters to work on the chain towers will take a daily penance from Silviana until the matter is rectified. Daily! And the Sitters of any Ajah that sends sisters to those . . . those talks will do the same. Write it out for me to sign!"

tɑɹnə dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. pɛnənsɪz maɪt wɝk ən ðeɪ maɪt nɑt, dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn haʊ sɛt ðə sɪɾɝz wɝ, ən ði ədʒɑ hɛdz - ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk θɪŋz hæd ɡɔn soʊ ɹɔŋ ðət ðeɪ maɪt ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt pɛnəns əɾ ɔl; ðət wəd bi ən ɛn tə ɪleɪɾə fəɹ ʃʊɹ, pɝhæps ən ɛn tə ðə taʊɝ. bʌt poʊstɪŋ ði ɔɹɾɝ pʌblɪkli, nɑɾ əlaʊɪŋ ðə sɪɾɝz ə skɹæp tə haɪd bɪhaɪn ən meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ dɪɡnəɾi, wɑz ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ tə ɡoʊ əbaʊɾ ɪt. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɪt maɪt wɛl bi ðə vɛɹi wɝst weɪ. "ɪf aɪ meɪ meɪk ə sədʒɛstʃən," ʃi bɪɡæn əz dɛləkətli əz ʃi kəd mænədʒ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn noʊn fəɹ dɛləkəsi.

Tarna drew a deep breath. Penances might work and they might not, depending on how set the Sitters were, and the Ajah heads - she did not think things had gone so wrong that they might refuse to accept penance at all; that would be an end to Elaida for sure, perhaps an end to the Tower. But posting the order publicly, not allowing the Sitters a scrap to hide behind and maintain their dignity, was the wrong way to go about it. In truth, it might well be the very worst way. "If I may make a suggestion," she began as delicately as she could manage. She had never been known for delicacy.

"ju meɪ nɑt," ɪleɪɾə kʌɾ ɪn hɑɹʃli. ʃi tʊk ənʌðɝ lɔŋ dʒɹɪŋk, dʒɹeɪnɪŋ əɹ ɡɑblət, ən ɡlaɪɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə kɑɹpət tə ɹifɪl ɪt. ʃi dʒɹæŋk tu mʌtʃ, ʌv leɪt. tɑɹnə hæɾ ivən sin əɹ dʒɹʌŋk wʌns! "haʊ ɪz sɪlviænə duɪŋ wɪð ði ælvɪɹ ɡɝl?" ʃi sɛɾ əz ʃi pɔɹd.

"You may not," Elaida cut in harshly. She took another long drink, draining her goblet, and glided across the carpet to refill it. She drank too much, of late. Tarna had even seen her drunk once! "How is Silviana doing with the al'Vere girl?" she said as she poured.

"ɛɡwin spɛnz nɪɹ ɪnʌf hæf ʌv ɛvɹi deɪ ɪn sɪlviænəz stʌɾi, mʌðɝ." ʃi wɑz kɛɹfəl tə kip əɹ toʊn nutʃɹəl. ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm ɪleɪɾə hæɾ æskt æftɝ ðə jʌŋ wʊmən sɪns əɹ kæptʃɝ, naɪn deɪz əɡoʊ.

"Egwene spends near enough half of every day in Silviana's study, Mother." She was careful to keep her tone neutral. This was the first time Elaida had asked after the young woman since her capture, nine days ago.

"soʊ mʌtʃ? aɪ wɑn əɹ teɪm tə ðə taʊɝz hɑɹnəs, nɑt bɹoʊkən."

"So much? I want her tamed to the Tower's harness, not broken."

"aɪ . . . daʊt ʃɪl bi bɹoʊkən, mʌðɝ. sɪlviænə wɪl bi kɛɹfəl ə ðæt." ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz ðə ɡɝl hɝsɛlf. ðət wɑz nɑt fəɹ ɪleɪɾəz ɪɹz, ðoʊ. tɑɹnə hæd bɪn ʃaʊɾəd ət mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf. ʃi hæd lɝn tə əvɔɪd sʌbʒɪkts ðəɾ oʊnli ɹɪzʌltɪɾ ɪn ʃaʊɾɪŋ. ædvaɪs ən sədʒɛstʃənz ənəfɝd wɝ noʊ mɔɹ jusləs ðən ædvaɪs ən sədʒɛstʃənz ənteɪkən, ən ɪleɪɾə ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ tʊk iðɝ. "ɛɡwinz stʌbɝn, bʌɾ aɪ ɪkspɛkt ʃi mʌs kʌm ɝaʊn sun." ðə ɡɝl hæd tə. ɡəlinə, biɾɪŋ tɑɹnəz blɑk aʊɾ ə hɝ, hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛndɪɾ ə tɛnθ ə ði ɛfɝt sɪlviænə wɑz pʊɾɪŋ ɪndə ɛɡwin. ðə ɡɝl hæd tə jil tə ðət sun.

"I . . . doubt she will be broken, Mother. Silviana will be careful of that." And then there was the girl herself. That was not for Elaida's ears, though. Tarna had been shouted at more than enough. She had learned to avoid subjects that only resulted in shouting. Advice and suggestions unoffered were no more useless than advice and suggestions untaken, and Elaida almost never took either. "Egwene's stubborn, but I expect she must come around soon." The girl had to. Galina, beating Tarna's block out of her, had not expended a tenth of the effort Silviana was putting into Egwene. The girl had to yield to that soon.

"ɛksələnt," ɪleɪɾə mɝmɝd. "ɛksələnt." ʃi lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, hɝ feɪs ə mæsk ə sɝɛnəɾi. hɝ aɪz stɪl ɡlɪɾɝd, ðoʊ. "pʊɾ əɹ neɪm ɑn ðə ɹɑstɝ tə ətɛn mi. ɪn fækt, hæv əɹ ətɛn mi tənaɪt. ʃi kən sɝv sʌpɝ fəɹ maɪdɑni ən mi."

"Excellent," Elaida murmured. "Excellent." She looked over her shoulder, her face a mask of serenity. Her eyes still glittered, though. "Put her name on the roster to attend me. In fact, have her attend me tonight. She can serve supper for Meidani and me."

"ɪt wɪl bi əz jə kəmænd, mʌðɝ." ɪt sim jɛɾ ənʌðɝ vɪzət tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz wɑz ɪnɛvəɾəbəl, bʌt noʊ daʊɾ ɛɡwin wəɾ ɝn dʒʌst əz mɛni ʌv ðoʊz ɪf ʃi nɛvɝ keɪm nɪɹ ɪleɪɾə.

"It will be as you command, Mother." It seemed yet another visit to the Mistress of Novices was inevitable, but no doubt Egwene would earn just as many of those if she never came near Elaida.

"ænd naʊ jəɹ ɹɪpɔɹts, tɑɹnə." ɪleɪɾə sæt daʊn əɡɛn ən kɹɔst əɹ lɛɡz.

"And now your reports, Tarna." Elaida sat down again and crossed her legs.

ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ əɹ bɛɹli tʌtʃt ɡɑbləɾ ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ, tɑɹnə tʊk ʌp əɹ foʊldɝ ən sæɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ maɪdɑni hæd bɪn juzɪŋ. "ðə ɹidʌn wɔɹdz əpɪɹ tə bi kipɪŋ ɹæts aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, mʌðɝ," fəɹ haʊ lɔŋ wɑz ənʌðɝ kwɛstʃən; ʃi tʃɛk ðoʊz wɔɹdz hɝsɛlf ɛvɹi deɪ, "bʌt ɹeɪvənz ən kɹoʊz əv bɪn sin ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz, soʊ ðə wɔɹdz ɑn ðə wɔlz mʌs bi. . . ."

Replacing her barely touched goblet on the tray, Tarna took up her folder and sat in the chair Meidani had been using. "The redone wards appear to be keeping rats out of the Tower, Mother," for how long was another question; she checked those wards herself every day, "but ravens and crows have been seen in the Tower grounds, so the wards on the walls must be. . . ."

ðə mɪddeɪ sʌn kæs dæpəld laɪt θɹu ðə lifi bɹæntʃəz ə ðə tɔl tʃɹiz, moʊsli oʊk ən lɛðɝlif ən saʊɝɡəm wɪð ə smæɾɝɪŋ ə kɑɾənwʊdz ən mæsɪv paɪnz. əpɛɹənli ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə fɪɹs wɪndstɔɹm səm jɪɹz bæk, kəz fɔlən tɪmbɝ, skæɾɝd əbaʊt hɪɹ ən ðəɹ bʌɾ ɔl stʃɹɛtʃt ɪn ðə seɪm dʒɛnɝəl dɝɛkʃən, pɹəvaɪɾəd ɡʊd siɾɪŋ wɪð oʊnli ə lɪɾəl hætʃət wɝk tə hæk əweɪ ə fju lɪmz. spɑɹs ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ əlaʊɾ ə ɡʊd vju ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz, ən nɑt fɑɹ ɔf, ə smɔl klɪɹ stʃɹim splæʃt oʊvɝ mɔsi stoʊnz. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ə ɡʊd kæmpsaɪɾ ɪf mæt hæd nɑt bɪn ɪntɛn ɑn kʌvɝɪŋ əz mʌtʃ ɡɹaʊn əz i kəɾ ɛvɹi deɪ, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd dʒʌst əz wɛl əz ə pleɪs tə ɹɛs ðə hɔɹsəz ən it. ðə deɪmoʊnə maʊntənz stɪl leɪ ət lis θɹi hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz tə ði ist, ən i ɪntɛndəd tə ɹitʃ əm ɪn ə wik. veɪnɪn sɛɾ i nu ə smʌɡəlɝz' pæs - pjʊɹli baɪ hɪɹseɪ, ʌv kɔɹs; dʒʌst sʌmθɪŋ i hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd baɪ tʃæns, bʌɾ i nu ɹaɪt wɛɹ tə faɪn ɪt - ðət wəɾ əv əm ɪnsaɪd mʊɹændi tu deɪz æftɝ ðæt. mʌtʃ seɪfɝ ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡoʊ nɔɹθ ɪndə ændɝ əɹ saʊθ təwɔɹɾ ɪljən. ɪn iðɝ dɝɛkʃən, ðə dɪstəns tə seɪfti wəd bi fɝðɝ ən ðə tʃæns ʌv ɛnkaʊntɝɪŋ sintʃæn ɡɹeɪɾɝ.

The midday sun cast dappled light through the leafy branches of the tall trees, mostly oak and leatherleaf and sourgum with a smattering of cottonwoods and massive pines. Apparently there had been a fierce windstorm some years back, because fallen timber, scattered about here and there but all stretched in the same general direction, provided good seating with only a little hatchet work to hack away a few limbs. Sparse undergrowth allowed a good view in all directions, and not far off, a small clear stream splashed over mossy stones. It would have been a good campsite if Mat had not been intent on covering as much ground as he could every day, but it did just as well as a place to rest the horses and eat. The Damona Mountains still lay at least three hundred miles to the east, and he intended to reach them in a week. Vanin said he knew a smugglers' pass - purely by hearsay, of course; just something he had overheard by chance, but he knew right where to find it - that would have them inside Murandy two days after that. Much safer than trying to go north into Andor or south toward Illian. In either direction, the distance to safety would be further and the chance of encountering Seanchan greater.

mæt nɔd ðə læst skɹæp ə mit fɹəm ə ɹæbəts haɪn lɛɡ, ən tɔs ðə boʊn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. bɔldɪŋ ləpɪn dɑɹɾɪd ɪn, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪz bɪɹɾ ɪn kɑnstɝneɪʃən, tə pɪk ɪɾ ʌp ən dʒɹɑp ɪɾ ɪn ðə pɪɾ i ən nɹɪm hæd meɪɾ ɪn ðə mʌltʃ-kʌvɝd fɔɹəs flɔɹ, ðoʊ ðə pɪt wəd bi dʌɡ ʌp baɪ ænəməlz wɪðɪn ə hæf-aʊɝ æftɝ ðɛɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ. mæt muv tə waɪp ɪz hænz ɑn ɪz bɹitʃɪz. tuɑn, nɪbəlɪŋ əɾ ə ɡɹaʊs lɛɡ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə loʊ faɪɝ, ɡeɪv ɪm ə vɛɹi dɝɛk lʊk, hɝ aɪbɹaʊz ɹeɪzd, waɪl ðə fɪŋɡɝz ə hɝ fɹi hænd wɪɡɡəld ət sɪlutʃə, hu hæd ɹævɪdʒ hæf ə ɡɹaʊs baɪ hɝsɛlf. ðə boʊsəmi wʊmən dɪd nɑt ɹɪplaɪ, bʌt ʃi snɪft. laʊdli. miɾɪŋ tuɑnz ɡeɪz, hi dɪlɪbɝətli waɪpt ɪz hænz ɑn ɪz bɹitʃɪz. hi cʊɾə ɡɔn oʊvɝ tə ðə stʃɹim, wɛɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ wɑʃɪŋ ðɛɹ hænz, bʌt noʊ wʌnz kloʊðɪŋ wɑz gɑnə bi pɹɪstin baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt mʊɹændi ɪn ɛni keɪs. bɪsaɪdz, wən ə wʊmən neɪm jə tɔɪ ɔl ðə taɪm, ɪt wɑz nætʃɹəl tə teɪk ɛni tʃæns tə lɛɾ əɹ noʊ jə wɝ noʊbɑdiz tɔɪ. ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən wæɡəld əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əɡɛn. ðɪs taɪm, sɪlutʃə læft, ən mæt fɛlt ɪz feɪs hit. hi kəɾ ɪmædʒən tu əɹ θɹi θɪŋz ʃi maɪɾ əv sɛd, nʌn ʌv wɪtʃ i wʊɾə ɛndʒɔɪd hɪɹɪŋ.

Mat gnawed the last scrap of meat from a rabbit's hind leg, and tossed the bone on the ground. Balding Lopin darted in, stroking at his beard in consternation, to pick it up and drop it in the pit he and Nerim had made in the mulch-covered forest floor, though the pit would be dug up by animals within a half-hour after their departure. Mat moved to wipe his hands on his breeches. Tuon, nibbling at a grouse leg on the other side of the low fire, gave him a very direct look, her eyebrows raised, while the fingers of her free hand wiggled at Selucia, who had ravaged half a grouse by herself. The bosomy woman did not reply, but she sniffed. Loudly. Meeting Tuon's gaze, he deliberately wiped his hands on his breeches. He could have gone over to the stream, where the Aes Sedai were washing their hands, but no one's clothing was going to be pristine by the time they reached Murandy in any case. Besides, when a woman named you Toy all the time, it was natural to take any chance to let her know you were nobody's toy. She shook her head and waggled her fingers again. This time, Selucia laughed, and Mat felt his face heat. He could imagine two or three things she might have said, none of which he would have enjoyed hearing.

sɛɾəl, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ɛn ə hɪz lɔɡ, meɪd ʃʊɹ i hɝd səm ə ðɛm ɛniweɪ. ɹitʃɪŋ ən əɡɹimənt wɪð ðə wʌntaɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɑt ʃɪftəɾ əɹ æɾətudz ə hɛɹ. "ʃi maɪɾ əv sɛd mɛn ɑɹ pɪɡz," ʃi mɝmɝd wɪθaʊt lɪftɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup, "ɔɹ dʒʌs ðət jə ɑɹ." hɝ dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs hæɾ ə haɪ nɛk, bʌt ʃi stɪl wɔɹ əɹ snʌɡ sɪlvɝ nɛkləs wɪð ðə mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ɪt. "ʃi meɪ hæv sɛd jəɹ ə mʌd-fʊɾɪd kʌntʃɹi laʊt wɪð dɝɾ ɪn jəɹ ɪɹz ən heɪ ɪn jəɹ hɛɹ. əɹ ʃi maɪɾ əv sɛd - "

Setalle, sitting on the end of his log, made sure he heard some of them anyway. Reaching an agreement with the onetime Aes Sedai had not shifted her attitudes a hair. "She might have said men are pigs," she murmured without lifting her eyes from her embroidery hoop, "or just that you are." Her dark gray riding dress had a high neck, but she still wore her snug silver necklace with the marriage knife hanging from it. "She may have said you're a mud-footed country lout with dirt in your ears and hay in your hair. Or she might have said - "

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ si ðə dɝɛkʃən jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ," hi toʊld əɹ θɹu ɡɹɪɾɪd tiθ. tuɑn ɡɪɡəld, ðoʊ ðə nɛkst ɪnstən əɹ feɪs bɪlɔŋd ɑn ən ɛksəkjuʃənɝ wʌns mɔɹ, koʊld ən stɝn.

"I think I see the direction you're going," he told her through gritted teeth. Tuon giggled, though the next instant her face belonged on an executioner once more, cold and stern.

pʊlɪŋ ɪz sɪlvɝ-maʊntəd paɪp ən ɡoʊtskɪn təbæk paʊtʃ fɹəm ɪz koʊt pɑkət, hi θʌm ðə boʊl fʊl ən lɪftəd ðə lɪɾ ɑn ðə bɑks ə stʃɹaɪkɝz əɾ ɪz fit. ɪt fæsəneɪɾəd ɪm ðə weɪ faɪɝ dʒʌst spɹæŋ ʌp, spaɪks ʌv ɪt dɑɹɾɪŋ ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz ət fɝst, wən i skɹætʃt ðə lʌmpi, ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt hɛɾ ʌv ə stʃɹaɪkɝ daʊn ðə ɹʌf saɪɾ ə ðə bɑks. hi weɪɾəd əntɪl ðə fleɪm bɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə hɛd bɪfɔɹ juzɪŋ ɪt tə laɪɾ ɪz paɪp. pʊlɪŋ ðə teɪst ən smɛl ə sʌlfɝ ɪndə hɪz maʊθ wʌns hæd bɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ hɪm. hi dʒɹɑp ðə bɝnɪŋ stɪk ən ɡɹaʊn ɪt fɝmli ʌndɝ ɪz but. ðə mʌltʃ wɑz stɪl dæmp fɹəm ðə læst ɹeɪn tə fɔl hɪɹ, bʌɾ i tʊk noʊ tʃænsəz wɪð faɪɝ ɪn wʊdz. ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, mɛn tɝn aʊt fɹəm maɪlz ɝaʊnd wən ðə wʊdz kɑt faɪɝ. səmtaɪmz hʌnʒɹədz ə mɑɹtʃɪz bɝnd, ivən soʊ.

Pulling his silver-mounted pipe and goatskin tabac pouch from his coat pocket, he thumbed the bowl full and lifted the lid on the box of strikers at his feet. It fascinated him the way fire just sprang up, spikes of it darting in all directions at first, when he scratched the lumpy, red-and-white head of a striker down the rough side of the box. He waited until the flame burned away from the head before using it to light his pipe. Pulling the taste and smell of sulphur into his mouth once had been enough for him. He dropped the burning stick and ground it firmly under his boot. The mulch was still damp from the last rain to fall here, but he took no chances with fire in woods. In the Two Rivers, men turned out from miles around when the woods caught fire. Sometimes hundreds of marches burned, even so.

"ðə stʃɹaɪkɝz, ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt bi weɪstəd," ɑlʌdʒɹə sɛd, lɪftɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm ðə smɔl stoʊnz bɔɹd bælənst ətɑp ə nɪɹbaɪ lɔɡ. tɑm, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ waɪt mʌstæʃɪz, kəntɪnjud tə kɑntəmpleɪt ðə kɹɔs-hætʃt bɔɹd. hi ɹɛɹli lɔst ət stoʊnz, jɛt ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə wɪn tu ɡeɪmz fɹəm ɪm sɪns ðeɪ lɛf ðə ʃoʊ. tu aʊɾ ʌv ə dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ, bʌt tɑm tʊk kɛɹ wɪð ɛniwʌn u kəd dɪfiɾ ɪm ivən wʌns. ʃi swɛpt əɹ biɾɪd bɹeɪdz bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. "mi, aɪ mʌs bi ɪn ðə seɪm pleɪs fəɹ tu deɪz tə meɪk mɔɹ. mɛn ɔlweɪz faɪnd weɪz tə meɪk wɝk fəɹ wɪmən, jɛs?"

"The strikers, they should not be wasted," Aludra said, lifting her eyes from the small stones board balanced atop a nearby log. Thom, stroking his long white mustaches, continued to contemplate the cross-hatched board. He rarely lost at stones, yet she had managed to win two games from him since they left the show. Two out of a dozen or more, but Thom took care with anyone who could defeat him even once. She swept her beaded braids back over her shoulders. "Me, I must be in the same place for two days to make more. Men always find ways to make work for women, yes?"

mæt pʌft əweɪ, ɪf nɑt kəntɛntədli, ət list wɪð səm dɪɡɹi ʌv plɛʒɝ. wɪmən! ə dɪlaɪt tə lʊk əɾ ən ə dɪlaɪt tə bi wɪð. wən ðeɪ wɝ nɑt faɪndɪŋ weɪz tə ɹʌb sɔlt ɪndə ə mænz haɪd. ɪt sim sɪks ʌp ən ə hæf dʌzən daʊn. ɪt tʃɹuli dɪd.

Mat puffed away, if not contentedly, at least with some degree of pleasure. Women! A delight to look at and a delight to be with. When they were not finding ways to rub salt into a man's hide. It seemed six up and a half dozen down. It truly did.

moʊst ə ðə pɑɹɾi hæd fɪnɪʃt iɾɪŋ - ðə bɛs pɑɹɾ ə tu ɡɹaʊs ən wʌn ɹæbət wɝ ɔl ðət ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ðə spɪts oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝ, bʌt ðeɪ wəd bi teɪkən əlɔŋ ɹæpt ɪn lɪnən; ðə hʌntɪŋ hæd bɪn ɡʊd dʊɹɪŋ ðə mɔɹnɪŋz ɹaɪd, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sɝɾənti ði æftɝnun wəd bi əz pɹɑfəɾəbəl, ən flætbɹɛɾ ən binz meɪɾ ə pʊɹ mil. ðoʊz u hæd fɪnɪʃt wɝ teɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ iz ɔɹ, ɪn ðə keɪs ə ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz, tʃɛkɪŋ ðə hɑbəl pækhɔɹsɪz, bɛɾɝ ðən sɪksti ʌv əm ɑn fɔɹ lidz. baɪɪŋ soʊ mɛni ɪn mɑɾɝɪn hæd bɪn ɪkspɛnsɪv, bʌt lukə hæd ɹʌʃt ɪndə taʊn tə teɪk kɛɹ ə ðə bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ hɪmsɛlf wʌns i hɝɾ əbaʊɾ ə mɝtʃən dɛɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹit. hi ɔlmoʊst - ɔlmoʊs bʌt nɑt kwaɪt - hæd bɪn ɹɛɾi tə ɡɪv əm pækhɔɹsɪz fɹəm ðə ʃoʊz ænəməlz tə bi ɹɪɾ ə mæt æftɝ ðæt. mɛni ʌv ði ænəməlz wɝ loʊɾəd wɪð ɑlʌdʒɹəz pɛɹəfəneɪljə ən əɹ səplaɪz. lukə hæɾ ɛndəɾ ʌp wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹt baɪ fɑɹ ə mæts ɡoʊld, wʌn weɪ ən ənʌðɝ. mæt hæd slɪpt ə fæt pɝs tə pɛtʃɹə ən klɛɹin, tu, bʌt ðət wɑz fɹɛndʃɪp, tə hɛlp əm baɪ ðɛɹ ɪn ə lɪɾəl sunɝ. wʌt ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf tə si ðɛm kʌmfɝɾəbli tə mʊɹændi, ðoʊ, ən ɔl i niɾəd tə ɹiplɛnɪʃ ɪt wɑz ə kɑmən ɹum wɛɹ daɪs wɝ biɪŋ tɔst.

Most of the party had finished eating - the best part of two grouse and one rabbit were all that remained on the spits over the fire, but they would be taken along wrapped in linen; the hunting had been good during the morning's ride, yet there was no certainty the afternoon would be as profitable, and flatbread and beans made a poor meal. Those who had finished were taking their ease or, in the case of the Redarms, checking the hobbled packhorses, better than sixty of them on four leads. Buying so many in Maderin had been expensive, but Luca had rushed into town to take care of the bargaining himself once he heard about a merchant dead in the street. He almost - almost but not quite - had been ready to give them packhorses from the show's animals to be rid of Mat after that. Many of the animals were loaded with Aludra's paraphernalia and her supplies. Luca had ended up with the greater part by far of Mat's gold, one way and another. Mat had slipped a fat purse to Petra and Clarine, too, but that was friendship, to help them buy their inn a little sooner. What remained in his saddlebags was more than enough to see them comfortably to Murandy, though, and all he needed to replenish it was a common room where dice were being tossed.

laɪlwɪn, wɪð ə kɝv sɔɹd hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ə bɹɔd lɛðɝ stʃɹæp ðət slæntəɾ əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst, ən doʊmən, wɪð ə ʃɔɹtsɔɝɾ ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə hɪz bɛlt ən ə bɹæs-stʌɾɪd kʌdʒəl ɑn ði ʌðɝ, wɝ tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð dʒulɪn ən æməðɛɹə ɑn jɛɾ ənʌðɝ lɔɡ kloʊs baɪ. laɪlwɪn - hi hæd kʌm tə æksɛp ðət ðət wɑz ði oʊnli neɪm ʃi wəd stʌmək - meɪɾ ə pɔɪn ə ʃoʊɪŋ ðət ʃi wəd nɑɾ əvɔɪd tuɑn əɹ sɪlutʃə, əɹ loʊɝ əɹ aɪz wən ðeɪ mɛt, ðoʊ ʃi hæd tə stil hɝsɛlf vɪzəbli tə kæɹi ɪɾ ɔf. dʒulɪn hæd ðə kʌfs ə hɪz blæk koʊt tɝn bæk, ə saɪn i fɛlt əmʌŋ fɹɛnz, əɹ ət lis pipəl i kəd tʃɹʌst. ðə wʌntaɪm pɑnɑɹtʃ ə tæɹɑbən stɪl klʌtʃt ðə θif-kætʃɝz ɑɹm taɪtli, bʌt ʃi mɛt laɪlwɪnz ʃɑɹp blu aɪz wɪð lɪɾəl flɪntʃɪŋ. ɪn fækt, ʃi ɔfən sim tə ɡeɪz ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɪð sʌmθɪŋ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɑ.

Leilwin, with a curved sword hanging from a broad leather strap that slanted across her chest, and Domon, with a shortsword on one side of his belt and a brass-studded cudgel on the other, were chatting with Juilin and Amathera on yet another log close by. Leilwin - he had come to accept that that was the only name she would stomach - made a point of showing that she would not avoid Tuon or Selucia, or lower her eyes when they met, though she had to steel herself visibly to carry it off. Juilin had the cuffs of his black coat turned back, a sign he felt among friends, or at least people he could trust. The onetime Panarch of Tarabon still clutched the thief-catcher's arm tightly, but she met Leilwin's sharp blue eyes with little flinching. In fact, she often seemed to gaze at the other woman with something approaching awe.

siɾəd kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ən ʌnmaɪnfəl ə ðə dæmpnəs, noʊl wɑz pleɪɪŋ sneɪks ən fɑksəz wɪð oʊlvɝ ən spɪnɪŋ waɪl teɪlz əbaʊt ðə lænz bɪɑn ði il weɪst, əbaʊt səm ɡɹeɪt koʊstəl sɪɾi ðət fɔɹənɝz wɝ nɑɾ əlaʊd tə liv ɪksɛp baɪ ʃɪp ən ði ɪnhæbəɾənts wɝ nɑɾ əlaʊd tə liv əɾ ɔl. mæt wɪʃt ðeɪ wəd faɪn ənʌðɝ ɡeɪm tə pleɪ. ɛvɹi taɪm ðeɪ bɹɔɾ aʊt ðət pis ə ɹɛd klɔθ wɪð ɪts spaɪɾɝwɛb ə blæk laɪnz, ɪt ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ə hɪz pɹɑməs tə tɑm, ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ðə blʌɾi ɛlfɪn wɝ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd sʌmhaʊ, ən meɪbi ðə fleɪmɪŋ æɛlfɪn, tu. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ keɪm ʌp fɹəm ðə stʃɹim, ən dʒoʊlin stɑp tə tɔk wɪð blɹɪk ən fɛn. bɛθəmən ən sɛɾə, tʃɹeɪlɪŋ əlɔŋ bɪhaɪnd, hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əntɪl ə dʒɛstʃɝ fɹəm ðə ɡɹin sɛn əm tə stæn bɪhaɪn ðə lɔɡ wɛɹ tɛslɪn ən idɛzinə sæt, əz fɑɹ əpɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ kəd mænədʒ, wɪð ʌnkʌt bɹæntʃəz bɪtwin, ən bɪɡæn ɹɛɾɪŋ smɔl lɛðɝ-baʊn bʊks teɪkən fɹəm ðɛɹ bɛl paʊtʃəz. boʊθ bɛθəmən ən sɛɾə stʊd bɪhaɪn idɛzinə.

Seated cross-legged on the ground and unmindful of the dampness, Noal was playing Snakes and Foxes with Olver and spinning wild tales about the lands beyond the Aiel Waste, about some great coastal city that foreigners were not allowed to leave except by ship and the inhabitants were not allowed to leave at all. Mat wished they would find another game to play. Every time they brought out that piece of red cloth with its spiderweb of black lines, it reminded him of his promise to Thom, reminded him the bloody Eelfinn were inside his head somehow, and maybe the flaming Aelfinn, too. The Aes Sedai came up from the stream, and Joline stopped to talk with Blaeric and Fen. Bethamin and Seta, trailing along behind, hesitated until a gesture from the Green sent them to stand behind the log where Teslyn and Edesina sat, as far apart as they could manage, with uncut branches between, and began reading small leather-bound books taken from their belt pouches. Both Bethamin and Seta stood behind Edesina.

ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd fɔɹmɝ sʌldəm hæd kʌm ɹaʊn ɪn spɛktækjəlɝ, ən peɪnfəl, fæʃən. peɪnfəl fəɹ əɹ ən fəɹ ðə sɪstɝz. wən ʃi fɝs hɛzɪɾəntli æskt əm tə titʃ hɝ, tu, ət sʌpɝ ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ, ðeɪ ɹəfjuzd. ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli titʃɪŋ bɛθəmən kəz ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi tʃænəld. sɛɾə wɑz tu oʊl tə bɪkʌm ə nɑvəs, ʃi hæd nɑt tʃænəld, ən ðət wɑz ðæt. soʊ ʃi duplɪkeɪɾɪd wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ðət bɛθəmən hæd dʌn ən hæɾ ɔl θɹi lipɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kʊkfaɪɝ ən skwilɪŋ ɪn ʃaʊɝz ə dænsɪŋ spɑɹks fəɹ əz lɔŋ əz ʃi kəd hoʊld ɑn tə ðə paʊɝ. ðeɪ əɡɹid tə titʃ əɹ ðɛn. ət list, dʒoʊlin ən idɛzinə dɪd. tɛslɪn stɪl wɑz hævɪŋ nʌn ʌv ɛni sʌldəm, fɔɹmɝ əɹ nɑt. ɔl θɹi ʌv əm tʊk ə hæn ɪn swɪtʃɪŋ hɝ, ðoʊ, ən ʃi hæd spɛn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ kəntɪnjuəli izɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪn əɹ sæɾəl. ʃi stɪl lʊkt əfɹeɪd, ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ ən meɪbi ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt stʃɹeɪnʒli, hɝ feɪs sʌmhaʊ simd . . . kɑntɛnt, tu. haʊ tə ʌndɝstæn ðət wɑz bɪɑn mæt.

The yellow-haired former sul'dam had come round in spectacular, and painful, fashion. Painful for her and for the sisters. When she first hesitantly asked them to teach her, too, at supper the night before, they refused. They were only teaching Bethamin because she had already channeled. Seta was too old to become a novice, she had not channeled, and that was that. So she duplicated whatever it was that Bethamin had done and had all three leaping about the cookfire and squealing in showers of dancing sparks for as long as she could hold on to the Power. They agreed to teach her then. At least, Joline and Edesina did. Teslyn still was having none of any sul'dam, former or not. All three of them took a hand in switching her, though, and she had spent the morning continually easing herself in her saddle. She still looked afraid, of the One Power and maybe of the Aes Sedai, but strangely, her face somehow seemed . . . content, too. How to understand that was beyond Mat.

hi ʃʊɾə fɛl kɑntɛn hɪmsɛlf. hi hæɾ əvɔɪɾəd ə tʃɑɹdʒ ə mɝɾɝ, əvɔɪɾəd ɹaɪɾɪŋ blaɪnli ɪndə ə sintʃæn tʃɹæp ðət wʊɾə kɪl tuɑn, ən lɛf ðə ɡoʊləm bɪhaɪn fəɹ ɡʊd ðɪs taɪm. ɪt wəd bi fɑloʊɪŋ lukəz ʃoʊ, ən lukə hæd bɪn wɔɹnd, fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɡʊd ðət wəd du. ɪn wɛl ʌndɝ tu wiks i wəd bi oʊvɝ ðə maʊntənz ɪndə mʊɹændi. ðə nid tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə ɡɛt tuɑn bæk tə ɛbu dɑɹ seɪfli, noʊ izi tæsk əɾ ɔl naʊ, ɪspɛʃli sɪns i wəɾ əv tə ɡɑɹɾ əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə spɪɹəɾ əɹ əweɪ, wəd min ðət mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ tə lʊk əɾ əɹ feɪs. ən tə tʃɹaɪ pʌzəlɪŋ aʊt wʌt wɛn ɑn bɪhaɪn ðoʊz bɪɡ bjuɾəfəl aɪz. hi ʃʊɾə bɪn əz hæpi əz ə ɡoʊɾ ɪn ə kɔɹn kɹɪb. hi wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm ɪt.

He should have felt content himself. He had avoided a charge of murder, avoided riding blindly into a Seanchan trap that would have killed Tuon, and left the gholam behind for good this time. It would be following Luca's show, and Luca had been warned, for whatever good that would do. In well under two weeks he would be over the mountains into Murandy. The need to figure out how to get Tuon back to Ebou Dar safely, no easy task at all now, especially since he would have to guard against Aes Sedai trying to spirit her away, would mean that much longer to look at her face. And to try puzzling out what went on behind those big beautiful eyes. He should have been as happy as a goat in a corn crib. He was far from it.

fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ɔl ðoʊz sɔɹd-kʌts i hæd ɹəsivd ɪn mɑɾɝɪn hɝt. səm ə ðɛm wɝ ɪnfleɪmd, ðoʊ hi hæd mænədʒ tə kip ðət fɹəm ɛniwʌn soʊ fɑɹ. hi heɪɾəd biɪŋ fʌst oʊvɝ nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz i heɪɾəd ɛniwʌn juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ɑn hɪm. ləpɪn ən nɹɪm hæd soʊɾ ɪm ʌp əz wɛl əz ðeɪ kʊd, ən i hæd ɹəfjuz hilɪŋ dɪspaɪɾ ətɛmptəd bʊliɪŋ baɪ ɔl θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪz ðət dʒoʊlin, ʌv ɔl pipəl, tʃɹaɪd tə ɪnsɪst, bʌt ʃi dɪd, ən flʌŋ ʌp əɹ hænz ɪn dɪsɡʌst wən i feɪl tə ɹɪlɛnt. ənʌðɝ sɝpɹaɪz hæd bɪn tuɑn.

For one thing, all those sword-cuts he had received in Maderin hurt. Some of them were inflamed, though he had managed to keep that from anyone so far. He hated being fussed over nearly as much as he hated anyone using the Power on him. Lopin and Nerim had sewed him up as well as they could, and he had refused Healing despite attempted bullying by all three Aes Sedai. He had been surprised that Joline, of all people, tried to insist, but she did, and flung up her hands in disgust when he failed to relent. Another surprise had been Tuon.

"doʊn bi fulɪʃ, tɔɪ," ʃi hæd dʒɹɔld ɪn ɪz tɛnt, stændɪŋ oʊvɝ hɪm, ɑɹmz foʊldəd bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, waɪl ləpɪn ən nɹɪm plaɪd ðɛɹ niɾəlz ən i ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ. hɝ pɹəpɹaɪətɛɹi ɛɹ, vɛɹi mʌtʃ ə wʊmən meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ əɹ pɹɑpɝɾi wɑz ɹɪpɛɹd pɹɑpɝli, hæd bɪn ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm ɡɹaɪn ɪz tiθ, nɛvɝ maɪn ðə niɾəlz. əɹ ðəɾ i wɑz daʊn tə hɪz smɔlkloʊðz! ʃi hæd dʒʌst wɔkt ɪn ən ɹəfjuz tə liv ʃɔɹɾ ə mænhænlɪŋ, ən i hæd fɛlt ɪn noʊ kəndɪʃən tə mænhændəl ə wʊmən i səspɛktəd maɪt bi eɪbəl tə bɹeɪk ɪz ɑɹm. "ðɪs hilɪŋ ɪz ə wʌndɝfəl θɪŋ. maɪ maɪələn noʊz ɪt, ən aɪ tɔɾ ɪt tə maɪ ʌðɝz, tu. ʌv kɔɹs, mɛni pipəl ɑɹ fulɪʃ əbaʊt hævɪŋ ðə paʊɝ tʌtʃ ðɛm. hæf maɪ sɝvəns wəd feɪn ət ðə sədʒɛstʃən, ən moʊst ə ðə blʌd, tu, aɪ ʃʊdn bi sɝpɹaɪzd. bʌɾ aɪ wʊdn əv ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪɾ ə ju." ɪf ʃi hæɾ ə kɔɹɾɝ ɪz ɪkspɪɹiəns ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi wəd hæv.

"Don't be foolish, Toy," she had drawled in his tent, standing over him, arms folded beneath her breasts, while Lopin and Nerim plied their needles and he gritted his teeth. Her proprietary air, very much a woman making sure her property was repaired properly, had been enough to make him grind his teeth, never mind the needles. Or that he was down to his smallclothes! She had just walked in and refused to leave short of manhandling, and he had felt in no condition to manhandle a woman he suspected might be able to break his arm. "This Healing is a wonderful thing. My Mylen knows it, and I taught it to my others, too. Of course, many people are foolish about having the Power touch them. Half my servants would faint at the suggestion, and most of the Blood, too, I shouldn't be surprised. But I wouldn't have expected it of you." If she had a quarter his experience of Aes Sedai, she would have.

ðeɪ hæd ɹɪɾən ɔf ʌp ðə ɹoʊd fɹəm mɑɾɝɪn əz ɪf sɛɾɪŋ aʊt fəɹ luɡɹd, ðən teɪkən tə ðə fɔɹəst əz sun əz ðə læs fɑɹmz wɝ aʊɾ ə saɪt. ðə moʊmən ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə tʃɹiz, ðə daɪs stɑɹɾəd ʌp ɪn ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn. ðət wɑz ði ʌðɝ θɪŋ ðət saʊɝɾ ɪz mud, ðoʊz blʌɾi daɪs dʒɹʌmɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd fəɹ tu deɪz. ðəɹ hɑɹdli simd ɛni weɪ ðeɪ kəd stɑp hɪɹ ɪn ðə fɔɹəst. wʌt kaɪndə moʊmɛntəs ɪvɛn kəd hæpən ɪn ðə wʊdz? stɪl, hi hæd steɪd wɛl klɪɹ ə ðə smɔl vɪlədʒəz ðeɪ hæd pæst. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðə daɪs wəd stɑp, ðoʊ, ən i kəɾ oʊnli weɪt fəɹ ɪt.

They had ridden off up the road from Maderin as if setting out for Lugard, then taken to the forest as soon as the last farms were out of sight. The moment they entered the trees, the dice started up in his head again. That was the other thing that soured his mood, those bloody dice drumming inside his head for two days. There hardly seemed any way they could stop here in the forest. What kind of momentous event could happen in the woods? Still, he had stayed well clear of the small villages they had passed. Sooner or later the dice would stop, though, and he could only wait for it.

tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə stʃɹim tə wɑʃ, wɪɡəlɪŋ ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝz ət wʌn ənʌðɝ ɹæpədli. tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ. wən wɪmən stɑɹɾəd pʊɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ, jə kəd bi ʃʊɹ -  æməðɛɹə skɹimd, ən ɛvɹi hɛd wɪpt ɝaʊn təwɔɹd hɝ. mæt spɑɾəd ðə kɑz əz kwɪkli əz dʒulɪn dɪd, ə blæk-skeɪl sneɪk ə ɡʊd sɛvən fit lɔŋ ɹɪəlɪŋ kwɪkli əweɪ fɹəm ðə lɔɡ dʒulɪn wɑz siɾəd ɑn. laɪlwɪn kɝst ən lɛp tə hɝ fit dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ sɔɹd, bʌt noʊ fæstɝ ðən dʒulɪn, hu tʌɡd ɪz ʃɔɹtsɔɝd fɹi ʌv ɪts skæbɝɾ ən stɑɹɾəd æftɝ ðə sneɪk soʊ swɪfli ðəɾ ɪz kɑnɪkəl ɹɛd kæp fɛl ɔf.

Tuon and Selucia headed for the stream to wash, wiggling their fingers at one another rapidly. Talking about him, he was sure. When women started putting their heads together, you could be sure -  Amathera screamed, and every head whipped around toward her. Mat spotted the cause as quickly as Juilin did, a black-scaled snake a good seven feet long wriggling quickly away from the log Juilin was seated on. Leilwin cursed and leaped to her feet drawing her sword, but no faster than Juilin, who tugged his shortsword free of its scabbard and started after the snake so swiftly that his conical red cap fell off.

"lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ, dʒulɪn," mæt sɛd. "ɪts hɛɾɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ʌs. lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ." ðə θɪŋ pɹɑbli hæɾ ə dɛn ʌndɝ ðət lɔɡ ən hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪz tə kʌm aʊɾ ən faɪn pipəl. lʌkəli, blæklənsɪz wɝ sɑlətɛɹi sneɪks.

"Let it go, Juilin," Mat said. "It's heading away from us. Let it go." The thing probably had a den under that log and had been surprised to come out and find people. Luckily, blacklances were solitary snakes.

dʒulɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ ðət kʌmfɝɾɪŋ ə ʃɪvɝɪŋ æməðɛɹə wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən tʃeɪsɪŋ ə sneɪk. "wʌt kaɪn ɪz ɪt, ɛniweɪ?" hi sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz. hi wɑz ə sɪɾi mæn, æftɝ ɔl. mæt toʊl hɪm, ən fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi lʊkt əz ðoʊ hi mɛn tə ɡoʊ æftɝ ɪɾ əɡɛn. waɪzli, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd əɡɛnst. blæklənsɪz wɝ kwɪk əz laɪtnɪŋ, ən wɪð ə ʃɔɹtsɔɝd, hi wʊɾə niɾəd tə ɡɛt kloʊs. ɛniweɪ, æməðɛɹə wɑz klɪŋɪŋ tə hɪm soʊ hɑɹɾ i wʊɾə hæɾ ə taɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ fɹi ʌv hɝ.

Juilin hesitated before deciding that comforting a shivering Amathera was more important than chasing a snake. "What kind is it, anyway?" he said, folding her in his arms. He was a city man, after all. Mat told him, and for a moment, he looked as though he meant to go after it again. Wisely, he decided against. Blacklances were quick as lightning, and with a shortsword, he would have needed to get close. Anyway, Amathera was clinging to him so hard he would have had a time getting free of her.

teɪkɪŋ ɪz hæt fɹəm ðə bʌɾ ə hɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ, wɪtʃ wɑz dʒɹɪvən pɔɪnt-daʊn ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, mæt sɛɾəld ɪɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd. "deɪlaɪts weɪstɪŋ," hi sɛɾ ɝaʊn ɪz paɪpɛstəm. "taɪm wi wɝ muvɪŋ ɑn. doʊn dɔɾəl oʊvɝ ðɛɹ, tuɑn. jəɹ hænz ɑɹ klin ɪnʌf." hi hæd tʃɹaɪd kɔlɪŋ əɹ pɹɛʃəs, bʌt sɪns əɹ kleɪm ə vɪktɝi bæk ɪn mɑɾɝɪn, ʃi ɹəfjuz tə æknɑlɪdʒ ðəɾ i hæɾ ivən spoʊkən wən i dɪd.

Taking his hat from the butt of his ashandarei, which was driven point-down into the ground, Mat settled it on his head. "Daylight's wasting," he said around his pipestem. "Time we were moving on. Don't dawdle over there, Tuon. Your hands are clean enough." He had tried calling her Precious, but since her claim of victory back in Maderin, she refused to acknowledge that he had even spoken when he did.

ʃi dɪd nɑt hɝi ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst, ʌv kɔɹs. baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi ɹɪtɝnd, dʒɹaɪɪŋ əɹ smɔl hænz ɑn ə smɔl pis ə taʊəlɪŋ ðət sɪlutʃə wəd dʒɹeɪp əkɹɔs ðə pɑməl ə hɝ sæɾəl tə dʒɹaɪ, nɹɪm ən ləpɪn hæd fɪld ɪn ðə ɹɛfjus pɪt, ɹæp ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə ðə mil ən tʌkt əm ɪndə nɹɪmz sæɾəlbæɡz, ən daʊs ðə faɪɝ wɪð wɔɾɝ bɹɔt fɹəm ðə stʃɹim ɪn foʊldɪŋ lɛðɝ bʌkəts. æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪn hænd, mæt wɑz ɹɛɾi tə maʊn pɪps.

She did not hurry in the slightest, of course. By the time she returned, drying her small hands on a small piece of toweling that Selucia would drape across the pommel of her saddle to dry, Nerim and Lopin had filled in the refuse pit, wrapped the remains of the meal and tucked them into Nerim's saddlebags, and doused the fire with water brought from the stream in folding leather buckets. Ashandarei in hand, Mat was ready to mount Pips.

"ə stʃɹeɪnʒ mæn, hu lɛts pɔɪzənəs sɝpəns ɡoʊ," tuɑn sɛd. "fɹʌm ðə fɛloʊz ɹiækʃən, aɪ əsum ə blækləns ɪz pɔɪzənəs?"

"A strange man, who lets poisonous serpents go," Tuon said. "From the fellow's reaction, I assume a blacklance is poisonous?"

"vɛɹi," hi toʊl hɝ. "bʌt sneɪks doʊn baɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪ kæn iɾ ənlɛs ðəɹ θɹɛɾənd." hi pʊɾ ə fʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝəp.

"Very," he told her. "But snakes don't bite anything they can't eat unless they're threatened." He put a foot in the stirrup.

"ju meɪ kɪs mi, tɔɪ."

"You may kiss me, Toy."

hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. hɝ wɝdz, nɑt spoʊkən sɔfli, hæd meɪɾ əm ði əbdʒɛkt ʌv ɛvɹi aɪ. sɪlutʃəz feɪs wɑz soʊ stɪfli ɪkspɹɛʃənləs əɹ dɪsəpɹuvəl kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn pleɪnɝ. "naʊ?" hi sɛd. "wɛn wi stɑp tənaɪt, wi kəd teɪk ə stʃɹoʊl əloʊn - "

He gave a start. Her words, not spoken softly, had made them the object of every eye. Selucia's face was so stiffly expressionless her disapproval could not have been plainer. "Now?" he said. "When we stop tonight, we could take a stroll alone - "

"baɪ tənaɪt, aɪ meɪ hæv tʃeɪnʒd maɪ maɪnd, tɔɪ. kɔl ɪɾ ə wɪm, fəɹ ə mæn u lɛts pɔɪzənəs sneɪks ɡoʊ." meɪbi ʃi sɔ wʌn ə hɝ oʊmənz ɪn ðæt?

"By tonight, I may have changed my mind, Toy. Call it a whim, for a man who lets poisonous snakes go." Maybe she saw one of her omens in that?

teɪkɪŋ ɔf ɪz hæɾ ən stɪkɪŋ ðə blæk spɪɹ bæk ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, hi tʊk ðə paɪp fɹəm bɪtwin ɪz tiθ ən plæntəɾ ə tʃeɪs kɪs ɑn əɹ fʊl lɪps. ə fɝs kɪs wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi ɹʌf wɪð. hi dɪd nɑt wɑn əɹ tə θɪŋk ɪm pʊʃi, əɹ kɹud. ʃi wɑz noʊ tævɝn meɪd tə ɛndʒɔɪ ə bɪɾ ə slæp ən tɪkəl. bɪsaɪdz, hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ɔl ðoʊz aɪz wɑtʃɪŋ. sʌmwʌn snɪkɝd. sɪlutʃə ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz.

Taking off his hat and sticking the black spear back into the ground, he took the pipe from between his teeth and planted a chaste kiss on her full lips. A first kiss was nothing to be rough with. He did not want her to think him pushy, or crude. She was no tavern maid to enjoy a bit of slap and tickle. Besides, he could almost feel all those eyes watching. Someone snickered. Selucia rolled her eyes.

tuɑn foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts ən lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm θɹu hɝ lɔŋ aɪlæʃɪz. "du aɪ ɹimaɪn jə ʌv jəɹ sɪstɝ?" ʃi æskt ɪn ə deɪnʒɝəs toʊn. "ɔɹ pɝhæps jəɹ mʌðɝ?" sʌmbɑɾi læft. mɔɹ ðən wʌn sʌmbɑɾi, ɪn fækt.

Tuon folded her arms beneath her breasts and looked up at him through her long eyelashes. "Do I remind you of your sister?" she asked in a dangerous tone. "Or perhaps your mother?" Somebody laughed. More than one somebody, in fact.

ɡɹɪmli, mæt tæp ðə dɑɾəl fɹəm ɪz paɪp ɑn ðə hil ə hɪz buɾ ən stʌf ðə wɔɹm paɪp ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkət. hi hʌŋ ɪz hæt bæk ɑn ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ. ɪf ʃi wɑntəɾ ə ɹil kɪs. . . . hæɾ i ɹɪli θɔt ʃi wəd nɑt fɪl ɪz ɑɹmz? slɪm, ʃi wɑz tə bi ʃʊɹ, ən smɔl, bʌt ʃi fɪld əm vɛɹi naɪsli ɪndid. hi bɛn ɪz hɛd tə hɝz. ʃi wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm ðə fɝst wʊmən i hæd kɪst. hi nu wʌɾ i wɑz əbaʊt. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli - əɹ ðən əɡɛn, pɝhæps nɑt soʊ sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli - ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ. ʃi wɑz ə kwɪk pjupəl, ðoʊ. vɛɹi kwɪk.

Grimly, Mat tapped the dottle from his pipe on the heel of his boot and stuffed the warm pipe into his coat pocket. He hung his hat back on the ashandarei. If she wanted a real kiss. . . . Had he really thought she would not fill his arms? Slim, she was to be sure, and small, but she filled them very nicely indeed. He bent his head to hers. She was far from the first woman he had kissed. He knew what he was about. Surprisingly - or then again, perhaps not so surprisingly - she did not know. She was a quick pupil, though. Very quick.

wən i faɪnəli ɹilis hɝ, ʃi stʊd ðəɹ lʊkɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ əɹ bɹɛθ. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, hɪz bɹɛθ keɪm ə lɪɾəl ɹæədli, tu. mɛtwɪn wɪsəld əpɹiʃieɪɾɪvli. mæt smaɪld. wʌt wəd ʃi θɪŋk ʌv wʌt pleɪnli wɑz əɹ fɝst ɹil kɪs ɛvɝ? hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə smaɪl tu waɪdli, ðoʊ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑn əɹ tə θɪŋk i wɑz smɝkɪŋ.

When he finally released her, she stood there looking up at him and trying to catch her breath. For that matter, his breath came a little raggedly, too. Metwyn whistled appreciatively. Mat smiled. What would she think of what plainly was her first real kiss ever? He tried not to smile too widely, though. He did not want her to think he was smirking.

ʃi leɪd fɪŋɡɝz əɡɛnst ɪz tʃik. "aɪ θɔt soʊ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ðət sloʊ hʌni dʒɹɔl. "jɔɹ fivɝɪʃ. səm ə jəɹ wunz mʌs bi ɪnfɛktəd."

She laid fingers against his cheek. "I thought so," she said in that slow honey drawl. "You're feverish. Some of your wounds must be infected."

mæt blɪŋkt. hi ɡeɪv əɹ ə kɪs ðət hæd tə hæv kɝld əɹ toʊz, ən ɔl ʃi sɛd wɑz ðəɾ ɪz feɪs wɑz hɑt? hi bɛn ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn - ðɪs taɪm, ʃi wəd blʌɾi wɛl nid hɛlp tə steɪ stændɪŋ! - bʌt ʃi pʊɾ ə hæn əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst, fɛndɪŋ ɪm ɔf.

Mat blinked. He gave her a kiss that had to have curled her toes, and all she said was that his face was hot? He bent his head again - this time, she would bloody well need help to stay standing! - but she put a hand against his chest, fending him off.

"sɪlutʃə, fɛtʃ ðə bɑks ʌv ɔɪnmənts aɪ ɡɑt fɹəm mɪstʃɹəs lukə," ʃi kəmændəd. sɪlutʃə wɛn skɝiɪŋ fəɹ tuɑnz blæk-ænd-waɪt maʊnt.

"Selucia, fetch the box of ointments I got from Mistress Luca," she commanded. Selucia went scurrying for Tuon's black-and-white mount.

"wi doʊn əv taɪm fəɹ ðət naʊ," mæt sɛd. "aɪl smɪɹ ɑn sʌmθɪŋ tənaɪt." hi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv kɛpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt.

"We don't have time for that now," Mat said. "I'll smear on something tonight." He might as well have kept his mouth shut.

"stʃɹɪp ɔf, tɔɪ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ðə seɪm toʊn ʃi hæd juzd wɪð əɹ meɪd. "ði ɔɪnmənt wɪl stɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə bi bɹeɪv."

"Strip off, Toy," she said in the same tone she had used with her maid. "The ointment will sting, but I expect you to be brave."

"aɪ æm nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə - !"

"I am not going to - !"

"ɹaɪɾɝz kʌmɪŋ," hɑɹnən ənaʊnst. hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ɑn ə dɑɹk beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ wɪð waɪt fɔɹfit, hoʊldɪŋ ðə lɛd tə wʌn ə ðə stʃɹɪŋz ə pækhɔɹsɪz. "wʌn ə ðɛmz veɪnɪn."

"Riders coming," Harnan announced. He was already in his saddle, on a dark bay gelding with white forefeet, holding the lead to one of the strings of packhorses. "One of them's Vanin."

mæt swʌŋ ʌp ɑntu pɪps fəɹ ə bɛɾɝ væntədʒ. ə pɛɹ ə hɔɹsmən wɝ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ əɾ ə ɡæləp, dɑdʒɪŋ ɝaʊn fɔlən tʃɹiz wən ðeɪ hæd tə. əsaɪd fɹəm ɹɛkəɡnaɪzɪŋ tʃəl veɪnɪnz dʌn, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðə mæn hɪmsɛlf. noʊbɑdi ɛls u wɑz ðət waɪɾ ən sæɾ ɪz sæɾəl laɪk ə sæk ə sut cʊɾə meɪnteɪn ɪz siɾ ət ðət peɪs wɪθaʊɾ ɛni əpɛɹən ɛfɝt. ðə mæn cʊɾə steɪɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl ɑn ə waɪl bɔɹ. ðən mæt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ði ʌðɝ ɹaɪɾɝ, huz kloʊk wɑz fleɪlɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən fɛlt əz ɪf i hæd bɪn pʌntʃt ɪn ðə bɛli. hi wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd ɪn ðə lis hæd ðə daɪs stɑp ðɛn, bʌt ðeɪ kɛp baʊnsɪŋ ɔf ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪz skʌl. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt wɑz tælmɑnz blʌɾi wɛl duɪŋ ɪn ɔltɑɹə?

Mat swung up onto Pips for a better vantage. A pair of horsemen were approaching at a gallop, dodging around fallen trees when they had to. Aside from recognizing Chel Vanin's dun, there was no mistaking the man himself. Nobody else who was that wide and sat his saddle like a sack of suet could have maintained his seat at that pace without any apparent effort. The man could have stayed in the saddle on a wild boar. Then Mat recognized the other rider, whose cloak was flailing behind him, and felt as if he had been punched in the belly. He would not have been surprised in the least had the dice stopped then, but they kept bouncing off the inside of his skull. What in the Light was Talmanes bloody well doing in Altara?

ðə tu ɹaɪɾɝz sloʊd tə ə wɔk ʃɔɹɾ ə mæt, ən veɪnɪn ɹeɪn ɪn tə lɛt tælmɑnz əpɹoʊtʃ əloʊn. ɪt wɑz nɑt ʃaɪnəs. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ʃaɪ əbaʊt veɪnɪn. hi lin læzəli ɑn ðə tɔl pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl ən spæt tə wʌn saɪd θɹu ə ɡæp ɪn ɪz tiθ. noʊ, hi nu mæt wəd nɑt bi bɛs plizd, ən i mɛn tə steɪ klɪɹ.

The two riders slowed to a walk short of Mat, and Vanin reined in to let Talmanes approach alone. It was not shyness. There was nothing shy about Vanin. He leaned lazily on the tall pommel of his saddle and spat to one side through a gap in his teeth. No, he knew Mat would not be best pleased, and he meant to stay clear.

"veɪnɪn bɹɔt mi ʌp tə deɪt, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd. ʃɔɹɾ ən wɪɹi, wɪð ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd ʃeɪvd ən paʊɾɝd, ðə kɛɹhinɪn hæd ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ stʃɹaɪps ə kʌlɝ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst ɪn kənsɪɾɝəbəl nʌmbɝ, bʌɾ ə smɔl ɹɛd hæn soʊn tə ðə bɹɛst ə hɪz dɑɹk koʊt wɑz ɪts oʊnli dɛkɝeɪʃən ənlɛs jə kaʊntəd ðə lɔŋ ɹɛd skɑɹf taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz lɛft ɑɹm. hi nɛvɝ læft ən sɛldəm smaɪld, bʌɾ i hæɾ ɪz ɹizənz. "aɪ wɑz sɑɹi tə hɪɹ əbaʊt neɪlzin ən ði ʌðɝz. ə ɡʊd mæn, neɪlzin. ðeɪ ɔl wɝ."

"Vanin brought me up to date, Mat," Talmanes said. Short and wiry, with the front of his head shaved and powdered, the Cairhienin had the right to wear stripes of color across his chest in considerable number, but a small red hand sewn to the breast of his dark coat was its only decoration unless you counted the long red scarf tied around his left arm. He never laughed and seldom smiled, but he had his reasons. "I was sorry to hear about Nalesean and the others. A good man, Nalesean. They all were."

"jɛs, ðeɪ wɝ," mæt sɛd, kipɪŋ ə taɪt ɹeɪn ɑn ɪz tɛmpɝ. "aɪ əsum ɛɡwin nɛvɝ keɪm tə jə fəɹ hɛlp ɡɛɾɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðoʊz ful ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt wʌɾ ɪn ðə blʌɾi fleɪmɪŋ laɪɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?" wɛl, meɪbi hi dɪd nɑɾ əv sətʃ ə taɪt ɹeɪn æftɝ ɔl. "æt lis tɛl mi jə hævən bɹɔt ðə hoʊl blʌɾi bæn θɹi hʌnʒɹəd blʌɾi maɪlz ɪndə ɔltɑɹə wɪð ju."

"Yes, they were," Mat said, keeping a tight rein on his temper. "I assume Egwene never came to you for help getting away from those fool Aes Sedai, but what in the bloody flaming Light are you doing here?" Well, maybe he did not have such a tight rein after all. "At least tell me you haven't brought the whole bloody Band three hundred bloody miles into Altara with you."

"ɛɡwin ɪz stɪl ði æmɪɝlɪn," ði ʌðɝ mæn sɛd kɑmli, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ɪz kloʊk. ənʌðɝ ɹɛd hænd, lɑɹdʒɝ, mɑɹk ðæt. "ju wɝ ɹɔŋ əbaʊt hɝ, mæt. ʃi ɹɪli ɪz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən ʃiz ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ baɪ ðə skɹʌf ə ðə nɛk. ðoʊ səm ə ðɛm maɪt nɑt noʊ ɪt jɛt. ðə læst aɪ sɔ, ʃi ən ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm wɝ ɔf tə bɪsidʒ tɑɹ vəlɑn. ʃi maɪɾ əv ɪt baɪ naʊ. ðeɪ kən meɪk hoʊlz ɪn ði ɛɹ laɪk ðə wʌn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn meɪd tə teɪk əs nɪɹ sɑlədɑɹ." ðə kʌlɝz spʌn ɪn mæts hɛd, ɹizɑlvɪŋ fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɪndə ɹænd tɔkɪŋ tə səm wʊmən wɪð ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ɪn ə bʌn ətɑp əɹ hɛd, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, hi θɔt, bʌɾ ɪz æŋɡɝ blu ði ɪmədʒ əweɪ laɪk mɪst.

"Egwene is still the Amyrlin," the other man said calmly, straightening his cloak. Another red hand, larger, marked that. "You were wrong about her, Mat. She really is the Amyrlin Seat, and she has those Aes Sedai by the scruff of the neck. Though some of them might not know it yet. The last I saw, she and the whole lot of them were off to besiege Tar Valon. She might have it by now. They can make holes in the air like the one the Dragon Reborn made to take us near Salidar." The colors spun in Mat's head, resolving for an instant into Rand talking to some woman with gray hair in a bun atop her head, an Aes Sedai, he thought, but his anger blew the image away like mist.

ɔl ðət tɔk ə ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ən tɑɹ vəlɑn ətʃɹæktəd ðə sɪstɝz, ʌv kɔɹs. ðeɪ hil ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ʌp bɪsaɪd mæt ən tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk oʊvɝ. wɛl, idɛzinə hʌŋ bæk ə lɪɾəl ðə weɪ ʃi dɪd wən tɛslɪn əɹ dʒoʊlin hæd ðə bɪɾ ɪn əɹ tiθ, bʌt ði ʌðɝ tu. . . .

All that talk of the Amyrlin Seat and Tar Valon attracted the sisters, of course. They heeled their horses up beside Mat and tried to take over. Well, Edesina hung back a little the way she did when Teslyn or Joline had the bit in her teeth, but the other two. . . .

"hu dʒju bi tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?" tɛslɪn dɪmændəd waɪl dʒoʊlin wɑz stɪl oʊpənɪŋ əɹ maʊθ. "ɛɡwin? ðəɹ dɪd bi ən æksɛptɪd neɪmd ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, bʌt ʃi bi ə ɹʌnəweɪ."

"Who do you be talking about?" Teslyn demanded while Joline was still opening her mouth. "Egwene? There did be an Accepted named Egwene al'Vere, but she be a runaway."

"ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ ɪz ðə wʌn, ɛɛs sədaɪ," tælmɑnz sɛd pəlaɪtli. ðə mæn wɑz ɔlweɪz pəlaɪt tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. "ænd ʃiz noʊ ɹʌnəweɪ. ʃiz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, maɪ wɝɾ ɑn ɪt." idɛzinə meɪɾ ə saʊn ðət wʊɾə bɪn kɔld ə skwik kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ɛniwʌn bʌɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"Egwene al'Vere is the one, Aes Sedai," Talmanes said politely. The man was always polite to Aes Sedai. "And she is no runaway. She is the Amyrlin Seat, my word on it." Edesina made a sound that would have been called a squeak coming from anyone but an Aes Sedai.

"leɪɾɝ fəɹ ðæt," mæt mʌɾɝd. dʒoʊlin oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əɡɛn, æŋɡɹəli. "leɪɾɝ, aɪ sɛd." ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə stɑp ðə slɛndɝ ɡɹin, bʌt tɛslɪn leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm ən mɝmɝd sʌmθɪŋ, ən ðət wɑz. dʒoʊlin stɪl ɡlɛɹd dæɡɝz, ðoʊ, pɹɑməsɪŋ tə dʒɹæɡ aʊɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi wɑntəd tə noʊ leɪɾɝ. "ðə bænd, tælmɑnz?"

"Later for that," Mat muttered. Joline opened her mouth again, angrily. "Later, I said." That was not enough to stop the slender Green, but Teslyn laid a hand on her arm and murmured something, and that was. Joline still glared daggers, though, promising to drag out everything she wanted to know later. "The Band, Talmanes?"

"oʊ. noʊ, aɪ oʊnli bɹɔt θɹi bænɝz ə hɔɹs ən fɔɹ θaʊzən maʊntəd kɹɔsboʊmən. aɪ lɛf θɹi bænɝz ə hɔɹs ən faɪv ə fʊt, ə lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ə kɹɔsboʊz, ɪn mʊɹændi wɪð ɔɹɾɝz tə muv nɔɹθ tə ændɝ. ən ðə meɪsənz bænɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. hændi tə hæv meɪsənz ɹɛɾi tə hæn ɪf jə niɾ ə bɹɪdʒ bɪlt əɹ ðə laɪk."

"Oh. No, I only brought three banners of horse and four thousand mounted crossbowmen. I left three banners of horse and five of foot, a little short of crossbows, in Murandy with orders to move north to Andor. And the Mason's Banner, of course. Handy to have masons ready to hand if you need a bridge built or the like."

mæt skwizd ɪz aɪz ʃʌt fəɹ ə moʊmənt. sɪks bænɝz ə hɔɹs ən faɪv ə fʊt. ən ə bænɝ ə meɪsənz! ðə bæn hæɾ oʊnli bɪn tu bænɝz kaʊntɪŋ hɔɹs ən fʊt wən i lɛft əm ɪn sɑlədɑɹ. hi wɪʃt i hæd bæk hæf ðə ɡoʊld i hæd hændəɾ oʊvɝ tə lukə soʊ fɹili. "haʊ æm aɪ səpoʊz tə peɪ ðət mɛni mɛn?" hi dɪmændəd. "aɪ kʊdn faɪn ɪnʌf daɪs ɡeɪmz ɪn ə jɪɹ!"

Mat squeezed his eyes shut for a moment. Six banners of horse and five of foot. And a banner of masons! The Band had only been two banners counting horse and foot when he left them in Salidar. He wished he had back half the gold he had handed over to Luca so freely. "How am I supposed to pay that many men?" he demanded. "I couldn't find enough dice games in a year!"

"wɛl, əz tə ðæt, aɪ meɪɾ ə smɔl dil wɪð kɪŋ ɹɔdʒɹən. fɪnɪʃt wɪð, naʊ, ən nɑt bɪfɔɹ taɪm - aɪ θɪŋk i wɑz əbaʊt ɹɛɾi tə tɝn ɑn ʌs; əl ɪkspleɪn leɪɾɝ - bʌt ðə bænz kɑfɝz hoʊld ə jɪɹz peɪ ən mɔɹ. bɪsaɪdz, sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl ɡɪv jə ɪsteɪts, ən ɡɹænd wʌnz. hiz ɹeɪz mɛn tə ɹul neɪʃənz, soʊ aɪ hɪɹ, ən jə ɡɹu ʌp wɪð hɪm."

"Well, as to that, I made a small deal with King Roedran. Finished with, now, and not before time - I think he was about ready to turn on us; I will explain later - but the Band's coffers hold a year's pay and more. Besides, sooner or later the Dragon Reborn will give you estates, and grand ones. He has raised men to rule nations, so I hear, and you grew up with him."

ðɪs taɪm, hi dɪd nɑt faɪt ðə kʌlɝz əz ðeɪ ɹizɑlvd ɪndə ɹænd ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪt wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, fəɹ ʃʊɹ. ə hɑɹd wʊmən, ʃi lʊkt. ɪf ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɪv ɪm ɛni taɪɾəlz, hi wəd stʌf əm daʊn ɹændz blʌɾi θɹoʊɾ ɪz wʌɾ i wəd du. mæt kɔθən hæd noʊ laɪkɪŋ fəɹ noʊbəlz - wɛl, ə fju laɪk tælmɑnz wɝ ɔl ɹaɪt; ən tuɑn; nɛvɝ fɝɡɛt tuɑn - ən i sɝɾənli hæd noʊ blʌɾi dɪzaɪɝ tə bɪkʌm wʌn! "ðæts əz meɪ bi," wɑz ɔl i sɛd, ðoʊ.

This time, he did not fight the colors as they resolved into Rand and the Aes Sedai. It was an Aes Sedai, for sure. A hard woman, she looked. If Rand tried to give him any titles, he would stuff them down Rand's bloody throat is what he would do. Mat Cauthon had no liking for nobles - well, a few like Talmanes were all right; and Tuon; never forget Tuon - and he certainly had no bloody desire to become one! "That's as may be," was all he said, though.

sɪlutʃə klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt laʊdli. ʃi ən tuɑn muv ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ʌp bɪsaɪd mæt, ən tuɑn wɑz soʊ stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn əɹ mɛɹz sæɾəl, soʊ kul-aɪd, koʊld-feɪst ən ɹiɡəl, ðəɾ i ɪkspɛktəd sɪlutʃə tə stɑɹt pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ əɹ taɪɾəlz. ʃi dɪd nʌθɪŋ ə ðə sɔɹt. ɪnstɛd, ʃi ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ dʌn ən skaʊld ət hɪm, aɪz laɪk blu koʊlz ɪn ə faɪɝ, ðən klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊɾ əɡɛn. vɛɹi laʊdli. ɑ.

Selucia cleared her throat loudly. She and Tuon moved their horses up beside Mat, and Tuon was so straight in her mare's saddle, so cool-eyed, cold-faced and regal, that he expected Selucia to start proclaiming her titles. She did nothing of the sort. Instead, she shifted on her dun and scowled at him, eyes like blue coals in a fire, then cleared her throat again. Very loudly. Ah.

"tuɑn," mæt sɛd, "əlaʊ mi tə pɹizɛn lɔɹd tælmɑnz dɛləvɪn ə kɛɹhin. hɪz fæmli ɪz dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt ən eɪntʃənt, ən hiz æɾəd ɑnɝz tə ɪts neɪm." ðə lɪɾəl wʊmən ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛd. pɝhæps ɔl ʌv ən ɪntʃ. "tælmɑnz, ðɪs ɪz tuɑn." soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi kɔld ɪm tɔɪ, ʃi wəd ɡɛt noʊ taɪɾəlz fɹəm hɪm. sɪlutʃə ɡlɛɹd, aɪz hɑɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ, ɪmpɑsəbəl əz ðət simd.

"Tuon," Mat said, "allow me to present Lord Talmanes Delovinde of Cairhien. His family is distinguished and ancient, and he has added honors to its name." The little woman inclined her head. Perhaps all of an inch. "Talmanes, this is Tuon." So long as she called him Toy, she would get no titles from him. Selucia glared, eyes hotter than ever, impossible as that seemed.

tælmɑnz blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ðoʊ, ən baʊd vɛɹi loʊ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl. veɪnɪn pʊl ðə sæɡɪŋ bɹɪm ə hɪz hæt loʊɝ, hæf haɪɾɪŋ ɪz feɪs. hi stɪl əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ dɝɛkli ət mæt. soʊ. ɪt sim ðə mæn hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi toʊl tælmɑnz ɪɡzækli hu tuɑn wɑz.

Talmanes blinked in surprise, though, and bowed very low in his saddle. Vanin pulled the sagging brim of his hat lower, half hiding his face. He still avoided looking directly at Mat. So. It seemed the man had already told Talmanes exactly who Tuon was.

ɡɹoʊlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, mæt lin fɹəm ðə sæɾəl tə snætʃ ɪz hæt fɹəm ðə spɪɹ ən pʊl ʌp ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ. hi klæp ðə hæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd. "wi wɝ ɹɛɾi tə muv ɑn, tælmɑnz. teɪk əs tə wɛɹ jəɹ mɛn ɑɹ weɪɾɪŋ, ən wɪl si ɪf wi kən əv əz ɡʊd lʌk əvɔɪɾɪŋ sintʃæn ɑn ðə weɪ aʊɾ ʌv ɔltɑɹə əz jə hæɾ ɑn ðə weɪ ɪn."

Growling under his breath, Mat leaned from the saddle to snatch his hat from the spear and pull up the ashandarei. He clapped the hat on his head. "We were ready to move on, Talmanes. Take us to where your men are waiting, and we'll see if we can have as good luck avoiding Seanchan on the way out of Altara as you had on the way in."

"wi sɔ ə ɡʊd mɛni sintʃæn," tælmɑnz sɛd, tɝnɪŋ ɪz beɪ tə fɔl ɪn bɪsaɪd pɪps. "ðoʊ moʊst ə ðə mɛn wi sɔ sim tə bi ɔltɑɹən. ðeɪv kæmps skæɾɝd ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ɪt simz. lʌkəli, wi sɔ nʌn ə ðoʊz flaɪɪŋ kɹitʃɝz aɪ hæv hɝd tɛl ʌv. bʌt ðəɹ ɪz ə pɹɑbləm, mæt. ðəɹ wɑz ə lændslaɪd. aɪ lɔs maɪ ɹɪɹ ɡɑɹɾ ən səm ə ðə pækhɔɹsɪz. ðə pæs ɪz wɛl ən tʃɹuli blɑkt, mæt. aɪ sɛn θɹi mɛn tə tʃɹaɪ klaɪmɪŋ oʊvɝ wɪð ði ɔɹɾɝz sɛndɪŋ ðə bæn tə ændɝ. wʌn bɹoʊk ɪz nɛk, ən ənʌðɝ ɪz lɛɡ."

"We saw a good many Seanchan," Talmanes said, turning his bay to fall in beside Pips. "Though most of the men we saw seemed to be Altaran. They have camps scattered everywhere, it seems. Luckily, we saw none of those flying creatures I have heard tell of. But there is a problem, Mat. There was a landslide. I lost my rear guard and some of the packhorses. The pass is well and truly blocked, Mat. I sent three men to try climbing over with the orders sending the Band to Andor. One broke his neck, and another his leg."

mæt stɑpt pɪps ʃɔɹt. "aɪm ɡɛsɪŋ ðɪs ɪz ðə seɪm pæs veɪnɪn wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?"

Mat stopped Pips short. "I'm guessing this is the same pass Vanin was talking about?"

tælmɑnz nɑɾəd, ən veɪnɪn, weɪɾɪŋ tə fɔl ɪn fɑɹðɝ bæk, sɛd, "blʌɾi ɹaɪt, ɪt wɑz. pæsəz doʊnt ɡɹoʊ ɑn tʃɹiz, nɑɾ ɪn maʊntənz laɪk ðə deɪmoʊnəz." hi wɑz noʊ ɹɪspɛktɝ ə ɹæŋk.

Talmanes nodded, and Vanin, waiting to fall in farther back, said, "Bloody right, it was. Passes don't grow on trees, not in mountains like the Damonas." He was no respecter of rank.

"ðɛn jəl əv tə faɪn ənʌðɝ wʌn," mæt toʊl hɪm. "aɪv hɝd jə kən faɪn jəɹ weɪ blaɪndfoʊldɪɾ ət mɪdnaɪt. ɪt ʃəd bi izi fəɹ ju." flæɾɝi nɛvɝ hɝt. bɪsaɪdz, hi hæd hɝd ðəɾ əbaʊt ðə mæn.

"Then you'll have to find another one," Mat told him. "I've heard you can find your way blindfolded at midnight. It should be easy for you." Flattery never hurt. Besides, he had heard that about the man.

veɪnɪn meɪɾ ə saʊn laɪk i wɑz swɑloʊɪŋ ɪz tʌŋ. "faɪn ənʌðɝ pæs?" hi mʌɾɝd. "faɪn ənʌðɝ pæs, ðə mæn sɛz. jə doʊn dʒʌst ɡoʊ faɪn ənʌðɝ pæs ɪn nu maʊntənz laɪk ðə deɪmoʊnəz. waɪ dʒju θɪŋk aɪ oʊnli nu ðə wʌn?" hi wɑz ʃeɪkən tə ədmɪt ðət mʌtʃ. bɪfɔɹ ðɪs, hi hæd bɪn æɾəmənt ðəɾ i hæɾ oʊnli hɝɾ ʌv ɪt.

Vanin made a sound like he was swallowing his tongue. "Find another pass?" he muttered. "Find another pass, the man says. You don't just go find another pass in new mountains like the Damonas. Why do you think I only knew the one?" He was shaken to admit that much. Before this, he had been adamant that he had only heard of it.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?" mæt dɪmændəd, ən veɪnɪn ɪkspleɪnd. ət ɡɹeɪt lɛŋθ, fəɹ hɪm.

"What are you talking about?" Mat demanded, and Vanin explained. At great length, for him.

"æn ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪkspleɪn ɪt tə mi, wʌns. jə si, ðɛɹz oʊl maʊntənz. ðeɪ wɑz ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, meɪbi ɑn ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə si əɹ ðə laɪk. ðeɪv pæsəz ɔl oʊvɝ, bɹɔɾ ən dʒɛntəl. jə kən ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ðoʊz ən əz lɔŋ jə kip jəɹ hɛɾ ən jəɹ dɝɛkʃən ən əv ɪnʌf səplaɪz, sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ jə kʌm aʊt ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ən ðən ðɛɹz maʊntənz meɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ." ðə fæt mæn tɝn ɪz hɛɾ ən spæt koʊpiəsli. "pæsəz ɪn ðoʊz ɑɹ nɛɹoʊ, twɪsti θɪŋz, ən səmtaɪmz ðeɪ ɑɹən ɹɪli wʌt jud kɔl pæsəz əɾ ɔl. ɹaɪɾ ɪndə wʌn ə ðoʊz, ən jə kən wɑndɝ ɝaʊn tɪl jəɹ fud ɹʌnz aʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ə weɪ tə ði ʌðɝ saɪd. lɔs ə ðət pæs ɪz gɑnə hɝɾ ə lɑɾ ə foʊks u juz ɪt fəɹ wʌt jə maɪt kɔl əntækst ɡʊdz, ən mɛnəl daɪ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ faɪn ə nu wʌn ðət ɡɛts əm ɔl ðə weɪ θɹu. wi ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə deɪmoʊnəz wɪð ðət pæs ɡɔn, laɪkli wɪl ɔl daɪ, tu. ðɛm əz dʌzn tɝn bæk ɪn taɪm ən hæzənt ɡɑɾən ðɛɹ hɛdz soʊ tɝn ɝaʊn ðeɪ kæn faɪn ðə weɪ bæk."

"An Aes Sedai explained it to me, once. You see, there's old mountains. They was there before the Breaking, maybe on the bottom of the sea or the like. They have passes all over, broad and gentle. You can ride into those and as long you keep your head and your direction and have enough supplies, sooner or later you come out the other side. And then there's mountains made during the Breaking." The fat man turned his head and spat copiously. "Passes in those are narrow, twisty things, and sometimes they aren't really what you'd call passes at all. Ride into one of those, and you can wander around till your food runs out trying to find a way to the other side. Loss of that pass is going to hurt a lot of folks who use it for what you might call untaxed goods, and men'll die before they find a new one that gets them all the way through. We go into the Damonas with that pass gone, likely we'll all die, too. Them as doesn't turn back in time and hasn't gotten their heads so turned around they can't find the way back."

mæt lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ət tuɑn, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɾ oʊlvɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn ɪm tə ɡɛɾ əm tə seɪfti, bʌɾ ɪz seɪf ɹuɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɔltɑɹə wɑz nɑt ðəɹ ɛni mɔɹ. "lɛts ɹaɪd," hi sɛd. "aɪ hæv tə θɪŋk." hi hæd tə blʌɾi θɪŋk fəɹ ɔl i wɑz wɝθ.

Mat looked around, at Tuon, the Aes Sedai, at Olver. They were all depending on him to get them to safety, but his safe route out of Altara was not there any more. "Let's ride," he said. "I have to think." He had to bloody think for all he was worth.

tʃæptɝ twɛntisɪks

CHAPTER 26

əz ɪf ðə wɝld wɝ fɑɡ tɔɪ sɛɾ ə fæs peɪs θɹu ðə fɔɹəst, bʌt tuɑn ɹoʊd kloʊs bɪhaɪn ɪm - wɪð sɪlutʃə əɾ əɹ saɪd, ʌv kɔɹs - soʊ ʃi kəd lɪsən ɪn ɑn ɪm ən tælmɑnz. hɝ oʊn θɔts ɪntɝfɪɹd wɪð ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ. soʊ hi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, hæd hi? ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn! ən i hæd dɪnaɪd noʊɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl ə ðə mæn. ðət wɑz wʌn laɪ ʌv ɪz ʃi hæd feɪl tə kætʃ, ən ʃi wɑz ɡʊɾ ət kætʃɪŋ laɪz. ɪn sindɑɹ, ði ʌndɪtɛktɪd laɪ maɪt bi ðə wʌn ðət kɪl jə əɹ sɛn jə tə ðə seɪl blɑk əz pɹɑpɝɾi. hæd ʃi noʊn ə hɪz pɹɛvɝəkeɪʃən, ʃi maɪɾ əv slæpt ɪz feɪs ɹæðɝ ðən əlaʊɪŋ ɪm tə kɪs hɝ. naʊ, ðət hæd bɪn ə ʃɑk, wʌn ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi hæd ɹəkʌvɝd fɹəm jɛt. sɪlutʃə hæd dɪskɹaɪbd biɪŋ kɪs baɪ ə mæn, bʌt ði æktʃəwæləɾi meɪd ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz dɪskɹɪpʃənz peɪl. noʊ, ʃi hæd tə lɪsən.

As If the World Were Fog Toy set a fast pace through the forest, but Tuon rode close behind him - with Selucia at her side, of course - so she could listen in on him and Talmanes. Her own thoughts interfered with eavesdropping, however. So he had grown up with the Dragon Reborn, had he? The Dragon Reborn! And he had denied knowing anything at all of the man. That was one lie of his she had failed to catch, and she was good at catching lies. In Seandar, the undetected lie might be the one that killed you or sent you to the sale block as property. Had she known of his prevarication, she might have slapped his face rather than allowing him to kiss her. Now, that had been a shock, one she was not sure she had recovered from yet. Selucia had described being kissed by a man, but the actuality made the other woman's descriptions pale. No, she had to listen.

"ju lɛft ɛstin ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ?" tɔɪ ɪɹʌptəd, soʊ laʊdli ðəɾ ə kʌvi ʌv ɡɹeɪ dʌvz bɝs fɹəm kʌvɝ ɪn ðə θɪn ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ wɪð ə mɔɹnfəl wɝɪŋ saʊnd. "ðə mænz ə ful!"

"You left Estean in charge?" Toy erupted, so loudly that a covey of gray doves burst from cover in the thin undergrowth with a mournful whirring sound. "The man's a fool!"

"nɑt tu mʌtʃ ʌv ə ful tə lɪsən tə dɝəd," tælmɑnz ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli. hi dɪd nɑt sim ə mæn tə ɡɛɾ oʊvɝli ɪksaɪɾəd. hi kɛpt ə kɛɹfəl wɑtʃ, hɛd swɪvəlɪŋ kɑnstənli. ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən i skæn ðə skaɪ θɹu ðə θɪk bɹæntʃəz oʊvɝhɛd, tu. hi hæɾ oʊnli hɝɾ ə ɹeɪkən, jɛɾ i wɑtʃt fəɹ ðɛm. hɪz wɝdz wɝ ivən kɹɪspɝ ən kwɪkɝ ðən tɔɪz, ən dɪfəkəl tə fɑloʊ. ðiz pipəl ɔl spoʊk soʊ fæst! "kɑɹləmɪn ən ɹaɪmən ɑɹ nɑt fulz, mæt - ət list, ɹaɪmən ɪz oʊnli ə ful səmtaɪmz - bʌt niðɝ wɪl ðeɪ lɪsən tə ə kɑmənɝ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ i noʊz əbaʊt wɔɹfɛɹ ðən ðeɪ du. ɛdɔɹiən wɪl, bʌɾ aɪ wɑntəɾ ɪm wɪð mi."

"Not too much of a fool to listen to Daerid," Talmanes replied calmly. He did not seem a man to get overly excited. He kept a careful watch, head swiveling constantly. Every so often he scanned the sky through the thick branches overhead, too. He had only heard of raken, yet he watched for them. His words were even crisper and quicker than Toy's, and difficult to follow. These people all spoke so fast! "Carlomin and Reimon are not fools, Mat - at least, Reimon is only a fool sometimes - but neither will they listen to a commoner, no matter how much more he knows about warfare than they do. Edorion will, but I wanted him with me."

ðət ɹɛd hæn sɪmbəl tælmɑnz wɔɹ wɑz ɪntʃɹiɡɪŋ. mɔɹ ðən ɪntʃɹiɡɪŋ. mʌtʃ mɔɹ. ʌv ən oʊld ən dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt haʊs, wɑz hi? bʌt tɔɪ wɑz ðə wʌn. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd hɔkwɪŋz feɪs. ðət simd ʌɾɝli ɪmpɑsəbəl, jɛɾ ɪz dɪnaɪəl ʌv ɪt hæd pleɪnli bɪn ə laɪ, əz pleɪn əz ðə spɑts ɑn ə lɛpɝd. kəd ðə ɹɛd hæn bi tɔɪz sɪdʒəl? bʌɾ ɪf soʊ, wʌɾ əbaʊɾ ɪz ɹɪŋ? ʃi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs feɪntɪd wən ʃi fɝst sɔ ðæt. wɛl, ʃi hæd kʌm əz kloʊs tə ɪɾ əz ʃi hæd sɪns tʃaɪldhʊd.

That red hand symbol Talmanes wore was intriguing. More than intriguing. Much more. Of an old and distinguished House, was he? But Toy was the one. He remembered Hawkwing's face. That seemed utterly impossible, yet his denial of it had plainly been a lie, as plain as the spots on a leopard. Could the Red Hand be Toy's sigil? But if so, what about his ring? She had almost fainted when she first saw that. Well, she had come as close to it as she had since childhood.

"ðæts ɡoʊɪŋ tə tʃeɪnʒ, tælmɑnz," tɔɪ ɡɹaʊld. "aɪ lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ ɑn tu lɔŋ əz ɪɾ ɪz. ɪf ɹaɪmən ən ði ʌðɝz kəmæn bænɝz naʊ, ðət meɪks əm bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəlz. ən jə ə lutɛnənt-dʒɛnɝəl. dɝəd kəmænz faɪv bænɝz, ən ðət meɪks ɪm ə lutɛnənt-dʒɛnɝəl, tu. ɹaɪmən ən ði ʌðɝz wɪl oʊbeɪ hɪz ɔɹɾɝz əɹ ðeɪ kən ɡoʊ hoʊm. kʌm tɑɹmən ɡdən, aɪm nɑt gɑnə hæv maɪ skʌl splɪɾ oʊpən kəz ðeɪ blʌɾi ɹəfjuz tə lɪsən tə sʌmbɑɾi hu dʌzn əv blʌɾi ɪsteɪts."

"That's going to change, Talmanes," Toy growled. "I let it go on too long as it is. If Reimon and the others command banners now, that makes them Banner-Generals. And you a Lieutenant-General. Daerid commands five banners, and that makes him a Lieutenant-General, too. Reimon and the others will obey his orders or they can go home. Come Tarmon Gai'don, I'm not going to have my skull split open because they bloody refuse to listen to somebody who doesn't have bloody estates."

tælmɑnz tɝn ɪz hɔɹs tə ɹaɪɾ ɝaʊn ə pætʃ ə bɹaɪɹz, ən ɛvɹiwʌn fɑloʊd. ðə tæŋɡəl vaɪnz sim tə hæv pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli lɔŋ θɔɹnz, ən hʊk bɪsaɪdz. "ðeɪ wɪl nɑt laɪk ɪt, mæt, bʌt ðəl nɑt ɡoʊ hoʊm, iðɝ. jə noʊ ðæt. hæv jə ɛni aɪdiəz jɛt haʊ wəɹ tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɔltɑɹə?"

Talmanes turned his horse to ride around a patch of briars, and everyone followed. The tangled vines seemed to have particularly long thorns, and hooked besides. "They will not like it, Mat, but they will not go home, either. You know that. Have you any ideas yet how we are to get out of Altara?"

"aɪm θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn ɪt," tɔɪ mʌɾɝd. "aɪm θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn ɪt. ðoʊz kɹɔsboʊmən. . . ." hi ɛksheɪl hɛvəli. "ðæt wɑznt waɪz, tælmɑnz. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ðəɹ juz tə mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn fit. hæf ə ðɛm wɪl əv ɔl ðeɪ kən də tə steɪ ɪn ðə sæɾəl ɪf wɝ muvɪŋ fæst, ən wɝ gɑnə hæv tə. ðeɪ kən bi jusfəl ɪn wʊdz laɪk ðiz, əɹ ɛniwɛɹ ðeɪv plɛnti ʌv kʌvɝ, bʌɾ ɪf wɝ ɑn oʊpən ɡɹaʊnd, wɪð noʊ paɪks, ðəl bi ɹɪɾən daʊn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kən lus ə sɛkən flaɪt."

"I'm thinking on it," Toy muttered. "I'm thinking on it. Those crossbowmen. . . ." He exhaled heavily. "That wasn't wise, Talmanes. For one thing, they're used to marching on their own feet. Half of them will have all they can do to stay in the saddle if we're moving fast, and we're going to have to. They can be useful in woods like these, or anywhere they have plenty of cover, but if we're on open ground, with no pikes, they'll be ridden down before they can loose a second flight."

ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ə laɪən kɔft. ɪn ðə dɪstəns, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə hɔɹsəz wɪkɝ nɝvəsli ən dæns ə fju stɛps. tɔɪ lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɑn ɪz ɡɛldɪŋz nɛk ən əpɪɹd tə wɪspɝ ɪn ði ænəməlz ɪɹ. ɪt kwaɪəɾəd ɪmiɾiətli. soʊ ðət hæd nɑt bɪn ənʌðɝ ə hɪz fænsɪfəl teɪlz æftɝ ɔl. ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl.

In the distance, a lion coughed. In the distance, but it was still enough to make the horses whicker nervously and dance a few steps. Toy leaned forward on his gelding's neck and appeared to whisper in the animal's ear. It quieted immediately. So that had not been another of his fanciful tales after all. Remarkable.

"aɪ pɪk mɛn u kəd ɹaɪd, mæt," tælmɑnz sɛd wʌns ɪz beɪ stɑp fɹɪskɪŋ. "æn ðeɪ ɔl əv ðə nu kɹæŋk." ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɪksaɪtmən ɛntɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs naʊ. ivən ɹistʃɹeɪn mɛn tɛndəd tə wɔɹmθ oʊvɝ wɛpənz. "θɹi tɝnz ə ðə kɹæŋk," hɪz hænz muvd ɪn ə kwɪk sɝkəl, dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ, "æn ðə bɑstʃɹɪŋ ɪz lætʃt. wɪð ə lɪɾəl tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, ə mæn kən ɡɛɾ ɔf sɛvən əɹ eɪt kwɔɹəlz ɪn ə mɪnət. wɪð ə hɛvi kɹɔsboʊ."
