"I picked men who could ride, Mat," Talmanes said once his bay stopped frisking. "And they all have the new crank." A touch of excitement entered his voice now. Even restrained men tended to warmth over weapons. "Three turns of the crank," his hands moved in a quick circle, demonstrating, "and the bowstring is latched. With a little training, a man can get off seven or eight quarrels in a minute. With a heavy crossbow."

sɪlutʃə meɪɾ ə smɔl saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt tə bi stɑɹɾəld. ɪf tælmɑnz wɑz tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ, ən i hæd noʊ ɹizən tə laɪ ðət tuɑn kəd faɪnd, ðən ʃi hæd tə əbteɪn wʌn ə ðiz mɑɹvələs kɹæŋks sʌmhaʊ. wɪð wʌn fəɹ ə pæɾɝn, ɑɹɾəzənz kəd meɪk mɔɹ. ɑɹtʃɝz kəd ʃut fæstɝ ðən kɹɔsboʊmən, bʌt ðeɪ tʊk lɔŋɡɝ tə tʃɹeɪn, tu. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz mɔɹ kɹɔsboʊmən ðən ɑɹtʃɝz.

Selucia made a small sound in her throat. She was right to be startled. If Talmanes was telling the truth, and he had no reason to lie that Tuon could find, then she had to obtain one of these marvelous cranks somehow. With one for a pattern, artisans could make more. Archers could shoot faster than crossbowmen, but they took longer to train, too. There were always more crossbowmen than archers.

"sɛvən?" tɔɪ ɪkskleɪmd ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "ðæt wəd bi mɔɹ ðən jusfəl, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ. ɛvɝ." hi mʌɾɝd ðəɾ əz ɪf ɪt hæd səm spɛʃəl səɡnɪfɪkəns, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "haʊ dɪd jə kʌm baɪ ɪt?"

"Seven?" Toy exclaimed incredulously. "That would be more than useful, but I never heard of such a thing. Ever." He muttered that as if it had some special significance, then shook his head. "How did you come by it?"

"sɛvən əɹ eɪt. ðəɹ wɑz ə məkænɪk ɪn mʊɹændi hu wɑntəd tə teɪk ə wæɡoʊnloʊɾ ə θɪŋz i hæɾ ɪnvɛntəɾ ʌp tə keɪɛmlɪn. ðəɹ ɪz ə skul ə səm sɔɹt ðəɹ fəɹ skɑlɝz ən ɪnvɛntɝz. hi niɾəd mʌni fəɹ ðə dʒɝni, ən i wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə titʃ ðə bænz ɑɹmɔɹɝz tə meɪk ðə θɪŋz. smʌðɝ jəɹ ɛnəmi wɪð æɹoʊz əɾ ɛvɹi ɑpɝtunəɾi. ɪts ɔlweɪz bɛɾɝ tə kɪl jəɹ ɛnəmiz fɑɹ ɔf ðən kloʊs ət hænd."

"Seven or eight. There was a mechanic in Murandy who wanted to take a wagonload of things he had invented up to Caemlyn. There is a school of some sort there for scholars and inventors. He needed money for the journey, and he was willing to teach the Band's armorers to make the things. Smother your enemy with arrows at every opportunity. It is always better to kill your enemies far off than close at hand."

sɪlutʃə hɛld əɹ hænz ʌp soʊ tuɑn kəd si ðɛm, slɪm fɪŋɡɝz muvɪŋ kwɪkli. wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs bæn ðeɪ spik ʌv? ʃi juz ðə pɹɑpɝ fɔɹm, ɪnfɪɹiɝ tə supɪɹiɝ, jɛɾ əɹ ɪmpeɪʃəns wɑz ɔlmoʊs pælpəbəl. ɪmpeɪʃəns wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət wɑz hæpənɪŋ. tuɑn kɛp fju sikɹəts fɹəm hɝ, bʌt səm simd ədvaɪzəbəl fəɹ ðə pɹɛzənt. ʃi wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæst sɪlutʃə tə ɹɪtɝn əɹ tə ɛbu dɑɹ fɔɹsəbli, soʊ ʃi wəd nɑt bi bɹeɪkɪŋ əɹ wɝd. ə ʃædoʊz duɾiz wɝ mɛni, ən səmtaɪmz ɹikwaɪɝd peɪɪŋ ðə faɪnəl sækɹəfaɪs. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə hæv tə ɔɹɾɝ sɪlutʃəz ɛksəkjuʃən.

Selucia held her hands up so Tuon could see them, slim fingers moving quickly. WHAT IS THIS BAND THEY SPEAK OF? She used the proper form, inferior to superior, yet her impatience was almost palpable. Impatience with everything that was happening. Tuon kept few secrets from her, but some seemed advisable for the present. She would not put it past Selucia to return her to Ebou Dar forcibly, so she would not be breaking her word. A shadow's duties were many, and sometimes required paying the final sacrifice. She did not want to have to order Selucia's execution.

ʃi ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ði ɪmpɛɹəɾɪv fɔɹm. tɔɪz pɝsənəl ɑɹmi, ɑbviəsli. lɪsən ən wi meɪ lɝn mɔɹ.

She replied in the imperative form. TOY'S PERSONAL ARMY, OBVIOUSLY. LISTEN AND WE MAY LEARN MORE.

tɔɪ kəmændɪŋ ən ɑɹmi sim vɛɹi ɑd. hi wɑz tʃɑɹmɪŋ ət taɪmz, ivən wɪɾi ən əmjuzɪŋ, bʌɾ ɔfən ə bəfun ən ɔlweɪz ə ɹæpskəljən. hi hæd sim vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɪn ɪz ɛləmən əz taɪlɪnz pɛt. jɛɾ i hæd simd ɪn ɪz ɛləmən əmʌŋ ðə ʃoʊz pɝfɔɹmɝz, tu, ən wɪð ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ən ðə tu ɪskeɪp deɪmeɪn, ən ɪn ðə hɛl. ðət hæd bɪn sətʃ ə dɪsəpɔɪnmənt. nɑɾ ivən wʌn faɪt! ɪvɛns leɪɾɝ hæd nɑt kɑmpənseɪɾəd fəɹ ðæt. ɡɛɾɪŋ swɛpt ʌp ɪn ə stʃɹit bɹɔl wɑz hɑɹdli ðə seɪm əz siɪŋ faɪts ɪn ə hɛl. wɪtʃ ædmɪɾɪdli hæd bɪn fɑɹ mɔɹ bɔɹɪŋ ðən ɹumɝ hɝɾ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ hæd meɪɾ ɪt sim. tɔɪ hæd dɪspleɪɾ ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd saɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðət stʃɹit bɹɔl. ə fɔɹməɾəbəl mæn, ðoʊ wɪð ə pəkjuljɝ wiknəs. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ʃi faʊn ðət stʃɹeɪnʒli ɛndiɹɪŋ.

Toy commanding an army seemed very odd. He was charming at times, even witty and amusing, but often a buffoon and always a rapscallion. He had seemed very much in his element as Tylin's pet. Yet he had seemed in his element among the show's performers, too, and with the marath'damane and the two escaped damane, and in the hell. That had been such a disappointment. Not even one fight! Events later had not compensated for that. Getting swept up in a street brawl was hardly the same as seeing fights in a hell. Which admittedly had been far more boring than rumor heard in Ebou Dar had made it seem. Toy had displayed an unexpected side of himself in that street brawl. A formidable man, though with a peculiar weakness. For some reason, she found that strangely endearing.

"ɡʊɾ ædvaɪs," hi sɛɾ æbsənli, tʌɡɪŋ ət ðə blæk skɑɹf taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. ʃi wʌndɝɾ əbaʊt ðə skɑɹ i tʊk sətʃ peɪnz tə haɪd. ðəɾ i dɪd wɑz ʌndɝstændəbəl. waɪ hæɾ i bɪn hæŋd, ən haʊ hæɾ i sɝvaɪvd? ʃi kəd nɑɾ æsk. ʃi dɪd nɑt maɪn loʊɝɪŋ ɪz aɪz ə lɪɾəl - ɪn fækt, ɪt wɑz ɛndʒɔɪəbəl meɪkɪŋ ɪm ɹɪð; ɪt tʊk soʊ lɪɾəl ɛfɝt - bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɪm. ət list, nɑt fəɹ ðə moʊmənt.

"Good advice," he said absently, tugging at the black scarf tied around his neck. She wondered about the scar he took such pains to hide. That he did was understandable. Why had he been hanged, and how had he survived? She could not ask. She did not mind lowering his eyes a little - in fact, it was enjoyable making him writhe; it took so little effort - but she did not want to destroy him. At least, not for the moment.

"du jə nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪt?" tælmɑnz sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz fɹəm jəɹ bʊk. kɪŋ ɹɔdʒɹən əz tu kɑpiz ɪn ɪz laɪbɹɛɹi. hiz ɪt mɛmɝaɪzd. ðə mæn θɪŋks ɪɾəl meɪk ɪm ə ɡɹeɪt kæptən. hi wɑz soʊ plizd wɪð haʊ əɹ bɑɹɡən wɝkt aʊt ðəɾ i hæɾ ə kɑpi pɹɪntəɾ ən baʊn fəɹ mi."

"Do you not recognize it?" Talmanes said. "It is from your book. King Roedran has two copies in his library. He has it memorized. The man thinks it will make him a great captain. He was so pleased with how our bargain worked out that he had a copy printed and bound for me."

tɔɪ ɡeɪv ði ʌðɝ mæn ə mɪstəfaɪd lʊk. "maɪ bʊk?"

Toy gave the other man a mystified look. "My book?"

"ðə wʌn jə toʊld əs əbaʊt, mæt. fɑɡ ən stil, baɪ mæɾək koʊmædʒɹɪn."

"The one you told us about, Mat. Fog and Steel, by Madoc Comadrin."

"oʊ, ðət bʊk." tɔɪ ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ ɹɛɾ ɪɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ."

"Oh, that book." Toy shrugged. "I read it a long time ago."

tuɑn ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz flæʃt. wən wɪl ðeɪ stɑp tɔkɪŋ ə bʊks ən ɡoʊ bæk tə ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ θɪŋz?

Tuon gritted her teeth. Her fingers flashed. WHEN WILL THEY STOP TALKING OF BOOKS AND GO BACK TO INTERESTING THINGS?

pɝhæps ɪf wi lɪsən wi meɪ lɝn mɔɹ, sɪlutʃə ɹɪplaɪd. tuɑn ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɝ, bʌt ðə wʊmən wɔɹ sətʃ ən ɪnəsən lʊk ðət ʃi kəd nɑt meɪnteɪn əɹ skaʊl. ʃi læft - sɔfli, soʊ əz nɑt tə lɛt tɔɪ ɹilaɪz haʊ kloʊs bɪhaɪn ɪm ʃi wɑz - ən sɪlutʃə dʒɔɪn ɪn. sɔfli.

PERHAPS IF WE LISTEN WE MAY LEARN MORE, Selucia replied. Tuon glared at her, but the woman wore such an innocent look that she could not maintain her scowl. She laughed - softly, so as not to let Toy realize how close behind him she was - and Selucia joined in. Softly.

tɔɪ hæd fɔlən saɪlənt, ðoʊ, ən tælmɑnz sim kɑntɛn tə liv ɪt soʊ. ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪn saɪləns seɪv fəɹ ðə saʊnz ə ðə fɔɹəst, bɝdz sɪŋɪŋ, stʃɹeɪnʒ blæk-teɪl skwɝəlz tʃɪɾɝɪŋ ɑn bɹæntʃəz. tuɑn sɛt hɝsɛlf tə wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ oʊmənz, bʌt nʌθɪŋ kɑɾ əɹ aɪ. bɹaɪt-fɛðɝd bɝdz dɑɹɾɪd əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz. wʌns ðeɪ spɑɾəd ə hɝɾ ə pɝhæps fɪfti tɔl, lin kæɾəl wɪð vɛɹi lɔŋ hɔɹnz ðət stʌk aʊɾ ɔlmoʊst stʃɹeɪt tə iðɝ saɪd. ði ænəməlz hæd hɝɾ əm kʌmɪŋ ən wɝ skwɛɹɾ ʌp, feɪsɪŋ ðɛm. ə bʊl tɔst ɪz hɛɾ ən pɔɾ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd. tɔɪ ən tælmɑnz lɛd ðə kɛɹfəl weɪ ɝaʊn ðə hɝd, kipɪŋ ðɛɹ dɪstəns. ʃi lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz - waɪ wɝ ðeɪ kɔl ðæt? ʃi wəɾ əv tə æsk tɔɪ - ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz wɝ liɾɪŋ ðə pækhɔɹsɪz, bʌt ɡɔɹɾɝən hæd ɹeɪzd ɪz kɹɔsboʊ, ən ði ʌðɝz hæɾ æɹoʊz nɑk tə ðɛɹ baʊz. soʊ ðiz kæɾəl wɝ deɪnʒɝəs. ðəɹ wɝ fju oʊmənz kənsɝnɪŋ kæɾəl, ən ʃi wɑz ɹɪlivd wən ðə hɝd dwɪndəl bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ʃi hæd nɑt kʌm ɔl ðɪs weɪ tə bi kɪl baɪ ə kaʊ. əɹ tə si tɔɪ kɪl baɪ wʌn.

Toy had fallen silent, though, and Talmanes seemed content to leave it so. They rode in silence save for the sounds of the forest, birds singing, strange black-tailed squirrels chittering on branches. Tuon set herself to watching for omens, but nothing caught her eye. Bright-feathered birds darted among the trees. Once they spotted a herd of perhaps fifty tall, lean cattle with very long horns that stuck out almost straight to either side. The animals had heard them coming and were squared up, facing them. A bull tossed his head and pawed at the ground. Toy and Talmanes led the careful way around the herd, keeping their distance. She looked over her shoulder. The Redarms - why were they called that? She would have to ask Toy - the Redarms were leading the packhorses, but Gorderan had raised his crossbow, and the others had arrows nocked to their bows. So these cattle were dangerous. There were few omens concerning cattle, and she was relieved when the herd dwindled behind them. She had not come all this way to be killed by a cow. Or to see Toy killed by one.

æftɝ ə taɪm, tɑm ən ɑlʌdʒɹə keɪm ʌp tə ɹaɪd bɪsaɪd hɝ. ðə wʊmən ɡlænst əɾ əɹ wʌns, ðən lʊk stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. ðə tæɹɑbənɝz feɪs, fɹeɪm baɪ ðoʊz bɹaɪtli biɾɪd bɹeɪdz, wɑz ɔlweɪz wʊɾən wən ʃi lʊkt əɾ əɹ əɹ sɪlutʃə, soʊ klɪɹli ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz u ɹəfjuz tə æksɛp ðə ɹɪtɝn. ʃi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ tɔɪ, ən ʃi lʊkt . . . sæɾəsfaɪd. əz ɪf sʌmθɪŋ hæd bɪn kənfɝm fəɹ hɝ, pɝhæps. waɪ hæd tɔɪ bɹɔɾ əɹ əlɔŋ? ʃʊɹli nɑt fəɹ əɹ faɪɹwɝks. ðoʊz wɝ pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf, bʌt ðeɪ kəd nɑt kəmpɛɹ wɪð skaɪ laɪts pɝfɔɹm baɪ ivən ə hæf-tʃɹeɪn deɪmeɪn.

After a time, Thom and Aludra came up to ride beside her. The woman glanced at her once, then looked straight ahead. The Taraboner's face, framed by those brightly beaded braids, was always wooden when she looked at her or Selucia, so clearly she was one of those who refused to accept the Return. She was watching Toy, and she looked . . . satisfied. As if something had been confirmed for her, perhaps. Why had Toy brought her along? Surely not for her fireworks. Those were pretty enough, but they could not compare with Sky Lights performed by even a half-trained damane.

tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ. pæɾəntli, ðə waɪt-hɛɹɾ oʊl mæn wɑz ən ɪkspɪɹiənst spaɪ. hu hæd sɛn ɪm tə ɛbu dɑɹ? ðə waɪt taʊɝ sim ðə moʊst ɑbviəs kændəɾeɪt. hi spɛn lɪɾəl taɪm ɝaʊn ðə θɹi hu kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ ə wɛl-tʃɹeɪn spaɪ wəd nɑt ɡɪv hɪmsɛlf əweɪ ɪn ðət fæʃən. hɪz pɹɛzəns tʃɹʌbəl hɝ. əntɪl ðə læst ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz liʃt, ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ tə bi wɛɹi ʌv. dɪspaɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ʃi stɪl hæd tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ θɔts ət taɪmz ðət sʌmhaʊ, tɔɪ wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv ə waɪt taʊɝ plɑt. ðət wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl ənlɛs səm ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɑmnɪʃənt, jɛt ðə θɔt səmtaɪmz keɪm tə hɝ.

Thom Merrilin was much more interesting. Patently, the white-haired old man was an experienced spy. Who had sent him to Ebou Dar? The White Tower seemed the most obvious candidate. He spent little time around the three who called themselves Aes Sedai, but a well-trained spy would not give himself away in that fashion. His presence troubled her. Until the last Aes Sedai was leashed, the White Tower was something to be wary of. Despite everything, she still had troubling thoughts at times that somehow, Toy was part of a White Tower plot. That was impossible unless some of the Aes Sedai were omniscient, yet the thought sometimes came to her.

"ə stʃɹeɪnʒ koʊɪnsɪɾəns, wʊdn jə seɪ, mæstɝ mɛɹɪlɪn?" ʃi sɛd. "ɛnkaʊntɝɪŋ pɑɹɾ ə tɔɪz ɑɹmi ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ən ɔltɑɹən fɔɹəst."

"A strange coincidence, wouldn't you say, Master Merrilin?" she said. "Encountering part of Toy's army in the middle of an Altaran forest."

hi stʃɹoʊkt ɪz lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz wɪð ə nʌkəl, feɪlɪŋ tə mæsk ə smɔl smaɪl. "hiz tɑvɝən, maɪ leɪɾi, ən jə kən nɛvɝ tɛl wʌt wɪl hæpən ɝaʊn ə tɑvɝən. ɪts ɔlweɪz . . . ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ . . . wən jə tʃɹævəl wɪð wʌn ə ðoʊz. mæt əz ə tɛndənsi tə faɪnd wʌɾ i nidz wən i nidz ɪt. səmtaɪmz bɪfɔɹ i noʊz i nidz ɪt."

He stroked his long mustaches with a knuckle, failing to mask a small smile. "He's ta'veren, my Lady, and you can never tell what will happen around a ta'veren. It's always . . . interesting . . . when you travel with one of those. Mat has a tendency to find what he needs when he needs it. Sometimes before he knows he needs it."

ʃi stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, bʌɾ i sim sɪɹiəs. "hiz taɪd tə ðə pæɾɝn?" ðət wɑz haʊ ðə wɝd wəd tʃɹænzleɪt. "wʌɾ ɪz ðət səpoʊz tə min?"

She stared at him, but he seemed serious. "He's tied to the Pattern?" That was how the word would translate. "What is that supposed to mean?"

ði oʊl mænz blu aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. "ju doʊnt noʊ? bʌɾ ɪts sɛɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wɑz ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəs tɑvɝən ɛniwʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, pɝhæps əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɹænd ælθɹ. aɪɾ əv θɔt jə ʌv ɔl pipəl wʊd. . . . wɛl, ɪf jə doʊnt, jə doʊnt. tɑvɝən ɑɹ pipəl ðə pæɾɝn ʃeɪps ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊnd, pipəl u wɝ spʌn aʊt baɪ ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf tə meɪnteɪn ðə pɹɑpɝ kɔɹs ə ðə wivɪŋ, pɝhæps tə kɝɛk flɔz ðət wɝ kɹipɪŋ ɪn. wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kəɾ ɪkspleɪn bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ." əz ɪf ʃi wəɾ əv kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð ə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, əɹ wɝs, ə ɹʌnəweɪ deɪmeɪn.

The old man's blue eyes widened in astonishment. "You don't know? But it's said Artur Hawkwing was the strongest ta'veren anyone had ever seen, perhaps as strong as Rand al'Thor. I'd have thought you of all people would. . . . Well, if you don't, you don't. Ta'veren are people the Pattern shapes itself around, people who were spun out by the Pattern itself to maintain the proper course of the weaving, perhaps to correct flaws that were creeping in. One of the Aes Sedai could explain better than I." As if she would have conversation with a marath'damane, or worse, a runaway damane.

"θæŋk ju," ʃi toʊld ɪm pəlaɪtli. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪv hɝɾ ɪnʌf." tɑvɝən. ɹɪdɪkjələs. ðiz pipəl ən ðɛɹ ɛnləs supɝstɪʃənz! ə smɔl bɹaʊn bɝd, ʃʊɹli ə fɪntʃ, flu aʊɾ ʌv ə tɔl oʊk ən sɝkəld wɪɾɝʃɪnz θɹi taɪmz əbʌv tɔɪz hɛd bɪfɔɹ flaɪɪŋ ɑn. ʃi hæd faʊn əɹ oʊmən. steɪ kloʊs tə tɔɪ. nɑt ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛni ɪntɛntʃən ə duɪŋ ʌðɝwaɪz. ʃi hæd ɡɪvən əɹ wɝd, pleɪɪŋ ðə ɡeɪm əz ɪt hæd tə bi pleɪd, ən ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɹoʊkən əɹ wɝɾ ɪn əɹ laɪf.

"Thank you," she told him politely. "I think I've heard enough." Ta'veren. Ridiculous. These people and their endless superstitions! A small brown bird, surely a finch, flew out of a tall oak and circled widdershins three times above Toy's head before flying on. She had found her omen. Stay close to Toy. Not that she had any intention of doing otherwise. She had given her word, playing the game as it had to be played, and she had never broken her word in her life.

lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ən aʊɝ æftɝ sɛɾɪŋ aʊt, əz ə bɝd wɔɹbəld əhɛd, sɪlutʃə pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðə fɝst sɛntʃɹi, ə mæn wɪð ə kɹɔsboʊ ʌp ɪn ðə θɪk bɹæntʃəz ʌv ə spɹɛɾɪŋ oʊk kʌpɪŋ ə hæn tə hɪz maʊθ. nɑɾ ə bɝd, ðɛn. mɔɹ bɝdkɔlz hɛɹəldɪd ðɛɹ ədvæns, ən sun ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ə taɪɾi ɛnkæmpmənt. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tɛns, bʌt ðə lænsɪz wɝ nitli stækt, ðə hɔɹsəz pɪkəɾɪd ɑn skæɾɝd laɪnz əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, nɪɹ tə ðə blæŋkəts ə ðə mɛn u wəd ɹaɪd ðɛm, wɪð ə sæɾəl əɹ pæksæɾəl əɾ ɛvɹi ænəməlz hɛd. ɪt wəd nɑt teɪk lɔŋ fəɹ əm tə bɹeɪk kæmp ən bi ɑn ðə mɑɹtʃ. ðɛɹ faɪɝz wɝ smɔl ən ɡeɪv ɔf lɪɾəl smoʊk.

Little more than an hour after setting out, as a bird warbled ahead, Selucia pointed out the first sentry, a man with a crossbow up in the thick branches of a spreading oak cupping a hand to his mouth. Not a bird, then. More birdcalls heralded their advance, and soon they were riding through a tidy encampment. There were no tents, but the lances were neatly stacked, the horses picketed on scattered lines among the trees, near to the blankets of the men who would ride them, with a saddle or packsaddle at every animal's head. It would not take long for them to break camp and be on the march. Their fires were small and gave off little smoke.

əz ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪn, mɛn ɪn dʌl ɡɹin bɹɛstpleɪts wɪð ðət ɹɛd hæn ɑn ðɛɹ koʊtslivz ən ɹɛd skɑɹvz taɪd tə ðɛɹ lɛft ɑɹmz bɪɡæn ɹaɪzɪŋ tə ðɛɹ fit. ʃi sɔ ɡɹɪzəl feɪsəz wɪð skɑɹz ən fɹɛʃ jʌŋ feɪsəz, ɔl wɪð ðɛɹ aɪz ɑn tɔɪ ən ɪkspɹɛʃənz ʃi kəɾ oʊnli kɔl iɡɝ. ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɝmɝ ə vɔɪsəz ɹoʊz, ɹʌslɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz laɪk ə bɹiz.

As they rode in, men in dull green breastplates with that red hand on their coatsleeves and red scarves tied to their left arms began rising to their feet. She saw grizzled faces with scars and fresh young faces, all with their eyes on Toy and expressions she could only call eager. A growing murmur of voices rose, rustling through the trees like a breeze.

"ɪts lɔɹd mæt."

"It's Lord Mat."

"lɔɹd mæt ɪz bæk."

"Lord Mat is back."

"lɔɹd mæts faʊn ʌs."

"Lord Mat's found us."

"lɔɹd mæt."

"Lord Mat."

tuɑn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð sɪlutʃə. ði əfɛkʃən ɪn ðoʊz vɔɪsəz wɑz ənfeɪənd. ðət wɑz ɹɛɹ, ən ɔfən wɛnt wɪð ə kəmændɝ u hæɾ ə slæk hæn ət dɪsəplən. bʌt ðɛn, ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛni ɑɹmi ʌv tɔɪz tə bi ə ɹæɡtæɡ əfɛɹ, fʊl ə mɛn u spɛn ðɛɹ taɪm dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ən ɡæmbəlɪŋ. oʊnli, ðiz mɛn lʊk noʊ mɔɹ ɹæɡtæɡ ðən ɛni ɹɛdʒəmən ðət hæd kɹɔst ə maʊntən ɹeɪnʒ ən ɹɪɾən sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz. noʊ wʌn lʊkt ənstɛɾi ɑn ɪz fit wɪð dʒɹɪŋk.

Tuon exchanged glances with Selucia. The affection in those voices was unfeigned. That was rare, and often went with a commander who had a slack hand at discipline. But then, she expected any army of Toy's to be a ragtag affair, full of men who spent their time drinking and gambling. Only, these men looked no more ragtag than any regiment that had crossed a mountain range and ridden several hundred miles. No one looked unsteady on his feet with drink.

"moʊsli wi kæmp dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪ ən muv ət naɪt tə əvɔɪd biɪŋ sin baɪ ðə sintʃæn," tælmɑnz sɛd tə tɔɪ. "dʒʌs kəz wɪv sin nʌn ə ðoʊz flaɪɪŋ bists dʌz nɑt min səm maɪt nɑt bi ɝaʊnd. moʊst ə ðə sintʃæn sim tə bi fɑɹðɝ nɔɹθ əɹ fɑɹðɝ saʊθ, bʌɾ əpɛɹənli ðeɪv ə kæmp nɑt θɝɾi maɪlz nɔɹθ ə hɪɹ, ən ɹumɝ sɛz ðəɹ ɪz wʌn ə ðə kɹitʃɝz ðɛɹ."

"Mostly we camp during the day and move at night to avoid being seen by the Seanchan," Talmanes said to Toy. "Just because we have seen none of those flying beasts does not mean some might not be around. Most of the Seanchan seem to be farther north or farther south, but apparently they have a camp not thirty miles north of here, and rumor says there is one of the creatures there."

"ju sim pɹɪɾi wɛl ɪnfɔɹmd," tɔɪ sɛd, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz ðeɪ pæst. hi nɑɾəd sʌɾənli, əz ɪf i hæd ɹitʃt ə dɪsɪʒən. hi simd ɡɹɪm ən . . . kəɾ ɪt bi ɹɪzaɪnd?

"You seem pretty well informed," Toy said, studying the soldiers they passed. He nodded suddenly, as if he had reached a decision. He seemed grim and . . . could it be resigned?

"aɪ æm ðæt, mæt. aɪ bɹɔt hæf ðə skaʊts, ən aɪ ɔlsoʊ saɪn səm ɔltɑɹənz u wɝ faɪɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn. wɛl, moʊst ə ðɛm sim tə hæv bɪn stilɪŋ hɔɹsəz mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, bʌt səm wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə ɡɪv ðəɾ ʌp fəɹ ə tʃæns tə ɹɪli faɪt ðɛm. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ noʊ wɛɹ moʊst ə ðə sintʃæn kæmps ɑɹ fɹəm ðə mɑlvaɪd nɛɹoʊz saʊθ tə hɪɹ."

"I am that, Mat. I brought half the scouts, and I also signed some Altarans who were fighting the Seanchan. Well, most of them seem to have been stealing horses more than anything else, but some were willing to give that up for a chance to really fight them. I think I know where most of the Seanchan camps are from the Malvide Narrows south to here."

sʌɾənli ə mæn bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ ɪn ə dip vɔɪs, ən ʌðɝz dʒɔɪn ɪn, ðə sɔŋ spɹɛɾɪŋ ɹæpədli.

Suddenly a man began to sing in a deep voice, and others joined in, the song spreading rapidly.

θɛɹɛɹ səm dɪlaɪɾ ɪn eɪl ən waɪn, ən səm ɪn ɡɝlz wɪð æŋkəlz faɪn, bʌt maɪ dɪlaɪt, jɛs, ɔlweɪz maɪn, ɪz tə dæns wɪð dʒæk oʊ' ðə ʃædoʊz.

There're some delight in ale and wine, and some in girls with ankles fine, but my delight, yes, always mine, is to dance with Jak o' the Shadows.

ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ðə kæmp wɑz sɪŋɪŋ, naʊ, θaʊzənz ə vɔɪsəz ɹɔɹɪŋ ðə sɔŋ.

Every man in the camp was singing, now, thousands of voices roaring the song.

wɪl tɔs ðə daɪs haʊɛvɝ ðeɪ fɔl, ən snʌɡəl ðə ɡɝlz bi ðeɪ ʃɔɹɾ əɹ tɔl, ðən fɑloʊ lɔɹd mæt wɛnɛvɝ i kɔlz, tə dæns wɪð dʒæk oʊ' ðə ʃædoʊz.

We'll toss the dice however they fall, and snuggle the girls be they short or tall, then follow Lord Mat whenever he calls, to dance with Jak o' the Shadows.

ðeɪ fɪnɪʃt wɪð ʃaʊts, læfɪŋ ən klæpɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ. hu ʌndɝ ðə laɪt wɑz ðɪs dʒæk oʊ' ðə ʃædoʊz?

They finished with shouts, laughing and clapping one another on the shoulder. Who under the Light was this Jak o' the Shadows?

ɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn, tɔɪ ɹeɪz ðə hæn hoʊldɪŋ ɪz ɑd spɪɹ. ðət wɑz ɔl, jɛt saɪləns spɹɛd θɹu ðə soʊlʒɝz. soʊ hi wɑz nɑt sɑft wɪð dɪsəplən. ðəɹ wɝ ə fju ʌðɝ ɹizənz fəɹ soʊlʒɝz tə bi fɑn ə ðɛɹ ɔfəsɝz, bʌt ðə moʊs kɑmən simd ənlaɪkli tə əplaɪ tə tɔɪ, ʌv ɔl pipəl.

Reining in, Toy raised the hand holding his odd spear. That was all, yet silence spread through the soldiers. So he was not soft with discipline. There were a few other reasons for soldiers to be fond of their officers, but the most common seemed unlikely to apply to Toy, of all people.

"lɛts nɑt lɛɾ əm noʊ wɝ hɪɹ əntɪl wi wɑn əm tə noʊ," tɔɪ sɛd laʊdli. hi wɑz nɑɾ ɔɹeɪɾɪŋ, dʒʌs meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ ɪz vɔɪs kæɹid. ən ðə mɛn hɝd, ɹɪpiɾɪŋ ɪz wɝdz oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz tə bi pæs bæk tə mɛn bɪɑn ðə saʊn ə hɪz vɔɪs. "wɝ ə lɔŋ weɪ fɹəm hoʊm, bʌɾ aɪ min tə ɡɛɾ əs hoʊm. soʊ bi ɹɛɾi tə muv, ən muv fæst. ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hæn kən muv fæstɝ ðən ɛnibəɾi ɛls, ən wɝ gɑnə hæv tə pɹuv ɪt." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃɪɹɪŋ, bʌt plɛnti ʌv nɑdz. tɝnɪŋ tə tælmɑnz, hi sɛd, "du juv mæps?"

"Let's not let them know we're here until we want them to know," Toy said loudly. He was not orating, just making sure his voice carried. And the men heard, repeating his words over their shoulders to be passed back to men beyond the sound of his voice. "We're a long way from home, but I mean to get us home. So be ready to move, and move fast. The Band of the Red Hand can move faster than anybody else, and we're going to have to prove it." There was no cheering, but plenty of nods. Turning to Talmanes, he said, "Do you have maps?"

"ðə bɛs tə bi faʊnd," tælmɑnz ɹɪplaɪd. "ðə bæn əz ɪts oʊn mæpmeɪkɝ, naʊ. mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl ɔlɹɛɾi hæd ɡʊd mæps ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɹəm ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən tə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, ən sɪns wi kɹɔs ðə deɪmoʊnəz, hi ən ɪz əsɪstəns əv bɪn meɪkɪŋ nu mæps ə ðə kʌntʃɹi wi kɹɔst. ðeɪ ivən mɑɹkt ə mæp ʌv istɝn ɔltɑɹə wɪð wʌt wɪv lɝn ə ðə sintʃæn. moʊst ə ðoʊz kæmps ɑɹ tɛmpɝɛɹi, ðoʊ. soʊlʒɝz hɛɾɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ɛls."

"The best to be found," Talmanes replied. "The Band has its own mapmaker, now. Master Roidelle already had good maps of everything from the Aryth Ocean to the Spine of the World, and since we crossed the Damonas, he and his assistants have been making new maps of the country we crossed. They even marked a map of eastern Altara with what we have learned of the Seanchan. Most of those camps are temporary, though. Soldiers heading somewhere else."

sɪlutʃə ʃɪftəɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ən tuɑn saɪn peɪʃəns ɪn haɪ ɪmpɛɹəɾɪv fɔɹm, ə kəmænd. ʃi kɛpt əɹ feɪs smuð, bʌɾ ɪnsaɪd, ʃi wɑz fjʊɹiəs. noʊɪŋ wɛɹ soʊlʒɝz wɝ ɡeɪv kluz tə wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ. ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm weɪ tə bɝn ðət mæp. ðət wəd bi əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt əz leɪɪŋ hænz ɑn wʌn ə ðə kɹɔsboʊ kɹæŋks.

Selucia shifted in her saddle, and Tuon signed PATIENCE in high imperative form, a command. She kept her face smooth, but inside, she was furious. Knowing where soldiers were gave clues to where they were going. There had to be some way to burn that map. That would be as important as laying hands on one of the crossbow cranks.

"aɪl wɑnə tɔk wɪð mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl, tu," tɔɪ sɛd.

"I'll want to talk with Master Roidelle, too," Toy said.

soʊlʒɝz keɪm tə teɪk ðə hɔɹsəz, ən fəɹ ə waɪl ɔl sim kənfjuʒən ən mɪlɪŋ əbaʊt. ə ɡæp-tuθ fɛloʊ tʊk əkaɪnz ɹeɪnz, ən tuɑn ɡeɪv ɪm ɪksplɪsəɾ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz ɑn kɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə mɛɹ. hi ɹɪtɝn əɹ ə saʊɝ lʊk əlɔŋ wɪð ɪz baʊ. kɑmənɝz ɪn ðiz lænz sim tə bɪliv ðɛmsɛlvz ikwəl tə ɛvɹiwʌn. sɪlutʃə ɡeɪv ðə seɪm sɔɹɾ ʌv ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz tə ðə læŋki jʌŋ mæn u tʊk ɹoʊzbʌd. ʃi θɔt ðəɾ ən əpɹoʊpɹiət neɪm fəɹ ə dʒɹɛsɝz hɔɹs. ðə jʌŋ mæn stɛɹɾ ət sɪlutʃəz tʃɛst, əntɪl ʃi slæp hɪm. hɑɹd. hi oʊnli ɡɹɪn ən lɛd ðə dʌn əweɪ ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tʃik. tuɑn saɪd. ðət wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl fəɹ sɪlutʃə, bʌt fəɹ hɝsɛlf, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ə kɑmənɝ wəd loʊɝ əɹ aɪz fəɹ mʌnθs.

Soldiers came to take the horses, and for a while all seemed confusion and milling about. A gap-toothed fellow took Akein's reins, and Tuon gave him explicit instructions on caring for the mare. He returned her a sour look along with his bow. Commoners in these lands seemed to believe themselves equal to everyone. Selucia gave the same sort of instructions to the lanky young man who took Rosebud. She thought that an appropriate name for a dresser's horse. The young man stared at Selucia's chest, until she slapped him. Hard. He only grinned and led the dun away rubbing his cheek. Tuon sighed. That was all very well for Selucia, but for herself, striking a commoner would lower her eyes for months.

sun ɪnʌf, ðoʊ, ʃi wɑz sɛɾəld ɑn ə foʊldɪŋ stul wɪð sɪlutʃə əɾ əɹ bæk, ən staʊt ləpɪn pɹizɛntəɾ əm wɪð tɪn kʌps fʊl ə dɑɹk ti, boʊɪŋ kwaɪt pɹɑpɝli tə sɪlutʃə əz wɛl əz tə hɝ. nɑt dipli ɪnʌf, bʌt ðə bɔldɪŋ mæn dɪd tʃɹaɪ. hɝ ti wɑz hʌnid tə pɝfɛkʃən, laɪtli, bʌt ðɛn, hi hæd sɝvd əɹ ɔfən ɪnʌf tə noʊ haʊ ʃi laɪkt ɪt. æktɪvəɾi bʌsəld əbaʊt ðɛm. tælmɑnz hæɾ ə bɹif ɹiunjən wɪð ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd nɹɪm, hu əpɛɹənli wɑz ɪz sɝvɪŋ mæn, ən hæpi tə bi ɹiunaɪɾɪd wɪð hɪm. ət list, ðə θɪn mænz nɔɹməli mɔɹnfəl kaʊntənəns æktʃəli  flæʃt ə moʊməntɛɹi smaɪl. ðət sɔɹɾ ə ʃʊɾə əv bɪn dʌn ɪn pɹaɪvət. laɪlwɪn ən doʊmən əlaʊd mæstɝ tʃɛɝɪn tə liɾ oʊlvɝ ɔf tə ɪksplɔɹ ðə kæmp wɪð dʒulɪn ən θɛɹə - tɑm ən ɑlʌdʒɹə wɛn tu, tə stʃɹɛtʃ ðɛɹ lɛɡz - ðən dɪlɪbɝətli tʊk stulz kloʊs baɪ. laɪlwɪn ivən wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə stɛɹ ənblɪŋkɪŋ ət tuɑn fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt. sɪlutʃə meɪɾ ə loʊ saʊn vɛɹi laɪk ə ɡɹaʊl, bʌt tuɑn ɪɡnɔɹd ðə pɹɑvəkeɪʃən ən dʒɛstʃɝd mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən tə bɹɪŋ əɹ stul oʊvɝ bɪsaɪd hɝ. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ðə tʃɹeɪɾɝz wəd bi pʌnɪʃt, ən ðə θif, ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ɹɪstɔɹd tə ɪts ɹaɪtfəl oʊnɝz, ən ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn liʃt, bʌt ðoʊz θɪŋz hæd tə weɪɾ ɑn wʌt wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

Soon enough, though, she was settled on a folding stool with Selucia at her back, and stout Lopin presented them with tin cups full of dark tea, bowing quite properly to Selucia as well as to her. Not deeply enough, but the balding man did try. Her tea was honeyed to perfection, lightly, but then, he had served her often enough to know how she liked it. Activity bustled about them. Talmanes had a brief reunion with gray-haired Nerim, who apparently was his serving man, and happy to be reunited with him. At least, the thin man's normally mournful countenance actually flashed a momentary smile. That sort of thing should have been done in private. Leilwin and Domon allowed Master Charin to lead Olver off to explore the camp with Juilin and Thera - Thom and Aludra went too, to stretch their legs - then deliberately took stools close by. Leilwin even went so far as to stare unblinking at Tuon for a long moment. Selucia made a low sound very like a growl, but Tuon ignored the provocation and gestured Mistress Anan to bring her stool over beside her. Eventually, the traitors would be punished, and the thief, the property restored to its rightful owners, and the marath'damane leashed, but those things had to wait on what was more important.

θɹi mɔɹ ɔfəsɝz əpɪɹd, jʌŋ noʊbəlmən wɪð ðət ɹɛd hæn ɑn ðɛɹ dɑɹk sɪlk koʊts, ən hæd ðɛɹ oʊn ɹiunjən wɪð tɔɪ, wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə læfɪŋ ən hɪɾɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ, wɪtʃ ðeɪ sim tə teɪk əz ə saɪn ə fɑndnəs. ʃi sun hæɾ əm sɔɹɾɪd aʊt. ɛdɔɹiən wɑz ðə dɑɹk, lin mæn wɪð ðə sɪɹiəs ɪkspɹɛʃən ɪksɛpt wən smaɪlɪŋ, ɹaɪmən ðə bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd fɛloʊ hu smaɪld ə ɡɹeɪt dil, ən kɑɹləmɪn ðə tɔl, slɛndɝ wʌn. ɛdɔɹiən wɑz klin-ʃeɪvən, waɪl ɹaɪmən ən kɑɹləmɪn boʊθ hæd dɑɹk bɪɹdz ðət wɝ tʃɹɪm tə pɔɪns ən ɡlɪsən əz ɪf ɔɪld. ɔl θɹi meɪd mʌtʃ oʊvɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, boʊɪŋ dipli. ðeɪ ivən baʊd tə bɛθəmən ən sɛɾə! tuɑn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

Three more officers appeared, young noblemen with that red hand on their dark silk coats, and had their own reunion with Toy, with a great deal of laughing and hitting each other on the shoulder, which they seemed to take as a sign of fondness. She soon had them sorted out. Edorion was the dark, lean man with the serious expression except when smiling, Reimon the broad-shouldered fellow who smiled a great deal, and Carlomin the tall, slender one. Edorion was clean-shaven, while Reimon and Carlomin both had dark beards that were trimmed to points and glistened as if oiled. All three made much over the Aes Sedai, bowing deeply. They even bowed to Bethamin and Seta! Tuon shook her head.

"aɪv toʊl jə ɔfən ɪnʌf ɪts ə dɪfɹənt wɝl ðən jəɹ juz tə," mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən mɝmɝd, "bʌt jə stɪl doʊn kwaɪt bɪliv ɪt, də ju?"

"I've told you often enough it's a different world than you're used to," Mistress Anan murmured, "but you still don't quite believe it, do you?"

"dʒʌs kəz ə θɪŋ ɪz ə sɝɾən weɪ," tuɑn ɹɪplaɪd, "dʌzn min ɪt ʃəd bi ðət weɪ, ivən ɪf ɪts bɪn fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm."

"Just because a thing is a certain way," Tuon replied, "doesn't mean it should be that way, even if it has been for a long time."

"sʌm maɪt seɪ ðə seɪm ə jəɹ pipəl, maɪ leɪɾi."

"Some might say the same of your people, my Lady."

"sʌm maɪt." tuɑn lɛɾ ɪt ɹɛs ðɛɹ, ðoʊ ʃi juʒəwəli ɛndʒɔɪɾ əɹ pɹaɪvət kɑnvɝseɪʃənz wɪð ðə wʊmən. mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ɑɹɡjuɾ əɡɛns liʃɪŋ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, əz maɪt bi ɪkspɛktəd, ən ivən əɡɛns kipɪŋ dækoʊvæl ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ dɪskʌʃənz ɹæðɝ ðən ɑɹɡjəməns, ən tuɑn hæd meɪɾ əɹ kənsiɾ ə fju pɔɪns. ʃi hæd hoʊps ə bɹɪŋɪŋ ðə wʊmən ɝaʊn ɪvɛntʃəwəli. nɑt tədeɪ, ðoʊ. ʃi wɑntəɾ əɹ maɪn foʊkəst ɑn tɔɪ.

"Some might." Tuon let it rest there, though she usually enjoyed her private conversations with the woman. Mistress Anan argued against leashing marath'damane, as might be expected, and even against keeping da'covale of all things, yet they were discussions rather than arguments, and Tuon had made her concede a few points. She had hopes of bringing the woman around eventually. Not today, though. She wanted her mind focused on Toy.

mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl əpɪɹd, ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ, ɹaʊnd-feɪs mæn huz bʌlk stʃɹeɪn ɪz dɑɹk koʊt, fɑloʊd baɪ sɪks fɪt-əpɪɹɪŋ jʌŋɡɝ mɛn itʃ kæɹiɪŋ ə lɔŋ, səlɪnʒɹɪkəl lɛðɝ keɪs. "aɪ bɹɔɾ ɔl ðə mæps ʌv ɔltɑɹə aɪ hæv, maɪ lɔɹd," hi toʊl tælmɑnz ɪn ə mjuzɪkəl æksɛn əz i baʊd. dɪɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðiz lænz spik əz ɪf ɹeɪsɪŋ tə ɡɛt ðə wɝdz aʊt? "sʌm kʌvɝ ðə hoʊl kʌntʃɹi, ðeɪ du, səm noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd skwɛɹ maɪlz. ðə bɛst ɑɹ maɪ oʊn, ʌv kɔɹs, ðoʊz aɪ meɪd ðiz pæst wiks."

Master Roidelle appeared, a graying, round-faced man whose bulk strained his dark coat, followed by six fit-appearing younger men each carrying a long, cylindrical leather case. "I brought all the maps of Altara I have, my Lord," he told Talmanes in a musical accent as he bowed. Did everyone in these lands speak as if racing to get the words out? "Some cover the whole country, they do, some no more than a hundred square miles. The best are my own, of course, those I made these past weeks."

"lɔɹd mæt wɪl tɛl jə wʌɾ i wɑns tə si," tælmɑnz sɛd. "ʃæl wi liv jə tə ɪt, mæt?"

"Lord Mat will tell you what he wants to see," Talmanes said. "Shall we leave you to it, Mat?"

bʌt tɔɪ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi tɛlɪŋ ðə mæpmeɪkɝ wʌɾ i wɑntəd, ðə mæp mɑɹkt wɪð ðə sintʃæn kæmps. ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ ɪt wɑz sɔɹɾɪd aʊt fɹəm ði ʌðɝz ɪn wʌn ə ðə keɪsəz ən spɹɛɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð tɔɪ skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz hilz bɪsaɪɾ ɪt. mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl sɛnt wʌn ə hɪz əsɪstəns ɹʌnɪŋ tə fɛtʃ ɪm ə stul. hi wʊɾə bɝst ɪz koʊt bʌɾənz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪməteɪt tɔɪ, ən laɪkli hæv fɔlən oʊvɝ bɪsaɪdz. tuɑn stɛɹɾ ət ðət mæp hʌŋɡɹəli. haʊ tə ɡɛɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ɪt?

But Toy was already telling the mapmaker what he wanted, the map marked with the Seanchan camps. In short order it was sorted out from the others in one of the cases and spread on the ground with Toy squatting on his heels beside it. Master Roidelle sent one of his assistants running to fetch him a stool. He would have burst his coat buttons trying to imitate Toy, and likely have fallen over besides. Tuon stared at that map hungrily. How to get her hands on it?

ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɡlænsɪz ən læfɪŋ əz ɪf biɪŋ snʌbd wɝ ðə fʌniəs θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld, tælmɑnz ən ði ʌðɝ θɹi mɛn stʃɹoʊl təwɔɹd tuɑn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ðə mæp ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn əntɪl tɔɪ toʊld əm tə kwɪt piɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðeɪ muvd ɔf ə lɪɾəl, bɛθəmən ən sɛɾə hilɪŋ əm əɾ ə dɪstəns, ən bɪɡæn tɔkɪŋ kwaɪətli əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, əkeɪʒənəli ɡlænsɪŋ ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən. ɪf tɔɪ hæd bɪn peɪɪŋ ɛni hid tə ðɛɹ ɪkspɹɛʃənz, ɪspɛʃli dʒoʊlinz, hi maɪɾ əv bɪn wɝiɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə ði ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl tɛɹæŋɡɹil mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən sɛɾ i kæɹid.

Exchanging glances and laughing as if being snubbed were the funniest thing in the world, Talmanes and the other three men strolled toward Tuon. The Aes Sedai gathered around the map on the ground until Toy told them to quit peering over his shoulder. They moved off a little, Bethamin and Seta heeling them at a distance, and began talking quietly among themselves, occasionally glancing in his direction. If Toy had been paying any heed to their expressions, especially Joline's, he might have been worried in spite of the incredible ter'angreal Mistress Anan said he carried.

"wɝ əbaʊt hɪɹ, ɹaɪt?" hi sɛd, mɑɹkɪŋ ə spɑt wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝ. mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl mɝmɝd ðət ðeɪ wɝ. "soʊ ðɪs ɪz ðə kæmp wɛɹ ðə ɹeɪkən səpoʊzədli ɪz? ðə flaɪɪŋ bist?" ənʌðɝ mɝmɝ ʌv əsɛnt. "ɡʊd. wʌt kaɪndə kæmp ɪz ɪt? haʊ mɛni mɛn ɑɹ ðɛɹ?"

"We're about here, right?" he said, marking a spot with his finger. Master Roidelle murmured that they were. "So this is the camp where the raken supposedly is? The flying beast?" Another murmur of assent. "Good. What kind of camp is it? How many men are there?"

"ɹɪpɔɹɾədli ɪts ə səplaɪ kæmp, maɪ lɔɹd. fəɹ ɹisʌplaɪɪŋ pətʃɹoʊlz." ðə jʌŋ mæn ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ənʌðɝ foʊldɪŋ stul, ən ðə staʊt mæn iz hɪmsɛlf daʊn wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt. "səpoʊzədli əbaʊɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd soʊlʒɝz, moʊsli ɔltɑɹən, ən əbaʊt tu hʌnʒɹəd leɪbɝɝz, bʌɾ aɪm toʊl ðəɹ kən bi əz mɛni əz faɪv hʌnʒɹəd mɔɹ soʊlʒɝz ət taɪmz." ə kɛɹfəl mæn, mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl.

"Reportedly it's a supply camp, my Lord. For resupplying patrols." The young man returned with another folding stool, and the stout man eased himself down with a grunt. "Supposedly about a hundred soldiers, mostly Altaran, and about two hundred laborers, but I'm told there can be as many as five hundred more soldiers at times." A careful man, Master Roidelle.

tælmɑnz meɪd wʌn ə ðoʊz ɑd baʊz, wɪð wʌn fʊt fɔɹwɝd, ən ði ʌðɝ θɹi mɪɹɝd hɪm. "maɪ leɪɾi," tælmɑnz sɛd, "veɪnɪn toʊl mi ʌv jəɹ sɝkəmstænsəz, ən ðə pɹɑməsəz lɔɹd mæt meɪd. aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə tɛl ju, hi kips ɪz wɝd."

Talmanes made one of those odd bows, with one foot forward, and the other three mirrored him. "My Lady," Talmanes said, "Vanin told me of your circumstances, and the promises Lord Mat made. I just want to tell you, he keeps his word."

"ðæɾ i dʌz, maɪ leɪɾi," ɛdɔɹiən mɝmɝd. "ɔlweɪz." tuɑn moʊʃən ɪm tə stɛp əsaɪd soʊ ʃi kəd kəntɪnju tə wɑtʃ tɔɪ, ən i dɪd soʊ wɪð ə sɝpɹaɪzd ɡlæns ət tɔɪ ən ənʌðɝ fəɹ hɝ. ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə stɝn lʊk. ðə læs θɪŋ ʃi wɑntəd wɑz fəɹ ðiz mɛn tə stɑɹɾ ɪmædʒənɪŋ θɪŋz. nɑɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd fɔlən aʊɾ əz ɪt hæd tə, jɛt. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ə tʃæns ðɪs kəɾ ɔl ɡoʊ ɝaɪ.

"That he does, my Lady," Edorion murmured. "Always." Tuon motioned him to step aside so she could continue to watch Toy, and he did so with a surprised glance at Toy and another for her. She gave him a stern look. The last thing she wanted was for these men to start imagining things. Not everything had fallen out as it had to, yet. There was still a chance this could all go awry.

"ɪz i ə lɔɹɾ əɹ ɪz i nɑt?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

"Is he a lord or is he not?" she demanded.

"ɪkskjus mi," tælmɑnz sɛd, "bʌt wəd jə seɪ ðəɾ əɡɛn? aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz. aɪ mʌst əv dɝɾ ɪn maɪ ɪɹz." ʃi ɹɪpiɾɪd hɝsɛlf kɛɹfəli, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl tʊk əm ə mɪnət tə pʌzəl aʊt wʌt ʃi hæd sɛd.

"Excuse me," Talmanes said, "but would you say that again? I apologize. I must have dirt in my ears." She repeated herself carefully, but it still took them a minute to puzzle out what she had said.

"bɝn maɪ soʊl, noʊ," ɹaɪmən sɛd faɪnəli wɪð ə læf. hi stʃɹoʊkt ɪz bɪɹd. "ɪksɛp tə ʌs. lɔɹɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ʌs."

"Burn my soul, no," Reimon said finally with a laugh. He stroked his beard. "Except to us. Lord enough for us."

"hi dɪslaɪks noʊbəlz fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt," kɑɹləmɪn sɛd. "aɪ kaʊn ɪɾ ən ɑnɝ tə bi əmʌŋ ðə fju hi dʌzn dɪslaɪk."

"He dislikes nobles for the most part," Carlomin said. "I count it an honor to be among the few he doesn't dislike."

"æn ɑnɝ," ɹaɪmən əɡɹid. ɛdɔɹiən kəntɛntəd hɪmsɛlf wɪð nɑɾɪŋ.

"An honor," Reimon agreed. Edorion contented himself with nodding.

"soʊlʒɝz, mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl," tɔɪ sɛd fɝmli. "ʃoʊ mi wɛɹ ðə soʊlʒɝz ɑɹ. ən mɔɹ ðən ɛni fju hʌnʒɹəd."

"Soldiers, Master Roidelle," Toy said firmly. "Show me where the soldiers are. And more than any few hundred."

"wʌɾ ɪz i duɪŋ?" tuɑn sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "hi kæn θɪŋk tə snik ðɪs mɛni mɛn aʊɾ ʌv ɔltɑɹə ivən ɪf i noʊz wɛɹ ɛvɹi læst soʊlʒɝ ɪz. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz pətʃɹoʊlz, ən swips baɪ ɹeɪkən." əɡɛn ðeɪ tʊk ðɛɹ taɪm bɪfɔɹ ænsɝɪŋ. pɝhæps ʃi ʃəd tʃɹaɪ spikɪŋ vɛɹi fæst.

"What is he doing?" Tuon said, frowning. "He can't think to sneak this many men out of Altara even if he knows where every last soldier is. There are always patrols, and sweeps by raken." Again they took their time before answering. Perhaps she should try speaking very fast.

"wiv sin noʊ pətʃɹoʊlz ɪn bɛɾɝ ðən θɹi hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz, ən noʊ - ɹeɪkən? - noʊ ɹeɪkən," ɛdɔɹiən sɛd kwaɪətli. hi wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ hɝ. tu leɪt tə stɑp ɪz ɪmædʒɪnɪŋz.

"We've seen no patrols in better than three hundred miles, and no - raken? - no raken," Edorion said quietly. He was studying her. Too late to stop his imaginings.

ɹaɪmən læft əɡɛn. "ɪf aɪ noʊ mæt, hiz plænɪŋ əs ə bæɾəl. ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hæn ɹaɪdz tə bæɾəl əɡɛn. ɪts bɪn tu lɔŋ, ɪf jə æsk mi."

Reimon laughed again. "If I know Mat, he's planning us a battle. The Band of the Red Hand rides to battle again. It's been too long, if you ask me."

sɪlutʃə snɪft, ən soʊ dɪd mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən. tuɑn hæd tə əɡɹi wɪð ðɛm. "ə bæɾəl woʊnt ɡɛt jə aʊɾ ʌv ɔltɑɹə," ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli.

Selucia sniffed, and so did Mistress Anan. Tuon had to agree with them. "A battle won't get you out of Altara," she said sharply.

"ɪn ðət keɪs," tælmɑnz sɛd, "hiz plænɪŋ əs ə wɔɹ." ði ʌðɝ θɹi nɑɾəd əɡɹimən əz ɪf ðət wɝ ðə moʊs nɔɹməl θɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt. ɹaɪmən ivən læft. hi sim tə θɪŋk ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz hjumɝəs.

"In that case," Talmanes said, "he's planning us a war." The other three nodded agreement as if that were the most normal thing under the Light. Reimon even laughed. He seemed to think everything was humorous.

"θɹi θaʊzənd?" tɔɪ sɛd. "jɔɹ ʃʊɹ? ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf, mæn. ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf wɪl du. veɪnɪn kən loʊkeɪɾ əm ɪf ðeɪ hævən muv tu fɑɹ."

"Three thousand?" Toy said. "You're sure? Sure enough, man. Sure enough will do. Vanin can locate them if they haven't moved too far."

tuɑn lʊkt ət hɪm, skwɑɾɪŋ ðəɹ baɪ ðə mæp, muvɪŋ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz oʊvɝ ɪts sɝfəs, ən sʌɾənli ʃi sɔ hɪm ɪn ə nu laɪt. ə bəfun? noʊ. ə laɪən stʌft ɪndə ə hɔɹs-stɔl maɪt lʊk laɪk ə pəkjuljɝ dʒoʊk, bʌɾ ə laɪən ɑn ðə haɪ pleɪnz wɑz sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi dɪfɹənt. tɔɪ wɑz lus ɑn ðə haɪ pleɪnz, naʊ. ʃi fɛlt ə tʃɪl. wʌt sɔɹɾ ə mæn hæd ʃi ɛntæŋɡəl hɝsɛlf wɪð? æftɝ ɔl ðɪs taɪm, ʃi ɹilaɪzd, ʃi hæd hɑɹdli ə klu.

Tuon looked at him, squatting there by the map, moving his fingers over its surface, and suddenly she saw him in a new light. A buffoon? No. A lion stuffed into a horse-stall might look like a peculiar joke, but a lion on the high plains was something very different. Toy was loose on the high plains, now. She felt a chill. What sort of man had she entangled herself with? After all this time, she realized, she had hardly a clue.

ðə naɪt wɑz kul ɪnʌf tə sɛn ə smɔl ʃɪvɝ θɹu pɛɹɪn wɛnɛvɝ ðə bɹiz ɡʌstɪd dɪspaɪɾ ɪz fɝ-laɪn kloʊk. ə heɪloʊ ɝaʊn ðə fæt kɹɛsən mun sɛd ðəɹ wəd bi mɔɹ ɹeɪn bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ. θɪk klaʊdz dʒɹɪftɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə mun meɪd ðə peɪl laɪt dɪm ən stʃɹɛŋθən, dɪm ən stʃɹɛŋθən, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪz aɪz. hi sæt stɛpɝ dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ði ɛdʒ ə ðə tʃɹiz ən wɑtʃt ðə klʌstɝ ə fɔɹ tɔl ɡɹeɪ stoʊn wɪndmɪlz ɪn ə klɪɹɪŋ ətɑp ðə ɹɪdʒ, ðɛɹ peɪl seɪlz ɡlimɪŋ ən ʃæɾoʊd baɪ tɝnz əz ðeɪ ɹoʊteɪɾɪd. ðə məʃinɝi ʌv ðə wɪndmɪlz ɡɹoʊn laʊdli. ɪt sim daʊtfəl ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ivən nu ðeɪ ʃəd ɡɹis ðə wɝks ə ðə θɪŋz. ðə stoʊn ækwədʌkt wɑz ə dɑɹk bɑɹ stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ist ɑn haɪ stoʊn ɑɹtʃəz pæst əbændən fɑɹmz ən ɹeɪl-fɛns filz - ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd plæntəd, tu ɝli, wɪð ðɪs mʌtʃ ɹeɪn - təwɔɹɾ ənʌðɝ ɹɪdʒ ən ðə leɪk bɪɑnd. mɔldən leɪ wʌn mɔɹ ɹɪdʒ wɛst. hi iz ðə hɛvi hæmɝ ɪn ɪts lup ɑn ɪz bɛlt. mɔldən ən feɪl. ɪn ə fju aʊɝz, hi wəɾ æɾ ə fɪfti-fɔɹθ nɑt tə ðə lɛðɝ kɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz pɑkət.

The night was cool enough to send a small shiver through Perrin whenever the breeze gusted despite his fur-lined cloak. A halo around the fat crescent moon said there would be more rain before long. Thick clouds drifting across the moon made the pale light dim and strengthen, dim and strengthen, yet it was enough for his eyes. He sat Stepper just inside the edge of the trees and watched the cluster of four tall gray stone windmills in a clearing atop the ridge, their pale sails gleaming and shadowed by turns as they rotated. The machinery of the windmills groaned loudly. It seemed doubtful the Shaido even knew they should grease the works of the things. The stone aqueduct was a dark bar stretching east on high stone arches past abandoned farms and rail-fenced fields - the Shaido had planted, too early, with this much rain - toward another ridge and the lake beyond. Malden lay one more ridge west. He eased the heavy hammer in its loop on his belt. Malden and Faile. In a few hours, he would add a fifty-fourth knot to the leather cord in his pocket.

hi kæst ɪz maɪn aʊt. ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi, snoʊi dɔn? hi θɔt. ɑɹ jə kloʊs ɪnʌf jɛt? wʊlvz əvɔɪɾəd taʊnz, ən wɪð ʃeɪɾoʊ hʌntɪŋ pɑɹɾiz ɪn ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ fɔɹəs dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪ, ðeɪ steɪd fɑɹðɝ fɹəm mɔldən ðən juʒəwəl.

He cast his mind out. Are you ready, Snowy Dawn? he thought. Are you close enough yet? Wolves avoided towns, and with Shaido hunting parties in the surrounding forest during the day, they stayed farther from Malden than usual.

peɪʃəns, jʌŋ bʊl, keɪm ðə ɹɪplaɪ, tʌtʃt wɪð ɪɹɪteɪʃən. bʌt ðɛn, snoʊi dɔn wɑz ɪɹæsɪbəl baɪ neɪtʃɝ, ə skɑɹd meɪl ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl eɪdʒ fəɹ ə wʊlf u hæd wʌns kɪld ə lɛpɝd baɪ hɪmsɛlf. ðoʊz oʊld ɪnʒɝiz səmtaɪmz kɛpt ɪm fɹəm slipɪŋ vɛɹi lɔŋ əɾ ə stʃɹɛtʃ. tu deɪz fɹəm naʊ, jə sɛd. wɪl bi ðɛɹ. naʊ lemi tʃɹaɪ tə slip. wi mʌs hʌnt wɛl təmɑɹoʊ, sɪns wi kænɑt hʌn ðə deɪ æftɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ɪmədʒəz ən smɛlz ɹæðɝ ðən wɝdz, ʌv kɔɹs - "tu deɪz" wɑz ðə sʌn kɹɔsɪŋ ðə skaɪ twaɪs, ən "hʌnt" ə pæk tʃɹɑɾɪŋ wɪð noʊzɪz ɪndə ðə bɹiz blɛndəd wɪð ðə sɛn ə dɪɹ - bʌt pɛɹɪnz maɪn kənvɝɾɪd ði ɪmədʒəz tə wɝdz ivən əz i sɔ ðɛm ɪn ɪz hɛd.

Patience, Young Bull, came the reply, touched with irritation. But then, Snowy Dawn was irascible by nature, a scarred male of considerable age for a wolf who had once killed a leopard by himself. Those old injuries sometimes kept him from sleeping very long at a stretch. Two days from now, you said. We will be there. Now let me try to sleep. We must hunt well tomorrow, since we cannot hunt the day after. They were images and smells rather than words, of course - "two days" was the sun crossing the sky twice, and "hunt" a pack trotting with noses into the breeze blended with the scent of deer - but Perrin's mind converted the images to words even as he saw them in his head.

peɪʃəns. jɛs. heɪst spɔɪl ðə wɝk. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz soʊ kloʊs. vɛɹi hɑɹd.

Patience. Yes. Haste spoiled the work. But it was hard now that he was so close. Very hard.

ə fɔɹm əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə dɑɹk dɔɹ ət ðə beɪs ə ðə nɪɹəst wɪndmɪl ən weɪvd ən il spɪɹ bæk ən fɔɹθ oʊvɝhɛd. ðə ɡɹoʊnɪŋ hæd kənvɪnst ɪm ðə wɪndmɪlz mʌst stɪl bi dɪzɝɾɪd - ðeɪ hæd bɪn wən ðə meɪɾənz skaʊɾəd əm ɝliɝ, ən noʊ wʌn wəd pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðət nɔɪz ɛni lɔŋɡɝ ðən ðeɪ hæd tə - bʌɾ i hæd sɛnt ɡɔl ən səm ə ðə meɪɾənz tə bi ʃʊɹ wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ.

A form appeared from the dark door at the base of the nearest windmill and waved an Aiel spear back and forth overhead. The groaning had convinced him the windmills must still be deserted - they had been when the Maidens scouted them earlier, and no one would put up with that noise any longer than they had to - but he had sent Gaul and some of the Maidens to be sure one way or another.

"lɛts ɡoʊ, mɪʃimə," hi sɛd, ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪnz. "ɪts dʌn." wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ.

"Let's go, Mishima," he said, gathering his reins. "It's done." One way or another.

"haʊ kən jə meɪk aʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ?" ðə sintʃæn mʌɾɝd. hi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn, huz ɡoʊldən aɪz wəd bi ɡloʊɪŋ ɪn ðə naɪt. ðət hæd meɪd ðə skɑɹd mæn dʒʌmp ðə fɝs taɪm i sɔ ɪt. hi dɪd nɑt smɛl əmjuz tənaɪt. hi smɛl tɛns. bʌɾ i kɔl sɔfli oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "bɹɪŋ ðə kɑɹts əhɛd. kwɪkli, naʊ. kwɪkli. ən bi kwaɪəɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, əɹ əl əv jəɹ ɪɹz!"

"How can you make out anything?" the Seanchan muttered. He avoided looking at Perrin, whose golden eyes would be glowing in the night. That had made the scarred man jump the first time he saw it. He did not smell amused tonight. He smelled tense. But he called softly over his shoulder. "Bring the carts ahead. Quickly, now. Quickly. And be quiet about it, or I'll have your ears!"

pɛɹɪn hild ɪz dʌn stæljən fɔɹwɝd wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝz, əɹ ðə sɪks haɪ-wil kɑɹts. lɪbɝəli ɡɹist æksəlz meɪɾ əm əz saɪlən əz kɑɹts kəd bi. ðeɪ stɪl saʊndəd nɔɪzi tə hɪm, ðə kɑɹt hɔɹsəz' hʊvz skwɛltʃɪŋ ɪn ðə mʌd, ðə kɑɹts ðɛmsɛlvz kɹikɪŋ əz wʊd flɛkst ən ɹʌbd, bʌɾ i daʊɾɪd ɛniwʌn ɛls cʊɾə hɝɾ əm fɪfti peɪsɪz ɔf, ən meɪbi nɑt kloʊsɝ. ət ðə tɑp ə ðə dʒɛntəl sloʊp i dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən lɛt stɛpɝz ɹeɪnz fɔl. ə tʃɹeɪnd wɔɹhɔɹs, ðə stæljən wəd stæn ðəɹ əz ɪf hɑbəl soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪz ɹeɪnz hʌŋ daʊn. ðə wɪndmɪl hɛdz skwild, tɝnɪŋ slaɪtli əz ðə bɹiz ʃɪftəd. ðə sloʊli spɪnɪŋ ɑɹmz wɝ lɔŋ ɪnʌf ðət pɛɹɪn cʊɾə tʌtʃt wʌn baɪ dʒʌmpɪŋ wən ɪt swʌŋ loʊ. hi stɛɹd təwɔɹd ðə læst ɹɪdʒ ðət hɪd mɔldən. nʌθɪŋ ɡɹu ðəɹ tɔlɝ ðən ə bʊʃ. nʌθɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. dʒʌst wʌn ɹɪdʒ bɪtwin ɪm ən feɪl. ðə meɪɾənz hæd kʌm aʊtsaɪd tə dʒɔɪn ɡɔl, ɔl ə ðɛm stɪl veɪld.

Perrin heeled his dun stallion forward without waiting on the others, or the six high-wheeled carts. Liberally greased axles made them as silent as carts could be. They still sounded noisy to him, the cart horses' hooves squelching in the mud, the carts themselves creaking as wood flexed and rubbed, but he doubted anyone else could have heard them fifty paces off, and maybe not closer. At the top of the gentle slope he dismounted and let Stepper's reins fall. A trained warhorse, the stallion would stand there as if hobbled so long as his reins hung down. The windmill heads squealed, turning slightly as the breeze shifted. The slowly spinning arms were long enough that Perrin could have touched one by jumping when it swung low. He stared toward the last ridge that hid Malden. Nothing grew there taller than a bush. Nothing moved in the darkness. Just one ridge between him and Faile. The Maidens had come outside to join Gaul, all of them still veiled.

"ðɛɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn," ɡɔl sɛd, nɑt kwaɪətli. ðɪs kloʊs, ðə ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ə ðə wɪndmɪlz' ɡɪɹz wʊɾə swɑloʊd kwaɪət wɝdz.

"There was no one," Gaul said, not quietly. This close, the grinding of the windmills' gears would have swallowed quiet words.

"ðə dʌst əz nɑt bɪn dɪstɝb sɪns aɪ wɑz hɪɹ læst," səlɪn æɾəd.

"The dust has not been disturbed since I was here last," Sulin added.

pɛɹɪn skɹætʃt ɪz bɪɹd. dʒʌst əz wɛl. hæd ðeɪ niɾəd tə kɪl ʃeɪɾoʊ, ðeɪ cʊɾə kæɹiɾ əweɪ ðə bɑɾiz, bʌt ðə dɛd wʊɾə bɪn mɪst, ən ɪt wʊɾə dʒɹɔn ətɛnʃən tə ðə wɪndmɪlz ən ækwədʌkt. ɪt maɪɾ əv stɑɹɾəd sʌmwʌn θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə wɔɾɝ.

Perrin scratched his beard. Just as well. Had they needed to kill Shaido, they could have carried away the bodies, but the dead would have been missed, and it would have drawn attention to the windmills and aqueduct. It might have started someone thinking about the water.

"hɛlp mi ɡɛt ðə lɪdz ɔf, ɡɔl." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ ɪm tə də ðæt. ɪt wəd seɪv oʊnli mɪnəts, bʌɾ i niɾəd tə bi duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. ɡɔl sɪmpli stʌk ɪz spɪɹ θɹu ðə hɑɹnəs hoʊldɪŋ ɪz boʊkeɪs tə dʒɔɪn ði ʌðɝz ɑn ɪz bæk.

"Help me get the lids off, Gaul." There was no need for him to do that. It would save only minutes, but he needed to be doing something. Gaul simply stuck his spear through the harness holding his bowcase to join the others on his back.

ði ækwədʌkt ɹæn əlɔŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɑn ðə ɹɪdʒtɑp, bɪtwin ðə fɔɹ wɪndmɪlz, ən stʊd ʃoʊldɝ-haɪ ɑn pɛɹɪn, lɛs ɑn ɡɔl, hu klaɪmd oʊvɝ. dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə læs pɛɹ ʌv wɪndmɪlz, bɹɑnz hændəlz ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ əlaʊɾ əm tə lɪft ɔf hɛvi pisəz ə stoʊn tu fit waɪɾ ən faɪv fit lɔŋ əntɪl ðeɪ hæd klɪɹɾ ə stʃɹɛtʃ ə sɪks fit. wʌt ði oʊpənɪŋ wɑz juz fɔɹ, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ. ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ laɪk ɪɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. meɪbi tə wɝk ɑn ðə flæps ðət meɪd ʃʊɹ wɔɾɝ floʊɾ oʊnli wʌn weɪ, əɹ tə ɡɛɾ ɪnsaɪd tə ɹɪpɛɹ ɛni liks. hi kəd si smɔl ɹɪpəlz ə moʊʃən əz ɪt stʃɹim təwɔɹd mɔldən, fɪlɪŋ mɔɹ ðən hæf ðə stoʊn tʃænəl.

The aqueduct ran along the ground on the ridgetop, between the four windmills, and stood shoulder-high on Perrin, less on Gaul, who climbed over. Just beyond the last pair of windmills, bronze handles on either side allowed them to lift off heavy pieces of stone two feet wide and five feet long until they had cleared a stretch of six feet. What the opening was used for, he did not know. There was another like it on the other side. Maybe to work on the flaps that made sure water flowed only one way, or to get inside to repair any leaks. He could see small ripples of motion as it streamed toward Malden, filling more than half the stone channel.

mɪʃimə dʒɔɪn əm ən dɪsmaʊntɪd tə stæn piɹɪŋ ənsɝteɪnli ət səlɪn ən ðə meɪɾənz. hi pɹɑbli bɪliv ðə naɪt hɪɾ ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən. hi smɛld wɛɹi, naʊ. hi wɑz fɑloʊd kwɪkli baɪ ðə fɝst ə ðə ɹɛd-koʊɾəd sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz skɹæmbəlɪŋ ʌp ðə mʌɾi sloʊp, itʃ kæɹiɪŋ tu mɪɾəlɪŋ-saɪzd dʒut sæks. mɪɾəlɪŋ, bʌt nɑt hɛvi. itʃ kənteɪn oʊnli tɛn paʊnz. aɪɪŋ ði il səspɪʃəsli, ðə wɪɹi wʊmən sɛɾ əɹ sæks daʊn ən slæʃt wʌn oʊpən wɪð əɹ dæɡɝ. ə hændfʊl ə faɪn dɑɹk ɡɹeɪnz spɪld ɑn ðə mʌɾi ɡɹaʊnd.

Mishima joined them and dismounted to stand peering uncertainly at Sulin and the Maidens. He probably believed the night hid his expression. He smelled wary, now. He was followed quickly by the first of the red-coated Seanchan soldiers scrambling up the muddy slope, each carrying two middling-sized jute sacks. Middling, but not heavy. Each contained only ten pounds. Eyeing the Aiel suspiciously, the wiry woman set her sacks down and slashed one open with her dagger. A handful of fine dark grains spilled on the muddy ground.

"du ðəɾ oʊvɝ ði oʊpənɪŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "meɪk ʃʊɹ ɛvɹi ɡɹeɪn ɡoʊz ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ."

"Do that over the opening," Perrin said. "Make sure every grain goes into the water."

ðə wɪɹi wʊmən lʊk tə mɪʃimə, hu sɛd fɝmli, "du əz lɔɹd pɛɹɪn kəmænz, ɹɑɾə."

The wiry woman looked to Mishima, who said firmly, "Do as Lord Perrin commands, Arrata."

pɛɹɪn wɑtʃt əz ʃi ɛmptid ðə sæk ɪndə ði ækwədʌkt, hænz lɪftəɾ oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd. ðə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪnz floʊɾəd əweɪ təwɔɹd mɔldən. hi hæd dʒɹɑpt ə pɪntʃ ɪndə ə kʌp ʌv wɔɾɝ, heɪɾɪŋ tə weɪst ivən ðæt, ən ðeɪ tʊk səm taɪm tə əbzɔɹb ɪnʌf wɔɾɝ tə sɪŋk. lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹitʃ ðə bɪɡ sɪstɝn ɪn ðə taʊn, hi hoʊpt. ən ɪf nɑt, ðeɪ kəd stip ɪn ði ækwədʌkt ɪtsɛlf. ðə sɪstɝn wəd stɪl tɝn tə fɔkɹut ti ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt wəd bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf. wɪð lʌk, meɪbi ivən stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə əfɛk ði ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ. ðə waɪz wʌnz u kəd tʃænəl wɝ ɪz tɑɹɡət, bʌɾ i wəd teɪk ɛni ædvæntɪdʒ i kəd ɡeɪn. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt dɪd nɑt ɡɹoʊ stʃɹɔŋ fæstɝ ðən i ɪkspɛktəd. ɪf ðoʊz waɪz wʌnz bɪɡæn stæɡɝɪŋ tu sun, ðeɪ maɪt pʌzəl aʊt ðə kɑz bɪfɔɹ i wɑz ɹɛɾi. bʌɾ ɔl i kəd də wɑz ɡoʊ əhɛɾ əz ɪf i nu ɪɡzækli. ðæt, ən pɹeɪ.

Perrin watched as she emptied the sack into the aqueduct, hands lifted over her head. The dark grains floated away toward Malden. He had dropped a pinch into a cup of water, hating to waste even that, and they took some time to absorb enough water to sink. Long enough to reach the big cistern in the town, he hoped. And if not, they could steep in the aqueduct itself. The cistern would still turn to forkroot tea eventually. The Light send it would be strong enough. With luck, maybe even strong enough to affect the algai'd'siswai. The Wise Ones who could channel were his target, but he would take any advantage he could gain. The Light send it did not grow strong faster than he expected. If those Wise Ones began staggering too soon, they might puzzle out the cause before he was ready. But all he could do was go ahead as if he knew exactly. That, and pray.

baɪ ðə taɪm ðə sɛkən sæk wɑz biɪŋ pɔɹɾ ɪndə ðə stoʊn tʃænəl, ði ʌðɝz bɪɡæn kɹaʊɾɪŋ ʌp ðə sloʊp. fɝs keɪm siɑnɪd, ə ʃɔɹt wʊmən hoʊldɪŋ əɹ dɑɹk dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə mʌd. ʃɪftɪŋ ɪz ətɛnʃən fɹəm ðə meɪɾənz tə hɝ, mɪʃimə meɪd wʌn ə ðoʊz smɔl dʒɛstʃɝz tə wɔɹɾ ɔf ivəl. stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət ðeɪ kəd bɪliv ə θɪŋ laɪk ðət wɝkt. ðə soʊlʒɝz laɪn ʌp wɪð ðɛɹ sæks stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, waɪd-aɪd fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ən ʃɪftəd ðɛɹ fit. ðə sintʃæn wɝ nʌn tu izi əbaʊt wɝkɪŋ wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. hɝ wɔɹɾɝz, fʊɹən ən tɛɹəl, wɝ əɾ əɹ hilz, itʃ wɪð ə hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌst əz ənizi əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn. ðə wʌn wɑz dɑɹk wɪð ɡɹeɪ stʃɹikɪŋ ɪz kɝli blæk hɛɹ, ði ʌðɝ fɛɹ ən jʌŋ, wɪð kɝl mʌstæʃɪz, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ əlaɪk əz tu binz, tɔl, lin ən hɑɹd. ɹoʊvɛɹ kɝklɪn keɪm ə lɪɾəl bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ə kɑmpæk mæn wɪð dɑɹk ɹɪsiɾɪŋ hɛɹ ən ə ɡlʌm ɪkspɹɛʃən. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm mɑsʊɝi. ɔl θɹi ʌv ðə mɛn hæd smɔl bʌndəlz kənteɪnɪŋ fud stʃɹæp tə ðɛɹ bæks ən fæt wɔɾɝskɪnz hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ə læŋki mæn ɹɛstəɾ ɪz sæks ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ði oʊpənɪŋ əz ðə wɪɹi wʊmən hɛɾəd daʊnsloʊp tə fɛtʃ mɔɹ. ðə kɑɹts wɝ paɪl haɪ wɪð ðɛm.

By the time the second sack was being poured into the stone channel, the others began crowding up the slope. First came Seonid, a short woman holding her dark divided skirts up out of the mud. Shifting his attention from the Maidens to her, Mishima made one of those small gestures to ward off evil. Strange that they could believe a thing like that worked. The soldiers lined up with their sacks stared at her, wide-eyed for the most part, and shifted their feet. The Seanchan were none too easy about working with Aes Sedai. Her Warders, Furen and Teryl, were at her heels, each with a hand resting on his sword hilt. They were just as uneasy about the Seanchan. The one was dark with gray streaking his curly black hair, the other fair and young, with curled mustaches, yet they were alike as two beans, tall, lean and hard. Rovair Kirklin came a little behind them, a compact man with dark receding hair and a glum expression. He did not like being separated from Masuri. All three of the men had small bundles containing food strapped to their backs and fat waterskins hanging from their shoulders. A lanky man rested his sacks on the side of the opening as the wiry woman headed downslope to fetch more. The carts were piled high with them.

"ɹɪmɛmbɝ," pɛɹɪn toʊl siɑnɪd, "ðə bɪɡəs deɪnʒɝ wɪl bi ɡɛɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə sɪstɝn tə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs. jəl əv tə juz ðə ɡɑɹdwɔk ɑn ðə wɔl, ən ðəɹ maɪt bi ʃeɪɾoʊ ɪn ðə taʊn ivən ət ðɪs aʊɝ." ælɪs hæd simd ənʃʊɹ ɑn ðæt. θʌndɝ bum hɑloʊli ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ðən əɡɛn. "meɪbi jəl əv ɹeɪn tə haɪd ju."

"Remember," Perrin told Seonid, "the biggest danger will be getting from the cistern to the fortress. You'll have to use the guardwalk on the wall, and there might be Shaido in the town even at this hour." Alyse had seemed unsure on that. Thunder boomed hollowly in the distance, then again. "Maybe you'll have rain to hide you."

"θæŋk ju," ʃi sɛɾ aɪsɪli. hɝ munʃæɾoʊd feɪs wɑz ə mæsk ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi, bʌɾ əɹ sɛn spaɪkt wɪð ɪndɪɡneɪʃən. "aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv noʊn ɛni ʌv ðəɾ ɪf jə hæd nɑt toʊl mi." ðə nɛks moʊmən əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən sɔfənd, ən ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. "aɪ noʊ jə ɑɹ wɝiɾ əbaʊt hɝ. wɪl də wʌt kən bi dʌn." hɝ toʊn wɑz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli wɔɹm - ɪt nɛvɝ wɑz - bʌt nɑt soʊ tʃɪl əz bɪfɔɹ, ən əɹ sɛn hæd mɛloʊd tə sɪmpəθi.

"Thank you," she said icily. Her moonshadowed face was a mask of Aes Sedai serenity, but her scent spiked with indignation. "I would not have known any of that if you had not told me." The next moment her expression softened, and she laid a hand on his arm. "I know you are worried about her. We will do what can be done." Her tone was not exactly warm - it never was - but not so chill as before, and her scent had mellowed to sympathy.

tɛɹəl lɪftəɾ əɹ ʌp ɑntu ði ɛdʒ ə ði ækwədʌkt - ðə sintʃæn ɛmptiɪŋ fɔkɹuɾ ɪndə ðə θɪŋ, ə tɔl fɛloʊ wɪð ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni skɑɹz əz mɪʃimə, nɪɹli dʒɹɑpt ɪz sæk - ən ʃi ɡɹɪməs feɪnli bɪfɔɹ swɪŋɪŋ əɹ lɛɡz oʊvɝ ən loʊɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ wɪð ə smɔl ɡæsp. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn koʊld. dʌkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ʃi muvd aʊɾ ə saɪt təwɔɹd mɔldən. fʊɹən klaɪmd ɪn æftɝ hɝ, ðən tɛɹəl, ən faɪnəli ɹoʊvɛɹ. ðeɪ hæd tə bɛnd ʃɑɹpli tə fɪɾ ʌndɝ ðə ɹuf ə ði ækwədʌkt.

Teryl lifted her up onto the edge of the aqueduct - the Seanchan emptying forkroot into the thing, a tall fellow with almost as many scars as Mishima, nearly dropped his sack - and she grimaced faintly before swinging her legs over and lowering herself into the water with a small gasp. It must have been cold. Ducking her head, she moved out of sight toward Malden. Furen climbed in after her, then Teryl, and finally Rovair. They had to bend sharply to fit under the roof of the aqueduct.

ɛlaɪəs klæpt pɛɹɪn ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ bɪfɔɹ hɔɪstɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp. "ʃʊɾ əv tʃɹɪmd maɪ bɪɹd ʃɔɹt laɪk jʊɹz tə kip ɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðæt," hi sɛd, ɡeɪzɪŋ daʊn ət ðə wɔɾɝ. ðət ɡɹeɪɪŋ bɪɹd, ɹʌfəl baɪ ðə bɹiz, spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, hɪz hɛɹ, ɡæðɝɾ ət ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk wɪð ə lɛðɝ kɔɹd, hʌŋ tə hɪz weɪst. hi kæɹiɾ ə smɔl bʌndəl ə fuɾ ən ə wɔɾɝskɪn, tu. "stɪl, ə koʊl bæθ hɛlps ə mæn kip ɪz maɪn ɔf ɪz tʃɹʌbəlz."

Elyas clapped Perrin on the shoulder before hoisting himself up. "Should have trimmed my beard short like yours to keep it out of that," he said, gazing down at the water. That graying beard, ruffled by the breeze, spread across his chest. For that matter, his hair, gathered at the back of his neck with a leather cord, hung to his waist. He carried a small bundle of food and a waterskin, too. "Still, a cold bath helps a man keep his mind off his troubles."

"aɪ θɔt ðət wɑz fəɹ kipɪŋ jəɹ maɪn ɔf wɪmən," pɛɹɪn sɛd. hi wɑz ɪn noʊ mud fəɹ dʒoʊkɪŋ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ɛvɹiwʌn tə bi əz ɡɹɪm əz i wɑz.

"I thought that was for keeping your mind off women," Perrin said. He was in no mood for joking, but he could not expect everyone to be as grim as he was.

ɛlaɪəs læft. "wʌɾ ɛls kɑzəz ə mænz tʃɹʌbəlz?" hi dɪsəpɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ, ən tɑlænvɝ ɹipleɪs hɪm.

Elyas laughed. "What else causes a man's troubles?" He disappeared into the water, and Tallanvor replaced him.

pɛɹɪn kɑɾ ɪz dɑɹk koʊtsliv. "noʊ hɪɹoʊɪks, maɪnd." hi hæd bɪn ə tu maɪnz əbaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ðə mæn bi pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs.

Perrin caught his dark coatsleeve. "No heroics, mind." He had been of two minds about letting the man be part of this.

"noʊ hɪɹoʊɪks, maɪ lɔɹd," tɑlænvɝ əɡɹid. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm, hi lʊkt iɡɝ. ðə smɛl ə hɪm kwɪvɝd wɪð iɡɝnəs. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛdʒ ə kɑʃən ɪn ɪt, tu. ðət kɑʃən wɑz ði oʊnli ɹizən i wɑz nɑt bæk ɪn ðɛɹ kæmp. "aɪ woʊn pʊt meɪaɪɡdɪn ət ɹɪsk. əɹ ðə leɪɾi feɪl. aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə si meɪaɪɡdɪn ðət mʌtʃ kwɪkɝ."

"No heroics, my Lord," Tallanvor agreed. For the first time in a long time, he looked eager. The smell of him quivered with eagerness. But there was an edge of caution in it, too. That caution was the only reason he was not back in their camp. "I won't put Maighdin at risk. Or the Lady Faile. I just want to see Maighdin that much quicker."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd ən lɛɾ ɪm ɡoʊ. hi kəɾ ʌndɝstæn ðæt. pɑɹɾ ə hɪm wɑntəd tə klaɪm ɪndə ði ækwədʌkt, tu. tə si feɪl əɡɛn ðət mʌtʃ kwɪkɝ. bʌɾ ɛvɹi pis ə ðə wɝk hæd tə bi dʌn pɹɑpɝli, ən i hæɾ ʌðɝ tæsks. bɪsaɪdz, ɪf i wɝ æktʃəli  ɪnsaɪd mɔldən, hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd ɹistʃɹeɪn hɪmsɛlf fɹəm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn hɝ. hi kəd nɑt kætʃ ɪz oʊn sɛnt, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ i daʊɾɪd ðəɹ wɑz ɛni kɑʃən ɪn ɪt naʊ. ðə wɪndmɪl hɛdz tɝn əɡɛn wɪð laʊd skwiks əz ðə wɪnd ʃɪftəd bæk. ət list ɪt nɛvɝ sim tə daɪ ʌp hɪɹ. ɛni stɑpɪdʒ ə ðə wɔɾɝ floʊ wəd bi dɪzæstʃɹəs.

Perrin nodded and let him go. He could understand that. Part of him wanted to climb into the aqueduct, too. To see Faile again that much quicker. But every piece of the work had to be done properly, and he had other tasks. Besides, if he were actually inside Malden, he was not sure he could restrain himself from trying to find her. He could not catch his own scent, of course, but he doubted there was any caution in it now. The windmill heads turned again with loud squeaks as the wind shifted back. At least it never seemed to die up here. Any stoppage of the water flow would be disastrous.

ðə ɹɪdʒtɑp wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ kɹaʊɾəd, naʊ. twɛnti ʌv feɪlz hæŋɝz-ɑn wɝ weɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tɝn ət ði ækwədʌkt, ɔl ðət ɹɪmeɪn seɪv ðə tu hu wɝ spaɪɪŋ ɑn mæsimə. ðə wɪmən wɔɹ mɛnz koʊts ən bɹitʃɪz ən hæd ðɛɹ hɛɹ kʌt ʃɔɹɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə teɪl ət ðə bæk ɪn ɪməteɪʃən ə ði il, ðoʊ noʊ il wʊɾə wɔɹn ə sɔɹɾ əz ðeɪ dɪd. mɛni ʌv ðə tɛɹən mɛn hæd ʃeɪv ðɛɹ bɪɹdz kəz il dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ðɛm. bɪhaɪn əm fɪfti tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn kæɹid hælbɝdz ən ənstʃɹʌŋ baʊz, ðɛɹ bɑstʃɹɪŋz seɪfli tʌkt əweɪ ɪnsaɪd ðɛɹ koʊts ən itʃ wɪð θɹi bɹɪsəlɪŋ kwɪvɝz taɪd tə hɪz bæk əlɔŋ wɪð ə pɑɹsəl ə fud. ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ðə kæmp hæd vɑləntɪɹd fəɹ ðɪs, ən pɛɹɪn hæd hæd tə lɛɾ əm tʃuz lɑts. hi hæd kənsɪɾɝd dʌbəlɪŋ ðə nʌmbɝ, əɹ mɔɹ. hæŋɝz-ɑn ən tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn hæd ðɛɹ bʌndəlz ə fuɾ ən ðɛɹ wɔɾɝskɪnz. ðə kɑnstən floʊ ʌv sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz kəntɪnjud, kæɹiɪŋ fʊl sæks ʌp ðə sloʊp ən ɛmpti sæks bæk daʊn. ðeɪ wɝ dɪsəplənd. wən ə mæn slɪpt ɪn ðə mʌɾ ən fɛl, əz hæpənd wɪð səm ɹɛɡjəlɛɹəɾi, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kɝsɪŋ əɹ ivən mʌɾɝz. ðeɪ dʒʌst ɡɑɾ ʌp ən wɛn əhɛd.

The ridgetop was becoming crowded, now. Twenty of Faile's hangers-on were waiting their turn at the aqueduct, all that remained save the two who were spying on Masema. The women wore men's coats and breeches and had their hair cut short except for a tail at the back in imitation of the Aiel, though no Aiel would have worn a sword as they did. Many of the Tairen men had shaved their beards because Aiel did not wear them. Behind them fifty Two Rivers men carried halberds and unstrung bows, their bowstrings safely tucked away inside their coats and each with three bristling quivers tied to his back along with a parcel of food. Every man in the camp had volunteered for this, and Perrin had had to let them choose lots. He had considered doubling the number, or more. Hangers-on and Two Rivers men had their bundles of food and their waterskins. The constant flow of Seanchan soldiers continued, carrying full sacks up the slope and empty sacks back down. They were disciplined. When a man slipped in the mud and fell, as happened with some regularity, there was no cursing or even mutters. They just got up and went ahead.

sɛlən dɛɹənɡəl, wɛɹɪŋ ə dɑɹk koʊt wɪð sɪks hɔɹəzɑntəl stʃɹaɪps ə kʌlɝ əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst, stɑp tə ɔfɝ pɛɹɪn əɹ hænd. ʃi oʊnli keɪm ʌp tə hɪz tʃɛst, bʌɾ ɛlaɪəs kleɪmd ʃi hændəl ðə sɔɹɾ əɾ əɹ hɪp kɹɛɾəbli. pɛɹɪn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ θɔt ʃi ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ fulz - wɛl, nɑɾ ɔl ðə taɪm - ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðɛɹ ətɛmps tə kɑpi il weɪz. wɪð dɪfɝənsɪz, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə teɪl ə dɑɹk hɛɹ ət sɛlənz neɪp wɑz taɪd wɪð ə lɛŋθ ə dɑɹk ɹɪbən. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ fɪɹ ɪn əɹ sɛnt, oʊnli dɪtɝməneɪʃən. "θæŋk jə fəɹ əlaʊɪŋ əs tə bi pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs, maɪ lɔɹd," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ðət pɹɪsaɪs kɛɹhinɪn æksɛnt. "wi wɪl nɑt lɛt jə daʊn. əɹ ðə leɪɾi feɪl."

Selande Darengil, wearing a dark coat with six horizontal stripes of color across the chest, stopped to offer Perrin her hand. She only came up to his chest, but Elyas claimed she handled the sword at her hip credibly. Perrin no longer thought she and the others were fools - well, not all the time - in spite of their attempts to copy Aiel ways. With differences, of course. The tail of dark hair at Selande's nape was tied with a length of dark ribbon. There was no fear in her scent, only determination. "Thank you for allowing us to be part of this, my Lord," she said in that precise Cairhienin accent. "We will not let you down. Or the Lady Faile."

"aɪ noʊ jə woʊnt," hi sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hænd. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə taɪm wən ʃi hæd bɪn pɔɪntəɾ əbaʊt sɝvɪŋ feɪl, ən nɑt hɪm. hi ʃʊk ðə hæn ʌv ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ klaɪmd ɪndə ði ækwədʌkt. ðeɪ ɔl smɛl dɪtɝmənd. soʊ dɪd bæn ælsin, hu kəmændəd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə mɔldən.

"I know you won't," he said, shaking her hand. There had been a time when she had been pointed about serving Faile, and not him. He shook the hand of every one of them before they climbed into the aqueduct. They all smelled determined. So did Ban al'Seen, who commanded the Two Rivers men going into Malden.

"wɛn feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz kʌm, wɛdʒ ði aʊɾɝ dɔɹz ʃʌt, bæn." pɛɹɪn hæd toʊld ɪm ðɪs bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt hɛlp ɹɪpiɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. "ðɛn si ɪf jə kən ɡɛɾ əm bæk ʌp ði ækwədʌkt." ðət fɔɹtʃɹəs hæd nɑt kɛp ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ aʊt ðə fɝs taɪm, ən ɪf ɛniθɪŋ wɛn ɹɔŋ, hi daʊɾɪd ɪt wəd kip əm aʊt ðɪs taɪm iðɝ. hi dɪd nɑt min tə ɹɪnɪɡ ɑn ɪz bɑɹɡən wɪð ðə sintʃæn - ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ gɑnə peɪ fəɹ wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn tə feɪl, ən bɪsaɪdz, hi kəd nɑt liv əm bɪhaɪn tə kəntɪnju ɹævɪdʒɪŋ ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd - bʌɾ i wɑntəɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə hɑɹmz weɪ əz sun əz pɑsəbəl.

"When Faile and the others come, wedge the outer doors shut, Ban." Perrin had told him this before, but he could not help repeating himself. "Then see if you can get them back up the aqueduct." That fortress had not kept the Shaido out the first time, and if anything went wrong, he doubted it would keep them out this time either. He did not mean to renege on his bargain with the Seanchan - the Shaido were going to pay for what they had done to Faile, and besides, he could not leave them behind to continue ravaging the countryside - but he wanted her out of harm's way as soon as possible.

bæn pɹɑpt ɪz bɑstɑv ən hælbɹɾ əɡɛns ði ækwədʌkt ən hɔɪstəd hɪmsɛlf ʌp tə ɹitʃ ə hæn daʊn ɪnsaɪd. wən i loʊɝd hɪmsɛlf bæk tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, hi waɪpt ɪz dæmp hæn ɑn ɪz koʊt ðən ɹʌb ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz pɹɑmənənt noʊz. "bɪloʊ ðə wɔɾɝ, ɪts koʊɾəd wɪð sʌmθɪŋ filz laɪk pɑn slaɪm. wɝ gɑnə hæv ə hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf taɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ daʊn ðət læst sloʊp wɪθaʊt slaɪɾɪŋ ðə hoʊl weɪ, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, mʌtʃ lɛs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə klaɪm ɪɾ əɡɛn. aɪ ɪkspɛk ðə bɛs θɪŋ ɪz tə weɪɾ ɪn ðət fɔɹtʃɹəs tɪl jə ɹitʃ ʌs."

Ban propped his bowstave and halberd against the aqueduct and hoisted himself up to reach a hand down inside. When he lowered himself back to the ground, he wiped his damp hand on his coat then rubbed the side of his prominent nose. "Below the water, it's coated with something feels like pond slime. We're going to have a hard enough time getting down that last slope without sliding the whole way, Lord Perrin, much less trying to climb it again. I expect the best thing is to wait in that fortress till you reach us."

pɛɹɪn saɪd. hi hæd θɔɾ ə sɛndɪŋ ɹoʊps, bʌt ðeɪ wʊɾə niɾəd nɪɹli tu maɪlz ʌv ɪt tə spæn ðət læst sloʊp, ə lɑt tə bi kæɹid, ən ɪf ɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ spɑɾəd ðə bʌɾ ɛn ʌv ɪɾ ɪn ðə mɔldən ɛn ə ði ækwədʌkt, ðeɪ wəd sɝtʃ ɛvɹi nʊk ən kɹæni ɪn ðə taʊn. ə smɔl ɹɪsk, pɝhæps, jɛt ðə bɪɾɝ lɔs ðət maɪt ɹɪzʌl meɪɾ ɪt lum lɑɹdʒ. "aɪl bi ðəɹ əz fæst əz aɪ kæn, bæn. aɪ pɹɑməs jə ðæt."

Perrin sighed. He had thought of sending ropes, but they would have needed nearly two miles of it to span that last slope, a lot to be carried, and if any Shaido spotted the butt end of it in the Malden end of the aqueduct, they would search every nook and cranny in the town. A small risk, perhaps, yet the bitter loss that might result made it loom large. "I'll be there as fast as I can, Ban. I promise you that."

hi ʃʊk hænz wɪð ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm, tu. læntɝn-dʒɔd tɑɾ ɑlkɑɹ ən liɑf tɔɹfɪn, wɪð ə waɪt stʃɹik θɹu hɪz hɛɹ wɛɹ ə skɑɹ ɹæn, ɡɪvən tə hɪm baɪ tʃɹɑləks. jʌŋ kɛnli mɹɪn, hu wɑz meɪkɪŋ ə stæb ət ɡɹoʊɪŋ ə bɪɹɾ əɡɛn ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ən bili ədʒɹə, hu wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz waɪɾ əz pɛɹɪn ɪf ə hænd ʃɔɹɾɝ. bili wɑz ə dɪstən kʌzən, ən səm ə ðə kloʊsəs kɪn pɛɹɪn hæd lɪvɪŋ. hi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð mɛni ʌv ðiz mɛn, ðoʊ səm wɝ ə fju jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən hi. səm wɝ ə fju jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ, tu. baɪ naʊ, hi nu ðə mɛn fɹəm daʊn tə dɛvən ɹaɪɾ ən ʌp tə wɑtʃ hɪl əz wɛl əz i dɪd ðoʊz fɹəm ɝaʊn ɛmənz fild. hi hæd mɔɹ ɹizən ðən feɪl əloʊn tə ɹitʃ ðət fɔɹtʃɹəs əz fæst əz i kʊd.

He shook hands with every one of them, too. Lantern-jawed Tod al'Caar and Leof Torfinn, with a white streak through his hair where a scar ran, given to him by Trollocs. Young Kenly Maerin, who was making a stab at growing a beard again unfortunately, and Bili Adarra, who was almost as wide as Perrin if a hand shorter. Bili was a distant cousin, and some of the closest kin Perrin had living. He had grown up with many of these men, though some were a few years older than he. Some were a few years younger, too. By now, he knew the men from down to Deven Ride and up to Watch Hill as well as he did those from around Emond's Field. He had more reason than Faile alone to reach that fortress as fast as he could.

hæɾ ælɔɹə, ə lin fɛloʊ wɪð θɪk mʌstæʃɪz laɪk ə tæɹɑbənɝ, wɑz ðə læst ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn. əz i klaɪmd ɪndə ði ækwədʌkt, ɡɔl əpɪɹd, feɪs stɪl veɪld ən fɔɹ spɪɹz ɡɹɪpt ɪn ðə hæn ðət hɛld ɪz bʊl-haɪd bʌkəlɝ. hi pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ði ækwədʌkt ən lɛpt ʌp tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə stoʊn koʊpɪŋ.

Had al'Lora, a lean fellow with thick mustaches like a Taraboner, was the last of the Two Rivers men. As he climbed into the aqueduct, Gaul appeared, face still veiled and four spears gripped in the hand that held his bull-hide buckler. He put a hand on the edge of the aqueduct and leapt up to sit on the stone coping.

"jɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn?" pɛɹɪn sɛɾ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz.

"You're going in?" Perrin said in surprise.

"ðə meɪɾənz kən də ɛni skaʊɾɪŋ jə nid, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə." ðə bɪɡ il ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ təwɔɹd ðə meɪɾənz. pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i skaʊld, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə bi ʃʊɹ kəz ə ðə blæk veɪl ðət hɪɾ ɔl bʌɾ ɪz aɪz. "aɪ hɝɾ əm tɔkɪŋ wən ðeɪ θɔɾ aɪ wɑz nɑt lɪsnɪŋ. ənlaɪk jəɹ waɪf ən ði ʌðɝz, kiæɾ ɪz pɹɑpɝli ɡeɪʃeɪn. beɪn, tu, bʌɾ aɪ kɛɹ nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ. kiæd stɪl əz ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ jɪɹ ən ə deɪ tə sɝv æftɝ wi ɹɛskju hɝ. wən ə mæn əz ə wʊmən əz ɡeɪʃeɪn, əɹ ə wʊmən ə mæn, səmtaɪmz ə mɛɹɪdʒ ɹiθ ɪz meɪɾ əz sun əz waɪɾ ɪz pʊɾ ɔf. ɪts nɑɾ ənkɑmən. bʌɾ aɪ hɝd ðə meɪɾənz seɪ ðeɪ wəd ɹitʃ kiæd fɝst, tə kip əɹ fɹəm mi." bɪhaɪn hɪm, səlɪnz fɪŋɡɝ flæʃt ɪn meɪɾən hæntɔk, ən wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz slæpt ə hæn oʊvɝ əɹ maʊθ əz ɪf staɪflɪŋ læftɝ. soʊ ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɡoʊɾɪŋ hɪm. meɪbi ðeɪ wɝ nɑt soʊ hɑɹɾ əɡɛnst ɪz sut fəɹ kiæɾ əz ðeɪ pɹitɛndəd. əɹ meɪbi ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ pɛɹɪn wɑz mɪsɪŋ. il hjumɝ kəd bi ɹʌf.

"The Maidens can do any scouting you need, Perrin Aybara." The big Aiel glanced over his shoulder toward the Maidens. Perrin thought he scowled, though it was hard to be sure because of the black veil that hid all but his eyes. "I heard them talking when they thought I was not listening. Unlike your wife and the others, Chiad is properly gai'shain. Bain, too, but I care nothing about her. Chiad still has the rest of her year and a day to serve after we rescue her. When a man has a woman as gai'shain, or a woman a man, sometimes a marriage wreath is made as soon as white is put off. It is not uncommon. But I heard the Maidens say they would reach Chiad first, to keep her from me." Behind him, Sulin's finger flashed in Maiden handtalk, and one of the others slapped a hand over her mouth as if stifling laughter. So they had been goading him. Maybe they were not so hard against his suit for Chiad as they pretended. Or maybe there was something Perrin was missing. Aiel humor could be rough.

ɡɔl slɪpt ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ. hi hæd tə bɛn ɔlmoʊs pɛɹəlɛl tə ðə sɝfəs tə ɡɛɾ ʌndɝ ði ækwədʌks tɑp. pɛɹɪn stɛɹɾ ət ði oʊpənɪŋ. soʊ izi tə fɑloʊ ɡɔl. tɝnɪŋ əweɪ wɑz hɑɹd. ðə laɪn ə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz stɪl sneɪkt ʌp ən daʊn ðə sloʊp.

Gaul slipped into the water. He had to bend almost parallel to the surface to get under the aqueduct's top. Perrin stared at the opening. So easy to follow Gaul. Turning away was hard. The line of Seanchan soldiers still snaked up and down the slope.

"mɪʃimə, ɪm ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə maɪ kæmp. ɡɹeɪɾi wɪl teɪk jə tə jʊɹz wən jəɹ dʌn hɪɹ. də wʌt jə kən tə blɝ ðə tʃɹæks bɪfɔɹ jə ɡoʊ."

"Mishima, I'm going back to my camp. Grady will take you to yours when you're done here. Do what you can to blur the tracks before you go."

"vɛɹi wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪv toʊld ɔf səm mɛn tə skɹeɪp ɡɹis fɹəm ði æksəlz ən ɡɹis ðiz wɪndmɪlz. ðeɪ saʊn əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd siz ʌp ɛni mɪnət. wi kən də ðoʊz ət ðə fɑɹ ɹɪdʒ, tu."

"Very well, my Lord. I've told off some men to scrape grease from the axles and grease these windmills. They sound as if they could seize up any minute. We can do those at the far ridge, too."

teɪkɪŋ ʌp stɛpɝz ɹeɪnz, pɛɹɪn lʊkt ʌp ət ðə sloʊ-tɝnɪŋ seɪlz. sloʊ, bʌt stɛɾi. ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn meɪd tə tɝn fæst. "æn ɪf səm ʃeɪɾoʊ dɪsaɪd tə kʌm aʊt hɪɹ təmɑɹoʊ ən wʌndɝ wɛɹ ðə fɹɛʃ ɡɹis keɪm fɹʌm?"

Taking up Stepper's reins, Perrin looked up at the slow-turning sails. Slow, but steady. They had never been made to turn fast. "And if some Shaido decide to come out here tomorrow and wonder where the fresh grease came from?"

mɪʃimə ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, hɪz feɪs hæf-hɪɾən baɪ munʃæɾoʊz. fəɹ wʌns, hi dɪd nɑt sim pʊɾ ɔf baɪ ɡloʊɪŋ jɛloʊ aɪz. hɪz sɛnt. . . . hi smɛld əz ɪf i sɔ sʌmθɪŋ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd. "ðə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl wɑz ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ju," hi sɛd sloʊli.

Mishima regarded him for a long moment, his face half-hidden by moonshadows. For once, he did not seem put off by glowing yellow eyes. His scent. . . . He smelled as if he saw something unexpected. "The Banner-General was right about you," he said slowly.

"wʌt dɪd ʃi seɪ?"

"What did she say?"

"jul əv tə æsk hɝ, maɪ lɔɹd."

"You'll have to ask her, my Lord."

pɛɹɪn ɹoʊd daʊn ðə sloʊp ən bæk tə ðə tʃɹiz θɪŋkɪŋ haʊ izi ɪt wəd bi tə tɝn ɝaʊnd. ɡælɛn kəd hændəl ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɹəm hɪɹ. ɪt wɑz ɔl leɪɾ aʊt. ɪksɛp ðət ðə minɝ bɪlivd ɛvɹi bæɾəl klaɪmækst wɪð ə ɡɹæn tʃɑɹdʒ ə hɔɹs. ən pɹɛfɝəbli bɪɡæn wɪð wʌn, tu. haʊ lɔŋ wəɾ i stɪk tə ðə plæn? ɑɹɡændə wɑz mɔɹ sɛnsəbəl, bʌɾ i wɑz soʊ æŋkʃəs fəɹ kwin æliændɝ ðəɾ i maɪt wɛl ɔɹɾɝ ðət tʃɑɹdʒ, əz wɛl. ðət lɛf hɪmsɛlf. ðə bɹiz ɡʌstɪd hɑɹd, ən i pʊld ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn hɪm.

Perrin rode down the slope and back to the trees thinking how easy it would be to turn around. Gallenne could handle everything from here. It was all laid out. Except that the Mayener believed every battle climaxed with a grand charge of horse. And preferably began with one, too. How long would he stick to the plan? Arganda was more sensible, but he was so anxious for Queen Alliandre that he might well order that charge, as well. That left himself. The breeze gusted hard, and he pulled his cloak around him.

ɡɹeɪɾi, ɛlboʊz ɑn ɪz niz, wɑz ɪn ə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə hæf-wɝk mɔsi stoʊn ðət wɑz pɑɹʃəli sʌŋkən ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊn ən noʊ daʊt lɛft oʊvɝ fɹəm bɪldɪŋ ði ækwədʌkt. ə fju ʌðɝz laɪk ɪt stʊɾ ɝaʊnd. ðə bɹiz kɛpt ɪz sɛn fɹəm pɛɹɪnz noʊz. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk ʌp əntɪl pɛɹɪn dʒɹu ɹeɪn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ðeɪ hæd juz tə kʌm hɪɹ stɪl stʊɾ oʊpən, ʃoʊɪŋ ənʌðɝ klɪɹɪŋ əmʌŋ tɔl tʃɹiz, nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm wɛɹ ðə sintʃæn wɝ naʊ kæmpt. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn iziɝ tə hæv hæɾ əm sɛɾ ʌp kloʊs tə pɛɹɪnz kæmp, bʌɾ i wɑntəd tə kip ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz əz fɑɹ fɹəm ðə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn əz pɑsəbəl. hi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə sintʃæn bɹeɪkɪŋ taɪliz wɝd, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz pɹæktəkli keɪm daʊn wɪð ðə pɪp dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt deɪmeɪn. pɹɑbli ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ənʊɹə wəd steɪ ðɛɹ hænz fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ. pɹɑbli. mɑsʊɝi, hi wɑz nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ ʌv. ɪn ə nʌmbɝ ʌv weɪz. bɛɾɝ tə kip ə fju liɡz bɪtwin əm fəɹ əz lɔŋ əz ɪt kəd bi mænədʒd.

Grady, elbows on his knees, was in a small clearing sitting on a half-worked mossy stone that was partially sunken into the ground and no doubt left over from building the aqueduct. A few others like it stood around. The breeze kept his scent from Perrin's nose. He did not look up until Perrin drew rein in front of him. The gateway they had used to come here still stood open, showing another clearing among tall trees, not far from where the Seanchan were now camped. It might have been easier to have had them set up close to Perrin's camp, but he wanted to keep the Aes Sedai and Wise Ones as far from the sul'dam and damane as possible. He was not afraid of the Seanchan breaking Tylee's word, but the Aes Sedai and Wise Ones practically came down with the pip just thinking about damane. Probably the Wise Ones and Annoura would stay their hands for the time being. Probably. Masuri, he was not so sure of. In a number of ways. Better to keep a few leagues between them for as long as it could be managed.

"ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt, ɡɹeɪɾi?" ðə mænz wɛðɝd feɪs sim tə hæv nu laɪnz ɪn ɪt. ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ə tʃɹɪk ə munʃæɾoʊz kæs baɪ ðə tʃɹiz, bʌt pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk soʊ. ðə kɑɹts hæd pæs θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ izəli, bʌt wɑz ɪɾ ə lɪɾəl smɔlɝ ðən ðə fɝst i hæd sin ɡɹeɪɾi meɪk?

"Are you all right, Grady?" The man's weathered face seemed to have new lines in it. That might have been a trick of moonshadows cast by the trees, but Perrin did not think so. The carts had passed through the gateway easily, but was it a little smaller than the first he had seen Grady make?

"dʒʌs taɪɝɾ ə lɪɾəl, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd wɛɹəli. hi ɹɪmeɪn siɾəd wɪð ɪz ɛlboʊz ɑn ɪz niz. "ɔl ðɪs tʃɹævlɪŋ wiv bɪn duɪŋ leɪtli. . . . wɛl, aɪ kʊdn əv hɛl ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɔl ðoʊz soʊlʒɝz tə ɹaɪd θɹu jɛstɝdeɪ. ðæts waɪ aɪv teɪkən tə taɪɪŋ əm ɔf."

"Just tired a little, my Lord," Grady said wearily. He remained seated with his elbows on his knees. "All this Traveling we've been doing lately. . . . Well, I couldn't have held the gateway open long enough for all those soldiers to ride through yesterday. That's why I've taken to tying them off."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. boʊθ ə ði æʃəmən wɝ taɪɝd. tʃænəlɪŋ tʊk stʃɹɛŋkθ aʊɾ ʌv ə mæn əz ʃʊɹli əz swɪŋɪŋ ə hæmɝ ɔl deɪ əɾ ə fɔɹdʒ. mɔɹ soʊ, ɪn tʃɹuθ. ðə mæn wɪð ðə hæmɝ kəd kip ɡoʊɪŋ fɑɹ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ɛni æʃəmən. ðət wɑz waɪ ði ækwədʌkt wɑz ðə ɹuɾ ɪndə mɔldən ən nɑɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ, waɪ ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ ɡeɪtweɪ tə bɹɪŋ feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz aʊɾ əɡɛn, mʌtʃ əz pɛɹɪn wɪʃt ðəɹ kəd bi. ðə tu æʃəmən oʊnli hæd soʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ lɛft ɪn əm əntɪl ðeɪ kəd ɹɛst, ən ðət lɪɾəl hæd tə bi juzd wɛɹ ɪt wɑz niɾəd moʊst. laɪt, bʌt ðət wɑz ə hɑɹd θɔt. oʊnli, ɪf ɡɹeɪɾi əɹ nil fɛl wʌn ɡeɪtweɪ ʃɔɹɾ ʌv wʌt wɑz niɾəd, ə lɑɾ ə mɛn wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ. ə hɑɹd dɪsɪʒən.

Perrin nodded. Both of the Asha'man were tired. Channeling took strength out of a man as surely as swinging a hammer all day at a forge. More so, in truth. The man with the hammer could keep going far longer than any Asha'man. That was why the aqueduct was the route into Malden and not a gateway, why there would be no gateway to bring Faile and the others out again, much as Perrin wished there could be. The two Asha'man only had so much more left in them until they could rest, and that little had to be used where it was needed most. Light, but that was a hard thought. Only, if Grady or Neald fell one gateway short of what was needed, a lot of men were going to die. A hard decision.

"aɪm gɑnə nid jə ən nil ðə deɪ æftɝ təmɑɹoʊ." ðət wɑz laɪk seɪɪŋ i niɾəd ɛɹ. wɪθaʊt ði æʃəmən, ɛvɹiθɪŋ bɪkeɪm ɪmpɑsəbəl. "jɔɹ gɑnə bi bɪzi ðɛn." ənʌðɝ ɡɹoʊs ʌndɝsteɪtmənt.

"I'm going to need you and Neald the day after tomorrow." That was like saying he needed air. Without the Asha'man, everything became impossible. "You're going to be busy then." Another gross understatement.

"bɪzi əz ə wʌn-ɑɹmd mæn plæstɝɪŋ ə silɪŋ, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Busy as a one-armed man plastering a ceiling, my Lord."

"ɑɹ jə ʌp tə ɪt?"

"Are you up to it?"

"hæv tə bi, doʊn aɪ, maɪ lɔɹd."

"Have to be, don't I, my Lord."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd əɡɛn. jə dɪd wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn. "sɛn mi bæk tə əɹ kæmp. æftɝ jə ɹɪtɝn mɪʃimə ən ɪz pipəl tə hɪz, jə ən ðə meɪɾənz kən slip ðəɹ ɪf jud laɪk." ðət wəd spɛɹ ɡɹeɪɾi ə lɪɾəl əɡɛns tu deɪz fɹəm naʊ.

Perrin nodded again. You did what had to be done. "Send me back to our camp. After you return Mishima and his people to his, you and the Maidens can sleep there if you'd like." That would spare Grady a little against two days from now.
