"doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt ðə meɪɾənz, maɪ lɔɹd, bʌɾ aɪɾ əz sun kʌm ɑn hoʊm tənaɪt." hi tɝn ɪz hɛd tə lʊk ət ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪθaʊt ɹaɪzɪŋ, ən ɪt dwɪndəld ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝs ə haʊ ɪt hæɾ oʊpənd, ðə vju θɹu ɪt simɪŋ tə ɹoʊteɪɾ əz ɪt nɛɹoʊd, fɪnɪʃɪŋ wɪð ə vɝɾɪkəl slæʃ ə sɪlvɝi blu laɪt ðət lɛft ə feɪn pɝplɪʃ bɑɹ ɪn pɛɹɪnz vɪʒən wən ɪt wɪŋkt aʊt. "ðoʊz deɪmeɪn fɛɹ meɪk maɪ skɪn kɹɔl. ðeɪ doʊnt wɑnə bi fɹi."

"Don't know about the Maidens, my Lord, but I'd as soon come on home tonight." He turned his head to look at the gateway without rising, and it dwindled in the reverse of how it had opened, the view through it seeming to rotate as it narrowed, finishing with a vertical slash of silvery blue light that left a faint purplish bar in Perrin's vision when it winked out. "Those damane fair make my skin crawl. They don't want to be free."

"haʊ wəd jə noʊ ðæt?"

"How would you know that?"

"aɪ tɔk tə səm ə ðɛm wən nʌn ə ðoʊz sʌldəm wɑz kloʊs baɪ. sun əz aɪ bɹɔɾ ʌp meɪbi ðeɪd laɪk ðoʊz liʃɪz ɔf, dʒʌs hɪntɪŋ laɪk, ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd skɹimɪŋ fəɹ ðə sʌldəm. ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ kɹaɪɪŋ, ən ðə sʌldəm pɛɾɪŋ əm ən stʃɹoʊkɪŋ əm ən ɡlɛɹɪŋ dæɡɝz ət mi. fɛɹ meɪd maɪ skɪn kɹɔl."

"I talked to some of them when none of those sul'dam was close by. Soon as I brought up maybe they'd like those leashes off, just hinting like, they started screaming for the sul'dam. The damane were crying, and the sul'dam petting them and stroking them and glaring daggers at me. Fair made my skin crawl."

stɛpɝ stæmpt ən ɪmpeɪʃən huf, ən pɛɹɪn pæɾəd ðə stæljənz nɛk. ɡɹeɪɾi wɑz lʌki ðoʊz sʌldəm hæd lɛɾ ɪm ɡoʊ wɪð ə hoʊl haɪd. "wʌtɛvɝ hæpənz wɪð ðə deɪmeɪn, ɡɹeɪɾi, ɪt woʊn bi ðɪs wik, əɹ nɛkst. ən ɪt woʊn bi əs u fɪksɪz ɪt. soʊ jə lɛt ðə deɪmeɪn bi. wɪv ə dʒɑb ʌv wɝk ɪn fɹʌn ʌv əs ðət nidz duɪŋ." ən ə dil wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn tə də ɪt. hi pʊʃt ðə θɔɾ əweɪ. ɛniweɪ, ɪt hæd ɡɹoʊn hɑɹd tə θɪŋk ə taɪli kɪɝɡən biɪŋ ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz saɪd. əɹ mɪʃimə. "ju ʌndɝstæn ðæt?"

Stepper stamped an impatient hoof, and Perrin patted the stallion's neck. Grady was lucky those sul'dam had let him go with a whole hide. "Whatever happens with the damane, Grady, it won't be this week, or next. And it won't be us who fixes it. So you let the damane be. We have a job of work in front of us that needs doing." And a deal with the Dark One to do it. He pushed the thought away. Anyway, it had grown hard to think of Tylee Khirgan being on the Dark One's side. Or Mishima. "You understand that?"

"aɪ ʌndɝstænd, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪm dʒʌst seɪɪŋ ɪt meɪks maɪ skɪn kɹɔl."

"I understand, my Lord. I'm just saying it makes my skin crawl."

ət læst ənʌðɝ sɪlvɝi blu slæʃ əpɪɹd, waɪɾənɪŋ ɪndə ən oʊpənɪŋ ðət ʃoʊɾ ə klɪɹɪŋ əmʌŋ lɑɹdʒ, waɪdli speɪs tʃɹiz ən ə loʊ stoʊn aʊtkɹɑp. linɪŋ loʊ ɑn stɛpɝz nɛk, pɛɹɪn ɹoʊd θɹu. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪŋkt aʊt bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən i ɹoʊɾ ɑn θɹu ðə tʃɹiz əntɪl i keɪm tə ðə lɑɹdʒ klɪɹɪŋ wɛɹ ðə kæmp leɪ, nɪɹ wʌt hæd wʌns bɪn ðə taɪni vɪlədʒ ə bɹaɪɾən, ə kəlɛkʃən ə fli-ɹɪɾəld hʌvəlz ðət ðə moʊst ɹeɪn-soʊk naɪt kəd nɑt tɛmpt ə mæn ɪntu. ðə sɛntʃɹiz ʌp ɪn ðə tʃɹiz ɡeɪv noʊ wɔɹnɪŋz, ʌv kɔɹs. ðeɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm.

At last another silvery blue slash appeared, widening into an opening that showed a clearing among large, widely spaced trees and a low stone outcrop. Leaning low on Stepper's neck, Perrin rode through. The gateway winked out behind him, and he rode on through the trees until he came to the large clearing where the camp lay, near what had once been the tiny village of Brytan, a collection of flea-riddled hovels that the most rain-soaked night could not tempt a man into. The sentries up in the trees gave no warnings, of course. They recognized him.

hi wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz i wɑntəɾ ɪz blæŋkəts ɹaɪt ðɛn. wɛl, feɪl, sɝɾənli, bʌt lækɪŋ hɝ, hi wɑntəd tə bi əloʊn ɪn ðə dɑɹk. laɪkli, hi wəd feɪl tə faɪn slip əɡɛn, bʌɾ i wəd spɛn ðə naɪɾ əz i hæd soʊ ɔfən bɪfɔɹ, θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɝ, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ hɝ. ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə tɛn-peɪs waɪd θɪkɪɾ ə ʃɑɹpən steɪks ðət sɝaʊndəd ðə kæmp, ðoʊ, hi ɹeɪn ɪn. ə ɹeɪkən wɑz kɹaʊtʃt dʒʌst aʊtsaɪd ðə steɪks, ɪts lɔŋ ɡɹeɪ nɛk loʊɝd soʊ ə wʊmən ɪn ə hʊɾɪd bɹaʊn koʊt kəd skɹætʃ ɪts lɛðɝi snaʊt. hɝ hʊd hʌŋ daʊn əɹ bæk, ɹɪvilɪŋ ʃɔɹt-kɹɑp hɛɹ ən ə hɑɹd, nɛɹoʊ feɪs. ʃi lʊkt ət pɛɹɪn əz ɪf ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm, bʌt wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn skɹætʃɪŋ. ðə sæɾəl ɑn ðə kɹitʃɝz bæk hæd pleɪsəz fəɹ tu ɹaɪɾɝz. ə mɛsənʒɝ hæd kʌm, ɪt simd. hi tɝn ɪndə wʌn ə ðə nɛɹoʊ, æŋɡəld leɪnz θɹu ðə steɪks ðət hæd bɪn lɛf tə əlaʊ hɔɹsəz θɹu. dʒʌs nɑt kwɪkli.

He wanted nothing so much as he wanted his blankets right then. Well, Faile, certainly, but lacking her, he wanted to be alone in the dark. Likely, he would fail to find sleep again, but he would spend the night as he had so often before, thinking of her, remembering her. Short of the ten-pace wide thicket of sharpened stakes that surrounded the camp, though, he reined in. A raken was crouched just outside the stakes, its long gray neck lowered so a woman in a hooded brown coat could scratch its leathery snout. Her hood hung down her back, revealing short-cropped hair and a hard, narrow face. She looked at Perrin as if she recognized him, but went right on scratching. The saddle on the creature's back had places for two riders. A messenger had come, it seemed. He turned into one of the narrow, angled lanes through the stakes that had been left to allow horses through. Just not quickly.

moʊst ɛvɹibɑɾi hæd tɝn ɪn ɔlɹɛɾi. hi sɛns muvmən ɑn ðə hɔɹslaɪnz, ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə kæmp, laɪkli səm ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn ɡɹumz əɹ fɛɹiɝz, bʌt ðə pætʃt kænvəs tɛns ən smɔl hʌts ʌv woʊvən ɛvɝɡɹin bɹæntʃəz, naʊ lɔŋ sɪns bɹaʊn, leɪ dɑɹk ən kwaɪət. nʌθɪŋ muvd əmʌŋ ðə loʊ il tɛns, ən oʊnli ə fju sɛntʃɹiz wɔkɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ɪn ðə nɪɹəs minɝ sɛkʃən ə ðə kæmp. ðə minɝz ən ɡildænɪn pʊt lɪɾəl tʃɹʌst ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ɪn ðə tʃɹiz. hɪz tɔl, ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp tɛnt wɑz əlaɪt, haʊɛvɝ, ən ðə ʃædoʊz ʌv ə nʌmbɝ ə pipəl ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ðə tɛnt wɔlz. wən i klaɪm daʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tɛnt, æθən tʃændɪn əpɪɹd tə teɪk ðə ɹeɪnz ən nʌkəl ɪz fɔɹhɛd waɪl i hʌntʃt ə sɔɹɾ ə baʊ. æθən wɑz ə ɡʊd baʊʃɑɾ əɹ i wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn hɪɹ, bʌɾ i hæɾ ə tʃɹʌklɪŋ mænɝ. pɛɹɪn wɛn ɪn ənpɪnɪŋ ɪz kloʊk.

Most everybody had turned in already. He sensed movement on the horselines, in the heart of the camp, likely some of the Cairhienin grooms or farriers, but the patched canvas tents and small huts of woven evergreen branches, now long since brown, lay dark and quiet. Nothing moved among the low Aiel tents, and only a few sentries walking up and down in the nearest Mayener section of the camp. The Mayeners and Ghealdanin put little trust in the Two Rivers men in the trees. His tall, red-striped tent was alight, however, and the shadows of a number of people shifted on the tent walls. When he climbed down in front of the tent, Athan Chandin appeared to take the reins and knuckle his forehead while he hunched a sort of bow. Athan was a good bowshot or he would not have been here, but he had a truckling manner. Perrin went in unpinning his cloak.

"ðɛɹ jə ɑɹ," bɹəleɪn sɛd bɹaɪtli. ʃi mʌst əv dʒɹɛs heɪstəli, kəz əɹ lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ lʊkt əz ðoʊ ɪt hæd hæd dʒʌst ə lɪk ən ə pɹɑməs fɹəm ə bɹʌʃ, bʌɾ əɹ haɪ-nɛkt ɡɹeɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs əpɪɹd niɾ ən fɹɛʃ. hɝ sɝvɪŋ wɪmən nɛvɝ lɛɾ əɹ dɑn ɛniθɪŋ ənlɛs ɪt wɑz fɹɛʃli aɪɝnd. ʃi hɛld aʊɾ ə sɪlvɝ waɪnkʌp fəɹ bɹin tə ɹifɪl fɹəm ə lɔŋ-nɛkt waɪn pɪtʃɝ, wɪtʃ ðə kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən dɪd wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs. feɪlz meɪd dɪslaɪk bɹəleɪn wɪð ə pæʃən. bɹəleɪn sim nɑt tə noʊɾəs, ðoʊ. "fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ ɛntɝteɪnɪŋ ɪn jəɹ tɛnt, bʌt ðə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl wɑntəd tə si ju, ən aɪ θɔɾ aɪd kip əɹ kʌmpəni. ʃiz bɪn tɛlɪŋ əs əbaʊt səm waɪtkloʊks."

"There you are," Berelain said brightly. She must have dressed hastily, because her long black hair looked as though it had had just a lick and a promise from a brush, but her high-necked gray riding dress appeared neat and fresh. Her serving women never let her don anything unless it was freshly ironed. She held out a silver winecup for Breane to refill from a long-necked wine pitcher, which the Cairhienin woman did with a grimace. Faile's maid disliked Berelain with a passion. Berelain seemed not to notice, though. "Forgive me for entertaining in your tent, but the Banner-General wanted to see you, and I thought I'd keep her company. She's been telling us about some Whitecloaks."

beɪlwɝ wɑz stændɪŋ ʌnəbtʃɹusɪvli ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ - ðə bɝd-laɪk lɪɾəl mæn kəd bi əz ənnɑɾəsəbəl əz ə lɪzɝɾ ɑn ə bɹæntʃ wən i wɪʃt tə bi - bʌɾ ɪz sɛnt ʃɑɹpən ət ðə mɛnʃən ʌv waɪtkloʊks.

Balwer was standing unobtrusively in a corner - the bird-like little man could be as unnoticeable as a lizard on a branch when he wished to be - but his scent sharpened at the mention of Whitecloaks.

taɪli, hɝ ʃoʊldɝz stʃɹeɪnɪŋ ə koʊt laɪk ðəɾ ə ðə flaɪɝ, meɪɾ ə stʃɹeɪt-lɛɡəd baʊ waɪl kipɪŋ wʌn aɪ ɑn ənʊɹə. ʃi sim tə bɪliv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪt tɝn ɪndə ɹeɪvinɪŋ waɪl dɑɡz əɾ ɛni moʊmənt. pɛɹɪn θɔt ʃi smɛld ə dɪstʃɹɛs, ðoʊ nʌn ʃoʊɾ ɑn əɹ dɑɹk feɪs. "maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ hæv tu pisəz ə nuz aɪ fɛlt aɪ hæd tə bɹɪŋ jə ɪmiɾiətli. hæv jə bɪɡʌn pʊɾɪŋ ðə fɔkɹuɾ ɪndə ðə taʊnz wɔɾɝ?"

Tylee, her shoulders straining a coat like that of the flier, made a straight-legged bow while keeping one eye on Annoura. She seemed to believe the Aes Sedai might turn into ravening wild dogs at any moment. Perrin thought she smelled of distress, though none showed on her dark face. "My Lord, I have two pieces of news I felt I had to bring you immediately. Have you begun putting the forkroot into the town's water?"

"aɪ hæv," hi sɛd wɝidli, tɔsɪŋ ɪz kloʊk daʊn ətɑp wʌn ə ðə bɹæs-bændɪd tʃɛsts. taɪli saɪd. "aɪ toʊl jə aɪ wʊd. aɪɾ əv dʌn ɪt tu deɪz əɡoʊ ɪf ðət ful wʊmən ɪn ælməzɹ hædn dʒɹæɡd əɹ hilz soʊ. wʌts hæpənd?"

"I have," he said worriedly, tossing his cloak down atop one of the brass-banded chests. Tylee sighed. "I told you I would. I'd have done it two days ago if that fool woman in Almizar hadn't dragged her heels so. What's happened?"

"fɝɡɪv mi," lini ənaʊnst, "bʌɾ aɪ wɑz ɹaʊz fɹəm maɪ blæŋkəts, ən aɪ wəd laɪk tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛm. dʌz ɛniwʌn ɹikwaɪɝ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ə mi tənaɪt?" ðəɹ wɝ noʊ kɝtsiz əɹ 'maɪ lɔɹdz' fɹəm ðə fɹeɪl-əpɪɹɪŋ wʊmən wɪð əɹ waɪt hɛɹ ɪn ə lus bɹeɪd fəɹ slipɪŋ. ənlaɪk wɪð bɹəleɪn, hɝ bɹaʊn dʒɹɛs lʊk heɪstəli dɑnd, ənjuʒəwəl fəɹ hɝ. hɝ sɛnt wɑz kɹɪsp ən ʃɑɹp wɪð dɪsəpɹuvəl. ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz u bɪliv ðə ɹɪdɪkjələs teɪl ðət pɛɹɪn hæd slɛpt wɪð bɹəleɪn ɑn ðə vɛɹi naɪɾ æftɝ feɪl hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd. ʃi mænədʒ tə əvɔɪd lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm waɪl əɹ ɡeɪz swɛpt ɝaʊn ðə tɛns ɪntɪɹiɝ.

"Forgive me," Lini announced, "but I was roused from my blankets, and I would like to return to them. Does anyone require anything else of me tonight?" There were no curtsies or 'my Lords' from the frail-appearing woman with her white hair in a loose braid for sleeping. Unlike with Berelain, her brown dress looked hastily donned, unusual for her. Her scent was crisp and sharp with disapproval. She was one of those who believed the ridiculous tale that Perrin had slept with Berelain on the very night after Faile had been captured. She managed to avoid looking at him while her gaze swept around the tent's interior.

"aɪl əv səm mɔɹ waɪn," ɛɹæm ənaʊnst, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz kʌp. ɡɹɪm-feɪst ən hæɡɝɾ ɪn ə ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp koʊt, hɪz aɪz hɑloʊ, hi wɑz ətɛmptɪŋ tə laʊnʒ ɪn wʌn ə ðə foʊldɪŋ kæmp tʃɛɹz, bʌt ðə sɔɹd stʃɹæp tə hɪz bæk meɪd linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə ɡɪlt-ɛdʒ bæk ɪmpɑsəbəl. bɹin stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd hɪm.

"I'll have some more wine," Aram announced, holding out his cup. Grim-faced and haggard in a red-striped coat, his eyes hollow, he was attempting to lounge in one of the folding camp chairs, but the sword strapped to his back made leaning against the gilt-edged back impossible. Breane started toward him.

"hiz hæɾ ɪnʌf," lini sɛd ʃɑɹpli, ən bɹin tɝn əweɪ. lini hæɾ ə fɝm hænd wɪð feɪlz sɝvəns.

"He's had enough," Lini said sharply, and Breane turned away. Lini had a firm hand with Faile's servants.

ɛɹæm mʌɾɝd ən oʊθ ən lɛp tə hɪz fit, tɔsɪŋ ɪz kʌp daʊn ɑn ðə flaʊɝd kɑɹpət ðət sɝvd əz ə flɔɹ. "aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡoʊ sʌmwɛɹ aɪ woʊn əv səm oʊld wʊmən næɡɪŋ ət mi ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ teɪk ə dʒɹɪŋk." hi ɡeɪv pɛɹɪn ə sʌlən ɡlɛɹ bɪfɔɹ stɔkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. daʊtləs ɑn ɪz weɪ tə mæsiməz kæmp. hi hæd pliɾəd tə bi wʌn ə ðə pɑɹɾi sɛn ɪndə mɔldən, bʌɾ ɪz hɑt hɛd kəd nɑt bi tʃɹʌstɪd wɪð ðæt.

Aram muttered an oath and leaped to his feet, tossing his cup down on the flowered carpet that served as a floor. "I might as well go somewhere I won't have some old woman nagging at me every time I take a drink." He gave Perrin a sullen glare before stalking out of the tent. Doubtless on his way to Masema's camp. He had pleaded to be one of the party sent into Malden, but his hot head could not be trusted with that.

"ju kən ɡoʊ, lini," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "bɹin kən lʊk æftɝ əs wɛl ɪnʌf." ə snɔɹt wɑz ði æknɑlɪdʒmən lini ɡeɪv - ʃi meɪɾ ɪt saʊn ɔlmoʊs dɛləkət - bɪfɔɹ ʃi stɔkt aʊt, stɪf-bækt ən ɹikɪŋ ə dɪsəpɹuvəl. ən stɪl nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn.

"You can go, Lini," Berelain said. "Breane can look after us well enough." A snort was the acknowledgment Lini gave - she made it sound almost delicate - before she stalked out, stiff-backed and reeking of disapproval. And still not looking at Perrin.

"fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd," taɪli dʒɹɔld ɪn kɛɹfəl toʊnz, "bʌt jə sim tə ɹʌn jəɹ haʊshoʊl mɔɹ . . . lusli . . . ðən aɪm əkʌstəm tə."

"Forgive me, my Lord," Tylee drawled in careful tones, "but you seem to run your household more . . . loosely . . . than I'm accustomed to."

"ɪts əɹ weɪ, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd, pɪkɪŋ ʌp ɛɹæmz kʌp. noʊ nid tə dɝɾi ənʌðɝ. "noʊbɑdi ɝaʊn hɪɹ ɪz pɹɑpɝɾi." ɪf ðət saʊndəd ʃɑɹp, soʊ bi ɪt. hi hæd kʌm tə laɪk taɪli æftɝ ə fæʃən, bʌt ðiz sintʃæn hæd weɪz ðət wəd meɪk ə ɡoʊt ɡæɡ. hi tʊk ðə pɪtʃɝ fɹəm bɹin - ʃi æktʃəli  tʃɹaɪd tə hoʊld ɑn tə ɪt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf ʃi wəd dɪnaɪ hɪm ə dʒɹɪŋk - ən pɔɹd fəɹ hɪmsɛlf bɪfɔɹ hændɪŋ ɪt bæk. ʃi snætʃt ðə pɪtʃɝ aʊɾ ə hɪz hænd. "naʊ, wʌt hæpənd? wʌɾ əbaʊt ðiz waɪtkloʊks?"

"It's our way, Banner-General," Perrin said, picking up Aram's cup. No need to dirty another. "Nobody around here is property." If that sounded sharp, so be it. He had come to like Tylee after a fashion, but these Seanchan had ways that would make a goat gag. He took the pitcher from Breane - she actually tried to hold on to it for a moment, frowning at him as if she would deny him a drink - and poured for himself before handing it back. She snatched the pitcher out of his hand. "Now, what happened? What about these Whitecloaks?"

"aɪ sɛn ɹeɪkən aʊt skaʊɾɪŋ əz fɑɹ əz ðeɪ kəd ɡoʊ dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ dɔn, ən əɡɛn dʒʌst æftɝ sʌnsɛt. wʌn ə ðə flaɪɝz tənaɪt tɝn bæk sunɝ ðən ɪkspɛktəd. ʃi sɔ sɛvən θaʊzən tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪɾ ɑn ðə muv nɑt fɪfti maɪlz fɹəm maɪ kæmp."

"I sent raken out scouting as far as they could go just before dawn, and again just after sunset. One of the fliers tonight turned back sooner than expected. She saw seven thousand Children of the Light on the move not fifty miles from my camp."

"ɑn ðə muv təwɔɹd ju?" pɛɹɪn fɹaʊn əɾ ɪz waɪn ɪnstɛɾ ə dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ. "sɛvən θaʊzən simz ə vɛɹi ɪɡzækt kaʊn tə meɪk ɪn ðə dɑɹk."

"On the move toward you?" Perrin frowned at his wine instead of drinking. "Seven thousand seems a very exact count to make in the dark."

"ɪt simz ðiz mɛn, ðeɪ ɑɹ dɛzɝɾɝz," ənʊɹə bɹoʊk ɪn. "æt list, ðə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl siz əm soʊ." ɪn ɡɹeɪ sɪlk, ʃi əpɪɹɾ əz niɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæd spɛn ən aʊɝ dʒɹɛsɪŋ. hɝ θɹʌstɪŋ noʊz meɪɾ əɹ lʊk laɪk ə kɹoʊ wɛɹɪŋ biɾɪd bɹeɪdz əz ʃi pɪɹɾ ət taɪli, ən ðə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ bɪɾ ə kɛɹiən. ʃi hɛld ə waɪnkʌp, bʌɾ ɪt simd əntʌtʃt. "aɪ hæv hɝd ɹumɝz ðət peɪdʒɹən naɪl daɪd faɪɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn, bʌɾ əpɛɹənli imən vɑldə, hu ɹipleɪs naɪl, swɔɹ fiəlti tə ðə sintʃæn ɛmpɹɛs." taɪli maʊðd, "meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ," ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ; pɛɹɪn daʊɾɪd ɛniwʌn bʌt hɪmsɛlf hɝd. beɪlwɝ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, tu, bʌt kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ. ðə waɪtkloʊks wɝ ə bʌɡbɛɹ tə hɪm. "sʌmθɪŋ oʊvɝ ə mʌnθ əɡoʊ, haʊɛvɝ," ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ wɛn ɑn, "ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd kɪl vɑldə ən lɛd sɛvən θaʊzənd waɪtkloʊks tə liv ðə sintʃæn kɑz. ə pɪɾi hi bɪkeɪm ɛnmɛʃt wɪð waɪtkloʊks, bʌt pɝhæps səm ɡʊɾ əz kʌm ʌv ɪt. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɪɾ əpɪɹz ðəɹ ɪz ə stændɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ ðət ðiz mɛn ɑɹ ɔl tə bi kɪld əz sun əz faʊnd. aɪ hæv sʌmd ɪɾ ʌp naɪsli, jɛs, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl?"

"It seems these men, they are deserters," Annoura broke in. "At least, the Banner-General sees them so." In gray silk, she appeared as neat as if she had spent an hour dressing. Her thrusting nose made her look like a crow wearing beaded braids as she peered at Tylee, and the Banner-General a particularly interesting bit of carrion. She held a winecup, but it seemed untouched. "I have heard rumors that Pedron Niall died fighting the Seanchan, but apparently Eamon Valda, who replaced Niall, swore fealty to the Seanchan Empress." Tylee mouthed, "may she live forever," under her breath; Perrin doubted anyone but himself heard. Balwer opened his mouth, too, but closed it again without speaking. The Whitecloaks were a bugbear to him. "Something over a month ago, however," the Gray sister went on, "Galad Damodred killed Valda and led seven thousand Whitecloaks to leave the Seanchan cause. A pity he became enmeshed with Whitecloaks, but perhaps some good has come of it. In any case, it appears there is a standing order that these men are all to be killed as soon as found. I have summed it up nicely, yes, Banner-General?"

taɪliz hæn twɪtʃt əz ɪf ɪt wɑntəd tə meɪk wʌn ə ðoʊz saɪnz əɡɛnst ivəl. "ðæts ə fɛɹ sʌmɪŋ ʌp," ʃi sɛd. tə pɛɹɪn, nɑɾ ənʊɹə. ðə sintʃæn wʊmən sim tə faɪn spikɪŋ tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪfəkəlt. "ɪksɛp ðə pɑɹɾ əbaʊt ɡʊd kʌmɪŋ ʌv ɪt. oʊθ-bɹeɪkɪŋ ən dɪzɝʃən kən nɛvɝ bi kɔld ɡʊd."

Tylee's hand twitched as if it wanted to make one of those signs against evil. "That's a fair summing up," she said. To Perrin, not Annoura. The Seanchan woman seemed to find speaking to an Aes Sedai difficult. "Except the part about good coming of it. Oath-breaking and desertion can never be called good."

"aɪ teɪk ɪt ðəɹ nɑt muvɪŋ təwɔɹd ju, əɹ juɾ əv sɛd." pɛɹɪn pʊɾ ə hɪn ə kwɛstʃən ɪndə ðæt, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kwɛstʃən ɪn ɪz maɪnd.

"I take it they're not moving toward you, or you'd have said." Perrin put a hint of question into that, though there was no question in his mind.

"nɔɹθ," taɪli ænsɝd. "ðeɪɹ hɛɾɪŋ nɔɹθ." beɪlwɝ hæf oʊpən ɪz maʊθ əɡɛn, ðən ʃʌɾ ɪt wɪð ə klɪk ə tiθ.

"North," Tylee answered. "They're heading north." Balwer half opened his mouth again, then shut it with a click of teeth.

"ɪf juv ædvaɪs," pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪm, "ðɛn ɡɪv ɪt. bʌɾ aɪ doʊn kɛɹ haʊ mɛni waɪtkloʊks dɪzɝt ðə sintʃæn. feɪl ɪz ði oʊnli θɪŋ aɪ kɛɹ əbaʊt. ən aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl wɪl ɡɪv ʌp ðə tʃæns tə kɑlɝ θɹi əɹ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd mɔɹ deɪmeɪn tə tʃeɪs æftɝ ðɛm." bɹəleɪn ɡɹɪməst. ənʊɹəz feɪs ɹɪmeɪn smuð, bʌt ʃi tʊk ə lɔŋ swɑloʊ ʌv əɹ waɪn. nʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fɛl vɛɹi kəmpleɪsən əbaʊt ðət pɑɹɾ ə ðə plæn. nʌn ə ðə waɪz wʌnz dɪd, iðɝ.

"If you have advice," Perrin told him, "then give it. But I don't care how many Whitecloaks desert the Seanchan. Faile is the only thing I care about. And I don't think the Banner-General will give up the chance to collar three or four hundred more damane to chase after them." Berelain grimaced. Annoura's face remained smooth, but she took a long swallow of her wine. None of the Aes Sedai felt very complacent about that part of the plan. None of the Wise Ones did, either.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt," taɪli sɛd fɝmli. "aɪ θɪŋk əl teɪk səm waɪn æftɝ ɔl." bɹin tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ bɪfɔɹ muvɪŋ tə kəmplaɪ, ən ə hɪn ə fɪɹ ɛntɝɾ əɹ sɛnt. əpɛɹənli ðə tɔl dɑɹk wʊmən ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd hɝ.

"I will not," Tylee said firmly. "I think I'll take some wine after all." Breane took a deep breath before moving to comply, and a hint of fear entered her scent. Apparently the tall dark woman intimidated her.

"aɪ woʊn dɪnaɪ aɪ wəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ə tʃæns tə stʃɹaɪk ə bloʊ ət ðə waɪtkloʊks," beɪlwɝ sɛɾ ɪn ðət dʒɹaɪ-æz-dʌs vɔɪs, "bʌɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ, aɪ fil aɪ oʊ ðɪs ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹɾ ə dɛɾ ʌv ɡɹæɾətud." pɝhæps ɪz ɡɹʌdʒ wɑz əɡɛns ðɪs vɑldə pɝsənəli. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, juv noʊ niɾ ə maɪ ædvaɪs hɪɹ. ɪvɛns ɑɹ ɪn moʊʃən ɪn mɔldən, ən ɪf ðeɪ wɝnt, aɪ daʊt jud hoʊl bæk ivən ə deɪ. nɔɹ wəɾ aɪ hæv ædvaɪzd ɪt, maɪ lɔɹd. ɪf aɪ meɪ bi soʊ boʊld, aɪm kwaɪt fɑn ə ðə leɪɾi feɪl."

"I won't deny I would enjoy a chance to strike a blow at the Whitecloaks," Balwer said in that dry-as-dust voice, "but in truth, I feel I owe this Galad Damodred a debt of gratitude." Perhaps his grudge was against this Valda personally. "In any case, you have no need of my advice here. Events are in motion in Malden, and if they weren't, I doubt you'd hold back even a day. Nor would I have advised it, my Lord. If I may be so bold, I am quite fond of the Lady Faile."

"ju meɪ," pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪm. "bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl, jə sɛd tu pisəz ə nuz?"

"You may," Perrin told him. "Banner-General, you said two pieces of news?"

ðə sintʃæn tʊk ðə pɹɑfɝd waɪnkʌp fɹəm bɹin ən lʊkt əɾ ɪm soʊ lɛvəli ɪt wɑz klɪɹ ʃi wɑz əvɔɪɾɪŋ ə ɡlæns ət ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə tɛnt. "meɪ wi spik əloʊn?" ʃi æskt kwaɪətli.

The Seanchan took the proffered winecup from Breane and looked at him so levelly it was clear she was avoiding a glance at the others in the tent. "May we speak alone?" she asked quietly.

bɹəleɪn ɡlaɪɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə kɑɹpət tə ɹɛst ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm ən smaɪl ʌp ət hɪm. "ənʊɹə ən aɪ doʊn maɪn livɪŋ," ʃi sɛd. laɪt, haʊ kəɾ ɛniwʌn bɪliv ðəɹ wɑz ɛniθɪŋ bɪtwin ɪm ən hɝ? ʃi wɑz əz bjuɾəfəl əz ɛvɝ, tʃɹu, jɛt ðə sɛn ðət hæd maɪndəɾ ɪm ʌv ə hʌntɪŋ kæt wɑz soʊ lɔŋ ɡɔn fɹəm əɹ smɛl ðəɾ i bɛɹli ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪt. ðə bɛdʒɹɑk ə hɝ sɛnt wɑz peɪʃəns ən ɹizɑlv, naʊ. ʃi hæd kʌm tə æksɛp ðəɾ i lʌv feɪl ən oʊnli feɪl, ən ʃi simd əz dɪtɝmən tə si feɪl fɹiɾ əz i wɑz.

Berelain glided across the carpet to rest a hand on his arm and smile up at him. "Annoura and I don't mind leaving," she said. Light, how could anyone believe there was anything between him and her? She was as beautiful as ever, true, yet the scent that had minded him of a hunting cat was so long gone from her smell that he barely remembered it. The bedrock of her scent was patience and resolve, now. She had come to accept that he loved Faile and only Faile, and she seemed as determined to see Faile freed as he was.

"ju kən steɪ," hi sɛd. "wʌtɛvɝ juv tə seɪ, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl, jə kən seɪ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn hɪɹ."

"You can stay," he said. "Whatever you have to say, Banner-General, you can say in front of everyone here."

taɪli hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ənʊɹə. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ tu lɑɹdʒ pɑɹɾiz ʌv il hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹd mɔldən," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst, ɹɪlʌktənli. "wʌn tə ðə saʊθist, wʌn tə ðə saʊθwɛst. ðə mɔɹətʃɹeɪkən ɛstəmət ðeɪ kəd bi ðəɹ ɪn θɹi deɪz."

Tylee hesitated, glancing at Annoura. "There are two large parties of Aiel heading toward Malden," she said at last, reluctantly. "One to the southeast, one to the southwest. The morat'raken estimate they could be there in three days."

sʌɾənli, ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim tə ɹɪpəl ɪn pɛɹɪnz saɪt. hi fɛl hɪmsɛlf ɹɪpəl. bɹin ɡeɪv ə kɹaɪ ən dʒɹɑp ðə pɪtʃɝ. ðə wɝld ɹɪpəld əɡɛn, ən bɹəleɪn klʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm. taɪliz hæn sim fɹoʊzən ɪn ðəɾ ɑd dʒɛstʃɝ, θʌm ən fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ fɔɹmɪŋ ə kɹɛsənt. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹɪpəl fəɹ ə θɝd taɪm, ən pɛɹɪn fɛlt əz ɪf i wɝ meɪɾ ə fɑɡ, əz ɪf ðə wɝld wɝ fɑɡ wɪð ə haɪ wɪn kʌmɪŋ. bɹəleɪn ʃʌɾɝəd, ən i pʊɾ ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ ɑɹm ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi klʌŋ tə hɪm, tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. saɪləns ən ðə sɛn ə fɪɹ fɪl ðə tɛnt. hi kəd hɪɹ vɔɪsəz biɪŋ ɹeɪzd aʊtsaɪd, ən ðeɪ saʊndəɾ əfɹeɪd, tu.

Suddenly, everything seemed to ripple in Perrin's sight. He felt himself ripple. Breane gave a cry and dropped the pitcher. The world rippled again, and Berelain clutched his arm. Tylee's hand seemed frozen in that odd gesture, thumb and forefinger forming a crescent. Everything rippled for a third time, and Perrin felt as if he were made of fog, as if the world were fog with a high wind coming. Berelain shuddered, and he put a comforting arm around her. She clung to him, trembling. Silence and the scent of fear filled the tent. He could hear voices being raised outside, and they sounded afraid, too.

"wʌt wɑz ðæt?" taɪli dɪmændəd faɪnəli.

"What was that?" Tylee demanded finally.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ." ənʊɹəz feɪs ɹɪmeɪn sɝin, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs wɑz ənstɛɾi. "laɪt, aɪ hæv noʊ aɪdiə."

"I don't know." Annoura's face remained serene, but her voice was unsteady. "Light, I have no idea."

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz," pɛɹɪn toʊl ðɛm. hi ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛɹ stɛɹz. "ɪn θɹi deɪz, ɪɾəl ɔl bi oʊvɝ. ðæts ɔl ðət mæɾɝz." feɪl wɑz ɔl ðət mæɾɝd.

"It doesn't matter what it was," Perrin told them. He ignored their stares. "In three days, it will all be over. That's all that matters." Faile was all that mattered.

ðə sʌn stʊd ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɪts nundeɪ pik, bʌt feɪl ɔlɹɛɾi fɛl hɝæst. ðə wɔɾɝ fəɹ sɪvænəz mɔɹnɪŋ bæθ - ʃi beɪð twaɪs ə deɪ, naʊ! - hæd nɑt bɪn hɑɾ ɪnʌf, ən feɪl hæd bɪn biɾən əlɔŋ wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, ɔlðoʊ ʃi ən æliændɝ hæɾ oʊnli bɪn ðəɹ tə skɹʌb ðə wʊmənz bæk. mɔɹ ðən twɛnti wɛtləndɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn hæd bɛɡd tə bi əlaʊd tə swɛɹ fiəlti dʒʌst sɪns sʌnɹaɪz. θɹi hæd sədʒɛstəd ɹaɪzɪŋ ʌp, pɔɪntɪŋ aʊt ðət ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn ɪn ɔl ðiz tɛns ðən ʃeɪɾoʊ. ðeɪ hæd sim tə lɪsən wən ʃi pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðət nɪɹli ɔl ə ði il nu haʊ tə juz ə spɪɹ, waɪl moʊst ə ðə wɛtləndɝz wɝ fɑɹmɝz əɹ kɹæftsfoʊk. fju hæɾ ɛvɝ hɛld ə wɛpən, ən fjuɝ stɪl juzd wʌn. ðeɪ hæd sim tə lɪsən, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs deɪ ɛniwʌn hæd sədʒɛstəd sətʃ ə θɪŋ ɹaɪɾ æftɝ swɛɹɪŋ. juʒəwəli ðeɪ tʊk sɛvɹəl deɪz tə wɝk ðɛmsɛlvz ɝaʊn tə ɪt. ðə pɹɛʃɝ wɑz bɪldɪŋ. təwɔɹɾ ə slɔɾɝ ənlɛs ʃi kəd θwɔɹɾ ɪt. ən naʊ ðɪs. . . .

The sun stood short of its noonday peak, but Faile already felt harassed. The water for Sevanna's morning bath - she bathed twice a day, now! - had not been hot enough, and Faile had been beaten along with everyone else, although she and Alliandre had only been there to scrub the woman's back. More than twenty wetlander gai'shain had begged to be allowed to swear fealty just since sunrise. Three had suggested rising up, pointing out that there were more gai'shain in all these tents than Shaido. They had seemed to listen when she pointed out that nearly all of the Aiel knew how to use a spear, while most of the wetlanders were farmers or craftsfolk. Few had ever held a weapon, and fewer still used one. They had seemed to listen, but this was the first day anyone had suggested such a thing right after swearing. Usually they took several days to work themselves around to it. The pressure was building. Toward a slaughter unless she could thwart it. And now this. . . .

"ɪɾ ɪz oʊnli ə ɡeɪm, feɪl bæʃɪɹ," ɹoʊlən sɛd, taʊɝɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ əz ðeɪ wɔkt əlɔŋ wʌn ə ðə mʌɾi stʃɹits ðət waʊn θɹu ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tɛns. hi saʊndəɾ əmjuzd, ən ə vɛɹi smɔl smaɪl kɝvd ɪz lɪps. ə bjuɾəfəl mæn tə bi ʃʊɹ.

"It is only a game, Faile Bashere," Rolan said, towering over her as they walked along one of the muddy streets that wound through the Shaido tents. He sounded amused, and a very small smile curved his lips. A beautiful man to be sure.

"ə kɪsɪŋ ɡeɪm, jə sɛd." ʃi ʃɪftəd ðə lɛŋθs ə stʃɹaɪp taʊəlɪŋ foʊldəɾ oʊvɝ əɹ ɑɹm tə dʒɹɔ hɪz ətɛnʃən. "aɪ hæv wɝk tə du, ən noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɡeɪmz. ɪspɛʃli kɪsɪŋ ɡeɪmz."

"A kissing game, you said." She shifted the lengths of striped toweling folded over her arm to draw his attention. "I have work to do, and no time for games. Especially kissing games."

ʃi kəd si ə fju il, sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm mɛn stæɡɝɪŋ dʒɹʌŋk ivən ət ðɪs aʊɝ, bʌt moʊst ə ðə pipəl ɪn ðə stʃɹit wɝ wɛtləndɝz wɛɹɪŋ dɝɾi ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz əɹ tʃɪlʒɹən splæʃɪŋ hæpəli ɪn ðə mʌd pʌɾəlz lɛf baɪ ðə naɪts hɛvi ɹeɪn. ðə stʃɹit wɑz θɹɔŋd wɪð mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn mʌd-steɪnd waɪt kæɹiɪŋ bæskəts əɹ bʌkəts əɹ pɑts. səm æktʃəli  wɛn əbaʊt tʃɔɹz. ðəɹ wɝ soʊ mɛni ɡeɪʃeɪn ɪn ðə kæmp ðət ðəɹ ɹɪli wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf wɝk tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊnd. ðət wəd nɑt stɑp ə ʃeɪɾoʊ fɹəm ɔɹɾɝɪŋ wʌt wɝ sin əz aɪɾəl hænz tə səm wɝk əɹ ʌðɝ ɪf ðoʊz hænz stʌk aʊɾ ʌv waɪt slivz, haʊɛvɝ, ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz meɪk-wɝk. tə əvɔɪd hævɪŋ tə dɪɡ jusləs hoʊlz ɪn mʌɾi filz əɹ skɹʌb pɑts ðət wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi klin, ə ɡʊd mɛni ʌv ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn hæd teɪkən tə kæɹiɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪɾ əm lʊk əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ wɝkɪŋ. ðət dɪd nɑt hɛlp ɛniwʌn əvɔɪd ðə ɹil wɝk, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd hɛlp əvɝt ði ʌðɝ kaɪnd. feɪl dɪd nɑɾ əv tə wɝi əbaʊt ðət wɪð moʊst ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, nɑt soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi wɔɹ ðoʊz θɪk ɡoʊldən tʃeɪnz ɝaʊn əɹ weɪst ən nɛk, bʌt ðə nɛkləs ən bɛlt wɝ ɪnæɾəkwət fəɹ dɪtɝɪŋ waɪz wʌnz. ʃi hæd skɹʌb klin pɑts fəɹ səm ə ðɛm. ən səmtaɪmz hæd bɪn pʌnɪʃt fəɹ nɑt biɪŋ əveɪləbəl wən sɪvænə wɑntəd hɝ. ðʌs ðə taʊəlɪŋ.

She could see a few Aiel, several of them men staggering drunk even at this hour, but most of the people in the street were wetlanders wearing dirty gai'shain robes or children splashing happily in the mud puddles left by the night's heavy rain. The street was thronged with men and women in mud-stained white carrying baskets or buckets or pots. Some actually went about chores. There were so many gai'shain in the camp that there really was not enough work to go around. That would not stop a Shaido from ordering what were seen as idle hands to some work or other if those hands stuck out of white sleeves, however, even if it was make-work. To avoid having to dig useless holes in muddy fields or scrub pots that were already clean, a good many of the gai'shain had taken to carrying something that made them look as if they were working. That did not help anyone avoid the real work, but it did help avert the other kind. Faile did not have to worry about that with most of the Shaido, not so long as she wore those thick golden chains around her waist and neck, but the necklace and belt were inadequate for deterring Wise Ones. She had scrubbed clean pots for some of them. And sometimes had been punished for not being available when Sevanna wanted her. Thus the toweling.

"wi kəd stɑɹt wɪð ə kɪsɪŋ ɡeɪm tʃɪlʒɹən pleɪ," hi sɛd, "ðoʊ ðə fɔɹfaɪts ɪn ðəɾ ɑɹ səmtaɪmz ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ. ɪn ðə ɡeɪm ədʌls pleɪ, ðə fɔɹfaɪts ɑɹ fʌn. luzɪŋ kən bi əz plɛzən əz wɪnɪŋ."

"We could start with a kissing game children play," he said, "though the forfeits in that are sometimes embarrassing. In the game adults play, the forfeits are fun. Losing can be as pleasant as winning."

ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp læfɪŋ. ðə mæn sɝɾənli wɑz pɝsɪstənt. sʌɾənli ʃi sɔ ɡəlinə hɝiɪŋ θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ waɪt sɪlk ɹoʊbz ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə mʌd, aɪz sɝtʃɪŋ ævədli. feɪl hæd hɝd ðə wʊmən wɑz əlaʊd kloʊðɪŋ əɡɛn əz ə ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn wɪθaʊt ðə tɔl nɛkləs ən waɪd bɛlt ʌv ɡoʊld ən faɪɝdʒɹɑps. ə kæp ə hɛɹ lɛs ðən ən ɪntʃ lɔŋ kʌvɝɾ əɹ hɛd, ən ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd baʊ wɑz pɪn ɪn ɪt. ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ðət wɑz baɪ ðə wʊmənz tʃɔɪs. oʊnli ə feɪs feɪl kəd nɑt pʊɾ ən eɪdʒ tə kənvɪnst əɹ ðət ɡəlinə ɹɪli wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. bɪɑn ðæt, ʃi wɑz ənʃʊɹ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ ɪksɛp ðə deɪnʒɝ ʃi pɹizɛntəd. ɡəlinə spɑɾəd əɹ ən stɑp dɛd, hænz niɾɪŋ əɹ ɹoʊbz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ aɪd ɹoʊlən ənsɝteɪnli.

She could not help laughing. The man certainly was persistent. Suddenly she saw Galina hurrying through the crowd in her direction, holding her white silk robes up out of the mud, eyes searching avidly. Faile had heard the woman was allowed clothing again as of this morning. Of course, she had never been without the tall necklace and wide belt of gold and firedrops. A cap of hair less than an inch long covered her head, and of all things, a large red bow was pinned in it. It seemed unlikely that was by the woman's choice. Only a face Faile could not put an age to convinced her that Galina really was Aes Sedai. Beyond that, she was unsure of anything about her except the danger she presented. Galina spotted her and stopped dead, hands kneading her robes. The Aes Sedai eyed Rolan uncertainly.

"aɪl əv tə θɪŋk ɑn ɪt, ɹoʊlən." ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə tʃeɪs ɪm əweɪ əntɪl ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɡəlinə. "aɪ nid taɪm tə θɪŋk."

"I'll have to think on it, Rolan." She was not about to chase him away until she was sure of Galina. "I need time to think."

"wɪmən ɔlweɪz wɑn taɪm tə θɪŋk. θɪŋk ɑn fɝɡɛɾɪŋ jəɹ tʃɹʌbəlz ɪn ðə plɛʒɝ ʌv ə hɑɹmləs ɡeɪm."

"Women always want time to think. Think on forgetting your troubles in the pleasure of a harmless game."

ðə fɪŋɡɝ i dʒɹu sɔfli daʊn əɹ tʃik bɪfɔɹ wɔkɪŋ əweɪ meɪɾ əɹ ʃɪvɝ. tə il, tʌtʃɪŋ sʌmwʌnz tʃik ɪn pʌblɪk wɑz əz mʌtʃ əz ə kɪs. ɪt ʃʊɹli hæd fɛlt laɪk ə kɪs tə hɝ. hɑɹmləs? sʌmhaʊ, ʃi daʊɾɪd ðəɾ ɛni ɡeɪm ðəɾ ɪnvɑlv kɪsɪŋ ɹoʊlən wəɾ ɛnd wɪð dʒʌs kɪsɪŋ. lʌkəli, ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv tə faɪn aʊt - əɹ haɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm pɛɹɪn - ɪf ɡəlinə pɹuv tʃɹu. ɪf.

The finger he drew softly down her cheek before walking away made her shiver. To Aiel, touching someone's cheek in public was as much as a kiss. It surely had felt like a kiss to her. Harmless? Somehow, she doubted that any game that involved kissing Rolan would end with just kissing. Luckily, she would not have to find out - or hide anything from Perrin - if Galina proved true. If.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɑɹɾɪd tə hɝ əz sun əz ɹoʊlən wɑz ɡɔn. "wɛɹ ɪz ɪt?" ɡəlinə dɪmændəd, sizɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm. "tɛl mi! aɪ noʊ juv ɪt. jə mʌst əv ɪt!" ðə wʊmən saʊndəɾ ɔlmoʊs pliɾɪŋ. θɛɝɑvəz tʃɹitmən ə hɝ hæd ʃæɾɝd ðət feɪbəld ɛɛs sədaɪ kəmpoʊʒɝ.

The Aes Sedai darted to her as soon as Rolan was gone. "Where is it?" Galina demanded, seizing her arm. "Tell me! I know you have it. You must have it!" The woman sounded almost pleading. Therava's treatment of her had shattered that fabled Aes Sedai composure.

feɪl ʃʊk ɔf əɹ ɡɹɪp. "fɝs tɛl mi əɡɛn ðət jəl teɪk maɪ fɹɛnz ən mi wɪð jə wən jə ɡoʊ. tɛl mi stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt. ən tɛl mi wən jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ."

Faile shook off her grip. "First tell me again that you will take my friends and me with you when you go. Tell me straight out. And tell me when you are going."

"doʊn jə dɛɹ tɔk tə mi ðət weɪ," ɡəlinə hɪst.

"Don't you dare talk to me that way," Galina hissed.

feɪl sɔ blæk flɛks floʊɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ vɪʒən bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi hæd bɪn slæpt. tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, ʃi slæp ði ʌðɝ wʊmən bæk əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd, stæɡɝɪŋ hɝ. ʃi ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm pʊɾɪŋ ə hæn tə hɝ stɪŋɪŋ feɪs, bʌt ɡəlinə ɹʌbd əɹ oʊn tʃik, hɝ aɪz waɪd wɪð ʃɑk. feɪl stil hɝsɛlf, pɝhæps fəɹ ə bloʊ wɪð ðə paʊɝ əɹ sʌmθɪŋ wɝs, bʌt nʌθɪŋ hæpənd. səm ə ðə pæsɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn stɛɹɾ ət ðɛm, bʌt nʌn stɑpt əɹ ivən sloʊd. ɛniθɪŋ ðət lʊk laɪk ə ɡæðɝɪŋ ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn wəd dʒɹɔ ʃeɪɾoʊ aɪz, ən ɝn pʌnɪʃməns fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪnvɑlvd.

Faile saw black flecks floating in her vision before she realized that she had been slapped. To her surprise, she slapped the other woman back as hard as she could, staggering her. She refrained from putting a hand to her stinging face, but Galina rubbed her own cheek, her eyes wide with shock. Faile steeled herself, perhaps for a blow with the Power or something worse, but nothing happened. Some of the passing gai'shain stared at them, but none stopped or even slowed. Anything that looked like a gathering of gai'shain would draw Shaido eyes, and earn punishments for everyone involved.

"tɛl mi," ʃi sɛɾ əɡɛn.

"Tell me," she said again.

"aɪ wɪl teɪk jə ən jəɹ fɹɛnz wɪð mi," ɡəlinə pɹæktəkli snɑɹəld, snætʃɪŋ əɹ hæn daʊn. "aɪ liv təmɑɹoʊ. ɪf juv ɪt. ɪf nɑt, sɪvænə wɪl noʊ hu jə ɑɹ wɪðɪn ði aʊɝ!" wɛl, ðət wɑz sɝɾənli spikɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt.

"I will take you and your friends with me," Galina practically snarled, snatching her hand down. "I leave tomorrow. If you have it. If not, Sevanna will know who you are within the hour!" Well, that was certainly speaking straight out.

"ɪts hɪɾən ɪn ðə taʊn. əl ɡɛɾ ɪt fəɹ jə naʊ."

"It's hidden in the town. I'll get it for you now."

bʌɾ əz ʃi tɝnd, ɡəlinə ɡɹæbd əɹ ɑɹm əɡɛn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd, ən ʃi loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs əz ɪf sʌɾənli kənsɝn əbaʊt biɪŋ oʊvɝhɝd. ʃi saʊndəd fɹaɪɾənd. "noʊ. əl teɪk noʊ tʃænsəz ɑn ɛniwʌn siɪŋ. jəl ɡɪv ɪt tə mi təmɑɹoʊ mɔɹnɪŋ. ɪn ðə taʊn. wɪl mit ðɛɹ. ɪn ðə saʊθ ɛn ə ðə taʊn. əl mɑɹk ðə bɪldɪŋ. wɪð ə ɹɛd skɑɹf."

But as she turned, Galina grabbed her arm again. The Aes Sedai's eyes darted, and she lowered her voice as if suddenly concerned about being overheard. She sounded frightened. "No. I'll take no chances on anyone seeing. You'll give it to me tomorrow morning. In the town. We'll meet there. In the south end of the town. I'll mark the building. With a red scarf."

feɪl blɪŋkt. ðə sʌðɝn hæf ə mɔldən wɑz ə bɝnd-aʊt ʃɛl. "waɪ ðɛɹ?" ʃi æskt ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli.

Faile blinked. The southern half of Malden was a burned-out shell. "Why there?" she asked incredulously.

"bɪkɔz noʊ wʌn ɡoʊz ðɛɹ, ful! kəz noʊ wʌn wɪl si ʌs!" ɡəlinəz aɪz wɝ stɪl dɑɹɾɪŋ. "təmɑɹoʊ mɔɹnɪŋ, ɝli. feɪl mi, ən jəl ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt!" ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə skɝts ə hɝ sɪlk ɹoʊb, ʃi skɝiɾ əweɪ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd.

"Because no one goes there, fool! Because no one will see us!" Galina's eyes were still darting. "Tomorrow morning, early. Fail me, and you'll regret it!" Gathering the skirts of her silk robe, she scurried away into the crowd.

feɪl fɹaʊn əz ʃi wɑtʃt ðə wʊmən ɡoʊ. ʃi ʃʊɾə fɛlt ɪɡzʌlteɪʃən, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt. ɡəlinə simd ɔlmoʊst ə waɪl θɪŋ, ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl. stɪl, ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt laɪ. ðəɹ sim noʊ weɪ fəɹ əɹ tə ɹɪɡəl aʊɾ ə hɝ pɹɑməs. ən ɪf ʃi faʊnd wʌn, ðəɹ wɝ stɪl əɹ oʊn plænz fəɹ ən ɪskeɪp, ðoʊ ðoʊz sim noʊ fɝðɝ əlɔŋ, ɪf mʌtʃ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs, ðən ðeɪ hæd wən fɝs bɪɡʌn. wɪtʃ lɛft ɹoʊlən. ən ɪz kɪsɪŋ ɡeɪmz. ɡəlinə hæd tə pɹuv tʃɹu. ʃi hæd tə.

Faile frowned as she watched the woman go. She should have felt exultation, but she did not. Galina seemed almost a wild thing, unpredictable. Still, Aes Sedai could not lie. There seemed no way for her to wriggle out of her promise. And if she found one, there were still her own plans for an escape, though those seemed no further along, if much more dangerous, than they had when first begun. Which left Rolan. And his kissing games. Galina had to prove true. She had to.

tʃæptɝ twɛntisɛvən

CHAPTER 27

eɪ pleɪn wʊɾən bɑks ðə mɪddeɪ ɔltɑɹən sʌn wɑz wɔɹm, ðoʊ ə ɡʌstɪŋ bɹiz səmtaɪmz wɪpt ɹændz kloʊk. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɑn ðə hɪltɑp fəɹ tu aʊɝz, naʊ. ə ɡɹeɪt mæs ə dɑɹk klaʊdz kɹipɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ əbʌv blu-ɡɹeɪ heɪz spoʊk ə ɹeɪn tə kʌm, ən ə kulɪŋ. ændɝ leɪ oʊnli ə fju maɪlz ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən əkɹɔs loʊ, fɔɹəstəd hɪlz ʌv oʊk ən paɪn, lɛðɝlif ən saʊɝɡəm. ðət bɔɹɾɝ hæd sin kaʊnləs dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz ə kæɾəl ɹeɪdz ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn boʊθ dɝɛkʃənz. wɑz ɪleɪn wɑtʃɪŋ ɪt ɹeɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn? ðət leɪ ə ɡʊd hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti liɡz ist, tu fɑɹ fəɹ əɹ tə bi mɔɹ ðən ə feɪn pɹɛzəns ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd. eɪvinhə, ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, wɑz feɪntɝ stɪl. hi hæd nɑt kənsɪɾɝd ðət ðə waɪz wʌnz wəd teɪk əɹ əlɔŋ. stɪl, ʃi wəd bi seɪf əmʌŋ tɛnz ə θaʊzənz ʌv il, əz seɪf əz ɪleɪn bɪhaɪn keɪɛmlɪnz wɔlz. teɪdeɪʃɝ stæmpt ə huf ən tɔst ɪz hɛd, iɡɝ tə bi muvɪŋ. ɹænd pæɾəd ðə bɪɡ blæks nɛk. ðə stæljən kəd ɹitʃ ðə bɔɹɾɝ ɪn ʌndɝ ən aʊɝ, bʌt ðɛɹ weɪ wɑz wɛs tədeɪ. ə ʃɔɹt weɪ wɛst ɪn dʒʌst ə ʃɔɹt waɪl, naʊ.

A Plain Wooden Box The midday Altaran sun was warm, though a gusting breeze sometimes whipped Rand's cloak. They had been on the hilltop for two hours, now. A great mass of dark clouds creeping down from the north above blue-gray haze spoke of rain to come, and a cooling. Andor lay only a few miles in that direction across low, forested hills of oak and pine, leatherleaf and sourgum. That border had seen countless generations of cattle raids going in both directions. Was Elayne watching it rain in Caemlyn? That lay a good hundred and fifty leagues east, too far for her to be more than a faint presence in the back of his head. Aviendha, in Arad Doman, was fainter still. He had not considered that the Wise Ones would take her along. Still, she would be safe among tens of thousands of Aiel, as safe as Elayne behind Caemlyn's walls. Tai'daishar stamped a hoof and tossed his head, eager to be moving. Rand patted the big black's neck. The stallion could reach the border in under an hour, but their way was west today. A short way west in just a short while, now.

hi hæd tə ɪmpɹɛs ət tədeɪz miɾɪŋ, ən i hæd tʃoʊzən ɪz ɡɑɹb wɪð kɛɹ. ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz sæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd fəɹ mɔɹ ɹizən ðən meɪkɪŋ ən ɪmpɹɛʃən, ðoʊ. hæf ðə smɔl sɔɹdz nɛsəld əmʌŋ ðə waɪd bæn ə lɔɹəl livz pɔɪntəd daʊn, meɪkɪŋ ɪɾ ənkʌmftəɹbəl tə wɛɹ, ɡɪvɪŋ kɑnstən ɹimaɪndɝz ʌv ɪts weɪt, ɪn ɡoʊld ən ɪn ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi. ə smɔl tʃɪp ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz lɔɹəl livz dʌɡ əɾ ɪz tɛmpəl tə ɹimaɪn ɪm ə ðə bæɾəl əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn wɛɹ ɪt hæd bɪn meɪd. ə bæɾəl lɔst wən i kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə luz. hɪz dɑɹk ɡɹin sɪlk koʊt wɑz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ɡoʊld ɑn ðə slivz, ʃoʊldɝz ən haɪ kɑlɝ, ə ɡoʊld-ɪnleɪd bʌkəl ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə dʒɹæɡən fæsən ɪz sɔɹdbɪlt, ən i hæd ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ ɪn hænd, ə tu-fʊt lɛŋθ ə spɪɹhɛd wɪð ə lɔŋ ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt tæsəl bɪloʊ ðə pɑlɪʃt stil pɔɪnt. ɪf ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪt fəɹ pɑɹɾ ʌv ə sintʃæn spɪɹ, ʃi mʌst ɔlsoʊ si ðə dʒɹæɡənz ðət meɪɾənz hæd kɑɹvd waɪndɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ hæft. tədeɪ, hi wɔɹ noʊ ɡlʌvz. ðə ɡoʊldən-meɪn dʒɹæɡənhɛdz ɑn ðə bæks ə hɪz hænz ɡlɪɾɝd mɛɾəlɪkli ɪn ðə sʌn. haʊɛvɝ haɪ ʃi stʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ʃi wəd noʊ hum ʃi feɪst.

He had to impress at today's meeting, and he had chosen his garb with care. The Crown of Swords sat on his head for more reason than making an impression, though. Half the small swords nestled among the wide band of laurel leaves pointed down, making it uncomfortable to wear, giving constant reminders of its weight, in gold and in responsibility. A small chip in one of those laurel leaves dug at his temple to remind him of the battle against the Seanchan where it had been made. A battle lost when he could not afford to lose. His dark green silk coat was embroidered in gold on the sleeves, shoulders and high collar, a gold-inlaid buckle in the shape of a dragon fastened his swordbelt, and he had the Dragon Scepter in hand, a two-foot length of spearhead with a long green-and-white tassel below the polished steel point. If the Daughter of the Nine Moons recognized it for part of a Seanchan spear, she must also see the dragons that Maidens had carved winding around the remaining haft. Today, he wore no gloves. The golden-maned dragonheads on the backs of his hands glittered metallically in the sun. However high she stood among the Seanchan, she would know whom she faced.

ə ful. luz θɝɪnz waɪld læftɝ ɛkoʊɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd. ə ful tə wɔk ɪndə ə tʃɹæp. ɹænd ɪɡnɔɹd ðə mædmæn. ɪt maɪt bi ə tʃɹæp, bʌɾ i wɑz ɹɛɾi tə spɹɪŋ ɪɾ ɪf ɪt wɑz. ɪt wɑz wɝθ ðə ɹɪsk. hi niɾəd ðɪs tʃɹus. hi kəd kɹʌʃ ðə sintʃæn, bʌɾ ət wʌt kɑst ɪn blʌd, ən ɪn taɪm i maɪt nɑt hæv? hi ɡlæns nɔɹθ əɡɛn. ðə skaɪ əbʌv ændɝ wɑz klɪɹ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju haɪ waɪt klaʊdz, dʒɹɪftɪŋ wɪsps. ðə læs bæɾəl wɑz kʌmɪŋ. hi hæd tə teɪk ðə ɹɪsk.

A fool. Lews Therin's wild laughter echoed inside his head. A fool to walk into a trap. Rand ignored the madman. It might be a trap, but he was ready to spring it if it was. It was worth the risk. He needed this truce. He could crush the Seanchan, but at what cost in blood, and in time he might not have? He glanced north again. The sky above Andor was clear except for a few high white clouds, drifting wisps. The Last Battle was coming. He had to take the risk.

mɪn, tɔɪɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹeɪnz ə hɝ ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ nɪɹbaɪ, wɑz filɪŋ smʌɡ, ən ðəɾ ɪɹəteɪɾəd hɪm. ʃi hæɾ ɪnveɪiɡəld ə pɹɑməs fɹəm ɪm ɪn ə wik moʊmən ən ɹəfjuz tə ɹilis hɪm. hi kəd dʒʌs bɹeɪk ɪt. hi ʃəd bɹeɪk ɪt. əz ɪf ʃi hæd hɝɾ ɪz θɔts, ʃi lʊkt ət hɪm. hɝ feɪs, sɝaʊndəd baɪ dɑɹk ʃoʊldɝ-lɛŋθ ɹɪŋləts, wɑz smuð, bʌt ðə bɑn sʌɾənli kæɹid səspɪʃən ən hɪns ʌv æŋɡɝ. ʃi sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə səpɹɛs boʊθ, jɛt ʃi ədʒʌstəd ðə kʌfs ə hɝ ɔɹnətli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɹɛd koʊt ðə weɪ ʃi dɪd wən tʃɛkɪŋ əɹ naɪvz. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi wəd nɑt juz wʌn ə hɝ bleɪdz ɑn hɪm. ʌv kɔɹs nɑt.

Min, toying with the reins of her gray mare nearby, was feeling smug, and that irritated him. She had inveigled a promise from him in a weak moment and refused to release him. He could just break it. He should break it. As if she had heard his thoughts, she looked at him. Her face, surrounded by dark shoulder-length ringlets, was smooth, but the bond suddenly carried suspicion and hints of anger. She seemed to be trying to suppress both, yet she adjusted the cuffs of her ornately embroidered red coat the way she did when checking her knives. Of course, she would not use one of her blades on him. Of course not.

ə wʊmənz lʌv kən bi vaɪələnt, luz θɝɪn mɝmɝd. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ hɝɾ ə mæn wɝs ðən ðeɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ hæv, wɝs ðən ðeɪ min tə. səmtaɪmz, ðəɹ ivən sɑɹi æftɝwɝdz. hi saʊndəd seɪn fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, bʌt ɹænd ʃʌv ðə vɔɪs daʊn.

A woman's love can be violent, Lews Therin murmured. Sometimes they hurt a man worse than they think they have, worse than they mean to. Sometimes, they're even sorry afterwards. He sounded sane for the moment, but Rand shoved the voice down.

"ju ʃəd lɛɾ əs skaʊt fɑɹðɝ aʊt, ɹænd ælθɹ," nændɛɹə sɛd. ʃi ən ðə tu dʌzən ʌðɝ meɪɾənz ɑn ðə spɑɹsli wʊɾɪd hɪltɑp wɔɹ ðɛɹ blæk veɪlz ʌp. səm hæd ðɛɹ baʊz ɪn hæn ən æɹoʊz nɑkt. ðə ɹɛst ə ðə meɪɾənz wɝ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz wɛl aʊt fɹəm ðə hɪl, kipɪŋ wɑtʃ əɡɛnst ənplɛzən sɝpɹaɪzəz. "ðə læn ɪz klɪɹ ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə mænɝ haʊs, bʌt ðɪs stɪl smɛlz ʌv ə tʃɹæp tə mi." ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə taɪm wən wɝdz laɪk "mænɝ" ən "haʊs" saʊndəɾ ɑkwɝɾ ɑn əɹ tʌŋ. ʃi hæd bɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm ɪn ðə wɛtlænz naʊ, ðoʊ.

"You should let us scout farther out, Rand al'Thor," Nandera said. She and the two dozen other Maidens on the sparsely wooded hilltop wore their black veils up. Some had their bows in hand and arrows nocked. The rest of the Maidens were among the trees well out from the hill, keeping watch against unpleasant surprises. "The land is clear all the way to the manor house, but this still smells of a trap to me." There had been a time when words like "manor" and "house" sounded awkward on her tongue. She had been a long time in the wetlands now, though.

"nændɛɹə spiks tʃɹuθ," əliviə mʌɾɝd sʌlənli, hilɪŋ əɹ ɹoʊn ɡɛldɪŋ kloʊsɝ. əpɛɹənli ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən stɪl ɹizɛntəd ðə fæk ðət ʃi wəd nɑt bi ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð hɪm, bʌɾ əɹ ɹiækʃən tə hɪɹɪŋ əɹ neɪɾɪv æksɛns ɪn tɛɹ meɪd ðəɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl. ʃi ədmɪɾəd hævɪŋ bɪn ʃeɪkən, bʌt kleɪmd ɪt hæd bɪn ðə sɝpɹaɪz ə ðə θɪŋ. hi kəd nɑt tʃæns ɪt, ðoʊ. "ju kænɑt tʃɹʌst ɛni ʌv ðə haɪ blʌd, ɪspɛʃli nɑɾ ə dɔɾɝ ə ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi - " hɝ maʊθ snæpt ʃʌt, ən ʃi smuðd əɹ dɑɹk blu skɝts ənnɛsəsɛɹəli, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ ət wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlmoʊst sɛd. hi tʃɹʌstɪd hɝ, lɪɾɝəli wɪð ɪz laɪf, bʌt ʃi hæd tu mɛni dip-bɛɹiɾ ɪnstɪŋks tə ɹɪsk pʊɾɪŋ əɹ feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð ðə wʊmən i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə mit. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ æŋɡɝ wɪð noʊ ɛfɝt tə səpɹɛs ɪt, naʊ. mɪn dɪslaɪk siɪŋ əliviə nɪɹ hɪm.

"Nandera speaks truth," Alivia muttered sullenly, heeling her roan gelding closer. Apparently the golden-haired woman still resented the fact that she would not be going with him, but her reaction to hearing her native accents in Tear made that impossible. She admitted having been shaken, but claimed it had been the surprise of the thing. He could not chance it, though. "You cannot trust any of the High Blood, especially not a daughter of the Empress, may she - " Her mouth snapped shut, and she smoothed her dark blue skirts unnecessarily, grimacing at what she had almost said. He trusted her, literally with his life, but she had too many deep-buried instincts to risk putting her face-to-face with the woman he was going to meet. The bond carried anger with no effort to suppress it, now. Min disliked seeing Alivia near him.

"ɪt smɛlz ʌv ə tʃɹæp tə mi, tu," bæʃɪɹ sɛd, izɪŋ ɪz sɪnjuəsli kɝv sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪts skæbɝd. hi wɑz pleɪnli klæd, ɪn bɝnɪʃt hɛlməɾ ən bɹɛstpleɪt, hɪz ɡɹeɪ sɪlk koʊɾ əloʊn mɑɹkɪŋ ɪm aʊt fɹəm ði eɪɾi-wʌn sɑldəiən lænsɝz ɝeɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə hɪltɑp. hɪz θɪk, daʊn-kɝv mʌstæʃɪz ɔlmoʊs bɹɪsəl bɪhaɪn ðə feɪs-bɑɹz ə hɪz hɛlmət. "aɪd ɡɪv tɛn θaʊzən kɹaʊnz tə noʊ haʊ mɛni soʊlʒɝz ʃiz aʊt ðɛɹ. ən haʊ mɛni deɪmeɪn. ðɪs dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz ɪz ði ɛɹ tə ðɛɹ θɹoʊn, mæn." hi hæd bɪn ʃɑkt wən əliviə ɹɪvil ðæt. noʊ wʌn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ hæd mɛnʃən ɪt tə hɪm, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə noʊ ɪmpɔɹɾəns. "ðeɪ meɪ kleɪm ðɛɹ kəntʃɹoʊl ɛnz fɑɹ saʊθ ə hɪɹ, bʌt jə kən weɪdʒɝ ʃiz ət list ə smɔl ɑɹmi tə si tə hɝ seɪfti."

"It smells of a trap to me, too," Bashere said, easing his sinuously curved sword in its scabbard. He was plainly clad, in burnished helmet and breastplate, his gray silk coat alone marking him out from the eighty-one Saldaean lancers arrayed around the hilltop. His thick, down-curved mustaches almost bristled behind the face-bars of his helmet. "I'd give ten thousand crowns to know how many soldiers she has out there. And how many damane. This Daughter of the Nine Moons is the heir to their throne, man." He had been shocked when Alivia revealed that. No one in Ebou Dar had mentioned it to him, as if it were of no importance. "They may claim their control ends far south of here, but you can wager she has at least a small army to see to her safety."

"æn ɪf əɹ skaʊts faɪn ðɪs ɑɹmi," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli, "kæn wi bi ʃʊɹ ðeɪ woʊn bi sin?" nændɛɹə meɪɾ ə skɔɹnfəl saʊnd. "bɛs nɑt tə əsum jəɹ ði oʊnli wʌn wɪð aɪz," hi toʊl hɝ. "ɪf ðeɪ θɪŋk wɝ plænɪŋ tə ətæk əm əɹ kɪdnæp ðə wʊmən, ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɔlz əpɑɹt." meɪbi ðət wɑz waɪ ðeɪ hæd kɛp ðɛɹ sikɹət. ði ɪmpɪɹiəl ɛɹ wəd bi ə mɔɹ tɛmptɪŋ tɑɹɡət fəɹ ə kɪdnæpɪŋ ðən ə mɪɹ haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ noʊbəlwʊmən. "ju dʒʌs kip wɑtʃ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ doʊn kætʃ əs baɪ sɝpɹaɪz. ɪf ɪɾ ɔl ɡoʊz ɹɔŋ, bæʃɪɹ, jə noʊ wʌt tə du. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi meɪ hæv ən ɑɹmi, bʌt soʊ də aɪ, ən nɑt soʊ smɔl." bæʃɪɹ hæd tə nɑɾ ət ðæt.

"And if our scouts find this army," Rand replied calmly, "can we be sure they won't be seen?" Nandera made a scornful sound. "Best not to assume you're the only one with eyes," he told her. "If they think we're planning to attack them or kidnap the woman, everything falls apart." Maybe that was why they had kept their secret. The Imperial heir would be a more tempting target for a kidnapping than a mere high-ranking noblewoman. "You just keep watch to make sure they don't catch us by surprise. If it all goes wrong, Bashere, you know what to do. Besides, she may have an army, but so do I, and not so small." Bashere had to nod at that.

əsaɪd fɹəm ðə sɑldəiənz ən ðə meɪɾənz, ðə hɪltɑp wɑz kɹaʊɾəd wɪð æʃəmən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz, bɛɾɝ ðən twɛnti-faɪv ɔl toʊld, ən əz fɔɹməɾəbəl ə ɡɹup əz ɛni smɔl ɑɹmi. ðeɪ mɪŋɡəld wɪð sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ iz, ən fju aʊtwɝd saɪnz ə tɛnʃən. oʊ, tʌvaɪn, ə ʃɔɹt, kɑpɝi-skɪn ɹɛd, wɑz skaʊlɪŋ ət lɑɡən, bʌt ɡɑbɹɛl, ə dʌski bɹaʊn wɪð suɾi ɡɹin aɪz, wɑz tɔkɪŋ wɪð ɪm kwaɪt kəmpænjənəbli, pɝhæps ivən koʊkɛɾɪʃli. ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ðə ɹizən fəɹ tʌvaɪnz skaʊl, ðoʊ dɪsəpɹuvəl simd mɔɹ laɪkli ðən dʒɛləsi. ɑdʒɹiɛl ən kɹɪn itʃ hæɾ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn ði ʌðɝz weɪst, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz tɔl ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝtɑp ðə dəmɑni æʃəmən, ən bjuɾəfəl wɛɹ i wɑz pleɪn ən hæd ɡɹeɪ əɾ ɪz tɛmpəlz. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðəɾ i hæd bɑndəd ðə ɡɹeɪ əɡɛnst əɹ wɪl. bɛldaɪn, nu ɪnʌf tə ðə ʃɔl ðət ʃi sɪmpli lʊk laɪk ɛni jʌŋ sɑldəiən wʊmən wɪð slaɪtli tɪltəd bɹaʊn aɪz, ɹitʃt aʊɾ ɛvɹi naʊ ən ðən tə tʌtʃ mænfɝ, ən i smaɪld əɾ əɹ wɛnɛvɝ ʃi dɪd. hɝ bɑndɪŋ ə hɪm hæd bɪn ə ʃɑk, bʌɾ əpɛɹənli ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd mæn hæd bɪn mɔɹ ðən wɪlɪŋ. niðɝ hæɾ æskt ɹænd ɪz əpɪnjən bɪfɔɹ ðə bɑndɪŋ.

Aside from the Saldaeans and the Maidens, the hilltop was crowded with Asha'man and Aes Sedai and Warders, better than twenty-five all told, and as formidable a group as any small army. They mingled with surprising ease, and few outward signs of tension. Oh, Toveine, a short, coppery-skinned Red, was scowling at Logain, but Gabrelle, a dusky Brown with sooty green eyes, was talking with him quite companionably, perhaps even coquettishly. That might have been the reason for Toveine's scowl, though disapproval seemed more likely than jealousy. Adrielle and Kurin each had an arm around the other's waist, though she was tall enough to overtop the Domani Asha'man, and beautiful where he was plain and had gray at his temples. Not to mention that he had bonded the Gray against her will. Beldeine, new enough to the shawl that she simply looked like any young Saldaean woman with slightly tilted brown eyes, reached out every now and then to touch Manfor, and he smiled at her whenever she did. Her bonding of him had been a shock, but apparently the yellow-haired man had been more than willing. Neither had asked Rand his opinion before the bonding.

stʃɹeɪnʒɪst ʌv ɔl pɝhæps wɝ dʒɛnɛɹ, peɪl ən stɝɾi ɪn ə ɡɹeɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ɹɛɾ ɑn ðə skɝts, ən kɑdʒimə, ə klɝkɪʃ fɛloʊ ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz u wɔɹ ɪz hɛɹ laɪk nɛɹɪʃmə, ɪn tu bɹeɪdz wɪð sɪlvɝ bɛlz ət ði ɛnz. ʃi læft ət sʌmθɪŋ kɑdʒimə sɛd, ən mɝmɝd sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪm læf ɪn tɝn. eɪ ɹɛd dʒoʊkɪŋ wɪð ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl! meɪbi teɪm hæɾ ɪfɛktəɾ ə tʃeɪnʒ fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ, wʌtɛvɝ i hæɾ ɪntɛndəd. ən meɪbi ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz lɪvɪŋ ɪn ə dʒɹim, tu. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ feɪməs fəɹ ðɛɹ dɪsəmbəlɪŋ. bʌt kəɾ ə ɹɛd dɪsəmbəl ðət fɑɹ?

Strangest of all perhaps were Jenare, pale and sturdy in a gray riding dress embroidered with red on the skirts, and Kajima, a clerkish fellow in his middle years who wore his hair like Narishma, in two braids with silver bells at the ends. She laughed at something Kajima said, and murmured something that made him laugh in turn. A Red joking with a man who could channel! Maybe Taim had effected a change for the better, whatever he had intended. And maybe Rand al'Thor was living in a dream, too. Aes Sedai were famous for their dissembling. But could a Red dissemble that far?

nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn fɛlt əɡɹiəbəl tədeɪ. aɪɑkoʊz aɪz simd ɔlmoʊs blæk əz ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət ɹænd, bʌt ðɛn, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wʌt hæpən tə ə wɔɹɾɝ wən ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ daɪd, ðə dɑɹk-kəmplɛktɪd lɪɾəl waɪt hæd ɹizən tə fɪɹ sændʌmɪɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə pɑsəbəl deɪnʒɝ. ði æʃəmən bɑn dɪfɝd fɹəm ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn ɪn səm ɹɪspɛks, bʌɾ ɪn ʌðɝz ɪt wɑz aɪdɛntɪkəl, ən noʊ wʌn jɛt nu ði ɪfɛks ʌv ən æʃəmənz dɛθ ɑn ðə wʊmən i hæd bɑndəd. ɛlzə wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ɹænd, tu, wʌn hæn ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ ə hɝ tɔl, lin wɔɹɾɝ fɝəl əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ɡɹɪpɪŋ ə ɡɑɹd dɔɡz kɑlɝ ən θɪŋkɪŋ ə lusɪŋ hɪm. nɑɾ əɡɛnst ɹænd, sɝɾənli, bʌɾ i wɝid fəɹ ɛniwʌn ʃi θɔt maɪt bi θɹɛɾənɪŋ hɪm. hi hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ɔɹɾɝz əbaʊt ðæt, ən əɹ oʊθ ʃəd si ðɛm oʊbeɪd, jɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd faɪn luphoʊlz ɪn ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ.

Not everyone felt agreeable today. Ayako's eyes seemed almost black as she glared at Rand, but then, considering what happened to a Warder when his Aes Sedai died, the dark-complected little White had reason to fear Sandomere going into possible danger. The Asha'man bond differed from the Warder bond in some respects, but in others it was identical, and no one yet knew the effects of an Asha'man's death on the woman he had bonded. Elza was frowning at Rand, too, one hand on the shoulder of her tall, lean Warder Fearil as if she were gripping a guard dog's collar and thinking of loosing him. Not against Rand, certainly, but he worried for anyone she thought might be threatening him. He had given her orders about that, and her oath should see them obeyed, yet Aes Sedai could find loopholes in almost anything.

mɛɹaɪs wɑz spikɪŋ fɝmli tə nɛɹɪʃmə, wɪð əɹ ʌðɝ tu wɔɹɾɝz sɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ə lɪɾəl weɪ ɔf. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðə weɪ ðə stɝn-feɪst wʊmən dʒɛstʃɝɾ əz ʃi spoʊk, linɪŋ kloʊs tə hɪm soʊ ʃi kəd spik ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. ʃi wɑz ɪnstʃɹʌktɪŋ ɪm əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ. ɹænd dɪslaɪk ðəɾ ɪn ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, jɛt ðəɹ sim lɪɾəl i kəd du. mɛɹaɪs hæd swɔɹn noʊ oʊðz, ən ʃi wəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ɪm wən ɪt keɪm tə wʌn ə hɝ wɔɹɾɝz. əɹ mʌtʃ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ.

Merise was speaking firmly to Narishma, with her other two Warders sitting their horses a little way off. There was no mistaking the way the stern-faced woman gestured as she spoke, leaning close to him so she could speak in a low voice. She was instructing him about something. Rand disliked that in the circumstances, yet there seemed little he could do. Merise had sworn no oaths, and she would ignore him when it came to one of her Warders. Or much of anything else, for that matter.

kædzueɪn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd, tu. ʃi ən nɪneɪiv wɝ wɛɹɪŋ ɔl ə ðɛɹ tɛɹæŋɡɹil dʒuəlɹi. nɪneɪiv wɑz meɪkɪŋ ə ɡʊd tʃɹaɪ əɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑm. ʃi sim tə pɹæktəs ðəɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil sɪns sɛndɪŋ læn wɛɹɛvɝ ʃi hæd sɛn hɪm. hæf ðə hɪltɑp sɛpɝeɪɾəd əɹ plʌmp bɹaʊn mɛɹ fɹəm kædzueɪnz beɪ, ʌv kɔɹs. nɪneɪiv wəd nɛvɝ ədmɪɾ ɪt, bʌt kædzueɪn ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd hɝ.

Cadsuane was watching Rand, too. She and Nynaeve were wearing all of their ter'angreal jewelry. Nynaeve was making a good try at Aes Sedai calm. She seemed to practice that a great deal since sending Lan wherever she had sent him. Half the hilltop separated her plump brown mare from Cadsuane's bay, of course. Nynaeve would never admit it, but Cadsuane intimidated her.

lɑɡən ɹoʊɾ ʌp bɪtwin ɹænd ən bæʃɪɹ, hɪz blæk ɡɛldɪŋ pɹænsɪŋ. ðə hɔɹs wɑz ɔlmoʊs ði ɪɡzækt ʃeɪɾ ə hɪz koʊɾ ən kloʊk. "ðə sʌn ɪz ɔlmoʊst stʃɹeɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd," hi sɛd. "taɪm wi ɡoʊ daʊn?" ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ə mɪɹ hɪn ə kwɛstʃən ɪn ðæt. ðə mæn tʃeɪft ət teɪkɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz. hi dɪd nɑt weɪɾ ɑn ə ɹɪplaɪ. "sændʌmɪɹ!" hi kɔld laʊdli. "nɛɹɪʃmə!"

Logain rode up between Rand and Bashere, his black gelding prancing. The horse was almost the exact shade of his coat and cloak. "The sun is almost straight overhead," he said. "Time we go down?" There was only a mere hint of question in that. The man chafed at taking orders. He did not wait on a reply. "Sandomere!" he called loudly. "Narishma!"

mɛɹaɪs hɛl nɛɹɪʃmə baɪ hɪz sliv fəɹ ənʌðɝ moʊmən ʌv ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ ɪm ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ, wɪtʃ meɪd lɑɡən skaʊl. sʌn-dɑɹk nɛɹɪʃmə wɪð ɪz dɑɹk, bɛl bɹeɪdz lʊk jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ ðən ɹænd, ðoʊ hi wɑz ə fju jɪɹz oʊldɝ ɪn tʃɹuθ. sɪɾɪŋ ɪz dʌn əz stʃɹeɪɾ əz ə sɔɹd, hi nɑɾəd tə lɑɡən əz tə ən ikwəl, pɹədusɪŋ ənʌðɝ skaʊl. sændʌmɪɹ spoʊk ə kwaɪət wɝd tə aɪɑkoʊ bɪfɔɹ maʊntɪŋ ɪz dæpəl, ən ʃi tʌtʃt ɪz θaɪ wʌns i wɑz ɪn ðə sæɾəl. ɹɪŋkəld, wɪð ɹɪsiɾɪŋ hɛɹ ən ə ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik bɪɹd tʃɹɪm tə ə pɔɪn ən ɔɪld, hi meɪɾ əɹ əpɪɹ juθfəl ɹæðɝ ðən eɪdʒləs. hi wɔɹ ðə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡən ɑn ɪz haɪ blæk kɑlɝ, naʊ, əz wɛl əz ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹd. ɛvɹi æʃəmən ɑn ðə hɪl dɪd, ivən mænfɝ. hi hæɾ oʊnli ɹisənli bɪn ɹeɪz tə dɛɾəkeɪtəd, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə fɝs tə kʌm tə ðə blæk taʊɝ, bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ wɑz ə blæk taʊɝ. moʊst ə ðə mɛn u hæd bɪɡʌn wɪð ɪm wɝ dɛd. ivən lɑɡən hæd nɑt dɪnaɪɾ i dɪzɝvd ɪt.

Merise held Narishma by his sleeve for another moment of instructions before letting him ride over, which made Logain scowl. Sun-dark Narishma with his dark, belled braids looked years younger than Rand, though he was a few years older in truth. Sitting his dun as straight as a sword, he nodded to Logain as to an equal, producing another scowl. Sandomere spoke a quiet word to Ayako before mounting his dapple, and she touched his thigh once he was in the saddle. Wrinkled, with receding hair and a gray-streaked beard trimmed to a point and oiled, he made her appear youthful rather than ageless. He wore the red-and-gold dragon on his high black collar, now, as well as the silver sword. Every Asha'man on the hill did, even Manfor. He had only recently been raised to Dedicated, but he had been one of the first to come to the Black Tower, before there was a Black Tower. Most of the men who had begun with him were dead. Even Logain had not denied he deserved it.

lɑɡən hæɾ ɪnʌf sɛns nɑt tə kɔl kædzueɪn əɹ nɪneɪiv, bʌt ðeɪ ɹoʊd tə dʒɔɪn ɹænd ɛniweɪ, pleɪsɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm, itʃ bɹifli aɪɪŋ hɪm, feɪsəz soʊ smuð ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ. ðɛɹ aɪz mɛt, ən nɪneɪiv lʊkt əweɪ kwɪkli. kædzueɪn ɡeɪv ə feɪn snɔɹt. ən mɪn keɪm, tu. hɪz "wʌn mɔɹ" tə bæləns ði ɑnɝz. ə mæn ʃəd nɛvɝ ɡɪv pɹɑməsəz ɪn bɛd. hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ən ʃi ɑɹtʃt ən aɪbɹaʊ, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm vɛɹi dɝɛkli. ðə bɑn fɛl fʊl ʌv . . . sʌmθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs.

Logain had enough sense not to call Cadsuane or Nynaeve, but they rode to join Rand anyway, placing themselves to either side of him, each briefly eyeing him, faces so smooth they might have been thinking anything. Their eyes met, and Nynaeve looked away quickly. Cadsuane gave a faint snort. And Min came, too. His "one more" to balance the honors. A man should never give promises in bed. He opened his mouth, and she arched an eyebrow, looking at him very directly. The bond felt full of . . . something dangerous.

"ju steɪ bɪhaɪn mi wʌns wi ɡɛt ðɛɹ," hi toʊl hɝ, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl wʌɾ i hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə seɪ.

"You stay behind me once we get there," he told her, not at all what he had intended to say.

deɪnʒɝ feɪɾəd tə wʌɾ i hæd kʌm tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əz lʌv. ðəɹ wɑz ɹaɪ əmjuzmən ɪn ðə bɑnd, tu, fəɹ səm ɹizən. "aɪ wɪl ɪf aɪ wɑn tə, jə wʊlhɛɾɪd ʃifɝɾɝ," ʃi sɛd wɪð mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl æspɹəɾi, dʒʌst əz ɪf ðə bɑnd wəd nɑt tɛl ɪm əɹ tʃɹu filɪŋz. hɑɹɾ əz ðoʊz maɪt bi tə dɪsaɪfɝ.

Danger faded to what he had come to recognize as love. There was wry amusement in the bond, too, for some reason. "I will if I want to, you woolheaded sheepherder," she said with more than a little asperity, just as if the bond would not tell him her true feelings. Hard as those might be to decipher.

"ɪf wɝ gɑnə də ðɪs ful θɪŋ, lɛts ɡɛɾ ɪt dʌn wɪð," kædzueɪn sɛd fɝmli, ən hild əɹ dɑɹk beɪ daʊn ðə hɪl.

"If we're going to do this fool thing, let's get it done with," Cadsuane said firmly, and heeled her dark bay down the hill.

ə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns fɹəm ðə hɪl, fɑɹmz bɪɡæn tə əpɪɹ əlɔŋ ə miændɝɪŋ dɝt ɹoʊd θɹu ðə fɔɹəst, hɑɹd-pæk baɪ lɔŋ jɪɹz ə jus bʌt stɪl kæɹiɪŋ ə slɪk ə mʌd fɹəm ðə læst ɹeɪnfɔl. ðə tʃɪmniz ə θætʃt stoʊn haʊsəz smoʊkt wɪð ðə mɪddeɪ mil-kʊkɪŋ. səmtaɪmz ɡɝlz ən wɪmən sæɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðə sʌn ət ðɛɹ spɪnɪŋ wilz. mɛn ɪn ɹʌf koʊts wɔkt ɪn ðə stoʊn-wɔl filz tʃɛkɪŋ ðɛɹ spɹaʊɾɪŋ kɹɑps əmɪd bɔɪz hoʊɪŋ widz. ðə pæstʃɝz hɛl bɹaʊn-ænd-waɪt kæɾəl əɹ blæk-teɪld ʃip, juʒəwəli wɑtʃt baɪ ə bɔɪ əɹ tu wɪð baʊz əɹ slɪŋz. ðəɹ wɝ wʊlvz ɪn ðiz fɔɹəsts, ən lɛpɝdz ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz ðəɾ ɛndʒɔɪd ðə teɪst ə bif ən mʌɾən. səm pipəl ʃeɪɾɪd ðɛɹ aɪz tə pɪɹ ət ðə pæsɝzbi, daʊtləs wʌndɝɪŋ u ðiz faɪnli dʒɹɛs foʊk wɝ u hæd kʌm tə vɪzət ðə leɪɾi dɪɹdʒɹu. ʃʊɹli ðəɹ kəd bi noʊ ʌðɝ ɹizən fəɹ ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns, hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə mænɝ haʊs ən soʊ fɑɹ fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. noʊ wʌn simd ædʒəteɪɾəd əɹ fɹaɪɾənd, ðoʊ, dʒʌst ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ deɪz wɝk. ɹumɝz ʌv ən ɑɹmi ɪn ðə ɹidʒən ʃʊɹli wʊɾə ʌpsɛt ðɛm, ən ɹumɝz ə ðət sɔɹt spɹɛd laɪk waɪldfaɪɝ. stʃɹeɪnʒ. ðə sintʃæn kəd nɑt tʃɹævəl ən ɝaɪv wɪθaʊt nuz spiɾɪŋ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ.

A short distance from the hill, farms began to appear along a meandering dirt road through the forest, hard-packed by long years of use but still carrying a slick of mud from the last rainfall. The chimneys of thatched stone houses smoked with the midday meal-cooking. Sometimes girls and women sat out in the sun at their spinning wheels. Men in rough coats walked in the stone-walled fields checking their sprouting crops amid boys hoeing weeds. The pastures held brown-and-white cattle or black-tailed sheep, usually watched by a boy or two with bows or slings. There were wolves in these forests, and leopards and other things that enjoyed the taste of beef and mutton. Some people shaded their eyes to peer at the passersby, doubtless wondering who these finely dressed folk were who had come to visit the Lady Deirdru. Surely there could be no other reason for their presence, heading toward the manor house and so far from anywhere important. No one seemed agitated or frightened, though, just going about their day's work. Rumors of an army in the region surely would have upset them, and rumors of that sort spread like wildfire. Strange. The Seanchan could not Travel and arrive without news speeding ahead of them. It was very strange.

hi fɛlt lɑɡən ən ði ʌðɝ tu mɛn siz seɪɾɪn, fɪlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð ɪt. lɑɡən hɛld ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz i kəɾ əv hɪmsɛlf, nɛɹɪʃmə ən sændʌmɪɹ sʌmwʌt lɛs. ðeɪ wɝ ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst əmʌŋ ði ʌðɝ æʃəmən, ðoʊ, ən boʊθ hæd bɪn ət dəməaɪz wɛlz. lɑɡən hæd pɹuvən i kəd hændəl hɪmsɛlf ɪn ʌðɝ pleɪsəz, ʌðɝ bæɾəlz. ɪf ðɪs wɑz ə tʃɹæp, ðeɪ wəd bi ɹɛɾi, ən ði ʌðɝ saɪd wəd nɛvɝ noʊ ɪɾ əntɪl tu leɪt. ɹænd dɪd nɑt ɹitʃ fəɹ ðə sɔɹs. hi kəd fil luz θɝɪn lɝkɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd. ðɪs wɑz noʊ taɪm tə ɡɪv ðə mædmæn ə tʃæns tə ɡɛt hoʊld ə ðə paʊɝ.

He felt Logain and the other two men seize saidin, filling themselves with it. Logain held almost as much as he could have himself, Narishma and Sandomere somewhat less. They were the strongest among the other Asha'man, though, and both had been at Dumai's Wells. Logain had proven he could handle himself in other places, other battles. If this was a trap, they would be ready, and the other side would never know it until too late. Rand did not reach for the Source. He could feel Lews Therin lurking in his head. This was no time to give the madman a chance to get hold of the Power.

"kædzueɪn, nɪneɪiv, jud bɛɾɝ ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs naʊ," hi sɛd. "wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊz."

"Cadsuane, Nynaeve, you'd better embrace the Source now," he said. "We're getting close."

"aɪv bɪn hoʊldɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ sɪns bæk ɑn ðət hɪl," nɪneɪiv toʊl hɪm. kædzueɪn snɔɹɾɪd ən ɡeɪv ɪm ə lʊk ðət kɔld ɪm ən ɪɾiət.

"I've been holding saidar since back on that hill," Nynaeve told him. Cadsuane snorted and gave him a look that called him an idiot.

ɹænd stɪld ə ɡɹɪmɑs bɪfɔɹ ɪt kəd bɪɡɪn. hɪz skɪn fɛl noʊ tɪŋɡəlɪŋ, noʊ ɡusbəmps. ðeɪ hæd mæsk ðɛɹ əbɪləɾi, ən wɪð ɪt, ʃildɪɾ ɪm fɹəm sɛnsɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ɪn ðɛm. mɛn hæd hæd fju ædvæntɪdʒɪz oʊvɝ wɪmən wən ɪt keɪm tə tʃænəlɪŋ, bʌt naʊ ðeɪ hæd lɔs ðoʊz fju waɪl wɪmən ɹɪteɪn ɔl ə ðɛɹz. səm ə ði æʃəmən wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʌzəl aʊt haʊ tə dupləkeɪt wʌt nætʃɛl hæd kɹieɪɾəd, tə faɪn ə wiv ðət wəɾ əlaʊ mɛn tə dɪtɛkt wɪmənz wivz, bʌt soʊ fɑɹ wɪθaʊt səksɛs. wɛl, ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi dɛlt wɪð baɪ sʌmwʌn ɛls. hi hæɾ ɔl i kəd mænədʒ ɑn ɪz pleɪɾ ət ðə moʊmənt.

Rand stilled a grimace before it could begin. His skin felt no tingling, no goosebumps. They had masked their ability, and with it, shielded him from sensing the Power in them. Men had had few advantages over women when it came to channeling, but now they had lost those few while women retained all of theirs. Some of the Asha'man were trying to puzzle out how to duplicate what Nacelle had created, to find a weave that would allow men to detect women's weaves, but so far without success. Well, it would have to be dealt with by someone else. He had all he could manage on his plate at the moment.

ðə fɑɹmz kəntɪnjud, səm əloʊn ɪn ə klɪɹɪŋ, ʌðɝz klʌstɝd θɹi əɹ fɔɹ əɹ faɪv təɡɛðɝ. ɪf ðeɪ fɑloʊd ðə ɹoʊd fɑɹ ɪnʌf ðeɪ wəd ɹitʃ ðə vɪlədʒ ə kɪŋz kɹɔsɪŋ ɪn ə fju maɪlz, wɛɹ ə wʊɾən bɹɪdʒ spæn ə nɛɹoʊ ɹɪvɝ kɔl ðə ɹiʃəl, bʌt wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðət ðə ɹoʊd pæs baɪ ə lɑɹdʒ klɪɹɪŋ mɑɹk baɪ ə pɛɹ ə tɔl stoʊn ɡeɪtpoʊsts, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɝ niðɝ ɡeɪts nɔɹ fɛns. ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əɹ mɔɹ bɪɑn ɪt, ət ði ɛn ʌv ə mʌd-slɪkt kleɪ leɪn, leɪ leɪɾi dɪɹdʒɹuz mænɝ, tu stɔɹiz ə θætʃ-ɹuft ɡɹeɪ stoʊn seɪv fɹəm lʊkɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ fɑɹmhaʊs oʊnli baɪ ðə ɡeɪtpoʊsts ən ðə tɔl twɪn dɔɹz ət ðə fɹʌnt. ðə steɪbəlz ən aʊtbɪldɪŋz hæd ðə seɪm pɹæktəkəl əpɪɹəns, stɝɾi ən ənɔɹnəmɛntɪd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ɪn saɪt, noʊ steɪbəlmən, noʊ sɝvən ɑn əɹ weɪ tə fɛtʃ ɛɡz, noʊ mɛn ɪn ðə filz ðət flæŋk ðə leɪn. ðə haʊsəz tɔl tʃɪmniz stʊd smoʊkləs. ɪt dɪd smɛl ʌv ə tʃɹæp. bʌt ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd wɑz kwaɪət, ðə fɑɹmɝz ənɹʌfəld. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə faɪn aʊt.

The farms continued, some alone in a clearing, others clustered three or four or five together. If they followed the road far enough they would reach the village of King's Crossing in a few miles, where a wooden bridge spanned a narrow river called the Reshalle, but well short of that the road passed by a large clearing marked by a pair of tall stone gateposts, though there were neither gates nor fence. A hundred paces or more beyond it, at the end of a mud-slicked clay lane, lay Lady Deirdru's manor, two stories of thatch-roofed gray stone saved from looking a large farmhouse only by the gateposts and the tall twinned doors at the front. The stables and outbuildings had the same practical appearance, sturdy and unornamented. There was no one in sight, no stablemen, no servant on her way to fetch eggs, no men in the fields that flanked the lane. The house's tall chimneys stood smokeless. It did smell of a trap. But the countryside was quiet, the farmers unruffled. There was only one way to find out.

ɹænd tɝn teɪdeɪʃɝ ɪn θɹu ðə ɡeɪtpoʊsts, ən ði ʌðɝz fɑloʊd. mɪn dɪd nɑt hiɾ ɪz wɔɹnɪŋ. ʃi pʊʃt əɹ ɡɹeɪ ɪn bɪtwin teɪdeɪʃɝ ən nɪneɪivz mɛɹ ən ɡɹɪn ət hɪm. ðə bɑn kæɹid nɝvəsnəs, bʌt ðə wʊmən ɡɹɪnd!

Rand turned Tai'daishar in through the gateposts, and the others followed. Min did not heed his warning. She pushed her gray in between Tai'daishar and Nynaeve's mare and grinned at him. The bond carried nervousness, but the woman grinned!

wən i wɑz hæfweɪ tə ðə haʊs, ðə dɔɹz oʊpənd, ən tu wɪmən keɪm aʊt, wʌn ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ, ði ʌðɝ ɪn blu wɪð ɹɛd pænəlz ɑn əɹ bɹɛst ən æŋkəl-lɛŋθ skɝts. sʌnlaɪt ɡlɪntɪɾ ɔf ðə sɪlvɝi liʃ kənɛktɪŋ ðɛm. tu mɔɹ əpɪɹd, ən tu mɔɹ, əntɪl θɹi pɛɹz stʊɾ ɪn ə ɹoʊ tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹ. əz i ɹitʃt ðə θɹi-kɔɹɾɝ pɔɪnt, ənʌðɝ wʊmən stɛpt ɪndə ðə dɔɹweɪ, vɛɹi dɑɹk ən vɛɹi smɔl, dʒɹɛst ɪn pliɾɪd waɪt, hɝ hɛd kʌvɝd baɪ ə tʃɹænspɛɹən skɑɹf ðət fɛl oʊvɝ əɹ feɪs. ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. ʃi hæd bɪn dɪskɹaɪb tə bæʃɪɹ ɹaɪt daʊn tə hɝ ʃeɪvən hɛd. ə tɛnʃən ɪn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz i hæd nɑt bɪn əwɛɹ ə mɛltəd. ðət ʃi wɑz æktʃəli  hɪɹ dɪɾ əweɪ wɪð ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv ə tʃɹæp. ðə sintʃæn wəd nɑt ɹɪsk ði ɛɹ tə ðɛɹ θɹoʊn ɪn ɛniθɪŋ soʊ deɪnʒɝəs. hi dʒɹu ɹeɪn ən dɪsmaʊntɪd.

When he was halfway to the house, the doors opened, and two women came out, one in dark gray, the other in blue with red panels on her breast and ankle-length skirts. Sunlight glinted off the silvery leash connecting them. Two more appeared, and two more, until three pairs stood in a row to either side of the door. As he reached the three-quarter point, another woman stepped into the doorway, very dark and very small, dressed in pleated white, her head covered by a transparent scarf that fell over her face. The Daughter of the Nine Moons. She had been described to Bashere right down to her shaven head. A tension in his shoulders he had not been aware of melted. That she was actually here did away with the possibility of a trap. The Seanchan would not risk the heir to their throne in anything so dangerous. He drew rein and dismounted.

"wʌn ə ðɛm ɪz tʃænəlɪŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd, dʒʌs laʊdli ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə hɪɹ, əz ʃi klaɪm daʊn fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl. "aɪ kæn si ɛniθɪŋ, soʊ ʃiz mæskt əɹ əbɪləɾi ən ɪnvɝɾɪd ðə wiv - ən aɪ wʌndɝ haʊ ðə sintʃæn lɝn ðæt! - bʌt ʃiz tʃænəlɪŋ. oʊnli wʌn; ðəɹ ɪzən ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪt tə bi tu." hɝ tɛɹæŋɡɹil kəd nɑt tɛl wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz seɪɾɪn əɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ biɪŋ tʃænəld, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli tə bi ə mæn.

"One of them is channeling," Nynaeve said, just loudly enough for him to hear, as she climbed down from her saddle. "I can't see anything, so she's masked her ability and inverted the weave - and I wonder how the Seanchan learned that! - but she's channeling. Only one; there isn't enough for it to be two." Her ter'angreal could not tell whether it was saidin or saidar being channeled, but it was unlikely to be a man.

aɪ toʊl jə ɪt wɑz tʃɹæp, luz θɝɪn ɡɹoʊnd. aɪ toʊl ju!

I told you it was trap, Lews Therin groaned. I told you!

ɹænd pɹitɛndəd tə tʃɛk ɪz sæɾəl ɡɝθ. "kæn jə tɛl wɪtʃ wʌn?" hi æskt kwaɪətli. hi stɪl dɪd nɑt ɹitʃ fəɹ seɪɾɪn. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ wʌt luz θɝɪn maɪt də ɪn ðiz sɝkəmstænsəz ɪf i mænədʒ tə ɡɹæb kəntʃɹoʊl əɡɛn. lɑɡən wɑz fɪdlɪŋ wɪð ɪz ɡɝθ, tu, ən nɛɹɪʃmə wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ sændʌmɪɹ tʃɛk wʌn ə ðə dæpəlz hʊvz. ðeɪ hæd hɝd. ðə smɔl wʊmən wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, vɛɹi stɪl bʌt noʊ daʊɾ ɪmpeɪʃən ən laɪkli əfɛndəd baɪ ðɛɹ əpɛɹən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz.

Rand pretended to check his saddle girth. "Can you tell which one?" he asked quietly. He still did not reach for saidin. There was no telling what Lews Therin might do in these circumstances if he managed to grab control again. Logain was fiddling with his girth, too, and Narishma was watching Sandomere check one of the dapple's hooves. They had heard. The small woman was waiting in the doorway, very still but no doubt impatient and likely offended by their apparent interest in their horses.

"noʊ," kædzueɪn ɹɪplaɪd ɡɹɪmli. "bʌɾ aɪ kən də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt. wʌns wɝ kloʊsɝ." hɝ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ɔɹnəməns sweɪɾ əz ʃi tɔst əɹ kloʊk bæk əz ðoʊ ənmæskɪŋ ə sɔɹd.

"No," Cadsuane replied grimly. "But I can do something about it. Once we're closer." Her golden hair ornaments swayed as she tossed her cloak back as though unmasking a sword.

"steɪ bɪhaɪn mi," hi toʊl mɪn, ən tə hɪz ɹɪlif, ʃi nɑɾəd. hɝ feɪs wɔɹ ə smɔl fɹaʊn, ən ðə bɑn kæɹid wɝi. nɑt fɪɹ, ðoʊ. ʃi nu hi wəd pɹətɛk hɝ.

"Stay behind me," he told Min, and to his relief, she nodded. Her face wore a small frown, and the bond carried worry. Not fear, though. She knew he would protect her.

livɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz stændɪŋ, hi stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn wɪð kædzueɪn ən nɪneɪiv ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm. lɑɡən, hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt əz ɪf ðət wɝ ɪz ɹil wɛpən, stʃɹoʊɾ əlɔŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə kædzueɪn, nɛɹɪʃmə ən sændʌmɪɹ bɪɑnd nɪneɪiv. ðə smɔl dɑɹk wʊmən bɪɡæn wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əm sloʊli, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ pliɾɪd skɝts ʌp ɔf ðə dæmp ɡɹaʊnd.

Leaving the horses standing, he started toward the sul'dam and damane with Cadsuane and Nynaeve a little distance to either side of him. Logain, hand resting on his sword hilt as if that were his real weapon, strode along on the other side of Cadsuane, Narishma and Sandomere beyond Nynaeve. The small dark woman began walking toward them slowly, holding her pleated skirts up off the damp ground.

əbɹʌpli, noʊ mɔɹ ðən tɛn peɪsɪz əweɪ, ʃi . . . flɪkɝd. fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ʃi wɑz tɔlɝ ðən moʊs mɛn, ɡɑɹbd ɔl ɪn blæk, sɝpɹaɪz ɑn əɹ feɪs, ən ðoʊ ʃi stɪl wɔɹ ðə veɪl, hɝ hɛd wɑz kʌvɝd wɪð ʃɔɹtkʌt weɪvi blæk hɛɹ. oʊnli ən ɪnstən bɪfɔɹ ðə smɔl wʊmən ɹɪtɝnd, hɝ stɛp fɔltɝɪŋ əz ʃi lɛɾ əɹ waɪt skɝts fɔl, bʌɾ ənʌðɝ flɪkɝ, ən ðə tɔl dɑɹk wʊmən stʊd ðɛɹ, hɝ feɪs twɪstəɾ ɪn fjʊɹi bɪhaɪn ðə veɪl. hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðət feɪs, ðoʊ hi hæd nɛvɝ sin ɪt bɪfɔɹ. luz θɝɪn hæd, ən ðət wɑz ɪnʌf.

Abruptly, no more than ten paces away, she . . . flickered. For an instant, she was taller than most men, garbed all in black, surprise on her face, and though she still wore the veil, her head was covered with shortcut wavy black hair. Only an instant before the small woman returned, her step faltering as she let her white skirts fall, but another flicker, and the tall dark woman stood there, her face twisted in fury behind the veil. He recognized that face, though he had never seen it before. Lews Therin had, and that was enough.

"sɛmɝhɪdʒ," hi sɛɾ ɪn ʃɑk bɪfɔɹ i kəd stɑp ðə wɝd, ən sʌɾənli ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim tə hæpən ət wʌns.

"Semirhage," he said in shock before he could stop the word, and suddenly everything seemed to happen at once.

hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə sɔɹs ən faʊn luz θɝɪn klɔɪŋ fəɹ ɪt, tu, itʃ ə ðɛm dʒɑsəlɪŋ ði ʌðɝ əsaɪd fɹəm ɹitʃɪŋ ɪt. sɛmɝhɪdʒ flɪkt əɹ hænd, ən ə smɔl bɔl ə faɪɝ stʃɹik təwɔɹɾ ɪm fɹəm əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps. ʃi maɪɾ əv ʃaʊɾəd sʌmθɪŋ, ən ɔɹɾɝ. hi kəd nɑt lip əsaɪd; mɪn stʊd ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɪm. fɹæntəkəli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə siz seɪɾɪn, hi flʌŋ ʌp ðə hæn hoʊldɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ ɪn dɛspɝeɪʃən. ðə wɝl sim tə ɪksploʊɾ ɪn faɪɝ.

He reached for the Source and found Lews Therin clawing for it, too, each of them jostling the other aside from reaching it. Semirhage flicked her hand, and a small ball of fire streaked toward him from her fingertips. She might have shouted something, an order. He could not leap aside; Min stood right behind him. Frantically trying to seize saidin, he flung up the hand holding the Dragon Scepter in desperation. The world seemed to explode in fire.

hɪz tʃik wɑz pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə dæmp ɡɹaʊnd, hi ɹilaɪzd. blæk flɛks ʃɪmɝɾ ɪn ɪz vɪʒən, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim feɪnli heɪzi, əz ɪf sin θɹu wɔɾɝ. wɛɹ wɑz hi? wʌt hæd hæpənd? hɪz hɛd fɛl stʌft wɪð wʊl. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz pɹɑɾɪŋ ɪm ɪn ðə ɹɪbz. hɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. ði oʊld wunz wɝ ə hɑɹd nɑɾ ə peɪn dʒʌst əbʌv ðæt. sloʊli, hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ, əɹ wʌt wɑz lɛft ʌv ɪt. ðə spɪɹpɔɪn ən ə fju ɪntʃəz ə tʃɑɹd hæf leɪ θɹi peɪsɪz əweɪ. smɔl, dænsɪŋ fleɪmz wɝ kənsumɪŋ ðə lɔŋ tæsəl. ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz leɪ bɪɑn ɪt.

His cheek was pressed against the damp ground, he realized. Black flecks shimmered in his vision, and everything seemed faintly hazy, as if seen through water. Where was he? What had happened? His head felt stuffed with wool. Something was prodding him in the ribs. His sword hilt. The old wounds were a hard knot of pain just above that. Slowly, he realized he was looking at the Dragon Scepter, or what was left of it. The spearpoint and a few inches of charred haft lay three paces away. Small, dancing flames were consuming the long tassel. The Crown of Swords lay beyond it.

əbɹʌpli ɪt keɪm tə hɪm ðəɾ i kəd fil seɪɾɪn biɪŋ tʃænəld. hɪz skɪn wɑz ɡus bʌmps ɔl oʊvɝ fɹəm seɪaɪdɑɹ biɪŋ wildɪd. ðə mænɝ haʊs. sɛmɝhɪdʒ! hi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ hɪmsɛlf ʌp, ən kəlæpst wɪð ə hɑɹʃ kɹaɪ. sloʊli hi pʊld ə lɛft ɑɹm ðət simd ɔl peɪn ʌp wɛɹ i kəd si hɪz hænd. si wɛɹ ɪz hæn hæd bɪn. oʊnli ə mæŋɡəld, blækən ɹuən ɹɪmeɪnd. ə stʌb stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə kʌf ðət ɡeɪv ɔf θɪn stʃɹimɝz ə smoʊk. bʌt ðə paʊɝ wɑz stɪl biɪŋ tʃænəld ɝaʊn hɪm. hɪz pipəl wɝ faɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ lɪvz. ðeɪ maɪt bi daɪɪŋ. mɪn! hi stʃɹʌɡəl tə ɹaɪz, ən fɛl əɡɛn.

Abruptly it came to him that he could feel saidin being channeled. His skin was goose bumps all over from saidar being wielded. The manor house. Semirhage! He tried to push himself up, and collapsed with a harsh cry. Slowly he pulled a left arm that seemed all pain up where he could see his hand. See where his hand had been. Only a mangled, blackened ruin remained. A stub sticking out of a cuff that gave off thin streamers of smoke. But the Power was still being channeled around him. His people were fighting for their lives. They might be dying. Min! He struggled to rise, and fell again.

əz ðoʊ θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɝ hæd sʌmən hɝ, mɪn wɑz kɹaʊtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ hɪm. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃild ɪm wɪð əɹ bɑɾi, hi ɹilaɪzd. ðə bɑnd wɑz fʊl ə kəmpæʃən ən peɪn. nɑt fɪzɪkəl peɪn. hi wʊɾə noʊn ɪf ʃi hæd ðə smɔləst ɪnʒɝi. ʃi wɑz filɪŋ peɪn fəɹ hɪm. "laɪ stɪl," ʃi sɛd. "juv. . . . juv bɪn hɝt."

As though thinking of her had summoned her, Min was crouching over him. Trying to shield him with her body, he realized. The bond was full of compassion and pain. Not physical pain. He would have known if she had the smallest injury. She was feeling pain for him. "Lie still," she said. "You've. . . . You've been hurt."

"aɪ noʊ," hi sɛd hɔɹsli. əɡɛn, hi ɹitʃt fəɹ seɪɾɪn, ən fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, ðɪs taɪm luz θɝɪn dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə ɪntɝfɪɹ. ðə paʊɝ fɪl hɪm, ən ðət ɡeɪv ɪm ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ tə pʊʃ hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fit wʌn-hændəd, pɹipɛɹɪŋ sɛvɹəl vɛɹi næsti wivz əz i dɪd soʊ. kɛɹləs ə hɪz mʌɾi koʊt, mɪn ɡɹɪpt ɪz ɡʊɾ ɑɹm əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊld ɪm əpɹaɪt. bʌt ðə faɪɾɪŋ wɑz oʊvɝ.

"I know," he said hoarsely. Again, he reached for saidin, and for a wonder, this time Lews Therin did not try to interfere. The Power filled him, and that gave him the strength to push himself to his feet one-handed, preparing several very nasty weaves as he did so. Careless of his muddy coat, Min gripped his good arm as though she were trying to hold him upright. But the fighting was over.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ wɑz stændɪŋ stɪfli wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz əɾ əɹ saɪdz, hɝ skɝts pɹɛst əɡɛnst əɹ lɛɡz, daʊtləs ɹæpt ʌp ɪn floʊz ʌv ɛɹ. ðə hɪlt ʌv wʌn ə mɪnz naɪvz stʊɾ aʊt fɹəm əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ən ʃi mʌst əv bɪn ʃildɪd, tu, bʌɾ əɹ dɑɹk, bjuɾəfəl feɪs wɑz kəntɛmptʃuəs. ʃi hæd bɪn ə pɹɪznɝ bɪfɔɹ, bɹifli, dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ʃi hæɾ ɪskeɪp fɹəm haɪ dɪtɛnʃən baɪ fɹaɪɾənɪŋ əɹ dʒeɪlɝz tə ðə pɔɪn ðət ðeɪ æktʃəli  smʌɡəld əɹ tə fɹiɾəm.

Semirhage was standing stiffly with her arms at her sides, her skirts pressed against her legs, doubtless wrapped up in flows of Air. The hilt of one of Min's knives stood out from her shoulder, and she must have been shielded, too, but her dark, beautiful face was contemptuous. She had been a prisoner before, briefly, during the War of the Shadow. She had escaped from high detention by frightening her jailers to the point that they actually smuggled her to freedom.

ʌðɝz hæd bɪn ɪnʒɝd mɔɹ sɪɹiəsli. ə ʃɔɹt dɑɹk sʌldəm ən tɔl peɪl-hɛɹd deɪmeɪn, lɪŋk baɪ ən æɾəm, leɪ spɹɔld ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə sʌn wɪð ɔlɹɛɾi ɡleɪzd aɪz, ən ənʌðɝ pɛɹ wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ niz ən klɪŋɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ, blʌd ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ feɪsəz ən mæɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛɹ. ði ʌðɝ pɛɹz stʊɾ əz stɪfli əz sɛmɝhɪdʒ, ən i kəd si ðə ʃilz ɑn θɹi ʌv ðə deɪmeɪn. ðeɪ lʊk stʌnd. wʌn ə ðə sʌldəm, ə slɛndɝ, dɑɹk-hɛɹd jʌŋ wʊmən, wɑz wipɪŋ sɔfli. nɛɹɪʃməz feɪs wɑz blʌɾid, tu, ən ɪz koʊɾ əpɪɹd sɪŋʒd. soʊ dɪd sændʌmɪɹz, ən ə boʊn dʒʌɾɪd θɹu hɪz lɛf koʊtsliv, waɪt smɪɹd wɪð ɹɛd, əntɪl nɪneɪiv fɝmli pʊld ɪz ɑɹm stʃɹeɪɾ ən ɡaɪɾəd ðə boʊn bæk ɪndə pleɪs. ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ ɪn peɪn, hi ɡeɪv ə ɡʌɾɝəl ɡɹoʊn. ʃi kʌpt əɹ hænz ɝaʊn ɪz ɑɹm oʊvɝ ðə bɹeɪk, ən moʊməns leɪɾɝ i wɑz flɛksɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm ən muvɪŋ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ən mɝmɝɪŋ θæŋks. lɑɡən əpɪɹɾ əntʌtʃt, əz dɪd nɪneɪiv ən kædzueɪn, hu wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ sɛmɝhɪdʒ ðə weɪ ə bɹaʊn maɪt stʌɾi ən ɪɡzɑɾɪk ænəməl nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ sin.

Others had been injured more seriously. A short dark sul'dam and tall pale-haired damane, linked by an a'dam, lay sprawled on the ground, staring up at the sun with already glazed eyes, and another pair were on their knees and clinging to one another, blood running down their faces and matting their hair.
