The other pairs stood as stiffly as Semirhage, and he could see the shields on three of the damane. They looked stunned. One of the sul'dam, a slender, dark-haired young woman, was weeping softly. Narishma's face was bloodied, too, and his coat appeared singed. So did Sandomere's, and a bone jutted through his left coatsleeve, white smeared with red, until Nynaeve firmly pulled his arm straight and guided the bone back into place. Grimacing in pain, he gave a guttural groan. She cupped her hands around his arm over the break, and moments later he was flexing his arm and moving his fingers and murmuring thanks. Logain appeared untouched, as did Nynaeve and Cadsuane, who was studying Semirhage the way a Brown might study an exotic animal never before seen.

sʌɾənli ɡeɪtweɪz bɪɡæn oʊpənɪŋ ɔl ɝaʊn ðə mænɝ haʊs, spɪlɪŋ aʊt maʊntəɾ æʃəmən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz, veɪl meɪɾənz ən bæʃɪɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ət ðə hɛɾ ə hɪz hɔɹsmən. ən æʃəmən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ə ɹɪŋ ə tu kəd meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ kənsɪɾɝəbli lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðoʊz ɹænd kəɾ əloʊn. soʊ sʌmwʌn hæd mænədʒ tə ɡɪv ðə sɪɡnəl, ə ɹɛd sʌnbɝst ɪn ðə skaɪ. ɛvɹi æʃəmən wɑz fʊl ə seɪɾɪn, ən ɹænd əsum ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ikwəli fʊl ə seɪaɪdɑɹ. ðə meɪɾənz bɪɡæn spɹɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz.

Suddenly gateways began opening all around the manor house, spilling out mounted Asha'man and Aes Sedai and Warders, veiled Maidens and Bashere riding at the head of his horsemen. An Asha'man and Aes Sedai in a ring of two could make a gateway considerably larger than those Rand could alone. So someone had managed to give the signal, a red sunburst in the sky. Every Asha'man was full of saidin, and Rand assumed the Aes Sedai were equally full of saidar. The Maidens began spreading out into the trees.

"ɑɡhæn, hæməd, sɝtʃ ðə haʊs!" bæʃɪɹ ʃaʊɾəd. "mətn, fɔɹm ðə lænsɝz! ðəl bi ɑn əs əz sun əz ðeɪ kæn!" tu soʊlʒɝz θɹʌs ðɛɹ lænsɪz ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊn ən lɛp daʊn tə ɹʌn ɪnsaɪd dʒɹɔɪŋ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz waɪl ði ʌðɝz bɪɡæn ɝeɪɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn tu ɹæŋks.

"Aghan, Hamad, search the house!" Bashere shouted. "Matoun, form the lancers! They'll be on us as soon as they can!" Two soldiers thrust their lances into the ground and leapt down to run inside drawing their swords while the others began arraying themselves in two ranks.

aɪɑkoʊ flʌŋ hɝsɛlf fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl ən ɹʌʃt tə sændʌmɪɹ nɑɾ ivən bɑðɝɪŋ tə hoʊld əɹ skɝts aʊɾ ə ðə mʌd. mɛɹaɪs ɹoʊd tə nɛɹɪʃmə bɪfɔɹ swɪŋɪŋ daʊn ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ən teɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn əɹ hænz wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd. hi dʒɝkt, hɪz bæk ɑɹtʃɪŋ ən nɪɹli pʊlɪŋ ɪz hɛd fɹi, əz ʃi hil hɪm. ʃi hæd lɪɾəl fəsɪlɪɾi wɪð nɪneɪivz mɛθəɾ ə hilɪŋ.

Ayako flung herself from her saddle and rushed to Sandomere not even bothering to hold her skirts out of the mud. Merise rode to Narishma before swinging down right in front of him and taking his head in her hands without a word. He jerked, his back arching and nearly pulling his head free, as she Healed him. She had little facility with Nynaeve's method of Healing.

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə tɝmɔɪl, nɪneɪiv ɡæðɝɾ əɹ skɝts ɪn blʌɾid hænz ən hɝid tə ɹænd. "oʊ, ɹænd," ʃi sɛd wən ʃi sɔ hɪz ɑɹm, "aɪm soʊ sɑɹi. aɪ. . . . əl də wʌɾ aɪ kæn, bʌɾ aɪ kæn fɪks ɪt ðə weɪ ɪt wɑz." hɝ aɪz wɝ fɪld wɪð æŋɡwɪʃ.

Ignoring the turmoil, Nynaeve gathered her skirts in bloodied hands and hurried to Rand. "Oh, Rand," she said when she saw his arm, "I'm so sorry. I. . . . I'll do what I can, but I can't fix it the way it was." Her eyes were filled with anguish.

wɝdləsli, hi hɛld aʊɾ ɪz lɛft ɑɹm. ɪt θɹɑbd wɪð æɡəni. stʃɹeɪnʒli, hi kəd stɪl fil ɪz hænd. ɪt simd i ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə meɪk ə fɪst wɪð ðə fɪŋɡɝz ðət wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðɛɹ. hɪz ɡus bʌmps ɪntɛnsəfaɪɾ əz ʃi dʒɹu mɔɹ dipli ɑn seɪaɪdɑɹ, ðə tɛnʒɹəlz ə smoʊk vænɪʃt fɹəm ɪz kʌf, ən ʃi ɡɹɪpt ɪz ɑɹm əbʌv ðə ɹɪst. hɪz ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹm bɪɡæn tɪŋɡəlɪŋ, ən ðə peɪn dʒɹeɪn əweɪ. sloʊli, blækən skɪn wɑz ɹipleɪs baɪ smuð skɪn ðət sim tə uz daʊn əntɪl ɪt kʌvɝd ðə smɔl lʌmp ðət hæd bɪn ðə beɪs ə hɪz hænd. ɪt wɑz ə mɝækjələs θɪŋ tə si. ðə skɑɹlət-ænd-ɡoʊl skeɪl dʒɹæɡən ɡɹu bæk, tu, əz mʌtʃ əz ɪt kʊd, ɛndɪŋ ɪn ə bɪɾ ə ðə ɡoʊldən meɪn. hi kəd stɪl fil ðə hoʊl hænd.

Wordlessly, he held out his left arm. It throbbed with agony. Strangely, he could still feel his hand. It seemed he should be able to make a fist with the fingers that were no longer there. His goose bumps intensified as she drew more deeply on saidar, the tendrils of smoke vanished from his cuff, and she gripped his arm above the wrist. His entire arm began tingling, and the pain drained away. Slowly, blackened skin was replaced by smooth skin that seemed to ooze down until it covered the small lump that had been the base of his hand. It was a miraculous thing to see. The scarlet-and-gold scaled dragon grew back, too, as much as it could, ending in a bit of the golden mane. He could still feel the whole hand.

"aɪm soʊ sɑɹi," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ əɡɛn. "lɛt mi dɛlv jə fəɹ ɛni ʌðɝ ɪnʒɝiz." ʃi æskt, bʌt dɪd nɑt weɪt, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi ɹitʃt ʌp tə kʌp ɪz hɛd bɪtwin əɹ hænz, ən ə tʃɪl ɹæn θɹu hɪm. "ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð jəɹ aɪz," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə fɹaʊn. "aɪm əfɹeɪd tə tʃɹaɪ fɪksɪŋ ðət wɪθaʊt stʌɾiɪŋ ɑn ɪt. ðə smɔləs mɪsteɪk kəd blaɪn ju. haʊ wɛl kən jə si? haʊ mɛni fɪŋɡɝz æm aɪ hoʊldɪŋ ʌp?"

"I'm so sorry," Nynaeve said again. "Let me delve you for any other injuries." She asked, but did not wait, of course. She reached up to cup his head between her hands, and a chill ran through him. "There's something wrong with your eyes," she said with a frown. "I'm afraid to try fixing that without studying on it. The smallest mistake could blind you. How well can you see? How many fingers am I holding up?"

"tu. aɪ kən si faɪn," hi laɪd. ðə blæk flɛks wɝ ɡɔn, bʌɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ stɪl sim sin θɹu wɔɾɝ, ən i wɑntəd tə skwɪn əɡɛnst ə sʌn ðəɾ əpɪɹd tə ɡlɛɹ tɛn taɪmz bɹaɪɾɝ ðən ɪt hæd. ði oʊld wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd wɝ nɑɾɪd wɪð peɪn.

"Two. I can see fine," he lied. The black flecks were gone, but everything still seemed seen through water, and he wanted to squint against a sun that appeared to glare ten times brighter than it had. The old wounds in his side were knotted with pain.

bæʃɪɹ klaɪm daʊn fɹəm ɪz kɑmpæk beɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ən fɹaʊn ət ðə stʌmp ə hɪz lɛft ɑɹm. ənbəklɪŋ ɪz hɛlmət, hi tʊk ɪɾ ɔf ən hɛld ɪɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm. "æt lis jəɹ əlaɪv," hi sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ. "aɪv sin mɛn hɝt wɝs."

Bashere climbed down from his compact bay in front of him and frowned at the stump of his left arm. Unbuckling his helmet, he took it off and held it under his arm. "At least you're alive," he said gruffly. "I've seen men hurt worse."

"mi, tu," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪl əv tə lɝn ðə sɔɹɾ ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn, ðoʊ." bæʃɪɹ nɑɾəd. moʊs fɔɹmz ɹikwaɪɝd tu hænz. ɹænd bɛn tə pɪk ʌp ðə kɹaʊn ʌv ɪljən, bʌt mɪn ɹilist ɪz ɑɹm ən hɝidli hændəd ðə kɹaʊn tə hɪm. hi sɛɾəld ɪɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd. "aɪl əv tə wɝk aʊt nu weɪz tə də ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

"Me, too," Rand said. "I'll have to learn the sword all over again, though." Bashere nodded. Most forms required two hands. Rand bent to pick up the crown of Illian, but Min released his arm and hurriedly handed the crown to him. He settled it on his head. "I'll have to work out new ways to do everything."

"ju mʌs bi ɪn ʃɑk," nɪneɪiv sɛd sloʊli. "juv dʒʌst sʌfɝɾ ə ɡɹivəs ɪnʒɝi, ɹænd. meɪbi jud bɛɾɝ laɪ daʊn. lɔɹd dævɹæm, hæv wʌn ə jəɹ mɛn bɹɪŋ ə sæɾəl tə pʊɾ ɪz fiɾ ʌp."

"You must be in shock," Nynaeve said slowly. "You've just suffered a grievous injury, Rand. Maybe you'd better lie down. Lord Davram, have one of your men bring a saddle to put his feet up."

"hiz nɑɾ ɪn ʃɑk," mɪn sɛd sædli. ðə bɑnd wɑz fʊl ə sædnəs. ʃi hæd teɪkən hoʊld ə hɪz ɑɹm əz ɪf tə hoʊld ɪm ʌp əɡɛn. "hi lɔst ə hænd, bʌt ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə də əbaʊɾ ɪt, soʊ hiz lɛft ɪt bɪhaɪn ɔlɹɛɾi."

"He's not in shock," Min said sadly. The bond was full of sadness. She had taken hold of his arm as if to hold him up again. "He lost a hand, but there's nothing to do about it, so he's left it behind already."

"wʊl-hɛɾəd ful," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd. hɝ hænd, stɪl smɪɹd wɪð sændʌmɪɹz blʌd, dʒɹɪftəd təwɔɹd ðə θɪk bɹeɪd hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, bʌt ʃi jæŋkt ɪt bæk daʊn. "juv bɪn hɝt bædli. ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt tə ɡɹiv. ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt tə fil stʌnd. ɪts nɔɹməl!"

"Wool-headed fool," Nynaeve muttered. Her hand, still smeared with Sandomere's blood, drifted toward the thick braid hanging over her shoulder, but she yanked it back down. "You've been hurt badly. It's all right to grieve. It's all right to feel stunned. It's normal!"

"aɪ doʊn əv taɪm," hi toʊl hɝ. mɪnz sædnəs θɹɛɾənd tə oʊvɝfloʊ ðə bɑnd. laɪt, hi wɑz ɔl ɹaɪt! waɪ dɪd ʃi fil soʊ sæd?

"I don't have time," he told her. Min's sadness threatened to overflow the bond. Light, he was all right! Why did she feel so sad?

nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd hæf ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ əbaʊt "wʊlhɛd" ən "ful" ən "mæn-stʌbɝn," bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt fɪnɪʃt. "ðoʊz oʊld wunz ɪn jəɹ saɪɾ əv bɹoʊkən oʊpən," ʃi ɔlmoʊst ɡɹaʊld. "ju ɑɹən bliɾɪŋ bædli, bʌt jə ɑɹ bliɾɪŋ. meɪbi aɪ kən faɪnəli də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm."

Nynaeve muttered half under her breath about "woolhead" and "fool" and "man-stubborn," but she was not finished. "Those old wounds in your side have broken open," she almost growled. "You aren't bleeding badly, but you are bleeding. Maybe I can finally do something about them."

bʌɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi tʃɹaɪd - ən ʃi tʃɹaɪd θɹi taɪmz - nʌθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd. hi stɪl fɛl ðə sloʊ tʃɹɪkəl ə blʌd slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɪz ɹɪbz. ðə wunz wɝ stɪl ə θɹɑbɪŋ nɑɾ ə peɪn. faɪnəli, hi pʊʃt əɹ hæn dʒɛnli əweɪ fɹəm ɪz saɪd.

But as hard as she tried - and she tried three times - nothing changed. He still felt the slow trickle of blood sliding down his ribs. The wounds were still a throbbing knot of pain. Finally, he pushed her hand gently away from his side.

"juv dʌn wʌt jə kæn, nɪneɪiv. ɪts ɪnʌf."

"You've done what you can, Nynaeve. It's enough."

"ful." ʃi dɪd ɡɹaʊl, ðɪs taɪm. "haʊ kən ɪt bi ɪnʌf wən jəɹ stɪl bliɾɪŋ?"

"Fool." She did growl, this time. "How can it be enough when you're still bleeding?"

"hu ɪz ðə tɔl wʊmən?" bæʃɪɹ æskt. hi ʌndɝstʊd, ət list. jə dɪd nɑt weɪs taɪm ɑn wʌt kəd nɑt bi mɛndɪd. "ðeɪ dɪdn tʃɹaɪ pæsɪŋ əɹ ɔf əz ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz, dɪd ðeɪ? nɑɾ æftɝ tɛlɪŋ mi ʃi wɑz ə lɪɾəl θɪŋ."

"Who is the tall woman?" Bashere asked. He understood, at least. You did not waste time on what could not be mended. "They didn't try passing her off as the Daughter of the Nine Moons, did they? Not after telling me she was a little thing."

"ðeɪ dɪd," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd, ən ɪkspleɪn bɹifli.

"They did," Rand replied, and explained briefly.

"sɛmɝhɪdʒ?" bæʃɪɹ mʌɾɝd ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "haʊ kən jə bi ʃʊɹ?"

"Semirhage?" Bashere muttered incredulously. "How can you be sure?"

"ʃiz ænæθ dɔɹdʒ, nɑt . . . nɑt wʌt jə kɔl hɝ," ə hʌni-skɪn sʌldəm sɛd laʊdli ɪn ə twɑnʒi dʒɹɔl. hɝ dɑɹk aɪz wɝ tɪltəd, ən əɹ hɛɹ wɑz stʃɹikt wɪð ɡɹeɪ. ʃi lʊk ði ɛldəst ə ðə sʌldəm, ən ðə lis fɹaɪɾənd. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk əfɹeɪd, bʌt ʃi kəntʃɹoʊld ɪt wɛl. "ʃiz ðə haɪ leɪɾiz tʃɹuθspikɝ."

"She's Anath Dorje, not . . . not what you called her," a honey-skinned sul'dam said loudly in a twangy drawl. Her dark eyes were tilted, and her hair was streaked with gray. She looked the eldest of the sul'dam, and the least frightened. It was not that she did not look afraid, but she controlled it well. "She's the High Lady's Truthspeaker."

"bi saɪlənt, fælɛnʒɹ," sɛmɝhɪdʒ sɛd koʊldli, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. hɝ ɡeɪz pɹɑməs peɪn. ðə leɪɾi ʌv peɪn wɑz ɡʊɾ ət dɪlɪvɝɪŋ ɑn əɹ pɹɑməsəz. pɹɪznɝz hæd kɪl ðɛmsɛlvz ɑn lɝnɪŋ ɪt wɑz ʃi hu hɛl ðɛm, mɛn ən wɪmən u mænədʒ tə oʊpən ə veɪn wɪð tiθ əɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz.

"Be silent, Falendre," Semirhage said coldly, looking over her shoulder. Her gaze promised pain. The Lady of Pain was good at delivering on her promises. Prisoners had killed themselves on learning it was she who held them, men and women who managed to open a vein with teeth or fingernails.

fælɛnʒɹ dɪd nɑt sim tə si ɪt, ðoʊ. "ju doʊn kəmæn mi," ʃi sɛd skɔɹnfəli. "jɔɹ nɑɾ ivən sɔɪhɪn."

Falendre did not seem to see it, though. "You don't command me," she said scornfully. "You're not even so'jhin."

"haʊ kən jə bi ʃʊɹ?" kædzueɪn dɪmændəd. ðoʊz ɡoʊldən munz ən stɑɹz, bɝdz ən fɪʃəz, swʌŋ əz ʃi muvd əɹ pɪɹsɪŋ ɡeɪz fɹəm ɹænd tə sɛmɝhɪdʒ ən bæk.

"How can you be sure?" Cadsuane demanded. Those golden moons and stars, birds and fishes, swung as she moved her piercing gaze from Rand to Semirhage and back.

sɛmɝhɪdʒ seɪvd ɪm ði ɛfɝɾ ə θɪŋkɪŋ ʌp ə laɪ. "hiz ɪnseɪn," ʃi sɛd kuli. stændɪŋ ðəɹ stɪf əz ə stætʃu, mɪnz naɪf hɪl stɪl stɪkɪŋ aʊt bɪsaɪɾ əɹ kɑlɝboʊn ən ðə fɹʌn ə hɝ blæk dʒɹɛs ɡlɪsnɪŋ wɪð blʌd, ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ə kwin ɑn əɹ θɹoʊn. "ɡɹeɪndəl kəɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪt bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ. mædnəs wɑz əɹ spɛʃəlti. əl tʃɹaɪ, haʊɛvɝ. jə noʊ ʌv pipəl u hɪɹ vɔɪsəz ɪn ðɛɹ hɛdz? səmtaɪmz, vɛɹi ɹɛɹli, ðə vɔɪsəz ðeɪ hɪɹ ɑɹ ðə vɔɪsəz ə pæs laɪvz. lænfɝ kleɪmd i nu θɪŋz fɹəm əɹ oʊn eɪdʒ, θɪŋz oʊnli luz θɝɪn tɛləmən kəd noʊ. klɪɹli, hiz hɪɹɪŋ luz θɝɪnz vɔɪs. ɪt meɪks noʊ dɪfɝəns ðəɾ ɪz vɔɪs ɪz ɹil, haʊɛvɝ. ɪn fækt, ðət meɪks ɪz sɪtʃueɪʃən wɝs. ivən ɡɹeɪndəl juʒəwəli feɪl tə ətʃiv ɹiɪntəɡɹeɪʃən wɪð sʌmwʌn u hɝɾ ə ɹil vɔɪs. aɪ ʌndɝstæn ðə dɪsɛn ɪndə tɝmənəl mædnəs kən bi . . . əbɹʌpt." hɝ lɪps kɝvd ɪn ə smaɪl ðət nɛvɝ tʌtʃt əɹ dɑɹk aɪz.

Semirhage saved him the effort of thinking up a lie. "He's insane," she said coolly. Standing there stiff as a statue, Min's knife hilt still sticking out beside her collarbone and the front of her black dress glistening with blood, she might have been a queen on her throne. "Graendal could explain it better than I. Madness was her specialty. I will try, however. You know of people who hear voices in their heads? Sometimes, very rarely, the voices they hear are the voices of past lives. Lanfear claimed he knew things from our own Age, things only Lews Therin Telamon could know. Clearly, he is hearing Lews Therin's voice. It makes no difference that his voice is real, however. In fact, that makes his situation worse. Even Graendal usually failed to achieve reintegration with someone who heard a real voice. I understand the descent into terminal madness can be . . . abrupt." Her lips curved in a smile that never touched her dark eyes.

wɝ ðeɪ lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm dɪfɹənli? lɑɡənz feɪs wɑz ə kɑɹv mæsk, ənɹiɾəbəl. bæʃɪɹ lʊkt əz ðoʊ hi stɪl kəd nɑt bɪliv. nɪneɪivz maʊθ hʌŋ oʊpən, ən əɹ aɪz wɝ waɪd. ðə bɑnd. . . . fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, ðə bɑnd wɑz fʊl ʌv . . . nʌmnəs. ɪf mɪn tɝn əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ i kəd stæn ɪt. ɪf ʃi tɝn əweɪ, ɪt wəd bi ðə bɛs θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝl fəɹ hɝ. bʌt kəmpæʃən ən dɪtɝməneɪʃən əz stʃɹɔŋ əz maʊntənz ɹipleɪs nʌmnəs, ən lʌv soʊ bɹaɪɾ i θɔɾ i cʊɾə wɔɹmd ɪz hænz oʊvɝ ɪt. hɝ ɡɹɪp ɑn ɪz ɑɹm taɪɾənd, ən i tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ ə hæn oʊvɝ hɝz. tu leɪt, hi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ən snætʃt ðə nʌb ə hɪz hæn əweɪ, bʌt nɑt bɪfɔɹ ɪt hæd tʌtʃt hɝ. nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðə bɑnd weɪvɝd baɪ ə hɛɹ.

Were they looking at him differently? Logain's face was a carved mask, unreadable. Bashere looked as though he still could not believe. Nynaeve's mouth hung open, and her eyes were wide. The bond. . . . For a long moment, the bond was full of . . . numbness. If Min turned away from him, he did not know whether he could stand it. If she turned away, it would be the best thing in the world for her. But compassion and determination as strong as mountains replaced numbness, and love so bright he thought he could have warmed his hands over it. Her grip on his arm tightened, and he tried to put a hand over hers. Too late, he remembered and snatched the nub of his hand away, but not before it had touched her. Nothing in the bond wavered by a hair.

kædzueɪn muv kloʊsɝ tə ðə tɔlɝ wʊmən ən lʊkt ʌp ət hɝ. feɪsɪŋ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən sim tə feɪz əɹ noʊ mɔɹ ðən feɪsɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn dɪd. "jɔɹ vɛɹi kɑm fəɹ ə pɹɪznɝ. ɹæðɝ ðən dɪnaɪ ðə tʃɑɹdʒ, jə ɡɪv ɛvəɾəns əɡɛns jɝsɛlf."

Cadsuane moved closer to the taller woman and looked up at her. Facing one of the Forsaken seemed to faze her no more than facing the Dragon Reborn did. "You're very calm for a prisoner. Rather than deny the charge, you give evidence against yourself."

sɛmɝhɪdʒ ʃɪftəd ðət koʊl smaɪl fɹəm ɹænd tə kædzueɪn. "waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ dɪnaɪ maɪsɛlf?" pɹaɪd dʒɹɪp fɹəm ɛvɹi wɝd. "aɪ æm sɛmɝhɪdʒ." sʌmwʌn ɡæspt, ən ə nʌmbɝ ə ðə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn stɑɹɾəd tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ ən wipɪŋ. wʌn sʌldəm, ə pɹɪɾi, jɛloʊ-hɛɹd wʊmən, sʌɾənli vɑməɾəd daʊn ðə fɹʌn ə hɝsɛlf, ən ənʌðɝ, stɑki ən dɑɹk, lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi maɪt.

Semirhage shifted that cold smile from Rand to Cadsuane. "Why should I deny myself?" Pride dripped from every word. "I am Semirhage." Someone gasped, and a number of the sul'dam and damane started trembling and weeping. One sul'dam, a pretty, yellow-haired woman, suddenly vomited down the front of herself, and another, stocky and dark, looked as if she might.

kædzueɪn sɪmpli nɑɾəd. "aɪ æm kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn. aɪ lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə lɔŋ tɔks wɪð ju." sɛmɝhɪdʒ snɪɹd. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ lækt kɝədʒ.

Cadsuane simply nodded. "I am Cadsuane Melaidhrin. I look forward to long talks with you." Semirhage sneered. She had never lacked courage.

"wi θɔt ʃi wɑz ðə haɪ leɪɾi," fælɛnʒɹ sɛd hɝidli, ən hɔltɪŋli ət ðə seɪm taɪm. hɝ tiθ sim nɪɹ tə tʃæɾɝɪŋ, bʌt ʃi fɔɹst wɝdz aʊt. "wi θɔt wi wɝ biɪŋ ɑnɝd. ʃi tʊk əs tə ə ɹum ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz ə . . . ə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən wi stɛp θɹu tə ðɪs pleɪs. aɪ swɛɹ ɪɾ ɑn maɪ aɪz! wi θɔt ʃi wɑz ðə haɪ leɪɾi."

"We thought she was the High Lady," Falendre said hurriedly, and haltingly at the same time. Her teeth seemed near to chattering, but she forced words out. "We thought we were being honored. She took us to a room in the Tarasin Palace where there was a . . . a hole in the air, and we stepped through to this place. I swear it on my eyes! We thought she was the High Lady."

"soʊ, noʊ ɑɹmi ɹʌʃɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ʌs," lɑɡən sɛd. jə kəd nɑɾ əv toʊl fɹəm ɪz toʊn wɛðɝ i wɑz ɹɪlivd əɹ dɪsəpɔɪntɪd. hi bɛɹɾ ən ɪntʃ ə hɪz sɔɹɾ ən θɹʌst ɪt bæk ɪndə ɪts skæbɝd hɑɹd. "wʌt də wi də wɪð ðɛm?" hi dʒɝkt ɪz hɛd təwɔɹd ðə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn. "sɛn əm tə keɪɛmlɪn laɪk ði ʌðɝz?"

"So, no army rushing toward us," Logain said. You could not have told from his tone whether he was relieved or disappointed. He bared an inch of his sword and thrust it back into its scabbard hard. "What do we do with them?" He jerked his head toward the sul'dam and damane. "Send them to Caemlyn like the others?"

"wi sɛn əm bæk tə ɛbu dɑɹ," ɹænd sɛd. kædzueɪn tɝn tə stɛɹ ət hɪm. hɝ feɪs wɑz ə pɝfək mæsk ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi, jɛɾ i daʊɾɪd ʃi wɑz ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ sɝin ɪnsaɪd. ðə liʃɪŋ ə deɪmeɪn wɑz ən əbɑməneɪʃən ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ tʊk pɝsənəli. nɪneɪiv wɑz ɛniθɪŋ bʌt sɝin. æŋɡɹi-aɪd, ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪɾ ɪn ə taɪt, blʌd-dɔb fɪst, ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌɾ i spoʊk oʊvɝ hɝ. "aɪ nid ðɪs tʃɹus, nɪneɪiv, ən teɪkɪŋ ðiz wɪmən pɹɪznɝ ɪz noʊ weɪ tə ɡɛt wʌn. doʊn ɑɹɡju. ðæts wʌt ðeɪd kɔl ɪt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə deɪmeɪn, ən jə noʊ ɪɾ əz wɛl əz aɪ du. ðeɪ kən kæɹi wɝd ðəɾ aɪ wɑnə mit ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. ði ɛɹ tə ðə θɹoʊn ɪz ði oʊnli wʌn u kən meɪk ə tʃɹus stænd."

"We send them back to Ebou Dar," Rand said. Cadsuane turned to stare at him. Her face was a perfect mask of Aes Sedai serenity, yet he doubted she was anywhere near serene inside. The leashing of damane was an abomination that Aes Sedai took personally. Nynaeve was anything but serene. Angry-eyed, gripping her braid in a tight, blood-daubed fist, she opened her mouth, but he spoke over her. "I need this truce, Nynaeve, and taking these women prisoner is no way to get one. Don't argue. That's what they'd call it, including the damane, and you know it as well as I do. They can carry word that I want to meet the Daughter of the Nine Moons. The heir to the throne is the only one who can make a truce stand."

"aɪ stɪl doʊn laɪk ɪt," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "wi kəd fɹi ðə deɪmeɪn. ði ʌðɝz wɪl də əz wɛl fəɹ kæɹiɪŋ mɛsədʒəz." ðə deɪmeɪn u hæd nɑt bɪn wipɪŋ bɪfɔɹ bɝst ɪndə tɛɹz. səm ə ðɛm kɹaɪd tə ðə sʌldəm tə seɪv ðɛm. nɪneɪivz feɪs tʊk ɑn sɪkli kæst, bʌt ʃi θɹu ʌp əɹ hænz ən ɡeɪv oʊvɝ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ.

"I still don't like it," she said firmly. "We could free the damane. The others will do as well for carrying messages." The damane who had not been weeping before burst into tears. Some of them cried to the sul'dam to save them. Nynaeve's face took on sickly cast, but she threw up her hands and gave over arguing.

ðə tu soʊlʒɝz bæʃɪɹ hæd sɛn ɪndə ðə haʊs keɪm aʊt, jʌŋ mɛn u wɔkt wɪð ə ɹoʊlɪŋ moʊʃən, mɔɹ əkʌstəm tə sæɾəlz ðən ðɛɹ oʊn fit. hæməd hæɾ ə ləɡʒɝiən blæk bɪɹd ðət fɛl bɪloʊ ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz hɛlməɾ ən ə skɑɹ daʊn ɪz feɪs. ɑɡhæn wɔɹ θɪk mʌstæʃɪz laɪk bæʃɪɹz ən kæɹiɾ ə pleɪn wʊɾən bɑks wɪð noʊ lɪɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm. ðeɪ baʊd tə bæʃɪɹ, fɹi hænz swɪŋɪŋ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz klɪɹ.

The two soldiers Bashere had sent into the house came out, young men who walked with a rolling motion, more accustomed to saddles than their own feet. Hamad had a luxuriant black beard that fell below the edge of his helmet and a scar down his face. Aghan wore thick mustaches like Bashere's and carried a plain wooden box with no lid under his arm. They bowed to Bashere, free hands swinging their swords clear.

"ðə haʊs ɪz ɛmpti, maɪ lɔɹd," ɑɡhæn sɛd, "bʌt ðɛɹz dʒɹaɪd blʌd steɪnɪŋ ðə kɑɹpəts ɪn sɛvɹəl ɹumz. lʊks laɪk ə slɔɾɝ jɑɹd, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ θɪŋk huɛvɝ lɪv hɪɹ ɪz dɛd. ðɪs wɑz sɪɾɪŋ baɪ ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ. ɪt dɪdn lʊk laɪk ɪt bɪlɔŋd, soʊ aɪ bɹɔɾ ɪɾ əlɔŋ." hi hɛld aʊt ðə bɑks fəɹ ɪnspɛkʃən. wɪðɪn leɪ kɔɪld æɾəm ən ə nʌmbɝ ə sɝkləts meɪɾ ə sɛɡmɛntɪd blæk mɛɾəl, səm lɑɹdʒ, səm smɔl.

"The house is empty, my Lord," Aghan said, "but there's dried blood staining the carpets in several rooms. Looks like a slaughter yard, my Lord. I think whoever lived here is dead. This was sitting by the front door. It didn't look like it belonged, so I brought it along." He held out the box for inspection. Within lay coiled a'dam and a number of circlets made of segmented black metal, some large, some small.

ɹænd stɑɹɾəd tə ɹitʃ ɪn wɪð ɪz lɛf hæn bɪfɔɹ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd. mɪn kɑt ðə muvmən ən ɹilist ɪz ɹaɪɾ ɑɹm soʊ hi kəd skup ʌp ə hændfʊl ə ðə blæk mɛɾəl pisəz. nɪneɪiv ɡæspt.

Rand started to reach in with his left hand before he remembered. Min caught the movement and released his right arm so he could scoop up a handful of the black metal pieces. Nynaeve gasped.

"ju noʊ wʌt ðiz ɑɹ?" hi æskt.

"You know what these are?" he asked.

"ðeɪɹ æɾəm fəɹ mɛn," ʃi sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli. "ɛdʒiənɪn sɛd ʃi wɑz gɑnə dʒɹɑp ðə θɪŋ ɪn ði oʊʃən! wi tʃɹʌstɪd hɝ, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ɪt tə sʌmbɑɾi tə kɑpi!"

"They're a'dam for men," she said angrily. "Egeanin said she was going to drop the thing in the ocean! We trusted her, and she gave it to somebody to copy!"

ɹænd dʒɹɑp ðə θɪŋz bæk ɪndə ðə bɑks. ðəɹ wɝ sɪks ə ðə lɑɹdʒɝ sɝkləts, ən faɪv ə ðə sɪlvɝi liʃɪz. sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd bɪn pɹipɛɹd noʊ mæɾɝ u hi bɹɔt wɪð hɪm. "ʃi ɹɪli θɔt ʃi kəd kæptʃɝ ɔl ʌv ʌs." ðət θɔt ʃʊɾə meɪɾ ɪm ʃɪvɝ. hi sim tə fil luz θɝɪn ʃɪvɝ. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə fɔl ɪndə sɛmɝhɪdʒəz hænz.

Rand dropped the things back into the box. There were six of the larger circlets, and five of the silvery leashes. Semirhage had been prepared no matter who he brought with him. "She really thought she could capture all of us." That thought should have made him shiver. He seemed to feel Lews Therin shiver. No one wanted to fall into Semirhage's hands.

"ʃi ʃaʊɾəd fəɹ əm tə ʃild ʌs," nɪneɪiv sɛd, "bʌt ðeɪ kʊdn kəz wi wɝ ɔl hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ɔlɹɛɾi. ɪf wi hædn bɪn, ɪf kædzueɪn ən aɪ hædn hæɾ əɹ tɛɹæŋɡɹil, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt wəɾ əv hæpənd." ʃi dɪd ʃɪvɝ.

"She shouted for them to shield us," Nynaeve said, "but they couldn't because we were all holding the Power already. If we hadn't been, if Cadsuane and I hadn't had our ter'angreal, I don't know what would have happened." She did shiver.

hi lʊkt ət ðə tɔl fɔɹseɪkən, ən ʃi stɛɹd bæk, ʌɾɝli kəmpoʊzd. ʌɾɝli koʊld. hɝ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən əz ə tɔɹtʃɝɝ lum soʊ lɑɹdʒ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz izi tə fɝɡɛt haʊ deɪnʒɝəs ʃi wɑz ʌðɝwaɪz. "taɪ ɔf ðə ʃilz ɑn ði ʌðɝz soʊ ðəl ənɹævəl ɪn ə fju aʊɝz, ən sɛn əm tə sʌmwɛɹ nɪɹ ɛbu dɑɹ." fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi θɔt nɪneɪiv wɑz gɑnə pɹoʊtɛst əɡɛn, bʌt ʃi kəntɛntəd hɝsɛlf wɪð ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ tʌɡ ən tɝnɪŋ əweɪ.

He looked at the tall Forsaken, and she stared back, utterly composed. Utterly cold. Her reputation as a torturer loomed so large that it was easy to forget how dangerous she was otherwise. "Tie off the shields on the others so they'll unravel in a few hours, and send them to somewhere near Ebou Dar." For a moment, he thought Nynaeve was going to protest again, but she contented herself with giving her braid a strong tug and turning away.

"hu ɑɹ jə tə æsk fəɹ ə miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə haɪ leɪɾi?" fælɛnʒɹ dɪmændəd. ʃi ɛmfəsaɪz ðə taɪɾəl fəɹ səm ɹizən.

"Who are you to ask for a meeting with the High Lady?" Falendre demanded. She emphasized the title for some reason.

"maɪ neɪm ɪz ɹænd ælθɹ. ɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn." ɪf ðeɪ hæd wɛpt ət hɪɹɪŋ sɛmɝhɪdʒəz neɪm, ðeɪ weɪld ət hɪɹɪŋ hɪz.

"My name is Rand al'Thor. I'm the Dragon Reborn." If they had wept at hearing Semirhage's name, they wailed at hearing his.

æʃhændʒɹeɪ slæntəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz sæɾəl, mæt sæt pɪps ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz ən weɪɾəd, sɝaʊndəd baɪ tu θaʊzən maʊntəd kɹɔsboʊmən. ðə sʌn wɑz nɑt lɔŋ daʊn, ən ɪvɛns ʃəd bi ɪn moʊʃən. ðə sintʃæn wɝ gɑnə bi hɪt hɑɹd tənaɪɾ ɪn hæf ə dʌzən pleɪsəz. səm smɔl ən səm nɑt soʊ smɔl, bʌt hɑɹɾ ɪn ɛvɹi keɪs. munlaɪt fɪltɝɪŋ θɹu ðə bɹæntʃəz oʊvɝhɛd ɡeɪv dʒʌst ɪnʌf ɪluməneɪʃən fəɹ ɪm tə meɪk aʊt tuɑnz ʃæɾoʊd feɪs. ʃi hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn steɪɪŋ wɪð hɪm, wɪtʃ mɛn sɪlutʃə wɑz əɾ əɹ saɪɾ ɑn əɹ dʌn, ʌv kɔɹs, ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əz juʒəwəl. ðəɹ wɝ nɑɾ ɪnʌf munʃæɾoʊz tə əbskjʊɹ ðæt, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. tuɑn mʌs bi ənhæpi əbaʊt wʌt wɑz tə hæpən tənaɪt, jɛt nʌθɪŋ ʃoʊɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs. wʌt wɑz ʃi θɪŋkɪŋ? hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz ɔl ðə stɝn mædʒəstʃɹeɪt.

Ashandarei slanted across his saddle, Mat sat Pips in the darkness among the trees and waited, surrounded by two thousand mounted crossbowmen. The sun was not long down, and events should be in motion. The Seanchan were going to be hit hard tonight in half a dozen places. Some small and some not so small, but hard in every case. Moonlight filtering through the branches overhead gave just enough illumination for him to make out Tuon's shadowed face. She had insisted on staying with him, which meant Selucia was at her side on her dun, of course, glaring at him as usual. There were not enough moonshadows to obscure that, unfortunately. Tuon must be unhappy about what was to happen tonight, yet nothing showed on her face. What was she thinking? Her expression was all the stern magistrate.

"jɔɹ skim də ɛnteɪl ə ɡʊd dil ə lʌk," tɛslɪn sɛd, nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. ivən ʃæɾoʊd, hɝ feɪs lʊk hɑɹd. ʃi ʃɪftəɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ kloʊk. "ɪt bi tu leɪt tə tʃeɪnʒ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, bʌt ðɪs pɑɹt kən bi əbændən sɝɾənli." hi wʊɾə pɹəfɝd tə hæv bɛθəmən əɹ sɛɾə, niðɝ baʊn baɪ ðə θɹi oʊðz ən boʊθ noʊɪŋ ðə wivz deɪmeɪn juz fəɹ wɛpənz, sʌmθɪŋ ðət hɔɹəfaɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. nɑt ðə wivz; dʒʌs ðət bɛθəmən ən sɛɾə nu ðɛm. ət list, hi θɔɾ i wʊd. laɪlwɪn hæd flætli ɹəfjuz tə faɪɾ ɛni sintʃæn ɪksɛp tə dɪfɛn hɝsɛlf. bɛθəmən ən sɛɾə maɪɾ əv dʌn ðə seɪm, əɹ faʊn ət ðə læs mɪnət ðət ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ ækt əɡɛns ðɛɹ kʌntʃɹimɪn. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd ɹɪdʒɛktɪɾ əlaʊɪŋ ðə tu wɪmən tə bi ɪnvɑlvd, ən niðɝ hæɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ wʌns ðət wɑz sɛd. ðət pɛɹ wɝ tu mik ɝaʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ tə seɪ bu tə ə ɡus.

"Your scheme do entail a good deal of luck," Teslyn said, not for the first time. Even shadowed, her face looked hard. She shifted in her saddle, adjusting her cloak. "It be too late to change everything, but this part can be abandoned certainly." He would have preferred to have Bethamin or Seta, neither bound by the Three Oaths and both knowing the weaves damane used for weapons, something that horrified the Aes Sedai. Not the weaves; just that Bethamin and Seta knew them. At least, he thought he would. Leilwin had flatly refused to fight any Seanchan except to defend herself. Bethamin and Seta might have done the same, or found at the last minute that they could not act against their countrymen. In any case, the Aes Sedai had rejected allowing the two women to be involved, and neither had opened her mouth once that was said. That pair were too meek around Aes Sedai to say boo to a goose.

"ɡɹeɪs feɪvɝ ju, tɛslɪn sədaɪ, bʌt lɔɹd mæt ɪz lʌki," kæptən mændəvwɪn sɛd. ðə stɑki wʌn-aɪd mæn hæd bɪn wɪð ðə bæn sɪns ðə fɝs deɪz ɪn kɛɹhin, ən i hæɾ ɝn ðə ɡɹeɪ stʃɹiks ɪn ɪz hɛɹ, hɪɾən naʊ bɪniθ ɪz ɡɹin-peɪntəd hɛlmət, ən oʊpən-feɪs fʊtmənz hɛlmət, ɪn bæɾəlz əɡɛns tiɹ ən ændɝ bɪfɔɹ ðæt. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ taɪmz wi wɝ aʊtnʌmbɝd, wɪð ɛnəmiz ɑn ɛvɹi saɪd, ən i dæns ðə bæn ɝaʊn ðɛm. nɑt tə slɪp əweɪ, maɪnd, bʌt tə bit ðɛm. bjuɾəfəl bæɾəlz."

"Grace favor you, Teslyn Sedai, but Lord Mat is lucky," Captain Mandevwin said. The stocky one-eyed man had been with the Band since the first days in Cairhien, and he had earned the gray streaks in his hair, hidden now beneath his green-painted helmet, an open-faced footman's helmet, in battles against Tear and Andor before that. "I remember times we were outnumbered, with enemies on every side, and he danced the Band around them. Not to slip away, mind, but to beat them. Beautiful battles."

"ə bjuɾəfəl bæɾəl ɪz wʌn jə doʊn əv tə faɪt," mæt sɛd, mɔɹ ʃɑɹpli ðən i ɪntɛndəd. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk bæɾəlz. jə kəd ɡɛt hoʊlz poʊkt ɪn jə ɪn ə bæɾəl. hi dʒʌs kɛpt ɡɛɾɪŋ kɑɾ ɪn ðɛm, ðət wɑz ɔl. moʊst ə ðət dænsɪŋ ɝaʊn hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə slɪp əweɪ. bʌt ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ slɪpɪŋ əweɪ tənaɪt, əɹ fəɹ mɛni deɪz tə kʌm. "aʊɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪts ɪmpɔɹɾənt, tɛslɪn." wʌt wɑz kipɪŋ ɑlʌdʒɹə, bɝn hɝ? ði ətæk ət ðə səplaɪ kæmp mʌs bi ʌndɝ weɪ ɔlɹɛɾi, dʒʌst stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf ðət ðə soʊlʒɝz dɪfɛndɪŋ ɪt wəd θɪŋk ðeɪ kəd hoʊld əntɪl hɛlp ɝaɪvd, stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk əm ʃʊɹ ðeɪ niɾəd hɛlp. ði ʌðɝz wəd bi fʊl stʃɹɛŋkθ fɹəm ðə stɑɹt, tə oʊvɝwɛlm ðə dɪfɛndɝz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ nu wʌt wɑz ɑn ðɛm. "aɪ min tə blʌɾi ðə sintʃæn, blʌɾi ðɛm soʊ hɑɹɾ ən fæst ən ɔfən ðət ðəɹ ɹiæktɪŋ tə wʌt wɝ duɪŋ ɪnstɛɾ ə meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn plænz." əz sun əz ðə wɝdz lɛft ɪz tʌŋ i wɪʃt i hæd fɹeɪz ðəɾ ənʌðɝ weɪ.

"A beautiful battle is one you don't have to fight," Mat said, more sharply than he intended. He did not like battles. You could get holes poked in you in a battle. He just kept getting caught in them, that was all. Most of that dancing around had been trying to slip away. But there would be no slipping away tonight, or for many days to come. "Our part of it is important, Teslyn." What was keeping Aludra, burn her? The attack at the supply camp must be under way already, just strong enough that the soldiers defending it would think they could hold until help arrived, strong enough to make them sure they needed help. The others would be full strength from the start, to overwhelm the defenders before they knew what was on them. "I mean to bloody the Seanchan, bloody them so hard and fast and often that they're reacting to what we're doing instead of making their own plans." As soon as the words left his tongue he wished he had phrased that another way.

tuɑn lin kloʊs tə sɪlutʃə, ən ðə tɔlɝ wʊmən pʊɾ əɹ skɑɹf-kʌvɝd hɛd daʊn tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ wɪspɝz. ɪt wɑz tu dɑɹk fəɹ ðɛɹ blʌɾi fɪŋɡɝ-tɔk, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt hɪɹ ə wɝd ðeɪ wɝ seɪɪŋ. hi kəɾ ɪmædʒən. ʃi hæd pɹɑməs nɑt tə bɪtʃɹeɪ hɪm, ən ðət hæd tə kʌvɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɪtʃɹeɪ hɪz plænz, jɛt ʃi mʌst wɪʃ ʃi hæd ðət pɹɑməs bæk. hi ʃʊɾə lɛft əɹ wɪð ɹaɪmən əɹ wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz. ðət wʊɾə bɪn seɪfɝ ðən lɛɾɪŋ əɹ steɪ wɪð hɪm. hi kəɾ əv ɪf i hæd taɪɾ əɹ ʌp, hɝ ən sɪlutʃə boʊθ. ən pɹɑbli sɛɾəl əz wɛl. ðət blʌɾi wʊmən stɪl tʊk tuɑnz saɪɾ ɛvɹi taɪm.

Tuon leaned close to Selucia, and the taller woman put her scarf-covered head down to exchange whispers. It was too dark for their bloody finger-talk, but he could not hear a word they were saying. He could imagine. She had promised not to betray him, and that had to cover trying to betray his plans, yet she must wish she had that promise back. He should have left her with Reimon or one of the others. That would have been safer than letting her stay with him. He could have if he had tied her up, her and Selucia both. And probably Setalle as well. That bloody woman still took Tuon's side every time.

mændəvwɪnz beɪ stæmpt ə huf, ən i pæɾəd ði ænəməlz nɛk wɪð ə ɡɔntələɾəd hænd. "ju kænɑt dɪnaɪ ðəɹ ɪz bæɾəl lʌk, wən jə faɪn ə wiknəs ɪn jəɹ ɛnəmiz laɪnz ðət jə nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd, ðət ʃəd nɑt bi ðɛɹ, wən jə faɪn ɪm ɝeɪd tə dɪfɛn əɡɛnst ətæk fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ oʊnli jə ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə saʊθ. bæɾəl lʌk ɹaɪdz ɑn jəɹ ʃoʊldɝ, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ hæv sin ɪt."

Mandevwin's bay stamped a hoof, and he patted the animal's neck with a gauntleted hand. "You cannot deny there is battle luck, when you find a weakness in your enemy's lines that you never expected, that should not be there, when you find him arrayed to defend against attack from the north only you are coming from the south. Battle luck rides on your shoulder, my Lord. I have seen it."

mæt ɡɹʌntɪɾ ən ɹisɛɾəld ɪz hæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. fəɹ ɛvɹi taɪm ə bænɝ ɡɑt lɔst ən blʌndɝɾ ɪndə ə blʌɾi tʃɪŋk ɪn ði ɛnəmiz dɪfɛnsəz, ðəɹ wɝ tɛn wən ɪt dʒʌst wɑz nɑt blʌɾi wɛɹ jə ɪkspɛktəd wən jə blʌɾi wɛl niɾəd ɪt. ðət wɑz ðə tʃɹuθ ə bæɾəl lʌk.

Mat grunted and resettled his hat on his head irritably. For every time a banner got lost and blundered into a bloody chink in the enemy's defenses, there were ten when it just was not bloody where you expected when you bloody well needed it. That was the truth of battle luck.

"wʌn ɡɹin naɪtfloʊɝ," ə mæn kɔl fɹəm əbʌv. "tu! boʊθ ɡɹin!" skɹeɪpɪŋz toʊld ə hɪm klaɪmɪŋ daʊn hɝidli.

"One green nightflower," a man called from above. "Two! Both green!" Scrapings told of him climbing down hurriedly.

mæt hivd ə smɔl saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. ðə ɹeɪkən wɑz əweɪ ən hɛɾəd wɛst. hi hæd kaʊntəɾ ɑn ðət - ðə nɪɹəs lɑɹdʒ bɑɾi ʌv soʊlʒɝz lɔɪəl tə ðə sintʃæn leɪ wɛst - ən ivən tʃiɾəd baɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ əz fɑɹ wɛst əz i dɛɹd. dʒʌs kəz jə wɝ ʃʊɹ jəɹ əpoʊnənt wəd ɹiækt ɪn ə sɝɾən weɪ dɪd nɑt min i wʊd. ɹaɪmən wəd bi oʊvɝɹʌnɪŋ ðə səplaɪ kæmp ɛni mɪnət, smʌðɝɪŋ ðə dɪfɛndɝz wɪð tɛn taɪmz ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ ən sɪkjʊɹɪŋ mʌtʃ-niɾəd pɹəvɪʒənz.

Mat heaved a small sigh of relief. The raken was away and headed west. He had counted on that - the nearest large body of soldiers loyal to the Seanchan lay west - and even cheated by riding as far west as he dared. Just because you were sure your opponent would react in a certain way did not mean he would. Reimon would be overrunning the supply camp any minute, smothering the defenders with ten times their number and securing much-needed provisions.

"ɡoʊ, veɪnɪn," hi sɛd, ən ðə fæt mæn dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪn, sɛndɪŋ ɪz dʌn ɔf ɪndə ðə naɪɾ əɾ ə kæntɝ. hi kəd nɑɾ aʊtpeɪs ðə ɹeɪkən, bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz i bɹɔt wɝɾ ɪn taɪm. . . . "taɪm tə muv, mændəvwɪn."

"Go, Vanin," he said, and the fat man dug his heels in, sending his dun off into the night at a canter. He could not outpace the raken, but so long as he brought word in time. . . . "Time to move, Mandevwin."

ə lin fɛloʊ dʒɹɑp ðə læs dɪstəns fɹəm ə loʊɝ lɪm, kɛɹfəli kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ ə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs ðəɾ i hændəɾ ʌp tə ðə kɛɹhinɪn.

A lean fellow dropped the last distance from a lower limb, carefully cradling a looking glass that he handed up to the Cairhienin.

"ɡɛt maʊntəd, lʌndʒɹeɪd," mændəvwɪn sɛd, stʌfɪŋ ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs ɪndə ðə səlɪnʒɹɪkəl lɛðɝ keɪs taɪd tə hɪz sæɾəl. "ɑnəl, fɔɹm ðə mɛn baɪ fɔɹz."

"Get mounted, Londraed," Mandevwin said, stuffing the looking glass into the cylindrical leather case tied to his saddle. "Connl, form the men by fours."

ə ʃɔɹt ɹaɪd tʊk əm tə ə nɛɹoʊ hɑɹd-pækt ɹoʊd, waɪndɪŋ θɹu loʊ hɪlz, ðət mæt hæɾ əvɔɪɾəd ɝliɝ. ðəɹ wɝ fju fɑɹmz ən fjuɝ vɪlədʒəz ɪn ðɪs ɛɹiə, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə spɹɛd ɹumɝz ə lɑɹdʒ pɑɹɾiz ʌv ɑɹmd mɛn. nɑɾ əntɪl i wɑntəɾ əm tə spɹɛd, ɛniweɪ. naʊ hi niɾəd spid, ən ɹumɝ kəd nɑɾ aʊtʃɹʌn ɪm ɪn tənaɪts bɪznəs. moʊst ə ðə fɑɹmhaʊsəz ðeɪ tʃɹɑɾəd baɪ wɝ dɑɹk ʃeɪps ɪn ðə munlaɪt, læmps ən kændəlz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃt. ðə θʌɾ ə hʊvz ən ðə kɹik ə sæɾəl lɛðɝ wɝ ði oʊnli saʊnz əsaɪd fɹəm ði əkeɪʒənəl θɪn, ɹiɾi kɹaɪ ʌv səm naɪt bɝɾ əɹ ən aʊlz huɾɪŋ, bʌt tu θaʊzən əɹ soʊ hɔɹsəz meɪɾ ə fɛɹ əmaʊn ə nɔɪz. ðeɪ pæs θɹu ə smɔl vɪlədʒ wɛɹ oʊnli ə hændfʊl ə θætʃ-ɹuf haʊsəz ən ðə taɪni stoʊn ɪn ʃoʊɾ ɛni laɪt, bʌt pipəl stʌk ðɛɹ hɛdz aʊɾ ə dɔɹz ən wɪndoʊz tə ɡeɪp. daʊtləs ðeɪ θɔt ðeɪ wɝ siɪŋ soʊlʒɝz lɔɪəl tə ðə sintʃæn. ðəɹ sim tə bi fju ʌv ɛni ʌðɝ kaɪn ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɪn moʊst ʌv ɔltɑɹə. sʌmbɑɾi ɹeɪzd ə tʃɪɹ, bʌɾ i wɑz ə loʊn vɔɪs.

A short ride took them to a narrow hard-packed road, winding through low hills, that Mat had avoided earlier. There were few farms and fewer villages in this area, but he did not want to spread rumors of large parties of armed men. Not until he wanted them to spread, anyway. Now he needed speed, and rumor could not outrun him in tonight's business. Most of the farmhouses they trotted by were dark shapes in the moonlight, lamps and candles already extinguished. The thud of hooves and the creak of saddle leather were the only sounds aside from the occasional thin, reedy cry of some night bird or an owl's hooting, but two thousand or so horses made a fair amount of noise. They passed through a small village where only a handful of thatch-roofed houses and the tiny stone inn showed any light, but people stuck their heads out of doors and windows to gape. Doubtless they thought they were seeing soldiers loyal to the Seanchan. There seemed to be few of any other kind remaining in most of Altara. Somebody raised a cheer, but he was a lone voice.

mæt ɹoʊɾ əlɔŋsaɪd mændəvwɪn wɪð tuɑn ən ði ʌðɝ wɪmən bɪhaɪnd, ən naʊ ən ðən i lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. nɑt tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ. stʃɹeɪnʒ əz ɪt wɑz, hi hæd noʊ daʊt ʃi wəd kip əɹ wɝd nɑt tə ɪskeɪp, ivən naʊ. ən nɑt tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz kipɪŋ ʌp. ðə ɹeɪzɝ hæɾ ən izi stʃɹaɪd, ən ʃi ɹoʊd wɛl. pɪps kəd nɑɾ əv aʊtʃɹʌn əkaɪn hæɾ i tʃɹaɪd. noʊ, hi dʒʌs laɪk lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ, ivən baɪ munlaɪt. meɪbi ɪspɛʃli baɪ munlaɪt. hi hæd tʃɹaɪd kɪsɪŋ əɹ əɡɛn ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ, ən ʃi hæd pʌntʃt ɪm ɪn ðə saɪd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ət fɝst i θɔt ʃi hæd bɹoʊkən wʌn ə hɪz ʃɔɹtʃɹɪbz. bʌt ʃi hæd kɪst ɪm dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd aʊt ðɪs ivnɪŋ. oʊnli wʌns, ən sɛd nɑt tə bi ɡɹiɾi wən i ətɛmptəɾ ə sɛkənd. ðə wʊmən mɛltəɾ ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz waɪl i wɑz kɪsɪŋ hɝ, ən tɝn tə aɪs ðə moʊmənt ʃi stɛp bæk. wʌt wɑz i tə meɪk ə hɝ? ə lɑɹdʒ aʊl pæst oʊvɝhɛd, wɪŋz flæpɪŋ saɪlənli. wəd ʃi si səm oʊmən ɪn ðæt? pɹɑbli.

Mat rode alongside Mandevwin with Tuon and the other women behind, and now and then he looked over his shoulder. Not to make sure she was still there. Strange as it was, he had no doubt she would keep her word not to escape, even now. And not to make sure she was keeping up. The razor had an easy stride, and she rode well. Pips could not have outrun Akein had he tried. No, he just liked looking at her, even by moonlight. Maybe especially by moonlight. He had tried kissing her again the night before, and she had punched him in the side so hard that at first he thought she had broken one of his shortribs. But she had kissed him just before they started out this evening. Only once, and said not to be greedy when he attempted a second. The woman melted in his arms while he was kissing her, and turned to ice the moment she stepped back. What was he to make of her? A large owl passed overhead, wings flapping silently. Would she see some omen in that? Probably.

hi ʃəd nɑt bi spɛndɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ taɪm θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ, nɑt tənaɪt. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi wɑz dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn lʌk tə səm ɪkstɛnt. ðə θɹi θaʊzən lænsɝz veɪnɪn hæd faʊnd, moʊsli ɔltɑɹənz wɪð ə fju sintʃæn, maɪɾ əɹ maɪt nɑt bi ðoʊz mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛl hæd mɑɹkt ɑn ɪz mæp, ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn tu fɑɹ fɹəm wɛɹ i pleɪs ðɛm, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ fəɹ ʃʊɹ ɪn wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən ðeɪ hæd muv sɪns. nɔɹθist, ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli, təwɔɹd ðə mɑlvaɪd nɛɹoʊz, ən ðə moʊlveɪn ɡæp bɪɑnd. ɪt sim ðəɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə læst stʃɹɛtʃ, ðə sintʃæn hæd teɪkən tə əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə luɡɹd ɹoʊd fəɹ muvɪŋ soʊlʒɝz, daʊtləs tə kənsil ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz ən dɛstəneɪʃənz ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi ɹoʊdz. sɝɾən wɑz nɑɾ æbsəlutli ʃʊɹ, haʊɛvɝ. ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt muv tu fɑɹ, ðɪs wɑz ðə ɹoʊd ðeɪ wəd juz tə ɹitʃ ðət səplaɪ kæmp. ɪf. bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ hæd ɹɪɾən fɑɹðɝ ðən i ɪkspɛktəd, ðeɪ maɪt juz ənʌðɝ ɹoʊd. noʊ deɪnʒɝ ðɛɹ; dʒʌst ə weɪstəd naɪt. ðɛɹ kəmændɝ maɪt dɪsaɪd tə kʌt stʃɹeɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə hɪlz, tu. ðət kəd pɹuv næsti ɪf i dɪsaɪɾɪd tə dʒɔɪn ðɪs ɹoʊɾ ət ðə ɹɔŋ pɔɪnt.

He should not be spending so much time thinking about her, not tonight. In truth, he was depending on luck to some extent. The three thousand lancers Vanin had found, mostly Altarans with a few Seanchan, might or might not be those Master Roidelle had marked on his map, though they had not been too far from where he placed them, but there was no telling for sure in which direction they had moved since. Northeast, almost certainly, toward the Malvide Narrows, and the Molvaine Gap beyond. It seemed that except for the last stretch, the Seanchan had taken to avoiding the Lugard Road for moving soldiers, doubtless to conceal their numbers and destinations in the country roads. Certain was not absolutely sure, however. If they had not moved too far, this was the road they would use to reach that supply camp. If. But if they had ridden farther than he expected, they might use another road. No danger there; just a wasted night. Their commander might decide to cut straight across the hills, too. That could prove nasty if he decided to join this road at the wrong point.

əbaʊt fɔɹ maɪlz bɪɑn ðə vɪlədʒ, ðeɪ keɪm tə ə pleɪs wɛɹ tu dʒɛnli sloʊpɪŋ hɪlz flæŋk ðə ɹoʊd, ən i kɔld ə hɔlt. mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛlz oʊn mæps wɝ faɪn, bʌt ðoʊz i hæd fɹəm ʌðɝ mɛn wɝ ðə wɝk ə mæstɝz, tu. ɹɔɪdɛl əkwaɪɝɾ oʊnli ðə bɛst. mæt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɪs spɑɾ əz ɪf i hæd sin ɪt bɪfɔɹ.

About four miles beyond the village, they came to a place where two gently sloping hills flanked the road, and he called a halt. Master Roidelle's own maps were fine, but those he had from other men were the work of masters, too. Roidelle acquired only the best. Mat recognized this spot as if he had seen it before.

mændəvwɪn wild ɪz hɔɹs ɝaʊnd. "ædmɑɝ, eɪndəl, teɪk jəɹ mɛn ʌp ðə nɔɹθ sloʊp. mædwɪn, dɑŋɡəl, ðə saʊθ sloʊp. wʌn mæn ɪn fɔɹ tə hoʊl hɔɹsəz."

Mandevwin wheeled his horse around. "Admar, Eyndel, take your men up the north slope. Madwin, Dongal, the south slope. One man in four to hold horses."

"hɑbəl ðə hɔɹsəz," mæt sɛd, "æn pʊt ðə fidbæɡz ɑn tə stɑp wɪniɪŋ." ðeɪ wɝ feɪsɪŋ lænsɝz. ɪf ɪɾ ɔl tɝn saʊɝ ən ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ɹʌn, ðoʊz lænsɝz wəd ɹaɪɾ əm daʊn laɪk ðeɪ wɝ hʌntɪŋ waɪl pɪɡz. ə kɹɔsboʊ wɑz noʊ ɡʊd fɹəm hɔɹsbæk, ɪspɛʃli ɪf jə wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ. ðeɪ hæd tə wɪn hɪɹ.

"Hobble the horses," Mat said, "and put the feedbags on to stop whinnying." They were facing lancers. If it all turned sour and they tried to run, those lancers would ride them down like they were hunting wild pigs. A crossbow was no good from horseback, especially if you were trying to get away. They had to win here.

ðə kɛɹhinɪn stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ɛni ɪkspɹɛʃən hɪɾən baɪ ðə feɪs-bɑɹz ə hɪz hɛlmət, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt hɛzəteɪt. "hɑbəl ðə hɔɹsəz ən pʊɾ ɑn ðɛɹ noʊzbæɡz," hi ɔɹɾɝd. "ɛvɹi mæn ɑn ðə laɪn."

The Cairhienin stared at him, any expression hidden by the face-bars of his helmet, but he did not hesitate. "Hobble the horses and put on their nosebags," he ordered. "Every man on the line."

"tɛl ɔf səm tə kip wɑtʃ nɔɹθ ən saʊθ," mæt toʊl hɪm. "bæɾəl lʌk kən ɹʌn əɡɛns jə əz izəli əz ɪn jəɹ feɪvɝ." mændəvwɪn nɑɾəd ən ɡeɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ.

"Tell off some to keep watch north and south," Mat told him. "Battle luck can run against you as easily as in your favor." Mandevwin nodded and gave the order.

ðə kɹɔsboʊmən dɪvaɪɾəd ən ɹoʊɾ ʌp ðə θɪnli tʃɹid sloʊps, ðɛɹ dɑɹk koʊts ən dʌl ɡɹin ɑɹmɝ feɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz. bɝnɪʃt ɑɹmɝ wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl fəɹ pɝeɪdz, bʌɾ ɪt kəd ɹəflɛk munlaɪɾ əz wɛl əz sʌnlaɪt. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə tælmɑnz, ðə hɑɹd pɑɹt hæd bɪn kənvɪnsɪŋ ðə lænsɝz tə ɡɪv ʌp ðɛɹ bɹaɪt bɹɛstpleɪts ən ðə noʊbəlz ðɛɹ sɪlvɝɪŋ ən ɡɪldɪŋ. ðə fʊt hæd sin sɛns stʃɹeɪɾ ɔf. fəɹ ə taɪm ðəɹ wɑz ðə ɹʌsəl ə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz muvɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə mʌltʃ, muvɪŋ θɹu bɹʌʃ, bʌt faɪnəli saɪləns fɛl. fɹəm ðə ɹoʊd, mæt kəd nɑɾ əv toʊl ðəɹ wɑz ɛniwʌn ɑn iðɝ sloʊp. naʊ hi dʒʌs hæd tə weɪt.

The crossbowmen divided and rode up the thinly treed slopes, their dark coats and dull green armor fading into the shadows. Burnished armor was all very well for parades, but it could reflect moonlight as well as sunlight. According to Talmanes, the hard part had been convincing the lancers to give up their bright breastplates and the nobles their silvering and gilding. The foot had seen sense straight off. For a time there was the rustle of men and horses moving across the mulch, moving through brush, but finally silence fell. From the road, Mat could not have told there was anyone on either slope. Now he just had to wait.

tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə kɛpt ɪm kʌmpəni, ən soʊ dɪd tɛslɪn. ə ɡʌstɪŋ bɹiz hæd spɹʌŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə wɛs ðət tʌɡd ət kloʊks, bʌɾ ə kɔɹs, ɛɛs sədaɪ kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ sətʃ θɪŋz, ðoʊ tɛslɪn hɛl hɝz ʃʌt. sɪlutʃə lɛt ðə ɡʌsts teɪk əɹ kloʊk wɛɹ ɪt wʊd, ɑdli, bʌt tuɑn tʊk tə hoʊldɪŋ hɝz kloʊzd wɪð wʌn hænd.

Tuon and Selucia kept him company, and so did Teslyn. A gusting breeze had sprung up from the west that tugged at cloaks, but of course, Aes Sedai could ignore such things, though Teslyn held hers shut. Selucia let the gusts take her cloak where it would, oddly, but Tuon took to holding hers closed with one hand.

"ju maɪt bi mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz," hi toʊl hɝ. "ðeɪl kʌt ðə wɪnd."

"You might be more comfortable among the trees," he told her. "They'll cut the wind."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi ʃʊk wɪð saɪlən læftɝ. "aɪm ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ wɑtʃɪŋ jə teɪk jəɹ iz ɑn jəɹ hɪltɑp," ʃi dʒɹɔld.

For a moment, she shook with silent laughter. "I'm enjoying watching you take your ease on your hilltop," she drawled.

mæt blɪŋkt. hɪltɑp? hi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ pɪps ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə blʌɾi ɹoʊd wɪð fleɪmɪŋ ɡʌsts kʌɾɪŋ θɹu hɪz koʊt laɪk wɪntɝ wɑz kʌmɪŋ bæk. wʌt wɑz ʃi tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, hɪltɑp?

Mat blinked. Hilltop? He was sitting Pips in the middle of the bloody road with flaming gusts cutting through his coat like winter was coming back. What was she talking about, hilltop?

"hæv ə kɛɹ wɪð dʒoʊlin," tɛslɪn sɛd, sʌɾənli ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli. "ʃi bi . . . tʃaɪldɪʃ . . . ɪn səm weɪz, ən jə də fæsəneɪɾ əɹ ðə weɪ ə ʃaɪni nu tɔɪ də fæsəneɪɾ ə tʃaɪld. ʃɪl bɑn jə ɪf ʃi kən dɪsaɪd haʊ tə kənvɪns jə tə əɡɹi. pɝhæps ivən ɪf jə də noʊ ɹilaɪz jə bi əɡɹiɪŋ."

"Have a care with Joline," Teslyn said, suddenly and unexpectedly. "She be . . . childish . . . in some ways, and you do fascinate her the way a shiny new toy do fascinate a child. She will bond you if she can decide how to convince you to agree. Perhaps even if you do no realize you be agreeing."

hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə seɪ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ blʌɾi fleɪmɪŋ tʃæns ə ðæt, bʌt tuɑn spoʊk fɝst.

He opened his mouth to say there was no bloody flaming chance of that, but Tuon spoke first.

"ʃi kænɑɾ əv hɪm," ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli. dʒɹɔɪŋ ə bɹɛθ, ʃi wɛn ɑn ɪn əmjuz toʊnz. "tɔɪ bɪlɔŋz tə mi. əntɪl aɪm θɹu pleɪɪŋ wɪð hɪm. bʌɾ ivən ðɛn, aɪ woʊnt ɡɪv ɪm tə ə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn. jə ʌndɝstæn mi, tɛsi? jə tɛl ɹɑsi ðæt. ðæts ðə neɪm aɪ ɪntɛndəd tə ɡɪv hɝ. jə kən tɛl əɹ ðæt, tu."

"She cannot have him," she said sharply. Drawing a breath, she went on in amused tones. "Toy belongs to me. Until I am through playing with him. But even then, I won't give him to a marath'damane. You understand me, Tessi? You tell Rosi that. That's the name I intended to give her. You can tell her that, too."

ðə ʃɑɹp ɡʌsts maɪt nɑɾ əv əfɛktəd tɛslɪn, bʌt ʃi ʃɪvɝɾ ət hɪɹɪŋ əɹ deɪmeɪn neɪm. ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi vænɪʃt əz ɹeɪdʒ kəntɔɹɾəd əɹ feɪs. "wʌɾ aɪ də ʌndɝstænd - !"

The sharp gusts might not have affected Teslyn, but she shivered at hearing her damane name. Aes Sedai serenity vanished as rage contorted her face. "What I do understand - !"

"ɡɪv oʊvɝ!" mæt kʌɾ ɪn. "boʊθ ə ju. aɪm ɪn noʊ mud tə lɪsən tə ðə pɛɹ ə jə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒæb itʃ ʌðɝ wɪð niɾəlz." tɛslɪn stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ɪndɪɡneɪʃən pleɪn ivən baɪ munlaɪt.

"Give over!" Mat cut in. "Both of you. I'm in no mood to listen to the pair of you trying to jab each other with needles." Teslyn stared at him, indignation plain even by moonlight.

"waɪ, tɔɪ," tuɑn sɛd bɹaɪtli, "jɔɹ biɪŋ mæstɝfəl əɡɛn." ʃi lin oʊvɝ tə sɪlutʃə ən wɪspɝd sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪd ðə boʊsəmi wʊmən ɡɪv ə laʊd ɡʌfɔ.

"Why, Toy," Tuon said brightly, "you're being masterful again." She leaned over to Selucia and whispered something that made the bosomy woman give a loud guffaw.

hʌntʃɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən pʊlɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn hɪm, hi lin ɑn ðə haɪ pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl ən wɑtʃt ðə naɪt fəɹ veɪnɪn. wɪmən! hi wəd ɡɪv ʌp ɔl ə hɪz lʌk - wɛl, hæf - ɪf i kəɾ ʌndɝstænd wɪmən.

Hunching his shoulders and pulling his cloak around him, he leaned on the high pommel of his saddle and watched the night for Vanin. Women! He would give up all of his luck - well, half - if he could understand women.

"wʌt dʒju θɪŋk jə kən ətʃiv wɪð ɹeɪdz ən æmbʊʃɪz?" tɛslɪn sɛd, əɡɛn nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. "ðə sintʃæn wɪl oʊnli sɛn ɪnʌf soʊlʒɝz tə hʌn jə daʊn." ʃi ən dʒoʊlin hæd kɛp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɪk ðɛɹ noʊzɪz ɪndə hɪz plænɪŋ, ən soʊ hæɾ idɛzinə tə ə lɛsɝ ɪkstɛnt, əntɪl i tʃeɪst əm əweɪ. ɛɛs sədaɪ θɔt ðeɪ nu ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ən waɪl dʒoʊlin ət lis dɪd noʊ sʌmθɪŋ ʌv wɔɹ, hi hæd nɑt niɾəd ædvaɪs. ɛɛs sədaɪ ædvaɪs saʊndəɾ ən ɑfəl lɑt laɪk tɛlɪŋ jə wʌt tə du. ðɪs taɪm, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ænsɝ hɝ.

"What do you think you can achieve with raids and ambushes?" Teslyn said, again not for the first time. "The Seanchan will only send enough soldiers to hunt you down." She and Joline had kept trying to stick their noses into his planning, and so had Edesina to a lesser extent, until he chased them away. Aes Sedai thought they knew everything, and while Joline at least did know something of war, he had not needed advice. Aes Sedai advice sounded an awful lot like telling you what to do. This time, he decided to answer her.

"aɪm kaʊntɪŋ ɑn əm sɛndɪŋ mɔɹ soʊlʒɝz, tɛslɪn," hi sɛd, stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ veɪnɪn. "ðə hoʊl ɑɹmi ðeɪv ɪn ðə moʊlveɪn ɡæp, ɪn fækt. ɪnʌf ʌv ɪt, ɛniweɪ. ðəɹ mɔɹ laɪkli tə juz ðət ðən ɛni ʌðɝ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ tɑm ən dʒulɪn pɪkt ʌp sɛz ðɛɹ bɪɡ pʊʃ ɪz eɪmd əɾ ɪljən. aɪ θɪŋk ði ɑɹmi ɪn ðə ɡæp ɪz tə ɡɑɹɾ əɡɛnst ɛniθɪŋ kʌmɪŋ əɾ əm aʊɾ ə mʊɹændi əɹ ændɝ. bʌt ðəɹ ðə stɑpɝ ɪn ðə dʒɑɹ fəɹ ʌs. aɪ min tə pʊl ðət stɑpɝ aʊt soʊ wi kən pæs θɹu."

"I'm counting on them sending more soldiers, Teslyn," he said, still watching for Vanin. "The whole army they have in the Molvaine Gap, in fact. Enough of it, anyway. They're more likely to use that than any other. Everything Thom and Juilin picked up says their big push is aimed at Illian. I think the army in the Gap is to guard against anything coming at them out of Murandy or Andor. But they're the stopper in the jar for us. I mean to pull that stopper out so we can pass through."

æftɝ sɛvɹəl mɪnəts ə saɪləns, hi lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðə θɹi wɪmən wɝ dʒʌst sɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ən wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. hi wɪʃt i hæɾ ɪnʌf laɪt tə meɪk aʊt ðɛɹ ɪkspɹɛʃənz. waɪ wɝ ðeɪ blʌɾi stɛɹɪŋ? hi sɛɾəld bæk tə lʊkɪŋ fəɹ veɪnɪn, jɛɾ ɪt simd i kəd fil ðɛɹ aɪz ɑn ɪz bæk.

After several minutes of silence, he looked over his shoulder. The three women were just sitting their horses and watching him. He wished he had enough light to make out their expressions. Why were they bloody staring? He settled back to looking for Vanin, yet it seemed he could feel their eyes on his back.

pɝhæps tu aʊɝz baɪ ðə ʃɪftɪŋ ə ðə fæt kɹɛsən mun wɛn baɪ, wɪð ðə wɪn sloʊli pɪkɪŋ ʌp stʃɹɛŋkθ. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə teɪk ðə naɪt bɪɑn kul ɪndə koʊld. piɹiɑɾɪkəli hi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ðə wɪmən teɪk ʃɛltɝ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, bʌt ðeɪ ɹɪzɪstɪd stʌbɝnli. hi hæd tə ɹɪmeɪn, tə kætʃ veɪnɪn wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ tə ʃaʊt - ðə lænsɝz wəd bi kloʊs bɪhaɪn ðə mæn; pɝhæps vɛɹi kloʊs ɪf ðɛɹ kəmændɝ wɑz ə ful - bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt. hi səspɛktəd ðət tɛslɪn ɹəfjuz kəz tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə dɪd. ðət meɪd noʊ sɛns, bʌt ðəɹ ɪt wɑz. əz fəɹ waɪ tuɑn ɹəfjuzd, hi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛɾ ənlɛs ɪt wɑz kəz ʃi laɪk tə lɪsən tə hɪm ɑɹɡjuɪŋ hɪmsɛlf hɔɹs.

Perhaps two hours by the shifting of the fat crescent moon went by, with the wind slowly picking up strength. It was enough to take the night beyond cool into cold. Periodically he tried to make the women take shelter among the trees, but they resisted stubbornly. He had to remain, to catch Vanin without having to shout - the lancers would be close behind the man; perhaps very close if their commander was a fool - but they did not. He suspected that Teslyn refused because Tuon and Selucia did. That made no sense, but there it was. As for why Tuon refused, he could not have said unless it was because she liked to listen to him arguing himself hoarse.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðə wɪn bɹɔt ðə saʊn ʌv ə ɹʌnɪŋ hɔɹs, ən i sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl. veɪnɪnz dʌn kæntɝɾ aʊɾ ə ðə naɪt, ðə bʌlki mæn əz ɔlweɪz ən ɪmpɹɑbəbəl saɪɾ ɪn ə sæɾəl.

Eventually the wind brought the sound of a running horse, and he sat up straight in his saddle. Vanin's dun cantered out of the night, the bulky man as always an improbable sight in a saddle.

veɪnɪn dʒɹu ɹeɪn ən spæt θɹu ə ɡæp ɪn ɪz tiθ. "ðeɪɹ ə maɪl əɹ soʊ bɪhaɪn mi, bʌt ðɛɹz meɪbi ə θaʊzən mɔɹ ðən ðəɹ wɑz ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. huɛvɝz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ noʊz ɪz bɪznəs. ðəɹ pʊʃɪŋ hɑɹd wɪθaʊt bloʊɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz."

Vanin drew rein and spat through a gap in his teeth. "They're a mile or so behind me, but there's maybe a thousand more than there was this morning. Whoever's in charge knows his business. They're pushing hard without blowing their horses."

"ɪf jə bi aʊtnʌmbɝd tu tə wʌn," tɛslɪn sɛd, "pɝhæps jəl ɹikənsɪɾɝ - "

"If you be outnumbered two to one," Teslyn said, "perhaps you will reconsider - "

"aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə ɡɪv əm ə stænd-ʌp faɪt," mæt bɹoʊk ɪn. "æn aɪ kæn əfɔɹd tə liv fɔɹ θaʊzən lænsɝz lus tə meɪk tʃɹʌbəl fəɹ mi. lɛts dʒɔɪn mændəvwɪn."

"I don't intend to give them a stand-up fight," Mat broke in. "And I can't afford to leave four thousand lancers loose to make trouble for me. Let's join Mandevwin."

ðə nilɪŋ kɹɔsboʊmən ɑn ðə sloʊp ə ðə nɔɹðɝn hɪl meɪd noʊ saʊnd wən i ɹoʊd θɹu ðɛɹ laɪn wɪð ðə wɪmən ən veɪnɪn, dʒʌst ʃʌfəld əsaɪd tə lɛɾ əm θɹu. hi wʊɾə pɹəfɝɾ ət lis tu ɹæŋks, bʌɾ i niɾəd tə kʌvɝ ə waɪd fɹʌnt. ðə spɑɹs tʃɹiz dɪd kʌt ðə wɪnd, bʌt nɑt baɪ mʌtʃ, ən moʊst ə ðə mɛn wɝ hʌɾəld ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks. stɪl, ɛvɹi kɹɔsboʊ hi kəd si wɑz dʒɹɔn, wɪð ə boʊlt ɪn pleɪs. mændəvwɪn hæd sin veɪnɪn ɝaɪv ən nu wʌɾ ɪt mɛnt.

The kneeling crossbowmen on the slope of the northern hill made no sound when he rode through their line with the women and Vanin, just shuffled aside to let them through. He would have preferred at least two ranks, but he needed to cover a wide front. The sparse trees did cut the wind, but not by much, and most of the men were huddled in their cloaks. Still, every crossbow he could see was drawn, with a bolt in place. Mandevwin had seen Vanin arrive and knew what it meant.

ðə kɛɹhinɪn wɑz peɪsɪŋ dʒʌs bɪhaɪn ðə laɪn əntɪl mæt əpɪɹɾ ən swʌŋ daʊn fɹəm pɪps. mændəvwɪn wɑz ɹɪliv tə hɪɹ ðəɾ i noʊ lɔŋɡɝ niɾəd tə kip ə wɑtʃ tə hɪz ɹɪɹ. hi mɪɹli nɑɾəd θɔtfəli ət hɪɹɪŋ ʌv ə θaʊzən mɔɹ lænsɝz ðən ɪkspɛktəɾ ən sɛn ə mæn ɹeɪsɪŋ ɔf tə bɹɪŋ ðə wɑtʃɝz daʊn fɹəm ðə kɹɛs tə teɪk ðɛɹ pleɪsəz ɪn ðə laɪn. ɪf mæt kɔθən tʊk ɪɾ ɪn stʃɹaɪd, soʊ wəd hi. mæt hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðəɾ əbaʊt ðə bænd. ðeɪ tʃɹʌstɪɾ ɪm æbsəlutli. wʌns, ðət hæɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ɪm bɹeɪk aʊɾ ɪn ə ɹæʃ. tənaɪt, hi wɑz ɡlæɾ ʌv ɪt.

The Cairhienin was pacing just behind the line until Mat appeared and swung down from Pips. Mandevwin was relieved to hear that he no longer needed to keep a watch to his rear. He merely nodded thoughtfully at hearing of a thousand more lancers than expected and sent a man racing off to bring the watchers down from the crest to take their places in the line. If Mat Cauthon took it in stride, so would he. Mat had forgotten that about the Band. They trusted him absolutely. Once, that had almost made him break out in a rash. Tonight, he was glad of it.

ən aʊl huɾɪd twaɪs, sʌmwɛɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən tuɑn saɪd.

An owl hooted twice, somewhere behind him, and Tuon sighed.

"ɪz ðəɹ ən oʊmən ɪn ðæt?" hi æskt, dʒʌs fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə seɪ.

"Is there an omen in that?" he asked, just for something to say.

"aɪm ɡlæd jə ɑɹ faɪnəli teɪkɪŋ ən ɪntʃɹəst, tɔɪ. pɝhæps əl bi eɪbəl tə ɛdʒəkeɪt jə jɛt." hɝ aɪz wɝ lɪkwəɾ ɪn ðə munlaɪt. "æn aʊl huɾɪŋ twaɪs minz sʌmwʌn wɪl daɪ sun." wɛl, ðət pʊɾ ə blʌɾi ɛn tə kɑnvɝseɪʃən.

"I'm glad you are finally taking an interest, Toy. Perhaps I will be able to educate you yet." Her eyes were liquid in the moonlight. "An owl hooting twice means someone will die soon." Well, that put a bloody end to conversation.

sun ɪnʌf, ðə sintʃæn əpɪɹd, fɔɹ əbɹɛst ən liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz əɾ ə tʃɹɑt, lænsɪz ɪn hænd. veɪnɪn hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ kəmændɝ noʊɪŋ ɪz dʒɑb. kæntɝd fəɹ ə taɪm ðən lɛɾ əɾ ə tʃɹɑt, hɔɹsəz kəd kʌvɝ ə lɑɾ ʌv ɡɹaʊn kwɪkli. fulz tʃɹaɪd tə ɡæləp lɔŋ dɪstənsəz ən ɛndəd wɪð dɛɾ əɹ kɹɪpəl hɔɹsəz. oʊnli ðə fɝs fɔɹɾi əɹ soʊ wɔɹ ðə sɛɡmɛntɪɾ ɑɹmɝ ən stʃɹeɪnʒ hɛlməts ə sintʃæn. ə pɪɾi, ðæt. hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə haʊ ðə sintʃæn wəd fil əbaʊt kæʒəwəltiz tə ðɛɹ ɔltɑɹən ælaɪz. lɔsəz tə ðɛɹ oʊn wəd kætʃ noʊɾəs, ðoʊ.

Soon enough, the Seanchan appeared, four abreast and leading their horses at a trot, lances in hand. Vanin had been right about their commander knowing his job. Cantered for a time then led at a trot, horses could cover a lot of ground quickly. Fools tried to gallop long distances and ended with dead or crippled horses. Only the first forty or so wore the segmented armor and strange helmets of Seanchan. A pity, that. He had no idea how the Seanchan would feel about casualties to their Altaran allies. Losses to their own would catch notice, though.

wən ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kɑləm wɑz ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ə dip vɔɪs ɑn ðə ɹoʊd sʌɾənli ʃaʊɾəd, "bænɝ! hɔlt!" ðoʊz tu wɝdz kæɹid ðə fəmɪljɝ slɝd dʒɹɔl ə ðə sintʃæn. ðə mɛn ɪn sɛɡmɛntɪɾ ɑɹmɝ stɑpt ʃɑɹpli. ði ʌðɝz stʃɹæɡəl tə ə hɔlt.

When the middle of the column was right in front of him, a deep voice on the road suddenly shouted, "Banner! Halt!" Those two words carried the familiar slurred drawl of the Seanchan. The men in segmented armor stopped sharply. The others straggled to a halt.

mæt dʒɹu bɹɛθ. naʊ ðət hæd tə bi tɑvɝən wɝk. ðeɪ kəd hɑɹdli hæv bɪn bɛɾɝ pleɪst ɪf i hæd ɡɪvən ði ɔɹɾɝ hɪmsɛlf. hi ɹɛstəɾ ə hæn ɑn tɛslɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. ʃi flɪntʃt slaɪtli, bʌɾ i niɾəd tə ɡɛɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən kwaɪətli.

Mat drew breath. Now that had to be ta'veren work. They could hardly have been better placed if he had given the order himself. He rested a hand on Teslyn's shoulder. She flinched slightly, but he needed to get her attention quietly.

"bænɝ!" ðə dip vɔɪs ʃaʊɾəd. "maʊnt!" bɪloʊ, soʊlʒɝz muv tə oʊbeɪ.

"Banner!" the deep voice shouted. "Mount!" Below, soldiers moved to obey.

"naʊ," mæt sɛd kwaɪətli.

"Now," Mat said quietly.

ðə fɑkshɛd wɛn koʊld ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, ən sʌɾənli ə bɔl ə ɹɛd laɪt wɑz floʊɾɪŋ haɪ əbʌv ðə ɹoʊd, beɪðɪŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz bɪloʊ ɪn ən ənɝθli ɡloʊ. ðeɪ hæɾ oʊnli ə hɑɹtbit tə ɡeɪp. əlɔŋ ðə laɪn bɪloʊ mæt, ə θaʊzən kɹɔsboʊ stʃɹɪŋz ɡeɪv wʌt saʊndəd laɪk wʌn laʊd snæp, ən ə θaʊzən boʊls stʃɹikt ɪndə ðə fɔɹmeɪʃən, pʌntʃɪŋ θɹu bɹɛstpleɪts ət ðət ʃɔɹt ɹeɪnʒ, nɑkɪŋ mɛn fɹəm ðɛɹ fit, sɛndɪŋ hɔɹsəz ɹɪɹɪŋ ən skɹimɪŋ, dʒʌst əz ə θaʊzən mɔɹ stʃɹʌk fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪd. nɑɾ ɛvɹi ʃɑt stʃɹʌk skwɛɹli, bʌt ðət hɑɹdli mæɾɝd wɪð ə hɛvi kɹɔsboʊ. mɛn wɛn daʊn wɪð ʃæɾɝd lɛɡz, wɪð lɛɡz ɹɪp hæf ɔf. mɛn klʌtʃt ət ðə stʌmps ə ɹuən ɑɹmz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɛm ðə floʊ ʌv blʌd. mɛn skɹimd əz laʊdli əz ðə hɔɹsəz.

The foxhead went cold on his chest, and suddenly a ball of red light was floating high above the road, bathing the soldiers below in an unearthly glow. They had only a heartbeat to gape. Along the line below Mat, a thousand crossbow strings gave what sounded like one loud snap, and a thousand bolts streaked into the formation, punching through breastplates at that short range, knocking men from their feet, sending horses rearing and screaming, just as a thousand more struck from the other side. Not every shot struck squarely, but that hardly mattered with a heavy crossbow. Men went down with shattered legs, with legs ripped half off. Men clutched at the stumps of ruined arms trying to stem the flow of blood. Men screamed as loudly as the horses.

hi wɑtʃt ə kɹɔsbaʊmən nɪɹbaɪ əz ðə fɛloʊ bɛn tə fæsən ðə pɛɹd hʊks ə ðə bʌlki, bɑkslaɪk kɹæŋk, hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ə stʃɹæp ət ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz bɛlt, tə hɪz kɹɔsboʊ stʃɹɪŋ. əz ðə mæn stʃɹeɪɾənd, ðə kɔɹd stʃɹimd aʊɾ ə ðə kɹæŋk, bʌt wʌns i wɑz ɪɹɛkt, hi sɛt ðə kɹæŋk ɑn ðə bʌɾ ə ði ʌpɛndəd kɹɔsboʊ, muvd ə smɔl lɛvɝ ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɑks, ən bɪɡæn tə wɝk ðə hændəlz. θɹi kwɪk tɝnz wɪð ə ɹʌf wɝɪŋ saʊnd, ən ðə stʃɹɪŋ kɑɾ ɑn ðə lætʃ.

He watched a crossbowman nearby as the fellow bent to fasten the paired hooks of the bulky, boxlike crank, hanging from a strap at the front of his belt, to his crossbow string. As the man straightened, the cord streamed out of the crank, but once he was erect, he set the crank on the butt of the upended crossbow, moved a small lever on the side of the box, and began to work the handles. Three quick turns with a rough whirring sound, and the string caught on the latch.

"ɪntu ðə tʃɹiz!" ðə dip vɔɪs ʃaʊɾəd. "kloʊs wɪð əm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kən ɹiloʊd! muv!"

"Into the trees!" the deep voice shouted. "Close with them before they can reload! Move!"

səm tʃɹaɪd tə maʊnt, tə ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ði ətæk, ən ʌðɝz dʒɹɑpt ɹeɪnz ən lænsɪz tə dʒɹɔ sɔɹdz. nʌn meɪɾ ɪɾ əz fɑɹ əz ðə tʃɹiz. tu θaʊzən mɔɹ boʊls slæʃt ɪndə ðɛm, kʌɾɪŋ mɛn daʊn, pʌntʃɪŋ θɹu mɛn tə kɪl mɛn bɪhaɪn əɹ tɑpəl hɔɹsəz. ɑn ðə hɪlsaɪd, mɛn bɪɡæn wɝkɪŋ ðɛɹ kɹæŋks fjʊɹiəsli, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid. ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, ə hɔɹs kɪk fibli hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ. ði oʊnli mɛn muvɪŋ wɝ fɹæntəkəli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə juz wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ hæd tə hæn fəɹ tʃɹnikɪts tə kip fɹəm bliɾɪŋ tə dɛθ. ðə wɪn bɹɔt ðə saʊn ə ɹʌnɪŋ hɔɹsəz. səm maɪɾ əv ɹaɪɾɝz. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɔɹ ʃaʊts fɹəm ðə dip vɔɪs.

Some tried to mount, to ride into the attack, and others dropped reins and lances to draw swords. None made it as far as the trees. Two thousand more bolts slashed into them, cutting men down, punching through men to kill men behind or topple horses. On the hillside, men began working their cranks furiously, but there was no need. On the road, a horse kicked feebly here and there. The only men moving were frantically trying to use whatever they had to hand for tourniquets to keep from bleeding to death. The wind brought the sound of running horses. Some might have riders. There were no more shouts from the deep voice.

"mændəvwɪn," mæt ʃaʊɾəd, "wɝ dʌn hɪɹ. maʊn ðə mɛn. wɪv pleɪsəz tə bi."

"Mandevwin," Mat shouted, "we're done here. Mount the men. We have places to be."

"ju mʌst steɪ tə ɔfɝ eɪd," tɛslɪn sɛd fɝmli. "ðə ɹulz ʌv wɔɹ də dɪmæn ɪt."

"You must stay to offer aid," Teslyn said firmly. "The rules of war do demand it."

"ðɪs ɪz ə nu kaɪndə wɔɹ," hi toʊld əɹ hɑɹʃli. laɪt, ɪt wɑz saɪlən ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, bʌɾ i kəd stɪl hɪɹ ðə skɹimɪŋ. "ðeɪl əv tə weɪt fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn tə ɡɪv əm eɪd."

"This is a new kind of war," he told her harshly. Light, it was silent on the road, but he could still hear the screaming. "They'll have to wait for their own to give them aid."

tuɑn mɝmɝd sʌmθɪŋ hæf ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. hi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz, "ə laɪən kən əv noʊ mɝsi," bʌt ðət wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs.

Tuon murmured something half under her breath. He thought it was, "A lion can have no mercy," but that was ridiculous.

ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz mɛn, hi lɛɾ əm daʊn ðə nɔɹθ saɪɾ ə ðə hɪl. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə lɛt ðə sɝvaɪvɝz si haʊ mɛni ðeɪ wɝ. ɪn ə fju aʊɝz ðeɪ wəd dʒɔɪn ʌp wɪð ðə mɛn fɹəm ði ʌðɝ hɪl, ən ɪn ə fju aʊɝz mɔɹ, wɪð kɑɹləmɪn. bɪfɔɹ sʌnɹaɪz ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə hɪt ðə sintʃæn əɡɛn. hi ɪntɛndəd tə meɪk əm ɹʌn tə pʊl ðət blʌɾi stɑpɝ fəɹ hɪm.

Gathering his men, he led them down the north side of the hill. There was no need to let the survivors see how many they were. In a few hours they would join up with the men from the other hill, and in a few hours more, with Carlomin. Before sunrise they were going to hit the Seanchan again. He intended to make them run to pull that bloody stopper for him.

tʃæptɝ twɛntieɪt

CHAPTER 28

ɪn mɔldən dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ fɝs laɪt, feɪl wɑz fæsənɪŋ ðə waɪd bɛlt ʌv ɡoʊldən lɪŋks ɝaʊn əɹ weɪs fəɹ ðə læs taɪm wən dɛɹeɪn ɛntɝd ðə smɔl, ɔlɹɛɾi kɹaʊɾəd pik tɛnt wɛɹ ðeɪ ɔl slɛpt. aʊtsaɪd, ðə skaɪ wəd bi stɑɹɾɪŋ tə tɝn ɡɹeɪ, bʌɾ ɪnsaɪd, ɪt maɪt stɪl əv bɪn naɪt. feɪlz aɪz hæɾ ədæptəd tə ðə dɑɹknəs, ðoʊ. ðə slɛndɝ lɪɾəl wʊmən wɪð blæk hɛɹ ðət spɪl tə hɝ weɪst ɪn weɪvz wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ jɔnz. ʃi hæd stʊd dʒʌs bɪloʊ ðə haɪ siɾ ə hɝ haʊs ɪn kɛɹhin, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn wækən ɪn ðə naɪt kəz sɪvænə kəd nɑt slip ən wɑntəd tə bi ɹɛd tə. sɪvænə ɛndʒɔɪd dɛɹeɪnz vɔɪs, ən laɪkli ðə teɪlz ʃi kæɹiɾ ə səpoʊz mɪsdidz əmʌŋ sɪvænəz ɡeɪʃeɪn. ðə kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən wɑz nɛvɝ tʃoʊzən aʊɾ əz wʌn ə ðoʊz u hæd feɪl tə pliz. hɝ hænz wɛn tə hɝ ɡoʊldən kɑlɝ, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd wən ʃi tʊk ɪn feɪl, æliændɝ ən meɪaɪɡdɪn, ɔlɹɛɾi dʒɹɛst ən ɑn ðɛɹ fit.

In Malden Just before first light, Faile was fastening the wide belt of golden links around her waist for the last time when Dairaine entered the small, already crowded peaked tent where they all slept. Outside, the sky would be starting to turn gray, but inside, it might still have been night. Faile's eyes had adapted to the darkness, though. The slender little woman with black hair that spilled to her waist in waves was frowning around her yawns. She had stood just below the High Seat of her House in Cairhien, but she had been wakened in the night because Sevanna could not sleep and wanted to be read to. Sevanna enjoyed Dairaine's voice, and likely the tales she carried of supposed misdeeds among Sevanna's gai'shain. The Cairhienin woman was never chosen out as one of those who had failed to please. Her hands went to her golden collar, then hesitated when she took in Faile, Alliandre and Maighdin, already dressed and on their feet.

"aɪ fɝɡɑt tə pʊt ðə bʊk bæk ɪn ðə pɹɑpɝ pleɪs," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk kɹɪstəl tʃaɪmz, tɝnɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd ðə tɛntflæp. "sɪvænə wɪl əv mi biɾən ɪf ʃi siz ɪɾ aʊɾ ə pleɪs wən ʃi weɪks."

"I forgot to put the book back in the proper place," she said in a voice like crystal chimes, turning back toward the tentflap. "Sevanna will have me beaten if she sees it out of place when she wakes."

"ʃiz laɪɪŋ," meɪaɪɡdɪn ɡɹaʊld, ən dɛɹeɪn dɑɹɾɪd fəɹ aʊtsaɪd.

"She's lying," Maighdin growled, and Dairaine darted for outside.

ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə kənvɪns feɪl. ʃi ɡɹæb ðə wʊmənz kaʊl ən hɔld əɹ bæk ɪndə ðə tɛnt. dɛɹeɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə skɹim, bʌɾ æliændɝ klæpt əɹ hæn oʊvɝ ɪt, ən ðə θɹi ʌv əm ɹɛsəl ðə wʊmən tə ðə blæŋkət-stʃɹun ɡɹaʊnd-klɔθ. ɪt tʊk ɔl θɹi. dɛɹeɪn wɑz smɔl, bʌt ʃi ɹɪθ laɪk ə sneɪk, tʃɹaɪd tə klɔ ət ðɛm, tə baɪt. waɪl ði ʌðɝ tu hɛl ðə wʊmən daʊn, feɪl pɹədus ðə sɛkənd naɪf ʃi hæd sɪkjʊɹd, ə kwaɪt sɝvəsəbəl dæɡɝ wɪð ə ɹɪdʒ stil hɪlt ən ə bleɪd lɔŋɡɝ ðən əɹ hænd, ən bɪɡæn slaɪsɪŋ stʃɹɪps fɹəm wʌn ə ðə blæŋkəts.

That was enough to convince Faile. She grabbed the woman's cowl and hauled her back into the tent. Dairaine opened her mouth to scream, but Alliandre clapped her hand over it, and the three of them wrestled the woman to the blanket-strewn ground-cloth. It took all three. Dairaine was small, but she writhed like a snake, tried to claw at them, to bite. While the other two held the woman down, Faile produced the second knife she had secured, a quite serviceable dagger with a ridged steel hilt and a blade longer than her hand, and began slicing strips from one of the blankets.

"haʊ dɪd jə noʊ?" æliændɝ sɛd, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə kənteɪn wʌn ə dɛɹeɪnz ɑɹmz waɪl kipɪŋ əɹ maʊθ kʌvɝd wɪθaʊt biɪŋ bɪɾən. meɪaɪɡdɪn hæd teɪkən kɛɹ ə ðə wʊmənz lɛɡz baɪ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn əm ən hæɾ əɹ ʌðɝ ɑɹm twɪstəd tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz. dɛɹeɪn stɪl mænədʒ tə twɪst, ɪf jusləsli.

"How did you know?" Alliandre said, struggling to contain one of Dairaine's arms while keeping her mouth covered without being bitten. Maighdin had taken care of the woman's legs by sitting on them and had her other arm twisted to her shoulder blades. Dairaine still managed to twist, if uselessly.

"ʃi wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ, bʌt wən ʃi spoʊk, hɝ feɪs wɛn smuð. aɪ kəd dʒʌs meɪk ɪɾ aʊt. ɪf ʃi wɝ ɹɪli wɝiɾ əbaʊt biɪŋ biɾən, ʃiɾ əv fɹaʊn hɑɹɾɝ, nɑt stɑpt." ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən wɑz nɑɾ ə vɛɹi skɪld leɪɾiz meɪd, jɛt ʃi wɑz ə vɛɹi əbzɝvənt wʌn.

"She was frowning, but when she spoke, her face went smooth. I could just make it out. If she were really worried about being beaten, she'd have frowned harder, not stopped." The golden-haired woman was not a very skilled lady's maid, yet she was a very observant one.

"bʌt wʌt meɪɾ əɹ səspɪʃəs?"

"But what made her suspicious?"

meɪaɪɡdɪn ʃɹʌɡd. "meɪbi wʌn ʌv əs lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd, əɹ ɡɪlti. ðoʊ aɪ kæn seɪ haʊ ʃi cʊɾə noʊɾəst wɪθaʊɾ ɛni laɪt."

Maighdin shrugged. "Maybe one of us looked surprised, or guilty. Though I can't say how she could have noticed without any light."

sun ɪnʌf ðeɪ hæd dɛɹeɪn tʃɹʌst ʌp wɪð əɹ æŋkəlz ən ɹɪsts taɪd təɡɛðɝ bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk. ʃi wəd nɑt ɹɪɡəl fɑɹ laɪk ðæt. ə wɑɾəd lɛŋθ tɔɹn fɹəm əɹ ʃɪft ən taɪɾ ɪn pleɪs wɪð ənʌðɝ pis ə blæŋkət sɝv fəɹ ə ɡæɡ ðət lɛɾ əɹ ɪmɪɾ oʊnli ɡɹʌns. ʃi twɪstəɾ əɹ hɛd tə ɡlɛɹ ʌp ət ðɛm. feɪl kəd nɑt si hɝ feɪs vɛɹi wɛl, bʌt ðə wʊmənz ɪkspɹɛʃən hæd tə bi iðɝ ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɹ pliɾɪŋ, ən dɛɹeɪn oʊnli pliɾəd wɪð ʃeɪɾoʊ. ʃi juzd əɹ pəzɪʃən əz wʌn ə sɪvænəz ɡeɪʃeɪn tə bʊli ɡeɪʃeɪn u wɝ nɑt, ən əɹ teɪl-kæɹiɪŋ tə bʊli ðoʊz u wɝ. ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɑz, ðeɪ kəd nɑt liv əɹ hɪɹ. sʌmwʌn maɪt kʌm əɾ ɛni moʊmən tə sʌmən wʌn ə ðɛm tə sɝv sɪvænə.

Soon enough they had Dairaine trussed up with her ankles and wrists tied together behind her back. She would not wriggle far like that. A wadded length torn from her shift and tied in place with another piece of blanket served for a gag that let her emit only grunts. She twisted her head to glare up at them. Faile could not see her face very well, but the woman's expression had to be either glaring or pleading, and Dairaine only pleaded with Shaido. She used her position as one of Sevanna's gai'shain to bully gai'shain who were not, and her tale-carrying to bully those who were. The trouble was, they could not leave her here. Someone might come at any moment to summon one of them to serve Sevanna.

"wi kən kɪl əɹ ən haɪd ðə bɑɾi," æliændɝ sədʒɛstəd, smuðɪŋ əɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ. ɪt hæd bɪkʌm dɪsɹeɪɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹʌɡəl.

"We can kill her and hide the body," Alliandre suggested, smoothing her long hair. It had become disarrayed in the struggle.

"wɛɹ?" meɪaɪɡdɪn sɛd, koʊmɪŋ əɹ oʊn sʌn-ɡoʊl hɛɹ wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn ə leɪɾiz meɪd spikɪŋ tə ə kwin. pɹɪznɝz wɝ ikwəlz ɪn ðɛɹ kæptɪvəɾi əɹ ɛls ðeɪ eɪɾəd ðɛɹ kæptɝz. ɪt hæd teɪkən taɪm tə titʃ æliændɝ ðæt. "ɪɾ əz tə bi sʌmwɛɹ ʃi woʊn bi faʊn fəɹ ət list ə deɪ. sɪvænə maɪt sɛn mɛn æftɝ ɡəlinə tə bɹɪŋ əs bæk ɪf wɝ səspɛktəɾ ə kɪlɪŋ wʌn ə hɝ bɪlɔŋɪŋz." ʃi vɛstəd ðət wɝd wɪð ɔl ðə skɔɹn ɪt wəd bɛɹ. "æn aɪ doʊn tʃɹʌst ɡəlinə nɑt tə lɛɾ əm bɹɪŋ əs bæk." dɛɹeɪn bɪɡæn stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ əɡɛnst əɹ bɑnz əɡɛn ən ɡɹʌntɪŋ hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ. meɪbi ʃi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə pliɾ æftɝ ɔl.

"Where?" Maighdin said, combing her own sun-gold hair with her fingers. She did not sound a lady's maid speaking to a queen. Prisoners were equals in their captivity or else they aided their captors. It had taken time to teach Alliandre that. "It has to be somewhere she won't be found for at least a day. Sevanna might send men after Galina to bring us back if we're suspected of killing one of her belongings." She vested that word with all the scorn it would bear. "And I don't trust Galina not to let them bring us back." Dairaine began struggling against her bonds again and grunting harder than ever. Maybe she had decided to plead after all.

"wi ɑɹən gɑnə kɪl hɝ," feɪl toʊl ðɛm. ʃi wɑz biɪŋ niðɝ skwimɪʃ nɔɹ mɝsɪfəl. ðəɹ sɪmpli wɑz noʊwɛɹ ðeɪ kəd bi ʃʊɹ ə bɑɾi wəd ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən lɔŋ ɪnʌf, nɑt ðət ðeɪ kəd ɹitʃ wɪθaʊt biɪŋ sin. "aɪm əfɹeɪɾ əɹ plænz əv tʃeɪnʒd ə lɪɾəl. weɪt hɪɹ."

"We aren't going to kill her," Faile told them. She was being neither squeamish nor merciful. There simply was nowhere they could be sure a body would remain hidden long enough, not that they could reach without being seen. "I'm afraid our plans have changed a little. Wait here."

dʌkɪŋ aʊtsaɪd, wɛɹ ðə skaɪ wɑz ɪndid bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə pɝl, ʃi faʊnd wʌt hæd meɪd dɛɹeɪn səspɪʃəs. beɪn ən kiæd wɝ ðəɹ ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪn waɪt ɹoʊbz əz ɪkspɛktəd, tə ɛskɔɹɾ əm əz fɑɹ əz ðə miɾɪŋ pleɪs. ɹoʊlən ən ɪz fɹɛnz maɪt nɑt bi dʌn bɹɛkfæstɪŋ jɛt - ʃi hoʊp ðeɪ wɝ nɑt; ðeɪ maɪt də sʌmθɪŋ fulɪʃ ən ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ - ən beɪn ən kiæd hæd vɑləntɪɹd tə daɪvɝɾ ɛni mɛn u tʃɹaɪd tə ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð ðɛm. ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk hɝsɛlf æsk haʊ ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd tə də ðæt. səm sækɹəfaɪsɪz dɪzɝvd ə veɪl ə sikɹəsi. ən ɔl ʌv ə hɑɹts ɡɹæɾətud. tu ɡeɪʃeɪn hoʊldɪŋ wɪkɝ bæskəts wɝ nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹaʊs səspɪʃən ɪn ðə kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən, bʌt θɝɾi əɹ fɔɹɾi ɡeɪʃeɪn wɝ, kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə nɛɹoʊ mʌɾi leɪn θɹu ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn tɛns. ɝɑvinz plʌmp pleɪn feɪs wɑtʃt əɹ fɹəm ə waɪt kaʊl, ən lusɑɹəz bjuɾəfəl wʌn. ælvən wɑz ðəɹ wɪð ɪz sʌn θɛɝɪl ɪn ðɛɹ ɹoʊbz ə mʌɾi tɛntklɔθ, ən əlɛniə, ə plʌmp ɑmɑdɪʃən sɪlvɝsmɪθ ɪn dɝɾi kɔɹs waɪt lɪnən, ən dɔɹmɪn, ə stɑki kɛɹhinɪn butmeɪkɝ, ən kɔɹvɪlə, ə lin wivɝ fɹəm ɹaɪt hɪɹ ɪn ɔltɑɹə, ænd. . . . ðeɪ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd nɑɾ ə tɛnθ pɑɹɾ ə ðoʊz u hæd swɔɹn tə hɝ, bʌɾ ə ɡæðɝɪŋ ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn ðɪs lɑɹdʒ wʊɾə plæntəd səspɪʃən ɪn ə stoʊn. ət list wən æɾəd tə ðə θɹi ʌv əm biɪŋ dʒɹɛst. dɛɹeɪn laɪkli hæd hɝɾ u hæd bɪn sʌmən tə sɪvænə ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. haʊ hæd ðeɪ lɝnd ʃi wɑz livɪŋ tədeɪ? ɪt wɑz tu leɪt tə wɝi əbaʊt ðæt. ɪf ɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ nu, ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl əv bɪn dʒɹæɡd fɹəm ðə tɛn bɪfɔɹ ðɪs.

Ducking outside, where the sky was indeed beginning to pearl, she found what had made Dairaine suspicious. Bain and Chiad were there in their plain white robes as expected, to escort them as far as the meeting place. Rolan and his friends might not be done breakfasting yet - she hoped they were not; they might do something foolish and ruin everything - and Bain and Chiad had volunteered to divert any men who tried to interfere with them. She had not been able to make herself ask how they intended to do that. Some sacrifices deserved a veil of secrecy. And all of a heart's gratitude. Two gai'shain holding wicker baskets were not enough to rouse suspicion in the Cairhienin woman, but thirty or forty gai'shain were, crowding the narrow muddy lane through the gai'shain tents. Aravine's plump plain face watched her from a white cowl, and Lusara's beautiful one. Alvon was there with his son Theril in their robes of muddy tentcloth, and Alainia, a plump Amadician silversmith in dirty coarse white linen, and Dormin, a stocky Cairhienin bootmaker, and Corvila, a lean weaver from right here in Altara, and. . . . They represented not a tenth part of those who had sworn to her, but a gathering of gai'shain this large would have planted suspicion in a stone. At least when added to the three of them being dressed. Dairaine likely had heard who had been summoned to Sevanna this morning. How had they learned she was leaving today? It was too late to worry about that. If any Shaido knew, they would all have been dragged from the tent before this.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

"What are you doing here?" she demanded.

"wi wɑntəd tə si jə ɡoʊ, maɪ leɪɾi," θɛɝɪl sɛɾ ɪn ɪz ɹʌf, bɛɹli ɪntɛlədʒəbəl æksɛns. "wi wɝ vɛɹi kɛɹfəl tə kʌm baɪ wʌnz ən tuz." lusɑɹə nɑɾəd hæpəli, ən ʃi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn.

"We wanted to see you go, my Lady," Theril said in his rough, barely intelligible accents. "We were very careful to come by ones and twos." Lusara nodded happily, and she was not the only one.

"wɛl, wi kən seɪ ɡʊd-baɪ naʊ," feɪl sɛd fɝmli. noʊ nid tə tɛl əm haʊ kloʊs ðeɪ hæd kʌm tə ɹuɪnɪŋ ði ɪskeɪp. "əntɪl aɪ kʌm bæk fəɹ ju." ɪf əɹ fɑðɝ wəd nɑt ɡɪv əɹ ən ɑɹmi, ðən pɛɹɪn wʊd. hɪz fɹɛndʃɪp wɪð ɹænd ælθɹ wəd pɹəvaɪɾ ɪt. laɪt, wɛɹ wɑz hi? noʊ! ʃi hæd tə bi ɡlæɾ i hæd nɑt kɑɾ ʌp jɛt, hæd nɑt ɡɑɾən hɪmsɛlf kɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə snik ɪndə ðə kæmp ən ɹɛskju hɝ. ʃi hæd tə bi ɡlæd, ən nɑt θɪŋk ʌv wʌt maɪt bi dɪleɪɪŋ hɪm. "naʊ ɡoʊ bɪfɔɹ sʌmwʌn siz jə hɪɹ ən ɹʌnz tə tɛl teɪlz. ən doʊn tɔk tə ɛniwʌn əbaʊt ðɪs." hɝ ædhɪɹəns wɝ seɪf ɪnʌf, ʌðɝwaɪz ʃi wəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bi tʃeɪnd, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni laɪk dɛɹeɪn əmʌŋ ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn, ən nɑɾ oʊnli əmʌŋ ðə lɔŋ-hɛl kɛɹhinɪn. səm pipəl nætʃɹəli sɛt tə lɪkɪŋ ɹɪsts wɛɹɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ.

"Well, we can say good-bye now," Faile said firmly. No need to tell them how close they had come to ruining the escape. "Until I come back for you." If her father would not give her an army, then Perrin would. His friendship with Rand al'Thor would provide it. Light, where was he? No! She had to be glad he had not caught up yet, had not gotten himself killed trying to sneak into the camp and rescue her. She had to be glad, and not think of what might be delaying him. "Now go before someone sees you here and runs to tell tales. And don't talk to anyone about this." Her adherents were safe enough, otherwise she would already be chained, but there were too many like Dairaine among the gai'shain, and not only among the long-held Cairhienin. Some people naturally set to licking wrists wherever they were.

ðeɪ baʊɾ əɹ kɝtsiɾ əɹ nʌkəl ðɛɹ fɔɹhɛdz, dʒʌst əz ɪf noʊbɑdi maɪt bi poʊkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz aʊt tə si, ən skæɾɝd ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən wɪð ʃəɡɹɪn ɪkspɹɛʃənz. ðeɪ ɹɪli hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə wɑtʃ əɹ liv! ʃi hæd noʊ taɪm tə fɹɪɾɝ əweɪ ɑn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən. hɝiɪŋ tə beɪn ən kiæd, ʃi heɪstəli ɪkspleɪn ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛnt.

They bowed or curtsied or knuckled their foreheads, just as if nobody might be poking their heads out to see, and scattered in every direction with chagrined expressions. They really had expected to watch her leave! She had no time to fritter away on exasperation. Hurrying to Bain and Chiad, she hastily explained the situation inside the tent.

ðeɪ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wən ʃi fɪnɪʃt ən pʊt daʊn ðə bæskəts tə fɹi fɪŋɡɝz fəɹ meɪɾən hæntɔk. ʃi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət ðɛɹ hænz, sɪns ðeɪ pleɪnli wɑntəd pɹaɪvəsi. nɑt ðət ʃi cʊɾə ʌndɝstʊd mʌtʃ ɪn ɛni keɪs. ðɛɹ hænz muvd vɛɹi fæst. fleɪm-hɛɹd beɪn wɪð əɹ dɑɹk blu aɪz stʊd nɪɹli hæf ə hæn tɔlɝ ðən ʃi, ɡɹeɪ-aɪd kiæd dʒʌst ə fɪŋɡɝ tɔlɝ. ðeɪ wɝ əɹ kloʊs fɹɛnz, bʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ədɑptəɾ itʃ ʌðɝ əz fɝst-sɪstɝz, ən ðət kɹieɪɾəd bɑnz kloʊsɝ ðən ɛni fɹɛndʃɪp.

They exchanged glances when she finished and put down the baskets to free fingers for Maiden handtalk. She avoided looking at their hands, since they plainly wanted privacy. Not that she could have understood much in any case. Their hands moved very fast. Flame-haired Bain with her dark blue eyes stood nearly half a hand taller than she, gray-eyed Chiad just a finger taller. They were her close friends, but they had adopted each other as first-sisters, and that created bonds closer than any friendship.

"wi wɪl teɪk kɛɹ ə dɛɹeɪn seɪɡən," kiæd sɛɾ ət læst. "bʌɾ ɪt minz jə mʌst ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə taʊn əloʊn."

"We will take care of Dairaine Saighan," Chiad said at last. "But it means you must go into the town alone."

feɪl saɪd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɛlpɪŋ ɪt. pɝhæps ɹoʊlən wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi əweɪk. hi kəd bi wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ ðət mɪnət. hi ɔlweɪz sim tə əpɪɹ aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ wən ʃi niɾəd hɪm. ʃʊɹli hi wəd nɑɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð əɹ livɪŋ, nɑt wən i hæd pɹɑməs tə teɪk əɹ wən i hɪmsɛlf lɛft. jɛɾ i stɪl hæd hoʊps, soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi wɔɹ waɪt. hɪm ən ɪz kɪsɪŋ ɡeɪmz! hi maɪt wɑnə kip əɹ ɪn ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. wən mɛn wɑntəd tə hɛlp, ðeɪ ɔlweɪz θɔt ðɛɹ weɪ wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ.

Faile sighed, but there was no helping it. Perhaps Rolan was already awake. He could be watching her that minute. He always seemed to appear out of nowhere when she needed him. Surely he would not interfere with her leaving, not when he had promised to take her when he himself left. Yet he still had hopes, so long as she wore white. Him and his kissing games! He might want to keep her in gai'shain robes a little longer. When men wanted to help, they always thought their way was the only way.

beɪn ən kiæd dʌkt ɪndə ðə smɔl pik tɛnt, ən æliændɝ ən meɪaɪɡdɪn keɪm aʊt. ðəɹ ɹɪli wɑz nɑt ɹum ɪnsaɪd fəɹ faɪv. meɪaɪɡdɪn wɛn ɝaʊn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə tɛn ən ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ə bæskət laɪk ðoʊz ði ʌðɝ wɪmən hæd bɪn kæɹiɪŋ. dɝɾi ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz bʌlʒd aʊɾ ə ðə tɑp ʌv itʃ, meɪkɪŋ əm əpɪɹ loʊdz ə lɔnʒɹi, bʌt bɪniθ wɝ dʒɹɛsəz ðət keɪm nɪɹ ɪnʌf fɪɾɪŋ, ə hætʃət, ə slɪŋ, kɔɹdz fəɹ meɪkɪŋ snɛɹz, flɪn ən stil, pækɪts ə flaʊɝ, mil, dʒɹaɪd binz, sɔlt ən jist, ə fju kɔɪnz ðeɪ hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə faɪnd, ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ wəd nid tə meɪk ðɛɹ weɪ wɛs tə faɪn pɛɹɪn. ɡəlinə wəd teɪk əm aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ seɪɪŋ wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən əɹ "ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪznəs" wəd teɪk əɹ ðɛn. ðeɪ hæd tə bi sɛlf-ɹɪlaɪən fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. feɪl wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæs ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə əbændən əm əz sun əz ʃi wɑz eɪbəl.

Bain and Chiad ducked into the small peaked tent, and Alliandre and Maighdin came out. There really was not room inside for five. Maighdin went around the side of the tent and returned with a basket like those the other women had been carrying.
