Dirty gai'shain robes bulged out of the top of each, making them appear loads of laundry, but beneath were dresses that came near enough fitting, a hatchet, a sling, cords for making snares, flint and steel, packets of flour, meal, dried beans, salt and yeast, a few coins they had been able to find, everything they would need to make their way west to find Perrin. Galina would take them out of the camp, but there was no saying which direction her "Aes Sedai business" would take her then. They had to be self-reliant from the start. Faile would not put it past the Aes Sedai to abandon them as soon as she was able.

meɪaɪɡdɪn stʊɾ oʊvɝ əɹ bæskət wɪð ən ɛɹ ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən, hɝ dʒɔ sɛɾ ən əɹ aɪz fɝm, bʌɾ æliændɝz feɪs wɑz ɹɛðd ɪn smaɪlz.

Maighdin stood over her basket with an air of determination, her jaw set and her eyes firm, but Alliandre's face was wreathed in smiles.

"tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə lʊk soʊ hæpi," feɪl toʊl hɝ. wɛtləndɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn sɛldəm smaɪld, ən nɛvɝ soʊ dʒɔɪfəli.

"Try not to look so happy," Faile told her. Wetlander gai'shain seldom smiled, and never so joyfully.

æliændɝ tʃɹaɪd tə mɑɾɝeɪt əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən, bʌɾ ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi smuðd əɹ smaɪlz əweɪ, ðeɪ kɹɛp bæk. "wɝ ɪskeɪpɪŋ tədeɪ," ʃi sɛd. "ɪts hɑɹd nɑt tə smaɪl."

Alliandre tried to moderate her expression, but every time she smoothed her smiles away, they crept back. "We're escaping today," she said. "It's hard not to smile."

"jul stɑp ɪf səm waɪz wʌn siz jə ən dɪsaɪdz tə faɪn aʊt waɪ jəɹ hæpi."

"You'll stop if some Wise One sees you and decides to find out why you're happy."

"wɝ hɑɹdli laɪkli tə miɾ ə waɪz wʌn əmʌŋ ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn tɛns əɹ ɪn mɔldən," ðə wʊmən sɛd θɹu ə smaɪl. dɪtɝmən əɹ nɑt, meɪaɪɡdɪn nɑɾəd əɡɹimənt.

"We're hardly likely to meet a Wise One among the gai'shain tents or in Malden," the woman said through a smile. Determined or not, Maighdin nodded agreement.

feɪl ɡeɪv ʌp. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi fɛlt ə lɪɾəl ɡɪɾi hɝsɛlf ɪn spaɪɾ ə dɛɹeɪn. ðeɪ wɝ ɪskeɪpɪŋ tədeɪ.

Faile gave up. In truth, she felt a little giddy herself in spite of Dairaine. They were escaping today.

beɪn keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt, hoʊldɪŋ ðə tɛntflæp fəɹ kiæd, hu wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ɑn əɹ bæk ə blæŋkət-ɹæp bʌndəl dʒʌs lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə bi ə smɔl wʊmən dʌbəld-ʌp. kiæd wɑz stʃɹɔŋ, bʌt ʃi hæd tə lin fɔɹwɝɾ ə lɪɾəl tə səpɔɹt ðə weɪt.

Bain came out of the tent, holding the tentflap for Chiad, who was carrying on her back a blanket-wrapped bundle just large enough to be a small woman doubled-up. Chiad was strong, but she had to lean forward a little to support the weight.

"waɪ ɪz ʃi soʊ stɪl?" feɪl æskt. ʃi hæd noʊ fɪɹ ðeɪ hæd kɪl dɛɹeɪn. ðeɪ wɝ fɪɹs əbaʊt fɑloʊɪŋ ðə ɹulz fəɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn, ən vaɪələns wɑz fɔɹbɪɾən. bʌt ðət blæŋkət cʊɾə bɪn fʊl ʌv wʊd fəɹ ɔl ðəɾ ɪt muvd.

"Why is she so still?" Faile asked. She had no fear they had killed Dairaine. They were fierce about following the rules for gai'shain, and violence was forbidden. But that blanket could have been full of wood for all that it moved.

beɪn spoʊk sɔfli, ən əmjuz laɪɾ ɪn əɹ aɪz. "aɪ stʃɹoʊkt əɹ hɛɹ ən toʊld əɹ aɪ wəd bi vɛɹi əpsɛɾ ɪf aɪ hæd tə hɝt hɝ. sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ haʊ mʌtʃ toʊ ivən slæpɪŋ əɹ wəd kɑs mi." kiæd tʃʌkəld. "aɪ θɪŋk dɛɹeɪn seɪɡən θɔt wi wɝ θɹɛɾənɪŋ hɝ. aɪ θɪŋk ʃɪl bi vɛɹi kwaɪəɾ ən vɛɹi stɪl əntɪl wi lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ." ʃi ʃʊk wɪð saɪlən læftɝ. il hjumɝ wɑz stɪl ə mɪstɝi tə feɪl. ʃi nu ðeɪ wəd bi pʌnɪʃt səvɪɹli fəɹ ðɪs, ðoʊ. eɪɾɪŋ ən ɪskeɪp ətɛmpt wɑz dɛlt wɪð əz hɑɹʃli əz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪskeɪp.

Bain spoke softly, an amused light in her eyes. "I stroked her hair and told her I would be very upset if I had to hurt her. Simple truth, considering how much toh even slapping her would cost me." Chiad chuckled. "I think Dairaine Saighan thought we were threatening her. I think she will be very quiet and very still until we let her go." She shook with silent laughter. Aiel humor was still a mystery to Faile. She knew they would be punished severely for this, though. Aiding an escape attempt was dealt with as harshly as trying to escape.

"ju hæv ɔl maɪ ɡɹæɾətud," ʃi sɛd, "ju ən kiæd boʊθ, naʊ ən fɝɛvɝ. aɪ hæv ɡɹeɪt toʊ." ʃi kɪs beɪn laɪtli ɑn ðə tʃik, wɪtʃ meɪd ðə wʊmən blʌʃ əz ɹɛɾ əz əɹ hɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs. il wɝ ɔlmoʊs pɹudiʃli ɹistʃɹeɪn ɪn pʌblɪk. ɪn səm weɪz.

"You have all my gratitude," she said, "you and Chiad both, now and forever. I have great toh." She kissed Bain lightly on the cheek, which made the woman blush as red as her hair, of course. Aiel were almost prudishly restrained in public. In some ways.

beɪn ɡlænst ət kiæd, ən ə feɪn smaɪl əpɪɹɾ ɑn əɹ lɪps. "wɛn jə si ɡɔl, tɛl ɪm kiæɾ ɪz ɡeɪʃeɪn tə ə mæn wɪð stʃɹɔŋ hænz, ə mæn huz hɑɹɾ ɪz faɪɝ. hɪl ʌndɝstænd. aɪ nid tə hɛlp əɹ kæɹi əɹ bɝɾən tə ə seɪf pleɪs. meɪ jə ɔlweɪz faɪnd wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd, feɪl bæʃɪɹ." ʃi tʌtʃt feɪlz tʃik laɪtli wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps. "wʌn deɪ, wɪl miɾ əɡɛn."

Bain glanced at Chiad, and a faint smile appeared on her lips. "When you see Gaul, tell him Chiad is gai'shain to a man with strong hands, a man whose heart is fire. He will understand. I need to help her carry our burden to a safe place. May you always find water and shade, Faile Bashere." She touched Faile's cheek lightly with her fingertips. "One day, we will meet again."

ɡoʊɪŋ oʊvɝ tə kiæd, ʃi tʊk wʌn ɛn ə ðə blæŋkət, ən ðeɪ hɝiɾ əweɪ kæɹiɪŋ ɪt bɪtwin ðɛm. ɡɔl maɪɾ ʌndɝstænd, bʌt feɪl dɪd nɑt. nɑt ðə hɑɹɾ ə faɪɝ, ɛniweɪ, ən ʃi daʊɾɪd ðət mænʒɹɪks hænz ɪntʃɹəstəd kiæɾ ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst. ðə mæn hæd bæd bɹɛθ ən stɑɹɾəd ɡɛɾɪŋ dʒɹʌŋk əz sun əz i woʊk ənlɛs i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ə ɹeɪɾ əɹ hʌntɪŋ. bʌt ʃi pʊt ɡɔl ən mænʒɹɪk aʊɾ ə hɝ maɪn ən ʃoʊldɝɾ əɹ bæskət. ðeɪ hæd weɪstəd tu mʌtʃ taɪm ɔlɹɛɾi.

Going over to Chiad, she took one end of the blanket, and they hurried away carrying it between them. Gaul might understand, but Faile did not. Not the heart of fire, anyway, and she doubted that Manderic's hands interested Chiad in the slightest. The man had bad breath and started getting drunk as soon as he woke unless he was going on a raid or hunting. But she put Gaul and Manderic out of her mind and shouldered her basket. They had wasted too much time already.

ðə skaɪ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə teɪk ɑn ði əpɪɹəns ʌv æktʃəwəl deɪlaɪt, ən ɡeɪʃeɪn wɝ stɝɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə waɪldli daɪvɝs tɛns ə ðə kæmp kloʊs ɑn mɔldənz wɔlz, skɝiɪŋ ɔf tə bi əbaʊt səm tʃɔɹ əɹ ət lis kæɹiɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ tə ɡɪv ə sɛmbləns ʌv wɝkɪŋ, bʌt nʌn peɪɾ ɛni maɪn tə θɹi wɪmən ɪn waɪt kæɹiɪŋ bæskəts ə lɔnʒɹi təwɔɹd ðə taʊnz ɡeɪts. ðəɹ ɔlweɪz sim tə bi lɔnʒɹi tə bi dʌn, ivən fəɹ sɪvænəz ɡeɪʃeɪn. ðəɹ wɝ fɑɹ tu mɛni wɛtləndɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn fəɹ feɪl tə noʊ ɛvɹiwʌn, ən ʃi sɔ noʊ wʌn ʃi nu əntɪl ðeɪ keɪm ɑn ɹɛlə ən lətʃəl, ʃɪftɪŋ fɹəm fʊt tə fʊt wɪð bæskəts ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. tɔlɝ ðən moʊst il wɪmən ən dɑɹk, ɹɛlə kɛpt əɹ blæk hɛɹ kʌɾ əz ʃɔɹɾ əz ɛni meɪɾən ən stʃɹoʊd laɪk ə mæn wən ʃi wɔkt. lətʃəl wɑz ʃɔɹɾ ən peɪl ən slɪm, ən hæd ɹɛd ɹɪbənz taɪɾ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ. hɝ wɔk wɑz ɡɹeɪsfəl ɪn ɹoʊbz, ən hæd bɪn ə skændələs sweɪ wən ʃi hæd wɔɹn bɹitʃɪz. ðɛɹ saɪz ə ɹɪlif wɝ nɪɹli aɪdɛntɪkəl, ðoʊ.

The sky was beginning to take on the appearance of actual daylight, and gai'shain were stirring among the wildly diverse tents of the camp close on Malden's walls, scurrying off to be about some chore or at least carrying something to give a semblance of working, but none paid any mind to three women in white carrying baskets of laundry toward the town's gates. There always seemed to be laundry to be done, even for Sevanna's gai'shain. There were far too many wetlander gai'shain for Faile to know everyone, and she saw no one she knew until they came on Arrela and Lacile, shifting from foot to foot with baskets on their shoulders. Taller than most Aiel women and dark, Arrela kept her black hair cut as short as any Maiden and strode like a man when she walked. Lacile was short and pale and slim, and had red ribbons tied in her hair, which was not much longer. Her walk was graceful in robes, and had been a scandalous sway when she had worn breeches. Their sighs of relief were nearly identical, though.

"wi θɔt sʌmθɪŋ hæd hæpənd," ɹɛlə sɛd.

"We thought something had happened," Arrela said.

"nʌθɪŋ wi kʊdn hændəl," feɪl toʊl hɝ.

"Nothing we couldn't handle," Faile told her.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ beɪn ən kiæd?" lətʃəl æskt æŋkʃəsli.

"Where are Bain and Chiad?" Lacile asked anxiously.

"ðeɪ hæv ənʌðɝ tæsk," feɪl sɛd. "wi ɡoʊ əloʊn."

"They have another task," Faile said. "We go alone."

ðeɪ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz, ən ðɛɹ saɪz wɝ fɑɹ fɹəm ɹɪliv ðɪs taɪm. ʌv kɔɹs ɹoʊlən wəd nɑɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ. nɑt wɪð əm ɡɛɾɪŋ əweɪ. ʌv kɔɹs nɑt.

They exchanged glances, and their sighs were far from relieved this time. Of course Rolan would not interfere. Not with them getting away. Of course not.

ði aɪɝn-stʃɹæpt ɡeɪts ə mɔldən stʊɾ oʊpən, ʃʌv bæk əɡɛns ðə ɡɹænət wɔlz, əz ðeɪ hæd sɪns ðə sɪɾi fɛl. ɹʌs hæd tɝn ðə bɹɔɾ aɪɝn stʃɹæps bɹaʊn, ən ðə hɪnʒɪz wɝ soʊ ɹʌsti ðət pʊʃɪŋ ðə ɡeɪts ʃʌɾ əɡɛn maɪt bi ɪmpɑsəbəl. pɪdʒənz nɛstəɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn taʊɝz flæŋkɪŋ ðɛm, naʊ.

The iron-strapped gates of Malden stood open, shoved back against the granite walls, as they had since the city fell. Rust had turned the broad iron straps brown, and the hinges were so rusty that pushing the gates shut again might be impossible. Pigeons nested in the gray stone towers flanking them, now.

ðeɪ wɝ ðə fɝs tə ɝaɪv. ət list, feɪl kəd si noʊ wʌn əhɛɾ ə ðɛm daʊn ðə stʃɹit. əz ðeɪ wɔk θɹu ðə ɡeɪts, ʃi ɹitʃɹivd əɹ dæɡɝ fɹəm ðə pɑkəɾ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ sliv ən hɛld ɪt wɪð ðə bleɪd pɹɛst əɡɛnst əɹ ɹɪst, pɔɪntɪŋ ʌp əɹ ɑɹm.

They were the first to arrive. At least, Faile could see no one ahead of them down the street. As they walked through the gates, she retrieved her dagger from the pocket inside her sleeve and held it with the blade pressed against her wrist, pointing up her arm.

ði ʌðɝ wɪmən meɪd sɪməlɝ moʊʃənz, ɪf nɑt soʊ dɛfli. wɪθaʊt beɪn ən kiæd, ən hoʊpɪŋ ðət ɹoʊlən ən ɪz fɹɛnz wɝ ʌðɝwaɪz ɑkjəpaɪd, ðeɪ hæd tə pɹəvaɪd ðɛɹ oʊn pɹətɛkʃən. mɔldən wɑz nɑɾ əz deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ ə wʊmən - fəɹ ə ɡeɪʃeɪn wʊmən; ʃeɪɾoʊ hu tʃɹaɪd tə pɹeɪ ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn ɡɑt ʃɔɹt ʃɹɪft - nɑɾ əz deɪnʒɝəs əz ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ pɔɹʃən ə ðə kæmp, jɛt wɪmən hæd bɪn əsɔltɪd ðɛɹ, səmtaɪmz baɪ ɡɹups ə mɛn. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əkɑstəd, ɪt wɑz oʊnli baɪ wʌn əɹ tu. wʌn əɹ tu ðeɪ maɪt kætʃ baɪ sɝpɹaɪz ən kɪl bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹilaɪz ðiz ɡeɪʃeɪn hæd tiθ. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ðən tu, ðeɪ wəd də wʌt ðeɪ kʊd, bʌɾ ən il wivɝ əɹ pɑɾɝ wɑz əz deɪnʒɝəs əz moʊs tʃɹeɪn ɑɹmmɪn. bæskəts əɹ noʊ bæskəts, ðeɪ wɔkt ɑn ðɛɹ toʊz, hɛdz swɪvəlɪŋ, ɹɛɾi tə spɹɪŋ ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən.

The other women made similar motions, if not so deftly. Without Bain and Chiad, and hoping that Rolan and his friends were otherwise occupied, they had to provide their own protection. Malden was not as dangerous for a woman - for a gai'shain woman; Shaido who tried to prey on their own got short shrift - not as dangerous as the Shaido portion of the camp, yet women had been assaulted there, sometimes by groups of men. The Light send if they were accosted, it was only by one or two. One or two they might catch by surprise and kill before they realized these gai'shain had teeth. If there were more than two, they would do what they could, but an Aiel weaver or potter was as dangerous as most trained armsmen. Baskets or no baskets, they walked on their toes, heads swiveling, ready to spring in any direction.

ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə ðə taʊn hæd nɑt bɪn bɝnd, jɛɾ ɪt hæɾ ə lʊk ə dɛsəleɪʃən. bɹoʊkən dɪʃəz ən pɑɾɝi kɹʌntʃt bɪniθ ðɛɹ sɑft waɪt buts. bɪts ə kloʊðɪŋ, kʌɾ ɔf mɛn ən wɪmən meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn, stɪl lɪɾɝd ðə ɡɹeɪ peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. ðoʊz sɑɹi, bɪdʒɹæɡəld ɹæɡz hæd leɪn fɝst ɪn ðə snoʊ ən ðən ɪn ðə ɹeɪn fəɹ wɛl oʊvɝ ə mʌnθ, ən ʃi daʊɾɪd ɛni ɹæɡpɪkɝ wʊɾə ɡæðɝd ðɛm, naʊ. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ leɪ tʃɪlʒɹənz tɔɪz, ə wʊɾən hɔɹs əɹ ə dɑl huz peɪnt wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fleɪk, dʒɹɑp baɪ ðə vɛɹi jʌŋ u hæd bɪn əlaʊd tə fli, laɪk ðə vɛɹi oʊld, ði ɪl ən ɪnfɝm. sleɪt-ɹuf bɪldɪŋz ʌv wʊɾ əɹ stoʊn əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit ʃoʊd ɡeɪpɪŋ hoʊlz wɛɹ ðɛɹ dɔɹz ən wɪndoʊz hæd bɪn. əlɔŋ wɪð ɛniθɪŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kənsɪɾɝd væljəbəl əɹ jusfəl, ðə taʊn hæd bɪn stʃɹɪpt ʌv ɛvɹi izəli ɹɪmuvəbəl pis ʌv wʊd, ən oʊnli ðə fæk ðət tɛɹɪŋ daʊn haʊsəz wɑz lɛs ɪfɪʃən ðən kʌɾɪŋ faɪɝwʊɾ ɪn ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ fɔɹəsts hæd spɛɹd ðə wʊɾən stʃɹʌktʃɝz ðɛmsɛlvz. ðoʊz oʊpənɪŋz maɪndəd feɪl ʌv aɪ sɑkəts ɪn skʌlz. ʃi hæd wɔkt əlɔŋ ðɪs stʃɹit kaʊnləs taɪmz, jɛt ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ðeɪ sim tə bi wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ. ðeɪ meɪɾ əɹ skælp kɹɔl.

This part of the town had not been burned, yet it had a look of desolation. Broken dishes and pottery crunched beneath their soft white boots. Bits of clothing, cut off men and women made gai'shain, still littered the gray paving stones. Those sorry, bedraggled rags had lain first in the snow and then in the rain for well over a month, and she doubted any ragpicker would have gathered them, now. Here and there lay children's toys, a wooden horse or a doll whose paint was beginning to flake, dropped by the very young who had been allowed to flee, like the very old, the ill and infirm. Slate-roofed buildings of wood or stone along the street showed gaping holes where their doors and windows had been. Along with anything the Shaido considered valuable or useful, the town had been stripped of every easily removable piece of wood, and only the fact that tearing down houses was less efficient than cutting firewood in the surrounding forests had spared the wooden structures themselves. Those openings minded Faile of eye sockets in skulls. She had walked along this street countless times, yet this morning, they seemed to be watching her. They made her scalp crawl.

hæfweɪ əkɹɔs ðə taʊn, ʃi lʊk bæk təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪts, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti peɪsɪz bɪhaɪnd. ðə stʃɹit wɑz stɪl ɛmpti fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, bʌt sun ðə fɝst waɪt-klæd mɛn ən wɪmən wəd mətɪɹiəlaɪz wɪð ðɛɹ wɔɾɝ bʌkəts. fɛtʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ wɑz ə tæsk ðət bɪɡæn ɝli ən læstəɾ ɔl deɪ. ðeɪ hæd tə hɝi, naʊ. tɝnɪŋ daʊn ə nɛɹoʊɝ saɪd stʃɹit, ʃi stɑɹɾəd tə wɔk fæstɝ, ɔlðoʊ ʃi hæd tʃɹʌbəl kipɪŋ əɹ bæskət bælənst. ði ʌðɝz mʌst əv bɪn hævɪŋ ðə seɪm dɪfəkəlti, jɛt noʊ wʌn kəmpleɪnd. ðeɪ hæd tə bi aʊɾ ə saɪt bɪfɔɹ ðoʊz ɡeɪʃeɪn əpɪɹd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ɛni ɡeɪʃeɪn ɛntɝɪŋ ðə taʊn tə liv ðə meɪn stʃɹiɾ əntɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə sɪstɝn bɪloʊ ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs. ən ətɛmp tə kʌɹi feɪvɝ əɹ dʒʌst ə kɛɹləs wɝd kəd sɛnd ʃeɪɾoʊ ɪndə ðə taʊn hʌntɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm, ən ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ aʊt, ʃɔɹɾ ə klaɪmɪŋ ɑntu ðə wɔlz ən dʒɹɑpɪŋ tɛn peɪsɪz tə ðə ɡɹaʊn hoʊpɪŋ ðət noʊ wʌn bɹoʊk ə lɛɡ.

Halfway across the town, she looked back toward the gates, no more than a hundred and fifty paces behind. The street was still empty for the moment, but soon the first white-clad men and women would materialize with their water buckets. Fetching water was a task that began early and lasted all day. They had to hurry, now. Turning down a narrower side street, she started to walk faster, although she had trouble keeping her basket balanced. The others must have been having the same difficulty, yet no one complained. They had to be out of sight before those gai'shain appeared. There was no reason for any gai'shain entering the town to leave the main street until they reached the cistern below the fortress. An attempt to curry favor or just a careless word could send Shaido into the town hunting for them, and there was only one way out, short of climbing onto the walls and dropping ten paces to the ground hoping that no one broke a leg.

əɾ ə naʊ saɪnləs ɪn, θɹi stɔɹiz ə stoʊn ən ɛmpti wɪndoʊz, ʃi dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ðə kɑmən ɹum fɑloʊd baɪ ði ʌðɝz. lətʃəl sɛt daʊn əɹ bæskəɾ ən pɹɛs hɝsɛlf əɡɛns ðə dɔɹfɹeɪm tə kip wɑtʃ ʌp ðə stʃɹit. ðə bim-silɪŋɡd ɹum wɑz bɛɹ tə ðə dʌsti flɔɹbɔɹdz, ən ðə stoʊn faɪɝpleɪsəz wɝ mɪsɪŋ ðɛɹ ændaɪɝənz ən faɪɝtulz. ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ hæd bɪn stʃɹɪp fɹəm ðə stɛɹkeɪs ət ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum, ən ðə dɔɹ tə ðə kɪtʃən wɑz ɡɔn, tu. ðə kɪtʃən wɑz dʒʌst əz ɛmpti. ʃi hæd tʃɛkt. pɑts ən naɪvz ən spunz wɝ jusfəl. feɪl loʊɝɾ əɹ bæskət tə ðə flɔɹ ən hɝid tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stɛɹkeɪs. ɪt wɑz ə stɝɾi pis ʌv wɝk, ʌv hɛvi tɪmbɝz ən meɪd tə læs fəɹ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz. tɛɹɪŋ ɪt daʊn wʊɾə bɪn nɪɹli əz hɑɹɾ əz tɛɹɪŋ daʊn ə haʊs. ʃi fɛlt ʌndɝniθ, əlɔŋ ðə tɑp ə ðə waɪɾ aʊɾɝ səpɔɹt, ən əɹ hæn kloʊzd ɑn ðə ɹɪst-θɪk, nɑt kwaɪt ɡlæsi ɹɑd. ɪt hæd simd əz ɡʊɾ ə haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs əz ʃi kəd faɪnd, ə pleɪs noʊ wʌn wəɾ əv ɛni ɹizən tə lʊk, bʌt ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪnd ʃi hæd bɪn hoʊldɪŋ əɹ bɹɛθ.

At a now signless inn, three stories of stone and empty windows, she darted into the common room followed by the others. Lacile set down her basket and pressed herself against the doorframe to keep watch up the street. The beam-ceilinged room was bare to the dusty floorboards, and the stone fireplaces were missing their andirons and firetools. The railing had been stripped from the staircase at the back of the room, and the door to the kitchen was gone, too. The kitchen was just as empty. She had checked. Pots and knives and spoons were useful. Faile lowered her basket to the floor and hurried to the side of the staircase. It was a sturdy piece of work, of heavy timbers and made to last for generations. Tearing it down would have been nearly as hard as tearing down a house. She felt underneath, along the top of the wide outer support, and her hand closed on the wrist-thick, not quite glassy rod. It had seemed as good a hiding place as she could find, a place no one would have any reason to look, but she was surprised to find she had been holding her breath.

lətʃəl ɹɪmeɪn baɪ ðə dɔɹweɪ, bʌt ði ʌðɝz hɝid tə feɪl wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ bæskəts.

Lacile remained by the doorway, but the others hurried to Faile without their baskets.

"æt læst," æliændɝ sɛd, dʒɪnʒɝli tʌtʃɪŋ ðə ɹɑd wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps. "ðə pɹaɪs ʌv əɹ fɹiɾəm. wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"At last," Alliandre said, gingerly touching the rod with her fingertips. "The price of our freedom. What is it?"

"æn æŋɡɹil," feɪl sɛd, "ɔɹ pɝhæps ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. aɪ doʊnt noʊ fəɹ sɝɾən, ɪksɛp ðət ɡəlinə wɑns ɪt vɛɹi bædli, soʊ ɪt mʌs bi wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ."

"An angreal," Faile said, "or perhaps a ter'angreal. I don't know for certain, except that Galina wants it very badly, so it must be one or the other."

meɪaɪɡdɪn pʊɾ əɹ hæn ɑn ðə ɹɑd boʊldli. "ɪt kəd bi iðɝ," ʃi mɝmɝd. "ðeɪ ɔfən əv ən ɑd fil. soʊ aɪv bɪn toʊld, ɛniweɪ." ʃi kleɪm nɛvɝ tə hæv bɪn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt feɪl wɑz nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ əz ʃi wʌns hæd bɪn. meɪaɪɡdɪn kəd tʃænəl, bʌt soʊ wikli ən wɪð soʊ mʌtʃ dɪfəkəlti ðət ðə waɪz wʌnz sɔ noʊ deɪnʒɝ ɪn lɛɾɪŋ əɹ wɔk fɹi. wɛl, əz fɹi əz ɛni ɡeɪʃeɪn wɑz. hɝ dɪnaɪəlz maɪt wɛl bi ə mæɾɝ ə ʃeɪm. feɪl hæd hɝd ðət wɪmən u hæd bɪn pʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ kəz ðeɪ kəd nɑt bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ səmtaɪmz dɪnaɪɾ ɛvɝ hævɪŋ ɡɔn ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə haɪd ðɛɹ feɪljɝ.

Maighdin put her hand on the rod boldly. "It could be either," she murmured. "They often have an odd feel. So I've been told, anyway." She claimed never to have been to the White Tower, but Faile was not so sure as she once had been. Maighdin could channel, but so weakly and with so much difficulty that the Wise Ones saw no danger in letting her walk free. Well, as free as any gai'shain was. Her denials might well be a matter of shame. Faile had heard that women who had been put out of the Tower because they could not become Aes Sedai sometimes denied ever having gone in order to hide their failure.

ɹɛlə ɡeɪv ə ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛɾ ən bækt əweɪ ə stɛp. ʃi wɑz tɛɹən, ən dɪspaɪt tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi wɑz stɪl ənkʌmftəɹbəl oʊvɝ ðə paʊɝ əɹ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪt. ʃi lʊkt ət ðə smuð waɪt ɹɑɾ əz ɪf əɾ ə ɹɛɾ æɾɝ ən lɪkt əɹ lɪps. "ɡəlinə maɪt bi weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ʌs. ʃi maɪt ɡɛɾ æŋɡɹi ɪf wi meɪk əɹ weɪt lɔŋ."

Arrela gave a shake of her head and backed away a step. She was Tairen, and despite traveling with Aes Sedai, she was still uncomfortable over the Power or anything to do with it. She looked at the smooth white rod as if at a red adder and licked her lips. "Galina might be waiting on us. She might get angry if we make her wait long."

"ɪz ðə weɪ stɪl klɪɹ, lətʃəl?" feɪl æskt əz ʃi stʌk ðə ɹɑd fɑɹ daʊn ɪndə hɝ bæskət. ɹɛlə ɛksheɪl hɛvəli, klɪɹli əz ɹɪlivd ət hævɪŋ ðə θɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ saɪɾ əz ʃi hæd bɪn tə si feɪl ɝliɝ.

"Is the way still clear, Lacile?" Faile asked as she stuck the rod far down into her basket. Arrela exhaled heavily, clearly as relieved at having the thing out of her sight as she had been to see Faile earlier.

"jɛs," ðə kɛɹhinɪn ɹɪplaɪd, "bʌɾ aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ." ʃi stɪl stʊd soʊ ðət wʌn aɪ kəd pik ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə dɔɹfɹeɪm. "ðə fɝst ɡeɪʃeɪn ʃəd bi kʌmɪŋ fəɹ wɔɾɝ baɪ naʊ."

"Yes," the Cairhienin replied, "but I do not understand why." She still stood so that one eye could peek around the corner of the doorframe. "The first gai'shain should be coming for water by now."

"meɪbi sʌmθɪŋ əz hæpən ɪn ðə kæmp," meɪaɪɡdɪn sɛd. sʌɾənli, hɝ feɪs wɑz ɡɹɪm ən əɹ naɪf wɑz ɪn əɹ hænd, ə wʊɾən-hændəld əfɛɹ wɪð ə tʃɪpt ən pɪɾəd bleɪd.

"Maybe something has happened in the camp," Maighdin said. Suddenly, her face was grim and her knife was in her hand, a wooden-handled affair with a chipped and pitted blade.

feɪl nɑɾəd sloʊli. meɪbi sʌmθɪŋ sətʃ əz dɛɹeɪn hævɪŋ bɪn faʊn ɔlɹɛɾi. ʃi kəd nɑt tɛl wɛɹ feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ, bʌt ʃi maɪɾ əv ɹɛkəɡnaɪz səm əmʌŋ ðə weɪɾɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn. haʊ lɔŋ wəd ðeɪ hoʊld aʊɾ ɪf pʊt tə ðə kwɛstʃən? haʊ lɔŋ wəɾ ælvən hoʊld aʊɾ ɪf θɛɝɪl wɝ? "ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ wi kən də əbaʊɾ ɪt, ɪn ɛni keɪs. ɡəlinə wɪl ɡɛɾ əs aʊt."

Faile nodded slowly. Maybe something such as Dairaine having been found already. She could not tell where Faile and the others had been going, but she might have recognized some among the waiting gai'shain. How long would they hold out if put to the question? How long would Alvon hold out if Theril were? "There's nothing we can do about it, in any case. Galina will get us out."

ivən soʊ, wən ðeɪ lɛf ði ɪn, ðeɪ ɹæn, kæɹiɪŋ ðə bæskəts ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊld ʌp ðɛɹ lɔŋ ɹoʊbz soʊ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt tʃɹɪp. feɪl wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn tə lʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ fɹikwənli ən stʌmbəl. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi wɑz ɹɪliv tə faɪnəli si ɡeɪʃeɪn kæɹiɪŋ bʌkəts ɑn joʊks dʒɹɪft əkɹɔs ðə kɹɔsɪŋ ə ðə taʊnz meɪn stʃɹit. ʃi sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt sloʊ daʊn.

Even so, when they left the inn, they ran, carrying the baskets in front of them and trying to hold up their long robes so they did not trip. Faile was not the only one to look over her shoulder frequently and stumble. She was not sure whether or not she was relieved to finally see gai'shain carrying buckets on yokes drift across the crossing of the town's main street. She certainly did not slow down.

ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ əv fɑɹ tə ɹʌn. ɪn moʊməns, ðə smɛl ə tʃɑɹd wʊd ðət hæd feɪɾəd fɹəm ðə ɹɛst ə mɔldən bɪɡæn tə ɡɹoʊ. ðə sʌðɝn ɛn ə mɔldən wɑz ə ɹuən. ðeɪ hɔltəɾ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə dɛvəsteɪʃən ən ɛdʒd ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ soʊ ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi sin baɪ ɛniwʌn ɡlænsɪŋ daʊn ðə stʃɹit. fɹəm wɛɹ ðeɪ stʊd tə ðə sʌðɝn wɔl, nɪɹ tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz, mɑɹtʃt ɹufləs ʃɛlz wɪð blækən stoʊn wɔlz ɪntɝspɝst wɪð paɪlz ə tʃɑɹd bimz wɑʃt klin ʌv æʃ baɪ ðə ɹeɪnz. ɪn pleɪsəz, nɑɾ ivən ðə hɛviəs tɪmbɝz ɹɪmeɪnd. oʊnli ɑn ðə saʊθ saɪɾ ə ðɪs stʃɹit wɝ ðəɹ ɛni stʃɹʌktʃɝz ivən kloʊs tə hoʊl. ðɪs wɑz wɛɹ ðə faɪɝ ðət ɹeɪdʒd æftɝ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tʊk ðə sɪɾi hæd bɪn faɪnəli stɑpt. hæf ə dʌzən bɪldɪŋz stʊd wɪθaʊt ɹufs, ðoʊ ðə loʊɝ flɔɹz lʊkt ɪntækt, ən twaɪs əz mɛni wɝ linɪŋ paɪlz ə blæk tɪmbɝz ən hæf-bɝn bɔɹdz ðəɾ əpɪɹɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə kəlæps.

They did not have far to run. In moments, the smell of charred wood that had faded from the rest of Malden began to grow. The southern end of Malden was a ruin. They halted at the edge of the devastation and edged around a corner so they would not be seen by anyone glancing down the street. From where they stood to the southern wall, near two hundred paces, marched roofless shells with blackened stone walls interspersed with piles of charred beams washed clean of ash by the rains. In places, not even the heaviest timbers remained. Only on the south side of this street were there any structures even close to whole. This was where the fire that raged after the Shaido took the city had been finally stopped. Half a dozen buildings stood without roofs, though the lower floors looked intact, and twice as many were leaning piles of black timbers and half-burned boards that appeared on the edge of collapse.

"ðɛɹ," meɪaɪɡdɪn sɛd, pɔɪntɪŋ ist əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit. ə lɔŋ lɛŋθ ə ɹɛd klɔθ flʌɾɝd ɪn ðə bɹiz wɛɹ ʃi pɔɪntəd. ɪt wɑz taɪd tə ə haʊs ðət simd ɹɛɾi tə fɔl ɪn. wɔkɪŋ tə ɪt sloʊli, ðeɪ ɹɛstəd ðɛɹ bæskəts ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. ðə ɹɛd klɔθ flʌɾɝd əɡɛn.

"There," Maighdin said, pointing east along the street. A long length of red cloth fluttered in the breeze where she pointed. It was tied to a house that seemed ready to fall in. Walking to it slowly, they rested their baskets on the paving stones. The red cloth fluttered again.

"waɪ wəd ʃi wɑnə miɾ əs hɪɹ?" æliændɝ mʌɾɝd. "ðæt kəd keɪv ɪn ɪf ɛnibəɾi snizd." ʃi ɹʌbd əɾ əɹ noʊz əz ðoʊ ðə wɝd hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ði ɝdʒ.

"Why would she want to meet us here?" Alliandre muttered. "That could cave in if anybody sneezed." She rubbed at her nose as though the word had given her the urge.

"ɪɾ ɪz kwaɪt saʊnd. aɪ ɪnspɛktɪɾ ɪt." ɡəlinəz vɔɪs bɪhaɪn əm dʒɝk feɪlz hɛɾ ɝaʊnd. ðə wʊmən wɑz stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɛm, pleɪnli fɹəm wʌn ə ðə saʊn bɪldɪŋz ɑn ðə nɔɹθ saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit. æftɝ soʊ lɔŋ siɪŋ əɹ ɪn ðət bɛlt ən kɑlɝ ʌv ɡoʊld ən faɪɝdʒɹɑps, ʃi lʊkt ɑd wɪθaʊt ðɛm. ʃi stɪl wɔɹ əɹ waɪt sɪlk ɹoʊbz, bʌt ði æbsəns ə ðə dʒuəlɹi wɑz kənvɪnsɪŋ. ɡəlinə hæd nɑt sʌmhaʊ mænədʒ tə tɝn tʃɹuθ ɑn ɪts hɛd. ʃi wɑz livɪŋ tədeɪ.

"It is quite sound. I inspected it." Galina's voice behind them jerked Faile's head around. The woman was striding toward them, plainly from one of the sound buildings on the north side of the street. After so long seeing her in that belt and collar of gold and firedrops, she looked odd without them. She still wore her white silk robes, but the absence of the jewelry was convincing. Galina had not somehow managed to turn truth on its head. She was leaving today.

"waɪ nɑɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə saʊn bɪldɪŋz?" feɪl dɪmændəd. "ɔɹ ɹaɪt hɪɹ?"

"Why not in one of the sound buildings?" Faile demanded. "Or right here?"

"bɪkɔz aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛniwʌn tə si ɪɾ ɪn maɪ hænz," ɡəlinə sɛd, wɔkɪŋ pæs hɝ. "bɪkɔz noʊ wʌn wɪl lʊk ɪnsaɪd ðət ɹuən. kəz aɪ seɪ soʊ." ʃi stɛp θɹu wʌt hæd bɪn ə dɔɹweɪ, dʌkɪŋ ʌndɝ ə hɛvi, tʃɑɹd ɹuf bim ðət slæntəɾ əkɹɔs ði oʊpənɪŋ, ən ɪmiɾiətli tɝn tə hɝ ɹaɪɾ ən bɪɡæn dɪsɛndɪŋ stɛɹz. "doʊn dɔɾəl."

"Because I don't want anyone to see it in my hands," Galina said, walking past her. "Because no one will look inside that ruin. Because I say so." She stepped through what had been a doorway, ducking under a heavy, charred roof beam that slanted across the opening, and immediately turned to her right and began descending stairs. "Don't dawdle."

feɪl ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð ði ʌðɝ wɪmən. ðɪs wɑz mɔɹ ðən pæsɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒ.

Faile exchanged looks with the other women. This was more than passing strange.

"ɪf ʃɪl ɡɛɾ əs aʊɾ ə hɪɹ," æliændɝ ɡɹaʊld, snætʃɪŋ ʌp əɹ bæskət, "aɪm wɪlɪŋ tə hæn əɹ ðə θɪŋ ɪn ə pɹɪvi." stɪl, ʃi weɪɾəd ɑn feɪl tə pɪk ʌp əɹ oʊn bæskəɾ ən lɛd ðə weɪ.

"If she'll get us out of here," Alliandre growled, snatching up her basket, "I'm willing to hand her the thing in a privy." Still, she waited on Faile to pick up her own basket and lead the way.

tʃɑɹd tɪmbɝz ən blækən bɔɹdz hʌŋ loʊ oʊvɝ ðə stoʊn stɛɹz ðət lɛd daʊnwɝd, bʌt ɡəlinəz iz əɾ ɛntɝɪŋ ɹiəʃʊɹd feɪl. ðə wʊmən wəd nɑt ɹɪsk biɪŋ bɛɹiɾ əlaɪv əɹ kɹʌʃt ət ðə vɛɹi moʊmənt ʃi faɪnəli ɡeɪn ðə ɹɑd. bɑɹz ən bimz ə laɪt fɪltɝɪŋ θɹu ɡæps ɪn ðə ɹɛkədʒ ɡeɪv ɪnʌf ɪluməneɪʃən tə ʃoʊ ðət ðə beɪsmənt wɑz kwaɪt klɪɹ dɪspaɪt ðə tʃɹɛtʃɝəs neɪtʃɝ ʌv wʌt leɪ əbʌv. lɑɹdʒ bæɹəlz stækt əlɔŋ wʌn stoʊn wɔl, moʊst skɔɹtʃt ən wɪð steɪvz spɹʌŋ fɹəm ðə hit, sɛd ðɪs hæd bɪn ən ɪn əɹ ə tævɝn. əɹ pɝhæps ə waɪn mɝtʃəns ʃɑp. ði ɛɹiə ɝaʊn mɔldən hæd pɹədust ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə miɾioʊkɝ waɪn.

Charred timbers and blackened boards hung low over the stone stairs that led downward, but Galina's ease at entering reassured Faile. The woman would not risk being buried alive or crushed at the very moment she finally gained the rod. Bars and beams of light filtering through gaps in the wreckage gave enough illumination to show that the basement was quite clear despite the treacherous nature of what lay above. Large barrels stacked along one stone wall, most scorched and with staves sprung from the heat, said this had been an inn or a tavern. Or perhaps a wine merchant's shop. The area around Malden had produced a great deal of mediocre wine.

ɡəlinə stʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɡɹɪt-kʌvɝd stoʊn flɔɹ, ɪn ə smɔl bim ə laɪt. hɝ feɪs wɑz ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑm, hɝ ædʒəteɪʃən ə ðə pɹiviəs deɪ kəmplitli səbdud. "wɛɹ ɪz ɪt?" ʃi sɛd kuli. "ɡɪv ɪt tə mi."

Galina stood in the middle of the grit-covered stone floor, in a small beam of light. Her face was all Aes Sedai calm, her agitation of the previous day completely subdued. "Where is it?" she said coolly. "Give it to me."

feɪl sɛɾ əɹ bæskət daʊn ən ʃʌvd əɹ hæn dip ɪnsaɪd. wən ʃi bɹɔɾ aʊt ðə waɪt ɹɑd, ɡəlinəz hænz twɪtʃt. feɪl ɪkstɛndəd ðə ɹɑd təwɔɹd hɝ, ən ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs hɛzɪɾəntli. ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn bɛɾɝ, feɪl wʊɾə sɛd ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪd tə tʌtʃ ɪt. ɡəlinəz fɪŋɡɝz kloʊzd ɝaʊn ðə ɹɑd, ən ʃi ɛksheɪl hɛvəli. ʃi dʒɝk ðə ɹɑɾ əweɪ bɪfɔɹ feɪl kəd ɹilis ɪt. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sim tə bi tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, bʌɾ əɹ smaɪl wɑz . . . tʃɹaɪʌmfənt.

Faile set her basket down and shoved her hand deep inside. When she brought out the white rod, Galina's hands twitched. Faile extended the rod toward her, and she reached for it almost hesitantly. If she had not known better, Faile would have said she was afraid to touch it. Galina's fingers closed around the rod, and she exhaled heavily. She jerked the rod away before Faile could release it. The Aes Sedai seemed to be trembling, but her smile was . . . triumphant.

"haʊ dʒju ɪntɛn tə ɡɛɾ əs əweɪ fɹəm ðə kæmp?" feɪl æskt. "ʃʊd wi tʃeɪnʒ əɹ kloʊðz naʊ?"

"How do you intend to get us away from the camp?" Faile asked. "Should we change our clothes now?"

ɡəlinə oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, ðən sʌɾənli ɹeɪzd əɹ fɹi hænd, pɑm aʊt. hɝ hɛd tɪltəd təwɔɹd ðə stɛɹz əz ɪf lɪsnɪŋ. "ɪt meɪ bi nʌθɪŋ," ʃi sɛd sɔfli, "bʌɾ ɪts bɛst ɪf aɪ tʃɛk. weɪt hɪɹ ən bi kwaɪət. bi kwaɪət," ʃi hɪst wən feɪl stɑɹɾəd tə spik. lɪftɪŋ ðə hɛm ə hɝ sɪlk ɹoʊbz, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ skɝid tə ðə stɛɹz ən stɑɹɾəd ʌp laɪk ə wʊmən ənizi əbaʊt wʌt ʃi maɪt faɪn ət ðə tɑp. hɝ fit pæst aʊɾ ə saɪt bɪhaɪn ðə sæɡɪŋ bɔɹdz ən bimz.

Galina opened her mouth, then suddenly raised her free hand, palm out. Her head tilted toward the stairs as if listening. "It may be nothing," she said softly, "but it's best if I check. Wait here and be quiet. Be quiet," she hissed when Faile started to speak. Lifting the hem of her silk robes, the Aes Sedai scurried to the stairs and started up like a woman uneasy about what she might find at the top. Her feet passed out of sight behind the sagging boards and beams.

"dɪɾ ɛni ʌv jə hɪɹ ɛniθɪŋ?" feɪl wɪspɝd. ðeɪ ɔl ʃʊk ðɛɹ hɛdz. "meɪbi ʃiz hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. aɪv hɝd ðət kən - "

"Did any of you hear anything?" Faile whispered. They all shook their heads. "Maybe she's holding the Power. I've heard that can - "

"ʃi wɑznt," meɪaɪɡdɪn ɪntɝʌptɪd. "aɪv nɛvɝ sin əɹ ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ - "

"She wasn't," Maighdin interrupted. "I've never seen her embracing - "

sʌɾənli, wʊd ɡɹoʊn oʊvɝhɛd, ən wɪð ə θʌndɝəs kɹæʃ tʃɑɹd bimz ən bɔɹdz kəlæpst, sɛndɪŋ aʊt blaɪndɪŋ bɪloʊz ə blæk dʌst ən ɡɹɪt ðət sɛn feɪl ɪndə pɛɹɑksəzəmz ə kɑfɪŋ. ðə smɛl ə tʃæɹɪŋ sʌɾənli wɑz əz θɪk ɪn ði ɛɹ əz ɪt hæd bɪn ðə deɪ mɔldən bɝnd. sʌmθɪŋ fɔlɪŋ fɹəm əbʌv hɪɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ hɑɹd, ən ʃi kɹaʊtʃt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹətɛkt əɹ hɛd. sʌmwʌn kɹaɪɾ aʊt. ʃi hɝɾ ʌðɝ fɔlɪŋ ɑbʒɛkts hɪt ðə beɪsməns stoʊn flɔɹ, bɔɹdz əɹ pisəz ə bɔɹdz. nʌθɪŋ meɪɾ ə laʊɾ ɪnʌf nɔɪz tə bi ə ɹuf bim əɹ ə hɛvi dʒɔɪst.

Suddenly, wood groaned overhead, and with a thunderous crash charred beams and boards collapsed, sending out blinding billows of black dust and grit that sent Faile into paroxysms of coughing. The smell of charring suddenly was as thick in the air as it had been the day Malden burned. Something falling from above hit her shoulder hard, and she crouched, trying to protect her head. Someone cried out. She heard other falling objects hit the basement's stone floor, boards or pieces of boards. Nothing made a loud enough noise to be a roof beam or a heavy joist.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli - ɪt sim laɪk aʊɝz; ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn mɪnəts - ðə ɹeɪn ə dəbɹi stɑpt. ðə dʌs bɪɡæn tə θɪn. kwɪkli ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊn fəɹ əɹ kəmpænjənz, ən faʊn əm ɔl hʌɾəlɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ wɪð ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz. ðəɹ sim tə bi mɔɹ laɪt ðən bɪfɔɹ. ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ. səm ə ðə ɡæps oʊvɝhɛd wɝ waɪɾɝ, naʊ. ə tʃɹɪkəl ə blʌd ɹæn daʊn æliændɝz feɪs fɹəm əɹ skælp. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz dʌstɪd wɪð blæk fɹəm hɛd tə fʊt.

Eventually - it seemed like hours; it might have been minutes - the rain of debris stopped. The dust began to thin. Quickly she looked around for her companions, and found them all huddling on the floor with their arms around their heads. There seemed to be more light than before. A little more. Some of the gaps overhead were wider, now. A trickle of blood ran down Alliandre's face from her scalp. Everyone was dusted with black from head to foot.

"ɪz ɛniwʌn ɪnʒɝd?" feɪl æskt, fɪnɪʃɪŋ wɪð ə kɑf. ðə dʌs hæd nɑt klɪɹd kəmplitli, ən əɹ θɹoʊɾ ən tʌŋ fɛl koʊɾəd wɪð ɪt. ðə stʌf teɪstəd laɪk tʃɑɹkoʊl.

"Is anyone injured?" Faile asked, finishing with a cough. The dust had not cleared completely, and her throat and tongue felt coated with it. The stuff tasted like charcoal.

"noʊ," æliændɝ sɛd, tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ skælp dʒɪnʒɝli. "ə skɹeɪp, ðæts ɔl." ði ʌðɝz dɪnaɪɾ ɪnʒɝi əz wɛl, ðoʊ ɹɛlə sim tə bi muvɪŋ əɹ ɹaɪɾ ɑɹm kɛɹfəli. noʊ daʊt ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl sʌfɝd bɹuzəz, ən feɪl θɔɾ əɹ lɛft ʃoʊldɝ wɑz gɑnə bi blæk ən blu ʃɔɹtli, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt kaʊn ðəɾ ə ɹil ɪnʒɝi.

"No," Alliandre said, touching her scalp gingerly. "A scrape, that's all." The others denied injury as well, though Arrela seemed to be moving her right arm carefully. No doubt they had all suffered bruises, and Faile thought her left shoulder was going to be black and blue shortly, but she would not count that a real injury.

ðən əɹ aɪz fɛl ɑn ðə stɛɹz, ən ʃi wɑntəd tə wip. ɹɛkədʒ fɹəm əbʌv fɪl ðə hoʊl speɪs wɛɹ ðə stɛɹkeɪs hæd bɪn. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn eɪbəl tə skwiz θɹu səm ə ðə ɡæps oʊvɝhɛd. feɪl θɔt ʃi kəd ɹitʃ əm stændɪŋ ɑn ɹɛləz ʃoʊldɝz, bʌt ʃi daʊɾɪd ʃi kəd pʊl hɝsɛlf θɹu wɪð wʌn ɡʊɾ ɑɹm. əɹ ðət ɹɛlə kʊd. ən ɪf iðɝ mænədʒd, ʃi wəd bi ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə bɝnd-aʊt ɹuən ən laɪkli əz nɑt tə meɪk ðə ɹɛst ə ðə θɪŋ fɔl ɪn, tu.

Then her eyes fell on the stairs, and she wanted to weep. Wreckage from above filled the whole space where the staircase had been. They might have been able to squeeze through some of the gaps overhead. Faile thought she could reach them standing on Arrela's shoulders, but she doubted she could pull herself through with one good arm. Or that Arrela could. And if either managed, she would be in the middle of a burned-out ruin and likely as not to make the rest of the thing fall in, too.

"noʊ!" æliændɝ moʊnd. "nɑt naʊ! nɑt wən wi wɝ soʊ kloʊs!" ɹaɪzɪŋ, ʃi ɹʌʃt əz nɪɹ tə ðə ɹʌbəl əz ʃi kəd ɡɛt, ɔlmoʊs pɹɛsɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪt, ən bɪɡæn tə ʃaʊt. "ɡəlinə! hɛlp ʌs! wɝ tʃɹæpt! tʃænəl ən lɪf ðə bɔɹdz əweɪ! klɪɹ ə pæθ fəɹ əs tə ɡɛɾ aʊt! ɡəlinə! ɡəlinə! ɡəlinə!" ʃi sæɡd əɡɛns ðə tæŋɡəl ə tɪmbɝz, ʃoʊldɝz ʃeɪkɪŋ. "ɡəlinə," ʃi wɛpt. "ɡəlinə, hɛlp ʌs."

"No!" Alliandre moaned. "Not now! Not when we were so close!" Rising, she rushed as near to the rubble as she could get, almost pressing against it, and began to shout. "Galina! Help us! We're trapped! Channel and lift the boards away! Clear a path for us to get out! Galina! Galina! Galina!" She sagged against the tangle of timbers, shoulders shaking. "Galina," she wept. "Galina, help us."

"ɡəlinəz ɡɔn," feɪl sɛd bɪɾɝli. ðə wʊmən wʊɾə ænsɝɾ ɪf ʃi wɑz stɪl əbʌv əɹ hæɾ ɛni ɪntɛntʃən ʌv eɪɾɪŋ ðɛm. "wɪð əs tʃɹæp daʊn hɪɹ, meɪbi dɛd, ʃiz ðə pɝfəkt ɪkskjus fəɹ livɪŋ əs bɪhaɪnd. ɛniweɪ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛðɝ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd muv səm ə ðoʊz tɪmbɝz ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd." ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə mɛnʃən ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət ɡəlinə hæɾ ɝeɪnʒd ðəɾ ɪkskjus hɝsɛlf. laɪt, ʃi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv slæp ðə wʊmən. ɪt wɑz tu leɪt fəɹ sɛlf-ɹɪkɹɪmɪneɪʃən, ðoʊ.

"Galina's gone," Faile said bitterly. The woman would have answered if she was still above or had any intention of aiding them. "With us trapped down here, maybe dead, she has the perfect excuse for leaving us behind. Anyway, I don't know whether an Aes Sedai could move some of those timbers if she tried." She did not want to mention the possibility that Galina had arranged that excuse herself. Light, she should never have slapped the woman. It was too late for self-recrimination, though.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ wi gɑnə də naʊ?" ɹɛlə æskt.

"What are we going to do now?" Arrela asked.

"dɪɡ aʊɝsɛlvz aʊt," feɪl ən meɪaɪɡdɪn sɛɾ ət ðə seɪm ɪnstənt. feɪl lʊkt ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. hɝ meɪdz dɝɾi feɪs wɔɹ ə kwinz ɹizɑlv.

"Dig ourselves out," Faile and Maighdin said at the same instant. Faile looked at the other woman in surprise. Her maid's dirty face wore a queen's resolve.

"jɛs," æliændɝ sɛd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ. ʃi tɝn ɝaʊnd, ən ɪf ɹʌnəlz ə tɛɹ-tʃɹæks mɑɹk ðə dʌst ɑn əɹ feɪs, noʊ nu tɪɹz əpɪɹd. ʃi ɹɪli wɑz ə kwin, ən kəd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ ʃeɪm baɪ ðə kɝədʒ ʌv ə leɪɾiz meɪd. "wil dɪɡ aʊɝsɛlvz aʊt. ən ɪf wi feɪl. . . . ɪf wi feɪl, əl nɑt daɪ wɛɹɪŋ ðɪs!" ənfæsənɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊldən bɛlt, ʃi flʌŋ ɪt kəntɛmptʃwəsli ɪndə ə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə beɪsmənt. hɝ ɡoʊldən kɑlɝ fɑloʊd.

"Yes," Alliandre said, straightening. She turned around, and if runnels of tear-tracks marked the dust on her face, no new tears appeared. She really was a queen, and could not like being shamed by the courage of a lady's maid. "We'll dig ourselves out. And if we fail. . . . If we fail, I will not die wearing this!" Unfastening her golden belt, she flung it contemptuously into a corner of the basement. Her golden collar followed.

"wil nid ðoʊz tə meɪk əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp," feɪl sɛd dʒɛnli. "ɡəlinə meɪ nɑt bi teɪkɪŋ əs aʊt, bʌɾ aɪ ɪntɛn livɪŋ tədeɪ." dɛɹeɪn meɪd ðəɾ ɪmpɛɹəɾɪv. beɪn ən kiæd kəd nɑt kip əɹ hɪɾən lɔŋ. "ɔɹ əz sun wi kən dɪɡ aʊt, ɛniweɪ. wɪl pɹitɛnd wiv bɪn sɛn tə pɪk bɛɹiz." ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə stɛp ɑn əɹ lidʒ-wʊmənz boʊl dʒɛstʃɝ, ðoʊ. "haʊɛvɝ, wi doʊnt nid tə wɛɹ əm naʊ." ɹimuvɪŋ əɹ bɛlt ən kɑlɝ, ʃi ɹaɪɾɪd əɹ bæskəɾ ən sɛɾ əm ətɑp ðə dɝɾi ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz. ði ʌðɝz ɛmjəleɪɾɪd hɝ. æliændɝ ɹitʃɹivd əɹ oʊn bɛlt ən kɑlɝ wɪð ə ɹufəl læf. ət list ʃi kəd læf əɡɛn. feɪl wɪʃt ʃi kʊd.

"We'll need those to make our way through the Shaido camp," Faile said gently. "Galina may not be taking us out, but I intend leaving today." Dairaine made that imperative. Bain and Chiad could not keep her hidden long. "Or as soon we can dig out, anyway. We'll pretend we've been sent to pick berries." She did not want to step on her liege-woman's bold gesture, though. "However, we don't need to wear them now." Removing her belt and collar, she righted her basket and set them atop the dirty gai'shain robes. The others emulated her. Alliandre retrieved her own belt and collar with a rueful laugh. At least she could laugh again. Faile wished she could.

ðə dʒʌmbəl ə tʃɑɹd tɪmbɝz ən hæf-bɝn bɔɹdz fɪlɪŋ ðə stɛɹkeɪs ɹɪzɛmbəld wʌn ə ðoʊz blæksmɪθs pʌzəlz əɹ pɛɹɪn ɛndʒɔɪd. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim tə bi pɹɑpɪŋ ʌp sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. wɝs, ðə hɛviɝ tɪmbɝz maɪt bi bɪɑn ɔl ə ðɛm wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ kəd klɪɹ ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə bi eɪbəl tə kɹɔl θɹu, ɹaɪðɪŋ bɪtwin ðə θɪk bimz. . . . ɪt wəd bi deɪnʒɝəs, ðət kɹɔl. bʌt wən ə deɪnʒɝəs pæθ wɑz jəɹ oʊnli ɹut tə seɪfti, jə hæd tə teɪk ɪt.

The jumble of charred timbers and half-burned boards filling the staircase resembled one of those blacksmith's puzzles her Perrin enjoyed. Almost everything seemed to be propping up something else. Worse, the heavier timbers might be beyond all of them working together. But if they could clear enough for them to be able to crawl through, writhing between the thick beams. . . . It would be dangerous, that crawl. But when a dangerous path was your only route to safety, you had to take it.

ə fju bɔɹdz keɪm əweɪ izəli ən wɝ paɪld ət ðə bæk ə ðə beɪsmənt, bʌɾ æftɝ ðəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd tə bi tʃoʊzən wɪð kɛɹ, ɪɡzæmən tə si wɛðɝ ɛniθɪŋ wəd fɔl ɪf ɪt wɝ ɹimuvd, hænz filɪŋ bæk əz fɑɹ əz ðeɪ kəd ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə tæŋɡəl, ɡɹoʊpɪŋ fəɹ neɪlz ðət maɪɾ əv kɑt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðə hoʊl paɪl ʃɪftɪŋ ən tʃɹæpɪŋ ən ɑɹm, kɹʌʃɪŋ ɪt. oʊnli ðən kəd ðeɪ bɪɡɪn pʊlɪŋ, səmtaɪmz tu ʌv əm təɡɛðɝ, tʌɡɪŋ hɑɹɾɝ ən hɑɹɾɝ əntɪl ðə pis sʌɾənli ɡeɪv. ðət wɝk wɛn sloʊli, wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪt paɪl əkeɪʒənəli ɡɹoʊnɪŋ, əɹ ʃɪftɪŋ slaɪtli. ɛvɹiwʌn dɑɹɾɪd bæk, hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ bɹɛθ, wən ðət hæpənd. noʊbɑdi muvd əɡɛn əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ʃʊɹ ðə snɑɹl ə tɪmbɝz wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə kəlæps. ðə wɝk bɪkeɪm ðə foʊkəs ə ðɛɹ wɝld. wʌns, feɪl θɔt ʃi hɝd wʊlvz haʊlɪŋ. wʊlvz dʒɛnɝəli meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ə pɛɹɪn, bʌt nɑt ðɪs taɪm. ðə wɝk wɑz ɔl.

A few boards came away easily and were piled at the back of the basement, but after that everything had to be chosen with care, examined to see whether anything would fall if it were removed, hands feeling back as far as they could go into the tangle, groping for nails that might have caught, trying not to think about the whole pile shifting and trapping an arm, crushing it. Only then could they begin pulling, sometimes two of them together, tugging harder and harder until the piece suddenly gave. That work went slowly, with the great pile occasionally groaning, or shifting slightly. Everyone darted back, holding their breath, when that happened. Nobody moved again until they were sure the snarl of timbers was not going to collapse. The work became the focus of their world. Once, Faile thought she heard wolves howling. Wolves generally made her think of Perrin, but not this time. The work was all.

ðən æliændɝ ɹɛntʃt ə tʃɑɹd bɔɹd fɹi, ən wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt ɡɹoʊn, ðə mæs bɪɡæn tə ʃɪft. təwɔɹd ðɛm. ɛvɹiwʌn ɹæn təwɔɹd ðə bæk ə ðə beɪsmən əz ðə paɪl fɛl ɪn wɪð ə dɛfənɪŋ ɹʌmbəl, sɛndɪŋ ʌp mɔɹ bɪloʊz ə dʌst.

Then Alliandre wrenched a charred board free, and with a great groan, the mass began to shift. Toward them. Everyone ran toward the back of the basement as the pile fell in with a deafening rumble, sending up more billows of dust.

wən ðeɪ stɑp kɑfɪŋ ən kəd si əɡɛn, dɪmli, wɪð dʌst stɪl hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, pɝhæps ə kɔɹɾɝ ə ðə beɪsmənt wɑz fɪld. ɔl ə ðɛɹ wɝk əndʌn, ən wɝs, ðə dʒʌmbəl wɑz linɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əm pɹɪkɛɹiəsli. ɡɹoʊnɪŋ, ɪt sæɡd ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ təwɔɹɾ əm ən stɑpt. ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt sɛd ðə fɝs bɔɹd pʊl fɹi wəd bɹɪŋ ðə hoʊl mæs daʊn ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz. ɹɛlə bɪɡæn tə kɹaɪ sɔfli. tæntəlaɪzɪŋ ɡæps ədmɪɾəd sʌnlaɪɾ ən əlaʊɾ əm tə si ðə stʃɹit, ðə skaɪ, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ɛniwʌn kəd ɹɪɡəl θɹu, ivən lətʃəl. feɪl kəd si ðə ɹɛd skɑɹf ɡəlinə hæd juz tə mɑɹk ðə bɪldɪŋ. ɪt flʌɾɝd fəɹ ə moʊmən ɪn ðə bɹiz.

When they stopped coughing and could see again, dimly, with dust still hanging in the air, perhaps a quarter of the basement was filled. All of their work undone, and worse, the jumble was leaning toward them precariously. Groaning, it sagged a little more toward them and stopped. Everything about it said the first board pulled free would bring the whole mass down on their heads. Arrela began to cry softly. Tantalizing gaps admitted sunlight and allowed them to see the street, the sky, but nothing anyone could wriggle through, even Lacile. Faile could see the red scarf Galina had used to mark the building. It fluttered for a moment in the breeze.

stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə skɑɹf, ʃi siz meɪaɪɡdɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. "aɪ wɑn jə tə tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk ðət skɑɹf də sʌmθɪŋ ðə wɪnd wʊdn meɪk ɪt du."

Staring at the scarf, she seized Maighdin's shoulder. "I want you to try to make that scarf do something the wind wouldn't make it do."

"ju wɑnə ətʃɹækt ətɛnʃən?" æliændɝ sɛd hɔɹsli. "ɪts fɑɹ mɔɹ laɪkli tə bi ʃeɪɾoʊ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls."

"You want to attract attention?" Alliandre said hoarsely. "It's far more likely to be Shaido than anyone else."

"bɛɾɝ ðət ðən daɪɪŋ daʊn hɪɹ ə θɝst," feɪl ɹɪplaɪd, hɝ vɔɪs hɑɹʃɝ ðən ʃi wɑntəd. ʃi wəd nɛvɝ si pɛɹɪn əɡɛn, ðɛn. ɪf sɪvænə hæɾ əɹ tʃeɪnd, ʃi wəɾ ət lis bi əlaɪv fəɹ ɪm tə ɹɛskju. hi wəd ɹɛskju hɝ; ʃi nu ɪt. hɝ duɾi naʊ wɑz tə kip ðə wɪmən u fɑloʊɾ əɹ əlaɪv. ən ɪf ðət mɛn kæptɪvəɾi, soʊ bi ɪt. "meɪaɪɡdɪn?"

"Better that than dying down here of thirst," Faile replied, her voice harsher than she wanted. She would never see Perrin again, then. If Sevanna had her chained, she would at least be alive for him to rescue. He would rescue her; she knew it. Her duty now was to keep the women who followed her alive. And if that meant captivity, so be it. "Maighdin?"

"aɪ maɪt spɛn ɔl deɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ən nɛvɝ səksid," ðə sʌn-hɛɹd wʊmən sɛɾ ɪn dʌl toʊnz. ʃi stʊd slʌmpt, stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ. hɝ feɪs sədʒɛstəd ðət ʃi sɔ ən əbɪs bɪniθ əɹ fit. "æn ɪf aɪ də ɛmbɹeɪs ɪt, aɪ kən ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ wiv ɛniθɪŋ."

"I might spend all day trying to embrace the Source and never succeed," the sun-haired woman said in dull tones. She stood slumped, staring at nothing. Her face suggested that she saw an abyss beneath her feet. "And if I do embrace it, I can almost never weave anything."

feɪl lusən əɹ ɡɹɪp ɑn meɪaɪɡdɪn ən smuðd əɹ hɛɹ ɪnstɛd. "aɪ noʊ ɪts dɪfəkəlt," ʃi sɛd suðɪŋli. "wɛl, ɪn tʃɹuθ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ. aɪv nɛvɝ dʌn ɪt. bʌt jə hæv. ən jə kən də ɪɾ əɡɛn. əɹ lɪvz dɪpɛn ɑn ju, meɪaɪɡdɪn. aɪ noʊ ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ðæts ɪn ju. aɪv sin ɪt taɪm ən əɡɛn. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ sɝɛndɝ ɪn ju. aɪ noʊ jə kən də ɪt, ən soʊ də ju."

Faile loosened her grip on Maighdin and smoothed her hair instead. "I know it's difficult," she said soothingly. "Well, in truth, I don't know. I've never done it. But you have. And you can do it again. Our lives depend on you, Maighdin. I know the strength that's in you. I've seen it time and again. There is no surrender in you. I know you can do it, and so do you."

sloʊli, meɪaɪɡdɪnz bæk stʃɹeɪɾənd, ən dɪspɛɹ slɪɾ ɔf əɹ feɪs. ʃi maɪt stɪl si ði əbɪs, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi fɛl, ʃi wəd fɔl wɪθaʊt flɪntʃɪŋ. "aɪl tʃɹaɪ," ʃi sɛd.

Slowly, Maighdin's back straightened, and despair slid off her face. She might still see the abyss, but if she fell, she would fall without flinching. "I'll try," she said.

fəɹ ə lɔŋ waɪl ʃi stɛɹɾ ʌp ət ðə skɑɹf, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd dɪdʒɛktɪdli. "ðə sɔɹs ɪz ðɛɹ, laɪk ðə sʌn dʒʌs bɪɑn ði ɛdʒ ə saɪt," ʃi wɪspɝd, "bʌɾ ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ tʃɹaɪ tə ɛmbɹeɪs ɪt, ɪts laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ smoʊk wɪð maɪ fɪŋɡɝz."

For a long while she stared up at the scarf, then shook her head dejectedly. "The Source is there, like the sun just beyond the edge of sight," she whispered, "but every time I try to embrace it, it's like trying to catch smoke with my fingers."

feɪl heɪstəli pʊl ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz fɹəm əɹ bæskəɾ ən ənʌðɝ, kɛɹləs ə ðə ɡoʊl bɛls ən kɑlɝz fɔlɪŋ tə ðə stoʊn flɔɹ. "sɪt daʊn," ʃi sɛd, ɝeɪnʒɪŋ ðə ɹoʊbz ɪn ə paɪl. "meɪk jɝsɛlf kʌmftəɹbəl. aɪ noʊ jə kən də ɪt, meɪaɪɡdɪn." pɹɛsɪŋ ði ʌðɝ wʊmən daʊn, ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ lɛɡz ən sæt bɪsaɪd hɝ.

Faile hastily pulled the gai'shain robes from her basket and another, careless of the gold belts and collars falling to the stone floor. "Sit down," she said, arranging the robes in a pile. "Make yourself comfortable. I know you can do it, Maighdin." Pressing the other woman down, she folded her legs and sat beside her.

"ju kən də ɪt," æliændɝ sɛd sɔfli, sɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɑn meɪaɪɡdɪnz ʌðɝ saɪd.

"You can do it," Alliandre said softly, sitting down on Maighdin's other side.

"jɛs, jə kæn," lətʃəl wɪspɝd, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðɛm.

"Yes, you can," Lacile whispered, joining them.

"aɪ noʊ jə kæn," ɹɛlə sɛɾ əz ʃi loʊɝd hɝsɛlf tə ðə flɔɹ.

"I know you can," Arrela said as she lowered herself to the floor.

taɪm pæst, wɪð meɪaɪɡdɪn stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə skɑɹf. feɪl wɪspɝɾ ɛnkɝɪdʒmən ən hɛld ɑn tə hoʊp hɑɹd. sʌɾənli ðə skɑɹf wɛn ɹɪdʒəd, əz ɪf sʌmθɪŋ hæd pʊld ɪt tɔt. ə wʌnʒɹəs smaɪl əpɪɹɾ ɑn meɪaɪɡdɪnz feɪs əz ðə skɑɹf bɪɡæn tə swɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ laɪk ə pɛnʒələm. sɪks, sɛvən, eɪt taɪmz ɪt swʌŋ. ðən ɪt flʌɾɝd ɪn ðə bɹiz ən fɛl lɪmp.

Time passed, with Maighdin staring at the scarf. Faile whispered encouragement and held on to hope hard. Suddenly the scarf went rigid, as if something had pulled it taut. A wondrous smile appeared on Maighdin's face as the scarf began to swing back and forth like a pendulum. Six, seven, eight times it swung. Then it fluttered in the breeze and fell limp.

"ðæt wɑz mɑɹvələs," feɪl sɛd.

"That was marvelous," Faile said.

"mɑɹvələs," æliændɝ sɛd. "jɔɹ gɑnə seɪv ʌs, meɪaɪɡdɪn."

"Marvelous," Alliandre said. "You're going to save us, Maighdin."

"jɛs," ɹɛlə mɝmɝd, "jɔɹ gɑnə seɪv ʌs, meɪaɪɡdɪn."

"Yes," Arrela murmured, "you're going to save us, Maighdin."

ðəɹ wɝ mɛni kaɪnz ə bæɾəl. sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, wɪspɝɪŋ ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt, meɪaɪɡdɪn faɪɾɪŋ tə faɪnd wʌt ʃi kəd sɛldəm faɪnd, ðeɪ fɔt fəɹ ðɛɹ laɪvz waɪl ðə skɑɹf swʌŋ, ðən fɛl tə ðə bɹiz, swʌŋ ən fɛl lɪmp. bʌt ðeɪ fɔɾ ɑn.

There were many kinds of battle. Sitting on the floor, whispering encouragement, Maighdin fighting to find what she could seldom find, they fought for their lives while the scarf swung, then fell to the breeze, swung and fell limp. But they fought on.

ɡəlinə kɛpt əɹ hɛd daʊn ən tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə hɝi əz ʃi meɪɾ əɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə mɔldən, pæs ðə stʃɹimz ʌv waɪt-klæd mɛn ən wɪmən kæɹiɪŋ ɛmpti bʌkəts ɪndə ðə taʊn ən fʊl bʌkəts bæk aʊt. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ətʃɹækt ətɛnʃən, nɑt wɪθaʊt ðət kɝs bɛlt ən nɛkləs. ʃi hæd dɑn ðə θɪŋz wən ʃi dʒɹɛst ɪn ðə naɪt, waɪl θɛɝɑvə wɑz stɪl əslip, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn sətʃ ə plɛʒɝ tə ɹimuv əm ən haɪɾ əm wɪð ðə kloʊðz ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz ʃi hæd səkɹiɾəd əweɪ fəɹ əɹ ɪskeɪp ðət ʃi kəd nɑt ɹɪzɪst. bɪsaɪdz, θɛɝɑvə wʊɾə bɪn æŋɡɝd tə weɪk ən faɪn əɹ mɪsɪŋ. ʃi wʊɾə ɔɹɾɝd ə wɑtʃ fəɹ əɹ "lɪɾəl linə," ən ɛvɹiwʌn mɑɹkt əɹ baɪ ðoʊz dʒuəlz. wɛl, ðeɪ wəd peɪ tə hɛlp əɹ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə taʊɝ, naʊ, ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ ɹaɪtfəl pleɪs. ðəɾ ɛɹəɡən feɪl ən ði ʌðɝ fulz wɝ dɛɾ əɹ əz ɡʊɾ æz, ən ʃi wɑz fɹi. ʃi stʃɹoʊk ðə ɹɑd, hɪɾən ɪn əɹ sliv, ən ʃɪvɝd wɪð dɪlaɪt. fɹi!

Galina kept her head down and tried not to hurry as she made her way out of Malden, past the streams of white-clad men and women carrying empty buckets into the town and full buckets back out. She did not want to attract attention, not without that cursed belt and necklace. She had donned the things when she dressed in the night, while Therava was still asleep, but it had been such a pleasure to remove them and hide them with the clothes and other things she had secreted away for her escape that she could not resist. Besides, Therava would have been angered to wake and find her missing. She would have ordered a watch for her "little Lina," and everyone marked her by those jewels. Well, they would pay to help her return to the Tower, now, return to her rightful place. That arrogant Faile and the other fools were dead or as good as, and she was free. She stroked the rod, hidden in her sleeve, and shivered with delight. Free!

ʃi dɪd heɪt livɪŋ θɛɝɑvə əlaɪv, bʌɾ ɪf ɛniwʌn hæɾ ɛntɝd ðə wʊmənz tɛn ən faʊn əɹ wɪð ə naɪf θɹu hɝ hɑɹt, ɡəlinə wʊɾə bɪn ðə fɝst səspɛkt. bɪsaɪdz. . . . ɪmədʒəz ɹoʊz ɪn əɹ hɛd, ʌv əɹ bɛndɪŋ stɛlθəli oʊvɝ ðə slipɪŋ θɛɝɑvə, ðə wʊmənz oʊn bɛl naɪf ɪn hænd, ʌv θɛɝɑvəz aɪz snæpɪŋ oʊpən, miɾɪŋ hɝz ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ʌv əɹ skɹimɪŋ, ʌv əɹ hæn oʊpənɪŋ nɝvləsli tə dʒɹɑp ðə naɪf, ʌv əɹ bɛɡɪŋ, ʌv θɛɝɑvə. . . . noʊ. noʊ! ɪt wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ðət weɪ. sɝɾənli nɑt! ʃi hæd lɛf θɛɝɑvə əlaɪv ə nəsɛsəɾi, nɑt kəz ʃi wɑz. . . . nɑt fəɹ ɛni ʌðɝ ɹizən.

She did hate leaving Therava alive, but if anyone had entered the woman's tent and found her with a knife through her heart, Galina would have been the first suspect. Besides. . . . Images rose in her head, of her bending stealthily over the sleeping Therava, the woman's own belt knife in hand, of Therava's eyes snapping open, meeting hers in the darkness, of her screaming, of her hand opening nervelessly to drop the knife, of her begging, of Therava. . . . No. No! It would not have been that way. Certainly not! She had left Therava alive of necessity, not because she was. . . . Not for any other reason.

sʌɾənli wʊlvz haʊld, wʊlvz ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, ə dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ. hɝ fit stɑpt ə ðɛɹ oʊn əkɔɹd. ə mɑtli kəlɛkʃən ə tɛns sɝaʊndəd hɝ, wɔl tɛns, pik tɛns, loʊ il tɛns. ʃi hæd wɔkt ɹaɪt θɹu ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn pɔɹʃən ə ðə kæmp wɪθaʊt ɹilaɪzɪŋ ɪt. hɝ aɪz ɹoʊz tə ðə ɹɪdʒ wɛst ə mɔldən, ən ʃi flɪntʃt. θɪk fɑɡ kɝld əlɔŋ ðə hoʊl lɛŋθ ʌv ɪt, kənsilɪŋ ðə tʃɹiz əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəd si ɪn iðɝ dɝɛkʃən. ðə taʊn wɔlz hɪd ðə ɹɪdʒ tə ði ist, jɛt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wəd bi θɪk fɑɡ ðɛɹ, tu. ðə mæn hæd kʌm! ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd pɹəzɝv hɝ, ʃi hæd bɪn dʒʌst ɪn taɪm. wɛl, hi wəd nɑt faɪn ɪz ful waɪf ivən ɪf i mænədʒ tə sɝvaɪv wʌtɛvɝ i wɑz əbaʊt tə tʃɹaɪ, nɔɹ wəɾ i faɪnd ɡəlinə kæsbən.

Suddenly wolves howled, wolves in every direction, a dozen or more. Her feet stopped of their own accord. A motley collection of tents surrounded her, walled tents, peaked tents, low Aiel tents. She had walked right through the gai'shain portion of the camp without realizing it. Her eyes rose to the ridge west of Malden, and she flinched. Thick fog curled along the whole length of it, concealing the trees as far as she could see in either direction. The town walls hid the ridge to the east, yet she was sure there would be thick fog there, too. The man had come! The Great Lord preserve her, she had been just in time. Well, he would not find his fool wife even if he managed to survive whatever he was about to try, nor would he find Galina Casban.

θæŋkɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd ðət θɛɝɑvə hæd nɑt fɔɹbɪɾən əɹ tə ɹaɪd - ðə wʊmən hæd mʌtʃ pɹəfɝd dæŋɡəlɪŋ ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət ʃi maɪt bi əlaʊd, ɪf ʃi ɡɹoʊvəl səfɪʃənli - ɡəlinə hɝid təwɔɹɾ əɹ hɪɾən stɔɹz. lɛt ðə fulz u wɑntəd tə daɪ hɪɹ, daɪ. ʃi wɑz fɹi. fɹi!

Thanking the Great Lord that Therava had not forbidden her to ride - the woman had much preferred dangling the possibility that she might be allowed, if she groveled sufficiently - Galina hurried toward her hidden stores. Let the fools who wanted to die here, die. She was free. Free!

tʃæptɝ twɛntinaɪn

CHAPTER 29

ðə læs nɑt pɛɹɪn stʊd dʒʌs bɪloʊ ðə ɹɪdʒtɑp, nɪɹ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə fɑɡ, ən stʌɾid ði ɛnkæmpmən ən stoʊn-wɔl taʊn bɪloʊ. tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ə fɛɹli stip sloʊp spɑɹsli dɑɾəd wɪð loʊ bɹʌʃ daʊn tə lɛvəl ɡɹaʊnd, pɝhæps sɛvən hʌnʒɹəd mɔɹ ə klɪɹd ɡɹaʊn tə ðə fɝs tɛns, ðən bɛɾɝ ðən ə maɪl tə ðə taʊn. ɪt sim soʊ kloʊs, naʊ. hi dɪd nɑt juz ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. ə ɡlɪn ɔf ðə lɛnz fɹəm ðə sʌn dʒʌs pikɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə hɝaɪzən, ə fɪŋɡɝneɪl ɛdʒ ʌv ɡoʊldən-ɹɛd, maɪt ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ðə ɡɹeɪnəs ɝaʊn ɪm kɝl bʌt dɪd nɑt ɹɪli muv wɪð ðə bɹiz, ivən wən ɪt ɡʌstɪɾ ən meɪɾ ɪz kloʊk stɝ. ðə dɛns mɪst ɑn ðə fɑɹ ɹɪdʒ, əbskjʊɹɪŋ ðə wɪndmɪl ðɛɹ, sim tu stɪl əz wɛl, ɪf jə stʌɾid ɪɾ ə waɪl. haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ sʌmwʌn əmʌŋ ðoʊz tɛns noʊɾəst? ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn fəɹ ɪt. ðə fɑɡ fɛlt laɪk ɛni fɑɡ, dæmp ən ə lɪɾəl kul, bʌt sʌmhaʊ nil hæd fɪks ðiz mɪsts ɪn pleɪs bɪfɔɹ i wɛn ɔf tə hɪz ʌðɝ tæsks. ðə sʌn wəd nɑt bɝn əm ɔf ivən ət nundeɪ, əɹ soʊ ði æʃəmən kleɪmd. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wəd bi dʌn baɪ nun, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, bʌt pɛɹɪn hoʊp ðə mæn wɑz ɹaɪt. ðə skaɪ wɑz klɪɹ, ən ðə deɪ lʊk tə bi wɔɹm fəɹ ɝli spɹɪŋ.

The Last Knot Perrin stood just below the ridgetop, near the edge of the fog, and studied the encampment and stone-walled town below. Two hundred paces of fairly steep slope sparsely dotted with low brush down to level ground, perhaps seven hundred more of cleared ground to the first tents, then better than a mile to the town. It seemed so close, now. He did not use his looking glass. A glint off the lens from the sun just peeking over the horizon, a fingernail edge of golden-red, might ruin everything. The grayness around him curled but did not really move with the breeze, even when it gusted and made his cloak stir. The dense mist on the far ridge, obscuring the windmill there, seemed too still as well, if you studied it a while. How long before someone among those tents noticed? There was nothing to be done for it. The fog felt like any fog, damp and a little cool, but somehow Neald had fixed these mists in place before he went off to his other tasks. The sun would not burn them off even at noonday, or so the Asha'man claimed. Everything would be done by noon, one way or another, but Perrin hoped the man was right. The sky was clear, and the day looked to be warm for early spring.

oʊnli ə fju ʃeɪɾoʊ sim tə bi aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðə kæmp, ɹɛləɾɪvli spikɪŋ, bʌt θaʊzənz ʌv waɪt-klæd fɪɡjɝz bʌsəld əbaʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə tɛns. tɛnz ə θaʊzənz. hɪz aɪz ætʃt tə faɪn feɪl əmʌŋ ðɛm, hɪz hɑɹɾ ætʃt tə si hɝ, bʌɾ i kəɾ əz wɛl tʃɹaɪ tə pɪk aʊt wʌn pɝtɪkjəlɝ pɪn fɹəm ə bɑɹli-bæskəɾ ə ðɛm spɪld ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɪnstɛd, hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə taʊnz ɡeɪts, stændɪŋ waɪɾ oʊpən əz ðeɪ hæɾ ɛvɹi taɪm i hæd ɡeɪzd ɑn ðɛm. ɪnvaɪɾɪŋli waɪd. ðeɪ kɔl tə hɪm. sun, feɪl ən əɹ kəmpænjənz wəd noʊ ɪt wɑz taɪm tə hɛd fəɹ ðoʊz ɡeɪts, ən ðə taʊɝd fɔɹtʃɹəs ðət bʌlkt ət ðə nɔɹθ ɛn ə ðə taʊn. ʃi maɪt bi ət tʃɔɹz, ɪf ðə meɪɾənz wɝ ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt haʊ ðə pɹɪznɝz wəd bi tʃɹiɾəd əz ɡeɪʃeɪn, bʌt ʃi wəd noʊ tə slɪp əweɪ ən ɡoʊ tə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs. ʃi ən əɹ fɹɛnz, ən laɪkli ælɪs əz wɛl. wʌtɛvɝ əɹ skim wɪð ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ə bæɾəlɡɹaʊnd. ə sɛkən sɪstɝ ɪn ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs maɪt kʌm ɪn hændi. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt dɪd nɑt kʌm tə ðæt.

Only a few Shaido seemed to be outside in the camp, relatively speaking, but thousands of white-clad figures bustled about among the tents. Tens of thousands. His eyes ached to find Faile among them, his heart ached to see her, but he could as well try to pick out one particular pin from a barley-basket of them spilled on the ground. Instead, he stared at the town's gates, standing wide open as they had every time he had gazed on them. Invitingly wide. They called to him. Soon, Faile and her companions would know it was time to head for those gates, and the towered fortress that bulked at the north end of the town. She might be at chores, if the Maidens were right about how the prisoners would be treated as gai'shain, but she would know to slip away and go to the fortress. She and her friends, and likely Alyse as well. Whatever her scheme with the Shaido, the Aes Sedai would not want to remain on a battleground. A second sister in the fortress might come in handy. The Light send it did not come to that.

hi hæd plænd wɪð kɛɹ fəɹ ɛvɹi əvɛntʃuælɪɾi hi kəɾ ɪmædʒən daʊn tə aʊtʃɹaɪt dɪzæstɝ, jɛt ðɪs wɑz noʊ blæksmɪθs pʌzəl haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ i wɪʃt ɪt wɝ. ðə twɪstəɾ aɪɝn pisəz ʌv ə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl muvd oʊnli ɪn sɝɾən weɪz. muv əm ɪn ðə ɹaɪt weɪ, ən ðə pʌzəl keɪm əpɑɹt. pipəl kəd muv ɪn ə θaʊzənd weɪz, səmtaɪmz ɪn dɝɛkʃənz jə nɛvɝ bɪliv pɑsəbəl tɪl ɪt hæpənd. wəɾ ɪz plænz stæn ʌp wən ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ dɪd sʌmθɪŋ ʌnɪkspɛktɪd? ðeɪ wəd də ɪt, ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli, ən ɔl i kəd də ɪn ɹɪtɝn wɑz hoʊp ɪt wəd nɑt lɛd tə ðət dɪzæstɝ. wɪð ə læst, lɔŋɪŋ lʊk ət mɔldənz ɡeɪts, hi tɝn ən wɔk bæk ʌp ðə ɹɪdʒ.

He had planned with care for every eventuality he could imagine down to outright disaster, yet this was no blacksmith's puzzle however much he wished it were. The twisted iron pieces of a blacksmith's puzzle moved only in certain ways. Move them in the right way, and the puzzle came apart. People could move in a thousand ways, sometimes in directions you never believed possible till it happened. Would his plans stand up when the Shaido did something unexpected? They would do it, almost certainly, and all he could do in return was hope it would not lead to that disaster. With a last, longing look at Malden's gates, he turned and walked back up the ridge.

ɪnsaɪd ðə fɑɡ, ivən i kəd nɑt si tɛn peɪsɪz, bʌɾ i sun faʊn dænɪl luɪn əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz ɑn ðə ɹɪdʒtɑp. lin tə ðə pɔɪn ə skɪni, wɪð ə pɪkeɪks fəɹ ə noʊz ən θɪk mʌstæʃɪz ɪn ðə tæɹɑbənɝ staɪl, dænɪl stʊɾ aʊɾ ivən wən jə kəd nɑt si hɪz feɪs klɪɹli. ʌðɝ tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝ ʃeɪps bɪɑn hɪm, ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɪmɝ ən dɪmɝ wɪð dɪstəns. moʊst wɝ skwɑɾɪŋ əɹ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɹɛstɪŋ waɪl ðeɪ hæd ðə tʃæns. dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝ wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪntaɪs səm ə ði ʌðɝz ɪndə ə ɡeɪm ə daɪs, bʌɾ i wɑz kwaɪəɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, soʊ pɛɹɪn lɛɾ ɪt pæs. noʊ wʌn wɑz æksɛptɪŋ ði ɔfɝ ɛniweɪ. dʒɔɹi wɑz ənkɑmən lʌki wɪð ɪz daɪs.

Inside the fog, even he could not see ten paces, but he soon found Dannil Lewin among the trees on the ridgetop. Lean to the point of skinny, with a pickaxe for a nose and thick mustaches in the Taraboner style, Dannil stood out even when you could not see his face clearly. Other Two Rivers men were shapes beyond him, growing dimmer and dimmer with distance. Most were squatting or sitting on the ground, resting while they had the chance. Jori Congar was trying to entice some of the others into a game of dice, but he was quiet about it, so Perrin let it pass. No one was accepting the offer anyway. Jori was uncommon lucky with his dice.

dænɪl meɪɾ ə lɛɡ wən i sɔ pɛɹɪn ən mɝmɝd, "maɪ lɔɹd." ðə mæn hæd bɪn spɛndɪŋ tu mʌtʃ taɪm wɪð feɪlz pipəl. hi kɔld ɪɾ əkwaɪɹɪŋ pɑlɪʃ, wʌtɛvɝ ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə min. ə mæn wɑz nɑɾ ə pis ə bɹæs.

Dannil made a leg when he saw Perrin and murmured, "My Lord." The man had been spending too much time with Faile's people. He called it acquiring polish, whatever that was supposed to mean. A man was not a piece of brass.

"meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊbɑdi dʌz ɛniθɪŋ wʊlhɛd fulɪʃ laɪk aɪ dʒʌs dɪd, dænɪl. ʃɑɹp aɪz bɪloʊ maɪt spɑt muvmənt nɪɹ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə fɑɡ ən sɛn mɛn tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt."

"Make sure nobody does anything woolhead foolish like I just did, Dannil. Sharp eyes below might spot movement near the edge of the fog and send men to investigate."

dænɪl kɔf dɪskɹitli ɪndə hɪz hænd. laɪt, hi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ əz bæɾ əz ɛni ʌv ðoʊz kɛɹhinɪn ən tɛɹənz. "æz jə seɪ, maɪ lɔɹd. əl kip ɛvɹibɑɾi bæk."

Dannil coughed discreetly into his hand. Light, he was getting as bad as any of those Cairhienin and Tairens. "As you say, my Lord. I'll keep everybody back."

"maɪ lɔɹd?" beɪlwɝz dʒɹaɪ vɔɪs sɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə mɪst. "ɑ, ðəɹ jə ɑɹ, maɪ lɔɹd." ðə lɪɾəl stɪk ʌv ə mæn əpɪɹd, fɑloʊd baɪ tu lɑɹdʒɝ ʃeɪps, ðoʊ wʌn wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ tɔlɝ. ðeɪ hɔltəɾ əɾ ə dʒɛstʃɝ fɹəm hɪm, ɪndɪstɪŋk fɔɹmz ɪn ðə fɑɡ, ən i keɪm ɑn əloʊn. "mæsimə hæz pʊɾ ɪn ən əpɪɹəns bɪloʊ, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛd kwaɪətli, foʊldɪŋ ɪz hænz. "aɪ θɔɾ ɪt bɛs tə kip hɑviɑɹ ən nɛɹiən aʊɾ ə hɪz saɪt, ən ɪz mɛnz, ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz. aɪ doʊn bɪliv hiz səspɪʃəs ə ðɛm. aɪ θɪŋk hiz ɛniwʌn hiz səspɪʃəs ə kɪld. bʌɾ aʊɾ ə saɪt, aʊɾ ə maɪn ɪz bɛst."

"My Lord?" Balwer's dry voice said out of the mist. "Ah, there you are, my Lord." The little stick of a man appeared, followed by two larger shapes, though one was not much taller. They halted at a gesture from him, indistinct forms in the fog, and he came on alone. "Masema has put in an appearance below, my Lord," he said quietly, folding his hands. "I thought it best to keep Haviar and Nerion out of his sight, and his men's, under the circumstances. I don't believe he is suspicious of them. I think he has anyone he is suspicious of killed. But out of sight, out of mind is best."

pɛɹɪnz dʒɔ taɪɾənd. mæsimə wɑz səpoʊz tə bi bɪɑn ði istɝn ɹɪdʒ wɪð ɪz ɑɹmi, ɪf ɪt kəd bi kɔl ðæt. hi hæd kaʊntəd ðoʊz mɛn - ən ə fju wɪmən - əz ðeɪ ʃʌfəld ənizəli θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz meɪd baɪ ðə tu æʃəmən, ən ðeɪ wɝ twɛnti θaʊzən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ wʌn. mæsimə hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn veɪɡ əbaʊt ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz, ən pɛɹɪn hæd nɑt hæɾ ən ækjɝət kaʊn əntɪl læs naɪt. ɹæɡəɾ ən dɝɾi, oʊnli wʌn hɪɹ əɹ ðəɹ wɔɹ ə hɛlmət mʌtʃ lɛs ə bɹɛstpleɪt, bʌɾ ɛvɹi hæn hæd ɡɹɪp sɔɹɾ əɹ spɪɹ əɹ æks, hælbɹɾ əɹ kɹɔsboʊ, ðə wɪmən ɪnkluɾəd. ðə wɪmən əmʌŋ mæsiməz fɑloʊɝz wɝ wɝs ðən ðə mɛn baɪ fɑɹ, ən ðət wɑz seɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm wɝ oʊnli ɡʊd fəɹ tɛɹɝaɪzɪŋ pipəl ɪndə swɛɹɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn - ðə kʌlɝz wɝld ɪn ɪz hɛɾ ən wɝ ʃæɾɝd baɪ hɪz æŋɡɝ - ðəɾ ən mɝɾɝɪŋ əm ɪf ðeɪ ɹəfjuzd. ðeɪ hæɾ ə bɛɾɝ pɝpəs tədeɪ. "meɪbi ɪts taɪm fəɹ hɑviɑɹ ən nɛɹiən tə stɑɹt steɪɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm mæsiməz pipəl fəɹ ɡʊd," hi sɛd.

Perrin's jaw tightened. Masema was supposed to be beyond the eastern ridge with his army, if it could be called that. He had counted those men - and a few women - as they shuffled uneasily through gateways made by the two Asha'man, and they were twenty thousand if they were one. Masema had always been vague about their numbers, and Perrin had not had an accurate count until last night. Ragged and dirty, only one here or there wore a helmet much less a breastplate, but every hand had gripped sword or spear or axe, halberd or crossbow, the women included. The women among Masema's followers were worse than the men by far, and that was saying something. For the most part the lot of them were only good for terrorizing people into swearing to follow the Dragon Reborn - the colors whirled in his head and were shattered by his anger - that and murdering them if they refused. They had a better purpose today. "Maybe it's time for Haviar and Nerion to start staying away from Masema's people for good," he said.

"ɪf jə wɪʃ ɪt, maɪ lɔɹd, bʌɾ ɪn maɪ dʒʌdʒmənt, ðeɪ stɪl ɑɹ əz seɪf əz ɛni mæn kən bi duɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ du, ən ðəɹ iɡɝ." beɪlwɝ tɪltəɾ ɪz hɛd, ə kjʊɹiəs spɛɹoʊ ɪn ə bɹæntʃ. "ðeɪ hævən bɪn kɝʌptɪd, ɪf ðæts wʌt jə fɪɹ, maɪ lɔɹd. ðæts ɔlweɪz ə deɪnʒɝ wən jə sɛn ə mæn tə pɹitɛn tə bi wʌɾ i ɪzənt, bʌɾ aɪ hæv ə kin noʊz fəɹ ðə saɪnz."

"If you wish it, my Lord, but in my judgment, they still are as safe as any man can be doing what they do, and they're eager." Balwer tilted his head, a curious sparrow in a branch. "They haven't been corrupted, if that's what you fear, my Lord. That's always a danger when you send a man to pretend to be what he isn't, but I have a keen nose for the signs."

"kip əm kloʊs, beɪlwɝ." æftɝ tədeɪ, wɪð lʌk, ðəɹ maɪt nɑt bi mʌtʃ ə mæsiməz ɑɹmi lɛf tə spaɪ ɑn ɪn ɛni keɪs. ðəɹ maɪt nɑɾ ivən bi ə mæsimə tə wɝi əbaʊt.

"Keep them close, Balwer." After today, with luck, there might not be much of Masema's army left to spy on in any case. There might not even be a Masema to worry about.

pɛɹɪn skɹæmbəl daʊn ðə bɹʌʃi ɹɪvɝs sloʊp, pæst wɛɹ ðə minɝ ən ɡildænɪn lænsɝz wɝ weɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɪn ðə θɪk mɪst, stʃɹimɝd lænsɪz pɹɑpt ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz əɹ stil hɛdz dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz' ɹɛd-peɪntəd hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts maɪɾ əv bɪn seɪf ɪnʌf ɑn ðə ɹɪdʒtɑp, bʌt nɑt ðə ɡildænɪnz bɝnɪʃt ɑɹmɝ, ən sɪns ɡælɛn ən ɑɹɡændə boʊθ bɹɪsəld ɪf wʌn wɑz feɪvɝɾ oʊvɝ ði ʌðɝ, boʊθ weɪɾəd hɪɹ. ðə fɑɡ ɪkstɛndəd kwaɪt səm dɪstəns - nil kleɪm ðət wɑz ɪntɛnʃənəl, bʌt ðə mæn hæd smɛl sɝpɹaɪzd, ən plizd, wən i ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ i hæd dʌn - soʊ pɛɹɪn wɑz stɪl wɔkɪŋ θɹu ɡɹeɪnəs wən i ɹitʃt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə ɹɪdʒ, wɛɹ ɔl ə ðə haɪ-wil kɑɹts stʊɾ ɪn ə laɪn wɪð hɔɹsəz hɪtʃt. ðə dɪm fɪɡjɝz ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz muvd əbaʊt ðɛm, tʃɛkɪŋ hɑɹnəs, taɪɾənɪŋ ðə ɹoʊps ðət hɛl ðə kænvəs kʌvɝz ɑn.

Perrin scrambled down the brushy reverse slope, past where the Mayener and Ghealdanin lancers were waiting beside their horses in the thick mist, streamered lances propped on their shoulders or steel heads driven into the ground. The Winged Guards' red-painted helmets and breastplates might have been safe enough on the ridgetop, but not the Ghealdanin's burnished armor, and since Gallenne and Arganda both bristled if one was favored over the other, both waited here. The fog extended quite some distance - Neald claimed that was intentional, but the man had smelled surprised, and pleased, when he realized what he had done - so Perrin was still walking through grayness when he reached the bottom of the ridge, where all of the high-wheeled carts stood in a line with horses hitched. The dim figures of the Cairhienin cart drivers moved about them, checking harness, tightening the ropes that held the canvas covers on.

mæsimə wɑz weɪɾɪŋ, ən pɛɹɪn wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz tə tʃu ɔf ðə mænz ɑɹm, bʌɾ i spɑɾəd ðə staʊt ʃeɪp ə bɑzəl ɡɪl bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə kɑɹts ən hɛɾəd ðət weɪ. lini wɑz wɪð hɪm, ɹæpt ɪn ə dɑɹk kloʊk, ən bɹin wɪð əɹ ɑɹm ɝaʊn ðə weɪst ə læmɡwɪn, pɛɹɪnz hʌlkɪŋ mænsɝvənt. mæstɝ ɡɪl snætʃt ɔf ɪz bɹɪm hæt tə ɹɪvil θɪn ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ koʊm bæk oʊvɝ ə bɔl spɑt ðəɾ ɪt feɪl tə kʌvɝ. lini snɪft ən pɔɪntɪdli əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn waɪl pɹitɛndɪŋ tə ədʒʌst əɹ kaʊl. ʃi smɛld ʌv æŋɡɝ ən fɪɹ. mæstɝ ɡɪl dʒʌst smɛld ə fɪɹ.

Masema was waiting, and Perrin wanted nothing so much as to chew off the man's arm, but he spotted the stout shape of Basel Gill beside one of the carts and headed that way. Lini was with him, wrapped in a dark cloak, and Breane with her arm around the waist of Lamgwin, Perrin's hulking manservant. Master Gill snatched off his brimmed hat to reveal thin graying hair combed back over a bald spot that it failed to cover. Lini sniffed and pointedly avoided looking at Perrin while pretending to adjust her cowl. She smelled of anger and fear. Master Gill just smelled of fear.

"ɪts taɪm fəɹ jə tə stɑɹt nɔɹθ, mæstɝ ɡɪl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wɛn jə ɹitʃ ðə maʊntənz, fɑloʊ ðɛm əntɪl jə stʃɹaɪk ðə dʒəhænə ɹoʊd. wɪð lʌk, wɪl kætʃ jə ʌp bɪfɔɹ jə ɹitʃ ðə maʊntənz, bʌɾ ɪf nɑt, sɛn æliændɝz sɝvəns ɔf tə dʒəhænə, ðən jə hɛɾ is θɹu ðə pæs, ðən nɔɹθ əɡɛn. wɪl bi əz kloʊs bɪhaɪn jə əz wi kæn." ɪf ɪz plæn dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ tu fɑɹ ɝaɪ. laɪt, hi wɑz ə blæksmɪθ, nɑɾ ə soʊlʒɝ. bʌɾ ivən taɪli hæd faɪnəli əɡɹiɾ ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd plæn.

"It's time for you to start north, Master Gill," Perrin said. "When you reach the mountains, follow them until you strike the Jehannah Road. With luck, we'll catch you up before you reach the mountains, but if not, send Alliandre's servants off to Jehannah, then you head east through the pass, then north again. We'll be as close behind you as we can." If his plan did not go too far awry. Light, he was a blacksmith, not a soldier. But even Tylee had finally agreed it was a good plan.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt liv ðɪs spɑɾ əntɪl aɪ noʊ ðət meɪaɪɡdɪn ɪz seɪf," lini toʊl ðə fɑɡ, hɝ θɪn vɔɪs ə ɹiɾ ʌv aɪɝn. "æn ðə leɪɾi feɪl, ʌv kɔɹs."

"I will not leave this spot until I know that Maighdin is safe," Lini told the fog, her thin voice a reed of iron. "And the Lady Faile, of course."

mæstɝ ɡɪl ɹʌbd ə hæn bæk oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. "maɪ lɔɹd, læmɡwɪn ən aɪ wɝ θɪŋkɪŋ meɪbi wi kəd hɛlp aʊt. ðə leɪɾi feɪl minz ə ɡɹeɪt dil tə ʌs, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn . . . meɪaɪɡdɪn ɪz wʌn ʌv əɹ oʊn. aɪ noʊ wʌn ɛn ʌv ə sɔɹd fɹəm ði ʌðɝ, ən soʊ dʌz læmɡwɪn." hi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ wʌn bɛltəɾ ɝaʊn ɪz bʌlk, jɛɾ ɪf i hæd hændəld ə sɔɹd ðiz pæs twɛnti jɪɹz, pɛɹɪn wəɾ it ðə hoʊl ɡɹeɪt lɛŋθ ə ðət bɛlt. bɹinz ɡɹɪp ɑn læmɡwɪn taɪɾənd, bʌt ðə bɪɡ mæn pæɾəd əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən ɹɛstəɾ ɪz ʌðɝ hæn ɑn ðə hɪlt ʌv ə ʃɔɹtsɔɝd. ðə fɑɡ əbskjʊɹɾ ɪz skɑɹd feɪs ən sʌŋkən nʌkəlz. hi wɑz ə tævɝn bɹɔlɝ, ðoʊ ə ɡʊd mæn ivən soʊ, bʌt nɛvɝ ə sɔɝdzmən.

Master Gill rubbed a hand back over his head. "My Lord, Lamgwin and I were thinking maybe we could help out. The Lady Faile means a great deal to us, and Maighdin . . . Maighdin is one of our own. I know one end of a sword from the other, and so does Lamgwin." He was wearing one belted around his bulk, yet if he had handled a sword these past twenty years, Perrin would eat the whole great length of that belt. Breane's grip on Lamgwin tightened, but the big man patted her shoulder and rested his other hand on the hilt of a shortsword. The fog obscured his scarred face and sunken knuckles. He was a tavern brawler, though a good man even so, but never a swordsman.

"jɔɹ maɪ ʃæmbaɪən, mæstɝ ɡɪl," pɛɹɪn sɛd fɝmli. "ɪts jəɹ duɾi tə ɡɛt ðə kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz ən ɡɹumz ən sɝvəns tə seɪfti. jʊɹz ən læmɡwɪnz. naʊ ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð jə ən si tə ɪt." ðə staʊt mæn nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli. bɹin bɹiðd ə smɔl saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif wən læmɡwɪn nʌkəld ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ ɪn ækwiɛsəns. pɛɹɪn daʊɾɪd ðət ðə mæn cʊɾə hɝd ðə saɪ, ðoʊ læmɡwɪn pʊɾ ɪz ɑɹm ɝaʊn əɹ ən mɝmɝd kʌmfɝɾɪŋ wɝdz.

"You're my shambayan, Master Gill," Perrin said firmly. "It's your duty to get the cart drivers and grooms and servants to safety. Yours and Lamgwin's. Now go on with you and see to it." The stout man nodded reluctantly. Breane breathed a small sigh of relief when Lamgwin knuckled his forehead in acquiescence. Perrin doubted that the man could have heard the sigh, though Lamgwin put his arm around her and murmured comforting words.

lini wɑz nɑt soʊ kəmplaɪənt. bæk stɪf əz ə ɹɑd, ʃi ədʒɹɛs ðə fɑɡ əɡɛn. "aɪ wɪl nɑt liv ðɪs spɑɾ əntɪl aɪ noʊ - "

Lini was not so compliant. Back stiff as a rod, she addressed the fog again. "I will not leave this spot until I know - "

pɛɹɪn slæpt ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ wɪð ə laʊd kɹæk, stɑɹtlɪŋ əɹ ɪndə lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "ɔl jə kən də hɪɹ ɪz kætʃ ði æɡ fɹəm stændɪŋ ɪn ðə dæmp. ðəɾ ən daɪ, ɪf ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ mænədʒ tə bɹeɪk θɹu. əl bɹɪŋ feɪl aʊt. əl bɹɪŋ meɪaɪɡdɪn ən ði ʌðɝz aʊt." hi wʊd, əɹ daɪ hɪmsɛlf ɪn ði ətɛmpt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn seɪɪŋ ðæt, ðoʊ, ən ɹizən nɑt tə. ðeɪ hæd tə bɪliv ɪn ðɛɹ boʊnz ðəɾ i wəd bi fɑloʊɪŋ wɪð feɪl ən ðə ɹɛst. "æn jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ nɔɹθ, lini. feɪl wɪl bi əpsɛt wɪð mi ɪf aɪ lɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ hæpən tə ju. mæstɝ ɡɪl, jə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi ɹaɪdz wɪð jə ɪf juv tə taɪ hɝ ʌp ən pʊɾ əɹ ɪn ðə bæk ʌv ə kɑɹt."

Perrin slapped his hands together with a loud crack, startling her into looking at him in surprise. "All you can do here is catch the ague from standing in the damp. That and die, if the Shaido manage to break through. I'll bring Faile out. I'll bring Maighdin and the others out." He would, or die himself in the attempt. There was no point saying that, though, and reason not to. They had to believe in their bones that he would be following with Faile and the rest. "And you are going north, Lini. Faile will be upset with me if I let anything happen to you. Master Gill, you make sure she rides with you if you have to tie her up and put her in the back of a cart."

mæstɝ ɡɪl dʒɝkt, kɹʌmplɪŋ ɪz hæt bɪtwin ɪz hænz. hi smɛld ʌv əlɑɹm, sʌɾənli, ən lini ʌv pjʊɹ ɪndɪɡneɪʃən. əmjuzmən fɪld læmɡwɪnz sɛnt, ən i ɹʌbd əɾ ɪz noʊz əz ðoʊ kənsilɪŋ ə smaɪl, bʌt stʃɹeɪnʒli, bɹin wɑz ɪndɪɡnənt, tu. wɛl, hi hæd nɛvɝ kleɪm tə ʌndɝstænd wɪmən. ɪf i kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðə wʊmən i wɑz mɛɹid tə, wɪtʃ i kəd nɑt hæf ðə taɪm, ðən ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli hi ɛvɝ wəɾ ʌndɝstæn ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm.

Master Gill jerked, crumpling his hat between his hands. He smelled of alarm, suddenly, and Lini of pure indignation. Amusement filled Lamgwin's scent, and he rubbed at his nose as though concealing a smile, but strangely, Breane was indignant, too. Well, he had never claimed to understand women. If he could not understand the woman he was married to, which he could not half the time, then it was unlikely he ever would understand the rest of them.

ɪn ði ɛnd, lini æktʃəli  klaɪmd ʌp bɪsaɪd ðə dʒɹaɪvɝ ʌv ə kɑɹt wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ tə bi fɔɹst, ðoʊ ʃi slæpt əweɪ mæstɝ ɡɪlz hænd wən i tʃɹaɪd tə əsɪs hɝ, ən ðə laɪn ə kɑɹts bɪɡæn tə tʃɹʌndəl ɔf nɔɹθwɝd ðoʊ ðə fɑɡ. bɪhaɪnd wʌn ə ðə kɑɹts, leɪɾən wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz' tɛns ən pəzɛʃənz, mɑɹtʃt ə klʌstɝ ʌv waɪt-klæd ɡeɪʃeɪn, mik ivən naʊ, mɛn ən wɪmən wɪð ðɛɹ kaʊlz ʌp ən ðɛɹ aɪz loʊɝd. ðeɪ wɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ, teɪkən ət kɛɹhin, ən ɪn ə fju mʌnθs ðeɪ wəd pʊɾ ɔf waɪɾ ən ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ klæn. pɛɹɪn hæd hæɾ əm wɑtʃt, dɪskɹitli, dɪspaɪt ðə waɪz wʌnz' əʃʊɹənsɪz ðət ðeɪ wəɾ ədhɪɹ tə dʒiɾoʊ ɪn ðɪs ɹəɡɑɹd wʌtɛvɝ ʌðɝz ðeɪ əbændənd, jɛɾ ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ ɹaɪt. ðeɪ stɪl nʌmbɝd sɛvəntin. nʌn hæd tʃɹaɪd tə ɹʌn ɔf ən wɔɹn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ bɪɑn ðə ɹɪdʒ. ðə kɑɹts' æksəlz hæd bɪn ɡɹis lɪbɝəli, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl kɹikt ən skwil tə hɪz ɪɹz. wɪð lʌk, hi ən feɪl wəd kætʃ ʌp tə ðɛm ʃaɪ ʌv ðə maʊntənz.

In the end, Lini actually climbed up beside the driver of a cart without having to be forced, though she slapped away Master Gill's hand when he tried to assist her, and the line of carts began to trundle off northward though the fog. Behind one of the carts, laden with the Wise Ones' tents and possessions, marched a cluster of white-clad gai'shain, meek even now, men and women with their cowls up and their eyes lowered. They were Shaido, taken at Cairhien, and in a few months they would put off white and return to their clan. Perrin had had them watched, discreetly, despite the Wise Ones' assurances that they would adhere to ji'e'toh in this regard whatever others they abandoned, yet it appeared the Wise Ones were right. They still numbered seventeen. None had tried to run off and warn the Shaido beyond the ridge. The carts' axles had been greased liberally, but they still creaked and squealed to his ears. With luck, he and Faile would catch up to them shy of the mountains.

əz ðə stʃɹɪŋz ə spɛɹ hɔɹsəz bɪɡæn tə pæs hɪm, ɑn lɔŋ lidz hɛl baɪ maʊntəd ɡɹumz, ə meɪɾən əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə mɪs kʌmɪŋ daʊn ðə laɪn ə kɑɹts. sloʊli ʃi ɹizɑlvd ɪndə səlɪn, ʃoʊufə ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk tə bɛɹ əɹ ʃɔɹt waɪt hɛɹ ən blæk veɪl hæŋɪŋ daʊn ɑntu hɝ tʃɛst. ə fɹɛʃ slæʃ əkɹɔs əɹ lɛf tʃik wəɾ æɾ ənʌðɝ skɑɹ tə hɝ feɪs ənlɛs ʃi æksɛptɪd hilɪŋ fɹəm wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz. ʃi maɪt nɑt. meɪɾənz sim tə hæv ɑɾ æɾətudz əbaʊt waɪz wʌnz' əpɹɛntəsɪz, əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðət ðiz əpɹɛntəsɪz wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ ivən sɔ ənʊɹə əz ən əpɹɛntəs, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz nɑt.

As the strings of spare horses began to pass him, on long leads held by mounted grooms, a Maiden appeared in the mist coming down the line of carts. Slowly she resolved into Sulin, shoufa around her neck to bare her short white hair and black veil hanging down onto her chest. A fresh slash across her left cheek would add another scar to her face unless she accepted Healing from one of the sisters. She might not. Maidens seemed to have odd attitudes about Wise Ones' apprentices, or maybe it was just that these apprentices were Aes Sedai. They even saw Annoura as an apprentice, though she was not.

"ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ sɛntʃɹiz tə ðə nɔɹθ ɑɹ dɛd, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ʃi sɛd. "æn ðə mɛn u wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt tə ɹipleɪs ðɛm. ðeɪ dænst wɛl, fəɹ ʃeɪɾoʊ."

"The Shaido sentries to the north are dead, Perrin Aybara," she said. "And the men who were going out to replace them. They danced well, for Shaido."

"ju tʊk kæʒəwəltiz?" hi æskt kwaɪətli.

"You took casualties?" he asked quietly.

"ɛləəndə ən bɹieɪn woʊk fɹəm ðə dʒɹim." ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn spikɪŋ ə ðə wɛðɝ ɹæðɝ ðən tu dɛθs əmʌŋ wɪmən ʃi nu. "wi ɔl mʌst weɪk ɪvɛntʃəwəli. wi hæd tə kæɹi eɪviɛlɪn ðə læs tu maɪlz. ʃɪl nid hilɪŋ." soʊ. ʃi wəɾ æksɛpt ɪt.

"Elienda and Briain woke from the dream." She might have been speaking of the weather rather than two deaths among women she knew. "We all must wake eventually. We had to carry Aviellin the last two miles. She will need Healing." So. She would accept it.

"aɪl sɛnd wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ju," hi sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪn ðə fɑɡ. əsaɪd fɹəm ðə laɪn ə hɔɹsəz pæsɪŋ hɪm, hi kəd si nʌθɪŋ. "æz sun əz aɪ kən faɪnd wʌn."

"I'll send one of the Aes Sedai with you," he said, looking around in the fog. Aside from the line of horses passing him, he could see nothing. "As soon as I can find one."

ðeɪ faʊn ɪm ɔlmoʊst əz i spoʊk, ənʊɹə ən mɑsʊɝi stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə fɑɡ liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɪð bɹəleɪn ən mæsimə, hɪz ʃeɪvən hɛd ɡlɪsnɪŋ dæmpli. ivən ɪn ðə mɪst, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðə ɹʌmpəl neɪtʃɝ ə ðə mænz bɹaʊn koʊt, əɹ ðə kɹud dɑɹn ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ. nʌn ə ðə ɡoʊld ɪz fɑloʊɝz luɾəd stʌk tə hɪz hænz. ɪɾ ɔl wɛn tə ðə pʊɹ. ðət wɑz ði oʊnli ɡʊd ðət kəd bi sɛɾ ə mæsimə. bʌt ðɛn, ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə ðə pʊɹ ðət ɡoʊld wɛn tə fid hæd bɪn meɪd pʊɹ baɪ hævɪŋ ðɛɹ pəzɛʃənz stoʊlən ən ðɛɹ ʃɑps əɹ fɑɹmz bɝn baɪ mæsiməz pipəl. fəɹ səm ɹizən, bɹəleɪn wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ðə kɔɹənɛɾ ə ðə fɝst ə min ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ðə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪn flaɪɾ əbʌv əɹ bɹaʊ, ðoʊ hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ən kloʊk wɝ pleɪn dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ. bɪniθ əɹ laɪt, flaʊɝi pɝfjum, hɝ sɛnt wɑz peɪʃəns ən æŋzaɪəɾi, əz ɑɾ ə kɑmbəneɪʃən əz pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ smɛld. ðə sɪks waɪz wʌnz wɝ wɪð ðɛm, tu, dɑɹk ʃɔlz dʒɹeɪpt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz, foʊldəd kɝtʃəfs ɝaʊn ðɛɹ tɛmpəlz hoʊldɪŋ bæk ðɛɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ. wɪð ɔl ðɛɹ nɛkləsɪz ən bɹeɪslɪts ʌv ɡoʊld ən aɪvɝi, ðeɪ meɪd bɹəleɪn əpɪɹ sɪmpli dʒɹɛs fəɹ wʌns. ɛɹæm wɑz wʌn ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ əz wɛl, ðə wʊlfhɛd pɑməl ə hɪz sɔɹd ɹaɪzɪŋ əbʌv wʌn ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪpt ʃoʊldɝ, ən ðə fɑɡ kəd nɑt haɪd ði æbsəns ə hɪz həbɪtʃuəl ɡlaʊɝ. ðə mæn ɡɹævəteɪɾɪd təwɔɹd mæsimə ən simd ɔlmoʊs tə bæsk ɪn səm laɪt ðət mæsimə ɡeɪv ɔf. pɛɹɪn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ i ʃʊɾə sɛn ɛɹæm wɪð ðə kɑɹts. bʌɾ ɪf i hæd, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɛɹæm wʊɾə lɛpt ɔf ən snik bæk əz sun əz i wɑz aʊɾ ə pɛɹɪnz saɪt.

They found him almost as he spoke, Annoura and Masuri striding out of the fog leading their horses with Berelain and Masema, his shaven head glistening damply. Even in the mist, there was no mistaking the rumpled nature of the man's brown coat, or the crude darn on the shoulder. None of the gold his followers looted stuck to his hands. It all went to the poor. That was the only good that could be said of Masema. But then, a fair number of the poor that gold went to feed had been made poor by having their possessions stolen and their shops or farms burned by Masema's people. For some reason, Berelain was wearing the coronet of the First of Mayene this morning, the golden hawk in flight above her brow, though her riding dress and cloak were plain dark gray. Beneath her light, flowery perfume, her scent was patience and anxiety, as odd a combination as Perrin had ever smelled.
