The six Wise Ones were with them, too, dark shawls draped over their arms, folded kerchiefs around their temples holding back their long hair. With all their necklaces and bracelets of gold and ivory, they made Berelain appear simply dressed for once. Aram was one of their number as well, the wolfhead pommel of his sword rising above one red-striped shoulder, and the fog could not hide the absence of his habitual glower. The man gravitated toward Masema and seemed almost to bask in some light that Masema gave off. Perrin wondered whether he should have sent Aram with the carts. But if he had, he was sure Aram would have leaped off and sneaked back as soon as he was out of Perrin's sight.

hi ɪkspleɪn eɪviɛlɪnz nid tə ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, wən mɑsʊɝi sɛd ʃi wəd kʌm, fɛɹ-hɛɹɾ ɛdʒɹə ɹeɪzd ə hæn ðət stɑp ðə slɪm bɹaʊn ɪn əɹ tʃɹæks. ənʊɹə ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli. ʃi wɑz noʊ əpɹɛntəs, ən ənizi oʊvɝ siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝiz ɹileɪʃənʃɪp wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz. ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ɪnkluɾ əɹ ɪn ɪt, ən səmtaɪmz səksiɾəd.

He explained Aviellin's need to the two Aes Sedai, but to his surprise, when Masuri said she would come, fair-haired Edarra raised a hand that stopped the slim Brown in her tracks. Annoura shifted uncomfortably. She was no apprentice, and uneasy over Seonid and Masuri's relationship with the Wise Ones. They tried to include her in it, and sometimes succeeded.

"dʒəninə wɪl si tə ɪt," ɛdʒɹə sɛd. "ʃi hæz mɔɹ skɪl ðən ju, mɑsʊɝi soʊkɑwə."

"Janina will see to it," Edarra said. "She has more skill than you, Masuri Sokawa."

mɑsʊɝiz maʊθ taɪɾənd, bʌt ʃi kɛp saɪlənt. ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ kwaɪt keɪpəbəl ə swɪtʃɪŋ ən əpɹɛntəs fəɹ spikɪŋ ʌp ət ðə ɹɔŋ taɪm, ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd hæpən tə bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. səlɪn lɛd dʒəninə, ə fleɪksən-hɛɹd wʊmən u nɛvɝ sim tə bi ɹʌfəl baɪ ɛniθɪŋ, ɔf ɪndə ðə fɑɡ, dʒəninə stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əz kwɪkli əz səlɪn dɪspaɪɾ əɹ bʌlki skɝts. soʊ ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd lɝn hilɪŋ, hæd ðeɪ? ðət maɪt bi jusfəl leɪɾɝ ɪn ðə deɪ; ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt wɑz nɑt niɾəd ɔfən.

Masuri's mouth tightened, but she kept silent. The Wise Ones were quite capable of switching an apprentice for speaking up at the wrong time, even if she did happen to be an Aes Sedai. Sulin led Janina, a flaxen-haired woman who never seemed to be ruffled by anything, off into the fog, Janina striding as quickly as Sulin despite her bulky skirts. So the Wise Ones had learned Healing, had they? That might be useful later in the day; the Light send it was not needed often.

wɑtʃɪŋ ðə pɛɹ dɪsəpɪɹ ɪndə ðə mɝk, mæsimə ɡɹʌntɪd. ðə θɪk mɪs hɪd ði ɛvɝ-bɝnɪŋ ɪntɛnsəɾi ʌv ɪz dip-sɛɾ aɪz ən əbskjʊɹd ðə tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ waɪt skɑɹ ɑn ɪz tʃik, bʌɾ ɪz sɛnt wɑz fʊl ɪn pɛɹɪnz noʊz, hɑɹɾ ən ʃɑɹp əz ə fɹɛʃli stʃɹɑpt ɹeɪzɝ jɛt twɪtʃɪŋ ɪn ə fɹɛnzi. ðət smɛl ə mædnəs səmtaɪmz meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ɪz noʊz mʌs blid fɹəm bɹiðɪŋ ɪt.

Watching the pair disappear into the murk, Masema grunted. The thick mist hid the ever-burning intensity of his deep-set eyes and obscured the triangular white scar on his cheek, but his scent was full in Perrin's nose, hard and sharp as a freshly stropped razor yet twitching in a frenzy. That smell of madness sometimes made him think his nose must bleed from breathing it.

"bæɾ ɪnʌf jə juz ðiz blæsfəməs wɪmən u də wʌɾ oʊnli ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, blɛsɪd bi hɪz neɪm, meɪ du," mæsimə sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs fʊl ə ðə hit ðət ðə fɑɡ kənsild ɪn ɪz aɪz.

"Bad enough you use these blasphemous women who do what only the Lord Dragon, blessed be his name, may do," Masema said, his voice full of the heat that the fog concealed in his eyes.

ðə kʌlɝz spɪnɪŋ ɪn pɛɹɪnz hɛd tɝn ɪndə ə bɹif ɪmədʒ ə ɹænd ən mɪn ən ə tɔl mæn ɪn ə blæk koʊt, ən æʃəmən, ən i fɛlt ə ʃɑk ɹaɪt daʊn tə hɪz buts. ɹændz lɛf hænd wɑz ɡɔn! noʊ mæɾɝ. wʌtɛvɝ hæd hæpənd, hæd hæpənd. ən tədeɪ hɪz bɪznəs leɪ ɛlswɛɹ.

The colors spinning in Perrin's head turned into a brief image of Rand and Min and a tall man in a black coat, an Asha'man, and he felt a shock right down to his boots. Rand's left hand was gone! No matter. Whatever had happened, had happened. And today his business lay elsewhere.

". . . bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ noʊ hilɪŋ," mæsimə kəntɪnjud, "ɪt wɪl bi ðət mʌtʃ hɑɹɾɝ tə kɪl ðə sævədʒəz. ə pɪɾi jə woʊn lɛt ðə sintʃæn liʃ ɔl ə ðɛm."

". . . but if they know Healing," Masema continued, "it will be that much harder to kill the savages. A pity you won't let the Seanchan leash all of them."

hɪz saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlæns əɾ ənʊɹə ən mɑsʊɝi sɛɾ i ɪnkluɾəd ðɛm, dɪspaɪt ðə fæk boʊθ hæd vɪzəɾəd ɪm ɪn sikɹət mɔɹ ðən wʌns. ðeɪ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑm, ðoʊ mɑsʊɝiz slɪm hænz muvd wʌns əz ɪf tə smuð əɹ bɹaʊn skɝts. ʃi sɛd ʃi hæd tʃeɪnʒd əɹ maɪn ən naʊ bɪliv ðə mæn mʌs bi kɪld, soʊ waɪ wɑz ʃi miɾɪŋ hɪm? waɪ wɑz ənʊɹə? waɪ dɪd mæsimə əlaʊ ðɛm? hi mɔɹ ðən heɪɾəd ɛɛs sədaɪ. pɝhæps ænsɝz kəd bi faʊnd naʊ ðət hɑviɑɹ ən nɛɹiən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ niɾəd pɹətɛkʃən.

His sidelong glance at Annoura and Masuri said he included them, despite the fact both had visited him in secret more than once. They regarded him with Aes Sedai calm, though Masuri's slim hands moved once as if to smooth her brown skirts. She said she had changed her mind and now believed the man must be killed, so why was she meeting him? Why was Annoura? Why did Masema allow them? He more than hated Aes Sedai. Perhaps answers could be found now that Haviar and Nerion no longer needed protection.

bɪhaɪn mæsimə, ðə waɪz wʌnz stɝd. faɪɝ-hɛɹd kɛɹɛl, hu lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi pəzɛst ə tɛmpɝ ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt, æktʃəli  stʃɹoʊk ðə hɪlt ə hɝ bɛl naɪf, ən nəvɛɝɪn, cʊɾə əv ɡɪvən nɪneɪiv lɛsənz ɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ æŋɡɹi, ɡɹɪp hɝz. ʃʊɾə əv fɛl ðoʊz aɪz bɔɹɪŋ ɪndə hɪz bæk, bʌɾ ɪz sɛnt nɛvɝ ʃɪftəd. ɪnseɪn i maɪt bi, bʌt nɛvɝ ə kaʊɝd.

Behind Masema, the Wise Ones stirred. Fire-haired Carelle, who looked as if she possessed a temper though she did not, actually stroked the hilt of her belt knife, and Nevarin, who could have given Nynaeve lessons in getting angry, gripped hers. Masema should have felt those eyes boring into his back, but his scent never shifted. Insane he might be, but never a coward.

"ju wɑntəd tə spik tə lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, maɪ lɔɹd pɹɑfət," bɹəleɪn sɛd dʒɛnli, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn kəd smɛl ðə stʃɹeɪn ə hɝ smaɪl.

"You wanted to speak to Lord Perrin, my Lord Prophet," Berelain said gently, though Perrin could smell the strain of her smile.

mæsimə stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. "aɪ æm sɪmpli ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, nɑɾ ə lɔɹd. ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɪz ði oʊnli lɔɹd, naʊ. hɪz kʌmɪŋ əz ʃæɾɝd ɔl bɑnz ən dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɔl taɪɾəlz. kɪŋ ən kwinz, lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz, ɑɹ bʌt dʌs bɪniθ ɪz fit."

Masema stared at her. "I am simply the Prophet of the Lord Dragon, not a lord. The Lord Dragon is the only lord, now. His coming has shattered all bonds and destroyed all titles. King and queens, lords and ladies, are but dust beneath his feet."

ðoʊz wɝlɪŋ hjuz θɹɛɾənd əɡɛn, bʌt pɛɹɪn kɹʌʃt ðɛm. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?" hi dɪmændəd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə sɑfən moʊməns wɪð mæsimə. ðə mæn wɑz əz hɑɹɾ əz ə ɡʊd faɪl. "jɔɹ səpoʊz tə bi wɪð jəɹ mɛn. jə ɹɪsk biɪŋ sin baɪ kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ, ən jəl ɹɪsk ɪɾ əɡɛn ɡoʊɪŋ bæk. aɪ doʊn tʃɹʌs jəɹ pipəl tə hoʊl fəɹ faɪv mɪnəts wɪθaʊt jə ðəɹ tə stɪfən ðɛɹ spaɪnz. ðəl ɹʌn əz sun əz ðeɪ si ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kʌmɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ."

Those whirling hues threatened again, but Perrin crushed them. "What are you doing here?" he demanded. There was no way to soften moments with Masema. The man was as hard as a good file. "You're supposed to be with your men. You risked being seen by coming here, and you'll risk it again going back. I don't trust your people to hold for five minutes without you there to stiffen their spines. They'll run as soon as they see the Shaido coming their way."

"ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt maɪ pipəl, eɪbɑɹə. ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡənz pipəl." laɪt, biɪŋ ɝaʊn mæsimə mɛn hævɪŋ tə stɑmp ɑn ðoʊz kʌlɝz ɛvɹi fju mɪnəts! "aɪ lɛf nɛŋɡɝ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ. hiz fɔt mɔɹ bæɾəlz ðən juv dʒɹimd ʌv. ɪnkluɾɪŋ əɡɛns ðə sævədʒəz. aɪ ɔlsoʊ ɡeɪv ðə wɪmən ɔɹɾɝz tə kɪl ɛni mæn u tʃɹaɪz tə ɹʌn ən əv lɛɾ ɪt bi noʊn ðəɾ əl hʌn daʊn ɛniwʌn u ɪskeɪps ðə wɪmən. ðəl hoʊl tə ðə læs mæn, eɪbɑɹə."

"They are not my people, Aybara. They are the Lord Dragon's people." Light, being around Masema meant having to stomp on those colors every few minutes! "I left Nengar in charge. He has fought more battles than you have dreamed of. Including against the savages. I also gave the women orders to kill any man who tries to run and have let it be known that I will hunt down anyone who escapes the women. They will hold to the last man, Aybara."

"ju saʊn əz ɪf jəɹ nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ bæk," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"You sound as if you're not going back," Perrin said.

"aɪ ɪntɛn tə steɪ kloʊs tə ju." fɑɡ maɪt haɪd ðə hiɾ ɪn mæsiməz aɪz, bʌt pɛɹɪn kəd fil ɪt. "ə pɪɾi ɪf ɛni mɪsfɔɹtʃən ʃəd bɪfɔl jə dʒʌst əz jə ɹikleɪm jəɹ waɪf."

"I intend to stay close to you." Fog might hide the heat in Masema's eyes, but Perrin could feel it. "A pity if any misfortune should befall you just as you reclaim your wife."

soʊ ə smɔl pɑɹɾ ə hɪz plæn hæɾ ənɹævəld ɔlɹɛɾi. ə hoʊp ɹɪli, ɹæðɝ ðən pɑɹɾ ə ðə plæn. ɪf ɔl ɛls wɛnt wɛl, ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hu mænədʒ tə fli wəd kɑɹv ə weɪ θɹu mæsiməz pipəl wɪθaʊt mɔɹ ðən sloʊɪŋ ə stɛp, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə teɪkɪŋ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ spɪɹ θɹu hɪz ɹɪbz, mæsimə wəd bi . . . kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn hɪm. wɪθaʊɾ ɛni daʊt, ðə mænz bɑɾiɡɑɹd wɑz nɑt fɑɹ ɔf ɪn ðə fɑɡ, tu hʌnʒɹəd əɹ soʊ ɹʌfaɪənz bɛɾɝ ɑɹmd ən bɛɾɝ maʊntəd ðən ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz ɑɹmi. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt lʊk ət bɹəleɪn, bʌt ðə sɛn ə hɝ wɝi hæd stʃɹɛŋθənd. mæsimə hæd ɹizən tə wɑn boʊθ ə ðɛm dɛd. hi wəd wɔɹn ɡælɛn ðəɾ ɪz pɹaɪmɛɹi tæsk tədeɪ wəd bi pɹətɛktɪŋ bɹəleɪn fɹəm mæsiməz mɛn. ən i wəɾ əv tə wɑtʃ ɪz oʊn bæk.

So a small part of his plan had unraveled already. A hope really, rather than part of the plan. If all else went well, the Shaido who managed to flee would carve a way through Masema's people without more than slowing a step, but instead of taking a Shaido spear through his ribs, Masema would be . . . keeping an eye on him. Without any doubt, the man's bodyguard was not far off in the fog, two hundred or so ruffians better armed and better mounted than the rest of his army. Perrin did not look at Berelain, but the scent of her worry had strengthened. Masema had reason to want both of them dead. He would warn Gallenne that his primary task today would be protecting Berelain from Masema's men. And he would have to watch his own back.

ɔf ɪn ðə fɑɡ, ə bɹif flæʃ ə sɪlvɝ-blu laɪɾ əpɪɹd, ən i fɹaʊnd. ɪt wɑz tu ɝli jɛt fəɹ ɡɹeɪɾi. tu fɪɡjɝz koʊəlɛst aʊɾ ə ðə mɪst. wʌn wɑz nild, nɑt stʃɹʌɾɪŋ fəɹ wʌns. ɪn fækt, hi stʌmbəld. hɪz feɪs lʊk taɪɝd. bɝn hɪm, waɪ wɑz i weɪstɪŋ ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ ðɪs weɪ? ði ʌðɝ wɑz ə jʌŋ sintʃæn ɪn lækɝɾ ɑɹmɝ wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl θɪn plum ɑn ðə pəkjuljɝ hɛlməɾ i kæɹid bɪniθ ɪz ɑɹm. pɛɹɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm, ɡaɪ ɹɑbə, ə lutɛnən taɪli θɔt wɛl ʌv. ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡæðɝd ðɛɹ skɝts əz ɪf tə kip ɪm fɹəm bɹʌʃɪŋ əɡɛns ðɛm, ðoʊ hi wɛnt noʊwɛɹ nɪɹ ðɛm. fəɹ ɪz pɑɹt, hi mɪst ə stɛp wən i keɪm kloʊs ɪnʌf tə meɪk aʊt ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ən pɛɹɪn hɝɾ ɪm swɑloʊ hɑɹd. hi smɛl skɪɾɪʃ, ʌv ə sʌɾən.

Off in the fog, a brief flash of silver-blue light appeared, and he frowned. It was too early yet for Grady. Two figures coalesced out of the mist. One was Neald, not strutting for once. In fact, he stumbled. His face looked tired. Burn him, why was he wasting his strength this way? The other was a young Seanchan in lacquered armor with a single thin plume on the peculiar helmet he carried beneath his arm. Perrin recognized him, Gueye Arabah, a lieutenant Tylee thought well of. The two Aes Sedai gathered their skirts as if to keep him from brushing against them, though he went nowhere near them. For his part, he missed a step when he came close enough to make out their faces, and Perrin heard him swallow hard. He smelled skittish, of a sudden.

ɹɑbəz baʊ ɪnkluɾəd pɛɹɪn ən bɹəleɪn, ən i fɹaʊn slaɪtli ət mæsimə əz ðoʊ wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt sətʃ ə ɹæɡəd fɛloʊ wɑz duɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ kʌmpəni. mæsimə snɪɹd, ən ðə sintʃænz fɹi hæn dʒɹɪftəd təwɔɹɾ ɪz sɔɹd hɪl bɪfɔɹ i stɑpt ɪt. ðeɪ sim tʌtʃi foʊk, sintʃæn dɪd. bʌt ɹɑbə dɪd nɑt weɪs taɪm. "bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl kɪɝɡənz kɑmpləməns, maɪ lɔɹd, maɪ leɪɾi fɝst. mɔɹətʃɹeɪkən ɹipɔɹt ðoʊz bænz ʌv il ɑɹ muvɪŋ fæstɝ ðən ɪkspɛktəd. ðəl ɝaɪv səm taɪm tədeɪ, pɑsəbli əz sun əz nun. ðə ɡɹup tə ðə wɛst ɪz pɝhæps twɛnti-faɪv əɹ θɝɾi θaʊzənd, ðə wʌn tə ði is lɑɹdʒɝ baɪ ə θɝd. əbaʊt hæf ə ðɛm ɑɹ wɛɹɪŋ waɪt, ən ðəɹ wɪl bi tʃɪlʒɹən, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz stɪl ə lɑɾ ə spɪɹz tə hæv bɪhaɪn ju. ðə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl wɪʃɪz tə noʊ ɪf jə wəd laɪk tə dɪskʌs ɔltɝɪŋ ðə dɪplɔɪməns. ʃi sədʒɛsts muvɪŋ ə fju θaʊzən ə ði ɔltɑɹən lænsɝz tə dʒɔɪn ju."

Arabah's bow included Perrin and Berelain, and he frowned slightly at Masema as though wondering what such a ragged fellow was doing in their company. Masema sneered, and the Seanchan's free hand drifted toward his sword hilt before he stopped it. They seemed touchy folk, Seanchan did. But Arabah did not waste time. "Banner-General Khirgan's compliments, my Lord, my Lady First. Morat'raken report those bands of Aiel are moving faster than expected. They will arrive some time today, possibly as soon as noon. The group to the west is perhaps twenty-five or thirty thousand, the one to the east larger by a third. About half of them are wearing white, and there will be children, of course, but that is still a lot of spears to have behind you. The Banner-General wishes to know if you would like to discuss altering the deployments. She suggests moving a few thousand of the Altaran lancers to join you."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪməst. ðəɹ wəd bi ət lis θɹi əɹ fɔɹ θaʊzən ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ wɪð itʃ ə ðoʊz bænz. ə lɑɾ ə spɪɹz tə hæv əɾ ɪz bæk fəɹ sɝɾən ʃʊɹ. nil jɔnd. "haʊ ɑɹ jə filɪŋ, nild?"

Perrin grimaced. There would be at least three or four thousand algai'd'siswai with each of those bands. A lot of spears to have at his back for certain sure. Neald yawned. "How are you feeling, Neald?"

"oʊ, aɪm ɹɛɾi tə də wʌtɛvɝ nidz duɪŋ, aɪ æm, maɪ lɔɹd," ðə mæn sɛd wɪð dʒʌst ə hɪn ə hɪz juʒəwəl dʒɔntinəs.

"Oh, I'm ready to do whatever needs doing, I am, my Lord," the man said with just a hint of his usual jauntiness.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ði æʃəmən kəd nɑt bi æsk tə meɪk wʌn ɡeɪtweɪ mɔɹ ðən nɛsəsɛɹi. hi pɹeɪd ðət ðeɪ wəd nɑt fɔl wʌn ʃɔɹt. "baɪ nun, wɪl bi dʌn hɪɹ. tɛl ðə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl wi ɡoʊ əhɛɾ əz plænd." ən pɹeɪ ðət nʌθɪŋ ɛls wɛn əmɪs. hi dɪd nɑɾ æd ðəɾ əlaʊd, ðoʊ.

Perrin shook his head. The Asha'man could not be asked to make one gateway more than necessary. He prayed that they would not fall one short. "By noon, we'll be done here. Tell the Banner-General we go ahead as planned." And pray that nothing else went amiss. He did not add that aloud, though.

aʊɾ ɪn ðə fɑɡ, wʊlvz haʊld, ən ɪɹi kɹaɪ ðət ɹoʊz ɔl ɝaʊn mɔldən. ɪt wɑz tʃɹuli bɪɡʌn, naʊ.

Out in the fog, wolves howled, an eerie cry that rose all around Malden. It was truly begun, now.

"jɔɹ duɪŋ wʌndɝfəli, meɪaɪɡdɪn," feɪl kɹoʊkt. ʃi fɛlt laɪt-hɛɾəd, ən əɹ θɹoʊt wɑz dʒɹaɪ fɹəm ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ ðə wʊmən. ɛvɹiwʌnz θɹoʊt wɑz dʒɹaɪ. baɪ ðə slæn ə ðə laɪt kʌmɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡæps oʊvɝhɛd, ɪt wɑz nɪɹ mɪdmɔɹnɪŋ, ən ðeɪ hæd bɪn tɔkɪŋ wɪθaʊt sis fəɹ moʊst ə ðæt. ðeɪ hæd tʃɹaɪd tæpɪŋ ði ənbɹoʊkən bæɹəlz, bʌt ðə waɪn ɪnsaɪd wɑz tu ɹænsɪɾ ivən fəɹ wɛɾɪŋ lɪps. naʊ ðeɪ wɝ teɪkɪŋ tɝnz wɪð ði ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt. ʃi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪɾ əɹ sʌn-hɛɹd meɪd waɪl ði ʌðɝz ɹɛstəɾ əɡɛns ðə bæk wɔl, əz fɑɹ fɹəm ðət linɪŋ dʒʌmbəl ə bɔɹdz ən tɪmbɝz əz ðeɪ kəd ɡɛt. "jɔɹ gɑnə seɪv ʌs, meɪaɪɡdɪn."

"You're doing wonderfully, Maighdin," Faile croaked. She felt light-headed, and her throat was dry from encouraging the woman. Everyone's throat was dry. By the slant of the light coming through the gaps overhead, it was near midmorning, and they had been talking without cease for most of that. They had tried tapping the unbroken barrels, but the wine inside was too rancid even for wetting lips. Now they were taking turns with the encouragement. She was sitting alongside her sun-haired maid while the others rested against the back wall, as far from that leaning jumble of boards and timbers as they could get. "You're going to save us, Maighdin."

əbʌv ðɛm, ðə ɹɛd skɑɹf wɑz dʒʌs vɪzəbəl θɹu ðət nɛɹoʊ ɡæp ɪn ðə tæŋɡəl. ɪt hæd hʌŋ lɪmpli fəɹ səm taɪm, naʊ, ɪksɛpt wən ðə bɹiz kɑɾ ɪt. meɪaɪɡdɪn stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt fɪksədli. hɝ dɝɾi feɪs ɡlɪsənd wɪð swɛt, ən ʃi bɹiðd əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ hɑɹd. sʌɾənli ðə skɑɹf wɛn tɔɾ ən bɪɡæn tə swɪŋ, wʌns, twaɪs, θɹi taɪmz. ðən ðə bɹiz sɛn ɪt flʌɾɝɪŋ, ən ɪt fɛl. meɪaɪɡdɪn kəntɪnjud tə stɛɹ.

Above them, the red scarf was just visible through that narrow gap in the tangle. It had hung limply for some time, now, except when the breeze caught it. Maighdin stared at it fixedly. Her dirty face glistened with sweat, and she breathed as if she had been running hard. Suddenly the scarf went taut and began to swing, once, twice, three times. Then the breeze sent it fluttering, and it fell. Maighdin continued to stare.

"ðæt wɑz bjuɾəfəl," feɪl sɛd hɔɹsli. ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ taɪɝd. mɔɹ taɪm wɑz pæsɪŋ bɪtwin itʃ səksɛs, ən ðə səksɛsəz wɝ læstɪŋ ə ʃɔɹɾɝ taɪm. "ɪt wɑz - "

"That was beautiful," Faile said hoarsely. The other woman was getting tired. More time was passing between each success, and the successes were lasting a shorter time. "It was - "

əbɹʌpli ə feɪs əpɪɹd bɪsaɪd ðə skɑɹf, wʌn hænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə lɛŋθ ə ɹɛd. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi θɔt ʃi mʌs bi ɪmædʒənɪŋ ɪt. ɝɑvinz feɪs fɹeɪm baɪ hɝ waɪt kaʊl.

Abruptly a face appeared beside the scarf, one hand gripping the length of red. For a moment, she thought she must be imagining it. Aravine's face framed by her white cowl.

"aɪ si hɝ!" ðə wʊmən sɛɾ ɪksaɪɾədli. "aɪ si ðə leɪɾi feɪl ən meɪaɪɡdɪn! ðəɹ əlaɪv!" vɔɪsəz ɹeɪzd ə tʃɪɹ, kwɪkli stɪld.

"I see her!" the woman said excitedly. "I see the Lady Faile and Maighdin! They're alive!" Voices raised a cheer, quickly stilled.

meɪaɪɡdɪn sweɪɾ əz ɪf ʃi maɪt fɔl oʊvɝ, bʌɾ ə bjuɾəfəl smaɪl ɹɛðd əɹ feɪs. feɪl hɝd wipɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ, ən wɑntəd tə wip wɪð dʒɔɪ hɝsɛlf. fɹɛnz hæd faʊn ðɛm, nɑt ʃeɪɾoʊ. ðeɪ maɪɾ ɪskeɪp jɛt.

Maighdin swayed as if she might fall over, but a beautiful smile wreathed her face. Faile heard weeping behind her, and wanted to weep with joy herself. Friends had found them, not Shaido. They might escape yet.

pʊʃɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fit, ʃi muv kloʊsɝ tə ðə linɪŋ paɪl ə tʃɑɹd ɹʌbəl. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə wɝk mɔɪstʃɝ ɪndə hɝ maʊθ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz θɪk. "wɝ ɔl əlaɪv," ʃi mænədʒd ɪn hʌski vɔɪs. "haʊ ɪn ðə laɪt dɪd jə faɪn ʌs?"

Pushing herself to her feet, she moved closer to the leaning pile of charred rubble. She tried to work moisture into her mouth, but it was thick. "We're all alive," she managed in husky voice. "How in the Light did you find us?"

"ɪt wɑz θɛɝɪl, maɪ leɪɾi," ɝɑvin ɹɪplaɪd. "ðə skæmp fɑloʊd jə dɪspaɪt jəɹ ɔɹɾɝz, ən ðə laɪt blɛs ɪm fəɹ ɪt. hi sɔ ɡəlinə liv, ən ðə bɪldɪŋ fɔl ɪn, ən i θɔt jə wɝ dɛd. hi sæt daʊn ən kɹaɪd." ə vɔɪs pɹətɛstəɾ ɪn ɹʌf ɑmɑdɪʃən æksɛns, ən ɝɑvin tɝn əɹ hɛd fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "aɪ noʊ sʌmwʌn huz bɪn kɹaɪɪŋ wən aɪ si hɪm, bɔɪ. jə dʒʌs bi θæŋkfəl jə stɑp tə kɹaɪ. wən i sɔ ðə skɑɹf muv, maɪ leɪɾi, hi keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ hɛlp."

"It was Theril, my Lady," Aravine replied. "The scamp followed you despite your orders, and the Light bless him for it. He saw Galina leave, and the building fall in, and he thought you were dead. He sat down and cried." A voice protested in rough Amadician accents, and Aravine turned her head for a moment. "I know someone who's been crying when I see him, boy. You just be thankful you stopped to cry. When he saw the scarf move, my Lady, he came running for help."

"ju tɛl ɪm ðɛɹz noʊ ʃeɪm ɪn tɪɹz," feɪl sɛd. "tɛl ɪm aɪv sin maɪ hʌzbən kɹaɪ wən tɪɹz wɝ kɔl fɔɹ."

"You tell him there's no shame in tears," Faile said. "Tell him I've seen my husband cry when tears were called for."

"maɪ leɪɾi," ɝɑvin sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli, "hi sɛd ɡəlinə pʊld ɑn ə tɪmbɝ wən ʃi keɪm aʊt. ɪt wɑz sɛt laɪk ə lɛvɝ, hi sɛd. hi sɛd ʃi meɪd ðə bɪldɪŋ kəlæps."

"My Lady," Aravine said hesitantly, "he said Galina pulled on a timber when she came out. It was set like a lever, he said. He said she made the building collapse."

"waɪ wəd ʃi də ðæt?" æliændɝ dɪmændəd. ʃi hæd hɛlp meɪaɪɡdɪn tə hɝ fiɾ ən hæf səpɔɹɾəd əɹ tə ɹitʃ feɪlz saɪd. lətʃəl ən ɹɛlə dʒɔɪn ðɛm, ɔltɝneɪɾɪŋ bɪtwin tɪɹz ən læftɝ. æliændɝz feɪs wɑz ə θʌndɝhɛd.

"Why would she do that?" Alliandre demanded. She had helped Maighdin to her feet and half supported her to reach Faile's side. Lacile and Arrela joined them, alternating between tears and laughter. Alliandre's face was a thunderhead.

feɪl ɡɹɪməst. haʊ ɔfən ɪn ðə læs fju aʊɝz hæd ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd ðət slæp bæk? ɡəlinə hæd pɹɑməst! kəd ðə wʊmən bi blæk ədʒɑ? "ðæt dʌzn mæɾɝ naʊ. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, əl si hɝ ɹipeɪd." haʊ wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. ɡəlinə wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, æftɝ ɔl. "ɝɑvin, haʊ mɛni pipəl dɪd jə bɹɪŋ? kən jə - ?"

Faile grimaced. How often in the last few hours had she wished she had that slap back? Galina had promised! Could the woman be Black Ajah? "That doesn't matter now. One way or another, I'll see her repaid." How was another matter. Galina was Aes Sedai, after all. "Aravine, how many people did you bring? Can you - ?"

lɑɹdʒ hænz tʊk ɝɑvin baɪ ðə ʃoʊldɝz ən muvd əɹ əsaɪd. "ɪnʌf tɔk." ɹoʊlənz feɪs əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə ɡæp, ʃoʊufə ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk ən veɪl hæŋɪŋ ɑntu hɪz tʃɛst. ɹoʊlən! "wi kænɑt klɪɹ ɛniθɪŋ wɪð jə stændɪŋ ðɛɹ, feɪl bæʃɪɹ. ðɪs θɪŋ meɪ fɔl ɪn wən wi stɑɹt. ɡoʊ tə ði ʌðɝ ɛn ən hʌɾəl əɡɛns ðə fɑɹ wɔl."

Large hands took Aravine by the shoulders and moved her aside. "Enough talk." Rolan's face appeared in the gap, shoufa around his neck and veil hanging onto his chest. Rolan! "We cannot clear anything with you standing there, Faile Bashere. This thing may fall in when we start. Go to the other end and huddle against the far wall."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

"What are you doing here?" she demanded.

ðə mæn tʃʌkəld. hi tʃʌkəld! "ju stɪl wɛɹ waɪt, wʊmən. də əz jə ɑɹ toʊld, əɹ wən aɪ hæv jə aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ, əl smæk jəɹ bɑɾəm saʊnli. ən ðən meɪbi wɪl suð jəɹ tɪɹz wɪð ə kɪsɪŋ ɡeɪm."

The man chuckled. He chuckled! "You still wear white, woman. Do as you are told, or when I have you out of there, I will smack your bottom soundly. And then maybe we will soothe your tears with a kissing game."

ʃi ʃoʊɾ ɪm əɹ tiθ, hoʊpɪŋ i dɪd nɑt teɪk ɪt fəɹ ə ɡɹɪn. bʌɾ i wɑz ɹaɪɾ əbaʊɾ əm niɾɪŋ tə muv əweɪ, soʊ ʃi lɛɾ əɹ kəmpænjənz əkɹɔs ðə bɔɹd-stʃɹun stoʊn flɔɹ tə ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə beɪsmənt wɛɹ ðeɪ kɹaʊtʃt əɡɛns ðə wɔl. ʃi kəd hɪɹ vɔɪsəz mʌɾɝɪŋ aʊtsaɪd, laɪkli dɪskʌsɪŋ ɪɡzækli haʊ tə ɡoʊ əbaʊt klɪɹɪŋ ə pæθ wɪθaʊt meɪkɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə bɪldɪŋ kəlæps ɑn əɹ hɛd.

She showed him her teeth, hoping he did not take it for a grin. But he was right about them needing to move away, so she led her companions across the board-strewn stone floor to the far end of the basement where they crouched against the wall. She could hear voices muttering outside, likely discussing exactly how to go about clearing a path without making the rest of the building collapse on her head.

"ɔl ðɪs fəɹ nʌθɪŋ," æliændɝ sɛd bɪɾɝli. "haʊ mɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ dʒju səpoʊz ɑɹ ʌp ðɛɹ?"

"All this for nothing," Alliandre said bitterly. "How many Shaido do you suppose are up there?"

wʊd skɹeɪp laʊdli, ən wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn, ðə linɪŋ paɪl ə ɹʌbəl lin ɪnwɝɾ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ. ðə vɔɪsəz bɪɡæn əɡɛn.

Wood scraped loudly, and with a groan, the leaning pile of rubble leaned inward a little more. The voices began again.

"aɪ hævən ɛni aɪdiə," feɪl toʊl hɝ. "bʌt ðeɪ mʌst ɔl bi mɛɝeɪɾɪn, nɑt ʃeɪɾoʊ." ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ dɪd nɑt mɪŋɡəl wɪð ðə bɹʌðɝləs. "ðɛɹ maɪt bi səm hoʊp ɪn ðæt." ʃʊɹli ɹoʊlən wəd lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ wʌns i lɝn əbaʊt dɛɹeɪn. ʌv kɔɹs, hi wʊd. ən ɪf i ɹɪmeɪn stʌbɝn. . . . ɪn ðət keɪs, ʃi wəd də wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə kənvɪns hɪm. pɛɹɪn wəd nɛvɝ əv tə faɪn aʊt.

"I haven't any idea," Faile told her. "But they must all be Mera'din, not Shaido." The Shaido did not mingle with the Brotherless. "There might be some hope in that." Surely Rolan would let her go once he learned about Dairaine. Of course, he would. And if he remained stubborn. . . . In that case, she would do whatever was necessary to convince him. Perrin would never have to find out.

wʊd skɹeɪpt ɑn wʊɾ əɡɛn, ən wʌns mɔɹ ðə hip ə bɝn tɪmbɝz ən bɔɹdz tɪltəɾ ɪnwɝɾ ə lɪɾəl fɝðɝ.

Wood scraped on wood again, and once more the heap of burned timbers and boards tilted inward a little further.

ðə fɑɡ hɪd ðə sʌn, bʌt pɛɹɪn ɛstəmeɪɾəd ɪt mʌs bi nɪɹ mɪdmɔɹnɪŋ. ɡɹeɪɾi wəd bi kʌmɪŋ sun. hi ʃʊɾə bɪn ðəɹ baɪ naʊ. ɪf ðə mæn hæd ɡɹoʊn tu taɪɝd tə meɪk ənʌðɝ ɡeɪtweɪ. . . . noʊ. ɡɹeɪɾi wəd kʌm. sun. bʌɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz wɝ əz taɪɾ əz ɪf i hæd bɪn wɝkɪŋ ə fɔɹdʒ fəɹ ə fʊl deɪ ən lɔŋɡɝ.

The fog hid the sun, but Perrin estimated it must be near midmorning. Grady would be coming soon. He should have been there by now. If the man had grown too tired to make another gateway. . . . No. Grady would come. Soon. But his shoulders were as tight as if he had been working a forge for a full day and longer.

"aɪ tɛl ju, aɪ doʊn laɪk ðɪs wʌn bɪt," ɡælɛn mʌɾɝd. ɪn ðə θɪk mɪst, hɪz ɹɛɾ aɪpætʃ wɑz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ ʃædoʊ. hɪz hɛvi-tʃɛstəd beɪ noʊzd ɪz bæk, ɪmpeɪʃən tə bi muvɪŋ, ən i pæɾəd ði ænəməlz nɛk æbsənli. "ɪf mæsimə ɹɪli wɑns tə kɪl ðə leɪɾi fɝst, aɪ seɪ wi fɪnɪʃ ɪm naʊ. wi aʊtnʌmbɝ hɪm. wi kən oʊvɝwɛlm ɪz bɑɾiɡɑɹd ɪn mɪnəts."

"I tell you, I don't like this one bit," Gallenne muttered. In the thick mist, his red eyepatch was just another shadow. His heavy-chested bay nosed his back, impatient to be moving, and he patted the animal's neck absently. "If Masema really wants to kill the Lady First, I say we finish him now. We outnumber him. We can overwhelm his bodyguard in minutes."

"ful," ɑɹɡændə ɡɹaʊld, ɡlænsɪŋ ɔf tə hɪz ɹaɪɾ əz ɪf i kəd si mæsimə ən ɪz mɛn θɹu ðə kɝlɪŋ ɡɹeɪnəs. ənlaɪk ðə minɝ, hi hæd pʊɾ ɑn ɪz sɪlvɝd hɛlmət wɪð ɪts θɹi fæt waɪt plumz. ɪɾ ən ɪz bɹɛstpleɪt, wɝkt ɪn ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ, ɡlɪsənd wɪð kɑndənseɪʃən. fɑɡ əɹ noʊ fɑɡ, hɪz ɑɹmɝ simd ɔlmoʊs tə ɡloʊ. "ju θɪŋk wi kən kɪl tu hʌnʒɹəd mɛn wɪθaʊt meɪkɪŋ ə saʊnd? ʃaʊts wɪl bi hɝd ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðɪs ɹɪdʒ. juv jəɹ ɹulɝ wɛɹ jə kən sɝaʊn əɹ wɪð naɪn hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ən meɪbi ɡɛɾ əɹ əweɪ. æliændɝ ɪz stɪl ɪn ðət blʌɾi taʊn, ən sɝaʊndəd baɪ ʃeɪɾoʊ."

"Fool," Arganda growled, glancing off to his right as if he could see Masema and his men through the curling grayness. Unlike the Mayener, he had put on his silvered helmet with its three fat white plumes. It and his breastplate, worked in gold and silver, glistened with condensation. Fog or no fog, his armor seemed almost to glow. "You think we can kill two hundred men without making a sound? Shouts will be heard the other side of this ridge. You have your ruler where you can surround her with nine hundred men and maybe get her away. Alliandre is still in that bloody town, and surrounded by Shaido."

ɡælɛn bɹɪsəld, hænd ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, əz ðoʊ hi maɪt pɹæktəs ɑn ɑɹɡændə bɪfɔɹ muvɪŋ ɑn tə mæsimə.

Gallenne bristled, hand going to his sword hilt, as though he might practice on Arganda before moving on to Masema.

"wɝ nɑt kɪlɪŋ ɛnibəɾi bʌt ʃeɪɾoʊ tədeɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd fɝmli. ɡælɛn ɡɹʌntɪd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə ɑɹɡju. hi stæŋk ə dɪskəntɛnt, ðoʊ. pɹətɛktɪŋ bɹəleɪn wəd kip ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz aʊɾ ə ðə faɪɾɪŋ.

"We're not killing anybody but Shaido today," Perrin said firmly. Gallenne grunted, but he did not try to argue. He stank of discontent, though. Protecting Berelain would keep the Winged Guards out of the fighting.

ɔf tə ðə lɛft, ə bluɪʃ flæʃ əpɪɹd, dɪm baɪ ðə θɪk mɪst, ən ðə taɪtnəs ɪn pɛɹɪnz ʃoʊldɝz lusənd. ɡɹeɪɾi əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə fɑɡ, piɹɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm. hɪz stɛp pɪkt ʌp wən i sɔ pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ənstɛɾi. ənʌðɝ mæn wɑz wɪð hɪm, liɾɪŋ ə tɔl, dɑɹk hɔɹs. pɛɹɪn smaɪl fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn ə lɔŋ waɪl.

Off to the left, a bluish flash appeared, dimmed by the thick mist, and the tightness in Perrin's shoulders loosened. Grady appeared in the fog, peering about him. His step picked up when he saw Perrin, but it was unsteady. Another man was with him, leading a tall, dark horse. Perrin smiled for the first time in a long while.

"ɪts ɡʊd tə si ju, tæm," hi sɛd.

"It's good to see you, Tam," he said.

"ɡʊd tə si ju, tu, maɪ lɔɹd." tæm ælθɹ wɑz stɪl ə blɑki mæn u lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə wɝk fɹəm sʌnʌp tə sʌndaʊn wɪθaʊt slækɪŋ, bʌt ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz hɛd hæd ɡɔn kəmplitli ɡɹeɪ sɪns pɛɹɪn hæd sin ɪm læst, ən i hæɾ ə fju mɔɹ laɪnz ɑn ɪz blʌf feɪs. hi tʊk ɪn ɑɹɡændə ən ɡælɛn wɪð ə stɛɾi ɡeɪz. fænsi ɑɹmɝ dɪd nɑɾ ɪmpɹɛs hɪm.

"Good to see you, too, my Lord." Tam al'Thor was still a blocky man who looked ready to work from sunup to sundown without slacking, but the hair on his head had gone completely gray since Perrin had seen him last, and he had a few more lines on his bluff face. He took in Arganda and Gallenne with a steady gaze. Fancy armor did not impress him.

"haʊ ɑɹ jə hoʊldɪŋ ʌp, ɡɹeɪɾi?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"How are you holding up, Grady?" Perrin asked.

"aɪm hoʊldɪŋ ʌp, maɪ lɔɹd." ðə wɛðɝd mænz vɔɪs saʊndəd boʊn wɪɹi. ʃæɾoʊd baɪ ðə fɑɡ əz ɪt wɑz, hɪz feɪs stɪl lʊkt oʊldɝ ðən tæmz.

"I'm holding up, my Lord." The weathered man's voice sounded bone weary. Shadowed by the fog as it was, his face still looked older than Tam's.

"wɛl, əz sun əz jəɹ dʌn hɪɹ, dʒɔɪn mɪʃimə. aɪ wɑn sʌmbɑɾi kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn hɪm. sʌmbɑɾi hu meɪks ɪm tu nɝvəs tə θɪŋk ðeɪ kən tʃeɪnʒ wʌt ðeɪ əɡɹid tə." hi wʊɾə laɪk tə tɛl ɡɹeɪɾi tə taɪ ɔf ðɪs ɡeɪtweɪ. ɪt wəd meɪk ə ʃɔɹt pæθ tə teɪk feɪl bæk tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. bʌɾ ɪf θɪŋz wɛn ɹɔŋ tədeɪ, ɪt wəd meɪk ə ʃɔɹt pæθ fəɹ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, tu.

"Well, as soon as you're done here, join Mishima. I want somebody keeping an eye on him. Somebody who makes him too nervous to think they can change what they agreed to." He would have liked to tell Grady to tie off this gateway. It would make a short path to take Faile back to the Two Rivers. But if things went wrong today, it would make a short path for the Shaido, too.

"doʊnt noʊ əz aɪ kəd meɪk ə kæt nɝvəs ɹaɪt naʊ, maɪ lɔɹd, bʌɾ əl də wʌɾ aɪ kæn."

"Don't know as I could make a cat nervous right now, my Lord, but I'll do what I can."

fɹaʊnɪŋ, tæm wɑtʃt ɡɹeɪɾi vænɪʃ ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪ mɝk. "aɪ kəd wɪʃ aɪd hæd səm ʌðɝ weɪ tə ɡɛt hɪɹ," hi sɛd. "fɛloʊz laɪk ɪm vɪzəɾəd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ə waɪl bæk. wʌn kɔl hɪmsɛlf mæzɹim teɪm, ə neɪm wiɾ ɔl hɝd. ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. oʊnli naʊ hi wɛɹz ə blæk koʊt wɪð fænsi ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ən kɔlz hɪmsɛlf ðə l. ðeɪ tɔkt ɛvɹiwɛɹ əbaʊt titʃɪŋ mɛn tə tʃænəl, əbaʊt ðɪs blæk taʊɝ." hi fɹeɪɾɪd ðə wɝdz wɪð saʊɝnəs. "ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəlz tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ ə stɑp tə ɪt, ən ðə wɪmənz sɝkəlz, bʌt ðeɪ ɛndəɾ ʌp teɪkɪŋ əbʌv fɔɹɾi mɛn ən bɔɪz wɪð ðɛm. θæŋk ðə laɪt səm lɪsən tə sɛns, əɹ aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪɾ əv hæd tɛn taɪmz ðæt." hɪz ɡeɪz ʃɪftəd tə pɛɹɪn. "teɪm sɛd ɹænd sɛn hɪm. hi sɛd ɹænd ɪz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn." ðəɹ wɑz ə tʌtʃ ə kwɛstʃənɪŋ ɪn ðæt, pɝhæps ə hoʊp fəɹ dɪnaɪəl, pɝhæps ə dɪmæn tə noʊ waɪ pɛɹɪn hæd kɛp saɪlənt.

Frowning, Tam watched Grady vanish into the gray murk. "I could wish I'd had some other way to get here," he said. "Fellows like him visited the Two Rivers a while back. One called himself Mazrim Taim, a name we'd all heard. A false Dragon. Only now he wears a black coat with fancy embroidery and calls himself the M'Hael. They talked everywhere about teaching men to channel, about this Black Tower." He freighted the words with sourness. "The Village Councils tried to put a stop to it, and the Women's Circles, but they ended up taking above forty men and boys with them. Thank the Light some listened to sense, or I think they'd have had ten times that." His gaze shifted to Perrin. "Taim said Rand sent him. He said Rand is the Dragon Reborn." There was a touch of questioning in that, perhaps a hope for denial, perhaps a demand to know why Perrin had kept silent.

ðoʊz hjuz wɝld ɪn pɛɹɪnz hɛd, bʌɾ i bæɾɪd əm əweɪ ən ænsɝd baɪ nɑɾ ænsɝɪŋ. wʌt wɑz, wɑz. "nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn əbaʊɾ ɪt naʊ, tæm." əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild, ðə blæk taʊɝ dɪd nɑt dʒʌs lɛt mɛn ɡoʊ wʌns ðeɪ saɪn ɑn.

Those hues whirled in Perrin's head, but he batted them away and answered by not answering. What was, was. "Nothing to be done about it now, Tam." According to Grady and Neald, the Black Tower did not just let men go once they signed on.

sædnəs ɛntɝd tæmz sɛnt, ðoʊ hi lɛt nʌθɪŋ ʃoʊ ɑn ɪz feɪs. hi nu ðə feɪɾ ə mɛn u kəd tʃænəl. ɡɹeɪɾi ən nil kleɪm ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə sɔɹs wɑz klin, naʊ, bʌt pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt si haʊ ðət kəd bi. wʌt wɑz, wɑz. jə dɪd ðə dʒɑb jə wɝ ɡɪvən, fɑloʊd ðə ɹoʊd jə hæd tə fɑloʊ, ən ðət wɑz ðæt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn kəmpleɪnɪŋ əbaʊt blɪstɝz, əɹ ɹɑks ʌndɝfʊt.

Sadness entered Tam's scent, though he let nothing show on his face. He knew the fate of men who could channel. Grady and Neald claimed the male half of the Source was clean, now, but Perrin could not see how that could be. What was, was. You did the job you were given, followed the road you had to follow, and that was that. There was no point complaining about blisters, or rocks underfoot.

pɛɹɪn wɛn ɑn. "ðɪs ɪz bɝteɪn ɡælɛn, lɔɹd kæptən ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz, ən dʒɝɑɹɾ ɑɹɡændə, fɝs kæptən ə ðə lidʒən ə ðə wɔl." ɑɹɡændə ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli. ðət neɪm kæɹid pəlɪɾəkəl weɪɾ ɪn ɡildən, ən əpɛɹənli æliændɝ hæd nɑt fɛl stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ənaʊns ðət ʃi wɑz ɹikənstɪtuɾɪŋ ðə lidʒən. beɪlwɝ hæɾ ə noʊz fəɹ snɪfɪŋ aʊt sikɹəts, ðoʊ. ðɪs wʌn meɪd ʃʊɹ ɑɹɡændə wəd nɑt ɡoʊ waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹitʃ ɪz kwin. "ɡælɛn, ɑɹɡændə, ðɪs ɪz tæm ælθɹ. hiz maɪ fɝs kæptən. jə stʌɾid ðə mæp, tæm, ən maɪ plæn?"

Perrin went on. "This is Bertain Gallenne, Lord Captain of the Winged Guards, and Gerard Arganda, First Captain of the Legion of the Wall." Arganda shrugged uncomfortably. That name carried political weight in Ghealdan, and apparently Alliandre had not felt strong enough to announce that she was reconstituting the Legion. Balwer had a nose for sniffing out secrets, though. This one made sure Arganda would not go wild trying to reach his queen. "Gallenne, Arganda, this is Tam al'Thor. He's my First Captain. You studied the map, Tam, and my plan?"

"aɪ stʌɾid ðɛm, maɪ lɔɹd," tæm sɛd dʒɹaɪli. ʌv kɔɹs i wəd hæv. "ɪt lʊks ə ɡʊd plæn tə mi. əz ɡʊɾ əz ɛni tɪl ði æɹoʊz stɑɹt flaɪɪŋ."

"I studied them, my Lord," Tam said dryly. Of course he would have. "It looks a good plan to me. As good as any till the arrows start flying."

ɑɹɡændə pʊɾ ə buɾɪd fʊɾ ɪn ɪz ɹoʊnz stɝəp. "soʊ lɔŋ əz hiz jəɹ fɝs kæptən, maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ hæv noʊ əbdʒɛkʃənz." hi hæɾ ɔfɝd plɛnti ɝliɝ. niðɝ i nɔɹ ɡælɛn hæd bɪn pliz ðət pɛɹɪn wɑz pʊɾɪŋ sʌmwʌn oʊvɝ ðɛm.

Arganda put a booted foot in his roan's stirrup. "So long as he's your First Captain, my Lord, I have no objections." He had offered plenty earlier. Neither he nor Gallenne had been pleased that Perrin was putting someone over them.

fɹəm ʌp ðə sloʊp keɪm ə blæk-wɪŋ mɑkɝz ʃɹɪl kɹaɪ ʌv əlɑɹm. oʊnli wʌn. ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn ə ɹil bɝd, ðə kɔl wʊɾə bɪn ɹɪpiɾɪd.

From up the slope came a black-winged mocker's shrill cry of alarm. Only one. If it had been a real bird, the call would have been repeated.

pɛɹɪn skɹæmbəld ʌp ðə sloʊp əz fæst əz i kʊd. ɑɹɡændə ən ɡælɛn pæst ɪm ɑn ðɛɹ maʊns, bʌt ðeɪ dɪvaɪɾəd tə ɹaɪd tə ðɛɹ mɛn, dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə θɪk ɡɹeɪ heɪz. pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud tə ðə tɑp ən bɪɑnd. dænɪl wɑz stændɪŋ ɔlmoʊst ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə fɑɡ, piɹɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɛnkæmpmənt. hi pɔɪntəd, bʌt ðə ɹizən fəɹ ði əlɑɹm wɑz ɑbviəs. ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup ʌv ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ wɑz livɪŋ ðə tɛns, meɪbi fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ sɛn aʊt ɹeɪɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz fɹikwənli, bʌt ðɪs wʌn wɑz eɪm stʃɹeɪɾ ət pɛɹɪn. ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌst wɔkɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wəd nɑt teɪk əm lɔŋ tə ɹitʃ ðə ɹɪdʒ.

Perrin scrambled up the slope as fast as he could. Arganda and Gallenne passed him on their mounts, but they divided to ride to their men, disappearing into the thick gray haze. Perrin continued to the top and beyond. Dannil was standing almost at the edge of the fog, peering toward the Shaido encampment. He pointed, but the reason for the alarm was obvious. A large group of algai'd'siswai was leaving the tents, maybe four hundred or more. The Shaido sent out raiding parties frequently, but this one was aimed straight at Perrin. They were just walking, but it would not take them long to reach the ridge.

"ɪts taɪm tə lɛɾ əm si ʌs, dænɪl," hi sɛd, ənpɪnɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ən dʒɹeɪpɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ə loʊ bʊʃ. hi wəd kʌm bæk fəɹ ɪt leɪɾɝ. ɪf i kʊd. ɪt wəɾ oʊnli ɡɛɾ ɪn ɪz weɪ, naʊ. dænɪl skɛtʃt ə baʊ bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ bæk ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz əz ɛɹæm əpɪɹd, sɔɹɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn hænd. hi smɛld iɡɝ. ðə kloʊk pɪn pɛɹɪn pʊɾ ɪndə hɪz pɑkət kɛɹfəli. feɪl hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ðæt. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə luz ɪt. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz faʊn ðə lɛðɝ kɔɹɾ i hæd nɑɾɪd fəɹ ɛvɹi deɪ ʌv əɹ kæptɪvəɾi. pʊlɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt, hi lɛɾ ɪt fɔl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪθaʊt ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ɪt. ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ hæd sin ðə læs nɑt.

"It's time to let them see us, Dannil," he said, unpinning his cloak and draping it over a low bush. He would come back for it later. If he could. It would only get in his way, now. Dannil sketched a bow before hurrying back into the trees as Aram appeared, sword already in hand. He smelled eager. The cloak pin Perrin put into his pocket carefully. Faile had given him that. He did not want to lose it. His fingers found the leather cord he had knotted for every day of her captivity. Pulling it out, he let it fall to the ground without glancing at it. This morning had seen the last knot.

tʌkɪŋ ɪz θʌmz bɪhaɪn ðə waɪd bɛl ðət səpɔɹɾəd ɪz hæmɝ ən bɛl naɪf, hi stʃɹoʊld aʊɾ ə ðə fɑɡ. ɛɹæm ədvænst ʌp ɑn ɪz toʊz, ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz sɔɹd stænsɪz. pɛɹɪn dʒʌst wɔkt. ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn, ɪndid hæfweɪ tə ɪts nun pik, wɑz ɪn ɪz aɪz. hi hæd kənsɪɾɝd teɪkɪŋ ði istɝn ɹɪdʒ ən pʊɾɪŋ mæsiməz mɛn hɪɹ, bʌɾ ɪt wʊɾə mɛn ðət mʌtʃ fɑɹðɝ tə ɹitʃ ðə taʊn ɡeɪts. ə fulɪʃ ɹizən, jɛt ðoʊz ɡeɪts dʒɹu hɪm əz ə loʊdstoʊn dʒɹu aɪɝn faɪlɪŋz. hi izd ɪz hɛvi hæmɝ ɪn ɪts lup ɑn ɪz bɛlt, izd ɪz bɛl naɪf. ðət hæɾ ə bleɪɾ əz lɔŋ əz ɪz hænd.

Tucking his thumbs behind the wide belt that supported his hammer and belt knife, he strolled out of the fog. Aram advanced up on his toes, already in one of those sword stances. Perrin just walked. The morning sun, indeed halfway to its noon peak, was in his eyes. He had considered taking the eastern ridge and putting Masema's men here, but it would have meant that much farther to reach the town gates. A foolish reason, yet those gates drew him as a lodestone drew iron filings. He eased his heavy hammer in its loop on his belt, eased his belt knife. That had a blade as long as his hand.

ði əpɪɹəns ə tu mɛn, əpɛɹənli wɔkɪŋ aɪdli təwɔɹd ðɛm, wɑz ɪnʌf tə hɔl ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. wɛl, pɝhæps nɑt soʊ aɪdli, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ɛɹæmz sɔɹd. ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə bi blaɪn tə mɪs ðə sʌn ɡlɪntɪŋ ɔf ɪz lɔŋ bleɪd. ðeɪ mʌst əv bɪn wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ mædmən. hæfweɪ daʊn ðə sloʊp, hi stɑpt.

The appearance of two men, apparently walking idly toward them, was enough to halt the Shaido. Well, perhaps not so idly, considering Aram's sword. They would have to be blind to miss the sun glinting off his long blade. They must have been wondering whether they were watching madmen. Halfway down the slope, he stopped.

"ɹɪlæks," hi toʊld ɛɹæm. "jɔɹ gɑnə taɪɝ jɝsɛlf aʊt ðət weɪ."

"Relax," he told Aram. "You're going to tire yourself out that way."

ði ʌðɝ mæn nɑɾəd wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz fɹəm ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ən plæntəɾ ɪz fit fɝmli. hɪz sɛnt wɑz ðəɾ ʌv ə hʌntɝ æftɝ deɪnʒɝəs kwɔɹi ən dɪtɝmən tə pʊl ɪt daʊn.

The other man nodded without taking his eyes from the Shaido and planted his feet firmly. His scent was that of a hunter after dangerous quarry and determined to pull it down.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hæf ə dʌzən ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðɛm, sloʊli. ðeɪ hæd nɑt veɪld. laɪkli ðeɪ wɝ hoʊpɪŋ i ən ɛɹæm wəd nɑt bi fɹaɪɾənd ɪndə ɹʌnɪŋ. əmʌŋ ðə tɛns, pipəl wɝ pɔɪntɪŋ ət ðə tu fulz ɑn ðə sloʊp.

After a moment, half a dozen of the Shaido started toward them, slowly. They had not veiled. Likely they were hoping he and Aram would not be frightened into running. Among the tents, people were pointing at the two fools on the slope.

ðə saʊn ə ɹʌnɪŋ buts ən hʊvz ən snɔɹɾɪŋ hɔɹsəz meɪɾ ɪm lʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ɑɹɡændəz ɡildænɪn əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə fɑɡ fɝst, ɪn ðɛɹ bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts, ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ə ɹɪpəlɪŋ ɹɛd bænɝ ðət bɔɹ ðə θɹi sɪks-pɔɪntəd sɪlvɝ stɑɹz ʌv ɡildən, ən ðən ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz ɪn ðɛɹ ɹɛɾ ɑɹmɝ bɪhaɪn ðə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɑn ə fild ə blu ʌv min. bɪtwin ðɛm, dænɪl bɪɡæn ɝeɪɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ɪn θɹi ɹæŋks. ɛvɹi mæn kæɹiɾ ə pɛɹ ə bɹɪsəlɪŋ kwɪvɝz əɾ ɪz bɛlt ən ɔlsoʊ ə bʌndəl ə ʃæfs ðəɾ i stʌk pɔɪn daʊn ɪndə ðə sloʊp bɪfɔɹ slaɪsɪŋ ðə baɪndɪŋ kɔɹdz. ðeɪ wɔɹ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz ən ʃɔɹtsɝdz, bʌt ðə hælbɝdz ən ʌðɝ pɑlɹmz hæd bɪn lɛft ɑn ðə kɑɹts ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. wʌn ə ðɛm hæd bɹɔɾ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɛd wʊlfhɛd bænɝ, bʌt ðə stæf wɑz stʌk æslɑn ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪhaɪn ðɛm. noʊ wʌn kəd bi spɛɹd tə kæɹi ðə θɪŋ. dænɪl kæɹiɾ ə baʊ, tu.

The sound of running boots and hooves and snorting horses made him look over his shoulder. Arganda's Ghealdanin appeared out of the fog first, in their burnished breastplates and helmets, riding behind a rippling red banner that bore the three six-pointed silver stars of Ghealdan, and then the Winged Guards in their red armor behind the golden hawk on a field of blue of Mayene. Between them, Dannil began arraying the Two Rivers men in three ranks. Every man carried a pair of bristling quivers at his belt and also a bundle of shafts that he stuck point down into the slope before slicing the binding cords. They wore their swords and shortswords, but the halberds and other polearms had been left on the carts this morning. One of them had brought along the red wolfhead banner, but the staff was stuck aslant into the ground behind them. No one could be spared to carry the thing. Dannil carried a bow, too.

mæsimə ən ɪz bɑɾiɡɑɹd ə lænsɝz tʊk pəzɪʃən ɑn ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz' ɹaɪt, ðɛɹ pʊɹli hændəl hɔɹsəz plʌnʒɪŋ ən ɹɪɹɪŋ. ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ ʃoʊd pætʃəz ə spɛkəl bɹaʊn wɛɹ ɹʌs hæd bɪn skɹeɪpt əweɪ ɪnstɛɾ ə pɹɑpɝli klind. mæsimə hɪmsɛlf wɑz aʊɾ ɪn fɹʌnt, ə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz hɪp bʌt hɛlmɔɪtləs ən wɪθaʊɾ ə bɹɛstpleɪt. noʊ, hi dɪd nɑt læk kɝədʒ. hi wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə minɝz, wɛɹ pɛɹɪn kəd dʒʌs meɪk aʊt bɹəleɪn ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðət fɔɹəst ə lænsɪz. hi kəd nɑt ɡɛɾ ə klɪɹ vju ʌv əɹ feɪs, bʌɾ i ɪmædʒən ɪt wɑz stɪl fɹɔsti. ʃi hæɾ əbdʒɛktəd stʃɹɛnjuəsli tə hɝ soʊlʒɝz biɪŋ hɛl bæk fɹəm ðə faɪɾɪŋ, ən i hæd niɾəd tə bi vɛɹi fɝm tə meɪk əɹ si ɹizən. laɪt, ðə wʊmən hæd hæf sədʒɛstəd ʃi maɪt lɛɾ əm ɪn ə tʃɑɹdʒ!

Masema and his bodyguard of lancers took position on the Winged Guards' right, their poorly handled horses plunging and rearing. Their armor showed patches of speckled brown where rust had been scraped away instead of properly cleaned. Masema himself was out in front, a sword at his hip but helmetless and without a breastplate. No, he did not lack courage. He was glaring at the Mayeners, where Perrin could just make out Berelain in the middle of that forest of lances. He could not get a clear view of her face, but he imagined it was still frosty. She had objected strenuously to her soldiers being held back from the fighting, and he had needed to be very firm to make her see reason. Light, the woman had half suggested she might lead them in a charge!

ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ faɪl daʊn bɪtwin ðə ɡildænɪn ən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn əkʌmpənid baɪ ðə meɪɾənz, itʃ ə hum hæd lɔŋ stʃɹɪps ə ɹɛd klɔθ taɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ʌpɝ ɑɹmz ən dæŋɡəlɪŋ tə ðə ɹɪst. hi kəd nɑt pɪk aʊɾ eɪviɛlɪn, bʌt baɪ ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ ʃi mʌs bi əmʌŋ ðɛm, nuli hild əɹ nɑt. blæk veɪlz kʌvɝd ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɪksɛp fəɹ ðɛɹ aɪz, jɛɾ i dɪd nɑt nid tə si ðɛɹ feɪsəz əɹ kætʃ ðɛɹ sɛns tə noʊ ðeɪ wɝ ɪndɪɡnənt. ðə mɑɹkɪŋz wɝ nɛsəsɛɹi tə əvɔɪɾ æksəɾənts, bʌɾ ɛdʒɹə hæd hæd tə pʊɾ əɹ fʊt daʊn tə meɪk əm wɛɹ ðə θɪŋz.

The Wise Ones and the two Aes Sedai filed down between the Ghealdanin and the Two Rivers men accompanied by the Maidens, each of whom had long strips of red cloth tied around her upper arms and dangling to the wrist. He could not pick out Aviellin, but by their number she must be among them, newly Healed or not. Black veils covered their faces except for their eyes, yet he did not need to see their faces or catch their scents to know they were indignant. The markings were necessary to avoid accidents, but Edarra had had to put her foot down to make them wear the things.

bɹeɪslɪts ʌv ɡoʊld ən aɪvɝi ɹæɾəld əz ɛdʒɹə ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ dɑɹk ʃɔl. wɪð smuð sʌn-dɑɹk tʃiks ðət sim dɑɹkɝ kəz ə hɝ peɪl-jɛloʊ hɛɹ, ʃi lʊk lɪɾəl oʊldɝ ðən pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ əɹ blu aɪz hɛld ən ənʃeɪkəbəl kɑm. hi səspɛktəd ʃi wɑz fɑɹ oʊldɝ ðən ʃi əpɪɹd. ðoʊz aɪz hæd sin ə ɡɹeɪt dil. "aɪ θɪŋk ɪɾəl bɪɡɪn sun, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ʃi sɛd.

Bracelets of gold and ivory rattled as Edarra adjusted her dark shawl. With smooth sun-dark cheeks that seemed darker because of her pale-yellow hair, she looked little older than Perrin, but her blue eyes held an unshakable calm. He suspected she was far older than she appeared. Those eyes had seen a great deal. "I think it will begin soon, Perrin Aybara," she said.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. ðə ɡeɪts kɔl tə hɪm.

Perrin nodded. The gates called to him.

ði əpɪɹəns ə nɪɹ ɪnʌf tu θaʊzən lænsɝz ən tu hʌnʒɹəd-ɑd boʊmən wɑz səfɪʃən tə meɪk ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ bɪloʊ ɹeɪz ðɛɹ veɪlz ən spɹɛɾ aʊt waɪl mɔɹ bɪɡæn ɹʌʃɪŋ fɹəm ðə tɛns tə dʒɔɪn əm ɪn ə θɪk, lɛŋθənɪŋ laɪn. pɔɪntɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz əlɔŋ ðət laɪn, pɔɪntɪŋ spɪɹz, meɪɾ ɪm lʊk bæk əɡɛn.

The appearance of near enough two thousand lancers and two hundred-odd bowmen was sufficient to make the Shaido below raise their veils and spread out while more began rushing from the tents to join them in a thick, lengthening line. Pointing fingers along that line, pointing spears, made him look back again.

tæm wɑz ɑn ðə sloʊp, naʊ, ən mɔɹ tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝ pɔɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə fɑɡ wɪð lɔŋboʊz ɪn hænd. səm tʃɹaɪd tə mɪŋɡəl wɪð ðə mɛn u hæd fɑloʊd pɛɹɪn, tə ɹiunaɪt wɪð bɹʌðɝz, sʌnz, nɛfjuz, fɹɛnz, bʌt tæm tʃɪiɾ əm əweɪ, tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ɪz blæk ɡɛldɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn əz i ɝeɪnʒd əm ɪn θɹi ɛvɝ-ɪkspændɪŋ ɹæŋks tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə hɔɹsmən. pɛɹɪn spɑɾəd hu bæɹən ən ɪz ikwəli læŋki bɹʌðɝ tæd, ðə steɪbəlmən fɹəm ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn, ən skwɛɹ-feɪs bɑɹ daʊtʃɹi, oʊnli ə fju jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən i hɪmsɛlf wɑz, hu wɑz meɪkɪŋ ə neɪm fəɹ hɪmsɛlf əz ə kæbəntmeɪkɝ, ən skɪni θæd tɔɹfɪn, hu sɛldəm lɛft ɪz fɑɹm ɪksɛp tə kʌm ɪndə ɛmənz fild. ɔɹən daʊtʃɹi, lin ən tɔl, stʊd bɪtwin dʒɑn aɪɛlɪn, hu wɑz hʌlkɪŋ ən bɔld, ən kɛv bɑɹstɪɹ, hu faɪnəli hæd ɡɑɾən aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz mʌðɝz θʌm ɪf i wɑz hɪɹ. ðəɹ wɝ mɑɹwənz ən ɑldeɪz, ælsinz ən koʊlz, θeɪnz ən ɑlkɑɹz ən kɹɔwz, mɛn fɹəm ɛvɹi fæmli hi nu, mɛn i dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz, fɹəm daʊn tə dɛvən ɹaɪɾ əɹ ʌp tə wɑtʃ hɪl əɹ tɛɹən fɛɹi, ɔl ɡɹɪm-feɪst ən bɝɾənd wɪð pɛɹz ə bɹɪsəlɪŋ kwɪvɝz ən ɛkstʃɹə ʃivz ʌv æɹoʊz. ən əmʌŋ əm stʊɾ ʌðɝz, mɛn wɪð kɑpɝi skɪnz, mɛn wɪð tʃɹænspɛɹən veɪlz əkɹɔs ðə loʊɝ hæf ə ðɛɹ feɪsəz, fɛɹ-skɪn mɛn u dʒʌs dɪd nɑɾ əv ðə lʊk ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ðeɪ kæɹid ʃɔɹɾɝ baʊz, ʌv kɔɹs - ɪt tʊk ə laɪftaɪm tə lɝn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz lɔŋboʊ - bʌɾ ɛvɹi feɪs i kəd meɪk aʊt lʊkt əz dɪtɝmən əz ɛni tu ɹɪvɝz mæn. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt wɝ ði aʊtləndɝz duɪŋ hɪɹ? ɑn ən ɑn ðə stʃɹimz ə ɹʌnɪŋ mɛn kəntɪnjuɾ əntɪl faɪnəli ðoʊz θɹi lɔŋ laɪnz hɛld ət lis θɹi θaʊzən mɛn, meɪbi fɔɹ.

Tam was on the slope, now, and more Two Rivers men were pouring out of the fog with longbows in hand. Some tried to mingle with the men who had followed Perrin, to reunite with brothers, sons, nephews, friends, but Tam chivvied them away, trotting his black gelding up and down as he arranged them in three ever-expanding ranks to either side of the horsemen. Perrin spotted Hu Barran and his equally lanky brother Tad, the stablemen from the Winespring Inn, and square-faced Bar Dowtry, only a few years older than he himself was, who was making a name for himself as a cabinetmaker, and skinny Thad Torfinn, who seldom left his farm except to come into Emond's Field. Oren Dautry, lean and tall, stood between Jon Ayellin, who was hulking and bald, and Kev Barstere, who finally had gotten out from under his mother's thumb if he was here. There were Marwins and al'Dais, al'Seens and Coles, Thanes and al'Caars and Crawes, men from every family he knew, men he did not recognize, from down to Deven Ride or up to Watch Hill or Taren Ferry, all grim-faced and burdened with pairs of bristling quivers and extra sheaves of arrows. And among them stood others, men with coppery skins, men with transparent veils across the lower half of their faces, fair-skinned men who just did not have the look of the Two Rivers. They carried shorter bows, of course - it took a lifetime to learn the Two Rivers longbow - but every face he could make out looked as determined as any Two Rivers man. What in the Light were the outlanders doing here? On and on the streams of running men continued until finally those three long lines held at least three thousand men, maybe four.

tæm wɔkt ɪz hɔɹs daʊn ðə sloʊp tə pɛɹɪn ən sæt stʌɾiɪŋ ðə swɛlɪŋ ʃeɪɾoʊ ɹæŋks bɪloʊ, jɛɾ i sim tə hɪɹ pɛɹɪnz ənspoʊkən kwɛstʃən. "aɪ æsk fəɹ vɑləntɪɹz fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ən pɪk ðə bɛs baʊʃɑts, bʌt ðoʊz jə tʊk ɪn stɑɹɾəd kʌmɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ɡɹups. jə ɡeɪv əm ən ðɛɹ fæmliz hoʊmz, ən ðeɪ sɛd ðeɪ wɝ tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn tu, naʊ. səm ə ðoʊz baʊz woʊn kæɹi mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz, bʌt ðə mɛn aɪ tʃoʊz hɪt wʌt ðeɪ eɪm æt."

Tam walked his horse down the slope to Perrin and sat studying the swelling Shaido ranks below, yet he seemed to hear Perrin's unspoken question. "I asked for volunteers from the Two Rivers men and picked the best bowshots, but those you took in started coming forward in groups. You gave them and their families homes, and they said they were Two Rivers men too, now. Some of those bows won't carry much more than two hundred paces, but the men I chose hit what they aim at."

bɪloʊ, ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ bɪɡæn biɾɪŋ ðɛɹ spɪɹz ɹɪðmɪkli əɡɛns ðɛɹ bʊl-haɪd bʌklɝz. ɹæt-tæt-tæt-tæt! ɹæt-tæt-tæt-tæt! ɹæt-tæt-tæt-tæt! ðə saʊn ɹoʊz laɪk θʌndɝ. ðə floʊ ʌv veɪld ʃeɪps ɹʌnɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ðə tɛns sloʊd tə ə tʃɹɪkəl ðət dwɪndəl fɝðɝ ən ðən sist. ɔl ə ði ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ hæd bɪn dʒɹɔn aʊt, ɪt simd. ðət wɑz ðə plæn, æftɝ ɔl. ðəɹ mʌst əv bɪn twɛnti θaʊzən ə ðɛm, nɪɹ ɪnʌf, ɔl paʊndɪŋ ðɛɹ bʌklɝz. ɹæt-tæt-tæt-tæt! ɹæt-tæt-tæt-tæt! ɹæt-tæt-tæt-tæt!

Below, the Shaido began beating their spears rhythmically against their bull-hide bucklers. RAT-tat-tat-tat! RAT-tat-tat-tat! RAT-tat-tat-tat! The sound rose like thunder. The flow of veiled shapes running out from the tents slowed to a trickle that dwindled further and then ceased. All of the algai'd'siswai had been drawn out, it seemed. That was the plan, after all. There must have been twenty thousand of them, near enough, all pounding their bucklers. RAT-tat-tat-tat! RAT-tat-tat-tat! RAT-tat-tat-tat!

"æftɝ ði il wɔɹ, aɪ hoʊp nɛvɝ tə hɪɹ ðəɾ əɡɛn," tæm sɛd laʊdli, tə bi hɝd. ðət nɔɪz kəd ɡɛɾ ɑn ə mænz nɝvz. "wɪl jə ɡɪv ðə kəmænd, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn?"

"After the Aiel War, I hoped never to hear that again," Tam said loudly, to be heard. That noise could get on a man's nerves. "Will you give the command, Lord Perrin?"

"ju də ɪt." pɛɹɪn izd ɪz hæmɝ əɡɛn, hɪz bɛl naɪf. hɪz aɪz kɛpt ɡoʊɪŋ fɹəm ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tə ðə taʊn ɡeɪts, ən ðə dɑɹk mæs ə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ɪnsaɪd ðə taʊn. feɪl wɑz ɪn ðɛɹ.

"You do it." Perrin eased his hammer again, his belt knife. His eyes kept going from the Shaido to the town gates, and the dark mass of the fortress inside the town. Faile was in there.

"sun naʊ wɪl noʊ," ɛdʒɹə sɛd. əbaʊt ðə ti, ʃi mɛnt. ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt weɪɾəd lɔŋ ɪnʌf, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dɛd. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kɑm, ðoʊ. ɛɹæm ʃɪftəd, ʌp ɑn ɪz toʊz əɡɛn, sɔɹɾ əpɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ ɪm ɪn boʊθ hænz.

"Soon now we will know," Edarra said. About the tea, she meant. If they had not waited long enough, they were all dead. Her voice was calm, though. Aram shifted, up on his toes again, sword upright before him in both hands.

pɛɹɪn kəd hɪɹ tæm kɔlɪŋ əz i ɹoʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə laɪnz ə boʊmən. "lɔŋboʊz, nɑk! ʃɔɹtbaʊz, hoʊl tɪl jəɹ kloʊs! lɔŋboʊz, nɑk! ʃɔɹtbaʊz, hoʊl tɪl jəɹ kloʊs! doʊn dʒɹɔ, jə ful! jə noʊ bɛɾɝ! lɔŋboʊz . . . !"

Perrin could hear Tam calling as he rode along the lines of bowmen. "Longbows, nock! Shortbows, hold till you're close! Longbows, nock! Shortbows, hold till you're close! Don't draw, you fool! You know better! Longbows . . . !"

bɪloʊ, pɝhæps ə kɔɹɾɝ ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tɝn ən bɪɡæn tʃɹɑɾɪŋ nɔɹθ, pɛɹəlɛlɪŋ ðə ɹɪdʒ, stɪl biɾɪŋ ðɛɹ bʌklɝz. ənʌðɝ kɔɹɾɝ bɪɡæn tʃɹɑɾɪŋ saʊθ. ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd tə swip ɝaʊn ən kætʃ ðə mɛn ɑn ðə sloʊp fɹəm iðɝ saɪd. flæŋkɪŋ, taɪli kɔld ɪt. ə ɹɪpəl pæs θɹu ðoʊz ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ əz ðeɪ bɪɡæn stɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ spɪɹz θɹu ðə hɑɹnəs hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ boʊkeɪsɪz, hæŋɪŋ ðɛɹ bʌklɝz ɑn ðɛɹ bɛls, ənlɪmbɝɪŋ ðɛɹ baʊz.

Below, perhaps a quarter of the Shaido turned and began trotting north, paralleling the ridge, still beating their bucklers. Another quarter began trotting south. They intended to sweep around and catch the men on the slope from either side. Flanking, Tylee called it. A ripple passed through those remaining as they began sticking their spears through the harness holding their bowcases, hanging their bucklers on their belts, unlimbering their bows.

"vɛɹi sun," ɛdʒɹə mɝmɝd.

"Very soon," Edarra murmured.

ə faɪɝbɔl lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə mænz hɛɾ ɑɹtʃt aʊt fɹəm ðə tɛns təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪdʒ, ðən ənʌðɝ, twaɪs ðə saɪz, ən mɔɹ, stʃɹimz ə ðɛm. seɪlɪŋ haɪ, ðə fɝs tɝn daʊn. ən ɪksploʊɾəd wɪð laʊd ɹɔɹz ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz oʊvɝhɛd. ɪn ɹæpəd səksɛʃən, ði ʌðɝz bɪɡæn ɪksploʊɾɪŋ hɑɹmləsli, tu, bʌt mɔɹ fɑloʊd, sfɪɹz ə fleɪm spiɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪdʒ ɪn ə kəntɪnjuəs floʊ. fɔɹk sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋ stæb daʊn fɹəm ə klaʊdləs skaɪ ən ɪɹʌptəd wɪð bumɪŋ kɹæʃɪz ə θʌndɝ ən ɡɹeɪt ʃaʊɝz ə spɑɹks wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɝ kʌmɪŋ nɪɹ ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

A fireball larger than a man's head arched out from the tents toward the ridge, then another, twice the size, and more, streams of them. Sailing high, the first turned down. And exploded with loud roars a hundred paces overhead. In rapid succession, the others began exploding harmlessly, too, but more followed, spheres of flame speeding toward the ridge in a continuous flow. Forked silver lightning stabbed down from a cloudless sky and erupted with booming crashes of thunder and great showers of sparks without ever coming near the ground.

"pɝhæps fɪftin əɹ twɛnti waɪz wʌnz ɪskeɪp ðə ti," ɛdʒɹə sɛd, "ʌðɝwaɪz mɔɹ wʊɾə dʒɔɪn ɪn baɪ naʊ. aɪ kən si oʊnli naɪn wɪmən tʃænəlɪŋ. ðə ɹɛs mʌs bi əmʌŋ ðə tɛns." ʃi dɪslaɪk ði əɡɹimən i hæd wɪð ðə sintʃæn ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd, jɛɾ əɹ vɔɪs wɑz kɑm. ɪn əɹ bʊk, ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd vaɪəleɪɾɪd dʒiɾoʊ tə sətʃ ə dɪɡɹi ðəɾ ɪt wɑz kwɛstʃənəbəl wɛðɝ ðeɪ kəd bi kɔld il ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. tə hɝ, ðeɪ wɝ sʌmθɪŋ ðət hæd tə bi kʌɾ aʊɾ ə ðə bɑɾi ʌv ði il, ən ðɛɹ waɪz wʌnz wɝ ðə wɝst ə ðə sɪknəs fəɹ əlaʊɪŋ ɪt. mɑsʊɝi dʒɹu hɝ ɑɹm bæk, bʌɾ ɛdʒɹə leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. "nɑt jɛt, mɑsʊɝi soʊkɑwə. wɪl tɛl jə wɛn." mɑsʊɝi nɑɾəd oʊbiɾiəntli, ðoʊ ʃi smɛld ʌv ɪmpeɪʃəns.

"Perhaps fifteen or twenty Wise Ones escaped the tea," Edarra said, "otherwise more would have joined in by now. I can see only nine women channeling. The rest must be among the tents." She disliked the agreement he had with the Seanchan almost as much as the Aes Sedai did, yet her voice was calm. In her book, the Shaido had violated ji'e'toh to such a degree that it was questionable whether they could be called Aiel any longer. To her, they were something that had to be cut out of the body of the Aiel, and their Wise Ones were the worst of the sickness for allowing it. Masuri drew her arm back, but Edarra laid a hand on her shoulder. "Not yet, Masuri Sokawa. We will tell you when." Masuri nodded obediently, though she smelled of impatience.

"wɛl, aɪ fəɹ wʌn fil ɪn deɪnʒɝ," ənʊɹə sɛd fɝmli, dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm bæk. ɛdʒɹə lʊkt əɾ əɹ lɛvəli. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ loʊɝɾ əɹ ɑɹm. hɝ biɾɪd bɹeɪdz klɪk təɡɛðɝ əz ʃi twɪstəɾ əɹ hɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə waɪz wʌnz stɛɹ. hɝ sɛnt wɑz ə stʃɹɔŋ əniz. "pɝhæps aɪ kən weɪɾ ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ," ʃi mʌɾɝd.

"Well, I for one feel in danger," Annoura said firmly, drawing her arm back. Edarra looked at her levelly. After a moment, the Aes Sedai lowered her arm. Her beaded braids clicked together as she twisted her head away from the Wise One's stare. Her scent was of strong unease. "Perhaps I can wait a little longer," she muttered.

ðə faɪɝbɔlz hɝtlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ kəntɪnjud tə ɪksploʊd fɑɹ əbʌv, ðə laɪtnɪŋ dʒæb təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪdʒ, bʌt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ bɪloʊ wɝ nɑt weɪɾɪŋ. wɪð ə ʃaʊt, ðə meɪn mæs bɪɡæn tʃɹɑɾɪŋ kwɪkli təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪdʒ. ən sɪŋɪŋ ət ðə tɑps ə ðɛɹ lʌŋz. pɛɹɪn daʊɾɪd ɛniwʌn ɛls ɑn ðə sloʊp kəd meɪk aʊt mɔɹ ðən ə ɹɔɹ, bʌɾ ɪz ɪɹz kɑt wɝdz feɪnli. ðeɪ wɝ sɪŋɪŋ ɪn pɑɹts.

The fireballs hurtling across the sky continued to explode far above, the lightning jabbed toward the ridge, but the Shaido below were not waiting. With a shout, the main mass began trotting quickly toward the ridge. And singing at the tops of their lungs. Perrin doubted anyone else on the slope could make out more than a roar, but his ears caught words faintly. They were singing in parts.

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz . . .

Wash the spears . . .

. . . waɪl ðə sʌn klaɪmz haɪ.

. . . while the sun climbs high.

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz . . .

Wash the spears . . .

. . . waɪl ðə sʌn fɔlz loʊ.

. . . while the sun falls low.

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz . . .

Wash the spears . . .

. . . hu fɪɹz tə daɪ?

. . . who fears to die?

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz . . .

Wash the spears . . .

. . . noʊ wʌn aɪ noʊ!

. . . no one I know!

hi ʃʌt ðə saʊn aʊt, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɪt waɪl ɪz aɪz dʒɹɪftəd bɪɑn ði ɑnɹʌʃɪŋ mæs ə veɪl fɪɡjɝz tə ðə ɡeɪts ə mɔldən. aɪɝn faɪlɪŋz tə ə loʊdstoʊn. ðə ʃeɪps bɪloʊ sim tə hæv sloʊd hæf ə stɛp, ðoʊ hi nu ðeɪ hæd nɑt. ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim tə sloʊ daʊn fəɹ ɪm ət taɪmz laɪk ðɪs. haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ keɪm ɪn ɹeɪnʒ? ðeɪ hæd kʌvɝd lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən hæf ðə dɪstəns tə ðə ɹɪdʒ.

He shut the sound out, ignoring it while his eyes drifted beyond the onrushing mass of veiled figures to the gates of Malden. Iron filings to a lodestone. The shapes below seemed to have slowed half a step, though he knew they had not. Everything seemed to slow down for him at times like this. How long before they came in range? They had covered little more than half the distance to the ridge.

"lɔŋboʊz, ɹeɪz! ɑn maɪ sɪɡnəl!" tæm ʃaʊɾəd. "lɔŋboʊz, ɹeɪz! ɑn maɪ sɪɡnəl!"

"Longbows, raise! On my signal!" Tam shouted. "Longbows, raise! On my signal!"

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ɪt wɑz tu sun. θaʊzənz ə bɑstʃɹɪŋz snæp bɪhaɪn hɪm. æɹoʊz ɑɹst oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. ðə skaɪ sim blæk wɪð ðɛm. sɛkənz leɪɾɝ ənʌðɝ flaɪt fɑloʊd, ðən ə θɝd. faɪɝbɔlz bɝn swɑðz θɹu ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl θaʊzənz ʌv æɹoʊz ðət fɛl ɪn ə dɛdli heɪl ɑntu ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. ʌv kɔɹs. hi hæd fɝɡɑɾən tə fæktɝ ɪn ðə boʊmənz ɛləveɪʃən. ðət ɡeɪv əm ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ dɪstəns. tʃɹʌs tæm tə si ɪt ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. nɑɾ ɛvɹi æɹoʊ stʃɹʌk ə mæn, ʌv kɔɹs. mɛni plʌnʒd ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. pɝhæps hæf stʃɹʌk ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ, pɪɹsɪŋ ɑɹmz əɹ lɛɡz, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ bɑɾiz. wundəd ʃeɪɾoʊ hɑɹdli sloʊd, ivən wən ðeɪ hæd tə stʃɹʌɡəl ʌp fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðeɪ lɛf hʌnʒɹədz laɪɪŋ stɪl, ðoʊ, ən ðə sɛkən flaɪt pʊt daʊn hʌnʒɹədz mɔɹ, əz dɪd ðə θɝd, wɪð ðə fɔɹθ ən fɪfθ ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ðə weɪ. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kɛp kʌmɪŋ, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ əz ɪf tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ɪndə ə dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɹeɪn waɪl ðɛɹ waɪz wʌnz' bɔlz ə faɪɝ ən laɪtnɪŋz ɪksploʊɾəd fɑɹ oʊvɝhɛd. ðeɪ wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɪŋɪŋ. səm ɹeɪz ðɛɹ baʊz ən ʃɑt. ən æɹoʊ ɡɹeɪz pɛɹɪnz lɛft ɑɹm, bʌt ðə ɹɛs fɛl ʃɔɹt. nɑt baɪ fɑɹ, ðoʊ. ənʌðɝ twɛnti peɪsɪz, ən -  ðə sʌɾən ʃɑɹp saʊn ə sintʃæn hɔɹnz pʊld ɪz ɡeɪz nɔɹθ ən saʊθ dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə si ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪɹʌpt ɪn faʊntənz ə faɪɝ əmʌŋ ðə flæŋkɪŋ pɑɹɾiz. spɪɹz ə laɪtnɪŋ stæbd ɪndə ðɛm. ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ biɪŋ kɛp bæk ɪn ðə tʃɹiz, fəɹ ðə taɪm, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd dɛdli wɝk. əɡɛn ən əɡɛn, ɪksploʊʒənz ə faɪɝ əɹ laɪtnɪŋ hɝl mɛn laɪk twɪɡz. ðoʊz ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ kəɾ əv noʊ aɪdiə wɛɹ ði ətæk wɑz kʌmɪŋ fɹʌm. ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə ɹʌn təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹiz, təwɔɹd ðɛɹ kɪlɝz. səm ə ðə faɪɝbɔlz kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp bɪɡæn flaɪɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə fɔɹəsts wɛɹ ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ, ən laɪtnɪŋz dʒæb təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹiz, bʌt wɪð əz lɪɾəl ɪfɛkt əz ðeɪ hæɾ əɡɛns ðə ɹɪdʒ. taɪli kleɪm deɪmeɪn wɝ juz fəɹ ɔl sɔɹts ə tæsks, bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz, ðeɪ wɝ wɛpənz ʌv wɔɹ, ən ðeɪ ən ðə sʌldəm wɝ vɛɹi ɡʊɾ əɾ ɪt.

Perrin shook his head. It was too soon. Thousands of bowstrings snapped behind him. Arrows arced over his head. The sky seemed black with them. Seconds later another flight followed, then a third. Fireballs burned swathes through them, but it was still thousands of arrows that fell in a deadly hail onto the Shaido. Of course. He had forgotten to factor in the bowmen's elevation. That gave them a little more distance. Trust Tam to see it right away. Not every arrow struck a man, of course. Many plunged into the ground. Perhaps half struck algai'd'siswai, piercing arms or legs, striking bodies. Wounded Shaido hardly slowed, even when they had to struggle up from the ground. They left hundreds lying still, though, and the second flight put down hundreds more, as did the third, with the fourth and fifth already on the way. The Shaido kept coming, leaning forward as if trotting into a driving rain while their Wise Ones' balls of fire and lightnings exploded far overhead. They were no longer singing. Some raised their bows and shot. An arrow grazed Perrin's left arm, but the rest fell short. Not by far, though. Another twenty paces, and -  The sudden sharp sound of Seanchan horns pulled his gaze north and south just in time to see the ground erupt in fountains of fire among the flanking parties. Spears of lightning stabbed into them. The damane were being kept back in the trees, for the time, but they did deadly work. Again and again, explosions of fire or lightning hurled men like twigs. Those algai'd'siswai could have no idea where the attack was coming from. They began to run toward the trees, toward their killers. Some of the fireballs coming out of the camp began flying toward the forests where the damane were, and lightnings jabbed toward the trees, but with as little effect as they had against the ridge. Tylee claimed damane were used for all sorts of tasks, but the truth was, they were weapons of war, and they and the sul'dam were very good at it.

"naʊ," ɛdʒɹə sɛd, ən faɪɝbɔlz bɪɡæn ɹeɪnɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ bɪloʊ. ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪd θɹoʊɪŋ moʊʃənz wɪð boʊθ ɑɹmz əz fæst əz ðeɪ kʊd, ən ɛvɹi taɪm, ə bɔl ə fleɪm sim tə ɹaɪz fɹəm ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps. mɛni ʌv ðoʊz ɪksploʊɾəd tu sun, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ waɪz wʌnz wɝ wɝkɪŋ tə dɪfɛn ðɛɹ oʊn. bʌt ði ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ wɝ mʌtʃ nɪɹɝ tə ðə ɹɪdʒ, soʊ ðeɪ hæd lɛs taɪm tə ɹiækt. faɪɝbɔlz bɝst əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, hɝlɪŋ mɛn əsaɪd, flɪŋɪŋ sɛvɝɾ ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz ɪndə ði ɛɹ. sɪlvɝ-blu laɪtnɪŋ boʊls fɔɹk daʊn, ən moʊst ə ðoʊz stʃɹʌk, tu. ðə hɛɹ ɑn pɛɹɪnz ɑɹmz stɝd. ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz hɛd tʃɹaɪd tə stænd. ði ɛɹ sim tə kɹækəl wɪð ðə laɪtnɪŋz' dɪstʃɑɹdʒəz.

"Now," Edarra said, and fireballs began raining down on the Shaido below. The Wise Ones and Aes Sedai made throwing motions with both arms as fast as they could, and every time, a ball of flame seemed to rise from their fingertips. Many of those exploded too soon, of course. The Shaido Wise Ones were working to defend their own. But the algai'd'siswai were much nearer to the ridge, so they had less time to react. Fireballs burst among the Shaido, hurling men aside, flinging severed arms and legs into the air. Silver-blue lightning bolts forked down, and most of those struck, too. The hair on Perrin's arms stirred. The hair on his head tried to stand. The air seemed to crackle with the lightnings' discharges.

ivən əz ðeɪ flʌŋ dɛθ ət ðə mɛn bɪloʊ, ɛdʒɹə ən ði ʌðɝz kəntɪnjud tə pɛɹi ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ waɪz wʌnz' ətæks, ən ɔl ðə waɪl, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝk ðɛɹ baʊz əz fæst əz ðeɪ kʊd. ə tʃɹeɪn mæn kəd lus twɛlv ʃæfs ɪn ə mɪnət, ən ðə ɹeɪnʒ wɑz ʃɔɹɾɝ naʊ. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ læk noʊ mɔɹ ðən tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ə ɹitʃɪŋ ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə ɹɪdʒ. ðɛɹ æɹoʊz stɪl fɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə pɛɹɪn, bʌt ðə tu ɹɪvɝz æɹoʊz wɝ stʃɹaɪkɪŋ hoʊm ɛvɹi taɪm ət ðɪs ɹeɪnʒ. itʃ boʊmən wɑz pɪkɪŋ ɪz oʊn tɑɹɡət, ʌv kɔɹs, soʊ pɛɹɪn sɔ ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ fɔl pɪɹs baɪ tu, θɹi, ivən fɔɹ ʃæfs.

Even as they flung death at the men below, Edarra and the others continued to parry the Shaido Wise Ones' attacks, and all the while, the Two Rivers men worked their bows as fast as they could. A trained man could loose twelve shafts in a minute, and the range was shorter now. The Shaido lacked no more than two hundred paces of reaching the bottom of the ridge. Their arrows still fell short of Perrin, but the Two Rivers arrows were striking home every time at this range. Each bowman was picking his own target, of course, so Perrin saw algai'd'siswai fall pierced by two, three, even four shafts.

flɛʃ kəɾ oʊnli teɪk soʊ mʌtʃ. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ bɪɡæn tə fɔl bæk. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə ɹaʊt. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt fli. mɛni ʃɑɾ æɹoʊz bæk ət ðə ɹɪdʒ dɪspaɪt noʊ hoʊp ə meɪkɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnʒ. bʌt ðeɪ tɝn əz ɪf ɑn ə kəmæn ən ɹæn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə aʊtpeɪs ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ʃæfs ən ðə ɹeɪn ə faɪɝ ən laɪtnɪŋ ðət pɝsud ðɛm. ðə flæŋkɝz wɝ fɔlɪŋ bæk, tu, əz lænsɝz əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz fɔɹmɪŋ ɹæŋks ə θaʊzən hɔɹsəz waɪd, ədvænsɪŋ sloʊli waɪl faɪɝ ən laɪtnɪŋ hɛɹid ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ.

Flesh could only take so much. The Shaido began to fall back. It was not a rout. They did not flee. Many shot arrows back at the ridge despite no hope of making the range. But they turned as if on a command and ran, trying to outpace the Two Rivers shafts and the rain of fire and lightning that pursued them. The flankers were falling back, too, as lancers appeared out of the trees forming ranks a thousand horses wide, advancing slowly while fire and lightning harried the Shaido.

"baɪ ɹæŋks," tæm ʃaʊɾəd, "ədvæns θɹi peɪsɪz ən lus!"

"By ranks," Tam shouted, "advance three paces and loose!"

"ədvæns əɾ ə wɔk!" ɑɹɡændə bɛloʊd.

"Advance at a walk!" Arganda bellowed.

"wɪð mi!" mæsimə ʃaʊɾəd.

"With me!" Masema shouted.

pɛɹɪn wɑz səpoʊz tə meɪk ðət sloʊ ədvæns wɪð ði ʌðɝz, bʌɾ i bɪɡæn tə wɔk daʊn ðə sloʊp fæstɝ ən fæstɝ. ðə ɡeɪts tʌɡd ət hɪm. hɪz blʌd wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ faɪɝ. ɛlaɪəs kleɪmd ɪt wɑz ə nætʃɹəl filɪŋ wən jə wɝ ɪn deɪnʒɝ ə jəɹ laɪf, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt si ɪt. hi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs dʒɹaʊn ɪn ðə wɔɾɝwʊd wʌns, ən i hæd fɛl nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs θɹɪl ðət wɑz sɝdʒɪŋ θɹu hɪm naʊ. sʌmwʌn bɪhaɪnd ʃaʊɾəd ɪz neɪm, bʌɾ i tʃɹɑɾəd ɑn, pɪkɪŋ ʌp spid. fɹiɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ fɹəm ɪts bɛlt lup, hi dʒɹu hɪz bɛl naɪf wɪð ɪz lɛf hænd. ɛɹæm wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm, hi ɹilaɪzd, bʌɾ ɪz oʊn foʊkəs wɑz ɑn ðə ɡeɪts, ɑn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hu stɪl stʊd bɪtwin ɪm ən feɪl. faɪɝ, laɪtnɪŋ ən æɹoʊz fɛl əmʌŋ əm laɪk heɪl, ən ðeɪ wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ tɝnɪŋ tə faɪɝ ðɛɹ oʊn æɹoʊz, ðoʊ ðeɪ ɔfən lʊkt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. bʌt mɛni wɝ səpɔɹɾɪŋ wundəd, mɛn u dʒɹæɡd ə lɛɡ əɹ klʌtʃt ə saɪd wɪð ə tu ɹɪvɝz ʃæf dʒʌɾɪŋ fɹəm ɪt, ən i wɑz kætʃɪŋ ʌp.

Perrin was supposed to make that slow advance with the others, but he began to walk down the slope faster and faster. The gates tugged at him. His blood was becoming fire. Elyas claimed it was a natural feeling when you were in danger of your life, but he could not see it. He had almost drowned in the Waterwood once, and he had felt nothing like this thrill that was surging through him now. Someone behind shouted his name, but he trotted on, picking up speed. Freeing his hammer from its belt loop, he drew his belt knife with his left hand. Aram was running beside him, he realized, but his own focus was on the gates, on the Shaido who still stood between him and Faile. Fire, lightning and arrows fell among them like hail, and they were no longer turning to fire their own arrows, though they often looked over their shoulders. But many were supporting wounded, men who dragged a leg or clutched a side with a Two Rivers shaft jutting from it, and he was catching up.

əbɹʌpli, hæf ə dʌzən veɪl mɛn tɝn bæk ɡɹɪpɪŋ spɪɹz ən stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹɾ ɪm ən ɛɹæm ət ðə ɹʌn. nɑt juzɪŋ ðɛɹ baʊz mɛn ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkspɛndɪd ðɛɹ æɹoʊz. hi hæd hɝd teɪlz ə tʃæmpiənz, ʌv mɛn u dɪsaɪɾɪd ðə fjutʃɝ baɪ sɪŋɡəl kɑmbæt bɪtwin tu ɑɹmiz ðət wəɾ əbaɪd baɪ ði aʊtkʌm. ði il hæd noʊ sətʃ teɪlz. hi dɪd nɑt sloʊ daʊn, ðoʊ. hɪz blʌd wɑz faɪɝ. hi wɑz faɪɝ.

Abruptly, half a dozen veiled men turned back gripping spears and started toward him and Aram at the run. Not using their bows meant they had expended their arrows. He had heard tales of champions, of men who decided the future by single combat between two armies that would abide by the outcome. The Aiel had no such tales. He did not slow down, though. His blood was fire. He was fire.

eɪ tu ɹɪvɝz ʃæf tʊk wʌn ʃeɪɾoʊ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə hɪz tʃɛst, ən ivən əz i fɛl, θɹi mɔɹ wɝ fɛðɝd wɪð ət list ə dʌzən æɹoʊz itʃ. bʌt naʊ hi ən ɛɹæm wɝ tu kloʊz tə ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ tu. ɛniwʌn bʌt ðə vɛɹi bɛs baʊʃɑts wəd ɹɪsk hɪɾɪŋ ɪm əɹ ɛɹæm ɪf i faɪɝd. ɛɹæm floʊd təwɔɹd wʌn ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ əz ɪf dænsɪŋ, hɪz bleɪɾ ə bɹaɪt blɝ, bʌt pɛɹɪn hæd noʊ taɪm tə wɑtʃ ɛniwʌn ɛls faɪɾ ɪf i hæd wɑntəd tə. ə veɪl mæn u oʊvɝtɑpt ɪm baɪ ə hɛd stæbd əɾ ɪm wɪð ə ʃɔɹt spɪɹ hɛl nɪɹ ɪts beɪs. blɑkɪŋ ðə spɪɹ wɪð ɪz bɛl naɪf, pɛɹɪn swʌŋ ɪz hæmɝ. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp ɪt wɪð ɪz bʌkəlɝ, bʌɾ i ɔltɝd ðə swɪŋ slaɪtli, ən hɝd ðə boʊnz ɪn ðə mænz fɔɹɑɹm snæp ʌndɝ tɛn paʊnz ə stil swʌŋ baɪ ə blæksmɪθs ɑɹm. hi wɑz ɪnsaɪd ðə spɪɹ, naʊ, ən wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ, hi slæʃt əkɹɔs ðə mænz θɹoʊt wɪð ɪz naɪf. blʌd ɡtəd, ən i wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ əɡɛn waɪl ðə mæn wɑz fɔlɪŋ. hi hæd tə ɹitʃ feɪl. faɪɝ ɪn ɪz blʌd, faɪɝ ɪn ɪz hɑɹt. faɪɝ ɪn ɪz hɛd. noʊ wʌn ən nʌθɪŋ wəd kip ɪm fɹəm feɪl.

A Two Rivers shaft took one Shaido in the middle of his chest, and even as he fell, three more were feathered with at least a dozen arrows each. But now he and Aram were too close to the remaining two. Anyone but the very best bowshots would risk hitting him or Aram if he fired. Aram flowed toward one of the Shaido as if dancing, his blade a bright blur, but Perrin had no time to watch anyone else fight if he had wanted to. A veiled man who overtopped him by a head stabbed at him with a short spear held near its base. Blocking the spear with his belt knife, Perrin swung his hammer. The Shaido tried to stop it with his buckler, but he altered the swing slightly, and heard the bones in the man's forearm snap under ten pounds of steel swung by a blacksmith's arm. He was inside the spear, now, and without slowing, he slashed across the man's throat with his knife. Blood gouted, and he was running again while the man was falling. He had to reach Faile. Fire in his blood, fire in his heart. Fire in his head. No one and nothing would keep him from Faile.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾi

CHAPTER 30

aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡeɪts feɪl tʃɹaɪd tə ɛstəmeɪt ðə taɪm baɪ ðə slæn ə laɪt fɔlɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡæps ɪn ðə ɹuən bɪldɪŋ oʊvɝhɛd; ɪt sim stɪl ʃɔɹɾ ə nun. ɔl ðət hæd bɪn klɪɹd wɑz ə smɔl speɪs ət ðə vɛɹi tɑp ə ðə beɪsmən stɛɹz. ɛni ʌv əm cʊɾə pæs θɹu ɪt, ɪf ðeɪ dɛɹd tə tʃɹaɪ klaɪmɪŋ ðə slæntɪŋ paɪl ə blækən ɹʌbəl, bʌt ðət stɪl lʊkt əz ðoʊ ɪt maɪt fɔl ɪn ɛni moʊmənt. ðə tæŋɡəl hip stɪl kɹikt əlɑɹmɪŋli ət taɪmz. ði oʊnli ɡʊd θɪŋ wɑz ðəɾ ɪt hæd nɑt stɑɹɾəd ɹeɪnɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz. haʊ lɔŋ ðət wəd læst wɑz ə kwɛstʃən. ʃi hæd bɪn hɪɹɪŋ θʌndɝ fəɹ səm taɪm, kwaɪɾ ə lɑɾ ʌv ɪt, ən sloʊli kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ. ðə bumz wɝ ɔlmoʊs kəntɪnjuəs. ə stɔɹm ðət fɪɹs maɪt bi ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə bɪldɪŋ fɪnɪʃ kəlæpsɪŋ. laɪt, ʃi wɑz θɝsti.

Outside the Gates Faile tried to estimate the time by the slant of light falling through the gaps in the ruined building overhead; it seemed still short of noon. All that had been cleared was a small space at the very top of the basement stairs. Any of them could have passed through it, if they dared to try climbing the slanting pile of blackened rubble, but that still looked as though it might fall in any moment. The tangled heap still creaked alarmingly at times. The only good thing was that it had not started raining on their heads. How long that would last was a question. She had been hearing thunder for some time, quite a lot of it, and slowly coming closer. The booms were almost continuous. A storm that fierce might be enough to make the building finish collapsing. Light, she was thirsty.

ɹoʊlən sʌɾənli əpɪɹɾ ɪn ði oʊpənɪŋ ən leɪ daʊn ɑn ðə stoʊn lændɪŋ. hi wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ðə hɑɹnəs ðət hɛld ɪz baʊ keɪs. kɛɹfəli hi ɹɪəld ɪz weɪ aʊɾ ɑntu ðə ɹʌbəl. ðə paɪl ɡɹoʊn sɔfli ʌndɝ ɪz weɪt. kɪnhuən, ə ɡɹin-aɪd mæn ə ɡʊd hæn əɹ mɔɹ ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən hi, nɛl tə ɡɹɪp ɪz æŋkəlz. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli θɹi ʌv ðə bɹʌðɝləs ʌp ðɛɹ, ɪt simd, bʌt ðət wɑz θɹi tu mɛni.

Rolan suddenly appeared in the opening and lay down on the stone landing. He was not wearing the harness that held his bow case. Carefully he wriggled his way out onto the rubble. The pile groaned softly under his weight. Kinhuin, a green-eyed man a good hand or more shorter than he, knelt to grip his ankles. There were only three of the Brotherless up there, it seemed, but that was three too many.

hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz stɪkɪŋ oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹʌbəl, ɹoʊlən loʊɝd wʌn ɑɹm. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ mɔɹ taɪm, feɪl bæʃɪɹ. teɪk maɪ hænd."

Head and shoulders sticking over the edge of the rubble, Rolan lowered one arm. "There is no more time, Faile Bashere. Take my hand."

"meɪaɪɡdɪn fɝst," feɪl sɛd θɪkli, weɪvɪŋ əweɪ ðə sʌn-hɛɹd wʊmənz wɪɹi pɹoʊɾɛsts. laɪt, bʌɾ əɹ maʊθ wɑz koʊɾəd wɪð ɡɹɪɾ ən tu dʒɹaɪ tə spɪɾ ɛni ʌv ɪɾ aʊt. "ɹɛlə ən lətʃəl nɛkst. əl ɡoʊ læst." æliændɝ nɑɾəd əpɹuvɪŋli, bʌt ɹɛlə ən lətʃəl tʃɹaɪd tə əbdʒɛkt, tu. "bi kwaɪəɾ ən də əz aɪ seɪ," ʃi toʊld əm fɝmli. θʌndɝ kɹæʃt ən kɹæʃt. ðə stɔɹm ðət pɹədus ðət mʌtʃ θʌndɝ wəd bɹɪŋ ə dɛljudʒ, nɑt sɪmpəl ɹeɪnfɔl.

"Maighdin first," Faile said thickly, waving away the sun-haired woman's weary protests. Light, but her mouth was coated with grit and too dry to spit any of it out. "Arrela and Lacile next. I'll go last." Alliandre nodded approvingly, but Arrela and Lacile tried to object, too. "Be quiet and do as I say," she told them firmly. Thunder crashed and crashed. The storm that produced that much thunder would bring a deluge, not simple rainfall.

ɹoʊlən læft. haʊ kəd ðə mæn læf əɾ ə taɪm laɪk ðɪs? hi oʊnli stɑpt wən ðə tʃɑɹd tɪmbɝz bɪniθ ɪm ɡɹoʊn əɡɛn fɹəm ɪz ʃeɪkɪŋ. "ju stɪl wɛɹ waɪt, wʊmən. soʊ bi kwaɪəɾ ən də əz aɪ seɪ." ðəɹ wɑz ə tʌtʃ ə mɑkɪŋ ɪn ɪz toʊn ət ðæt, bʌt nɑt wən i æɾəd, "noʊ wʌn wɪl bi teɪkən aʊt bɪfɔɹ ju." ðət saʊndəd laɪk kæst aɪɝn.

Rolan laughed. How could the man laugh at a time like this? He only stopped when the charred timbers beneath him groaned again from his shaking. "You still wear white, woman. So be quiet and do as I say." There was a touch of mocking in his tone at that, but not when he added, "No one will be taken out before you." That sounded like cast iron.

"maɪ leɪɾi," æliændɝ sɛd kwaɪətli, hɔɹsli, "aɪ bɪliv i minz ɪt. əl sɛn ði ʌðɝz aʊɾ ɪn ði ɔɹɾɝ jə ɡeɪv."

"My Lady," Alliandre said quietly, hoarsely, "I believe he means it. I will send the others out in the order you gave."

"stɑp paʊɾɪŋ ən ɡɪmi jəɹ hænd," ɹoʊlən kəmændəd.

"Stop pouting and give me your hand," Rolan commanded.

ʃi wɑz nɑt paʊɾɪŋ! ðə mæn kəd bi əz ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋli stʌbɝn əz əɹ pɛɹɪn. oʊnli, ɪn pɛɹɪn, ɪt wɑz ɪntʃɹiɡɪŋ, nɑt ɹɪli ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ. ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ ɹaɪt hæn əz haɪ əz ɪt wəd ɡoʊ, ʃi lɛt ɹoʊlənz hæn ɪnvɛləp hɝz. hi lɪftəɾ əɹ izəli, tɪl əɹ feɪs wɑz dʒʌs bɪloʊ hɪz.

She was not pouting! The man could be as infuriatingly stubborn as her Perrin. Only, in Perrin, it was intriguing, not really infuriating. Raising her right hand as high as it would go, she let Rolan's hand envelop hers. He lifted her easily, till her face was just below his.

"kætʃ hoʊld ə maɪ koʊt." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɪn ə stʃɹeɪn ɪn ɪz vɔɪs dɪspaɪt ði ɑkwɝɾ æŋɡəl ə hɪz ɑɹm. "ju wɪl əv tə klaɪm oʊvɝ mi."

"Catch hold of my coat." There was no hint of strain in his voice despite the awkward angle of his arm. "You will have to climb over me."

ʃi swʌŋ əɹ lɛf hæn ʌp ən kɑɾ ə fɪsfəl ə ðə ɹʌf wʊl, hoʊldɪŋ ɑn hɑɹd. ðə peɪn ɪn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ toʊld əɹ ɪt wɑz bɹuzd əz bædli əz ʃi fɪɹd. wən i ɹilist əɹ ʌðɝ hænd, ʃi ɡæspt ət ðə dʒoʊlt ʌv æɡəni ən kwɪkli ɡɹæbd ɪz koʊt wɪð ðət wʌn, tu. ɡɹæspɪŋ əɹ weɪst ɪn boʊθ hænz, hi bustɪɾ əɹ haɪɝ, soʊ ʃi wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz bɹɔd bæk. θʌndɝ bumd ən bumd wɪθaʊt sisɪŋ. ðə ɹeɪn mʌst stɑɹt fɔlɪŋ sun. ðət wəd meɪk ɡɛɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝz aʊt mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt.

She swung her left hand up and caught a fistful of the rough wool, holding on hard. The pain in her shoulder told her it was bruised as badly as she feared. When he released her other hand, she gasped at the jolt of agony and quickly grabbed his coat with that one, too. Grasping her waist in both hands, he boosted her higher, so she was lying on his broad back. Thunder boomed and boomed without ceasing. The rain must start falling soon. That would make getting the others out more difficult.

"aɪ laɪk filɪŋ jəɹ weɪɾ ɑn mi, feɪl bæʃɪɹ, bʌt meɪbi jə kəd klaɪm ə lɪɾəl fæstɝ soʊ aɪ kən bɹɪŋ ði ʌðɝz aʊt." hi pɪntʃt əɹ bɑɾəm, ən ʃi læft ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. ðə mæn dʒʌst wəd nɑt stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ!

"I like feeling your weight on me, Faile Bashere, but maybe you could climb a little faster so I can bring the others out." He pinched her bottom, and she laughed in spite of herself. The man just would not stop trying!

ðə klaɪm oʊvɝ ɪm wɑz sloʊɝ ðən ʃi cʊɾə hoʊp fɔɹ. ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɛniθɪŋ wɑz bɹoʊkən ɪn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, bʌɾ ɪt hɝt. wʌns, ʃi θɔt ʃi kɪkt ɹoʊlən ɪn ðə hɛd. pɪntʃ hɝ, wəd hi?

The climb over him was slower than she could have hoped for. She did not believe anything was broken in her shoulder, but it hurt. Once, she thought she kicked Rolan in the head. Pinch her, would he?

ət læst ʃi wɑz aʊtsaɪɾ ən pæs kɪnhuən, ɑn əɹ fiɾ ʌndɝ ðə skaɪ wʌns mɔɹ. hɝ fɝst saɪɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ fɹəm aʊtsaɪd meɪɾ əɹ swɑloʊ, ən ðən kɑf vɪɡɝəsli əz bɪts ʌv ɡɹɪɾ ɛntɝɾ əɹ θɹoʊt. ðə tʃɑɹd tɪmbɝz wɝ tɪltɪŋ tə ən əlɑɹmɪŋ dɪɡɹi, ɹɛɾi tə kɹæʃ ɪndə ðə beɪsmənt. ðə θɝd bɹʌðɝləs, ɔɝeɪɾɪn, ə blu-aɪd mæn wɪð ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ ən ə feɪs ðət fɛl nɑt fɑɹ ʃɔɹɾ ə pɹɪɾinəs, wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ kɪnhuən ən ɹoʊlən, bʌɾ ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən i ɡlænst ət ðə bɪldɪŋ əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə si ɪt fɔl. hi wɑz skwɑt fəɹ ən il, nɑt kwaɪɾ əz tɔl əz pɛɹɪn bʌt hæf əɡɛn əz waɪd. ðəɹ mʌst əv bɪn ət list ə hʌnʒɹəd ə hɝ pipəl ɪn ðə stʃɹit, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ æŋkʃəsli, səm ə ðɛɹ waɪt ɹoʊbz steɪnd wɪð sʊt fɹəm ðɛɹ ɛfɝts ət dɪɡɪŋ əɹ aʊt. ə hʌnʒɹəd! ʃi kəd nɑt faɪn ɪɾ ɪn əɹ hɑɹt tə ʌpbɹeɪd ðɛm, haʊɛvɝ. ɪspɛʃli æftɝ ɝɑvin θɹʌst ə plʌmp wɔɾɝskɪn ɪndə hɝ hænz. ðə fɝs maʊθfʊl wɛn tə wɑʃ əweɪ ɡɹɪɾ ən dʌst, ðoʊ ʃi wɑntəd dɛspɝətli tə swɑloʊ ɪɾ ɛniweɪ, bʌɾ æftɝ ðæt, ʃi hɛld ʌp ðə skɪn ən ɔl bʌt pɔɹd wɔɾɝ daʊn əɹ θɹoʊt. hɝ bɹuzd ʃoʊldɝ pɹətɛstəd. ʃi ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪɾ ən dʒɹæŋk ən dʒɹæŋk.

At last she was outside and past Kinhuin, on her feet under the sky once more. Her first sight of the building from outside made her swallow, and then cough vigorously as bits of grit entered her throat. The charred timbers were tilting to an alarming degree, ready to crash into the basement. The third Brotherless, Jhoradin, a blue-eyed man with red-gold hair and a face that fell not far short of prettiness, was watching Kinhuin and Rolan, but every so often he glanced at the building as if expecting to see it fall. He was squat for an Aiel, not quite as tall as Perrin but half again as wide. There must have been at least a hundred of her people in the street, staring at her anxiously, some of their white robes stained with soot from their efforts at digging her out. A hundred! She could not find it in her heart to upbraid them, however. Especially after Aravine thrust a plump waterskin into her hands. The first mouthful went to wash away grit and dust, though she wanted desperately to swallow it anyway, but after that, she held up the skin and all but poured water down her throat. Her bruised shoulder protested. She ignored it and drank and drank.

sʌɾənli ʃi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹaɪkɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊn tə ðə wɛst ən loʊɝd ðə wɔɾɝskɪn tə stɛɹ. kloʊs aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊn. aʊɾ ʌv ə klaʊdləs skaɪ. ən səmtaɪmz nɑt stʃɹaɪkɪŋ. mɛni ʌv ðoʊz fɔɹk sɪlvɝi boʊls ɪɹʌptəd wɪð θʌndɝəs ɹɔɹz fɑɹ əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd. bɔlz ə faɪɝ hɝɾəld əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ, səmtaɪmz bɝstɪŋ ɪn ɛɹ wɪð ə bum laɪk θʌndɝ. sʌmwʌn wɑz faɪɾɪŋ ə bæɾəl wɪð ðə paʊɝ! bʌt hu? kəd pɛɹɪn əv faʊn ɪnʌf ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ æʃəmən tə ətæk ðə kæmp? bʌt sʌmθɪŋ wɑz vɛɹi ɑd. ʃi nu haʊ mɛni waɪz wʌnz ɪn ðə kæmp kəd tʃænəl, ən ðəɹ dɪd nɑt sim tə bi ɪnʌf laɪtnɪŋ əɹ faɪɝbɔlz. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz nɑt pɛɹɪn æftɝ ɔl. ðəɹ wɝ fækʃənz əmʌŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz. nɑt dʒʌs bɪtwin ðoʊz səpɔɹɾɪŋ əɹ əpoʊzɪŋ sɪvænə, bʌt bɪtwin sɛps wɪð oʊld əlaɪənsəz əɹ ænəmɑsəɾiz. meɪbi wʌn ə ðoʊz fækʃənz wɑz faɪɾɪŋ ənʌðɝ. ðət sim haɪli ənlaɪkli, bʌt lɛs soʊ ðən pɛɹɪn faɪndɪŋ ɪnʌf ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ətæk ən ðə waɪz wʌnz nɑt faɪɾɪŋ bæk wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ kəd mʌstɝ.

Suddenly she became aware of lightning striking outside the town to the west and lowered the waterskin to stare. Close outside the town. Out of a cloudless sky. And sometimes not striking. Many of those forked silvery bolts erupted with thunderous roars far above the ground. Balls of fire hurtled across the sky, sometimes bursting in air with a boom like thunder. Someone was fighting a battle with the Power! But who? Could Perrin have found enough Aes Sedai or Asha'man to attack the camp? But something was very odd. She knew how many Wise Ones in the camp could channel, and there did not seem to be enough lightning or fireballs. Perhaps it was not Perrin after all. There were factions among the Wise Ones.
