Not just between those supporting or opposing Sevanna, but between septs with old alliances or animosities. Maybe one of those factions was fighting another. That seemed highly unlikely, but less so than Perrin finding enough Aes Sedai to attack and the Wise Ones not fighting back with everything they could muster.

"wɛn ðə laɪtnɪŋz stɑɹɾəd, ɹoʊlən sɛd ðəɹ wɑz ə bæɾəl," ɝɑvin sɛd wən feɪl æsk hɝ. "ðæts ɔl. noʊbɑdi wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ faɪn aʊt mɔɹ əntɪl wi nu jə wɝ seɪf."

"When the lightnings started, Rolan said there was a battle," Aravine said when Faile asked her. "That's all. Nobody wanted to go find out more until we knew you were safe."

feɪl ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə dil wɪð ɹoʊlən, wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz maɪt meɪk ɪskeɪpɪŋ ðət mʌtʃ mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt. ɪf oʊnli ʃi nu wʌɾ ɪt wɑz, ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə si haʊ tə əvɔɪɾ ɪt. əɹ juz ɪt. "noʊ wʌn ɪz tə ɡoʊ ɛniwɛɹ, ɝɑvin. ɪt maɪt bi deɪnʒɝəs." ən ðeɪ maɪɾ ɪnədvɝɾəntli lɛd ʃeɪɾoʊ bæk wən ðeɪ ɹɪtɝnd. laɪt, wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn?

Faile ground her teeth in frustration. Even if she did not have to deal with Rolan, whatever was going on outside the walls might make escaping that much more difficult. If only she knew what it was, she might be able to see how to avoid it. Or use it. "No one is to go anywhere, Aravine. It might be dangerous." And they might inadvertently lead Shaido back when they returned. Light, what was going on?

meɪaɪɡdɪn stæɡɝɾ aʊt pæs kɪnhuən ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ hɪp. "hi pɪntʃt mi!" hɝ vɔɪs wɑz θɪk, bʌɾ ɪndɪɡneɪʃən keɪm θɹu. feɪl fɛlt ə stæb ʌv. . . . nɑt dʒɛləsi. sɝɾənli nɑt ðæt. ðə blʌɾi mæn kəd pɪntʃ ɛni wʊmən i wɑntəd tə. hi wɑz nɑt pɛɹɪn.

Maighdin staggered out past Kinhuin rubbing her hip. "He pinched me!" Her voice was thick, but indignation came through. Faile felt a stab of. . . . Not jealousy. Certainly not that. The bloody man could pinch any woman he wanted to. He was not Perrin.

ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ, ʃi hændəd ðə sʌn-hɛɹd wʊmən ðə wɔɾɝskɪn, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn wɑʃt aʊɾ əɹ maʊθ hɝidli bɪfɔɹ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɡʌlp θɝstəli. ʃi wɑz nɑt soʊ sʌn-hɛɹɾ ət ðə moʊmənt, hɝ kɝlz ɔl swɛt-mæɾɪd ən əz koʊɾəd wɪð dʌst əz əɹ swɛɾi feɪs. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ivən pɹɪɾi ət ðə moʊmənt.

Grimacing, she handed the sun-haired woman the waterskin, and Maighdin washed out her mouth hurriedly before beginning to gulp thirstily. She was not so sun-haired at the moment, her curls all sweat-matted and as coated with dust as her sweaty face. She was not even pretty at the moment.

ɹɛlə keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə ɹuən ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ bɑɾəm ən lʊkɪŋ ɡɹɪm əz dɛθ, bʌt ʃi iɡɝli tʊk ðə wɔɾɝskɪn ðəɾ ɑldin ɔfɝd. ðə tɔl jʌŋ ɑmɑdɪʃən, ə skwɛɹ-ʃoʊldɝd fɛloʊ hu lʊk mɔɹ ə soʊlʒɝ ðən ðə bʊkkipɝ i wɑz, ɡeɪzd əɾ əɹ ævədli əz ʃi dʒɹæŋk. ɹɛlə dɪd nɑt laɪk mɛn ðət weɪ, bʌɾ ɑldin ɹəfjuz tə æksɛp ðəɾ i kəd nɑt kənvɪns əɹ tə mɛɹi hɪm. lətʃəl əpɪɹd - ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ bɑɾəm! - ən ɔɝeɪɾɪn hændəɾ əɹ ənʌðɝ wɔɾɝskɪn, dʒɹɔɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ daʊn əɹ dɝɾi tʃik. ʃi smaɪld ʌp əɾ ɪm bɪfɔɹ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə dʒɹɪŋk. ɔlɹɛɾi pɹipɛɹɪŋ əɹ weɪ bæk ɪndə hɪz blæŋkəts ɪf ɹoʊlən pɹuvd ɑbstənət. ət list, feɪl θɔt ðət wɑz wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ.

Arrela came out of the ruin rubbing her bottom and looking grim as death, but she eagerly took the waterskin that Aldin offered. The tall young Amadician, a square-shouldered fellow who looked more a soldier than the bookkeeper he was, gazed at her avidly as she drank. Arrela did not like men that way, but Aldin refused to accept that he could not convince her to marry him. Lacile appeared - rubbing her bottom! - and Jhoradin handed her another waterskin, drawing a finger down her dirty cheek. She smiled up at him before beginning to drink. Already preparing her way back into his blankets if Rolan proved obstinate. At least, Faile thought that was what she was doing.

ət læst æliændɝ stɔk pæs kɪnhuən, ən ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑt ɹʌbɪŋ hɝsɛlf, hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən ə fɹɔsti aɪɹ toʊl ðə teɪl pleɪnli ɪnʌf. kɪnhuən bækt aʊɾ ə ði oʊpənɪŋ ən stʊd waɪl ɹoʊlən bɪɡæn wɝkɪŋ ɪz weɪ bæk əkɹɔs ðə deɪnʒɝəs paɪl ə tɪmbɝz.

At last Alliandre stalked past Kinhuin, and if she was not rubbing herself, her expression of frosty ire told the tale plainly enough. Kinhuin backed out of the opening and stood while Rolan began working his way back across the dangerous pile of timbers.

"maɪ leɪɾi," ɝɑvin kɔld æŋkʃəsli, ən feɪl tɝn tə faɪn ðə plʌmp-feɪst wʊmən nilɪŋ ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ən lɪftɪŋ meɪaɪɡdɪnz hɛɾ ɑntu hɝ læp. meɪaɪɡdɪnz aɪlɪdz flʌɾɝd bʌt nɛvɝ keɪm mɔɹ ðən hæf oʊpən. hɝ lɪps muvd wikli, bʌɾ oʊnli mʌmbəlz ɪmɝdʒd.

"My Lady," Aravine called anxiously, and Faile turned to find the plump-faced woman kneeling on the paving stones and lifting Maighdin's head onto her lap. Maighdin's eyelids fluttered but never came more than half open. Her lips moved weakly, but only mumbles emerged.

"wʌt hæpənd?" feɪl sɛd, hɝiɪŋ tə nil bɪsaɪd ðɛm.

"What happened?" Faile said, hurrying to kneel beside them.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ, maɪ leɪɾi. ʃi wɑz dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə ɛmpti ðə skɪn, ən sʌɾənli ʃi stæɡɝd. ðə nɛkst aɪ nu, ʃi dʒʌs kəlæpst." ɝɑvinz hænz flʌɾɝd laɪk fɔlɪŋ livz.

"I don't know, my Lady. She was drinking as if she intended to empty the skin, and suddenly she staggered. The next I knew, she just collapsed." Aravine's hands fluttered like falling leaves.

"ʃi mʌs bi vɛɹi taɪɝd," feɪl sɛd, smuðɪŋ əɹ meɪdz hɛɹ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə θɪŋk ə haʊ ðeɪ wɝ tə ɡɛt ðə wʊmən aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp ɪf ʃi kəd nɑt wɔk. ɪt wəd bi dʌn ɪf ðeɪ hæd tə kæɹi hɝ. laɪt, ʃi fɛlt ə tʌtʃ wɑbəli hɝsɛlf. "ʃi seɪvd ʌs, ɝɑvin." ði ɑmɑdɪʃən wʊmən nɑɾəd ɡɹeɪvli.

"She must be very tired," Faile said, smoothing her maid's hair and trying not to think of how they were to get the woman out of the camp if she could not walk. It would be done if they had to carry her. Light, she felt a touch wobbly herself. "She saved us, Aravine." The Amadician woman nodded gravely.

"aɪ wɪl haɪd jə sʌmwɛɹ seɪf əntɪl tənaɪt, feɪl bæʃɪɹ," ɹoʊlən sɛd, fæsənɪŋ ðə læs bʌkəlz ə hɪz baʊ keɪs hɑɹnəs. hɪz bɹaʊn ʃoʊufə wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd. "ðɛn əl teɪk jə tə ðə fɔɹəst." teɪkɪŋ θɹi ʃɔɹt spɪɹz fɹəm ɔɝeɪɾɪn, hi θɹʌst əm ʌp θɹu ðə hɑɹnəs bɪhaɪn soʊ ðə lɔŋ spɪɹpɔɪns, ɡlɪntɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn, stʌk ʌp əbʌv ɪz hɛd.

"I will hide you somewhere safe until tonight, Faile Bashere," Rolan said, fastening the last buckles of his bow case harness. His brown shoufa was already wrapped around his head. "Then I will take you to the forest." Taking three short spears from Jhoradin, he thrust them up through the harness behind so the long spearpoints, glinting in the sun, stuck up above his head.

feɪl ɔlmoʊs kəlæps bɪsaɪd meɪaɪɡdɪn wɪð ɹɪlif. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ nid tə kənsil ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm pɛɹɪn. bʌt ʃi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd wiknəs, nɑt naʊ. "aʊɝ səplaɪz," ʃi bɪɡæn, ən əz ɪf ðə saʊn ə hɝ vɔɪs wɝ ðə læst stʃɹɔ, ðə bɪldɪŋ ɡeɪv ə skwilɪŋ ɡɹoʊn ən fɛl ɪn wɪð ə kɹæʃ ðət dʒɹaʊn aʊt ði ɪksploʊʒənz fəɹ ə moʊmənt.

Faile almost collapsed beside Maighdin with relief. There would be no need to conceal anything from Perrin. But she could not afford weakness, not now. "Our supplies," she began, and as if the sound of her voice were the last straw, the building gave a squealing groan and fell in with a crash that drowned out the explosions for a moment.

"aɪ wɪl si ðət juv wʌt jə nid," ɹoʊlən toʊl hɝ, ɹeɪzɪŋ ðə blæk veɪl əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs. ɔɝeɪɾɪn hændəɾ ɪm ənʌðɝ spɪɹ ən ɪz bʌkəlɝ, wɪtʃ i hʌŋ ɑn ɪz bɛl naɪf bɪfɔɹ sizɪŋ əɹ ɹaɪɾ ɑɹm ən dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ tə hɝ fit. "wi mʌs muv kwɪkli. aɪ də nɑt noʊ hu wəɹ dænsɪŋ ðə spɪɹz wɪð, bʌt ðə mɛɝeɪɾɪn wɪl dæns tədeɪ."

"I will see that you have what you need," Rolan told her, raising the black veil across his face. Jhoradin handed him another spear and his buckler, which he hung on his belt knife before seizing her right arm and drawing her to her feet. "We must move quickly. I do not know who we are dancing the spears with, but the Mera'din will dance today."

"ɑldin, wɪl jə kæɹi meɪaɪɡdɪn?" wɑz ɔl ʃi mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ aʊt bɪfɔɹ ɹoʊlən stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ pʊlɪŋ əɹ wɪð hɪm.

"Aldin, will you carry Maighdin?" was all she managed to get out before Rolan strode away pulling her with him.

ʃi lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ tə si ɑldin lɪftɪŋ ə lɪmp meɪaɪɡdɪn ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz. ɔɝeɪɾɪn hæd lətʃəl baɪ hɝ ɑɹm əz fɝmli əz ɹoʊlən hæd hɝ. ðə θɹi bɹʌðɝləs wɝ liɾɪŋ ə pɝeɪɾ ʌv waɪt-ɡɑɹb mɛn ən wɪmən. ən wʌn bɔɪ. θɛɝɪl wɔɹ ə ɡɹɪm ɪkspɹɛʃən. fʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn əɹ sliv, noʊ izi mæɾɝ wɪð ɹoʊlənz bɪɡ hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm, ʃi kloʊzd əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɝaʊn ðə ɹɪdʒ hɪlt ə hɝ dæɡɝ. wʌtɛvɝ wɑz hæpənɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz, ʃi maɪɾ əv niɾ ə ðət bleɪd bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl.

She looked over her shoulder to see Aldin lifting a limp Maighdin in his arms. Jhoradin had Lacile by her arm as firmly as Rolan had her. The three Brotherless were leading a parade of white-garbed men and women. And one boy. Theril wore a grim expression. Fumbling in her sleeve, no easy matter with Rolan's big hand on her arm, she closed her fingers around the ridged hilt of her dagger. Whatever was happening outside the walls, she might have need of that blade before nightfall.

pɛɹɪn ɹæn əlɔŋ ðə waɪndɪŋ stʃɹit θɹu ðə tɛns. noʊ wʌn muvd ɪn ɪz saɪt, bʌt θɹu ðə ɹɔɹ ʌv ɪksploʊɾɪŋ faɪɝbɔlz ən laɪtnɪŋz, hi kəd hɪɹ ʌðɝ saʊnz ə bæɾəl. stil klæʃɪŋ ɑn stil. mɛn ʃaʊɾɪŋ, əz ðeɪ kɪld əɹ daɪd. mɛn skɹimɪŋ. blʌd ɹæn daʊn ðə lɛf saɪɾ ə hɪz feɪs fɹəm ə ɡæʃ ɪn ɪz skælp, ən i kəd fil ɪɾ uzɪŋ daʊn ɪz ɹaɪt saɪd fɹəm wɛɹ ə spɪɹ hæd ɡɹeɪz hɪm, uzɪŋ daʊn ɪz lɛf θaɪ fɹəm ə spɪɹ ðət hæd bɪɾən dipɝ. nɑɾ ɔl ə ðə blʌɾ ɑn ɪm wɑz ɪz oʊn. ə feɪs əpɪɹɾ ət ði oʊpənɪŋ tə ə loʊ, dɑɹk tɛn ən dʒɹu bæk hɝidli. ə tʃaɪlz feɪs, ən fɹaɪɾənd, nɑt ðə fɝst i hæd sin. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ biɪŋ pɹɛst soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ə ɡʊd mɛni tʃɪlʒɹən hæd bɪn lɛf bɪhaɪnd. ðeɪ wəd bi ə pɹɑbləm fəɹ leɪɾɝ, ðoʊ. oʊvɝ ðə tɛns, hi kəd si ðə ɡeɪts lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əhɛd. bɪɑn əm leɪ ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ən feɪl.

Perrin ran along the winding street through the tents. No one moved in his sight, but through the roar of exploding fireballs and lightnings, he could hear other sounds of battle. Steel clashing on steel. Men shouting, as they killed or died. Men screaming. Blood ran down the left side of his face from a gash in his scalp, and he could feel it oozing down his right side from where a spear had grazed him, oozing down his left thigh from a spear that had bitten deeper. Not all of the blood on him was his own. A face appeared at the opening to a low, dark tent and drew back hurriedly. A child's face, and frightened, not the first he had seen. The Shaido were being pressed so hard that a good many children had been left behind. They would be a problem for later, though. Over the tents, he could see the gates little more than a hundred paces ahead. Beyond them lay the fortress and Faile.

tu veɪld ʃeɪɾoʊ dɑɹɾɪd aʊt fɹəm bɪsaɪɾ ə dɝɾi bɹaʊn wɔl-tɛnt, spɪɹz ət ðə ɹɛɾi. bʌt nɑt fəɹ hɪm. ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ ɔf tə ðə lɛft. wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ, hi ɹæn ɪndə ðɛm. boʊθ wɝ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən hi, bʌt ðə fɔɹs ə hɪz ɹʌʃ kæɹiɾ əm ɔl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən i fɛl ɔlɹɛɾi faɪɾɪŋ. hɪz hæmɝ smæʃt ɪndə ðə bɑɾəm ʌv wʌn mænz tʃɪn waɪl i stæbd ən stæbd ət ði ʌðɝ mæn, bleɪd baɪɾɪŋ dip. ðə hæmɝ ɹoʊz ən kɹʌʃt ðə fɝs mænz feɪs, splæʃɪŋ blʌd, ɹoʊz ən fɛl əɡɛn waɪl i stæbd. ðə mæn wɪð ðə ɹuən feɪs twɪtʃt wʌns əz pɛɹɪn ɹoʊz. ði ʌðɝ leɪ stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə skaɪ.

Two veiled Shaido darted out from beside a dirty brown wall-tent, spears at the ready. But not for him. They were looking at something off to the left. Without slowing, he ran into them. Both were larger than he, but the force of his rush carried them all to the ground, and he fell already fighting. His hammer smashed into the bottom of one man's chin while he stabbed and stabbed at the other man, blade biting deep. The hammer rose and crushed the first man's face, splashing blood, rose and fell again while he stabbed. The man with the ruined face twitched once as Perrin rose. The other lay staring at the sky.

ə hɪn ə moʊʃən ət ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz lɛft aɪ meɪɾ ɪm θɹoʊ hɪmsɛlf tə ðə ɹaɪt. ə sɔɹd wɪsk θɹu ði ɛɹ wɛɹ ɪz nɛk wəɾ əv bɪn. ɛɹæmz sɔɹd. ðə wʌntaɪm tɪŋkɝ hæd teɪkən wunz, tu. blʌd koʊɾəd hæf ɪz feɪs laɪk ə stʃɹeɪnʒ mæsk, ðəɹ wɝ blʌd-wɛt ɹɛns ɪn ɪz ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp koʊt, ən ɪz aɪz lʊkt ɔlmoʊst ɡleɪzd, laɪk ðoʊz ʌv ə kɔɹps, bʌɾ i stɪl sim tə bi dænsɪŋ wɪð ðət bleɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænz. hɪz sɛnt wɑz ðə sɛn ə dɛθ, ə dɛθ i sɔt.

A hint of motion at the corner of his left eye made him throw himself to the right. A sword whisked through the air where his neck would have been. Aram's sword. The onetime Tinker had taken wounds, too. Blood coated half his face like a strange mask, there were blood-wet rents in his red-striped coat, and his eyes looked almost glazed, like those of a corpse, but he still seemed to be dancing with that blade in his hands. His scent was the scent of death, a death he sought.

"hæv jə ɡɔn mæd?" pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld. stil ɹæŋ əɡɛnst stil əz i blɑk ðət sɔɹɾ əweɪ wɪð ðə hɛɾ ə hɪz hæmɝ. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?" hi blɑkt ənʌðɝ slaɪs ə ðə bleɪd, tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɹæpəl ði ʌðɝ mæn, ən bɛɹli dæns bæk ɪn taɪm tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð oʊnli ə ɡæʃ əkɹɔs ɪz ɹɪbz.

"Have you gone mad?" Perrin growled. Steel rang against steel as he blocked that sword away with the head of his hammer. "What are you doing?" He blocked another slice of the blade, tried to grapple the other man, and barely danced back in time to get away with only a gash across his ribs.

"ðə pɹɑfəɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪt tə mi." ɛɹæm saʊndəɾ ɪn ə deɪz, jɛɾ ɪz sɔɹd muvd wɪð lɪkwəɾ iz, bloʊz bɛɹli daɪvɝɾɪd wɪð hæmɝ əɹ bɛl naɪf əz pɛɹɪn bækt əweɪ. ɔl i kəd də wɑz hoʊp i dɪd nɑt tʃɹɪp oʊvɝ ə tɛn ɹoʊp əɹ kʌm ʌp əɡɛnst ə tɛnt. "jɔɹ aɪz. jəɹ ɹɪli ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. ɪt wɑz jə hu bɹɔt ðə tʃɹɑləks tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. hi ɪkspleɪn ɪɾ ɔl. ðoʊz aɪz. aɪ ʃʊɾə noʊn ðə fɝs taɪm aɪ sɔ ju. jə ən ɛlaɪəs wɪð ðoʊz ʃæɾoʊzpɔn aɪz. aɪ hæv tə ɹɛskju ðə leɪɾi feɪl fɹəm ju."

"The Prophet explained it to me." Aram sounded in a daze, yet his sword moved with liquid ease, blows barely diverted with hammer or belt knife as Perrin backed away. All he could do was hope he did not trip over a tent rope or come up against a tent. "Your eyes. You're really Shadowspawn. It was you who brought the Trollocs to the Two Rivers. He explained it all. Those eyes. I should have known the first time I saw you. You and Elyas with those Shadowspawn eyes. I have to rescue the Lady Faile from you."

pɛɹɪn ɡæðɝd hɪmsɛlf. hi kəd nɑt kip muvɪŋ tɛn paʊnz ə stil əz kwɪkli əz ɛɹæm muvd ə sɔɹd ðət weɪɾ ə θɝɾ ə ðæt. sʌmhaʊ, hi hæd tə ɡɛt kloʊs, ɡɛt bɪɑn ðət bleɪd blɝɪŋ wɪð ðə spiɾ ʌv ɪts moʊʃən. hi kəd nɑt də soʊ wɪθaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ kʌt, ən laɪkli bædli, bʌɾ ɪf i weɪɾəd mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, ðə mæn wɑz gɑnə kɪl hɪm. sʌmθɪŋ kɑɾ ɪz hil, ən i stæɡɝd bækwɝd, nɪɹli fɔlɪŋ.

Perrin gathered himself. He could not keep moving ten pounds of steel as quickly as Aram moved a sword that weighed a third of that. Somehow, he had to get close, get beyond that blade blurring with the speed of its motion. He could not do so without getting cut, and likely badly, but if he waited much longer, the man was going to kill him. Something caught his heel, and he staggered backward, nearly falling.

ɛɹæm dɑɹɾɪd ɪn, sɔɹd tʃɑpɪŋ daʊn. sʌɾənli, hi stɪfənd, aɪz ɡoʊɪŋ waɪd, ən ðə bleɪd dʒɹɑp fɹəm ɪz hænz. hi tɑpəl fɔɹwɝd tə laɪ ɑn ɪz feɪs, tu æɹoʊz dʒʌɾɪŋ fɹəm ɪz bæk. θɝɾi peɪsɪz bɪɑn hɪm, ə pɛɹ ə veɪld ʃeɪɾoʊ ɔlɹɛɾi hæɾ æɹoʊz nɑkt ən dʒɹɔn əɡɛn. pɛɹɪn lɛp saɪdweɪz, bɪhaɪn ə ɡɹin, pik tɛnt, ɹoʊlɪŋ tə hɪz fit kwɪkli. ət ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə tɛnt, ən æɹoʊ poʊk θɹu ðə kænvəs, stɪl kwɪvɝɪŋ. kɹaʊtʃɪŋ, hi meɪɾ ɪz weɪ pæs ðə ɡɹin tɛn ən ðən ə feɪɾəd blu wʌn, ə loʊ tɛn ə dɪnʒi bɹaʊn, hæmɝ ɪn wʌn hænd, naɪf ɪn ði ʌðɝ. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm i hæd pleɪd ðɪs ɡeɪm tədeɪ. kɔʃəsli, hi pikt ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə bɹaʊn tɛnt. ðə tu ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ noʊwɛɹ tə bi sin. ðeɪ maɪt bi stɔkɪŋ ɪm ɪn tɝn, əɹ ɔf hʌntɪŋ sʌmwʌn ɛls ɔlɹɛɾi. ðə ɡeɪm hæd tɝn boʊθ weɪz bɪfɔɹ. hi kəd si ɛɹæm, laɪɪŋ wɛɹ i hæd fɔlən. ə skɹæp ə bɹiz ɹʌfəl ðə dɑɹk flɛtʃɪŋz ɑn ði æɹoʊz stɪkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ɪz bæk. ɛlaɪəs hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. hi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv lɛɾ ɛɹæm pɪk ʌp ðət sɔɹd. hi ʃʊɾə sɛn ɪm əweɪ wɪð ðə kɑɹts, əɹ meɪɾ ɪm ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə tɪŋkɝz. soʊ mɛni θɪŋz i ʃəɾ əv dʌn. tu leɪt, naʊ.

Aram darted in, sword chopping down. Suddenly, he stiffened, eyes going wide, and the blade dropped from his hands. He toppled forward to lie on his face, two arrows jutting from his back. Thirty paces beyond him, a pair of veiled Shaido already had arrows nocked and drawn again. Perrin leaped sideways, behind a green, peaked tent, rolling to his feet quickly. At the corner of the tent, an arrow poked through the canvas, still quivering. Crouching, he made his way past the green tent and then a faded blue one, a low tent of dingy brown, hammer in one hand, knife in the other. This was not the first time he had played this game today. Cautiously, he peeked around the edge of the brown tent. The two Shaido were nowhere to be seen. They might be stalking him in turn, or off hunting someone else already. The game had turned both ways before. He could see Aram, lying where he had fallen. A scrap of breeze ruffled the dark fletchings on the arrows sticking up from his back. Elyas had been right. He should never have let Aram pick up that sword. He should have sent him away with the carts, or made him go back to the Tinkers. So many things he should have done. Too late, now.

ðə ɡeɪts kɔl tə hɪm. hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. soʊ kloʊs, naʊ. stɪl kɹaʊtʃɪŋ, hi bɪɡæn tə ɹʌn əɡɛn əlɔŋ ðoʊz twɪstɪŋ stʃɹits, wɛɹi ʌv ðoʊz tu ʃeɪɾoʊ əɹ ɛni ʌðɝz ðət maɪt bi lɝkɪŋ. ðə saʊnz ə bæɾəl wɝ əhɛɾ ə hɪm, naʊ, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm nɔɹθ ən saʊθ, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt min ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ stʃɹæɡlɝz.

The gates called to him. He glanced over his shoulder. So close, now. Still crouching, he began to run again along those twisting streets, wary of those two Shaido or any others that might be lurking. The sounds of battle were ahead of him, now, coming from north and south, but that did not mean there would be no stragglers.

ɹaʊndɪŋ ə kɔɹnɝ oʊnli ə fju peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə waɪd-oʊpən ɡeɪts, hi faʊn əm fɪld wɪð pipəl. moʊst wɝ ɡɑɹbd ɪn dɝɾi waɪt ɹoʊbz, bʌt θɹi wɝ veɪld ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ, wʌn ə ðɛm ə hʌlkɪŋ fɛloʊ hu wʊɾə dwɔɹf læmɡwɪn. ðət wʌn hæd feɪlz ɑɹm ɪn ɪz fɪst. ʃi lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ɹoʊld ɪn ðə dɝt.

Rounding a corner only a few paces from the wide-open gates, he found them filled with people. Most were garbed in dirty white robes, but three were veiled algai'd'siswai, one of them a hulking fellow who would have dwarfed Lamgwin. That one had Faile's arm in his fist. She looked as if she had been rolled in the dirt.

wɪð ə ɹɔɹ, pɛɹɪn ɹʌʃt fɔɹwɝd ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ, ən ðə hjudʒ mæn flʌŋ feɪl bæk ən ɹæn təwɔɹd hɪm, spɪɹ kʌmɪŋ ʌp əz i plʌkt ɪz bʌkəlɝ fɹəm ɪz bɛlt.

With a roar, Perrin rushed forward raising his hammer, and the huge man flung Faile back and ran toward him, spear coming up as he plucked his buckler from his belt.

"pɛɹɪn!" feɪl skɹimd.

"Perrin!" Faile screamed.

ðə bɪɡ ʃeɪɾoʊ sim tə hɛzəteɪt fəɹ ə hɑɹtbit, ən pɛɹɪn tʊk ædvæntɪdʒ ʌv ɪt. hɪz hæmɝ hɪt ðə saɪɾ ə ðə mænz hɛd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪz fit lɛf ðə ɡɹaʊn əz i fɛl. ənʌðɝ wɑz ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɪm, ðoʊ, spɪɹ ɹɛɾi tə stæb. sʌɾənli ðə mæn ɡɹʌntɪd, sɝpɹaɪz ɪn ðə ɡɹin aɪz əbʌv ɪz blæk veɪl, ən dʒɹɑp tə hɪz niz piɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət feɪl, hu stʊd kloʊs. sloʊli hi fɛl fɔɹwɝd, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə ɹɪdʒ stil hɪlt ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ɪz bæk. pɛɹɪn lʊk heɪstəli fəɹ ðə θɝd, ən faʊn ɪm ɔlsoʊ laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz feɪs, wɪð tu wʊɾən naɪf hɪls stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz bæk. lətʃəl wɑz linɪŋ əɡɛnst ɹɛlə, wipɪŋ. noʊ daʊt ʃi hæd faʊn æktʃəli  kɪlɪŋ sʌmwʌn nɑt soʊ izi əz ʃi hæd səpoʊzd.

The big Shaido seemed to hesitate for a heartbeat, and Perrin took advantage of it. His hammer hit the side of the man's head so hard that his feet left the ground as he fell. Another was right behind him, though, spear ready to stab. Suddenly the man grunted, surprise in the green eyes above his black veil, and dropped to his knees peering over his shoulder at Faile, who stood close. Slowly he fell forward, revealing a ridged steel hilt rising from his back. Perrin looked hastily for the third, and found him also lying on his face, with two wooden knife hilts sticking out of his back. Lacile was leaning against Arrela, weeping. No doubt she had found actually killing someone not so easy as she had supposed.

æliændɝ wɑz ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kɹaʊd, tu, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɝ, kæɹid baɪ ə tɔl jʌŋ mæn ɪn waɪt, bʌt pɛɹɪn hæɾ aɪz oʊnli fəɹ feɪl. lɛɾɪŋ naɪf ən hæmɝ fɔl, hi stɛpt oʊvɝ ðə dɛd mɛn ən ɡæðɝɾ əɹ ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz. ðə smɛl ə hɝ fɪld ɪz noʊz. ɪt fɪld ɪz hɛd. ʃi smɛl stʃɹɔŋli ʌv tʃɑɹd wʊd, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, bʌɾ i kəd stɪl smɛl hɝ.

Alliandre was at the front of the crowd, too, and Maighdin right behind her, carried by a tall young man in white, but Perrin had eyes only for Faile. Letting knife and hammer fall, he stepped over the dead men and gathered her in his arms. The smell of her filled his nose. It filled his head. She smelled strongly of charred wood, of all things, but he could still smell her.

"aɪv dʒɹimd ə ðɪs moʊmən soʊ lɔŋ," hi bɹiðd.

"I've dreamed of this moment so long," he breathed.

"aɪ hæv, tu," ʃi sɛɾ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst, hʌɡɪŋ ɪm hɑɹd. hɝ sɛnt wɑz fʊl ə dʒɔɪ, bʌt ʃi wɑz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ.

"I have, too," she said against his chest, hugging him hard. Her scent was full of joy, but she was trembling.

"dɪd ðeɪ hɝt ju?" hi æsk dʒɛnli.

"Did they hurt you?" he asked gently.

"noʊ. ðeɪ. . . . noʊ, pɛɹɪn, ðeɪ dɪdn hɝt mi." ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ smɛlz mɪkst ɪn wɪð əɹ dʒɔɪ, ðoʊ, leɪs θɹu ɪɾ ɪnɛkstʃɹɪkəbli. ðə dʌl, eɪkɪŋ sɛn ə sædnəs ən ðə ɡɹisi ɝoʊmə ʌv ɡɪlt. ʃeɪm, laɪk θaʊzənz ə hɛɹ-faɪn niɾəlz pɹɪkɪŋ. wɛl, ðə mæn wɑz dɛd, ən ə wʊmən hæd ðə ɹaɪt tə kip əɹ sikɹəts ɪf ʃi wɑntəd.

"No. They. . . . No, Perrin, they didn't hurt me." There were other smells mixed in with her joy, though, laced through it inextricably. The dull, aching scent of sadness and the greasy aroma of guilt. Shame, like thousands of hair-fine needles pricking. Well, the man was dead, and a woman had the right to keep her secrets if she wanted.

"ɔl ðət mæɾɝz ɪz ðət jəɹ əlaɪv, ən wɝ təɡɛðɝ əɡɛn," hi toʊl hɝ. "ðæts ɔl ðət mæɾɝz ɪn ðə wɝld."

"All that matters is that you're alive, and we're together again," he told her. "That's all that matters in the world."

"ɔl ðət mæɾɝz," ʃi əɡɹid, hʌɡɪŋ ɪm ivən hɑɹɾɝ. hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf ðət ʃi æktʃəli  ɡɹoʊnd wɪð ði ɛfɝt. bʌt ðə nɛkst ɪnstənt, ʃi hæd pʊʃt bæk ən wɑz ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ɪz wunz, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ oʊpən tɪɹz ɪn ɪz koʊt tə lʊk ət ðɛm. "ðiz doʊn lʊk tu bæd," ʃi sɛd bɹɪskli, ðoʊ ɔl ə ðoʊz ɪmoʊʃənz stɪl leɪ tæŋɡəld ɪn əɹ dʒɔɪ. ʃi ɹitʃt ʌp tə pɑɹɾ ɪz hɛɹ ən tʌɡd əntɪl i bɛn ɪz hɛd soʊ ʃi kəɾ ɪɡzæmɪn ðə slæʃ əlɔŋ ɪz skælp. "jul nid hilɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs. haʊ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd jə bɹɪŋ? haʊ dɪd jə - ? noʊ, ðæts ə noʊ mæɾɝ ɹaɪt naʊ. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɪnʌf ə ðɛm tə dɪfit ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ən ðəɾ ɪz wʌts ɪmpɔɹɾənt."

"All that matters," she agreed, hugging him even harder. Hard enough that she actually groaned with the effort. But the next instant, she had pushed back and was examining his wounds, fingering open tears in his coat to look at them. "These don't look too bad," she said briskly, though all of those emotions still lay tangled in her joy. She reached up to part his hair and tugged until he bent his head so she could examine the slash along his scalp. "You'll need Healing, of course. How many Aes Sedai did you bring? How did you - ? No, that's of no matter right now. There are enough of them to defeat the Shaido, and that is what's important."

"ðɪs lɑɾ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ," hi sɛd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ tə lʊk daʊn ət hɝ. laɪt, dɝɾ əɹ noʊ dɝt, ʃi wɑz soʊ bjuɾəfəl. "ðɛɹəl bi ənʌðɝ sɪks əɹ sɛvən θaʊzən spɪɹz hɪɹ ɪn . . ." hi ɡlænst ət ðə sʌn; ɪt simd ɪt ʃəd bi haɪɝ, "lɛs ðən tu aʊɝz, meɪbi. wi nid tə fɪnɪʃ ʌp hɪɹ ən bi muvɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðɛn, ɪf wi kæn. wʌts ɹɔŋ wɪð meɪaɪɡdɪn?" ʃi wɑz lɪmp əz ə fɛðɝ pɪloʊ əɡɛns ðə jʌŋ mænz tʃɛst. hɝ aɪlɪdz wɝ flʌɾɝɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ oʊpənɪŋ fʊli.

"This lot of Shaido," he said, straightening to look down at her. Light, dirt or no dirt, she was so beautiful. "There'll be another six or seven thousand spears here in . . ." he glanced at the sun; it seemed it should be higher, "less than two hours, maybe. We need to finish up here and be moving before then, if we can. What's wrong with Maighdin?" She was limp as a feather pillow against the young man's chest. Her eyelids were fluttering without opening fully.

"ʃi taɪɝd hɝsɛlf aʊt seɪvɪŋ əɹ lɪvz," feɪl sɛd, əbændənɪŋ ɪz ɪnʒɝiz ən tɝnɪŋ tə ði ʌðɝ pipəl ɪn waɪt. "ɝɑvin, ɔl ə ju, stɑɹt ɡæðɝɪŋ ʌp ɡeɪʃeɪn. nɑt dʒʌs ðoʊz swɔɹn tə mi. ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn waɪt. wi liv noʊ wʌn wi kən ɹitʃ bɪhaɪnd. pɛɹɪn, wʌt dɝɛkʃən ɪz seɪfəst?"

"She tired herself out saving our lives," Faile said, abandoning his injuries and turning to the other people in white. "Aravine, all of you, start gathering up gai'shain. Not just those sworn to me. Everybody in white. We leave no one we can reach behind. Perrin, what direction is safest?"

"nɔɹθ," hi toʊl hɝ. "nɔɹθ ɪz seɪf."

"North," he told her. "North is safe."

"stɑɹɾ əm muvɪŋ nɔɹθ," feɪl wɛn ɑn. "ɡæðɝ kɑɹts, wæɡənz, pækhɔɹsɪz, ən loʊɾ əm wɪð wʌtɛvɝ jə θɪŋk wɪl nid. hɝi!" pipəl stɑɹɾəd muvɪŋ. ɹʌnɪŋ. "noʊ, jə steɪ hɪɹ, ɑldin. meɪaɪɡdɪn stɪl nidz tə bi kæɹid. jə steɪ, tu, æliændɝ. ən ɹɛlə. lətʃəl nidz ə ʃoʊldɝ tə kɹaɪ ɑn fəɹ ə waɪl."

"Start them moving north," Faile went on. "Gather carts, wagons, packhorses, and load them with whatever you think we'll need. Hurry!" People started moving. Running. "No, you stay here, Aldin. Maighdin still needs to be carried. You stay, too, Alliandre. And Arrela. Lacile needs a shoulder to cry on for a while."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪnd. pʊɾ ɪz waɪf daʊn ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə haʊs ɪnɡʌlft ɪn fleɪmz, ən ʃi wəd kɑmli sɛɾ əbaʊt pʊɾɪŋ ðə faɪɝ aʊt. ʃi wəd pʊɾ ɪɾ aʊt, tu. bɛndɪŋ, hi klin ɪz bɛl naɪf ɑn ðə ɡɹin-aɪd mænz koʊt bɪfɔɹ ʃiðɪŋ ɪt. hɪz hæmɝ niɾəd ə ɡʊd waɪpɪŋ, tu. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌɾ i wɑz smɪɹɪŋ ɑn ðə mænz koʊt. ðə faɪɝ wɑz feɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ɪz blʌd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ θɹɪl ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ, oʊnli taɪɹədnəs. hɪz wunz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɹəb. "wɪl jə sɛn sʌmwʌn tə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs tə lɛt bæn ən siɑnɪd noʊ ðeɪ kən kʌm aʊt naʊ?" hi sɛɾ əz i slɪp ðə hæmɝz hæf bæk θɹu ðə lup ɑn ɪz bɛlt.

Perrin grinned. Put his wife down in the middle of a house engulfed in flames, and she would calmly set about putting the fire out. She would put it out, too. Bending, he cleaned his belt knife on the green-eyed man's coat before sheathing it. His hammer needed a good wiping, too. He tried not to think about what he was smearing on the man's coat. The fire was fading from his blood. There was no thrill remaining, only tiredness. His wounds were beginning to throb. "Will you send someone to the fortress to let Ban and Seonid know they can come out now?" he said as he slipped the hammer's haft back through the loop on his belt.

feɪl stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm ɪn əmeɪzmənt. "ðeɪɹ ɪn ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs? haʊ? waɪ?"

Faile stared at him in amazement. "They're in the fortress? How? Why?"

"ælɪs dɪdn tɛl ju?" hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn sloʊ tə æŋɡɝ əntɪl feɪl wɑz teɪkən. naʊ, hi fɛl fjʊɹi bʌbəlɪŋ ʌp ɪn hɪm. bʌbəlz laɪk waɪt-hɑɾ aɪɝn. "ʃi sɛd ʃi wɑz teɪkɪŋ jə wɪð əɹ wən ʃi lɛft, bʌt ʃi pɹɑməs tə tɛl jə tə ɡoʊ tə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs wən jə sɔ fɑɡ ɑn ðə ɹɪdʒəz ən hɝd wʊlvz haʊl baɪ deɪlaɪt. aɪd swɛɹ ʃi sɛɾ ɪt stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt. bɝn mi, jə kæn tʃɹʌst ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɪntʃ."

"Alyse didn't tell you?" He had always been slow to anger until Faile was taken. Now, he felt fury bubbling up in him. Bubbles like white-hot iron. "She said she was taking you with her when she left, but she promised to tell you to go to the fortress when you saw fog on the ridges and heard wolves howl by daylight. I'd swear she said it straight out. Burn me, you can't trust Aes Sedai an inch."

feɪl ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə wɛstɝn ɹɪdʒ, wɛɹ ðə fɑɡ stɪl klʌŋ θɪkli, ən ɡɹɪməst. "nɑɾ ælɪs, pɛɹɪn. ɡəlinə. ɪf ðət wɑzn ə laɪ, tu. ɪts tə bi hɝ. ən ʃiz tə bi blæk ədʒɑ. oʊ, haʊ aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu hɝ ɹil neɪm." ʃi muvd əɹ lɛft ɑɹm ən wɪnst. ʃi hæd bɪn hɝt. pɛɹɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf wɑntɪŋ tə kɪl ðə bɪɡ ʃeɪɾoʊ ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn. feɪl dɪd nɑt lɛɾ əɹ ɪnʒɝi sloʊ hɝ, ðoʊ. "θɛɝɪl, kʌm aʊt fɹəm ðɛɹ. aɪ si jə pikɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə ɡeɪt."

Faile glanced toward the western ridge, where the fog still clung thickly, and grimaced. "Not Alyse, Perrin. Galina. If that wasn't a lie, too. It has to be her. And she has to be Black Ajah. Oh, how I wish I knew her real name." She moved her left arm and winced. She had been hurt. Perrin found himself wanting to kill the big Shaido all over again. Faile did not let her injury slow her, though. "Theril, come out from there. I see you peeking around the gate."

ə skɪni jʌŋ mæn ɛdʒd ʃaɪli ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɡeɪt. "maɪ fɑðɝ toʊl mi tə steɪ ən kip ən aɪ ɑn ju, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛɾ ɪn ən æksɛn soʊ ɹʌf ðət pɛɹɪn kəd bɛɹli ʌndɝstænd.

A skinny young man edged shyly around the corner of the gate. "My father told me to stay and keep an eye on you, my Lady," he said in an accent so rough that Perrin could barely understand.

"ðæts əz meɪ bi," feɪl sɛd fɝmli, "bʌt jə ɹʌn tə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs əz fæst əz jə kən ən tɛl huɛvɝ jə faɪn ðəɹ ðət lɔɹd pɛɹɪn sɛz ðəɹ tə kʌm. ɹʌn, naʊ." ðə bɔɪ nʌkəld ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ ən ɹæn.

"That's as may be," Faile said firmly, "but you run to the fortress as fast as you can and tell whoever you find there that Lord Perrin says they're to come. Run, now." The boy knuckled his forehead and ran.

ɪn ə kɔɹɾɝ ʌv ən aʊɝ əɹ soʊ hi ɹiəpɪɹd, stɪl ɹʌnɪŋ, fɑloʊd baɪ siɑnɪɾ ən bæn ən ɔl ði ʌðɝz. bæn meɪɾ ə lɛɡ tə feɪl ən mɝmɝd smuðli haʊ plizd i wɑz tə si hɝ əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ ɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn tə sɛɾ ʌp ə ɡɑɹd ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə ɡeɪt, baʊz ət ðə ɹɛɾi ən hælbɝdz stʌk ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi juzd ɪz nɔɹməl vɔɪs fəɹ ðæt. hi wɑz ənʌðɝ u wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əkwaɪɝ pɑlɪʃ. sɛlən ən feɪlz ʌðɝ hæŋɝz-ɑn ɹʌʃt ɝaʊn hɝ, ɔl bæbəlɪŋ wɪð ɪksaɪtmən ən seɪɪŋ haʊ wɝid ðeɪ hæd bɪn wən ʃi feɪl tə əpɪɹ æftɝ ðə wʊlvz haʊld.

In a quarter of an hour or so he reappeared, still running, followed by Seonid and Ban and all the others. Ban made a leg to Faile and murmured smoothly how pleased he was to see her again before ordering the Two Rivers men to set up a guard ring around the gate, bows at the ready and halberds stuck in the ground. He used his normal voice for that. He was another who was trying to acquire polish. Selande and Faile's other hangers-on rushed around her, all babbling with excitement and saying how worried they had been when she failed to appear after the wolves howled.

"aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə mɑsʊɝi," kɝklɪn ənaʊnst ɪn toʊnz ðət dɛɹd tʃælənʒ. hi dɪd nɑt weɪt fəɹ wʌn, ðoʊ, sɪmpli dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ən ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf əlɔŋ ðə wɔl tə ðə nɔɹθ.

"I'm going to Masuri," Kirklin announced in tones that dared challenge. He did not wait for one, though, simply drawing his sword and running off along the wall to the north.

tɑlænvɝ ɡeɪv ə kɹaɪ wən i sɔ meɪaɪɡdɪn biɪŋ hɛl baɪ ðə tɔl jʌŋ mæn ən hæd tə bi kənvɪns ðət ʃi wɑz oʊnli ɪɡzɔstəd. hi stɪl tʊk əɹ əweɪ fɹəm ðə fɛloʊ ən hɛld əɹ əɡɛnst ɪz oʊn tʃɛst, wɪspɝɪŋ tə hɝ.

Tallanvor gave a cry when he saw Maighdin being held by the tall young man and had to be convinced that she was only exhausted. He still took her away from the fellow and held her against his own chest, whispering to her.

"wɛɹ ɪz kiæd?" ɡɔl dɪmændəd. ɑn lɝnɪŋ ðət ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn wɪð ðɛm, hi lɪftəd ðə veɪl əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs. "ðə meɪɾənz tʃɹɪk mi," hi sɛd ɡɹɪmli, "bʌɾ əl faɪn əɹ bɪfɔɹ ðɛm."

"Where is Chiad?" Gaul demanded. On learning that she had never been with them, he lifted the veil across his face. "The Maidens tricked me," he said grimly, "but I will find her before them."

pɛɹɪn kɑɾ ɪz ɑɹm. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ə lɑɾ ə mɛn aʊt ðəɹ hul teɪk jə fəɹ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ."

Perrin caught his arm. "There are a lot of men out there who'll take you for a Shaido."

"aɪ hæv tə faɪn əɹ fɝst, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə." ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ði ilz vɔɪs, sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ɪz sɛnt, ðət pɛɹɪn kəɾ oʊnli kɔl hɑɹteɪk. hi ʌndɝstʊd ðə sɑɹoʊ ʌv θɪŋkɪŋ ðə wʊmən jə lʌv maɪt bi lɔs tə jə fɝɛvɝ. hi lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv ɡɔlz sliv, ən ðə mæn dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ðə laɪn ə boʊmən, spɪɹ ən bʌkəlɝ ɪn hænd.

"I have to find her first, Perrin Aybara." There was something in the Aiel's voice, something in his scent, that Perrin could only call heartache. He understood the sorrow of thinking the woman you loved might be lost to you forever. He let go of Gaul's sleeve, and the man darted through the line of bowmen, spear and buckler in hand.

"aɪl ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm." ɛlaɪəs ɡɹɪnd. "meɪbi aɪ kən kip ɪm aʊɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl." dʒɹɔɪŋ ðə lɔŋ naɪf ðət hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ɪz neɪm əmʌŋ ðə wʊlvz, lɔŋ tuθ, hi wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ æftɝ ðə tɔl ilmən. ɪf ðə tu ʌv əm kəd nɑt meɪk ðɛɹ weɪ seɪfli aʊt ðɛɹ, ðən noʊ wʌn kʊd.

"I'll go with him." Elyas grinned. "Maybe I can keep him out of trouble." Drawing the long knife that had given him his name among the wolves, Long Tooth, he went running after the tall Aielman. If the two of them could not make their way safely out there, then no one could.

"ɪf jə ɑɹ dʌn dʒæbɝɪŋ, pɝhæps jəl stæn stɪl fəɹ hilɪŋ," siɑnɪd toʊl pɛɹɪn. "ju lʊk əz ɪf jə niɾ ɪt." fʊɹən ən tɛɹəl wɝ hilɪŋ hɝ, hænz ɑn ðɛɹ sɔɹd hɪls ən aɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɑtʃ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. ðə ɹɪŋ ə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝ ɔl vɛɹi wɛl, ðɛɹ æɾətud sim tə seɪ, bʌt siɑnɪdz seɪfti wɑz ðɛɹ tʃɑɹdʒ. ðeɪ lʊk laɪk lɛpɝdz hilɪŋ ə haʊs kæt. oʊnli ʃi wɑz noʊ haʊs kæt.

"If you are done jabbering, perhaps you will stand still for Healing," Seonid told Perrin. "You look as if you need it." Furen and Teryl were heeling her, hands on their sword hilts and eyes trying to watch in every direction. The ring of Two Rivers men were all very well, their attitude seemed to say, but Seonid's safety was their charge. They looked like leopards heeling a house cat. Only she was no house cat.

"si tə feɪl fɝst," hi sɛd. "hɝ ɑɹm ɪz hɝt." feɪl wɑz tɔkɪŋ wɪð æliændɝ, boʊθ ə ðɛm soʊ æŋɡɹi ðeɪ ʃʊɾə hæd teɪlz tə bɹɪsəl. noʊ daʊɾ æŋɡɹi oʊvɝ ælɪs əɹ ɡəlinə əɹ wʌtɛvɝ əɹ neɪm wɑz.

"See to Faile first," he said. "Her arm is hurt." Faile was talking with Alliandre, both of them so angry they should have had tails to bristle. No doubt angry over Alyse or Galina or whatever her name was.

"aɪ də nɑt si hɝ bliɾɪŋ laɪk ə stʌk pɪɡ." siɑnɪd lɪftəɾ əɹ hænz tə kʌp ɪz hɛd, ən ðət tu fəmɪljɝ tʃɪl hɪt hɪm, laɪk sʌɾənli biɪŋ ɪmɝst ɪn ə wɪntɝ pɑn ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə fɹizɪŋ. hi ɡæspt ən dʒɝkt, ɑɹmz fleɪlɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz kəntʃɹoʊl, ən wən ʃi ɹilis hɪm, hɪz wunz wɝ ɡɔn, ɪf nɑt ðə blʌd smɪɹɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs ən steɪnɪŋ ɪz koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz. hi ɔlsoʊ fɛlt i kəɾ iɾ ə hoʊl dɪɹ baɪ hɪmsɛlf.

"I do not see her bleeding like a stuck pig." Seonid lifted her hands to cup his head, and that too familiar chill hit him, like suddenly being immersed in a winter pond on the brink of freezing. He gasped and jerked, arms flailing out of his control, and when she released him, his wounds were gone, if not the blood smeared on his face and staining his coat and breeches. He also felt he could eat a whole deer by himself.

"wʌt wɑz ðæt?" ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv ɡɹin tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ɪm təwɔɹd feɪl. "dɪd jə mɛnʃən ɡəlinə kæsbən?"

"What was that?" The diminutive Green turned away from him toward Faile. "Did you mention Galina Casban?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ hɝ læs neɪm," feɪl sɛd. "ə ɹaʊnd-feɪst ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ə plʌmp maʊθ ən blæk hɛɹ ən bɪɡ aɪz. pɹɪɾi ɪn ə weɪ, bʌɾ ən ənplɛzənt wʊmən. dʒju noʊ hɝ? aɪ θɪŋk ʃi mʌs bi blæk ədʒɑ."

"I don't know her last name," Faile said. "A round-faced Aes Sedai with a plump mouth and black hair and big eyes. Pretty in a way, but an unpleasant woman. Do you know her? I think she must be Black Ajah."

siɑnɪd stɪfənd, hænz nɑɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ skɝts. "ðæt saʊnz laɪk ɡəlinə. eɪ ɹɛd, ən dɪsaɪɾədli ənplɛzənt. bʌt waɪ wəd jə meɪk sətʃ ən ækjəzeɪʃən? ɪts nɑɾ ə tʃɑɹdʒ tə bɹɪŋ əɡɛnst ə sɪstɝ laɪtli, ivən əɡɛnst wʌn əz dɪsəɡɹiəbəl əz ɡəlinə."

Seonid stiffened, hands knotting in her skirts. "That sounds like Galina. A Red, and decidedly unpleasant. But why would you make such an accusation? It is not a charge to bring against a sister lightly, even against one as disagreeable as Galina."

əz feɪl ɪkspleɪnd, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə fɝs miɾɪŋ wɪð ɡəlinə, pɛɹɪnz æŋɡɝ ɡɹu əɡɛn. ðə wʊmən hæd blækmeɪl hɝ, θɹɛɾənd hɝ, laɪd tə hɝ, ðən tʃɹaɪd tə mɝɾɝ hɝ. hɪz fɪsts klɛntʃt soʊ taɪt ðəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz ʃʊk. "aɪl bɹeɪk əɹ nɛk wən aɪ ɡɛt maɪ hænz ɑn ɪt," hi ɡɹaʊld wən ʃi fɛl saɪlənt.

As Faile explained, beginning with the first meeting with Galina, Perrin's anger grew again. The woman had blackmailed her, threatened her, lied to her, then tried to murder her. His fists clenched so tight that his arms shook. "I'll break her neck when I get my hands on it," he growled when she fell silent.

"ðæɾ ɪz nɑt jəɹ ɹaɪt," siɑnɪd sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ɡəlinə mʌs bi tʃɹaɪd bɪfɔɹ θɹi sɪstɝz sɪɾɪŋ əz ə kɔɹt, ən fəɹ ðɪs tʃɑɹdʒ, ðeɪ mʌs bi sɪɾɝz. ði ɪntaɪɝ hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ maɪt sɪt fəɹ ɪt. ɪf ʃiz faʊnd ɡɪlti, ʃɪl bi stɪld ən ɛksəkjuɾəd, bʌt dʒʌstəs ɪn ðɪs laɪz wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"That is not your right," Seonid said sharply. "Galina must be tried before three sisters sitting as a court, and for this charge, they must be Sitters. The entire Hall of the Tower might sit for it. If she is found guilty, she will be stilled and executed, but justice in this lies with Aes Sedai."

"ɪf?" hi sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "ju hɝd wʌt feɪl sɛd. kən juv ɛni daʊt?" hi mʌst əv lʊk θɹɛɾənɪŋ, kəz fʊɹən ən tɛɹəl ɡlaɪɾɪd ɪn tə flæŋk siɑnɪd, ðɛɹ hænz ɹɛstɪŋ laɪtli ɑn sɔɹd hɪls, ðɛɹ aɪz hɑɹɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs.

"If?" he said incredulously. "You heard what Faile said. Can you have any doubt?" He must have looked threatening, because Furen and Teryl glided in to flank Seonid, their hands resting lightly on sword hilts, their eyes hard on his face.

"ʃiz ɹaɪt, pɛɹɪn," feɪl sɛd dʒɛnli. "wɛn dʒæk kɑplɪn ən lɛn kɔŋɡɝ wɝ əkjuzd ə stilɪŋ ə kaʊ, jə nu ðeɪ wɝ θivz, bʌt jə meɪd mæstɝ θeɪn pɹuv ðeɪ hæd stoʊlən ɪt bɪfɔɹ jə lɛt ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl əv əm stʃɹæpt. ɪts dʒʌst əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt wɪð ɡəlinə."

"She's right, Perrin," Faile said gently. "When Jac Coplin and Len Congar were accused of stealing a cow, you knew they were thieves, but you made Master Thane prove they had stolen it before you let the Village Council have them strapped. It's just as important with Galina."

"ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl wʊdn əv stʃɹæpt əm wɪθaʊɾ ə tʃɹaɪəl wʌtɛvɝ aɪd sɛd," hi mʌɾɝd. feɪl læft. ʃi læft! laɪt, ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə hɪɹ əɡɛn. "oʊ, ɔl ɹaɪt. ɡəlinə bɪlɔŋz tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ doʊn teɪk kɛɹ ə hɝ, əl ɪf aɪ ɛvɝ faɪn əɹ əɡɛn. aɪ doʊn laɪk pipəl hɝɾɪŋ ju."

"The Village Council wouldn't have strapped them without a trial whatever I'd said," he muttered. Faile laughed. She laughed! Light, it was good to hear again. "Oh, all right. Galina belongs to the Aes Sedai. But if they don't take care of her, I will if I ever find her again. I don't like people hurting you."

siɑnɪd snɪft ət hɪm, hɝ sɛn dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ. "jɔɹ ɑɹm ɪz ɪnʒɝd, maɪ leɪɾi?"

Seonid sniffed at him, her scent disapproving. "Your arm is injured, my Lady?"

"si tə ɹɛlə fɝst, pliz," feɪl sɛd. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz ɪn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən ən tʊk feɪlz hɛd bɪtwin əɹ hænz. feɪl ʃɪvɝɾ ən ɛksheɪld, hɑɹdli mɔɹ ðən ə hɛvi saɪ. nɑɾ ə bæɾ ɪnʒɝi, ðɛn, ən ɡɔn naʊ ɪn ɛni keɪs. ʃi θæŋk siɑnɪd waɪl liɾɪŋ əɹ tə ɹɛlə.

"See to Arrela first, please," Faile said. The Aes Sedai rolled her eyes in exasperation and took Faile's head between her hands. Faile shivered and exhaled, hardly more than a heavy sigh. Not a bad injury, then, and gone now in any case. She thanked Seonid while leading her to Arrela.

sʌɾənli pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪzd i kəd nɑt hɪɹ ði ɪksploʊʒənz ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ɪn fækt, hi kəd nɑt ɹikɔl hɪɹɪŋ wʌn fəɹ səm taɪm. ðət hæd tə bi ɡʊd. "aɪ nid tə faɪn aʊt wʌts hæpənɪŋ. bæn, jə kip ə kloʊs ɡɑɹɾ ɑn feɪl."

Suddenly Perrin realized he could not hear the explosions any longer. In fact, he could not recall hearing one for some time. That had to be good. "I need to find out what's happening. Ban, you keep a close guard on Faile."

feɪl pɹətɛstəɾ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ əloʊn, ən baɪ ðə taɪm i faɪnəli əɡɹid tə teɪk tɛn ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, ə ɹaɪɾɝ ɪn lækɝɾ ɑɹmɝ hæɾ əpɪɹd ɹaʊndɪŋ ðə nɔɹðɝn kɔɹnɝ ə ðə taʊn wɔl. θɹi θɪn blu plumz mɑɹkt əɹ əz taɪli. əz ʃi ɹoʊd kloʊsɝ, hi ɹilaɪzd ʃi hæɾ ə nud wʊmən dʒɹeɪpt əkɹɔs əɹ tɔl beɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə sæɾəl. ə wʊmən baʊn əɾ æŋkəlz ən niz, ɹɪsts ən ɛlboʊz. hɝ lɔŋ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ɔlmoʊs bɹʌʃt ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən ðəɹ wɝ dʒuəl nɛkləsɪz ən ɹoʊps ə pɝlz kɑɾ ɪn ɪt. ə stʃɹæn ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹin stoʊnz ən ɡoʊl slɪd fɹi ən fɛl tə ðə dɝɾ əz taɪli ɹeɪn ɪn. ɹimuvɪŋ əɹ pəkjuljɝ hɛlmət wɪð ɡɔntələɾəd hænz, ʃi ɹɛstəɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə wʊmənz ʌptɝn bɑɾəm.

Faile protested his going alone, and by the time he finally agreed to take ten of the Two Rivers men, a rider in lacquered armor had appeared rounding the northern corner of the town wall. Three thin blue plumes marked her as Tylee. As she rode closer, he realized she had a nude woman draped across her tall bay in front of the saddle. A woman bound at ankles and knees, wrists and elbows. Her long golden hair almost brushed the ground, and there were jeweled necklaces and ropes of pearls caught in it. A strand of large green stones and gold slid free and fell to the dirt as Tylee reined in. Removing her peculiar helmet with gauntleted hands, she rested it on the woman's upturned bottom.

"ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl wɛpən, ðoʊz baʊz ə jʊɹz," ʃi dʒɹɔld, aɪɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn. "aɪ wɪʃ wi hæd ðə laɪk. kɝklɪn toʊl mi wɛɹ tə faɪn ju, maɪ lɔɹd. ðeɪv bɪɡʌn sɝɛndɝɪŋ. mæsiməz mɛn hɛl tə ðə pɔɪn ə suəsaɪd - moʊst ə ðɛm ɑɹ dɛɾ əɹ daɪɪŋ, aɪ θɪŋk - ən ðə deɪmeɪn tɝn ðət ɹɪdʒ ɪndə ə dɛθtʃɹæp oʊnli ə mædmæn wəd wɔk ɪntu. bɛst ʌv ɔl, ðə sʌldəm əv ɔlɹɛɾi fɪɾəd æɾəm tə oʊvɝ tu hʌnʒɹəd wɪmən. ðət 'koʊl ti' ʌv jʊɹz wɑz ɪnʌf ðət moʊst ə ðɛm kəd nɑt stænd wɪθaʊt hɛlp. əl əv tə sɛn fəɹ tɔɹeɪkən tə flaɪ ðɛm ɔl aʊt."

"A remarkable weapon, those bows of yours," she drawled, eyeing the Two Rivers men. "I wish we had the like. Kirklin told me where to find you, my Lord. They've begun surrendering. Masema's men held to the point of suicide - most of them are dead or dying, I think - and the damane turned that ridge into a deathtrap only a madman would walk into. Best of all, the sul'dam have already fitted a'dam to over two hundred women. That 'cold tea' of yours was enough that most of them could not stand without help. I'll have to send for to'raken to fly them all out."

siɑnɪd meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. hɝ feɪs wɑz smuð, bʌɾ əɹ sɛnt wɑz dæɡɝ-ʃɑɹp fjʊɹi. ʃi stɛɹɾ ət taɪli əz ðoʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɛɹ ə hoʊl θɹu hɝ. taɪli peɪɾ əɹ noʊ maɪn əɾ ɔl ɪksɛp tə ʃeɪk əɹ hɛd slaɪtli.

Seonid made a sound in her throat. Her face was smooth, but her scent was dagger-sharp fury. She stared at Tylee as though trying to stare a hole through her. Tylee paid her no mind at all except to shake her head slightly.

"æftɝ maɪ pipəl ən aɪ ɑɹ ɡɔn," pɛɹɪn sɛd. hɪz əɡɹimənt wɑz wɪð hɝ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪsk tɛstɪŋ ɪt wɪð ɛniwʌn ɛls. "wʌɾ ɑɹ əɹ lɔsəz əsaɪd fɹəm mæsiməz mɛn?"

"After my people and I are gone," Perrin said. His agreement was with her. He did not want to risk testing it with anyone else. "What are our losses aside from Masema's men?"

"laɪt," taɪli ɹɪplaɪd. "bɪtwin jəɹ ɑɹtʃɝz ən ðə deɪmeɪn, ðeɪ nɛvɝ ɹɪli mænədʒ tə kloʊz wɪð ʌs. aɪv nɛvɝ sin ə bæɾəl plæn kʌm ɔf soʊ smuðli. ɪf wɪv ə hʌnʒɹəd dɛd bɪtwin ʌs, əl bi sɝpɹaɪzd."

"Light," Tylee replied. "Between your archers and the damane, they never really managed to close with us. I've never seen a battle plan come off so smoothly. If we have a hundred dead between us, I'll be surprised."

pɛɹɪn wɪnst. hi səpoʊz ðoʊz wɝ laɪt kæʒəwəltiz ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, bʌt səm wəd bi tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn. wɛðɝ əɹ nɑɾ i nu ðɛm, ðeɪ wɝ ɪz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi. "du jə noʊ wɛɹ mæsimə ɪz?"

Perrin winced. He supposed those were light casualties under the circumstances, but some would be Two Rivers men. Whether or not he knew them, they were his responsibility. "Do you know where Masema is?"

"wɪð wʌts lɛft ə hɪz ɑɹmi. hiz noʊ kaʊɝd, əl seɪ ðət fəɹ hɪm. hi ən ɪz tu hʌnʒɹəd - wɛl, əbaʊt wʌn hʌnʒɹəd, naʊ - kʌɾ ə pæθ ɔl ðə weɪ θɹu ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tə ðə ɹɪdʒ."

"With what's left of his army. He's no coward, I'll say that for him. He and his two hundred - well, about one hundred, now - cut a path all the way through the Shaido to the ridge."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ. ðə mæn wɑz bæk sɝaʊndəd baɪ hɪz ɹæbəl. ɪt wəd bi hɪz wɝɾ əɡɛns mæsiməz əbaʊt waɪ ɛɹæm hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɪm, ən ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðə mænz fɑloʊɝz wəd sɝɛndɝ ɪm fəɹ tʃɹaɪəl. "wi nid tə stɑɹt muvɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ði ʌðɝz ɡɛt hɪɹ. ɪf ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ θɪŋk ɹɛskju ɪz ət hænd, ðeɪ maɪt dɪsaɪd tə fɝɡɛt ðeɪ sɝɛndɝd. huz jəɹ pɹɪznɝ?"

Perrin ground his teeth. The man was back surrounded by his rabble. It would be his word against Masema's about why Aram had tried to kill him, and in any event, it was unlikely the man's followers would surrender him for trial. "We need to start moving before the others get here. If the Shaido think rescue is at hand, they might decide to forget they surrendered. Who's your prisoner?"

"sɪvænə," feɪl sɛɾ ɪn ə koʊl vɔɪs. ðə smɛl ə hɝ heɪtʃɹəd wɑz nɪɹli əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɪt hæd bɪn waɪl spikɪŋ ʌv ɡəlinə.

"Sevanna," Faile said in a cold voice. The smell of her hatred was nearly as strong as it had been while speaking of Galina.

ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən twɪstəd hɝsɛlf ʌpwɝd, ʃeɪkɪŋ hɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɝ feɪs ən luzɪŋ sɛvɹəl mɔɹ nɛkləsɪz ɪn ðə pɹɑsɛs. hɝ aɪz, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət feɪl, wɝ ɡɹin faɪɝ əbʌv ə stʃɹɪp ə klɔθ ðət hæd bɪn taɪd fəɹ ə ɡæɡ. ʃi stæŋk ə ɹeɪdʒ.

The golden-haired woman twisted herself upward, shaking hair out of her face and losing several more necklaces in the process. Her eyes, glaring at Faile, were green fire above a strip of cloth that had been tied for a gag. She stank of rage.

"sɪvænə ʌv ðə dʒuməaɪ ʃeɪɾoʊ." sæɾəsfækʃən wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn taɪliz vɔɪs. "ʃi toʊl mi soʊ pɹaʊdli. ʃiz noʊ kaʊɝd, iðɝ. mɛɾ əs wɛɹɪŋ nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ə sɪlk ɹoʊb ən əɹ dʒuəlz, bʌt ʃi mænədʒ tə spɪɹ tu ʌv maɪ ɔltɑɹənz bɪfɔɹ aɪ tʊk ɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ." sɪvænə snɑɹəl θɹu hɝ ɡæɡ ən stʃɹʌɡəld əz ɪf tə θɹoʊ hɝsɛlf fɹəm ðə hɔɹs. əntɪl taɪli smækt əɹ bɑɾəm, ɛniweɪ. æftɝ ðæt, ʃi kəntɛntəd hɝsɛlf wɪð ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn saɪt. ʃi wɑz naɪsli ɹaʊndəd, ðoʊ hi ʃəd nɑt bi noʊɾɪsɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðət wɪð ɪz waɪf ðɛɹ. ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɛlaɪəs sɛd ʃi wəɾ ɪkspɛkt ɪm tə noʊɾəs, soʊ hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf stʌɾi hɝ oʊpənli.

"Sevanna of the Jumai Shaido." Satisfaction was strong in Tylee's voice. "She told me so proudly. She's no coward, either. Met us wearing nothing but a silk robe and her jewels, but she managed to spear two of my Altarans before I took it away from her." Sevanna snarled through her gag and struggled as if to throw herself from the horse. Until Tylee smacked her bottom, anyway. After that, she contented herself with glaring at everyone in sight. She was nicely rounded, though he should not be noticing something like that with his wife there. Except that Elyas said she would expect him to notice, so he made himself study her openly.

"aɪ kleɪm ðə kɑntɛns ə hɝ tɛnt," feɪl ənaʊnst, ʃuɾɪŋ ɪm ə ʃɑɹp lʊk. meɪbi hi wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə bi ðəɾ oʊpən. "ʃi hæz ə hjudʒ tʃɛst ə dʒuəlz ɪn ðɛɹ, ən aɪ wɑn ðɛm. doʊn lʊk ət mi laɪk ə lubi, pɛɹɪn. wɪv ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən pipəl tə fid, kloʊð ən hɛlp ɡɛt bæk tə ðɛɹ hoʊmz. ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən ət list."

"I claim the contents of her tent," Faile announced, shooting him a sharp look. Maybe he was not supposed to be that open. "She has a huge chest of jewels in there, and I want them. Don't look at me like a looby, Perrin. We have a hundred thousand people to feed, clothe and help get back to their homes. A hundred thousand at least."

"aɪ wɑnə kʌm wɪð ju, maɪ leɪɾi, ɪf jəl əv mi," ðə jʌŋ fɛloʊ hu hæd bɪn hoʊldɪŋ meɪaɪɡdɪn paɪpt ʌp. "aɪ woʊn bi ði oʊnli wʌn, ɪf jəl əv ʌs."

"I want to come with you, my Lady, if you'll have me," the young fellow who had been holding Maighdin piped up. "I won't be the only one, if you'll have us."

"jɔɹ leɪɾi waɪf, aɪ pɹɪzum, maɪ lɔɹd," taɪli sɛd, aɪɪŋ feɪl.

"Your lady wife, I presume, my Lord," Tylee said, eyeing Faile.

"ʃi ɪz. feɪl, əlaʊ mi tə pɹizɛn bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl taɪli kɪɝɡən, ɪn sɝvəs tə ði ɛmpɹɛs ə sintʃæn." pɝhæps i wɑz əkwaɪɹɪŋ səm ə ðət pɑlɪʃ hɪmsɛlf. "bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl, maɪ waɪf, leɪɾi feɪl ni bæʃɪɹ teɪbɑɹə." taɪli baʊɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl. feɪl meɪɾ ə smɔl kɝtsi, ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛd slaɪtli. dɝɾi feɪs əɹ noʊ dɝɾi feɪs, ʃi wɑz ɹiɡəl. wɪtʃ meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə ðə bɹoʊkən kɹaʊn. dɪskʌʃən ə ðət lɪɾəl mæɾɝ wəɾ əv tə kʌm leɪɾɝ. noʊ daʊɾ ɪt wəd bi ə pɹəlɔŋ dɪskʌʃən. hi θɔɾ i maɪt nɑt faɪn ɪt soʊ hɑɹd tə ɹeɪz ɪz vɔɪs, ðə weɪ ʃi əpɛɹənli wɑntəd, ðɪs taɪm. "æn ðɪs ɪz æliændɝ mɛɹɪðə kɪɡɑɝɪn, kwin ʌv ɡildən, blɛsɪɾ ə ðə laɪt, dɪfɛndɝ ʌv ɡæɹənz wɔl. ən maɪ lidʒ wʊmən. ɡildən ɪz ʌndɝ maɪ pɹətɛkʃən." ful θɪŋ tə seɪ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd tə bi sɛd.

"She is. Faile, allow me to present Banner-General Tylee Khirgan, in service to the Empress of Seanchan." Perhaps he was acquiring some of that polish himself. "Banner-General, my wife, Lady Faile ni Bashere t'Aybara." Tylee bowed in her saddle. Faile made a small curtsy, inclined her head slightly. Dirty face or no dirty face, she was regal. Which made him think of the Broken Crown. Discussion of that little matter would have to come later. No doubt it would be a prolonged discussion. He thought he might not find it so hard to raise his voice, the way she apparently wanted, this time. "And this is Alliandre Maritha Kigarin, Queen of Ghealdan, Blessed of the Light, Defender of Garen's Wall. And my liege woman. Ghealdan is under my protection." Fool thing to say, but it had to be said.

"aʊɝ əɡɹimən dʌzn spik tə ðæt, maɪ lɔɹd," taɪli sɛd kɛɹfəli. "aɪ doʊn dɪsaɪd wɛɹ ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi ɡoʊz."

"Our agreement doesn't speak to that, my Lord," Tylee said carefully. "I don't decide where the Ever Victorious Army goes."

"dʒʌst soʊ jə noʊ, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl. ən tɛl ðoʊz əbʌv jə ðeɪ kæn əv ɡildən." æliændɝ smaɪld əɾ ɪm soʊ waɪdli, soʊ ɡɹeɪtfəli, hi ɔlmoʊst wɑntəd tə læf. laɪt, feɪl wɑz smaɪlɪŋ, tu. ə pɹaʊd smaɪl. hi ɹʌb ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz noʊz. "wi ɹɪli də nid tə bɪɡɪn muvɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðoʊz ʌðɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ ɝaɪv. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə faɪn maɪsɛlf wɪð əm ɪn fɹʌn ə mi ən ɔl ðoʊz pɹɪznɝz bɪhaɪn mi θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt pɪkɪŋ ʌp ə spɪɹ əɡɛn."

"Just so you know, Banner-General. And tell those above you they can't have Ghealdan." Alliandre smiled at him so widely, so gratefully, he almost wanted to laugh. Light, Faile was smiling, too. A proud smile. He rubbed the side of his nose. "We really do need to begin moving before those other Shaido arrive. I don't want to find myself with them in front of me and all those prisoners behind me thinking about picking up a spear again."

taɪli tʃʌkəld. "aɪ hæv ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð ðiz pipəl ðən ju, maɪ lɔɹd. wʌns ðeɪ sɝɛndɝ, ðeɪ woʊn faɪɾ əɡɛn əɹ tʃɹaɪ tə ɪskeɪp fəɹ θɹi deɪz. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ hæv səm ə maɪ ɔltɑɹənz meɪkɪŋ bɑnfaɪɝz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ spɪɹz ən baʊz dʒʌs tə meɪk ʃʊɹ. wɪv taɪm tə meɪk əɹ dɪplɔɪməns. maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ hoʊp aɪ nɛvɝ əv tə feɪs jə ɪn ðə fild," ʃi sɛd, pʊlɪŋ ðə stil-bækt ɡɔnlət fɹəm əɹ ɹaɪt hænd. "aɪ wəd bi ɑnɝɾ ɪf jud kɔl mi taɪli." ʃi bɛn oʊvɝ sɪvænə tə ɔfɝ əɹ hænd.

Tylee chuckled. "I have a little more experience with these people than you, my Lord. Once they surrender, they won't fight again or try to escape for three days. Besides, I have some of my Altarans making bonfires out of their spears and bows just to make sure. We have time to make our deployments. My Lord, I hope I never have to face you in the field," she said, pulling the steel-backed gauntlet from her right hand. "I would be honored if you'd call me Tylee." She bent over Sevanna to offer her hand.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, pɛɹɪn kəɾ oʊnli stɛɹ. ɪt wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ wɝld. hi hæd ɡɔn tə hɝ θɪŋkɪŋ i wɑz meɪkɪŋ ə dil wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən ðə laɪt nu, səm ʌv wʌt ðə sintʃæn dɪd wɑz bɪɑn ɹɪpʌɡnənt, bʌt ðə wʊmən wɑz stɔlwɝɾ ən tʃɹu tə hɝ wɝd.

For a moment, Perrin could only stare. It was a strange world. He had gone to her thinking he was making a deal with the Dark One, and the Light knew, some of what the Seanchan did was beyond repugnant, but the woman was stalwart and true to her word.

"aɪm pɛɹɪn, taɪli," hi sɛd, klæspɪŋ əɹ hænd. ə vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ wɝld.

"I'm Perrin, Tylee," he said, clasping her hand. A very strange world.

stʃɹɪpɪŋ ɔf əɹ ʃɪft, ɡəlinə tɔst ɪt daʊn ətɑp ðə sɪlk ɹoʊb ən bɛn tə pɪk ʌp ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ʃi hæd pʊl fɹəm swɪfs sæɾəlbæɡz. ðə θɪŋ hæd bɪn soʊn fəɹ ə slaɪtli lɑɹdʒɝ wʊmən, bʌɾ ɪt wəd səfaɪs əntɪl ʃi kəd sɛl wʌn ə ðoʊz faɪɝdʒɹɑps.

Stripping off her shift, Galina tossed it down atop the silk robe and bent to pick up the riding dress she had pulled from Swift's saddlebags. The thing had been sewn for a slightly larger woman, but it would suffice until she could sell one of those firedrops.

"stæn əz jə ɑɹ, linə," keɪm θɛɝɑvəz vɔɪs, ən sʌɾənli ɡəlinə kəd nɑɾ əv stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪf ðə fɔɹəst ɝaʊn əɹ hæd bɪn ɑn faɪɝ. ʃi kəd skɹim, ðoʊ. "bi saɪlənt." ʃi tʃoʊkt əz əɹ θɹoʊt swɑloʊd ðə skɹim kənvʌlsɪvli. ʃi kəd stɪl wip, saɪlənli, ən tɪɹz bɪɡæn tə fɔl ɑn ðə mʌltʃ ə ðə fɔɹəs flɔɹ. ə hæn slæpt əɹ ɹudli. "sʌmhaʊ, juv ðə ɹɑd," θɛɝɑvə sɛd. "ju wəd nɑt bi aʊt hɪɹ, ɛls. ɡɪv ɪt tə mi, linə."

"Stand as you are, Lina," came Therava's voice, and suddenly Galina could not have straightened if the forest around her had been on fire. She could scream, though. "Be silent." She choked as her throat swallowed the scream convulsively. She could still weep, silently, and tears began to fall on the mulch of the forest floor. A hand slapped her rudely. "Somehow, you have the rod," Therava said. "You would not be out here, else. Give it to me, Lina."

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kwɛstʃən ivən ə ɹɪzɪstɪŋ. stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ, ɡəlinə dʌɡ ðə ɹɑɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ sæɾəlbæɡz ən hændəɾ ɪt tə ðə hɔk-aɪd wʊmən, tɪɹz slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃiks.

There was no question even of resisting. Straightening, Galina dug the rod out of her saddlebags and handed it to the hawk-eyed woman, tears sliding down her cheeks.

"stɑp snaɪvəlɪŋ, linə. ən pʊɾ ɑn jəɹ nɛkləs ən kɑlɝ. əl əv tə pʌnɪʃ jə fəɹ teɪkɪŋ əm ɔf."

"Stop sniveling, Lina. And put on your necklace and collar. I will have to punish you for taking them off."

ɡəlinə flɪntʃt. ivən θɛɝɑvəz kəmæn kəd nɑt ʃʌɾ ɔf əɹ tɪɹz, ən ʃi nu ʃi wəd bi pʌnɪʃt fəɹ ðæt, tu. ɡoʊldən nɛkləs ən kɑlɝ keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəlbæɡz ən wɛn ɑntu hɝ. ʃi stʊd ðəɹ wɛɹɪŋ oʊnli hɝ peɪl wʊlən stɑkɪŋz ən sɑf leɪst waɪt buts, ən ðə weɪɾ ə ðə faɪɝdʒɹɑp-stʌɾɪd kɑlɝ ən bɛl simd ɪnʌf tə bɛɹ əɹ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hɝ aɪz fæsən ðɛmsɛlvz tə ðə waɪt ɹɑɾ ɪn θɛɝɑvəz hænz.

Galina flinched. Even Therava's command could not shut off her tears, and she knew she would be punished for that, too. Golden necklace and collar came out of the saddlebags and went onto her. She stood there wearing only her pale woolen stockings and soft laced white boots, and the weight of the firedrop-studded collar and belt seemed enough to bear her to the ground. Her eyes fastened themselves to the white rod in Therava's hands.

"jɔɹ hɔɹs wɪl də fəɹ ə pæk ænəməl, linə. əz fəɹ ju, jə ɑɹ fɔɹbɪɾən tə ɹaɪɾ ɛvɝ əɡɛn."

"Your horse will do for a pack animal, Lina. As for you, you are forbidden to ride ever again."

ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm weɪ tə ɡɛt ðət ɹɑɾ əɡɛn. ðəɹ hæd tə bi! θɛɝɑvə tɝn ðə θɪŋ oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ ɪn əɹ hænz, tɔntɪŋ hɝ.

There had to be some way to get that rod again. There had to be! Therava turned the thing over and over in her hands, taunting her.

"stɑp pleɪɪŋ wɪð jəɹ pɛt, θɛɝɑvə. wʌɾ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?" bəlɪnd, ə slɛndɝ waɪz wʌn wɪð hɛɹ blitʃt ɔlmoʊst waɪt baɪ ðə sʌn, stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp tə ɡlɛɹ ət θɛɝɑvə wɪð peɪl blu aɪz. ʃi wɑz boʊni, wɪð ə feɪs wɛl suɾəd tə ɡlɛɹɪŋ.

"Stop playing with your pet, Therava. What are we going to do?" Belinde, a slender Wise One with hair bleached almost white by the sun, strode up to glare at Therava with pale blue eyes. She was bony, with a face well suited to glaring.

ðət wɑz ðə fɝst ɡəlinə ɹilaɪz ðət θɛɝɑvə wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd mɛn, wɪmən ən tʃɪlʒɹən stʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, səm ə ðə mɛn kæɹiɪŋ wɪmən slʌŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ʌv ɔl θɪŋz. ʃi kʌvɝd hɝsɛlf wɪð əɹ hænz, hɝ feɪs hiɾɪŋ. ðoʊz lɔŋ deɪz ʌv ɛnfɔɹs neɪkədnəs hæd nɑɾ ɪnjʊɹɾ əɹ tə biɪŋ ənkloʊðd ɪn fɹʌn ə mɛn. ðən ʃi noʊɾəst ənʌðɝ ɑɾəti. oʊnli ə hændfʊl wɝ ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ, wɪð baʊ keɪsəz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks ən kwɪvɝz ət ðɛɹ hɪps, bʌɾ ɛvɹi mæn ən ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪksɛp ðə waɪz wʌnz əmʌŋ əm wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ət list wʌn spɪɹ. ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ feɪsəz veɪld, tu, wɪð ə skɑɹf əɹ dʒʌst ə skɹæp ə klɔθ. wʌt kəɾ ɪt min?

That was the first Galina realized that Therava was not alone. Several hundred men, women and children stood among the trees behind them, some of the men carrying women slung over their shoulders of all things. She covered herself with her hands, her face heating. Those long days of enforced nakedness had not inured her to being unclothed in front of men. Then she noticed another oddity. Only a handful were algai'd'siswai, with bow cases on their backs and quivers at their hips, but every man and every woman except the Wise Ones among them was carrying at least one spear. They had their faces veiled, too, with a scarf or just a scrap of cloth. What could it mean?

"wi ɑɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd," θɛɝɑvə sɛd. "wi wɪl sɛn ɹʌnɝz tə faɪn ɛvɹi sɛp ðət kən bi faʊn ən tɛl əm tə əbændən ðɛɹ wɛtləndɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn, əbændən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ mʌst, ən meɪk ðɛɹ weɪ baɪ stɛlθ bæk tə ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd. wɪl ɹibɪld əɹ klæn. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɪl ɹaɪz fɹəm ðə dɪzæstɝ sɪvænə lɛɾ əs tə."

"We are returning to the Three-fold Land," Therava said. "We will send runners to find every sept that can be found and tell them to abandon their wetlander gai'shain, abandon everything they must, and make their way by stealth back to the Three-fold Land. We will rebuild our clan. The Shaido will rise from the disaster Sevanna led us to."

"ðæt wɪl teɪk dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz!" moʊdʒɹə pɹətɛstəd. slɪm ən kwaɪt pɹɪɾi, bʌɾ ivən tɔlɝ ðən θɛɝɑvə, əz tɔl əz moʊst ilmɛn, ʃi stʊɾ ʌp tə θɛɝɑvə ənflɪntʃɪŋli. ɡəlinə kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn haʊ ʃi dɪd ðæt. ðə wʊmən meɪɾ əɹ flɪntʃ wɪð ə ɡlæns.

"That will take generations!" Modarra protested. Slim and quite pretty, but even taller than Therava, as tall as most Aielmen, she stood up to Therava unflinchingly. Galina could not understand how she did that. The woman made her flinch with a glance.

"ðɛn wɪl teɪk dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz," θɛɝɑvə sɛd fɝmli. "wi wɪl teɪk wʌtɛvɝ taɪm ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi. ən wɪl nɛvɝ liv ðə θɹi-foʊld læn əɡɛn." hɝ ɡeɪz ʃɪftəd tə ɡəlinə. hu flɪntʃt. "ju wɪl nɛvɝ tʌtʃ ðɪs əɡɛn," ʃi sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ðə ɹɑd bɹifli. "æn jəl nɛvɝ tʃɹaɪ tə ɪskeɪp mi əɡɛn. ʃiz ə stʃɹɔŋ bæk. loʊd hɝ, ən lɛɾ əs bi ɑn əɹ weɪ. ðeɪ meɪ tʃɹaɪ tə pɝsu ʌs."

"Then we will take generations," Therava said firmly. "We will take whatever time is necessary. And we will never leave the Three-fold Land again." Her gaze shifted to Galina. Who flinched. "You will never touch this again," she said, raising the rod briefly. "And you will never try to escape me again. She has a strong back. Load her, and let us be on our way. They may try to pursue us."

bɝɾənd wɪð wɔɾɝskɪnz ən pɑts ən kɛɾəlz tɪl ʃi ɔlmoʊs fɛl disənli kʌvɝd, ɡəlinə stæɡɝd θɹu ðə fɔɹəst ət θɛɝɑvəz hilz. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ə ðə ɹɑd, əɹ ɪskeɪp. sʌmθɪŋ hæd bɹoʊkən ɪn hɝ. ʃi wɑz ɡəlinə kæsbən, haɪəst ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, hu sæɾ ɑn ðə səpɹim kaʊnsəl ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ən ʃi wɑz gɑnə bi θɛɝɑvəz pleɪθɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ laɪf. ʃi wɑz θɛɝɑvəz lɪɾəl linə. fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ laɪf. ʃi nu ðət tə hɝ boʊnz. tɪɹz ɹoʊl saɪlənli daʊn əɹ feɪs.

Burdened with waterskins and pots and kettles till she almost felt decently covered, Galina staggered through the forest at Therava's heels. She did not think of the rod, or escape. Something had broken in her. She was Galina Casban, Highest of the Red Ajah, who sat on the Supreme Council of the Black Ajah, and she was going to be Therava's plaything for the rest of her life. She was Therava's little Lina. For the rest of her life. She knew that to her bones. Tears rolled silently down her face.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾiwʌn

CHAPTER 31

ðə haʊs ɑn fʊl mun stʃɹit "ðeɪ mʌst steɪ təɡɛðɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd fɝmli. "ðə tu ʌv jə ʃʊdn bi aʊt baɪ jʊɹsɛlvz, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ɔlweɪz θɹi əɹ fɔɹ təɡɛðɝ ɛniwɛɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ðæts ði oʊnli weɪ tə bi seɪf." dʒʌs tu ʌv ðə mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps wɝ lɪt, sɪks fleɪmz fɪlɪŋ ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum wɪð ə dɪm laɪɾ ən ðə sɛn ə lɪliz - soʊ mʌtʃ ə ðə læmp ɔɪl hæd ɡɔn bæd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz pɝfjumd, naʊ - bʌɾ ə kɹæklɪŋ faɪɝ ɑn ðə hɑɹθ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə teɪk əweɪ səm ə ði ɝli aʊɝz kulnəs.

The House on Full Moon Street "They must stay together," Elayne said firmly. "The two of you shouldn't be out by yourselves, for that matter. Always three or four together anywhere in Caemlyn. That's the only way to be safe." Just two of the mirrored stand-lamps were lit, six flames filling the sitting room with a dim light and the scent of lilies - so much of the lamp oil had gone bad that it was always perfumed, now - but a crackling fire on the hearth was beginning to take away some of the early hour's coolness.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ taɪmz ə wʊmən wɑns ə lɪɾəl pɹaɪvəsi," sumeɪkoʊ ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli, əz ɪf jɛɾ ənʌðɝ kɪnswʊmən hæd nɑt dʒʌs daɪd fɹəm wɑntɪŋ pɹaɪvəsi. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kɑm, ət list, bʌt plʌmp hænz smuðd əɹ dɑɹk blu skɝts.

"There are times a woman wants a little privacy," Sumeko replied calmly, as if yet another Kinswoman had not just died from wanting privacy. Her voice was calm, at least, but plump hands smoothed her dark blue skirts.

"ɪf jə woʊn pʊt ðə fɪɹ ə ðə laɪɾ ɪndə ðɛm, sumeɪkoʊ, aɪ wɪl," æləz sɛd, hɝ juʒəwəli maɪl feɪs stɝn. ʃi lʊk ði ɛldɝ ə ðə tu, wɪð tʌtʃəz ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ kəmpɛɹd tə ðə ɡlɔsi blæk hɛɹ ðət fɛl bɪloʊ sumeɪkoʊz staʊt ʃoʊldɝz, jɛt ʃi wɑz ðə jʌŋɡɝ baɪ bɛɾɝ ðən tu hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. æləz hæd bɪn ɪntʃɹɛpəd wən ɛbu dɑɹ fɛl ən ðeɪ wɝ fɔɹs tə fli ðə sintʃæn, bʌɾ əɹ hænz muvd ɑn əɹ bɹaʊn skɝts, tu.

"If you won't put the fear of the Light into them, Sumeko, I will," Alise said, her usually mild face stern. She looked the elder of the two, with touches of gray in her hair compared to the glossy black hair that fell below Sumeko's stout shoulders, yet she was the younger by better than two hundred years. Alise had been intrepid when Ebou Dar fell and they were forced to flee the Seanchan, but her hands moved on her brown skirts, too.

ɪt wɑz lɔŋ pæs ðə bɛdtaɪm ðəɾ ɛsænz nis mɛlfən hæd dɪkɹid, bʌt taɪɝɾ əz ʃi wɑz ɔl ðə taɪm, wʌns ɪleɪn woʊk, ʃi kəd nɛvɝ ɡɛt bæk tə slip, ən wɔɹm ɡoʊts mɪlk dɪd nɑt hɛlp. wɔɹm ɡoʊts mɪlk teɪstəd wɝs ðən kul. ʃi wɑz gɑnə meɪk ɹænd blʌɾi ælθɹ dʒɹɪŋk wɔɹm blʌɾi ɡoʊts mɪlk tɪl ɪt keɪm aʊɾ ə hɪz ɪɹz! ɹaɪɾ æftɝ ʃi faʊn aʊt wʌt hæd hɝɾ ɪm bædli ɪnʌf ðət ʃi sɛnst ə smɔl dʒoʊlt ə peɪn waɪl ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ɪn ðət smɔl nɑɾ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd ðət wɑz ɪm ɹɪmeɪn əz veɪɡ əz ə stoʊn. ɪt hæd bɪn ɔl ə stoʊn əɡɛn ɛvɝ sɪns, soʊ hi wɑz ɔl ɹaɪt, jɛt sʌmθɪŋ hæd hɝɾ ɪm dipli fəɹ əɹ tə sɛns ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. ən waɪ wɑz i tʃɹævlɪŋ soʊ ɔfən? wʌn deɪ, hi wɑz fɑɹ tə ðə saʊθist, ðə nɛks tə ðə nɔɹθwɛst ən ivən mɔɹ dɪstənt, ðə deɪ æftɝ ðət sʌmwɛɹ ɛls. wɑz i ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm huɛvɝ hæd hɝt hɪm? bʌt ʃi hæɾ əɹ oʊn wɝiz ət ðə moʊmənt.

It was long past the bedtime that Essande's niece Melfane had decreed, but tired as she was all the time, once Elayne woke, she could never get back to sleep, and warm goat's milk did not help. Warm goat's milk tasted worse than cool. She was going to make Rand bloody al'Thor drink warm bloody goat's milk till it came out of his ears! Right after she found out what had hurt him badly enough that she sensed a small jolt of pain while everything else in that small knot in the back of her head that was him remained as vague as a stone. It had been all a stone again ever since, so he was all right, yet something had hurt him deeply for her to sense anything at all. And why was he Traveling so often? One day, he was far to the southeast, the next to the northwest and even more distant, the day after that somewhere else. Was he running from whoever had hurt him? But she had her own worries at the moment.

əneɪbəl tə slip ən ɹɛsləs, ʃi hæd dʒɹɛs hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə fɝs θɪŋ ðət keɪm tə hænd, ə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs, ən ɡɔn fəɹ ə wɔk tə ɛndʒɔɪ ðə stɪlnəs ə ðə pæləs ɪn ðə smɔl aʊɝz ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, wən ivən ðə sɝvəns wɝ əbɛɾ ən flɪkɝɪŋ stænd-læmps wɝ ði oʊnli θɪŋz ðət muvd ɪn ðə hɔlweɪz əsaɪd fɹəm hɝ. hɝ ən əɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹdz, bʌt ʃi wɑz lɝnɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns. ʃi dɪɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ðə sɑlətud, əntɪl ðə tu wɪmən ɪnkaʊntɝɾ əɹ ən dɪlɪvɝd ðə sæd nuz ðət wʊɾə əweɪɾəd sʌnɹaɪz ʌðɝwaɪz. ʃi hæd bɹɔɾ əm bæk tə hɝ smɔlɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum tə dɪskʌs ðə mæɾɝ bɪhaɪn ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛns lɪsənɝz.

Unable to sleep and restless, she had dressed herself in the first thing that came to hand, a dark gray riding dress, and gone for a walk to enjoy the stillness of the palace in the small hours of the morning, when even the servants were abed and flickering stand-lamps were the only things that moved in the hallways aside from her. Her and her bodyguards, but she was learning to ignore their presence. She did enjoy the solitude, until the two women encountered her and delivered the sad news that would have awaited sunrise otherwise. She had brought them back to her smaller sitting room to discuss the matter behind a ward against listeners.

sumeɪkoʊ ʃɪftəɾ əɹ bʌlk ɪn əɹ ɑɹmtʃɛɹ tə ɡlɛɹ əɾ æləz. "ɹin lɛt jə pɹɛs baʊndɝiz, bʌɾ əz ɛldəst, aɪ ɪkspɛkt - "

Sumeko shifted her bulk in her armchair to glare at Alise. "Reanne let you press boundaries, but as Eldest, I expect - "

"jɔɹ nɑɾ ɛldəst, sumeɪkoʊ," ðə smɔlɝ wʊmən sɛd kuli. "ju hæv ði əθɔɹəɾi hɪɹ, bʌt baɪ ðə ɹul, ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl kənsɪsts ə ðə θɝtin ɛldəst ʌv əs ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. wi ɑɹən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, soʊ ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl."

"You're not Eldest, Sumeko," the smaller woman said coolly. "You have the authority here, but by the Rule, the Knitting Circle consists of the thirteen eldest of us in Ebou Dar. We aren't in Ebou Dar any longer, so there is no Knitting Circle."

sumeɪkoʊz ɹaʊn feɪs ɡɹu hɑɹɾ əz ɡɹænət. "æt lis jə ədmɪɾ aɪ hæv ði əθɔɹəɾi."

Sumeko's round face grew hard as granite. "At least you admit I have the authority."

"æn aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə juz ɪt tə pɹɪvɛn ɛni mɔɹ ʌv əs biɪŋ mɝɾɝd. sədʒɛstɪŋ ɪzən ɪnʌf, sumeɪkoʊ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ stʃɹɔŋli jə seɪ jə sədʒɛst. ɪɾ ɪzən ɪnʌf."

"And I expect you to use it to prevent any more of us being murdered. Suggesting isn't enough, Sumeko, no matter how strongly you say you suggest. It isn't enough."

"ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪl ɡɛɾ əs noʊwɛɹ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "aɪ noʊ jəɹ ɑn ɛdʒ. aɪ æm, tu." laɪt, θɹi wɪmən mɝɾɝd wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪn ðə læs tɛn deɪz, ən vɛɹi laɪkli sɛvən mɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ðæt, wɝ ɪnʌf tə pʊɾ ən ænvəl ɑn ɛdʒ. "bʌt snæpɪŋ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ ɪz ðə wɝs θɪŋ wi kən du. sumeɪkoʊ, jə nid tə pʊt jəɹ fʊt daʊn. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ haʊ mʌtʃ ɛniwʌn wɑns pɹaɪvəsi, noʊ wʌn kən bi baɪ hɝsɛlf fəɹ ə mɪnət. æləz, juz jəɹ pɝsweɪʒən." pɝsweɪʒən wɑz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ðə wɝd. æləz dɪd nɑt pɝsweɪd. ʃi sɪmpli ɪkspɛktəd pipəl tə də əz ʃi sɛd, ən ðeɪ nɪɹli ɔlweɪz dɪd. "kənvɪns ði ʌðɝz ðət sumeɪkoʊ ɪz ɹaɪt. bɪtwin ðə tu ʌv ju, juv tə - "

"Arguing will get us nowhere," Elayne said. "I know you're on edge. I am, too." Light, three women murdered with the One Power in the last ten days, and very likely seven more before that, were enough to put an anvil on edge. "But snapping at each other is the worst thing we can do. Sumeko, you need to put your foot down. I don't care how much anyone wants privacy, no one can be by herself for a minute. Alise, use your persuasion." Persuasion was not exactly the word. Alise did not persuade. She simply expected people to do as she said, and they nearly always did. "Convince the others that Sumeko is right. Between the two of you, you have to - "

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən tə ədmɪt dɪni, hu kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn bɪhaɪn əɹ ən baʊd, wʌn hæn ɑn əɹ sɔɹd hɪlt, ði ʌðɝ ɑn əɹ lɔŋ kʌdʒəl. ðə ɹɛd-lækɝd bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts, tʃɹɪmd ɪn waɪt, hæd bɪn dɪlɪvɝɾ oʊnli jɛstɝdeɪ, ən ðə stɑki wʊmən hæd bɪn smaɪlɪŋ ɛvɝ sɪns ʃi dɑn hɝz, bʌt ʃi lʊk sɑləm bɪhaɪn ðə feɪs-bɑɹz naʊ. "pɑɹɾən fəɹ ɪntɝʌptɪŋ, maɪ leɪɾi, bʌt ðɛɹz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪɹ dɪmændɪŋ tə si ju. eɪ ɹɛd, baɪ hɝ ʃɔl. aɪ toʊld əɹ jə wɝ laɪkli slipɪŋ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə kʌm ɪn ən weɪk jə hɝsɛlf."

The door opened to admit Deni, who closed it again behind her and bowed, one hand on her sword hilt, the other on her long cudgel. The red-lacquered breastplates and helmets, trimmed in white, had been delivered only yesterday, and the stocky woman had been smiling ever since she donned hers, but she looked solemn behind the face-bars now. "Pardon for interrupting, my Lady, but there's an Aes Sedai here demanding to see you. A Red, by her shawl. I told her you were likely sleeping, but she was ready to come in and wake you herself."

eɪ ɹɛd. ðəɹ wɝ ɹɪpɔɹts ə ɹɛdz ɪn ðə sɪɾi fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm, ðoʊ nɑt soʊ ɔfən əz wʌns - moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə sɪɾi wɛnt wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ ʃɔlz, kənsilɪŋ ðɛɹ ədʒəz - jɛt wʌt wəɾ ə ɹɛd wɑnt wɪð hɝ? ʃʊɹli ðeɪ ɔl nu baɪ naʊ ðət ʃi stʊd wɪð ɛɡwin ən əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə. ənlɛs sʌmwʌn wɑz faɪnəli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɹɪŋ əɹ tə bʊk fəɹ ðə bɑɹɡən wɪð ðə si foʊk.

A Red. There were reports of Reds in the city from time to time, though not so often as once - most Aes Sedai in the city went without their shawls, concealing their Ajahs - yet what would a Red want with her? Surely they all knew by now that she stood with Egwene and against Elaida. Unless someone was finally trying to bring her to book for the bargain with the Sea Folk.

"tɛl əɹ ðəɾ aɪm - "

"Tell her that I'm - "

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən əɡɛn, bʌmpɪŋ dɪniz bæk, pʊʃɪŋ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. ðə wʊmən u ɛntɝd, vaɪn-woʊvən ʃɔl dʒɹeɪpt əlɔŋ əɹ ɑɹmz soʊ ðə lɔŋ ɹɛd fɹɪnʒ dɪspleɪɾ ɪtsɛlf tə ædvæntɪdʒ, wɑz tɔl ən slɪm ən kɑpɝ-skɪnd. ʃi wʊɾə bɪn pɹɪɾi, ɪksɛp ðəɾ əɹ maʊθ wɑz kəmpɹɛst əntɪl əɹ fʊl lɪps sim θɪn. hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs wɑz soʊ dɑɹk ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn blæk, bʌt ðə peɪl laɪɾ ə ðə stænd-mɪɹɝz pɪkt ʌp hɪns ə ɹɛd, ən ðə dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts wɝ slæʃt wɪð bɹaɪɾɝ ɹɛd. dʌɑɹə bəseɪhin nɛvɝ meɪɾ ɛni sikɹəɾ ə hɝ ədʒɑ. wʌns, sumeɪkoʊ ən æləz wʊɾə bɪn ɑn ðɛɹ fiɾ ən kɝtsiɪŋ fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ə flæʃ, bʌt naʊ ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn siɾəd, stʌɾiɪŋ hɝ. dɪni, nɔɹməli plæsəd, ɪn əpɪɹəns ət list, skaʊld ən fɪŋɡɝɾ əɹ kʌdʒəl.

The door opened again, bumping Deni's back, pushing her out of the way. The woman who entered, vine-woven shawl draped along her arms so the long red fringe displayed itself to advantage, was tall and slim and copper-skinned. She would have been pretty, except that her mouth was compressed until her full lips seemed thin. Her riding dress was so dark it might have been black, but the pale light of the stand-mirrors picked up hints of red, and the divided skirts were slashed with brighter red. Duhara Basaheen never made any secret of her Ajah. Once, Sumeko and Alise would have been on their feet and curtsying for an Aes Sedai in a flash, but now they remained seated, studying her. Deni, normally placid, in appearance at least, scowled and fingered her cudgel.

"aɪ si ðə teɪlz ə jə ɡæðɝɪŋ waɪldɝz ɑɹ tʃɹu," dʌɑɹə sɛd. "ə ɡɹeɪt pɪɾi, ðæt. ðə tu ʌv jə ɡɛɾ aʊt. aɪ wɪʃ tə spik wɪð ɪleɪn pɹaɪvətli. ɪf jəɹ waɪz, jəl liv tənaɪt, hɛɾɪŋ ɪn dɪfɹən dɝɛkʃənz, ən tɛl ɛni ʌðɝz laɪk jə tə də ðə seɪm. ðə waɪt taʊɝ lʊks əmɪs ɑn waɪldɝz ɡæðɝɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. wən ðə taʊɝ lʊks ɑn sʌmθɪŋ əmɪs, θɹoʊnz əv bɪn noʊn tə tʃɹɛmbəl." niðɝ sumeɪkoʊ nɔɹ æləz muvd. æləz æktʃəli  ɑɹtʃt ən aɪbɹaʊ.

"I see the tales of you gathering wilders are true," Duhara said. "A great pity, that. The two of you get out. I wish to speak with Elayne privately. If you're wise, you will leave tonight, heading in different directions, and tell any others like you to do the same. The White Tower looks amiss on wilders gathering together. When the Tower looks on something amiss, thrones have been known to tremble." Neither Sumeko nor Alise moved. Alise actually arched an eyebrow.

"ðeɪ kən steɪ," ɪleɪn sɛd koʊldli. wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn hɝ, hɝ ɪmoʊʃənz wɝ nɑt baʊnsɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ stɛɾi ɪn ən aɪsi æŋɡɝ. "ðeɪ ɑɹ wɛlkəm hɪɹ. ju, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd. . . . ɪleɪɾə tʃɹaɪd tə hæv mi kɪdnæpt, dʌɑɹə. kɪdnæpt! jə kən liv."

"They can stay," Elayne said coldly. With the Power in her, her emotions were not bouncing. They were steady in an icy anger. "They are welcome here. You, on the other hand. . . . Elaida tried to have me kidnapped, Duhara. Kidnapped! You can leave."

"ə pʊɹ wɛlkəm, ɪleɪn, wən aɪ keɪm tə ðə pæləs əz sun əz aɪ ɝaɪvd. ən æftɝ ə dʒɝni ðət wəd bi əz tɔɹtʃjəs tə dɪskɹaɪb əz ɪt wɑz tə ɛndʒjʊɹ. ændɝ əz ɔlweɪz hæd ɡʊd ɹileɪʃənz wɪð ðə taʊɝ. ðə taʊɝ ɪntɛnz tə si ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn ɡʊd. ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jə wɑn ðiz waɪldɝz tə hɪɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ hæv tə seɪ tə ju? vɛɹi wɛl. ɪf jə ɪnsɪst." ɡlaɪɾɪŋ tə wʌn ə ðə kɑɹv saɪdbɔɹdz, ʃi ɹɪŋkəld əɹ noʊz ət ðə sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ hoʊldɪŋ ɡoʊts mɪlk ən pɔɹd hɝsɛlf ə kʌp ə dɑɹk waɪn bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ə tʃɛɹ əkɹɔs fɹəm ɪleɪn. dɪni meɪɾ ə muv əz ɪf tə tʃɹaɪ dʒɹæɡɪŋ əɹ aʊt, bʌɾ ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ðə dəmɑni sɪstɝ ɪɡnɔɹd ðə kɪnswɪmən əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd sis tə ɪɡzɪst. "ðə wʊmən u dʒɹʌɡd jə hæz bɪn pʌnɪʃt, ɪleɪn. ʃi wɑz flɑɡd ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ oʊn ʃɑp wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn əɹ vɪlədʒ wɑtʃɪŋ." dʌɑɹə sɪpt əɹ waɪn, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪleɪn tə ɹɪspɑnd.

"A poor welcome, Elayne, when I came to the palace as soon as I arrived. And after a journey that would be as torturous to describe as it was to endure. Andor has always had good relations with the Tower. The Tower intends to see they remain good. Are you sure you want these wilders to hear everything I have to say to you? Very well. If you insist." Gliding to one of the carved sideboards, she wrinkled her nose at the silver pitcher holding goat's milk and poured herself a cup of dark wine before taking a chair across from Elayne. Deni made a move as if to try dragging her out, but Elayne shook her head. The Domani sister ignored the Kinswomen as if they had ceased to exist. "The woman who drugged you has been punished, Elayne. She was flogged in front of her own shop with everyone in her village watching." Duhara sipped her wine, waiting for Elayne to respond.

ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ʃi nu vɛɹi wɛl ðət ɹɑn məkʊə hæd bɪn flɑɡd fəɹ feɪljɝ ɹæðɝ ðən fəɹ fiɾɪŋ əɹ ðət vaɪl ti, bʌt seɪɪŋ soʊ wəd meɪk dʌɑɹə wʌndɝ haʊ ʃi nu, ən ðət maɪt lɛd tə θɪŋz ðət niɾəd tə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən.

She said nothing. She knew very well that Ronde Macura had been flogged for failure rather than for feeding her that vile tea, but saying so would make Duhara wonder how she knew, and that might lead to things that needed to remain hidden.

ðə saɪləns stʃɹɛtʃt, ən faɪnəli ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɛn ɑn. "ju mʌs noʊ ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑns vɛɹi mʌtʃ fəɹ jə tə maʊn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. tə ətʃiv ðəɾ ɛnd, ɪleɪɾə hæz sɛn mi tə bi jəɹ ædvaɪzɝ."

The silence stretched, and finally the other woman went on. "You must know that the White Tower wants very much for you to mount the Lion Throne. To achieve that end, Elaida has sent me to be your advisor."

ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn læft. ɪleɪɾə hæd sɛn əɹ ən ædvaɪzɝ? ɪt wɑz luɾəkɹəs! "aɪ hæv ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ædvaɪz mi wən aɪ niɾ ædvaɪs, dʌɑɹə. jə mʌs noʊ aɪ əpoʊz ɪleɪɾə. aɪ wʊdn æksɛpt ə pɛɹ ə stɑkɪŋz fɹəm ðət wʊmən."

In spite of herself, Elayne laughed. Elaida had sent her an advisor? It was ludicrous! "I have Aes Sedai to advise me when I need advice, Duhara. You must know I oppose Elaida. I wouldn't accept a pair of stockings from that woman."

"jɔɹ soʊ-kɔld ædvaɪzɝz ɑɹ ɹɛbəlz, tʃaɪld," dʌɑɹə sɛd tʃaɪɾɪŋli, wɪð ə hɛvi doʊs ə dɪsteɪst ɑn ðə wɝd "ɹɛbəlz." ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd wɪð ðə sɪlvɝ waɪnkʌp. "waɪ dʒju θɪŋk juv soʊ mɛni haʊsəz əpoʊzɪŋ ju, soʊ mɛni stændɪŋ əsaɪd? ðeɪ ʃʊɹli noʊ jə doʊn ɹɪli hæv ðə bækɪŋ ə ðə taʊɝ. wɪð mi əz jəɹ ædvaɪzɝ, ðət tʃeɪnʒəz. aɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə pʊt ðə kɹaʊn ɑn jəɹ hɛɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ə wik. ət moʊst, ɪt ʃəd teɪk noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə mʌnθ əɹ tu."

"Your so-called advisors are rebels, child," Duhara said chidingly, with a heavy dose of distaste on the word "rebels." She gestured with the silver winecup. "Why do you think you have so many Houses opposing you, so many standing aside? They surely know you don't really have the backing of the Tower. With me as your advisor, that changes. I might be able to put the crown on your head inside a week. At most, it should take no more than a month or two."

ɪleɪn mɛt ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz ɡeɪz wɪð ə lɛvəl ɡeɪz ə hɝ oʊn. hɝ hænz wɑntəd tə meɪk fɪsts, bʌt ʃi kɛpt əm stɪl ɪn əɹ læp. "ivən wɝ ðət soʊ, aɪd ɹɛfjus ju. aɪ ɪkspɛk tə hɪɹ ɛni deɪ ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə hæz bɪn dɪpoʊzd. ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɪl bi hoʊl əɡɛn, ən noʊ wʌn wɪl bi eɪbəl tə kleɪm aɪ læk ɪts bækɪŋ ðɛn."

Elayne met the other woman's gaze with a level gaze of her own. Her hands wanted to make fists, but she kept them still in her lap. "Even were that so, I'd refuse you. I expect to hear any day that Elaida has been deposed. The White Tower will be whole again, and no one will be able to claim I lack its backing then."

dʌɑɹə stʌɾid əɹ waɪn fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hɝ feɪs ə mæsk ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi. "ɪt woʊn bi ɪntaɪɝli smuð ɡoʊɪŋ fəɹ ju," ʃi sɛɾ əz ɪf ɪleɪn hæd nɑt spoʊkən. "ðɪs ɪz ðə pɑɹt wʌn θɔt jə wʊdnt wɑn ðə waɪldɝz tə hɪɹ. ən ðət ɡɑɹd. dʌz ʃi θɪŋk aɪm gɑnə ətæk ju? noʊ mæɾɝ. wʌns juv ðə kɹaʊn fɝmli ɑn jəɹ hɛd, jəl əv tə əpɔɪn ə ɹidʒənt, kəz jə mʌst ɹɪtɝn tə ðə taʊɝ ðɛn, tə kəmplit jəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ən ɪvɛntʃəwəli bi tɛstəd fəɹ ðə ʃɔl. jə niɾ əv noʊ fɪɹ ə biɪŋ bɝtʃt əz ə ɹʌnəweɪ. ɪleɪɾə æksɛps ðət sɪuən sɑntʃ ɔɹɾɝd jə tə liv ðə taʊɝ. jəɹ pɹitɛns ə biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. ðæt, jəl peɪ fəɹ wɪð tɪɹz." sumeɪkoʊ ən æləz stɝd, ən dʌɑɹə tʊk noʊɾəs ə ðɛm əɡɛn. "ɑ, jə dɪdnt noʊ ðəɾ ɪleɪn ɪz ɹɪli oʊnli wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd?"

Duhara studied her wine for a moment, her face a mask of Aes Sedai serenity. "It won't be entirely smooth going for you," she said as if Elayne had not spoken. "This is the part I thought you wouldn't want the wilders to hear. And that guard. Does she think I'm going to attack you? No matter. Once you have the crown firmly on your head, you will have to appoint a regent, because you must return to the Tower then, to complete your training and eventually be tested for the shawl. You need have no fear of being birched as a runaway. Elaida accepts that Siuan Sanche ordered you to leave the Tower. Your pretense of being Aes Sedai is another matter. That, you will pay for with tears." Sumeko and Alise stirred, and Duhara took notice of them again. "Ah, you didn't know that Elayne is really only one of the Accepted?"

ɪleɪn ɹoʊz ən stɛɹd daʊn ət dʌɑɹə. juʒəwəli, sʌmwʌn siɾəd hɛl ði ædvæntɪdʒ oʊvɝ sʌmwʌn stændɪŋ, bʌt ʃi meɪɾ əɹ stɛɹ hɑɹɾ ən əɹ vɔɪs hɑɹɾɝ. ʃi wɑntəd tə slæp ðə wʊmənz feɪs! "aɪ wɑz ɹeɪzd ɛɛs sədaɪ baɪ ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ ɑn ðə deɪ ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz ɹeɪzd æmɪɝlɪn. aɪ tʃoʊz ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ ən wɑz ədmɪɾəd. doʊn jə ɛvɝ seɪ aɪm nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, dʌɑɹə. bɝn mi ɪf əl stæn stɪl fəɹ ɪt!"

Elayne rose and stared down at Duhara. Usually, someone seated held the advantage over someone standing, but she made her stare hard and her voice harder. She wanted to slap the woman's face! "I was raised Aes Sedai by Egwene al'Vere on the day she herself was raised Amyrlin. I chose the Green Ajah and was admitted. Don't you ever say I'm not Aes Sedai, Duhara. Burn me if I'll stand still for it!"

dʌɑɹəz maʊθ pɪntʃt daʊn tɪl əɹ lɪps simd ə ɡæʃ. "θɪŋk, ən jəl si ðə ɹiæləɾi ʌv jəɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "θɪŋk hɑɹd, ɪleɪn. ə blaɪnd wʊmən kəd si haʊ mʌtʃ jə nid mi, ən ðə waɪt taʊɝz blɛsɪŋ. wɪl tɔk əɡɛn leɪɾɝ. hæv sʌmwʌn ʃoʊ mi tə maɪ ɹumz. aɪm mɔɹ ðən ɹɛɾi fəɹ maɪ bɛd."

Duhara's mouth pinched down till her lips seemed a gash. "Think, and you will see the reality of your situation," she said finally. "Think hard, Elayne. A blind woman could see how much you need me, and the White Tower's blessing. We will talk again later. Have someone show me to my rooms. I am more than ready for my bed."

"jul əv tə faɪn ə ɹum əɾ ən ɪn, dʌɑɹə. ɛvɹi bɛɾ ɪn ðə pæləs ɔlɹɛɾi hæz θɹi əɹ fɔɹ pipəl slipɪŋ ɪn ɪt." ɪf dʌzənz ə bɛdz hæd bɪn fɹi, ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ɔfɝd dʌɑɹə wʌn. tɝnɪŋ əɹ bæk, ʃi wɔk tə ðə faɪɝpleɪs ən stʊd wɔɹmɪŋ əɹ hænz. ðə ɡɪldɪd pɛnʒələm klɑk ɑn ðə skɹoʊl-kɑɹv mɑɹbəl mæntəl tʃaɪm θɹi taɪmz. pɝhæps əz mɛni aʊɝz ɹɪmeɪn tɪl sʌnɹaɪz. "dɪni, hæv sʌmwʌn ɛskɔɹt dʌɑɹə tə ðə ɡeɪts."

"You'll have to find a room at an inn, Duhara. Every bed in the palace already has three or four people sleeping in it." If dozens of beds had been free, she would not have offered Duhara one. Turning her back, she walked to the fireplace and stood warming her hands. The gilded pendulum clock on the scroll-carved marble mantel chimed three times. Perhaps as many hours remained till sunrise. "Deni, have someone escort Duhara to the gates."

"ju woʊn fɛn mi ɔf soʊ izəli, tʃaɪld. noʊ wʌn fɛnz ɔf ðə waɪt taʊɝ izəli. θɪŋk, ən jəl si aɪm jəɹ oʊnli hoʊp." sɪlk wɪskt əɡɛnst sɪlk əz ʃi lɛf ðə ɹum, ən ðə dɔɹ klɪkt ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɝ. ɪt sim vɛɹi pɑsəbəl dʌɑɹə wəd kɑz tʃɹʌbəl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk hɝsɛlf niɾəd, bʌt wʌn pɹɑbləm əɾ ə taɪm.

"You won't fend me off so easily, child. No one fends off the White Tower easily. Think, and you'll see I'm your only hope." Silk whisked against silk as she left the room, and the door clicked shut behind her. It seemed very possible Duhara would cause trouble trying to make herself needed, but one problem at a time.

"dɪd ʃi pʊt daʊts ɪn jəɹ maɪnz?" ɪleɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ fɹəm ðə faɪɝ.

"Did she put doubts in your minds?" Elayne said, turning from the fire.
