"nʌn," sumeɪkoʊ ɹɪplaɪd. "vændin ən ði ʌðɝ tu æksɛp jə əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, soʊ jə mʌs bi." kənvɪkʃən wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs, bʌt ðɛn, ʃi hæd ɹizən tə wɑnə bɪliv. ɪf ɪleɪn wɝ ə laɪɝ, hɝ dʒɹimz ə ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə taʊɝ, ʌv dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ, daɪd.

"None," Sumeko replied. "Vandene and the other two accept you as Aes Sedai, so you must be." Conviction was strong in her voice, but then, she had reason to want to believe. If Elayne were a liar, her dreams of returning to the Tower, of joining the Yellow Ajah, died.

"bʌt ðɪs dʌɑɹə bɪlivz ʃi wɑz spikɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ." æləz spɹɛɾ əɹ hænz. "aɪm nɑt seɪɪŋ aɪ daʊt ju. aɪ doʊnt. bʌt ðə wʊmən bɪlivz."

"But this Duhara believes she was speaking the truth." Alise spread her hands. "I'm not saying I doubt you. I don't. But the woman believes."

ɪleɪn saɪd. "ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən ɪz . . . kɑmpləkeɪɾəd." ðət wɑz laɪk seɪɪŋ wɔɾɝ wɑz mɔɪst. "aɪ æm ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt dʌɑɹə dʌzn bɪliv. ʃi kænt, kəz ðət wəd bi ædmɪɾɪŋ ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ tʃɹuli ɪz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən dʌɑɹə woʊn də ðəɾ əntɪl ɪleɪɾə hæz bɪn bɹɔt daʊn." ʃi hoʊp dʌɑɹə wəd bɪliv ðɛn. æksɛpt, ət list. ðə taʊɝ hæd tə bi meɪd hoʊl. "sumeɪkoʊ, jəl ɔɹɾɝ ðə kɪnswɪmən tə steɪ ɪn ɡɹups? ɔlweɪz?" ðə staʊt wʊmən mʌɾɝd ðət ʃi wʊd. ənlaɪk ɹin, sumeɪkoʊ hæd noʊ flɛɹ fəɹ liɾɝʃɪp, əɹ laɪkɪŋ fəɹ ɪt, iðɝ. ə pɪɾi noʊ oʊldɝ kɪnswʊmən hæɾ əpɪɹd tə teɪk ðə bɝɾən fɹəm hɝ. "æləz, jəl meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ oʊbeɪ?" æləzəz əɡɹimənt wɑz fɝm ən kwɪk. ʃi wʊɾə bɪn ðə pɝfəkt kændəɾeɪt ɪf ðə kɪn dɪd nɑt dətɝmən ðɛɹ ɹæŋkɪŋz baɪ eɪdʒ. "ðɛn wiv dʌn wʌt wi kæn. ɪts lɔŋ pæs taɪm jə wɝ ɪn jəɹ bɛdz."

Elayne sighed. "The situation is . . . complicated." That was like saying water was moist. "I am Aes Sedai, but Duhara doesn't believe. She can't, because that would be admitting Egwene al'Vere truly is the Amyrlin Seat, and Duhara won't do that until Elaida has been brought down." She hoped Duhara would believe then. Accept, at least. The Tower had to be made whole. "Sumeko, you will order the Kinswomen to stay in groups? Always?" The stout woman muttered that she would. Unlike Reanne, Sumeko had no flair for leadership, or liking for it, either. A pity no older Kinswoman had appeared to take the burden from her. "Alise, you'll make sure they obey?" Alise's agreement was firm and quick. She would have been the perfect candidate if the Kin did not determine their rankings by age. "Then we've done what we can. It's long past time you were in your beds."

"lɔŋ pæs taɪm fəɹ ju, tu," æləz sɛɾ əz ʃi stʊd. "aɪ kəd sɛn fəɹ mɛlfən."

"Long past time for you, too," Alise said as she stood. "I could send for Melfane."

"noʊ nid tə ɹɑb əɹ ə slip, tu," ɪleɪn sɛd heɪstəli. ən fɝmli. mɛlfən wɑz ʃɔɹɾ ən staʊt, ə mɛɹi wʊmən wɪð ə ɹɛɾi læf, ən ənlaɪk əɹ æn ɪn ʌðɝ weɪz, əz wɛl. mɛɹi əɹ nɑt, ðə mɪdwaɪf wɑz ə taɪɹən u wəd nɑt bi pliz tə lɝn ðət ʃi wɑz əweɪk. "aɪl slip wən aɪ kæn."

"No need to rob her of sleep, too," Elayne said hastily. And firmly. Melfane was short and stout, a merry woman with a ready laugh, and unlike her aunt in other ways, as well. Merry or not, the midwife was a tyrant who would not be pleased to learn that she was awake. "I'll sleep when I can."

wʌns ðeɪ lɛft, ʃi ɹilist seɪaɪdɑɹ ən tʊk ʌp ə bʊk fɹəm sɛvɹəl ɑn ðə sɛkən saɪdbɔɹd, jɛɾ ənʌðɝ hɪstɝi ʌv ændɝ, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt kɑnsəntʃɹeɪt. bɝɛft ə ðə paʊɝ, ʃi fɛlt ɡɹʌmpi. bɝn hɝ, ʃi wɑz soʊ wɪɹi ðəɾ əɹ aɪz fɛlt ɡɹeɪni. ʃi nu ðəɾ ɪf ʃi leɪ daʊn, ðoʊ, ʃi wəd stɛɹ ət ðə silɪŋ tɪl ðə sʌn ɹoʊz. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi hæd stɛɹɾ ət ðə peɪdʒ fəɹ oʊnli mɪnəts wən dɪni əpɪɹɾ əɡɛn.

Once they left, she released saidar and took up a book from several on the second sideboard, yet another history of Andor, but she could not concentrate. Bereft of the Power, she felt grumpy. Burn her, she was so weary that her eyes felt grainy. She knew that if she lay down, though, she would stare at the ceiling till the sun rose. In any case, she had stared at the page for only minutes when Deni appeared again.

"mæstɝ nɔɹi ɪz hɪɹ, maɪ leɪɾi, wɪð ðət hɑɹk fɛloʊ. sɛd hid hɝd jə wɝ ʌp ən wʌndɝɾ ɪf jə kəd spɛɹ ɪm ə fju mɪnəts."

"Master Norry is here, my Lady, with that Hark fellow. Said he'd heard you were up and wondered if you could spare him a few minutes."

hi hæd hɝd ʃi wɑz ʌp? ɪf i wɑz hævɪŋ əɹ wɑtʃt . . . ! ði ɪmpɔɹt bɹoʊk θɹu hɝ ɡɹʌmpinəs. hɑɹk. hi hæd nɑt bɹɔt hɑɹk sɪns ðət fɝs vɪzət, tɛn deɪz əɡoʊ. noʊ, ɪlɛvən deɪz, naʊ. ɪbʊljəns ɹipleɪs pivɪʃnəs. tɛlɪŋ dɪni tə sɛn əm ɪn, ʃi fɑloʊd ðə wʊmən əz fɑɹ əz ði æntəɹum, wɛɹ ə pæɾɝnd kɑɹpət kʌvɝd moʊst ə ðə ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt flɔɹ taɪlz. hɪɹ, tu, oʊnli ə pɛɹ ə stænd-læmps wɝ lɪt, ɡɪvɪŋ ɔf ə dɪm, weɪvɝɪŋ laɪɾ ən ə sɛn ə ɹoʊzɪz.

He had heard she was up? If he was having her watched . . . ! The import broke through her grumpiness. Hark. He had not brought Hark since that first visit, ten days ago. No, eleven days, now. Ebullience replaced peevishness. Telling Deni to send them in, she followed the woman as far as the anteroom, where a patterned carpet covered most of the red-and-white floor tiles. Here, too, only a pair of stand-lamps were lit, giving off a dim, wavering light and a scent of roses.

mæstɝ nɔɹi lʊk mɔɹ ðən ɛvɝ ə waɪt-kɹɛstəd weɪɾɪŋ bɝd wɪð ɪz lɔŋ, spɪnli ʃæŋks, ən tʌfs ə hɛɹ stɪkɪŋ ʌp bɪhaɪn ɪz ɪɹz, bʌt fəɹ wʌns, hi ɔlmoʊst simd ɪksaɪɾəd. hi wɑz æktʃəli  ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ. hi wɑz nɑt kæɹiɪŋ ɪz lɛðɝ foʊldɝ tənaɪt; ivən ɪn ðə dɪm laɪt, ði ɪŋk steɪnz ɑn ɪz kɹɪmzən tɑbɝd ʃoʊd. wʌn hæd tɝn ðə tʌft ə ðə waɪt laɪənz teɪl blæk. hi ɔfɝɾ ə stɪf baʊ, ən ðə nɑndɪskɹɪp hɑɹk ɪməteɪɾɪd ɪm ɔkwɝdli, ðən nʌkəld ɪz fɔɹhɛd fəɹ ɡʊd mɛʒɝ. hi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə dɑɹkɝ bɹaʊn ðən i hæd pɹiviəsli, bʌt ðə seɪm bɛlt ən bʌkəl. "fɝɡɪv ði aʊɝ, maɪ leɪɾi," nɔɹi bɪɡæn ɪn ðət dʒɹaɪ vɔɪs.

Master Norry looked more than ever a white-crested wading bird with his long, spindly shanks, and tufts of hair sticking up behind his ears, but for once, he almost seemed excited. He was actually rubbing his hands together. He was not carrying his leather folder tonight; even in the dim light, the ink stains on his crimson tabard showed. One had turned the tuft of the White Lion's tail black. He offered a stiff bow, and the nondescript Hark imitated him awkwardly, then knuckled his forehead for good measure. He was wearing a darker brown than he had previously, but the same belt and buckle. "Forgive the hour, my Lady," Norry began in that dry voice.

"haʊ dɪd jə noʊ aɪ wɑz əweɪk?" ʃi dɪmændəd, ɪmoʊʃənz baʊnsɪŋ əɡɛn.

"How did you know I was awake?" she demanded, emotions bouncing again.

nɔɹi blɪŋkt, stɑɹɾəld baɪ ðə kwɛstʃən. "wʌn ə ðə kʊks mɛnʃən sɛndɪŋ ʌp wɔɹm ɡoʊts mɪlk fəɹ jə wən aɪ wɛn tə ɡɛt səm fəɹ maɪsɛlf, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪ faɪnd wɔɹm ɡoʊts mɪlk vɛɹi suðɪŋ wən aɪ kæn slip. bʌt ʃi mɛnʃənd waɪn, tu, soʊ aɪ əsum jə hæd vɪzəɾɝz ən maɪt stɪl bi əweɪk."

Norry blinked, startled by the question. "One of the cooks mentioned sending up warm goat's milk for you when I went to get some for myself, my Lady. I find warm goat's milk very soothing when I can't sleep. But she mentioned wine, too, so I assumed you had visitors and might still be awake."

ɪleɪn snɪft. ʃi stɪl wɑntəd tə snæp ət sʌmwʌn. kipɪŋ ðəɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ vɔɪs ɹikwaɪɝɾ ən ɛfɝt. "aɪ səpoʊz juv səksɛs tə ɹipɔɹt, mæstɝ hɑɹk?"

Elayne sniffed. She still wanted to snap at someone. Keeping that out of her voice required an effort. "I suppose you've success to report, Master Hark?"

"aɪ fɑloʊɾ ɪm laɪk jə sɛd, maɪ leɪɾi, ən hiz bɪn tə ðə seɪm haʊs θɹi naɪts, kaʊntɪŋ ðɪs wʌn. ɪts ɑn fʊl mun stʃɹiɾ ɪn ðə nu sɪɾi, ɪɾ ɪz. oʊnli pleɪs i ɛvɝ ɡoʊz ɪksɛp tævɝnz ən kɑmən ɹumz. hi dʒɹɪŋks sʌm, hi dʌz. daɪsɪz ə lɑt, tu." ðə mæn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, dʒɹaɪ-wɑʃɪŋ ɪz hænz nɝvəsli. "aɪ kən ɡoʊ naʊ, ɹaɪt, maɪ leɪɾi? jəl teɪk ɔf wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz jə pʊɾ ɑn mi?"

"I followed him like you said, my Lady, and he's been to the same house three nights, counting this one. It's on Full Moon Street in the New City, it is. Only place he ever goes except taverns and common rooms. He drinks some, he does. Dices a lot, too." The man hesitated, dry-washing his hands nervously. "I can go now, right, my Lady? You'll take off whatever it was you put on me?"

"əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə tæks ɹoʊlz," nɔɹi sɛd, "ðə haʊs ɪz oʊn baɪ ðə leɪɾi ʃieɪn əvɑɹhən, maɪ leɪɾi. ʃi simz tə bi ðə læst ə ðə haʊs."

"According to the tax rolls," Norry said, "the house is owned by the Lady Shiaine Avarhin, my Lady. She seems to be the last of the House."

"wʌɾ ɛls kən jə tɛl mi əbaʊt ðə pleɪs, mæstɝ hɑɹk? hu ɛls lɪvz ðəɹ bɪsaɪdz ðɪs leɪɾi ʃieɪn?"

"What else can you tell me about the place, Master Hark? Who else lives there besides this Lady Shiaine?"

hɑɹk ɹʌbd ɪz noʊz ənizəli. "wɛl, aɪ doʊnt noʊ əz ðeɪ laɪvz ðɛɹ, maɪ leɪɾi, bʌt ðɛɹz tu ɛɛs sədaɪ ðəɹ tənaɪt. aɪ sɔ wʌn ə ðɛm lɛɾɪŋ mɛlɝ aʊt waɪl ði ʌðɝ wɑz kʌmɪŋ ɪn, ən ðə wʌn u wɑz kʌmɪŋ ɪn sɛd, 'ə pɪɾi ðəɹ ɑɹ oʊnli tu ʌv ʌs, fæljən, ðə weɪ leɪɾi ʃieɪn wɝks ʌs.' oʊnli, ʃi sɛd leɪɾi laɪk ʃi dɪdn min ɪt, ʃi dɪd. fʌni. ʃi wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪ kæt, ə θɪŋ skɹɔni əz ʃi wɑz." hi bɑbd ə sʌɾən, nɝvəs baʊ. "bɛɡɪŋ jəɹ pɑɹɾən, maɪ leɪɾi. dɪdn min noʊ əfəns, spikɪŋ ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ðət weɪ, bʌɾ ɪt tʊk mi ə mɪnət tə ɹilaɪz ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪt dɪd. ðəɹ wɑz ɡʊd laɪt fɹəm ði ɛntʃɹi hɔl, ðəɹ wɑz, bʌt ʃi wɑz soʊ θɪn ən pleɪn, wɪð ə waɪd noʊz, ðət noʊbɑdi wəd teɪk əɹ fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪθaʊt səm stʌɾi."

Hark rubbed his nose uneasily. "Well, I don't know as they lives there, my Lady, but there's two Aes Sedai there tonight. I saw one of them letting Mellar out while the other was coming in, and the one who was coming in said, 'A pity there are only two of us, Falion, the way Lady Shiaine works us.' Only, she said Lady like she didn't mean it, she did. Funny. She was carrying a stray cat, a thing scrawny as she was." He bobbed a sudden, nervous bow. "Begging your pardon, my Lady. Didn't mean no offence, speaking of an Aes Sedai that way, but it took me a minute to realize she was Aes Sedai, it did. There was good light from the entry hall, there was, but she was so thin and plain, with a wide nose, that nobody would take her for Aes Sedai without some study."

ɪleɪn leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. ɪksaɪtmən bʌbəld ɪn əɹ vɔɪs, ən ʃi lɛɾ ɪt. "wʌt wɝ ðɛɹ æksɛns?"

Elayne laid a hand on his arm. Excitement bubbled in her voice, and she let it. "What were their accents?"

"ðɛɹ æksɛns, maɪ leɪɾi? wɛl, ðə wʌn wɪð ðə kæt, ʃiz fɹəm ɹaɪt hɪɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn aɪd seɪ. ði ʌðɝ. . . . wɛl, ʃi dɪdn seɪ əbʌv tu sɛntənsəz, bʌɾ aɪd seɪ ʃi wɑz kændɔɹi. kɔl ði ʌðɝ mɑɹilɪn, ɪf ðət hɛlps, maɪ leɪɾi."

"Their accents, my Lady? Well, the one with the cat, she's from right here in Caemlyn I'd say. The other. . . . Well, she didn't say above two sentences, but I'd say she was Kandori. Called the other Marillin, if that helps, my Lady."

læfɪŋ, ɪleɪn keɪpɝɾ ə fju stɛps. ʃi nu hu hæd sɛt mɛlɝ ɑn əɹ naʊ, ən ɪt wɑz wɝs ðən ʃi hæd fɪɹd. mɑɹilɪn ɡəmɑlfɪn ən fæljən boʊɾə, tu blæk sɪstɝz u hæd flɛd ðə taʊɝ æftɝ duɪŋ mɝɾɝ. ðət hæd bɪn tə fəsɪləteɪt θɛft, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə mɝɾɝz ðət wəd si ðɛm stɪld ən bɪhɛɾɪd. ɪt hæd bɪn tə faɪn ðɛm, ən ði ʌðɝz wɪð ðɛm, ðət ʃi, ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv hæd bɪn sɛn aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ. ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæd plæntəd mɛlɝ nɛks tə hɝ, tə spaɪ moʊs laɪkli, bʌt stɪl ə tʃɪlɪŋ θɔt. wɝs ðən ʃi hæd fɪɹd, ən jɛt, faɪndɪŋ ðə tu naʊ wɑz laɪk kəmpliɾɪŋ ðə sɝkəl.

Laughing, Elayne capered a few steps. She knew who had set Mellar on her now, and it was worse than she had feared. Marillin Gemalphin and Falion Bhoda, two Black sisters who had fled the Tower after doing murder. That had been to facilitate theft, but it was the murders that would see them stilled and beheaded. It had been to find them, and the others with them, that she, Egwene and Nynaeve had been sent out of the Tower. The Black Ajah had planted Mellar next to her, to spy most likely, but still a chilling thought. Worse than she had feared, and yet, finding the two now was like completing the circle.

hɑɹk wɑz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ wɪð ɪz maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən, ʃi ɹilaɪzd. mæstɝ nɔɹi wɑz stuɾiəsli ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə laɪənz steɪn teɪl. ʃi stɑp dænsɪŋ ən foʊldəɾ əɹ hænz. ful mɛn! "wɛɹ ɪz mɛlɝ naʊ?"

Hark was staring at her with his mouth hanging open, she realized. Master Norry was studiously examining the lion's stained tail. She stopped dancing and folded her hands. Fool men! "Where is Mellar now?"

"ɪn ɪz ɹumz, aɪ bɪliv," nɔɹi sɛd.

"In his rooms, I believe," Norry said.

"maɪ leɪɾi, jəl teɪk ɪɾ ɔf naʊ?" hɑɹk sɛd. "æn aɪ kən ɡoʊ? aɪ dɪd wʌt jə æskt."

"My Lady, you'll take it off now?" Hark said. "And I can go? I did what you asked."

"fɝs juv tə liɾ əs tə ðɪs haʊs," ʃi sɛd, dɑɹɾɪŋ pæst ɪm tə ðə twɪn dɔɹz. "ðɛn wɪl tɔk." pʊɾɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, ʃi faʊn dɪni ən sɛvən mɔɹ ɡɑɹdzwɪmən laɪn ʌp ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹz. "dɪni, sɛn sʌmwʌn tə fɛtʃ ðə leɪɾi bɝdʒɪɾ əz fæst əz pɑsəbəl, ən sʌmwʌn ɛls tə weɪk ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən æsk əm tə kʌm, tu, wɪð ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz ən pɹipɛɹd tə teɪk ə ɹaɪd. ðən jə ɡoʊ ən weɪk haʊɛvɝ mɛni ɡɑɹdzwɪmən jə θɪŋk jə nid tə ɝɛs mɛlɝ. jə nidn bi tu dʒɛntəl əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðə tʃɑɹdʒəz ɑɹ mɝɾɝ ən biɪŋ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. lɑk ɪm ɪn wʌn ə ðə beɪsmən stɔɹɹumz wɪð ə stʃɹɔŋ ɡɑɹd." ðə stɑki wʊmən smaɪl bɹɔdli ən bɪɡæn ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz əz ɪleɪn wɛn bæk ɪnsaɪd.

"First you have to lead us to this house," she said, darting past him to the twinned doors. "Then we'll talk." Putting her head out into the corridor, she found Deni and seven more Guardswomen lined up on either side of the doors. "Deni, send someone to fetch the Lady Birgitte as fast as possible, and someone else to wake the Aes Sedai and ask them to come, too, with their Warders and prepared to take a ride. Then you go and wake however many Guardswomen you think you need to arrest Mellar. You needn't be too gentle about it. The charges are murder and being a Darkfriend. Lock him in one of the basement storerooms with a strong guard." The stocky woman smiled broadly and began giving orders as Elayne went back inside.

hɑɹk wɑz ɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz hænz ən ʃɪftɪŋ fɹəm wʌn fʊt tə ði ʌðɝ æŋkʃəsli. "maɪ leɪɾi, wʌt dʒju min wɪl tɔk? jə pɹɑməs tə teɪk ðɪs θɪŋ ɔf mi ɪf aɪ fɑloʊd ðə mæn, jə dɪd. ən aɪ dɪd, soʊ juv tə kip jəɹ wɝd."

Hark was wringing his hands and shifting from one foot to the other anxiously. "My Lady, what do you mean we'll talk? You promised to take this thing off me if I followed the man, you did. And I did, so you have to keep your word."

"aɪ nɛvɝ sɛɾ aɪd ɹimuv ðə faɪndɝ, mæstɝ hɑɹk. aɪ sɛd jud bi ɛɡzaɪl tə bɛɹlən ɪnstɛɾ ə hæŋɪŋ, bʌt wʊdn jə ɹæðɝ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn?"

"I never said I'd remove the Finder, Master Hark. I said you'd be exiled to Baerlon instead of hanging, but wouldn't you rather remain in Caemlyn?"

ðə mæn waɪɾənd ɪz aɪz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk sənsɪɹ. ən feɪlɪŋ. hi ivən smaɪld. "oʊ, noʊ, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪv bɪn dʒɹimɪŋ əbaʊt ðə fɹɛʃ kʌntʃɹi ɛɹ ɪn bɛɹlən, aɪ hæz. əl weɪdʒɝ ðɛɹz nɛvɝ ə wɝi əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɑɾən miɾ ɪn jəɹ stu ðɛɹ. hɪɹ, jə ɡɑt tə snɪf kɛɹfəl bɪfɔɹ jə iɾ ɛniθɪŋ. aɪm lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə ɪt, aɪ æm."

The man widened his eyes, trying to look sincere. And failing. He even smiled. "Oh, no, my Lady. I've been dreaming about the fresh country air in Baerlon, I has. I'll wager there's never a worry about getting rotten meat in your stew there. Here, you got to sniff careful before you eat anything. I'm looking forward to it, I am."

ɪleɪn pʊɾ ɑn ðə stɝn feɪs əɹ mʌðɝ hæɾ ɔlweɪz wɔɹn pæsɪŋ dʒʌdʒmənt. "jud bi aʊɾ ə bɛɹlən tu mɪnəts bɪhaɪn ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn u ɛskɔɹɾɪd jə ðɛɹ. ən ðən jud hæŋ fəɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ jəɹ ɛɡzaɪl. mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ fəɹ jə tə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ən teɪk ɑn ə nu laɪn ʌv wɝk. mæstɝ nɔɹi, kəd jə juz ə mæn wɪð hɑɹks tæləns?"

Elayne put on the stern face her mother had always worn passing judgment. "You'd be out of Baerlon two minutes behind the Guardsmen who escorted you there. And then you'd hang for breaking your exile. Much better for you to remain in Caemlyn and take on a new line of work. Master Norry, could you use a man with Hark's talents?"

"aɪ kʊd, maɪ leɪɾi," nɔɹi ɹɪplaɪd wɪθaʊɾ ivən ə pɔz fəɹ θɔt. ə sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl tʌtʃt ɪz θɪn lɪps, ən ɪleɪn ɹilaɪzd wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn. ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ə tul tə ɪnkɹoʊtʃ ɑn mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝz ɡɹaʊnd. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ənduɪŋ ɪt, naʊ.

"I could, my Lady," Norry replied without even a pause for thought. A satisfied smile touched his thin lips, and Elayne realized what she had done. She had given him a tool to encroach on Mistress Harfor's ground. But there was no undoing it, now.

"ðə wɝk woʊn bi soʊ ɹimjunɝəɾɪv əz jəɹ fɔɹmɝ 'tʃɹeɪd,' mæstɝ hɑɹk, bʌt jə woʊn hæŋ fəɹ ɪt."

"The work won't be so remunerative as your former 'trade,' Master Hark, but you won't hang for it."

"nɑt soʊ wʌt, maɪ leɪɾi?" hɑɹk sɛd, skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz hɛd.

"Not so what, my Lady?" Hark said, scratching his head.

"ɪt woʊn peɪ soʊ wɛl. wʌt dʒju seɪ? bɛɹlən, wɛɹ jəl ʃʊɹli kʌɾ ə pɝs əɹ boʊlt, ən hæŋ fəɹ iðɝ wʌn, əɹ keɪɛmlɪn, wɛɹ jəl əv stɛɾi wɝk ən noʊ fɪɹ ə ðə hæŋmən. ənlɛs jə teɪk ʌp kʌɾɪŋ pɝsɪz əɡɛn."

"It won't pay so well. What do you say? Baerlon, where you'll surely cut a purse or bolt, and hang for either one, or Caemlyn, where you'll have steady work and no fear of the hangman. Unless you take up cutting purses again."

hɑɹk sweɪɾ ɑn ɪz fit, skɹʌbɪŋ ðə bæk ə hɪz hæn əkɹɔs ɪz maʊθ. "aɪ nidz ə dʒɹɪŋk, aɪ dʌz," hi mʌɾɝd hɔɹsli. vɛɹi laɪkli hi bɪliv ðə faɪndɝ wəɾ əlaʊ hɝ tə noʊ ɪf i kʌɾ ə pɝs. ɪf soʊ, ʃi hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə dɪsɑbɪzɪŋ hɪm.

Hark swayed on his feet, scrubbing the back of his hand across his mouth. "I needs a drink, I does," he muttered hoarsely. Very likely he believed the Finder would allow her to know if he cut a purse. If so, she had no intention of disabusing him.

mæstɝ nɔɹi skaʊld ət ðə mæn, bʌt wən i oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ʃi sɛd, "ðɛɹz waɪn ɪn ðə smɔl sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. lɛɾ ɪm əv wʌn kʌp, ðən dʒɔɪn mi ɪn ðə lɑɹdʒ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum."

Master Norry scowled at the man, but when he opened his mouth, she said, "There's wine in the small sitting room. Let him have one cup, then join me in the large sitting room."

ðə lɑɹdʒ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum wɑz dɑɹk wən ʃi wɔkt ɪn, bʌt ʃi tʃænəl tə laɪt ðə mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk-pænəld wɔlz, ən ðə kɪnlɪŋ ə ðə faɪɝz nitli leɪɾ ɑn ðə feɪsɪŋ hɑɹθs. ðən ʃi tʊk ə siɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə loʊ-bæk tʃɛɹz ɝaʊn ðə skɹoʊl-ɛdʒ teɪbəl ən ɹilist seɪaɪdɑɹ əɡɛn. sɪns əɹ ɪkspɛɹəmən ət hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ɔl deɪ, ʃi hæd nɑt hɛld ɪt lɔŋɡɝ ðən nɛsəsɛɹi. hɝ mud swʌŋ fɹəm dʒɔɪfəl ɪksaɪtmən tə mɝoʊs wɝi ən bæk. ɑn ðə wʌn hænd, ʃi wɑz dʌn wɪð hævɪŋ tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð mɛlɝ, ən sun ʃi wəɾ əv əɹ hænz ɑn tu blæk sɪstɝz. kwɛstʃənɪŋ əm maɪt lɛd tə ðə ɹɛst, əɹ ət list ɹɪvil ðɛɹ plænz. ən ɪf nɑt, ðɪs ʃieɪn wəɾ əv əɹ oʊn sikɹəts. ɛniwʌn u wɑz "wɝkɪŋ" tu dɑɹkfɹɛn sɪstɝz wəɾ əv sikɹəts wɝθ noʊɪŋ. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, wʌt wəd dʌɑɹə də tə tʃɹaɪ fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ æksɛptəns əz ən ædvaɪzɝ? dʌɑɹə wəd tʃɹaɪ tə mɛɾəl sʌmhaʊ, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt si haʊ. bɝn hɝ, ʃi dɪd nɑt niɾ ɛni mɔɹ dɪfəkəltiz bɪtwin əɹ ən ðə θɹoʊn. wɪð ə lɪɾəl lʌk, tənaɪt wəd nɑɾ oʊnli snɛɹ tu blæk sɪstɝz, ɪt maɪɾ ənkʌvɝ ə θɝd, ə mɝɾɝɝ tɛn taɪmz oʊvɝ. bæk ən fɔɹθ ʃi wɛnt, fɹəm fæljən ən mɑɹilɪn tə dʌɑɹə, ivən æftɝ mæstɝ nɔɹi ən hɑɹk dʒɔɪn hɝ.

The large sitting room was dark when she walked in, but she channeled to light the mirrored stand-lamps against the dark-paneled walls, and the kindling of the fires neatly laid on the facing hearths. Then she took a seat in one of the low-backed chairs around the scroll-edged table and released saidar again. Since her experiment at holding the Power all day, she had not held it longer than necessary. Her mood swung from joyful excitement to morose worry and back. On the one hand, she was done with having to put up with Mellar, and soon she would have her hands on two Black sisters. Questioning them might lead to the rest, or at least reveal their plans. And if not, this Shiaine would have her own secrets. Anyone who was "working" two Darkfriend sisters would have secrets worth knowing. On the other hand, what would Duhara do to try forcing her acceptance as an advisor? Duhara would try to meddle somehow, but she could not see how. Burn her, she did not need any more difficulties between her and the throne. With a little luck, tonight would not only snare two Black sisters, it might uncover a third, a murderer ten times over. Back and forth she went, from Falion and Marillin to Duhara, even after Master Norry and Hark joined her.

hɑɹk, ə sɪlvɝ kʌp ɪn ɪz hænd, tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk ə siɾ ət ðə teɪbəl, bʌt mæstɝ nɔɹi tæpt ɪm ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ ən dʒɝkt ɪz hɛd təwɔɹɾ ə kɔɹnɝ. sʌlənli, hɑɹk wɛnt wɛɹ i wɑz dɝɛktəd. hi mʌst əv bɪɡʌn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ əz sun əz ðə kʌp wɑz fɪld, kəz i ɛmptiɾ ɪɾ ɪn wʌn lɔŋ pʊl ðən stʊd tɝnɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪn ɪz hænz ən stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪt. sʌɾənli hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən dɝɛktəɾ ən ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪɾɪŋ ɡɹɪn ət hɝ. wʌtɛvɝ i sɔ ɑn əɹ feɪs meɪɾ ɪm flɪntʃ. skʌɾəlɪŋ tə ðə lɔŋ teɪbəl əɡɛns ðə wɔl, hi sɛt ðə kʌp daʊn wɪð ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd kɛɹ, ðən skʌɾəld bæk tə hɪz kɔɹnɝ.

Hark, a silver cup in his hand, tried to take a seat at the table, but Master Norry tapped him on the shoulder and jerked his head toward a corner. Sullenly, Hark went where he was directed. He must have begun drinking as soon as the cup was filled, because he emptied it in one long pull then stood turning it over in his hands and staring at it. Suddenly he gave a start and directed an ingratiating grin at her. Whatever he saw on her face made him flinch. Scuttling to the long table against the wall, he set the cup down with exaggerated care, then scuttled back to his corner.

bɝdʒɪt wɑz ðə fɝs tə ɝaɪv, ðə bɑn fɪld wɪð wɪɹi dɪskəntɛnt. "ə ɹaɪd?" ʃi sɛd, ən wən ɪleɪn ɪkspleɪnd, ʃi bɪɡæn ɹeɪzɪŋ əbdʒɛkʃənz. wɛl, səm ʌv ɪt wɑz əbdʒɛkʃənz; ðə ɹɛst wɑz dʒʌst ɪnsʌls.

Birgitte was the first to arrive, the bond filled with weary discontent. "A ride?" she said, and when Elayne explained, she began raising objections. Well, some of it was objections; the rest was just insults.

"wʌt hɛɹ-bɹeɪnd, kɹæk-pəɾɪd skim ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, bɝdʒɪt?" vændin sɛɾ əz ʃi ɛntɝd ðə ɹum. ʃi wɔɹ ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ðət hʌŋ lus ɑn hɝ. wʌn ə hɝ sɪstɝz, ɪt wəɾ əv fɪɾ əɹ pɝfəkli waɪl æɾɪliz wɑz əlaɪv, bʌt ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən hæd lɔst weɪt. hɝ jeɪɛm, wɪɹi ən nɑɹld, tʊk wʌn lʊk ət hɑɹk ən pleɪs hɪmsɛlf wɛɹ i kəd wɑtʃ ðə mæn. hɑɹk vɛntʃɝɾ ə smaɪl, bʌɾ ɪt feɪɾəd wən jeɪɛmz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɹɪmeɪn hɑɹɾ əz aɪɝn. ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ wɑz θɪn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ sɑft əbaʊt hɪm.

"What hare-brained, crack-pated scheme are you talking about, Birgitte?" Vandene said as she entered the room. She wore a riding dress that hung loose on her. One of her sister's, it would have fit her perfectly while Adeleas was alive, but the white-haired woman had lost weight. Her Jaem, wiry and gnarled, took one look at Hark and placed himself where he could watch the man. Hark ventured a smile, but it faded when Jaem's expression remained hard as iron. The Warder's graying hair was thin, but there was nothing soft about him.

"ʃi ɪntɛnz tə tʃɹaɪ kæptʃɝɪŋ tu blæk sɪstɝz tənaɪt," bɝdʒɪt ɹɪplaɪd, ʃuɾɪŋ ə hɑɹd lʊk əɾ ɪleɪn.

"She intends to try capturing two Black sisters tonight," Birgitte replied, shooting a hard look at Elayne.

"tu blæk sɪstɝz?" sɝaɪðə ɪkskleɪmd wɔkɪŋ θɹu ðə dɔɹ. ʃi ɡæðɝɾ əɹ dɑɹk kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ əz ðoʊ ðə wɝdz hæd ɡɪvən ə tʃɪl. "hu?" hɝ wɔɹɾɝ nɛd, ə tɔl, bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd jʌŋ mæn wɪð jɛloʊ hɛɹ, aɪd hɑɹk ən tʌtʃt ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. hi tʃoʊz ə spɑt wɛɹ i kəd wɑtʃ ðə mæn, tu. hɑɹk ʃɪftəɾ ɪz fit. hi maɪɾ əv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹʌn.

"Two Black sisters?" Sareitha exclaimed walking through the door. She gathered her dark cloak around her as though the words had given a chill. "Who?" Her Warder Ned, a tall, broad-shouldered young man with yellow hair, eyed Hark and touched his sword hilt. He chose a spot where he could watch the man, too. Hark shifted his feet. He might have been thinking of trying to run.

"fæljən boʊɾə ən mɑɹilɪn ɡəmɑlfɪn," ɪleɪn sɛd. sɝaɪðəz maʊθ hɑɹɾənd.

"Falion Bhoda and Marillin Gemalphin," Elayne said. Sareitha's mouth hardened.

"wʌɾ əbaʊt fæljən ən mɑɹilɪn?" kɛɝin æskt əz ʃi ɡlaɪɾɪd ɪndə ðə ɹum. hɝ wɔɹɾɝz wɝ dɪspɝɪt mɛn, ə tɔl, ɡæŋli tɛɹən, ə bleɪd-slɛndɝ sɑldəiən, ən ə bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd kɛɹhinɪn. ðeɪ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz, ən teɪvən, ðə kɛɹhinɪn, lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl wɑtʃɪŋ hɑɹk waɪl sɪɛɹəl ən ɛnɝ stʊɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. hɑɹks maʊθ tʊk ɑn ə sɪkli twɪst.

"What about Falion and Marillin?" Careane asked as she glided into the room. Her Warders were disparate men, a tall, gangly Tairen, a blade-slender Saldaean, and a broad-shouldered Cairhienin. They exchanged glances, and Tavan, the Cairhienin, leaned against the wall watching Hark while Cieryl and Venr stood in the doorway. Hark's mouth took on a sickly twist.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt bʌt tə ɪkspleɪn əɡɛn fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. wɪtʃ ɪleɪn dɪd wɪð ə ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃəns ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð əɹ ʃɪftɪŋ mudz. ðə lɔŋɡɝ ðɪs tʊk, ðə mɔɹ tʃæns ðət fæljən ən mɑɹilɪn maɪt bi ɡɔn baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi ɹitʃt ðə haʊs ɑn fʊl mun stʃɹit. ʃi wɑntəd ðɛm. ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə hæv ðɛm! ʃi ʃʊɾə meɪd bɝdʒɪt weɪɾ əntɪl ɛvɹiwʌn hæd ɡæðɝd.

There was nothing for it but to explain again from the beginning. Which Elayne did with a rising impatience that had nothing to do with her shifting moods. The longer this took, the more chance that Falion and Marillin might be gone by the time she reached the house on Full Moon Street. She wanted them. She intended to have them! She should have made Birgitte wait until everyone had gathered.

"ə ɡʊd plæn, aɪ θɪŋk," vændin sɛd wən ʃi fɪnɪʃt. "jɛs, ɪɾəl də naɪsli." ʌðɝz wɝ nɑt soʊ əɡɹiəbəl.

"A good plan, I think," Vandene said when she finished. "Yes, it will do nicely." Others were not so agreeable.

"ɪɾ ɪzən ə plæn, ɪts blʌɾi mædnəs!" bɝdʒɪt sɛd ʃɑɹpli. ɑɹmz foʊldəd bɪniθ əɹ bʊzəm, ʃi skaʊl daʊn əɾ ɪleɪn, ðə bɑn sətʃ ə tɝmɔɪl ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ðəɾ ɪleɪn kəd bɛɹli meɪk əm aʊt. "ðə fɔɹ ə jə ɛntɝ ðə haʊs əloʊn. əloʊn! ðəɾ ɪzən ə plæn. ɪts fleɪmɪŋ ɪnsænəɾi! wɔɹɾɝz ɑɹ səpoʊz tə ɡɑɹd ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪz bæks. lɛɾ əs kʌm wɪð ju." ði ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz pʊɾ ɪn ɛmfæɾɪk əɡɹiməns, bʌɾ ət list ʃi wɑz nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɑp ðə hoʊl θɪŋ ɛni mɔɹ.

"It isn't a plan, it's bloody madness!" Birgitte said sharply. Arms folded beneath her bosom, she scowled down at Elayne, the bond such a turmoil of emotions that Elayne could barely make them out. "The four of you enter the house alone. Alone! That isn't a plan. It's flaming insanity! Warders are supposed to guard their Aes Sedai's backs. Let us come with you." The other Warders put in emphatic agreements, but at least she was not trying to stop the whole thing any more.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ fɔɹ ʌv ʌs," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ. "wi kən wɑtʃ əɹ oʊn bæks. ən sɪstɝz də nɑɾ æsk ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz tə feɪs ʌðɝ sɪstɝz." bɝdʒɪts feɪs dɑɹkənd. "ɪf aɪ nid ju, əl ʃaʊt soʊ laʊd jud bi eɪbəl tə hɪɹ mi ɪf jə wɝ bæk hɪɹ ɪn ðə pæləs. ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɹɪmeɪn aʊtsaɪd!" ʃi æɾəd wən bɝdʒɪɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊð. ðə bɑn fɪld wɪð fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, bʌt bɝdʒɪts dʒɔ snæpt ʃʌt.

"There are four of us," Elayne told her. "We can watch our own backs. And sisters do not ask their Warders to face other sisters." Birgitte's face darkened. "If I need you, I'll shout so loud you'd be able to hear me if you were back here in the palace. The Warders remain outside!" she added when Birgitte opened her mouth. The bond filled with frustration, but Birgitte's jaw snapped shut.

"pɝhæps ðɪs mæn kən bi tʃɹʌstɪd," sɝaɪðə sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət hɑɹk wɪð noʊ tʃɹʌst əɾ ɔl, "bʌɾ ivən ɪf i hɝd kɝɛkli, nʌθɪŋ sɛz ðəɹ ɑɹ stɪl oʊnli tu sɪstɝz ɪn ðə haʊs. əɹ ɛni. ɪf ðeɪv ɡɔn, ðɛɹz noʊ deɪnʒɝ, bʌɾ ɪf ʌðɝz əv dʒɔɪn ðɛm, wi maɪɾ əz wɛl pʊɾ əɹ nɛks ɪn ə nus ən spɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹæp aʊɝsɛlvz."

"Perhaps this man can be trusted," Sareitha said, glancing at Hark with no trust at all, "but even if he heard correctly, nothing says there are still only two sisters in the house. Or any. If they have gone, there's no danger, but if others have joined them, we might as well put our necks in a noose and spring the trap ourselves."

kɛɝin foʊldəɾ əɹ stɝɾi ɑɹmz ən nɑɾəd. "ðə deɪnʒɝ ɪz tu ɡɹeɪt. jə jɝsɛlf toʊld əs ðət wən ðeɪ flɛd ðə taʊɝ, ðeɪ stoʊl ə nʌmbɝ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, səm vɛɹi deɪnʒɝəs ɪndid. aɪv nɛvɝ bɪn kɔld ə kaʊɝd, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn fænsi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə snik ʌp ɑn sʌmwʌn u maɪɾ əv ə ɹɑd ðət kən meɪk bɑlfaɪɝ."

Careane folded her sturdy arms and nodded. "The danger is too great. You yourself told us that when they fled the Tower, they stole a number of ter'angreal, some very dangerous indeed. I've never been called a coward, but I don't fancy trying to sneak up on someone who might have a rod that can make balefire."

"hi kəd hɑɹdli hæv mɪʃɝd sʌmθɪŋ əz sɪmpəl əz 'ðɛɹ ɑɹ oʊnli tu ʌv ʌs,' " ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd fɝmli. "æn ðeɪ spoʊk əz ɪf ðeɪ dɪdn ɪkspɛkt ɛni ʌðɝz." bɝn hɝ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ əɹ stændɪŋ wɪð ɹɪspɛk tə ðɛm, ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn dʒʌmpɪŋ tə oʊbeɪ ɹæðɝ ðən ɑɹɡjuɪŋ. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðɪs ɪzən ə dɪskʌʃən." ə pɪɾi boʊθ əbdʒɛktəd. ɪf oʊnli wʌn hæd, ɪt cʊɾə bɪn ə klu. ənlɛs ðeɪ boʊθ wɝ blæk ədʒɑ. ə boʊn-fɹizɪŋ θɔt, ðæt, jɛɾ əɹ plæn tʊk ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ɪndə əkaʊnt. "fæljən ən mɑɹilɪn woʊnt noʊ wəɹ kʌmɪŋ əntɪl ɪts tu leɪt. ɪf ðəɹ ɡɔn, wɪl ɝɛs ðɪs ʃieɪn, bʌt wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ."

"He could hardly have misheard something as simple as 'there are only two of us,' " Elayne replied firmly. "And they spoke as if they didn't expect any others." Burn her, considering her standing with respect to them, they should have been jumping to obey rather than arguing. "In any case, this isn't a discussion." A pity both objected. If only one had, it could have been a clue. Unless they both were Black Ajah. A bone-freezing thought, that, yet her plan took the possibility into account. "Falion and Marillin won't know we are coming until it's too late. If they're gone, we'll arrest this Shiaine, but we are going."

ɪt wɑz ə lɑɹdʒɝ pɑɹɾi ðən ɪleɪn hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðət ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə kwinz steɪbliɑɹd bɪhaɪn əɹ ən hɑɹk. bɝdʒɪt hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn bɹɪŋɪŋ fɪfti ɡɑɹdzwɪmən, ðoʊ ɔl ðeɪ wəd bi duɪŋ wɑz mɪsɪŋ slip, ə kɑləm ə tuz ɪn ɹɛd-lækɝd hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts, blæk ɪn ðə naɪt, ðət sneɪkt əlɔŋ ðə pæləs bɪhaɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz. ɹitʃɪŋ ðə fɹʌn ə ðə pæləs, ðeɪ skɝɾɪd ði ɛdʒ ə ðə kwinz plɑzə, ðə ɡɹeɪɾ oʊvəl kɹaʊɾəd naʊ wɪð ɹud ʃɛltɝz ðət haʊz slipɪŋ ɡɑɹdzmɪn ən noʊbəlz' ɑɹmmɪn. mɛn wɝ bɪləɾəd ɛvɹiwɛɹ ɹum kəd bi faʊnd, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ɪnsəfɪʃən beɪsməns ən æɾɪks ən spɛɹ ɹumz nɪɹ ɪnʌf ðə pæləs, ən ðə pɑɹks wɛɹ sɝkəlz ə kɪnswɪmən wəd teɪk ðə mɛn tə ðə pleɪsəz wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ niɾəd. ðə faɪɾɪŋ ðeɪ dɪd wɑz əfʊt, ɑn ðə wɔlz, soʊ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɝ ɔl pɪkəɾɪd ɪn nɪɹbaɪ pɑɹks ən ɪn ðə lɑɹdʒɝ pæləs ɡɑɹɾənz. ə fju sɛntʃɹiz ʃɪftəɾ əz ðeɪ pæst, hɛdz swɪvəlɪŋ tə fɑloʊ, bʌt wɪð əɹ hʊɾ ʌp, ɔl ðeɪ kəd bi ʃʊɹ ʌv wɑz ðəɾ ə lɑɹdʒ kəntɪnʒənt ʌv ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɝ ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ ə pɑɹɾi θɹu ðə naɪt. ðə skaɪ tə ði ist wɑz stɪl dɑɹk, bʌɾ ɪt mʌs bi lɛs ðən tu aʊɝz tɪl fɝs laɪt. ðə laɪt sɛn dɔn wəd si fæljən ən mɑɹilɪn ɪn kʌstəɾi. ən wʌn mɔɹ. ət list wʌn mɔɹ.

It was a larger party than Elayne had expected that rode out of the Queen's Stableyard behind her and Hark. Birgitte had insisted on bringing fifty Guardswomen, though all they would be doing was missing sleep, a column of twos in red-lacquered helmets and breastplates, black in the night, that snaked along the palace behind the Aes Sedai and Warders. Reaching the front of the palace, they skirted the edge of the Queen's Plaza, the great oval crowded now with rude shelters that housed sleeping Guardsmen and nobles' armsmen. Men were billeted everywhere room could be found, but there were insufficient basements and attics and spare rooms near enough the palace, and the parks where circles of Kinswomen would take the men to the places where they were needed. The fighting they did was afoot, on the walls, so their horses were all picketed in nearby parks and in the larger palace gardens. A few sentries shifted as they passed, heads swiveling to follow, but with her hood up, all they could be sure of was that a large contingent of Guardswomen were escorting a party through the night. The sky to the east was still dark, but it must be less than two hours till first light. The Light send dawn would see Falion and Marillin in custody. And one more. At least one more.

waɪndɪŋ stʃɹits lɛɾ oʊvɝ ən ɝaʊn ðə hɪlz pæs nɛɹoʊ, taɪl-kʌvɝd taʊɝz ðət wəd ɡlɪɾɝ wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd kʌlɝz wən ðə sʌn ɹoʊz ən ɡlɪɾɝd feɪnli ɪn ðə klaʊd-dæpəl munlaɪt, pæst saɪlənt ʃɑps ən laɪtləs ɪnz, sɪmpəl stoʊn haʊsəz wɪð sleɪt ɹufs ən smɔl pæləsəz ðət maɪɾ əv fɪɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðə ɹɪŋ ə hɔɹsʃuz ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ən ðə feɪn kɹik ə sæɾəl lɛðɝ saʊndəd laʊɾ ɪn ðə saɪləns. ɪksɛp fəɹ ən əkeɪʒənəl dɔɡ ðət slʌŋk əweɪ ɪndə ðə dipɝ ʃædoʊz ʌv æliz, nʌθɪŋ ɛls muvd. ðə stʃɹits wɝ deɪnʒɝəs ət ðɪs aʊɝ, bʌt noʊ fʊtpæd wəd bi mæɾ ɪnʌf tə kʌm ɪn saɪɾ ə soʊ lɑɹdʒ ə pɑɹɾi. hæf ən aʊɝ æftɝ livɪŋ ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs, ɪleɪn ɹoʊd faɪɹhɑɹt θɹu ðə mɑndəl ɡeɪt, ə waɪd, twɛnti-fʊt-haɪ ɑɹtʃ ɪn ði ɪnɝ sɪɾiz tɔl waɪt wɔl. wʌns ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn ɡɑɹdzmɪn ɑn duɾi ðɛɹ, tə kip ðə pis, bʌt ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz wɝ spɹɛd tu θɪn naʊ fəɹ ðæt.

Winding streets led over and around the hills past narrow, tile-covered towers that would glitter with a hundred colors when the sun rose and glittered faintly in the cloud-dappled moonlight, past silent shops and lightless inns, simple stone houses with slate roofs and small palaces that might have fit in Tar Valon. The ring of horseshoes on the paving stones and the faint creak of saddle leather sounded loud in the silence. Except for an occasional dog that slunk away into the deeper shadows of alleys, nothing else moved. The streets were dangerous at this hour, but no footpad would be mad enough to come in sight of so large a party. Half an hour after leaving the Royal Palace, Elayne rode Fireheart through the Mondel Gate, a wide, twenty-foot-high arch in the Inner City's tall white wall. Once there would have been Guardsmen on duty there, to keep the peace, but the Queen's Guards were spread too thin now for that.

ɔlmoʊst əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ ɪndə ðə nu sɪɾi, hɑɹk tɝn ist ɪndə ə wɔɹən ə stʃɹits ðət miændɝɾ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən θɹu ðə sɪɾiz hɪlz. hi ɹoʊɾ ɔkwɝdli, ɑn ə beɪ mɛɹ ðət hæd bɪn faʊn fəɹ hɪm. kʌtpɝsɪz sɛldəm spɛn taɪm ɪn ðə sæɾəl. səm ə ðə stʃɹits wɝ kwaɪt nɛɹoʊ hɪɹ, ən ɪt wɑz ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz ðəɾ i faɪnəli dʒɹu ɹeɪn, sɝaʊndəd baɪ stoʊn haʊsəz ə tu əɹ θɹi əɹ ivən fɔɹ stɔɹiz. bɝdʒɪt ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə hɔl ðə kɑləm. ðə sʌɾən saɪləns sim dɛfənɪŋ.

Almost as soon as they were into the New City, Hark turned east into a warren of streets that meandered in every direction through the city's hills. He rode awkwardly, on a bay mare that had been found for him. Cutpurses seldom spent time in the saddle. Some of the streets were quite narrow here, and it was in one of those that he finally drew rein, surrounded by stone houses of two or three or even four stories. Birgitte raised a hand to halt the column. The sudden silence seemed deafening.

"ɪts dʒʌst ɝaʊn ðət kɔɹnɝ ðɛɹ, ɪɾ ɪz, maɪ leɪɾi, ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit," hɑɹk sɛɾ ɪn ə nɪɹ wɪspɝ, "bʌɾ ɪf wi ɡoʊ ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ, ðeɪ maɪt hɪɹ əs əɹ si ʌs. pɑɹɾən, maɪ leɪɾi, bʌɾ ɪf ðiz ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ wʌt jə sɛz ðeɪ ɑɹ, aɪ doʊnt wɑn əm siɪŋ mi." hi skɹæmbəl daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl klʌmsəli ən lʊkt ʌp hɝ, ɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz hænz, hɪz munʃæɾoʊd feɪs æŋkʃəs.

"It's just around that corner there, it is, my Lady, the other side of the street," Hark said in a near whisper, "but if we go riding out there, they might hear us or see us. Pardon, my Lady, but if these Aes Sedai are what you says they are, I don't want them seeing me." He scrambled down from his saddle clumsily and looked up her, wringing his hands, his moonshadowed face anxious.

dɪsmaʊntɪŋ, ɪleɪn lɛd faɪɹhɑɹt tə ðə kɔɹnɝ ən pikt ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ʌv ə nɛɹoʊ, θɹi-stɔɹi haʊs. ðə haʊsəz əlɔŋ ði ʌðɝ stʃɹit stʊd dɑɹk ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn, fɔɹ səbstæntʃəl stɔɹiz ə stoʊn wɪð ðə kloʊzd ɡeɪɾ ʌv ə steɪbliɑɹd bɪsaɪɾ ɪt. nɑɾ ən ɔɹneɪt bɪldɪŋ, bʌt lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə wɛlθi mɝtʃən əɹ bæŋkɝ. bæŋkɝz ən mɝtʃəns wɝ ənlaɪkli tə bi əweɪk ət ðɪs aʊɝ, haʊɛvɝ.

Dismounting, Elayne led Fireheart to the corner and peeked around the corner of a narrow, three-story house. The houses along the other street stood dark except for one, four substantial stories of stone with the closed gate of a stableyard beside it. Not an ornate building, but large enough for a wealthy merchant or banker. Bankers and merchants were unlikely to be awake at this hour, however.

"ðɛɹ," hɑɹk wɪspɝd hɔɹsli, pɔɪntɪŋ. hi stʊd fɑɹ bæk, soʊ hi hæd tə lin fɔɹwɝd tə pɔɪnt. hi ɹɪli dɪd fɪɹ biɪŋ sin. "ðə wʌn wɪð ðə laɪɾ ɑn ðə sɛkən flɔɹ, ɪɾ ɪz."

"There," Hark whispered hoarsely, pointing. He stood far back, so he had to lean forward to point. He really did fear being seen. "The one with the light on the second floor, it is."

"bɛs tə faɪn aʊɾ ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛls ɪz əweɪk ɪn ðɛɹ," vændin sɛd, piɹɪŋ pæst ɪleɪn. "jeɪɛm? doʊnt ɡoʊ ɪnsaɪd ðə haʊs."

"Best to find out if anyone else is awake in there," Vandene said, peering past Elayne. "Jaem? Don't go inside the house."

ɪleɪn ɪkspɛktəd ðə lin oʊld wɔɹɾɝ tə snik əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit, bʌɾ i dʒʌst stʃɹoʊld aʊt hoʊldɪŋ ɪz kloʊk kloʊs ɝaʊn ɪm əɡɛns ði ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ tʃɪl. ivən ðə deɪnʒɝəs ɡɹeɪs ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ əpɪɹd tə hæv dɪzɝɾɪd hɪm. vændin sim tə sɛns əɹ sɝpɹaɪz.

Elayne expected the lean old Warder to sneak across the street, but he just strolled out holding his cloak close around him against the early morning chill. Even the dangerous grace of a Warder appeared to have deserted him. Vandene seemed to sense her surprise.

"skʌlkɪŋ dʒɹɔz ði aɪ ən kɹieɪts səspɪʃən," ʃi sɛd. "jeɪɛm ɪz dʒʌst ə mæn wɔkɪŋ, ən ɪf ɪts ɝli tə bi aʊɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹits, hi ɪzən snikɪŋ, soʊ ɛniwʌn u siz ɪm wɪl θɪŋk ə səm məndeɪn ɹizən fəɹ ɪm tə bi aʊt."

"Skulking draws the eye and creates suspicion," she said. "Jaem is just a man walking, and if it's early to be out in the streets, he isn't sneaking, so anyone who sees him will think of some mundane reason for him to be out."

ɹitʃɪŋ ðə steɪbliɑɹd ɡeɪt, jeɪɛm pʊld ɪɾ oʊpən ən wɔk θɹu əz ɪf i hæɾ ə pɝfəkt ɹaɪt. lɔŋ mɪnəts pæs bɪfɔɹ i keɪm bæk aʊt, ʃʌɾɪŋ ðə ɡeɪt kɛɹfəli bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən stʃɹoʊl bæk əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit. hi ɹaʊndəd ðə kɔɹnɝ ən ðə lɛpɝd-laɪk ɡɹeɪs ɹiəpɪɹɾ ɪn ɪz stɛp.

Reaching the stableyard gate, Jaem pulled it open and walked through as if he had a perfect right. Long minutes passed before he came back out, shutting the gate carefully behind him, and strolled back along the street. He rounded the corner and the leopard-like grace reappeared in his step.

"ɔl ðə wɪndoʊz ɑɹ dɑɹk ɪksɛp ðət wʌn," hi toʊl vændin kwaɪətli. "ðə kɪtʃən dɔɹ ɪz ənlætʃt. soʊ ɪz ðə bæk dɔɹ. ðət lɛts ɑntu ən æli. tʃɹʌstɪŋ, fəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. əɹ ɛls deɪnʒɝəs ɪnʌf ðeɪ doʊnt wɝi əbaʊt bɝɡlɝz. ðɛɹz ə bɪɡ fɛloʊ slipɪŋ ɪn ðə bɑɹn, ʌp ɪn ðə lɔft. bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə skɛɹ ɛni bɝɡlɝ, bʌt hiz soʊ dʒɹʌŋk i dɪdnt weɪk waɪl aɪ wɑz taɪɪŋ ɪm ʌp." vændin ɹeɪzd ə kwɛstʃənɪŋ aɪbɹaʊ. "aɪ θɔɾ aɪd bɛɾɝ bi seɪf. dʒɹʌŋks səmtaɪmz weɪk wən jə list ɪkspɛkt. jə wʊdnt wɑn ɪm siɪŋ jə ɡoʊ ɪn ən stɑɹt meɪkɪŋ nɔɪz." ʃi nɑɾəd əpɹuvəl.

"All the windows are dark except that one," he told Vandene quietly. "The kitchen door is unlatched. So is the back door. That lets onto an alley. Trusting, for Darkfriends. Or else dangerous enough they don't worry about burglars. There's a big fellow sleeping in the barn, up in the loft. Big enough to scare any burglar, but he's so drunk he didn't wake while I was tying him up." Vandene raised a questioning eyebrow. "I thought I'd better be safe. Drunks sometimes wake when you least expect. You wouldn't want him seeing you go in and start making noise." She nodded approval.

"ɪts taɪm tə ɡɛt ɹɛɾi," ɪleɪn sɛd. muvɪŋ bæk fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ən hændɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz tə bɝdʒɪt, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. ɪt wɑz laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ smoʊk wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ən æŋɡɝ wɛld ʌp, ɔl ðə θɪŋz jə niɾəd tə səpɹɛs ɪf jə wɝ tə tʃænəl. ʃi tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn, ən feɪld əɡɛn. fæljən ən mɑɹilɪn wɝ gɑnə ɡɛɾ əweɪ. tə kʌm ðɪs kloʊs. . . . ðeɪ hæd tə bi ɪn ðət laɪɾəd ɹum. ʃi nu ɪt. ən ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɪskeɪp. sædnəs ɹipleɪst æŋɡɝ, ən sʌɾənli seɪaɪdɑɹ floʊɾ ɪndə hɝ. ʃi bɛɹli staɪfəld ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. "aɪl mɛl ðə floʊz, sɝaɪðə. vændin, jə mɛl fəɹ kɛɝin."

"It's time to get ready," Elayne said. Moving back from the corner and handing her reins to Birgitte, she tried to embrace the Source. It was like trying to catch smoke with her fingers. Frustration and anger welled up, all the things you needed to suppress if you were to channel. She tried again, and failed again. Falion and Marillin were going to get away. To come this close. . . . They had to be in that lighted room. She knew it. And they were going to escape. Sadness replaced anger, and suddenly saidar flowed into her. She barely stifled a sigh of relief. "I'll meld the flows, Sareitha. Vandene, you meld for Careane."

"aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd waɪ wɪv tə lɪŋk," ðə tɛɹən bɹaʊn mʌɾɝd, bʌt ʃi pʊt hɝsɛlf ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. "wɪð tu ʌv əm ən fɔɹ ʌv ʌs, wi aʊtnʌmbɝ ðɛm, bʌt lɪŋkt, ɪts tu ən tu." ə klu? pɝhæps ʃi wɪʃt ɪt tə bi θɹi ən θɹi?

"I don't understand why we have to link," the Tairen Brown muttered, but she put herself on the edge of embracing the Power. "With two of them and four of us, we outnumber them, but linked, it's two and two." A clue? Perhaps she wished it to be three and three?

"tu stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝwɛlm əm ivən ɪf ðəɹ hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, sɝaɪðə." ɪleɪn ɹitʃt θɹu hɝ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ən æŋɡɹil, ən ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd ði ʌðɝ wʊmən əz ðə lɪŋk wɑz kəmpliɾəd. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɪt sɝaʊndəd boʊθ ə ðɛm, bʌt ʃi kəɾ oʊnli si ðə pɑɹɾ ɝaʊn sɝaɪðə - əntɪl ʃi woʊv spɪɹəɾ ɝaʊn hɝ. ðən ðə ɡloʊ vænɪʃt. ʃi pleɪs ðə seɪm wiv ɑn hɝsɛlf ən pɹipɛɹd fɔɹ ʃilz ən sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ wivz, ɔl ɪnvɝɾɪd. ʃi fɛlt ɔlmoʊst ɡɪɾi wɪð ɪksaɪtmənt, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə bi kɑt baɪ sɝpɹaɪz. fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən stɪl pʌlsd əlɔŋ ðə bɑnd, bʌt fəɹ ðə ɹɛst, bɝdʒɪt fɛlt laɪk ə dʒɹɔn æɹoʊ. ɪleɪn tʌtʃt əɹ ɑɹm. "wi wɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪt." bɝdʒɪt snɔɹɾɪd ən flʌŋ əɹ θɪk bɹeɪd bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. "kip ən aɪ ɑn mæstɝ hɑɹk, bɝdʒɪt. ɪt wəd bi ə ʃeɪm ɪf i hæd tə bi hæŋ kəz i wɑz tɛmptəd tə ɹʌn." hɑɹk skwikt.

"Two strong enough to overwhelm them even if they're holding the Power, Sareitha." Elayne reached through her as if she were an angreal, and the glow of saidar surrounded the other woman as the link was completed. In truth, it surrounded both of them, but she could only see the part around Sareitha - until she wove Spirit around her. Then the glow vanished. She placed the same weave on herself and prepared four shields and several other weaves, all inverted. She felt almost giddy with excitement, but she did not intend to be caught by surprise. Frustration still pulsed along the bond, but for the rest, Birgitte felt like a drawn arrow. Elayne touched her arm. "We will be all right." Birgitte snorted and flung her thick braid back over her shoulder. "Keep an eye on Master Hark, Birgitte. It would be a shame if he had to be hanged because he was tempted to run." Hark squeaked.

ʃi ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð vændin, hu sɛd, "wi maɪɾ əz wɛl bi əbaʊɾ ɪt."

She exchanged glances with Vandene, who said, "We might as well be about it."

ðə fɔɹ ə ðɛm wɔkt ʌp fʊl mun stʃɹit, sloʊli, əz ɪf aʊt fəɹ ə stʃɹoʊl, ən slɪpt ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊ-ʃɹaʊɾɪd steɪbliɑɹd. ɪleɪn oʊpən ðə kɪtʃən dɔɹ sloʊli, bʌt ðə hɪnʒɪz wɝ wɛl-ɔɪld, ɪmɪɾɪŋ nɑɾ ə skwik. ðə bɹɪk-wɔl kɪtʃən wɑz lɪɾ oʊnli baɪ ə taɪni faɪɝ ɪn ðə waɪd stoʊn faɪɝpleɪs wɛɹ ə kɛɾəl hʌŋ stimɪŋ, jɛt ðət wɑz ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə kɹɔs ðə flɔɹ wɪθaʊt bʌmpɪŋ ɪndə ðə teɪbəl əɹ tʃɛɹz. sʌmwʌn saɪd, ən ʃi pɹɛst ə wɔɹnɪŋ fɪŋɡɝ tə hɝ lɪps. vændin fɹaʊn ət kɛɝin, hu lʊkt ɪmbɛɹəst ən spɹɛɾ əɹ hænz.

The four of them walked up Full Moon Street, slowly, as if out for a stroll, and slipped into the shadow-shrouded stableyard. Elayne opened the kitchen door slowly, but the hinges were well-oiled, emitting not a squeak. The brick-walled kitchen was lit only by a tiny fire in the wide stone fireplace where a kettle hung steaming, yet that was enough for them to cross the floor without bumping into the table or chairs. Someone sighed, and she pressed a warning finger to her lips. Vandene frowned at Careane, who looked embarrassed and spread her hands.

ə ʃɔɹt hɔl lɛd tə stɛɹz ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə haʊs. ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts, ɪleɪn stɑɹɾəd ʌp, saɪlən ɑn slɪpɝd fit. ʃi wɑz kɛɹfəl tə kip sɝaɪðə wɛɹ ʃi kəd si hɝ. vændin wɑz duɪŋ ðə seɪm wɪð kɛɝin. ðeɪ kəd də nʌθɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ, bʌt ðət hɑɹdli mɛn ðeɪ kəd də nʌθɪŋ. ɑn ðə sɛkən flaɪɾ ə stɛɹz, ʃi bɪɡæn hɪɹɪŋ ðə mɝmɝ ə vɔɪsəz. laɪt spɪl fɹəm ən oʊpən dɔɹ.

A short hall led to stairs at the front of the house. Gathering her skirts, Elayne started up, silent on slippered feet. She was careful to keep Sareitha where she could see her. Vandene was doing the same with Careane. They could do nothing with the Power, but that hardly meant they could do nothing. On the second flight of stairs, she began hearing the murmur of voices. Light spilled from an open door.

". . . . doʊn kɛɹ wʌt jə θɪŋk," ə wʊmən sɛɾ ɪn ðət ɹum. "ju liv ðə θɪŋkɪŋ tə mi ən də əz jəɹ toʊld."

". . . . don't care what you think," a woman said in that room. "You leave the thinking to me and do as you're told."

ɪleɪn muv tə ðə dɔɹ. ɪt wɑz ə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, wɪð ɡɪldɪd stænd-læmps ən ɹɪtʃ kɑɹpəts ɑn ðə flɔɹ ən ə tɔl faɪɝpleɪs ə blu mɑɹbəl, bʌt ʃi hæɾ aɪz oʊnli fəɹ ðə θɹi wɪmən ɪn ɪt. oʊnli wʌn, ə ʃɑɹp-feɪst wʊmən, wɑz siɾəd. ðət mʌs bi ʃieɪn. ði ʌðɝ tu stʊd wɪð ðɛɹ bæks tə ðə dɔɹ, hɛdz baʊd laɪk pɛnɪɾənts. ðə ʃɑɹp-feɪst wʊmənz aɪz waɪɾənd wən ʃi sɔ hɝ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn ɡeɪv əɹ noʊ taɪm tə oʊpən əɹ maʊð. ðə tu blæk sɪstɝz kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn əlɑɹm əz ʃilz wɛn ɑntu ðɛm, ən floʊz ʌv ɛɹ baʊn ðɛɹ ɑɹmz tə ðɛɹ saɪdz, taɪɾənd ðɛɹ skɝts ɝaʊn ðɛɹ lɛɡz. mɔɹ floʊz ʌv ɛɹ fæsənd ʃieɪn tə hɝ ɡɪldɪɾ ɑɹmtʃɛɹ.

Elayne moved to the door. It was a sitting room, with gilded stand-lamps and rich carpets on the floor and a tall fireplace of blue marble, but she had eyes only for the three women in it. Only one, a sharp-faced woman, was seated. That must be Shiaine. The other two stood with their backs to the door, heads bowed like penitents. The sharp-faced woman's eyes widened when she saw her in the doorway, but Elayne gave her no time to open her mouth. The two Black sisters cried out in alarm as shields went onto them, and flows of Air bound their arms to their sides, tightened their skirts around their legs. More flows of Air fastened Shiaine to her gilded armchair.

ɪleɪn dʒɹu sɝaɪðə ɪndə ðə ɹum wɪð əɹ ən muv tə wɛɹ ʃi kəd si ɔl ə ðɛɹ feɪsəz. sɝaɪðə tʃɹaɪd tə stɛp bæk. ʃi maɪɾ oʊnli hæv bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɪv əɹ ðə pleɪs ə pɹɑmənəns, bʌɾ ɪleɪn kɑɾ əɹ sliv əɡɛn, kipɪŋ əɹ ɪn vju, tu. vændin ən kɛɝin dʒɔɪn ðɛm. mɑɹilɪnz nɛɹoʊ feɪs hɛld ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑm, bʌt fæljən snɑɹəl saɪlənli.

Elayne drew Sareitha into the room with her and moved to where she could see all of their faces. Sareitha tried to step back. She might only have been trying to give her the place of prominence, but Elayne caught her sleeve again, keeping her in view, too. Vandene and Careane joined them. Marillin's narrow face held Aes Sedai calm, but Falion snarled silently.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðə minɪŋ ə ðɪs?" ʃieɪn dɪmændəd. "aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ju. jəɹ ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. bʌt ðət ɡɪvz jə noʊ ɹaɪt tə ɪnveɪd maɪ hoʊm ən əsɔl mi."

"What is the meaning of this?" Shiaine demanded. "I recognize you. You're Elayne Trakand, the Daughter-Heir. But that gives you no right to invade my home and assault me."

"fæljən boʊɾə," ɪleɪn sɛd kɑmli, "mɑɹilɪn ɡəmɑlfɪn, ʃieɪn əvɑɹhən, aɪ ɝɛs jə əz dɑɹkfɹɛnz." wɛl, hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kɑm. ɪnsaɪd, ʃi wɑntəd tə skɪp wɪð ɡli. ən bɝdʒɪt θɔt ðɪs wəd bi deɪnʒɝəs!

"Falion Bhoda," Elayne said calmly, "Marillin Gemalphin, Shiaine Avarhin, I arrest you as Darkfriends." Well, her voice was calm. Inside, she wanted to skip with glee. And Birgitte thought this would be dangerous!

"ðæɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs," ʃieɪn sɛɾ ɪn aɪsi toʊnz. "aɪ wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt!"

"That is ridiculous," Shiaine said in icy tones. "I walk in the Light!"

"nɑɾ ɪf jə wɔk wɪð ðiz tu," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ. "tə maɪ sɝɾən nɑlədʒ ðeɪv pɹuvən ðɛmsɛlvz blæk ədʒɑ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, tiɹ ən tæntʃəkoʊ. jə doʊn hɪɹ əm dɪnaɪɪŋ ɪt, də ju? ðæts kəz ðeɪ noʊ aɪ - "

"Not if you walk with these two," Elayne told her. "To my certain knowledge they've proven themselves Black Ajah in Tar Valon, Tear and Tanchico. You don't hear them denying it, do you? That's because they know I - "

sʌɾənli spɑɹks dænst ɔl oʊvɝ əɹ fɹəm hɛd tə toʊ. ʃi twɪtʃt hɛlpləsli, mʌsəlz spæzəmɪŋ, seɪaɪdɑɹ slɪpɪŋ fɹəm əɹ ɡɹæsp. ʃi kəd si vændin ən kɛɝin ən sɝaɪðə dʒɝkɪŋ əz spɑɹks flɪkɝɾ əkɹɔs əm əz wɛl. oʊnli ə moʊmən ɪt læstəd, bʌt wən ðə spɑɹks vænɪʃt, ɪleɪn fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn fɛd θɹu ə mæŋɡəl. ʃi hæd tə hoʊld ɑn tə sɝaɪðə tə steɪ ɑn əɹ fit, ən sɝaɪðə klʌŋ tə hɝ əz hɑɹd. vændin ən kɛɝin wɝ səpɔɹɾɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ, sweɪɪŋ, itʃ wɪð əɹ tʃɪn ɑn ði ʌðɝz ʃoʊldɝ. fæljən ən mɑɹilɪn wɔɹ stɑɹɾəld ɪkspɹɛʃənz, bʌt ðə laɪɾ ə ðə paʊɝ ɛnvɛləpt əm ɪn hɑɹtbits. ɪleɪn fɛl ðə ʃil fæsən ɑn tə hɝ, sɔ ðɛm sɛɾəl ɑn ði ʌðɝ θɹi. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ baɪndɪŋ. ɛni ʌv əm wʊɾə fɔlən oʊvɝ wɪθaʊt səpɔɹt. ʃi wʊɾə ʃaʊɾəd ɪf ʃi kəd hæv. ɪf ʃi θɔt ðət bɝdʒɪɾ ən ði ʌðɝz kəd də mɔɹ ðən daɪ.

Suddenly sparks danced all over her from head to toe. She twitched helplessly, muscles spasming, saidar slipping from her grasp. She could see Vandene and Careane and Sareitha jerking as sparks flickered across them as well. Only a moment it lasted, but when the sparks vanished, Elayne felt as if she had been fed through a mangle. She had to hold on to Sareitha to stay on her feet, and Sareitha clung to her as hard. Vandene and Careane were supporting one another, swaying, each with her chin on the other's shoulder. Falion and Marillin wore startled expressions, but the light of the Power enveloped them in heartbeats. Elayne felt the shield fasten on to her, saw them settle on the other three. There was no need for binding. Any of them would have fallen over without support. She would have shouted if she could have. If she thought that Birgitte and the others could do more than die.

fɔɹ wɪmən ɪleɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɛntɝd ðə ɹum. æn zɹəmin ən təmeɪl kɪndɝəd. tʃɛzməl ɛmɹi ən ɛlʒɹɪθ ɑndɑɹ. fɔɹ blæk sɪstɝz. ʃi kəɾ əv wɛpt. sɝaɪðə ɡɹoʊn sɔfli.

Four women Elayne recognized entered the room. Asne Zeramene and Temaile Kinderode. Chesmal Emry and Eldrith Jhondar. Four Black sisters. She could have wept. Sareitha groaned softly.

"waɪ dɪd jə weɪt soʊ lɔŋ?" æn dɪmændəɾ ə fæljən ən mɑɹilɪn. ðə sɑldəiənz dɑɹk tɪltəɾ aɪz wɝ æŋɡɹi. "aɪ juz ðɪs soʊ ðeɪ wʊdn fil əs ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌt waɪ dɪd jə dʒʌst stæn ðɛɹ?" ʃi weɪvd ə smɔl, bɛn blæk ɹɑd, pɝhæps ən ɪntʃ ɪn daɪæməɾɝ, ðət hæɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒli dʌl lʊk. ðə θɪŋ sim tə fæsəneɪt hɝ. "ə 'ɡɪft' fɹəm mɑɡiɾin. ə wɛpən fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. aɪ kən kɪl ə mæn əɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz wɪð ðɪs, əɹ dʒʌst stʌn ɪm ɪf aɪ wɑnə pʊɾ ɪm tə ðə kwɛstʃən."

"Why did you wait so long?" Asne demanded of Falion and Marillin. The Saldaean's dark tilted eyes were angry. "I used this so they wouldn't feel us embrace saidar, but why did you just stand there?" She waved a small, bent black rod, perhaps an inch in diameter, that had a strangely dull look. The thing seemed to fascinate her. "A 'gift' from Moghedien. A weapon from the Age of Legends. I can kill a man at a hundred paces with this, or just stun him if I want to put him to the question."

"aɪ kən kɪl ə mæn ɪf aɪ kən si hɪm," tʃɛzməl sɛd skɔɹnfəli. tɔl ən hænsəm, ʃi wɑz ði ɪmədʒ ʌv aɪsi ɛɹəɡəns.

"I can kill a man if I can see him," Chesmal said scornfully. Tall and handsome, she was the image of icy arrogance.

æn snɪft. "bʌt maɪ tɑɹɡət kəd bi sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə hʌnʒɹəd sɪstɝz, ən nɑt wʌn wəd noʊ wʌt kɪl hɪm."

Asne sniffed. "But my target could be surrounded by a hundred sisters, and not one would know what killed him."

"aɪ səpoʊz ɪts ɪts juzɪz," tʃɛzməl ədmɪɾəd ɪn ɡɹʌdʒɪŋ toʊnz. "waɪ dɪd jə dʒʌst stæn ðɛɹ?"

"I suppose it has its uses," Chesmal admitted in grudging tones. "Why did you just stand there?"

"ðeɪ hæɾ əs ʃildɪd," fæljən sɛd bɪɾɝli.

"They had us shielded," Falion said bitterly.

ɛlʒɹɪθs bɹɛθ kɑt, ən ʃi pʊɾ ə plʌmp hæn tə ə ɹaʊn tʃik. "ðæts ɪmpɑsəbəl. ənlɛs. . . ." hɝ dɑɹk aɪz ʃɑɹpənd. "ðeɪv dɪskʌvɝɾ ə weɪ tə haɪd ðə ɡloʊ, tə haɪd ðɛɹ wivz. naʊ, ðət wəd bi moʊs jusfəl."

Eldrith's breath caught, and she put a plump hand to a round cheek. "That's impossible. Unless. . . ." Her dark eyes sharpened. "They've discovered a way to hide the glow, to hide their weaves. Now, that would be most useful."

"ju hæv maɪ θæŋks fəɹ jəɹ taɪmli ɹɛskju," ʃieɪn sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ, "bʌt juv ə ɹizən fəɹ kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ tənaɪt? dɪd mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛn ju?"

"You have my thanks for your timely rescue," Shiaine said, rising, "but do you have a reason for coming here tonight? Did Moridin send you?"

æn tʃænəld ə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ ðət stʃɹʌk ʃieɪnz tʃik wɪð ə laʊd kɹæk, stæɡɝɪŋ hɝ. "kip ə sɪvəl tʌŋ ɪn jəɹ maʊθ, ən pɝhæps wɪl lɛt jə liv wɪð ʌs. əɹ wi kən liv jə bɪhaɪn dɛd." ʃieɪnz tʃik wɑz ɹɛɾənd, bʌɾ əɹ hænz ɹɪmeɪn əɾ əɹ saɪdz. hɝ feɪs wɑz ɪkspɹɛʃənləs.

Asne channeled a flow of Air that struck Shiaine's cheek with a loud crack, staggering her. "Keep a civil tongue in your mouth, and perhaps we'll let you leave with us. Or we can leave you behind dead." Shiaine's cheek was reddened, but her hands remained at her sides. Her face was expressionless.

"ɪleɪnz ði oʊnli wʌn wi nid," təmeɪl sɛd. ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi ɪn ə fɑks-feɪst weɪ, ɔlmoʊst ə fɹædʒəl tʃaɪld ɪn əpɪɹəns dɪspaɪɾ əɹ eɪdʒləs feɪs, bʌɾ əɹ blu aɪz hɛld ən ənhɛlθi laɪt. ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ lɪps wɪð ðə tɪp ə hɝ tʌŋ. "aɪɾ ɛndʒɔɪ pleɪɪŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝz, bʌt ðeɪd bi ə bɝɾən wi doʊnt nid."

"Elayne's the only one we need," Temaile said. She was pretty in a fox-faced way, almost a fragile child in appearance despite her ageless face, but her blue eyes held an unhealthy light. She touched her lips with the tip of her tongue. "I'd enjoy playing with the others, but they'd be a burden we don't need."

"ɪf jəɹ gɑnə kɪl ðɛm," mɑɹilɪn sɛɾ əz ðoʊ dɪskʌsɪŋ ðə pɹaɪs ə bɹɛd, "spɛɹ kɛɝin. ʃiz wʌn ʌv ʌs."

"If you're going to kill them," Marillin said as though discussing the price of bread, "spare Careane. She is one of us."

"ə ɡɪft fɹəm æɾɪliz," vændin mɝmɝd, ən kɛɝinz aɪz wɛn vɛɹi waɪd. hɝ maʊθ oʊpənd, bʌt noʊ saʊn keɪm aʊt. ðə tu wɪmən sæɡd ən fɛl tə ðə kɑɹpət. vændin bɪɡæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊʃ hɝsɛlf ʌp, bʌt kɛɝin leɪ stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə silɪŋ, ðə hɪlt ə vændinz bɛl naɪf pɹoʊtʃɹuɾɪŋ fɹəm bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛstboʊn.

"A gift from Adeleas," Vandene murmured, and Careane's eyes went very wide. Her mouth opened, but no sound came out. The two women sagged and fell to the carpet. Vandene began trying to push herself up, but Careane lay staring at the ceiling, the hilt of Vandene's belt knife protruding from beneath her breastbone.

ðə ɡloʊ sɝaʊndəd tʃɛzməl, ən ʃi tʌtʃt vændin wɪð ə kɑmplɛks wiv ə faɪɝ, ɝθ ən wɔɾɝ. ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən kəlæpst əz ɪf əɹ boʊnz hæd mɛltəd. ðə seɪm wiv tʌtʃt sɝaɪðə, ən ʃi pʊld ɪleɪn daʊn ətɑp əɹ əz ʃi fɛl. sɝaɪðəz aɪz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡleɪzɪŋ.

The glow surrounded Chesmal, and she touched Vandene with a complex weave of Fire, Earth and Water. The white-haired woman collapsed as if her bones had melted. The same weave touched Sareitha, and she pulled Elayne down atop her as she fell. Sareitha's eyes were already glazing.

"ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz wɪl bi kʌmɪŋ naʊ," tʃɛzməl sɛd. "ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ kɪlɪŋ tə du."

"Their Warders will be coming now," Chesmal said. "A little more killing to do."

ɹʌn, bɝdʒɪt, ɪleɪn θɔt, wɪʃɪŋ ðə bɑn kəd kæɹi wɝdz. ɹʌn!

Run, Birgitte, Elayne thought, wishing the bond could carry words. Run!

tʃæptɝ θɝɾitu

CHAPTER 32

tə kip ðə bɑɹɡən bɝdʒɪt wɑz linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə stoʊn wɔl ə ðə θɹi-stɔɹi haʊs, θɪŋkɪŋ sædli ʌv ɡeɪɾəl, wən ðə bʌndəl ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ən fɪzɪkəl sɛnseɪʃənz ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd, hɝ əwɛɹnəs ʌv ɪleɪn, sʌɾənli spæzmd. ðət wɑz ði oʊnli wɝd fəɹ ɪt. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz læstəd dʒʌst ə moʊmənt, bʌɾ æftɝwɝd, ðə bɑnd wɑz fʊl ʌv . . . lɪmpnəs. ɪleɪn wɑz kɑnʃəs, bʌɾ ənstɛɾi. ʃi wɑz ʌnəfɹeɪd, haʊɛvɝ. stɪl, bɝdʒɪt θɹu bæk əɹ kloʊk ən muv tə ðə kɔɹnɝ tə pɪɹ ʌp fʊl mun stʃɹit. ɪleɪn kəd bi tu bɹeɪv fəɹ əɹ oʊn ɡʊd. ðə hɑɹɾəst θɪŋ əbaʊt biɪŋ ɪleɪnz wɔɹɾɝ wɑz kipɪŋ əɹ fɹəm ɛndeɪnʒɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf bɪɑnd nid. noʊbɑdi wɑz ɪndəstʃɹʌktɪbəl, bʌt ðə blʌɾi wʊmən θɔt ʃi blʌɾi wɛl wɑz. hɝ sɪdʒəl ʃʊɾə bɪn ən aɪɝn laɪən ɹæðɝ ðən ə ɡoʊldən lɪli. ðət laɪt ʃoʊn ɪn ðə wɪndoʊ, spɪlɪŋ ə peɪl pul ɪndə ðə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹit, ən ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə saʊn ɪksɛp fəɹ ə kæt jaʊlɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə naɪt.

To Keep the Bargain Birgitte was leaning against the stone wall of the three-story house, thinking sadly of Gaidal, when the bundle of emotions and physical sensations in the back of her head, her awareness of Elayne, suddenly spasmed. That was the only word for it. Whatever it was lasted just a moment, but afterward, the bond was full of . . . limpness. Elayne was conscious, but unsteady. She was unafraid, however. Still, Birgitte threw back her cloak and moved to the corner to peer up Full Moon Street. Elayne could be too brave for her own good. The hardest thing about being Elayne's Warder was keeping her from endangering herself beyond need. Nobody was indestructible, but the bloody woman thought she bloody well was. Her sigil should have been an iron lion rather than a golden lily. That light shone in the window, spilling a pale pool into the narrow street, and there was not a sound except for a cat yowling somewhere in the night.

"sɝaɪðə filz . . . mʌzi," nɛd jɑɹmən mʌɾɝd bɪsaɪd hɝ. ðə tɔl jʌŋ wɔɹɾɝz bɔɪɪʃ feɪs wɑz ə ɡɹɪm ʃæɾoʊd mæsk ɪnsaɪd ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk. "ʃi filz wik."

"Sareitha feels . . . muzzy," Ned Yarman muttered beside her. The tall young Warder's boyish face was a grim shadowed mask inside the hood of his cloak. "She feels weak."

bɝdʒɪt bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə ði ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz kɹaʊɾɪŋ əɹ kloʊs, stoʊn-feɪst ən hɑɹd-aɪd. ðət wɑz klɪɹ ɪnʌf ivən baɪ munlaɪt. sʌmθɪŋ hæd hæpən tə ɔl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪt simd. bʌt wʌt? "ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn sɛd ʃid ʃaʊɾ ɪf ʃi niɾəd ʌs," ʃi toʊl ðɛm, əz mʌtʃ tə ɹiəʃʊɹ hɝsɛlf əz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ivən ɪf boʊθ kɛɝin ən sɝaɪðə wɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn hɛlpləs tə də ɛniθɪŋ lɪŋkt, ən əpɛɹənli wʌtɛvɝ hæd hæpən hæd hæpən tə ðɛm, əz wɛl. bɝn hɝ, ʃi ʃʊɾə ɪnsɪstəd ðət ʃi ən ði ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz ɡoʊ əlɔŋ.

Birgitte became aware of the other Warders crowding her close, stone-faced and hard-eyed. That was clear enough even by moonlight. Something had happened to all of the Aes Sedai, it seemed. But what? "The Lady Elayne said she'd shout if she needed us," she told them, as much to reassure herself as anything else. Even if both Careane and Sareitha were Darkfriends, they would have been helpless to do anything linked, and apparently whatever had happened had happened to them, as well. Burn her, she should have insisted that she and the other Warders go along.

"kɛɝin woʊn bi plizd ɪf wi ɪntɝfɪɹ nidləsli," ɛnɝ koʊsən sɛd kwaɪətli. bleɪd slɪm ən dɑɹk, wɪð tʌtʃəz ʌv waɪɾ ɪn ɪz taɪtli kɝl blæk hɛɹ ən ʃɔɹt bɪɹd, hi əpɪɹd kəmplitli əɾ iz. "aɪ seɪ wi weɪt. ʃi filz kɑnfəɾənt, wʌtɛvɝz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn."

"Careane won't be pleased if we interfere needlessly," Venr Kosaan said quietly. Blade slim and dark, with touches of white in his tightly curled black hair and short beard, he appeared completely at ease. "I say we wait. She feels confident, whatever's going on."

"mɔɹ soʊ ðən ʃi dɪd ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn," sɪɛɹəl ɑɹdʒunə æɾəd, ɝnɪŋ ɪm ə ʃɑɹp ɡlæns fɹəm ɛnɝ. stɪl ʃɔɹɾ ə hɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz, sɪɛɹəl simd ɔl boʊnz, ðoʊ hɪz ʃoʊldɝz wɝ waɪd.

"More so than she did going in," Cieryl Arjuna added, earning him a sharp glance from Venr. Still short of his middle years, Cieryl seemed all bones, though his shoulders were wide.

bɝdʒɪt nɑɾəd. ɪleɪn wɑz kɑnfəɾənt, tu. bʌt ðɛn, ɪleɪn wəd fil sɛlf-əʃʊɹd wɔkɪŋ ən ənɹævəlɪŋ ɹoʊp stʃɹɛtʃt oʊvɝ ə pɪt fʊl ə ʃɑɹp steɪks. ə dɔɡ bɪɡæn bɑɹkɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ən ðə jaʊlɪŋ kæt wɛn saɪlənt, bʌɾ ʌðɝ dɑɡz ænsɝd ðə fɝst ɪn ə spɹɛɾɪŋ ɹɪpəl ðət feɪɾəd əweɪ əz sʌɾənli əz ɪt hæd bɪɡʌn.

Birgitte nodded. Elayne was confident, too. But then, Elayne would feel self-assured walking an unraveling rope stretched over a pit full of sharp stakes. A dog began barking in the distance, and the yowling cat went silent, but other dogs answered the first in a spreading ripple that faded away as suddenly as it had begun.

ðeɪ weɪɾəd, wɪð bɝdʒɪt fɹɛɾɪŋ ɪn saɪləns. sʌɾənli, ɛnɝ ɡɹaʊld ən oʊθ ən ʃɛɾ ɪz kloʊk. ðə nɛkst ɪnstənt, hɪz bleɪd wɑz ɪn ɪz hæn ən i wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp ðə stʃɹit fɑloʊd baɪ sɪɛɹəl ən teɪvən, kloʊks bɪloʊɪŋ bɪhaɪnd, ðɛɹ bleɪdz bɛɹd, tu. bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn tu stɛps, jeɪɛm ɡeɪv ə waɪl kɹaɪ. ənʃiðɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd, hi θɹu hɪz kloʊk daʊn ən ɹeɪst æftɝ ði ʌðɝ θɹi əɾ ə spid ðət bɪlaɪɾ ɪz eɪdʒ. bɛloʊɪŋ wɪð ɹeɪdʒ, nɛd ɹæn, tu, ðə stil ɪn ɪz fɪst ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə munlaɪt. fjʊɹi stæb θɹu ðə bɑnd, laɪk ðə bæɾəl fjʊɹi ðət tʊk səm mɛn. ən sædnəs, tu, bʌt stɪl noʊ fɪɹ.

They waited, with Birgitte fretting in silence. Suddenly, Venr growled an oath and shed his cloak. The next instant, his blade was in his hand and he was running up the street followed by Cieryl and Tavan, cloaks billowing behind, their blades bared, too. Before they had gone two steps, Jaem gave a wild cry. Unsheathing his sword, he threw his cloak down and raced after the other three at a speed that belied his age. Bellowing with rage, Ned ran, too, the steel in his fist glittering in the moonlight. Fury stabbed through the bond, like the battle fury that took some men. And sadness, too, but still no fear.

bɝdʒɪt hɝd ðə sɑft ɹæsp ə sɔɹdz biɪŋ ənʃið bɪhaɪn əɹ ən spʌn, kloʊk flɛɹɪŋ. "pʊt ðoʊz ʌp! ðəɹ noʊ jus hɪɹ."

Birgitte heard the soft rasp of swords being unsheathed behind her and spun, cloak flaring. "Put those up! They're no use here."

"aɪ noʊ wʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn minz əz wɛl əz ju, maɪ leɪɾi," jʊɹɪθ sɛɾ ɪn kɔɹtli æksɛns, oʊbeɪɪŋ smuðli. ən wɪð klɪɹ ɹɪlʌktəns. lin ən əz tɔl əz moʊs mɛn, ðə sɑldəiən dɪnaɪd biɪŋ nɑbli bɔɹn, bʌt wɛnɛvɝ ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən keɪm ɝaʊn tə wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn bɪfɔɹ swɛɹɪŋ ði oʊθ əz ə hʌntɝ fəɹ ðə hɔɹn, ʃi ɔlweɪz ɡeɪv wʌn ə hɝ ɹɛɹ smaɪlz ən tʃeɪnʒd ðə sʌbʒɪkt. ʃi wɑz skɪld wɪð ðət sɔɹd, haʊɛvɝ. "ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ daɪɪŋ - "

"I know what the Warders running in means as well as you, my Lady," Yurith said in courtly accents, obeying smoothly. And with clear reluctance. Lean and as tall as most men, the Saldaean denied being nobly born, but whenever the conversation came around to what she had done before swearing the oath as a Hunter for the Horn, she always gave one of her rare smiles and changed the subject. She was skilled with that sword, however. "If the Aes Sedai are dying - "

"ɪleɪn ɪz əlaɪv," bɝdʒɪt kʌɾ ɪn. əlaɪv, ən ɪn tʃɹʌbəl. "ʃiz əɹ kənsɝn, naʊ, bʌt wɪl niɾ ə lɑt mɔɹ sɔɹdz tə ɹɛskju hɝ." ən mɔɹ ðən sɔɹdz. "sʌmbɑɾi kɑlɝ ðət mæn!" tu ɡɑɹdzwɪmən siz hɑɹks koʊt bɪfɔɹ i kəd slɪp əweɪ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. əpɛɹənli hi hæd noʊ wɪʃ tə steɪ nɪɹ wɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd daɪd. niðɝ dɪd ʃi. "ɡæðɝ ðə . . . ði ɛkstʃɹə hɔɹsəz ən fɑloʊ mi," ʃi sɛd, swɪŋɪŋ ɪndə æɹoʊz sæɾəl. "æn ɹaɪd laɪk faɪɝ!" ʃi suɾəd əɹ wɝdz, dɪɡɪŋ əɹ hilz ɪndə ðə ɹeɪnʒi ɡɹeɪ ɡɛldɪŋz flæŋks wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ.

"Elayne is alive," Birgitte cut in. Alive, and in trouble. "She's our concern, now, but we'll need a lot more swords to rescue her." And more than swords. "Somebody collar that man!" Two Guardswomen seized Hark's coat before he could slip away into the darkness. Apparently he had no wish to stay near where Aes Sedai had died. Neither did she. "Gather the . . . the extra horses and follow me," she said, swinging into Arrow's saddle. "And ride like fire!" She suited her words, digging her heels into the rangy gray gelding's flanks without waiting.

ɪt wɑz ə waɪld ɡæləp θɹu dɑɹk, twɪstɪŋ stʃɹits wɛɹ pipəl wɝ dʒʌs bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə əpɪɹ. ʃi ɹeɪn æɹoʊ ɝaʊn ðə fju kɑɹts ən wæɡənz aʊt ðɪs ɝli, bʌt mɛn ən wɪmən hæd tə lip fɹəm əɹ pæθ, ɔfən ʃeɪkɪŋ fɪsts ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ kɝsɪz. ʃi oʊnli ɝdʒ ðə ɡɛldɪŋ fəɹ mɔɹ spid, hɝ kloʊk flæpɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹitʃt ðə mɑndəl ɡeɪt, ɪleɪn wɑz muvɪŋ. ʃi hæd bɪn ənsɝɾən ət fɝst, bʌt ðəɹ kəd bi noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ɪt naʊ. ɪleɪn wɑz muvɪŋ nɔɹθist əɾ əbaʊt wɔkɪŋ spid. ðə bɑn sɛd ʃi wɑz tu wɑbəli tə wɔk fɑɹ, meɪbi tə wɔk əɾ ɔl, bʌɾ ə wæɡən wəd meɪk ðə seɪm peɪs. ðə skaɪ wɑz tɝnɪŋ ɡɹeɪ. haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd ɡæðɝ wʌt wɑz niɾəd? ɪn ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi, ðə stʃɹit spaɪɹəld ɪnwɝd, ɹaɪzɪŋ pæs taʊɝz ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd kʌlɝz təwɔɹd ðə ɡoʊldən doʊmz ən peɪl spaɪɹz ə ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs, ətɑp ðə haɪəst ə keɪɛmlɪnz hɪlz. əz ʃi ɡæləpt ɝaʊn ðə ɹɪm ə ðə kwinz plɑzə, soʊlʒɝz stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ fɛd fɹəm blæk kɛɾəlz ətɑp pʊʃbæɹoʊz, kʊks lædlɪŋ səm sɔɹɾ ə bɹaʊn stu ɑntu tɪn pleɪts, ən ɛvɹi mæn ʃi kəd si wɔɹ ɪz bɹɛstpleɪɾ ən hæɾ ɪz hɛlmət hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. ɡʊd. ɛvɹi moʊmən seɪvd wɑz ə moʊmən təwɔɹd seɪvɪŋ ɪleɪn.

It was a wild gallop through dark, twisting streets where people were just beginning to appear. She reined Arrow around the few carts and wagons out this early, but men and women had to leap from her path, often shaking fists and shouting curses. She only urged the gelding for more speed, her cloak flapping behind. Before she reached the Mondel Gate, Elayne was moving. She had been uncertain at first, but there could be no mistaking it now. Elayne was moving northeast at about walking speed. The bond said she was too wobbly to walk far, maybe to walk at all, but a wagon would make the same pace. The sky was turning gray. How long before she could gather what was needed? In the Inner City, the street spiraled inward, rising past towers glittering in a hundred colors toward the golden domes and pale spires of the Royal Palace, atop the highest of Caemlyn's hills. As she galloped around the rim of the Queen's Plaza, soldiers stared at her. They were being fed from black kettles atop pushbarrows, cooks ladling some sort of brown stew onto tin plates, and every man she could see wore his breastplate and had his helmet hanging from his sword hilt. Good. Every moment saved was a moment toward saving Elayne.

tu laɪnz ʌv ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɝ pɹæktəsɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ ɪn ðə kwinz steɪbliɑɹd wən ʃi ɡæləpt ɪn, bʌt ðə læθ bleɪdz stɑpt ɹætlɪŋ wən ʃi flʌŋ hɝsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl, lɛɾ æɹoʊz ɹeɪnz dʒɹɑp ən ɹæn təwɔɹd ðə kɑləneɪd. "hædɔɹə, ɹʌn tɛl ðə wɪndfɪndɝz tə mit mi ɪn ðə mæp ɹum ɹaɪɾ əweɪ!" ʃi ʃaʊɾəd wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ. "ɔl ə ðɛm! səntɝ, jə də ðə seɪm fəɹ kæptən ɡaɪbɑn! ən əv ənʌðɝ hɔɹs sæɾəld fəɹ mi!" æɹoʊ wɑz pleɪɾ aʊt fəɹ tədeɪ. ʃi wɑz pæs ðə kɑləmz baɪ ðət taɪm, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk bæk tə si wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ oʊbeɪɪŋ. ðeɪ wəd bi.

Two lines of Guardswomen were practicing the sword in the Queen's Stableyard when she galloped in, but the lath blades stopped rattling when she flung herself out of the saddle, let Arrow's reins drop and ran toward the colonnade. "Hadora, run tell the Windfinders to meet me in the Map Room right away!" she shouted without slowing. "All of them! Sanetre, you do the same for Captain Guybon! And have another horse saddled for me!" Arrow was played out for today. She was past the columns by that time, but she did not look back to see whether they were obeying. They would be.

ʃi ɹeɪs θɹu tæpəstʃɹi-hʌŋ hɔlweɪz ən ʌp swipɪŋ mɑɹbəl stɛɹz, ɡɑt lɔst ən ʃaʊɾəd kɝsɪz əz ʃi ɹitʃɹeɪst əɹ stɛps əɾ ə ɹʌn. lɪvɹid sɝvɪŋ mɛn ən wɪmən ɡeɪpt əz ðeɪ dɑdʒd aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ. ət læst ʃi ɹitʃt ðə laɪən-kɑɹv dɔɹz ə ðə mæp ɹum, wɛɹ ʃi pɔzd oʊnli lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə tɛl ðə tu bɝli ɡɑɹdzmɪn ɑn duɾi tə ədmɪt ðə wɪndfɪndɝz əz sun əz ðeɪ əpɪɹd, ðən wɛn ɪn. ɡaɪbɑn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ, ɪn ɪz bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪt wɪð ðə θɹi ɡoʊldən nɑts ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən daɪɛlɪn, dɛləkətli hoʊldɪŋ əɹ blu sɪlk skɝts ʌp əz ʃi muvd, ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə hjudʒ moʊzeɪɪk mæp, wɛɹ wɛl oʊvɝ ə dʌzən ɹɛd dɪsks mɑɹk ðə sɪɾiz nɔɹðɝn wɔl. nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ hæd ðəɹ bɪn soʊ mɛni əsɔls ət wʌns, nɑɾ ivən tɛn, bʌt bɝdʒɪt spɛɹd ðə dɪsks bɛɹli ə ɡlæns.

She raced through tapestry-hung hallways and up sweeping marble stairs, got lost and shouted curses as she retraced her steps at a run. Liveried serving men and women gaped as they dodged out of her way. At last she reached the lion-carved doors of the Map Room, where she paused only long enough to tell the two burly Guardsmen on duty to admit the Windfinders as soon as they appeared, then went in. Guybon was already there, in his burnished breastplate with the three golden knots on his shoulder, and Dyelin, delicately holding her blue silk skirts up as she moved, the pair of them frowning at the huge mosaic map, where well over a dozen red discs marked the city's northern wall. Never before had there been so many assaults at once, not even ten, but Birgitte spared the discs barely a glance.

"ɡaɪbɑn, aɪ niɾ ɛvɹi hɔɹs ən hælbɹd jə kən mʌstɝ," ʃi sɛd, ənpɪnɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ən tɔsɪŋ ɪt daʊn ɑn əɹ lɔŋ ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl. "ðə kɹɔsboʊmən ən ɑɹtʃɝz wɪl əv tə hændəl ɛniθɪŋ ðət kɹɑps ʌp baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz fəɹ ə fju aʊɝz. ɪleɪnz bɪn kæptʃɝd baɪ dɑɹkfɹɛn ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kæɹi hɝ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi." səm ə ðə klɝks ən mɛsənʒɝz bɪɡæn mɝmɝɪŋ, bʌt mɪstʃɹəs ɑnfɝd saɪlənst əm wɪð ə ʃɑɹp ɔɹɾɝ tə si tə ðɛɹ wɝk. bɝdʒɪɾ aɪd ðə kʌlɝfəl mæp ɪn ðə flɔɹ, mɛʒɝɪŋ dɪstənsəz. ɪleɪn sim tə bi muvɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə sʌnɹaɪz ɡeɪɾ ən ðə ɹoʊd tə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn, bʌɾ ivən ɪf ðeɪ juzd wʌn ə ðə smɔlɝ ɡeɪts, ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn tu fɑɹ tə bi eɪmɪŋ əɾ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt ði istɝn wɔl. "ðeɪl pɹɑbli hæv əɹ θɹu ðə ɡeɪts baɪ ðə taɪm wɝ ɹɛɾi tə muv. wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə tʃɹævəl tə dʒʌs ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪdʒ ist ə ðə sɪɾi." ən teɪk wʌt wɑz gɑnə hæpən aʊɾ ə ðə stʃɹits, əweɪ fɹəm pipəlz hoʊmz. ɪt wəd bi bɛɾɝ aʊɾ ɪn ði oʊpən ɪn ɛni keɪs. ɪn ðət tæŋɡəl ə stʃɹits, wɪð hɔɹsmən ən hælbɝdmən dʒæm təɡɛðɝ, ðəɹ wəd bi tu mɛni pipəl tə ɡɛɾ ɪn ðə weɪ, tu mʌtʃ tʃæns ʌv æksəɾənts.

"Guybon, I need every horse and halberd you can muster," she said, unpinning her cloak and tossing it down on her long writing table. "The crossbowmen and archers will have to handle anything that crops up by themselves for a few hours. Elayne's been captured by Darkfriend Aes Sedai, and they're trying to carry her out of the city." Some of the clerks and messengers began murmuring, but Mistress Anford silenced them with a sharp order to see to their work. Birgitte eyed the colorful map in the floor, measuring distances. Elayne seemed to be moving toward the Sunrise Gate and the road to the River Erinin, but even if they used one of the smaller gates, they had gone too far to be aiming at anything but the eastern wall. "They'll probably have her through the gates by the time we're ready to move. We're going to Travel to just this side of the ridge east of the city." And take what was going to happen out of the streets, away from people's homes. It would be better out in the open in any case. In that tangle of streets, with horsemen and halberdmen jammed together, there would be too many people to get in the way, too much chance of accidents.

ɡaɪbɑn nɑɾəd, ɔlɹɛɾi ɪʃuɪŋ tɝs ɔɹɾɝz ðət bɹaʊn-klæd klɝks kɑpid daʊn heɪstəli fəɹ ɪm tə saɪn ən pæs tə jʌŋ mɛsənʒɝz ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-waɪɾ u wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ əz sun əz ðə peɪpɝ wɑz ɪn hænd. ðə bɔɪz' feɪsəz wɝ fɹaɪɾənd. bɝdʒɪt hæd noʊ taɪm fəɹ əɹ oʊn fɪɹ. ɪleɪn fɛl nʌn, ən ʃi wɑz ə pɹɪznɝ. sædnəs, jɛs, bʌt noʊ fɪɹ.

Guybon nodded, already issuing terse orders that brown-clad clerks copied down hastily for him to sign and pass to young messengers in red-and-white who went running as soon as the paper was in hand. The boys' faces were frightened. Birgitte had no time for her own fear. Elayne felt none, and she was a prisoner. Sadness, yes, but no fear.

"wi sɝɾənli nid tə ɹɛskju ɪleɪn," daɪɛlɪn sɛd kɑmli, "bʌt ʃɪl hɑɹdli θæŋk jə ɪf jə ɡɪv ɛɹəmɪlə keɪɛmlɪn baɪ duɪŋ ɪt. nɑt kaʊntɪŋ ðə mɛn ɪn ðə taʊɝz ən hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɡeɪts, ɔlmoʊs hæf ðə tʃɹeɪn soʊlʒɝz ən ɑɹmmɪn ɪn ðə sɪɾi ɑɹ ɑn ðə nɔɹðɝn wɔl. ɪf jə stʃɹɪp əweɪ ðə ɹɛst, wʌn mɔɹ ətæk wɪl ɡeɪn ə stʃɹɛtʃ ə ðə wɔl. kɹɔsboʊz ən baʊz əloʊn woʊn stɑp ðɛm. wʌns ðeɪv ðæt, ɛɹəmɪləz fɔɹsɪz wɪl pɔɹ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝwɛlm wʌt jə pɹəpoʊz tə liv. jəl əv nitli ɹɪvɝst əɹ pəzɪʃənz, ən wɝsən jʊɹz. ɛɹəmɪlə wɪl əv keɪɛmlɪn, ən ɪleɪn wɪl bi aʊtsaɪd wɪθaʊɾ ɪnʌf ɑɹmmɪn tə ɡɛt bæk ɪn. ənlɛs ðiz dɑɹkfɹɛnz əv sʌmhaʊ smʌɡəld ən ɑɹmi ɪnsaɪd keɪɛmlɪn, ə fju hʌnʒɹəd mɛn wɪl də əz wɛl əz θaʊzənz."

"We certainly need to rescue Elayne," Dyelin said calmly, "but she'll hardly thank you if you give Arymilla Caemlyn by doing it. Not counting the men in the towers and holding the gates, almost half the trained soldiers and armsmen in the city are on the northern wall. If you strip away the rest, one more attack will gain a stretch of the wall. Crossbows and bows alone won't stop them. Once they have that, Arymilla's forces will pour into the city, enough to overwhelm what you propose to leave. You will have neatly reversed our positions, and worsened yours. Arymilla will have Caemlyn, and Elayne will be outside without enough armsmen to get back in. Unless these Darkfriends have somehow smuggled an army inside Caemlyn, a few hundred men will do as well as thousands."

bɝdʒɪt skaʊld ət hɝ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə laɪk daɪɛlɪn. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ waɪ, ɪɡzækli, bʌt daɪɛlɪn hæd dʒʌs meɪɾ əɹ bɹɪsəl ət fɝst saɪt. ʃi wɑz fɛɹli sɝɾən ði ʌðɝ wʊmən fɛl ðə seɪm əbaʊt hɝ. ʃi kəd nɛvɝ seɪ "ʌp" wɪθaʊt daɪɛlɪn seɪɪŋ "daʊn." "ju kɛɹ əbaʊt pʊɾɪŋ ɪleɪn ɑn ðə θɹoʊn, daɪɛlɪn. aɪ kɛɹ əbaʊt kipɪŋ əɹ əlaɪv tə maʊn ðət θɹoʊn. əɹ nɑt, soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃiz əlaɪv. aɪ oʊ hɝ maɪ laɪf, ən aɪ woʊn lɛt hɝz tʃɹɪkəl əweɪ ɪn dɑɹkfɹɛn hænz." daɪɛlɪn snɪft ən wɛn bæk tə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə ɹɛd dɪsks əz ɪf ʃi kəd si ðə soʊlʒɝz faɪɾɪŋ, hɝ fɹaʊn dipənɪŋ ðə laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz.

Birgitte scowled at her. She had never been able to like Dyelin. She did not know why, exactly, but Dyelin had just made her bristle at first sight. She was fairly certain the other woman felt the same about her. She could never say "up" without Dyelin saying "down." "You care about putting Elayne on the throne, Dyelin. I care about keeping her alive to mount that throne. Or not, so long as she's alive. I owe her my life, and I won't let hers trickle away in Darkfriend hands." Dyelin sniffed and went back to studying the red discs as if she could see the soldiers fighting, her frown deepening the lines at the corners of her eyes.

bɝdʒɪt klæspt əɹ hænz bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk ən fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə stæn stɪl. ʃi wɑntəd tə peɪs wɪð ɪmpeɪʃəns. ɪleɪn wɑz stɪl tʃɹʌnlɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə sʌnɹaɪz ɡeɪt. "ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ jə nid tə noʊ, ɡaɪbɑn. wɪl bi feɪsɪŋ ət lis tu ɛɛs sədaɪ, laɪkli mɔɹ, ən ðeɪ meɪ hæv ə wɛpən, ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət meɪks bɑlfaɪɝ. hæv jə ɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðæt?"

Birgitte clasped her hands behind her back and forced herself to stand still. She wanted to pace with impatience. Elayne was still trundling toward the Sunrise Gate. "There's something you need to know, Guybon. We'll be facing at least two Aes Sedai, likely more, and they may have a weapon, a ter'angreal that makes balefire. Have you ever heard of that?"

"nɛvɝ. ɪt saʊnz deɪnʒɝəs, ðoʊ."

"Never. It sounds dangerous, though."

"oʊ, ɪɾ ɪz. deɪnʒɝəs ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɪts pɹoʊhɪbəɾəd fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪn ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ivən dɑɹkfɹɛnz stɑp juzɪŋ ɪt." ʃi bɑɹkt ə bɪɾɝ læf. ɔl ʃi nu ʌv bɑlfaɪɝ naʊ wɑz wʌɾ ɪleɪn hæd toʊl hɝ. ɪt hæd kʌm fɹəm əɹ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, jɛt ðəɾ oʊnli meɪd mæɾɝz wɝs. wəɾ ɔl ə hɝ mɛmɹiz ɡoʊ? ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi hæd lɔst ɛni ɹisənli, bʌt haʊ wəd ʃi noʊ ɪf ʃi hæd? ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ bɪts ə ðə faʊndɪŋ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, pisəz ʌv wʌt ʃi ən ɡeɪɾəl hæd dʌn tə hɛlp ɪt bi faʊndəd, bʌt nʌθɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðæt. ɔl ə hɝ ɝliɝ mɛmɹiz wɝ jɛstɝdeɪz smoʊk.

"Oh, it is. Dangerous enough that it's prohibited for Aes Sedai. In the War of the Shadow, even Darkfriends stopped using it." She barked a bitter laugh. All she knew of balefire now was what Elayne had told her. It had come from her in the first place, yet that only made matters worse. Would all of her memories go? She did not think she had lost any recently, but how would she know if she had? She could remember bits of the founding of the White Tower, pieces of what she and Gaidal had done to help it be founded, but nothing before that. All of her earlier memories were yesterday's smoke.

"wɛl, ət list wɪl əv ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv əɹ oʊn," ɡaɪbɑn sɛd, saɪnɪŋ ənʌðɝ ɔɹɾɝ.

"Well, at least we'll have Aes Sedai of our own," Guybon said, signing another order.

"ðeɪɹ ɔl dɛd, ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪleɪn," ʃi toʊld ɪm flætli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə ɡɪl ðæt. daɪɛlɪn ɡæspt, hɝ feɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ peɪl. wʌn ə ðə klɝks klæspt əɹ hænz tə hɝ maʊθ, ən ənʌðɝ nɑkt oʊvɝ ɪz ɪŋk dʒɑɹ. ði ɪŋk fæn əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəltɑp ɪn ə blæk stʃɹim ən bɪɡæn dʒɹɪpɪŋ ɑntu ðə flɔɹ. ɹæðɝ ðən ɹipɹəmændɪŋ ðə mæn, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnfɝd stɛɾid hɝsɛlf wɪð ə hæn ɑn ənʌðɝ klɝks ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl. "aɪ hoʊp tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ ðæt," bɝdʒɪt wɛn ɑn, "bʌɾ aɪ kæn pɹɑməs ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðət wɝ gɑnə luz mɛn tədeɪ. meɪbi ə lɑɾ ə mɛn."

"They're all dead, except for Elayne," she told him flatly. There was no way to gild that. Dyelin gasped, her face growing pale. One of the clerks clasped her hands to her mouth, and another knocked over his ink jar. The ink fanned across the tabletop in a black stream and began dripping onto the floor. Rather than reprimanding the man, Mistress Anford steadied herself with a hand on another clerk's writing table. "I hope to make up for that," Birgitte went on, "but I can't promise anything except that we're going to lose men today. Maybe a lot of men."

ɡaɪbɑn stʃɹeɪɾənd. hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz θɔtfəl, hɪz heɪzəl aɪz stɛɾi. "ðæt wɪl meɪk fəɹ ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ deɪ," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "bʌt wɪl ɡɛt ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ bæk, wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɑst." ə sɑləd mæn, ɑɹlz ɡaɪbɑn, ən bɹeɪv. hi hæd dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾəd ðəɾ ɔfən ɪnʌf ɑn ðə wɔlz. tu ɡʊd-lʊkɪŋ fəɹ əɹ teɪst, ʌv kɔɹs.

Guybon straightened. His expression was thoughtful, his hazel eyes steady. "That will make for an interesting day," he said finally. "But we'll get the Daughter-Heir back, whatever the cost." A solid man, Charlz Guybon, and brave. He had demonstrated that often enough on the walls. Too good-looking for her taste, of course.

bɝdʒɪt ɹilaɪzd ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn peɪsɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ əkɹɔs ðə moʊzeɪɪk ən stɑpt. ʃi nu nʌθɪŋ ə biɪŋ ə dʒɛnɝəl, wʌtɛvɝ ɪleɪn θɔt, bʌt ʃi nu ðət ʃoʊɪŋ nɝvz kəɾ ɪnfɛkt ʌðɝz wɪð ðɛm. ɪleɪn wɑz əlaɪv. ðət wɑz ɔl ðət wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. əlaɪv ən muvɪŋ fɑɹðɝ əweɪ baɪ ðə mɪnət. ðə lɛft-hæn dɔɹ oʊpənd, ən wʌn ə ðə bɝli ɡɑɹdzmɪn ənaʊns ðət dʒulənjə foʊɾ ən kɛɹeɪl sɝtɑvni hæd ɹɪtɝnd. ɡaɪbɑn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ tə hɝ, bʌt wən ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, hi toʊl ðə mæn tə ədmɪt ðɛm.

Birgitte realized she had begun pacing back and forth across the mosaic and stopped. She knew nothing of being a general, whatever Elayne thought, but she knew that showing nerves could infect others with them. Elayne was alive. That was all that was important. Alive and moving farther away by the minute. The left-hand door opened, and one of the burly Guardsmen announced that Julanya Fote and Keraille Surtovni had returned. Guybon hesitated, looking to her, but when she said nothing, he told the man to admit them.

ðeɪ wɝ vɛɹi dɪfɹənt wɪmən, ɪn əpɪɹəns ət list, ðoʊ itʃ kæɹiɾ ə wʊɾən wɔkɪŋ stæf. dʒulənjə wɑz plʌmp ən pɹɪɾi, wɪð tʌtʃəz ʌv waɪɾ ɪn əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ, waɪl kɛɹeɪl wɑz ʃɔɹɾ ən slɪm, wɪð tɪltəd ɡɹin aɪz ən faɪɝi ɹɛd kɝlz. bɝdʒɪt wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðoʊz wɝ ðɛɹ ɹil neɪmz. ðiz kɪnswɪmən tʃeɪnʒd neɪmz əz izəli əz ʌðɝ wɪmən tʃeɪnʒd stɑkɪŋz. ðeɪ wɔɹ pleɪn wʊlənz suɾəbəl fəɹ kʌntʃɹi pɛdlɝz, wɪtʃ itʃ hæd bɪn ɪn ðə pæst, ən itʃ wɑz ə kin əbzɝvɝ, skɪld ət teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ ə hɝsɛlf. ðeɪ kəd tɔk ðɛɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə moʊst sɪtʃueɪʃənz, bʌt ðɛɹ sɪmpəl bɛl naɪvz wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli bleɪdz ðeɪ kæɹiɾ ən ðeɪ kəd sɝpɹaɪz ə stʃɹɔŋ mæn wɪð wʌt ðeɪ kəd də wɪð ðoʊz wɔkɪŋ stæfs. boʊθ ɔfɝd kɝtsiz. dʒulənjəz skɝts ən kloʊk wɝ dæmp ən splæʃt wɪð mʌɾ ɝaʊn ðə hɛm.

They were very different women, in appearance at least, though each carried a wooden walking staff. Julanya was plump and pretty, with touches of white in her dark hair, while Keraille was short and slim, with tilted green eyes and fiery red curls. Birgitte wondered whether those were their real names. These Kinswomen changed names as easily as other women changed stockings. They wore plain woolens suitable for country peddlers, which each had been in the past, and each was a keen observer, skilled at taking care of herself. They could talk their way out of most situations, but their simple belt knives were not the only blades they carried and they could surprise a strong man with what they could do with those walking staffs. Both offered curtsies. Julanya's skirts and cloak were damp and splashed with mud around the hem.

"ɛlɹin, lwɑn ən æbəl bɪɡæn bɹeɪkɪŋ kæmp ɝli ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, maɪ leɪɾi," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ oʊnli steɪd lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ə ðɛɹ dɝɛkʃən - nɔɹθ - bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ tə ɹipɔɹt."

"Ellorien, Luan and Abelle began breaking camp early this morning, my Lady," she said. "I only stayed long enough to make sure of their direction - north - before coming to report."

"ðə seɪm ɪz tʃɹu wɪð æɛmlɪn, ɑɝəθɛl ən pɛlɪvɑɹ, maɪ leɪɾi," kɛɹeɪl æɾəd. "ðeɪɹ kʌmɪŋ fəɹ keɪɛmlɪn."

"The same is true with Aemlyn, Arathelle and Pelivar, my Lady," Keraille added. "They're coming for Caemlyn."

bɝdʒɪt dɪd nɑt nid tə ɪɡzæmɪn ðə lɑɹdʒ mæp spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl wɪð ɪts mɑɹkɝz. dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn haʊ mʌɾi ðə ɹoʊdz wɝ, haʊ mʌtʃ ɹeɪn ðeɪ hæd tə kəntɛnd wɪð, ðeɪ kəd ɹitʃ ðə sɪɾi baɪ ðəɾ æftɝnun.
