"juv dʌn wɛl, boʊθ ə ju. ɡoʊ faɪn jʊɹsɛlvz hɑt bæθs. dʒju θɪŋk ðeɪv hæɾ ə tʃeɪnʒ ə hɑɹt?" ʃi æsk daɪɛlɪn wʌns ðə tu wɪmən hæd lɛft.

Birgitte did not need to examine the large map spread out on the table with its markers. Depending on how muddy the roads were, how much rain they had to contend with, they could reach the city by that afternoon. "You've done well, both of you. Go find yourselves hot baths. Do you think they've had a change of heart?" she asked Dyelin once the two women had left.

"noʊ," ðə wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən, ðən saɪɾ ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ fɪɹ ðə moʊs laɪkli θɪŋ ɪz ðəɾ ɛlɹin əz kənvɪns ði ʌðɝz tə səpɔɹɾ əɹ fəɹ ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. ðeɪ meɪ bi θɪŋkɪŋ tə dɪfiɾ ɛɹəmɪlə ən teɪk oʊvɝ ðə sidʒ. ðeɪv hæf əɡɛn əɹ nʌmbɝz, ən dʌbəl aʊɝz." ʃi lɛt ðət hæŋ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə seɪ ðə ɹɛst. ivən juzɪŋ kɪnswɪmən tə ʃɪf mɛn, ðeɪ wəd bi hɑɹd pɹɛs tə hoʊl ðə wɔl əɡɛns ðət mɛni.

"No," the woman replied without hesitation, then sighed and shook her head. "I fear the most likely thing is that Ellorien has convinced the others to support her for the Lion Throne. They may be thinking to defeat Arymilla and take over the siege. They have half again her numbers, and double ours." She let that hang. There was no need to say the rest. Even using Kinswomen to shift men, they would be hard pressed to hold the wall against that many.

"fɝst wi ɡɛɾ ɪleɪn bæk, ðən wi kən wɝi əbaʊt ðət lɑt," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. wɛɹ wɝ ðoʊz blʌɾi wɪndfɪndɝz?

"First we get Elayne back, then we can worry about that lot," Birgitte said. Where were those bloody Windfinders?

noʊ sunɝ dɪd ʃi hæv ðə θɔt ðən ðeɪ wɝ pæɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum bɪhaɪn tʃənɛl, ə ɹaɪəɾəs ɹeɪnboʊ ʌv sɪlks. ɪksɛp fəɹ ɹɪneɪl, læst ɪn laɪn ɪn əɹ lɪnənz, jɛɾ ə ɹɛd blaʊs, ɡɹin tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ə dip jɛloʊ sæʃ meɪɾ əɹ bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf, ðoʊ ivən ɹeɪnɪn, ə ɹaʊnd-tʃik jʌŋ wʊmən wɪð dʒʌs hæf ə dʌzən ɡoʊldən mədæljənz dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɑntu hɝ tʃik, meɪd ɹɪneɪlz ɑnɝ tʃeɪn lʊk bɛɹ. ɹɪneɪlz feɪs wɔɹ ən ɪkspɹɛʃən ə stoʊɪk ɛndɝəns.

No sooner did she have the thought than they were padding into the room behind Chanelle, a riotous rainbow of silks. Except for Renaile, last in line in her linens, yet a red blouse, green trousers and a deep yellow sash made her bright enough, though even Rainyn, a round-cheeked young woman with just half a dozen golden medallions dangling onto her cheek, made Renaile's honor chain look bare. Renaile's face wore an expression of stoic endurance.

"aɪ də nɑɾ əpɹiʃieɪt biɪŋ θɹɛɾənd!" tʃənɛl sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli, snɪfɪŋ ðə ɡoʊldən sɛn bɑks ɑn ɪts ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. hɝ dɑɹk tʃiks wɝ flʌʃt. "ðæt ɡɑɹdzwʊmən sɛɾ ɪf wi dɪd nɑt ɹʌn, ʃi wəd kɪk - ! nɛvɝ maɪnd wʌt ʃi sɛd, ɪɡzækli. ɪt wɑz ə θɹɛt, ən əl nɑt bi - !"

"I do not appreciate being threatened!" Chanelle said angrily, sniffing the golden scent box on its golden chain around her neck. Her dark cheeks were flushed. "That Guardswoman said if we did not run, she would kick - ! Never mind what she said, exactly. It was a threat, and I will not be - !"

"ɪleɪn əz bɪn kæptʃɝd baɪ dɑɹkfɹɛn ɛɛs sədaɪ," bɝdʒɪt kʌɾ ɪn. "aɪ nid jə tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ fəɹ ðə mɛn u ɑɹ gɑnə ɹɛskju hɝ." ə mɝmɝ ɹoʊz əmʌŋ ði ʌðɝ wɪndfɪndɝz. tʃənɛl dʒɛstʃɝd ʃɑɹpli, bʌɾ oʊnli ɹɪneɪl fɛl saɪlənt. ði ʌðɝz dʒʌs loʊɝd ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz tə wɪspɝz, tə hɝ ɑbviəs dɪsplɛʒɝ. baɪ ðə mədæljənz kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðɛɹ ɑnɝ tʃeɪnz, sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm mætʃt tʃənɛlz ɹæŋk.

"Elayne has been captured by Darkfriend Aes Sedai," Birgitte cut in. "I need you to make a gateway for the men who are going to rescue her." A murmur rose among the other Windfinders. Chanelle gestured sharply, but only Renaile fell silent. The others just lowered their voices to whispers, to her obvious displeasure. By the medallions crowding their honor chains, several of them matched Chanelle's rank.

"waɪ dɪd jə sʌmən ɔl ʌv əs fəɹ wʌn ɡeɪtweɪ?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "aɪ kip ðə bɑɹɡən, jə kən si. aɪ bɹɔɾ ɛvɹiwʌn əz jə ɔɹɾɝd. bʌt waɪ dʒju nid mɔɹ ðən wʌn?"

"Why did you summon all of us for one gateway?" she demanded. "I keep the bargain, you can see. I brought everyone as you ordered. But why do you need more than one?"

"bɪkɔz jəɹ ɔl gɑnə fɔɹm ə sɝkəl ən meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə teɪk θaʊzənz ə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz." ðət wɑz wʌn ɹizən.

"Because you're all going to form a circle and make a gateway big enough to take thousands of men and horses." That was one reason.

tʃənɛl stɪfənd, ən ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. kɹɪn, hɝ feɪs laɪk ə blæk stoʊn, pɹæktəkli kwɪvɝd wɪð aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ, ən ɹaɪsl, nɔɹməli ə vɛɹi dɪɡnəfaɪd wʊmən, dɪd kwɪvɝ. sɛnaɪn, wɪð əɹ wɛðɝd feɪs ən oʊl mɑɹks ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ ʃi wʌns hæd wɔɹn mɔɹ ðən sɪks ɪɹɪŋz, ən fæɾɝ wʌnz, fɪŋɡɝd ðə dʒuəl dæɡɝ θɹʌs bɪhaɪn əɹ ɡɹin sæʃ.

Chanelle stiffened, and she was not alone. Kurin, her face like a black stone, practically quivered with outrage, and Rysael, normally a very dignified woman, did quiver. Senine, with her weathered face and old marks indicating she once had worn more than six earrings, and fatter ones, fingered the jeweled dagger thrust behind her green sash.

"soʊlʒɝz?" tʃənɛl sɛɾ ɪndɪɡnənli. "ðæɾ ɪz fɔɹbɪɾən! əɹ bɑɹɡən sɛz wɪl teɪk noʊ pɑɹɾ ɪn jəɹ wɔɹ. zeɪɾə dɪn pɑɹid blæk wɪŋ kəmændəɾ ɪt soʊ, ən naʊ ðət ʃiz mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps, ðət kəmæn kæɹiz ivən ɡɹeɪɾɝ weɪt. juz ðə kɪnswɪmən. juz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Soldiers?" Chanelle said indignantly. "That is forbidden! Our bargain says we will take no part in your war. Zaida din Parede Black Wing commanded it so, and now that she is Mistress of the Ships, that command carries even greater weight. Use the Kinswomen. Use the Aes Sedai."

bɝdʒɪt stɛp kloʊs tə ðə dɑɹk wʊmən, lʊkɪŋ əɹ stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ði aɪz. ðə kɪn wɝ jusləs fəɹ ðɪs. nʌn ə ðɛm hæɾ ɛvɝ juz ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən. ðeɪ maɪt nɑɾ ivən noʊ haʊ. "ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ dɛd," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. sʌmwʌn bɪhaɪn əɹ moʊnd, wʌn ə ðə klɝks. "wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ bɑɹɡən wɝθ ɪf ɪleɪn ɪz lɔst? ɛɹəmɪlə sɝɾənli woʊn ɑnɝ ɪt." kipɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs stɛɾi seɪɪŋ ðət tʊk ɛfɝt. ɪt wɑntəd tə ʃeɪk wɪð æŋɡɝ, ʃeɪk wɪð fɪɹ. ʃi niɾəd ðiz wɪmən, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt lɛɾ əm noʊ waɪ əɹ ɪleɪn wəd bi lɔst. "wʌt wɪl zeɪɾə seɪ ɪf jə ɹuən əɹ bɑɹɡən wɪð ɪleɪn?"

Birgitte stepped close to the dark woman, looking her straight in the eyes. The Kin were useless for this. None of them had ever used the Power as a weapon. They might not even know how. "The other Aes Sedai are dead," she said softly. Someone behind her moaned, one of the clerks. "What is your bargain worth if Elayne is lost? Arymilla certainly won't honor it." Keeping her voice steady saying that took effort. It wanted to shake with anger, shake with fear. She needed these women, but she could not let them know why or Elayne would be lost. "What will Zaida say if you ruin her bargain with Elayne?"

tʃənɛlz tætud hæn hæf-lɪftəd ðə pɪɹswɝk sɛn bɑks tə hɝ noʊz əɡɛn, ðən lɛɾ ɪt fɔl əmʌŋ əɹ mɛni dʒuəl nɛkləsɪz. fɹəm wʌt bɝdʒɪt nu ʌv zeɪɾə dɪn pɑɹid, ʃi wəd bi mɔɹ ðən dɪsplizd wɪð ɛniwʌn u ɹɛk ðət bɑɹɡən, ən ɪt wɑz bɪɑn daʊtfəl ðət tʃənɛl wɪʃt tə feɪs ðə wʊmənz æŋɡɝ, jɛt ʃi oʊnli lʊk pɛnsɪv. "vɛɹi wɛl," ʃi sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "fɔɹ tʃɹænspɔɹɾ oʊnli, ðoʊ. ɪts əɡɹid?" ʃi kɪs ðə fɪŋɡɝtɪps ə hɝ ɹaɪt hænd, pɹipɛɹd tə sil ðə bɑɹɡən.

Chanelle's tattooed hand half-lifted the piercework scent box to her nose again, then let it fall among her many jeweled necklaces. From what Birgitte knew of Zaida din Parede, she would be more than displeased with anyone who wrecked that bargain, and it was beyond doubtful that Chanelle wished to face the woman's anger, yet she only looked pensive. "Very well," she said after a moment. "For transport only, though. It is agreed?" She kissed the fingertips of her right hand, prepared to seal the bargain.

"ju oʊnli nid də wʌt jə wɑnt," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ. "ɡaɪbɑn, ɪts taɪm. ðeɪ mʌst əv əɹ tə ðə ɡeɪt baɪ naʊ."

"You only need do what you want," Birgitte said, turning away. "Guybon, it's time. They must have her to the gate by now."

ɡaɪbɑn bʌkəld ɑn ɪz sɔɹd, tʊk ʌp ɪz hɛlməɾ ən stil-bækt ɡɔnləts, ən fɑloʊɾ əɹ ən daɪɛlɪn aʊɾ ə ðə mæp ɹum tʃɹeɪl baɪ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, wɪð tʃənɛl laʊdli ɪnsɪstɪŋ ðət ðeɪ wəd pɹəvaɪɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊnli. bɝdʒɪt wɪspɝɾ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz tə ɡaɪbɑn bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ ɪm stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə fɹʌn ə ðə pæləs waɪl ʃi hɝid tə ðə kwinz steɪbliɑɹd wɛɹ ʃi faʊn ə hæmɝ-noʊz dʌn ɡɛldɪŋ wɛɹɪŋ əɹ sæɾəl ən weɪɾɪŋ, ðə ɹeɪnz hɛl baɪ ə jʌŋ ɡɹum wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ə bɹeɪd nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm əɹ oʊn. ʃi ɔlsoʊ faʊn ɔl hʌnʒɹəd ən twɛnti-wʌn ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ɑɹmɝɾ ən maʊntəd. klaɪmɪŋ ɪndə ðə dʌnz sæɾəl, ʃi moʊʃən əm tə fɑloʊ hɝ. ðə sʌn wɑz ə ɡoʊldən bɔl klɪɹ ə ðə hɝaɪzən ɪn ə skaɪ wɪð oʊnli ə fju haɪ waɪt klaʊdz. ət lis ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv ɹeɪn tə kəntɛnd wɪð, tu. ivən ə wæɡən maɪɾ əv bɪn eɪbəl tə slɪp əweɪ ɪn səm ə ðə hɛvi ɹeɪnstɔɹmz keɪɛmlɪn hæd sin leɪtli.

Guybon buckled on his sword, took up his helmet and steel-backed gauntlets, and followed her and Dyelin out of the Map Room trailed by the Windfinders, with Chanelle loudly insisting that they would provide a gateway only. Birgitte whispered instructions to Guybon before leaving him striding toward the front of the palace while she hurried to the Queen's Stableyard where she found a hammer-nosed dun gelding wearing her saddle and waiting, the reins held by a young groom with her hair in a braid not much different from her own. She also found all hundred and twenty-one Guardswomen armored and mounted. Climbing into the dun's saddle, she motioned them to follow her. The sun was a golden ball clear of the horizon in a sky with only a few high white clouds. At least they would not have rain to contend with, too. Even a wagon might have been able to slip away in some of the heavy rainstorms Caemlyn had seen lately.

ə θɪk sneɪk ə mɛn tɛn ən twɛlv əbɹɛst spæn ðə kwinz plɑzə, naʊ, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ɪn boʊθ dɝɛkʃənz, hɔɹsmən ɪn hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts ɔltɝneɪɾɪŋ wɪð mɛn ɪn ɛvɹi sɔɹɾ ə hɛlməɾ ɪmædʒənəbəl kæɹiɪŋ ʃoʊldɝd hælbɝdz, moʊst wɛɹɪŋ meɪl ʃɝts əɹ dʒɝkɪnz soʊn wɪð stil dɪsks ən oʊnli ɹɛɹli ə bɹɛstpleɪt, itʃ ɡɹup lɑɹdʒ əɹ smɔl hɛɾəd baɪ ðə bænɝ ʌv ɪts haʊs. əɹ ðə bænɝ ʌv ə mɝsənɛɹi kʌmpəni. ðə sɛl-sɔɹdz wəɾ əv tu mɛni wɑtʃɝz tə tʃɹaɪ slækɪŋ ɔf tədeɪ. maɪnəs ðə kɹɔsboʊmən ən ɑɹtʃɝz, ðəɹ wəd bi kloʊs ɑn twɛlv θaʊzən mɛn ɪn ðət kɑləm, tu-θɝdz ə ðɛm maʊntəd. haʊ mɛni wəd bi dɛd bɪfɔɹ nun? ʃi pʊʃt ðət θɔɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ maɪnd. ʃi niɾəd ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm tə kənvɪns ðə si foʊk. ɛni mæn u daɪd tədeɪ kəd daɪ əz izəli ɑn ðə wɔl təmɑɹoʊ. ɛvɹi mæn ə ðɛm hæd kʌm tə keɪɛmlɪn pɹipɛɹd tə daɪ fəɹ ɪleɪn.

A thick snake of men ten and twelve abreast spanned the Queen's Plaza, now, stretching out of sight in both directions, horsemen in helmets and breastplates alternating with men in every sort of helmet imaginable carrying shouldered halberds, most wearing mail shirts or jerkins sewn with steel discs and only rarely a breastplate, each group large or small headed by the banner of its House. Or the banner of a mercenary company. The sell-swords would have too many watchers to try slacking off today. Minus the crossbowmen and archers, there would be close on twelve thousand men in that column, two-thirds of them mounted. How many would be dead before noon? She pushed that thought out of her mind. She needed every one of them to convince the Sea Folk. Any man who died today could die as easily on the wall tomorrow. Every man of them had come to Caemlyn prepared to die for Elayne.

ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kɑləm wɝ bɛɾɝ ðən ə θaʊzənd ɡɑɹdzmɪn, hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn, stil-tɪp lænsɪz slæntəd pɹɪsaɪsli, ðə fɝst ə ðɛm weɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə bænɝ ʌv ændɝ, ðə ɹɪɹɪŋ waɪt laɪən ɑn ə fild ə skɑɹlət, ən ɪleɪnz bænɝ, ðə ɡoʊldən lɪli ɑn blu, ət ði ɛdʒ ʌv wʌn ə keɪɛmlɪnz mɛni pɑɹks. ɪt hæd bɪn ə pɑɹk, ɛniweɪ, bʌɾ oʊks hʌnʒɹədz ə jɪɹz oʊl hæd bɪn kʌt daʊn ən hɔld əweɪ əlɔŋ wɪð ɔl ði ʌðɝ tʃɹiz ən ðə flaʊɝɪŋ bʊʃəz, ðɛɹ ɹuts dʌɡ aʊt tə klɪɹ ə smuð speɪs ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz waɪd. ðə ɡɹævəl pæðz ən ɡɹæsi ɡɹaʊn hæd lɔŋ sɪns bɪn tʃɹæmpəl tə mʌd baɪ hʊvz ən buts. θɹi ʌðɝ pɑɹks ɝaʊn ðə pæləs hæd ɹəsiv ðə seɪm tʃɹitmənt, tə meɪk pleɪsəz fəɹ wivɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪz.

At the head of the column were better than a thousand Guardsmen, helmets and breastplates gleaming in the sun, steel-tipped lances slanted precisely, the first of them waiting behind the banner of Andor, the rearing White Lion on a field of scarlet, and Elayne's banner, the Golden Lily on blue, at the edge of one of Caemlyn's many parks. It had been a park, anyway, but oaks hundreds of years old had been cut down and hauled away along with all the other trees and the flowering bushes, their roots dug out to clear a smooth space a hundred paces wide. The graveled paths and grassy ground had long since been trampled to mud by hooves and boots. Three other parks around the palace had received the same treatment, to make places for weaving gateways.

ɡaɪbɑn ən daɪɛlɪn wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ, əlɔŋ wɪð ɔl ðə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz u hæɾ ænsɝɾ ɪleɪnz kɔl, fɹəm jʌŋ pɛɝaɪvəl mæntʃɹ tə bɹænɪn mɑɹɾən ən ɪz waɪf, ɔl maʊntəd. pɛɝaɪvəl wɔɹ hɛlməɾ ən bɹɛstpleɪt laɪk ɛvɹi ʌðɝ meɪl pɹɛzənt. bɹænɪnz wɝ pleɪn ən dʌl ən slaɪtli dɛntɪd wɛɹ ði ɑɹmɔɹɝz hæmɝ hæd feɪld ɪts tæsk, tulz ə hɪz tʃɹeɪɾ əz ʃʊɹli əz ðə pleɪn-hɪltɪd sɔɹd skæbɑɹɾɪd əɾ ɪz saɪd. pɛɝaɪvəlz wɝ əz ɡɪldɪɾ əz kɑneɪlz ən bɹænləts, wɝkt wɪð ðə sɪlvɝ ænvəl ə mæntʃɹ wɛɹ ðɛɹz wɝ lækɝd wɪð nɔɹθənz blæk iɡəlz ən ʒəljɑɹdz ɹɛd lɛpɝdz. pɹɪɾi ɑɹmɝ, fəɹ biɪŋ sin ɪn. bɝdʒɪt hoʊp ðə wɪmən hæd sɛns ɪnʌf tə kip ðoʊz bɔɪz aʊɾ ʌv ɛni faɪɾɪŋ. lʊkɪŋ ət səm ə ðoʊz wɪmənz feɪsəz, ɡɹɪm ən dɪtɝmənd, ʃi hoʊp ðeɪ hæd sɛns ɪnʌf tə steɪ klɪɹ ðɛmsɛlvz. ət lis nʌn wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə sɔɹd. ðə sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ wɑz, ə wʊmən hæd tə bi mɔɹ skɪl ðən ə mæn tə feɪs ɪm wɪð ə sɔɹd. stʃɹɔŋɝ ɑɹmz meɪd tu mʌtʃ dɪfɝəns, ʌðɝwaɪz. mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ tə juz ə baʊ.

Guybon and Dyelin were already there, along with all the lords and ladies who had answered Elayne's call, from young Perival Mantear to Brannin Martan and his wife, all mounted. Perival wore helmet and breastplate like every other male present. Brannin's were plain and dull and slightly dented where the armorer's hammer had failed its task, tools of his trade as surely as the plain-hilted sword scabbarded at his side. Perival's were as gilded as Conail's and Branlet's, worked with the silver Anvil of Mantear where theirs were lacquered with Northan's Black Eagles and Gilyard's Red Leopards. Pretty armor, for being seen in. Birgitte hoped the women had sense enough to keep those boys out of any fighting. Looking at some of those women's faces, grim and determined, she hoped they had sense enough to stay clear themselves. At least none was wearing a sword. The simple truth was, a woman had to be more skilled than a man to face him with a sword. Stronger arms made too much difference, otherwise. Much better to use a bow.

ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ əz ðeɪ ʃɪftəd ðɛɹ bɛɹ fiɾ ənizəli ɑn ɡɹaʊn stɪl mʌɾi fɹəm jɛstɝdeɪz daʊnpɔɹ. wɛt, ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ ðən əkʌstəm tə, bʌt nɑt mʌd.

The Windfinders were grimacing as they shifted their bare feet uneasily on ground still muddy from yesterday's downpour. Wet, they were more than accustomed to, but not mud.

"ðɪs mæn wɪl nɑt tɛl mi wɛɹ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪz tə ɹitʃ," tʃənɛl sɛd fjʊɹiəsli, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ɡaɪbɑn əz bɝdʒɪt dɪsmaʊntɪd. "aɪ wɑnə bi dʌn soʊ aɪ kən wɑʃ maɪ fit."

"This man will not tell me where the gateway is to reach," Chanelle said furiously, pointing to Guybon as Birgitte dismounted. "I want to be done so I can wash my feet."

"maɪ leɪɾi!" ə wʊmənz vɔɪs kɔl fɹəm bæk daʊn ðə stʃɹit. "maɪ leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt!" ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp ðə laɪn ʌv ɡɑɹdzmɪn, hɝ ɹɛd skɝts hɛl haɪ, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ əɹ stɑkɪnɡd lɛɡz tə ðə ni. bɝdʒɪt dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ðə wʊmən soʊ mʌtʃ əz tʃɹɑt. mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz wɪmən u ɔlweɪz dɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ pɝfəkli. ɛvɹi taɪm ðeɪ mɛt ʃi meɪd bɝdʒɪt kɑnʃəs ʌv ɛvɹi læs mɪsteɪk ʃi hɝsɛlf hæɾ ɛvɝ meɪd. tu mɛn ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt lɪvɝi wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ, kæɹiɪŋ ə lɪɾɝ bɪtwin ðɛm. wən ðeɪ keɪm kloʊsɝ, bɝdʒɪt sɔ ðəɾ ɪt hɛld ə læŋki, hɛlmɔɪtləs ɡɑɹdzmæn wɪð ən æɹoʊ pɪɹsɪŋ ɪz ɹaɪɾ ɑɹm ən ənʌðɝ dʒʌɾɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ɹaɪt θaɪ. blʌd tʃɹɪkəl daʊn boʊθ ʃæfs, soʊ hi lɛft ə θɪn tʃɹeɪl ə dʒɹɑps ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. "hi ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn biɪŋ bɹɔt tə jə əɹ kæptən ɡaɪbɑn ɪmiɾiətli, maɪ leɪɾi," mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ sɛd bɹɛθləsli, fænɪŋ hɝsɛlf wɪð wʌn hænd.

"My Lady!" a woman's voice called from back down the street. "My Lady Birgitte!" Reene Harfor came running up the line of Guardsmen, her red skirts held high, exposing her stockinged legs to the knee. Birgitte did not think she had ever seen the woman so much as trot. Mistress Harfor was one of those women who always did everything perfectly. Every time they met she made Birgitte conscious of every last mistake she herself had ever made. Two men in red-and-white livery were running behind her, carrying a litter between them. When they came closer, Birgitte saw that it held a lanky, helmetless Guardsman with an arrow piercing his right arm and another jutting from his right thigh. Blood trickled down both shafts, so he left a thin trail of drops on the paving stones. "He insisted on being brought to you or Captain Guybon immediately, my Lady," Mistress Harfor said breathlessly, fanning herself with one hand.

ðə jʌŋ ɡɑɹdzmæn stʃɹʌɡəl tə sɪɾ ʌp əntɪl bɝdʒɪt pɹɛst ɪm bæk daʊn. "θɹi əɹ fɔɹ kʌmpəniz ə mɝsənɛɹiz ɑɹ ətækɪŋ ðə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡeɪt, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd, peɪn ɹækɪŋ ɪz feɪs ən tɪnɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs. "fɹʌm ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi, aɪ min. ðeɪ pleɪst ɑɹtʃɝz tə ʃuɾ ɛniwʌn u tʃɹaɪd tə weɪv ðə sɪɡnəl flæɡz fəɹ hɛlp, bʌɾ aɪ mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ, ən maɪ hɔɹs læstəd dʒʌs lɔŋ ɪnʌf."

The young Guardsman struggled to sit up until Birgitte pressed him back down. "Three or four companies of mercenaries are attacking the Far Madding Gate, my Lady," he said, pain wracking his face and tinging his voice. "From inside the city, I mean. They placed archers to shoot anyone who tried to wave the signal flags for help, but I managed to get away, and my horse lasted just long enough."

bɝdʒɪt ɡɹaʊld ən oʊθ. kɔɹdwɪn, ɡoʊmsən ən bɑkəvʌn wəd bi əmʌŋ ðɛm, ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə weɪdʒɝ. ʃi ʃʊɾə pɹɛst ɪleɪn tə pʊɾ əm aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi əz sun əz ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ dɪmænz. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz ʃi hæd spoʊkən əlaʊɾ əntɪl ðə wundəd ɡɑɹdzmæn spoʊk ʌp.

Birgitte growled an oath. Cordwyn, Gomaisen and Bakuvun would be among them, she was ready to wager. She should have pressed Elayne to put them out of the city as soon as they made their demands. She did not realize she had spoken aloud until the wounded Guardsman spoke up.

"noʊ, maɪ leɪɾi. listwaɪz, nɑt bɑkəvʌn. hɪm ən ə dʌzən əɹ soʊ ʌv ɪz mɛn dʒɹɑp baɪ tə tɔs . . . ʌ, tə pæs ðə taɪm, ən ðə lutɛnən fɪɡjɝz ðəɹ ði oʊnli ɹizən wiv mænədʒ tə hoʊld ɑn. ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ stɪl hoʊldɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ juzɪŋ bæɾɝɪŋ ɹæmz ɑn ðə taʊɝ dɔɹz wən aɪ lʊk bæk. bʌt ðɛɹz mɔɹ, maɪ leɪɾi. ðɛɹz mɛn mæsɪŋ ɪn loʊ keɪɛmlɪn aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡeɪts. tɛn θaʊzənd, meɪbi twaɪs ðæt. hɑɹd tə tɛl, ðə weɪ ðoʊz stʃɹits twɪst."

"No, my Lady. Leastwise, not Bakuvun. Him and a dozen or so of his men dropped by to toss . . . uh, to pass the time, and the lieutenant figures they're the only reason we've managed to hold on. If they are still holding. They were using battering rams on the tower doors when I looked back. But there's more, my Lady. There's men massing in Low Caemlyn outside the gates. Ten thousand, maybe twice that. Hard to tell, the way those streets twist."

bɝdʒɪt wɪnst. tɛn θaʊzən mɛn wəd bi ɪnʌf tə kæɹi ən əsɔl fɹəm ði aʊtsaɪd wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðə mɝsənɛɹiz wɝ hɛld ɔf ənlɛs ʃi sɛn ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ən ʃi kəd nɑt. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt wɑz ʃi tə du? bɝn hɝ, ʃi kəd plæn ə ɹeɪd tə ɹɛskju sʌmwʌn fɹəm ə fɔɹtʃɹəs əɹ skaʊɾ ɪn kʌntʃɹi hɛl baɪ ði ɛnəmi wɪð kɑnfəɾəns ðət ʃi nu wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə bæɾəl, wɪð ðə feɪɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn ən meɪbi ðə θɹoʊn ɪn ðə bæləns. stɪl, ʃi hæɾ ɪt tə du. "mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ, teɪk ðɪs mæn bæk tə ðə pæləs ən si hɪz wunz tɛndəd, pliz." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn æskɪŋ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz fəɹ hilɪŋ. ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ ðət wɑz teɪkɪŋ pɑɹɾ ɪn ðə wɔɹ, ɪn ðɛɹ vju. "daɪɛlɪn, liv mi ɔl ə ðə hɔɹs ən ə θaʊzən hælbɝdmən. jə teɪk ðə ɹɛst ən ɔl ə ðə kɹɔsboʊmən ən ɑɹtʃɝz əveɪləbəl. ən ɛvɹi mæn jə kən skɹeɪp təɡɛðɝ u kən hoʊld ə sɔɹd. ɪf ðə ɡeɪɾ ɪz stɪl hoʊldɪŋ wən ðə kɪnswɪmən ɡɛt jə ðɛɹ, meɪk ʃʊɹ ɪt kəntɪnjuz tə hoʊld. ɪf ɪts fɔlən, teɪk ɪt bæk. ən hoʊl ðət blʌɾi wɔl tɪl aɪ kən ɡɛt ðɛɹ."

Birgitte winced. Ten thousand men would be enough to carry an assault from the outside whether or not the mercenaries were held off unless she sent everything, and she could not. What in the Light was she to do? Burn her, she could plan a raid to rescue someone from a fortress or scout in country held by the enemy with confidence that she knew what she was doing, but this was a battle, with the fate of Caemlyn and maybe the throne in the balance. Still, she had it to do. "Mistress Harfor, take this man back to the palace and see his wounds tended, please." There was no point in asking the Windfinders for Healing. They had already made it clear that was taking part in the war, in their view. "Dyelin, leave me all of the horse and a thousand halberdmen. You take the rest and all of the crossbowmen and archers available. And every man you can scrape together who can hold a sword. If the gate is still holding when the Kinswomen get you there, make sure it continues to hold. If it's fallen, take it back. And hold that bloody wall till I can get there."

"vɛɹi wɛl," daɪɛlɪn sɛɾ əz ɪf ðoʊz wɝ ði iziəst ɔɹɾɝz ɪn ðə wɝl tə kæɹi aʊt. "kɑneɪl, kæɾəlɪn, bɹænlət, pɛɝaɪvəl, jə kʌm wɪð mi. jəɹ fʊt wɪl faɪt bɛɾɝ wɪð jə ðɛɹ." kɑneɪl lʊk dɪsəpɔɪntɪd, noʊ daʊt siɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə ɡælən tʃɑɹdʒ, bʌɾ i ɡæðɝɾ ɪz ɹeɪnz ən wɪspɝd sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪd ðə tu jʌŋɡɝ bɔɪz tʃʌkəl.

"Very well," Dyelin said as if those were the easiest orders in the world to carry out. "Conail, Catalyn, Branlet, Perival, you come with me. Your foot will fight better with you there." Conail looked disappointed, no doubt seeing himself riding in a gallant charge, but he gathered his reins and whispered something that made the two younger boys chuckle.

"soʊ wɪl maɪ hɔɹs faɪt bɛɾɝ," kæɾəlɪn pɹətɛstəd. "aɪ wɑnə hɛlp ɹɛskju ɪleɪn."

"So will my horse fight better," Catalyn protested. "I want to help rescue Elayne."

"ju keɪm tə hɛlp əɹ sɪkjʊɹ ðə θɹoʊn," daɪɛlɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli, "æn jəl ɡoʊ wɛɹ jəɹ niɾəd tə si tə ðæt, əɹ jə ən əl əv ənʌðɝ tɔk leɪɾɝ." wʌtɛvɝ ðət mɛnt, kæɾəlɪnz plʌmp feɪs ɹɛɾənd, bʌt ʃi sʌlənli fɑloʊd daɪɛlɪn ən ði ʌðɝz wən ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ əweɪ.

"You came to help her secure the throne," Dyelin said sharply, "and you'll go where you're needed to see to that, or you and I will have another talk later." Whatever that meant, Catalyn's plump face reddened, but she sullenly followed Dyelin and the others when they rode away.

ɡaɪbɑn lʊkt ət bɝdʒɪt, jɛɾ i sɛd nʌθɪŋ, ðoʊ laɪkli hi wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ ʃi wɑz nɑt sɛndɪŋ mɔɹ. hi wəd nɑt tʃælənʒ əɹ pʌblɪkli. ðə pɹɑbləm wɑz, ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ mɛni blæk sɪstɝz wəd bi wɪð ɪleɪn. ʃi niɾəd ɛvɹi wɪndfɪndɝ, niɾəd əm tə bɪliv ðeɪ wɝ ɔl nɛsəsɛɹi. hæd ðəɹ bɪn taɪm, ʃi wʊɾə stʃɹɪp ðə sɛntʃɹiz fɹəm ði aʊɾɝ taʊɝz, stʃɹɪpt ivən ðə ɡeɪts.

Guybon looked at Birgitte, yet he said nothing, though likely he was wondering why she was not sending more. He would not challenge her publicly. The problem was, she did not know how many Black sisters would be with Elayne. She needed every Windfinder, needed them to believe they were all necessary. Had there been time, she would have stripped the sentries from the outer towers, stripped even the gates.

"meɪk ðə ɡeɪtweɪ," ʃi toʊl tʃənɛl. "tə dʒʌs ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪdʒ ist ə ðə sɪɾi, ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə ði ɛɹɪnɪn ɹoʊɾ ən feɪsɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi."

"Make the gateway," she told Chanelle. "To just this side of the ridge east of the city, right on top of the Erinin Road and facing away from the city."

ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ə sɝkəl, duɪŋ wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ hæd tə də tə lɪŋk ən teɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ blʌɾi taɪm əbaʊɾ ɪt. sʌɾənli ðə vɝɾɪkəl sɪlvɝ-blu slæʃ ʌv ə ɡeɪtweɪ əpɪɹd, waɪɾənɪŋ ɪndə ən oʊpənɪŋ, faɪv peɪsɪz tɔl ən kʌvɝɪŋ ðə hoʊl wɪdθ ə ðə klɪɹd ɡɹaʊnd, ðət ʃoʊɾ ə waɪd ɹoʊɾ ə hɑɹd-pækt kleɪ klaɪmɪŋ ðə dʒɛntəl sloʊp ə ðə tɛn-spæn-haɪ ɹɪdʒ ɑn ɪts weɪ tə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn. ɛɹəmɪlə hæd kæmps bɪɑn ðət ɹɪdʒ. ɡɪvən ðə nuz, ðeɪ maɪt bi ɛmpti - wɪð lʌk, ðeɪ wɝ - bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt kənsɝn hɝsɛlf wɪð əm naʊ ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt.

The Windfinders gathered in a circle, doing whatever they had to do to link and taking their bloody time about it. Suddenly the vertical silver-blue slash of a gateway appeared, widening into an opening, five paces tall and covering the whole width of the cleared ground, that showed a wide road of hard-packed clay climbing the gentle slope of the ten-span-high ridge on its way to the River Erinin. Arymilla had camps beyond that ridge. Given the news, they might be empty - with luck, they were - but she could not concern herself with them now in any event.

"fɔɹwɝɾ ən dɪplɔɪ əz ɔɹɾɝd!" ɡaɪbɑn ʃaʊɾəd, ən spɝɾ ɪz tɔl beɪ θɹu fɑloʊd baɪ ðə ɡæðɝd noʊbəlz ən ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn tɛn əbɹɛst. ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn bɪɡæn kɝlɪŋ ɔf tə ðə lɛft ən aʊɾ ə saɪt waɪl ðə noʊbəlz tʊk ə pəzɪʃən ə lɪɾəl ʌp ðə ɹɪdʒ. səm bɪɡæn piɹɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə sɪɾi θɹu lʊkɪŋ ɡlæsəz. ɡaɪbɑn dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən ɹæn, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ, tə pɪɹ oʊvɝ ðə kɹɛs θɹu hɪz. bɝdʒɪt kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ði ɪmpeɪʃəns ə ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən weɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ.

"Forward and deploy as ordered!" Guybon shouted, and spurred his tall bay through followed by the gathered nobles and the Guardsmen ten abreast. The Guardsmen began curling off to the left and out of sight while the nobles took a position a little up the ridge. Some began peering toward the city through looking glasses. Guybon dismounted and ran, crouching, to peer over the crest through his. Birgitte could almost feel the impatience of the Guardswomen waiting behind her.

"ju dɪd nɑt niɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ ðɪs lɑɹdʒ," tʃənɛl sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə kɑləm ə hɔɹsmən floʊɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. "waɪ - ?"

"You did not need a gateway this large," Chanelle said, frowning at the column of horsemen flowing into the gateway. "Why - ?"

"kʌm wɪð mi," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ðə wɪndfɪndɝ baɪ hɝ ɑɹm. "aɪ wɑnə ʃoʊ jə sʌmθɪŋ." pʊlɪŋ ðə dʌn əlɔŋ baɪ hɪz ɹeɪnz, ʃi bɪɡæn dʒɹɔɪŋ ðə wʊmən təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. "ju kən kʌm bæk wʌns juv sin ɪt." ɪf ʃi nu ðə lis θɪŋ əbaʊt tʃənɛl, ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn ɡaɪɾɪŋ ðə sɝkəl. fəɹ ðə ɹɛst, ʃi wɑz kaʊntɪŋ ɑn hjumən neɪtʃɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk bæk, jɛt ʃi nɪɹli saɪd wɪð ɹɪlif wən ʃi hɝd ði ʌðɝ wɪndfɪndɝz mɝmɝɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz bɪhaɪn hɝ. fɑloʊɪŋ.

"Come with me," Birgitte said, taking the Windfinder by her arm. "I want to show you something." Pulling the dun along by his reins, she began drawing the woman toward the gateway. "You can come back once you've seen it." If she knew the least thing about Chanelle, she was the one guiding the circle. For the rest, she was counting on human nature. She did not look back, yet she nearly sighed with relief when she heard the other Windfinders murmuring among themselves behind her. Following.

wʌtɛvɝ ɡaɪbɑn hæd sin, ɪt wɑz ɡʊd nuz, kəz i stʃɹeɪɾənd ʌp bɪfɔɹ ɹʌnɪŋ bæk daʊn tə hɪz hɔɹs. ɛɹəmɪlə mʌst əv stʃɹɪpt əɹ kæmps tə ðə boʊn. meɪk ɪt twɛnti θaʊzən ət ðə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡeɪt, ðɛn, ɪf nɑt mɔɹ. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt wɑz hoʊldɪŋ. ðə laɪt sɛn ɛvɹiwɛɹ wɑz hoʊldɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪleɪn fɝst. fɝst ən əbʌv ɔl ɛls.

Whatever Guybon had seen, it was good news, because he straightened up before running back down to his horse. Arymilla must have stripped her camps to the bone. Make it twenty thousand at the Far Madding Gate, then, if not more. The Light send it was holding. The Light send everywhere was holding. But Elayne first. First and above all else.

wən ʃi ɹitʃt ɡaɪbɑn, hu wɑz bæk ɑn ɪz beɪ, ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ɝeɪd ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn θɹi laɪnz bɪhaɪn keɪsil ɔf tə wʌn saɪd. ðə hoʊl hʌnʒɹəd-peɪs wɪdθ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz fɪld wɪð mɛn ən hɔɹsəz naʊ, tʃɹɑɾɪŋ əz ðeɪ hɝid lɛft ən ɹaɪt tə dʒɔɪn ði ʌðɝz ɔlɹɛɾi fɔɹmɪŋ ɪn θɹi ɹæŋks ðət ɡɹu tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd. ɡʊd. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ izi weɪ fəɹ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz tə dʌk bæk θɹu fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl. ə wæɡən wɪð ən ɑɹtʃt kænvəs kʌvɝ ən ə fɔɹ-hɔɹs tim, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə smɔl maʊntəd pɑɹɾi, wɑz hɔltəɾ ɪn ðə ɹoʊd dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə læs bɪldɪŋz ə loʊ keɪɛmlɪn, pɝhæps ə maɪl dɪstənt. bɪɑn ɪt, pipəl bʌsəld ɪn ði oʊpən bɹɪk mɑɹkəts ðət laɪn ðə ɹoʊd, ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ laɪvz əz bɛs ðeɪ kʊd, bʌt ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl nɑɾ əv ɪɡzɪstəd. ɪleɪn wɑz ɪn ðət wæɡən. bɝdʒɪt ɹeɪzd əɹ hænd wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm ðə vihɪkəl, ən ɡaɪbɑn pʊɾ ɪz bɹæs-maʊntəd lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs ɪn əɹ pɑm. wæɡən ən ɹaɪɾɝz lɛp kloʊsɝ wən ʃi ɹeɪz ðə tub tə hɝ aɪ.

When she reached Guybon, who was back on his bay, the Guardswomen arrayed themselves in three lines behind Caseille off to one side. The whole hundred-pace width of the gateway was filled with men and horses now, trotting as they hurried left and right to join the others already forming in three ranks that grew to either side of the road. Good. There would be no easy way for the Windfinders to duck back through for a little while. A wagon with an arched canvas cover and a four-horse team, surrounded by a small mounted party, was halted in the road just beyond the last buildings of Low Caemlyn, perhaps a mile distant. Beyond it, people bustled in the open brick markets that lined the road, going about their lives as best they could, but they might as well not have existed. Elayne was in that wagon. Birgitte raised her hand without taking her eyes from the vehicle, and Guybon put his brass-mounted looking glass in her palm. Wagon and riders leaped closer when she raised the tube to her eye.

"wʌt dɪd jə wɑn mi tə si?" tʃənɛl dɪmændəd.

"What did you want me to see?" Chanelle demanded.

"ɪn ə moʊmənt," bɝdʒɪt ɹɪplaɪd. ðəɹ wɝ fɔɹ mɛn, θɹi ʌv əm maʊntəd, bʌt mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt wɝ ðə sɛvən wɪmən ɑn hɔɹsbæk. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, bʌt nɑt ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə meɪk aʊɾ ən eɪdʒləs feɪs ət ðət dɪstəns. stɪl, ʃi hæd tə əsum ɔl sɛvən wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. eɪɾ əɡɛnst sɛvən maɪɾ əv simd ɔlmoʊst ivən ɑdz, bʌt nɑt wən ði eɪt wɝ lɪŋkt. nɑɾ ɪf ʃi kəd meɪk ði eɪt teɪk pɑɹt. wʌt wɝ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz θɪŋkɪŋ, siɪŋ θaʊzənz ə soʊlʒɝz ən ɑɹmmɪn əpɪɹ fɹəm bɪhaɪnd wʌt wəd sim tə ðɛm ə hit heɪz hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ? ʃi loʊɝd ðə ɡlæs. noʊbəlmən wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹaɪd daʊn əz ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn keɪm aʊɾ ən wɛn tə dʒɔɪn ðə laɪnz.

"In a moment," Birgitte replied. There were four men, three of them mounted, but more important were the seven women on horseback. It was a good looking glass, but not good enough for her to make out an ageless face at that distance. Still, she had to assume all seven were Aes Sedai. Eight against seven might have seemed almost even odds, but not when the eight were linked. Not if she could make the eight take part. What were the Darkfriends thinking, seeing thousands of soldiers and armsmen appear from behind what would seem to them a heat haze hanging in the air? She lowered the glass. Noblemen were beginning to ride down as their armsmen came out and went to join the lines.

haʊɛvɝ sɝpɹaɪz ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt dɪðɝ lɔŋ. laɪtnɪŋ bɪɡæn flæʃɪŋ daʊn aʊɾ ʌv ə klɪɹ skaɪ, sɪlvɝ-blu boʊls ðət stʃɹʌk ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð θʌndɝəs kɹæʃɪz ən θɹu mɛn ən hɔɹsəz laɪk splæʃt mʌd. hɔɹsəz ɹɪɹɾ ən plʌnʒd ən skɹimd, bʌt mɛn fɔt tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛɹ maʊns, tə hoʊl ðɛɹ pleɪsəz. noʊ wʌn ɹæn. ðə bumɪŋ θʌndɝ ðəɾ əkʌmpənid ðoʊz blæsts stʃɹʌk bɝdʒɪt laɪk bloʊz, stæɡɝɪŋ hɝ. ʃi kəd fil əɹ hɛɹ stɝɪŋ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹaɪz aʊɾ ə hɝ bɹeɪd. ði ɛɹ smɛld . . . ʃɑɹp. ɪt sim tə tɪŋɡəl. əɡɛn laɪtnɪŋ læʃt ðə ɹæŋks. ɪn loʊ keɪɛmlɪn, pipəl wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ. moʊst wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ, bʌt səm fulz æktʃəli  ɹæn tə wɛɹ ðeɪ kəɾ əv ə bɛɾɝ vju. ði ɛnz ə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹits oʊpənɪŋ ɑntu ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd bɪɡæn fɪlɪŋ wɪð spɛkteɪɾɝz.

However surprised the Darkfriends were, they did not dither long. Lightning began flashing down out of a clear sky, silver-blue bolts that struck the ground with thunderous crashes and threw men and horses like splashed mud. Horses reared and plunged and screamed, but men fought to control their mounts, to hold their places. No one ran. The booming thunder that accompanied those blasts struck Birgitte like blows, staggering her. She could feel her hair stirring, trying to rise out of her braid. The air smelled . . . sharp. It seemed to tingle. Again lightning lashed the ranks. In Low Caemlyn, people were running. Most were running away, but some fools actually ran to where they could have a better view. The ends of narrow streets opening onto the countryside began filling with spectators.

"ɪf wɝ gɑnə feɪs ðæt, wi maɪɾ əz wɛl bi muvɪŋ ən meɪk ɪt hɑɹɾɝ fəɹ ðɛm," ɡaɪbɑn sɛd, ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪnz. "wɪð jəɹ pɝmɪʃən, maɪ leɪɾi?"

"If we're going to face that, we might as well be moving and make it harder for them," Guybon said, gathering his reins. "With your permission, my Lady?"

"wil luz fjuɝ ɪf jəɹ muvɪŋ," bɝdʒɪɾ əɡɹid, ən i spɝd daʊn ðə ɹɪdʒ.

"We'll lose fewer if you're moving," Birgitte agreed, and he spurred down the ridge.

keɪsil hɔltəɾ əɹ hɔɹs ɪn fɹʌn ə bɝdʒɪɾ ən səluɾəd, ən ɑɹm əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst. hɝ nɛɹoʊ feɪs wɑz ɡɹɪm bɪhaɪn ðə feɪs-bɑɹz ə hɝ lækɝd hɛlmət. "pɝmɪʃən fəɹ ðə bɑɾiɡɑɹd tə dʒɔɪn ðə laɪn, maɪ leɪɾi?" jə kəd hɪɹ ðə kæpəɾəl. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt dʒʌst ɛni bɑɾiɡɑɹd, ðeɪ wɝ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz bɑɾiɡɑɹd ən wəd bi ðə kwinz bɑɾiɡɑɹd.

Caseille halted her horse in front of Birgitte and saluted, an arm across her chest. Her narrow face was grim behind the face-bars of her lacquered helmet. "Permission for the Bodyguard to join the line, my Lady?" You could hear the capital. They were not just any bodyguard, they were the Daughter-Heir's Bodyguard and would be the Queen's Bodyguard.

"ɡɹæntəd," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. ɪf ɛniwʌn hæɾ ə ɹaɪt, ðiz wɪmən dɪd.

"Granted," Birgitte said. If anyone had a right, these women did.

ði ɝæfɛlɪn wɝld əɹ hɔɹs ən ɡæləp daʊn ðə sloʊp fɑloʊd baɪ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə bɑɾiɡɑɹd tə teɪk ðɛɹ pleɪs ɪn ðoʊz laɪtnɪŋ-tɔɹn ɹæŋks. ə kʌmpəni ʌv mɝsənɛɹiz, pɝhæps tu hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ɪn blæk-peɪntəd hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts, ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ə ɹɛd bænɝ bɛɹɪŋ ə ɹʌnɪŋ blæk wʊlf, hɔltəd wən ðeɪ sɔ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪntu, bʌt mɛn bɪhaɪn ðə bænɝz ə hæf ə dʌzən haʊsəz pʊʃt pæs ðɛm, ən ðeɪ hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə ɡoʊ ɑn. mɔɹ noʊbəlmən ɹoʊd daʊn tə lid ðɛɹ mɛn, bɹænɪn ən kɛlwɪn, lɝəɾ ən bɑɹəl, ʌðɝz. nʌn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd wʌns i sɔ hɪz oʊn bænɝ əpɪɹ. sɝɡeɪs wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʊmən tə muv əɹ hɔɹs ə fju peɪsɪz əz ɪf ʃi, tu, mɛn tə dʒɔɪn wɪð əɹ ɑɹmmɪn wən əɹ bænɝ keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ.

The Arafellin whirled her horse and galloped down the slope followed by the rest of the Bodyguard to take their place in those lightning-torn ranks. A company of mercenaries, perhaps two hundred men in black-painted helmets and breastplates, riding behind a red banner bearing a running black wolf, halted when they saw what they were riding into, but men behind the banners of half a dozen Houses pushed past them, and they had no choice but to go on. More noblemen rode down to lead their men, Brannin and Kelwin, Laerid and Barel, others. None hesitated once he saw his own banner appear. Sergase was not the only woman to move her horse a few paces as if she, too, meant to join with her armsmen when her banner came out of the gateway.

"æɾ ə wɔk!" ɡaɪbɑn ʃaʊɾəd, tə bi hɝɾ oʊvɝ ði ɪksploʊʒənz. ɔl əlɔŋ ðə laɪn, ʌðɝ vɔɪsəz ɛkoʊd hɪm. "ədvæns!" wilɪŋ ɪz beɪ, hi ɹoʊd sloʊli təwɔɹd ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn ɛɛs sədaɪ waɪl laɪtnɪŋ bumd ən kɹæʃt ən mɛn ən hɔɹsəz flu ɪn faʊntənz ə ɝθ.

"At a walk!" Guybon shouted, to be heard over the explosions. All along the line, other voices echoed him. "Advance!" Wheeling his bay, he rode slowly toward the Darkfriend Aes Sedai while lightning boomed and crashed and men and horses flew in fountains of earth.

"wʌt dɪd jə wɑn mi tə si?" tʃənɛl dɪmændəɾ əɡɛn. "aɪ wɑnə bi əweɪ fɹəm ðɪs pleɪs." smɔl deɪnʒɝ ə ðət fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. mɛn wɝ stɪl kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ɡæləpɪŋ əɹ ɹʌnɪŋ tə kætʃ ʌp. faɪɝbɔlz fɛl əmʌŋ ðə ɹæŋks, tu, naʊ, æɾɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn ɪɹʌpʃənz ə dɝt, ɑɹmz, lɛɡz. ə hɔɹsəz hɛd spʌn læzəli ɪndə ði ɛɹ.

"What did you want me to see?" Chanelle demanded again. "I want to be away from this place." Small danger of that for the moment. Men were still coming out of the gateway, galloping or running to catch up. Fireballs fell among the ranks, too, now, adding their own eruptions of dirt, arms, legs. A horse's head spun lazily into the air.

"ðɪs," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ðə sin ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm. ɡaɪbɑn hæd bɪɡʌn tə tʃɹɑt, pʊlɪŋ ði ʌðɝz wɪð hɪm, ðə θɹi ɹæŋks hoʊldɪŋ stɛɾi ɪn ðɛɹ ədvæns, ʌðɝz kʌmɪŋ əz hɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ kəd tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm. əbɹʌpli ə lɛɡ-θɪk bɑɹ ʌv wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi lɪkwəd waɪt faɪɝ ʃɑɾ aʊt fɹəm wʌn ə ðə wɪmən bɪsaɪd ðə wæɡən. ɪt kwaɪt lɪɾɝəli kɑɹvd ə ɡæp fɪftin peɪsɪz waɪɾ ɪn ðə laɪnz. fəɹ ə hɑɹtbit, ʃɪmɝɪŋ flɛks floʊɾəd ɪn ði ɛɹ, ðə ʃeɪps ə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz stʃɹʌk, ən ðən wɝ kənsumd. ðə bɑɹ sʌɾənli dʒɝkt ʌp ɪndə ði ɛɹ, haɪɝ ən haɪɝ, ðən wɪŋkt aʊt livɪŋ dɪm pɝpəl laɪnz əkɹɔs bɝdʒɪts vɪʒən. bɑlfaɪɝ, bɝnɪŋ mɛn aʊɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn soʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝ dɛd bɪfɔɹ ɪt stʃɹʌk ðɛm. ʃi swʌŋ ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs ʌp tə hɝ aɪ lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə spɑt ðə wʊmən hoʊldɪŋ ə slɪm blæk ɹɑd ðəɾ əpɪɹd tə bi pɝhæps ə peɪs lɔŋ.

"This," Birgitte said, gesturing to the scene in front of them. Guybon had begun to trot, pulling the others with him, the three ranks holding steady in their advance, others coming as hard as they could to join them. Abruptly a leg-thick bar of what appeared to be liquid white fire shot out from one of the women beside the wagon. It quite literally carved a gap fifteen paces wide in the lines. For a heartbeat, shimmering flecks floated in the air, the shapes of men and horses struck, and then were consumed. The bar suddenly jerked up into the air, higher and higher, then winked out leaving dim purple lines across Birgitte's vision. Balefire, burning men out of the Pattern so that they were dead before it struck them. She swung the looking glass up to her eye long enough to spot the woman holding a slim black rod that appeared to be perhaps a pace long.

ɡaɪbɑn bɪɡæn tə tʃɑɹdʒ. ɪt wɑz tu sun, bʌɾ ɪz oʊnli hoʊp wɑz tə kloʊz waɪl i stɪl hæd mɛn əlaɪv. hɪz oʊnli hoʊp bʌt wʌn. oʊvɝ ðə θʌndɝəs ɪksploʊʒənz ə faɪɝbɔlz ən laɪtnɪŋ ɹoʊz ə ɹæɡəd kɹaɪ ʌv, "ɪleɪn ən ændɝ!" ɹæɡəd, bʌt fʊl-θɹoʊɾɪd. ðə bænɝz wɝ ɔl stʃɹimɪŋ. ə bɹeɪv saɪt, ɪf jə kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ haʊ mɛni wɝ fɔlɪŋ. ə hɔɹs ən ɹaɪɾɝ stʃɹʌk skwɛɹli baɪ ə faɪɝbɔl sɪmpli dɪsɪntəɡɹeɪɾɪd, mɛn ən hɔɹsəz ɔl ɝaʊn əm ɡoʊɪŋ daʊn əz wɛl. səm mænədʒ tə ɹaɪz əɡɛn. ə ɹaɪɾɝləs hɔɹs stʊɾ ɑn θɹi lɛɡz, tʃɹaɪd tə ɹʌn ən fɛl oʊvɝ θɹæʃɪŋ.

Guybon began to charge. It was too soon, but his only hope was to close while he still had men alive. His only hope but one. Over the thunderous explosions of fireballs and lightning rose a ragged cry of, "Elayne and Andor!" Ragged, but full-throated. The banners were all streaming. A brave sight, if you could ignore how many were falling. A horse and rider struck squarely by a fireball simply disintegrated, men and horses all around them going down as well. Some managed to rise again. A riderless horse stood on three legs, tried to run and fell over thrashing.

"ðɪs?" tʃənɛl sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "aɪ hæv noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə wɑtʃ mɛn daɪ." ənʌðɝ bɑɹ ə bɑlfaɪɝ slaɪst ə bɹitʃ ə nɪɹli twɛnti peɪsɪz ɪn ðə tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ ɹæŋks bɪfɔɹ naɪfəŋ daʊn ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, kʌɾɪŋ ə tʃɹɛntʃ hæfweɪ bæk tə ðə wæɡən bɪfɔɹ ɪt vænɪʃt. ðəɹ wɝ ə ɡʊd mɛni dɛd, ðoʊ nɑt soʊ mɛni əz ɪt sim ðəɹ ʃəd bi. bɝdʒɪt hæd sin ðə seɪm ɪn bæɾəlz dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz wɛɹ ðə paʊɝ hæd bɪn juzd. fəɹ ɛvɹi mæn u leɪ stɪl, tu əɹ θɹi wɝ stæɡɝɪŋ tə ðɛɹ fiɾ əɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɛm ə floʊ ʌv blʌd. fəɹ ɛvɹi hɔɹs stɪf-lɛɡəɾ ɪn dɛθ, tu mɔɹ stʊɾ ɑn wɑbəli lɛɡz. ðə heɪl ə faɪɝ ən laɪtnɪŋ kəntɪnjuɾ ʌnəbeɪɾɪd.

"This?" Chanelle said incredulously. "I have no desire to watch men die." Another bar of balefire sliced a breach of nearly twenty paces in the charging ranks before knifing down into the ground, cutting a trench halfway back to the wagon before it vanished. There were a good many dead, though not so many as it seemed there should be. Birgitte had seen the same in battles during the Trolloc Wars where the Power had been used. For every man who lay still, two or three were staggering to their feet or trying to stem a flow of blood. For every horse stiff-legged in death, two more stood on wobbly legs. The hail of fire and lightning continued unabated.

"ðɛn stɑp ɪt," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "ɪf ðeɪ kɪl ɔl ðə soʊlʒɝz, əɹ dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə ɹɛs bɹeɪk, ðən ɪleɪn ɪz lɔst." nɑt fɝɛvɝ. bɝn hɝ, ʃi wəd tʃɹæk əɹ fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ laɪf tə si hɝ fɹi, bʌt ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu wʌt ðeɪ maɪt də tə hɝ ɪn ðət taɪm. "zeɪɾəz bɑɹɡən ɪz lɔst. jəl əv lɔst ɪt."

"Then stop it," Birgitte said. "If they kill all the soldiers, or just enough to make the rest break, then Elayne is lost." Not forever. Burn her, she would track her for the rest of her life to see her free, but the Light only knew what they might do to her in that time. "Zaida's bargain is lost. You will have lost it."

ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɑz nɑt wɔɹm, jɛt swɛt biɾɪd ɑn tʃənɛlz fɔɹhɛd. faɪɝbɔlz ən laɪtnɪŋ ɪɹʌptəɾ əmʌŋ ðə ɹaɪɾɝz fɑloʊɪŋ ɡaɪbɑn. ðə wʊmən hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹɑd ɹeɪzd əɹ ɑɹm əɡɛn. ivən wɪθaʊt juzɪŋ ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, bɝdʒɪt wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz pɔɪntəd stʃɹeɪɾ ət ɡaɪbɑn. hi hæd tə si ɪt, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ swɝvd ə hɛɹ.

The morning was not warm, yet sweat beaded on Chanelle's forehead. Fireballs and lightning erupted among the riders following Guybon. The woman holding the rod raised her arm again. Even without using the looking glass, Birgitte was sure it was pointed straight at Guybon. He had to see it, but he never swerved a hair.

sʌɾənli ənʌðɝ boʊlt ə laɪtnɪŋ slæʃt daʊn. ən stʃɹʌk ðə wʊmən hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹɑd. ʃi flu ɪn wʌn dɝɛkʃən, hɝ maʊn ɪn ənʌðɝ. wʌn ə ðə wæɡən tim sæɡd tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd waɪl ði ʌðɝz dænst ən ɹɪɹd. ðeɪ wʊɾə ɹʌn ɪksɛp fəɹ ðɛɹ dɛd tʃɹeɪs-meɪt. ði ʌðɝ hɔɹsəz ɝaʊn ðə wæɡən wɝ ɹɪɹɪŋ ən plʌnʒɪŋ, tu. ðə ɹeɪn ə faɪɝ ən laɪtnɪŋ sist əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fɔt tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, tə meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz. ɹæðɝ ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɑm ɪz tim, ðə mæn ɑn ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz sit lɛp daʊn ən dʒɹu hɪz sɔɹɾ əz i bɪɡæn tə ɹʌn təwɔɹd ðə tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ hɔɹsmən. ði ɔnlʊkɝz ɪn loʊ keɪɛmlɪn wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ əɡɛn, tu, ðɪs taɪm əweɪ.

Suddenly another bolt of lightning slashed down. And struck the woman holding the rod. She flew in one direction, her mount in another. One of the wagon team sagged to the ground while the others danced and reared. They would have run except for their dead trace-mate. The other horses around the wagon were rearing and plunging, too. The rain of fire and lightning ceased as the Aes Sedai fought to control their horses, to maintain their saddles. Rather than trying to calm his team, the man on the driver's seat leaped down and drew his sword as he began to run toward the charging horsemen. The onlookers in Low Caemlyn were running again, too, this time away.

"teɪk ði ʌðɝz əlaɪv!" bɝdʒɪt snæpt. ʃi dɪd nɑt mʌtʃ kɛɹ wɛðɝ ðeɪ lɪvd - ðeɪ wəd daɪ sun ɪnʌf fəɹ biɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ən mɝɾɝɝz - bʌɾ ɪleɪn wɑz ɪn ðət blʌɾi wæɡən!

"Take the others alive!" Birgitte snapped. She did not much care whether they lived - they would die soon enough for being Darkfriends and murderers - but Elayne was in that bloody wagon!

tʃənɛl nɑɾəd stɪfli, ən ɝaʊn ðə wæɡən, ɹaɪɾɝz bɪɡæn tɑpəlɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ fɹækʃəs maʊns tə laɪ stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn əz ɪf baʊn hæn ən fʊt. wɪtʃ ðeɪ wɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə ɹʌnɪŋ mæn fɛl ɑn ɪz feɪs ən leɪ ɹaɪðɪŋ. "aɪ ʃildɪd ðə wɪmən, tu," tʃənɛl sɛd. ivən hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn noʊ mætʃ fəɹ ə sɝkəl ʌv eɪt.

Chanelle nodded stiffly, and around the wagon, riders began toppling from their fractious mounts to lie struggling on the ground as if bound hand and foot. Which they were, of course. The running man fell on his face and lay writhing. "I shielded the women, too," Chanelle said. Even holding the Power, they would have been no match for a circle of eight.

ɡaɪbɑn ɹeɪzd ɪz hænd, sloʊɪŋ ðə tʃɑɹdʒ tə ə wɔk. ɪt wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl haʊ ʃɔɹɾ ə taɪm ɪɾ ɔl hæd teɪkən. hi wɑz lɛs ðən hæfweɪ tə ðə wæɡən. mɛn maʊntəɾ ən əfʊt wɝ stɪl pɔɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. swɪŋɪŋ ɪndə ðə dʌnz sæɾəl, bɝdʒɪt ɡæləp təwɔɹɾ ɪleɪn. blʌɾi wʊmən, ʃi θɔt. ðə bɑn hæd nɛvɝ wʌns kæɹiɾ ɛni hɪn ə fɪɹ.

Guybon raised his hand, slowing the charge to a walk. It was remarkable how short a time it all had taken. He was less than halfway to the wagon. Men mounted and afoot were still pouring out of the gateway. Swinging into the dun's saddle, Birgitte galloped toward Elayne. Bloody woman, she thought. The bond had never once carried any hint of fear.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾiθɹi

CHAPTER 33

naɪn aʊɾ ə tɛn ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz hæd teɪkən noʊ tʃænsəz wɪð ɪleɪn. əsaɪd fɹəm ʃildɪŋ hɝ, təmeɪl hæd teɪkən simɪŋli məlɪʃəs plɛʒɝ ɪn taɪɪŋ əɹ ɪn ə taɪt nɑt wɪð əɹ hɛd bɪtwin əɹ niz. hɝ mʌsəlz ɔlɹɛɾi ætʃt fɹəm ðə kɹæmpt pəzɪʃən. ðə ɡæɡ, ə dɝɾi pis ə ɹæɡ wɪð ə vaɪl, ɔɪli teɪst, taɪd soʊ taɪtli ðəɾ ɪt dʌɡ ɪndə ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ maʊθ, hæd bɪn mɛn tə kip əɹ fɹəm ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ hɛlp ət ðə ɡeɪts. nɑt ðət ʃi wəd hæv; ɔl ðət wʊɾə dʌn wɑz sɛntəns ðə mɛn ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə ɡeɪts tə dɛθ. ʃi kəd fil ðə sɪks blæk sɪstɝz hoʊldɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ θɹu ðə ɡeɪt. bʌt ðə blaɪndfoʊl hæd bɪn ən ənnɛsəsɛɹi tʌtʃ. ʃi θɔt ðeɪ wɑntəd tə æd tə hɝ sɛns ə hɛlpləsnəs, jɛt ʃi ɹəfjuz tə fil hɛlpləs. æftɝ ɔl, ʃi wɑz pɝfəkli seɪf əntɪl əɹ beɪbiz wɝ bɔɹn, ən soʊ wɝ əɹ beɪbiz. mɪn hæd sɛd soʊ.

Nine Out of Ten The Darkfriends had taken no chances with Elayne. Aside from shielding her, Temaile had taken seemingly malicious pleasure in tying her in a tight knot with her head between her knees. Her muscles already ached from the cramped position. The gag, a dirty piece of rag with a vile, oily taste, tied so tightly that it dug into the corners of her mouth, had been meant to keep her from shouting for help at the gates. Not that she would have; all that would have done was sentence the men guarding the gates to death. She could feel the six Black sisters holding saidar until they were through the gate. But the blindfold had been an unnecessary touch. She thought they wanted to add to her sense of helplessness, yet she refused to feel helpless. After all, she was perfectly safe until her babies were born, and so were her babies. Min had said so.

ʃi nu ʃi wɑz ɪn ə wæɡən əɹ kɑɹt baɪ ðə saʊn ə hɑɹnəs ən ðə fil ə ɹʌf bɔɹdz bɪniθ hɝ. ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɑðɝd tə pæd ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz wɪð ə blæŋkət. ə wæɡən, ʃi θɔt. ðəɹ sim tə bi mɔɹ ðən wʌn hɔɹs pʊlɪŋ ɪt. ðə wæɡən bɑks smɛld ʌv oʊl heɪ soʊ stʃɹɔŋli ðət ʃi wɑntəd tə sniz. hɝ sɪtʃueɪʃən sim hoʊpləs, bʌt bɝdʒɪt wəd nɑt feɪl hɝ.

She knew she was in a wagon or cart by the sound of harness and the feel of rough boards beneath her. They had not bothered to pad the floorboards with a blanket. A wagon, she thought. There seemed to be more than one horse pulling it. The wagon box smelled of old hay so strongly that she wanted to sneeze. Her situation seemed hopeless, but Birgitte would not fail her.

ʃi fɛl bɝdʒɪt lip fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ maɪlz bɪhaɪn əɹ tə pɝhæps ə maɪl əhɛd, ən ʃi wɑntəd tə læf. ðə bɑn sɛd bɝdʒɪt wɑz eɪmd əɾ əɹ tɑɹɡət, ən bɝdʒɪt sɪlvɝboʊ nɛvɝ mɪst. wən ðə tʃænəlɪŋ stɑɹɾəd ɑn boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə wæɡən, ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə læf feɪɾəd. dɪtɝməneɪʃən hɛld ɹɑk-stɛɾi ɪn ðə bɑnd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls əz wɛl, naʊ, ə stʃɹɔŋ dɪsteɪst ən ə ɹaɪzɪŋ . . . nɑɾ æŋɡɝ, bʌt kloʊs. mɛn wəd bi daɪɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ. ɪnstɛɾ ə læfɪŋ, ɪleɪn wɑntəd tə wip fəɹ ðɛm. ðeɪ dɪzɝv sʌmwʌn tə wip fəɹ ðɛm, ən ðeɪ wɝ daɪɪŋ fəɹ hɝ. əz vændin ən sɝaɪðə hæd daɪd. sædnəs fəɹ əm wɛld ʌp ɪn əɹ əɡɛn. noʊ ɡɪlt, ðoʊ. oʊnli baɪ lɛɾɪŋ fæljən ən mɑɹilɪn wɔk fɹi kəd ðeɪv bɪn spɛɹd, ən niðɝ wʊɾə kaʊntənəns ðæt. ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ weɪ tə æntɪsəpeɪt ði ɝaɪvəl ə ði ʌðɝz, əɹ ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ wɛpən æn hæd.

She felt Birgitte leap from somewhere miles behind her to perhaps a mile ahead, and she wanted to laugh. The bond said Birgitte was aimed at her target, and Birgitte Silverbow never missed. When the channeling started on both sides of the wagon, the desire to laugh faded. Determination held rock-steady in the bond, but there was something else as well, now, a strong distaste and a rising . . . not anger, but close. Men would be dying out there. Instead of laughing, Elayne wanted to weep for them. They deserved someone to weep for them, and they were dying for her. As Vandene and Sareitha had died. Sadness for them welled up in her again. No guilt, though. Only by letting Falion and Marillin walk free could they have been spared, and neither would have countenanced that. There had been no way to anticipate the arrival of the others, or that strange weapon Asne had.

ə θʌndɝəs kɹæʃ keɪm kloʊs ət hænd, ən əɹ kənveɪəns wɑz dʒoʊltɪd soʊ vaɪələnli ðət ʃi baʊnst ɑn ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz. hɝ niz ən ʃɪnz wɝ gɑnə bi bɹuz fɹəm ðæt. ʃi snizd ɪn ðə dʌs ðət hæd ɹɪzən wɪð hɝ, snizd əɡɛn. ʃi kəd fil ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl hɛɹz lɪftɪŋ wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt hɛl daʊn baɪ ðə ɡæɡ ən blaɪndfoʊld. ði ɛɹ smɛl pəkjuljɝ. ə laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹaɪk, ɪɾ əpɪɹd. ʃi hoʊp bɝdʒɪt hæd mænədʒ tə ɪnvɑlv ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, ənlaɪkli əz ðət simd. ðə taɪm wəd kʌm wən ðə kɪn wəɾ əv tə juz ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən - noʊ wʌn kəd stæn əsaɪd fɹəm tɑɹmən ɡdən - bʌt lɛɾ əm pɹəzɝv ðɛɹ ɪnəsəns ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. moʊməns leɪɾɝ, ðə ʃild ɑn əɹ vænɪʃt.

A thunderous crash came close at hand, and her conveyance was jolted so violently that she bounced on the floorboards. Her knees and shins were going to be bruised from that. She sneezed in the dust that had risen with her, sneezed again. She could feel individual hairs lifting where they were not held down by the gag and blindfold. The air smelled peculiar. A lightning strike, it appeared. She hoped Birgitte had managed to involve the Windfinders, unlikely as that seemed. The time would come when the Kin would have to use the Power as a weapon - no one could stand aside from Tarmon Gai'don - but let them preserve their innocence a little longer. Moments later, the shield on her vanished.

əneɪbəl tə si, ʃi kəd nɑt tʃænəl tə ɛni ɹil pɝpəs, bʌt ʃi kəd sɛns wivz nɪɹ hɝ, səm ə spɪɹət, səm ʌv ɛɹ. wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ðə wivz, ʃi wɑz əneɪbəl tə noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ, jɛt ʃi kəd meɪk ə ɹizənəbəl ɡɛs. hɝ kæptɝz wɝ ðɛmsɛlvz kæptɪvz naʊ, ʃildɪɾ ən baʊnd. ən ɔl ʃi kəd də wɑz weɪɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. bɝdʒɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ ɹæpədli, jɛt naʊ ʃi fɛlt æŋkʃəs tə hæv ðət blʌɾi wɛb ə ɹoʊps ɔf hɝ.

Unable to see, she could not channel to any real purpose, but she could sense weaves near her, some of Spirit, some of Air. Without seeing the weaves, she was unable to know what they were, yet she could make a reasonable guess. Her captors were themselves captives now, shielded and bound. And all she could do was wait impatiently. Birgitte was coming closer rapidly, yet now she felt anxious to have that bloody web of ropes off her.

ðə wæɡən bɑks kɹikt əz sʌmwʌn hiv hɝsɛlf ɪn. bɝdʒɪt. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ ə flæʃ ə dʒɔɪ. ɪn moʊməns, ðə ɹoʊps fɛl əweɪ fɹəm əɹ ən bɝdʒɪts hænz wɛn tə ðə nɑɾ ə ðə ɡæɡ. muvɪŋ ə lɪɾəl stɪfli, ɪleɪn əntaɪd ðə blaɪndfoʊl hɝsɛlf. laɪt, ʃi wɑz gɑnə eɪk laɪk fjʊɹi əntɪl ʃi kəɾ æsk fəɹ hilɪŋ. ðət ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ ðət ʃi wəɾ əv tə æsk ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, ən ðə sædnəs ɹoʊz ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn fəɹ vændin ən sɝaɪðə.

The wagon box creaked as someone heaved herself in. Birgitte. The bond carried a flash of joy. In moments, the ropes fell away from her and Birgitte's hands went to the knot of the gag. Moving a little stiffly, Elayne untied the blindfold herself. Light, she was going to ache like fury until she could ask for Healing. That reminded her that she would have to ask the Windfinders, and the sadness rose all over again for Vandene and Sareitha.

wʌns ʃi kəd spɪɾ aʊt ðə ɡæɡ, ʃi wɑntəd tə æsk fəɹ wɔɾɝ tə wɑʃ əweɪ ði ɔɪli teɪst, bʌɾ ɪnstɛd, ʃi sɛd, "wʌt kɛp ju?" hɝ læftɝ ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz sʌɾən kɑnstɝneɪʃən wɑz kʌt ʃɔɹt baɪ ənʌðɝ sniz. "lɛts ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ, bɝdʒɪt. ðə kɪn?"

Once she could spit out the gag, she wanted to ask for water to wash away the oily taste, but instead, she said, "What kept you?" Her laughter at the other woman's sudden consternation was cut short by another sneeze. "Let's get out of here, Birgitte. The Kin?"

"wɪndfɪndɝz," bɝdʒɪɾ ænsɝd, hoʊldɪŋ oʊpən ðə kænvəs flæp ət ðə bæk ə ðə wæɡən. "tʃənɛl dɪsaɪɾɪd ʃid ɹæðɝ nɑt ɹipɔɹt luzɪŋ əɹ bɑɹɡən tə zeɪɾə."

"Windfinders," Birgitte answered, holding open the canvas flap at the back of the wagon. "Chanelle decided she'd rather not report losing her bargain to Zaida."

ɪleɪn snɪft ɪn dɪsdeɪn, ə mɪsteɪk. snizɪŋ ɹɪpiɾɪdli, ʃi klaɪm daʊn fɹəm ðə wæɡən əz kwɪkli əz ʃi kəd mænədʒ. hɝ lɛɡz wɝ əz stɪf əz əɹ ɑɹmz. bɝn hɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑntəɾ ə hɑt bæθ. ən ə hɛɹbɹʌʃ. bɝdʒɪts waɪt-kɑlɝd ɹɛd koʊt lʊk sʌmwʌt ɹʌmpəld, bʌɾ ɪleɪn səspɛktəd ʃi meɪɾ əɹ wɔɹɾɝ əpɪɹ fɹɛʃ fɹəm ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum.

Elayne sniffed in disdain, a mistake. Sneezing repeatedly, she climbed down from the wagon as quickly as she could manage. Her legs were as stiff as her arms. Burn her, but she wanted a hot bath. And a hairbrush. Birgitte's white-collared red coat looked somewhat rumpled, but Elayne suspected she made her warder appear fresh from the dressing room.

wən əɹ fit hɪt ðə ɡɹaʊnd, maʊntəd ɡɑɹdzmɪn ɪn ə θɪk ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə wæɡən ɹeɪzd ə laʊd tʃɪɹ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ lænsɪz ɪn ði ɛɹ. ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wupt, tu, əpɛɹənli ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə ðɛm. tu ʌv ðə mɛn bɔɹ ændɝz waɪt laɪən ən əɹ ɡoʊldən lɪli. ðət bɹɔɾ ə smaɪl. ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz wɝ swɔɹn tə dɪfɛn ændɝ, ðə kwin ən ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, jɛt ðə dɪsɪʒən tə kæɹi hɝ pɝsənəl bænɝ hæd tə hæv bɪn ɑɹlz ɡaɪbɑnz. sɪɾɪŋ ə tɔl beɪ wɪð ɪz hɛlmət ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ðə sæɾəlboʊ, hi baʊd tə hɝ, ə bɹɔd smaɪl ɑn ɪz lɪps. ðə mæn wɑz ə plɛʒɝ tə lʊk æt. pɝhæps i wəd də fəɹ ə θɝd wɔɹɾɝ. bɪɑn ðə ɡɑɹdz ɹoʊz haʊs bænɝz ən bænɝz ə mɝsənɛɹi kʌmpəniz, bænɝ æftɝ bænɝ. laɪt, haʊ mɛni mɛn hæd bɝdʒɪt bɹɔt? ðət kəd bi ænsɝd leɪɾɝ, ðoʊ. fɝst ɪleɪn wɑntəd tə si hɝ pɹɪznɝz.

When her feet hit the ground, mounted Guardsmen in a thick ring around the wagon raised a loud cheer, shaking their lances in the air. Guardswomen whooped, too, apparently almost every last one of them. Two of the men bore Andor's White Lion and her Golden Lily. That brought a smile. The Queen's Guards were sworn to defend Andor, the Queen and the Daughter-Heir, yet the decision to carry her personal banner had to have been Charlz Guybon's. Sitting a tall bay with his helmet resting on the saddlebow, he bowed to her, a broad smile on his lips. The man was a pleasure to look at. Perhaps he would do for a third Warder. Beyond the Guards rose House banners and banners of mercenary companies, banner after banner. Light, how many men had Birgitte brought? That could be answered later, though. First Elayne wanted to see her prisoners.

æn leɪ spɹɛdiɡəld ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, hɝ ɛmpti aɪz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə skaɪ; ðə ʃild ɑn əɹ wɑz ənniɾɪd. ði ʌðɝz leɪ əz stɪl, baʊnd wɪð floʊz ʌv ɛɹ ðət hɛl ðɛɹ ɑɹmz tə ðɛɹ saɪdz ən snʌɡd ðɛɹ dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts əɡɛns ðɛɹ lɛɡz. ə mʌtʃ mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl pəzɪʃən ðən ʃi hæd bɪn ɪn. moʊst simd ɹɪmɑɹkəbli kəmpoʊz kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðɛɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən, ðoʊ təmeɪl skaʊld əɾ əɹ ən fæljən əpɪɹɾ əbaʊt tə sɪk ʌp. ʃieɪnz mʌd-smɪɹd feɪs wʊɾə dʌn kɹɛɾət tə ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə θɹi mɛn baʊnd wɪð ɛɹ wɝ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt kəmpoʊzd. ðeɪ ɹɪθd ən stʃɹʌɡəld, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɹaɪɾɝz sɝaʊndɪŋ əm əz ɪf ðeɪ wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən tə ətæk əm ɔl. ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə aɪdɛntəfaɪ ðɛm əz ænz wɔɹɾɝz, ðoʊ nɑt nɛsəsɛɹəli əz dɑɹkfɹɛnz. wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ əɹ nɑt, ðeɪ wəd stɪl əv tə bi ɪmpɹɪzənd, tə pɹətɛkt ʌðɝz fɹəm ðə dɛθ-ɹeɪdʒ ðəɾ ænz dɛθ hæd fɪld əm wɪð. ðeɪ wəd də ɛniθɪŋ tə kɪl humɛvɝ ðeɪ hɛld ɹispɑnsəbəl.

Asne lay spreadeagled on the road, her empty eyes staring at the sky; the shield on her was unneeded. The others lay as still, bound with flows of Air that held their arms to their sides and snugged their divided skirts against their legs. A much more comfortable position than she had been in. Most seemed remarkably composed considering their situation, though Temaile scowled at her and Falion appeared about to sick up. Shiaine's mud-smeared face would have done credit to any Aes Sedai. The three men bound with Air were anything but composed. They writhed and struggled, glaring at the riders surrounding them as if they wanted nothing more than to attack them all. That was enough to identify them as Asne's Warders, though not necessarily as Darkfriends. Whether they were or not, they would still have to be imprisoned, to protect others from the death-rage that Asne's death had filled them with. They would do anything to kill whomever they held responsible.

"haʊ dɪd ðeɪ faɪn ʌs?" tʃɛzməl dɪmændəd. ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹoʊd wɪð ə dɝɾi feɪs, noʊ wʌn wʊɾə θɔɾ əɹ ə pɹɪznɝ.

"How did they find us?" Chesmal demanded. If she had not been lying in the road with a dirty face, no one would have thought her a prisoner.

"maɪ wɔɹɾɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ ət bɝdʒɪt. "wʌn ə ðɛm."

"My Warder," Elayne said, smiling at Birgitte. "One of them."

"ə wʊmən wɔɹɾɝ?" tʃɛzməl sɛd dɪsdeɪnfəli.

"A woman Warder?" Chesmal said disdainfully.

mɑɹilɪn ʃʊk ɪn əɹ bɑnz wɪð saɪlən læftɝ fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "aɪd hɝd ðæt," ʃi sɛd wən ðə ʃeɪkɪŋ sist, "bʌɾ ɪt sim tu ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl tə bi tʃɹu."

Marillin shook in her bonds with silent laughter for a moment. "I'd heard that," she said when the shaking ceased, "but it seemed too incredible to be true."

"ju hɝd ðɪs, ən jə nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ɪt?" təmeɪl sɛd, twɪstɪŋ ɝaʊn tə tʃɹænsfɝ əɹ skaʊl tə mɑɹilɪn. "ju ɡɹeɪt ful!"

"You heard this, and you never mentioned it?" Temaile said, twisting around to transfer her scowl to Marillin. "You great fool!"

"ju fɝɡɛt jɝsɛlf," mɑɹilɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli, ən ðə nɛkst ɪnstən ðeɪ wɝ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ əbaʊt wɛðɝ təmeɪl ʃəd dɪfɝ tə hɝ! ɪn tʃɹuθ, təmeɪl ʃəd - ɪleɪn kəd sɛns ðɛɹ ɹɛləɾɪv stʃɹɛŋkθs - jɛɾ ɪt hɑɹdli simd ə tɑpɪk ðeɪ wəɾ ɑɹɡju oʊvɝ naʊ!

"You forget yourself," Marillin said sharply, and the next instant they were arguing about whether Temaile should defer to her! In truth, Temaile should - Elayne could sense their relative strengths - yet it hardly seemed a topic they would argue over now!

"sʌmbɑɾi ɡæɡ ðiz wɪmən," ɪleɪn ɔɹɾɝd. keɪsil dɪsmaʊntɪd, hændɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz tə ənʌðɝ ɡɑɹdzwʊmən, ən stʃɹoʊɾ oʊvɝ tə bɪɡɪn kʌɾɪŋ ə stʃɹɪp fɹəm təmeɪlz skɝts wɪð əɹ dæɡɝ. "loʊɾ əm ɪndə ðə wæɡən ən kʌɾ əweɪ ðət dɛd hɔɹs. aɪ wɑnə ɡɛt bæk ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz bɪfɔɹ ɛɹəmɪləz pipəl bɪɑn ðə ɹɪdʒ fil tɛmptəd." ðə læs θɪŋ ʃi niɾəd naʊ wɑz ə pɪtʃt bæɾəl. wʌtɛvɝ ði aʊtkʌm, ɛɹəmɪlə kəɾ əfɔɹd tə luz mɔɹ mɛn ðən ʃi. "wɛɹ ɑɹ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, bɝdʒɪt?"

"Somebody gag these women," Elayne ordered. Caseille dismounted, handing her reins to another Guardswoman, and strode over to begin cutting a strip from Temaile's skirts with her dagger. "Load them into the wagon and cut away that dead horse. I want to get back inside the walls before Arymilla's people beyond the ridge feel tempted." The last thing she needed now was a pitched battle. Whatever the outcome, Arymilla could afford to lose more men than she. "Where are the Windfinders, Birgitte?"

"stɪl ɑn ðə ɹɪdʒ. aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ bɪliv ðeɪ kən dɪnaɪ teɪkɪŋ pɑɹɾ ɪf ðeɪ doʊnt ɡɛt tu nɪɹ ðə kɑɹnɪdʒ. bʌt jə doʊn əv tə wɝi əbaʊt biɪŋ ətæk hɪɹ. ðə kæmps bɪɑn ðə ɹɪdʒ ɑɹ ɛmpti." keɪsil hɔɪstəd təmeɪl oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən stæɡɝɾ oʊvɝ tə hiv əɹ ɪndə ðə wæɡən laɪk ə sæk ʌv ɡɹeɪn. ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɝ pɪkɪŋ ʌp ði ʌðɝ wɪmən, tu. ðeɪ waɪzli lɛf ðə stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ wɔɹɾɝz tə ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn. ɪt ɹikwaɪɝd tu tə hændəl itʃ ə ðɛm. ə pɛɹ ə tɔl ɡɑɹdzmɪn wɝ ənfæsənɪŋ ðə dɛd hɔɹsəz hɑɹnəs.

"Still on the ridge. I think they believe they can deny taking part if they don't get too near the carnage. But you don't have to worry about being attacked here. The camps beyond the ridge are empty." Caseille hoisted Temaile over her shoulder and staggered over to heave her into the wagon like a sack of grain. Guardswomen were picking up the other women, too. They wisely left the struggling Warders to the Guardsmen. It required two to handle each of them. A pair of tall Guardsmen were unfastening the dead horse's harness.

"ɔl aɪ sɔ wɝ kæmp fɑloʊɝz, ɡɹumz ən ðə laɪk," ɑɹlz pʊɾ ɪn.

"All I saw were camp followers, grooms and the like," Charlz put in.

"aɪ θɪŋk ɔl ə hɝ kæmps meɪ bi ɛmpti," bɝdʒɪt wɛn ɑn. "ʃi sɛn hɛvi əsɔls əɡɛns ðə nɔɹðɝn wɔl ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ tə dʒɹɔ əz mɛni ʌv əɹ mɛn əz pɑsəbəl, ən ʃiz twɛnti θaʊzən əɹ mɔɹ ɪn loʊ keɪɛmlɪn bɪloʊ ðə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡeɪt. səm ə ðə mɝsənɛɹiz tʃeɪnʒd kʌlɝz ən ɑɹ ətækɪŋ ɪt fɹəm ɪnsaɪd, bʌɾ aɪ sɛn daɪɛlɪn wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ kəd spɛɹ. əz sun əz jəɹ seɪf ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz, əl teɪk ðə ɹɛs tə hɛlp hɝ. tə æd tə ðə ɡʊd nuz, lwɑn ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðət lɑɾ ɑɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ nɔɹθ. ðeɪ kəd bi hɪɹ ðɪs æftɝnun."

"I think all of her camps may be empty," Birgitte went on. "She sent heavy assaults against the northern wall this morning to draw as many of our men as possible, and she has twenty thousand or more in Low Caemlyn below the Far Madding Gate. Some of the mercenaries changed colors and are attacking it from inside, but I sent Dyelin with everything I could spare. As soon as you're safe inside the walls, I'll take the rest to help her. To add to the good news, Luan and the rest of that lot are riding north. They could be here this afternoon."

ɪleɪnz bɹɛθ kɑt. lwɑn ən ðə ɹɛst wəɾ əv tə bi dɛlt wɪð wən ðeɪ əpɪɹd, bʌt ði ʌðɝ nuz . . . ! "du jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ ɹipɔɹɾəd, bɝdʒɪt? ɛɹəmɪlə ən ði ʌðɝz ɔl ɪntɛn tə bi wɪð ðə fɝs pɑɹɾi tə ɹaɪɾ ɪndə keɪɛmlɪn. ðeɪ mʌs bi aʊtsaɪd ðə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡeɪt, tu. haʊ mɛni mɛn juv hɪɹ?"

Elayne's breath caught. Luan and the rest would have to be dealt with when they appeared, but the other news . . . ! "Do you remember what Mistress Harfor reported, Birgitte? Arymilla and the others all intend to be with the first party to ride into Caemlyn. They must be outside the Far Madding Gate, too. How many men do you have here?"

"wʌts ðə bʊtʃɝz bɪl, ɡaɪbɑn?" bɝdʒɪɾ æskt, aɪɪŋ ɪleɪn wɛɹəli. ðə bɑn kæɹid wɛɹinɪs, tu. ɡɹeɪt wɛɹinɪs.

"What's the butcher's bill, Guybon?" Birgitte asked, eyeing Elayne warily. The bond carried wariness, too. Great wariness.

"aɪ doʊn əv ə fʊl tæli jɛt, maɪ leɪɾi. səm ə ðə bɑɾiz. . . ." ɑɹlz ɡɹɪməst. "aɪd seɪ əz mɛni əz faɪv əɹ sɪks hʌnʒɹəd dɛd, ðoʊ, pɝhæps ə fju mɔɹ. twaɪs əz mɛni wundəd wʌn weɪ ən ənʌðɝ. əz næsti ə fju mɪnəts əz aɪv ɛvɝ sin."

"I don't have a full tally yet, my Lady. Some of the bodies. . . ." Charlz grimaced. "I'd say as many as five or six hundred dead, though, perhaps a few more. Twice as many wounded one way and another. As nasty a few minutes as I've ever seen."

"kɔl ɪt tɛn θaʊzənd, ɪleɪn," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, θɪk bɹeɪd sweɪɪŋ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ʃi tʌkt əɹ θʌmz bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt, ən dɪtɝməneɪʃən fɪl ðə bɑnd. "ɛɹəmɪlə hæz tə hæv ət lis twaɪs ðəɾ ət ðə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡeɪt, meɪbi θɹi taɪmz ɪf ʃiz ɹɪli stʃɹɪpt əɹ kæmps. ɪf jəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ wʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ. . . . aɪ toʊl daɪɛlɪn tə ɹiteɪk ðə ɡeɪɾ ɪf ɪt hæd fɔlən, bʌɾ ɪts mɔɹ laɪkli ʃiz faɪɾɪŋ ɛɹəmɪlə ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. ɪf, baɪ səm mɪɹəkəl, ðə ɡeɪɾ ɪz hoʊldɪŋ, jəɹ tɔkɪŋ bɛɾɝ ðən tu tə wʌn ɑdz əɡɛnst ʌs."

"Call it ten thousand, Elayne," Birgitte said, thick braid swaying as she shook her head. She tucked her thumbs behind her belt, and determination filled the bond. "Arymilla has to have at least twice that at the Far Madding Gate, maybe three times if she's really stripped her camps. If you're thinking what I think you're thinking. . . . I told Dyelin to retake the gate if it had fallen, but it's more likely she's fighting Arymilla inside the city. If, by some miracle, the gate is holding, you're talking better than two to one odds against us."

"ɪf ðəɹ θɹu ðə ɡeɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd stʌbɝnli, "ɪts ənlaɪkli ðeɪ kloʊzd ɪt bɪhaɪn ðɛm. wɪl teɪk əm ɪn ðə ɹɪɹ." ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɔl stʌbɝnnəs. nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli. ʃi hæd nɑt tʃɹeɪnd wɪð wɛpənz, bʌt ʃi hæd ɹəsivd ɔl ə ði ʌðɝ lɛsənz ɡɔɪn hæd ɡɑɾən fɹəm ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. ə kwin hæd tə ʌndɝstæn ðə bæɾəl plænz əɹ dʒɛnɝəlz ɡeɪv əɹ ɹæðɝ ðən sɪmpli æksɛpt əm blaɪnli. "ɪf ðə ɡeɪɾ ɪz hoʊldɪŋ, wɪl əv əm tʃɹæp bɪtwin əs ən ðə wɔl. nʌmbɝz woʊn kaʊn soʊ mʌtʃ ɪn loʊ keɪɛmlɪn. ɛɹəmɪlə woʊn bi eɪbəl tə laɪn ʌp ɛni mɔɹ mɛn əkɹɔs ə stʃɹit ðən wi kæn. wəɹ gɑnə də ɪt, bɝdʒɪt. naʊ sʌmbɑɾi faɪn mi ə hɔɹs."

"If they're through the gate," Elayne said stubbornly, "it's unlikely they closed it behind them. We'll take them in the rear." It was not all stubbornness. Not entirely. She had not trained with weapons, but she had received all of the other lessons Gawyn had gotten from Gareth Bryne. A queen had to understand the battle plans her generals gave her rather than simply accept them blindly. "If the gate is holding, we'll have them trapped between us and the wall. Numbers won't count so much in Low Caemlyn. Arymilla won't be able to line up any more men across a street than we can. We are going to do it, Birgitte. Now somebody find me a horse."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi θɔt ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɹəfjuz, wɪtʃ ɹætʃəɾɪd ʌp əɹ stʌbɝnnəs, bʌt bɝdʒɪɾ ɛksheɪl hɛvəli. "zɪɡən, kætʃ ʌp ðət tɔl ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ fəɹ leɪɾi ɪleɪn."

For a moment, she thought the other woman was going to refuse, which ratcheted up her stubbornness, but Birgitte exhaled heavily. "Tzigan, catch up that tall gray mare for Lady Elayne."

ɪt sim ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɝaʊn əm ɪksɛp ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz saɪd. ðeɪ mʌst əv θɔt ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə si ə dɪspleɪ ʌv ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənz feɪbəl tɛmpɝ. noʊɪŋ ðəɾ ɔlmoʊst spɑɹkt wʌn. bɝn əɹ baʊnsɪŋ mudz!

It seemed that everyone around them except the Darkfriends sighed. They must have thought they were going to see a display of Elayne Trakand's fabled temper. Knowing that almost sparked one. Burn her bouncing moods!

stɛpɪŋ kloʊsɝ, bɝdʒɪt loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs. "bʌt jəl ɹaɪd sɝaʊndəd baɪ jəɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹd. ðɪs ɪzən səm ful stɔɹi wɪð ə kwin kæɹiɪŋ əɹ bænɝ ɪndə bæɾəl tə liɾ əɹ tʃɹups. aɪ noʊ wʌn ə jəɹ ænsɛstɝz dɪd ðæt, bʌt jəɹ nɑt hɝ, ən jə doʊn əv ə bɹoʊkən ɑɹmi tə ɹæli."

Stepping closer, Birgitte lowered her voice. "But you'll ride surrounded by your bodyguard. This isn't some fool story with a queen carrying her banner into battle to lead her troops. I know one of your ancestors did that, but you're not her, and you don't have a broken army to rally."

"waɪ, ðət wɑz ɪɡzækli maɪ plæn," ɪleɪn sɛd switli. "haʊ ɛvɝ dɪd jə ɡɛs?"

"Why, that was exactly my plan," Elayne said sweetly. "How ever did you guess?"

bɝdʒɪt snɔɹɾɪd wɪð læftɝ ən mʌɾɝd "blʌɾi wʊmən" nɑt kwaɪt sɔfli ɪnʌf tə ɪskeɪp dɪtɛkʃən. əfɛkʃən floʊɾ ɪn ðə bɑnd, ðoʊ.

Birgitte snorted with laughter and muttered "Bloody woman" not quite softly enough to escape detection. Affection flowed in the bond, though.

ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ sɪmpəl, ʌv kɔɹs. mɛn hæd tə bi toʊld ɔf tə hɛlp ðə wundəd. səm kəd wɔk, bʌt mɛni kəd nɑt. tu mɛni hæd tʃɹnikɪts ɝaʊn ðə blʌɾi stʌmp ʌv ən ɑɹm əɹ ə lɛɡ. ɑɹlz ən ðə noʊbəlz ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ɪleɪn ən bɝdʒɪt tə hɪɹ ðə plæn ʌv ətæk, wɪtʃ wɑz sɪmpəl ə nəsɛsəɾi, bʌt ðən tʃənɛl ɹəfjuz tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ əntɪl ɪleɪn əɡɹid ðət ðɪs taɪm ðeɪ nid pɹəvaɪd tʃɹænspɔɹɾ oʊnli ən sil ði əɡɹimənt wɪð əm boʊθ kɪsɪŋ ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps ən pɹɛsɪŋ əm tə ði ʌðɝz lɪps. oʊnli ðən dɪd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ dwɪndəl tə ə vɝɾɪkəl sɪlvɝi slæʃ ən waɪɾən əɡɛn ɪndə ə hʌnʒɹəd-peɪs-waɪd vju ʌv keɪɛmlɪn fɹəm ðə saʊθ.

It was not so simple, of course. Men had to be told off to help the wounded. Some could walk, but many could not. Too many had tourniquets around the bloody stump of an arm or a leg. Charlz and the nobles gathered around Elayne and Birgitte to hear the plan of attack, which was simple of necessity, but then Chanelle refused to change the gateway until Elayne agreed that this time they need provide transport only and sealed the agreement with them both kissing their fingertips and pressing them to the other's lips. Only then did the gateway dwindle to a vertical silvery slash and widen again into a hundred-pace-wide view of Caemlyn from the south.

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ pipəl ɪn ðə bɹɪk mɑɹkəts laɪnɪŋ ðə waɪd ɹoʊd ðət ɹæn nɔɹθ fɹəm ðə ɡeɪtweɪ tə ðə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡeɪt, bʌɾ ə ɡɹeɪt mæs ə mɛn, maʊntəɾ ən əfʊt, kɹaʊɾəd ðə ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə baʊʃɑt fɹəm ðə wɔlz. ðə fɝst ə ðɛm wɑz oʊnli ə fju hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðət ðeɪ spɪld ɪndə ðə saɪd stʃɹits, tu. ðə maʊntəd mɛn wɝ tə ðə fɹʌnt wɪð ə θɪkɪɾ ə bænɝz, bʌt kævəlɹi əɹ ɪnfəntʃɹi, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl lʊkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪts ə keɪɛmlɪn ɪtsɛlf. ðə kloʊzd ɡeɪts. ɪleɪn cʊɾə ʃaʊɾəd fəɹ dʒɔɪ.

There were no people in the brick markets lining the wide road that ran north from the gateway to the Far Madding Gate, but a great mass of men, mounted and afoot, crowded the road out of bowshot from the walls. The first of them was only a few hundred paces from the gateway. It appeared that they spilled into the side streets, too. The mounted men were to the front with a thicket of banners, but cavalry or infantry, they were all looking toward the gates of Caemlyn itself. The closed gates. Elayne could have shouted for joy.

ʃi ɹoʊd θɹu fɝst, bʌt bɝdʒɪt wɑz teɪkɪŋ noʊ tʃænsəz. hɝ bɑɾiɡɑɹd ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn hɝ, hɝɾɪŋ əɹ ɔf tə wʌn saɪd. bɝdʒɪt wɑz ɹaɪt baɪ hɝ saɪd, bʌt sʌmhaʊ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə bi hɝɾɪŋ hɝ. fɔɹtʃənətli, noʊ wʌn tʃɹaɪd tə əbdʒɛk tə hɝ pʊʃɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪ fɔɹwɝɾ əntɪl oʊnli ə sɪŋɡəl laɪn ʌv ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɑz bɪtwin əɹ ən ðə ɹoʊd. ðət laɪn maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ə stoʊn wɔl. ðə ɡɹeɪ wɑz ɪndid tɔl, haʊɛvɝ, soʊ ʃi kəd si wɪθaʊt stændɪŋ ɪn ðə stɝəps. ʃi ʃʊɾə lɛŋθən ðoʊz. ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl ʃɔɹt fəɹ hɝ. ðət meɪd ðɪs tʃɛzməlz hɔɹs, sɪns ʃi wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn u keɪm kloʊs tə hɝ oʊn haɪt. ə hɔɹs kəd nɑt bi teɪntɪd baɪ ɪts ɹaɪɾɝ - dʒʌs kəz tʃɛzməl wɑz blæk ədʒɑ dɪd nɑt meɪk ðə hɔɹs ivəl - bʌt ʃi fɛlt ənkʌmftəɹbəl ɑn ði ænəməl fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ʃɔɹt stɝəps. ðə ɡɹeɪ wəd bi soʊld, ðə ɡɹeɪ ən ɔl ði ʌðɝ hɔɹsəz ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ, ən ðə mʌni dɪstʃɹɪbjəɾəd tə ðə pʊɹ.

She rode through first, but Birgitte was taking no chances. Her bodyguard gathered around her, herding her off to one side. Birgitte was right by her side, but somehow they did not seem to be herding her. Fortunately, no one tried to object to her pushing the gray forward until only a single line of Guardswomen was between her and the road. That line might as well have been a stone wall. The gray was indeed tall, however, so she could see without standing in the stirrups. She should have lengthened those. They were just a little short for her. That made this Chesmal's horse, since she was the only one who came close to her own height. A horse could not be tainted by its rider - just because Chesmal was Black Ajah did not make the horse evil - but she felt uncomfortable on the animal for more than short stirrups. The gray would be sold, the gray and all the other horses the Darkfriends had been riding, and the money distributed to the poor.

kævəlɹi ən fʊt keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ bɪhaɪn ɑɹlz, ɪnʌf tə fɪl ɪt fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd. fɑloʊd baɪ ðə waɪt laɪən ən ðə ɡoʊldən lɪli, hi stɑɹɾəd ʌp ðə ɹoʊɾ əɾ ə tʃɹɑt wɪð faɪv hʌnʒɹəd ɡɑɹdzmɪn, spɹɛɾ aʊt tə kʌvɝ ðə wɪdθ ə ðə ɹoʊd. ʌðɝ pɑɹɾiz ə sɪməlɝ saɪz splɪɾ ɔf ən vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə stʃɹits ə loʊ keɪɛmlɪn. wən ðə læs mɛn ɛɡzəɾɪd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ɪt dwɪndəld ən vænɪʃt. naʊ, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kwɪk ɪskeɪp ɪf ɛniθɪŋ wɛn ɹɔŋ. naʊ, ðeɪ hæd tə wɪn, əɹ ɛɹəmɪlə wəɾ əz ɡʊɾ əz əv ðə θɹoʊn wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi hæd keɪɛmlɪn.

Cavalry and foot came out of the gateway behind Charlz, enough to fill it from side to side. Followed by the White Lion and the Golden Lily, he started up the road at a trot with five hundred Guardsmen, spread out to cover the width of the road. Other parties of similar size split off and vanished into the streets of Low Caemlyn. When the last men exited the gateway, it dwindled and vanished. Now, there was no quick escape if anything went wrong. Now, they had to win, or Arymilla would as good as have the throne whether or not she had Caemlyn.

"wi nid mæt kɔθənz blʌɾi lʌk tədeɪ," bɝdʒɪt mʌɾɝd.

"We need Mat Cauthon's bloody luck today," Birgitte muttered.

"ju sɛd sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðət bɪfɔɹ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "wʌt dʒju min?"

"You said something like that before," Elayne said. "What do you mean?"

bɝdʒɪt ɡeɪv əɹ ə pəkjuljɝ lʊk. ðə bɑn kæɹid . . . əmjuzmənt! "hæv jə ɛvɝ sin ɪm dɪsɪŋ?"

Birgitte gave her a peculiar look. The bond carried . . . amusement! "Have you ever seen him dicing?"

"aɪ hɑɹdli spɛn mʌtʃ taɪm ɪn pleɪsəz wɛɹ ðɛɹz dɪsɪŋ, bɝdʒɪt."

"I hardly spend much time in places where there's dicing, Birgitte."

"lɛts dʒʌst seɪ hiz lʌkiɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ mæn aɪv ɛvɝ mɛt."

"Let's just say he's luckier than any other man I've ever met."

ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ɪleɪn pʊt mæt kɔθən aʊɾ ə hɝ maɪnd. ɑɹlzəz mɛn wɝ ʃʌɾɪŋ ɔf əɹ vju əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd. nɑt tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ jɛt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk noʊ mɔɹ nɔɪz ðən æbsəlutli nɛsəsɛɹi. wɪð ə lɪɾəl lʌk, hɝ mɛn wəɾ əv ɛɹəmɪləz sɝaʊndəd bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ nu wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. ən ðən ðeɪ wəd hɪɾ ɛɹəmɪlə fɹəm ɛvɹi saɪd. mæt wɑz ðə ləkis mæn bɝdʒɪt hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛt? ɪn ðət keɪs, hi mʌs bi vɛɹi lʌki ɪndid.

Shaking her head, Elayne put Mat Cauthon out of her mind. Charlz's men were shutting off her view as they rode forward. Not charging yet, trying to make no more noise than absolutely necessary. With a little luck, her men would have Arymilla's surrounded before they knew what was happening. And then they would hit Arymilla from every side. Mat was the luckiest man Birgitte had ever met? In that case, he must be very lucky indeed.

sʌɾənli ɑɹlzəz ɡɑɹdzmɪn wɝ muvɪŋ fæstɝ, ðɛɹ stil-tɪp lænsɪz swɪŋɪŋ daʊn. sʌmwʌn mʌst əv lʊk bæk. ʃaʊts ɹoʊz, kɹaɪz ʌv əlɑɹm ən wʌn θʌndɝəs ʃaʊt ʃi hɝd ɹɪpiɾɪd fɹəm mɛni dɝɛkʃənz. "ɪleɪn ən ændɝ!"

Suddenly Charlz's Guardsmen were moving faster, their steel-tipped lances swinging down. Someone must have looked back. Shouts rose, cries of alarm and one thunderous shout she heard repeated from many directions. "Elayne and Andor!"

ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ kɹaɪz, əz wɛl. "ðə munz!" ən "ðə fɑks!" "ðə tʃɹɪpəl kiz!" ən "ðə hæmɝ!" ən "ðə blæk bænɝ!" ʌðɝz, fəɹ lɛsɝ haʊsəz. bʌt fɹəm əɹ saɪd keɪm oʊnli ðə wʌn, ɹɪpiɾɪd əɡɛn ən əɡɛn. "ɪleɪn ən ændɝ!"

There were other cries, as well. "The Moons!" and "The Fox!" "The Triple Keys!" and "The Hammer!" and "The Black Banner!" Others, for lesser Houses. But from her side came only the one, repeated again and again. "Elayne and Andor!"

sʌɾənli ʃi wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ, hæf læfɪŋ, hæf wipɪŋ. ðə laɪt sɛnd ʃi wɑz nɑt kənsaɪnɪŋ ðoʊz mɛn tə ðɛɹ dɛθs fəɹ nʌθɪŋ.

Suddenly she was shaking, half laughing, half weeping. The Light send she was not consigning those men to their deaths for nothing.

ðə kɹaɪz feɪɾəd, lɑɹdʒli ɹipleɪs baɪ ðə klæʃ ə stil ɑn stil, baɪ ʃaʊts ən skɹimz əz mɛn kɪld əɹ daɪd. əbɹʌpli ʃi ɹilaɪz ðə ɡeɪts wɝ swɪŋɪŋ aʊt. ən ʃi kəd nɑt si! kɪkɪŋ əɹ fit fɹi ʌv ðə stɝəps, ʃi klæmbɝɾ ʌp tə stæn ɑn ðə haɪ-kæntəl sæɾəl. ðə ɡɹeɪ ʃɪftəd nɝvəsli, ʌnəkʌstəm tə biɪŋ ə stɛpstul, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə dɪstɝb əɹ bæləns. bɝdʒɪt mʌɾɝd ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli pʌnʒənt oʊθ, bʌt ðə nɛks moʊmənt ʃi wɑz stændɪŋ ɑn əɹ sæɾəl, tu. hʌnʒɹədz ə kɹɔsboʊmən ən ɑɹtʃɝz wɝ pɔɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡeɪt, bʌt wɝ ðeɪ hɝ mɛn, əɹ ðə ɹɛnəɡeɪd mɝsənɛɹiz?

The cries faded, largely replaced by the clash of steel on steel, by shouts and screams as men killed or died. Abruptly she realized the gates were swinging out. And she could not see! Kicking her feet free of the stirrups, she clambered up to stand on the high-cantled saddle. The gray shifted nervously, unaccustomed to being a stepstool, but not enough to disturb her balance. Birgitte muttered a particularly pungent oath, but the next moment she was standing on her saddle, too. Hundreds of crossbowmen and archers were pouring out of the Far Madding Gate, but were they her men, or the renegade mercenaries?

fəɹ ænsɝ, ɑɹtʃɝz bɪɡæn faɪɹɪŋ əɾ ɛɹəmɪləz mæs kævəlɹi əz fæst əz ðeɪ kəd nɑk ən dʒɹɔ. ðə fɝs kɹɔsboʊz wɛn ʌp ən lust ə vɑli. ɪmiɾiətli ðoʊz mɛn bɪɡæn wɝkɪŋ ðɛɹ kɹæŋks tə ɹiwɪn ðɛɹ kɹɔsboʊz, bʌɾ ʌðɝz ɹʌʃt pæst əm tə lus ə sɛkən flaɪɾ ə boʊls ðət kʌt daʊn mɛn ən hɔɹsəz laɪk saɪθz ɹipɪŋ bɑɹli. mɔɹ ɑɹtʃɝz spɪld aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪt, faɪɹɪŋ əz fæst əz ðeɪ kʊd. ə θɝd ɹæŋk ə kɹɔsboʊmən ɹæn fɔɹwɝd tə faɪɝ, ə fɔɹθ, ə fɪfθ, ən ðən mɛn wildɪŋ hælbɝdz wɝ pʊʃɪŋ pæs ðə kɹɔsboʊmən stɪl ɹʌnɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪt. ə hælbɹd wɑz ə fɪɹsəm wɛpən, kəmbaɪnɪŋ spɪɹpɔɪn ən æks bleɪd wɪð ə hʊk fəɹ pʊlɪŋ mɛn aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl. hɔɹsmən wɪð noʊ ɹum tə tʃɑɹdʒ ðɛɹ lænsɪz, ðɛɹ sɔɹdz aʊt-ɹitʃt baɪ ðə hælbɹdz lɔŋ hæft, bɪɡæn fɔlɪŋ. mɛn ɪn ɹɛd koʊts ən bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪts wɝ ɡæləpɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪt naʊ, ɡɑɹdzmɪn swɪŋɪŋ tə lɛft ən ɹaɪt tə faɪn ənʌðɝ weɪ tə ɡɛɾ əɾ ɛɹəmɪləz ɹæŋks. ðə floʊ ʌv əm wɛn ɑn ən ɑn, ənsisɪŋ. haʊ ɪn ðə laɪt kəd daɪɛlɪn əv soʊ mɛni ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdz? ənlɛs. . . . bɝn ðə wʊmən, ʃi mʌst əv skupt ʌp ðə hæf-tʃɹeɪn mɛn! wɛl, hæf-tʃɹeɪn əɹ nɑt, ðeɪ wəd bi ənɔɪntəɾ ɪn blʌd tədeɪ.

For answer, archers began firing at Arymilla's massed cavalry as fast as they could nock and draw. The first crossbows went up and loosed a volley. Immediately those men began working their cranks to rewind their crossbows, but others rushed past them to loose a second flight of bolts that cut down men and horses like scythes reaping barley. More archers spilled out of the gate, firing as fast as they could. A third rank of crossbowmen ran forward to fire, a fourth, a fifth, and then men wielding halberds were pushing past the crossbowmen still running out of the gate. A halberd was a fearsome weapon, combining spearpoint and axe blade with a hook for pulling men out of the saddle. Horsemen with no room to charge their lances, their swords out-reached by the halberd's long haft, began falling. Men in red coats and burnished breastplates were galloping out of the gate now, Guardsmen swinging to left and right to find another way to get at Arymilla's ranks. The flow of them went on and on, unceasing. How in the Light could Dyelin have so many of the Guards? Unless. . . . Burn the woman, she must have scooped up the half-trained men! Well, half-trained or not, they would be anointed in blood today.

sʌɾənli θɹi fɪɡjɝz ɪn ɡɪldɪd hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts ɹoʊd θɹu ðə ɡeɪts, sɔɹdz ɪn hænd. tu ʌv əm wɝ vɛɹi smɔl. ðə ʃaʊts ðət ɹoʊz wən ðeɪ əpɪɹd wɝ θɪn wɪð dɪstəns, bʌt stɪl ɑɾəbəl oʊvɝ ðə dɪn ə bæɾəl. "ðə blæk iɡəlz!" ən "ði ænvəl!" ən "ðə ɹɛd lɛpɝdz!" tu maʊntəd wɪmən əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə ɡeɪt, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ əntɪl ðə tɔlɝ mænədʒ tə pʊl ði ʌðɝz hɔɹs bæk aʊɾ ə saɪt.

Suddenly three figures in gilded helmets and breastplates rode through the gates, swords in hand. Two of them were very small. The shouts that rose when they appeared were thin with distance, but still audible over the din of battle. "The Black Eagles!" and "The Anvil!" and "The Red Leopards!" Two mounted women appeared in the gate, struggling until the taller managed to pull the other's horse back out of sight.

"blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!" ɪleɪn snæpt. "kɑneɪlz oʊld ɪnʌf, aɪ səpoʊz, bʌt bɹænləɾ ən pɛɝaɪvəl ɑɹ bɔɪz! sʌmbɑɾi ʃʊɾə kɛpt əm aʊɾ ə ðæt!"

"Blood and bloody ashes!" Elayne snapped. "Conail's old enough, I suppose, but Branlet and Perival are boys! Somebody should have kept them out of that!"

"daɪɛlɪn hɛld əm bæk lɔŋ ɪnʌf," bɝdʒɪt sɛd kɑmli. ðə bɑn kæɹid boʊn-dip kɑm. "lɔŋɡɝ ðən aɪ θɔt ʃi kəd hoʊl kɑneɪl. ən ʃi dɪd mænədʒ tə kip kæɾəlɪn aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. ɛniweɪ, ðə bɔɪz əv ə fju hʌnʒɹəd mɛn bɪtwin əm ən ðə fɔɹfɹʌnt, ən aɪ doʊn si ɛniwʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ɹum fəɹ əm tə skwiz fɔɹwɝd." ɪt wɑz tʃɹu. ðə θɹi wɝ weɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz ɪmpəɾəntli ət lis fɪfti peɪsɪz fɹəm wɛɹ mɛn wɝ daɪɪŋ. bʌt ðɛn, fɪfti peɪsɪz wɑz ə ʃɔɹt ɹeɪnʒ fəɹ baʊ əɹ kɹɔsboʊ.

"Dyelin held them back long enough," Birgitte said calmly. The bond carried bone-deep calm. "Longer than I thought she could hold Conail. And she did manage to keep Catalyn out of it. Anyway, the boys have a few hundred men between them and the forefront, and I don't see anyone trying to make room for them to squeeze forward." It was true. The three were waving their swords impotently at least fifty paces from where men were dying. But then, fifty paces was a short range for bow or crossbow.

mɛn bɪɡæn əpɪɹɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹuftɑps, fɝs dʌzənz ðən hʌnʒɹədz, ɑɹtʃɝz ən kɹɔsboʊmən klaɪmɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɹuf piks, wɝkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ əkɹɔs ðə sleɪts laɪk spaɪɾɝz əntɪl ðeɪ kəd ʃut daʊn ɪndə ðə pæk mæs bɪloʊ. wʌn slɪpt ən fɛl, hɪz bɑɾi laɪɪŋ ətɑp ðə mɛn ɪn ðə stʃɹiɾ ən dʒɝkɪŋ əz ɪt wɑz stæbd ɹɪpiɾɪdli. ənʌðɝ sʌɾənli ɹɪɹɾ ʌp, ə ʃæf stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz saɪd, ən tɑpəl fɹəm ɪz pɝtʃ. hi ɔlsoʊ leɪ ətɑp ðə mɛn ɪn ðə stʃɹit, twɪtʃɪŋ əz i wɑz stæbd əɡɛn ən əɡɛn.

Men began appearing on the rooftops, first dozens then hundreds, archers and crossbowmen climbing over the roof peaks, working their way across the slates like spiders until they could shoot down into the packed mass below. One slipped and fell, his body lying atop the men in the street and jerking as it was stabbed repeatedly. Another suddenly reared up, a shaft sticking out of his side, and toppled from his perch. He also lay atop the men in the street, twitching as he was stabbed again and again.

"ðeɪɹ dʒæm təɡɛðɝ tu taɪtli," bɝdʒɪt sɛɾ ɪksaɪɾədli. "ðeɪ kæn ɹeɪz ə baʊ mʌtʃ lɛs dʒɹɔ wʌn. əl weɪdʒɝ ðə dɛd doʊn ivən əv ɹum tə fɔl daʊn. ɪt woʊn bi lɔŋ, naʊ."

"They're jammed together too tightly," Birgitte said excitedly. "They can't raise a bow much less draw one. I'll wager the dead don't even have room to fall down. It won't be long, now."
