bʌt ðə slɔɾɝ kəntɪnjud fəɹ ə ɡʊd hæf-aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə fɝst ʃaʊts ʌv "kɔɹɾɝ!" ɹoʊz. mɛn bɪɡæn hæŋɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛlməts ɑn sɔɹd hɪls ən ɹeɪzɪŋ əm oʊvɝhɛd, ɹɪskɪŋ dɛθ ɪn ðə hoʊp ə laɪf. fʊtmən stʃɹɪpt ɔf hɛlməts ən hɛl ðɛɹ hænz ʌp ɛmpti. hɔɹsmən flʌŋ daʊn lænsɪz, hɛlməts, sɔɹdz, ən ɹeɪz ðɛɹ hænz. ɪt spɹɛd laɪk ə fivɝ, ðə kɹaɪ bɛloʊɪŋ fɹəm θaʊzənz ə θɹoʊts. "kɔɹɾɝ!"

But the slaughter continued for a good half-hour before the first shouts of "Quarter!" rose. Men began hanging their helmets on sword hilts and raising them overhead, risking death in the hope of life. Footmen stripped off helmets and held their hands up empty. Horsemen flung down lances, helmets, swords, and raised their hands. It spread like a fever, the cry bellowing from thousands of throats. "Quarter!"

ɪleɪn sæt daʊn ɑn əɹ sæɾəl pɹɑpɝli. ɪt wɑz dʌn. naʊ tə lɝn haʊ wɛl ɪt hæd bɪn dʌn.

Elayne sat down on her saddle properly. It was done. Now to learn how well it had been done.

ðə faɪɾɪŋ dɪd nɑt stɑp ɪmiɾiətli, ʌv kɔɹs. səm tʃɹaɪd tə faɪɾ ɑn, bʌt ðeɪ fɔɾ əloʊn ən daɪɾ əɹ wɝ pʊl daʊn baɪ mɛn ɝaʊn əm u wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹɛɾi tə daɪ. ət læst, haʊɛvɝ, ivən ðə moʊs daɪhɑɹd bɪɡæn ʃɛɾɪŋ wɛpənz ən ɑɹmɝ, ən ɪf nɑɾ ɛvɹi vɔɪs kɹaɪd fəɹ kɔɹɾɝ, ðə ɹɔɹ wɑz stɪl θʌndɝəs. wɛpənləs mɛn ʃɔɹn ə hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts ən ɛni ʌðɝ ɑɹmɝ ðeɪ maɪɾ əv wɔɹn bɪɡæn stæɡɝɪŋ θɹu ðə laɪn ʌv ɡɑɹdzmɪn, hænz əbʌv ðɛɹ hɛdz. hælbɝdmən hɝɾɪd əm laɪk ʃip. ðeɪ hæd sʌmθɪŋ ə ðə stʌn lʊk ə ʃip ɪn ə slɔɾɝ jɑɹd. ðə seɪm θɪŋ mʌst əv bɪn biɪŋ ɹɪpiɾɪd ɑn dʌzənz ə loʊ keɪɛmlɪnz nɛɹoʊ stʃɹits, ən ət ðə ɡeɪts, kəz ði oʊnli ʃaʊts ʃi hɝd wɝ fəɹ kɔɹɾɝ, ən ðoʊz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə dwɪndəl əz mɛn ɹilaɪzd ɪt wɑz biɪŋ ɡɹæntəd.

The fighting did not stop immediately, of course. Some tried to fight on, but they fought alone and died or were pulled down by men around them who were no longer ready to die. At last, however, even the most diehard began shedding weapons and armor, and if not every voice cried for quarter, the roar was still thunderous. Weaponless men shorn of helmets and breastplates and any other armor they might have worn began staggering through the line of Guardsmen, hands above their heads. Halberdmen herded them like sheep. They had something of the stunned look of sheep in a slaughter yard. The same thing must have been being repeated on dozens of Low Caemlyn's narrow streets, and at the gates, because the only shouts she heard were for quarter, and those were beginning to dwindle as men realized it was being granted.

ðə sʌn læk noʊ mɔɹ ðən ən aʊɝ ʌv ɪts nundeɪ pik baɪ ðə taɪm ðə noʊbəlz wɝ ɔl sɛpɝeɪɾəd aʊt. ðə lɛsɝ wɝ ɛskɔɹɾɪd ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi, wɛɹ ðeɪ wəd bi hɛl fəɹ ɹænsəm. tə bi peɪd wʌns ðə θɹoʊn wɑz sɪkjʊɹ. ðə fɝst ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ noʊbəlz tə bi bɹɔt tə hɝ, ɛskɔɹɾɪd baɪ ɑɹlz ən ə dʌzən ɡɑɹdzmɪn, wɝ ɛɹəmɪlə, nɑiən ən ɛləniə. ɑɹlz hæɾ ə blʌɾi ɡæʃ daʊn ɪz lɛf sliv, ən ə dɛn ɪn ɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ bɹɛstpleɪt ðət mʌst əv bɪn meɪd baɪ ə hæmɝ bloʊ, bʌɾ ɪz fitʃɝz wɝ kəmpoʊz bɪhaɪn ðə feɪs-bɑɹz ə hɪz hɛlmət. ʃi hivd ə hjudʒ saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif tə si ðə θɹi wɪmən. əmʌŋ ðə dɛɾ əɹ əmʌŋ ðə kæptɪvz, ði ʌðɝz wəd bi faʊnd. ʃi hæd dikæpəteɪɾɪd əɹ ɑpəzɪʃən. ət list əntɪl lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz ɝaɪvd. ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ ət læs muvd əsaɪd soʊ ʃi kəd kənfɹʌn əɹ pɹɪznɝz.

The sun lacked no more than an hour of its noonday peak by the time the nobles were all separated out. The lesser were escorted inside the city, where they would be held for ransom. To be paid once the throne was secure. The first of the greater nobles to be brought to her, escorted by Charlz and a dozen Guardsmen, were Arymilla, Naean and Elenia. Charlz had a bloody gash down his left sleeve, and a dent in his shining breastplate that must have been made by a hammer blow, but his features were composed behind the face-bars of his helmet. She heaved a huge sigh of relief to see the three women. Among the dead or among the captives, the others would be found. She had decapitated her opposition. At least until Luan and the others arrived. The Guardswomen in front of her at last moved aside so she could confront her prisoners.

ðə θɹi wɝ ɡɑɹbd əz ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə ətɛn ɛɹəmɪləz kɔɹəneɪʃən ðət vɛɹi deɪ. hɝ ɹɛd sɪlk dʒɹɛs wɑz soʊn wɪð sid pɝlz ɑn ðə bʊzəm ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ɹɪɹɪŋ waɪt laɪənz mɑɹtʃɪŋ ʌp ðə slivz. sweɪɪŋ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ʃi hæd ðə seɪm stʌn lʊk ɪn əɹ bɹaʊn aɪz ðəɾ əɹ soʊlʒɝz hæd. nɑiən, slɪm ən stʃɹeɪt-bækt ɪn blu wɪð ðə sɪlvɝ tʃɹɪpəl kiz ʌv ɑɝɔn klaɪmɪŋ əɹ slivz ən sɪlvɝ skɹɑlwɝk əkɹɔs əɹ bʊzəm, hɝ ɡlimɪŋ blæk hɛɹ kɑɾ ɪn ə sɪlvɝ nɛt sɛt wɪð sæfaɪɝz, sim səbdud ɹæðɝ ðən nʌm. ʃi ivən mænədʒd ə snɪɹ, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz wik. hʌni-hɛɹɾ ɛləniə, ɪn ɡɹin ɪlæbɹətli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ɡoʊld, ʃɛɹɾ əɹ ɡlɛɹz bɪtwin ɛɹəmɪlə ən ɪleɪn. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ ikwəl mɛʒɝz ə tʃɹaɪəmf ən dɪsɡʌst. bɝdʒɪts dɪslaɪk ə ðiz wɪmən wɑz əz pɝsənəl əz ɪleɪnz oʊn.

The three were garbed as if they had intended to attend Arymilla's coronation that very day. Her red silk dress was sewn with seed pearls on the bosom and embroidered with rearing white lions marching up the sleeves. Swaying in her saddle, she had the same stunned look in her brown eyes that her soldiers had. Naean, slim and straight-backed in blue with the silver Triple Keys of Arawn climbing her sleeves and silver scrollwork across her bosom, her gleaming black hair caught in a silver net set with sapphires, seemed subdued rather than numb. She even managed a sneer, though it was weak. Honey-haired Elenia, in green elaborately embroidered with gold, shared her glares between Arymilla and Elayne. The bond carried equal measures of triumph and disgust. Birgitte's dislike of these women was as personal as Elayne's own.

"ju wɪl bi maɪ ɡɛsts ɪn ðə pæləs fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ," ɪleɪn toʊl ðɛm. "aɪ hoʊp jəɹ kɑfɝz ɑɹ dip. jəɹ ɹænsəmz wɪl peɪ fəɹ ðɪs wɔɹ juv kɑzd." ðət wɑz məlɪʃəs ə hɝ, bʌt ʃi fɛl spaɪtfəl ɔl ʌv ə sʌɾən. ðɛɹ kɑfɝz wɝ nɑt dip əɾ ɔl. ðeɪ hæd bɑɹoʊd fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ kəd ɹipeɪ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə haɪɝ mɝsənɛɹiz. ən bɹaɪb mɝsənɛɹiz. ðeɪ feɪst ɹuən wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ɹænsəm. wɪð, ðeɪ feɪs dɛvəsteɪʃən.

"You will be my guests in the palace for the time being," Elayne told them. "I hope your coffers are deep. Your ransoms will pay for this war you've caused." That was malicious of her, but she felt spiteful all of a sudden. Their coffers were not deep at all. They had borrowed far more than they could repay in order to hire mercenaries. And bribe mercenaries. They faced ruin without any ransom. With, they faced devastation.

"ju kænɑt bɪliv ɪɾ ɛnz ðɪs weɪ," ɛɹəmɪlə sɛd hɔɹsli. ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns hɝsɛlf. "dʒɑɝɪɾ ɪz stɪl ɪn ðə fild wɪð ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl fɔɹs. dʒɑɝɪɾ ən ʌðɝz. tɛl hɝ, ɛləniə."

"You cannot believe it ends this way," Arymilla said hoarsely. She sounded as if she were trying to convince herself. "Jarid is still in the field with a considerable force. Jarid and others. Tell her, Elenia."

"dʒɑɝɪd wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə pɹəzɝv wʌɾ i kən ə sɑɝən fɹəm ðɪs dɪzæstɝ juv fɔɹst əs ɪntu," ɛləniə snɑɹəld. ðeɪ bɪɡæn ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. ʃi wʌndɝd haʊ ðeɪ wəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ʃɛɹɪŋ ə bɛd wɪð nɑiən.

"Jarid will try to preserve what he can of Sarand from this disaster you've forced us into," Elenia snarled. They began shouting at one another, but Elayne ignored them. She wondered how they would enjoy sharing a bed with Naean.

nɛks tə əpɪɹ ʌndɝ ɛskɔɹt wɑz lɝ bɛɹɪn, ən moʊməns leɪɾɝ kɑɝɪn ænʃɝ. əz slɛndɝ əz ə bleɪd, ən əz stʃɹɔŋ, lɝ wɔɹ ə θɔtfəl ɪkspɹɛʃən ɹæðɝ ðən dɪfaɪən əɹ sʌlən. hɪz ɡɹin koʊt, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ðə sɪlvɝ wɪŋ hæmɝ ə haʊs bɛɹɪn ɑn ðə haɪ kɑlɝ, bɔɹ ðə mɑɹks ə ðə bɹɛstpleɪɾ i wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɛɹɪŋ, ən ɪz dɑɹk hɛɹ wɑz mæɾɪd wɪð swɛt. mɔɹ ɡlɪsən ɑn ɪz feɪs. hi hæd nɑt ɡɑɾən soʊ swɛɾi wɑtʃɪŋ ʌðɝ mɛn faɪt. kɑɝɪnd wɑz ɡɑɹbd əz ɡɹænli əz ði ʌðɝ wɪmən, ɪn ʃɪmɝɪŋ blu sɪlk hɛvi wɪð sɪlvɝ bɹeɪɾ ən pɝlz ɪn əɹ ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik hɛɹ. hɝ skwɛɹ feɪs lʊkt ɹɪzaɪnd, ɪspɛʃli æftɝ ɪleɪn toʊld əm əbaʊt ðɛɹ ɹænsəmz. niðɝ hæd bɑɹoʊɾ əz hɛvəli əz ði ʌðɝ θɹi soʊ fɑɹ əz ʃi nu, bʌt ðət ɹænsəm wəd stɪl kʌt dip.

Next to appear under escort was Lir Baryn, and moments later Karind Anshar. As slender as a blade, and as strong, Lir wore a thoughtful expression rather than defiant or sullen. His green coat, embroidered with the silver Winged Hammer of House Baryn on the high collar, bore the marks of the breastplate he was no longer wearing, and his dark hair was matted with sweat. More glistened on his face. He had not gotten so sweaty watching other men fight. Karind was garbed as grandly as the other women, in shimmering blue silk heavy with silver braid and pearls in her gray-streaked hair. Her square face looked resigned, especially after Elayne told them about their ransoms. Neither had borrowed as heavily as the other three so far as she knew, but that ransom would still cut deep.

ðən tu ɡɑɹdzmɪn əpɪɹd wɪð ə wʊmən ə lɪɾəl oʊldɝ ðən ɪleɪn, ɪn sɪmpəl blu, ə wʊmən ʃi θɔt ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd. ə sɪŋɡəl ɪnæməl bɹutʃ, ə ɹɛd stɑɹ ən sɪlvɝ sɔɹɾ ɑn ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ blæk, əpɪɹd tə bi hɝ oʊnli dʒuəlɹi. bʌt waɪ wɑz sɪlveɪs kɝən biɪŋ bɹɔt tə hɝ? ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən wɪð əlɝt blu aɪz ðət hɛl stɛɾi ɑn ɪleɪnz feɪs, ʃi wɑz lɔɹd næsənz ɛɹ, nɑt ðə haɪ siɾ ə kɝən.

Then two Guardsmen appeared with a woman a little older than Elayne, in simple blue, a woman she thought she recognized. A single enameled brooch, a red star and silver sword on glittering black, appeared to be her only jewelry. But why was Sylvase Caeren being brought to her? A pretty woman with alert blue eyes that held steady on Elayne's face, she was Lord Nasin's heir, not the High Seat of Caeren.

"kɝən stænz fəɹ tʃɹəkənd," sɪlveɪs sɛd ʃɑkɪŋli əz sun əz ʃi ɹeɪn ɪn. ðə bɑn ɛkoʊɾ ɪleɪnz stɑɹɾəlmənt. ɛɹəmɪlə ɡeɪpt ət sɪlveɪs əz ɪf ʃi wɝ mæd. "maɪ ɡɹændfɑðɝ sʌfɝɾ ə siʒɝ, ɛɹəmɪlə," ðə jʌŋ wʊmən sɛd kɑmli, "æn maɪ kʌzənz fɛl oʊvɝ ðɛmsɛlvz əfɝmɪŋ mi əz haɪ sit. əl pʌblɪʃ ɪt, ɪleɪn, ɪf jə wɪʃ."

"Caeren stands for Trakand," Sylvase said shockingly as soon as she reined in. The bond echoed Elayne's startlement. Arymilla gaped at Sylvase as if she were mad. "My grandfather suffered a seizure, Arymilla," the young woman said calmly, "and my cousins fell over themselves affirming me as High Seat. I will publish it, Elayne, if you wish."

"ðæt maɪt bi bɛst," ɪleɪn sɛd sloʊli. pʌbləkeɪʃən wəd meɪk əɹ səpɔɹɾ ɪɹɛvəkəbəl. ðɪs wəd nɑt bi ðə fɝs taɪm ə haʊs hæd swɪtʃt saɪdz, ivən wɪθaʊt ðə dɛθ ʌv ə haɪ sit, bʌt bɛs tə bi sɝɾən. "tʃɹəkənd wɛlkəmz kɝən wɔɹmli, sɪlveɪs." bɛs nɑt tə bi tu dɪstənt, iðɝ. ʃi nu lɪɾəl ə sɪlveɪs kɝən.

"That might be best," Elayne said slowly. Publication would make her support irrevocable. This would not be the first time a House had switched sides, even without the death of a High Seat, but best to be certain. "Trakand welcomes Caeren warmly, Sylvase." Best not to be too distant, either. She knew little of Sylvase Caeren.

sɪlveɪs nɑɾəd, æksɛptɪŋ. soʊ ʃi hæɾ ət list ə dɪɡɹi ʌv ɪntɛlədʒəns. ʃi nu ʃi wəd nɑt bi fʊli tʃɹʌstɪɾ əntɪl ʃi dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾəd əɹ lɔɪəlti baɪ sɛndɪŋ aʊt ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃənz ə səpɔɹt. "ɪf jə tʃɹʌs mi ə lɪɾəl, meɪ aɪ hæv kʌstəɾi ʌv ɛɹəmɪlə, nɑiən ən ɛləniə? ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs, ʌv kɔɹs, əɹ wɛɹɛvɝ jə tʃuz tə haʊs mi. aɪ bɪliv maɪ nu sɛkɹətɛɹi, mæstɝ laʊnɔlt, meɪ bi eɪbəl tə kənvɪns əm tə θɹoʊ ðɛɹ səpɔɹt tə ju."

Sylvase nodded, accepting. So she had at least a degree of intelligence. She knew she would not be fully trusted until she demonstrated her loyalty by sending out the proclamations of support. "If you trust me a little, may I have custody of Arymilla, Naean and Elenia? In the Royal Palace, of course, or wherever you choose to house me. I believe my new secretary, Master Lounalt, may be able to convince them to throw their support to you."

fəɹ səm ɹizən, nɑiən ɡeɪv ə laʊd kɹaɪ ən wʊɾə fɔlən fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl ɪf ə ɡɑɹdzmæn hæd nɑt ɡɹæbd əɹ ɑɹm tə səpɔɹt hɝ. ɛɹəmɪlə ən ɛləniə boʊθ əpɪɹd ɹɛɾi tə sɪk ʌp.

For some reason, Naean gave a loud cry and would have fallen from her saddle if a Guardsman had not grabbed her arm to support her. Arymilla and Elenia both appeared ready to sick up.

"aɪ θɪŋk nɑt," ɪleɪn sɛd. noʊ pɹəpoʊz kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð ə sɛkɹətɛɹi pɹədus ðoʊz ɹiækʃənz. ɪt sim sɪlveɪs hæɾ ə hɑɹd kɔɹ tə hɝ. "nɑiən ən ɛləniə hæv pʌblɪʃt ðɛɹ səpɔɹɾ ʌv ɛɹəmɪlə. ðəl hɑɹdli dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛmsɛlvz baɪ ɹəkæntɪŋ." ðət tʃɹuli wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm. smɔlɝ haʊsəz swɔɹn tə ðɛm wəd bɪɡɪn fɔlɪŋ əweɪ əntɪl ðɛɹ oʊn haʊs dwɪndəld ɪn ɪmpɔɹɾəns. ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz maɪt nɑt sɝvaɪv əz haɪ sits mʌtʃ bɪɑn ənaʊnsɪŋ ðət ðeɪ naʊ stʊd fəɹ tʃɹəkənd. ən əz fəɹ ɛɹəmɪlə. . . . ɪleɪn wəd nɑɾ əlaʊ ɛɹəmɪlə tə tʃeɪnʒ əɹ tun. ʃi wəd ɹəfjuz ðə wʊmənz səpɔɹɾ ɪf ɪt wɝ ɔfɝd!

"I think not," Elayne said. No proposed conversation with a secretary produced those reactions. It seemed Sylvase had a hard core to her. "Naean and Elenia have published their support of Arymilla. They'll hardly destroy themselves by recanting." That truly would destroy them. Smaller Houses sworn to them would begin falling away until their own House dwindled in importance. They themselves might not survive as High Seats much beyond announcing that they now stood for Trakand. And as for Arymilla. . . . Elayne would not allow Arymilla to change her tune. She would refuse the woman's support if it were offered!

sʌmθɪŋ ɡɹɪm ɛntɝd sɪlveɪsəz ɡeɪz əz ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə θɹi wɪmən. "ðeɪ maɪt, wɪð ðə pɹɑpɝ pɝsweɪʒən." oʊ, jɛs; ə vɛɹi hɑɹd kɔɹ. "bʌɾ əz jə wɪʃ, ɪleɪn. bi vɛɹi kɛɹfəl ə ðɛm, ðoʊ. tʃɹɛtʃɝi ɪz ɪn ðɛɹ blʌɾ ən boʊnz."

Something grim entered Sylvase's gaze as she glanced at the three women. "They might, with the proper persuasion." Oh, yes; a very hard core. "But as you wish, Elayne. Be very careful of them, though. Treachery is in their blood and bones."

"bɛɹɪn stænz fəɹ tʃɹəkənd," lɝ ənaʊnst sʌɾənli. "aɪ, tu, wɪl pʌblɪʃ ɪt, ɪleɪn."

"Baryn stands for Trakand," Lir announced suddenly. "I, too, will publish it, Elayne."

"ænʃɝ stænz fəɹ tʃɹəkənd," kɑɝɪn sɛɾ ɪn fɝm toʊnz. "aɪ wɪl sɛn ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃənz aʊt tədeɪ."

"Anshar stands for Trakand," Karind said in firm tones. "I will send the proclamations out today."

"tʃɹeɪɾɝz!" ɛɹəmɪlə kɹaɪd. "aɪl si jə dɛd fəɹ ðɪs!" ʃi fʌmbəld əɾ əɹ bɛlt, wɛɹ ə dæɡɝz skæbɝd hʌŋ, dʒuəld ən ɛmpti, əz ɪf ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə si tə ðə mæɾɝ hɝsɛlf. ɛləniə bɪɡæn tə læf, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn əmjuzd. ɪt saʊndəɾ ɔlmoʊs laɪk wipɪŋ.

"Traitors!" Arymilla cried. "I'll see you dead for this!" She fumbled at her belt, where a dagger's scabbard hung, jeweled and empty, as if she intended to see to the matter herself. Elenia began to laugh, but she did not sound amused. It sounded almost like weeping.

ɪleɪn dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. naʊ ʃi hæd naɪn ə ðə tɛn haʊsəz niɾəd. ʃi wɑz ʌndɝ noʊ ɪluʒənz. wʌtɛvɝ sɪlveɪsəz ɹizənz, lɝ ən kɑɝɪnd wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sælvədʒ wʌt ðeɪ kəd baɪ kʌɾɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz lus fɹəm ə lɔs kɑz ən hɪtʃɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz tə wʌn ðət sʌɾənli əpɪɹd tə bi ɹaɪzɪŋ. ðeɪ wəɾ ɪkspɛkt əɹ tə ɡɪv əm pɹɛfɝmən fəɹ stændɪŋ fəɹ əɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd ðə θɹoʊn waɪl fɝɡɛɾɪŋ ðət ðeɪ hæɾ ɛvɝ səpɔɹɾəd ɛɹəmɪlə. ʃi wəd də niðɝ. bʌt niðɝ kəd ʃi ɹɪdʒɛkt əm aʊɾ ə hænd. "tʃɹəkənd wɛlkəmz bɛɹɪn." nɛvɝ wɔɹmli, ðoʊ. nɛvɝ ðæt. "tʃɹəkənd wɛlkəmz ænʃɝ. kæptən ɡaɪbɑn, ɡɛt ðə pɹɪznɝz ɪndə ðə sɪɾi əz sun əz jə kæn. ɑɹmmɪn fəɹ kɝən, bɛɹɪn ən ænʃɝ wɪl bi ɹɪstɔɹd ðɛɹ wɛpənz ən ɑɹmɝ wʌns ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃənz əv bɪn sɛn aʊt, bʌt ðeɪ kən əv ðɛɹ bænɝz bæk naʊ." hi səluɾəd əɹ ən wild ɪz beɪ, ɔlɹɛɾi ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz.

Elayne drew a deep breath. Now she had nine of the ten Houses needed. She was under no illusions. Whatever Sylvase's reasons, Lir and Karind were trying to salvage what they could by cutting themselves loose from a lost cause and hitching themselves to one that suddenly appeared to be rising. They would expect her to give them preferment for standing for her before she had the throne while forgetting that they had ever supported Arymilla. She would do neither. But neither could she reject them out of hand. "Trakand welcomes Baryn." Never warmly, though. Never that. "Trakand welcomes Anshar. Captain Guybon, get the prisoners into the city as soon as you can. Armsmen for Caeren, Baryn and Anshar will be restored their weapons and armor once the proclamations have been sent out, but they can have their banners back now." He saluted her and wheeled his bay, already shouting orders.

əz ʃi hil ðə ɡɹeɪ təwɔɹd daɪɛlɪn, hu wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə saɪd stʃɹit fɑloʊd baɪ kæɾəlɪn ən ðə θɹi jʌŋ fulz ɪn ðɛɹ ɡɪldɪɾ ɑɹmɝ, sɪlveɪs, lɝ ən kɑɝɪn fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪn əɹ ən bɝdʒɪt. ʃi fɛl noʊ dɪskwaɪət hævɪŋ əm əɾ əɹ bæk, nɑt wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ət ðɛɹz. ðeɪ wəd bi wɑtʃt vɛɹi kloʊsli əntɪl ðoʊz pɹɑkləmeɪʃənz wɝ sɛnt. ɪnkluɾɪŋ sɪlveɪs. ɪleɪnz maɪnd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi kæstɪŋ ɪtsɛlf əhɛd.

As she heeled the gray toward Dyelin, who was riding out of a side street followed by Catalyn and the three young fools in their gilded armor, Sylvase, Lir and Karind fell in behind her and Birgitte. She felt no disquiet having them at her back, not with a hundred Guardswomen at theirs. They would be watched very closely until those proclamations were sent. Including Sylvase. Elayne's mind was already casting itself ahead.

"jɔɹ ɑfli kwaɪət," bɝdʒɪt sɛd sɔfli. "juv dʒʌst wʌn ə ɡɹeɪt vɪktɝi."

"You're awfully quiet," Birgitte said softly. "You've just won a great victory."

"æn ɪn ə fju aʊɝz," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd, "aɪl lɝn wɛðɝ aɪ hæv tə wɪn ənʌðɝ."

"And in a few hours," she replied, "I'll learn whether I have to win another."

tʃæptɝ θɝɾifɔɹ

CHAPTER 34

eɪ kʌp ə kæf fɹɪk kɛɹid pɹɛst ɪz ɡɔntələɾəd fɪs tə hɪz hɑɹt, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ðə sɛntʃɹiz səlut, ən ɪɡnɔɹd ðə fæk ðət ðə mæn spæɾ əz i ɹoʊd pæst. hi hoʊp ði eɪɾi mɛn ən twɛnti-wʌn oʊɡiɝ bɪhaɪn ɪm ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt, tu. ðeɪ hæd bɛɾɝ, ɪf ðeɪ nu wʌt wɑz ɡʊd fəɹ ðɛm. hi wɑz hɪɹ fəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, ən ə kɪlɪŋ wəd meɪk ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪt mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt. sɪns ɪz mænsɝvən ædʒɪmbʊɹə hæd plæntəɾ ɪz naɪf ɪn ə stænʒɹdbɛɹɝz hɑɹɾ oʊvɝ ə pɝsivd ɪnsəl tə hɪz mæstɝ - ɪn tʃɹuθ, ə ɹil ɪnsəlt, bʌɾ ædʒɪmbʊɹə ʃʊɾə hɛld ɪz tɛmpɝ ðə weɪ hi hɪmsɛlf hæd - sɪns ðɛn, hi hæd teɪkən tə livɪŋ ðə wɪɹi lɪɾəl hɪl-tʃɹaɪbsmən ɪn ðə fɔɹəst wɪð ðə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn ən səm ə ðə ɡɑɹdz tə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ ðə pækhɔɹsɪz wən i ɛntɝɾ ə kæmp. hi hæd kʌm ə lɔŋ weɪ fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ tʃeɪsɪŋ ðə wɪnd, ɔlmoʊs fɔɹ wiks ə hɛɹɪŋ æftɝ ɹumɝz, əntɪl ðə nuz bɹɔɾ ɪm hɪɹ tə ðɪs kæmp ɪn ist sɛntʃɹəl ɔltɑɹə.

A Cup of Kaf Furyk Karede pressed his gauntleted fist to his heart, returning the sentry's salute, and ignored the fact that the man spat as he rode past. He hoped the eighty men and twenty-one Ogier behind him ignored it, too. They had better, if they knew what was good for them. He was here for information, and a killing would make getting it more difficult. Since his manservant Ajimbura had planted his knife in a Standardbearer's heart over a perceived insult to his master - in truth, a real insult, but Ajimbura should have held his temper the way he himself had - since then, he had taken to leaving the wiry little hill-tribesman in the forest with the sul'dam and damane and some of the Guards to watch over the packhorses when he entered a camp. He had come a long way from Ebou Dar chasing the wind, almost four weeks of haring after rumors, until the news brought him here to this camp in east central Altara.

ðə nit ɹoʊz ə peɪl tɛns ən hɔɹslaɪnz stʊɾ ɪn ə fɔɹəs klɪɹɪŋ lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɹeɪkən tə lænd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ə ɹeɪkən əɹ flaɪɝz, noʊ ɡɹaʊn kʌmpəni wɪð ɪts wæɡənz ən ɹeɪkən-ɡɹumz. bʌt ðɛn, hi hæd nɑt sin ə ɹeɪkən ɪn ðə skaɪz fəɹ səm taɪm naʊ. səpoʊzədli ɔlmoʊst ɔl hæd bɪn sɛnt wɛst. waɪ, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ ən dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. ðə haɪ leɪɾi wɑz ɪz ɡoʊl ən ɪz ɪntaɪɝ wɝld. ə tɔl θɪn mɛsədʒ poʊl kæst ɪts lɔŋ ʃædoʊ ɪn ði ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn, ðoʊ, soʊ ðəɹ mʌs bi ɹeɪkən sʌmwɛɹ əbaʊt. hi θɔt ðə kæmp maɪt kənteɪn ə θaʊzən mɛn, nɑt kaʊntɪŋ fɛɹiɝz ən kʊks ən ðə laɪk. ɪntɝɛstɪŋli, ɛvɹi læst soʊlʒɝ i kəd si wɔɹ fəmɪljɝ ɑɹmɝ fɹəm hoʊm ɹæðɝ ðən ðoʊz sɑləd bɹɛstpleɪts ən bɑɹd hɛlməts. pɹæktəs wɑz tə pæɾ aʊt moʊs fɔɹsɪz wɪð mɛn fɹəm ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən. ɪt wɑz ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɑɹmɝd, tu. ə ɹɛɹ kəmændɝ kɛpt ɪz soʊlʒɝz ɪn ɑɹmɝ ənlɛs i ɪkspɛktəɾ ækʃən sun. fɹəm ðə ɹumɝz i hæd pɪkt ʌp, ðət maɪt bi ðə keɪs hɪɹ.

The neat rows of pale tents and horselines stood in a forest clearing large enough for raken to land, but there was no sign of raken or fliers, no ground company with its wagons and raken-grooms. But then, he had not seen a raken in the skies for some time now. Supposedly almost all had been sent west. Why, he did not know and did not care. The High Lady was his goal and his entire world. A tall thin message pole cast its long shadow in the early morning sun, though, so there must be raken somewhere about. He thought the camp might contain a thousand men, not counting farriers and cooks and the like. Interestingly, every last soldier he could see wore familiar armor from home rather than those solid breastplates and barred helmets. Practice was to pad out most forces with men from this side of the ocean. It was interesting that they were all armored, too. A rare commander kept his soldiers in armor unless he expected action soon. From the rumors he had picked up, that might be the case here.

θɹi flæɡstɑfs mɑɹk ðə kəmæn tɛnt, ə tɔl, wɔld əfɛɹ ə peɪl kænvəs wɪð ɛɹ vɛns əlɔŋ ðə pik ðət dʌbəld əz smoʊk hoʊlz. noʊ smoʊk ɪʃud fɹəm əm naʊ, fəɹ ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɑz oʊnli ə lɪɾəl kul, ðoʊ ðə sʌn hʌŋ nɑt fɑɹ əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən. ɑn wʌn flæɡstæf ðə blu-bɔɹɾɝd ɪmpɪɹiəl bænɝ hʌŋ ɪn lɪmp foʊlz, haɪɾɪŋ ðə spɹɛd-wɪŋd ɡoʊldən hɔk klʌtʃɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ ɪn ɪts təlɑnz. səm kəmændɝz hʌŋ ɪt fɹəm ə hɔɹəzɑntəl stæf soʊ ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz vɪzəbəl ɪn fʊl, bʌɾ i θɔt ðəɾ ɑstənteɪʃəs. ði ʌðɝ tu bænɝz, ɑn ʃɔɹɾɝ flæŋkɪŋ stæfs, wəd bi ʌv ðə ɹɛdʒəməns ðiz mɛn bɪlɔŋ tə.

Three flagstaffs marked the command tent, a tall, walled affair of pale canvas with air vents along the peak that doubled as smoke holes. No smoke issued from them now, for the morning was only a little cool, though the sun hung not far above the horizon. On one flagstaff the blue-bordered Imperial Banner hung in limp folds, hiding the spread-winged golden hawk clutching lightning in its talons. Some commanders hung it from a horizontal staff so it was always visible in full, but he thought that ostentatious. The other two banners, on shorter flanking staffs, would be of the regiments these men belonged to.

kɛɹid dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðət tɛn ən ɹimuvd ɪz hɛlmət. kæptən mjuzənʒ ɛmjəleɪɾɪd hɪm, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə ɡɹɪm ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪz wɛðɝd feɪs. ði ʌðɝ mɛn klaɪm daʊn tu, tə ɹɛs ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ən stʊd baɪ ðɛɹ ænəməlz. ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɑɹɾənɝz lin ɑn ðɛɹ lɔŋ-hæftɪd, blæk-tæsɛld æksiz. ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi steɪɪŋ lɔŋ.

Karede dismounted in front of that tent and removed his helmet. Captain Musenge emulated him, revealing a grim expression on his weathered face. The other men climbed down too, to rest their horses, and stood by their animals. The Ogier Gardeners leaned on their long-hafted, black-tasseled axes. Everyone knew they would not be staying long.

"kip ðə mɛn aʊɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl," hi toʊl mjuzənʒ. "ɪf ðət minz æksɛptɪŋ ɪnsʌls, soʊ bi ɪt."

"Keep the men out of trouble," he told Musenge. "If that means accepting insults, so be it."

"ðɛɹəd bi fjuɝ ɪnsʌls ɪf wi kɪld ə fju ʌv ðɛm," mjuzənʒ mʌɾɝd. hi hæd bɪn ɪn ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz ivən lɔŋɡɝ ðən kɛɹid, ðoʊ hɪz hɛɹ wɑz ənbɹoʊkən blæk, ən i wəd sʌfɝ ɪnsʌls tə ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, əz ɡlædli əz ɪnsʌls tə ðə ɡɑɹdz.

"There'd be fewer insults if we killed a few of them," Musenge muttered. He had been in the Deathwatch Guards even longer than Karede, though his hair was unbroken black, and he would suffer insults to the Empress, might she live forever, as gladly as insults to the Guards.

hɑɹɾə skɹætʃt wʌn ə hɪz lɔŋ ɡɹeɪ mʌstæʃɪz wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ ðə saɪz ʌv ə fæt sɔsədʒ. ðə fɝst ɡɑɹɾənɝ, kəmændɝ ʌv ɔl ði oʊɡiɝ ɪn ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑnz bɑɾiɡɑɹd, wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz tɔl əz ə mæn ɪn ðə sæɾəl, ən waɪd wɪð ɪt. hɪz ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin lækɝɾ ɑɹmɝ kənteɪn ɪnʌf stil tə meɪk ɑɹmɝ fəɹ θɹi əɹ fɔɹ hjumənz. hɪz feɪs wɑz əz daʊɝ əz mjuzənʒəz, jɛɾ ɪz bumɪŋ vɔɪs wɑz kɑm. oʊɡiɝ wɝ ɔlweɪz kɑm ɪksɛpt ɪn bæɾəl. ðən ðeɪ wɝ əz koʊld əz dip wɪntɝ ɪn dʒɛɹənəm. "æftɝ wi ɹɛskju ðə haɪ leɪɾi wi kən kɪl əz mɛni ʌv əm əz nid kɪlɪŋ, mjuzənʒ."

Hartha scratched one of his long gray mustaches with a finger the size of a fat sausage. The First Gardener, commander of all the Ogier in the High Lady Tuon's bodyguard, was almost as tall as a man in the saddle, and wide with it. His red-and-green lacquered armor contained enough steel to make armor for three or four humans. His face was as dour as Musenge's, yet his booming voice was calm. Ogier were always calm except in battle. Then they were as cold as deep winter in Jeranem. "After we rescue the High Lady we can kill as many of them as need killing, Musenge."

ɹɪkɔl tə hɪz duɾi, mjuzənʒ flʌʃt fəɹ hævɪŋ əlaʊd hɪmsɛlf tə stʃɹeɪ. "æftɝ," hi əɡɹid.

Recalled to his duty, Musenge flushed for having allowed himself to stray. "After," he agreed.

kɛɹid hæd skul hɪmsɛlf tu hɑɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz, hæd bɪn skul tu hɑɹd baɪ hɪz tʃɹeɪnɝz, tə saɪ, bʌt hæɾ i bɪn ʌðɝ ðən ə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd, hi maɪɾ əv dʌn soʊ naʊ. nɑt kəz mjuzənʒ wɑntəd tə kɪl sʌmwʌn ən ɔlmoʊst ɛniwʌn wəd du. ɹæðɝ ɪt wɑz kəz ði ɪnsʌls i hæd wɔkt əweɪ fɹəm ðiz pæst wiks tʃeɪft ɪm əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ dɪd mjuzənʒ ən hɑɹɾə. bʌt ðə ɡɑɹdz dɪd wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə kæɹi aʊt ðɛɹ əsaɪnməns, ən ɪf ðət mɛnt wɔkɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm mɛn u spæɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɑɹmɝ ɪn ɹɛɾ ən ðə dɑɹk ɡɹin moʊs kɔl blæk, əɹ dɛɹd tə mɝmɝ əbaʊt loʊɝɾ aɪz ɪn ɪz hɪɹɪŋ, ðən wɔk əweɪ hi mʌst. faɪndɪŋ ən ɹɛskjuɪŋ ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn wɑz ɔl ðət mæɾɝd. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls wɑz dʒɹɔs bɪsaɪd ðæt.

Karede had schooled himself too hard over the years, had been schooled too hard by his trainers, to sigh, but had he been other than a Deathwatch Guard, he might have done so now. Not because Musenge wanted to kill someone and almost anyone would do. Rather it was because the insults he had walked away from these past weeks chafed him as much as they did Musenge and Hartha. But the Guards did whatever was necessary to carry out their assignments, and if that meant walking away from men who spat on the ground at the sight of armor in red and the dark green most called black, or dared to murmur about lowered eyes in his hearing, then walk away he must. Finding and rescuing the High Lady Tuon was all that mattered. Everything else was dross beside that.

hɛlməɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm, hi dʌkt ɪndə ðə tɛn tə faɪnd wʌt mʌst əv bɪn moʊst ə ðə kæmps ɔfəsɝz ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ə lɑɹdʒ mæp spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn ə foʊldɪŋ kæmp teɪbəl. hæf wɔɹ sɛɡmɛntɪd bɹɛstpleɪts lækɝɾ ɪn hɔɹəzɑntəl ɹɛɾ ən blu stʃɹaɪps, ði ʌðɝ hæf ɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ. ðeɪ stʃɹeɪɾənd ən stɛɹd wən i wɔkt ɪn, mɛn fɹəm kaʊil əɹ dælənʃɝ wɪð skɪn blækɝ ðən tʃɑɹkoʊl, hʌni-bɹaʊn mɛn fɹəm ɑn, fɛɹ-hɛɹd mɛn fɹəm mɛkoʊkən, peɪl-aɪd mɛn fɹəm ælkəm, mɛn fɹəm ɛvɹi pɑɹɾ ə ði ɛmpaɪɝ. ðɛɹ stɛɹz hɛl nɑt ðə wɛɹinɪs ɔfən tɪŋd wɪð ædmɝeɪʃən ðəɾ i hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn juz tə, bʌt vɛɹi nɪɹli tʃælənʒɪz. ɪt simd ɛvɹiwʌn bɪliv ðə fɪlθi teɪl ʌv ɡɑɹdz' ɪnvɑlvmənt wɪð ə ɡɝl pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn ən ɪkstɔɹɾɪŋ ɡoʊld ən dʒuəlz fɹəm mɝtʃəns. laɪkli ðeɪ bɪliv ðəɾ ʌðɝ, wɪspɝd teɪl əbaʊt ðə ɡɝl, nɑt mɪɹli vaɪl bʌt hɔɹɪfɪk. noʊ. ðət ðə haɪ leɪɾi wɑz ɪn deɪnʒɝ ə hɝ laɪf fɹəm ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi ɪtsɛlf wɛn bɪɑn hɔɹɪfɪk. ðət wɑz ə wɝld ɡɔn mæd.

Helmet under his arm, he ducked into the tent to find what must have been most of the camp's officers gathered around a large map spread out on a folding camp table. Half wore segmented breastplates lacquered in horizontal red and blue stripes, the other half red and yellow. They straightened and stared when he walked in, men from Khoweal or Dalenshar with skin blacker than charcoal, honey-brown men from N'Kon, fair-haired men from Mechoacan, pale-eyed men from Alqam, men from every part of the Empire. Their stares held not the wariness often tinged with admiration that he had always been used to, but very nearly challenges. It seemed everyone believed the filthy tale of Guards' involvement with a girl pretending to be the High Lady Tuon and extorting gold and jewels from merchants. Likely they believed that other, whispered tale about the girl, not merely vile but horrific. No. That the High Lady was in danger of her life from the Ever Victorious Army itself went beyond horrific. That was a world gone mad.

"fɹɪk kɛɹid," hi sɛd kuli. hɪz hænd wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ tə hɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. oʊnli dɪsəplən kɛpt ɪɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd. dɪsəplən ən duɾi. hi hæɾ æksɛptɪd sɔɹd θɹʌsts fəɹ duɾi. hi kəɾ æksɛpt ɪnsəls fəɹ ɪt. "aɪ wɪʃ tə spik tə ðə kəmændɝ ə ðɪs kæmp." fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən ðə saɪləns stʃɹɛtʃt.

"Furyk Karede," he said coolly. His hand wanted to go to his sword hilt. Only discipline kept it at his side. Discipline and duty. He had accepted sword thrusts for duty. He could accept insults for it. "I wish to speak to the commander of this camp." For a long moment the silence stretched.

"ɛvɹibɑɾi aʊt," ə tɔl lin mæn bɑɹkt ət læst ɪn ðə ʃɑɹp æksɛns ə dælənʃɝ. ði ʌðɝz səluɾəd, ɡæðɝd ðɛɹ hɛlməts fɹəm ənʌðɝ teɪbəl ən faɪld aʊt. nɑt wʌn ɔfɝd kɛɹiɾ ə səlut. hɪz ɹaɪt hæn twɪtʃt wʌns, filɪŋ ə fæntəm hɪlt əɡɛnst ɪz pɑm, ən wɑz stɪl.

"Everybody out," a tall lean man barked at last in the sharp accents of Dalenshar. The others saluted, gathered their helmets from another table and filed out. Not one offered Karede a salute. His right hand twitched once, feeling a phantom hilt against his palm, and was still.

"ɡɑməl laʊn," ðə lin mæn ɪntʃɹədus hɪmsɛlf. mɪsɪŋ ðə tɑp ə hɪz ɹaɪɾ ɪɹ, hi hæɾ ə slæʃ ə sɑləd waɪt ðəɹ θɹu hɪz taɪt blæk kɝlz ən flɛks ʌv waɪɾ ɛlswɛɹ. "wʌt dʒju wɑnt?" ðəɹ wɑz ðə bɛɹəs tʌtʃ ʌv wɛɹinɪs ɪn ðæt. ə hɑɹd mæn, ən sɛlf-kəntʃɹoʊld. hi wʊɾə hæd tə bi tə ɝn ðə θɹi ɹɛd plumz dɛkɝeɪɾɪŋ ðə hɛlməɾ ətɑp ɪz sɔɹd-ɹæk. wik mɛn wɪθaʊt mæstɝi ʌv ðɛmsɛlvz dɪd nɑt ɹaɪz tə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl. kɛɹid səspɛktəd ði oʊnli ɹizən laʊn wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə tɔk tə hɪm wɑz ðəɾ ɪz oʊn hɛlmət bɔɹ θɹi blæk plumz.

"Gamel Loune," the lean man introduced himself. Missing the top of his right ear, he had a slash of solid white there through his tight black curls and flecks of white elsewhere. "What do you want?" There was the barest touch of wariness in that. A hard man, and self-controlled. He would have had to be to earn the three red plumes decorating the helmet atop his sword-rack. Weak men without mastery of themselves did not rise to Banner-General. Karede suspected the only reason Loune was willing to talk to him was that his own helmet bore three black plumes.

"nɑt tə ɪntɝfɪɹ ɪn jəɹ kəmænd." laʊn hæd kɑz tə fɪɹ ðæt. ɹæŋks ɪn ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd stʊd hæf ə stɛp haɪɝ ðən ðoʊz aʊtsaɪd. hi cʊɾə koʊ-ɑptɪd ðə mænz kəmæn hæɾ i niɾəd tə, ðoʊ hi wʊɾə bɪn ɹikwaɪɝd tə ɪkspleɪn ɪz ɹizənz leɪɾɝ. ðeɪ wʊɾə hæd tə bi ɡʊd ɹizənz fəɹ ɪm tə əvɔɪd luzɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "aɪ ʌndɝstæn ðəɹ əv bɪn . . . dɪfəkəltiz ɪn ðɪs pɑɹɾ ʌv ɔltɑɹə ɹisənli. aɪ wɑnə noʊ wʌɾ aɪm ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪntu."

"Not to interfere in your command." Loune had cause to fear that. Ranks in the Deathwatch Guard stood half a step higher than those outside. He could have co-opted the man's command had he needed to, though he would have been required to explain his reasons later. They would have had to be good reasons for him to avoid losing his head. "I understand there have been . . . difficulties in this part of Altara recently. I want to know what I am riding into."

laʊn ɡɹʌntɪd. " 'dɪfəkəltiz.' ðæts wʌn wɝd fəɹ ɪt."

Loune grunted. " 'Difficulties.' That's one word for it."

ə stɑki mæn ɪn ə pleɪn bɹaʊn koʊt, ə nɛɹoʊ bɪɹd dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ðə pɔɪn ə hɪz tʃɪn, ɛntɝd ðə tɛnt, kæɹiɪŋ ə hɛvəli kɑɹvd wʊɾən tʃɹeɪ wɪð ə sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ ən tu stɝɾi waɪt kʌps, ðə sɔɹt ðət wəd nɑt bɹeɪk izəli waɪl biɪŋ kæɹiɾ əbaʊɾ ɪn wæɡənz. ðə sɛn ə fɹɛʃli bɹud kæf bɪɡæn tə sʌfjus ði ɛɹ.

A stocky man in a plain brown coat, a narrow beard dangling from the point of his chin, entered the tent, carrying a heavily carved wooden tray with a silver pitcher and two sturdy white cups, the sort that would not break easily while being carried about in wagons. The scent of freshly brewed kaf began to suffuse the air.

"jɔɹ kæf, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl." sɛɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə teɪbəl hoʊldɪŋ ðə mæp, hi kɛɹfəli fɪld wʌn kʌp wɪð ðə blæk lɪkwəd waɪl wɑtʃɪŋ kɛɹid fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ. sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz, hi wɔɹ ə pɛɹ ə lɔŋ naɪvz əɾ ɪz bɛlt, ən ɪz hænz hæɾ ə naɪfmənz kælʌsɪz. kɛɹid sɛns kloʊs kɪn tə ædʒɪmbʊɹə, ɪn spɪɹət bʌt nɑt blʌd. ðoʊz dɑɹk bɹaʊn aɪz nɛvɝ keɪm fɹəm ðə kɛnsɑɾə hɪlz. "aɪ weɪɾəd tɪl ði ʌðɝz lɛf sɪns ðɛɹz hɑɹdli ɪnʌf fəɹ jə ɛni mɔɹ. doʊnt noʊ wən aɪm gɑnə ɡɛt mɔɹ, aɪ doʊnt."

"Your kaf, Banner-General." Setting the tray on the edge of table holding the map, he carefully filled one cup with the black liquid while watching Karede from the corner of his eye. Somewhere in his middle years, he wore a pair of long knives at his belt, and his hands had a knifeman's calluses. Karede sensed close kin to Ajimbura, in spirit but not blood. Those dark brown eyes never came from the Kaensada Hills. "I waited till the others left since there's hardly enough for you any more. Don't know when I'm going to get more, I don't."

"wɪl jə teɪk kæf, kɛɹid?" laʊnz ɹɪlʌktəns wɑz ɑbviəs, bʌɾ i kəd hɑɹdli feɪl tə ɔfɝ. fəɹ ən ɪnsəl ðət lɑɹdʒ, kɛɹid wʊɾə bɪn fɔɹs tə kɪl hɪm. əɹ soʊ ðə mæn wəd θɪŋk.

"Will you take kaf, Karede?" Loune's reluctance was obvious, but he could hardly fail to offer. For an insult that large, Karede would have been forced to kill him. Or so the man would think.

"wɪð plɛʒɝ," kɛɹid ɹɪplaɪd. pleɪsɪŋ ɪz hɛlməɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə tʃɹeɪ, hi dɑft ɪz stil-bækt ɡɔnləts ən leɪɾ əm bɪsaɪɾ ɪt.

"With pleasure," Karede replied. Placing his helmet alongside the tray, he doffed his steel-backed gauntlets and laid them beside it.

ðə sɝvɪŋ mæn fɪl ðə sɛkən kʌp, ðən stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹɾ ə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə tɛnt, bʌt laʊn sɛd, "ðæt wɪl bi ɔl fəɹ naʊ, mæntʃuəl." ðə stɑki mæn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, aɪɪŋ kɛɹid, bɪfɔɹ meɪkɪŋ ə baʊ tə laʊn, tʌtʃɪŋ aɪz ən lɪps wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝtɪps, ən dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ.

The serving man filled the second cup, then started toward a corner of the tent, but Loune said, "That will be all for now, Mantual." The stocky man hesitated, eyeing Karede, before making a bow to Loune, touching eyes and lips with his fingertips, and departing.

"mæntʃuəl ɪz oʊvɝ-pɹətɛktɪv ə mi," laʊn ɪkspleɪnd. klɪɹli hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɪkspleɪn, bʌɾ i dɪd wɑnə əvɔɪd wʌt maɪt bi teɪkən fəɹ oʊpən ɪnsəlt. "ɑd fɛloʊ. ətætʃt hɪmsɛlf tə mi jɪɹz əɡoʊ ɪn pudʒili, wɝmd ɪz weɪ ɪndə bɪkʌmɪŋ maɪ mænsɝvənt. aɪ θɪŋk hid steɪ ɪf aɪ stɑpt peɪɪŋ hɪm." jɛs, vɛɹi kloʊs kɪn tə ædʒɪmbʊɹə.

"Mantual is over-protective of me," Loune explained. Clearly he did not want to explain, but he did want to avoid what might be taken for open insult. "Odd fellow. Attached himself to me years ago in Pujili, wormed his way into becoming my manservant. I think he'd stay if I stopped paying him." Yes, very close kin to Ajimbura.

fəɹ ə taɪm ðeɪ sɪmpli sɪp kæf, bælənsɪŋ ðə kʌps ɑn fɪŋɡɝtɪps ən ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðə pʌnʒənt bɪɾɝnəs. ɪt sim tə bi ə pjʊɹ ɪdʒəz maʊntənz bɹu, ən ɪf soʊ, vɛɹi ɪkspɛnsɪv. kɛɹidz oʊn səplaɪ ʌv blæk binz, moʊs dɛfənətli nɑɾ ɪdʒəz maʊntənz, hæd ɹʌn aʊɾ ə wik əɡoʊ, ən i hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ mʌtʃ i mɪs hævɪŋ kæf. hi nɛvɝ juz tə maɪnd ɡoʊɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ ət nid. ðə fɝs kʌps dʌn, laʊn ɹifɪl ðɛm.

For a time they simply sipped kaf, balancing the cups on fingertips and enjoying the pungent bitterness. It seemed to be a pure Ijaz Mountains brew, and if so, very expensive. Karede's own supply of black beans, most definitely not Ijaz Mountains, had run out a week ago, and he had been surprised at how much he missed having kaf. He never used to mind going without anything at need. The first cups done, Loune refilled them.

"ju wɝ gɑnə tɛl mi əbaʊt ðə dɪfəkəltiz," kɛɹid pɹɑmptəd naʊ ðət kɑnvɝseɪʃən wəd nɑt bi ɪmpəlaɪt. hi ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə bi pəlaɪɾ ivən wɪð mɛn i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə kɪl, ən ɹudnəs hɪɹ wəd dæm ʌp ðə mænz tʌŋ.

"You were going to tell me about the difficulties," Karede prompted now that conversation would not be impolite. He always tried to be polite even with men he was going to kill, and rudeness here would dam up the man's tongue.

laʊn sɛɾ ɪz kʌp daʊn ən lin ɪz fɪsts ɑn ðə teɪbəl, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə mæp. smɔl ɹɛd wɛdʒəz səpɔɹɾɪŋ taɪni peɪpɝ bænɝz wɝ skæɾɝd əkɹɔs ɪt, mɑɹkɪŋ sintʃæn fɔɹsɪz ɑn ðə muv, ən ɹɛd stɑɹz ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ fɔɹsɪz hoʊldɪŋ ɪn pleɪs. lɪɾəl blæk dɪsks mɑɹkɪŋ ɛnɡeɪdʒməns pɛpɝd ðə mæp, bʌt stʃɹeɪnʒli, noʊ waɪt dɪsks tə ɪndəkeɪt ði ɛnəmi. nʌn.

Loune set his cup down and leaned his fists on the table, frowning at the map. Small red wedges supporting tiny paper banners were scattered across it, marking Seanchan forces on the move, and red stars indicating forces holding in place. Little black discs marking engagements peppered the map, but strangely, no white discs to indicate the enemy. None.

"oʊvɝ ðə læst wik," laʊn sɛd, "ðɛɹ əv bɪn fɔɹ saɪzəbəl ɛnɡeɪdʒməns ən ʌpwɝdz ə sɪksti æmbʊʃɪz, skɝmɪʃɪz ən ɹeɪdz, mɛni kwaɪt lɑɹdʒ, ɔl spɹɛɾ aʊɾ əkɹɔs θɹi hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz." ðəɾ ɛnkʌmpəst ɔlmoʊs ði ɪntaɪɝ mæp. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz stɪf. pleɪnli, ɡɪvən ə tʃɔɪs, hi wʊɾə toʊl kɛɹid nʌθɪŋ. ðət hæf-stɛp ɡeɪv ɪm nʌn, haʊɛvɝ. "ðɛɹ mʌs bi sɪks əɹ eɪt dɪfɹən ɑɹmiz ɪnvɑlvd ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ðə naɪɾ æftɝ ðə fɝs lɑɹdʒ ɛnɡeɪdʒmən sɔ naɪn meɪdʒɝ ɹeɪdz, itʃ fɔɹɾi tə fɪfti maɪlz fɹəm ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bæɾəl. nɑt smɔl ɑɹmiz, iðɝ, ət lis nɑt teɪkən ɔltəɡɛðɝ, bʌt wi kæn faɪn ðɛm, ən noʊbɑdi hæz ɛni aɪləs aɪdiə wɛɹ ðeɪ keɪm fɹʌm. huɛvɝ ðeɪ ɑɹ, ðeɪv deɪmeɪn, ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɪð ðɛm, ən meɪbi ðoʊz kɝst æʃəmən. mɛn əv bɪn tɔɹn əpɑɹt baɪ ɪksploʊʒənz əɹ deɪmeɪn seɪ wɝn kɑz baɪ ðə paʊɝ."

"Over the last week," Loune said, "there have been four sizeable engagements and upwards of sixty ambushes, skirmishes and raids, many quite large, all spread out across three hundred miles." That encompassed almost the entire map. His voice was stiff. Plainly, given a choice, he would have told Karede nothing. That half-step gave him none, however. "There must be six or eight different armies involved on the other side. The night after the first large engagement saw nine major raids, each forty to fifty miles from the site of the battle. Not small armies, either, at least not taken altogether, but we can't find them, and nobody has any eyeless idea where they came from. Whoever they are, they have damane, those Aes Sedai, with them, and maybe those cursed Asha'man. Men have been torn apart by explosions our damane say weren't caused by the Power."

kɛɹid sɪpt ɪz kæf. ðə mæn wɑz nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ. ɪf ði ɛnəmi hæɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən æʃəmən, ðeɪ kəd juz ðə θɪŋ kɔl tʃɹævlɪŋ tə muv əz fɑɹ əz ðeɪ wɪʃt ɪn ə stɛp. bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ kəd də ðæt, waɪ hæd ðeɪ nɑt juzd ɪt tə stɛp ɔl ðə weɪ tə seɪfti wɪð ðɛɹ pɹaɪz? pɝhæps nɑɾ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ ən æʃəmən kəd tʃɹævəl, jɛt ðət bɛɡd ənʌðɝ kwɛstʃən. waɪ hæd ðeɪ nɑt sɛn ðoʊz u kʊd? meɪbi ði oʊnli ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ðə deɪmeɪn stoʊlən fɹəm ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs. ɹɪpɔɹɾədli, nʌn ə ðɛm hæd hæɾ ɛni aɪdiə haʊ tə tʃɹævəl. ðət meɪd sɛns. "wʌt də ðə pɹɪznɝz seɪ əbaʊɾ u sɛn ðɛm?"

Karede sipped his kaf. The man was not thinking. If the enemy had Aes Sedai and Asha'man, they could use the thing called Traveling to move as far as they wished in a step. But if they could do that, why had they not used it to step all the way to safety with their prize? Perhaps not all Aes Sedai and Asha'man could Travel, yet that begged another question. Why had they not sent those who could? Maybe the only Aes Sedai were the damane stolen from the Tarasin Palace. Reportedly, none of them had had any idea how to Travel. That made sense. "What do the prisoners say about who sent them?"

laʊnz læf wɑz bɪɾɝ. "bɪfɔɹ jə kən əv aɪləs pɹɪznɝz, jə niɾ ən aɪləs vɪktɝi. wʌt wiv hæɾ ɑɹ ə stʃɹɪŋ ʌv aɪləs dɪfits." pɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz kʌp, hi tʊk ə sɪp. hɪz vɔɪs lusən əz ɪf i hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðə kʌlɝz ə kɛɹidz ɑɹmɝ. hi wɑz dʒʌst ə soʊlʒɝ tɔkɪŋ ɪz tʃɹeɪd, naʊ. "ɡɹɑt θɔɾ i hæd səm ə ðɛm tu deɪz əɡoʊ. hi lɔs fɔɹ bænɝz ə hɔɹs ən faɪv ə fʊɾ ɔlmoʊs tə ðə læs mæn. nɑɾ ɔl dɛd, bʌt moʊst ə ðə wundəɾ ɑɹ ðə nɛks θɪŋ tə ɪt. pɪŋkuʃənd wɪð kɹɔsboʊ boʊls. moʊsli tæɹɑbənɝz ən ɑmɑdɪʃənz, bʌt ðəɾ ɪzən səpoʊz tə mæɾɝ, ɪz ɪt. hæd tə bi twɛnti θaʊzən əɹ mɔɹ kɹɔsboʊmən tə pʊɾ aʊt ðət vɑljum. θɝɾi θaʊzənd, meɪbi. ən jɛt ðeɪ mænədʒ tə haɪd fɹəm ðə mɔɹətʃɹeɪkən. aɪ noʊ wiv kɪl səm - ðə ɹɪpɔɹts kleɪm ɪt, ət list - bʌt ðeɪ doʊn ivən liv ðɛɹ dɛd bɪhaɪnd. səm fulz əv bɪɡʌn wɪspɝɪŋ ðət wɝ faɪɾɪŋ spɪɹəts." fulz i maɪt kənsɪɾɝ ðɛm, bʌt ðə fɪŋɡɝz ə hɪz lɛf hæn hʊkt ɪn ə saɪn tə wɔɹɾ ɔf ivəl. "aɪl tɛl jə wʌn θɪŋ aɪ noʊ, kɛɹid. ðɛɹ kəmændɝz ɑɹ vɛɹi ɡʊd. vɛɹi, vɛɹi ɡʊd. ɛvɹi mæn tə feɪs əm əz bɪn fɔɾ ɔf ɪz fit, aʊtmənuvɝɾ ən aʊtfoʊt kəmplitli."

Loune's laugh was bitter. "Before you can have eyeless prisoners, you need an eyeless victory. What we've had are a string of eyeless defeats." Picking up his cup, he took a sip. His voice loosened as if he had forgotten the colors of Karede's armor. He was just a soldier talking his trade, now. "Gurat thought he had some of them two days ago. He lost four banners of horse and five of foot almost to the last man. Not all dead, but most of the wounded are the next thing to it. Pincushioned with crossbow bolts. Mostly Taraboners and Amadicians, but that isn't supposed to matter, is it. Had to be twenty thousand or more crossbowmen to put out that volume. Thirty thousand, maybe. And yet they manage to hide from the morat'raken. I know we've killed some - the reports claim it, at least - but they don't even leave their dead behind. Some fools have begun whispering that we're fighting spirits." Fools he might consider them, but the fingers of his left hand hooked in a sign to ward off evil. "I'll tell you one thing I know, Karede. Their commanders are very good. Very, very good. Every man to face them has been fought off his feet, outmaneuvered and outfought completely."

kɛɹid nɑɾəd θɔtfəli. hi hæd spɛkjəleɪɾəd ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝ mʌst əv tæskt wʌn ʌv ɪts bɛs tə kɪdnæp ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə laɪnz ʌv wʌt pipəl ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən kɔl ðə ɡɹeɪt kæptənz. pɝhæps tɑm mɛɹɪlɪnz ɹil neɪm wɑz eɪɡəlmɝ dʒəɡəɾ əɹ ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. hi lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə miɾɪŋ ðə mæn, nɑt lis tə æsk ɪm haʊ hi hæd noʊn ʃi wəd bi kʌmɪŋ tə ɛbu dɑɹ. hi maɪt haɪd sjuɹɔθs ɪnvɑlvmənt, bʌt ðən əɡɛn, hi maɪt nɑt. ɑn ðə haɪts, tədeɪz ælaɪ kəd bi təmɑɹoʊz sækɹəfaɪs. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə ɡɑɹɾənɝz, ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz wɝ dækoʊvæl tə ði ɛmpɹɛs hɝsɛlf, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, jɛt ðeɪ lɪvd ɑn ðə haɪts. "ðɛɹ mʌs bi səm plæn fəɹ faɪndɪŋ əm ən pɪnɪŋ ðɛm. ɑɹ jə ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ʌv ɪt?"

Karede nodded thoughtfully. He had speculated that the White Tower must have tasked one of its best to kidnap the High Lady Tuon, but he had not been thinking along the lines of what people this side of the ocean called the great captains. Perhaps Thom Merrilin's real name was Agelmar Jagad or Gareth Bryne. He looked forward to meeting the man, not least to ask him how he had known she would be coming to Ebou Dar. He might hide Suroth's involvement, but then again, he might not. On the heights, today's ally could be tomorrow's sacrifice. Except for the Gardeners, the Deathwatch Guards were da'covale to the Empress herself, might she live forever, yet they lived on the heights. "There must be some plan for finding them and pinning them. Are you in charge of it?"

"noʊ, pɹeɪz bi tə ðə laɪt!" laʊn sɛd fɝvənli. hi tʊk ə lɔŋ dʒɹɪŋk əz ðoʊ wɪʃɪŋ ɪt wɝ bɹændi. "dʒɛnɝəl tʃɪsən ɪz bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz ɪntaɪɝ ɑɹmi bæk θɹu ðə mɑlvaɪd nɛɹoʊz. əpɛɹənli ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs dɪsaɪɾɪd ðɪs wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnʌf tə ɹɪsk θɹʌsts aʊɾ ə mʊɹændi əɹ ændɝ, ðoʊ fɹəm wʌɾ aɪv hɝd, niðɝ wʌn ɪz keɪpəbəl ə stʃɹaɪkɪŋ əɾ ɛniwʌn ət ðə moʊmənt. aɪ dʒʌst əv tə weɪt hɪɹ əntɪl tʃɪsən ɝaɪvz. wɪl si ə dɪfɹən ɹɪzʌl ðɛn, aɪ θɪŋk. mɔɹ ðən hæf tʃɪsənz mɛn wɪl bi vɛɾɝənz fɹəm hoʊm."

"No, praise be to the Light!" Loune said fervently. He took a long drink as though wishing it were brandy. "General Chisen is bringing his entire army back through the Malvide Narrows. Apparently the Tarasin Palace decided this was important enough to risk thrusts out of Murandy or Andor, though from what I've heard, neither one is capable of striking at anyone at the moment. I just have to wait here until Chisen arrives. We'll see a different result then, I think. More than half Chisen's men will be veterans from home."

əbɹʌpli laʊn sim tə ɹikɔl u hi wɑz tɔkɪŋ tə. hɪz feɪs tɝn tə dɑɹk wʊd, ə hɑɹd mæsk. ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. kɛɹid wɑz kənvɪns ðɪs wɑz ðə wɝk ə mɛɹɪlɪn əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɪz neɪm wɑz. ən i nu waɪ ðə mæn wɑz duɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ. ʌndɝ dɪfɹən sɝkəmstænsəz, hi wʊɾə toʊld laʊn ɪz ɹizənɪŋ, bʌt ðə haɪ leɪɾi wəd nɑt bi seɪf əntɪl ʃi wɑz bæk ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs əmʌŋ ðoʊz u nu hɝ feɪs. ɪf ðə mæn feɪl tə bɪliv ɪm ɑn ðə ki pɔɪnt, ðət ʃi wɑz ðə haɪ leɪɾi, hi wʊɾə ɪnkɹist əɹ deɪnʒɝ fəɹ nʌθɪŋ.

Abruptly Loune seemed to recall who he was talking to. His face turned to dark wood, a hard mask. It did not matter. Karede was convinced this was the work of Merrilin or whatever his name was. And he knew why the man was doing what he was doing. Under different circumstances, he would have told Loune his reasoning, but the High Lady would not be safe until she was back in the Tarasin Palace among those who knew her face. If the man failed to believe him on the key point, that she was the High Lady, he would have increased her danger for nothing.

"aɪ θæŋk jə fəɹ ðə kæf," hi sɛd, sɛɾɪŋ ðə kʌp daʊn ən teɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz hɛlməɾ ən ɡɔnləts. "ðə laɪt si jə seɪf, laʊn. wɪl miɾ ɪn sindɑɹ sʌmdeɪ."

"I thank you for the kaf," he said, setting the cup down and taking up his helmet and gauntlets. "The Light see you safe, Loune. We will meet in Seandar someday."

"ðə laɪt si jə seɪf, kɛɹid," laʊn sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt, pleɪnli sɝpɹaɪz baɪ ðə pəlaɪt fɛɹwɛl. "wi wɪl miɾ ɪn sindɑɹ sʌmdeɪ." ðə mæn hæd ʃɛɹd kæf, ən kɛɹid hæd noʊ kwɔɹəl wɪð hɪm. waɪ ʃəɾ i bi sɝpɹaɪzd?

"The Light see you safe, Karede," Loune said after a moment, plainly surprised by the polite farewell. "We will meet in Seandar someday." The man had shared kaf, and Karede had no quarrel with him. Why should he be surprised?

kɛɹid dɪd nɑt spik tə mjuzənʒ əntɪl ðeɪ hæd ɹɪɾən aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp, ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɑɹɾənɝz stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə ðə hjumən ɡɑɹdz. hɑɹɾə wɑz wɔkɪŋ ɑn kɛɹidz ʌðɝ saɪd, hɪz lɔŋ æks pɹɑpt ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, hɪz hɛd nɪɹli lɛvəl wɪð ðɛɹz.

Karede did not speak to Musenge until they had ridden out of the camp, the Ogier Gardeners striding along just ahead of the human Guards. Hartha was walking on Karede's other side, his long axe propped on his shoulder, his head nearly level with theirs.

"wi hɛd nɔɹθist," hi sɛd, "fɔɹ ðə mɑlvaɪd nɛɹoʊz." ɪf i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə mæps kɝɛkli, ən i sɛldəm fɝɡɑɾ ɛni mæp i hæd mɔɹ ðən ɡlɪmpst, ðeɪ kəd ɹitʃ ɪɾ ɪn fɔɹ deɪz. "ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn əs ðət wi ɝaɪv bɪfɔɹ ðə haɪ leɪɾi." ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt, ðə pɝsut wəd kəntɪnju, ɔl ðə weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi. ðə θɔɾ ə tɝnɪŋ bæk wɪθaʊt ðə haɪ leɪɾi nɛvɝ əkɝd tə hɪm. ɪf i hæd tə bɹɪŋ əɹ aʊɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, hi wʊd.

"We head northeast," he said, "for the Malvide Narrows." If he remembered the maps correctly, and he seldom forgot any map he had more than glimpsed, they could reach it in four days. "The Light shine on us that we arrive before the High Lady." If they did not, the pursuit would continue, all the way to Tar Valon if necessary. The thought of turning back without the High Lady never occurred to him. If he had to bring her out of Tar Valon, he would.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾifaɪv

CHAPTER 35

ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ə daɪɛlɪn "ðeɪ wɑn seɪf kʌndəkt?" ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "tə ɛntɝ keɪɛmlɪn?" laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt aʊtsaɪd ðə wɪndoʊz, ən θʌndɝ bumd. aʊtsaɪd, ə dɛljudʒ fɛl ɑn keɪɛmlɪn, ə hæmɝɪŋ daʊnpɔɹ. ðə sʌn mʌst əv bɪn wɛl əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən, bʌt ðə stænd-læmps wɝ lɪɾ əɡɛns twaɪlaɪt dɑɹknəs.

The Importance of Dyelin "They want safe conduct?" Elayne said incredulously. "To enter Caemlyn?" Lightning flashed outside the windows, and thunder boomed. Outside, a deluge fell on Caemlyn, a hammering downpour. The sun must have been well above the horizon, but the stand-lamps were lit against twilight darkness.

ðə slɛndɝ jʌŋ mæn stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ loʊ-bæk tʃɛɹ kʌlɝd wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt, jɛɾ i kəntɪnjud tə lʊk əɹ ɪn ði aɪ. hi wɑz lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə bɔɪ, ɹɪli, hɪz smuð tʃiks laɪkli ʃeɪvd əz mʌtʃ fəɹ fɔɹm əz kəz i niɾəd ə ɹeɪzɝ vɛɹi ɔfən. vɛɹi pɹɑpɝli, hænsəl ɹɛnʃɝ, ɑɝəθɛlz ɡɹændsʌn, wɔɹ niðɝ sɔɹd nɔɹ ɑɹmɝ, bʌt ðə mɑɹks ə bɹɛstpleɪt stʃɹæps ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ɪz ɡɹin koʊt, ɪmpɹɪntɪd baɪ lɔŋ wɛɹ. ə lɑɹdʒ dæmp spɑɾ ɑn ɪz lɛft ʃoʊldɝ ʃoʊd wɛɹ ɪz kloʊk hæd lik θɹu. ɑd, ðə θɪŋz jə noʊɾəst ət taɪmz laɪk ðɪs. "aɪ wɑz ɪnstʃɹʌktəd tə æsk fəɹ ɪt, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs stɛɾi.

The slender young man standing in front of her low-backed chair colored with embarrassment, yet he continued to look her in the eye. He was little more than a boy, really, his smooth cheeks likely shaved as much for form as because he needed a razor very often. Very properly, Hanselle Renshar, Arathelle's grandson, wore neither sword nor armor, but the marks of breastplate straps remained on his green coat, imprinted by long wear. A large damp spot on his left shoulder showed where his cloak had leaked through. Odd, the things you noticed at times like this. "I was instructed to ask for it, my Lady," he said, his voice steady.

daɪɛlɪn, ɑɹmz foʊldəd bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, ɡɹʌntɪd saʊɝli. ʃi wɑz nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm skaʊlɪŋ. mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ, ɹisplɛndən əz ɔlweɪz ɪn əɹ kɹɪmzən tɑbɝd wɪð ðə waɪt laɪən spɑtləs ɑn əɹ fɔɹməɾəbəl bʊzəm, snɪft ɑɾəbli. hænsəl kʌlɝɾ əɡɛn. ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ɪleɪnz smɔlɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, wɛɹ ə smɔl faɪɝ ɑn ðə mɑɹbəl hɑɹθ tʊk əweɪ moʊst ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋz tʃɪl ən læmp ɔɪl sɛntɪd ði ɛɹ wɪð ɹoʊzɪz. ʃi wɪʃt bɝdʒɪt wɑz ðɛɹ. fɹəm ðə maɪld ɪɹɪteɪʃən floʊɪŋ θɹu ðə bɑnd, ʃi wɑz dilɪŋ wɪð ɹɪpɔɹts. hɝ ənɔɪəns wɑz nɑt ɡɹeɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪt tə bi ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ ɝdʒənt.

Dyelin, arms folded beneath her breasts, grunted sourly. She was not far from scowling. Mistress Harfor, resplendent as always in her crimson tabard with the White Lion spotless on her formidable bosom, sniffed audibly. Hanselle colored again. They were in Elayne's smaller sitting room, where a small fire on the marble hearth took away most of the morning's chill and lamp oil scented the air with roses. She wished Birgitte was there. From the mild irritation flowing through the bond, she was dealing with reports. Her annoyance was not great enough for it to be anything more urgent.

ði ɝaɪvəl ə lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz bɪloʊ ðə sɪɾi tu deɪz əɡoʊ wɪð ðɛɹ sɪksti θaʊzən ɑɹmmɪn hæɾ əkeɪʒən mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl ɪksaɪtmənt, ən ɪmpɹɑmptu sɛləbɹeɪʃənz ɪn ðə stʃɹits baɪ ðə sɪɾəzənz, wʌns ɪt bɪkeɪm klɪɹ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt gɑnə ɑkjəpaɪ ðə kæmps əbændənd wən dʒɑɝɪd sɑɝən lɛft. teɪkɪŋ wɪð ɪm mɛn fɹəm haʊsəz ðət naʊ saɪɾəd wɪð ɪleɪn, ðoʊ ðeɪ kəd nɑt noʊ ɪt jɛt. ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu wʌt tʃɹʌbəl ðət blʌɾi mæn wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə kɑz. bʌt hænsəlz mɛsədʒ pʊɾ ə nu kəmplɛkʃən ɑn ðə hjudʒ ɛnkæmpmən dʒʌst ə maɪl saʊθ ə loʊ keɪɛmlɪn. ɪf ɑɝəθɛl, lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz nu əbaʊt ðə sɪɾi biɪŋ səplaɪd fɹəm tiɹ ən ɪljən θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz, ən ʃʊɹli ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ændɝ nu baɪ ðɪs taɪm, pɝhæps ðeɪ hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ə sidʒ wəɾ əkɑmplɪʃ nʌθɪŋ. seɪf kʌndəkt wɑz ə mæɾɝ ə bæɾəl laɪnz. pɝhæps ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd tə kɔl fəɹ keɪɛmlɪnz sɝɛndɝ tə əvɔɪɾ ə ɡɹæn əsɔlt. ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃənz ə səpɔɹt, kæɹid baɪ kɪnswɪmən ɹæðɝ ðən ɹaɪɾɝz, hæd bɪn poʊstɪd fɹəm ɑɹɪŋɡəl tə ðə maɪnɪŋ vɪlədʒəz ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, əɹ sun wəd bi, bʌɾ ivən wɪð sumeɪkoʊ ən ʌðɝ kɪnswɪmən wɛɹɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz aʊɾ ɪn hilɪŋ, ði ɑɹmmɪn ə kɝən, ænʃɝ ən bɛɹɪn u hæd nɑt bɪn kæɹiɾ ɔf baɪ dʒɑɝɪd dɪd nɑt bɹɪŋ əɹ nʌmbɝz ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ sɪksti θaʊzənd. smɔl bænz ʌv ɑɹmmɪn wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə floʊ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi əz wɝd spɹɛd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz seɪf tə əpɹoʊtʃ keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf jɛt. ɪt maɪt bi ə wik əɹ mɔɹ bɪfɔɹ saɪzəbəl pɑɹɾiz əpɪɹd. ðoʊz hæd bɪn steɪɪŋ klɪɹ ə ðə sɪɾi fəɹ fɪɹ ʌv ɛɹəmɪləz ɑɹmi. ði aʊtkʌm ʌv ə mæsɪv əsɔlt wɑz nɑɾ ə fɔɹɡɔn kənkluʒən - mɛn ətɑp ə wɔl hæd kənsɪɾɝəbəl ædvæntɪdʒ oʊvɝ ðoʊz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə skeɪl ɪt - bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi ə nɪɹ-ɹʌn θɪŋ ət bɛst, ən noʊ hoʊp fəɹ mɔɹ hɛlp sun. daɪɛlɪn hæd peɪɾ ənʌðɝ vɪzət tə deɪnin kændʒɹeɪɾ ɪn ðə wɛst, bʌt ðə wʊmən stɪl dɪðɝd. ɪleɪn hæd naɪn haʊsəz wɛɹ ʃi niɾəd tɛn, ɛvɹiθɪŋ hʌŋ ɪn ðə bæləns, ən deɪnin kəd nɑt blʌɾi dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt tə stæn fəɹ tʃɹəkənd.

The arrival of Luan and the others below the city two days ago with their sixty thousand armsmen had occasioned more than a little excitement, and impromptu celebrations in the streets by the citizens, once it became clear they were not going to occupy the camps abandoned when Jarid Sarand left. Taking with him men from Houses that now sided with Elayne, though they could not know it yet. The Light only knew what trouble that bloody man was going to cause. But Hanselle's message put a new complexion on the huge encampment just a mile south of Low Caemlyn. If Arathelle, Luan and the others knew about the city being supplied from Tear and Illian through gateways, and surely everyone in Andor knew by this time, perhaps they had decided a siege would accomplish nothing. Safe conduct was a matter of battle lines. Perhaps they intended to call for Caemlyn's surrender to avoid a grand assault. The proclamations of support, carried by Kinswomen rather than riders, had been posted from Aringill to the mining villages in the Mountains of Mist, or soon would be, but even with Sumeko and other Kinswomen wearing themselves out in Healing, the armsmen of Caeren, Anshar and Baryn who had not been carried off by Jarid did not bring her numbers anywhere near sixty thousand. Small bands of armsmen were beginning to flow into the city as word spread that it was safe to approach Caemlyn, but not enough yet. It might be a week or more before sizeable parties appeared. Those had been staying clear of the city for fear of Arymilla's army. The outcome of a massive assault was not a foregone conclusion - men atop a wall had considerable advantage over those trying to scale it - but it would be a near-run thing at best, and no hope for more help soon. Dyelin had paid another visit to Danine Candraed in the west, but the woman still dithered. Elayne had nine Houses where she needed ten, everything hung in the balance, and Danine could not bloody decide whether or not to stand for Trakand.

"waɪ də ðeɪ wɪʃ tə spik wɪð mi?" ʃi mænədʒ tə kip bɝdʒɪts ɪɹɪteɪʃən fɹəm tɪnɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs. bɝdʒɪts ən əɹ oʊn.

"Why do they wish to speak with me?" She managed to keep Birgitte's irritation from tinging her voice. Birgitte's and her own.

hænsəl ɹɛɾənd jɛɾ əɡɛn. hi sim tə də ðəɾ izəli. bɝn hɝ, ðeɪ tʃɹuli hæd sɛn ə bɔɪ! "aɪ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnfɔɹmd, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪ wɑz sɪmpli toʊl tə æsk fəɹ seɪf kʌndəkt." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ðeɪ wɪl nɑɾ ɛntɝ keɪɛmlɪn wɪθaʊɾ ɪt, maɪ leɪɾi."

Hanselle reddened yet again. He seemed to do that easily. Burn her, they truly had sent a boy! "I was not informed, my Lady. I was simply told to ask for safe conduct." He hesitated. "They will not enter Caemlyn without it, my Lady."

ɹaɪzɪŋ, ʃi wɛn tə hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dɛsk, ɹimuvd ə smuð ʃiɾ ʌv ɡʊd waɪt peɪpɝ fɹəm ðə ɹoʊzwʊd peɪpɝ-bɑks ən dɪpt ə pɛn ɪn ðə sɪlvɝ-maʊntəd kɹɪstəl ɪŋk dʒɑɹ. pɹɪsaɪs lɛɾɝz floʊɾ ɑntu ðə peɪdʒ wɪθaʊɾ əɹ juʒəwəl flɝɪʃəz. ʃi wɑz ʃɔɹɾ ən tə ðə pɔɪnt.

Rising, she went to her writing desk, removed a smooth sheet of good white paper from the rosewood paper-box and dipped a pen in the silver-mounted crystal ink jar. Precise letters flowed onto the page without her usual flourishes. She was short and to the point.

lɔɹd lwɑn nɔɹwlɪn, leɪɾi ɑɝəθɛl ɹɛnʃɝ, lɔɹd pɛlɪvɑɹ koʊələn, leɪɾi æɛmlɪn kɑɝənd, leɪɾi ɛlɹin tʃɹæmən ən lɔɹɾ æbəl pɛnʒɹ meɪ fil seɪf ɪn ɛntɝɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn ən bi əʃʊɹd ðət ðeɪ ən ðɛɹ ɹɛɾənjuz meɪ dɪpɑɹt ðə sɪɾi əɾ ɛni taɪm ðeɪ wɪʃ. əl ɹəsiv əm ɪnfɔɹməli ðɪs æftɝnun ɪn ðə ɡɹæn hɔl əz bɪfɪts ðɛɹ steɪʃənz. wi mʌst spik ə ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz.

Lord Luan Norwelyn, Lady Arathelle Renshar, Lord Pelivar Coelan, Lady Aemlyn Carand, Lady Ellorien Traemane and Lord Abelle Pendar may feel safe in entering Caemlyn and be assured that they and their retinues may depart the city at any time they wish. I will receive them informally this afternoon in the Grand Hall as befits their stations. We must speak of the Borderlanders.

ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪnteɪn kɑm, bʌt ðə stil nɪb dʌɡ ɪndə ðə peɪpɝ wɪð ðə læs lɛɾɝz. seɪf kʌndəkt. ʃi tʃænəld ə silɪŋ kændəl əlaɪt, ən əɹ hæn tʃɹɛmbəld əz ʃi dʒɹɪbəld ɡoʊldən jɛloʊ wæks ɑntu ðə peɪdʒ. ðeɪ ɪmplaɪd ʃi wəd tʃɹaɪ tə hoʊld əm baɪ fɔɹs. noʊ, mɔɹ ðən ɪmplaɪd! ðeɪ əz ɡʊɾ əz sɛɾ ɪt! ʃi pɹɛst əɹ sil, ə blɑsəmɪŋ lɪli, ɪndə ðə wæks əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒɹaɪv ɪt θɹu ðə teɪbəltɑp.

Elayne Trakand Daughter-Heir of Andor High Seat of House Trakand She tried to maintain calm, but the steel nib dug into the paper with the last letters. Safe conduct. She channeled a sealing candle alight, and her hand trembled as she dribbled golden yellow wax onto the page. They implied she would try to hold them by force. No, more than implied! They as good as said it! She pressed her seal, a blossoming lily, into the wax as if trying to drive it through the tabletop.

"hɪɹ," ʃi sɛd, hændɪŋ ðə ʃit tə ðə jʌŋ mæn. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz aɪs, ən ʃi meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə wɔɹm ɪt. "ɪf ðɪs feɪlz tə meɪk əm fil seɪf, pɝhæps ðeɪ maɪt tʃɹaɪ ɹæpɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn swɑɾəlɪŋ." θʌndɝ bum fəɹ pʌŋktʃueɪʃən.

"Here," she said, handing the sheet to the young man. Her voice was ice, and she made no effort to warm it. "If this fails to make them feel safe, perhaps they might try wrapping themselves in swaddling." Thunder boomed for punctuation.

hi kʌlɝd wʌns mɔɹ, ðɪs taɪm pleɪnli ɪn æŋɡɝ, bʌt waɪzli kənfaɪn hɪmsɛlf tə ɔfɝɪŋ θæŋks əz i foʊldəd ðə peɪdʒ. hi wɑz kɛɹfəli tʌkɪŋ ɪɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz koʊt wən mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ ʃoʊɾ ɪm aʊt. ʃi wəɾ ɛskɔɹɾ ɪm tə hɪz hɔɹs pɝsənəli. ə mɛsənʒɝ fɹəm noʊbəlz əz paʊɝfəl əz lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz hæd tə bi ɡɪvən ə sɝɾən lɛvəl ʌv ɑnɝ.

He colored once more, this time plainly in anger, but wisely confined himself to offering thanks as he folded the page. He was carefully tucking it inside his coat when Mistress Harfor showed him out. She would escort him to his horse personally. A messenger from nobles as powerful as Luan and the others had to be given a certain level of honor.

sʌɾənli ɪleɪnz æŋɡɝ tɝn tə sædnəs. ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛd wʌt ʃi wɑz sæɾ oʊvɝ. hɝ mudz ɔfən sim tə tʃeɪnʒ wɪθaʊt kɑz. pɝhæps fəɹ ɔl ðoʊz u hæd daɪɾ ən ɔl ðoʊz u wʊd. "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən jə doʊnt wɑnə bi kwin, daɪɛlɪn? lwɑn ən ðət lɑt wəd stæn fəɹ jə ɪn ə hɑɹtbit, ən ɪf aɪ stæn fəɹ ju, ðoʊz huv stʊd fəɹ mi wɪl stænd wɪð mi. bɝn mi, deɪnin wəd pɹɑbli stæn fəɹ ju."

Suddenly Elayne's anger turned to sadness. She could not have said what she was sad over. Her moods often seemed to change without cause. Perhaps for all those who had died and all those who would. "Are you certain you don't want to be queen, Dyelin? Luan and that lot would stand for you in a heartbeat, and if I stand for you, those who've stood for me will stand with me. Burn me, Danine would probably stand for you."

daɪɛlɪn tʊk ə tʃɛɹ, spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ blu skɝts kɛɹfəli, bɪfɔɹ ænsɝɪŋ. "aɪm æbsəlutli sɝɾən. ɹʌnɪŋ maɪ oʊn haʊs ɪz wɝk ɪnʌf fəɹ mi wɪθaʊɾ æɾɪŋ ɔl ʌv ændɝ tə ɪt. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ dɪsəpɹuv ə ðə θɹoʊn tʃeɪnʒɪŋ haʊsəz wɪθaʊt ɡʊd kɑz - ðə læk ʌv ə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, əɹ wɝs, wʌn huz ə ful əɹ ɪnkɑmpəɾənt, kɹuəl əɹ ɡɹiɾi. jəɹ nʌn ə ðoʊz θɪŋz. kɑntənuəɾi pɹəvaɪdz stəbɪlɪɾi, ən stəbɪlɪɾi bɹɪŋz pɹɑspɛɹəɾi." ʃi nɑɾəd; ʃi laɪk ðət tɝn ə fɹeɪz. "maɪnd, hæd jə daɪd bɪfɔɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn ən meɪkɪŋ jəɹ kleɪm, aɪ wʊɾə ɛntɝd maɪ oʊn, bʌt ðə sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ ɪz, jəl meɪk ə bɛɾɝ ɹulɝ ðən aɪ wʊd. bɛɾɝ fəɹ ændɝ. ɪn pɑɹt ðæts kəz ə jəɹ kənɛkʃən tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn." daɪɛlɪnz ɹeɪzd aɪbɹaʊ ɪnvaɪɾəd ɪleɪn tə ɪkspaʊn ɑn ðət kənɛkʃən. "bʌɾ ɪn lɑɹdʒ pɑɹt," ʃi wɛn ɑn wən ɪleɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ, "ɪts jə jɝsɛlf. aɪ wɑtʃt jə ɡɹoʊ ʌp, ən baɪ ðə taɪm jə wɝ fɪftin aɪ nu jud bi ə ɡʊd kwin, pɝhæps əz ɡʊɾ əz ændɝ əz ɛvɝ hæd."

Dyelin took a chair, spreading her blue skirts carefully, before answering. "I'm absolutely certain. Running my own House is work enough for me without adding all of Andor to it. Besides, I disapprove of the throne changing Houses without good cause - the lack of a Daughter-Heir, or worse, one who's a fool or incompetent, cruel or greedy. You're none of those things. Continuity provides stability, and stability brings prosperity." She nodded; she liked that turn of phrase. "Mind, had you died before returning to Caemlyn and making your claim, I would have entered my own, but the simple truth is, you'll make a better ruler than I would. Better for Andor. In part that's because of your connection to the Dragon Reborn." Dyelin's raised eyebrow invited Elayne to expound on that connection. "But in large part," she went on when Elayne said nothing, "it's you yourself. I watched you grow up, and by the time you were fifteen I knew you'd be a good queen, perhaps as good as Andor has ever had."

ɪleɪnz feɪs ɡɹu hɑt, ən tɪɹz wɛld ɪn əɹ aɪz. bɝn əɹ baʊnsɪŋ mudz! oʊnli ʃi nu ʃi kəd nɑt bleɪm əɹ pɹɛɡnənsi ðɪs taɪm. pɹeɪz fɹəm daɪɛlɪn wɑz laɪk pɹeɪz fɹəm əɹ mʌðɝ, nɛvɝ ɡɹʌdʒɪŋ, bʌt nɛvɝ ɡɪvən ənlɛs ʃi fɛlt ɪt wɑz dɪzɝvd.

Elayne's face grew hot, and tears welled in her eyes. Burn her bouncing moods! Only she knew she could not blame her pregnancy this time. Praise from Dyelin was like praise from her mother, never grudging, but never given unless she felt it was deserved.

hɝ mɔɹnɪŋ wɑz bɪzi, ən ʃi hæɾ oʊnli keɪɛmlɪn ən ðə pæləs tə dil wɪð ɹæðɝ ðən ɔl ʌv ændɝ. mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ ɹipɔɹɾəd ðət ðə spaɪz ɪn ðə pæləs u kəd bi kənfɝmd əz ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɛɹəmɪlə əɹ əɹ ælaɪz hæd ɡɹoʊn vɛɹi kwaɪəɾ ən stɪl, laɪk maɪs ðət fɪɹɾ ə kæt maɪt bi wɑtʃɪŋ.

Her morning was busy, and she had only Caemlyn and the palace to deal with rather than all of Andor. Mistress Harfor reported that the spies in the palace who could be confirmed as reporting to Arymilla or her allies had grown very quiet and still, like mice that feared a cat might be watching.

"æt list ɪts seɪf tə dɪsmɪs əm naʊ, maɪ leɪɾi," ɹɪn sɛɾ ɪn toʊnz ʌv ɡɹeɪt sæɾəsfækʃən. ʃi dɪslaɪk hævɪŋ spaɪz ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs əz mʌtʃ əz ɪleɪn dɪd, pɝhæps mɔɹ. dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ əɹ kwin maɪt lɪv ɪn ðə pæləs, bʌɾ ɪn ðə fɝs meɪdz aɪz, ɪt bɪlɔŋ tə hɝ. "ɔl ə ðɛm." spaɪz fəɹ ʌðɝz hæd bɪn lɛft ɪn pleɪs soʊ ðət noʊ wʌn wəd səspɛk ðət ɹɪn nu.

"At least it's safe to dismiss them now, my Lady," Reene said in tones of great satisfaction. She disliked having spies in the Royal Palace as much as Elayne did, perhaps more. Daughter-Heir or Queen might live in the palace, but in the First Maid's eyes, it belonged to her. "All of them." Spies for others had been left in place so that no one would suspect that Reene knew.

"kip əm ɔl ɑn ən kəntɪnju tə wɑtʃ ðɛm," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ. "ðeɪɹ ðə moʊs laɪkli tə teɪk kɔɪn fɹəm sʌmwʌn ɛls, ən wi noʊ hu ðeɪ ɑɹ." ə spaɪ hu wɑz noʊn kəd bi kɛp fɹəm lɝnɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt, ən jə kəd meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ lɝn ɪɡzækli wʌt jə wɑntəɾ əm tə. ðət wɛn fəɹ ði ədʒɑ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ hæɾ ənkʌvɝd, tu. ði ədʒəz hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə spaɪ ɑn hɝ, ən ɪf ʃi əkeɪʒənəli spun-fɛɾ əm fɔls ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, ɪt wəd bi ðɛɹ oʊn fɔlt ɪf ðeɪ æktəɾ ɑn ɪt. ʃi kəd nɑt də ðət tu ɔfən əɹ ðeɪ wəd ɹilaɪz ʃi hæɾ ənkʌvɝd ðɛɹ spaɪz, bʌt ʃi kəɾ ət nid.

"Keep them all on and continue to watch them," Elayne told her. "They're the most likely to take coin from someone else, and we know who they are." A spy who was known could be kept from learning anything they should not, and you could make sure they learned exactly what you wanted them to. That went for the Ajah eyes-and-ears Mistress Harfor had uncovered, too. The Ajahs had no right to spy on her, and if she occasionally spoon-fed them false information, it would be their own fault if they acted on it. She could not do that too often or they would realize she had uncovered their spies, but she could at need.

"æz jə seɪ, maɪ leɪɾi. ðə wɝld əz tʃeɪnʒd, hæzən ɪt?"

"As you say, my Lady. The world has changed, hasn't it?"

"aɪm əfɹeɪɾ ɪt hæz, mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ."

"I'm afraid it has, Mistress Harfor."

ðə ɹaʊnd wʊmən nɑɾəd sædli, bʌt ʃi kwɪkli ɹɪtɝn tə bɪznəs. "wʌn ə ðə wɪndoʊz ɪn ðə ɡɹæn hɔl əz dɪvɛləpt ə lik, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪɾ əv sin tə ɛniθɪŋ maɪnɝ wɪθaʊt bɑðɝɪŋ ju, bʌt ðɪs ɪz ə kɹæk ɪn ðə ɡlæs, wɪtʃ minz kɔlɪŋ ɪn. . . ." ðə lɪst ə pɹɑbləmz ðət niɾəd ɪleɪnz əpɹuvəl ən peɪpɝz ðət niɾəd əɹ sɪɡnətʃɝ wɛn ɑn.

The round woman nodded sadly, but she quickly returned to business. "One of the windows in the Grand Hall has developed a leak, my Lady. I'd have seen to anything minor without bothering you, but this is a crack in the glass, which means calling in. . . ." The list of problems that needed Elayne's approval and papers that needed her signature went on.

mæstɝ nɔɹi ɹipɔɹɾəd ɑn wæɡoʊnloʊdz ʌv ɡɹeɪn ən binz ən tʃɹeɪd ɡʊdz ɪn ðət dʌsti vɔɪs ə hɪz, ən ənaʊnst wɪð səm sɝpɹaɪz ðət ðə nʌmbɝ ʌv ɑɹsənz hæd nɑt dɪkɹist. sɛvəntin bɪldɪŋz hæd bɝn ɪn ðə naɪt. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ðə kæptʃɝ ʌv ɛɹəmɪlə wəd si ən ɛn tə ðæt, ən i wɑz ɹufəl oʊvɝ biɪŋ ɹɔŋ. hi bɹɔt dɛθ wɔɹəns ɪn ðə neɪmz ə ɹaɪz ɑbɑlɑmən ən ældɝd ɡoʊmsən fəɹ əɹ tə saɪn ən sil. mɝsənɛɹiz u tɝn ðɛɹ kʌlɝz kəɾ ɪkspɛk noʊ mɔɹ ənlɛs ðɛɹ nu mæstɝz pɹɪveɪld. ɪvɹd kɔɹdwɪn hæd daɪɾ ət ðə ɡeɪɾ əɹ i wʊɾə ɡɔn tə ðə ɡæloʊz, tu. hɑfin bɑkəvʌn hæd sɛn ə pətɪʃən æskɪŋ ə ɹɪwɔɹd fəɹ ɪz ækʃənz ət ðə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡeɪt, jɛt ðət wɑz izi ɪnʌf tə ɹɪdʒɛkt. ðə pɹɛzəns ə ðə dəmɑni mɝsənɛɹi ən ɪz mɛn maɪt wɛl əv bɪn ðə dɪfɝəns ɪn ðə ɡeɪt hoʊldɪŋ əntɪl daɪɛlɪn ɝaɪvd, bʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɝnɪŋ ðɛɹ peɪ, noʊ mɔɹ.

Master Norry reported on wagonloads of grain and beans and trade goods in that dusty voice of his, and announced with some surprise that the number of arsons had not decreased. Seventeen buildings had burned in the night. He had been sure the capture of Arymilla would see an end to that, and he was rueful over being wrong. He brought death warrants in the names of Rhys a'Balaman and Aldred Gomaisen for her to sign and seal. Mercenaries who turned their colors could expect no more unless their new masters prevailed. Evard Cordwyn had died at the gate or he would have gone to the gallows, too. Hafeen Bakuvun had sent a petition asking a reward for his actions at the Far Madding Gate, yet that was easy enough to reject. The presence of the Domani mercenary and his men might well have been the difference in the gate holding until Dyelin arrived, but they had been earning their pay, no more.

"ðə pɹɪznɝz ɑɹ stɪl biɪŋ kloʊsəməðd, aɪ fɪɹ," nɔɹi sɛd, slaɪɾɪŋ ðə ɹəfjuz pətɪʃən bæk ɪndə hɪz lɛðɝ foʊldɝ. hi sim tə fil ðəɾ ɪf i dɪd ðət kwɪkli ɪnʌf ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm əz nɛvɝ hævɪŋ ɹimuvd ɪt. "ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪ min, maɪ leɪɾi. ən ði ʌðɝ tu. vɛɹi kloʊsəməðd ɪksɛp fəɹ . . . ʌm . . . ɪnvɛktɪv. mɛlɝ ɪz ðə wɝst wɪð ðæt, ʃaʊɾɪŋ əbaʊt wʌɾ i ɪntɛnz tə də tə ðə wɪmən u ɝɛstəd hɪm," dɪni hæd teɪkən əɹ ɪnstʌkʃənz lɪɾɝəli; ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən hæd pʌməl mɛlɝ səvɪɹli, livɪŋ ɪm ə mæs ə bɹuzəz fɹəm hɛd tə fʊt, "bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kən bi kwaɪt . . . ʌm . . . vitupɝəɾɪv, əz wɛl. aɪ fɪɹ ɪt meɪ bi nɛsəsɛɹi tə pʊɾ əm tə ðə kwɛstʃən ɪf wi hoʊp tə lɝn ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl."

"The prisoners are still being closemouthed, I fear," Norry said, sliding the refused petition back into his leather folder. He seemed to feel that if he did that quickly enough it was the same as never having removed it. "The Darkfriend Aes Sedai, I mean, my Lady. And the other two. Very closemouthed except for . . . um . . . invective. Mellar is the worst with that, shouting about what he intends to do to the women who arrested him," Deni had taken her instuctions literally; the Guardswomen had pummeled Mellar severely, leaving him a mass of bruises from head to foot, "but the Aes Sedai can be quite . . . um . . . vituperative, as well. I fear it may be necessary to put them to the question if we hope to learn anything useful."

"doʊn kɔl əm ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi snæpt. hɪɹɪŋ "ɛɛs sədaɪ" lɪŋkt wɪð "dɑɹkfɹɛnd" meɪɾ əɹ stʌmək ɹɪð. "ðoʊz wɪmən əv ɡɪvən ʌp ɛni ɹaɪt tə bi kɔld ɛɛs sədaɪ." ʃi hæd teɪkən ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋz hɝsɛlf ən hæɾ əm mɛltəd daʊn. ðət wɑz ɛɡwinz pɹɪɹɑɡəɾɪv, nɑt hɝz, ən ʃi maɪt wɛl bi ɹɛpɹəmændɪd fəɹ ɪt, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt ɹistʃɹeɪn hɝsɛlf. "æsk ðə leɪɾi sɪlveɪs fəɹ ðə jus ə hɝ sɛkɹətɛɹi." ʃi hæd noʊ kwɛstʃənɝz əmʌŋ əɹ pipəl, ən əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə eɪvinhə, ən ənskɪl kwɛstʃənɝ wɑz laɪkli tə kɪl ðə wʌn biɪŋ pʊɾ ʌnsəksɛsfəli tə ðə kwɛstʃən. wən wɑz əɹ sɪstɝ gɑnə bi əlaʊd tə vɪzət? laɪt, ʃi mɪst eɪvinhə. "aɪ səspɛk hiz noʊ sətʃ θɪŋ." laɪtnɪŋ lɪɾ ʌp ðə wɪndoʊz ə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ðə ɡlæs keɪsməns ɹætlɪŋ wɪð ðə bum ʌv ɪts θʌndɝ.

"Don't call them Aes Sedai," she snapped. Hearing "Aes Sedai" linked with "Darkfriend" made her stomach writhe. "Those women have given up any right to be called Aes Sedai." She had taken their Great Serpent rings herself and had them melted down. That was Egwene's prerogative, not hers, and she might well be reprimanded for it, but she could not restrain herself. "Ask the Lady Sylvase for the use of her secretary." She had no questioners among her people, and according to Aviendha, an unskilled questioner was likely to kill the one being put unsuccessfully to the question. When was her sister going to be allowed to visit? Light, she missed Aviendha. "I suspect he's no such thing." Lightning lit up the windows of the sitting room, the glassed casements rattling with the boom of its thunder.

nɔɹi pɹɛst ɪz fɪŋɡɝtɪps təɡɛðɝ, hoʊldɪŋ ðə foʊldɝ əɡɛnst ɪz ɪŋk-steɪn tɑbɝd wɪð ðə hilz ə hɪz hænz ən fɹaʊnɪŋ ɡɹeɪvli. "fju pipəl kip ə pɹaɪvət kwɛstʃənɝ, maɪ leɪɾi. ɪt sədʒɛsts . . . ʌm . . . ə dɑɹk saɪd. bʌt ðɛn, əz aɪ ʌndɝstæn mæɾɝz, hɝ ɡɹændfɑðɝ tʃeɪst əweɪ ɛvɹi mæn u ʃoʊɾ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn əɹ əntɪl mɛn stɑpt ʃoʊɪŋ ɪntʃɹəst, ən ʃiz bɪn vɝtʃuəli ə pɹɪznɝ sɪns ɹitʃɪŋ əɹ mədʒɔɹəɾi. ðət wəd tɛn tə ɡɪv ɛniwʌn ə dɑɹk vju ʌv ðə wɝld. ʃi meɪ nɑt . . . ʌm . . . bi əz tʃɹʌstwɝði əz jə kəd wɪʃ, maɪ leɪɾi."

Norry pressed his fingertips together, holding the folder against his ink-stained tabard with the heels of his hands and frowning gravely. "Few people keep a private questioner, my Lady. It suggests . . . um . . . a dark side. But then, as I understand matters, her grandfather chased away every man who showed interest in her until men stopped showing interest, and she has been virtually a prisoner since reaching her majority. That would tend to give anyone a dark view of the world. She may not . . . um . . . be as trustworthy as you could wish, my Lady."

"du jə θɪŋk jə kən bɹaɪb səm ə hɝ sɝvəns tə bi maɪ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz?" haʊ izi ɪt wɑz tə æsk ðæt. spaɪz hæd bɪkʌm ə pɑɹɾ ə hɝ laɪf, əz mʌtʃ əz meɪsənz əɹ ɡleɪzɝz.

"Do you think you can bribe some of her servants to be my eyes-and-ears?" How easy it was to ask that. Spies had become a part of her life, as much as masons or glaziers.

"ðæt ʃəd bi pɑsəbəl, maɪ leɪɾi. əl noʊ fəɹ sɝɾən ɪn ə deɪ əɹ tu." wʌns, hi wʊɾə bɪn hɔɹəfaɪd baɪ ðə vɛɹi aɪdiə ʌv hævɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð spaɪɪŋ. ɔl θɪŋz tʃeɪnʒd ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ɪt simd. hɪz hænz ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ðə foʊldɝ, ɔlmoʊs bʌt nɑt kwaɪɾ oʊpənɪŋ ɪt. "aɪ fɪɹ ðə suɝz ɪn ðə sʌðɝn pɑɹɾ ə ðə nu sɪɾi niɾ ətɛnʃən ɝdʒənli."

"That should be possible, my Lady. I will know for certain in a day or two." Once, he would have been horrified by the very idea of having anything to do with spying. All things changed eventually, it seemed. His hands shifted on the folder, almost but not quite opening it. "I fear the sewers in the southern part of the New City need attention urgently."

ɪleɪn saɪd. nɑɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd. bɝn hɝ, wʌns ʃi dɪɾ əv ɔl ʌv ændɝ, ʃi səspɛktəd ʃi wəd sɛldəm əv ən aʊɝ tə hɝsɛlf. wʌd lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz wɑnt?

Elayne sighed. Not everything changed. Burn her, once she did have all of Andor, she suspected she would seldom have an hour to herself. What did Luan and the others want?

nɑt lɔŋ æftɝ mɪdmɔɹnɪŋ, mɛlfən dɔlɪʃ əpɪɹɾ ən hæɾ ɛsæn ən nɛɹɪs stʃɹɪp ɪleɪn tə ðə skɪn soʊ ʃi kəd bi weɪɾ ɪn ə hjudʒ, wʊɾən-ɑɹmd bæləns skeɪl ðə mɪdwaɪf hæd bɹɔɾ əlɔŋ, ə deɪli ɹɪtʃuəl. ðə bɹæs pæn wɑz pæɾəd wɪð ə blæŋkət, θæŋk ðə laɪt! ðə staʊt lɪɾəl wʊmən lɪsən tə hɝ hɑɹt ðoʊ ə hɑloʊ wʊɾən tub pɹɛs tə hɝ tʃɛst ən bæk, θʌm bæk əɹ aɪlɪdz tə ɪɡzæmɪn əɹ aɪz, ən smɛld əɹ bɹɛθ. ʃi hæɾ ɪleɪn meɪk wɔɾɝ, ðən hɛl ðə ɡlæs dʒɑɹ ʌp tə ðə laɪɾ ʌv ə stænd-læmp tə stʌɾi ɪt. ʃi smɛl ðæt, tu, ən ivən dɪpt ə fɪŋɡɝ ɪn ən lɪkt ɪt! ɪt wɑz ənʌðɝ deɪli ɹɪtʃuəl. ɪleɪn əvɝɾəd əɹ aɪz, pʊlɪŋ əɹ flaʊɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd sɪlk ɹoʊb taɪɾ ɝaʊn hɝ, bʌt ʃi stɪl ʃʌɾɝəd. ðɪs taɪm, mɛlfən noʊɾəst.

Not long after midmorning, Melfane Dawlish appeared and had Essande and Neris strip Elayne to the skin so she could be weighed in a huge, wooden-armed balance scale the midwife had brought along, a daily ritual. The brass pan was padded with a blanket, thank the Light! The stout little woman listened to her heart though a hollow wooden tube pressed to her chest and back, thumbed back her eyelids to examine her eyes, and smelled her breath. She had Elayne make water, then held the glass jar up to the light of a stand-lamp to study it. She smelled that, too, and even dipped a finger in and licked it! It was another daily ritual. Elayne averted her eyes, pulling her flower-embroidered silk robe tight around her, but she still shuddered. This time, Melfane noticed.

"aɪ kən tɛl səm sɪknəs fɹəm tʃeɪnʒəz ɪn ðə teɪst, maɪ leɪɾi. ɛniweɪ, ðɛɹz wɝs θɪŋz. maɪ bɔɪ jeɪɛm, ðə wʌn u kæɹid ðə skeɪl fəɹ mi, hɪz fɝs peɪd dʒɑb ʌv wɝk wɑz mʌkɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ə steɪbəl. hi kleɪmd ɛvɹiθɪŋ i eɪt teɪstəd laɪk - " hɝ ɹaʊn bɛli ʃʊk wɪð læftɝ. "wɛl, jə kən ɪmædʒən, maɪ leɪɾi." ɪleɪn kʊd, ən wɑz ɡlæd ʃi wɑz nɑt pɹoʊn tə nɔziə. ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd əɡɛn ɛniweɪ. ɛsæn sim kwaɪt kəmpoʊzd, hænz foʊldəɾ əɾ əɹ weɪst ən wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ nis wɪð əpɹuvəl, bʌt nɛɹɪs lʊkt əbaʊt tə sɪk ʌp. "pɪɾi hi kæn lɝn maɪ kɹæft, bʌt noʊ wʌn wəd baɪ ɝbz fɹəm ə mæn. əɹ əv ə mæn mɪdwaɪf." mɛlfən læft əpɹɔɑɹiəsli ət ðət ɹɪdɪkjələs noʊʃən. "wɑns tə bi əpɹɛntəs tə ən ɑɹmɔɹɝ, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz. oʊl fəɹ ɪt, bʌt ðəɹ ɪɾ ɪz. naʊ, jə bi ʃʊɹ tə ɹid tə jəɹ beɪb." ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ðən daʊtfəl ʌv ɪleɪnz kleɪm ðət ʃi wəɾ əv ə bɔɪ ən ə ɡɝl. ʃi wəd nɑɾ æksɛpt ɪɾ əntɪl ʃi kəd hɪɹ ðɛɹ hɑɹtbits, ən ðət wəd bi səm fju wiks jɛt. "æn əv mjuzɪʃənz pleɪ fəɹ hɝ. ʃɪl lɝn ðə saʊn ə jəɹ vɔɪs. lɝn tə laɪk ɹɛɾɪŋ ən mjuzɪk, tu. ɪt hɛlps ɪn ʌðɝ weɪz bɪsaɪdz. meɪks ðə tʃaɪl bɹaɪɾɝ."

"I can tell some sickness from changes in the taste, my Lady. Anyway, there's worse things. My boy Jaem, the one who carried the scale for me, his first paid job of work was mucking out in a stable. He claimed everything he ate tasted like - " Her round belly shook with laughter. "Well, you can imagine, my Lady." Elayne could, and was glad she was not prone to nausea. She shuddered again anyway. Essande seemed quite composed, hands folded at her waist and watching her niece with approval, but Neris looked about to sick up. "Pity he can't learn my craft, but no one would buy herbs from a man. Or have a man midwife." Melfane laughed uproariously at that ridiculous notion. "Wants to be apprenticed to an armorer, of all things. Old for it, but there it is. Now, you be sure to read to your babe." She was more than doubtful of Elayne's claim that she would have a boy and a girl. She would not accept it until she could hear their heartbeats, and that would be some few weeks yet. "And have musicians play for her. She'll learn the sound of your voice. Learn to like reading and music, too. It helps in other ways besides. Makes the child brighter."

"ju seɪ ðəɾ ɛvɹi taɪm, mɪstʃɹəs dɔlɪʃ," ɪleɪn sɛd pivɪʃli. "aɪ kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ, jə noʊ. ən aɪm duɪŋ ɪt."

"You say that every time, Mistress Dawlish," Elayne said peevishly. "I can remember, you know. And I am doing it."

mɛlfən læft əɡɛn, ə twɪŋkəl ɪn əɹ dɑɹk aɪz. ʃi æksɛptɪɾ ɪleɪnz baʊnsɪŋ mudz ðə weɪ ʃi æksɛptɪd ɹeɪn ən laɪtnɪŋ. "jud bi sɝpɹaɪz haʊ mɛni doʊn bɪliv ə beɪb ɪn ðə wum kən hɪɹ, bʌɾ aɪ kən si ðə dɪfɝəns ɪn ðoʊz u ɡɛt ɹɛd tə ən ðoʊz u doʊnt. dʒju maɪn ɪf aɪ hæv ə fju wɝdz wɪð maɪ æn bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɡoʊ, maɪ leɪɾi? aɪ bɹɔɾ əɹ ə paɪ ən ən ɔɪnmənt fəɹ əɹ dʒɔɪns." ɛsænz feɪs ɹɛɾənd. wɛl, naʊ ðəɾ əɹ laɪ wɑz ɪkspoʊzd, ʃi wəɾ æksɛp hilɪŋ əɹ ɪleɪn wəd noʊ ðə ɹizən waɪ.

Melfane laughed again, a twinkle in her dark eyes. She accepted Elayne's bouncing moods the way she accepted rain and lightning. "You'd be surprised how many don't believe a babe in the womb can hear, but I can see the difference in those who get read to and those who don't. Do you mind if I have a few words with my aunt before I go, my Lady? I brought her a pie and an ointment for her joints." Essande's face reddened. Well, now that her lie was exposed, she would accept Healing or Elayne would know the reason why.

ət ði ɛn ə ðə mɪddeɪ mil, ɪleɪn bɹɔɾ ʌp ði ɪntɛntʃənz ə lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz wɪð bɝdʒɪt. ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝfəl mil, ən ʃi eɪt ɹeɪvənəsli. mɛlfən hæd læmbæstɪd ðə kʊks ən ɛvɹi ʌðɝ wʊmən ɪn ɪɹʃɑt fəɹ ðə blæn daɪət ðeɪ hæd bɪn fiɾɪŋ hɝ. tədeɪ ðəɹ wɝ smɔl pɑn tʃɹaʊt ɡɹɪl tə pɝfɛkʃən, kæbədʒ ɹoʊlz stʌft wɪð kɹʌmbli waɪɾ uz mɪlk tʃiz, bɹɔd binz wɪð pɪnɛnʌts, ən ə tæŋi æpəl tɑɹt. ənʌðɝ ɹizən ɪt wɑz mɑɹvələs wɑz ðət nʌθɪŋ hæd ðə feɪntəs hɪn ə spɔɪlɪŋ. tə dʒɹɪŋk, ðəɹ wɑz ɡʊd blæk ti wɪð mɪn ðət meɪɾ əɹ tɛns fəɹ ə moʊmən əntɪl ʃi ɹilaɪzd ɪt ɹɪli wɑz mɪnt. ði oʊnli θɪŋ mɛlfən hæd fɔɹbɪɾən wɑz waɪn, haʊɛvɝ wɛl wɔɾɝd. bɝdʒɪt hæɾ ivən ɡɪvən ʌp dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ðoʊ ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ɪt kəɾ əv ɛni ɪfɛk θɹu ðə bɑnd. ɪleɪn ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm pɔɪntɪŋ ðəɾ aʊt. bɝdʒɪt hæd bɪn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ tu mʌtʃ tə dʌl ðə peɪn ə luzɪŋ əɹ ɡeɪɾəl. ɪleɪn ʌndɝstʊɾ ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əpɹuv. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən wʌt ʃi wəd də ɪf ɹænd daɪd.

At the end of the midday meal, Elayne brought up the intentions of Luan and the others with Birgitte. It was a wonderful meal, and she ate ravenously. Melfane had lambasted the cooks and every other woman in earshot for the bland diet they had been feeding her. Today there were small pond trout grilled to perfection, cabbage rolls stuffed with crumbly white ewe's milk cheese, broad beans with pinenuts, and a tangy apple tart. Another reason it was marvelous was that nothing had the faintest hint of spoiling. To drink, there was good black tea with mint that made her tense for a moment until she realized it really was mint. The only thing Melfane had forbidden was wine, however well watered. Birgitte had even given up drinking herself, though it seemed impossible it could have any effect through the bond. Elayne refrained from pointing that out. Birgitte had been drinking too much to dull the pain of losing her Gaidal. Elayne understood even if she did not approve. She could not imagine what she would do if Rand died.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," bɝdʒɪt sɛɾ æftɝ wʊlfɪŋ daʊn ðə læst ə hɝ tɑɹt. "maɪ bɛst ɡɛs ɪz ðeɪv kʌm tə æsk jə tə hɛlp əm muv əɡɛns ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz. ðə wʌn blʌɾi θɪŋ ðæts ʃʊɹ ɪz ðət ðeɪ dɪdn blʌɾi kʌm tə θɹoʊ ðɛɹ səpɔɹt tə ju."

"I don't know," Birgitte said after wolfing down the last of her tart. "My best guess is they've come to ask you to help them move against the Borderlanders. The one bloody thing that's sure is that they didn't bloody come to throw their support to you."

"ðæts maɪ bɛst ɡɛs, tu." ɪleɪn pɪkt ʌp kɹʌmz ə tʃiz wɪð ə dæmp fɪŋɡɝɾɪp ən pɑpt əm ɪndə hɝ maʊθ. ʃi cʊɾə iɾən əz mʌtʃ əɡɛn əz hæd bɪn ɑn əɹ pleɪt, bʌt mɛlfən hæɾ ənaʊnst əɹ stʃɹɪkt ɪntɛntʃən tə lɪməɾ əɹ weɪt ɡeɪn. dʒʌst ɪnʌf ən nɑt tu mʌtʃ. pɝhæps ə kaʊ biɪŋ fæɾənd fəɹ mɑɹkət fɛlt laɪk ðɪs. "ənlɛs ðəɹ gɑnə dɪmæn aɪ sɝɛndɝ keɪɛmlɪn."

"That's my best guess, too." Elayne picked up crumbs of cheese with a damp fingertip and popped them into her mouth. She could have eaten as much again as had been on her plate, but Melfane had announced her strict intention to limit her weight gain. Just enough and not too much. Perhaps a cow being fattened for market felt like this. "Unless they're going to demand I surrender Caemlyn."

"ðɛɹz ɔlweɪz ðæt," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɔlmoʊs tʃɪɹfəl. ðə bɑn sɛd ʃi wɑz ɛniθɪŋ bʌt. "wi stɪl əv wɑtʃɝz ɪn ðə taʊɝz, ðoʊ, ən dʒulənjə ən kɛɹeɪl əv ɡɑɾən wɝk əz lɔnʒɹəsəz ɪn ðɛɹ kæmp, soʊ wɪl noʊ ɪf ðeɪ bɪɡɪn tə muv əɡɛns ðə sɪɾi bɪfɔɹ ðə fɝs mæn sɛts aʊt."

"There's always that," Birgitte said, sounding almost cheerful. The bond said she was anything but. "We still have watchers in the towers, though, and Julanya and Keraille have gotten work as laundresses in their camp, so we'll know if they begin to move against the city before the first man sets out."

ɪleɪn wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑt saɪ soʊ ɔfən. bɝn hɝ, ʃi hæɾ ɛɹəmɪlə, nɑiən ən ɛləniə ʌndɝ ɡɑɹɾ ən dɛfənətli nɑɾ ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ʃɛɹɪŋ ə bɛd - ʃi nu ðə θɔt ʃəd nɑt ɡɪv əɹ plɛʒɝ bʌɾ ɪt dɪd - ən ʃi hæd ɡeɪn θɹi mɔɹ ælaɪz, ɪf nɑt nɛsəsɛɹəli ðə moʊst sɑləd. ət lis ðeɪ wɝ taɪd tə hɝ ɪnɛkstʃɹɪkəbli, naʊ. ʃi ʃʊɾə bɪn filɪŋ tʃɹaɪʌmfənt.

Elayne wished she did not sigh so often. Burn her, she had Arymilla, Naean and Elenia under guard and definitely not enjoying sharing a bed - she knew the thought should not give her pleasure but it did - and she had gained three more allies, if not necessarily the most solid. At least they were tied to her inextricably, now. She should have been feeling triumphant.
