ðəɾ æftɝnun, ɛsæn ən sɛfæni dʒɹɛst əɹ ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹin slæʃt wɪð ɛmɹəld ɑn ðə skɝts ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð sɪlvɝ əkɹɔs ðə bʊzəm, daʊn ðə slivz ən ɝaʊn ðə hɛm. fəɹ dʒuəlɹi, ʃi wɔɹ əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ən ə lɑɹdʒ sɪlvɝ pɪn ɪnæməl blu ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə ʃeɪp ə tʃɹəkənz kistoʊn. ðə pɪn meɪɾ əɹ mɝoʊs. ɪnsaɪd ðə haʊs ɪt wɑz sɛd ðət tʃɹəkənd wɑz ðə kistoʊn ðət hɛld ændɝ təɡɛðɝ. ʃi hæd nɑt dʌn ə vɛɹi ɡʊd dʒɑb ʌv ɪt soʊ fɑɹ.

That afternoon, Essande and Sephanie dressed her in dark green slashed with emerald on the skirts and embroidered with silver across the bosom, down the sleeves and around the hem. For jewelry, she wore her Great Serpent ring and a large silver pin enameled blue except for the shape of Trakand's Keystone. The pin made her morose. Inside the House it was said that Trakand was the keystone that held Andor together. She had not done a very good job of it so far.

ʃi ən bɝdʒɪt tʊk tɝnz ɹiɾɪŋ əlaʊd tə hɝ beɪbz. fɹəm hɪstɝiz, ʌv kɔɹs; ɪf mɛlfən wɑz ɹaɪt, ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə dɝɛkt əm tə fɹɪvələs teɪlz. dʒɹaɪ stʌf, ɪt wɑz. ə plʌmp mæn ɪn ɹɛɾ ən waɪt pleɪd ðə flut waɪl ə lin wʊmən ɪn lɪvɝi pleɪd ðə twɛlv-stʃɹɪŋ bɪɾɝn, pɹədusɪŋ laɪvli, dʒɔɪəs tunz. ət list wən kɹæʃɪz ə θʌndɝ dɪd nɑt dʒɹaʊn əm aʊt. bɑɹdz dɪd nɑt ɡɹoʊ ɑn tʃɹiz, ən bɝdʒɪt hæd bɪn ənsɝɾən əbaʊɾ əlaʊɪŋ ɛniwʌn fɹəm aʊtsaɪd ðə pæləs nɪɹ ɪleɪn, bʌt mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ hæd faʊn ə nʌmbɝ ʌv əkɑmplɪʃt mjuzɪʃənz u hæd lɛpt ət ðə tʃæns tə pʊɾ ɑn lɪvɝi. ðɛɹ peɪ wɑz kənsɪɾɝəbli bɛɾɝ ɪn ðə pæləs ðən ɪn ə kɑmən ɹum, ən ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ wɑz pɹəvaɪɾəd wɪð ɪt. ɪleɪn θɔɾ ə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪɝ ə ɡlimən, bʌt ðət meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ə tɑm. wɑz i dʒɹaɪ? wɑz i ivən əlaɪv? ɔl ʃi kəd də wɑz pɹeɪ. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt soʊ. pliz.

She and Birgitte took turns reading aloud to her babes. From histories, of course; if Melfane was right, she did not want to direct them to frivolous tales. Dry stuff, it was. A plump man in red and white played the flute while a lean woman in livery played the twelve-string bittern, producing lively, joyous tunes. At least when crashes of thunder did not drown them out. Bards did not grow on trees, and Birgitte had been uncertain about allowing anyone from outside the palace near Elayne, but Mistress Harfor had found a number of accomplished musicians who had leapt at the chance to put on livery. Their pay was considerably better in the palace than in a common room, and their clothing was provided with it. Elayne thought of trying to hire a gleeman, but that made her think of Thom. Was he dry? Was he even alive? All she could do was pray. The Light send it so. Please.

mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ keɪm tə ənaʊns ði ɝaɪvəl ə lwɑn, ɑɝəθɛl ən ði ʌðɝz, ən ɪleɪn dɑn ðə kɔɹənɛɾ ə ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, ə sɪmpəl ɡoʊl bæn ðət hɛld ə sɪŋɡəl ɡoʊldən ɹoʊz sɝaʊndəd baɪ θɔɹnz əbʌv əɹ bɹaʊz. keɪsil, əlɔŋ wɪð eɪt ɡɑɹdzwɪmən, fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪn hɝ, bɝdʒɪɾ ən ɛsæn əz ðeɪ lɛft əɹ əpɑɹtməns, buts θəɾɪŋ laʊdli ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz ɪn stɛp. naɪn ɡɑɹdzwɪmən hæd bɪn əmʌŋ ðə dɛd wən ʃi wɑz ɹɛskjud fɹəm ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən ðət sim tə hæv bɑndəd ði ʌðɝz təɡɛðɝ ivən mɔɹ taɪtli. ðeɪ ɡɑt lɔs twaɪs faɪndɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ tə ðə ɡɹæn hɔl, bʌt noʊ wʌn soʊ mʌtʃ əz mɝmɝd. wʌt wɝ ʃɪftɪŋ kɔɹɪɾɝz wən jə hæd feɪs paʊɝ-ɹɔt faɪɝ ən laɪtnɪŋ? ðə ɡɹeɪɾ ɑɹtʃt dɔɹz ə ðə ɡɹæn hɔl, kɑɹvd wɪð tɔl laɪənz ɑn boʊθ saɪdz, stʊɾ oʊpən, ən keɪsil tʊk ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən tə stæn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm waɪl ʃi, bɝdʒɪɾ ən ɛsænd wɛn ɪn.

Mistress Harfor came to announce the arrival of Luan, Arathelle and the others, and Elayne donned the coronet of the Daughter-Heir, a simple gold band that held a single golden rose surrounded by thorns above her brows. Caseille, along with eight Guardswomen, fell in behind her, Birgitte and Essande as they left her apartments, boots thudding loudly on the floor tiles in step. Nine Guardswomen had been among the dead when she was rescued from the Darkfriends, and that seemed to have bonded the others together even more tightly. They got lost twice finding their way to the Grand Hall, but no one so much as murmured. What were shifting corridors when you had faced Power-wrought fire and lightning? The great arched doors of the Grand Hall, carved with tall lions on both sides, stood open, and Caseille took the Guardswomen to stand in front of them while she, Birgitte and Essande went in.

ðə tɔl wɪndoʊz ɪn ðə wɔlz wɝ dɑɹk wɪð ɹeɪn ɪksɛpt wən laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt, bʌt ðə mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps, əɡɛns ðə wɔlz ən ɝaʊn ðə waɪt kɑləmz ðət mɑɹtʃt ɪn ɹoʊz əlɔŋ ðə saɪdz ə ðə tʃeɪmbɝ, wɝ ɔl lɪt. ə laʊd, stɛɾi plʌŋk-plʌŋk-plʌŋk ɛkoʊɾ ɪn ðə væst speɪs, dʒɹɑps fɔlɪŋ ɪndə ə pɹoʊzeɪɪk wʊɾən bʌkət stændɪŋ bɪniθ wʌn ə ðə kʌlɝd wɪndoʊz sɛɾ ɪn ðə silɪŋ twɛnti peɪsɪz oʊvɝhɛd, wɛɹ wʌn ə ðə ɹɪɹɪŋ waɪt laɪənz hæd bidz ʌv wɔɾɝ ɡlɪsnɪŋ əlɔŋ ə kɹæk, nɪɹ sinz ə bæɾəl ən ðə feɪsəz ʌv ændɝz ɝliəs kwinz. əz ɔlweɪz ɪn ðɪs hɔl, ɪleɪn fɛl ðoʊz wɪmən dʒʌdʒɪŋ əɹ əz ʃi kɹɔs ðə ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt flɔɹ taɪlz. ðeɪ hæd bɪlt ændɝ wɪð ðə ʃɑɹpnəs ə ðɛɹ maɪnz ən ðə blʌɾ ə ðɛɹ sʌnz ən hʌzbənz, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl sɪɾi ən moʊldɪŋ ə stʃɹɔŋ neɪʃən aʊɾ ə ðə ɹʌbəl ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɛmpaɪɝ. ðeɪ hæɾ ə ɹaɪt tə dʒʌdʒ ɛni wʊmən u sæɾ ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. ʃi səspɛktəd ðɛɹ vɪsɪdʒɪz hæd bɪn pleɪs ðəɹ soʊ ɛvɹi kwin wəd fil əɹ ækʃənz dʒʌdʒ baɪ hɪstɝi.

The tall windows in the walls were dark with rain except when lightning flashed, but the mirrored stand-lamps, against the walls and around the white columns that marched in rows along the sides of the chamber, were all lit. A loud, steady plunk-plunk-plunk echoed in the vast space, drops falling into a prosaic wooden bucket standing beneath one of the colored windows set in the ceiling twenty paces overhead, where one of the rearing White Lions had beads of water glistening along a crack, near scenes of battle and the faces of Andor's earliest queens. As always in this hall, Elayne felt those women judging her as she crossed the red-and-white floor tiles. They had built Andor with the sharpness of their minds and the blood of their sons and husbands, beginning with a single city and molding a strong nation out of the rubble of Artur Hawkwing's empire. They had a right to judge any woman who sat on the Lion Throne. She suspected their visages had been placed there so every queen would feel her actions judged by history.

ðə θɹoʊn ɪtsɛlf sæɾ ətɑp ə waɪt mɑɹbəl deɪz ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə tʃeɪmbɝ, kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪɾ ən saɪz fəɹ ə wʊmən, jɛt mæsɪv ɑn ɪts laɪən-pɔd lɛɡz. ðə waɪt laɪən, fɔɹm fɹəm munstoʊnz sɛɾ ɪn ə fild ʌv ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɹubiz ɑn ɪts tɔl bæk, wəd stæn əbʌv ðə hɛɾ ə ðə tɔlɪst wʊmən u sæɾ ɑn ðət θɹoʊn. daɪɛlɪn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi stændɪŋ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə deɪzəz stɛps, wɑtʃɪŋ sɪlveɪs kɑnvɝs wɪð kɑneɪl ən kæɾəlɪn waɪl bɹænləɾ ən pɛɝaɪvəl lɪsən kloʊsli. pɛɝaɪvəl ɹeɪkt ɪz fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ ən nɑɾəd. dɪd daɪɛlɪn əv kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt sɪlveɪs, tu? lɝ ən kɑɝɪn stʊɾ əpɑɹt fɹəm ðə ɹɛst, ən əpɑɹt fɹəm itʃ ʌðɝ əz wɛl. niðɝ ivən ɡlænst ət ði ʌðɝ. hævɪŋ bɪn ælaɪz əɡɛnst ɪleɪn, ðeɪ wəd nɑt wɑn əɹ tə θɪŋk ðeɪ wɝ əlaɪd stɪl. ɛsænd wɛn tə dʒɔɪn ðə sɝvɪŋ mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn ðə lɪvɝiz ə ði eɪɾ ʌðɝ haʊsəz, ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ə teɪbəl ðət hɛl tɔl sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝz ʌv waɪn ən ti. ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɪnfɔɹməl mɛn ɪn ðɪs kɑntɛkst. itʃ ə ðɛm wəd bɹɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl sɝvən ɪn ətɛndəns. fəɹ ə fɔɹməl miɾɪŋ, ɪleɪn wʊɾə pɹəvaɪɾəd ɔl ə ðə sɝvəns, ən ðə ɡɹæn hɔl wʊɾə bɪn kɹaʊɾəd wɪð ɛvɹi noʊbəl ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ɛvɹi noʊbəl fɹəm ði ɛnkæmpmən bɪloʊ keɪɛmlɪn.

The throne itself sat atop a white marble dais at the far end of the chamber, carved and gilded and sized for a woman, yet massive on its lion-pawed legs. The White Lion, formed from moonstones set in a field of glittering rubies on its tall back, would stand above the head of the tallest woman who sat on that throne. Dyelin was already standing at the foot of the dais's steps, watching Sylvase converse with Conail and Catalyn while Branlet and Perival listened closely. Perival raked his fingers through his hair and nodded. Did Dyelin have questions about Sylvase, too? Lir and Karind stood apart from the rest, and apart from each other as well. Neither even glanced at the other. Having been allies against Elayne, they would not want her to think they were allied still. Essande went to join the serving men and women in the liveries of the eight other Houses, gathered around a table that held tall silver pitchers of wine and tea. That was what informal meant in this context. Each of them would bring a single servant in attendance. For a formal meeting, Elayne would have provided all of the servants, and the Grand Hall would have been crowded with every noble in Caemlyn, every noble from the encampment below Caemlyn.

"ɛlɹin meɪ wɛl bi pɹoʊvɑkəɾɪv, ɪleɪn," daɪɛlɪn sɛd fəɹ əbaʊt ðə fɪfθ taɪm sɪns hɪɹɪŋ ə ðə seɪf kʌndəkt ɹɪkwɛst. hɝ feɪs wɑz kul ən kɑm, jɛt ʃi mʌst əv bɪn filɪŋ əɹ nɝvz. hɝ hænz smuðd ənnɛsəsɛɹəli əɾ əɹ ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd skɝts.

"Ellorien may well be provocative, Elayne," Dyelin said for about the fifth time since hearing of the safe conduct request. Her face was cool and calm, yet she must have been feeling her nerves. Her hands smoothed unnecessarily at her gold-embroidered skirts.

"aɪ woʊn lɛɾ əɹ pɹəvoʊk mi," ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "niðɝ wɪl ɛniwʌn ɛls. aɪ min ju, kɑneɪl, ən ju, lɝ." kɑneɪl, ɪn ɡoʊld-wɝk blu, kʌlɝɾ əz kwɪkli əz hænsəl hæd. hi hæd ɡɑɾən ɪndə ə faɪt wɪð ə mɝsənɛɹi hi θɔt hæd spoʊkən dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli ʌv ɪleɪn ən ɔlmoʊs kɪl ðə mæn. ɪt wɑz wɛl fəɹ ɪm ði ʌðɝ mæn hæd bɪɡʌn dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd fɝst. ivən mɝsənɛɹiz dɪzɝv dʒʌstəs, ən ændɝ wɑz nɑt tɛɹ, wɛɹ noʊbəlz kəd kɪl kɑmənɝz wɪð ɪmpjunɪɾi. wɛl, bɪfɔɹ ɹænd tʃeɪnʒd soʊ mɛni ʌv ðɛɹ lɔz. bɝn hɪm, waɪ wɑz i lipɪŋ əbaʊt soʊ?

"I won't let her provoke me," Elayne replied. "Neither will anyone else. I mean you, Conail, and you, Lir." Conail, in gold-worked blue, colored as quickly as Hanselle had. He had gotten into a fight with a mercenary he thought had spoken disparagingly of Elayne and almost killed the man. It was well for him the other man had begun drawing his sword first. Even mercenaries deserved justice, and Andor was not Tear, where nobles could kill commoners with impunity. Well, before Rand changed so many of their laws. Burn him, why was he leaping about so?

"aɪ stʊd fəɹ ju, ɪleɪn, ən ðət minz aɪ ɔlweɪz stæn ʌp fəɹ ju," lɝ sɛd smuðli. hi lʊkt ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ðə sɛlf-kɑnfəɾənt kɔɹɾiɝ ɪn sɪlvɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɡɹin sɪlk wɪð haʊs bɛɹɪnz sɪlvɝ wɪŋ hæmɝ ɑn ðə kɑlɝ, jɛɾ i wɑz tu smuð baɪ hæf, lɝ wɑz. "bʌɾ əl hoʊl maɪ tɛmpɝ wʌtɛvɝ ɛlɹin sɛz." ðə bɑn sɝdʒd wɪð fliɾɪŋ kəntɛmpt. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɛmənstʃɹeɪt haʊ lɔɪəl i wɑz tə ɪleɪn, lɝ hæd fɔt wɪð mɝsənɛɹiz θɹi taɪmz. ɪn tu deɪz. ðə mæn hæd tə hæv bɪn sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ faɪts tə mænədʒ ðæt.

"I stood for you, Elayne, and that means I always stand up for you," Lir said smoothly. He looked every inch the self-confident courtier in silver-embroidered green silk with House Baryn's silver Winged Hammer on the collar, yet he was too smooth by half, Lir was. "But I'll hold my temper whatever Ellorien says." The bond surged with fleeting contempt. Trying to demonstrate how loyal he was to Elayne, Lir had fought with mercenaries three times. In two days. The man had to have been searching for fights to manage that.

"ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪz tə ɡoʊɾ ʌs, waɪ ʃəd wi baɪɾ əɹ tʌŋz?" kæɾəlɪn dɪmændəd. hɝ ɹɛd dʒɹɛs, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð bɹɔd bænz ʌv ɡoʊld ət ðə hɛm ən ɑn ðə slivz, dɪd nɑt suɾ əɹ kʌlɝɪŋ, ɪspɛʃli wən əɹ plʌmp tʃiks wɝ kɹɪmzən wɪð æŋɡɝ. hɝ tʃɪn wɑz ɹeɪzd. pɝhæps ʃi wɔɹ ðət lɑɹdʒ ɪnæməl pɪn bɛɹɪŋ hɛvɪnz blu bɛɹ wɛɹ ʃi dɪd soʊ ʃi wəd bi fɔɹs tə kip əɹ tʃɪn haɪ ən lʊk daʊn əɹ noʊz əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn. "aɪv nɛvɝ əlaʊɾ ɛniwʌn tə poʊk ət mi ən wɔk əweɪ ənskeɪðd."

"If she tries to goad us, why should we bite our tongues?" Catalyn demanded. Her red dress, embroidered with broad bands of gold at the hem and on the sleeves, did not suit her coloring, especially when her plump cheeks were crimson with anger. Her chin was raised. Perhaps she wore that large enameled pin bearing Haevin's Blue Bear where she did so she would be forced to keep her chin high and look down her nose at everyone. "I've never allowed anyone to poke at me and walk away unscathed."

"æn ɑks ɹɪspɑnz tə ðə ɡoʊɾ ən dʌz əz ði ɑks-hɝd wɑns," daɪɛlɪn sɛd dʒɹɪli. "ðə seɪm weɪ jəl bi duɪŋ wʌɾ ɛlɹin wɑns ɪf jə ɹɪspɑn tə hɝ ɡoʊdz." ðə kɹɪmzən ɹɪmeɪn ɪn kæɾəlɪnz tʃiks, noʊ daʊt fɹəm ɪmbɛɹəsmənt, naʊ.

"An ox responds to the goad and does as the ox-herd wants," Dyelin said drily. "The same way you will be doing what Ellorien wants if you respond to her goads." The crimson remained in Catalyn's cheeks, no doubt from embarrassment, now.

ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. "maɪ leɪɾiz," ʃi sɛd laʊdli, hɝ vɔɪs ɛkoʊɪŋ ɪn ðə nɪɹli ɛmpti tʃeɪmbɝ. "maɪ lɔɹdz."

Reene Harfor appeared in the doorway. "My Ladies," she said loudly, her voice echoing in the nearly empty chamber. "My Lords."

ðɪs wɑz ɪnfɝmælɪɾi, wən tu saɪdz mɛɾ ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ noʊɪŋ haʊ fɑɹ əpɑɹt ðeɪ wɝ. mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ ənaʊns ðə nuli ɝaɪv lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz ɪn stʃɹɪkt ɔɹɾɝ ə pɹɛsəɾəns, ðoʊ əmʌŋ ðə haʊsəz ɡæðɝd hɪɹ, ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil bɪtwin ðɛm. lwɑn nɔɹwlɪn, hɑɹd-feɪst ən mɔɹ ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd ðən wən ɪleɪn læst sɔ hɪm, hɪz blu koʊɾ ʌndɪkɝeɪɾɪd ɪksɛp fəɹ nɔɹwlɪnz sɪlvɝ sæmən ɑn ðə haɪ kɑlɝ. ɑɝəθɛl ɹɛnʃɝ, hɝ feɪs kɹist ən əɹ bɹaʊn hɛɹ θɪk wɪð ɡɹeɪ, ɪn ə ɹɛd ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ɔɹnətli wɝkt wɪð ɡoʊld ən ə lɑɹdʒ ɹubi-stʌɾɪd pɪn ðət dɪspleɪd ðə θɹi ɡoʊldən haʊnz. pɛlɪvɑɹ koʊələn, tɔl ən lin, hɪz dɑɹk hɛɹ ɹɪsiɾɪŋ tɪl i ɔlmoʊs lʊkt əz ɪf i hæd ʃeɪv ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd laɪk ə kɛɹhinɪn, ɪn sɪlvɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd blu wɪð twɪn ɹɛd ɹoʊzɪz wɝkt ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ, ðə ɹoʊzɪz ə koʊələn. æɛmlɪn kɑɝənd, plʌmp ɪn ɡɹeɪ sɪlk wɪð ðə θɹi ɡoʊldən æɹoʊz klaɪmɪŋ əɹ slivz ən soʊ θɪk ɑn əɹ bʊzəm ʃi lʊk laɪk ə bɹɪsəlɪŋ kwɪvɝ. ɛlɹin tʃɹæmən, nɑt soʊ plʌmp əz ɪleɪn ɹɪkɔl bʌt stɪl pɹɪɾi ɪn ɡɹin-slæʃt blu ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ɡoʊldən-ænlɝd waɪt stæɡz, ðə waɪt stæɡ ʌv tʃɹæmən, ɑn ðə slivz. æbəl pɛnʒɹ, hɪz æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs stɝn bɪniθ ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ, ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ wɪð ðə θɹi ɡoʊldən stɑɹz ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ. ðeɪ wɔkt ʌp ðə ɡɹæn hɔl təɡɛðɝ, tʃɹeɪl baɪ ðɛɹ sɝvəns, bʌt nɑt ɡɹupt əz ənaʊnst. ɛlɹin ən æbəl wɔkt wɪð lwɑn, pɛlɪvɑɹ ən æɛmlɪn wɪð ɑɝəθɛl, tu peɪsɪz bɪtwin ðə ɡɹups. soʊ. ðeɪ æsk fəɹ seɪf kʌndəkt əz wʌn, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt wʌn. ðət meɪɾ ə dɪmæn fəɹ sɝɛndɝ ə lɪɾəl lɛs laɪkli. ivən oʊpən ɛnəmiz kəɾ ækt ɪn kɑnsɝɾ ət taɪmz. dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ən snʌɡ bɹitʃɪz ɡlɪsən dæmpli. ðə faɪnəs kloʊk kəd nɑt pɹətɛkt ə pɝsən kəmplitli ɪn ə daʊnpɔɹ laɪk ðɪs. ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi ɪn ðɛɹ bɛs tɛmpɝz.

This was informality, when two sides met and there was no knowing how far apart they were. Mistress Harfor announced the newly arrived lords and ladies in strict order of precedence, though among the Houses gathered here, there was not a great deal between them. Luan Norwelyn, hard-faced and more gray-haired than when Elayne last saw him, his blue coat undecorated except for Norwelyn's Silver Salmon on the high collar. Arathelle Renshar, her face creased and her brown hair thick with gray, in a red riding dress ornately worked with gold and a large ruby-studded pin that displayed the three Golden Hounds. Pelivar Coelan, tall and lean, his dark hair receding till he almost looked as if he had shaved the front of his head like a Cairhienin, in silver-embroidered blue with twinned red roses worked on his collar, the Roses of Coelan. Aemlyn Carand, plump in gray silk with the three Golden Arrows climbing her sleeves and so thick on her bosom she looked like a bristling quiver. Ellorien Traemane, not so plump as Elayne recalled but still pretty in green-slashed blue embroidered with golden-antlered white stags, the White Stag of Traemane, on the sleeves. Abelle Pendar, his angular face stern beneath gray hair, in dark gray with the three Golden Stars on his collar. They walked up the Grand Hall together, trailed by their servants, but not grouped as announced. Ellorien and Abelle walked with Luan, Pelivar and Aemlyn with Arathelle, two paces between the groups. So. They asked for safe conduct as one, yet they were not one. That made a demand for surrender a little less likely. Even open enemies could act in concert at times. Divided skirts and snug breeches glistened damply. The finest cloak could not protect a person completely in a downpour like this. They would not be in their best tempers.

"bi wɛlkəm," ʃi toʊld əm əz ðɛɹ sɝvəns pild əweɪ tə dʒɔɪn ði ʌðɝz. "wɪl jə teɪk waɪn, əɹ ti? ðə waɪn ɪz hɑɾ ən spaɪst. ðɪs simz ə wɪntɝi deɪ fəɹ spɹɪŋ."

"Be welcome," she told them as their servants peeled away to join the others. "Will you take wine, or tea? The wine is hot and spiced. This seems a wintery day for spring."

lwɑn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, bʌɾ ɛlɹin spoʊk fɝst. "æt lis jəɹ nɑt sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn." hɝ feɪs maɪɾ əv bɪn kɑɹv fɹəm mɑɹbəl, ən əɹ vɔɪs wɑz ðət hɑɹɾ ən koʊld. "aɪ hæf ɪkspɛktəd jə tə bi." θʌndɝ ɹoʊld oʊvɝhɛd.

Luan opened his mouth, but Ellorien spoke first. "At least you're not sitting on the throne." Her face might have been carved from marble, and her voice was that hard and cold. "I half expected you to be." Thunder rolled overhead.

lwɑn lʊk peɪnd. ɑɝəθɛl ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz əz ɪf ʃi wɝ hɪɹɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ʃi hæd hɝɾ ɔl tu ɔfən bɪfɔɹ. lɝ stɝd, bʌɾ ɪleɪn fɪkst ɪm wɪð ə stɛɾi lʊk, ən i ɡeɪv ə smɔl, əpɑlədʒɛɾɪk baʊ.

Luan looked pained. Arathelle rolled her eyes as if she were hearing something she had heard all too often before. Lir stirred, but Elayne fixed him with a steady look, and he gave a small, apologetic bow.

"aɪ hæv noʊ ɹaɪt tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn, ɛlɹin," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli. laɪt, pliz lɛɾ əɹ mud hoʊl stɛɾi naʊ. "jɛt." ðəɹ wɑz ən ʌnɪntɛndɪd tʌtʃ ə baɪɾ ɪn ðæt. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz nɑt soʊ kɑm əz ʃi wɪʃt tə bi.

"I have no right to sit on the throne, Ellorien," she replied calmly. Light, please let her mood hold steady now. "Yet." There was an unintended touch of bite in that. Perhaps she was not so calm as she wished to be.

ɛlɹin snɪɹd. "ɪf jəɹ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ deɪnin tə meɪk jəɹ tɛn, jəl əv ə lɔŋ weɪt. deɪnin spɛn ðə læst səksɛʃən vɪzəɾɪŋ əɹ mænɝz. ʃi nɛvɝ dɪklɛɹd fəɹ ɛniwʌn."

Ellorien sneered. "If you're waiting for Danine to make your ten, you'll have a long wait. Danine spent the last Succession visiting her manors. She never declared for anyone."

ɪleɪn smaɪld, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəlt. eɪ səksɛʃən wɑz wən wʌn haʊs səksiɾəd ənʌðɝ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn. "aɪ wɪl əv ti."

Elayne smiled, but it was difficult. A Succession was when one House succeeded another on the throne. "I will have tea."

ɛlɹin blɪŋkt, bʌɾ ɪt spɑɹk ði ʌðɝz tə ənaʊns wʌt ðeɪ wəd teɪk. oʊnli ɪleɪn, bɝdʒɪt, bɹænləɾ ən pɛɝaɪvəl tʊk ti. ɛvɹiwʌn snɪft ət ðɛɹ kʌps, wɛðɝ sɪlvɝ kʌps ʌv waɪn əɹ pɔɹsələn tikəps, bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ə sɪp. ɪleɪn fɛl noʊ ɪnsəlt. fuɾ ən waɪn kəd bi faɪn ɪn ðə kɪtʃənz ən teɪntɪd baɪ ðə taɪm ɪt ɹitʃt ðə teɪbəl. ðəɹ wɑz nɛvɝ ɛni tɛlɪŋ wɛɹ əɹ wən spɔɪlədʒ wəd stʃɹaɪk. ðə ti hæɾ ə feɪn tæŋ ə dʒɪnʒɝ, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝwɛlm ðə teɪst ʌv ɡʊd tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ blæk.

Ellorien blinked, but it sparked the others to announce what they would take. Only Elayne, Birgitte, Branlet and Perival took tea. Everyone sniffed at their cups, whether silver cups of wine or porcelain teacups, before taking a sip. Elayne felt no insult. Food and wine could be fine in the kitchens and tainted by the time it reached the table. There was never any telling where or when spoilage would strike. The tea had a faint tang of ginger, but not enough to overwhelm the taste of good Tremalking black.

"aɪ si juv ɡæðɝd moʊst ə jəɹ səpɔɹɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ən ɛɹəmɪləz livɪŋz," ɛlɹin sɛd. kæɾəlɪn tɝn əz ɹɛɾ əz əɹ dʒɹɛs, ən bɹænlət stʃɹeɪɾənd æŋɡɹəli, əntɪl pɛɝaɪvəl pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ə lɛvəl-hɛɾəd bɔɪ, pɛɝaɪvəl, ən bɹaɪt bɪɑn ɪz jɪɹz. lɝ mænədʒ tə ɹistʃɹeɪn hɪmsɛlf ðɪs taɪm, bʌt kɑneɪl stɑɹɾəd tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ ʃɑɹp bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪnz fɝm lʊk snæpt ɪz tiθ ʃʌt. kɑɝɪn mɪɹli ɹɪtɝn ɛlɹinz spaɪtfəl stɛɹ stɑlɪdli. kɑɝɪnd wɑz nɑt vɛɹi ɪntɛlədʒənt, bʌt lɪɾəl ɹʌfəl hɝ.

"I see you've gathered most of your support among the children and Arymilla's leavings," Ellorien said. Catalyn turned as red as her dress, and Branlet straightened angrily, until Perival put a hand on his arm and shook his head. A level-headed boy, Perival, and bright beyond his years. Lir managed to restrain himself this time, but Conail started to say something sharp before Elayne's firm look snapped his teeth shut. Karind merely returned Ellorien's spiteful stare stolidly. Karind was not very intelligent, but little ruffled her.

"ju mʌst əv hæɾ ə ɹizən fəɹ æskɪŋ ðɪs miɾɪŋ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ɪf ɪt wɑz mɪɹli tə ɔfɝ ɪnsʌls. . . ." ʃi lɛt ðət tʃɹeɪl ɔf. ʃi hæɾ əɹ oʊn ɹizənz fəɹ wɑntɪŋ ðɪs miɾɪŋ. ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ æsk fəɹ əɹ tə kʌm tə ðɛm, ʃi wəd hæv. wɪθaʊɾ æskɪŋ fəɹ seɪf kʌndəkt. filɪŋ ə pʌls ʌv æŋɡɝ θɹu ðə bɑnd, ʃi tʊk ə fɝm ɹeɪn ɑn hɝz. bɝdʒɪt wɔɹ ə skaʊl dɝɛktəɾ əɾ ɛlɹin laɪk ə dæɡɝ. ɪf ðeɪ bɪɡæn fiɾɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝz tɛmpɝ. . . . ðət dɪd nɑt bɛɹ θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt, nɑt hɪɹ, nɑt naʊ.

"You must have had a reason for asking this meeting," Elayne said. "If it was merely to offer insults. . . ." She let that trail off. She had her own reasons for wanting this meeting. If they had asked for her to come to them, she would have. Without asking for safe conduct. Feeling a pulse of anger through the bond, she took a firm rein on hers. Birgitte wore a scowl directed at Ellorien like a dagger. If they began feeding one another's temper. . . . That did not bear thinking about, not here, not now.

ɛlɹin oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əɡɛn, ən ðɪs taɪm, lwɑn kʌɾ əɹ ɔf. "wiv kʌm tə æsk fəɹ ə tʃɹus, ɪleɪn." ə flæʃ ə laɪtnɪŋ lɪt ðə nɔɹðɝn wɪndoʊz, ən ðoʊz ɪn ðə silɪŋ, bʌt ði ɪntɝvəl tə θʌndɝ sɛɾ ɪt hæd bɪn səm dɪstəns ɔf.

Ellorien opened her mouth again, and this time, Luan cut her off. "We've come to ask for a truce, Elayne." A flash of lightning lit the northern windows, and those in the ceiling, but the interval to thunder said it had been some distance off.

"ə tʃɹus? ɑɹ wi ət wɔɹ, lwɑn? hæz sʌmwʌn dɪklɛɹd fəɹ ðə θɹoʊn ðəɾ aɪ hævən hɝɾ ʌv?" sɪks sɛts ʌv aɪz swʌŋ tə daɪɛlɪn, hu ɡɹʌntɪd.

"A truce? Are we at war, Luan? Has someone declared for the throne that I haven't heard of?" Six sets of eyes swung to Dyelin, who grunted.

"fulz. aɪ toʊl jə ən toʊl ju, ən jə wʊdn bɪliv mi. pɝhæps jəl bɪliv ðɪs. wən sɪlveɪs, kɑɝɪn ən lɝ sɛn ðɛɹ pɹɑkləmeɪʃənz ə səpɔɹt, aɪ sɛn maɪ oʊn. tæɹɑvɪn stænz fəɹ tʃɹəkənd, ən ðə hoʊl ʌv ændɝ wɪl noʊ ɪt sun ɪnʌf."

"Fools. I told you and told you, and you wouldn't believe me. Perhaps you'll believe this. When Sylvase, Karind and Lir sent their proclamations of support, I sent my own. Taravin stands for Trakand, and the whole of Andor will know it soon enough."

ɛlɹin kʌlɝɾ æŋɡɹəli ən mænədʒ tə meɪk ivən ðət sim koʊld. æɛmlɪn tʊk ə lɔŋ dʒɹɪŋk, lʊkɪŋ θɔtfəl. ɑɝəθɛl əlaʊɾ ə tʌtʃ ə dɪsəpɔɪnmənt tə tʌtʃ əɹ feɪs bɪfɔɹ ɪt ɹɪtɝn tə ə mæsk nɪɹli əz hɑɹɾ əz ɛlɹinz.

Ellorien colored angrily and managed to make even that seem cold. Aemlyn took a long drink, looking thoughtful. Arathelle allowed a touch of disappointment to touch her face before it returned to a mask nearly as hard as Ellorien's.

"bi ðəɾ əz ɪt meɪ," lwɑn sɛd, "wi stɪl wɑnt . . . ɪf nɑɾ ə tʃɹus, ðən ə tɛmpɝɛɹi əɡɹimənt." hi dʒɹæŋk ə smɔl swɑloʊ fɹəm ɪz waɪnkʌp ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sædli. "ivən ɡæðɝɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wi kæn, wɪl əv ə dɪfəkəl taɪm dɪfiɾɪŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz, bʌɾ ɪf wi feɪl tə æk təɡɛðɝ, ðəl kɑɹv ʌp ændɝ wʌns ðeɪ dɪsaɪd tə muv. fɹæŋkli, aɪm sɝpɹaɪz ðeɪv ɹɪmeɪn ɪn wʌn pleɪs ðɪs lɔŋ. ðɛɹ mɛn ɔt tə bi wɛl ɹɛstəd baɪ naʊ ivən æftɝ ə θaʊzənd-liɡ mɑɹtʃ." laɪtnɪŋ lɪt ðə sʌðɝn wɪndoʊz bɹaɪtli, ən θʌndɝ kɹæʃt soʊ laʊdli ɪt sim ðə ɡlæs peɪnz ʃəd ʃɪvɝ. kloʊs, ðət wʌn.

"Be that as it may," Luan said, "we still want . . . if not a truce, then a temporary agreement." He drank a small swallow from his winecup and shook his head sadly. "Even gathering everything we can, we'll have a difficult time defeating the Borderlanders, but if we fail to act together, they'll carve up Andor once they decide to move. Frankly, I'm surprised they've remained in one place this long. Their men ought to be well rested by now even after a thousand-league march." Lightning lit the southern windows brightly, and thunder crashed so loudly it seemed the glass panes should shiver. Close, that one.

"aɪ ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə bi ɪndə mʊɹændi baɪ naʊ maɪsɛlf," ɪleɪn sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv ðɛɹ ɹizən fəɹ sɪɾɪŋ ɪn wʌn pleɪs ɪz ə fɪɹ ə spɑɹkɪŋ ə wɔɹ ɪf ðeɪ kʌm tu nɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn. ðeɪ sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ə weɪ tə mʊɹændi juzɪŋ kʌntʃɹi ɹoʊdz. jə noʊ wʌt kəndɪʃən ðoʊz ɑɹ ɪn ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ. ðeɪ wɑnt noʊ wɔɹ wɪð ʌs. wən aɪ ɡeɪv əm pɝmɪʃən tə kɹɔs ændɝ, ðeɪ toʊl mi ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

"I expected them to be into Murandy by now myself," Elayne said. "But I believe their reason for sitting in one place is a fear of sparking a war if they come too near Caemlyn. They seem to be trying to find a way to Murandy using country roads. You know what condition those are in this time of year. They want no war with us. When I gave them permission to cross Andor, they told me they were looking for the Dragon Reborn."

ɛlɹin spləɾɝd, ən tʃɪps ʌv aɪs ʃʊɾə kʌm fɹəm əɹ maʊθ. "wɛn jə wʌt? jə pɹeɪɾ ə haʊ juv noʊ ɹaɪt tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn - jɛt - ən ðən jə æɹoʊɡeɪt tə jɝsɛlf ðə ɹaɪɾ ʌv - !"

Ellorien spluttered, and chips of ice should have come from her mouth. "When you what? You prate of how you have no right to sit on the throne - yet - and then you arrogate to yourself the right of - !"

"ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɛlɹin." ɪleɪn hɛld ʌp əɹ ɹaɪt hæn soʊ ðeɪ kəd nɑt mɪs ðə ɡoʊldən ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɛnsɝkəlɪŋ ðə θɝd fɪŋɡɝ. hɝ oʊn vɔɪs wɑz fɹɔsti dɪspaɪɾ ɔl ʃi kəd du. "aɪ dɪd nɑt spik əz dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ əɹ ivən haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd. aɪ spoʊk əz ɪleɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ. hæɾ aɪ nɑt, ðeɪ wʊɾə kʌm ɛniweɪ. ðeɪ wɝ vɛɹi ʃɔɹɾ ə fuɾ ən fɑɾɝ. hæɾ aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp ðɛm, hæɾ ɛniwʌn tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp ðɛm, ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn wɔɹ. ðeɪ ɑɹ dɪtɝmən tə faɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ə wɔɹ ændɝ hæd feɪn tʃæns ʌv wɪnɪŋ. jə spik ʌv æktɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, lwɑn? ɡæðɝ ɔl ʌv ændɝz stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən wi kəd nɪɹli mætʃ ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz, bʌt tu ɪn θɹi ʌv aʊɝz wəd bi mɛn u kən hændəl ə hælbɹɾ əɹ spɪɹ bʌt spɛn moʊst ə ðɛɹ deɪz bɪhaɪn ə plaʊ. ɛvɹi mæn ə ðɛɹz ɪz ə lɔŋ-sɝvɪŋ ɑɹmsmən u wəd nɑt bi sɝpɹaɪz tə feɪs tʃɹɑləks ɛni deɪ ʌv ɪz laɪf. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə wɔɹ ðət wəd soʊk ændɝ ɪn blʌɾ ən kɹɪpəl əɹ fəɹ ə dʒɛnɝeɪʃən, wɪv ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz kɹɔsɪŋ əɹ neɪʃən pisfəli. aɪ hæv əm wɑtʃt. ðeɪ peɪ fəɹ ðə fuɾ ən fɑɾɝ ðeɪ nid, ən peɪ wɛl." ənʌðɝ taɪm, wɪð ʌðɝ lɪsənɝz, ʃi wʊɾə læft oʊvɝ ðæt. ændɔɝən fɑɹmɝz wəd tʃɹaɪ tə pɹaɪ haɪ pɹaɪsəz aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. "ðə wɝs ðeɪv dʌn ɪz flɑɡ ə fju hɔɹsɛθivz, ən ɪf ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn hændəɾ oʊvɝ tə ə mædʒəstʃɹeɪt, aɪ kæn fɔl ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz fəɹ ɪt. naʊ tɛl mi, ɛlɹin. wʌt wəd juv dʌn dɪfɹənli, ən haʊ?"

"Of an Aes Sedai, Ellorien." Elayne held up her right hand so they could not miss the golden Great Serpent encircling the third finger. Her own voice was frosty despite all she could do. "I did not speak as Daughter-Heir or even High Seat of House Trakand. I spoke as Elayne Aes Sedai of the Green Ajah. Had I not, they would have come anyway. They were very short of food and fodder. Had I tried to stop them, had anyone tried to stop them, there would have been war. They are determined to find the Dragon Reborn. It would have been a war Andor had faint chance of winning. You speak of acting together, Luan? Gather all of Andor's strength, and we could nearly match their numbers, but two in three of ours would be men who can handle a halberd or spear but spend most of their days behind a plow. Every man of theirs is a long-serving armsman who would not be surprised to face Trollocs any day of his life. Instead of a war that would soak Andor in blood and cripple her for a generation, we have the Borderlanders crossing our nation peacefully. I have them watched. They pay for the food and fodder they need, and pay well." Another time, with other listeners, she would have laughed over that. Andoran farmers would try to pry high prices out of the Dark One. "The worst they've done is flog a few horsethieves, and if they should have been handed over to a magistrate, I can't fault the Borderlanders for it. Now tell me, Ellorien. What would you have done differently, and how?"

ɛlɹin blɪŋkt, aɪsɪli sʌlən, ðən snɪf dɪsmɪsɪvli ən sɪpt əɾ əɹ waɪn.

Ellorien blinked, icily sullen, then sniffed dismissively and sipped at her wine.

"ænd wʌt dʒju plæn fəɹ ðɪs blæk taʊɝ?" æbəl æskt kwaɪətli. "aɪ . . . səspɛk juv ə plæn fəɹ ðɛm, tu." dɪɾ i səspɛkt əɹ ʌðɝ ɹizən fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz kɹɔs ændɝ? lɛt hɪm, soʊ lɔŋ əz i dɪd nɑt ɡɪv ɪt vɔɪs. soʊ lɔŋ əz i kɛp saɪlənt, hɝ moʊɾɪvz sim pjʊɹli fəɹ ændɝz ɡʊd. ðət wɑz hɪpəkɹɪɾɪkəl, noʊ boʊnz əbaʊɾ ɪt, bʌt ɹiəlɪstɪk əz wɛl. ʃi hæd spoʊkən tʃɹuθfəli kənsɝnɪŋ əɹ ʌðɝ ɹizənz, bʌt ðət wʌn, spoʊkən əlaʊd, kəd kɑs hɝ. ʃi stɪl niɾəd wʌn mɔɹ haʊs, ən ɪt lʊkt əz ɪf kændʒɹeɪd hæd tə bi ɪt, bʌt deɪnin wəd nɛvɝ muv ɪf ʃi θɔɾ ɪleɪn wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs əɹ ɪndə ɪt.

"And what do you plan for this Black Tower?" Abelle asked quietly. "I . . . suspect you have a plan for them, too." Did he suspect her other reason for letting the Borderlanders cross Andor? Let him, so long as he did not give it voice. So long as he kept silent, her motives seemed purely for Andor's good. That was hypocritical, no bones about it, but realistic as well. She had spoken truthfully concerning her other reasons, but that one, spoken aloud, could cost her. She still needed one more House, and it looked as if Candraed had to be it, but Danine would never move if she thought Elayne was trying to force her into it.

"nʌθɪŋ," ʃi toʊl hɪm. "aɪ sɛnd ɡɑɹdzmɪn piɹiɑɾɪkəli tə ɹaɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə blæk taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz ən ɹimaɪn əm ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn ændɝ ən sʌbʒɪkt tə ændɝz lɔz, bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðæt, aɪ kən də noʊ mɔɹ ðən aɪ kəɾ ɪf ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɝ sʌmhaʊ tʃɹænspɔɹɾəd tə keɪɛmlɪn." fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən ðeɪ stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, ɔl sɪks ə ðɛm ənblɪŋkɪŋ.

"Nothing," she told him. "I send Guardsmen periodically to ride around the Black Tower grounds and remind them they are in Andor and subject to Andor's laws, but aside from that, I can do no more than I could if the White Tower were somehow transported to Caemlyn." For a long moment they stared at her, all six of them unblinking.

"pɛnʒɹ stænz fəɹ tʃɹəkənd," æbəl sɛd sʌɾənli, ən ɹaɪɾ ətɑp hɪm, lwɑn sɛd, "nɔɹwlɪn stænz fəɹ tʃɹəkənd." laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt oʊvɝhɛd, bɹaɪɾənɪŋ ðə kʌlɝd wɪndoʊz ɪn ðə silɪŋ.

"Pendar stands for Trakand," Abelle said suddenly, and right atop him, Luan said, "Norwelyn stands for Trakand." Lightning flashed overhead, brightening the colored windows in the ceiling.

ɪleɪn kɛp hɝsɛlf fɹəm sweɪɪŋ wɪð ən ɛfɝt. bɝdʒɪts feɪs wɑz smuð, bʌt ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ əmeɪzmənt. ɪt wɑz dʌn. ʃi hæɾ ɪlɛvən, ən ðə θɹoʊn wɑz hɝz.

Elayne kept herself from swaying with an effort. Birgitte's face was smooth, but the bond carried amazement. It was done. She had eleven, and the throne was hers.

"ðə mɔɹ u stæn fəɹ hɝ, ðə bɛɾɝ fəɹ ændɝ." daɪɛlɪn saʊndəɾ ə tʌtʃ deɪz hɝsɛlf. "stænd wɪð mi fəɹ tʃɹəkənd."

"The more who stand for her, the better for Andor." Dyelin sounded a touch dazed herself. "Stand with me for Trakand."

ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ pɔz, lɔŋɡɝ, fʊl ʌv ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz, bʌt ðɛn, wʌn baɪ wʌn, ɑɝəθɛl, pɛlɪvɑɹ ən æɛmlɪn ənaʊns ðət ðɛɹ haʊsəz stʊd fəɹ tʃɹəkənd. duɪŋ soʊ fəɹ daɪɛlɪn, ðoʊ. ɪleɪn wəɾ əv tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. pɝhæps ʃi kəd wɪn ðɛɹ lɔɪəlti ɪn taɪm, bʌt fəɹ ðə pɹɛzənt, ðeɪ səpɔɹɾəd əɹ fəɹ daɪɛlɪnz seɪk.

There was another pause, longer, full of exchanged glances, but then, one by one, Arathelle, Pelivar and Aemlyn announced that their Houses stood for Trakand. Doing so for Dyelin, though. Elayne would have to remember that. Perhaps she could win their loyalty in time, but for the present, they supported her for Dyelin's sake.

"ʃi hæz ðə θɹoʊn," ɛlɹin sɛd, əz koʊld əz ɛvɝ. "ðə ɹɛst ɪz flʌf ən fɛðɝz."

"She has the throne," Ellorien said, as cold as ever. "The rest is fluff and feathers."

ɪleɪn tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk əɹ vɔɪs wɔɹm. "wɪl jə daɪn wɪð əs ðɪs ivnɪŋ, ɛlɹin? ət list ɹɪmeɪn əntɪl ðə ɹeɪn əbeɪts."

Elayne tried to make her voice warm. "Will you dine with us this evening, Ellorien? At least remain until the rain abates."

"aɪ hæv maɪ oʊn kʊks," ɛlɹin ɹɪplaɪd, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹz. hɝ sɝvɪŋ wʊmən keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ tə teɪk əɹ kʌp ən ɹɪtɝn ɪt tə ðə teɪbəl. "æz sun əz ðə ɹeɪn stɑps, əl bi livɪŋ fəɹ ʃɛldɪn. aɪv bɪn əweɪ tu lɔŋ."

"I have my own cooks," Ellorien replied, turning away toward the doors. Her serving woman came running to take her cup and return it to the table. "As soon as the rain stops, I will be leaving for Sheldyn. I've been away too long."

"tɑɹmən ɡdən ɪz kʌmɪŋ sun, ɛlɹin," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ju woʊn bi eɪbəl tə ɹɪmeɪn ɑn jəɹ ɪsteɪts ðɛn."

"Tarmon Gai'don is coming soon, Ellorien," Elayne said. "You won't be able to remain on your estates then."

ɛlɹin pɔzd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. "wɛn tɑɹmən ɡdən kʌmz, tʃɹæmən ɹaɪdz fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl, ən wi ɹaɪd bɪhaɪn ðə laɪən ʌv ændɝ." θʌndɝ bumd əz ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹæn hɔl wɪð əɹ sɝvɪŋ wʊmən əɾ əɹ hilz.

Ellorien paused, looking over her shoulder. "When Tarmon Gai'don comes, Traemane rides for the Last Battle, and we ride behind the Lion of Andor." Thunder boomed as she strode out of the Grand Hall with her serving woman at her heels.

"wɪl jə ɔl dʒɔɪn mi ɪn maɪ əpɑɹtməns?" ɪleɪn æsk ði ʌðɝz.

"Will you all join me in my apartments?" Elayne asked the others.

bɪhaɪn ðə laɪən ʌv ændɝ, bʌt nɑɾ ə wɝɾ əbaʊt bɪhaɪn ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd. nɪɹli hæf əɹ səpɔɹt wɑz səspɛkt wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, dʒɑɝɪd sɑɝənd wɑz stɪl ɑn ðə lus wɪð ə nɑɾ ɪnkɑnsɪɾɝəbəl fɔɹs, ən ʃi wəɾ əv tʃɹʌbəl fɹəm ɛlɹin ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ ðɪs weɪ ɪn stɔɹiz. ɪn stɔɹiz, ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ɔlweɪz ɹæpt ʌp nitli baɪ ði ɛnd. ɹil laɪf wɑz mʌtʃ . . . mɛsiɝ. stɪl, ʃi hæd ðə θɹoʊn ət læst. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ðə kɔɹəneɪʃən, bʌt ðət wɑz ə fɔɹmæləɾi naʊ. əz ʃi lɛd ðə pɹəsɛʃən fɹəm ðə ɡɹæn hɔl, tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð lwɑn ən pɛlɪvɑɹ, θʌndɝ ɹoʊld oʊvɝhɛd laɪk mɑɹʃəl dʒɹʌmz biɾɪŋ ðə mɑɹtʃ fəɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən. haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ændɝz bænɝz hæd tə mɑɹtʃ tə ðə læs bæɾəl?

Behind the Lion of Andor, but not a word about behind Elayne Trakand. Nearly half her support was suspect one way or another, Jarid Sarand was still on the loose with a not inconsiderable force, and she would have trouble from Ellorien eventually. It was never this way in stories. In stories, everything was always wrapped up neatly by the end. Real life was much . . . messier. Still, she had the throne at last. There was still the coronation, but that was a formality now. As she led the procession from the Grand Hall, chatting with Luan and Pelivar, thunder rolled overhead like martial drums beating the march for Tarmon Gai'don. How long before Andor's banners had to march to the Last Battle?

tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɪks

CHAPTER 36

ʌndɝ ən oʊk ðə sʌn stʊd wɛl əbʌv ðə maʊntənz əz kɛɹid ɹoʊd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz təwɔɹd ðə soʊ-kɔl mɑlvaɪd nɛɹoʊz, pɝhæps tu liɡz əhɛd. ðə faɪv-maɪl-waɪd ɡæp ɪn ðə maʊntənz kæɹid ðə ɹoʊd fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ tə luɡɹd, ə maɪl saʊθ ə hɪm. wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə nɛɹoʊz, ðoʊ, hi wəd faɪn ðə kæmp ædʒɪmbʊɹə hæd loʊkeɪɾəd fəɹ hɪm. ædʒɪmbʊɹə hæd nɑt bɪn ful ɪnʌf tə tʃɹaɪ ɛntɝɪŋ ðə kæmp, soʊ kɛɹid stɪl dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ i wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ə dɛθtʃɹæp fəɹ nʌθɪŋ. noʊ, nɑt fəɹ nʌθɪŋ. fəɹ ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn. ɛni dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd wɑz ɹɛɾi tə daɪ fəɹ hɝ. ðɛɹ ɑnɝ wɑz duɾi, ən duɾi ɔfən mɛn dɛθ. ðə skaɪ hɛld oʊnli bɪloʊɪŋ waɪt klaʊdz wɪð noʊ θɹɛɾ ə ɹeɪn. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz hoʊp tə daɪ ɪn sʌnlaɪt.

Under an Oak The sun stood well above the mountains as Karede rode through the trees toward the so-called Malvide Narrows, perhaps two leagues ahead. The five-mile-wide gap in the mountains carried the road from Ebou Dar to Lugard, a mile south of him. Well short of the Narrows, though, he would find the camp Ajimbura had located for him. Ajimbura had not been fool enough to try entering the camp, so Karede still did not know whether he was riding into a deathtrap for nothing. No, not for nothing. For the High Lady Tuon. Any Deathwatch Guard was ready to die for her. Their honor was duty, and duty often meant death. The sky held only billowing white clouds with no threat of rain. He had always hoped to die in sunlight.

hi hæd bɹɔt dʒʌst ə smɔl pɑɹɾi. ædʒɪmbʊɹə ɑn ɪz waɪt-fʊɾɪd tʃɛsnʌt tə ʃoʊ ðə weɪ, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə wɪɹi lɪɾəl mæn hæd kʌɾ ɔf ɪz waɪt-stʃɹikt ɹɛd bɹeɪd, ə mɛʒɝ ə hɪz ɡɹeɪt dɪvoʊʃən. ðə hɪl tʃɹaɪbz tʊk ðoʊz bɹeɪdz əz tʃɹoʊfiz fɹəm ðoʊz ðeɪ kɪld ɪn ðɛɹ ɛnləs fjudz, ən tə bi wɪθaʊt wʌn wɑz tə bi dɪsɡɹeɪst ɪn ði aɪz ʌv ɔl ðə tʃɹaɪbz ən fæmliz, ə sɛlf-pɹoʊkleɪm kaʊɝd. ðət dɪvoʊʃən wɑz tə kɛɹid ɹæðɝ ðən ðə haɪ leɪɾi əɹ ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, bʌt kɛɹidz oʊn dɪvoʊʃən wɑz sətʃ ðəɾ ɪt keɪm tə ðə seɪm θɪŋ. tu ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdz ɹoʊɾ ət kɛɹidz bæk, ðɛɹ ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin ɑɹmɝ bʌf tɪl ɪt ʃoʊn, laɪk ɪz oʊn. hɑɹɾə ən ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɑɹɾənɝz stʃɹoʊɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ðɛɹ lɔŋ-hæftɪɾ æksiz ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, izəli kipɪŋ peɪs wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz. ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ ɡlɪsən əz wɛl. mɛlɪtin, ðə haɪ leɪɾiz dɝsʌldəm, hɝ lɔŋ, ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ taɪd wɪð ə bɹaɪt ɹɛd ɹɪbən tədeɪ, wɑz ɑn ə haɪ-stɛpɪŋ ɡɹeɪ, ðə sɪlvɝi lɛŋθ ʌv ən æɾəm kənɛktɪŋ əɹ lɛft ɹɪs tə maɪələnz nɛk. ðəɹ hæd bɪn lɪɾəl ðət kəd bi dʌn tə meɪk ðoʊz tu əpɪɹ mɔɹ ɪmpɹɛsɪv, bʌt ði æɾəm ən mɛlɪtinz blu dʒɹɛs, ðə ɹɛd pænəlz ɑn skɝts ən bʊzəm hoʊldɪŋ sɪlvɝ fɔɹk laɪtnɪŋ boʊls, ʃəd dʒɹɔ ði aɪ. teɪkən ɔltəɡɛðɝ, noʊ wʌn ʃəd noʊɾəs ædʒɪmbʊɹə əɾ ɔl. ðə ɹɛst wɝ bæk wɪð mjuzənʒ, ɪn keɪs ɪt tʃɹuli wɑz ə dɛθtʃɹæp.

He had brought just a small party. Ajimbura on his white-footed chestnut to show the way, of course. The wiry little man had cut off his white-streaked red braid, a measure of his great devotion. The hill tribes took those braids as trophies from those they killed in their endless feuds, and to be without one was to be disgraced in the eyes of all the tribes and families, a self-proclaimed coward. That devotion was to Karede rather than the High Lady or the Crystal Throne, but Karede's own devotion was such that it came to the same thing. Two of the Guards rode at Karede's back, their red-and-green armor buffed till it shone, like his own. Hartha and a pair of Gardeners strode along with their long-hafted axes on their shoulders, easily keeping pace with the horses. Their armor glistened as well. Melitene, the High Lady's der'sul'dam, her long, graying hair tied with a bright red ribbon today, was on a high-stepping gray, the silvery length of an a'dam connecting her left wrist to Mylen's neck. There had been little that could be done to make those two appear more impressive, but the a'dam and Melitene's blue dress, the red panels on skirts and bosom holding silver forked lightning bolts, should draw the eye. Taken altogether, no one should notice Ajimbura at all. The rest were back with Musenge, in case it truly was a deathtrap.

hi hæd kənsɪɾɝd juzɪŋ ənʌðɝ deɪmeɪn ðən maɪələn. ðə taɪni wʊmən wɪð ðə feɪs i kəd nɛvɝ pʊɾ ən eɪdʒ tə ɔlmoʊs baʊnst ɪn əɹ sæɾəl wɪð iɡɝnəs tə leɪ aɪz ɑn ðə haɪ leɪɾi əɡɛn. ʃi wɑz nɑt pɹɑpɝli kəmpoʊzd. stɪl, ʃi kəd də nʌθɪŋ wɪθaʊt mɛlɪtin, ən ʃi wɑz jusləs əz ə wɛpən, ə fæk ðət hæd meɪɾ əɹ hæŋ əɹ hɛd wən i pɔɪntəɾ ɪɾ aʊt tə ðə dɝsʌldəm. ʃi hæd niɾəd kənsoʊlɪŋ, hɝ sʌldəm pɛɾɪŋ əɹ ən tɛlɪŋ əɹ wʌt bjuɾəfəl skaɪ laɪts ʃi meɪd, haʊ wʌndɝfəl əɹ hilɪŋ wɑz. ivən θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðət meɪd kɛɹid ʃʌɾɝ. teɪkən ɪn ði æbstʃɹækt, ɪt maɪt sim ə wʌndɝfəl θɪŋ, wunz əndʌn ɪn moʊməns, bʌɾ i θɔɾ i wəd nid tə bi nɪɹ dɛθ bɪfɔɹ i wəd lɛɾ ɛniwʌn tʌtʃ ɪm wɪð ðə paʊɝ. ən jɛt, ɪf ɪt cʊɾə seɪvd ɪz waɪf kɑliə. . . . noʊ, ðə wɛpənz hæd bɪn lɛft wɪð mjuzənʒ. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə bæɾəl tədeɪ, ɪt wəd bi ʌv ə dɪfɹən sɔɹt.

He had considered using another damane than Mylen. The tiny woman with the face he could never put an age to almost bounced in her saddle with eagerness to lay eyes on the High Lady again. She was not properly composed. Still, she could do nothing without Melitene, and she was useless as a weapon, a fact that had made her hang her head when he pointed it out to the der'sul'dam. She had needed consoling, her sul'dam petting her and telling her what beautiful Sky Lights she made, how wonderful her Healing was. Even thinking about that made Karede shudder. Taken in the abstract, it might seem a wonderful thing, wounds undone in moments, but he thought he would need to be near death before he would let anyone touch him with the Power. And yet, if it could have saved his wife Kalia. . . . No, the weapons had been left with Musenge. If there was a battle today, it would be of a different sort.

ðə fɝs bɝdkɔl i hɝd sim noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ʌðɝz i hæd hɝd ðət mɔɹnɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɹɪpiɾɪd əhɛd, ən ðən əɡɛn. dʒʌst wʌn kɔl itʃ taɪm. hi spɑɾəd ə mæn ʌp ɪn ə tɔl oʊk wɪð ə kɹɔsboʊ ðət tʃɹækt ɪm əz i ɹoʊd. siɪŋ ɪm wɑz nɑɾ izi; hɪz bɹɛstpleɪɾ ən oʊpən-feɪs hɛlmət wɝ peɪntəɾ ə dʌl ɡɹin ðət feɪɾəd ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz foʊlɪdʒ. ə lɛŋθ ə ɹɛd klɔθ taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz lɛft ɑɹm hɛlpt, ðoʊ. ɪf i ɹɪli wɑntəd tə haɪd, hi ʃʊɾə ɹimuv ðæt.

The first birdcall he heard seemed no different from others he had heard that morning, but it was repeated ahead, and then again. Just one call each time. He spotted a man up in a tall oak with a crossbow that tracked him as he rode. Seeing him was not easy; his breastplate and open-faced helmet were painted a dull green that faded into the tree's foliage. A length of red cloth tied around his left arm helped, though. If he really wanted to hide, he should have removed that.

kɛɹid moʊʃən tə ædʒɪmbʊɹə ən ðə wɪɹi lɪɾəl mæn ɡɹɪn ət hɪm, ə waɪzənd, blu-aɪd ɹæt, bɪfɔɹ əlaʊɪŋ ɪz tʃɛsnʌt tə fɔl bæk bɪhaɪn ðə ɡɑɹdz. hɪz lɔŋ naɪf wɑz ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt tədeɪ. hi ʃəd pæs fəɹ ə sɝvənt.

Karede motioned to Ajimbura and the wiry little man grinned at him, a wizened, blue-eyed rat, before allowing his chestnut to fall back behind the Guards. His long knife was under his coat today. He should pass for a servant.

sun ɪnʌf kɛɹid wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə kæmp ɪtsɛlf. ɪt hæd noʊ tɛns əɹ ʃɛltɝz ʌv ɛni kaɪnd, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ lɔŋ hɔɹslaɪnz leɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝli fæʃən, ən mɛni mɔɹ mɛn ɪn ɡɹin bɹɛstpleɪts. hɛdz tɝn tə wɑtʃ ɪz pɑɹɾi pæs, bʌt fju mɛn wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ fit, ən fjuɝ hɛld ə kɹɔsboʊ. ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə ðɛm wɝ əslip ɑn ðɛɹ blæŋkəts, daʊtləs taɪɝd fɹəm ɔl ðə hɑɹd ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðeɪ hæd bɪn duɪŋ baɪ naɪt. soʊ ðə bɝdkɔl hæd toʊld əm i wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə pɹizɛn ə deɪnʒɝ. ðeɪ hæd ðə lʊk ʌv wɛl-tʃɹeɪn soʊlʒɝz, bʌɾ i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ əz mʌtʃ. wʌɾ i hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd wɑz haʊ fju ðeɪ wɝ. oʊ, ðə tʃɹiz maɪt bi haɪɾɪŋ sʌm, bʌt ʃʊɹli ðə kæmp hɛl noʊ mɔɹ ðən sɛvən əɹ eɪt θaʊzən mɛn, fɑɹ tu fju tə hæv kæɹiɾ aʊt ðə kæmpeɪn laʊn hæd dɪskɹaɪbd. hi fɛlt ə sʌɾən taɪtnəs ɪn ɪz tʃɛst. wɛɹ wɝ ðə ɹɛst? ðə haɪ leɪɾi maɪt bi wɪð wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ bænz. hi hoʊpt ædʒɪmbʊɹə wɑz teɪkɪŋ noʊɾ ə ðə nʌmbɝz.

Soon enough Karede was riding into the camp itself. It had no tents or shelters of any kind, but there were long horselines laid out in orderly fashion, and many more men in green breastplates. Heads turned to watch his party pass, but few men were on their feet, and fewer held a crossbow. A fair number of them were asleep on their blankets, doubtless tired from all the hard riding they had been doing by night. So the birdcall had told them he was not enough to present a danger. They had the look of well-trained soldiers, but he had expected as much. What he had not expected was how few they were. Oh, the trees might be hiding some, but surely the camp held no more than seven or eight thousand men, far too few to have carried out the campaign Loune had described. He felt a sudden tightness in his chest. Where were the rest? The High Lady might be with one of the other bands. He hoped Ajimbura was taking note of the numbers.

bɪfɔɹ i hæd ɡɔn fɑɹ, ə ʃɔɹt mæn maʊntəɾ ɑn ə tɔl dʌn mɛɾ ɪm ən ɹeɪn ɪn wɛɹ i hæd tə stɑp əɹ ɹaɪd ðə mæn daʊn. ðə fɹʌn hæf ə hɪz hɛd wɑz ʃeɪvd, ən əpɪɹd tə bi paʊɾɝd, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz. hi wɑz noʊ poʊpənʒ, ðoʊ. hɪz dɑɹk koʊt maɪt bi sɪlk, jɛɾ i wɔɹ ðə seɪm dʌl ɡɹin bɹɛstpleɪɾ əz ðə kɑmən soʊlʒɝz. hɪz aɪz wɝ hɑɹɾ ən ɪkspɹɛʃənləs əz i skæn mɛlɪtin ən maɪələn, ði oʊɡiɝ. hɪz feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ əz ɪz ɡeɪz ɹɪtɝn tə kɛɹid. "lɔɹd mæt dɪskɹaɪb ðəɾ ɑɹmɝ tə ʌs," hi sɛɾ ɪn æksɛns ivən kwɪkɝ ən mɔɹ klɪp ðən ðoʊz ə ði ɔltɑɹənz. "tə wʌt də wi oʊ ði ɑnɝ ʌv ə vɪzət fɹəm ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd?"

Before he had gone far, a short man mounted on a tall dun met him and reined in where he had to stop or ride the man down. The front half of his head was shaved, and appeared to be powdered, of all things. He was no popinjay, though. His dark coat might be silk, yet he wore the same dull green breastplate as the common soldiers. His eyes were hard and expressionless as he scanned Melitene and Mylen, the Ogier. His face did not change as his gaze returned to Karede. "Lord Mat described that armor to us," he said in accents even quicker and more clipped than those of the Altarans. "To what do we owe the honor of a visit from the Deathwatch Guard?"

lɔɹd mæt? hu ʌndɝ ðə laɪt wɑz lɔɹd mæt? "fɹɪk kɛɹid," kɛɹid sɛd. "aɪ wɪʃ tə spik wɪð ðə mæn u kɔlz hɪmsɛlf tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn."

Lord Mat? Who under the Light was Lord Mat? "Furyk Karede," Karede said. "I wish to speak with the man who calls himself Thom Merrilin."

"tælmɑnz dɛləvɪnd," ðə mæn sɛd, faɪndɪŋ mænɝz. "ju wɑnə tɔk tə tɑm? wɛl, aɪ si noʊ hɑɹm ɪn ɪt. əl teɪk jə tə hɪm."

"Talmanes Delovinde," the man said, finding manners. "You want to talk to Thom? Well, I see no harm in it. I will take you to him."

kɛɹid hild ɑldəzɑɹ æftɝ dɛləvɪnd. ðə mæn hæd meɪd noʊ mɛnʃən ə ði ɑbviəs, ðəɾ i ən ði ʌðɝz kəd nɑt bi əlaʊd tə liv ən kæɹi wɝɾ ə ðɪs ɑɹmiz loʊkeɪʃən. hi hæd səm mænɝz. ət list, ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi əlaʊd tə liv ənlɛs kɛɹidz mæd plæn wɝkt. mjuzənʒ ɡeɪv ɪm oʊnli wʌn tʃæns ɪn tɛn ə səksɛs, wʌn ɪn faɪv ə lɪvɪŋ. pɝsənəli, hi hɪmsɛlf bɪliv ði ɑdz lɔŋɡɝ, bʌɾ i hæd tə meɪk ði ətɛmpt. ən mɛɹɪlɪnz pɹɛzəns ɑɹɡjuɾ ɪn feɪvɝ ə ðə haɪ leɪɾiz pɹɛzəns.

Karede heeled Aldazar after Delovinde. The man had made no mention of the obvious, that he and the others could not be allowed to leave and carry word of this army's location. He had some manners. At least, they would not be allowed to leave unless Karede's mad plan worked. Musenge gave him only one chance in ten of success, one in five of living. Personally, he himself believed the odds longer, but he had to make the attempt. And Merrilin's presence argued in favor of the High Lady's presence.

dɛləvɪn dɪsmaʊntɪɾ əɾ ən ɑdli dəmɛstɪk sin əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, pipəl ɑn kæmp stulz əɹ blæŋkəts ɝaʊn ə smɔl faɪɝ bɪniθ ə spɹɛɾɪŋ oʊk wɛɹ ə kɛɾəl wɑz hiɾɪŋ. kɛɹid stɛp daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, moʊʃənɪŋ ðə ɡɑɹdz ən ædʒɪmbʊɹə tə dɪsmaʊn əz wɛl. mɛlɪtin ən maɪələn ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ðɛɹ maʊns fəɹ ði ædvæntɪdʒ ə haɪt. ʌv ɔl pipəl, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən, hu hæd wʌns oʊn ði ɪn wɛɹ i steɪɾ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn wʌn ə ðə θɹi-lɛɡəd stulz ɹiɾɪŋ ə bʊk. ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɔɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz ɹɪvilɪŋ dʒɹɛsəz i hæɾ ɛndʒɔɪd lʊkɪŋ æt, bʌɾ əɹ kloʊs-fɪɾɪŋ nɛkləs stɪl dæŋɡəl ðət smɔl, dʒuəl naɪf ɑntu hɝ ɪmpɹɛsɪv bʊzəm. ʃi kloʊzd əɹ bʊk ən ɡeɪv ɪm ə smɔl nɑɾ əz ɪf i hæd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən æftɝ ən æbsəns ʌv ə fju aʊɝz. hɝ heɪzəl aɪz wɝ kwaɪt kəmpoʊzd. pɝhæps ðə plɑt wɑz ivən mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəkət ðən ðə sikɝ mɔɹ hæd θɔt.

Delovinde dismounted at an oddly domestic scene among the trees, people on camp stools or blankets around a small fire beneath a spreading oak where a kettle was heating. Karede stepped down from his saddle, motioning the Guards and Ajimbura to dismount as well. Melitene and Mylen remained on their mounts for the advantage of height. Of all people, Mistress Anan, who had once owned the inn where he stayed in Ebou Dar, was sitting on one of the three-legged stools reading a book. She no longer wore one of those revealing dresses he had enjoyed looking at, but her close-fitting necklace still dangled that small, jeweled knife onto her impressive bosom. She closed her book and gave him a small nod as if he had returned to the Wandering Woman after an absence of a few hours. Her hazel eyes were quite composed. Perhaps the plot was even more intricate than the Seeker Mor had thought.

ə tɔl, lin waɪt-hɛɹd mæn wɪð mʌstæʃɪz nɪɹli əz lɔŋ əz hɑɹɾəz wɑz sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ə stʃɹaɪp blæŋkəɾ əkɹɔs ə stoʊnz bɔɹd fɹəm ə slɛndɝ wʊmən wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɪn mɛni biɾɪd bɹeɪdz. hi kwɝkt ən aɪbɹaʊ ət kɛɹid, ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən ɹɪtɝn tə pɝuzɪŋ ðə kɹɔs-hætʃt bɔɹd. ʃi ɡlɛɹd pjʊɹ heɪtʃɹəɾ ət kɛɹiɾ ən ðoʊz bɪhaɪn hɪm. ə nɑɹld oʊl fɛloʊ wɪð lɔŋ waɪt hɛɹ wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn ənʌðɝ blæŋkət wɪð ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ʌɡli jʌŋ bɔɪ, pleɪɪŋ səm ɡeɪm əɹ ʌðɝ ɑn ə pis ə ɹɛd klɔθ spaɪɾɝwɪbɛd wɪð blæk laɪnz. ðeɪ sæɾ ʌp, ðə bɔɪ stʌɾiɪŋ ði oʊɡiɝ wɪð ɪntʃɹəst, ðə mæn wɪð wʌn hæn hʌvɝɪŋ əz ɪf tə ɹitʃ fəɹ ə naɪf bɪniθ ɪz koʊt. ə deɪnʒɝəs mæn, ən wɛɹi. pɝhæps i wɑz mɛɹɪlɪn.

A tall, lean white-haired man with mustaches nearly as long as Hartha's was sitting cross-legged on a striped blanket across a stones board from a slender woman with her hair in many beaded braids. He quirked an eyebrow at Karede, shook his head and returned to perusing the cross-hatched board. She glared pure hatred at Karede and those behind him. A gnarled old fellow with long white hair was lying on another blanket with a remarkably ugly young boy, playing some game or other on a piece of red cloth spiderwebbed with black lines. They sat up, the boy studying the Ogier with interest, the man with one hand hovering as if to reach for a knife beneath his coat. A dangerous man, and wary. Perhaps he was Merrilin.

tu mɛn ən tu wɪmən sɪɾɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ɑn kæmp stulz hæd bɪn kənvɝsɪŋ wən kɛɹid ɹoʊɾ ʌp, bʌɾ əz i wɑz stɛpɪŋ daʊn, ə stɝn-feɪst wʊmən stʊɾ ən fɪkst əɹ blu aɪz ɑn ɪz ɪn vɛɹi nɪɹli ə tʃælənʒ. ʃi wɔɹ ə sɔɹɾ ɑn ə waɪd lɛðɝ stʃɹæp slæntɪŋ əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst, ðə weɪ səm seɪlɝz dɪd. hɝ hɛɹ wɑz kloʊs-kɹɑpt ɹæðɝ ðən kʌɾ ɪn ðə staɪl ə ðə loʊ blʌd, hɝ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz wɝ ʃɔɹɾ ən nʌn wɝ lækɝd, bʌɾ i wɑz sɝɾən ʃi wɑz ɛdʒiənɪn tæmɝəθ. ə hɛvisɛt mæn wɪð hɛɹ əz ʃɔɹɾ əz hɝz ən wʌn ə ðoʊz ɑɾ ɪliɑnɝ bɪɹdz stʊd bɪsaɪd hɝ, wʌn hæn ɑn ðə hɪlt ʌv ə ʃɔɹtsɔɝd, stɛɹɪŋ ət kɛɹiɾ əz ɪf i ɪntɛndəd tə sɛkən əɹ tʃælənʒ. ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən wɪð dɑɹk, weɪst-lɔŋ hɛɹ ən ðə seɪm ɹoʊzbʌd maʊθ əz ðə tæɹɑbənɝ stʊd, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən ɪt simd ʃi maɪt nil əɹ pɹɑstʃɹeɪt hɝsɛlf, bʌt ðən ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd ən lʊkt ɪm ɹaɪɾ ɪn ði aɪz. ðə læs mæn, ə lin fɛloʊ ɪn ə pəkjuljɝ ɹɛd kæp u lʊkt kɑɹv fɹəm dɑɹk wʊd, ɡeɪv ə laʊd læf ən flʌŋ ɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝ. ðə ɡɹɪnɪŋ stɛɹ i ɡeɪv kɛɹid kəɾ oʊnli bi kɔl tʃɹaɪʌmfənt.

Two men and two women sitting together on camp stools had been conversing when Karede rode up, but as he was stepping down, a stern-faced woman stood and fixed her blue eyes on his in very nearly a challenge. She wore a sword on a wide leather strap slanting across her chest, the way some sailors did. Her hair was close-cropped rather than cut in the style of the low Blood, her fingernails were short and none were lacquered, but he was certain she was Egeanin Tamarath. A heavyset man with hair as short as hers and one of those odd Illianer beards stood beside her, one hand on the hilt of a shortsword, staring at Karede as if he intended to second her challenge. A pretty woman with dark, waist-long hair and the same rosebud mouth as the Taraboner stood, and for a moment it seemed she might kneel or prostrate herself, but then she straightened and looked him right in the eyes. The last man, a lean fellow in a peculiar red cap who looked carved from dark wood, gave a loud laugh and flung his arms around her. The grinning stare he gave Karede could only be called triumphant.

"tɑm," dɛləvɪn sɛd, "ðɪs ɪz fɹɪk kɛɹid. hi wɑns tə tɔk wɪð ə mæn u 'kɔlz hɪmsɛlf' tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn."

"Thom," Delovinde said, "this is Furyk Karede. He wants to talk with a man who 'calls himself' Thom Merrilin."

"wɪð mi?" ðə lin, waɪt-hɛɹd mæn sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ ɔkwɝdli. hɪz ɹaɪt lɛɡ əpɪɹd slaɪtli stɪf. ən oʊl bæɾəl ɪnʒɝi, pɝhæps? "bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt 'kɔl maɪsɛlf' tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn. ɪts maɪ neɪm, ðoʊ aɪm sɝpɹaɪz jə noʊ ɪt. wʌt dʒju wɑn ə mi?"

"With me?" the lean, white-haired man said, rising awkwardly. His right leg appeared slightly stiff. An old battle injury, perhaps? "But I don't 'call myself' Thom Merrilin. It's my name, though I'm surprised you know it. What do you want of me?"

kɛɹid ɹimuvd ɪz hɛlmət, bʌt bɪfɔɹ i kəɾ oʊpən ɪz maʊð, ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən wɪð lɑɹdʒ bɹaʊn aɪz ɹʌʃt ʌp, pɝsud baɪ tu ʌðɝz. ɔl θɹi hæd ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪsəz, wʌn mɪnət lʊkɪŋ twɛnti, ðə nɛks twaɪs ðæt, ðə θɝd sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi dɪskənsɝɾɪŋ.

Karede removed his helmet, but before he could open his mouth, a pretty woman with large brown eyes rushed up, pursued by two others. All three had those Aes Sedai faces, one minute looking twenty, the next twice that, the third somewhere in the middle. It was very disconcerting.

"ðæts ʃɛɝeɪn!" ðə pɹɪɾi wʊmən kɹaɪd, stɛɹɪŋ ət maɪələn. "ɹilis hɝ!"

"That's Sheraine!" the pretty woman cried, staring at Mylen. "Release her!"

"ju də noʊ ʌndɝstænd, dʒoʊlin," wʌn ə ðə wɪmən wɪð əɹ sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli. θɪn-lɪpt, wɪð ə nɛɹoʊ noʊz, ʃi lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi kəd tʃu ɹɑks. "ʃi də noʊ bi ʃɛɝeɪn ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ʃi wʊɾə bɪtʃɹeɪɾ ʌs, ɡɪvən ə tʃæns."

"You do no understand, Joline," one of the women with her said angrily. Thin-lipped, with a narrow nose, she looked as if she could chew rocks. "She do no be Sheraine any longer. She would have betrayed us, given a chance."

"tɛslɪn ɪz ɹaɪt, dʒoʊlin," ðə θɝd wʊmən sɛd. hænsəm ɹæðɝ ðən pɹɪɾi, ʃi hæd lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ ðət fɛl ɪn weɪvz tə hɝ weɪst. "ʃi wʊɾə bɪtʃɹeɪɾ ʌs."

"Teslyn is right, Joline," the third woman said. Handsome rather than pretty, she had long black hair that fell in waves to her waist. "She would have betrayed us."

"aɪ doʊn bɪliv ɪt, idɛzinə," dʒoʊlin snæpt. "ju wɪl fɹi hɝ ɪmiɾiətli," ʃi toʊl mɛlɪtin, "ɔɹ əl - " sʌɾənli ʃi ɡæspt.

"I don't believe it, Edesina," Joline snapped. "You will free her immediately," she told Melitene, "or I'll - " Suddenly she gasped.

"aɪ dɪd tɛl ju," tɛslɪn sɛd bɪɾɝli.

"I did tell you," Teslyn said bitterly.

ə jʌŋ mæn ɪn ə waɪd-bɹɪm blæk hæt ɡæləpt ʌp ɑn ə dɑɹk, blʌnt-noʊz tʃɛsnʌt wɪð ə dip tʃɛst ən flʌŋ hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl. "wʌts blʌɾi ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn hɪɹ?" hi dɪmændəd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp tə ðə faɪɝ.

A young man in a wide-brimmed black hat galloped up on a dark, blunt-nosed chestnut with a deep chest and flung himself out of the saddle. "What's bloody going on here?" he demanded, striding up to the fire.

kɛɹiɾ ɪɡnɔɹd hɪm. ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn hæd ɹɪɾən ʌp wɪð ðə jʌŋ mæn, ɑn ə blæk-ænd-waɪt hɔɹs wɪð mɑɹkɪŋz laɪk nʌn i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. sɪlutʃə wɑz əɾ əɹ saɪd, ɑn ə dʌn, hɝ hɛd ɹæpt ɪn ə skɑɹlət skɑɹf, bʌɾ i hæɾ aɪz oʊnli fəɹ ðə haɪ leɪɾi. ʃɔɹt blæk hɛɹ kʌvɝɾ əɹ hɛd, bʌɾ i kəd nɛvɝ mɪsteɪk ðət feɪs. ʃi spɛɹɾ ɪm oʊnli wʌn ɪkspɹɛʃənləs ɡlæns bɪfɔɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ə stʌɾi ʌv ðə jʌŋ mæn. kɛɹid wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm. pɹɑbli nɑt. ɪt hæd bɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm sɪns i hæd sɝvd ɪn əɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹd. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, bʌɾ i nu ðət ðə ɹeɪnz ʌv ædʒɪmbʊɹəz tʃɛsnʌt wɝ naʊ hɛl baɪ wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdz. əpɛɹənli ənɑɹmd ən ɪz dɪstɪŋktɪv bɹeɪd ɡɔn, hi ʃəɾ əv noʊ pɹɑbləm livɪŋ ðə kæmp. ðə sɛntʃɹiz wəd nɛvɝ si ðə lɪɾəl mæn. ædʒɪmbʊɹə wɑz ə ɡʊd ɹʌnɝ əz wɛl əz stɛlθi. sun, mjuzənʒ wəd noʊ ðət ðə haɪ leɪɾi wɑz ɪndid hɪɹ.

Karede ignored him. The High Lady Tuon had ridden up with the young man, on a black-and-white horse with markings like none he had ever seen. Selucia was at her side, on a dun, her head wrapped in a scarlet scarf, but he had eyes only for the High Lady. Short black hair covered her head, but he could never mistake that face. She spared him only one expressionless glance before returning to a study of the young man. Karede wondered whether she recognized him. Probably not. It had been a long time since he had served in her bodyguard. He did not look over his shoulder, but he knew that the reins of Ajimbura's chestnut were now held by one of the Guards. Apparently unarmed and his distinctive braid gone, he should have no problem leaving the camp. The sentries would never see the little man. Ajimbura was a good runner as well as stealthy. Soon, Musenge would know that the High Lady was indeed here.

"ʃi hæz əs ʃildɪd, mæt," dʒoʊlin sɛd, ən ðə jʌŋ mæn snætʃt ɔf ɪz hæɾ ən stʃɹoʊd tə mɛlɪtinz hɔɹs əz ɪf i ɪntɛndəd tə siz ðə bɹaɪɾəl. hi wɑz lɔŋ-lɪmd, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑt bi kɔl tɔl, ən i wɔɹ ə blæk sɪlk skɑɹf taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk ən dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɑntu hɪz tʃɛst. ðət meɪɾ ɪm ðə wʌn ɛvɹiwʌn hæd kɔl taɪlɪnz tɔɪ, əz ɪf biɪŋ ðə kwinz pleɪθɪŋ wɝ ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt fitʃɝ ə hɪm. laɪkli ɪt wɑz. pleɪθɪŋz sɛldəm hæɾ ənʌðɝ saɪd tə ðɛm. stʃɹeɪnʒ, bʌɾ i hɑɹdli sim hænsəm ɪnʌf fəɹ ðæt. hi dɪd lʊk fɪt, ðoʊ.

"She has us shielded, Mat," Joline said, and the young man snatched off his hat and strode to Melitene's horse as if he intended to seize the bridle. He was long-limbed, though he could not be called tall, and he wore a black silk scarf tied around his neck and dangling onto his chest. That made him the one everyone had called Tylin's Toy, as if being the queen's plaything were the most important feature of him. Likely it was. Playthings seldom had another side to them. Strange, but he hardly seemed handsome enough for that. He did look fit, though.

"ɹilis ðə ʃild," hi toʊld əɹ əz ɪf i ɪkspɛktəɾ oʊbiɾiəns. kɛɹidz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz. ðɪs wɑz ðə pleɪθɪŋ? mɛlɪtin ən maɪələn ɡæspt ɔlmoʊst əz wʌn, ən ðə jʌŋ mæn bɑɹkt ə læf. "ju si, ɪt dʌznt wɝk ɑn mi. naʊ jə blʌɾi wɛl ɹilis ðə ʃilz, əɹ əl blʌɾi wɛl hɔl jə aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl ən pæɾəl jəɹ bɑɾəmz." mɛlɪtinz feɪs dɑɹkənd. fju pipəl dɛɹd spik soʊ tə ə dɝsʌldəm.

"Release the shield," he told her as if he expected obedience. Karede's eyebrows rose. This was the plaything? Melitene and Mylen gasped almost as one, and the young man barked a laugh. "You see, it doesn't work on me. Now you bloody well release the shields, or I'll bloody well haul you out of the saddle and paddle your bottoms." Melitene's face darkened. Few people dared speak so to a der'sul'dam.

"ɹilis ðə ʃilz, mɛlɪtin," kɛɹid sɛd.

"Release the shields, Melitene," Karede said.

"ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn wɑz ɑn ðə pɔɪn ʌv ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv oʊbeɪɪŋ. "ðɛɹz noʊ tɛlɪŋ wʌt ʃi maɪɾ əv - "

"The marath'damane was on the point of embracing saidar," she said instead of obeying. "There's no telling what she might have - "

"ɹilis ðə ʃilz," hi sɛd fɝmli. "æn ɹilis ðə paʊɝ."

"Release the shields," he said firmly. "And release the Power."

ðə jʌŋ mæn ɡeɪv ə sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd, ðən sʌɾənli spʌn, pɔɪntɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ ət ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ. "naʊ doʊn jə blʌɾi wɛl stɑɹt! ʃiz lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv ðə paʊɝ. jə də ɪt, tu. ɡoʊ əhɛd!" əɡɛn i nɑɾəd, fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝld əz ɪf i wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ hæɾ oʊbeɪd. fɹəm ðə weɪ mɛlɪtin wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, pɝhæps i wɑz. meɪbi hi wɑz ən æʃəmən? pɝhæps æʃəmən kəd dɪtɛkt ə deɪmeɪnz tʃænəlɪŋ sʌmhaʊ. ðət hɑɹdli sim laɪkli, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl kɛɹid kəd θɪŋk ʌv. jɛt ðət hɑɹdli skwɛɹd wɪð haʊ taɪlɪn ɹɪpɔɹɾədli hæd tʃɹiɾəd ðə jʌŋ mæn.

The young man gave a satisfied nod, then suddenly spun, pointing a finger at the three Aes Sedai. "Now don't you bloody well start! She's let go of the Power. You do it, too. Go ahead!" Again he nodded, for all the world as if he was sure they had obeyed. From the way Melitene was staring at him, perhaps he was. Maybe he was an Asha'man? Perhaps Asha'man could detect a damane's channeling somehow. That hardly seemed likely, but it was all Karede could think of. Yet that hardly squared with how Tylin reportedly had treated the young man.

"wʌn ə ðiz deɪz, mæt kɔθən," dʒoʊlin sɛɾ æsədli, "sʌmwʌn wɪl titʃ jə tə ʃoʊ pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɛk tə ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən aɪ hoʊp aɪm ðəɹ tə si ɪt."

"One of these days, Mat Cauthon," Joline said acidly, "someone will teach you to show proper respect to Aes Sedai, and I hope I am there to see it."

ðə haɪ leɪɾi ən sɪlutʃə læft əpɹɔɑɹiəsli. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə si ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə kip əɹ spɪɹəts ʌp ɪn kæptɪvəɾi. daʊtləs əɹ meɪdz kəmpænjənʃɪp hæd hɛlpt. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz taɪm tə ɡɛɾ ɑn, tu. taɪm tə teɪk ɪz mæd ɡæmbəl.

The High Lady and Selucia laughed uproariously. It was good to see she had managed to keep her spirits up in captivity. Doubtless her maid's companionship had helped. But it was time to get on, too. Time to take his mad gamble.

"dʒɛnɝəl mɛɹɪlɪn," kɛɹid sɛd, "ju fɔɾ ə ʃɔɹt bʌt ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl kæmpeɪn ən ətʃiv mɪɹəkəlz ət kipɪŋ jəɹ fɔɹsɪz ʌndɪtɛktɪd, bʌt jəɹ lʌk ɪz əbaʊt tə ɹʌn aʊt. dʒɛnɝəl tʃɪsən dɪdus jəɹ ɹil pɝpəs. hiz tɝn ɪz ɑɹmi ɝaʊn ən ɪz mɑɹtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə mɑlvaɪd nɛɹoʊz əz fæst əz i kæn. hɪl bi hɪɹ ɪn tu deɪz. aɪ hæv tɛn θaʊzən mɛn nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm hɪɹ, ɪnʌf tə pɪn jə əntɪl i ɝaɪvz. bʌt ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn wəd bi ɪn deɪnʒɝ, ən aɪ wɑnə əvɔɪd ðæt. lemi liv wɪð hɝ, ən əl əlaʊ jə ən jəɹ mɛn tə dɪpɑɹɾ ənhɪndɝd. jə kən bi wɛl ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə maʊntənz, ɪndə ðə moʊlveɪn ɡæp, bɪfɔɹ tʃɪsən ɝaɪvz, ən ɪndə mʊɹændi bɪfɔɹ i kən kætʃ ju. ði oʊnli ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs ɪz ənaɪəleɪʃən. tʃɪsən əz ɪnʌf mɛn tə waɪp jə aʊt. ɪt woʊn bi ə bæɾəl. ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən mɛn əɡɛnst eɪt θaʊzənd wɪl bi ə slɔɾɝ."

"General Merrilin," Karede said, "you fought a short but remarkable campaign and achieved miracles at keeping your forces undetected, but your luck is about to run out. General Chisen deduced your real purpose. He has turned his army around and is marching for the Malvide Narrows as fast as he can. He will be here in two days. I have ten thousand men not far from here, enough to pin you until he arrives. But the High Lady Tuon would be in danger, and I want to avoid that. Let me leave with her, and I will allow you and your men to depart unhindered. You can be well the other side of the mountains, into the Molvaine Gap, before Chisen arrives, and into Murandy before he can catch you. The only other choice is annihilation. Chisen has enough men to wipe you out. It won't be a battle. A hundred thousand men against eight thousand will be a slaughter."

ðeɪ hɝɾ ɪm aʊt, ɛvɹi feɪs əz blæŋk əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ stʌnd. ðeɪ skul ðɛmsɛlvz wɛl. əɹ pɝhæps ðeɪ wɝ stʌn ət mɛɹɪlɪnz plæn əpɛɹənli ənɹævəlɪŋ ət ðə læst ɪnstənt.

They heard him out, every face as blank as if they were stunned. They schooled themselves well. Or perhaps they were stunned at Merrilin's plan apparently unraveling at the last instant.

mɛɹɪlɪn stʃɹoʊkt wʌn ə hɪz waɪt mʌstæʃɪz wɪð ə lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝ. hi sim tə bi haɪɾɪŋ ə smaɪl. "aɪ fɪɹ juv mɪsteɪkən mi, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl kɛɹid." fəɹ ðə speɪs ʌv ə sɛntəns ɪz vɔɪs bɪkeɪm ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɛzənənt. "aɪ æm ə ɡlimən, ə pəzɪʃən haɪɝ ðən kɔɹt-bɑɹd tə bi ʃʊɹ, bʌt noʊ dʒɛnɝəl. ðə mæn jə wɑn ɪz lɔɹd meɪtʃɹim kɔθən." hi meɪɾ ə smɔl baʊ təwɔɹd ðə jʌŋ mæn, hu wɑz sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪz flæt-tɑp hæt bæk ɑn ɪz hɛd.

Merrilin stroked one of his white mustaches with a long finger. He seemed to be hiding a smile. "I fear you have mistaken me, Banner-General Karede." For the space of a sentence his voice became extremely resonant. "I am a gleeman, a position higher than court-bard to be sure, but no general. The man you want is Lord Matrim Cauthon." He made a small bow toward the young man, who was settling his flat-topped hat back on his head.

kɛɹid fɹaʊnd. taɪlɪnz tɔɪ wɑz ðə dʒɛnɝəl? wɝ ðeɪ pleɪɪŋ ə ɡeɪm wɪð hɪm?

Karede frowned. Tylin's Toy was the general? Were they playing a game with him?

"ju hæv əbaʊɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn, dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, ən meɪbi twɛnti ɡɑɹɾənɝz," kɔθən sɛd kɑmli. "fɹʌm wʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ, ðət kəd meɪk ən ivən faɪɾ əɡɛns faɪv taɪmz ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ fəɹ moʊst soʊlʒɝz, bʌt ðə bæn ɑɹən moʊst soʊlʒɝz, ən aɪ hæv ə saɪt mɔɹ ðən sɪks hʌnʒɹəd. əz fəɹ tʃɪsən, ɪf ðæts ðə fɛloʊ hu pʊl bæk θɹu ðə nɛɹoʊz, ivən ɪf hiz fɪɡjɝɾ aʊt wʌɾ aɪ wɑz ʌp tə, hi kʊdnt ɡɛt bæk ɪn lɛs ðən faɪv deɪz. maɪ skaʊts' læst ɹɪpɔɹts hæɾ ɪm pʊʃɪŋ saʊθwɛst əlɔŋ ði ɛbu dɑɹ ɹoʊɾ əz fæst i kəd mɑɹtʃ. ðə ɹil kwɛstʃən ɪz ðɪs, ðoʊ. kən jə ɡɛt tuɑn tə ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs seɪfli?"

"You have about a hundred men, Deathwatch Guards, and maybe twenty Gardeners," Cauthon said calmly. "From what I hear, that could make an even fight against five times their number for most soldiers, but the Band aren't most soldiers, and I have a sight more than six hundred. As for Chisen, if that's the fellow who pulled back through the Narrows, even if he has figured out what I was up to, he couldn't get back in less than five days. My scouts' last reports had him pushing southwest along the Ebou Dar Road as fast he could march. The real question is this, though. Can you get Tuon to the Tarasin Palace safely?"

kɛɹid fɛlt əz ɪf hɑɹɾə hæd kɪkt ɪm ɪn ðə bɛli, ən nɑɾ oʊnli kəz ðə mæn hæd juz ðə haɪ leɪɾiz neɪm soʊ kæʒəwəli. "ju min tə lemi teɪk əɹ əweɪ?" hi sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli.

Karede felt as if Hartha had kicked him in the belly, and not only because the man had used the High Lady's name so casually. "You mean to let me take her away?" he said incredulously.

"ɪf ʃi tʃɹʌsts ju. ɪf jə kən ɡɛɾ əɹ tə ðə pæləs seɪfli. ʃiz ɪn deɪnʒɝ tɪl ʃi ɹitʃəz ðæt. ɪn keɪs jə doʊnt noʊ ɪt, jəɹ hoʊl blʌɾi ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs fleɪmɪŋ ɑɹmi ɪz ɹɛɾi tə slɪɾ əɹ θɹoʊɾ əɹ bæʃ ɪn əɹ hɛd wɪð ə ɹɑk."

"If she trusts you. If you can get her to the palace safely. She's in danger till she reaches that. In case you don't know it, your whole bloody Ever Victorious flaming Army is ready to slit her throat or bash in her head with a rock."

"aɪ noʊ," kɛɹid sɛd, mɔɹ kɑmli ðən i fɛlt. waɪ wəd ðɪs mæn dʒʌst ɹilis ðə haɪ leɪɾi æftɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd ɡɔn tə ɔl ðə tʃɹʌbəl ə kɪdnæpɪŋ hɝ? waɪ, æftɝ faɪɾɪŋ ðət ʃɔɹt, blʌɾi kæmpeɪn? "wi wɪl daɪ tə ðə mæn ɪf ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ ɪz niɾəd tə si hɝ seɪf. ɪɾəl bi bɛst ɪf wi sɛɾ aʊɾ ɪmiɾiətli." bɪfɔɹ ðə mæn tʃeɪnʒd ɪz maɪnd. bɪfɔɹ kɛɹid woʊk fɹəm ðɪs fivɝ-dʒɹim. ɪt ʃʊɹli simd ə fivɝ-dʒɹim.

"I know," Karede said, more calmly than he felt. Why would this man just release the High Lady after the White Tower had gone to all the trouble of kidnapping her? Why, after fighting that short, bloody campaign? "We will die to the man if that is what is needed to see her safe. It will be best if we set out immediately." Before the man changed his mind. Before Karede woke from this fever-dream. It surely seemed a fever-dream.

"nɑt soʊ fæst." kɔθən tɝn təwɔɹd ðə haɪ leɪɾi. "tuɑn, dʒju tʃɹʌs ðɪs mæn tə si jə seɪf tə ðə pæləs ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ?" kɛɹid staɪfəld ən ɪmpəls tə wɪns. dʒɛnɝəl ən lɔɹd ðə mæn maɪt bi, bʌɾ i hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə juz ðə haɪ leɪɾiz neɪm soʊ!

"Not so fast." Cauthon turned toward the High Lady. "Tuon, do you trust this man to see you safe to the palace in Ebou Dar?" Karede stifled an impulse to wince. General and lord the man might be, but he had no right to use the High Lady's name so!

"aɪ tʃɹʌs ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz wɪð maɪ laɪf," ðə haɪ leɪɾi ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli, "æn ɪm mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ." ʃi feɪvɝd kɛɹid wɪð ə smaɪl. ivən əz ə tʃaɪld, smaɪlz fɹəm əɹ hæd bɪn ɹɛɹ. "du jə baɪ ɛni tʃæns stɪl əv maɪ dɑl, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl kɛɹid?"

"I trust the Deathwatch Guards with my life," the High Lady replied calmly, "and him more than any other." She favored Karede with a smile. Even as a child, smiles from her had been rare. "Do you by any chance still have my doll, Banner-General Karede?"

hi baʊd tə hɝ fɔɹməli. ðə mænɝ ə hɝ spikɪŋ toʊld ɪm ʃi wɑz stɪl ʌndɝ ðə veɪl. "fɝɡɪvnəs, haɪ leɪɾi. aɪ lɔst ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt faɪɝ ə soʊhimə."

He bowed to her formally. The manner of her speaking told him she was still under the veil. "Forgiveness, High Lady. I lost everything in the Great Fire of Sohima."

"ðæt minz jə kɛpt ɪt fəɹ tɛn jɪɹz. juv maɪ kəməzɝeɪʃən ɑn ðə lɔs ə jəɹ waɪf, ən ə jəɹ sʌn, ðoʊ hi daɪd bɹeɪvli ən wɛl. fju mɛn wɪl ɛntɝ ə bɝnɪŋ bɪldɪŋ wʌns. hi seɪv faɪv pipəl bɪfɔɹ i wɑz oʊvɝkʌm."

"That means you kept it for ten years. You have my commiseration on the loss of your wife, and of your son, though he died bravely and well. Few men will enter a burning building once. He saved five people before he was overcome."

kɛɹidz θɹoʊt taɪɾənd. ʃi hæd fɑloʊd nuz ə hɪm. ɔl i kəd də wɑz baʊ əɡɛn, mɔɹ dipli.

Karede's throat tightened. She had followed news of him. All he could do was bow again, more deeply.

"ɪnʌf ə ðæt," kɔθən mʌɾɝd. "jɔɹ gɑnə nɑk jəɹ hɛɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪf jə kip ðəɾ ʌp. əz sun əz ʃi ən sɪlutʃə kən ɡɛt ðɛɹ θɪŋz təɡɛðɝ, jə teɪk əm aʊɾ ə hɪɹ ən ɹaɪd hɑɹd. tælmɑnz, ɹs ðə bænd. ɪɾ ɪzən ðəɾ aɪ doʊn tʃɹʌs ju, kɛɹid, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk əl slip iziɝ bɪɑn ðə nɛɹoʊz."

"Enough of that," Cauthon muttered. "You're going to knock your head on the ground if you keep that up. As soon as she and Selucia can get their things together, you take them out of here and ride hard. Talmanes, roust the Band. It isn't that I don't trust you, Karede, but I think I'll sleep easier beyond the Narrows."

"meɪtʃɹim kɔθən ɪz maɪ hʌzbənd," ðə haɪ leɪɾi sɛɾ ɪn ə laʊd, klɪɹ vɔɪs. ɛvɹiwʌn fɹoʊz wɛɹ ðeɪ stʊd. "meɪtʃɹim kɔθən ɪz maɪ hʌzbənd."

"Matrim Cauthon is my husband," the High Lady said in a loud, clear voice. Everyone froze where they stood. "Matrim Cauthon is my husband."

kɛɹid fɛlt əz ɪf hɑɹɾə hæd kɪkt ɪm əɡɛn. noʊ, nɑt hɑɹɾə. ɑldəzɑɹ. wʌt mædnəs wɑz ðɪs? kɔθən lʊk laɪk ə mæn wɑtʃɪŋ ən æɹoʊ flaɪ təwɔɹɾ ɪz feɪs, noʊɪŋ i hæd noʊ tʃæns tə dɑdʒ.

Karede felt as if Hartha had kicked him again. No, not Hartha. Aldazar. What madness was this? Cauthon looked like a man watching an arrow fly toward his face, knowing he had no chance to dodge.

"blʌɾi meɪtʃɹim kɔθən ɪz maɪ hʌzbənd. ðəɾ ɪz ðə wɝɾɪŋ jə juzd, ɪz ɪt nɑt?"

"Bloody Matrim Cauthon is my husband. That is the wording you used, is it not?"

ðɪs hæd tə bi ə fivɝ-dʒɹim.

This had to be a fever-dream.

ɪt tʊk ə mɪnət bɪfɔɹ mæt kəd spik. bɝn hɪm, ɪt sim tə teɪk ə blʌɾi aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ i kəd muv. wən i kʊd, hi snætʃt ɔf ɪz hæt, stʃɹoʊd tə tuɑn ən siz ðə ɹeɪzɝz bɹaɪɾəl. ʃi lʊk daʊn ət hɪm, kul əz ɛni kwin ɑn ə blʌɾi θɹoʊn. ɔl ðoʊz bæɾəlz wɪð ðə fleɪmɪŋ daɪs ɹætlɪŋ əweɪ ɪn ɪz hɛd, ɔl ðoʊz skɝmɪʃɪz ən ɹeɪdz, ən ðeɪ hæd tə stɑp wən ʃi sɛɾ ə fju wɝdz. wɛl, ət lis ðɪs taɪm i nu wʌt hæd hæpən ðət wɑz blʌɾi feɪtfəl fəɹ mæt blʌɾi kɔθən. "waɪ? aɪ min, aɪ nu jə wɝ gɑnə sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, bʌt waɪ naʊ? aɪ laɪk ju, meɪbi mɔɹ ðən laɪk ju, ən aɪ ɛndʒɔɪ kɪsɪŋ ju," hi θɔt kɛɹid ɡɹʌntɪd, "bʌt jə hævən bɪheɪv laɪk ə wʊmən ɪn lʌv. jəɹ aɪs hæf ðə taɪm ən spɛn moʊst ə ðə ɹɛs dɪɡɪŋ ʌndɝ maɪ skɪn."

It took a minute before Mat could speak. Burn him, it seemed to take a bloody hour before he could move. When he could, he snatched off his hat, strode to Tuon and seized the razor's bridle. She looked down at him, cool as any queen on a bloody throne. All those battles with the flaming dice rattling away in his head, all those skirmishes and raids, and they had to stop when she said a few words. Well, at least this time he knew what had happened that was bloody fateful for Mat bloody Cauthon. "Why? I mean, I knew you were going to sooner or later, but why now? I like you, maybe more than like you, and I enjoy kissing you," he thought Karede grunted, "but you haven't behaved like a woman in love. You're ice half the time and spend most of the rest digging under my skin."

"lʌv?" tuɑn saʊndəd sɝpɹaɪzd. "pɝhæps wɪl kʌm tə lʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ, meɪtʃɹim, bʌɾ aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz noʊn aɪ wəd mɛɹi tə sɝv ði ɛmpaɪɝ. wʌt dʒju min, jə nu ðəɾ aɪ wɑz gɑnə spik ðə wɝdz?"

"Love?" Tuon sounded surprised. "Perhaps we will come to love one another, Matrim, but I have always known I would marry to serve the Empire. What do you mean, you knew that I was going to speak the words?"

"kɔl mi mæt." oʊnli hɪz mʌðɝ hæɾ ɛvɝ kɔld ɪm meɪtʃɹim, wən i wɑz ɪn tʃɹʌbəl, ən ɪz sɪstɝz wən ðeɪ wɝ kæɹiɪŋ teɪlz tə ɡɛɾ ɪm ɪn tʃɹʌbəl.

"Call me Mat." Only his mother had ever called him Matrim, when he was in trouble, and his sisters when they were carrying tales to get him in trouble.

"jɔɹ neɪm ɪz meɪtʃɹim. wʌd jə min?"

"Your name is Matrim. What did you mean?"

hi saɪd. ðə wʊmən nɛvɝ wɑntəd mʌtʃ. dʒʌst əɹ oʊn weɪ. laɪk dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɛvɹi ʌðɝ wʊmən i hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn. "aɪ wɛn θɹu ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil tə sʌmwɛɹ ɛls, ənʌðɝ wɝl meɪbi. ðə pipəl ðəɹ ɑɹən ɹɪli pipəl - ðeɪ lʊk laɪk sneɪks - bʌt ðəl ænsɝ θɹi kwɛstʃənz fəɹ ju, ən ðɛɹ ænsɝz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz tʃɹu. wʌn ə maɪn wɑz ðəɾ aɪd mɛɹi ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. bʌt jə hævən ænsɝd maɪ kwɛstʃən. waɪ naʊ?"

He sighed. The woman never wanted much. Just her own way. Like just about every other woman he had ever known. "I went through a ter'angreal to somewhere else, another world maybe. The people there aren't really people - they look like snakes - but they'll answer three questions for you, and their answers are always true. One of mine was that I'd marry the Daughter of the Nine Moons. But you haven't answered my question. Why now?"

ə feɪn smaɪl ɑn əɹ lɪps, tuɑn lin daʊn fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl. ən ɹæpt ɪm hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə tɑp ə hɪz hɛd wɪð əɹ nʌkəlz! "jɔɹ supɝstɪʃənz ɑɹ bæɾ ɪnʌf, meɪtʃɹim, bʌɾ aɪ woʊn tɑlɝeɪt laɪz. ən əmjuzɪŋ laɪ, tʃɹu, bʌt stɪl ə laɪ."

A faint smile on her lips, Tuon leaned down from her saddle. And rapped him hard on the top of his head with her knuckles! "Your superstitions are bad enough, Matrim, but I won't tolerate lies. An amusing lie, true, but still a lie."

"ɪts ðə laɪts oʊn tʃɹuθ," hi pɹətɛstəd, klæpɪŋ ɪz hæɾ ɑn. meɪbi ɪt wəd ɡɪv ɪm səm pɹətɛkʃən. "ju kəd lɝn fəɹ jɝsɛlf ɪf jə kəd meɪk jɝsɛlf tɔk tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ kəd tɛl jə əbaʊt ði æɛlfɪn ən ði ɛlfɪn."

"It's the Light's own truth," he protested, clapping his hat on. Maybe it would give him some protection. "You could learn for yourself if you could make yourself talk to an Aes Sedai. They could tell you about the Aelfinn and the Eelfinn."

"ɪt kəd bi ðə tʃɹuθ," idɛzinə paɪpt ʌp əz ɪf ʃi wɝ biɪŋ hɛlpfəl. "ði æɛlfɪn kən bi ɹitʃt θɹu ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ, soʊ aɪ ʌndɝstænd, ən səpoʊzədli ðeɪ ɡɪv tʃɹu ænsɝz." mæt ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɝ. ə fæt lɑɾ ə hɛlp ʃi wɑz, wɪð əɹ "soʊ aɪ ʌndɝstænz" ən "səpoʊzliz." tuɑn kəntɪnjud tə stɛɹ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf idɛzinə hæd nɑɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ.

"It could be the truth," Edesina piped up as if she were being helpful. "The Aelfinn can be reached through a ter'angreal in the Stone of Tear, so I understand, and supposedly they give true answers." Mat glared at her. A fat lot of help she was, with her "so I understands" and "supposedlies." Tuon continued to stare at him as if Edesina had not opened her mouth.

"aɪ ænsɝd jəɹ kwɛstʃən, tuɑn, soʊ jə ænsɝ maɪn."

"I answered your question, Tuon, so you answer mine."

"ju noʊ ðət deɪmeɪn kən tɛl fɔɹtʃənz?" ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə stɝn lʊk, laɪkli ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɪm tə kɔl ɪt supɝstɪʃən, bʌɾ i nɑɾəd kɝtli. səm ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd fɔɹtɛl ðə fjutʃɝ. waɪ nɑɾ ə deɪmeɪn? "aɪ æsk lɪdʒjə tə tɛl maɪn dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ aɪ lændəɾ əɾ ɛbu dɑɹ. ðɪs ɪz wʌt ʃi sɛd. 'bɪwɛɹ ðə fɑks ðət meɪks ðə ɹeɪvənz flaɪ, fəɹ hɪl mɛɹi jə ən kæɹi jə əweɪ. bɪwɛɹ ðə mæn u ɹɪmɛmbɝz hɔkwɪŋz feɪs, fəɹ hɪl mɛɹi jə ən sɛt jə fɹi. bɪwɛɹ ðə mæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd, fəɹ ɪm jəl mɛɹi ən nʌn ʌðɝ.' ɪt wɑz jəɹ ɹɪŋ ðət kɑt maɪ aɪ fɝst." hi θʌm ðə lɔŋ ɹɪŋ ʌnkɑnʃəsli, ən ʃi smaɪld. ə smɔl smaɪl, bʌɾ ə smaɪl. "ə fɑks əpɛɹənli stɑɹtlɪŋ tu ɹeɪvənz ɪndə flaɪɾ ən naɪn kɹɛsən munz. sədʒɛstɪv, wʊdn jə seɪ? ən dʒʌs naʊ jə fʊlfɪl ðə sɛkən pɑɹt, soʊ aɪ nu fəɹ sɝɾən ɪt wɑz ju." sɪlutʃə meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, ən tuɑn wæɡəl fɪŋɡɝz ət hɝ. ðə boʊsəmi lɪɾəl wʊmən səbsaɪɾɪd, ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ hɛd skɑɹf, bʌt ðə lʊk ʃi ʃɑɾ ət mæt ʃʊɾə bɪn əkʌmpənid baɪ ə dæɡɝ ɪn əɹ hænd.

"You know that damane can tell fortunes?" She gave him a stern look, likely expecting him to call it superstition, but he nodded curtly. Some Aes Sedai could Foretell the future. Why not a damane? "I asked Lidya to tell mine just before I landed at Ebou Dar. This is what she said. 'Beware the fox that makes the ravens fly, for he will marry you and carry you away. Beware the man who remembers Hawkwing's face, for he will marry you and set you free. Beware the man of the red hand, for him you will marry and none other.' It was your ring that caught my eye first." He thumbed the long ring unconsciously, and she smiled. A small smile, but a smile. "A fox apparently startling two ravens into flight and nine crescent moons. Suggestive, wouldn't you say? And just now you fulfilled the second part, so I knew for certain it was you." Selucia made a sound in her throat, and Tuon waggled fingers at her. The bosomy little woman subsided, adjusting her head scarf, but the look she shot at Mat should have been accompanied by a dagger in her hand.

hi læf mɝθləsli. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz. ðə ɹɪŋ wɑz ə kɑɹvɝz tʃɹaɪ-pis, bɑɾ oʊnli kəz ɪt stʌk ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝ; hi wəd ɡɪv ʌp ðoʊz mɛmɹiz ə hɔkwɪŋz feɪs əlɔŋ wɪð ɛvɹi ʌðɝ oʊl mɛmɹi, ɪf ɪt wəd ɡɛt ðə blʌɾi sneɪks aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd; ən jɛt ðoʊz θɪŋz hæd ɡeɪn ɪm ə waɪf. ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd wəd nɛvɝ əv ɪɡzɪstəd wɪθaʊt ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz ə bæɾəlz.

He laughed mirthlessly. Blood and bloody ashes. The ring was a carver's try-piece, bought only because it stuck on his finger; he would give up those memories of Hawkwing's face along with every other old memory, if it would get the bloody snakes out of his head; and yet those things had gained him a wife. The Band of the Red Hand would never have existed without those old memories of battles.

"simz tə mi biɪŋ tɑvɝən wɝks ɑn mi əz mʌtʃ əz ɪt dʌz ɑn ɛnibəɾi ɛls." fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi θɔt ʃi wɑz gɑnə ɹæp ɪm əɡɛn. hi ɡeɪv əɹ ɪz bɛst smaɪl. "wʌn mɔɹ kɪs bɪfɔɹ jə liv?"

"Seems to me being ta'veren works on me as much as it does on anybody else." For a moment, he thought she was going to rap him again. He gave her his best smile. "One more kiss before you leave?"

"aɪm nɑɾ ɪn ðə muɾ ət ðə moʊmənt," ʃi sɛd kuli. ðət hæŋɪŋ mædʒəstʃɹeɪt wɑz bæk. ɔl pɹɪznɝz tə bi kəndɛmd ɪmiɾiətli. "pɝhæps leɪɾɝ. jə kəd ɹɪtɝn tə ɛbu dɑɹ wɪð mi. juv ən ɑnɝd pleɪs ɪn ði ɛmpaɪɝ, naʊ."

"I'm not in the mood at the moment," she said coolly. That hanging magistrate was back. All prisoners to be condemned immediately. "Perhaps later. You could return to Ebou Dar with me. You have an honored place in the Empire, now."

hi dɪd nɑt hɛzəteɪt bɪfɔɹ ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɑnɝd pleɪs weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ laɪlwɪn əɹ doʊmən, noʊ pleɪs əɾ ɔl fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ ðə bænd. "ðə nɛks taɪm aɪ si sintʃæn, aɪ ɪkspɛkt ɪɾəl bi ɑn ðə fil sʌmwɛɹ, tuɑn." bɝn hɪm, ɪt wəd bi. hɪz laɪf sim tə ɹʌn ðət weɪ noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ i dɪd. "jɔɹ nɑt maɪ ɛnəmi, bʌt jəɹ ɛmpaɪɝ ɪz."

He did not hesitate before shaking his head. There was no honored place waiting for Leilwin or Domon, no place at all for the Aes Sedai or the Band. "The next time I see Seanchan, I expect it will be on the field somewhere, Tuon." Burn him, it would be. His life seemed to run that way no matter what he did. "You're not my enemy, but your Empire is."

"nɔɹ ɑɹ jə maɪ ɛnəmi, hʌzbənd," ʃi sɛd kuli, "bʌɾ aɪ lɪv tə sɝv ði ɛmpaɪɝ."

"Nor are you my enemy, husband," she said coolly, "but I live to serve the Empire."

"wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz jud bɛɾɝ ɡɛt jəɹ θɪŋz. . . ." hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf ət ðə saʊn ʌv ə kæntɝɪŋ hɔɹs əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ.

"Well, I suppose you'd better get your things. . . ." He trailed off at the sound of a cantering horse approaching.

veɪnɪn ɹeɪn ɪn ə ɹeɪnʒi ɡɹeɪ bɪsaɪd tuɑn, aɪd kɛɹiɾ ən ði ʌðɝ dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, ðən spæt θɹu ə ɡæp ɪn ɪz tiθ ən lin ɑn ðə haɪ pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl. "ðɛɹz tɛn θaʊzən əɹ soʊ soʊlʒɝz əɾ ə lɪɾəl taʊn əbaʊt faɪv maɪlz wɛst ə hɪɹ," ðə fæt mæn toʊl mæt. "oʊnli wʌn mæn sintʃæn, nɪɹ əz aɪ kəd lɝn. ɹɛst ɑɹ ɔltɑɹənz, tæɹɑbənɝz, ɑmɑdɪʃənz. ɔl maʊntəd. θɪŋ ɪz, ðəɹ æskɪŋ æftɝ fɛloʊz wɛɹɪŋ ɑɹmɝ laɪk ðæt." hi nɑɾəd təwɔɹd kɛɹid. "æn ɹumɝ sɛz ðə wʌn ə ðɛm ðət kɪlz ə ɡɝl ðət saʊnz ə lɑt laɪk ðə haɪ leɪɾi ɡɛts hɪmsɛlf ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən kɹaʊnz ɡoʊld. ðɛɹ maʊðz ɑɹ dʒɹɪpɪŋ fəɹ ɪt."

Vanin reined in a rangy gray beside Tuon, eyed Karede and the other Deathwatch Guards, then spat through a gap in his teeth and leaned on the high pommel of his saddle. "There's ten thousand or so soldiers at a little town about five miles west of here," the fat man told Mat. "Only one man Seanchan, near as I could learn. Rest are Altarans, Taraboners, Amadicians. All mounted. Thing is, they're asking after fellows wearing armor like that." He nodded toward Karede. "And rumor says the one of them that kills a girl that sounds a lot like the High Lady gets himself a hundred thousand crowns gold. Their mouths are dripping for it."

"aɪ kən slɪp pæs ðɛm," kɛɹid sɛd. hɪz blʌf feɪs lʊk fɑðɝli. hɪz vɔɪs saʊndəd laɪk ə dʒɹɔn sɔɹd.

"I can slip past them," Karede said. His bluff face looked fatherly. His voice sounded like a drawn sword.

"æn ɪf jə kænt?" mæt æskt kwaɪətli. "ɪt kæn bi tʃæns ðəɹ ðɪs kloʊs. ðeɪv kɑt səm snɪf ə ju. wʌn mɔɹ smɛl maɪt bi ɔl ɪt teɪks tə kɪl tuɑn." kɛɹidz feɪs dɑɹkənd.

"And if you can't?" Mat asked quietly. "It can't be chance they're this close. They've caught some sniff of you. One more smell might be all it takes to kill Tuon." Karede's face darkened.

"du jə ɪntɛn tə ɡoʊ bæk ɑn jəɹ wɝd?" ə dʒɹɔn bleɪd ðət maɪt bi juz sun. wɝs, tuɑn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ, lʊkɪŋ ət mæt laɪk ðət hæŋɪŋ mædʒəstʃɹeɪɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ. bɝn hɪm, ɪf ʃi daɪd, sʌmθɪŋ wəd ʃɹɪvəl ʌp ɪnsaɪd hɪm. ən ði oʊnli weɪ tə stɑp ɪt, tə bi ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz stɑpt, wɑz tə də wʌɾ i heɪɾəd wɝs ðən wɝk. wʌns, hi hæd θɔt ðət faɪɾɪŋ bæɾəlz, mʌtʃ əz i heɪɾəd ɪt, wɑz stɪl bɛɾɝ ðən wɝk. nɪɹ ɪnʌf naɪn hʌnʒɹəd dɛɾ ɪn ðə speɪs ʌv ə fju deɪz hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪz maɪnd.

"Do you intend to go back on your word?" A drawn blade that might be used soon. Worse, Tuon was watching, looking at Mat like that hanging magistrate in truth.
