Burn him, if she died, something would shrivel up inside him. And the only way to stop it, to be sure it was stopped, was to do what he hated worse than work. Once, he had thought that fighting battles, much as he hated it, was still better than work. Near enough nine hundred dead in the space of a few days had changed his mind.

"noʊ," hi sɛd. "ʃi ɡoʊz wɪð ju. bʌt jə liv mi ə dʌzən ə jəɹ dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz ən səm ə ðə ɡɑɹɾənɝz. ɪf aɪm gɑnə teɪk ðiz pipəl ɔf jəɹ bæk, aɪ niɾ əm tə θɪŋk aɪm ju."

"No," he said. "She goes with you. But you leave me a dozen of your Deathwatch Guards and some of the Gardeners. If I'm going to take these people off your back, I need them to think I'm you."

tuɑn əbændən moʊst ə ðə kloʊðɪŋ meɪtʃɹim hæd bɑt fəɹ hɝ, sɪns ʃi wəd nid tə tʃɹævəl laɪt. ðə lɪɾəl klʌstɝ ə ɹɛd sɪlk ɹoʊzbʊdz i hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ʃi tʌkt əweɪ ɪn əɹ sæɾəlbæɡz, foʊldəɾ ɪn ə lɪnən klɔθ, əz kɛɹfəli əz ɪf ɪt wɝ bloʊn ɡlæs. ʃi hæd noʊ fɛɹwɛlz tə meɪk ɪksɛp fəɹ mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən - ʃi ɹɪli wəd mɪs ðɛɹ dɪskʌʃənz - soʊ ʃi ən sɪlutʃə wɝ ɹɛɾi tə ɹaɪd kwɪkli. maɪələn smaɪl soʊ bɹɔdli ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ ðət ʃi hæd tə pæt ðə lɪɾəl deɪmeɪn. ɪt sim ðət wɝɾ ʌv wʌt hæd hæpən hæd spɹɛd, kəz əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd θɹu ðə kæmp wɪð ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, mɛn ə ðə bæn stʊɾ ən baʊd tə hɝ. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi laɪk ɹivjuɪŋ ɹɛdʒəməns ɪn sindɑɹ.

Tuon abandoned most of the clothing Matrim had bought for her, since she would need to travel light. The little cluster of red silk rosebuds he had given her she tucked away in her saddlebags, folded in a linen cloth, as carefully as if it were blown glass. She had no farewells to make except for Mistress Anan - she really would miss their discussions - so she and Selucia were ready to ride quickly. Mylen smiled so broadly at the sight of her that she had to pat the little damane. It seemed that word of what had happened had spread, because as they rode through the camp with the Deathwatch Guards, men of the Band stood and bowed to her. It was very like reviewing regiments in Seandar.

"wʌt dʒju meɪk ə hɪm?" ʃi æskt kɛɹid wʌns ðeɪ wɝ əweɪ fɹəm ðə soʊlʒɝz ən bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə kæntɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə seɪ wɪtʃ "hi" ʃi mɛnt.

"What do you make of him?" she asked Karede once they were away from the soldiers and beginning to canter. There was no need to say which "he" she meant.

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt maɪ pleɪs tə meɪk dʒʌdʒməns, haɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd ɡɹeɪvli. hɪz hɛd swɪvɛld, kipɪŋ wɑtʃ ɑn ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ tʃɹiz. "aɪ sɝv ði ɛmpaɪɝ ən ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ."

"It is not my place to make judgments, High Lady," he said gravely. His head swivelled, keeping watch on the surrounding trees. "I serve the Empire and the Empress, may she live forever."

"æz də wi ɔl, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl. bʌɾ aɪ æsk jəɹ dʒʌdʒmənt."

"As do we all, Banner-General. But I ask your judgment."

"ə ɡʊd dʒɛnɝəl, haɪ leɪɾi," hi ɹɪplaɪd wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən. "bɹeɪv, bʌt nɑɾ oʊvɝli bɹeɪv. hi woʊnt ɡɛt hɪmsɛlf kɪl dʒʌs tə ʃoʊ haʊ bɹeɪv i ɪz, aɪ θɪŋk. ən hiz . . . ədæptəbəl. ə mæn ə mɛni leɪɝz. ən ɪf jəl fɝɡɪv mi, haɪ leɪɾi, ə mæn ɪn lʌv wɪð ju. aɪ sɔ haʊ hi lʊkt ət ju."

"A good general, High Lady," he replied without hesitation. "Brave, but not overly brave. He won't get himself killed just to show how brave he is, I think. And he is . . . adaptable. A man of many layers. And if you will forgive me, High Lady, a man in love with you. I saw how he looked at you."

ɪn lʌv wɪð hɝ? pɝhæps. ʃi θɔt ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə kʌm tə lʌv hɪm. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd lʌvd əɹ fɑðɝ, ɪt wɑz sɛd. ən ə mæn ə mɛni leɪɝz? meɪtʃɹim kɔθən meɪɾ ən ʌnjən lʊk laɪk ən æpəl! ʃi ɹʌbd ə hæn oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd. ʃi stɪl wɑz nɑɾ əkʌstəm tə ðə fil ə hɛɹ ɑn əɹ hɛd. "aɪ wɪl niɾ ə ɹeɪzɝ fɝs θɪŋ."

In love with her? Perhaps. She thought she might be able to come to love him. Her mother had loved her father, it was said. And a man of many layers? Matrim Cauthon made an onion look like an apple! She rubbed a hand over her head. She still was not accustomed to the feel of hair on her head. "I will need a razor first thing."

"ɪt meɪ bi bɛs tə weɪɾ əntɪl ɛbu dɑɹ, haɪ leɪɾi."

"It may be best to wait until Ebou Dar, High Lady."

"noʊ," ʃi sɛd dʒɛnli. "ɪf aɪ daɪ, əl daɪ əz u aɪ æm. aɪ hæv ɹimuv ðə veɪl."

"No," she said gently. "If I die, I will die as who I am. I have removed the veil."

"æz jə seɪ, haɪnəs." smaɪlɪŋ, hi səluɾəd, ɡɔntələɾəd fɪst stʃɹaɪkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz hɑɹt hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf ðət stil klæŋd ɑn stil. "ɪf wi daɪ, wɪl daɪ əz u wi ɑɹ."

"As you say, Highness." Smiling, he saluted, gauntleted fist striking over his heart hard enough that steel clanged on steel. "If we die, we will die as who we are."

tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɛvən

CHAPTER 37

pɹɪns ə ðə ɹeɪvənz linɪŋ ɑn ðə tɔl pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl, æʃhændʒɹeɪ slæntəɾ əkɹɔs pɪps' nɛk, mæt fɹaʊn ət ðə skaɪ. ðə sʌn wɑz wɛl pæst ɪts nun haɪt. ɪf veɪnɪn ən ðoʊz dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz dɪd nɑt ɹɪtɝn sun, hi maɪt faɪn hɪmsɛlf faɪɾɪŋ ə bæɾəl wɪð ðə sʌn ɪn ðə kɹɔsboʊmənz aɪz, əɹ wɝs, ɪn twaɪlaɪt. wɝst ʌv ɔl, dɑɹk klaʊdz lumd oʊvɝ ðə maʊntənz tə ði ist. ðə ɡʌstɪŋ wɪnd wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə nɔɹθ. noʊ hɛlp ðɛɹ. ɹeɪn wəd pʊt ðə wizəl ɪn ðə hɛn jɑɹd. bɑstʃɹɪŋz fɛɹd pʊɹli ɪn ɹeɪn. wɛl, ɛni ɹeɪn wɑz ə fju aʊɝz ɔf, wɪð lʌk, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ noʊɾəst ɪz lʌk seɪvɪŋ ɪm fɹəm ɡɛɾɪŋ soʊkt ɪn ə daʊnpɔɹ. hi hæd nɑt dɛɹd weɪɾ əntɪl təmɑɹoʊ. ðoʊz fɛloʊz hʌntɪŋ tuɑn maɪɾ əv ɡɑɾən ənʌðɝ wɪf ə kɛɹidz mɛn, ən ðən i wʊɾə hæd tə tʃɹaɪ ətækɪŋ ðɛm, əɹ leɪɪŋ ən æmbʊʃ, ən kæɹi ɪɾ aʊt bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd kætʃ kɛɹid. bɛɾɝ tə hæv əm kʌm tə hɪm, əɾ ə pleɪs ə hɪz tʃuzɪŋ. faɪndɪŋ ðə pɹɑpɝ spɑt hæd nɑt bɪn dɪfəkəlt, bɪtwin mæstɝ ɹɔɪdɛlz kəlɛkʃən ə mæps ɑn ðə wʌn hæn ən veɪnɪn ən ði ʌðɝ skaʊts ɑn ði ʌðɝ.

Prince of the Ravens Leaning on the tall pommel of his saddle, ashandarei slanted across Pips' neck, Mat frowned at the sky. The sun was well past its noon height. If Vanin and those Deathwatch Guards did not return soon, he might find himself fighting a battle with the sun in the crossbowmen's eyes, or worse, in twilight. Worst of all, dark clouds loomed over the mountains to the east. The gusting wind was out of the north. No help there. Rain would put the weasel in the hen yard. Bowstrings fared poorly in rain. Well, any rain was a few hours off, with luck, but he had never noticed his luck saving him from getting soaked in a downpour. He had not dared wait until tomorrow. Those fellows hunting Tuon might have gotten another whiff of Karede's men, and then he would have had to try attacking them, or laying an ambush, and carry it out before they could catch Karede. Better to have them come to him, at a place of his choosing. Finding the proper spot had not been difficult, between Master Roidelle's collection of maps on the one hand and Vanin and the other scouts on the other.

ɑlʌdʒɹə wɑz fʌsɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌn ə hɝ tɔl, mɛɾəl-baʊnd lɑftɪŋ tubz, biɾɪd bɹeɪdz haɪɾɪŋ əɹ feɪs əz ʃi ɪɡzæmən sʌmθɪŋ ət ðə bɹɔd wʊɾən beɪs. hi wɪʃt ʃi hæd bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə ɹɪmeɪn wɪð ðə pæk ænəməlz laɪk tɑm ən mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən. ivən noʊl hæd bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə steɪ, ɪf oʊnli tə hɛlp dʒulɪn ən æməðɛɹə meɪk ʃʊɹ oʊlvɝ dɪd nɑt ɹʌn ɔf tə wɑtʃ ðə bæɾəl. ðə bɔɪ wɑz dɛɾ iɡɝ, wɪtʃ kəd sun lɛd tə pleɪn dɛd. mæɾɝz hæd bɪn bæɾ ɪnʌf wən oʊnli hɑɹnən ən ði ʌðɝ θɹi hæd bɪn kɝʌptɪŋ oʊlvɝ, bʌt naʊ hi hæd hæf ðə mɛn titʃɪŋ ɪm haʊ tə juz ə sɔɹɾ əɹ dæɡɝ əɹ faɪt wɪð ɪz hænz ən fit, ən əpɛɹənli fɪlɪŋ ɪz hɛd wɪð teɪlz ə hɪɹoʊz fɹəm ðə weɪ hi hæd bɪn bɪheɪvɪŋ, bɛɡɪŋ tə ɡoʊ ɑn ɹeɪdz wɪð mæt ən ðə laɪk. ɑlʌdʒɹə wɑz nɪɹ əz bæd. ɛnibəɾi cʊɾə juzd wʌn ə ðoʊz stʃɹaɪkɝz tə laɪt ðə fjuz wʌns ʃi hæd loʊɾəd ðət tub, bʌt ʃi ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn duɪŋ ɪt hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɑz ə fɪɹs wʊmən, ɑlʌdʒɹə wɑz, ən nʌn tu plizd ət faɪndɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə seɪm saɪɾ əz sintʃæn, haʊɛvɝ tɛmpɝɛɹi ði ɝeɪnʒmənt wɑz. ɪt simd ɹɔŋ tə hɝ ðət ðeɪ wəd si səm ə hɝ hændiwɝk wɪθaʊt biɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹəsivɪŋ ɛnd. laɪlwɪn ən doʊmən sæt ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz nɪɹbaɪ kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn hɝ, əz mʌtʃ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi dɪd nʌθɪŋ fulɪʃ əz tə pɹətɛk hɝ. mæt hoʊp laɪlwɪn dɪd nʌθɪŋ fulɪʃ hɝsɛlf. sɪns ðəɹ wɑz əpɛɹənli oʊnli wʌn sintʃæn wɪð ðə pipəl ðeɪ wəd faɪt tədeɪ, ʃi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz ɔl ɹaɪt tə bi ðɛɹ, ən ðə weɪ ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət mjuzənʒ ən ði ʌðɝ dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, ɪt simd ʃi maɪt θɪŋk ʃi hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə pɹuv tə ðɛm.

Aludra was fussing over one of her tall, metal-bound lofting tubes, beaded braids hiding her face as she examined something at the broad wooden base. He wished she had been willing to remain with the pack animals like Thom and Mistress Anan. Even Noal had been willing to stay, if only to help Juilin and Amathera make sure Olver did not run off to watch the battle. The boy was dead eager, which could soon lead to plain dead. Matters had been bad enough when only Harnan and the other three had been corrupting Olver, but now he had half the men teaching him how to use a sword or dagger or fight with his hands and feet, and apparently filling his head with tales of heroes from the way he had been behaving, begging to go on raids with Mat and the like. Aludra was near as bad. Anybody could have used one of those strikers to light the fuse once she had loaded that tube, but she insisted on doing it herself. She was a fierce woman, Aludra was, and none too pleased at finding herself on the same side as Seanchan, however temporary the arrangement was. It seemed wrong to her that they would see some of her handiwork without being on the receiving end. Leilwin and Domon sat their horses nearby keeping an eye on her, as much to make sure she did nothing foolish as to protect her. Mat hoped Leilwin did nothing foolish herself. Since there was apparently only one Seanchan with the people they would fight today, she had decided it was all right to be there, and the way she glared at Musenge and the other Deathwatch Guards, it seemed she might think she had something to prove to them.

ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ, stændɪŋ təɡɛðɝ wɪð ðɛɹ ɹeɪnz ɪn hænd, kæs dɑɹk lʊks ət ðə sintʃæn, tu, əz dɪd blɹɪk ən fɛn, hu kɝɛs ðɛɹ sɔɹd hɪls pɝhæps ʌnkɑnʃəsli. dʒoʊlin ən əɹ tu wɔɹɾɝz hæd bɪn ði oʊnli wʌnz əɡæst ət ʃɛɝeɪnz wɪlɪŋ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ wɪð tuɑn - wʌɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fɛlt ɑn ɛni sʌbʒɪkt wɑz juʒəwəli haʊ hɝ wɔɹɾɝz fɛlt ɑn ɪt, tu - bʌt ðə mɛmɹi ʌv biɪŋ liʃt hæd tə bi tu fɹɛʃ fəɹ idɛzinə əɹ tɛslɪn tə fil kʌmftəɹbəl ɝaʊn sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz. bɛθəmən ən sɛɾə stʊd vɛɹi mikli, hænz foʊldəɾ ət ðɛɹ weɪsts, ə lɪɾəl əpɑɹt fɹəm ðə sɪstɝz. bɛθəmənz laɪt-kʌlɝd beɪ nʌdʒd əɹ ʃoʊldɝ wɪð ɪz noʊz, ən ðə tɔl, dɑɹk wʊmən hæf ɹitʃt ʌp tə stʃɹoʊk ði ænəməl bɪfɔɹ snætʃɪŋ əɹ hæn bæk daʊn ən ɹɪzumɪŋ əɹ hʌmbəl poʊz. ðeɪ stɪl wəd teɪk noʊ pɑɹt. dʒoʊlin ən idɛzinə hæd meɪd ðət pleɪn, jɛɾ ɪt sim ðeɪ wɑntəd ðə tu wɪmən ʌndɝ ðɛɹ aɪz tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. ðə sintʃæn wɪmən pleɪnli wɝ lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt ðə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, bɛθəmən, sɛɾə ən laɪlwɪn maɪɾ əz wɛl nɑɾ əv ɪɡzɪstəd fəɹ ɔl ə mjuzənʒ ən ðət lɑt. bɝn hɪm, ðəɹ wɝ soʊ mɛni tɛntʃənz ɪn ði ɛɹ i kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ðət hæŋɪŋ ɹoʊp ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk əɡɛn.

The three Aes Sedai, standing together with their reins in hand, cast dark looks at the Seanchan, too, as did Blaeric and Fen, who caressed their sword hilts perhaps unconsciously. Joline and her two Warders had been the only ones aghast at Sheraine's willing departure with Tuon - what an Aes Sedai felt on any subject was usually how her Warders felt on it, too - but the memory of being leashed had to be too fresh for Edesina or Teslyn to feel comfortable around Seanchan soldiers. Bethamin and Seta stood very meekly, hands folded at their waists, a little apart from the sisters. Bethamin's light-colored bay nudged her shoulder with his nose, and the tall, dark woman half reached up to stroke the animal before snatching her hand back down and resuming her humble pose. They still would take no part. Joline and Edesina had made that plain, yet it seemed they wanted the two women under their eyes to make sure of it. The Seanchan women plainly were looking at anything but the Seanchan soldiers. For that matter, Bethamin, Seta and Leilwin might as well not have existed for all of Musenge and that lot. Burn him, there were so many tensions in the air he could almost feel that hanging rope around his neck again.

pɪps stæmpt ə huf, ɪmpeɪʃən ət stændɪŋ ɪn wʌn pleɪs soʊ lɔŋ, ən mæt pæɾəd ɪz nɛk ðən skɹætʃt ðə skɑɹ fɔɹmɪŋ ɑn ɪz oʊn dʒɔ. tuɑnz ɔɪnmənts hæd stʌŋ əz bædli əz ʃi hæd sɛd ðeɪ wʊd, bʌt ðeɪ wɝkt. hɪz nu kəlɛkʃən ə skɑɹz dɪɾ ɪtʃ jɛt, ðoʊ. tuɑn. hɪz waɪf. hi wɑz mɛɹid! hi hæd noʊn ɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ, hæd noʊn fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, bʌt dʒʌs ðə seɪm. . . . mɛɹid. hi ʃʊɾə fɛlt . . . dɪfɹənt . . . sʌmhaʊ, bʌɾ i stɪl fɛlt laɪk hɪmsɛlf. hi ɪntɛndəd tə kip ɪt ðət weɪ, bɝn ɪm ɪf i dɪd nɑt! ɪf tuɑn ɪkspɛktəd mæt kɔθən tə sɛɾəl daʊn, tə ɡɪv ʌp ɡæmbəlɪŋ əɹ səm sʌtʃ, ʃi hæɾ ənʌðɝ θɪŋk kʌmɪŋ. hi səpoʊzd i wəɾ əv tə ɡɪv oʊvɝ tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ wɪmən, mʌtʃ lɛs kætʃɪŋ ðɛm, bʌɾ i wəd stɪl ɛndʒɔɪ dænsɪŋ wɪð ðɛm. ən lʊkɪŋ ət ðɛm. dʒʌs nɑt wən i wɑz wɪð hɝ. bɝn ɪm ɪf i nu wən ðət wəd bi. hi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ɡoʊ ɛniwɛɹ ʃi hæd ði ʌpɝ hænd, hɝ ən əɹ tɔk ə kʌbɛɹɝz ən ɹʌnɪŋ ɡɹumz ən mɛɹiɪŋ tə sɝv ði ɛmpaɪɝ. haʊ wɑz mɛɹiɪŋ ɪm səpoʊz tə sɝv ðə fleɪmɪŋ ɛmpaɪɝ?

Pips stamped a hoof, impatient at standing in one place so long, and Mat patted his neck then scratched the scar forming on his own jaw. Tuon's ointments had stung as badly as she had said they would, but they worked. His new collection of scars did itch yet, though. Tuon. His wife. He was married! He had known it was coming, had known for a long time, but just the same. . . . Married. He should have felt . . . different . . . somehow, but he still felt like himself. He intended to keep it that way, burn him if he did not! If Tuon expected Mat Cauthon to settle down, to give up gambling or some such, she had another think coming. He supposed he would have to give over chasing after women, much less catching them, but he would still enjoy dancing with them. And looking at them. Just not when he was with her. Burn him if he knew when that would be. He was not about to go anywhere she had the upper hand, her and her talk of cupbearers and running grooms and marrying to serve the Empire. How was marrying him supposed to serve the flaming Empire?

mjuzənʒ lɛf ði ʌðɝ tɛn mɛn ən faɪv oʊɡiɝ ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-blæk ɑɹmɝ ən tʃɹɑɾəd ɪz blæk ɡɛldɪŋ ʌp tə mæt. ðə hɔɹs hæd ɡʊd laɪnz, bɪl fəɹ spiɾ ən ɛndɝəns boʊθ, əz fɑɹ əz mæt kəd tɛl wɪθaʊɾ ə θɝoʊ ɪɡzæməneɪʃən. mjuzənʒ lʊk bɪl fəɹ ɛndɝəns, ə stɑki, stɑləd mæn, hɪz feɪs wɔɹn bʌt hɑɹd, hɪz aɪz laɪk pɑlɪʃt stoʊnz. "fɝɡɪvnəs, haɪnəs," hi dʒɹɔld, bæŋɪŋ ə ɡɔntələɾəd fɪst əɡɛnst ɪz bɹɛstpleɪt, "bʌt ʃʊdn ðə mɛn bi bæk tə wɝk?" hi slɝɾ ɪz wɝdz wɝs ðən sɪlutʃə, ɔlmoʊs tə ʌnɪntɛlədʒəbɪlɪɾi. "ðɛɹ ɹɛs bɹeɪk əz stʃɹɛtʃt ə lɔŋ taɪm. aɪ daʊt ðeɪ kən kəmplit ðə wɔl bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹeɪɾɝ ɝaɪvz əz ɪɾ ɪz." mæt hæd wʌndɝd haʊ lɔŋ ɪt wəd teɪk ɪm tə mɛnʃən ðæt. hi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪɾ ɝliɝ.

Musenge left the other ten men and five Ogier in red-and-black armor and trotted his black gelding up to Mat. The horse had good lines, built for speed and endurance both, as far as Mat could tell without a thorough examination. Musenge looked built for endurance, a stocky, stolid man, his face worn but hard, his eyes like polished stones. "Forgiveness, Highness," he drawled, banging a gauntleted fist against his breastplate, "but shouldn't the men be back to work?" He slurred his words worse than Selucia, almost to unintelligibility. "Their rest break has stretched a long time. I doubt they can complete the wall before the traitor arrives as it is." Mat had wondered how long it would take him to mention that. He had expected it earlier.

oʊpən-feɪs hɛlməts ɔf bʌt bɹɛstpleɪts stʃɹæpt ɑn, ðə kɹɔsboʊmən wɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪhaɪn ə lɔŋ kɝvɪŋ wɔl, pɝhæps ə θɝɾ ʌv ə sɝkəl meɪɾ ə ɝθ θɹoʊn ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹ-fʊt-dip tʃɹɛntʃ fɹʌntɪŋ ɪt, wɪð ə θɪkɪɾ ə ʃɑɹpən steɪks dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðəɾ ən ɪkstɛndɪŋ ə lɪɾəl bɪɑn ði ɛnz ə ðə tʃɹɛntʃ. ðeɪ hæd fɪnɪʃt ðəɾ ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ. ɪnfəntʃɹi niɾəd tə bi əz hændi wɪð ʃʌvəl, mætɑk ən æks əz ðeɪ wɝ wɪð wɛpənz. ivən kævəlɹi dɪd, bʌt meɪkɪŋ hɔɹsmən bɪliv wɑz hɑɹɾɝ. fʊtmən nu ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ tə hæv sʌmθɪŋ bɪtwin jə ən ði ɛnəmi ɪf jə kʊd. ðə tulz leɪ skæɾɝd əlɔŋ ðə tʃɹɛntʃ, naʊ. səm ə ðə mɛn wɝ dɪsɪŋ, ʌðɝz dʒʌs teɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ iz, ivən næpɪŋ. soʊlʒɝz slɛpt ɛni tʃæns ðeɪ ɡɑt. ə fju wɝ ɹiɾɪŋ bʊks, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz. ɹɛɾɪŋ! mændəvwɪn muvd əmʌŋ ðɛm, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ɪz aɪpætʃ ən naʊ ən ðən bɛndɪŋ tə seɪ ə fju wɝdz tə ə bænɝmən. ði oʊnli lænsɝ pɹɛzənt, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz hɔɹs, ɛvɹi laɪn ə hɪm seɪɪŋ i hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə kɹɔsboʊmən, hɛl noʊ læns, bʌt ɹæðɝ ə lɔŋ bænɝ-stæf keɪs fəɹ hæf ɪts lɛŋθ ɪn lɛðɝ.

Open-faced helmets off but breastplates strapped on, the crossbowmen were sitting on the ground behind a long curving wall, perhaps a third of a circle made of earth thrown up out of the four-foot-deep trench fronting it, with a thicket of sharpened stakes driven into the ground in front of that and extending a little beyond the ends of the trench. They had finished that in short order. Infantry needed to be as handy with shovel, mattock and axe as they were with weapons. Even cavalry did, but making horsemen believe was harder. Footmen knew it was better to have something between you and the enemy if you could. The tools lay scattered along the trench, now. Some of the men were dicing, others just taking their ease, even napping. Soldiers slept any chance they got. A few were reading books, of all things. Reading! Mandevwin moved among them, fingering his eyepatch and now and then bending to say a few words to a bannerman. The only lancer present, standing beside his horse, every line of him saying he had nothing to do with the crossbowmen, held no lance, but rather a long banner-staff cased for half its length in leather.

ɪt wɑz pɝfək tɝeɪn fəɹ wʌt mæt hæɾ ɪn maɪnd. nɪɹ tu maɪlz ʌv ɡɹæsi mɛdoʊ dɑɾəd wɪð waɪldflaʊɹz ən ə fju loʊ bʊʃəz stʃɹɛtʃt fɹəm ðə wɔl tə ðə tɔl tʃɹiz ət ðə wɛstɝn ɛnd. tə ðə nɔɹθ wɑz ə blækwɔɾɝ swɑmp, fʊl ʌv oʊks ən ɑd, waɪt-flaʊɝɪŋ tʃɹiz ðət sim hæf θɪk ɹuts, wɪð ə leɪk klɪŋɪŋ tə ɪts wɛstɝn ɛdʒ ən fɔɹəs bɪloʊ ðə leɪk. ə smɔl ɹɪvɝ floʊd saʊθ aʊɾ ə ðə swɑmp, hæf ə maɪl bɪhaɪn mæt, bɪfɔɹ kɝvɪŋ əweɪ tə ðə wɛst ɑn ɪz lɛft. ə smɔl ɹɪvɝ, bʌt waɪɾ ɪnʌf ən dip ɪnʌf ðət hɔɹsəz wəɾ əv tə swɪm ɪt. ðə fɑɹ bæŋk leɪ bɪɑn baʊʃɑt. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ fəɹ ɛni ətækɝ tə ɡɛɾ ət ðə wɔl. kʌm stʃɹeɪt fəɹ ɪt.

It was perfect terrain for what Mat had in mind. Near two miles of grassy meadow dotted with wildflowers and a few low bushes stretched from the wall to the tall trees at the western end. To the north was a blackwater swamp, full of oaks and odd, white-flowering trees that seemed half thick roots, with a lake clinging to its western edge and forest below the lake. A small river flowed south out of the swamp, half a mile behind Mat, before curving away to the west on his left. A small river, but wide enough and deep enough that horses would have to swim it. The far bank lay beyond bowshot. There was only one way for any attacker to get at the wall. Come straight for it.

"wɛn ðeɪ ɝaɪv, aɪ doʊnt wɑn əm stɑpɪŋ tə kaʊn haʊ mɛni mɛn ɪn ɹɛɾ ən blæk ɑɹ hɪɹ," hi ɹɪplaɪd. mjuzənʒ wɪnst slaɪtli fəɹ səm ɹizən. "aɪ wɑn əm tə si ən ənfɪnɪʃt wɔl ən tulz θɹoʊn daʊn kəz wi lɝn ðeɪ wɝ kloʊz. ðə pɹɑməs ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən kɹaʊnz ɡoʊld əz tə hæv ðɛɹ blʌɾ ʌp, bʌɾ aɪ wɑn əm tu ɪksaɪɾəd tə θɪŋk stʃɹeɪt. ðəl si əs vʌlnɝəbəl, əɹ dɪfɛnsəz ɪnkəmplit, ən wɪð ɛni lʌk, ðəl ɹʌʃ ɪn stʃɹeɪɾ əweɪ. ðəl fɪɡjɝ kloʊs tə hæf ə ðɛm wɪl daɪ wən wi lus, bʌt ðət wɪl dʒʌst ɹeɪz ðə tʃænsəz fəɹ wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz tə ɡɛt ðət ɡoʊld. ðəl oʊnli ɪkspɛkt əs tə mænədʒ wʌn vɑli." hi slæpt ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ, ən pɪps ʃɪftəd. "ðɛn ðə tʃɹæp kloʊzɪz."

"When they arrive, I don't want them stopping to count how many men in red and black are here," he replied. Musenge winced slightly for some reason. "I want them to see an unfinished wall and tools thrown down because we learned they were close. The promise of a hundred thousand crowns gold has to have their blood up, but I want them too excited to think straight. They'll see us vulnerable, our defenses incomplete, and with any luck, they'll rush in straight away. They'll figure close to half of them will die when we loose, but that will just raise the chances for one of the others to get that gold. They'll only expect us to manage one volley." He slapped his hands together, and Pips shifted. "Then the trap closes."

"stɪl, haɪnəs, aɪ wɪʃ wi hæd mɔɹ ə jəɹ kɹɔsboʊmən. aɪv hɝd jə meɪ hæv əz mɛni əz θɝɾi θaʊzənd." mjuzənʒ hæd hɝɾ ɪm tɛl tuɑn i wəd faɪt ðə sintʃæn, tu. ðə mæn wɑz pɹoʊbɪŋ fəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən.

"Still, Highness, I wish we had more of your crossbowmen. I've heard you may have as many as thirty thousand." Musenge had heard him tell Tuon he would fight the Seanchan, too. The man was probing for information.

"aɪ hæv fjuɝ ðən aɪ dɪd," mæt sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs. hɪz vɪktɝiz hæd hɑɹdli bɪn blʌdləs, oʊnli ɹɪmɑɹkəbli kloʊs tə ɪt. nɪɹ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd kɹɔsboʊmən leɪ ɪn ɔltɑɹən ɡɹeɪvz, ən kloʊs tə faɪv hʌnʒɹəd ə ðə kævəlɹi. ə smɔl ɪnʌf bʊtʃɝz bɪl, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ, jɛɾ i laɪkt ɪt bɛst wən ðə bʊtʃɝ pɹizɛntəd noʊ bɪl. "bʌt wʌɾ aɪ hæv ɪz ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə deɪ."

"I have fewer than I did," Mat said with a grimace. His victories had hardly been bloodless, only remarkably close to it. Near four hundred crossbowmen lay in Altaran graves, and close to five hundred of the cavalry. A small enough butcher's bill, considering, yet he liked it best when the butcher presented no bill. "But what I have is enough for the day."

"æz jə seɪ, haɪnəs." mjuzənʒəz vɔɪs wɑz soʊ nutʃɹəl i cʊɾə bɪn kɑmɛntɪŋ ɑn ðə pɹaɪs ə binz. stʃɹeɪnʒ. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk laɪk ə dɪfəɾənt mæn. "aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz bɪn ɹɛɾi tə daɪ fəɹ hɝ." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ ɪm tə seɪ wɪtʃ "hɝ" hi mɛnt.

"As you say, Highness." Musenge's voice was so neutral he could have been commenting on the price of beans. Strange. He did not look like a diffident man. "I have always been ready to die for her." There was no need for him to say which "her" he meant.

"aɪ ɡɛs aɪ æm, tu, mjuzənʒ." laɪt, hi θɔɾ i mɛn ðæt! jɛs, hi dɪd min ɪt. dɪd ðət min i wɑz ɪn lʌv? "bɛɾɝ tə lɪv fəɹ hɝ, ðoʊ, wʊdn jə seɪ?"

"I guess I am, too, Musenge." Light, he thought he meant that! Yes, he did mean it. Did that mean he was in love? "Better to live for her, though, wouldn't you say?"

"ʃʊd jə nɑt bi dɑnɪŋ jəɹ ɑɹmɝ, haɪnəs?"

"Should you not be donning your armor, Highness?"

"aɪ doʊn ɪntɛnd ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ðə faɪɾɪŋ tə niɾ ɑɹmɝ. ə dʒɛnɝəl u dʒɹɔz ɪz sɔɹɾ əz pʊɾ əsaɪɾ ɪz bətɑn ən bɪkʌm ə kɑmən soʊlʒɝ."

"I don't intend getting close enough to the fighting to need armor. A general who draws his sword has put aside his baton and become a common soldier."

hi wɑz oʊnli kwoʊɾɪŋ koʊmædʒɹɪn əɡɛn - hi sim tə də ðəɾ ə lɑt wən dɪskʌsɪŋ soʊlʒɝɪŋ, bʌt ðɛn, ðə mæn hæd noʊn dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðəɹ wɑz tə noʊ əbaʊt ðə kɹæft - dʒʌs kwoʊɾɪŋ, jɛɾ ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə ɪmpɹɛs ðə wɛðɝd mæn, hu səluɾəd ɪm əɡɛn ən æsk blʌɾi pɝmɪʃən bɪfɔɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ bæk tə hɪz mɛn. mæt wɑz tɛmptəd tə æsk wʌt ðət "haɪnəs" fulɪʃnəs wɑz əbaʊt. laɪkli ɪt wɑz dʒʌst səm sintʃæn weɪ ʌv kɔlɪŋ ɪm ə lɔɹd, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt hɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ɪɾ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ən i hæd bɪn sɝaʊndəd baɪ sintʃæn ðɛɹ.

He was only quoting Comadrin again - he seemed to do that a lot when discussing soldiering, but then, the man had known just about everything there was to know about the craft - just quoting, yet it appeared to impress the weathered man, who saluted him again and asked bloody permission before riding back to his men. Mat was tempted to ask what that "Highness" foolishness was about. Likely it was just some Seanchan way of calling him a lord, but he had not heard anything like it in Ebou Dar, and he had been surrounded by Seanchan there.

faɪv fɪɡjɝz əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹəst ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə mɛdoʊ, ən i dɪd nɑt niɾ ə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs tə noʊ ðɛm. ðə tu oʊɡiɝ ɪn ɑɹmɝ stʃɹaɪp bɹaɪt ɹɛɾ ən blæk wʊɾə toʊld ɪm ivən ɪf veɪnɪnz bʌlk hæd nɑt. ðə maʊntəd mɛn wɝ əɾ ə flæt ɡæləp, jɛt ði oʊɡiɝ kɛpt peɪs, lɔŋ ɑɹmz swɪŋɪŋ, æksiz swɪŋɪŋ laɪk ə sɔmɪlz dʒɹaɪv-ʃæft.

Five figures appeared out of the forest at the foot of the meadow, and he did not need a looking glass to know them. The two Ogier in armor striped bright red and black would have told him even if Vanin's bulk had not. The mounted men were at a flat gallop, yet the Ogier kept pace, long arms swinging, axes swinging like a sawmill's drive-shaft.

"slɪŋ-mɛn ɡɛt ɹɛɾi!" mæt ʃaʊɾəd. "ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls ɡoʊ pɪk ʌp ə ʃʌvəl!" ði əpɪɹəns hæd tə bi dʒʌst ɹaɪt.

"Sling-men get ready!" Mat shouted. "Everybody else go pick up a shovel!" The appearance had to be just right.

əz moʊst ə ðə kɹɔsboʊmən skæɾɝd tə pɪk ʌp tulz ən meɪk ə ʃoʊ ʌv wɝkɪŋ ɑn ðə tʃɹɛntʃ ən wɔl, fɪfti ʌðɝz stʃɹæpt ɑn ðɛɹ hɛlməts ən laɪn ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɑlʌdʒɹə. tɔl mɛn, ðeɪ stɪl kæɹid ðə ʃɔɹtsɝdz ðeɪ kɔl kæt-ɡʌɾɝz, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə kɹɔsboʊz, ðeɪ wɝ ɑɹmd wɪð fɔɹ-fʊt-lɔŋ slɪŋ-stæfs. hi wʊɾə laɪk mɔɹ ðən fɪfti, bʌɾ ɑlʌdʒɹə oʊnli hæd soʊ mʌtʃ ə hɝ paʊɾɝz. itʃ mæn wɔɹ ə klɔθ bɛl soʊn wɪð pɑkəts slʌŋ əkɹɔs ɪz bɹɛstpleɪt, ən itʃ pɑkət hɛld ə stʌbi lɛðɝ sɪləndɝ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə mænz fɪst wɪð ə ʃɔɹt lɛŋθ ə dɑɹk fjuz stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɛnd. ɑlʌdʒɹə hæd nɑt kʌm ʌp wɪð ə fænsi neɪm fəɹ əm jɛt. ʃi wʊd, ðoʊ. ʃi wɑz wʌn fəɹ fænsi neɪmz. dʒɹæɡənz, ən dʒɹæɡənz' ɛɡz.

As most of the crossbowmen scattered to pick up tools and make a show of working on the trench and wall, fifty others strapped on their helmets and lined up in front of Aludra. Tall men, they still carried the shortswords they called cat-gutters, but instead of crossbows, they were armed with four-foot-long sling-staffs. He would have liked more than fifty, but Aludra only had so much of her powders. Each man wore a cloth belt sewn with pockets slung across his breastplate, and each pocket held a stubby leather cylinder larger than a man's fist with a short length of dark fuse sticking out of the end. Aludra had not come up with a fancy name for them yet. She would, though. She was one for fancy names. Dragons, and dragons' eggs.

wʌn baɪ wʌn ðə mɛn hɛld ʌp lɔŋ pisəz ə sloʊ-mætʃ fəɹ əɹ tə laɪt wɪð ə stʃɹaɪkɝ. ʃi dɪɾ ɪt kwɪkli, juzɪŋ itʃ stʃɹaɪkɝ əntɪl ðə lɔŋ wʊɾən stɪk hæd bɝn daʊn nɪɹli tə hɝ fɪŋɡɝtɪps, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ wɪnst, dʒʌs dʒɹɑp ðə θɪŋ ən lɪɾ ənʌðɝ waɪl tɛlɪŋ ðə slɪŋ-mɛn tə bi fæstɝ, ʃi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ loʊ ɑn stʃɹaɪkɝz. laɪt, bʌt ʃi wɑz taɪt wɪð ðə θɪŋz. ʃi hæd faɪv mɔɹ bɑksəz ðət mæt nu ʌv. əz itʃ mæn tɝn əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, hi pʊt ðə smoʊkɪŋ sloʊ-mætʃ bɪtwin ɪz tiθ ən sɪkjʊɹd wʌn ə ðə sɪləndɝz tə hɪz slɪŋ-stæf əz i wɔk tə ðə wɔl. ðəɹ wɝ waɪɾ ɪntɝvəlz bɪtwin slɪŋ-mɛn. ðeɪ hæd tə kʌvɝ ðə hoʊl lɛŋθ ə ðə wɔl.

One by one the men held up long pieces of slow-match for her to light with a striker. She did it quickly, using each striker until the long wooden stick had burned down nearly to her fingertips, but she never winced, just dropped the thing and lit another while telling the sling-men to be faster, she was getting low on strikers. Light, but she was tight with the things. She had five more boxes that Mat knew of. As each man turned away from her, he put the smoking slow-match between his teeth and secured one of the cylinders to his sling-staff as he walked to the wall. There were wide intervals between sling-men. They had to cover the whole length of the wall.

"taɪm tə ɡɛt jəɹ pipəl ɪn pleɪs, mjuzənʒ," mæt sɛd laʊdli.

"Time to get your people in place, Musenge," Mat said loudly.

ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz fɔɹmd ə sɪŋɡəl laɪn əbɹɛst wɪð ðə ɡɑɹɾənɝz ɑn ði ɛnd. ɛnibəɾi hu tʊk wʌn ɡlæns θɹu ə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs wəd noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ. laɪt, ɔl ðeɪ niɾəd wɑz tə si oʊɡiɝ ɪn ɑɹmɝ ən ðə sʌn ɡlɪntɪŋ ɔf ɔl ðət ɹɛɾ ən blæk. ən ɪf ðeɪ stɑp tə θɪŋk haʊ fju ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdz ðəɹ wɝ, ðeɪ wəd stɪl si ðeɪ hæd mæt aʊtnʌmbɝd, ən ðəɹ wəd bi oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə faɪn aʊt wɛðɝ tuɑn wɑz wɪð hɪm.

The Deathwatch Guards formed a single line abreast with the Gardeners on the end. Anybody who took one glance through a looking glass would know what they were. Light, all they needed was to see Ogier in armor and the sun glinting off all that red and black. And if they stopped to think how few of the Guards there were, they would still see they had Mat outnumbered, and there would be only one way to find out whether Tuon was with him.

veɪnɪn ɡæləp bɪhaɪn ðə wɔl, flʌŋ hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl ən ɪmiɾiətli bɪɡæn wɔkɪŋ ɪz læðɝd dʌn tə kul ði ænəməl daʊn. əz sun əz i pæs ðə wɔl, kɹɔsboʊmən bɪɡæn dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðə tulz ən ɹʌnɪŋ tə pʊɾ ɑn hɛlməts ən pɪk ʌp kɹɔsboʊz. ðoʊz hæd bɪn leɪd soʊ ðət ðə mɛn fɔɹm θɹi speɪst ɹæŋks wɪð ɡæps wɛɹ ðə slɪŋ-mɛn stʊd. ɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ mæɾɝd ɪf ɛniwʌn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ fɹəm ðə fɔɹəst. wʌt ðeɪ sɔ wəd sim nætʃɹəl.

Vanin galloped behind the wall, flung himself out of the saddle and immediately began walking his lathered dun to cool the animal down. As soon as he passed the wall, crossbowmen began dropping the tools and running to put on helmets and pick up crossbows. Those had been laid so that the men formed three spaced ranks with gaps where the sling-men stood. It no longer mattered if anyone was watching from the forest. What they saw would seem natural.

mæt tʃɹɑɾəd pɪps tə veɪnɪn ən dɪsmaʊntɪd. ðə tu hjumən dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz ən ðə tu oʊɡiɝ wɛn tə dʒɔɪn ði ʌðɝz. ðə hɔɹsəz' nɑstʃɹəlz flɛɹd wɪð ðɛɹ hɛvi bɹiðɪŋ, bʌt ði oʊɡiɝ wɝ pæntɪŋ noʊ hɑɹɾɝ. wʌn wɑz hɑɹɾə, ə stoʊn-aɪd fɛloʊ hu əpɛɹənli ɹæŋk vɛɹi kloʊs tə mjuzənʒ.

Mat trotted Pips to Vanin and dismounted. The two human Deathwatch Guards and the two Ogier went to join the others. The horses' nostrils flared with their heavy breathing, but the Ogier were panting no harder. One was Hartha, a stone-eyed fellow who apparently ranked very close to Musenge.

veɪnɪn skaʊld ət ðə mɛn u hæd nɑt ɡɑɾən daʊn tə wɔk ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. ə hɔɹsɛθif i maɪt bi, ɹɪfɔɹmd əɹ nɑt, bʌɾ i dɪslaɪk mɪstʃɹiɾɪŋ hɔɹsflɛʃ. "ðeɪ wɛn ʌp laɪk wʌn ə hɝ naɪtfloʊɝz wən ðeɪ ɡlɪmpst ʌs," hi sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɑlʌdʒɹə. "wi meɪd ʃʊɹ ðeɪ ɡɑɾ ə ɡʊd lʊk ət ðət fænsi ɑɹmɝ, ðən haɪ-teɪld ɪɾ əz sun əz ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd ɡɛɾɪŋ maʊntəd. ðəɹ kʌmɪŋ hɑɹd bɪhaɪn ʌs. hɑɹɾɝ ðən ðeɪ ʃʊd." hi spæɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "aɪ dɪdnt ɡɛɾ ə ɡʊd lʊk ət ðɛɹ ænəməlz, bʌɾ aɪ daʊt ðəɹ ɔl ɡʊd fəɹ ðət ɹʌn. sʌməl faʊndɝ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɡɛt hɪɹ."

Vanin scowled at the men who had not gotten down to walk their horses. A horsethief he might be, reformed or not, but he disliked mistreating horseflesh. "They went up like one of her nightflowers when they glimpsed us," he said, nodding toward Aludra. "We made sure they got a good look at that fancy armor, then high-tailed it as soon as they started getting mounted. They're coming hard behind us. Harder than they should." He spat on the ground. "I didn't get a good look at their animals, but I doubt they're all good for that run. Some'll founder before they get here."

"ðə mɔɹ ðə bɛɾɝ," mæt sɛd. "ðə fjuɝ u meɪk ɪt, ðə bɛɾɝ ɪn maɪ bʊk." ɔl i niɾəd wɑz tə ɡɪv tuɑn ə deɪ əɹ tu hɛd stɑɹɾ ɑn ðɛm, ən ɪf ðət keɪm fɹəm ðɛɹ ɹuɪnɪŋ hɔɹsəz, ɪf ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz ən dɪsaɪɾɪd i hæd tu mɛni mɛn tə teɪk ɑn, hi wəd teɪk ðəɾ oʊvɝ ə bæɾəl ɛni deɪ. æftɝ tədeɪz sɪks-maɪl ɡæləp, ðeɪ wəd nid tə ɹɛs ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ə fju deɪz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ fɪt tə tʃɹævəl ɛni dɪstəns əɾ ɔl. veɪnɪn dɝɛktəd ðət skaʊl ət hɪm. ʌðɝz maɪt ɡoʊ ɝaʊn kɔlɪŋ ɪm maɪ lɔɹɾ ən haɪnəs, bʌt nɑt tʃəl veɪnɪn.

"The more the better," Mat said. "The fewer who make it, the better in my book." All he needed was to give Tuon a day or two head start on them, and if that came from their ruining horses, if they rode out of the trees and decided he had too many men to take on, he would take that over a battle any day. After today's six-mile gallop, they would need to rest their horses a few days before they were fit to travel any distance at all. Vanin directed that scowl at him. Others might go around calling him my Lord and Highness, but not Chel Vanin.

mæt læft ən klæpt ɪm ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ bɪfɔɹ swɪŋɪŋ bæk ɪndə pɪps' sæɾəl. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd ðəɹ wɑz sʌmwʌn u dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i wɑz ə ful noʊbəl, əɹ ət list, dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑɾ i wɑz. hi ɹoʊd tə dʒɔɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, hu wɝ maʊntəd naʊ.

Mat laughed and clapped him on the shoulder before swinging back into Pips' saddle. It was good there was someone who did not think he was a fool noble, or at least, did not care whether or not he was. He rode to join the Aes Sedai, who were mounted now.

blɹɪk ən fɛn, ðə wʌn ɑn ə beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ, ði ʌðɝ ɑn ə blæk, ɡeɪv ɪm stɛɹz ɔlmoʊst əz dɑɹk əz ðoʊz ðeɪ hæd dɝɛktəɾ ət mjuzənʒ. ðeɪ stɪl səspɛktəɾ i hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð wʌt hæd hæpən tə dʒoʊlin. hi θɔɾ ə tɛlɪŋ fɛn ðəɾ ɪz stʌb ʌv ə tɑpnɑt lʊkt ɹɪdɪkjələs. fɛn ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl ən stʃɹoʊkt ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. ðən əɡɛn, meɪbi nɑt.

Blaeric and Fen, the one on a bay gelding, the other on a black, gave him stares almost as dark as those they had directed at Musenge. They still suspected he had something to do with what had happened to Joline. He thought of telling Fen that his stub of a topknot looked ridiculous. Fen shifted in his saddle and stroked his sword hilt. Then again, maybe not.

". . . . wʌɾ aɪ toʊl ju," dʒoʊlin wɑz tɛlɪŋ bɛθəmən ən sɛɾə, ʃeɪkɪŋ ən ædmənətɔɹi fɪŋɡɝ. hɝ dɑɹk beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ lʊkt ə wɔɹhɔɹs, bʌt wɑz nɑt. ði ænəməl hæɾ ə ɡʊd tɝn ə spid, jɛɾ ɪts tɛmpɹəmənt wɑz maɪld əz mɪlk-wɔɾɝ. "ɪf jə ivən θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ, jəl ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt."

". . . . what I told you," Joline was telling Bethamin and Seta, shaking an admonitory finger. Her dark bay gelding looked a warhorse, but was not. The animal had a good turn of speed, yet its temperament was mild as milk-water. "If you even think about embracing saidar, you'll regret it."

tɛslɪn ɡɹʌntɪd saʊɝli. ʃi pæɾəd əɹ waɪt-feɪs tʃɛsnʌt mɛɹ, ə mʌtʃ mɔɹ faɪsti kɹitʃɝ ðən dʒoʊlinz maʊnt, ən spoʊk tə ði ɛɹ. "ʃi dʌz tʃɹeɪn waɪldɝz ən ɪkspɛks əm tə bɪheɪv wʌns aʊɾ ə hɝ saɪt. əɹ pɝhæps ʃi dʌz θɪŋk ðə taʊɝ wɪl æksɛpt oʊvɝ-eɪdʒ nɑvəsɪz." spɑts ə kʌlɝ əpɪɹɾ ɪn dʒoʊlinz tʃiks, bʌt ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪn əɹ sæɾəl wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ. əz juʒəwəl wən ðoʊz tu ɡɑɾ ɪndə ə kɑnflɪkt, idɛzinə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, ɪn ðɪs keɪs bɹʌʃɪŋ ɪmædʒənɛɹi dʌs fɹəm əɹ dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts. ɪnʌf tɛnʃən tə tʃoʊk ɑn.

Teslyn grunted sourly. She patted her white-faced chestnut mare, a much more feisty creature than Joline's mount, and spoke to the air. "She does train wilders and expects them to behave once out of her sight. Or perhaps she does think the Tower will accept over-age novices." Spots of color appeared in Joline's cheeks, but she straightened in her saddle without saying anything. As usual when those two got into a conflict, Edesina concentrated on something else, in this case brushing imaginary dust from her divided skirts. Enough tension to choke on.

sʌɾənli ɹaɪɾɝz pɔɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə mɛdoʊ ɪn ə tɔɹən ðət swɛld ɪndə ə spɹɛɾɪŋ leɪk ə stil-tɪp lænsɪz əz ðeɪ dʒɹu ɹeɪn, noʊ daʊɾ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz ət wʌt leɪ bɪfɔɹ ðɛm. ɪt sim ðət nɑɾ əz mɛni hɔɹsəz hæd faʊndɝɾ əz mæt hæd hoʊp fɔɹ. pʊlɪŋ ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs fɹəm ɪts skæbɝd taɪd tə hɪz sæɾəlz pɑməl, hi ɹeɪzd ɪt tə hɪz aɪ. ðə tæɹɑbənɝz wɝ izi tə pɪk aʊt, wɪð meɪl veɪlz haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz tə ði aɪz, bʌt ði ʌðɝz wɔɹ ɛvɹi sɔɹɾ ə hɛlmət, ɹaʊndəɾ əɹ kɑnɪkəl, wɪð feɪs-bɑɹz ən wɪθaʊt. hi ivən sɔ ə fju ɹɪdʒ tɛɹən hɛlməts, ðoʊ ðət dɪd nɑt min ðəɹ wɝ tɛɹənz əmʌŋ ðɛm. moʊs mɛn juzd wʌtɛvɝ ɑɹmɝ ðeɪ kəd faɪnd. doʊn θɪŋk, hi θɔt. ðə wʊmən ɪz hɪɹ. ðət hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzənd ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz ɪz weɪɾɪŋ. doʊn blʌɾi -  ə ʃɹɪl sintʃæn bjuɡəl saʊndəd, θɪn wɪð ðə dɪstəns, ən ðə hɔɹsmən bɪɡæn ədvænsɪŋ əɾ ə wɔk, ɔlɹɛɾi spɹɛɾɪŋ aʊt tə ɪkstɛn bɪɑn ðə wɔlz ɛdʒəz.

Suddenly riders poured out of the trees at the far end of the meadow in a torrent that swelled into a spreading lake of steel-tipped lances as they drew rein, no doubt in surprise at what lay before them. It seemed that not as many horses had foundered as Mat had hoped for. Pulling the looking glass from its scabbard tied to his saddle's pommel, he raised it to his eye. The Taraboners were easy to pick out, with mail veils hiding their faces to the eyes, but the others wore every sort of helmet, rounded or conical, with face-bars and without. He even saw a few ridged Tairen helmets, though that did not mean there were Tairens among them. Most men used whatever armor they could find. Don't think, he thought. The woman is here. That hundred thousand gold crowns is waiting. Don't bloody -  A shrill Seanchan bugle sounded, thin with the distance, and the horsemen began advancing at a walk, already spreading out to extend beyond the wall's edges.

"ənkeɪs ðə bænɝ, mækəl," mæt ɔɹɾɝd. soʊ ðiz fleɪmɪŋ sʌnz ʌv ɡoʊts θɔt ðeɪ wɝ kʌmɪŋ tə mɝɾɝ tuɑn, dɪd ðeɪ? "ðɪs taɪm, wɪl lɛɾ əm noʊ huz kɪlɪŋ ðɛm. mændəvwɪn, juv ðə kəmænd."

"Uncase the banner, Macoll," Mat ordered. So these flaming sons of goats thought they were coming to murder Tuon, did they? "This time, we'll let them know who's killing them. Mandevwin, you have the command."

mændəvwɪn tɝn ɪz beɪ tə feɪs fɹʌnt. "stæn ɹɛɾi!" hi ʃaʊɾəd, ən ʌndɝ-ɔfəsɝz ən bænɝmɪn ɛkoʊd ðə kɹaɪ.

Mandevwin turned his bay to face front. "Stand ready!" he shouted, and under-officers and bannermen echoed the cry.

mækəl pʊl ðə lɛðɝ keɪs ɔf, kɛɹfəli fæsənɪŋ ɪt tə hɪz sæɾəl, ən ðə bænɝ stʃɹimd ɑn ðə wɪnd, ə ɹɛd-fɹɪnd waɪt skwɛɹ wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ, oʊpən ɹɛd hæn ɪn ðə sɛntɝ, ən bɪniθ ɪt, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ɹɛd, ðə wɝdz doʊvjndi saʊθis tɑvjə sɑɡən. ɪts taɪm tə tɔs ðə daɪs, mæt θɔt, tʃɹænzleɪɾɪŋ. ən soʊ ɪt wɑz. hi sɔ mjuzənʒ aɪɪŋ ɪt. hi sim vɛɹi kɑm fəɹ ə mæn wɪð tɛn θaʊzən lænsɪz kʌmɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm.

Macoll pulled the leather case off, carefully fastening it to his saddle, and the banner streamed on the wind, a red-fringed white square with a large, open red hand in the center, and beneath it, embroidered in red, the words Dovie'andi se tovya sagain. It's time to toss the dice, Mat thought, translating. And so it was. He saw Musenge eyeing it. He seemed very calm for a man with ten thousand lances coming toward him.

"ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi, ɑlʌdʒɹə?" mæt kɔld.

"Are you ready, Aludra?" Mat called.

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪm ɹɛɾi," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ oʊnli wɪʃ aɪ hæd maɪ dʒɹæɡənz!" mjuzənʒ ʃɪftəɾ ɪz ətɛnʃən tə hɝ. bɝn hɝ, ʃi niɾəd tə wɑtʃ əɹ tʌŋ! mæt wɑntəd ðoʊz dʒɹæɡənz tə bi ə ʃɑk wən ðə sintʃæn fɝs feɪs ðɛm.

"Of course I am ready," she replied. "I only wish I had my dragons!" Musenge shifted his attention to her. Burn her, she needed to watch her tongue! Mat wanted those dragons to be a shock when the Seanchan first faced them.

pɝhæps twɛlv hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə wɔl, ðə ɹæŋks ə lænsɝz bɪɡæn tə tʃɹɑt, ən ət sɪks hʌnʒɹəd ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə ɡæləp, bʌt nɑɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ maɪt hæv. ðoʊz hɔɹsəz wɝ taɪɝɾ æftɝ ə lɔŋ ɹʌn ɔlɹɛɾi. ðeɪ lʌmbɝd. nʌn ə ðə lænsɪz hæd kʌm daʊn, jɛt. ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əntɪl ðə læs hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz. səm ə ðoʊz kæɹid stʃɹimɝz ðət floʊɾəd bɪhaɪn əm ɪn ði ɛɹ, ə lɑɹdʒ nɑɾ ə ɹɛd hɪɹ, ə klʌmp ʌv ɡɹin əɹ blu ðɛɹ. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn haʊs kʌlɝz, əɹ pɝhæps ðeɪ mɑɹk mɝsənɛɹi kʌmpəniz. ɔl ðoʊz hʊvz meɪɾ ə nɔɪz laɪk dɪstən θʌndɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ.

Perhaps twelve hundred paces from the wall, the ranks of lancers began to trot, and at six hundred they began to gallop, but not as hard as they might have. Those horses were tired after a long run already. They lumbered. None of the lances had come down, yet. They would not until the last hundred paces. Some of those carried streamers that floated behind them in the air, a large knot of red here, a clump of green or blue there. They might have been House colors, or perhaps they marked mercenary companies. All those hooves made a noise like distant thunder rolling.

"ɑlʌdʒɹə!" mæt ʃaʊɾəd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk. ə hɑloʊ θʌmp ən ən ækɹɪd sʌlfɝ smɛl ənaʊns ðə lɑftɪŋ tub sɛndɪŋ ɪts naɪtfloʊɝ əlɔft, ən ə laʊd pɑp ðə blumɪŋ ʌv ə bɔl ə ɹɛd stʃɹiks oʊvɝhɛd. səm ə ðə ɡæləpɪŋ hɔɹsmən pɔɪntəd tə ɪɾ əz ɪf ɪn əmeɪzmənt. nʌn lʊk bɪhaɪn əm tə si tælmɑnz liɾɪŋ ðə θɹi bænɝz ə hɔɹs aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹəs bɪloʊ ðə leɪk. ðɛɹ lænsɪz hæd bɪn lɛft wɪð ðə pæk ænəməlz, bʌɾ ɛvɹi mæn wəɾ əv ɪz hɔɹsboʊ aʊt. spɹɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl laɪn, ðeɪ bɪɡæn fɑloʊɪŋ ðə ɡæləpɪŋ ɹaɪɾɝz, ɪnkɹisɪŋ spiɾ əz ðeɪ keɪm. ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz hæd bɪn ɹɪɾən fɑɹ læs naɪt, bʌt nɑt pɹɛs tu hɑɹd, ən ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɹɛstəɾ ɔl mɔɹnɪŋ. ðə dɪstəns bɪtwin ðə tu ɡɹups ə ɹaɪɾɝz bɪɡæn tə nɛɹoʊ.

"Aludra!" Mat shouted without looking back. A hollow thump and an acrid sulphur smell announced the lofting tube sending its nightflower aloft, and a loud pop the blooming of a ball of red streaks overhead. Some of the galloping horsemen pointed to it as if in amazement. None looked behind them to see Talmanes leading the three banners of horse out of the forest below the lake. Their lances had been left with the pack animals, but every man would have his horsebow out. Spreading out in a single line, they began following the galloping riders, increasing speed as they came. Their horses had been ridden far last night, but not pressed too hard, and they had been rested all morning. The distance between the two groups of riders began to narrow.

"fɹʌn ɹæŋk!" mændəvwɪn ʃaʊɾəd wən ðə hɔɹsmən wɝ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əweɪ. "lus!" əbʌv ə θaʊzən boʊls flæʃt aʊt, dɑɹk stʃɹiks ɪn ði ɛɹ. ɪmiɾiətli ðə fɹʌn ɹæŋk bɛn tə fæsən ðɛɹ kɹæŋks tə ðɛɹ kɹɔsboʊz ən ðə sɛkən ɹæŋk ɹeɪz ðɛɹ wɛpənz. "sɛkən ɹæŋk!" mændəvwɪn ʃaʊɾəd. "lus!" ənʌðɝ θaʊzən kwɔɹəlz stʃɹik fəɹ ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ hɔɹsmən.

"Front rank!" Mandevwin shouted when the horsemen were four hundred paces away. "Loose!" Above a thousand bolts flashed out, dark streaks in the air. Immediately the front rank bent to fasten their cranks to their crossbows and the second rank raised their weapons. "Second rank!" Mandevwin shouted. "Loose!" Another thousand quarrels streaked for the oncoming horsemen.

ət ðət ɹeɪnʒ, ðeɪ kəd nɑt pʌntʃ θɹu ə bɹɛstpleɪt dɪspaɪt hɛdz dɪzaɪn tə də dʒʌs ðæt, bʌt mɛn wɪð ʃæɾɝd lɛɡz tɑpəl fɹəm ðɛɹ sæɾəlz ən mɛn wɪð ɹuən ɑɹmz ɹeɪn ɪn fɹæntəkəli tə tʃɹaɪ stɛmɪŋ ðə floʊ ʌv blʌd. ən ðə hɔɹsəz. . . . ɑ, laɪt, ðə pʊɹ hɔɹsəz. hɔɹsəz fɛl baɪ ðə hʌnʒɹədz, səm kɪkɪŋ ən skɹimɪŋ, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə stænd, ʌðɝz nɑt muvɪŋ əɾ ɔl, mɛni ʌv əm tʃɹɪpɪŋ mɔɹ ænəməlz. kæɾəpʌltɪd ɹaɪɾɝz tʌmbəld əkɹɔs ðə mɛdoʊ ɡɹæs əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹæmpəl baɪ ðə ɹaɪɾɝz bɪhaɪnd.

At that range, they could not punch through a breastplate despite heads designed to do just that, but men with shattered legs toppled from their saddles and men with ruined arms reined in frantically to try stemming the flow of blood. And the horses. . . . Ah, Light, the poor horses. Horses fell by the hundreds, some kicking and screaming, struggling to stand, others not moving at all, many of them tripping more animals. Catapulted riders tumbled across the meadow grass until they were trampled by the riders behind.

"θɝd ɹæŋk! lus!" mændəvwɪn ʃaʊɾəd, ən əz sun əz ðoʊz boʊls wɝ əweɪ, ðə fɹʌn ɹæŋk stʃɹeɪɾənd. "fɹʌn ɹæŋk!" mændəvwɪn kɔld. "lus!" ən ənʌðɝ θaʊzən boʊls æɾəd tə ðə kɑɹnɪdʒ. "sɛkən ɹæŋk! lus!"

"Third rank! Loose!" Mandevwin shouted, and as soon as those bolts were away, the front rank straightened. "Front rank!" Mandevwin called. "Loose!" And another thousand bolts added to the carnage. "Second rank! Loose!"

ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ wʌn-saɪɾəd əz ən æmbʊʃ, ʌv kɔɹs. səm ə ðə ɡæləpɪŋ hɔɹsmən hæd flʌŋ daʊn ðɛɹ lænsɪz ən ənkeɪs ðɛɹ hɔɹsboʊz. æɹoʊz bɪɡæn tə fɔl əmʌŋ ðə kɹɔsboʊmən. ʃuɾɪŋ ækjɝətli fɹəm ə ɡæləpɪŋ hɔɹs wɑz noʊ izi tæsk, ən ðə ɹeɪnʒ wɑz tu fɑɹ ət ðə stɑɹt fəɹ ði æɹoʊz tə kɪl, bʌt mɔɹ ðən wʌn mæn stʃɹʌɡəl tə wɝk ɪz kɹɔsboʊ wɪð ə ʃæf dʒʌɾɪŋ fɹəm ən ɑɹm. ðə wɔl pɹətɛktəd ðɛɹ lɛɡz, jɛt. tu fɑɹ tə kɪl ənlɛs jəɹ tɑɹɡəts lʌk hæd ɹʌn aʊt. mæt sɔ ə mæn fɔl wɪð ən æɹoʊ ɪn ɪz aɪ, ənʌðɝ wɪð ə ʃæf teɪkən ɪn ðə θɹoʊt. ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ ɡæps ɪn ðə ɹæŋks, əz wɛl. mɛn ʃʌfəl fɔɹwɝd kwɪkli tə fɪl ðɛm.

It was not so one-sided as an ambush, of course. Some of the galloping horsemen had flung down their lances and uncased their horsebows. Arrows began to fall among the crossbowmen. Shooting accurately from a galloping horse was no easy task, and the range was too far at the start for the arrows to kill, but more than one man struggled to work his crossbow with a shaft jutting from an arm. The wall protected their legs, yet. Too far to kill unless your target's luck had run out. Mat saw a man fall with an arrow in his eye, another with a shaft taken in the throat. There were other gaps in the ranks, as well. Men shuffled forward quickly to fill them.

"ju kəd dʒɔɪn ɪn ɛni taɪm, dʒoʊlin," hi sɛd.

"You could join in any time, Joline," he said.

"θɝd ɹæŋk! lus!"

"Third rank! Loose!"

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. "aɪ mʌs bi ɪn deɪnʒɝ. aɪ doʊn fil ɪn deɪnʒɝ jɛt." tɛslɪn nɑɾəd. ʃi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɑɹdʒ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə pɝeɪd, ən ə nɑt vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ wʌn ət ðæt.

The Aes Sedai shook her head irritably. "I must be in danger. I don't feel in danger yet." Teslyn nodded. She was watching the charge as if it were a parade, and a not very interesting one at that.

"ɪf jə wəɾ əlaʊ sɛɾə ən mi," bɛθəmən bɪɡæn, bʌt dʒoʊlin lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ koʊldli, ən ðə sintʃæn wʊmən səbsaɪɾɪd ən dʒɹɑpt əɹ aɪz tə hɝ hænz ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz. sɛɾə smaɪl nɝvəsli, bʌɾ ɪt slɪɾ ɔf əɹ feɪs ʌndɝ dʒoʊlinz stɛɹ.

"If you would allow Seta and me," Bethamin began, but Joline looked over her shoulder coldly, and the Seanchan woman subsided and dropped her eyes to her hands on the reins. Seta smiled nervously, but it slid off her face under Joline's stare.

"fɹʌn ɹæŋk! lus!"

"Front rank! Loose!"

mæt ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz tə ðə hɛvənz ən mʌɾɝd ə pɹɛɹ ðət wɑz hæf kɝs. ðə blʌɾi wɪmən dɪd nɑt fil ɪn deɪnʒɝ! hi fɛlt əz ðoʊ hɪz blʌɾi hɛd wɑz ɑn ðə tʃɑpɪŋ blɑk!

Mat rolled his eyes to the heavens and muttered a prayer that was half curse. The bloody women did not feel in danger! He felt as though his bloody head was on the chopping block!

"sɛkən ɹæŋk! lus!"

"Second rank! Loose!"

tælmɑnz hæd kʌm ɪn ɹeɪnʒ, naʊ, ən ənaʊns hɪmsɛlf wɪð ə vɑli fɹəm fɔɹ θaʊzən baʊz ət θɹi hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ðət klɪɹd sæɾəlz. kloʊzɪŋ ðə dɪstəns, ðeɪ faɪɝɾ əɡɛn. əɡɛn. ði ɛnəmi ɹæŋks sim tə ɹɪpəl wɪð ðə ʃɑk. səm mɛn wɝld əbaʊɾ ən tʃɑɹdʒd ət tælmɑnz' laɪn wɪð lænsɪz kʌmɪŋ daʊn. ʌðɝz bɪɡæn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ɪz heɪl ʌv æɹoʊz wɪð ðɛɹ oʊn. moʊs kəntɪnjuɾ ɑn, ðoʊ.

Talmanes had come in range, now, and announced himself with a volley from four thousand bows at three hundred paces that cleared saddles. Closing the distance, they fired again. Again. The enemy ranks seemed to ripple with the shock. Some men whirled about and charged at Talmanes' line with lances coming down. Others began returning his hail of arrows with their own. Most continued on, though.

"fɔɹm skwɛɹ!" mændəvwɪn ʃaʊɾəd ə hɑɹtbit bɪfɔɹ mæt kʊd. hi hoʊp ðə mæn hæd nɑt lɛft ɪt tu blʌɾi leɪt.

"Form square!" Mandevwin shouted a heartbeat before Mat could. He hoped the man had not left it too bloody late.

ðə bænd wɑz wɛl-tʃɹeɪnd, ðoʊ. ðə mɛn ɑn ðə flæŋks fɛl bæk ət ðə ɹʌn, əz kɑmli əz ɪf æɹoʊz wɝ nɑt pɛltɪŋ ðɛm, klæŋɪŋ ɔf bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts. ən səmtaɪmz nɑt. mɛn fɛl. ðə θɹi ɹæŋks nɛvɝ lɔs koʊhiʒən, ðoʊ, əz ðeɪ bɛn ɪndə ə hɑloʊ bɑks wɪð mæt əɾ ɪts sɛntɝ. mjuzənʒ ən ði ʌðɝ hjumən dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz hæd ðɛɹ sɔɹdz aʊt, ən ði oʊɡiɝ wɝ hɛftɪŋ ðɛɹ lɔŋ æksiz.

The Band was well-trained, though. The men on the flanks fell back at the run, as calmly as if arrows were not pelting them, clanging off breastplates and helmets. And sometimes not. Men fell. The three ranks never lost cohesion, though, as they bent into a hollow box with Mat at its center. Musenge and the other human Deathwatch Guards had their swords out, and the Ogier were hefting their long axes.

"slɪŋ-mɛn!" mændəvwɪn ʃaʊɾəd. "lus ət wɪl! fɹʌn ɹæŋk, wɛst! lus!" slɪŋ-mɛn əlɔŋ ðə wɛstɝn ɹæŋk ʃɪftəd ðɛɹ slɪŋ-stæfs soʊ ðeɪ kəd tʌtʃ ðə fjuzəz kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə stʌbi sɪləndɝz tə ðə sloʊ-mætʃəz hɛld ɪn ðɛɹ tiθ ænd, əz ðə vɑli lænst aʊt fɹəm ðə kɹɔsboʊz, wɪp ðɛɹ slɪŋz bæk ən ðən fɔɹwɝd. ðə dɑɹk sɪləndɝz flu mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz tə læn əmʌŋ ði ɑnɹʌʃɪŋ hɔɹsmən. ðə slɪŋ-mɛn wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi fɪɾɪŋ mɔɹ ə ðə sɪləndɝz tə ðɛɹ slɪŋz bɪfɔɹ ðə fɝs fɛl. ɑlʌdʒɹə hæd mɑɹkt itʃ fjuz wɪð pisəz ə θɹɛd tə ɪndəkeɪt dɪfɹən bɝnɪŋ taɪmz, ən itʃ sɪləndɝ ɪɹʌptəd wɪð ə ɹɔɹ ɪn ə bɝst ə fleɪm, səm ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, səm əz haɪ əz ə maʊntəd mænz hɛd. ði ɪksploʊʒən wɑz nɑt ðə ɹil wɛpən, ðoʊ ə mæn stʃɹʌk ɪn ðə feɪs wɑz sʌɾənli hɛdləs. hi steɪɾ əpɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl fəɹ θɹi stʃɹaɪdz bɪfɔɹ tɑpəlɪŋ. noʊ, ɑlʌdʒɹə hæd ɹæpt ə leɪɝ ə hɑɹd pɛbəlz ɝaʊn ðə paʊɾɝ ɪnsaɪɾ itʃ sɪləndɝ, ən ðoʊz pɪɹs flɛʃ dipli wən ðeɪ hɪt. ʃɹikɪŋ hɔɹsəz fɛl tə θɹæʃ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɹaɪɾɝz fɛl tə laɪ stɪl.

"Sling-men!" Mandevwin shouted. "Loose at will! Front rank, west! Loose!" Sling-men along the western rank shifted their sling-staffs so they could touch the fuses coming from the stubby cylinders to the slow-matches held in their teeth and, as the volley lanced out from the crossbows, whipped their slings back and then forward. The dark cylinders flew more than a hundred paces to land among the onrushing horsemen. The sling-men were already fitting more of the cylinders to their slings before the first fell. Aludra had marked each fuse with pieces of thread to indicate different burning times, and each cylinder erupted with a roar in a burst of flame, some on the ground, some as high as a mounted man's head. The explosion was not the real weapon, though a man struck in the face was suddenly headless. He stayed upright in the saddle for three strides before toppling. No, Aludra had wrapped a layer of hard pebbles around the powder inside each cylinder, and those pierced flesh deeply when they hit. Shrieking horses fell to thrash on the ground. Riders fell to lie still.

ən æɹoʊ tʌɡd ət mæts lɛf sliv, ənʌðɝ pɪɹst ɪz ɹaɪt sliv, oʊnli ðə flɛtʃɪŋz kipɪŋ ɪt fɹəm ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu klinli, ən ə θɝd ɹɪpt oʊpən ðə ɹaɪt ʃoʊldɝ ə hɪz koʊt. hi pʊɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ bɪhaɪn ðə skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk ən tʌɡd. ðə blʌɾi θɪŋ fɛlt ɑfli taɪɾ ʌv ə sʌɾən. meɪbi hi ʃəd kənsɪɾɝ wɛɹɪŋ ɑɹmɝ ət taɪmz laɪk ðɪs. ði ɛnəmi flæŋks wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə kɝl ɪn, naʊ, pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə ɪnvɛləp ðə kɹɔsboʊmən bɪhaɪn ðə wɔl. tælmɑnz' mɛn stɪl pɛpɝd ðɛɹ ɹɪɹ wɪð æɹoʊz, bʌt sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd mɛn hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə dʒɹɑp ðɛɹ baʊz tə dɪfɛn ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð sɔɹdz, ən ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðəɾ ɔl ə ðə hɔɹsəz wɪð ɛmpti sæɾəlz aʊt ðəɹ hæd bɪlɔŋ tə tæɹɑbənɝz əɹ ɑmɑdɪʃənz. hi hæd lɛft ə ɡæp ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə hɪz laɪn, ə pæθ fəɹ ɛniwʌn u dɪsaɪɾɪd tə fli, jɛt noʊ wʌn wɑz teɪkɪŋ ði ɔfɝɪŋ. ðeɪ kəd smɛl ðət hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən kɹaʊnz ɡoʊld.

An arrow tugged at Mat's left sleeve, another pierced his right sleeve, only the fletchings keeping it from going through cleanly, and a third ripped open the right shoulder of his coat. He put a finger behind the scarf around his neck and tugged. The bloody thing felt awfully tight of a sudden. Maybe he should consider wearing armor at times like this. The enemy flanks were beginning to curl in, now, preparing to envelop the crossbowmen behind the wall. Talmanes' men still peppered their rear with arrows, but several hundred men had been forced to drop their bows to defend themselves with swords, and it was unlikely that all of the horses with empty saddles out there had belonged to Taraboners or Amadicians. He had left a gap in the center of his line, a path for anyone who decided to flee, yet no one was taking the offering. They could smell that hundred thousand crowns gold.

"aɪ θɪŋk," dʒoʊlin sɛd sloʊli. "jɛs, aɪ fil ɪn deɪnʒɝ, naʊ." tɛslɪn sɪmpli dʒɹu bæk əɹ hæn ən θɹu ə sfɪɹ ə faɪɝ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə hɔɹsəz hɛd. ði ɪksploʊʒən hɝl dɝɾ ən pisəz ə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ɪt wɑz əbaʊt blʌɾi taɪm!

"I think," Joline said slowly. "Yes, I feel in danger, now." Teslyn simply drew back her hand and threw a sphere of fire larger than a horse's head. The explosion hurled dirt and pieces of men and horses into the air. It was about bloody time!

feɪsɪŋ ɪn θɹi dɝɛkʃənz, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪɡæn hɝlɪŋ faɪɝbɔlz əz fæst əz ðeɪ kəd swɪŋ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz, bʌt ðə dɛvəsteɪʃən ðeɪ ɹɔt dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə sloʊ ði ətæk. ðoʊz mɛn ʃʊɾə bɪn eɪbəl tə si ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʊmən mætʃɪŋ tuɑnz dɪskɹɪpʃən ɪnsaɪd ðə skwɛɹ baɪ ðɪs taɪm, bʌt ðɛɹ blʌd wɑz noʊ daʊɾ ɑn faɪɝ, ðə sɛn ə ɹɪtʃəz ɪn ðɛɹ nɑstʃɹəlz. ə mæn kəd lɪv ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz laɪf laɪk ə noʊbəl wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzən kɹaʊnz ɡoʊld. ðə skwɛɹ wɑz ɪnsɝkəld, ən ðeɪ fɔt tə kloʊz ɑn ɪt, fɔɾ ən daɪɾ əz vɑliz fɹəm ðə kɹɔsboʊz læʃt əm ən slɪŋ-mɛn kɪl ðɛm. ənʌðɝ wɔl bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪz, meɪɾ ə dɛɾ ən daɪɪŋ mɛn ən hɔɹsəz, ə wɔl ðət səm tʃɹaɪd tə ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ ən dʒɔɪn ɪn ði ətɛmpt. mɔɹ skɹæmbəl daʊn fɹəm ðɛɹ sæɾəlz ən tʃɹaɪd tə klæmbɝ oʊvɝ. kɹɔsboʊ boʊls hɝld əm bæk. ðɪs kloʊs, boʊls pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd bɹɛstpleɪts laɪk hɑt naɪvz ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə bʌɾɝ. ɑn ðeɪ keɪm, ən daɪd.

Facing in three directions, the Aes Sedai began hurling fireballs as fast as they could swing their arms, but the devastation they wrought did nothing to slow the attack. Those men should have been able to see there was no woman matching Tuon's description inside the square by this time, but their blood was no doubt on fire, the scent of riches in their nostrils. A man could live the rest of his life like a noble with a hundred thousand crowns gold. The square was encircled, and they fought to close on it, fought and died as volleys from the crossbows lashed them and sling-men killed them. Another wall began to rise, made of dead and dying men and horses, a wall that some tried to ride over and joined in the attempt. More scrambled down from their saddles and tried to clamber over. Crossbow bolts hurled them back. This close, bolts penetrated breastplates like hot knives going into butter. On they came, and died.

ðə saɪləns sim tə kʌm sʌɾənli. nɑt kwaɪt saɪləns. ði ɛɹ wɑz fʊl ə ðə saʊn ə pæntɪŋ mɛn u hæd bɪn wɝkɪŋ ðoʊz kɹæŋks əz fæst əz ðeɪ kʊd. ən ðəɹ wɑz moʊnɪŋ fɹəm ðə wundəd. ə hɔɹs wɑz stɪl ʃɹikɪŋ, sʌmwɛɹ. bʌt mæt kəd si noʊ wʌn ɑn ɪz fit bɪtwin ðə wɔl ə dɛɾ ən tælmɑnz, noʊ wʌn ɪn ðə sæɾəl ɪksɛp mɛn ɪn ɡɹin hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts. mɛn u hæd loʊɝd ðɛɹ baʊz ən sɔɹdz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ foʊldəd ðɛɹ hænz ɑn ðə haɪ pɑməlz ə ðɛɹ sæɾəlz. ðeɪ wɝ bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd, tu.

The silence seemed to come suddenly. Not quite silence. The air was full of the sound of panting men who had been working those cranks as fast as they could. And there was moaning from the wounded. A horse was still shrieking, somewhere. But Mat could see no one on his feet between the wall of dead and Talmanes, no one in the saddle except men in green helmets and breastplates. Men who had lowered their bows and swords. The Aes Sedai folded their hands on the high pommels of their saddles. They were breathing hard, too.

"ɪɾ ɪz dʌn, mæt!" keɪm tælmɑnz' ʃaʊt. "ðoʊz u ɑɹ nɑt dɛɾ ɑɹ daɪɪŋ. nɑt wʌn ə ðə fulz tʃɹaɪd tə ɪskeɪp."

"It is done, Mat!" came Talmanes' shout. "Those who are not dead are dying. Not one of the fools tried to escape."

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə bi hæf-mæd wɪð ðə lʌs fəɹ ɡoʊld. ðeɪ hæd bɪn kəmplitli mæd wɪð ɪt.

Mat shook his head. He had expected them to be half-mad with the lust for gold. They had been completely mad with it.

ɪt wəd bi nɛsəsɛɹi tə hɔl əweɪ dɛd mɛn ən hɔɹsəz fəɹ mæt ən ði ʌðɝz tə ɡɛɾ aʊt, ən tælmɑnz sɛt mɛn tə wɝk, fæsənɪŋ ɹoʊps tə hɔɹsəz tə dʒɹæɡ ðɛm əsaɪd. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə klaɪm oʊvɝ ðæt. noʊ wʌn bʌt ði oʊɡiɝ.

It would be necessary to haul away dead men and horses for Mat and the others to get out, and Talmanes set men to work, fastening ropes to horses to drag them aside. No one wanted to climb over that. No one but the Ogier.

"aɪ wɑnə si ɪf aɪ kən faɪn ðə tʃɹeɪɾɝ," hɑɹɾə sɛd, ən i ən ði ʌðɝ sɪks ɡɑɹɾənɝz ʃoʊldɝd ðɛɹ æksiz ən wɔkt oʊvɝ ðə maʊn ə bɑɾiz əz ɪf ɪt wɝ dɝt.

"I want to see if I can find the traitor," Hartha said, and he and the other six Gardeners shouldered their axes and walked over the mound of bodies as if it were dirt.

"wɛl, ət list wi sɛɾəld ðɪs," dʒoʊlin sɛd, pæɾɪŋ əɹ feɪs wɪð ə leɪs-ɛdʒ hæŋkɝtʃɪf. swɛt dɑɾəd əɹ fɔɹhɛd. "ju oʊ ə dɛt, mæt. ɛɛs sədaɪ də nɑt bɪkʌm ɪnvɑlvd ɪn pɹaɪvət wɔɹz əz ə ɹul. aɪ ʃæl əv tə θɪŋk ɑn haʊ jə kən peɪ ɪt." mæt hæɾ ə pɹɪɾi ɡʊɾ aɪdiə wʌt ʃi wəd kʌm ʌp wɪð. ʃi wɑz mæd hɝsɛlf ɪf ʃi θɔɾ i wəɾ əɡɹi.

"Well, at least we settled this," Joline said, patting her face with a lace-edged handkerchief. Sweat dotted her forehead. "You owe a debt, Mat. Aes Sedai do not become involved in private wars as a rule. I shall have to think on how you can pay it." Mat had a pretty good idea what she would come up with. She was mad herself if she thought he would agree.

"kɹɔsboʊz sɛɾəld ðɪs, mɛɹəθdəmeɪn," mjuzənʒ sɛd. hɪz hɛlmət, bɹɛstpleɪɾ ən koʊt wɝ ɔf, hɪz lɛft ʃɝt-sliv ɹɪpt əweɪ soʊ wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ ɡɑɹdz kəd ɹæp ə bændɪdʒ ɝaʊnd wɛɹ ən æɹoʊ hæd ɡɔn θɹu. ðə sliv hæd kʌm əweɪ vɛɹi nitli, əz ɪf ðə stɪtʃɪŋ hæd bɪn wik. hi hæɾ ə ɹeɪvən tætuɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "kɹɔsboʊz ən mɛn wɪð hɑɹt. jə nɛvɝ hæd mɔɹ ðən ðɪs, dɪd ju, haɪnəs." ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən. "ðɪs ən wʌtɛvɝ lɔsəz jə sʌfɝd."

"Crossbows settled this, marath'damane," Musenge said. His helmet, breastplate and coat were off, his left shirt-sleeve ripped away so one of the other Guards could wrap a bandage around where an arrow had gone through. The sleeve had come away very neatly, as if the stitching had been weak. He had a raven tattooed on his shoulder. "Crossbows and men with heart. You never had more than this, did you, Highness." That was not a question. "This and whatever losses you suffered."

"aɪ toʊl ju," mæt sɛd. "aɪ hæɾ ɪnʌf." hi wɑz nɑt gɑnə ɹɪvil ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ tə ðə mæn ðən i kəd nɑɾ əvɔɪd, bʌt mjuzənʒ nɑɾəd əz ɪf i hæd kənfɝmd ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

"I told you," Mat said. "I had enough." He was not going to reveal anything more to the man than he could not avoid, but Musenge nodded as if he had confirmed everything.

baɪ ðə taɪm ən oʊpənɪŋ kəd bi klɪɹd soʊ ðət mæt ən ði ʌðɝz kəd ɹaɪd θɹu, hɑɹɾə ən ðə ɡɑɹɾənɝz hæd ɹɪtɝnd. "aɪ faʊn ðə tʃɹeɪɾɝ," hɑɹɾə sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ə sɛvɝd hɛd baɪ ɪts hɛɹ.

By the time an opening could be cleared so that Mat and the others could ride through, Hartha and the Gardeners had returned. "I found the traitor," Hartha said, holding up a severed head by its hair.

mjuzənʒəz aɪbɹaʊz klaɪmd ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðət dɑɹk, hʊk-noʊz feɪs. "ʃi wɪl bi vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəstəd tə si ðɪs," hi sɛd sɔfli. sɔfli əz ðə saʊn ə sɔɹd biɪŋ dʒɹɔn ɪz sɑft. "wi mʌs kæɹi ɪt tə hɝ."

Musenge's eyebrows climbed at the sight of that dark, hook-nosed face. "She will be very interested to see this," he said softly. Softly as the sound of sword being drawn is soft. "We must carry it to her."

"ju noʊ hɪm?" mæt æskt.

"You know him?" Mat asked.

"wi noʊ hɪm, haɪnəs." mjuzənʒəz feɪs, sʌɾənli simɪŋ kɑɹv fɹəm stoʊn, sɛɾ i wəd seɪ noʊ mɔɹ ɑn ðə sʌbʒɪkt.

"We know him, Highness." Musenge's face, suddenly seeming carved from stone, said he would say no more on the subject.

"lʊk, wəd jə stɑp kɔlɪŋ mi ðæt? maɪ neɪm ɪz mæt. æftɝ tədeɪ, aɪd seɪ juv ə ɹaɪt tə juz ɪt." mæt sɝpɹaɪz hɪmsɛlf baɪ stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz hænd.

"Look, would you stop calling me that? My name is Mat. After today, I'd say you have a right to use it." Mat surprised himself by sticking out his hand.

ðət stoʊn mæsk kɹʌmpəld ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. "aɪ kəd nɑt də ðæt, haɪnəs," hi sɛɾ ɪn skændəlaɪz toʊnz. "wɛn ʃi mɛɹid ju, jə bɪkeɪm pɹɪns ə ðə ɹeɪvənz. tə spik jəɹ neɪm wəd loʊɝ maɪ aɪz fɝɛvɝ."

That stone mask crumpled in astonishment. "I could not do that, Highness," he said in scandalized tones. "When she married you, you became Prince of the Ravens. To speak your name would lower my eyes forever."

mæt tʊk ɔf ɪz hæɾ ən skɹʌb fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. hi hæd toʊld ɛvɹiwʌn u wəd lɪsən ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt laɪk noʊbəlz, dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi wʌn, ən i hæd mɛn ɪt. hi stɪl mɛn ɪt. ən naʊ hi blʌɾi wɑz wʌn! hi dɪd ði oʊnli θɪŋ i kʊd. hi læft əntɪl ɪz saɪdz ætʃt.

Mat took off his hat and scrubbed fingers through his hair. He had told everyone who would listen that he did not like nobles, did not want to be one, and he had meant it. He still meant it. And now he bloody was one! He did the only thing he could. He laughed until his sides ached.


ɛpəlɔɡ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ði oʊl seɪɪŋ



EPILOGUE Remember the Old Saying

ðə ɹɛd-wɔld ɹum, ɪts silɪŋ peɪntəd fænsɪfəli wɪð bɝdz ən fɪʃ kəvɔɹɾɪŋ əmʌŋ klaʊdz ən weɪvz, bʌsəld wɪð bɹaʊn-klæd klɝks skɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ ði aɪlz bɪtwin ðə lɔŋ teɪbəlz ðət kʌvɝd ðə flɔɹ. nʌn sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɪsən - moʊst sim stʌnd, wɪð kɑz - bʌt sjuɹɔθ dɪslaɪk ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns. ðeɪ hæd tə oʊvɝhɪɹ səm ʌv wʌt wɑz biɪŋ sɛd, ən ɪt wɑz pətɛnʃəli daɪɹ nuz. ɡælɡən hæɾ ɪnsɪstəd, ðoʊ. ðeɪ niɾəd tə wɝk tə kip ðɛɹ maɪnz ɔf ðə dɪzæstʃɹəs nuz fɹəm hoʊm, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɔl tʃɹʌstɪd mɛn ən wɪmən. hi ɪnsɪstəd! ət lis ðə waɪt-hɛɹɾ oʊl mæn wɑz nɑt dʒɹɛst əz ə soʊlʒɝ, ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. hɪz vəlumənəs blu tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ʃɔɹt, haɪ-kɑlɝd ɹɛd koʊt wɪð ɹoʊz ʌv ɡoʊl bʌɾənz ɪmbɔst wɪð ɪz sɪdʒəl wɝ ðə haɪɾ ə sindɑɹ fæʃən, wɪtʃ mɛn ðə haɪɾ ə fæʃən fəɹ ði ɛmpaɪɝ. wən i wɔɹ ɑɹmɝ, əɹ ivən dʒʌst ɪz ɹɛd junəfɔɹm, hi səmtaɪmz lʊkt əɾ əɹ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ə soʊlʒɝ ʌndɝ ɪz kəmænd!

The red-walled room, its ceiling painted fancifully with birds and fish cavorting among clouds and waves, bustled with brown-clad clerks scurrying along the aisles between the long tables that covered the floor. None seemed to be trying to listen - most seemed stunned, with cause - but Suroth disliked their presence. They had to overhear some of what was being said, and it was potentially dire news. Galgan had insisted, though. They needed to work to keep their minds off the disastrous news from home, and they were all trusted men and women. He insisted! At least the white-haired old man was not dressed as a soldier, this morning. His voluminous blue trousers and short, high-collared red coat with rows of gold buttons embossed with his sigil were the height of Seandar fashion, which meant the height of fashion for the Empire. When he wore armor, or even just his red uniform, he sometimes looked at her as if she were a soldier under his command!

wɛl, wʌns ɛlbɑɹ bɹɔt wɝd ðət tuɑn wɑz dɛd, ʃi kəɾ əv ɡælɡən kɪld. hɪz tʃiks wɝ smɪɹd wɪð æʃəz, əz wɝ hɝz. ðə ʃɪp sɛmɝhɪdʒ hæd pɹɑməs hæd bɹɔt wɝɾ ə ði ɛmpɹɛsəz dɛθ ən ði ɛmpaɪɝ wɑz ɹæk baɪ ɹɪbɛljən ɪn ɛvɹi kɔɹɾɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɛmpɹɛs, noʊ dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. tə kɑmənɝz, ðə wɝl tʃɹɛmbəld ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən. tə səm ə ðə blʌd, tu. wɪð ɡælɡən ən ə fju mɔɹ dɛd, ðəɹ wəd bi nʌn tə əbdʒɛk tə sjuɹɔθ səbəl mɛlʒɹəθ pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɛmpɹɛs. ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk ə ðə nu neɪm ʃi wəd teɪk. θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn ə nu neɪm bɪfɔɹhænd wɑz bæd lʌk.

Well, once Elbar brought word that Tuon was dead, she could have Galgan killed. His cheeks were smeared with ashes, as were hers. The ship Semirhage had promised had brought word of the Empress's death and the Empire was racked by rebellion in every quarter. There was no Empress, no Daughter of the Nine Moons. To commoners, the world trembled on the brink of destruction. To some of the Blood, too. With Galgan and a few more dead, there would be none to object to Suroth Sabelle Meldarath proclaiming herself Empress. She tried not to think of the new name she would take. Thinking on a new name beforehand was bad luck.

ə fɹaʊn kɹisɪŋ ɪz feɪs, ɡælɡən lʊk daʊn ət ðə mæp spɹɛɾ aʊt bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, ən pleɪst ə ɹɛd-lækɝd fɪŋɡɝneɪl ətɑp maʊntənz ɑn ðə sʌðɝn koʊst ʌv ɑɹæd dumən. sjuɹɔθ dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt ðə maʊntənz wɝ kɔld. ðə mæp ʃoʊɾ ɔl ʌv ɑɹæd dumən ən hɛl θɹi mɑɹkɝz, wʌn ɹɛd wɛdʒ ən tu waɪt sɝkəlz, speɪst aʊɾ ɪn ə lɔŋ laɪn nɔɹθ tə saʊθ. "hæz tʃɹən ɡɑɾən ən ækjɝət kaʊn ə haʊ mɛni mɛn keɪm aʊɾ ə ðiz maʊntənz tə dʒɔɪn ɪɾɝɑldi wən i kɹɔst ɪndə ɑɹæd dumən, jəmɑɾə?"

A frown creasing his face, Galgan looked down at the map spread out before them, and placed a red-lacquered fingernail atop mountains on the southern coast of Arad Doman. Suroth did not know what the mountains were called. The map showed all of Arad Doman and held three markers, one red wedge and two white circles, spaced out in a long line north to south. "Has Turan gotten an accurate count of how many men came out of these mountains to join Ituralde when he crossed into Arad Doman, Yamada?"

ɛfɹeɪm jəmɑɾə wɔɹ ði æʃəz, tu, sɪns i wɑz ə ðə blʌd, ɪf oʊnli ðə loʊ blʌd, hɪz hɛɹ kʌɾ ɪn ðə boʊl-ænd-teɪl ɹæðɝ ðən ə nɛɹoʊ kɹɛst əkɹɔs ən ʌðɝwaɪz ʃeɪv skælp. oʊnli ðə kɑmənɝz ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl, wʌtɛvɝ ðɛɹ ɹæŋk, wɝ wɪθaʊt. ɡɹeɪɪŋ ən tɔl ɪn ə blu-ænd-ɡoʊl bɹɛstpleɪt, wɪð bɹɔd ʃoʊldɝz ən lin hɪps, jəmɑɾə stɪl hɛl səm ə ðə bjuɾi ʌv ɪz juθ. "hi ɹɪpɔɹts ət list wʌn hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzənd, kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl. pɝhæps hæf əɡɛn ðæt."

Efraim Yamada wore the ashes, too, since he was of the Blood, if only the low Blood, his hair cut in the bowl-and-tail rather than a narrow crest across an otherwise shaved scalp. Only the commoners around the table, whatever their rank, were without. Graying and tall in a blue-and-gold breastplate, with broad shoulders and lean hips, Yamada still held some of the beauty of his youth. "He reports at least one hundred thousand, Captain-General. Perhaps half again that."

"æn haʊ mɛni keɪm aʊɾ æftɝ tʃɹən kɹɔs ðə bɔɹɾɝ?"

"And how many came out after Turan crossed the border?"

"pɑsəbli tu hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzənd, kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl."

"Possibly two hundred thousand, Captain-General."

ɡælɡən saɪɾ ən stʃɹeɪɾənd. "soʊ tʃɹən əz wʌn ɑɹmi əhɛɾ ə hɪm ən ənʌðɝ bɪhaɪnd, vɛɹi laɪkli ðə hoʊl ʌv ɑɹæd dumənz stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən bɪtwin əm hiz aʊtnʌmbɝd." ðə ful! steɪɾɪŋ ðə blaɪndɪŋli ɑbviəs.

Galgan sighed and straightened. "So Turan has one army ahead of him and another behind, very likely the whole of Arad Doman's strength, and between them he is outnumbered." The fool! Stating the blindingly obvious.

"tʃɹən ʃʊɾə stʃɹɪp tæɹɑbən ʌv ɛvɹi sɔɹɾ ən læns!" sjuɹɔθ snæpt. "ɪf i sɝvaɪvz ðɪs dəbɑkəl, əl əv ɪz hɛd!"

"Turan should have stripped Tarabon of every sword and lance!" Suroth snapped. "If he survives this debacle, I will have his head!"

ɡælɡən kwɝkt ə waɪɾ aɪbɹaʊ ət hɝ. "aɪ hɑɹdli θɪŋk tæɹɑbən ɪz lɔɪəl ɪnʌf tə səpɔɹt ðət dʒʌs jɛt," hi sɛd dʒɹɪli. "bɪsaɪdz, hiz deɪmeɪn ən ɹeɪkən. ðeɪ ʃəɾ ɔfsɛɾ ɪz lɛsɝ nʌmbɝz. spikɪŋ ə deɪmeɪn ən ɹeɪkən, aɪv saɪn ði ɔɹɾɝz ɹeɪzɪŋ taɪli kɪɝɡən tə lutɛnənt-dʒɛnɝəl ən ðə loʊ blʌd, sɪns juv dɪðɝɾ oʊvɝ ɪt, ən ɔɹɾɝz tə ɹɪtɝn moʊst ə ðoʊz ɹeɪkən tə ɑmɑdɪʃiə ən ɔltɑɹə. tʃɪsən stɪl hæzən faʊn huɛvɝ kɹieɪɾəd ðət lɪɾəl mɛs ɪn ðə nɔɹθ, ən aɪ doʊn laɪk ðə noʊʃən ðət huɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ɪz laɪɪŋ ɪn weɪt tə spɹɪŋ aʊɾ əz sun əz tʃɪsən ɹɪtɝnz tə ðə moʊlveɪn ɡæp."

Galgan quirked a white eyebrow at her. "I hardly think Tarabon is loyal enough to support that just yet," he said drily. "Besides, he has damane and raken. They should offset his lesser numbers. Speaking of damane and raken, I've signed the orders raising Tylee Khirgan to Lieutenant-General and the low Blood, since you've dithered over it, and orders to return most of those raken to Amadicia and Altara. Chisen still hasn't found whoever created that little mess in the north, and I don't like the notion that whoever it was is lying in wait to spring out as soon as Chisen returns to the Molvaine Gap."

sjuɹɔθ hɪst, ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ pliɾɪd blu skɝts ɪn əɹ fɪsts bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd stɑp əɹ hænz. ʃi wəd nɑt lɛt ðə mæn meɪk əɹ ʃoʊ ɪmoʊʃən! "ju oʊvɝstɛp jɝsɛlf, ɡælɡən," ʃi sɛd koʊldli. "aɪ kəmæn ðə fɔɹʌnɝz. fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ, aɪ kəmæn ðə ɹɪtɝn. jəl saɪn noʊ ɔɹɾɝz wɪθaʊt maɪ əpɹuvəl."

Suroth hissed, gripping her pleated blue skirts in her fists before she could stop her hands. She would not let the man make her show emotion! "You overstep yourself, Galgan," she said coldly. "I command the Forerunners. For the time being, I command the Return. You will sign no orders without my approval."

"ju kəmændəd ðə fɔɹʌnɝz, hu hæv bɪn sʌbsumd ɪndə ðə ɹɪtɝn," hi ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli, ən sjuɹɔθ teɪstəd bɪɾɝnəs. ðə nuz fɹəm ði ɛmpaɪɝ hæɾ ɛmboʊldən hɪm. wɪð ði ɛmpɹɛs dɛd, ɡælɡən ɪntɛndəd tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf ðə fɝst ɛmpɝɝ ɪn naɪn hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ɪt simd i wəɾ əv tə daɪ baɪ tənaɪt. "æz fəɹ jə kəmændɪŋ ðə ɹɪtɝn - " hi kʌɾ ɔf ət ðə saʊn ə hɛvi buts fɹəm ðə kɔɹəɾɝ.

"You commanded the Forerunners, who have been subsumed into the Return," he replied calmly, and Suroth tasted bitterness. The news from the Empire had emboldened him. With the Empress dead, Galgan intended to make himself the first Emperor in nine hundred years. It seemed he would have to die by tonight. "As for you commanding the Return - " He cut off at the sound of heavy boots from the corridor.

sʌɾənli dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz fɪl ðə dɔɹweɪ, ɑɹmɝɾ ən hænz ɑn ðɛɹ sɔɹd hɪls. hɑɹɾ aɪz stɛɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin hɛlməts tə sɝveɪ ðə ɹum. oʊnli wən ðeɪ wɝ sæɾəsfaɪd dɪd ðeɪ stɛp əsaɪd tə ɹɪvil ðət ðə kɔɹəɾɝ wɑz fɪld wɪð dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, hjumən ən oʊɡiɝ. sjuɹɔθ bɛɹli noʊɾəst ðɛm. ʃi hæɾ aɪz oʊnli fəɹ ðə smɔl dɑɹk wʊmən ɪn pliɾɪd blu wɪð ə ʃeɪvən hɛɾ ən æʃəz ɑn əɹ tʃiks. ðə nuz wɑz ɔl oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi. ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv ɹitʃt ðə pæləs wɪθaʊt hɪɹɪŋ ə hɝ mʌðɝz dɛθ, hɝ fæmliz dɛθs, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz ə stɝn mæsk. sjuɹɔθs niz hɪt ðə flɔɹ ɔɾəmætɪkli. ɝaʊn əɹ ðə blʌd nɛlt, ðə kɑmənɝz pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz.

Suddenly Deathwatch Guards filled the doorway, armored and hands on their sword hilts. Hard eyes stared out of their red-and-green helmets to survey the room. Only when they were satisfied did they step aside to reveal that the corridor was filled with Deathwatch Guards, human and Ogier. Suroth barely noticed them. She had eyes only for the small dark woman in pleated blue with a shaven head and ashes on her cheeks. The news was all over the city. She could not have reached the palace without hearing of her mother's death, her family's deaths, but her face was a stern mask. Suroth's knees hit the floor automatically. Around her the Blood knelt, the commoners prostrated themselves.

"ðə laɪts blɛsɪŋz fəɹ jəɹ seɪf ɹɪtɝn, haɪnəs," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn kɔɹəs wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə blʌd. soʊ ɛlbɑɹ hæd feɪld. noʊ mæɾɝ. tuɑn wəd nɑt teɪk ə nu neɪm əɹ bɪkʌm ɛmpɹɛs əntɪl ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɑz fɪnɪʃt. ʃi kəd stɪl daɪ, klɪɹɪŋ ðə weɪ fəɹ ə nu ɛmpɹɛs.

"The Light's blessings for your safe return, Highness," she said in chorus with the rest of the Blood. So Elbar had failed. No matter. Tuon would not take a new name or become empress until the mourning was finished. She could still die, clearing the way for a new empress.

"ʃoʊ ðɛm wʌt kæptən mjuzənʒ bɹɔt mi, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl kɛɹid," tuɑn sɛd.

"Show them what Captain Musenge brought me, Banner-General Karede," Tuon said.

ə tɔl mæn wɪð θɹi dɑɹk plumz ɑn ɪz hɛlmət bɛn tə kɛɹfəli ɛmpti ə lɑɹdʒ lʌmp fɹəm ə kænvəs bæɡ ɑntu ðə ɡɹin flɔɹ taɪlz. ðə ɡæɡɪŋ smɛl ə dəkeɪ bɪɡæn tə pɝmieɪt ðə ɹum. dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðə bæɡ, hi stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ tə stæn bɪsaɪd sjuɹɔθ.

A tall man with three dark plumes on his helmet bent to carefully empty a large lump from a canvas bag onto the green floor tiles. The gagging smell of decay began to permeate the room. Dropping the bag, he strode across the floor to stand beside Suroth.

ɪt tʊk əɹ ə moʊmən tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɛlbɑɹz hʊk-noʊz feɪs ɪn ðət ɹɑɾɪŋ mæs, bʌɾ əz sun əz ʃi dɪd, ʃi fɛl fɔɹwɝd, pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf, kɪsɪŋ ðə flɔɹ taɪlz. nɑɾ ɪn dɛspɝeɪʃən, ðoʊ. ʃi kəd ɹɪkʌvɝ fɹəm ðɪs. ənlɛs ðeɪ hæd pʊɾ ɛlbɑɹ tə ðə kwɛstʃən. "maɪ aɪz ɑɹ loʊɝd, haɪnəs, ðət wʌn ə maɪn əz əfɛndəd jə soʊ dipli ðət jə tʊk ɪz hɛd."

It took her a moment to recognize Elbar's hook-nosed face in that rotting mass, but as soon as she did, she fell forward, prostrating herself, kissing the floor tiles. Not in desperation, though. She could recover from this. Unless they had put Elbar to the question. "My eyes are lowered, Highness, that one of mine has offended you so deeply that you took his head."

"əfɛndəd mi." tuɑn sim tə bi weɪɪŋ ðə wɝdz. "ɪt maɪt bi sɛɾ i əfɛndəd mi. hi tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl mi."

"Offended me." Tuon seemed to be weighing the words. "It might be said he offended me. He tried to kill me."

ɡæsps fɪl ðə ɹum, ən bɪfɔɹ sjuɹɔθ kəd mɔɹ ðən oʊpən əɹ maʊð, ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl plæntəɾ ə buɾ ɑn əɹ bɑɾəm, sizd əɹ kɹɛst ɪn ɪz fɪst, ən hɔld əɹ ʌpɝ bɑɾi klɪɹ ə ðə flɔɹ. ʃi dɪd nɑt stʃɹʌɡəl. ðət wəɾ oʊnli hæv æɾəd tə ði ɪndɪɡnəɾi.

Gasps filled the room, and before Suroth could more than open her mouth, the Deathwatch Guard Banner-General planted a boot on her bottom, seized her crest in his fist, and hauled her upper body clear of the floor. She did not struggle. That would only have added to the indignity.

"maɪ aɪz ɑɹ dipli loʊɝd ðət wʌn ə maɪn ʃəd bi ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ, haɪnəs," ʃi sɛd hɔɹsli. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi cʊɾə spoʊkən nætʃɹəli, bʌt ðə kɝs mæn hæɾ əɹ bæk ɑɹtʃt tɪl ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ ʃi kəd spik əɾ ɔl. "hæɾ aɪ ivən səspɛktəd, aɪ wʊɾə hæɾ ɪm pʊt tə ðə kwɛstʃən maɪsɛlf. bʌɾ ɪf i tʃɹaɪd tə ɪmplɪkeɪt mi, haɪnəs, hi laɪd tə pɹətɛkt ɪz tʃɹu mæstɝ. aɪ hæv səm θɔts ɑn ðət wɪtʃ aɪ wəd ʃɛɹ wɪð jə ɪn pɹaɪvət, ɪf aɪ meɪ bi əlaʊd." wɪð ə lɪɾəl lʌk, ʃi kəd leɪ ðɪs tə ɡælɡən. hɪz jusɝpeɪʃən ə hɝ əθɔɹəɾi wəd hɛlp.

"My eyes are deeply lowered that one of mine should be a traitor, Highness," she said hoarsely. She wished she could have spoken naturally, but the cursed man had her back arched till it was a wonder she could speak at all. "Had I even suspected, I would have had him put to the question myself. But if he tried to implicate me, Highness, he lied to protect his true master. I have some thoughts on that which I would share with you in private, if I may be allowed." With a little luck, she could lay this to Galgan. His usurpation of her authority would help.

tuɑn lʊkt oʊvɝ sjuɹɔθs hɛd. ʃi mɛt ɡælɡənz aɪz, ən ɑbɑldɑɹz ən jəmɑɾəz, ən ðoʊz ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn ə ðə blʌd, bʌt nɑt sjuɹɔθs. "ɪɾ ɪz wɛl noʊn ðət zaɪɪɹɾ ɛlbɑɹ wɑz sjuɹɔθs mæn kəmplitli. hi dɪd nʌθɪŋ ðət ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɔɹɾɝ. ðɛɹfɔɹ sjuɹɔθ səbəl mɛlʒɹəθ ɪz noʊ mɔɹ. ðɪs dækoʊvæl wɪl sɝv ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ wɪʃ əntɪl əɹ hɛɹ əz ɡɹoʊn ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə bi disənt wən ʃiz sɛn tə ðə blɑk fəɹ seɪl."

Tuon looked over Suroth's head. She met Galgan's eyes, and Abaldar's and Yamada's, and those of everyone of the Blood, but not Suroth's. "It is well known that Zaired Elbar was Suroth's man completely. He did nothing that she did not order. Therefore Suroth Sabelle Meldarath is no more. This da'covale will serve the Deathwatch Guard as they wish until her hair has grown enough for her to be decent when she is sent to the block for sale."

sjuɹɔθ nɛvɝ θɔɾ ə ðə naɪf ʃi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə juz tə oʊpən əɹ veɪnz, ə naɪf bɪɑn ɹitʃ ɪn əɹ əpɑɹtməns. ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk əɾ ɔl. ʃi stɑɹɾəd skɹimɪŋ, ə wɝdləs haʊl, bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ivən bɪɡæn kʌɾɪŋ əɹ kloʊðɪŋ ɔf.

Suroth never thought of the knife she had intended to use to open her veins, a knife beyond reach in her apartments. She could not think at all. She started screaming, a wordless howl, before they even began cutting her clothing off.

ði ændɔɝən sʌn wɑz wɔɹm æftɝ tɑɹ vəlɑn. pɛvɑɹə ɹimuvd əɹ kloʊk ən bɪɡæn taɪɪŋ ɪt bɪhaɪn əɹ sæɾəl əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪŋkt ʃʌt, haɪɾɪŋ ðə vju ʌv ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊv ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. nʌn ə ðɛm hæd wɑntəɾ ɛniwʌn tə si ðɛm livɪŋ. ðeɪ wəd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə ɡɹoʊv fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən, ənlɛs mæɾɝz wɛn vɛɹi bædli. ɪn wɪtʃ keɪs, ðeɪ maɪt nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝn. ʃi hæd θɔt ðɪs tæsk mʌs bi kæɹiɾ aʊt baɪ sʌmwʌn u kəmbaɪn ðə haɪəs dɪpləmæɾɪk skɪlz wɪð ðə kɝədʒ ʌv ə laɪən. wɛl, ʃi wɑz noʊ kaʊɝd, ət list. ʃi kəd seɪ ðət mʌtʃ ə hɝsɛlf.

The Andoran sun was warm after Tar Valon. Pevara removed her cloak and began tying it behind her saddle as the gateway winked shut, hiding the view of the Ogier grove in Tar Valon. None of them had wanted anyone to see them leaving. They would return to the grove for the same reason, unless matters went very badly. In which case, they might never return. She had thought this task must be carried out by someone who combined the highest diplomatic skills with the courage of a lion. Well, she was no coward, at least. She could say that much of herself.

"wɛɹ dɪd jə lɝn ðə wiv fəɹ bɑndɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ?" dʒəvɪnʒɹə æskt əbɹʌpli, stoʊɪŋ əɹ oʊn kloʊk ɪn sɪməlɝ fæʃən.

"Where did you learn the weave for bonding a Warder?" Javindhra asked abruptly, stowing her own cloak in similar fashion.

"ju ʃəd ɹikɔl ðəɾ aɪ wʌns sədʒɛstəd ɹɛd sɪstɝz wəd bi wɛl sɝv baɪ hævɪŋ wɔɹɾɝz." pɛvɑɹə snʌɡd əɹ ɹɛd ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz, ʃoʊɪŋ noʊ kənsɝn fəɹ ðə kwɛstʃən. ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪt bɪfɔɹ ðɪs. "waɪ wəd jə bi sɝpɹaɪzd aɪ noʊ ðə wiv?" ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi hæd niɾəd tə æsk jukɪɝi, ən hæd bɪn hɑɹd pɹɛs tə dɪsəmbəl əɹ ɹizən fəɹ æskɪŋ. ʃi daʊɾɪd ðət jukɪɝi wɑz səspɪʃəs, ðoʊ. eɪ ɹɛd bɑndɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz əz laɪkli əz ə wʊmən flaɪɪŋ. ɪksɛpt, ʌv kɔɹs, ðət ðət wɑz waɪ ʃi hæd kʌm tə ændɝ. waɪ ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl kʌm.

"You should recall that I once suggested Red sisters would be well served by having Warders." Pevara snugged her red riding gloves, showing no concern for the question. She had expected it before this. "Why would you be surprised I know the weave?" In truth, she had needed to ask Yukiri, and had been hard pressed to dissemble her reason for asking. She doubted that Yukiri was suspicious, though. A Red bonding a Warder was as likely as a woman flying. Except, of course, that that was why she had come to Andor. Why they had all come.

dʒəvɪnʒɹə wɑz ðəɹ oʊnli ət tsutɑməz kəmænd, ɡɪvən wən pɛvɑɹə ən tɑɹnə kəd nɑt kʌm ʌp wɪð ɪnʌf neɪmz tə sut ðə haɪəst. ði æŋɡjəlɝ sɪɾɝ dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə haɪɾ əɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ oʊvɝ ðæt, nɑt fɹəm pɛvɑɹə, ɔlðoʊ ʃi hæd bɛɹiɾ ɪt dipli ɝaʊn tsutɑmə. tɑɹnə wɑz ðɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs, peɪl-hɛɹɾ ən aɪsi koʊld, hɝ kipɝz stoʊl lɛf bɪhaɪn bʌɾ əɹ dɪvaɪɾəd ɡɹeɪ skɝts ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ɹɛd tə ðə ni. fəɹ ɪleɪɾəz kipɝ tə hæv ə wɔɹɾɝ wəd bi dɪfəkəlt, ðoʊ ðə mɛn wɝ tə bi haʊzd ɪn ðə sɪɾi, əweɪ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ, jɛɾ ɪt hæɾ ɔl bɪn əɹ aɪdiə ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, ən ʃi wɑz, ɪf nɑɾ iɡɝ, ðən dɪtɝmən tə teɪk pɑɹɾ ɪn ðɪs fɝst ɪkspɛɹəmənt. bɪsaɪdz, ðə nid fəɹ nʌmbɝz wɑz pɛɹəmaʊnt, kəz ðeɪ hæd faʊn oʊnli θɹi ʌðɝ sɪstɝz wɪlɪŋ tə ɛntɝteɪn ði aɪdiə. ðə pɹaɪmɛɹi tæsk ə ðə ɹɛd fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ, faɪndɪŋ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl ən bɹɪŋɪŋ əm tə ðə taʊɝ tə bi dʒɛntəld, tɛndəd tə saʊɝ wɪmən ɑn ɔl mɛn, soʊ ðə kluz hæd bɪn fju ən fɑɹ bɪtwin. jɛzɹeɪl wɑz ə skwɛɹ-feɪs tɛɹən u kɛpt ə peɪntəd mɪniətʃʊɹ ə ðə bɔɪ ʃi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs mɛɹiɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə kʌmɪŋ tə ðə taʊɝ. hɪz ɡɹæntʃɪlʒɹən wəd bi ɡɹændpɛɹəns naʊ, bʌt ʃi stɪl spoʊk ə hɪm fɑnli. disɑlə, ə bjuɾəfəl kɛɹhinɪn wɪð lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk aɪz ən ən ənfɔɹtʃənət tɛmpɝ, wən ɡɪvən ðə tʃæns wəd dæns ɛni nʌmbɝ ə mɛn tə ɪɡzɔstʃən ɪn ə naɪt. ən mɛlɛɹ, plʌmp ən wɪɾi, wɪð ə lʌv ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən, sɛn mʌni tə ændɝ tə peɪ fəɹ əɹ ɡɹændnɛfuz' ɛdʒəkeɪʃən əz ʃi hæd fəɹ əɹ nɛfjuz ən nisɪz.

Javindhra was there only at Tsutama's command, given when Pevara and Tarna could not come up with enough names to suit the Highest. The angular Sitter did not bother to hide her displeasure over that, not from Pevara, although she had buried it deeply around Tsutama. Tarna was there, of course, pale-haired and icy cold, her Keeper's stole left behind but her divided gray skirts embroidered in red to the knee. For Elaida's Keeper to have a Warder would be difficult, though the men were to be housed in the city, away from the Tower, yet it had all been her idea in the first place, and she was, if not eager, then determined to take part in this first experiment. Besides, the need for numbers was paramount, because they had found only three other sisters willing to entertain the idea. The primary task of the Red for so long, finding men who could channel and bringing them to the Tower to be gentled, tended to sour women on all men, so the clues had been few and far between. Jezrail was a square-faced Tairen who kept a painted miniature of the boy she had almost married instead of coming to the Tower. His grandchildren would be grandparents now, but she still spoke of him fondly. Desala, a beautiful Cairhienin with large dark eyes and an unfortunate temper, when given the chance would dance any number of men to exhaustion in a night. And Melare, plump and witty, with a love of conversation, sent money to Andor to pay for her grandnephews' education as she had for her nephews and nieces.

wɪɹi ʌv sɝtʃɪŋ aʊt sətʃ taɪni kluz, wɪɹi ʌv pɹoʊbɪŋ dɛləkətli tə lɝn wɛðɝ ðeɪ mɛnt wʌt ðeɪ maɪt, pɛvɑɹə hæd kənvɪns tsutɑmə ðət sɪks wəd bi ɪnʌf tə bɪɡɪn. tu, ə lɑɹdʒɝ pɑɹɾi maɪt kɑz səm ənfɔɹtʃənət ɹiækʃən. æftɝ ɔl, ðə hoʊl ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ əpɪɹɪŋ ət ðɪs soʊ-kɔl blæk taʊɝ, əɹ ivən hæf, maɪt wɛl meɪk ðə mɛn θɪŋk ðɛmsɛlvz ʌndɝ ətæk. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ haʊ seɪn ðeɪ ɔl stɪl wɝ. ðət wɑz wʌn θɪŋ ðeɪ hæɾ əɡɹiɾ ɑn, bɪhaɪn tsutɑməz bæk. ðeɪ wəd bɑnd noʊ mɛn u ʃoʊɾ ɛni saɪnz ə mædnəs. ðət wɑz, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əlaʊd tə bɑn ɛni.

Weary of searching out such tiny clues, weary of probing delicately to learn whether they meant what they might, Pevara had convinced Tsutama that six would be enough to begin. Too, a larger party might cause some unfortunate reaction. After all, the whole Red Ajah appearing at this so-called Black Tower, or even half, might well make the men think themselves under attack. There was no telling how sane they all still were. That was one thing they had agreed on, behind Tsutama's back. They would bond no men who showed any signs of madness. That was, if they were allowed to bond any.
