ədʒɑ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn hæd sɛn koʊpiəs ɹɪpɔɹts ɑn ðə blæk taʊɝ, ən səm hæɾ ivən faʊn ɛmplɔɪmən ɪnsaɪɾ ɪt, soʊ ðeɪ hæd noʊ dɪfəkəlti loʊkeɪɾɪŋ ðə wɛl-wɔɹn dɝt tʃɹæk ðət lɛd daʊn fɹəm ðə sɪɾi tə ə ɡɹændioʊs dʌbəl-ɑɹtʃt blæk ɡeɪt, nɪɹ fɪfti fit tɔl ən tɛn spænz waɪd, tɑp baɪ kɹɛnəleɪʃənz oʊvɝ ə daʊn-pɔɪntɪŋ sɛntʃɹəl spaɪk ə stoʊn ən flæŋk baɪ ə pɛɹ ə θɪk, kɹɛnəleɪɾəd blæk taʊɝz ðət stʊɾ ət lis fɪftin spænz haɪ. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ æktʃəwəl ɡeɪts tə kloʊz ʌp ði oʊpənɪŋ, ən ðə blæk stoʊn wɔl ðət stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ist ən wɛst, mɑɹkt əɾ ɪntɝvəlz baɪ ðə faʊndeɪʃənz ə bæstʃənz ən taʊɝz, wɑz noʊwɛɹ haɪɝ ðən fɔɹ əɹ faɪv peɪsɪz ðət ʃi kəd si. widz ɡɹu əlɔŋ ði ənivən tɑp, ən ɡɹæsəz ɹʌfəl baɪ ðə bɹiz. ðoʊz ənfɪnɪʃt wɔlz, lʊkɪŋ əz ɪf ðeɪ maɪt nɛvɝ bi fɪnɪʃt, meɪd ðə ɡeɪt sim luɾəkɹəs.

Ajah eyes-and-ears in Caemlyn had sent copious reports on the Black Tower, and some had even found employment inside it, so they had no difficulty locating the well-worn dirt track that led down from the city to a grandiose double-arched black gate, near fifty feet tall and ten spans wide, topped by crenelations over a down-pointing central spike of stone and flanked by a pair of thick, crenelated black towers that stood at least fifteen spans high. There were no actual gates to close up the opening, and the black stone wall that stretched out of sight east and west, marked at intervals by the foundations of bastions and towers, was nowhere higher than four or five paces that she could see. Weeds grew along the uneven top, and grasses ruffled by the breeze. Those unfinished walls, looking as if they might never be finished, made the gate seem ludicrous.

ðə θɹi mɛn u stɛpt aʊɾ ɪndə ði oʊpənɪŋ wɝ nɑɾ əɾ ɔl luɾəkɹəs, haʊɛvɝ. ðeɪ wɔɹ lɔŋ blæk koʊts, ən sɔɹdz ət ðɛɹ hɪps. wʌn, ə lin jʌŋ fɛloʊ wɪð kɝl mʌstæʃɪz, hæɾ ə sɪlvɝ pɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz haɪ kɑlɝ. wʌn ə ðə dɛɾəkeɪtəd. pɛvɑɹə ɹɪzɪstɪd ði ɪnstɪŋk tə θɪŋk ə hɪm əz ɪkwɪvələn tə ən æksɛptɪɾ ən ði ʌðɝ tu əz nɑvəsɪz. nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd wɝ kɛp seɪf ən ɡaɪɾəd əntɪl ðeɪ nu ɪnʌf ə ðə paʊɝ tə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ. baɪ ɔl ɹɪpɔɹts, soʊlʒɝz ən dɛɾəkeɪtəd wɝ kənsɪɾɝd ɹɛɾi fəɹ bæɾəl ɔlmoʊst əz sun əz ðeɪ lɝn tə tʃænəl. ən ðeɪ wɝ fɔɹs fɹəm ðə fɝs deɪ, pɹɛs tə siz əz mʌtʃ ə seɪɾɪn əz ðeɪ kʊd, meɪd tə juz ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs kəntɪnjuəli. mɛn daɪd fɹəm ðæt, ən ðeɪ kɔld ɪt "tʃɹeɪnɪŋ lɔsəz," əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd haɪd dɛθ bɪhaɪn blænd wɝdz. ðə θɔɾ ə luzɪŋ nɑvəsɪz əɹ æksɛptɪɾ ɪn ðət fæʃən kɝɾəld pɛvɑɹəz stʌmək, bʌɾ ɪt sim ðət ðə mɛn tʊk ɪɾ ɪn stʃɹaɪd.

The three men who stepped out into the opening were not at all ludicrous, however. They wore long black coats, and swords at their hips. One, a lean young fellow with curled mustaches, had a silver pin in the shape of a sword on his high collar. One of the Dedicated. Pevara resisted the instinct to think of him as equivalent to an Accepted and the other two as novices. Novices and Accepted were kept safe and guided until they knew enough of the Power to become Aes Sedai. By all reports, Soldiers and Dedicated were considered ready for battle almost as soon as they learned to channel. And they were forced from the first day, pressed to seize as much of saidin as they could, made to use it almost continually. Men died from that, and they called it "training losses," as if they could hide death behind bland words. The thought of losing novices or Accepted in that fashion curdled Pevara's stomach, but it seemed that the men took it in stride.

"ə faɪn mɔɹnɪŋ tə ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ðə dɛɾəkeɪtəd sɛd wɪð ə smɔl baʊ əz ðeɪ ɹeɪn ɪn bɪfɔɹ hɪm. ə vɛɹi smɔl baʊ, nɛvɝ teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz fɹəm ðɛm. hɪz æksɛns wɝ ðoʊz ə mʊɹændi. "naʊ wʌt wəd sɪks sɪstɝz bi wɑntɪŋ hɪɹ ət ðə blæk taʊɝ ðɪs faɪn mɔɹnɪŋ?"

"A fine morning to you, Aes Sedai," the Dedicated said with a small bow as they reined in before him. A very small bow, never taking his eyes from them. His accents were those of Murandy. "Now what would six sisters be wanting here at the Black Tower this fine morning?"

"tə si ðə l," pɛvɑɹə ɹɪplaɪd, mænɪdʒɪŋ tə əvɔɪd tʃoʊkɪŋ ɑn ðə wɝd. ɪt mɛnt "liɾɝ" ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, bʌt ði ɪmpləkeɪʃən ə teɪkɪŋ ðəɾ əloʊn əz ə taɪɾəl ɡeɪv ðə wɝd mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ minɪŋ, əz ɪf i lɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

"To see the M'Hael," Pevara replied, managing to avoid choking on the word. It meant "leader" in the Old Tongue, but the implication of taking that alone as a title gave the word much stronger meaning, as if he led everyone and everything.

"ɑ, tə si ðə l, ɪz ɪt? ən ʌv wʌɾ ədʒəz ʃəɾ aɪ seɪ?"

"Ah, to see the M'Hael, is it? And of what Ajahs should I say?"

"ðə ɹɛd," pɛvɑɹə ɹɪplaɪɾ ən wɑtʃt ɪm blɪŋk. vɛɹi sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ. bʌt nɑt vɛɹi hɛlpfəl.

"The Red," Pevara replied and watched him blink. Very satisfying. But not very helpful.

"ðə ɹɛd," hi sɛd flætli. hi hæd nɑt ɹɪmeɪn stɑɹɾəld vɛɹi lɔŋ. "wɛl, ðɛn. ɛŋkəzɪn, ælsin, jə kip wɑtʃ waɪl aɪ si wʌt ðə l əz tə seɪ tə ðɪs."

"The Red," he said flatly. He had not remained startled very long. "Well, then. Enkazin, al'Seen, you keep watch while I see what the M'Hael has to say to this."

hi tɝn ɪz bæk, ən ðə vɝɾɪkəl sɪlvɝi slæʃ ʌv ə ɡeɪtweɪ əpɪɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, waɪɾənɪŋ ɪndə ən oʊpənɪŋ noʊ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə dɔɹ. wɑz ðəɾ əz lɑɹdʒ əz i kəd meɪk? ðəɹ hæd bɪn səm dɪskʌʃən əbaʊt wɛðɝ tə bɑn mɛn u wɝ əz stʃɹɔŋ əz pɑsəbəl əɹ ðoʊz u wɝ wik. ðə wik maɪt bi mɔɹ izəli kəntʃɹoʊld, waɪl ðə stʃɹɔŋ maɪt - wəd dɛfənətli - bi mɔɹ jusfəl. ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt noʊ kənsɛnsəs; itʃ sɪstɝ wəɾ əv tə dɪsaɪd fəɹ hɝsɛlf. hi dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ən kloʊzd ɪt bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæɾ ə tʃæns tə si mɔɹ ðən ə waɪt stoʊn plætfɔɹm wɪð stɛps liɾɪŋ ʌp wʌn saɪɾ ən ə skwɛɹd-ɔf blæk stoʊn ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn wʌn ə ðə bɪldɪŋ blɑks fəɹ ðə wɔl, pɑlɪʃt tɪl ɪt ʃoʊn ɪn ðə sʌn, sɪɾɪŋ ətɑp ɪt.

He turned his back, and the vertical silvery slash of a gateway appeared in front of him, widening into an opening no larger than a door. Was that as large as he could make? There had been some discussion about whether to bond men who were as strong as possible or those who were weak. The weak might be more easily controlled, while the strong might - would definitely - be more useful. They had reached no consensus; each sister would have to decide for herself. He darted through the gateway and closed it before she had a chance to see more than a white stone platform with steps leading up one side and a squared-off black stone that might have been one of the building blocks for the wall, polished till it shone in the sun, sitting atop it.

ðə tu hu ɹɪmeɪn steɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə dʌbəl ɑɹtʃ əz ɪf tə bɑɹ ðə sɪstɝz fɹəm ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn. wʌn wɑz ə sɑldəiən, ə skɪni bɹɔd-noʊz mæn dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə hɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz u hæd sʌmθɪŋ ə ðə lʊk ʌv ə klɝk əbaʊt hɪm, ə bɪɾ ʌv ə stup əz fɹəm hʌntʃɪŋ fəɹ lɔŋ aʊɝz oʊvɝ ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl, ði ʌðɝ ə bɔɪ, lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə tʃaɪld, hu ɹeɪk dɑɹk hɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz aɪz wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ðoʊ ðə bɹiz kwɪkli pʊɾ ɪt bæk əɡɛn. niðɝ sim ðə slaɪɾəst ənizi oʊvɝ kənfɹʌntɪŋ sɪks sɪstɝz əloʊn. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn. wɝ ðəɹ ʌðɝz ɪn ðoʊz taʊɝz? pɛvɑɹə ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə taʊɝ tɑps.

The two who remained stayed in the middle of the double arch as if to bar the sisters from riding in. One was a Saldaean, a skinny broad-nosed man just short of his middle years who had something of the look of a clerk about him, a bit of a stoop as from hunching for long hours over a writing table, the other a boy, little more than a child, who raked dark hair out of his eyes with his fingers though the breeze quickly put it back again. Neither seemed the slightest uneasy over confronting six sisters alone. If they were alone. Were there others in those towers? Pevara refrained from glancing at the tower tops.

"ju ðɛɹ, bɔɪ," disɑlə sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk tʃaɪmz. tʃaɪmz tɪŋd wɪð æŋɡɝ. ðə ʃʊɹɪst weɪ tə sɛɾ ɔf əɹ tɛmpɝ wɑz tə hɑɹm ə tʃaɪld. "ju ʃəd bi ət hoʊm wɪð jəɹ mʌðɝ stʌɾiɪŋ jəɹ lɛɾɝz. wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?" ðə bɔɪ flʌʃt bɹaɪt ɹɛɾ ən ɹeɪk hɛɹ fɹəm ɪz feɪs əɡɛn.

"You there, boy," Desala said in a voice like chimes. Chimes tinged with anger. The surest way to set off her temper was to harm a child. "You should be at home with your mother studying your letters. What are you doing here?" The boy flushed bright red and raked hair from his face again.

"sæməlz ɔl ɹaɪt, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ðə sɑldəiən sɛd, pæɾɪŋ ðə bɔɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "hiz ə kwɪk lɝnɝ, ən jə doʊnt nid tə ʃoʊ hɪm ɛniθɪŋ twaɪs bɪfɔɹ i noʊz ɪt." ðə bɔɪ stʊɾ ʌp vɛɹi stʃɹeɪt, pɹaɪɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs, ən tʌkt ɪz θʌmz bɪhaɪn ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt. ə sɔɹd, əɾ ɪz eɪdʒ! tʃɹu, ə noʊbəlz sʌn wʊɾə bɪn lɝnɪŋ ðə sɔɹd fəɹ sɛvɹəl jɪɹz ət sæməl ælsinz eɪdʒ, bʌɾ i wəd nɑt bi əlaʊd tə wɛɹ ðə θɪŋ əbaʊt!

"Saml's all right, Aes Sedai," the Saldaean said, patting the boy's shoulder. "He's a quick learner, and you don't need to show him anything twice before he knows it." The boy stood up very straight, pride on his face, and tucked his thumbs behind his sword belt. A sword, at his age! True, a noble's son would have been learning the sword for several years at Saml al'Seen's age, but he would not be allowed to wear the thing about!

"pɛvɑɹə," tɑɹnə sɛd kuli, "noʊ tʃɪlʒɹən. aɪ nu ðeɪ hæd tʃɪlʒɹən hɪɹ, bʌt noʊ tʃɪlʒɹən."

"Pevara," Tarna said coolly, "no children. I knew they had children here, but no children."

"laɪt!" mɛlɛɹ bɹiðd. hɝ waɪt mɛɹ sɛnst əɹ ædʒəteɪʃən ən tɔst əɹ hɛd. "sɝɾənli noʊ tʃɪlʒɹən!"

"Light!" Melare breathed. Her white mare sensed her agitation and tossed her head. "Certainly no children!"

"ðæt wəd bi ən əbɑməneɪʃən," jɛzɹeɪl sɛd.

"That would be an abomination," Jezrail said.

"noʊ tʃɪlʒɹən," pɛvɑɹə əɡɹid kwɪkli. "aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəd weɪt tə seɪ mɔɹ əntɪl wi si mæstɝ . . . ðə l." dʒəvɪnʒɹə snɪft.

"No children," Pevara agreed quickly. "I think we should wait to say more until we see Master . . . the M'Hael." Javindhra sniffed.

"noʊ tʃɪlʒɹən wʌt, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ɛŋkəzɪn æskt, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "noʊ tʃɪlʒɹən wʌt?" hi sɛɾ əɡɛn wən noʊ wʌn ænsɝd.

"No children what, Aes Sedai?" Enkazin asked, frowning. "No children what?" he said again when no one answered.

hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əpɪɹd soʊ mʌtʃ laɪk ə klɝk. ðə stup ɹɪmeɪnd, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ɪz tɪltəɾ aɪz sʌɾənli simd . . . deɪnʒɝəs. wɑz i hoʊldɪŋ ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ? ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi sɛn ə tʃɪl daʊn pɛvɑɹəz spaɪn, bʌt ʃi ɹɪzɪstɪd ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ. səm mɛn u kəd tʃænəl simd eɪbəl tə sɛns wən ə wʊmən wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. ɛŋkəzɪn lʊk laɪk i maɪt bi heɪsti, naʊ.

He no longer appeared so much like a clerk. The stoop remained, but something in his tilted eyes suddenly seemed . . . dangerous. Was he holding the male half of the Power? The possibility sent a chill down Pevara's spine, but she resisted the desire to embrace saidar. Some men who could channel seemed able to sense when a woman was holding the Power. Enkazin looked like he might be hasty, now.

ðeɪ weɪɾəd ɪn saɪləns ɪksɛp fəɹ ði əkeɪʒənəl stæmp ʌv ə huf, pɛvɑɹə skulɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə peɪʃəns, dʒəvɪnʒɹə ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. pɛvɑɹə kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt ðə wɝdz, bʌt ʃi nu ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ wən ʃi hɝɾ ɪt. tɑɹnə ən jɛzɹeɪl tʊk bʊks fɹəm ðɛɹ sæɾəlbæɡz ən ɹɛd. ɡʊd. lɛt ðiz æʃəmən si ðət ðeɪ wɝ ʌnkənsɝnd. oʊnli, nɑɾ ivən ðə bɔɪ simd ɪmpɹɛst. hi ən ðə sɑldəiən dʒʌst stʊd ðəɹ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɡeɪt wɑtʃɪŋ, hɑɹdli blɪŋkɪŋ.

They waited in silence except for the occasional stamp of a hoof, Pevara schooling herself to patience, Javindhra grumbling under her breath. Pevara could not make out the words, but she knew grumbling when she heard it. Tarna and Jezrail took books from their saddlebags and read. Good. Let these Asha'man see that they were unconcerned. Only, not even the boy seemed impressed. He and the Saldaean just stood there in the middle of the gate watching, hardly blinking.

æftɝ pɝhæps hæf ən aʊɝ, ə lɑɹdʒɝ ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən ən ðə mʊɹændiən stʃɹoʊd θɹu. "ðə l wɪl bi ɹəsivɪŋ jə ət ðə pæləs, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɡoʊ ɑn θɹu." hi dʒɝkt ɪz hɛd təwɔɹd ði oʊpənɪŋ.

After perhaps half an hour, a larger gateway opened and the Murandian strode through. "The M'Hael will be receiving you at the palace, Aes Sedai. Go on through." He jerked his head toward the opening.

"ju wɪl ʃoʊ əs ðə weɪ?" pɛvɑɹə sɛd, dɪsmaʊntɪŋ. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz lɑɹdʒɝ, bʌt ʃi wʊɾə hæd tə kɹaʊtʃ tə ɹaɪd θɹu.

"You will show us the way?" Pevara said, dismounting. The gateway was larger, but she would have had to crouch to ride through.

"ðɛɹəl bi sʌmwʌn ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd tə ɡaɪd ju." hi bɑɹkt ə læf. "ðə l dʌzn əsoʊsiət wɪð ðə laɪks ə mi." pɛvɑɹə faɪl ðəɾ əweɪ tə tʃu oʊvɝ leɪɾɝ.

"There'll be someone on the other side to guide you." He barked a laugh. "The M'Hael doesn't associate with the likes of me." Pevara filed that away to chew over later.

əz sun əz ðə læst ə ðɛm wɑz θɹu, nɪɹ ðə waɪt stoʊn plætfɔɹm wɪð ɪts mɪɹɝ-bɹaɪt blæk stoʊn, ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪŋkt ʃʌt, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ əloʊn. fɔɹ mɛn ən tu wɪmən ɪn ɹʌf wʊlənz tʊk ðə ɹeɪnz ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ən ə dɑɹk, hɛvisɛt mæn wɪð boʊθ ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹɾ ən ə sɪnwəs ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl fɪɡjɝ, ə dʒɹæɡən, ɑn ɪz tɔl blæk kɑlɝ ɡeɪv əm ə mɪnəməl baʊ.

As soon as the last of them was through, near the white stone platform with its mirror-bright black stone, the gateway winked shut, but they were not alone. Four men and two women in rough woolens took the reins of their horses, and a dark, heavyset man with both the silver sword and a sinuous red-and-gold figure, a dragon, on his tall black collar gave them a minimal bow.

"fɑloʊ mi," hi sɛd kɝtli ɪn ə tɛɹən æksɛnt. hɪz aɪz wɝ laɪk ɔɡɝz.

"Follow me," he said curtly in a Tairen accent. His eyes were like augers.

ðə pæləs ðə mʊɹændiən hæd spoʊkən ʌv wɑz dʒʌs ðæt, tu stɔɹiz ʌv waɪt mɑɹbəl tɑpt wɪð pɔɪntəd doʊmz ən spaɪɹz ɪn ðə staɪl ə sɑldɑiə, sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm ə lɑɹdʒ speɪs ə bɛɹ, hɑɹd-pækt ɡɹaʊn baɪ ðə waɪt plætfɔɹm. ɪt wɑz nɑt lɑɹdʒ əmʌŋ pæləsəz, bʌt moʊs noʊbəlz lɪvd ɪn bɪldɪŋz fɑɹ smɔlɝ ən lɛs ɡɹænd. bɹɔd stoʊn stɛɹz ɹoʊz tə ə waɪd lændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə tɔl twɪn dɔɹz. itʃ bɔɹ ə ɡɔntələɾəd fɪst ɡɹɪpɪŋ θɹi laɪtnɪŋ boʊls, kɑɹv lɑɹdʒ ən ɡɪldɪd. ðoʊz dɔɹz swʌŋ oʊpən bɪfɔɹ ðə tɛɹən ɹitʃt ðɛm, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ noʊ sɝvəns ɪn ɛvəɾəns. ðə mæn mʌst əv tʃænəld. pɛvɑɹə fɛl ðət tʃɪl əɡɛn. dʒəvɪnʒɹə mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. wɪð ə saʊn ə pɹɛɹ, ðɪs taɪm.

The palace the Murandian had spoken of was just that, two stories of white marble topped with pointed domes and spires in the style of Saldaea, separated from a large space of bare, hard-packed ground by the white platform. It was not large among palaces, but most nobles lived in buildings far smaller and less grand. Broad stone stairs rose to a wide landing in front of tall twinned doors. Each bore a gauntleted fist gripping three lightning bolts, carved large and gilded. Those doors swung open before the Tairen reached them, but there were no servants in evidence. The man must have channeled. Pevara felt that chill again. Javindhra muttered under her breath. With a sound of prayer, this time.

ðə pæləs maɪɾ əv bɪlɔŋ tə ɛni noʊbəl wɪð ə teɪs fəɹ tæpəstʃɹiz ʃoʊɪŋ bæɾəlz ən ɹɛd-ænd-blæk flɔɹ taɪlz, ɪksɛp ðət ðəɹ wɝ noʊ sɝvəns ɪn ɛvəɾəns. hi hæd sɝvəns, ðoʊ ənfɔɹtʃənətli noʊ ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz əmʌŋ ðɛm, bʌt dɪɾ i ɪkspɛkt əm tə ɹɪmeɪn aʊɾ ə saɪt wən nɑt niɾəd əɹ hæɾ i ɔɹɾɝd əm fɹəm ðə hɔlz? pɝhæps tə əvɔɪd hævɪŋ ɛniwʌn si sɪks ɛɛs sədaɪ ɝaɪv. ðət laɪn ə ɹizənɪŋ ɹæn təwɔɹd θɔts ʃi wəd ɹæðɝ nɑt kənsɪɾɝ. ʃi hæɾ æknɑlɪdʒ ðə deɪnʒɝz bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn dwɛlɪŋ ɑn ðɛm.

The palace might have belonged to any noble with a taste for tapestries showing battles and red-and-black floor tiles, except that there were no servants in evidence. He had servants, though unfortunately no Red Ajah eyes-and-ears among them, but did he expect them to remain out of sight when not needed or had he ordered them from the halls? Perhaps to avoid having anyone see six Aes Sedai arrive. That line of reasoning ran toward thoughts she would rather not consider. She had acknowledged the dangers before leaving the White Tower. There was no point dwelling on them.

ðə tʃeɪmbɝ ðə tɛɹən lɛɾ əm tə wɑz ə θɹoʊn ɹum, wɛɹ ə ɹɪŋ ə spaɪɹəl-kʌt blæk kɑləmz səpɔɹɾəd wʌt mʌst əv bɪn ðə pæləsəz lɑɹdʒəs doʊm, ɪts ɪntɪɹiɝ leɪɝd wɪð ɡɪlt ən hæf fɪld wɪð ɡɪldɪd læmps hæŋɪŋ ɑn ɡɪldɪd tʃeɪnz. tɔl mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps stʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə kɝvd wɔlz, tu. pɝhæps ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ɪn blæk koʊts wɝ stændɪŋ tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum. ɛvɹi mæn ʃi kəd si wɔɹ ðə sɔɹɾ ən ðə dʒɹæɡən, mɛn wɪð hɑɹd feɪsəz, lɪɹɪŋ feɪsəz, kɹuəl feɪsəz. ðɛɹ aɪz foʊkəst ɑn əɹ ən ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz.

The chamber the Tairen led them to was a throne room, where a ring of spiral-cut black columns supported what must have been the palace's largest dome, its interior layered with gilt and half filled with gilded lamps hanging on gilded chains. Tall mirrored stand-lamps stood along the curved walls, too. Perhaps a hundred men in black coats were standing to either side of the room. Every man she could see wore the sword and the dragon, men with hard faces, leering faces, cruel faces. Their eyes focused on her and the other sisters.

ðə tɛɹən dɪd nɑɾ ənaʊns ðɛm, bʌt ɹæðɝ sɪmpli dʒɔɪn ðə mæs ʌv æʃəmən ən lɛft əm tə meɪk ðɛɹ oʊn weɪ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum. ðə flɔɹ taɪlz wɝ ɹɛɾ ən blæk hɪɹ, tu. teɪm mʌs pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli laɪk ðoʊz kʌlɝz. ðə mæn hɪmsɛlf wɑz laʊnʒɪŋ ɑn wʌt kəɾ oʊnli bi kɔld ə θɹoʊn, ə mæsɪv tʃɛɹ əz hɛvəli kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪɾ əz ɛni θɹoʊn ʃi hæd sin, ətɑp ə waɪt mɑɹbəl deɪz. pɛvɑɹə foʊkəst ɑn hɪm, ən nɑɾ oʊnli tə əvɔɪd filɪŋ ɔl ðoʊz aɪz ə mɛn u kəd tʃænəl fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ. mæzɹim teɪm dʒɹu ði aɪ. hi wɑz tɔl, wɪð ə stʃɹɔŋli hʊk noʊz ən ən ɛɹ ə fɪzɪkəl stʃɹɛŋkθ əbaʊt hɪm. ən ɛɹ ə dɑɹknəs, tu. hi sæt ðəɹ wɪð ɪz æŋkəlz kɹɔst ən wʌn ɑɹm hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə hɛvi ɑɹm ə ðə θɹoʊn, jɛɾ i simd ɹɛɾi tə ɪksploʊɾ ɪndə vaɪələns. ɪntɝɛstɪŋli, ðoʊ hɪz blæk koʊt wɑz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð blu-ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡənz ðət twaɪn ɝaʊn ðə slivz fɹəm ɛlboʊz tə kʌfs, hi dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ðə kɑlɝ pɪnz.

The Tairen did not announce them, but rather simply joined the mass of Asha'man and left them to make their own way across the room. The floor tiles were red and black here, too. Taim must particularly like those colors. The man himself was lounging on what could only be called a throne, a massive chair as heavily carved and gilded as any throne she had seen, atop a white marble dais. Pevara focused on him, and not only to avoid feeling all those eyes of men who could channel following her. Mazrim Taim drew the eye. He was tall, with a strongly hooked nose and an air of physical strength about him. An air of darkness, too. He sat there with his ankles crossed and one arm hanging over the heavy arm of the throne, yet he seemed ready to explode into violence. Interestingly, though his black coat was embroidered with blue-and-gold dragons that twined around the sleeves from elbows to cuffs, he did not wear the collar pins.

"sɪks sɪstɝz ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ," hi sɛd wən ðeɪ stɑpt ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə deɪz. hɪz aɪz. . . . ʃi hæɾ oʊnli θɔt ðə tɛɹənz aɪz wɝ ɔɡɝz. "pleɪnli jə dɪdn kʌm tə tʃɹaɪ dʒɛntəlɪŋ əs ɔl." tʃʌkəlz ɹɪpəld ɝaʊn ðə ɹum. "waɪ dɪd jə kʌm æskɪŋ tə spik tə mi?"

"Six sisters of the Red Ajah," he said when they stopped short of the dais. His eyes. . . . She had only thought the Tairen's eyes were augers. "Plainly you didn't come to try gentling us all." Chuckles rippled around the room. "Why did you come asking to speak to me?"

"aɪ æm pɛvɑɹə təzɑnɑvni, sɪɾɝ fəɹ ðə ɹɛd," ʃi sɛd. "ðɪs ɪz dʒəvɪnʒɹə dɝeɪl, ɔlsoʊ ə ɹɛd sɪɾɝ. ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ tɑɹnə fiɹ, disɑlə nɛvæntʃ - "

"I am Pevara Tazanovni, Sitter for the Red," she said. "This is Javindhra Doraille, also a Red Sitter. The others are Tarna Feir, Desala Nevanche - "

"aɪ dɪdn æsk jəɹ neɪmz," teɪm kʌɾ ɪn koʊldli. "aɪ æskt waɪ jə keɪm hɪɹ."

"I didn't ask your names," Taim cut in coldly. "I asked why you came here."

ðɪs wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ wɛl. ʃi mænədʒ nɑt tə teɪk ə dip bɹɛθ, bʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə. aʊtwɝdli, ʃi wɑz kul ən kɑm. ɪnsaɪd, ʃi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi wəɾ ɛn ðə deɪ fɔɹsəbli bɑndəd. əɹ dɛd. "wi wɑnə dɪskʌs bɑndɪŋ æʃəmən əz wɔɹɾɝz. æftɝ ɔl, juv bɑndəd fɪfti-wʌn sɪstɝz. əɡɛns ðɛɹ wɪl." əz wɛl tə lɛɾ ɪm noʊ ðeɪ wɝ əwɛɹ ə ðət fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. "wi də nɑt pɹəpoʊz bɑndɪŋ ɛni mæn əɡɛnst ɪz wɪl, haʊɛvɝ."

This was not going well. She managed not to take a deep breath, but she wanted to. Outwardly, she was cool and calm. Inside, she wondered whether she would end the day forcibly bonded. Or dead. "We want to discuss bonding Asha'man as Warders. After all, you've bonded fifty-one sisters. Against their will." As well to let him know they were aware of that from the start. "We do not propose bonding any man against his will, however."

ə tɔl, ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd mæn stændɪŋ nɪɹ ðə deɪz snɪɹɾ ət hɝ. "waɪ ʃəd wi əlaʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə teɪk ɛni ɛm - " sʌmθɪŋ ənsin stʃɹʌk ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz hɛd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪz fit lɛf ðə flɔɹ taɪlz bɪfɔɹ i fɛl ɪn ə hip, aɪz kloʊzd ən blʌd tʃɹɪklɪŋ fɹəm ɪz nɑstʃɹəlz.

A tall, golden-haired man standing near the dais sneered at her. "Why should we allow Aes Sedai to take any m - " Something unseen struck the side of his head so hard that his feet left the floor tiles before he fell in a heap, eyes closed and blood trickling from his nostrils.

ə lin mæn wɪð ɹɪsiɾɪŋ ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik hɛɹ ən ə fɔɹk bɪɹd bɛn tə tʌtʃ ə fɪŋɡɝ tə ðə fɔlən mænz hɛd. "hiz əlaɪv," hi sɛɾ əz i stʃɹeɪɾənd, "bʌɾ ɪz skʌlz kɹækt ən ɪz dʒɔz bɹoʊkən." hi maɪɾ əv bɪn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə wɛðɝ. nʌn ə ðə mɛn meɪɾ ɛni muv tə ɔfɝ hilɪŋ. nɑt wʌn!

A lean man with receding gray-streaked hair and a forked beard bent to touch a finger to the fallen man's head. "He's alive," he said as he straightened, "but his skull's cracked and his jaw's broken." He might have been talking about the weather. None of the men made any move to offer Healing. Not one!

"aɪ hæv səm smɔl skɪl ɪn hilɪŋ," mɛlɛɹ sɛd, ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts ən ɔlɹɛɾi muvɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə fɔlən mæn. "ɪnʌf fəɹ ðɪs, aɪ θɪŋk. wɪð jəɹ pɝmɪʃən."

"I have some small skill in Healing," Melare said, gathering her skirts and already moving toward the fallen man. "Enough for this, I think. With your permission."

teɪm ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ju də nɑɾ əv maɪ pɝmɪʃən. ɪf mɪʃɹeɪl sɝvaɪvz tɪl naɪtfɔl, hɪl bi hild. pɝhæps ðə peɪn wɪl titʃ ɪm tə ɡɑɹɾ ɪz tʌŋ. jə seɪ jə wɑnə bɑnd wɔɹɾɝz? ɹɛdz?"

Taim shook his head. "You do not have my permission. If Mishraile survives till nightfall, he'll be Healed. Perhaps the pain will teach him to guard his tongue. You say you want to bond Warders? Reds?"

ðət læst wɝd kæɹiɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə kəntɛmpt, wɪtʃ pɛvɑɹə tʃoʊz tə ɪɡnɔɹ. tɑɹnəz aɪz cʊɾə tɝn ðə sʌn tə ən aɪsɪkəl, ðoʊ. pɛvɑɹə leɪɾ ə kɔʃənɛɹi hæn ɑn ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz ɑɹm əz ʃi spoʊk. "ɹɛdz əv ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð mɛn u kən tʃænəl." mʌɾɝz ɹoʊz əmʌŋ ðə wɑtʃɪŋ æʃəmən. æŋɡɹi mʌɾɝz. ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd ðæt, tu. "wi ɑɹ nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ə ðɛm. kʌstəm kən bi əz hɑɹd tə tʃeɪnʒ əz lɔ, hɑɹɾɝ ət taɪmz, bʌɾ ɪts bɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃeɪnʒ aʊɝz. hɛnsfɔɹθ, ɹɛd sɪstɝz meɪ bɑnd wɔɹɾɝz, bʌɾ oʊnli mɛn u kən tʃænəl. itʃ sɪstɝ meɪ bɑn əz mɛni əz ʃi filz kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð. ɡɪvən ðə ɡɹin, fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪz ənlaɪkli tə bi mɔɹ ðən θɹi əɹ fɔɹ."

That last word carried a great deal of contempt, which Pevara chose to ignore. Tarna's eyes could have turned the sun to an icicle, though. Pevara laid a cautionary hand on the other woman's arm as she spoke. "Reds have experience with men who can channel." Mutters rose among the watching Asha'man. Angry mutters. She ignored that, too. "We are not afraid of them. Custom can be as hard to change as law, harder at times, but it has been decided to change ours. Henceforth, Red sisters may bond Warders, but only men who can channel. Each sister may bond as many as she feels comfortable with. Given the Green, for example, I think that is unlikely to be more than three or four."

"vɛɹi wɛl."

"Very well."

pɛvɑɹə blɪŋkt ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. " 'vɛɹi wɛl'?" ʃi mʌst əv mɪsəndɝstʊd hɪm. hi kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn kənvɪnst soʊ izəli.

Pevara blinked in spite of herself. " 'Very well'?" She must have misunderstood him. He could not have been convinced so easily.

teɪmz aɪz sim tə bɔɹ ɪndə hɝ hɛd. hi spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz, ən ɪt wɑz ə mɑkɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝ. "wʌt wəd juv mi seɪ? fɛɹ ɪz fɛɹ? ikwəl ʃɛɹz? æksɛpt 'vɛɹi wɛl' ən æsk u wɪl lɛt jə bɑn ðɛm. bɪsaɪdz, jə mʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ ði oʊl seɪɪŋ. lɛt ðə lɔɹɾ ə keɪɑs ɹul." ðə tʃeɪmbɝ ɪɹʌptəd wɪð mɛnz læftɝ.

Taim's eyes seemed to bore into her head. He spread his hands, and it was a mocking gesture. "What would you have me say? Fair is fair? Equal shares? Accept 'very well' and ask who will let you bond them. Besides, you must remember the old saying. Let the lord of chaos rule." The chamber erupted with men's laughter.

pɛvɑɹə hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ɛni seɪɪŋ laɪk ðæt. ðə læftɝ meɪd ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɝ nɛk tʃɹaɪ tə stænd.

Pevara had never heard any saying like that. The laughter made the hair on the back of her neck try to stand.

ði ɛn ə ði ɪlɛvənθ bʊk ə ðə wil ə taɪm ɡlɔsɝi eɪ noʊɾ ɑn deɪts ɪn ðɪs ɡlɔsɝi. ðə toʊmən kæləndɝ (dɪvaɪz baɪ toʊmə dɝ ɑməd) wɑz ədɑptəɾ əpɹɑksəmətli tu sɛntʃɝiz æftɝ ðə dɛθ ə ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld (æb). soʊ mɛni ɹɛkɝdz wɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz ðəɾ ət ðɛɹ ɛn ðəɹ wɑz ɑɹɡjəmən əbaʊt ði ɪɡzæk jɪɹ ʌndɝ ði oʊl sɪstəm. ə nu kæləndɝ, pɹəpoʊz baɪ tiəm ʌv ɡɑzɹ, sɛləbɹeɪɾəd fɹiɾəm fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk θɹɛɾ ən ɹəkɔɹɾəd itʃ jɪɹ əz ə fɹi jɪɹ (fi). ðə ɡɑzɝən kæləndɝ ɡeɪnd waɪɾ æksɛptəns wɪðɪn twɛnti jɪɹz æftɝ ðə wɔɹz' ɛnd. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ətɛmptəd tə ɪstæblɪʃ ə nu kæləndɝ beɪst ɑn ðə faʊndɪŋ ə hɪz ɛmpaɪɝ (, fɹəm ðə faʊndɪŋ), bʌɾ oʊnli hɪstɔɹiənz naʊ ɹəfɝ tə ɪt. æftɝ ðə dɛθ ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ə θɝd kæləndɝ wɑz dɪvaɪz baɪ ɝɛn dɪn dʒubaɪ sɔɹɪŋ ɡʌl, ə skɑlɝ ə ðə si foʊk, ən pɹɑməlɡeɪɾəd baɪ ðə pɑnɑɹtʃ fɛɹiɾ ə tæɹɑbən. ðə fɛɹid kæləndɝ, deɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ði ɑɹbɪtʃɹɛɹəli dɪsaɪɾɪd ɛn ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ən ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz ə ðə nu ɛɹə (nəbɹæskə), ɪz kɝənli ɪn jus.

The End of the Eleventh Book of The Wheel of Time GLOSSARY A Note on Dates in This Glossary. The Toman Calendar (devised by Toma dur Ahmid) was adopted approximately two centuries after the death of the last male Aes Sedai, recording years After the Breaking of the World (AB). So many records were destroyed in the Trolloc Wars that at their end there was argument about the exact year under the old system. A new calendar, proposed by Tiam of Gazar, celebrated freedom from the Trolloc threat and recorded each year as a Free Year (FY). The Gazaran Calendar gained wide acceptance within twenty years after the Wars' end. Artur Hawkwing attempted to establish a new calendar based on the founding of his empire (FF, From the Founding), but only historians now refer to it. After the death and destruction of the War of the Hundred Years, a third calendar was devised by Uren din Jubai Soaring Gull, a scholar of the Sea Folk, and promulgated by the Panarch Farede of Tarabon. The Farede Calendar, dating from the arbitrarily decided end of the War of the Hundred Years and recording years of the New Era (NE), is currently in use.

æɛlfɪn: ə ɹeɪs ə biɪŋz, lɑɹdʒli hjumən ɪn əpɪɹəns bʌt wɪð sneɪk-laɪk kɛɹəktɝɪstɪks, hu wɪl ɡɪv tʃɹu ænsɝz tə θɹi kwɛstʃənz. wʌtɛvɝ ðə kwɛstʃən, ðɛɹ ænsɝz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz kɝɛkt, ɪf fɹikwənli ɡɪvən ɪn fɔɹmz ðəɾ ɑɹ nɑt klɪɹ, bʌt kwɛstʃənz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə ʃædoʊ kən bi ɪkstʃɹimli deɪnʒɝəs. ðɛɹ tʃɹu loʊkeɪʃən ɪz ənnoʊn, bʌt ðeɪ kən bi vɪzəɾəd baɪ pæsɪŋ θɹu ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, wʌns ə pəzɛʃən ə min bʌɾ ɪn ɹisən jɪɹz hɛld ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɹɪpɔɹts ðət ðeɪ kən ɔlsoʊ bi ɹitʃt baɪ ɛntɝɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ. ðeɪ spik ði oʊl tʌŋ, mɛnʃən tʃɹiɾiz ən əɡɹiməns, ən æsk ɪf ðoʊz ɛntɝɪŋ kæɹi aɪɝn, ɪnstʃɹəməns ə mjuzɪk əɹ dɪvaɪsəz ðət kən meɪk faɪɝ. si ɔlsoʊ ɛlfɪn.

Aelfinn: A race of beings, largely human in appearance but with snake-like characteristics, who will give true answers to three questions. Whatever the question, their answers are always correct, if frequently given in forms that are not clear, but questions concerning the Shadow can be extremely dangerous. Their true location is unknown, but they can be visited by passing through a ter'angreal, once a possession of Mayene but in recent years held in the Stone of Tear. There are reports that they can also be reached by entering the Tower of Ghenjei. They speak the Old Tongue, mention treaties and agreements, and ask if those entering carry iron, instruments of music or devices that can make fire. See also Eelfinn.

æmɑjɹ, ðə: ðə lænd-dwɛlɪŋ ɪnhæbəɾənts ə ðə si foʊk aɪlənz. noʊn tə fju pipəl ʌðɝ ðən ði æθɑn maɪɹ, ði æmɑjɹ ɑɹ ðə kɹæfsmən u meɪk wʌɾ ɪz noʊn əz si foʊk pɔɹsələn. fɑloʊɝz ə ðə wɔɾɝ weɪ, wɪtʃ pɹaɪzəz æksɛptəns ʌv wʌɾ ɪz ɹæðɝ ðən wʌt maɪt bi wɪʃt fɔɹ, ðeɪ ɑɹ vɛɹi ənkʌmftəɹbəl ət si ən oʊnli vɛntʃɝ ɑntu ðə wɔɾɝ ɪn smɔl boʊts fəɹ fɪʃɪŋ, nɛvɝ livɪŋ saɪɾ ə lænd. ðɛɹ weɪ ʌv laɪf ɪz vɛɹi pisfəl, ən ɹikwaɪɝz vɛɹi lɪɾəl oʊvɝsaɪt fɹəm ðə ɡʌvɝnɝz əpɔɪntəd fɹəm əmʌŋ ði æθɑn maɪɹ. sɪns æθɑn maɪɹ ɡʌvɝnɝz əv lɪɾəl dɪzaɪɝ tə ɡoʊ fɑɹ fɹəm ðə si, ði æmɑjɹ ɪsɛnʃəli ɹʌn ðɛɹ vɪlədʒəz əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðɛɹ oʊn ɹulz ən kʌstəmz.

Amayar, the: The land-dwelling inhabitants of the Sea Folk islands. Known to few people other than the Atha'an Miere, the Amayar are the craftsmen who make what is known as Sea Folk porcelain. Followers of the Water Way, which prizes acceptance of what is rather than what might be wished for, they are very uncomfortable at sea and only venture onto the water in small boats for fishing, never leaving sight of land. Their way of life is very peaceful, and requires very little oversight from the governors appointed from among the Atha'an Miere. Since Atha'an Miere governors have little desire to go far from the sea, the Amayar essentially run their villages according to their own rules and customs.

ɑɹæd dumən: ə neɪʃən ɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, kɝənli ɹæk baɪ sɪvəl wɔɹ ən baɪ wɔɹz əɡɛns ðoʊz u hæv dɪklɛɹd fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪts kæpəɾəl ɪz bændɑɹ ɛbən. ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, ðoʊz u ɑɹ dɪsɛndəd fɹəm ðə noʊbɪləɾi ət ðə taɪm ə ðə faʊndɪŋ ə ðə neɪʃən, əz əpoʊz tə ðoʊz ɹeɪz leɪɾɝ, ɑɹ noʊn əz ðə blʌdbɔɹn. ðə ɹulɝ (kɪŋ əɹ kwin) ɪz ɪlɛktəd baɪ ə kaʊnsəl ə ðə hɛdz ə mɝtʃənt ɡɪlz (ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns), hu ɑɹ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz wɪmən. hi əɹ ʃi mʌs bi fɹəm ðə noʊbəl klæs, nɑt ðə mɝtʃənt, ən ɪz ɪlɛktəd fəɹ laɪf. liɡəli ðə kɪŋ əɹ kwin əz æbsəluɾ əθɔɹəɾi, ɪksɛp ðəɾ i əɹ ʃi kən bi dɪpoʊz baɪ ə θɹi-kɔɹɾɝ voʊɾ ə ðə kaʊnsəl. ðə kɝən ɹulɝ ɪz kɪŋ ælsələm sɑiɾ ælməɾɝ, lɔɹɾ ʌv ælməɾɝ, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs ælməɾɝ. hɪz pɹɛzənt wɛɹəbaʊts ɑɹ mʌtʃ ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn mɪstɝi.

Arad Doman: A nation on the Aryth Ocean, currently racked by civil war and by wars against those who have declared for the Dragon Reborn. Its capital is Bandar Eban. In Arad Doman, those who are descended from the nobility at the time of the founding of the nation, as opposed to those raised later, are known as the bloodborn. The ruler (king or queen) is elected by a council of the heads of merchant guilds (the Council of Merchants), who are almost always women. He or she must be from the noble class, not the merchant, and is elected for life. Legally the king or queen has absolute authority, except that he or she can be deposed by a three-quarter vote of the Council. The current ruler is King Alsalam Saeed Almadar, Lord of Almadar, High Seat of House Almadar. His present whereabouts are much shrouded in mystery.

ɛɹiə, junəts ʌv: (wʌn) lænd: wʌn ɹɪbən ikwəlz twɛnti peɪsɪz  tɛn peɪsɪz (tuhʌnʒɹəd skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); wʌn kɔɹɾ ikwəlz twɛnti peɪsɪz  fɪfti peɪsɪz (wʌnθaʊzən skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); wʌn haɪɾ ikwəlz wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz  wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz (tɛnθaʊzən skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); wʌn ɹoʊp ikwəlz wʌnhʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz  wʌnθaʊzən peɪsɪz (wʌnhʌnʒɹədθaʊzənd skwɛɹ peɪsɪz); fɝs mɑɹtʃ ikwəlz wʌnθaʊzən peɪsɪz  wʌnθaʊzən peɪsɪz (wʌnfɔɹθ skwɛɹ maɪl). (tu) klɔθ: wʌn peɪs ikwəlz wʌn peɪs ən wʌn hænd  wʌn peɪs ən wʌn hænd.

area, units of: (1) Land: 1 ribbon = 20 paces  10 paces (200 square paces); 1 cord = 20 paces  50 paces (1000 square paces); 1 hide = 100 paces  100 paces (10,000 square paces); 1 rope = 100 paces  1000 paces (100,000 square paces); 1 march = 1000 paces  1000 paces (1/4 square mile). (2) Cloth: 1 pace = 1 pace and 1 hand  1 pace and 1 hand.

ɑɹmmɪn: soʊlʒɝz u oʊ əlidʒəns əɹ fiəlti tə ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi.

armsmen: Soldiers who owe allegiance or fealty to a particular lord or lady.

æʃəmən: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ɡɑɹɾiən" əɹ "ɡɑɹɾiənz," bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ə ɡɑɹɾiən ə dʒʌstəs ən tʃɹuθ. (tu) ðə neɪm ɡɪvən, boʊθ kəlɛktɪvli ən əz ə ɹæŋk, tə ðə mɛn u hæv kʌm tə ðə blæk taʊɝ, nɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn ɪn ændɝ, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə lɝn tə tʃænəl. ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ lɑɹdʒli kɑnsəntʃɹeɪts ɑn ðə weɪz ɪn wɪtʃ ðə wʌn paʊɝ kən bi juzd əz ə wɛpən, ən ɪn ənʌðɝ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ fɹəm ðə jusədʒəz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wʌns ðeɪ lɝn tə siz seɪɾɪn, ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹikwaɪɝd tə pɝfɔɹm ɔl tʃɔɹz ən leɪbɝz wɪð ðə paʊɝ. wən nuli ɛnɹoʊld, ə mæn ɪz tɝmd ə soʊlʒɝ; hi wɛɹz ə pleɪn blæk koʊt wɪð ə haɪ kɑlɝ, ɪn ði ændɔɝən fæʃən. biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə dɛɾəkeɪtəd bɹɪŋz ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ ə sɪlvɝ pɪn, kɔl ðə sɔɹd, ɑn ðə kɑlɝ ə hɪz koʊt. pɹəmoʊʃən tə æʃəmən bɹɪŋz ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ ə dʒɹæɡən pɪn, ɪn ɡoʊld ən ɹɛɾ ɪnæməl, ɑn ðə kɑlɝ ɑpəzət ðə sɔɹd. ɔlðoʊ mɛni wɪmən, ɪnkluɾɪŋ waɪvz, fli wən ðeɪ lɝn ðət ðɛɹ mɛn æktʃəli  kən tʃænəl, ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə mɛn ət ðə blæk taʊɝ ɑɹ mɛɹid, ən ðeɪ juz ə vɝʒən ə ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn tə kɹieɪɾ ə lɪŋk wɪð ðɛɹ waɪvz. ðɪs seɪm bɑnd, ɔltɝd tə kəmpɛl oʊbiɾiəns, hæz ɹisənli bɪn juz tə bɑn kæptʃɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ əz wɛl. səm æʃəmən əv bɪn bɑndəd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔlðoʊ ðə tʃɹədɪʃənəl wɔɹɾɝ bɑn ɪz juzd. ði æʃəmən ɑɹ lɛd baɪ mæzɹim teɪm, hu hæz staɪl hɪmsɛlf ðə l, oʊl tʌŋ fəɹ "liɾɝ."

Asha'man: (1) In the Old Tongue, "Guardian" or "Guardians," but always a guardian of justice and truth. (2) The name given, both collectively and as a rank, to the men who have come to the Black Tower, near Caemlyn in Andor, in order to learn to channel. Their training largely concentrates on the ways in which the One Power can be used as a weapon, and in another departure from the usages of the White Tower, once they learn to seize saidin, the male half of the Power, they are required to perform all chores and labors with the Power. When newly enrolled, a man is termed a Soldier; he wears a plain black coat with a high collar, in the Andoran fashion. Being raised to Dedicated brings the right to wear a silver pin, called the Sword, on the collar of his coat. Promotion to Asha'man brings the right to wear a Dragon pin, in gold and red enamel, on the collar opposite the Sword. Although many women, including wives, flee when they learn that their men actually can channel, a fair number of men at the Black Tower are married, and they use a version of the Warder bond to create a link with their wives. This same bond, altered to compel obedience, has recently been used to bond captured Aes Sedai as well. Some Asha'man have been bonded by Aes Sedai, although the traditional Warder bond is used. The Asha'man are led by Mazrim Taim, who has styled himself the M'Hael, Old Tongue for "leader."

beɪlwɝ, sɛbæn: fɔɹmɝli sɛkɹətɛɹi tə peɪdʒɹən naɪl (ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt) ɪn pʌblɪk, ən sikɹɪtli naɪlz spaɪmæstɝ. æftɝ naɪlz dɛθ, beɪlwɝ eɪɾəd ði ɪskeɪp ə mɔɹɡeɪs (wʌns kwin ʌv ændɝ) fɹəm ðə sintʃæn ɪn æmədɔɹ fəɹ ɪz oʊn ɹizənz, ən wɑz ɛmplɔɪɾ əz sɛkɹətɛɹi tə pɛɹɪn tæʃɪɹ eɪbɑɹə ən feɪl ni bæʃɪɹ teɪbɑɹə. hɪz duɾiz ɪkspændəd, haʊɛvɝ, ən i naʊ dɝɛks tʃɑ feɪl ɪn ðɛɹ æktɪvəɾiz, æktɪŋ əz ə spaɪmæstɝ fəɹ pɛɹɪn, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn dʌzn θɪŋk ə hɪm soʊ. si tʃɑ feɪl.

Balwer, Sebban: Formerly secretary to Pedron Niall (the Lord Captain Commander of the Children of the Light) in public, and secretly Niall's spymaster. After Niall's death, Balwer aided the escape of Morgase (once Queen of Andor) from the Seanchan in Amador for his own reasons, and was employed as secretary to Perrin t'Bashere Aybara and Faile ni Bashere t'Aybara. His duties expanded, however, and he now directs Cha Faile in their activities, acting as a spymaster for Perrin, though Perrin doesn't think of him so. See Cha Faile.

bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd: si ʃɛn ən kɑlhɑɹ.

Band of the Red Hand: See Shen an Calhar.

blʌd, ðə: tɝm juz baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə dɛzəɡneɪt ðə noʊbɪləɾi. ðəɹ ɑɹ fɔɹ dɪɡɹiz ə noʊbɪləɾi, tu ʌv ðə haɪ blʌɾ ən tu ʌv ðə loʊ, əɹ lɛsɝ, blʌd. ðə haɪ blʌd lɛt ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ɡɹoʊ tə ə lɛŋθ ʌv wʌn ɪntʃ ən ʃeɪv ðə saɪdz ə ðɛɹ hɛdz, livɪŋ ə kɹɛs daʊn ðə sɛntɝ, nɛɹoʊɝ fəɹ mɛn ðən fəɹ wɪmən. ðə lɛŋθ ə ðɪs kɹɛs vɛɹiz əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə fæʃən. ðə loʊ blʌɾ ɔlsoʊ ɡɹoʊ ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz lɔŋ, bʌt ðeɪ ʃeɪv ðə saɪdz ən bæk ə ðə hɛd livɪŋ wʌɾ əpɪɹz tə bi ə boʊl ə hɛɹ, wɪð ə waɪd teɪl ət ðə bæk əlaʊd tə ɡɹoʊ lɔŋɡɝ, ɔfən tə ðə ʃoʊldɝ fəɹ mɛn əɹ tə ðə weɪs fəɹ wɪmən. ðoʊz ə ðə haɪəs lɛvəl ə ðə haɪ blʌɾ ɑɹ kɔl haɪ leɪɾi əɹ haɪ lɔɹɾ ən lækɝ ðə fɝs tu fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ɑn itʃ hænd. ðoʊz ə ðə nɛks lɛvəl ə ðə haɪ blʌɾ ɑɹ kɔl sɪmpli lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi ən lækɝ oʊnli ðə neɪlz ə ðə fɔɹfɪŋɝz. ðoʊz ə ðə loʊ blʌɾ ɔlsoʊ ɑɹ kɔl sɪmpli leɪɾi əɹ lɔɹd, bʌt ðoʊz ə ðə haɪɝ ɹæŋk lækɝ ðə neɪlz ə ðə læs tu fɪŋɡɝz ɑn itʃ hænd, waɪl ðoʊz ɑn ðə loʊəs lɛvəl lækɝ oʊnli ðə neɪlz ə ðə lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝz. ði ɛmpɹɛs ən ɪmiɾiət mɛmbɝz ə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli ʃeɪv ðɛɹ hɛdz ɪntaɪɝli ən lækɝ ɔl ə ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz. wʌn kən bi ɹeɪz tə ðə blʌɾ əz wɛl əz bɔɹn tə ɪt, ən ðɪs ɪz fɹikwənli ə ɹɪwɔɹd fəɹ aʊtstændɪŋ əkɑmplɪʃmən əɹ sɝvəs tə ði ɛmpaɪɝ.

Blood, the: Term used by the Seanchan to designate the nobility. There are four degrees of nobility, two of the High Blood and two of the low, or lesser, Blood. The High Blood let their fingernails grow to a length of one inch and shave the sides of their heads, leaving a crest down the center, narrower for men than for women. The length of this crest varies according to fashion. The low Blood also grow their fingernails long, but they shave the sides and back of the head leaving what appears to be a bowl of hair, with a wide tail at the back allowed to grow longer, often to the shoulder for men or to the waist for women. Those of the highest level of the High Blood are called High Lady or High Lord and lacquer the first two fingernails on each hand. Those of the next level of the High Blood are called simply Lord or Lady and lacquer only the nails of the forefingers. Those of the low Blood also are called simply Lady or Lord, but those of the higher rank lacquer the nails of the last two fingers on each hand, while those on the lowest level lacquer only the nails of the little fingers. The Empress and immediate members of the Imperial family shave their heads entirely and lacquer all of their fingernails. One can be raised to the Blood as well as born to it, and this is frequently a reward for outstanding accomplishment or service to the Empire.

kæləndɝ: ðəɹ ɑɹ tɛn deɪz tə ðə wik, twɛntieɪt deɪz tə ðə mʌnθ ən θɝtin mʌnθs tə ðə jɪɹ. sɛvɹəl fis deɪz ɑɹ nɑt pɑɹɾ ʌv ɛni mʌnθ; ðiz ɪnklud sʌndeɪ (ðə lɔŋɡəs deɪ ʌv ðə jɪɹ), ðə fist ə θæŋksɡɪvɪŋ (wʌns ɛvɹi fɔɹ jɪɹz ət ðə spɹɪŋ ikwənɑks) ən ðə fist ʌv ɔl soʊlz sælveɪʃən, ɔlsoʊ kɔld ɔl soʊlz deɪ (wʌns ɛvɹi tɛn jɪɹz ət ði ɔɾəm ikwənɑks). waɪl ðə mʌnθs əv neɪmz - teɪʃəm, dʒumɑɹə, seɪbən, eɪn, ədɑɹ, sævən, ɑmɑdeɪn, tæməz, meɪaɪɡdəl, kɔɹən, ʃɔldin, nɛzæn ən dænu - ðiz ɑɹ sɛldəm juzd ɪksɛpt ɪn əfɪʃəl dɑkjəməns ən baɪ əfɪʃəlz. fəɹ moʊs pipəl, juzɪŋ ðə sizənz ɪz ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf.

calendar: There are 10 days to the week, 28 days to the month and 13 months to the year. Several feast days are not part of any month; these include Sunday (the longest day of the year), the Feast of Thanksgiving (once every four years at the spring equinox) and the Feast of All Souls Salvation, also called All Souls Day (once every ten years at the autumn equinox). While the months have names - Taisham, Jumara, Saban, Aine, Adar, Saven, Amadaine, Tammaz, Maigdhal, Choren, Shaldine, Nesan and Danu - these are seldom used except in official documents and by officials. For most people, using the seasons is good enough.

kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl: (wʌn) ðə mɪlətɛɹi ɹæŋk ə ðə liɾɝ ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑilaɪən. (tu) ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, ðoʊ noʊn oʊnli tə mɛmbɝz ə ðə ɡɹin. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ ædlɔɹnə bæstin ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ən maɪɹɛl bɛɹɛŋɡɑɹi əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ kəntɪnʒənt ʌndɝ ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ. (θɹi) eɪ sintʃæn ɹæŋk, ðə haɪəst ɪn ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi ɪksɛp fəɹ mɑɹʃəl-dʒɛnɝəl, wɪtʃ ɪz ə tɛmpɝɛɹi ɹæŋk səmtaɪmz ɡɪvən tə ə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl pʊɾ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ʌv ə wɔɹ.

Captain-General: (1) The military rank of the leader of the Queen's Guard. This position is currently held by Lady Birgitte Trahelion. (2) The title given to the head of the Green Ajah, though known only to members of the Green. This position is currently held by Adelorna Bastine in the Tower, and Myrelle Berengari among the rebel Aes Sedai contingent under Egwene al'Vere. (3) A Seanchan rank, the highest in the Ever Victorious Army except for Marshal-General, which is a temporary rank sometimes given to a Captain-General put in charge of a war.

tʃɑ feɪl: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə fælkənz tælən." (tu) neɪm teɪkən baɪ ðə jʌŋ kɛɹhinɪn ən tɛɹən noʊbəlz, ətɛmptəd fɑloʊɝz ə dʒiɾoʊ, hu hæv swɔɹn fiəlti tə feɪl ni bæʃɪɹ teɪbɑɹə. ɪn sikɹət, ðeɪ ækt əz əɹ pɝsənəl skaʊts ən spaɪz. sɪns əɹ kæptʃɝ baɪ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ðeɪ kəntɪnju ðɛɹ æktɪvəɾiz ʌndɝ ðə ɡaɪɾəns ə sɛbæn beɪlwɝ.

Cha Faile: (1) In the Old Tongue, "the Falcon's Talon." (2) Name taken by the young Cairhienin and Tairen nobles, attempted followers of ji'e'toh, who have sworn fealty to Faile ni Bashere t'Aybara. In secret, they act as her personal scouts and spies. Since her capture by the Shaido, they continue their activities under the guidance of Sebban Balwer.

tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt: səsaɪəɾi ʌv stʃɹɪkt əsɛɾɪk bɪlifs, oʊɪŋ əlidʒəns tə noʊ neɪʃən ən dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə dɪfiɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ʌv ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz. faʊndəd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz baɪ lɑthɛɹ mæntəlɝ tə pɹɑsələtaɪz əɡɛnst ən ɪnkɹis ɪn dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðeɪ ɪvɑlv dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ɪndə ə kəmplitli mɪlətɛɹi səsaɪəɾi. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɪdʒəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ bɪlifs, ən sɝɾən ðəɾ oʊnli ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ən ðə ɹaɪt. ðeɪ kənsɪɾɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɛni hu səpɔɹɾ əm tə bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz. noʊn dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli əz waɪtkloʊks, ə neɪm ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz dɪspaɪz, ðeɪ wɝ fɔɹmɝli hɛdkɔɹɾɝd ɪn æmədɔɹ, ɑmɑdɪʃiə, bʌt wɝ fɔɹst aʊt wən ðə sintʃæn kɑŋkɝd ðə sɪɾi. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ɑn ə fild ʌv waɪt. si ɔlsoʊ kwɛstʃənɝz.

Children of the Light: Society of strict ascetic beliefs, owing allegiance to no nation and dedicated to the defeat of the Dark One and the destruction of all Darkfriends. Founded during the War of the Hundred Years by Lothair Mantelar to proselytize against an increase in Darkfriends, they evolved during the war into a completely military society. They are extremely rigid in their beliefs, and certain that only they know the truth and the right. They consider Aes Sedai and any who support them to be Darkfriends. Known disparagingly as Whitecloaks, a name they themselves despise, they were formerly headquartered in Amador, Amadicia, but were forced out when the Seanchan conquered the city. Their sign is a golden sunburst on a field of white. See also Questioners.

kɔɝɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə ɹɪtɝn." ðə neɪm ɡɪvən baɪ ðə sintʃæn boʊθ tə ðə fliɾ ə θaʊzənz ə ʃɪps ən tə ðə hʌnʒɹədz ə θaʊzənz ə soʊlʒɝz, kɹæfsmən ən ʌðɝz kæɹid baɪ ðoʊz ʃɪps, hu keɪm bɪhaɪn ðə fɔɹʌnɝz tə ɹikleɪm ðə lænz stoʊlən fɹəm ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz dɪsɛndəns. ðə kɔɝɪn ɪz lɛd baɪ kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl lunəl ɡælɡən. si ɔlsoʊ heɪlin, ɹaɪædʒɛl.

Corenne: In the Old Tongue, "the Return." The name given by the Seanchan both to the fleet of thousands of ships and to the hundreds of thousands of soldiers, craftsmen and others carried by those ships, who came behind the Forerunners to reclaim the lands stolen from Artur Hawkwing's descendants. The Corenne is led by Captain-General Lunal Galgan. See also Hailene, Rhyagelle.

kwəndɪlɝ: ə səpoʊzədli ɪndəstʃɹʌktɪbəl sʌbstəns kɹieɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɛni noʊn fɔɹs juzd ɪn ən ətɛmp tə bɹeɪk ɪt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ɪz əbzɔɹbd, meɪkɪŋ kwəndɪlɝ stʃɹɔŋɝ. ɔlðoʊ ðə meɪkɪŋ ə kwəndɪlɝ wɑz θɔt lɔs fɝɛvɝ, nu ɑbʒɛkts meɪd fɹəm ɪɾ əv sɝfɪst. ɪts ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz hɑɹtstoʊn.

cuendillar: A supposedly indestructible substance created during the Age of Legends. Any known force used in an attempt to break it, including the One Power, is absorbed, making cuendillar stronger. Although the making of cuendillar was thought lost forever, new objects made from it have surfaced. It is also known as heartstone.

kɝənsi: æftɝ mɛni sɛntʃɝiz ə tʃɹeɪd, ðə stændɝd tɝmz fəɹ kɔɪnz ɑɹ ðə seɪm ɪn ɛvɹi lænd: kɹaʊnz (ðə lɑɹdʒəs kɔɪn ɪn saɪz), mɑɹks ən pɛniz. kɹaʊnz ən mɑɹks kən bi mɪntɪɾ ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ, waɪl pɛniz kən bi sɪlvɝ əɹ kɑpɝ, ðə læst ɔfən kɔl sɪmpli ə kɑpɝ. ɪn dɪfɹən lænz, haʊɛvɝ, ðiz kɔɪnz ɑɹ ə dɪfɹən saɪzəz ən weɪts. ivən ɪn wʌn neɪʃən, kɔɪnz ə dɪfɹən saɪzəz ən weɪts əv bɪn mɪntɪd baɪ dɪfɹən ɹulɝz. kəz ə tʃɹeɪd, ðə kɔɪnz ə mɛni neɪʃənz kən bi faʊn ɔlmoʊst ɛniwɛɹ, ən fəɹ ðət ɹizən, bæŋkɝz, mʌnilɛndɝz ən mɝtʃəns ɔl jus skeɪlz tə dətɝmən ðə vælju ʌv ɛni ɡɪvən kɔɪn. ivən lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə kɔɪnz ɑɹ weɪd.

currency: After many centuries of trade, the standard terms for coins are the same in every land: crowns (the largest coin in size), marks and pennies. Crowns and marks can be minted of gold or silver, while pennies can be silver or copper, the last often called simply a copper. In different lands, however, these coins are of different sizes and weights. Even in one nation, coins of different sizes and weights have been minted by different rulers. Because of trade, the coins of many nations can be found almost anywhere, and for that reason, bankers, moneylenders and merchants all use scales to determine the value of any given coin. Even large numbers of coins are weighed.

ðə hɛviəs kɔɪnz kʌm fɹəm ændɝ ən tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ɪn ðoʊz tu pleɪsəz ðə ɹɛləɾɪv væljuz ɑɹ: tɛn kɑpɝ pɛniz ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ pɛni; wʌnhʌnʒɹəd sɪlvɝ pɛniz ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ mɑɹk; tɛn sɪlvɝ mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ kɹaʊn; tɛn sɪlvɝ kɹaʊnz ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl mɑɹk; tɛn ɡoʊl mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl kɹaʊn. baɪ kɑntʃɹæst, ɪn ɔltɑɹə, wɛɹ ðə lɑɹdʒɝ kɔɪnz kənteɪn lɛs ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ, ðə ɹɛləɾɪv væljuz ɑɹ: tɛn kɑpɝ pɛniz ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ pɛni; twɛntiwʌn sɪlvɝ pɛniz ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ mɑɹk; twɛnti sɪlvɝ mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn sɪlvɝ kɹaʊn; twɛnti sɪlvɝ kɹaʊnz ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl mɑɹk; twɛnti ɡoʊl mɑɹks ikwəlz wʌn ɡoʊl kɹaʊn.

The heaviest coins come from Andor and Tar Valon, and in those two places the relative values are: 10 copper pennies = 1 silver penny; 100 silver pennies = 1 silver mark; 10 silver marks = 1 silver crown; 10 silver crowns = 1 gold mark; 10 gold marks = 1 gold crown. By contrast, in Altara, where the larger coins contain less gold or silver, the relative values are: 10 copper pennies = 1 silver penny; 21 silver pennies = 1 silver mark; 20 silver marks = 1 silver crown; 20 silver crowns = 1 gold mark; 20 gold marks = 1 gold crown.

ði oʊnli peɪpɝ kɝənsi ɪz "lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts," wɪtʃ ɑɹ ɪʃud baɪ bæŋkɝz, ɡɛɹəntiɪŋ tə pɹizɛn ə sɝɾən əmaʊn ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ wən ðə lɛɾɝ-ʌv-ɹaɪts ɪz pɹizɛntəd. kəz ə ðə lɔŋ dɪstənsəz bɪtwin sɪɾiz, ðə lɛŋθ ə taɪm niɾəd tə tʃɹævəl fɹəm wʌn tə ənʌðɝ, ən ðə dɪfəkəltiz ə tʃɹænzækʃənz ət lɔŋ dɪstəns, ə lɛɾɝ-ʌv-ɹaɪts meɪ bi æksɛptɪɾ ət fʊl vælju ɪn ə sɪɾi nɪɹ tə ðə bæŋk wɪtʃ ɪʃuɾ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt meɪ bi æksɛptɪɾ oʊnli əɾ ə loʊɝ vælju ɪn ə sɪɾi fɑɹðɝ əweɪ. dʒɛnɝəli, sʌmwʌn ɪntɛndɪŋ tə bi tʃɹævlɪŋ fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm wɪl kæɹi wʌn əɹ mɔɹ lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ fəɹ kɔɪn wən niɾəd. lɛɾɝz-ʌv-ɹaɪts ɑɹ juʒəwəli æksɛptɪɾ oʊnli baɪ bæŋkɝz əɹ mɝtʃəns, ən wəd nɛvɝ bi juzd ɪn ʃɑps.

The only paper currency is "letters-of-rights," which are issued by bankers, guaranteeing to present a certain amount of gold or silver when the letter-of-rights is presented. Because of the long distances between cities, the length of time needed to travel from one to another, and the difficulties of transactions at long distance, a letter-of-rights may be accepted at full value in a city near to the bank which issued it, but it may be accepted only at a lower value in a city farther away. Generally, someone intending to be traveling for a long time will carry one or more letters-of-rights to exchange for coin when needed. Letters-of-rights are usually accepted only by bankers or merchants, and would never be used in shops.

dækoʊvæl: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wʌn u ɪz oʊnd," əɹ "pɝsən u ɪz pɹɑpɝɾi." (tu) əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ðə tɝm ɔfən juzd, əlɔŋ wɪð pɹɑpɝɾi, fəɹ sleɪvz. sleɪvɝi hæz ə lɔŋ ən ənjuʒəwəl hɪstɝi əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, wɪð sleɪvz hævɪŋ ði əbɪləɾi tə ɹaɪz tə pəzɪʃənz ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ ən oʊpən əθɔɹəɾi, ɪnkluɾɪŋ əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ðoʊz u ɑɹ fɹi. ɪts ɔlsoʊ pɑsəbəl fəɹ ðoʊz ɪn pəzɪʃənz ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ tə bi ɹədus tə dækoʊvæl. si ɔlsoʊ sɔɪhɪn.

da'covale: (1) In the Old Tongue, "one who is owned," or "person who is property." (2) Among the Seanchan, the term often used, along with property, for slaves. Slavery has a long and unusual history among the Seanchan, with slaves having the ability to rise to positions of great power and open authority, including authority over those who are free. It is also possible for those in positions of great power to be reduced to da'covale. See also so'jhin.

dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd, ðə: ði ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ə ðə sintʃæn ɛmpaɪɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ boʊθ hjumənz ən oʊɡiɝ. ðə hjumən mɛmbɝz ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹɾ ɑɹ ɔl dækoʊvæl, bɔɹn əz pɹɑpɝɾi ən tʃoʊzən waɪl jʌŋ tə sɝv ði ɛmpɹɛs, huz pɝsənəl pɹɑpɝɾi ðeɪ ɑɹ. fənæɾɪkəli lɔɪəl ən fɪɹsli pɹaʊd, ðeɪ ɔfən dɪspleɪ ðə ɹeɪvənz tætuɾ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ðə mɑɹk ʌv ə dækoʊvæl ə ði ɛmpɹɛs. ði oʊɡiɝ mɛmbɝz ɑɹ noʊn əz ɡɑɹɾənɝz, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt dækoʊvæl. ðə ɡɑɹɾənɝz ɑɹ əz fɪɹsli lɔɪəl əz ðə hjumən dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, ðoʊ, ən ɑɹ ivən mɔɹ fɪɹd. hjumən əɹ oʊɡiɝ, ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz nɑɾ oʊnli ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə daɪ fəɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs ən ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli, bʌt bɪliv ðət ðɛɹ laɪvz ɑɹ ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ði ɛmpɹɛs, tə bi dɪspoʊzd ʌv əz ʃi wɪʃɪz. ðɛɹ hɛlməts ən ɑɹmɝ ɑɹ lækɝɾ ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹin (soʊ dɑɹk ðəɾ ɪts ɔfən mɪsteɪkənli kɔl blæk) ən blʌd-ɹɛd, ðɛɹ ʃilz ɑɹ lækɝd blæk, ən ðɛɹ sɔɹdz, spɪɹz, æksiz ən hælbɝdz kæɹi blæk tæsəlz. si ɔlsoʊ dækoʊvæl.

Deathwatch Guard, the: The elite military formation of the Seanchan Empire, including both humans and Ogier. The human members of the Deathwatch Guard are all da'covale, born as property and chosen while young to serve the Empress, whose personal property they are. Fanatically loyal and fiercely proud, they often display the ravens tattooed on their shoulders, the mark of a da'covale of the Empress. The Ogier members are known as Gardeners, and they are not da'covale. The Gardeners are as fiercely loyal as the human Deathwatch Guards, though, and are even more feared. Human or Ogier, the Deathwatch Guards not only are ready to die for the Empress and the Imperial family, but believe that their lives are the property of the Empress, to be disposed of as she wishes. Their helmets and armor are lacquered in dark green (so dark that it is often mistakenly called black) and blood-red, their shields are lacquered black, and their swords, spears, axes and halberds carry black tassels. See also da'covale.

dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn, ðə: ði ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ə tɛɹ. ðə kɝən kæptən ə ðə stoʊn (kəmændɝ ə ðə dɪfɛndɝz) ɪz ɹɑdʒɹəvɑɹ taɪhɛɹə. oʊnli tɛɹənz ɑɹ æksɛptɪɾ ɪndə ðə dɪfɛndɝz, ən ɔfəsɝz ɑɹ juʒəwəli ʌv noʊbəl bɝθ, ðoʊ ɔfən fɹəm maɪnɝ haʊsəz əɹ maɪnɝ bɹæntʃəz ə stʃɹɔŋ haʊzɪz. ðə dɪfɛndɝz ɑɹ tæsk tə hoʊl ðə ɡɹeɪt fɔɹtʃɹəs kɔl ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ, ɪn ðə sɪɾi ʌv tiɹ, tə dɪfɛn ðə sɪɾi, ən tə pɹəvaɪd pəlis sɝvəsəz ɪn pleɪs ʌv ɛni sɪɾi wɑtʃ əɹ ðə laɪk. ɪksɛpt ɪn taɪmz ʌv wɔɹ, ðɛɹ duɾiz sɛldəm teɪk əm fɑɹ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi. ðɛn, əz wɪð ʌðɝ sətʃ ɪlit fɔɹmeɪʃənz, ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə kɔɹ ɝaʊnd wɪtʃ ði ɑɹmi ɪz fɔɹmd. ðə junəfɔɹm ə ðə dɪfɛndɝz kənsɪsts ʌv ə blæk koʊt wɪð pæɾəd slivz stʃɹaɪp blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld wɪð blæk kʌfs, ə bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪɾ ən ə ɹɪm hɛlmət wɪð ə feɪsɡɑɹɾ ə stil bɑɹz. ðə kæptən ə ðə stoʊn wɛɹz θɹi ʃɔɹt waɪt plumz ɑn ɪz hɛlmət, ən ɑn ðə kʌfs ə hɪz koʊt θɹi ɪntɝtwaɪnd ɡoʊldən bɹeɪdz ɑn ə waɪt bænd. kæptənz wɛɹ tu waɪt plumz ən ə sɪŋɡəl laɪn ʌv ɡoʊldən bɹeɪɾ ɑn waɪt kʌfs, lutɛnəns wʌn waɪt plum ən ə sɪŋɡəl laɪn ə blæk bɹeɪɾ ɑn waɪt kʌfs, ən ʌndɝ-lutɛnəns wʌn ʃɔɹt blæk plum ən pleɪn waɪt kʌfs. bænɝmɪn əv ɡoʊld-kʌlɝd kʌfs ɑn ðɛɹ koʊts, ən skwədmən əv kʌfs stʃɹaɪp blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld.

Defenders of the Stone, the: The elite military formation of Tear. The current Captain of the Stone (commander of the Defenders) is Rodrivar Tihera. Only Tairens are accepted into the Defenders, and officers are usually of noble birth, though often from minor Houses or minor branches of strong Houses. The Defenders are tasked to hold the great fortress called the Stone of Tear, in the city of Tear, to defend the city, and to provide police services in place of any City Watch or the like. Except in times of war, their duties seldom take them far from the city. Then, as with other such elite formations, they are the core around which the army is formed. The uniform of the Defenders consists of a black coat with padded sleeves striped black-and-gold with black cuffs, a burnished breastplate and a rimmed helmet with a faceguard of steel bars. The Captain of the Stone wears three short white plumes on his helmet, and on the cuffs of his coat three intertwined golden braids on a white band. Captains wear two white plumes and a single line of golden braid on white cuffs, lieutenants one white plume and a single line of black braid on white cuffs, and under-lieutenants one short black plume and plain white cuffs. Bannermen have gold-colored cuffs on their coats, and squadmen have cuffs striped black-and-gold.

dɛlvɪŋ: (wʌn) juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə daɪəɡnoʊs fɪzɪkəl kəndɪʃən ən ɪlnəs. (tu) faɪndɪŋ dəpɑzɪts ə mɛɾəl ɔɹz wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðət ðɪs əz lɔŋ bɪn ə lɔst əbɪləɾi əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ əkaʊn fəɹ ðə neɪm bɪkʌmɪŋ ətætʃt tə ənʌðɝ əbɪləɾi.

Delving: (1) Using the One Power to diagnose physical condition and illness. (2) Finding deposits of metal ores with the One Power. That this has long been a lost ability among Aes Sedai may account for the name becoming attached to another ability.

dɪpɑzətɔɹi: ə dɪvɪʒən ə ðə taʊɝ laɪbɹɛɹi. ðəɹ ɑɹ twɛlv pʌblɪkli noʊn dəpɑzətɔɹiz, itʃ hævɪŋ bʊks ən ɹɛkɝdz pɝteɪnɪŋ tə ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ sʌbʒɪkt, əɹ tə ɹɪleɪɾɪd sʌbʒɪkts. eɪ θɝtinθ dɪpɑzətɔɹi, noʊn oʊnli tə səm ɛɛs sədaɪ, kənteɪnz sikɹət dɑkjəməns, ɹɛkɝdz ən hɪstɝiz wɪtʃ meɪ bi æksɛst oʊnli baɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ðə kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz ən ðə sɪɾɝz ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. ænd, ʌv kɔɹs, baɪ ðət hændfʊl ə laɪbɹɛɹiənz u meɪnteɪn ðə dɪpɑzətɔɹi.

Depository: A division of the Tower Library. There are twelve publicly known Depositories, each having books and records pertaining to a particular subject, or to related subjects. A Thirteenth Depository, known only to some Aes Sedai, contains secret documents, records and histories which may be accessed only by the Amyrlin Seat, the Keeper of the Chronicles and the Sitters in the Hall of the Tower. And, of course, by that handful of librarians who maintain the depository.

dɝmɝæt-: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "mæstɝ hænlɝ." (tu) əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ðə pɹifɪks əplaɪd tə ɪndəkeɪɾ ə sinjɝ ən haɪli skɪl hænlɝ ʌv wʌn ə ði ɛɡzɑɾɪks, wʌn u tʃɹeɪnz ʌðɝz, əz ɪn dɝmɝətʃɹeɪkən. dɝmɝæt kən əv ə fɛɹli haɪ soʊʃəl stæɾəs, ðə haɪəst ʌv ɔl hɛl baɪ dɝsʌldəm, ðə tʃɹeɪnɝz ə sʌldəm, hu ɹæŋk wɪð fɛɹli haɪ mɪlətɛɹi ɔfəsɝz. si ɔlsoʊ mɔɝæt-.

der'morat-: (1) In the Old Tongue, "master handler." (2) Among the Seanchan, the prefix applied to indicate a senior and highly skilled handler of one of the exotics, one who trains others, as in der'morat'raken. Der'morat can have a fairly high social status, the highest of all held by der'sul'dam, the trainers of sul'dam, who rank with fairly high military officers. See also morat-.

ɛlfɪn: ə ɹeɪs ə biɪŋz, lɑɹdʒli hjumən ɪn əpɪɹəns bʌt wɪð fɑks-laɪk kɛɹəktɝɪstɪks, hu wɪl ɡɹæn θɹi wɪʃɪz, ɔlðoʊ ðeɪ æsk fəɹ ə pɹaɪs ɪn ɹɪtɝn. ɪf ðə pɝsən æskɪŋ dʌz nɑt nəɡoʊʃieɪɾ ə pɹaɪs, ði ɛlfɪn tʃuz ɪt. ðə moʊs kɑmən pɹaɪs ɪn sətʃ sɝkəmstænsəz ɪz dɛθ, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl fʊlfɪl ðɛɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən, ɔlðoʊ ðə mænɝ ɪn wɪtʃ ðeɪ fʊlfɪl ɪts sɛldəm ðə mænɝ ðə wʌn æskɪŋ ɪkspɛks. ðɛɹ tʃɹu loʊkeɪʃən ɪz ənnoʊn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə vɪzəɾ əm baɪ minz ʌv ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət wɑz loʊkeɪɾəd ɪn ɹɪɾiən. ðət tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz teɪkən baɪ mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd tə kɛɹhin, wɛɹ ɪt wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd. ɪts ɔlsoʊ ɹipɔɹɾəd ðət ðeɪ meɪ bi ɹitʃt baɪ ɛntɝɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ʌv ɡɛndʒeɪaɪ. ðeɪ æsk ðə seɪm kwɛstʃənz əz ði æɛlfɪn ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ faɪɝ, aɪɝn ən mjuzɪkəl ɪnstʃɹəməns. si ɔlsoʊ æɛlfɪn.

Eelfinn: A race of beings, largely human in appearance but with fox-like characteristics, who will grant three wishes, although they ask for a price in return. If the person asking does not negotiate a price, the Eelfinn choose it. The most common price in such circumstances is death, but they still fulfill their part of the bargain, although the manner in which they fulfill it is seldom the manner the one asking expects. Their true location is unknown, but it was possible to visit them by means of a ter'angreal that was located in Rhuidean. That ter'angreal was taken by Moiraine Damodred to Cairhien, where it was destroyed. It is also reported that they may be reached by entering the Tower of Ghenjei. They ask the same questions as the Aelfinn regarding fire, iron and musical instruments. See also Aelfinn.

feɪn, pdən: fɔɹmɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnd, naʊ mɔɹ ən wɝs ðən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ən ən ɛnəmi ʌv ðə fɔɹseɪkən əz mʌtʃ əz hiz ə ɹænd ælθɹ, hum i heɪts wɪð ə pæʃən. læst sin ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾən, hu daɪd ðɛɹ.

Fain, Padan: Former Darkfriend, now more and worse than a Darkfriend, and an enemy of the Forsaken as much as he is of Rand al'Thor, whom he hates with a passion. Last seen in Far Madding in company with Toram Riatin, who died there.

fɛl, hɹɪd: ði ɔθɝ ə ɹizən ən ənɹisən ən ʌðɝ bʊks. fɛl wɑz ə stuɾənt (æn titʃɝ) ʌv hɪstɝi ən fəlɑsəfi ət ði əkæɾəmi ʌv kɛɹhin. hi wɑz dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪn ɪz stʌɾi tɔɹn lɪm fɹəm lɪm.

Fel, Herid: The author of Reason and Unreason and other books. Fel was a student (and teacher) of history and philosophy at the Academy of Cairhien. He was discovered in his study torn limb from limb.

fɝst ɹizənɝ: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə waɪɾ ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ fɛɹən nhɝən, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. fɛɹən sədaɪ ɪz wʌn ʌv oʊnli tu ədʒɑ hɛdz tə sɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ət pɹɛzənt.

First Reasoner: The title given to the head of the White Ajah. This position is currently held by Ferane Neheran, an Aes Sedai in the White Tower. Ferane Sedai is one of only two Ajah heads to sit in the Hall of the Tower at present.

fɝst wivɝ: ðə taɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ. ðɪs pəzɪʃən ɪz kɝənli hɛl baɪ swænə dʒɹeɪɡən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. swænə sədaɪ ɪz wʌn ʌv oʊnli tu ədʒɑ hɛdz tə sɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ət pɹɛzənt. əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹoʊmændə kæsɪn hoʊlz ðɪs pəzɪʃən.

First Weaver: The title given to the head of the Yellow Ajah. This position is currently held by Suana Dragand in the White Tower. Suana Sedai is one of only two Ajah heads to sit in the Hall of the Tower at present. Among the rebel Aes Sedai, Romanda Cassin holds this position.

fɔɹsɪŋ; fɔɹst: wən sʌmwʌn wɪð ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl hændəlz əz mʌtʃ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ðeɪ kən oʊvɝ lɔŋ pɪɹiədz ə taɪm ən tʃænəlz kəntɪnjuəli, ðeɪ lɝn fæstɝ ən ɡeɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ mɔɹ ɹæpədli. ðɪs ɪz kɔl fɔɹsɪŋ, əɹ biɪŋ fɔɹst, baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, hu æbdʒʊɝ ðə pɹæktəs wɪð nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd kəz ə ðə deɪnʒɝ ə dɛθ əɹ biɪŋ bɝn aʊt.

forcing; forced: When someone with the ability to channel handles as much of the One Power as they can over long periods of time and channels continually, they learn faster and gain strength more rapidly. This is called forcing, or being forced, by Aes Sedai, who abjure the practice with novices and Accepted because of the danger of death or being burned out.

fɔɹʌnɝz, ðə: si heɪlin.

Forerunners, the: See Hailene.

fɔɹseɪkən, ðə: ðə neɪm ɡɪvən tə θɝtin paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, mɛn ən wɪmən boʊθ, hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə ʃædoʊ dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ən wɝ tʃɹæpt ɪn ðə silɪŋ ə ðə bɔɹ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. waɪl ɪts lɔŋ bɪn bɪliv ðət ðeɪ əloʊn əbændən ðə laɪt dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ɪn fækt ʌðɝz dɪɾ əz wɛl; ðiz θɝtin wɝ oʊnli ðə haɪəst-ɹæŋkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛm. ðə fɔɹseɪkən (hu kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə tʃoʊzən) ɑɹ sʌmwʌt ɹədust ɪn nʌmbɝ sɪns ðɛɹ əweɪkənɪŋ ɪn ðə pɹɛzən deɪ. səm ə ðoʊz kɪld əv bɪn ɹiɪnkɑɹneɪɾɪd ɪn nu bɑɾiz ən ɡɪvən nu neɪmz, bʌt mʌtʃ ɪz əz jɛɾ ənnoʊn əbaʊt ðɛɹ aɪdɛntɪɾiz ən loʊkeɪʃənz.

Forsaken, the: The name given to thirteen powerful Aes Sedai, men and women both, who went over to the Shadow during the Age of Legends and were trapped in the sealing of the Bore into the Dark One's prison. While it has long been believed that they alone abandoned the Light during the War of the Shadow, in fact others did as well; these thirteen were only the highest-ranking among them. The Forsaken (who call themselves the Chosen) are somewhat reduced in number since their awakening in the present day. Some of those killed have been reincarnated in new bodies and given new names, but much is as yet unknown about their identities and locations.

heɪlin: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "fɔɹʌnɝz," əɹ "ðoʊz u kʌm bɪfɔɹ." ðə tɝm əplaɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə ðə mæsɪv ɛkspədɪʃənɛɹi fɔɹs sɛn əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən tə skaʊɾ aʊt ðə lænz wɛɹ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wʌns ɹuld. naʊ ʌndɝ ðə kəmæn ə ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ, ɪts nʌmbɝz swoʊlən baɪ ɹəkɹuts fɹəm kɑŋkɝd lænz, ðə heɪlin əz ɡɔn fɑɹ bɪɑn ɪts ɝɪdʒənəl ɡoʊlz, ən əz ɪn fæk bɪn səksiɾəd baɪ ðə kɔɝɪn. si kɔɝɪn, ɹaɪædʒɛl.

Hailene: In the Old Tongue, "Forerunners," or "Those Who Come Before." The term applied by the Seanchan to the massive expeditionary force sent across the Aryth Ocean to scout out the lands where Artur Hawkwing once ruled. Now under the command of the High Lady Suroth, its numbers swollen by recruits from conquered lands, the Hailene has gone far beyond its original goals, and has in fact been succeeded by the Corenne. See Corenne, Rhyagelle.

hænd: ɪn sintʃæn, hæn ɹəfɝz tə ə pɹaɪmɛɹi əsɪstən əɹ wʌn ʌv ə haɪɝɑɹki ʌv ɪmpɪɹiəl fʌŋkʃənɛɹiz. eɪ hæn ə ði ɛmpɹɛs ɪz ə ðə fɝst ɹæŋk, ən lɛsɝ hænz wɪl bi faʊn ət loʊɝ ɹæŋks. səm hænz ɑpɝeɪɾ ɪn sikɹət, sətʃ əz ðoʊz u ɡaɪd ðə sikɝz ən lɪsənɝz; ʌðɝz ɑɹ noʊn ən dɪspleɪ ðɛɹ ɹæŋk baɪ wɛɹɪŋ ði əpɹoʊpɹiət nʌmbɝ ʌv ɡoʊldən hænz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ.

Hand: In Seanchan, Hand refers to a primary assistant or one of a hierarchy of imperial functionaries. A Hand of the Empress is of the First Rank, and Lesser Hands will be found at lower ranks. Some Hands operate in secret, such as those who guide the Seekers and Listeners; others are known and display their rank by wearing the appropriate number of golden hands embroidered on their clothing.

hænlən, dɑvd: eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnd, fɔɹmɝli kəmændɝ ə ðə waɪt laɪənz ɪn sɝvəs tə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɹɑvɪn waɪl i hɛl keɪɛmlɪn juzɪŋ ðə neɪm lɔɹd ɡeɪbɹəl. fɹəm ðɛɹ, hænlən tʊk ðə waɪt laɪənz tə kɛɹhin ʌndɝ ɔɹɾɝz tə fɝðɝ ðə ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðə waɪt laɪənz wɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪd baɪ ə "bʌbəl ʌv ivəl," ən hænlən wɑz ɔɹɾɝd bæk tə keɪɛmlɪn ænd, ʌndɝ ðə neɪm dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝ, ɪnɡɹæʃieɪɾɪd hɪmsɛlf wɪð ɪleɪn, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɹumɝ, hi dɪd kənsɪɾɝəbli mɔɹ ðən ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪt hɪmsɛlf.

Hanlon, Daved: A Darkfriend, formerly commander of the White Lions in service to the Forsaken Rahvin while he held Caemlyn using the name Lord Gaebril. From there, Hanlon took the White Lions to Cairhien under orders to further the rebellion against the Dragon Reborn. The White Lions were destroyed by a "bubble of evil," and Hanlon was ordered back to Caemlyn and, under the name Doilin Mellar, ingratiated himself with Elayne, the Daughter-Heir. According to rumor, he did considerably more than ingratiate himself.

hɑɹt: ðə beɪsɪk junəɾ ʌv ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən ɪn ðə blæk ədʒɑ. ɪn ɪfɛkt, ə sɛl. ə hɑɹt kənsɪsts ə θɹi sɪstɝz u noʊ itʃ ʌðɝ, wɪð itʃ mɛmbɝ ə ðə hɑɹt noʊɪŋ wʌn ədɪʃənəl sɪstɝ ə ðə blæk u ɪz ənnoʊn tə ði ʌðɝ tu ʌv əɹ hɑɹt.

heart: The basic unit of organization in the Black Ajah. In effect, a cell. A heart consists of three sisters who know each other, with each member of the heart knowing one additional sister of the Black who is unknown to the other two of her heart.

ɪluməneɪɾɝz, ɡɪld ʌv: ə səsaɪəɾi ðət hɛl ðə sikɹəɾ ə meɪkɪŋ faɪɹwɝks. ɪt ɡɑɹɾəd ðɪs sikɹət vɛɹi kloʊsli, ivən tə ði ɪkstɛn ə duɪŋ mɝɾɝ tə pɹətɛkt ɪt. ðə ɡɪld ɡeɪn ɪts neɪm fɹəm ðə ɡɹæn dɪspleɪz, kɔld ɪluməneɪʃənz, ðəɾ ɪt pɹəvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹulɝz ən səmtaɪmz fəɹ ɡɹeɪɾɝ lɔɹdz. lɛsɝ faɪɹwɝks wɝ soʊl fəɹ jus baɪ ʌðɝz, bʌt wɪð daɪɹ wɔɹnɪŋz ə ðə dɪzæstɝ ðət kəd ɹɪzʌl fɹəm ətɛmptɪŋ tə lɝn wʌt wɑz ɪnsaɪd ðɛm. ðə ɡɪld wʌns hæd tʃæptɝ haʊsəz ɪn kɛɹhin ən tæntʃəkoʊ, bʌt boʊθ ɑɹ naʊ dɪstʃɹɔɪd. ɪn ədɪʃən, ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə ɡɪld ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ ɹɪzɪstɪd ði ɪnveɪʒən baɪ ðə sintʃæn ən wɝ meɪd dækoʊvæl, ən ðə ɡɪld əz sətʃ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪɡzɪsts. haʊɛvɝ, ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl ɪluməneɪɾɝz stɪl ɪɡzɪst aʊtsaɪɾ ə sintʃæn ɹul ən wɝk tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət ðə ɡɪld wɪl bi ɹɪmɛmbɝd. si ɔlsoʊ dækoʊvæl.

Illuminators, Guild of: A society that held the secret of making fireworks. It guarded this secret very closely, even to the extent of doing murder to protect it. The Guild gained its name from the grand displays, called Illuminations, that it provided for rulers and sometimes for greater lords. Lesser fireworks were sold for use by others, but with dire warnings of the disaster that could result from attempting to learn what was inside them. The Guild once had chapter houses in Cairhien and Tanchico, but both are now destroyed. In addition, the members of the Guild in Tanchico resisted the invasion by the Seanchan and were made da'covale, and the Guild as such no longer exists. However, individual Illuminators still exist outside of Seanchan rule and work to make sure that the Guild will be remembered. See also da'covale.

ɪʃɑɹə: ðə fɝs kwin ʌv ændɝ (sɝkə fi naɪnnaɪnfɔɹwʌnzɪɹoʊɾuzɪɹoʊ). ət ðə dɛθ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, ɪʃɑɹə kənvɪnst əɹ hʌzbənd, wʌn ə hɔkwɪŋz fɔɹmoʊs dʒɛnɝəlz, tə ɹeɪz ðə sidʒ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən əkʌmpəni hɝ tə keɪɛmlɪn wɪð əz mɛni soʊlʒɝz əz i kəd bɹeɪk əweɪ fɹəm ði ɑɹmi. wɛɹ ʌðɝz tʃɹaɪd tə siz ðə hoʊl ə hɔkwɪŋz ɛmpaɪɝ ən feɪld, ɪʃɑɹə tʊk ə fɝm hoʊld ɑn ə smɔl pɑɹɾ ən səksiɾəd. tədeɪ, nɪɹli ɛvɹi noʊbəl haʊs ɪn ændɝ kənteɪnz səm ʌv ɪʃɑɹəz blʌd, ən ðə ɹaɪt tə kleɪm ðə laɪən θɹoʊn dɪpɛnz boʊθ ɑn dɝɛk dɪsɛn fɹəm əɹ ən ɑn ðə nʌmbɝ ə laɪnz ə kənɛkʃən tə hɝ ðət kən bi ɪstæblɪʃt.

Ishara: The first Queen of Andor (circa FY 9941020). At the death of Artur Hawkwing, Ishara convinced her husband, one of Hawkwing's foremost generals, to raise the siege of Tar Valon and accompany her to Caemlyn with as many soldiers as he could break away from the army. Where others tried to seize the whole of Hawkwing's empire and failed, Ishara took a firm hold on a small part and succeeded. Today, nearly every noble House in Andor contains some of Ishara's blood, and the right to claim the Lion Throne depends both on direct descent from her and on the number of lines of connection to her that can be established.

kɛnsɑɾə: ən ɛɹiə ʌv sintʃæn ðəɾ ɪz pɑpjəleɪɾəd baɪ lɛs-ðæn-sɪvəlaɪz hɪl tʃɹaɪbz. ðiz tʃɹaɪbz faɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, əz də ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl fæmliz wɪðɪn ðə tʃɹaɪbz. itʃ tʃɹaɪb əz ɪts oʊn kʌstəmz ən tæbuz, ðə læɾɝ ʌv wɪtʃ ɔfən meɪk noʊ sɛns tə ɛniwʌn aʊtsaɪd ðət tʃɹaɪb. moʊst ə ðə tʃɹaɪbzmɪn əvɔɪd ðə mɔɹ sɪvəlaɪzd ɹɛzəɾənts ə sintʃæn.

Kaensada: An area of Seanchan that is populated by less-than-civilized hill tribes. These tribes fight a great deal among themselves, as do individual families within the tribes. Each tribe has its own customs and taboos, the latter of which often make no sense to anyone outside that tribe. Most of the tribesmen avoid the more civilized residents of Seanchan.

kɪn, ðə: ivən dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, mɔɹ ðən tu θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ (sɝkə wʌnzɪɹoʊzɪɹoʊzɪɹoʊwʌnθɹifaɪvzɪɹoʊ æb), ðə waɪt taʊɝ kəntɪnjud tə meɪnteɪn ɪts stændɝdz, pʊɾɪŋ aʊt wɪmən u feɪl tə mɛʒɝ ʌp. wʌn ɡɹup ə ðiz wɪmən, fɪɹɪŋ tə ɹɪtɝn hoʊm ɪn ðə mɪdst ə ðə wɔɹz, flɛd tə bɑɹɑʃtə (nɪɹ ðə pɹɛzənt-deɪ saɪɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ), əz fɑɹ fɹəm ðə faɪɾɪŋ əz wɑz pɑsəbəl tə ɡoʊ ət ðət taɪm. kɔlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ðə kɪn, ən kɪnswɪmən, ðeɪ kɛpt ɪn haɪɾɪŋ ən ɔfɝɾ ə seɪf heɪvən fəɹ ʌðɝz u hæd bɪn pʊɾ aʊt. ɪn taɪm, ðɛɹ əpɹoʊtʃɪz tə wɪmən toʊl tə liv ðə taʊɝ lɛd tə kɑntæks wɪð ɹʌnəweɪz, ən waɪl ði ɪɡzækt ɹizənz meɪ nɛvɝ bi noʊn, ðə kɪn bɪɡæn tə æksɛpt ɹʌnəweɪz, əz wɛl. ðeɪ meɪd ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝts tə kip ðiz ɡɝlz fɹəm lɝnɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kɪn əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd nɑt swup daʊn ən ɹiteɪk ðɛm. æftɝ ɔl, ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðət ɹʌnəweɪz wɝ ɔlweɪz kɑt sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ən ðə kɪn nu ðəɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ hɛl ðɛmsɛlvz sikɹət, ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz wəd bi pʌnɪʃt səvɪɹli.

Kin, the: Even during the Trolloc Wars, more than two thousand years ago (circa 10001350 AB), the White Tower continued to maintain its standards, putting out women who failed to measure up. One group of these women, fearing to return home in the midst of the wars, fled to Barashta (near the present-day site of Ebou Dar), as far from the fighting as was possible to go at that time. Calling themselves the Kin, and Kinswomen, they kept in hiding and offered a safe haven for others who had been put out. In time, their approaches to women told to leave the Tower led to contacts with runaways, and while the exact reasons may never be known, the Kin began to accept runaways, as well. They made great efforts to keep these girls from learning anything about the Kin until they were sure that Aes Sedai would not swoop down and retake them. After all, everyone knew that runaways were always caught sooner or later, and the Kin knew that unless they held themselves secret, they themselves would be punished severely.

ənnoʊn tə ðə kɪn, ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə taʊɝ wɝ əwɛɹ ə ðɛɹ ɛɡzɪstəns ɔlmoʊs fɹəm ðə vɛɹi fɝst, bʌt pɹɑsəkjuʃən ə ðə wɔɹz lɛf noʊ taɪm fəɹ dilɪŋ wɪð ðɛm. baɪ ði ɛn ə ðə wɔɹz, ðə taʊɝ ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪt maɪt nɑt bi ɪn ðɛɹ bɛst ɪntʃɹəsts tə snʌf aʊt ðə kɪn. pɹaɪɝ tə ðət taɪm, ə mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv ɹʌnəweɪz æktʃəli  hæd mænədʒ tə ɪskeɪp, wʌtɛvɝ ðə taʊɝz pɹɑpəɡændə, bʌt wʌns ðə kɪn bɪɡæn hɛlpɪŋ ðɛm, ðə taʊɝ nu ɪɡzækli wɛɹ ɛni ɹʌnəweɪ wɑz hɛɾɪŋ, ən ðeɪ bɪɡæn ɹəteɪkɪŋ naɪn aʊɾ ə tɛn. sɪns kɪnswɪmən muvd ɪn ən aʊɾ ə bɑɹɑʃtə (æn leɪɾɝ ɛbu dɑɹ) ɪn ən ɛfɝt tə haɪd ðɛɹ ɛɡzɪstəns ən ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz, nɛvɝ steɪɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ mɔɹ ðən tɛn jɪɹz lɛst sʌmwʌn noʊɾəs ðət ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ eɪdʒ əɾ ə nɔɹməl spid, ðə taʊɝ bɪliv ðeɪ wɝ fju, ən ðeɪ sɝɾənli wɝ kipɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz loʊ. ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə juz ðə kɪn əz ə tʃɹæp fəɹ ɹʌnəweɪz, ðə taʊɝ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə liv əm əloʊn, ənlaɪk ɛni ʌðɝ sɪməlɝ ɡɹup ɪn hɪstɝi, ən tə kip ðə vɛɹi ɛɡzɪstəns ə ðə kɪn ə sikɹət noʊn oʊnli tə fʊl ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Unknown to the Kin, Aes Sedai in the Tower were aware of their existence almost from the very first, but prosecution of the wars left no time for dealing with them. By the end of the wars, the Tower realized that it might not be in their best interests to snuff out the Kin. Prior to that time, a majority of runaways actually had managed to escape, whatever the Tower's propaganda, but once the Kin began helping them, the Tower knew exactly where any runaway was heading, and they began retaking nine out of ten. Since Kinswomen moved in and out of Barashta (and later Ebou Dar) in an effort to hide their existence and their numbers, never staying anywhere more than ten years lest someone notice that they did not age at a normal speed, the Tower believed they were few, and they certainly were keeping themselves low. In order to use the Kin as a trap for runaways, the Tower decided to leave them alone, unlike any other similar group in history, and to keep the very existence of the Kin a secret known only to full Aes Sedai.

ðə kɪn də nɑɾ əv lɔz, bʌt ɹæðɝ ɹulz (kɔld "ðə ɹul") beɪst ɪn lɑɹdʒ pɑɹɾ ɑn ðə ɹulz fəɹ nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ɪn pɑɹɾ ɑn ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv meɪnteɪnɪŋ sikɹəsi. əz maɪt bi ɪkspɛktəd ɡɪvən ði ɔɹədʒɪnz ə ðə kɪn, ɔl ə ðɛɹ mɛmbɝz meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ ɹulz vɛɹi fɝmli.

The Kin do not have laws, but rather rules (called "the Rule") based in large part on the rules for novices and Accepted in the White Tower, and in part on the necessity of maintaining secrecy. As might be expected given the origins of the Kin, all of their members maintain their rules very firmly.

ɹisən oʊpən kɑntæks bɪtwin ɛɛs sədaɪ ən kɪnswɪmən, waɪl noʊn oʊnli tə ə hændfʊl ə sɪstɝz, hæv pɹədust ə nʌmbɝ ə ʃɑks, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə fæks ðət ðəɹ ɑɹ twaɪs əz mɛni kɪnswɪmən əz ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðət səm əv lɪv mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz lɔŋɡɝ ðən ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. ði ɪfɛkt ə ðiz ɹɛvəleɪʃənz, boʊθ ɑn ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɑn kɪnswɪmən, ɪz əz jɛɾ ə mæɾɝ fəɹ spɛkjəleɪʃən. si ɔlsoʊ nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl, ðə.

Recent open contacts between Aes Sedai and Kinswomen, while known only to a handful of sisters, have produced a number of shocks, including the facts that there are twice as many Kinswomen as Aes Sedai and that some have lived more than a hundred years longer than any Aes Sedai since before the Trolloc Wars. The effect of these revelations, both on Aes Sedai and on Kinswomen, is as yet a matter for speculation. See also Knitting Circle, the.

nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl, ðə: ðə liɾɝz ə ðə kɪn. sɪns noʊ mɛmbɝ ə ðə kɪn əz ɛvɝ noʊn haʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɝeɪnʒ ðɛɹ oʊn haɪɝɑɹki - nɑlədʒ pæst ɑn oʊnli wən ən æksɛptɪɾ əz pæst əɹ tɛs fəɹ ðə ʃɔl - ðeɪ pʊt noʊ stɔɹ ɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ bʌt ɡɪv ɡɹeɪt weɪt tə eɪdʒ, wɪð ði oʊldɝ wʊmən ɔlweɪz stændɪŋ əbʌv ðə jʌŋɡɝ. ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl (ə taɪɾəl tʃoʊzən, laɪk ðə kɪn, kəz ɪts ɪnɑkjuəs) ðʌs kənsɪsts ə ðə θɝtin oʊldəs kɪnswɪmən ɹɛzəɾənt ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, wɪð ði oʊldəst ɡɪvən ðə taɪɾəl ʌv ɛldəst. baɪ ðə ɹulz, ɔl wɪl əv tə stɛp daʊn wən ɪts taɪm fəɹ əm tə muv ɑn, bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɛzəɾənt ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ðeɪv səpɹim əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ðə kɪn, tə ə dɪɡɹi ðəɾ ɛni æmɪɝlɪn sit wəɾ ɛnvi. sɪns ðə kɪn əv lɛft ɛbu dɑɹ, ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl dʌz nɑt tɛknɪkəli ɪɡzɪst. si ɔlsoʊ kɪn, ðə.

Knitting Circle, the: The leaders of the Kin. Since no member of the Kin has ever known how Aes Sedai arrange their own hierarchy - knowledge passed on only when an Accepted has passed her test for the shawl - they put no store in strength in the Power but give great weight to age, with the older woman always standing above the younger. The Knitting Circle (a title chosen, like the Kin, because it is innocuous) thus consists of the thirteen oldest Kinswomen resident in Ebou Dar, with the oldest given the title of Eldest. By the rules, all will have to step down when it is time for them to move on, but so long as they are resident in Ebou Dar, they have supreme authority over the Kin, to a degree that any Amyrlin Seat would envy. Since the Kin have left Ebou Dar, the Knitting Circle does not technically exist. See also Kin, the.

læns-kæptən: ɪn moʊs lænz, noʊbəlwɪmən də nɑt pɝsənəli lɛd ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn ɪndə bæɾəl ʌndɝ nɔɹməl sɝkəmstænsəz. ɪnstɛd, ðeɪ haɪɝ ə pɹəfɛʃənəl soʊlʒɝ, ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz ə kɑmənɝ, hu ɪz ɹispɑnsəbəl boʊθ fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ən liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn. dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn ðə lænd, ðɪs mæn kən bi kɔld ə læns-kæptən, sɔɹd-kæptən, mæstɝ ə ðə hɔɹs əɹ mæstɝ ə ðə lænsɪz. ɹumɝz ə kloʊsɝ ɹileɪʃənʃɪps ðən leɪɾi ən sɝvən ɔfən spɹɪŋ ʌp, pɝhæps ɪnɛvəɾəbli. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹu.

Lance-Captain: In most lands, noblewomen do not personally lead their armsmen into battle under normal circumstances. Instead, they hire a professional soldier, almost always a commoner, who is responsible both for training and leading their armsmen. Depending on the land, this man can be called a Lance-Captain, Sword-Captain, Master of the Horse or Master of the Lances. Rumors of closer relationships than Lady and servant often spring up, perhaps inevitably. Sometimes they are true.

lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, ðə: ə lɑɹdʒ mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən, ɔl ɪnfəntʃɹi, ɡɪvɪŋ əlidʒəns tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, tʃɹeɪn baɪ dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ əlɔŋ laɪnz wɝkt aʊt baɪ hɪmsɛlf ən mæt kɔθən, laɪnz wɪtʃ dɪpɑɹt ʃɑɹpli fɹəm ðə juʒəwəl ɛmplɔɪmən ə fʊt. waɪl mɛni mɛn sɪmpli wɔk ɪn tə vɑləntɪɹ, lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə ðə lidʒən ɑɹ skupt ʌp baɪ ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz fɹəm ðə blæk taʊɝ, hu fɝst ɡæðɝ ɔl ə ðə mɛn ɪn ən ɛɹiə hu ɑɹ wɪlɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən oʊnli æftɝ teɪkɪŋ əm θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz nɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn wɪnoʊ aʊt ðoʊz u kən bi tɔt tə tʃænəl. ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ, baɪ fɑɹ ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ nʌmbɝ, ɑɹ sɛn tə bæʃɪɹz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ kæmps.

Legion of the Dragon, the: A large military formation, all infantry, giving allegiance to the Dragon Reborn, trained by Davram Bashere along lines worked out by himself and Mat Cauthon, lines which depart sharply from the usual employment of foot. While many men simply walk in to volunteer, large numbers of the Legion are scooped up by recruiting parties from the Black Tower, who first gather all of the men in an area who are willing to follow the Dragon Reborn, and only after taking them through gateways near Caemlyn winnow out those who can be taught to channel. The remainder, by far the greater number, are sent to Bashere's training camps.

lidʒən ə ðə wɔl: fɔɹmɝli ən ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ʌv ɡildən wɪtʃ pɹəvaɪɾəd nɑɾ oʊnli ə kɔɹ tə ɛni ɑɹmi ðət wɑz ɹeɪz fɹəm ðə ɡildænɪn nɑbɪltiz ɑɹmmɪn bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ pɹəvaɪɾəd ə bɑɾiɡɑɹd fəɹ ðə ɹulɝ ʌv ɡildən, ən pəlis dʒəhænə, ðə kæpəɾəl, ɪn pleɪs ʌv ə sɪɾi wɑtʃ. æftɝ ðeɪ wɝ slɔɾɝd ən ðə sɝvaɪvɝz dɪspɝs baɪ ðə fɑloʊɝz ə ðə pɹɑfət mæsimə, ðə noʊbəlz ə ðə kɹaʊn haɪ kaʊnsəl dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət wɪθaʊt ðə lidʒən, ðɛɹ oʊn paʊɝ ən ðɛɹ ɪnfluəns oʊvɝ ɛni ɹulɝ wɑz ɪnkɹist, soʊ ðeɪ mænədʒ tə stɑp ðə lidʒən fɹəm biɪŋ ɹeɪ-fɔɹmd. ðə kɝən kwin, æliændɝ mɛɹɪðə kɪɡɑɝɪn, hæz plænz tə də dʒʌs ðæt, haʊɛvɝ; plænz wɪtʃ wəɾ əv ən ɪksploʊsɪv ɪfɛkt ɪf ðeɪ bɪkeɪm noʊn tə ðə kɹaʊn haɪ kaʊnsəl.

Legion of the Wall: Formerly an elite military formation of Ghealdan which provided not only a core to any army that was raised from the Ghealdanin nobilty's armsmen but also provided a bodyguard for the ruler of Ghealdan, and policed Jehannah, the capital, in place of a City Watch. After they were slaughtered and the survivors dispersed by the followers of the Prophet Masema, the nobles of the Crown High Council decided that without the Legion, their own power and their influence over any ruler was increased, so they managed to stop the Legion from being re-formed. The current Queen, Alliandre Maritha Kigarin, has plans to do just that, however; plans which would have an explosive effect if they became known to the Crown High Council.

lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv: tɛn ɪntʃəz ikwəlz wʌn fʊt; θɹi fiɾ ikwəlz wʌn peɪs; tu peɪsɪz ikwəlz wʌn spæn; wʌnθaʊzən spænz ikwəlz wʌn maɪl; fɔɹ maɪlz ikwəlz wʌn liɡ.

length, units of: 10 inches = 1 foot; 3 feet = 1 pace; 2 paces = 1 span; 1000 spans = 1 mile; 4 miles = 1 league.

lɪsənɝz: eɪ sintʃæn spaɪ ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən. ɔlmoʊst ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə haʊshoʊld ʌv ə sintʃæn noʊbəl, mɝtʃən əɹ bæŋkɝ meɪ bi ə lɪsənɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ dækoʊvæl əkeɪʒənəli, ðoʊ sɛldəm sɔɪhɪn. ðeɪ teɪk noʊ æktɪv ɹoʊl, mɪɹli wɑtʃɪŋ, lɪsnɪŋ ən ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ. ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts ɑɹ sɛn tə lɛsɝ hænz u kəntʃɹoʊl boʊθ əm ən ðə sikɝz ən dɪsaɪd wʌt ʃəd bi pæst ɑn tə ðə sikɝz fəɹ fɝðɝ ækʃən. si ɔlsoʊ sikɝz, hænd.

Listeners: A Seanchan spy organization. Almost anyone in the household of a Seanchan noble, merchant or banker may be a Listener, including da'covale occasionally, though seldom so'jhin. They take no active role, merely watching, listening and reporting. Their reports are sent to Lesser Hands who control both them and the Seekers and decide what should be passed on to the Seekers for further action. See also Seekers, Hand.

mɛɹəθdəmeɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðoʊz u mʌs bi liʃt," ən ɔlsoʊ "wʌn u mʌs bi liʃt." ðə tɝm əplaɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə ɛni wʊmən keɪpəbəl ə tʃænəlɪŋ u hæz nɑt bɪn kɑlɝɾ əz ə deɪmeɪn.

marath'damane: In the Old Tongue, "those who must be leashed," and also "one who must be leashed." The term applied by the Seanchan to any woman capable of channeling who has not been collared as a damane.

mɑɹtʃ: si ɛɹiə, junəts ə mæstɝ ə ðə hɔɹs; mæstɝ ə ðə lænsɪz: si læns-kæptən.

march: See area, units of Master of the Horse; Master of the Lances: See Lance-Captain.

mɛlɝ, dɔɪlɪn: si hænlən, dɑvd.

Mellar, Doilin: See Hanlon, Daved.

mɛɝeɪɾɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə bɹʌðɝləs." ðə neɪm ədɑptəd, əz ə səsaɪəɾi, baɪ ðoʊz il u əbændən klæn ən sɛpt ən wɛn tə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kəz ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ æksɛpt ɹænd ælθɹ, ə wɛtləndɝ, əz ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn, əɹ kəz ðeɪ ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt ɪz ɹɛvəleɪʃənz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə hɪstɝi ən ɔɹədʒɪnz ə ði il. dɛzɝɾɪŋ klæn ən sɛp fəɹ ɛni ɹizən ɪz ənæθəmə əmʌŋ ði il, ðɛɹfɔɹ ðɛɹ oʊn wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ ənwɪlɪŋ tə teɪk əm ɪn, ən ðeɪ fɔɹm ðɪs səsaɪəɾi, ðə bɹʌðɝləs.

Mera'din: In the Old Tongue, "the Brotherless." The name adopted, as a society, by those Aiel who abandoned clan and sept and went to the Shaido because they could not accept Rand al'Thor, a wetlander, as the Car'a'carn, or because they refused to accept his revelations concerning the history and origins of the Aiel. Deserting clan and sept for any reason is anathema among the Aiel, therefore their own warrior societies among the Shaido were unwilling to take them in, and they formed this society, the Brotherless.
